title: Excerpts From the Ethnic Press
description: During the past month, a Jewish newspaper explored a kosher-food controversy; a Chinese-language newspaper pondered the political fate of the city comptroller, John C. Liu, the first Asian-American to hold a major citywide office; and a columnist for a Spanish-language newspaper asked a provocative question about the Latino birth rate. SAM DOLNICK

title: A Time for Gravy and Football
description: Bartolo Valastro, universally called Buddy, is a fourth-generation Italian baker whose Hoboken storefront, Carlos, uses 1,000 pounds of sugar each week to produce 500 birthday cakes, 50 or 60 wedding cakes and the occasional life-size racecar framed in fondant. He stars as the Cake Boss on TLC and in a new spinoff, Next Great Baker. Mr. Valastro, 33, also published a memoir studded with recipes, in November. He lives in East Hanover, N.J., with his wife, Lisa, and their children, 7-year-old Sophia; 6-year-old Buddy; and Marco, who is 3 (a fourth is due in February). JODI RUDOREN

title: Conflicts Many Marks on the Map
description: It has been said that geography creates war and wars create geography. Nobodys Property: Art, Land, Space, 2000-2010, at the Princeton University Art Museum, might be used as evidence, since its works, by nine artists  including two artist duos  center mostly on disputed land and the scorching aftermath of war.

title: The Wilderness Below Your Feet
description: IT must have been the third or fourth day  time, by that point, had started to dissolve  when I stood in camping gear on Fifth Avenue, waiting as my companions went to purchase waterproof waders at the Orvis store. We had already hiked through sewers in the Bronx, slept in a basement boiler room, passed a dusty evening in a train tunnel; we were soiled and sleep-deprived, and we smelled of rotting socks. Yet no one on that sidewalk seemed to notice. As I stood among the businessmen and fashionable women, it dawned on me that New Yorkers  an ostensibly perceptive lot  sometimes see only whats directly in front of their eyes.

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: SLEDDING IN CENTRAL PARK is dominated by two hills on the East Side: Pilgrim Hill near 72nd Street and Cedar Hill between 76th and 79th Streets.

title: A Medieval Skill Is Nurtured in Gold-Leaf Splendor
description: East Hampton, N.Y.

title: Chancellor Black: Please Consider This
description: MONDAY is Cathleen P. Blacks first day of school  running them, that is. As Ms. Black, a longtime magazine executive, takes over as chancellor of the New York City school system, we asked some of the citys most respected principals to give her some advice.

title: New Yorkers in Feathers, Counted in the Cold
description: It was the morning after Christmas  painfully early in the morning, and a blustery morning at that. Up in the frozen tundra of the northern Bronx, some creatures were stirring, yes, but not the yellow-bellied sapsucker that Christopher Lyons was looking for.

title: Old Movie Palaces, Trying on the New
description: FOR 15 years, a plastic likeness of Humphrey Bogart has been turning heads in the lobby of the Garde Arts Center in New London. Standing in the lavishly restored faux-Moroccan interior, the statue brings to mind the classic Bogart film Casablanca  recalling in the process a bygone era when moviegoers regularly filled the Gardes 1,472-seat auditorium.

title: A Kurdish Rebel Softens His Tone for Skeptical Ears
description: QANDIL, Iraq

title: Missing the A Train, and Taking Not-the-Quickest Way
description: The A train and I have long been locked in a complicated love-hate relationship. During the years I lived in Washington Heights, the A was a reliable parent figure when it appeared promptly, an infuriating no-show adolescent when it kept me waiting. Whatever its failings  riders in the Rockaways were without A train service Monday after the storm  I remained faithful to it, sometimes grudgingly. When I saw that blue circle with a white A inside cruising toward me on the platform, I knew I was as good as home.

title: A Blizzard of Blame
description: On Wednesday, John J. Doherty, like countless other New Yorkers, was stuck in the snow, and had to hire a couple of enterprising shovelers to remove his Chevy Tahoe from a drift in Brooklyn. It would have been an unremarkable moment, were Doherty not the citys sanitation commissioner, the man responsible for unburying the rest of us. It was, he told The Timess Sam Dolnick, very embarrassing. Well, perhaps he can take comfort in the fact that hes not the only one red in the face on this New Years weekend.

title: A Push to Privatize Pennsylvania Liquor Stores
description: FOREST CITY, Pa.  Ralph Miranda was looking for eggnog here the other day at the state liquor store, a dated and somewhat forlorn little shop with no name, just the Soviet-style designation #5801. When the store manager told him they were out, Mr. Miranda muttered, Thats why you privatize.

title: Wisconsin State Workers Fret, as G.O.P. Takes Over
description: MADISON, Wis.  In preparation for Mondays inauguration of the new governor, Scott Walker, red, white and blue bunting has been draped around the Capitols echoing rotunda. Lawmakers are unpacking files in their newly assigned offices. And state workers are fretting.

title: In California, Few Signs of Transition
description: SACRAMENTO  Just days before Governor-elect Jerry Brown takes over the nations most populous state  again  there were no visible signs that a transition was afoot.

title: Power Shift Toward G.O.P. Resonates in 3 States
description: JAN. 1 is technically no different from any other day of the year; the quasi-magical aura that surrounds it emanates from the fact that it holds the promise of a clean start, a new beginning, as if everything can be remade.

title: Giving Alzheimers Patients Their Way, Even Chocolate
description: PHOENIX  Margaret Nance was, to put it mildly, a difficult case. Agitated, combative, often reluctant to eat, she would hit staff members and fellow residents at nursing homes, several of which kicked her out. But when Beatitudes nursing home agreed to an urgent plea to accept her, all that changed.

title: American Airlines Barred From Safety Board Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  The National Transportation Safety Board has barred American Airlines from its investigation into why an American jetliner skidded off the end of a snowy runway in Jackson Hole, Wyo., on Wednesday morning, because the airline copied all of the data from one of the black boxes, or flight recorders, before turning it over.

title: Guilty Verdict for a Tycoon, and Russia
description: It took most of the week for Judge Viktor Danilkin to deliver the sentence against Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former Russian tycoon.

title: The Week in Pictures for Dec. 31
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the New York region in the past week. Subjects include a Russian church revived, a debutante ball and snow, snow, snow.

title: Turkey: 10 Suspects Held in Attack Plot
description: Turkish police officers detained 10 people with suspected links to Al Qaeda in operations conducted in Bursa and Istanbul, following tips that the group was plotting attacks ahead of New Years Eve, the semiofficial Anatolian Agency reported. During security operations on Wednesday, the antiterror units in Bursa, a town in the northwest, rounded up eight people, one of whom was the suspected leader of a local Qaeda cell, the report said.

title: The Week in Pictures for Dec. 31
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the New York region in the past week. Subjects include a Russian church revived, a debutante ball and snow, snow, snow.

title: Giants Slide Could Make a 10th Win Worthless
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Only five quarters ago, the Giants controlled their playoff chances, appearing poised to cinch up the N.F.C. East. But those five quarters over two games have drastically altered the teams course.

title: Back in Albany, 16 Years Later, to Serve Another Gov. Cuomo
description: They are pouring into Albany, older and sometimes grayer, with families at home, other careers in the rear-view mirror, and gauzy or not-so-gauzy memories of late nights spent on the Capitols second floor.

title: Iraq Moves to Ban Toy Guns as Play Turns Real
description: BAGHDAD  The Ministry of Health here is campaigning to ban the sale of guns in Iraq. Toy guns, that is.

title: New York Tries to Plow Its Way Back to Normal
description: The weather and the calendar conspired on Friday to give New York City the break it had been looking for since the paralyzing blizzard that ended Monday: Temperatures reached 45 degrees, and many workers had the day off in observance of New Years Day.

title: Turkey Withdraws as Host of European Womens Chess Championship
description: In a letter posted on the Turkish Chess Federations Web site on Wednesday, Ali Nihat Yazici, the federations president, announced that Turkey had withdrawn as host of the European Womens Chess Championship. It was to be held in March 2011 in Gaziantep, a city in the southeastern part of the country.

title: Missing Pieces Temper Knicks Resurgence
description: In the last quarter of the last game of a transformative year, the Knicks flaunted their full potential and their range of limitations.

title: Tiding a Couple Over and Helping Their Daughter Learn to Dance
description: Whenever life throws an obstacle in Desiree Whitlows path, she simply changes direction.

title: Texas Rivals Are Older, Wiser and Tough as Ever
description: DALLAS  Over the last few seasons, the Dallas Mavericks have changed their point guard, their coach and a sizable chunk of their roster as they tried to keep the window to a championship propped open.

title: Seceding from Secession
description: Parkersburg, Va., Jan. 1, 1861

title: A Building, and a City, as a Way Station to a Better Life
description: For two years, a five-story walk-up apartment building in the Bronx has served as a small beachhead for a new immigrant community: refugee families from the South Asian nation of Bhutan. From this new home on University Avenue, where they were placed by a resettlement agency, the families have made their first, tentative steps in an unfamiliar culture and language.

title: In Ivory Coast, Bid to Ease Out Defiant Leader
description: WASHINGTON  President Laurent Gbagbo vowed Friday that he would not cede power in Ivory Coast, while Obama administration officials warned that he was running out of time to accept an offer they had made to help him leave the country peacefully.

title: For Alzheimers Patients, Focusing on Comfort
description: In a strategy that disregards typical nursing-home rules, the Beatitudes nursing home in Phoenix allows patients practically anything that brings comfort.

title: This Year, Change Your Mind
description: NEW Years resolutions often have to do with eating more healthfully, going to the gym more, giving up sweets, losing weight  all admirable goals aimed at improving ones physical health. Most people, though, do not realize that they can strengthen their brains in a similar way.

title: Lottery Numbers
Political Battle on Illegal Immigration Shifts to States
description: Legislative leaders in at least half a dozen states say they will propose bills similar to a controversial law to fight illegal immigration that was adopted by Arizona last spring, even though a federal court has suspended central provisions of that statute.

title: Rose Bowl Matchup
description: Texas Christian (12-0) vs. Wisconsin (11-1)

title: New Years Day Schedules in New York Region
description: NEW YORK

title: Fiesta Bowl Matchup
description: Connecticut (8-4) vs. Oklahoma (11-2)

title: An Americas Cup by the Bay: San Francisco Is Chosen as the 2013 Host
description: After months of sometimes contentious negotiations, the organizers of the Americas Cup said on Friday that San Francisco would host the 34th race in late 2013.

title: Boomers Hit New Self-Absorption Milestone: Age 65
description: In keeping with a generations fascination with itself, the time has come to note the passing of another milestone: On New Years Day, the oldest members of the Baby Boom Generation will turn 65, the age once linked to retirement, early bird specials and gray Velcro shoes that go with everything.

title: The Next Treaties
description: Even after the herculean effort required to win Senate ratification of the New Start treaty, President Obama has no time to rest. The treaty, which mandates modest cuts in long-range nuclear weapons, is on its way to approval by the Duma, the lower house of Parliament in Russia. Once that happens, Washington and Moscow should quickly begin discussing other, more far-reaching agreements.

title: What a Property Tax Cap Would Do
description: To the Editor:

title: The End-of-the-Year Quiz
description: I. Happy New Year! Besides the Times Square ball, the glorious American mosaic of things scheduled to be dropped around the nation on New Years Eve also included all but which one of the following:

title: Success and Failure on the G.E.D.
description: Nearly 40 million Americans are locked into dead-end jobs because they do not have a high school diploma. A daylong exam called the General Educational Development test, or G.E.D., provides the equivalent of a high school diploma  and better chances in the job market  to those who pass it. Nearly 800,000 people take the exam each year, and about 500,000 pass.

title: Still Tinkering
description: Of all the recommendations by the independent 9/11 Commission in 2004, the one that Congress has had the most difficulty with is the summons to Congress to reform itself. The commission urged lawmakers to junk the hydra-headed, multicommittee system of intelligence oversight in favor of single panels in the House and the Senate combining the clout of budgeting with oversight.

title: Changing Notions of Friendship in the Facebook Era
description: To the Editor:

title: Reforming Juvenile Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Plea for Pollards Release
description: To the Editor:

title: A Year Anew
description: 2011. Perhaps you can remember when the thought of a brand new year  even the very numeral  was exciting. Somehow, it is harder to place the moment when the excitement of a new year turned to wariness and then to alarm and then to futile questions about the nature of time. Are we tunneling forward into the future, or is time blowing past us like a stiff breeze? Perhaps we simply carry time within us. To be conscious at all is to be conscious of time.

title: For Two Sisters, the End of an Ordeal
description: I got a call on New Years Eve from Gladys Scott, which was a terrific way for 2010 to end.

title: Corrections
description: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Messages on news coverage can be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left toll-free at 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). Comments on editorials may be e-mailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.

title: In College, Coaches Can Be Married Only to the Job
description: LOS ANGELES  When Arnie Bielemas son Bret got ready to leave the family farm in Prophetstown, Ill., to attend college at Iowa and walk on with the football team, Arnie passed along some parting advice. Not surprisingly, considering that Bret Bielemas daily chores included washing out hog pens for five hours, the talk was grounded in Midwestern sensibility.

title: Art Intended to Make the End of Life Beautiful
description: For most of his mothers life, Tobi Kahn would make a present on each of her birthdays. The gifts began during his childhood as hand-drawn cards, more tender than precocious. As he grew into a formally trained and then a critically acclaimed artist, he made her a pocketbook one year, a desk set another, photographs worthy of museum exhibition.

title: Pre-Inauguration Jitters for a High School Choir
description: ALBANY  Eliot Spitzer had Natalie Merchant of 10,000 Maniacs fame. Andrew M. Cuomo has the Albanettes.

title: Saturday: A New Year
description: Welcome to 1/1/11. (If youre checking in and its still 2010, use your imagination.)

title: Cuomo Names Developers of a Student Loan Center
description: In the hours before he became governor, New Yorks departing attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, announced that he was tying up a loose end from one of his signature campaigns: an investigation of the student loan industry that uncovered kickbacks and deceptive marketing tactics.

title: In Classic Matchup, the Penguins Star Shines the Brightest
description: PITTSBURGH  Each N.H.L. Winter Classic has had a theme. The first, amid the fat snowflakes of suburban Buffalo in 2008, was about playing outdoors to celebrate the origins of hockey. The next two were about playing at two iconic baseball stadiums, Chicagos Wrigley Field and Bostons Fenway Park.

title: Forecast Bumps Winter Classic Into Evening
description: PITTSBURGH  The N.H.L. announced Friday that the Winter Classics start time would be pushed back to 8 p.m. from 1 p.m. on New Years Day because of forecasts of heavy rain.

title: Cuomo Is Sworn In as New Yorks Governor
description: ALBANY  Andrew Mark Cuomo was sworn in on Friday night as New Yorks 56th governor in a private ceremony with family and friends at the Executive Mansion. He planned to waste no time getting to work, scheduling his first staff meeting on Saturday morning before his formal inauguration ceremony.

title: Photo Replay: Dec. 31
description: The final day in sports in 2010 included ski jumping in Germany, college basketball in Kentucky and the start of a yacht race that will eventually go around the world.

title: Roger Milliken, Conservative Tycoon, Dies at 95
description: Roger Milliken, a South Carolina textile magnate who supported conservative causes and was instrumental in building the state into a bastion of the Republican Party, died Thursday in Spartanburg, S.C. He was 95.

title: Denis Dutton, Philosopher, Dies at 66
description: Denis Dutton, a distinguished philosopher, writer and digital-media guru who founded Arts & Letters Daily, one of the first Web sites to exploit the Internet as a vehicle for meaningful intellectual exchange, died on Tuesday in Christchurch, New Zealand, where he lived. He was 66.

title: Philip Burton Jr., Documentarian, Dies at 76
description: Philip Burton Jr., who wrote, produced and directed award-winning television documentaries about the struggle for African-American equality and the inner workings of American government, died on Dec. 24 in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 76 and lived in Ojai, Calif.

title: North Korea Calls for Dialogue With the South
description: SEOUL, South Korea --- In an annual New Years commentary that is widely seen as an indicator of the countrys political and economic goals for the coming year, North Korea called Saturday for dialogue with South Korea and a relaxation of tensions as soon as possible.

title: Too Much to Drink? Try Yoga
description: @import url("http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/SlidingGallery.css");

title: Hearst in Talks to Buy Magazines
description: Lagardre, Frances biggest publisher, is in exclusive talks to sell its international magazine business, including Car and Driver and the foreign editions of Elle, to the Hearst Corporation, the companies said on Friday.

title: The Early Word: a New Year, and New Issues
description: In Todays Times:

title: N.F.L. Notables Who Died in 2010
description: A look back at how the Fifth Down remembered some of the pro football notables who died in 2010:

title: Osgoods Rsum More Than Numbers
description: With an outstanding 46-save performance last Monday against Colorado, the Red Wings Chris Osgood became only the 10th N.H.L. goalie to record 400 career victories.

title: Where Rules Are Stricter, a Hit Is Penalized
description: When it comes to head-trauma safety, the difference between international and North American hockey was made clear at the world junior tournament in Buffalo last week.

title: Defending the Giants Coordinators
description: It turns out that saying something nice about Tom Coughlin wasnt so hard.Many readers responded to the Coughlin or Cowher post on Thursday. Well round up some reaction on Sunday morning.

title: Snow Job
description: Its always important to realize that someone can disagree with you politically without being a bad person. But there are bad people in politics, too. Maybe its just my bias that gives me the impression that there are more mean, self-centered whiners on one side of the aisle than on the other; but anyway, a spectacular performance by my governor:

title: The Long Road Ahead
description: The figure above illustrates Okuns Law  the relationship between growth and unemployment. (Gah  Ive tried to remove the connecting lines, to no avail.) The horizontal axis shows annual growth rates of real GDP; the vertical axis shows the year-to-year change in the unemployment rate. Two things are clear. First, the economy has to grow around 2 1/2 percent per year just to keep unemployment from rising. Second, growth above that level leads to a less than one-for-one fall in unemployment (because hours per worker rise, more people enter the work force, etc.). Roughly, it takes two point-years of extra growth to reduce the unemployment rate by one point.

title: Tear Gas Kills a Palestinian Protester
description: JERUSALEM  A Palestinian woman died Saturday after inhaling tear gas fired by Israeli forces a day earlier at a protest against Israels separation barrier in a West Bank village.

title: U.S. Stepping Up Fight on Afghan Smuggling
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Janet Napolitano, the United States homeland security secretary, said Saturday that her department planned to triple the number of agents in Afghanistan to train border and customs workers  an effort that is partly aimed at curbing the smuggling of cash out of the country.

title: Belarus Ejects European Watchdog Agency
description: MOSCOW  In what appears to be another step in suppressing criticism and dissent, Belarus asked the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe to leave the country after its election monitors accused the government of fraud in the presidential election last month.

title: Benedict Announces Meeting of Faiths
description: ROME  Pope Benedict XVI on Saturday announced that he would hold an interfaith meeting in Assisi, Italy, this October to mark the 25th anniversary of a watershed meeting held there by his predecessor, John Paul II.

title: Acrostic: Of Course
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Is there more to talk about after solving a crossword than an acrostic? Looking at the number of comments for the daily posts here on Wordplay, the answer seems to be yes. But that doesnt need to be the case.

title: Choosing Between Allegiance to Family or to Alma Mater
description: Emilie Deutsch is vice president for original programming with the CBS College Sports Network.

title: Russian Plane Catches Fire, Killing Three
description: MOSCOW  A Soviet-made airliner caught fire on Saturday at an airport in Siberia, leaving at least three people dead, three missing and 39 hospitalized with burns, carbon monoxide poisoning and other injuries, officials said.

title: Losing His Mobility, but Not His Musical Dreams
description: At the flip of some switches on his computer, Jason Celiks room fills with a melodic hip-hop beat. After a few bars, his older brothers sleepy, streetwise rhymes kick in, reminiscent of the young rapper Drake. Their father, Muzzafer, who is from Istanbul, stands in the background and proudly bobs his head, delighted by the strains of traditional Turkish music woven into the track.

title: Prosecutor Confirms Accusation Against Sudan Leader
description: PARIS  The International Criminal Courts chief prosecutor has confirmed reports that he told diplomats that his office had found evidence that President Omar al-Bashir of Sudan had a huge personal fortune skimmed from his countrys oil income and kept in foreign accounts.

title: Oprahs Cable Channel Flickers to Life
description: At precisely 12 oclock on New Years Day, Oprah Winfrey welcomed television viewers to OWN, a cable channel that she has said will espouse her live your best life mantra.

title: Caregiving and Dementia: New Ideas
description: The Times reports today on research into new ways to care for people with Alzheimers disease and other forms of dementia.

title: Cuomo Promises Emergency Plan on Finance Woes
description: ALBANY  Andrew Mark Cuomo became the 56th governor of New York on Saturday, promising to immediately take on the states huge financial problems and to fight to limit taxes on homeowners across the state.

title: Governor Cuomo's Inaugural Address
description: In a private ceremony, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo delivered his inaugural address.

title: Mali Tackles Al Qaeda and Drug Traffic
description: BAMAKO, Mali  The tourism minister, NDiaye Bah, visibly bristled when asked about the possibility that Al Qaedas North African offshoot might kidnap foreigners in fabled Timbuktu or anywhere across Malis northern desert.

title: Other Blacks Drop Out and Throw Support to Moseley Braun in Chicago Mayoral Race
description: CHICAGO  Danny K. Davis, a longtime United States representative, has dropped out of the race to become Chicagos mayor, creating the scenario that African-American leaders here had for months been clamoring for: a campaign that includes only one major African-American candidate.

title: Top Iran Prosecutor Vows to Charge Opposition Leaders
description: TEHRAN  Signaling that Iran might be ready to punish the leaders of the countrys opposition movement more than a year after the last major antigovernment protests, a top Iranian judicial official has vowed to prosecute them.

title: Gay Utah Teenager Takes Another Step in 10-Year Journey
description: ST. GEORGE, Utah  One bond among many of the members of the Gay-Straight Alliances in Utah high schools is a history of secrecy, depression and even self-loathing in a community where gay children have sometimes been shunned at church or kicked out of their homes.

title: In Isolated Utah City, New Clubs for Gay Students
description: ST. GEORGE, Utah  Some disapproving classmates called members of the new club Satanists. Another asked one of the girls involved, Do you have a disease?

title: The New Speed of Money, Reshaping Markets
description: Secaucus, N.J.

title: A Speaking Manner Rooted in Queens but All His Own
description: When Andrew M. Cuomo is asked whether he speaks like a New Yorker, he likes to shake his head. No, he sometimes says. Thats a Queens accent.

title: Cuomos Albany Housing, From Old Hotel to Mansion
description: ALBANY  In the middle of downtown, half a block from the State Capitol, the hollowed-out remains of five brick and stone buildings stare blankly out at State Street. Only the facades remain, some of them covered by plywood.

title: Coupons for Patients, but Higher Bills for Insurers
description: EXECUTIVES of a small insurance company in Albany were mystified when, almost overnight, its payments for a certain class of antibiotics nearly doubled, threatening to add about a half-million dollars annually in costs.

title: A Father Looks On Not With Pride, but With Gratitude
description: ALBANY  He was invited by his son, Andrew M. Cuomo, to stand behind him as New Yorks chief judge administered the oath of office. A few seconds later, the new governor gave him a hug and a kiss on the cheek, which he returned with a paternal slap on the arm.

title: Fatal Bomb Hits a Church in Egypt
description: A bomb, possibly worn by a suicide attacker, ripped through a throng of worshipers outside of a Coptic Christian church in the port city of Alexandria, Egypt, early Saturday, killing at least 21 people in the worst attack against Egypts Christian minority in recent memory.

title: Got an Idea? Sell It to Me in 30 Seconds
description: This interview with Catherine Winder, president and executive producer of Rainmaker Entertainment, an animation studio, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

description: Vancouver, British Columbia

title: Europes Young Grow Agitated Over Future Prospects
description: LECCE, Italy  Francesca Esposito, 29 and exquisitely educated, helped win millions of euros in false disability and other lawsuits for her employer, a major Italian state agency. But one day last fall she quit, fed up with how surreal and ultimately sad it is to be young in Italy today.

title: At Sea in South Korea
description: I remember March 26 vividly. I was watching the news as I do each night when the words Cheonan Sunk appeared on the screen.

title: Englands Political Pandas
description: London

title: Market Wisdom Applies to E.T.F.s, Too
description: I WAS standing in the aisle of a commuter train rolling slowly into Manhattan, with time to kill. So I plugged some earbuds into my iPhone and began listening to music, reading e-mail and scanning the days news. Then I began to check the financial numbers.

title: Israels Present Tense
description: My great-grandfather was obsessed with the past. His generation venerated a bygone world. My grandmother was obsessed with the future. That was her generations rebellion. We, the young generation in Israel, suffer from an obsession with the present, a worship of the here and now, and a lack of faith in our power to bring about change.

title: Ex-Senator Is Now the Only Major Black Hopeful in a Chicago Race
description: CHICAGO  Danny K. Davis, a longtime United States representative, has dropped out of the race to become Chicagos mayor, creating the situation that black leaders here had for months been clamoring for: a campaign that includes only one major African-American candidate.

title: Obama Is Serious About His Vacation. And, Please, No Shirtless Shots.
description: HONOLULU  President Obama has accomplished something extraordinary during his Hawaiian escape from Washington: his White House has gone dark for more than a week.

title: Ruth Park, Australian Realist Author, Dies at 93
description: Ruth Park, whose novel of the Sydney slums, The Harp in the South, shocked Australians in the 1940s but did not prevent her from becoming one of the countrys most revered writers, died on Dec. 14 in Sydney. She was 93.

title: When Innovation, Too, Is Made in China
description: AS a national strategy, China is trying to build an economy that relies on innovation rather than imitation. Clearly, its leaders recognize that being the worlds low-cost workshop for assembling the breakthrough products designed elsewhere  think iPads and a host of other high-tech goods  has its limits.

title: My Familys Flop
description: THE show was called Via Galactica. In 1972, as this science fiction musical was being prepared for its Broadway opening, some members of the creative team feared that no one would be able to say its name. And in any case, what did it mean? According to the shows publicity material it meant, road to the stars.

title: Propane Leak Prompts Evacuation of 3,000 People on Long Island
description: 8:49 p.m. | Updated  Propane seeping from a 30,000-gallon underground tank behind a department store in Suffolk County early Saturday led emergency officials to evacuate about 3,000 people from 900 homes within one mile of the leak, the authorities said.

title: A C.T. Scan for Hairline Fractures (in Industrial Parts, That Is)
description: ENGINE parts, pacemakers and millions of other crucial manufactured objects have something in common: they must be inspected carefully for dangerous defects like hairline cracks.

title: For Capitols Nursing Mothers, an Escape From Politics

title: Tea Party Activists Angry at G.O.P. Leaders
description: As Tea Party politicians prepare to take their seats when the 112th Congress convenes this week, they are already taking issue with Republicans for failing to hold the line against the flurry of legislation enacted in the waning weeks of Democratic control of the House of Representatives and for not giving some candidates backed by Tea Party groups powerful leadership positions.

title: Stirrings of a Challenge From an Obama Appointee
description: President Obama may have thought he had sidelined a possible rival when he nominated Jon Huntsman, a former Republican governor from Utah, to be his ambassador to China.

title: Overweight, Out of Work at Rail Yard
description: The burly Teamsters who transfer double-stacked shipping containers between trains and trucks at BNSF Railways Corwith rail yard on the Southwest Side typically spend their days concerned with deft maneuvers of heavy equipment.

title: Prosperity, Real or Imagined
description: THE past is never dead, William Faulkner wrote in 1951. Its not even past. Six decades later, R. Christopher Whalen takes up the gauntlet implied in those words in Inflated: How Money and Debt Built the American Dream (John Wiley & Sons, $34.95).

title: In Politics, Live in the Present and Kick Problems to the Future
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative

title: Face of City Has Changed Dramatically, Census Estimates Show
description: The electorate that will soon choose the successor to Mayor Richard M. Daley looks a lot different than the voters who first put him in office more than two decades ago.

title: School District Moves Slowly to Manage Its Real Estate
description: Despite being one of the largest financially struggling landowners in the city, the San Francisco Unified School District has largely failed to actively manage its holdings, leaving a number of valuable properties idle for years.

title: The Economy in 2011
description: When people say that the recovery does not feel like a recovery, they are describing reality. The economy is growing, but for many Americans life is not getting better. Unemployment remains high. Home values are depressed. And state budgets are in deep trouble, presaging more layoffs, service cuts and tax increases.

title: Some Techy Predictions as the Bubble Keeps Inflating
description: Jonathan Weber writes a regular column for The Bay Citizen

title: Chinas Naval Ambitions
description: Beijings drive to extend its military and territorial reach is making Americas close allies in the region nervous and raising legitimate questions about American diplomacy and future military procurement. The commander of Americas Pacific forces recently revealed that China could soon deploy a ballistic missile capable of threatening American aircraft carriers in the region.

title: Homeland Blather
description: It is disturbing to listen to Representative Peter King, the incoming chairman of the Homeland Security Committee. He has announced plans to hold a hearing next month into what he calls the radicalization of the American Muslim community. Mr. King, a New York Republican, is no stranger to bluster, but his sweeping slur on Muslim citizens is unacceptable.

title: Shoe Garden
description: One-of-a-kind weirdness, a collection of shoes and flowers, has blossomed in this 12.7-acre park that boasts a colorful history, and picturesque Victorians on its perimeter. The Shoe Garden sprouted a decade ago and is still charming residents.

title: Timeless Tragedy in Modern Guise
description: Even die-hard fans of the director Franco Zeffirellis productions for the Metropolitan Opera have to concede that his 1998 staging of Verdis Traviata was terrible. With its opulently garish sets and knee-jerk realism, the production dwarfed the cast, no matter what stars were singing. So the time has long since come for something different. And the intriguing production by the German director Willy Decker that the Met introduced on New Years Eve could not be more different.

title: Looking Back
description: Im standing in the barnyard with the farrier. Remedy, the quarter horse, is getting his winter shoes. Were surrounded by vast heaps of plowed snow. Its a sparkling day, and for some reason I find myself thinking about a photograph we found after my father died. My grandfather is sitting on a high bank of snow, dressed in his work clothes, and hes holding up a fox terrier, which looks as if its ready to eat the camera. This is the home farm in northwest Iowa, probably 1936.

title: Livermore Retirees Sue University Over Health Care Benefits
description: As one of the countrys leading nuclear physicists at one of the countrys most prestigious scientific institutions, Jay Davis has worked in the golden hills of Livermore and weapons depots of Iraq. In 1988, Mr. Davis founded the renowned Livermore Labs Center for Accelerator Mass Spectrometry, which reveals the chemical makeup of substances and has helped advance research across many disciplines.

title: Equality, a True Soul Food
description: John Steinbeck observed that a sad soul can kill you quicker, far quicker, than a germ.

title: Resolved: Fix the Filibuster
description: Minneapolis

description: To the Editor:

title: Real Estate Developers Prosper Despite Defaults
description: Larry Gluck, the apartment building king whose company defaulted on loans in New York, San Francisco, Los Angeles and Washington, recently bought the Windermere Hotel in Manhattan and Tivoli Towers, a subsidized housing complex in Brooklyn.

title: Treasures of Youth Vanish in Custody of a State Agency Intended to Protect Them
description: Crystal Martinezs possessions are more precious than the average teenagers. The 18-year-old, who as a child was abused and neglected by her biological family, has not had a permanent home since entering foster care at 7.

title: Legislature Is Coming: A Primer on the Session
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column

title: A Small Town Is Transformed, Led by Chocolate
description: Residents of Calvert will tell you that their charming town, on Highway 6 between Waco and Bryan, has led many lives.

title: Universities Are Challenged as Demographics Shift
description: In August, 60 years after the University of Texas admitted its first black student, the school welcomed the first freshman class in which white students were in the minority.

title: Stretch | Beyond Breath and Silence
description: As I lay in savasana at Yoga High on the Lower East Side, intoxicated by the sound of a bluesy harmonica, it struck me that yoga and music belong together, like a popping fire on a snowy day.

title: Sunday: Works in Translation
description: Puzzle note: For online solvers, a PDF is also available since Across Lite cant display the foreign alphabets used in three of the clues (it uses English-letter transliterations instead). Here are the three clues:

title: Music and Fried Chicken
description: I WAS 2 when my father left the Air Force and got a job in the electronics industry. We moved six times, to wherever company plants were being built. I enjoyed moving. I was interested in different cultures, and I learned to read people quickly.

title: Farewell: The Sequel
description: Note: The Sunday puzzle post directly precedes this one.

title: In Jacksons Farewell Tour, Lakers Show Need for Tuneup
description: Phil Jackson has been here before. Twice, in fact, with entirely different results.

title: Offering Help (Carefully) to Jobless Friends
description: IF I hear of something, Ill let you know.

title: From Turmoil, Revis Learns to Take Care of Business
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Near the end of his fourth and longest season, Darrelle Revis feels older than 25. He is back in the Pro Bowl, back in the playoffs, back rendering receivers invisible at cornerback for the Jets. To that end, life has returned to normal.

title: Letters: Stimulus, at What Price?
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: If Giants Cant Hang On, Dont Expect a Fall Guy
description: The Giants tried to strike all the right notes last week as they talked about playing a game Sunday against the Washington Redskins that they could be proud of, a game to drown out the dissonance of the last two weeks. On Friday, when he was asked if he had discussed his job status with his players, Tom Coughlin said the only thing a sensible coach could say: it was not about him.

title: Arnold Weiss Dies at 86; Helped to Find Hitlers Will
description: Arnold Hans Weiss, who fled to the United States from Nazi Germany as a 13-year-old and returned as an American soldier during World War II, becoming a principal in the investigation that led to the discovery of Hitlers last will and political testament, died Dec. 7 in Rockville, Md. He was 86 and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Auriemma Brash From the Beginning
description: Once upon a time, for a very brief time, Geno Auriemma was not simultaneously blessed and burdened by championship expectation and regular-season perfection. A quarter-century ago, long before anyone in Connecticut could fathom Diana Taurasi and Maya Moore, Auriemma set sail in the shallow waters of womens college basketball with Audrey Epstein and Peggy Walsh.

title: In Poll, Seattle Fans Say They Want Seahawks to Lose
description: You might be wondering how Seattle fans are feeling about their Seahawks. It turns out that many are about as excited as most N.F.L. fans about the prospect of a losing team making the playoffs.

title: Searching for Sports First Female Pitchman
description: Serena Williams won two tennis Grand Slam singles titles in 2009, but she did not appear among the 50 top-earning American athletes ranked last summer by SI.com, whose formula included 2009 salaries or winnings and endorsements. The only woman on the earning lists was another tennis player, Maria Sharapova, who came in 20th among international athletes.

title: N.F.L. Is on Pace for a Season Record for Touchdown Passes
description: It is a staple of the New Orleans Saints game plan, a simple formation that puts Reggie Bush in motion and leaves tight end Jimmy Graham in a mismatch with an opposing cornerback near the goal line. But the play, which produced the Saints winning touchdown against the Atlanta Falcons last Monday  and generated a touchdown pass in the Super Bowl last February  helps explain a startling statistical leap the N.F.L. will take this season.

title: Full Text of Cuomos Inauguration Speech
description: Well, thank you and good afternoon to all of you. First let me begin by thanking the people of the State of New York for this tremendous honor. I am humbled to be their public servant, and I will honor their trust and their confidence every day. Thank you.

title: Rafael Palmeiro May Find Door Closed to Hall of Fame
description: Three baseball milestones have traditionally guaranteed a players entry into the Hall of Fame. Smack more than 500 home runs, pile up more than 3,000 hits or win more than 300 games, and Cooperstown beckons.

title: Wizards Wall Shows Rare Streak of Durability
description: When Washington hosted the New Orleans Hornets on Saturday night, John Wall started for the Wizards.

title: Intense to the End, Meyer Walks Away a Winner
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Florida Coach Urban Meyer yanked the headset from the top of his head and flung it to the ground in disgust. A moment later, he ripped the power pack to the headset off his belt and bounced that off the turf, too. He raised his arms straight over his head in despair for a touchdown that did not come in the third quarter of the Outback Bowl.

title: Nice to Meet You, Governor. And Sandra Lee! Wow!
description: ALBANY  Andrew M. Cuomo flung open the doors of the Executive Mansion on Saturday, saying he wanted people to feel connected once again to their state government.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu: Jan. 2
description: The Sunday television talk shows examine whats in store for 2011 as the 112th Congress rolls into town this week.

title: Rose Bowl Victory Shows Texas Christians Prowess
description: PASADENA, Calif.  In the shadow of the San Gabriel Mountains, change can come slowly. At the Rose Bowl, where college football clings to tradition with white-knuckle fervor, fullbacks can still be in vogue, tight ends act as primary pass catchers and the punter can be valued as a skill position player.

title: Rain and Soft Ice Cant Dampen Capitals Delight
description: PITTSBURGH  It may not have been very wintry, but it was spectacular nonetheless as the Pittsburgh Penguins and the Washington Capitals clashed in the N.H.L. Winter Classic before a capacity crowd of 68,111 at Heinz Field on New Years night.

description: Andrew M. Cuomo became New Yorks 56th governor.

title: Pitt Fires Its New Coach
description: The University of Pittsburgh fired Coach Mike Haywood on Saturday in the wake of his arrest on a charge of domestic battery in Indiana against the mother of his child. Pittsburgh hired Haywood, who was the coach at Miami (Ohio), on Dec. 16 to replace Dave Wannstedt.

description: The Clippers rookie Blake Griffin scored 30 points and pulled down 12 rebounds Wednesday night to record his 20th straight double-double.

description: A 25-year-old David Beckham might be a perfect fit for a team like free-wheeling, goal-scoring, title-contending Tottenham. But could a 35-year-old Beckham be a good addition for Spurs, too?

title: Several Warnings, Then a Soldiers Lonely Death
description: WASHINGTON  A gentle snow fell on the funeral of Staff Sgt. David Senft at Arlington National Cemetery on Dec. 16, when his bitterly divided California family came together to say goodbye. His 5-year-old son received a flag from a grateful nation.

title: 30 Seconds With Carl Banks
description: Carl Banks was a hard-hitting All-Pro linebacker for Giants teams that won two Super Bowls. Off the field, he was one of the best-dressed athletes around town. Banks, who retired as a player in 1995, is an analyst on Giants radio broadcasts, a commentator on WFAN and a host on Sirius Radio. He recently started an apparel line with N.F.L. team logos for Lord & Taylor stores.

description: Caitlin Dube and Scott Reding had a poetry-fueled whirlwind romance. When the inspiration to propose suddenly hit him, Mr. Reding fashioned a ring from blue masking tape.

description: Hundreds of correctional officers from prisons across America descended last spring on a shuttered penitentiary in West Virginia for annual training exercises.

description: Highlights from the day in college football: Texas Christian wins the Rose Bowl, the Big Ten went 0-5 and Urban Meyer coached his last game at Florida.

title: In Paris, a Crash Course in Modern Fashion
description: If you missed the last two decades in fashion, heres your chance to catch up. The Idealized History of Contemporary Fashion Vol. 2, the second of a two-part exhibition that looks back at contemporary fashion history, runs through May 8 at the Muse des Arts Dcoratifs (107 rue de Rivoli; 33-1-44-55-57-50; www.lesartsdecoratifs.fr).

description: Below is a sampling of reader responses from the Coughlin or Cowher post on Thursday.

description: This is a good moment to think ahead of topics and issues that Id like to focus on for the coming year. I always do that informally, sort of mumbling to myself, but let me also invite your thoughts. I wont promise to follow your suggestions, but I will read them and consider them.

description: The road to the euro began with coal and steel. Heres Robert Schuman, the French foreign minister, in 1950, proposing the creation of the European Coal and Steel Community:

description: Oprah Winfrey said that she wanted to create a cable network without a trace of mean-spirited programming, and she has wrung every drop of it from the Oprah Winfrey Network.

title: Egypt Orders Tighter Security After Church Bombing
description: CAIRO  Egyptian authorities increased security around churches on Monday as sectarian tensions mounted after a bombing in the coastal city of Alexandria that killed 21 and wounded nearly 100 leaving a New Years Mass.

description: JERUSALEM  Israeli soldiers shot and killed a Palestinian man as he approached a checkpoint in the northern West Bank early Sunday holding a glass bottle, the military said.

description: In an Op-Ed piece in The New York Times on Sunday, Jennifer George, the daughter of the producer George W. George, writes about the debacle that was her parents musical Via Galactica, one of Broadways most famed flops.

title: G.O.P. Newcomers Set Out to Undo Obama Victories
description: WASHINGTON  Soon after the 112th Congress convenes Wednesday, Republicans in the House plan to make good on a campaign promise that helped vault many new members to victory: voting to repeal President Obamas health care overhaul.

title: Live Analysis: Giants 17, Redskins 14, Final
description: LANDOVER, Md.  The Giants held on to beat the Redskins, 17-14, but their season was over when the Packers Nick Collins intercepted a Jay Cutler pass with 10 seconds left at Lambeau Field. The Bears-Packers game was closer than a lot of people expected (the betting line kept rising during the week and settled around 10 points). Lovie Smith stuck to his word and played his starters the whole way in a 10-3 loss. The Bears knew heading into the game that they had nothing to play for, but led into the third quarter as the Packers struggled to run the ball and do much of anything on offense. The Giants did their job; it wasnt pretty, but they survived the loss of Rich Seubert to injury and finished 10-6. Now the question turns to Tom Coughlins future. But how can you fire a coach who won 10 games? The Giants are not known for such impatience. Toni Monkovic The live analysis of the game, by Mark Viera, is below. Pregame:

title: Rose Bowl Ratings Fall, but Are Still Good for ESPN
description: For ESPN, the decision to show all of the Bowl Championship Series games began to pay off when Texas Christians 21-19 victory over Wisconsin in the Rose Bowl on Saturday generated an 11.7 preliminary overnight Nielsen rating. While the games rating was the highest for any program on cable except for N.FL. games since 2001, it fell from what it had been on ABC, where it had 13.8 last year, a 12.6 in 2009 and a 12.1 in 2008.

title: Rested Jets End Regular Season in a Preseason Atmosphere
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Moments after the Jets regular season ended, the confetti machine outside the teams tunnel malfunctioned, shooting shiny, tiny slips of green and white paper about two feet into the air. That fit perfectly with the muted celebration.

title: Diplomats Help Push Sales of Jetliners on the Global Market
description: This article was reported by Eric Lipton, Nicola Clark and Andrew W. Lehren and was written by Mr. Lipton.

title: Hardcover Business Best Sellers
Paperback Business Best Sellers
Caring for the Patient With Alzheimers
description: In a recent New York Times article, Giving Alzheimers Patients Their Way, Even Chocolate, I looked at caregiving for people with Alzheimers disease and described how scientists and researchers are studying approaches to caregiving that appear to ease some of the most troubling symptoms, like wandering or agitated and aggressive behavior. Certain approaches to caregiving can make life more pleasant for patients, who, research suggests, continue to feel emotions like joy or sadness even if they have no memory of the experiences that caused those emotions. And they can, in turn, make things easier for caregivers, allowing people to care for relatives with Alzheimers at home and delay placing them in nursing homes.

title: Bug Causes iPhone Alarm to Greet New Year With Silence
description: Pat Kiernan, a morning anchor on NY1, the New York City cable news channel, is no stranger to alarm clock problems. Thats why he usually relies on several clocks, phones and other devices to wake him in time for his early newscasts.

title: Stoned
description: Many stones have been thrown since we first met here in May. Some have shattered windows of received wisdom; others have bounced off walls of resistance. Some have plopped quietly into inviting ponds of assent; others have rattled down unexplored alleys of thought.

title: How an Engineer Became a White-Haired General
description: Poor Robert E. Lee. All these years later he still cant beat Ulysses S. Grant.

title: The Psychopath Killer in Average-Guy Garb
description: At Lifetime, the cable channel built on the idea that the male of the species is at heart pure evil, the real-life case of Philip Markoff must have seemed like something the script department concocted. Lifetime has always trafficked in woman-in-jeopardy movies in which a central element is often the old hes not what he seems villain. Mr. Markoff was certainly that: a top medical student, good looking, charming, limitless future.

title: Nutcracker Riddles With Many Answers
description: Whats The Nutcracker really about? Within its tale of children, the magician godfather Drosselmeyer, snow and sweets, the most striking images are ones of metamorphosis. In a famous scene worthy of Lewis Carrolls Alice books, the Christmas tree grows colossal, and the childrens toys return to the stage, human size and alive.

title: Staying Civil as the World Convulses
description: Being Polite to Hitler opens on Oct. 5, 1953, with the Dodgers losing the World Series to the Yankees during a heat wave. Agnes Scofield, a widowed baseball fan and schoolteacher in Washburn, Ohio, has allowed her third graders to listen to the final game on the radio, and then, amid her own intense disappointment, finds herself telling a furious child that learning how to lose is part of growing up.

title: Need a Gala? Tchaikovsky Is a Go-To Guy
description: For much of the music world the new year arrives to the opulent sounds of Johann Strauss, whose perfectly formed Viennese dance elaborations fuse nostalgia with a vibrancy and optimism suited to forging ahead. You could search long and hard without finding music better suited to the occasion; for proof look to the New York Philharmonic, where a restless shuffling of the New Years Eve playlist in recent seasons has offered its share of hits and misses but still hasnt yielded a better alternative.

title: On the Hunt for an 11th Trick After the Clubs Break Badly
description: Saturdays column involved a duel between the defenders and the declarer in which the defenders came out on top. In the diagramed deal the declarer had the upper hand. It featured a pretty piece of play by Chuck Lamprey of White Plains. He was partnering Arch McKellar of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., in a pair event at the Bridge Deck in Scarsdale, N.Y., last October.

title: Major Party Walks Out of Coalition in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The second-largest party in the ruling coalition here announced late Sunday that it was ending its partnership with the Pakistan Peoples Party, putting into question the fate of Prime Minister Yusuf Raza Gilanis government, which is grappling with a fragile economy as it tries to ward off political and terrorism-related troubles.

title: Obama Signs Bill to Help 9/11 Workers
description: HONOLULU  President Obama took time out of his Hawaiian vacation on Sunday to sign into law one of the surprise accomplishments of the lame-duck Congress: a measure covering the cost of medical care for rescue workers and others sickened by toxic fumes and dust after the 2001 terrorist attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Turiafs Blocks Carve Out a Path for the Knicks
description: For Ronny Turiaf, Sundays game was part basketball, part wrestling. He had his eye poked, his ribs elbowed and his shoulder tugged against the Indiana Pacers. In between the bodily damage, Turiaf blocked enough shots to provide a spark and nudge the Knicks to a victory.

title: True Grit Continues to Lure Moviegoers Into 2011
description: Hollywood started the New Year with a relative whimper. North American ticket sales for the holiday weekend were down 20 percent compared with the same period last year, as a group of holdover releases failed to match the heat generated last winter by Avatar. For the weekend Little Fockers (Universal) was No. 1 with an estimated $26.3 million for a two-week total of $103.2 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office statistics. True Grit (Paramount), with Jeff Bridges, right, was a surprisingly close second with $24.5 million for a two-week total of $86.8 million, a phenomenal result for an adult drama. Tron: Legacy (Disney) chugged away in third place with $18.3 million for three-week total of $130.9 million. Yogi Bear (Warner) was fourth with about $13 million, bringing its three-week total to $66.1 million, while The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader was fifth. That fantasy from 20th Century Fox sold about $10.5 million over the weekend for a four-week total of about $87 million.

title: Modigliani Painting in War Crimes Case
description: Serbian prosecutors say they believe that Goran Hadzic, a former Croatian Serb rebel leader wanted for war crimes, may have tried to raise money for his life in hiding by selling a painting by Amedeo Modigliani, The Associated Press reported. On Thursday Serbian police officers searching the home of one of Mr. Hadzics friends for clues about his whereabouts reported that they found about 50 paintings, as well as a photograph of a Modigliani. The office of Serbias war crimes prosecutor said in a statement that the painting was estimated to be worth over a million euros ($1.3 million) and that Mr. Hadzic had probably tried to sell it, The A.P. said. The painting was not named or described further, and it was unclear if it was stolen. A Modigliani painting from 1917, Nude Sitting on a Divan (The Beautiful Roman Woman), sold at Sothebys in November for $68.9 million, an auction record for the artist. Mr. Hadzic and the Bosnian Serb army commander Ratko Mladic are the last two suspects wanted by the United Nations War Crimes Tribunal in The Hague. Serbias failure to arrest the two men is a sticking point in its attempts to join the European Union.

title: Bhutan Grants Access to Temples
description: The Himalayan kingdom Bhutan has granted British art experts rare access to the countrys roughly 2,000 Buddhist temples and monasteries in an effort to preserve wall paintings from the 16th through 19th centuries, The Observer of London reported. The research project, a joint effort between the Courtauld Institute of Art in London and the Bhutan Culture Department, was financed by an anonymous United States donor. The experts have finished their fieldwork and analysis, and they will publish a report. Bhutans art is largely restricted to veneration within the temples and monasteries, so it is little known in the West and hard to gain access to even inside Bhutan. In 2008 the government allowed some sacred artworks to leave for an exhibition organized by the Honolulu Academy of Arts on the condition that they be chaperoned by Bhutanese monks, who performed daily rituals to safeguard the works spiritual well-being.

title: Nashville Music Hall Reopens After Flood
description: The Schermerhorn Symphony Center in Nashville, above, which was badly damaged in a flood in May, reopened on Friday evening with a concert featuring the violinist Itzhak Perlman, The Tennessean reported. The center, completed in 2006 and the home of the Nashville Symphony Orchestra, required $40 million worth of repairs after the flood filled the basement and subbasement. Most of the cost is expected to be covered by insurance and by financing from the Federal Emergency Management Agency, according to Reuters. The rest is to be made up through a fund-raising campaign. In an acknowledgment of the flood the concert included Strausss Thunder and Lightning Polka; the music director, Giancarlo Guerrero, said he had picked it over Handels Water Music.

title: Disney Tests Broadway Ticket Flexibility
description: Beginning with performances this week the Broadway productions of The Lion King and Mary Poppins will allow ticket holders to exchange seats for other dates through March 10 for any reason, without penalty, as many times as needed. Disney Theatrical Productions announced its worry-free winter 2011 exchange policy for the two musicals as an experiment to allow greater flexibility at the box office. Policies for Broadway plays and musicals vary for those who want to exchange tickets for another date; this pilot program is meant to help Disney evaluate how many theatergoers might use and appreciate such a policy as well as to offer peace of mind for those worried about making their shows when, say, a blizzard looms. People have busy lives and need more flexibility when the unexpected happens and plans change, David Schrader, executive vice president of Disney Theatrical Productions, said in a statement. We recognize the time is right to reduce restrictions and put more power in the hands of the customer. Customers who exchange tickets would not be able to receive a full or partial refund if a refund were offered for a specific performance. The policy covers a traditionally slow-selling stretch for many shows and comes during a time when tickets are relatively available for Mary Poppins and to some extent for The Lion King, which is the bigger hit.

title: Dick Clark Wins on New Years Eve
description: ABC announced that about 9.1 million people tuned in between 10 and 11 p.m. on Friday to watch Dick Clarks Primetime New Years Rockin Eve With Ryan Seacrest, allowing the program to beat NBCs New Years Eve With Carson Daly and handing ABC an overall ratings victory for the evening. Dick Clark, 81, began hosting the program in 1972. He had a stroke in 2004 that affected his speech, and most of the M.C. duties are now handled by his co-host, Ryan Seacrest (above left, with Mr. Clark). Mr. Clark, however, still does his signature countdown to the ball drop in Times Square. The broadcast drew its biggest audience in three years and attracted 1.2 million more viewers than the last time New Years Eve fell on a Friday night, in 2004.

title: Monday: The Song Remains the Same
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Greetings and happy new year! I hope everyone has recovered sufficiently from the holiday seasons festivities and Mr. Happy Pencil cocktail toasts.

title: An Album and Its Buzz
description: Welcome to 2011, a year that  once the last of the snow is scraped away  will bring new hope, the promise of renewal, a chance to wake up in a world in which Kanye Wests My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy is not the consensus pick for album of the year.

title: With Murky Details, Defendant in 1978 Newark Murders Builds a Case
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J.  Lee Evans sat with his broad back to the wall of a mostly empty diner and picked at his Spanish omelet and grits on a December afternoon, his face only once breaking into a grin, to greet an acquaintance in workers overalls. The man smiled back, something Mr. Evans can no longer take for granted, despite having lived most of his 57 years in and around Newark, a plumber on call day and night.

title: 9/11 Health Bill Signed Into Law by Obama
description: President Obama took time out of his Hawaiian vacation on Sunday to sign into law one of the surprise accomplishments of the lame-duck Congress: a measure covering the cost of medical care for rescue workers and others sickened by toxic fumes and dust after the 2001 terrorist attack on the World Trade Center. title: Japan Keeps a High Wall for Foreign Labor
description: KASHIWA, Japan  Maria Fransiska, a young, hard-working nurse from Indonesia, is just the kind of worker Japan would seem to need to replenish its aging work force.

title: A Bronx Elementary School, Surrounded by Prostitutes
description: When Nicole Murrays 10-year-old daughter, Diamond, first started going to West Farms elementary school three years ago, she asked her mother why one woman they passed was barely dressed.

title: 3-D Wrinkle for Portable Gaming
description: Keys, wallet, cellphone ... game machine?

title: Car Licenses in Demand in Beijing
description: Residents in Beijing rushed to apply for new vehicle licenses under a quota system started Jan. 1 as Chinas government seeks to ease traffic congestion.

title: Packers Claim a Wild-Card Berth
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  The Chicago Bears and the Green Bay Packers have been battling each other since 1921, making them the N.F.L.s oldest rivals. Their competition is usually fierce and unfriendly, and Sundays 181st meeting will go down as one of the most memorable in this remarkable rivalry.

title: Babylon: Ancient Site, Modern Problems
description: Antiquities officials and restoration experts face the difficult task of halting the ravages of man and nature before restoring ancient monuments.

title: Jets Replay: Jan. 2
description: Despite several starters being listed as inactive, the Jets routed the Buffalo Bills, 38-7.

title: Both Hero and Traitor, but No Longer on the Map
description: TREMBLOIS-LS-CARIGNAN, France  The municipal council here on the edge of the Ardennes Forest recently voted to change a third of the villages street names.

title: Giants Win but Dont Get Help They Need

title: Peaceful Vote on Sudan Appears More Likely
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton has called the situation a ticking time bomb.

title: War in the Cabinet

description: ORLANDO, Fla.  He has zero faith in the incoming speaker of the House, John A. Boehner, whom he calls a tool of special interest.

title: Outlawed, Cellphones Are Thriving in Prisons
description: ATLANTA  A counterfeiter at a Georgia state prison ticks off the remaining days of his three-year sentence on his Facebook page. He has 91 digital friends. Like many of his fellow inmates, he plays the online games FarmVille and Street Wars.

title: A Triage to Save the Ruins of Babylon
description: JIMIJMA, Iraq  The damage done to the ruins of ancient Babylon is visible from a small hilltop near the Tower of Babel, whose biblical importance is hard to envision from what is left of it today.

title: Cuomos Twitter Feed? Somethings a Little Off
description: ALBANY  Consider it a lesson for newly inaugurated politicians in the digital age.

title: A Tour of Iraqs Ancient Sites
description: The war has long put Iraqs ancient historic and religious sites off limits to all but the most daring of scholars, archeologists, tourists and ordinary Iraqis. Slowly, if unevenly, that may be changing.

title: Columbia Pictures Hopes to End Oscar Drought
description: LOS ANGELES  Remember 1988?

title: Worries Follow Route of High-Speed California Line
description: MADERA, Calif.  The area just south of this agricultural city is not much to look at: miles of farmland, a collection of dingy fast food outlets and a gold rush ghost called Borden, where all that remains is a tiny cemetery devoted to long dead Chinese workers.

title: Jets Ryan Regains Bluster and Reaches Crossroads
description: East Rutherford, N.J.

title: After Two Slow Years, an Industry Rebound Begins
description: WHEN Stephen Colbert wanted to raise money for the recovery efforts after the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, he worked with a behemoth technology company, Microsoft. Every time Mr. Colbert said the word Bing on the Colbert Report, the company donated $2,500 to the Colbert Nation Gulf of America Fund.

title: Maryland Picks Edsall to Rebuild
description: Marylands athletic department faced an intriguing choice as its coaching searched narrowed. The two primary candidates, Connecticut Coach Randy Edsall and the former Texas Tech coach Mike Leach, presented starkly different possibilities.

title: The Cuomo Team
description: After winning the election in November, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo vowed to recruit the best and brightest talent to his administration. In the end, Mr. Cuomo decided he did not need to look very far. In announcing key appointments, he leaned mostly on familiarity: Many of Mr. Cuomos top aides in the attorney generals office will be part of his central staff. Experience in law enforcement is another theme. His secretary, counsel, chief of staff and special assistant are all former federal prosecutors. Here are many of the top officials whose selection Mr. Cuomo has already announced, some of whom require Senate confirmation. Some key positions, including budget director, have not yet been filled.

title: China Quietly Extends Footprints Into Central Asia
description: MURGHAB, Tajikistan  On the outskirts of this wind-scoured town, founded in 1893 as a Russian military post, the construction of a new customs compound heralds the return of another major power.

title: TV Viewing Continues to Edge Up
description: Historians may someday note with wonder that by the end of 2010, at least six cable television shows were about auctioneers and pawnbrokers. And all were considered successes by their respective channels.

title: When Movies Meet the Law
description: Attorneys in an environmental case against oil giant Chevron in Ecuador invited a respected documentary filmmaker to tell their story.  The unused film clips have been used against them in courts.

title: Szeto Wah, Political Activist in Hong Kong, Dies at 79
description: HONG KONG  Szeto Wah, a Hong Kong union leader and critic of British colonial rule who became an implacable critic of the Chinese Communist Party after the Tiananmen Square killings in 1989, died on Sunday after a long struggle with lung cancer. He was 79.

title: Giants, Despite Falling, Stand for Right Things
description: LANDOVER, Md.

title: Record Year for Brady and the Patriots
description: Drew Brees and Tom Brady each threw a touchdown pass Sunday, making them the sixth and seventh quarterbacks to have at least one in every game since the N.F.L. went to a 16-game schedule. Chase Stuart wrote about this last week.

title: Sports Replay: Jan. 2
description: A look at the Alpine Skiing World Cup, a tennis exhibition on the water and more.

title: Scenes Cut From Film Find New Role in Court
description: The film clips look like evidence from a sting operation: in one, a lawyer plans a huge protest at a courthouse because the judges make decisions based on who they fear the most.

title: Bowl Ratings Down, but High for Cable
description: For ESPN, the decision to show all of the Bowl Championship Series games began to pay off when Texas Christians 21-19 victory over Wisconsin in the Rose Bowl on Saturday generated an 11.7 preliminary overnight Nielsen rating. Although the games rating was the highest for any program on cable except for N.F.L. games since 2001, it fell from what it had been on ABC. The ratings on ABC were a 13.8 last year, a 12.6 in 2009 and a 12.1 in 2008.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: A Modest Proposal for the Next Winter Classic
description: ERIE, Pa.  Im en route from Pittsburgh to Buffalo where Ill be picking up the semifinals and final of the World Junior Championship, and by en route I mean sitting in a Greyhound bus as it rolls along the southeast shore of Lake Erie. Luxurious? Perhaps not, but it gives me the chance to reflect on Saturday nights Winter Classic.

title: For Critics of Lees Contract, Brown Deal Is Not Supporting Evidence
description: As the dollars and years mounted in the offers to Cliff Lee this off-season, many pessimistic observers invoked the specter of the games most infamous pitching contract: the seven-year, $105 million deal signed in 1998 by the surly sinkerballer Kevin Brown. His name has become synonymous with free-agent excess, and serves as a cautionary tale for any general manager contemplating a long-term contract with a pitcher.

title: The Great Mashup of 2011
description: For years, those of us who toiled in the backwater of media reporting  covering people who cover other people  were left to trace the slow-motion decline of mainstream media and the inconsequential pratfalls of nascent digital efforts.

title: Cuomo Plans One-Year Freeze on State Workers Pay
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo will seek a one-year salary freeze for state workers as part of an emergency financial plan he will lay out in his State of the State address on Wednesday, senior administration officials said.

title: Chewing Gum for Terrorists
description: Washington

title: New Rules Impose Systems for Sharing of Tips
description: Rosemarie Ingleton left a $110.40 tip on a $552 check at Indochine on Wednesday night, after making an ineffable calculation based on ambiance, food and, of course, service. But she did not give a lot of thought to how it would be distributed among the staff.

title: Critic of Steele Drops Bid to Replace Him

description: The new Senate will face one of its most momentous decisions in its opening hours on Wednesday: a vote on whether to change its rules to prohibit the widespread abuse of the filibuster. Americans are fed up with Washington gridlock. The Senate should seize the opportunity.

description: If theres one piece of economic wisdom I hope people will grasp this year, its this: Even though we may finally have stopped digging, were still near the bottom of a very deep hole.

title: The Unborn Paradox
description: The American entertainment industry has never been comfortable with the act of abortion. Film or television characters might consider the procedure, but even on the most libertine programs (a Mad Men, a Sex and the City), theyre more likely to have a change of heart than actually go through with it. Reality TV thrives on shocking scenes and subjects  extreme pregnancies and surgeries, suburban polygamists and the gay housewives of New York  but abortion remains a little too controversial, and a little bit too real.

title: Buy These Stamps, and Forget About Rate Increases
description: About 70 new stamp designs that the United States Postal Service plans to issue this year will commemorate familiar themes and subjects: famous people, historic events, Americas cultural heritage and holidays. But in a twist, nearly every new first-class stamp will bear the word Forever in place of a monetary denomination, and will remain valid regardless of any price increases.

A study to be published in the Journal of Consumer Research, conducted by Sara Kim and Professor Ann L. McGill of the University of Chicago, pursues this inquiry into the murky crossroads of risk and societal status.

title: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week

description: The videos resemble something a college fraternity could have put together as a joke and posted on YouTube. There are scenes showing women showering together, frequent sexual references and a number of antigay slurs and vulgarities.

title: Janine Pommy Vega, Restless Poet, Dies at 68

She was 68.

title: In Berlin, One Artists Unusual Vision for Living
description: The Israeli artist Absalon died in Paris in 1993 at age 28. But before his untimely death, he produced a large body of work, including six tiny all-white dwellings that he wanted to install in downtown Tokyo, Paris, Zurich, New York, Tel Aviv and Frankfurt. The artist designed these Cellules (cells), as he called them, to fit his precise dimensions in a totally scaled-down living environment so that he would, in his own words, be obliged to live my ideas. Now, the KW Institute for Contemporary Art (Auguststrasse 69; 49-30-243-4590; www.kw-berlin.de) has brought together all six cells under one roof.

title: Fiat Shares Rise After Company Splits
description: Fiat Industrial and the Fiat auto business both gained on Monday in their first day of trading as separate entities, a corporate split that could lead to greater integration with the Chrysler Group, David Jolly reports in The New York Times.

description: Andy Barall, who writes about pro football history for the Fifth Down, wrote this comment on the Coughlin or Cowher? thread.  He wrote it before the Giants won their 10th game and before John Mara said Tom Coughlin was still the guy that we want. Ive updated some numbers after Sundays game. TM

title: The Temporary Vegetarian: A Portuguese Empada
description: Luisa Fernandes, 56, consulting chef at the Best Chocolate Cake in the World in Brooklyn, and executive chef at Nomad in Manhattan, makes a savory empada  a Portuguese stuffed pastry  that is similar to a ratatouille wrapped in puff pastry. She sauts eggplant, tomatoes, squash, onions and garlic, and once the vegetables are cooled, she tucks them into puff pastry in muffin tins, and bakes them until they are golden. Its a very old Portuguese recipe thats served for lunch with a salad, said Ms. Fernandes, who makes it for the Best Chocolate Cake in the World.

title: Best Political Quotes of the Weekend
description: Happy New Year. You may have been a bit too bleary-eyed from New Years Eve reveling to catch the best political commentary of the weekend, but we at The Caucus werent. Heres a quick roundup.

title: Morning Buzz | Cuomo Forecast Calls for Pay Freeze
description: Good morning. Its back to chilly today, with a high of only 35 and a decent chance of residential trash pickup. Alternate side parking remains suspended for the 10th day in a row. Is that some kind of modern record? Here is the news.

description: The 112th Congress convenes on Wednesday. Republicans who took control of the House of Representatives in the midterm election are shortly expected to introduce a measure to repeal and replace the health care legislation passed in March.

title: A Planetary Simulator That Averts Crises
description: Technological advances over the next decade could pave the way for the realization of one of the most staggeringly complex computer projects ever conceived: a planetary simulator with the ability to simultaneously model everything from the spread of infectious diseases to the behavior of financial markets, a European scientific group developing the idea suggests.

description: By defeating the St. Louis Rams Sunday night, the Seattle Seahawks qualified for the N.F.L. playoffs in spite of having lost nine games and won only seven.

description: Stocks in the United States got 2011 off to an energetic start on Monday as financial shares rose and new data suggested a better outlook for the economy.
