title: A Pop-Up Will Hold the Space While Cabritos Replacement Awaits
description: While they wait to begin renovating the recently closed Cabrito into what it will be next, Zakary Pelaccio and Rick Camac will use the space for a pop-up bar and restaurant called Fatty Johnsons.

title: Ceci Nest Pas un Birkin
description: Spring is shaping up to be the season of the basic Parisian shopper. And of all the lo-fi carryalls about to hit stores, were partial to the Together Bag from Thursday Friday, a screen-printed tote featuring a likeness of Hermss iconic Birkin bag. Roni Brunn and Olena Sholomytska, the duo behind Thursday Friday, were looking to create a bag that could be used for everything, including the groceries, when inspiration hit. We realized that we were using an extra bag to supplement our real bags, Sholomytskasays. So we ended up with a surreal design that references luxury but is ultimately an anti-status status symbol. And the Birkin references dont stop there: in a fittingly bizarre twist, there is already a three-month waiting list.

title: Diplomacy Again Falls Short in Tense Ivory Coast Standoff
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  African leaders came to this West African nation for the second time in less than a week, pressing Laurent Gbagbo to cede power after losing an election in November and hoping to settle a political crisis that threatens to reignite civil war.

title: The Caregivers Bookshelf: The Goodbye Grows Longer
description: Forty years ago, when Elisabeth Kbler-Ross published her landmark book On Death and Dying, losing a family member was typically a swifter and more sudden event. Often people literally dropped dead with heart attacks. Todays families usually confront a different reality.

title: Vain Glorious | Black Soap
description: Aside from a good straight-razor shave, grooming doesnt offer a man many indulgences. But theres one simple luxury that should be in every dopp kit: a great bar of soap. The latest specimens to catch my eye are black  they smell of earth and ash and their color gives them a primal ruggedness, as if youre back in the cave, washing yourself with mud. They dont, counterintuitively, lather black. The way this nonchemist understands the science is that the particles in these bars arent actually black but completely opaque, and when theyre compressed into soap, no light gets in. No light equals black. But never mind all that. Lets suds them up.

title: Monday Reading: More Forever Stamps
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

description: Still on the Road, a new film by Sara Wolkowitz, documents several months in the lives of the Acting Company, a theater troupe that travels around the United States teaching and performing classical works in communities where theater is a luxury, if its around at all. Ms. Wolkowitz will introduce her debut feature film, which she directed, edited and produced, when it is screened Monday night by the Film Society of Lincoln Center.

description: BAGHDAD  Two members of the United States military were killed Sunday night in central Iraq, the first such deaths here this year at a time when American casualties had become a rarity.

title: What Were Reading
description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.

title: N.F.L. Makes Case on Labor Talks to Fans
description: With the regular season over and the clock ticking on the expiring collective bargaining agreement, the N.F.L. sent an e-mail message directly to fans Monday morning, laying out managements position in the labor talks. The message, sent to about 5 million fans  and also distributed to teams so they can distribute it  mentions proposals for the 18-game season (and cutbacks in off-season workout programs that would accompany it) and for a rookie wage scale.

title: India Examines Possible Tax Evasion in Kraft Takeover of Cadbury
description: 6:32 p.m. | Updated

title: 400 Artworks by Women Are Donated to the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts
description: Believing that women are underrepresented on the walls of most art museums, Linda Lee Alter, a Philadelphia collector and artist, donated some 400 works by artists including Louise Bourgeois, Kiki Smith, Alice Neel, Nancy Spero and Louise Nevelson to the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts.

title: More on the Twiblings
description: Fourteen years ago, when I first wrote on the subject of egg donation for The New York Times Magazine, I visited a woman who was one of the first brokers in the country to match donors and prospective parents. We sat in her sunny California garden (all new things start in L.A.) and paged through books of donor profiles  complete with their health histories, lists of likes and dislikes and smiling photos of themselves and, often, their children.

title: Seahawks Are Playoffs Inglorious Underdog
description: Bill Parcells used to dismiss the excuses and analysis and sum up the entire N.F.L. with a simple, biting adage: you are what your record says you are.

title: Moviegoers Do the Documentary Side-Step
description: What was the most popular documentary of 2010? Jackass 3D.

title: Resolved: Laurence Kotlikoff, Economist
description: This week on the Bucks blog, our contributors, along with some of our favorite sources, are writing about their new years financial resolutions. Here, Laurence J. Kotlikoff, an economics professor at Boston University, shares his own plans. He is also president of Economic Security Planning, which provides financial planning software.

title: Monday Morning Skate: Kanes Surprise, Winter Classic to Stay in Daylight, Lightning Upgrade in Goal
description: Atlantas Kane Takes a Seat, Scores

title: Mayo Learns to Adjust in Memphis
description: O.J. Mayo says he has learned a valuable life lesson: sometimes, you have to accept change and find a way to thrive under new circumstances.

title: Before Move-In Day, Evicting the Old Auras
description: Ziporah Reich sat cross-legged on her living room floor. As Judith Wendell chanted and burned incense that seeped into every crevice of the apartment, Ms. Reich meditated over an altar that included bowls of water with candles and wildflowers and a stack of brightly colored papers on which she wrote her wishes: finding her soul mate, starting a family and having more success in her career.

title: Lennons Abbey Road Suit Sold at Auction
description: The crisp white two-piece suit that John Lennon wore on the cover of the 1969 Beatles record album Abbey Road sold at a Connecticut auction on New Years Day for $46,000.

title: Tell Us Your Good Luck Rituals
description: When people move into new homes, they carry plenty of hopes and expectations with them. Is this the apartment where I am going to find true love? Is this the apartment where we are going to start a family?

title: In Japan, Pfizer Is Short of Drug to Help Smokers
description: TOKYO  When the Japanese government raised the tax on cigarettes on Oct. 1, it could have started a public health revolution in this land of heavy smokers.

title: My Resolution: The 24-Burger Strategy
description: Its the season for resolutions  a time to take stock of the recent past and set goals for the coming year. As my husband and I strive to position our small-business brokerage firm as the best in class in our region, we continually try to draw on lessons learned from other professional service providers: law firms, accounting practices and wealth planners, to name a few. Next year, however, we will be looking to a rather unlikely source for business inspiration: a pub.

title: Elisabete Matos to Replace Deborah Voigt at the Metropolitan Opera Tonight
description: The Portuguese soprano Elisabete Matos will replace Deborah Voigt as Minnie, the fearless, gun-toting saloon owner in Puccinis Fanciulla del West, at the Metropolitan Opera on Monday night. Ms. Voigt, who is ill, has starred in the role since the production opened early last month.

title: The Jobs They Are A-Changin
description: A large fraction of displaced workers who have found new jobs have had to switch careers, and most of those career-changers have downgraded to a lower-paying job, according to a new report from Rutgerss Heldrich Center for Workforce Development.

title: Pinewood Derbies Grow Up
description: At Cub Scouts Pinewood Derbies, there are always small jalopies hacked together by earnest children and their tool-challenged parents, the misshapen wooden blocks scraping slowly down an angled plastic track and, perhaps, across a finish line. These builders cheer and laugh, proud of making and racing their cars together as teammates.

title: Poparazzi | Neography Lesson
description: How do you get to Carnegie Hall, goes the vintage joke about a tourist asking for directions in Manhattan. The answer, as you probably know, is: Practice, practice, practice!

title: Lady Gaga Announces Release Date of New Album
description: Ever the provocateur, Lady Gaga posted a picture of herself on her Web site, dancing with her blonde hair flying in the wind and wearing nothing but a Born This Way jacket. The image follows her first Twitter posting of 2011 in which she announced that her new single, Born This Way, will be available in stores on Feb. 13 and that the album of the same name will be for sale on May 23.

title: The Art of the Very Long Sentence
description: In a recent essay for the Book Review, I wrote about the art of the very long sentence, from Molly Blooms soliloquy to several whoppers that stretch the length of an entire novel without ever coming to a full stop.

title: The Art of the Very Long Sentence
description: In a recent essay for the Book Review, I wrote about the art of the very long sentence, from Molly Blooms soliloquy to several whoppers that stretch the length of an entire novel without ever coming to a full stop.

title: Putting a Price Tag on Facebook
description: As DealBook reported, the popular social networking site Facebook has raised $500 million from Goldman Sachs and a Russian investment firm, Digital Sky Technologies.

title: Former Congressman Patrick Murphy Joins Fox Rothschild
description: Patrick J. Murphy, a former congressman of Pennsylvania, has joined Fox Rothschild as a partner in the firms litigation practice group.

title: Putting a Price Tag on Facebook
description: DealBooks Andrew Ross Sorkin and Evelyn M. Rusli discuss Facebooks valuation after the social networking site raised $500 million from Goldman Sachs and a Russian investor.

title: John Roberts Leaves CNN for Fox News
description: John Roberts, recently removed from his post as the co-anchor for CNNs American Morning program, has found a new cable news home at the Fox News Channel.

title: Ill Never Ration. Not Me. Not I.
description: Opposition to health-care rationing is a little like opposition to growing up. It sounds great. Its just not very practical.

title: The Case for Morris: Big Moments Count
description: Most Baseball Hall of Fame voters think Jack Morris deserves a plaque in Cooperstown. That is not enough to get Morris into the Hall of Fame  he had 52 percent of the vote last year, and candidates need 75  but it is significant. And it infuriates a lot of people.

title: Sports Replay: Jan. 4
description: A view of the day in sports, with big jumps, packs of skiers and a return to soccer.

title: 2 Yoga Masters to Lead New York Workshops
description: For two yoga masters trained in the Himalayas, the path toward world peace leads straight through New York.

title: For Seafood on a Budget, Just Add Pasta
description: While researching the cooking of Sicily some years ago, I spent an afternoon with a chef who had a small restaurant in Palermo, where I watched him take a single piece of tuna and turn it into a pasta sauce that fed four of us. Mediterranean cooks, I knew, have a knack for making meals from small amounts of animal protein. Italians often accomplish this by combining pasta and seafood.

title: Oscar-Worthy Performances, for Your Consideration
description: Rounding out the Baggers day of things you may have missed in The New York Times  give us a break, were probably suffering from social jet lag  is the awards season best-ofs from our colleagues. A. O. Scott praises Natalie Portman in Black Swan, for participating in the invention of a new kind of screen performance. As Nina, the unraveling ballerina, she inverts Method acting to tell a story about the artistic interplay of instinct and technique  which is, at its heart, what the movie is about. Manohla Dargis writes that in one minute of screen time, Christian Bale summons his characters entire life in The Fighter. Stephen Holden calls Colin Firths performance as a stammering monarch in The Kings Speech a tour de force of body language concentrated on the eyes and mouth. And Larry Rohter takes stock of the humbleness of Javier Bardem in Biutiful. Theres all that and more, including the critics lists of those they think should be nominated. Worth catching up while we recover/wrangle some outside material.

title: Judges Set to Rule on Afghan Election Complaints Within 2 Weeks
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A five-judge panel set up last week by Afghanistans Supreme Court said Monday that it would issue rulings within two weeks on hundreds of complaints of election abuse in Septembers national vote, in time for President Hamid Karzai to keep his promise to seat a new Parliament by Jan. 20.

title: Obama in Oahu: Semper Fit
description: HONOLULU  If President Obama has been consistent about one thing during his Hawaiian vacation, it has been his daily morning workout at the Marine Corps Base Hawaii here. His first one took place on Dec. 24, eight hours after he landed on the island of Oahu.

title: Job Clinging and Slackoisie
description: [1] Holding on to a job rather than retiring or moving elsewhere. [2] Young workers who view employment as an entitlement, while complaining about hours and remuneration.Writing for Forbes, Victoria Pynchon spotlighted two terms associated with Generation Y and boomer workers:

title: Conservative Seeks Balance on His Way to Senate
description: ZIONSVILLE, Pa.  Patrick J. Toomey was elected to the Senate in November as part of the Republican revolution, with a big assist from Tea Party activists, an endorsement from Sarah Palin and the expectation that he would join with other antiestablishment conservatives to remake Washington. But as he prepared to take office this week, Mr. Toomey hardly sounded like a partisan rabble-rouser.

title: Siemens Invests in Expanding Wind Power
description: FRANKFURT  A reader of the annual report of Siemens, the German engineering giant, could easily get the idea that the company was investing in wind energy because management wants to save the planet.

title: President Bids Soviet Leaders Visit U.S., Accept TV Exchange; Outlines 'Great Society' Plan
description: Washington, Jan. 4. -- President Johnson expressed the hope tonight that the new leaders of the Soviet Union could visit the United States and that they and American leaders could exchange television appearances in their respective countries.

title: Dirksen Dead in Capital at 73
description: It was Sept. 11, 1963. The Senate floor was unusually filled, the galleries crowded, for Everett McKinley Dirksen was about to speak on the nuclear test-ban treaty.

title: American Juniors Try to Repeat Defeat of Canada
description: BUFFALO  Its going to feel like last years Olympic final again, another hockey showdown in a growing series of them between the United States and Canada, when their two junior teams clash tonight at HSBC Arena in the semifinal of the world junior tournament.

title: Stanislavsky Dies in Moscow At 75
description: Moscow, Aug. 7 -- Constantin Sergeivitch Stanislavsky, one of the greatest masters of Russian drama and a founder of the Moscow Art Theatre, died here today of a heart ailment.

title: [Ford] Gives $10,000,000 To 26,000 Employees
description: Detroit, Mich., Jan. 5. -- Henry Ford, head of the Ford Motor Company, announced today one of the most remarkable business moves of his entire remarkable career. In brief it is:

title: Steele Debates Four Challengers for R.N.C. Leadership
description: As he battles to retain his position as chairman of the Republican National Committee, Michael Steele on Monday defended his rocky two-year tenure while his rivals decried the party apparatus as broke and lacking credibility with its donors and its conservative base.

title: First Victim of Cuomos Salary Ax: Himself
description: Salary cuts for state employees will begin at the top, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Monday.

title: Rayburn Is Dead; Served 17 Years As House Speaker
description: Bonham, Tex., Nov. 16 -- House Speaker Sam Rayburn died of cancer in his sleep today. He was 79 years old.

title:
Theodore Roosevelt Dies Suddenly at Oyster Bay Home; Nation Shocked, Pays Tribute to Former
President; Our Flag on All Seas and in All Lands at Half Mast
description: Oyster Bay, L.I., Jan. 6. -- Theodore Roosevelt, former President of the United States, died this morning between 4 and 4:15 o'clock while asleep in his bed at his home on Sagamore Hill, in this place.

title: Rev the Scientific Engine. Great. How?
description: As Republicans take control of the House, as stasists on energy and climate policy look forward to at least a couple of years in which they will probably get their way, Id like to raise a question or two.

title: Patterns: When a Bumper Crop Led to a Baby Bulge
description: Ministers of the Lutheran Church in 18th-century Finland kept careful records of births, deaths and marriages so they could efficiently tax their congregants, but 21st-century biologists are using the data for quite a different purpose.

title: Behavior: Distracted Eating Adds More to Waistlines
description: Catching up with e-mail while you eat lunch? Watching television? You may end the day eating more than you think.

title: After Apple Says Otherwise, iPhone Alarm Still Remains Silent
description: If you use your iPhone as an alarm clock, it might be time for a backup plan.

title: Diet: Fried Fish Is Seen as a Stroke Belt Culprit
description: A wide swath of the South has long been known as the stroke belt because it has higher rates of stroke and other cardiovascular illnesses than the rest of the country. Now researchers are suggesting one culprit: fried fish.

title: Murder Charge in Swimsuit Designers Death
description: Nicholas Brooks, the boyfriend of the swimsuit designer whose body was found in a bathtub in the fashionable Soho House hotel in Manhattan last month, has been indicted on second-degree murder charges, according to court papers.

title: Connecting the Dots: Interpreting U.S. Census Data
description: Overview | How can census data provide insights into ones community and state, as well as the nation? What are the implications of the population data provided by the census? In this lesson, students examine maps that represent census data, from the present to the past 100 years, on levels from national to state to street, then generate and find answers to related research questions. They can also design and conduct an ethnography study in their community to gain insight into the real people behind the statistics.

title: Mel Gibsons Ex-Girlfriend  to Keep Her Lawyer
description: LOS ANGELES  I am now an attorney of record in the case. So said Martin Garbus, in a brief phone conversation after a closed-door hearing Monday in the child custody dispute between Mel Gibson and his former girlfriend, Oksana Grigorieva. Mr. Gibsons lawyers had opposed a request by Mr. Garbus, who is from New York, to be allowed to represent Ms. Grigorieva in the Los Angeles County Superior Court case. They cited, among other things, his public remarks about the dispute during a November interview on one of Larry Kings final televised interview shows for CNN. On the program, Ms. Grigorieva described how she had recorded Mr. Gibsons obscene rants to her because she feared he might kill her. Mr. Garbus, who appeared with her on the program, had said that Mr. Gibson did not want to pay any support for his daughter with Ms. Grigorieva.

title: Bank of America Buys Back $2.5 Billion in Mortgage Debt
description: 7:31 p.m. | Updated

title: Facebooks London Back Door
description: 5:23 p.m. | Updated You want to invest in Facebook, but youre not a high net-worth client of Goldman Sachs. There is a way  sort of.

title: What Gift to Bring a Child?
description: A business trip can call up all sorts of emotions for the parent and the child left behind, starting with loss, guilt, anxiety and a feeling of liberation. But the parent bringing home a gift may raise different issues.

title: An Academy No-No Scuttles Buried Chances
description: Is it too early in the year for an Oscar scandal? No way!

title: Dunkel, a Brew Ideal for Long Debates
description: DUNKEL-STYLE beers are perhaps not the easiest to market to the American public. Even as American beer drinkers have learned to navigate a range of stylistic terms  stout, pilsner, hefeweizen, India pale ale and the rest  dunkel mystifies. Whats a dunkel? We might as well be talking about doughnuts.

title: The Claim: Taking a Walk Can Help Reduce Cravings
description: THE FACTS

title: Resolved: Eat Less, Lose Weight
description: If you, like millions of others seeking to lose weight, made a resolution to eat less in the coming year, a focused walk around the block may help you meet your goals.

title: Why Jack Morris Passes the Cooperstown Test
description: Orel Hershiser, at the end of the 1988 season, was as unhittable as any pitcher ever. He gave up a run in the fifth inning on Aug. 30, and by the time anyone scored off him again, he had thrown 67 consecutive scoreless innings and the Dodgers were in the playoffs. Hershiser kept rolling, winning the most valuable player award in both the National League Championship Series and the World Series. Just for fun, he mixed in a save and a three-hit game that October.

title: Missions Abroad, and Odd Moments, That Bring a Smile
description: IVE been flying around the world for the last 16 years to help provide free cleft surgery for children in developing countries.

title: Rare Ferrari FXX Evoluzione Is Coming to Auction
description: Among the richest collections of contemporary Italian super cars ever offered will hit the auction dais this month, and its biggest prize could fetch $2.5 million.

title: Gay or Straight, Youths Arent So Different
description: This fall, when an 18-year-old Rutgers student killed himself after a live video showing him having intimate relations with another young man was transmitted on the Internet, public attention once again focused on the risk of suicide among gay teenagers.

title: Iran May Drop Stoning Sentence
description: TEHRAN  Iranian authorities could block the sentence of death by stoning handed down to an Iranian woman convicted of adultery, a senior judicial official said Sunday.

title: Naked Angels Names New Artistic Director
description: The New York theater company Naked Angels, which develops new plays and had its first production on Broadway last year with the drama Next Fall, announced on Monday that Andy Donald would succeed Geoffrey Nauffts as artistic director in July. Mr. Donald, a theater director and producer, has been associate artistic director of Naked Angels since April 2009. Mr. Nauffts, an actor, director, and long-time company member of Naked Angels, became artistic director in September 2007 but soon found himself celebrated as a writer for Next Fall, his first play. The Naked Angels production of Next Fall had a critically acclaimed run Off Broadway in 2009, then transferred to Broadway the next year. While receiving strong reviews there as well as Tony Award nominations, including for best play, the production was not a commercial success and ran for about five months. Mr. Nauffts said in a statement that he planned to continue to write and direct for Naked Angels, and advise on artistic matters as a board member. Mr. Donald, the founding artistic director of the Charlie B. Theater Company in Los Angeles, said in the statement that he looked forward to bringing new writers and others into the company. Among the companys offerings this season is the world premiere of the play A Long and Happy Life, by Bekah Brunstetter, and another world premiere, Outside People, by Zayd Dohrn.

title: For Arkansas Blackbirds, the New Year Never Came
description: Times Square had the ball drop, and Brasstown, N.C., had its descending possum. But no place had a New Years Eve as unusual, or freakishly disturbing, as Beebe, Ark.

title: TimesCast | January 3, 2011
description: Michael Steele, chairman of the Republican National Committee, debates for his job; Jerry Brown takes over as governor of California, again; and Facebook proves an I.P.O. is no longer the name of the game.

title: Facebook and the 500-Person Threshold
description: 9:59 a.m. | Updated Goldman Sachss investment in Facebook once again raises the issue of whether the Securities and Exchange Commission will force the social networking company into an initial public offering. In particular, this issue arises because of the special purpose vehicle that Goldman plans to create in order to allow its clients to invest up to $1.5 billion in Facebook.

title: Brown Returns as California Governor, Facing Some Familiar Challenges
description: SACRAMENTO  Jerry Brown began his return engagement as governor of California on Monday, using his inaugural address to call for an end to partisan battling that he said was paralyzing the state and to promise, in what is presumably the last chapter of his public life, to lead California out of one of the toughest budget crises of its history.

title: Penne With Arugula and Clams
description: This is an adaptation of another recipe that I learned from Clifford A. Wright. In Apulia, part of southeastern Italy, arugula is cooked like a green as well as eaten raw in salads.

title: Chief Says Fiat May Try to Add to Stake in Chrysler Before a Public Offering
description: Fiats chief executive, Sergio Marchionne, said Monday that it might seek to raise its stake in Chrysler Group to 51 percent before Chryslers initial public offering, which is planned for this year.

title: Linguine With Red Clam Sauce
description: A classic dish that has been popular in Italian-American restaurants for decades, this dish can be made with a light hand, as it is here.

title: Spaghetti With Mussels and Peas
description: When you think you have no vegetables in the house for dinner, remember those peas buried deep in your freezer. You can use them with mussels steamed in white wine, then tossed with pasta. The broth from the mussels makes a flavorful sauce for the spaghetti.

title: Fusilli With Swordfish or Tuna and Tomato Sauce
description: The sauce here is a sort of fish rag common throughout Sicily and Southern Italy. In summer, use fresh tomatoes, but you can make it now with canned.

title: Bradys Spectacular Season
description: Time to end the most valuable player conversation. Tom Brady finished the season with 36 touchdown passes and 4 interceptions, an astonishing 9.0 touchdown-to-interception ratio. That broke the previous record of 6.25, also set by Brady in 2007, when he threw 50 touchdowns and had eight interceptions. No other quarterback has ever topped a 6.0 ratio.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: A sampling of whats making the rounds in the deal-making ecosystem:

title: Broadway Enters 2011 With Big Ticket Sales
description: Broadway did smashing business during the week of the New Years holiday in spite of inconveniences related to the blizzard cleanup, with 16 musicals and one play (The Merchant of Venice) each drawing more than $1 million and contributing to a total take of $35 million, according to the Broadway League, the theater trade group that publishes weekly grosses every Monday. That $35 million represents a sizable increase over the $28.1 million for the comparable week in 2009.

title: Steeles Rivals Ratchet Up Criticism After Debate
description: Michael Steeles rivals offered even tougher criticism of the Republican National Committee chairman after Mondays five-way debate ended than they did during the 90-minute exchange.

title: The Classics as the Antidote to Modern Malaise
description: The philosopher Hubert Dreyfus and his former student Sean Dorrance Kelly have a story to tell, and it is not a pretty tale for us moderns. Ours is an age of nihilism, they say, meaning not so much that we have nothing in which to believe, but that we dont know how to choose among the various things to which we might commit ourselves. Looking down from their perches at Berkeley and Harvard, they see the human indecision that plagues us all. In All Things Shining they offer readings of classic texts to show both how we got into this mess and how we can overcome it.

title: When Frugality Crosses the Line
description: One way my husband and I save a little money is to use the shampoo, conditioner and other products weve collected from hotel stays.

title: Obama Likely to Face Fight Over Cost of Food Safety Bill
description: HONOLULU  President Obama, who wraps up his 11-day Hawaiian escape Monday night and returns to Washington on Tuesday, will sign a far-reaching overhaul of the nations food safety system into law when he gets back to the White House. But he is likely to face a fight from budget-minded Republicans over the cost of the measure, estimated at $1.4 billion over five years.

title: Eureka! A Fossil Bone, and Water Ferns to Boot
description: Bonnie F. Jacobs, a paleobotanist at Southern Methodist University, writes from Ethiopia, where she is studying fossils of ancient plant and animal life. The current field season in the Mush Valley of Ethiopia is financed by a grant to Ellen Currano of Miami University, Ohio, from the National Geographic Society Committee on Research and Exploration.

title: Ending Federal Subsidies for Mortgages
description: Could the government stop subsidizing mortgages altogether? Probably not in real life. But that is where the debate over reforming Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, as well as righting the public-private sector balance in housing, should begin.

title: 'The Squid and the Whale'
description: A. O. Scott looks at Noah Baumbach's family drama set in Brooklyn in the 1980s.

title: The Specter of Minarchy
description: Since I wasnt blogging over the holidays, I missed the online dust-up over Chris Beams big essay on libertarianisms moment in the political sun. What earned Beam the most pushback from libertarians was probably the way he finished his piece: After briskly surveying libertarian thought, from Ayn Rand to Will Wilkinson, he concluded with an extended argument that libertarianism ventures down some fascinating paths but usually ends up deep in the wilderness. That wilderness, in his view, is the impossible dream of minarchy  a vision of government in which the state is responsible for a standing army, local security, and a courts system, and thats it which Beam dismissed with the following critique:

title: Rh Factor, 1944
description: The so-called Rh factor makes few headlines these days, but until the middle of the 20th century it was a serious public-health concern, implicated in the deaths and severe disabilities of 10,000 babies in this country every year.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Pakistan, Australia and Austria.

title: Turning the East Rivers Flow Into Electricity
description: An attempt to harness the mighty ebb and flow of the East River just got closer to fruition. A company hoping to build hundreds of electricity-generating turbines in the river announced Monday that it had filed for federal approval to build what it said would be the first tidal power plant in the United States, just off Roosevelt Island.

title: Save Your Confederate Money, Boys . . .
description: This year is the 150th anniversary of the beginning of the Civil War, in which the South won some early victories but lost in the end.

title: Quest for Dark Energy May Fade to Black
description: What happens to a dark energy dream deferred?

title: Apple Mobile Operating System Still Tops Google Android
description: Many thought this race would be determined by the end of 2010, but as we roll into 2011 themobile phone race is still too close to call.

title: Footnote
description: The Russian American Foundation and the Bolshoi Ballet Academy are holding auditions to fill two spots at the school for the summer. The winning dancers, one man, one woman, will be offered scholarships to train in Moscow for whats known as a summer intensive. The auditions will be held on Sunday at the American Musical and Dramatic Academy, 211 West 61st Street in Manhattan. More information can be found at russianamericanfoundation.org or (212) 687-6118.

title: Football Puts NBC on Top
description: The Seattle Seahawks victory over the St. Louis Rams propelled NBC to No. 1 in the ratings on Sunday. While final figures for Sunday Night Football were not expected until Tuesday, Nielsens overnight audience estimate was higher than for the equivalent game a year ago, which drew 16.3 million viewers. But the audience was smaller than the one for last weeks postponed broadcast of the game between the Minnesota Vikings and the Philadelphia Eagles, which drew 23.7 million viewers on Tuesday. CBS ranked second for the night with 60 Minutes at 7 p.m. (13.6 million) and new episodes of CSI: Miami (11.1 million) and Undercover Boss (11.8 million) at 8 and 9. Desperate Housewives lifted ABC into third place, with 12.1 million viewers at 9; the network drew more modest ratings for Extreme Makeover: Home Edition at 8 (9.3 million) and Brothers & Sisters at 10 (8 million). Fox was fourth with reruns of its comedy lineup.

title: A Record? Twelve Days of Parking Amnesty
description: Ladies and gentlemen, we think we have a modern-day record: the city announced this afternoon that alternate-side rules would be suspended Tuesday to facilitate snow removal, which will make 12 days in a row that cars have not had to be moved. The streak began Friday, Dec. 24, in honor of Christmas, which fell the next day.

title: Ahmadinejad Was Slapped by General, Leaked Cable Says
description: Last January, as Irans leadership struggled to contain postelection protests, nerves frayed to such an extent that the countrys president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, was slapped in the face by a military commander at one contentious meeting, according to a confidential Iranian source who spoke to an American diplomat in a neighboring country.

title: Another Release For Lindsay Lohan
description: Heres hoping that 2011 will be better for Lindsay Lohan, below. Ms. Lohan, the 24-year-old actress, was jailed twice last year and made two trips to rehabilitation centers stemming from a 2007 drunken-driving conviction. She was scheduled to be released on Monday from the Betty Ford Rehabilitation Center in Palm Springs, Calif. Today is the first day of the rest of my life, she wrote in a New Year message posted on Twitter. The future depends on what we do in the present.  Mahatma Gandhi ... One step at a time. Ms. Lohan remains under investigation over a report that she attacked a female staff member at the clinic. She must also satisfy a judge that she complied with her probation terms during her three-month stay at Betty Ford.

title: Hellos and Thank Yous at Family Reunion
description: Judith Jamison is leaving the post of artistic director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater with a smile and laughter. On Sunday night the company ended its annual season at City Center with a tribute to her that lasted over three hours. Well paced, it seemed shorter; but when Ms. Jamison came to the stage at the end, one of her first utterances, delivered in teasing tones of amazement, was simply to thank the audience for staying, and applauding, that long.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Pakistan, Australia and Austria.

title: Learning to Fly
description: Scientists at the University of Montana Flight Laboratory are obsessed with bridging the gap in flying abilities between birds and human beings.

title: Skins Will Arrive Soon on MTV, Baring All That It Can
description: In a downstairs recording studio in the West Village, Bryan Elsley, a co-creator of the British teenage comedy-drama Skins, was guiding James Newman, a star of the MTV remake of the show, through a typical line of dialogue.

title: Mocked as Uncool, the Minivan Rises Again
description: DETROIT  Could driving a minivan, the ultimate embodiment of the suburban family vehicle, ever be considered cool?

title: Flying Machines, Amazing at Any Angle
description: MISSOULA, Mont.  The flying abilities of even the most prosaic bird put airplane maneuvers to shame, and experts here at the University of Montana Flight Laboratory are cognizant of that every day.

title: Getting to Know Your Neighbors Below the Surface
description: Over the last 10 years, thousands of scientists, from dozens of countries, on hundreds of research voyages, have collaborated on an enormous research effort to catalog the plants and animals in the worlds oceans.

title: French Film Festival Offers Web Version
description: Cineastes wont have to leave their computers to see the work of emerging French filmmakers. UniFrance, a government-sponsored association of French Film industry professionals, in partnership with AlloCin, an online Paris film directory, have organized a new online event called My French Film Festival and are offering it around the world for two weeks starting Jan. 14. Featuring 10 full-length films and 10 shorts, all recently released in France by emerging directors, the festival will make them available individually or as a group. Visitors can go to myfrenchfilmfestival.com to stream a feature film for $2.60; a short for $1.30 or the entire slate for $18.40. The festival will be judged and voted on by the public, bloggers and critics, with the winner receiving a noncash award to be announced at the end of the festival, on Jan. 29.

title: Critics Picks Video: The Squid and the Whale
description: In this weeks Critics Pick, A. O. Scott revisits Noah Baumbachs 2005 drama The Squid and the Whale. Set in the 1980s and told from the point of view of the 16-year-old Walt Berkman (Jesse Eisenberg), the film explores how a boy is affected by his parents separation. Mr. Scott praises the films performances, including Jeff Daniels as Walts teacher/novelist father Bernard and Laura Linney as his mother Joan. Have you seen The Squid and the Whale? Please share your thoughts.

title: Under the Radar: Five Questions About Gob Squads Kitchen
description: Under the Radar, the Public Theaters annual festival of out-there performance from around the world, begins Wednesday for a 12-day run. (At $15 a ticket, its one of the best theater deals in town.) Over the course of the festival Erik Piepenburg will spotlight a few of the theater companies bringing their shows, many for the first time, to New York.

title: Under the Radar: Five Questions About Gob Squads Kitchen
description: Under the Radar, the Public Theaters annual festival of out-there performance from around the world, begins Wednesday for a 12-day run. (At $15 a ticket, its one of the best theater deals in town.) Over the course of the festival Erik Piepenburg will spotlight a few of the theater companies bringing their shows, many for the first time, to New York.

title: Goldman Learns You Cant Buy Friends On Facebook
description: Goldman Sachs may have found a new friend in Facebook, but the financial firm isnt finding much love from members of the social network.

title: Knicks Gallinari to Miss 2-3 Weeks
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Danilo Gallinari grimaced when Indianas Brandon Rush landed on his left knee Sunday, and the Knicks held their breath. That air was not fully exhaled Monday when a magnetic resonance imaging test revealed that Gallinari had mildly sprained his knee.

title: Searching for the Source of a Fountain of Courage
description: In his 20 years as a firefighter and paramedic in Colorado Springs, Bruce Monson, 43, has had his little fist-bumps with death: a burning roof collapsing on top of him, toxic fumes nearly suffocating him.

title: Patrick J. Toomey
description: BORN Nov. 17, 1961; Rhode Island; third of six children.

title: Murders Rise in New York City, but Remain Near Historic Lows
description: With the last homicide recorded on New Years Eve, the New York Police Department counted 532 murders in 2010  a 13 percent increase from 2009, when there were 471.

title: In a Crisis, Travel Agents Can Still Have an Edge
description: SO just about everybody is back home or at least moving smoothly on the road. The air travel system seems to have returned to what we now regard as normal after all the snow-related disruptions last week.

title: A Family Reunion at City Center
description: Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater honored Judith Jamison, outgoing artistic director.

title: Exhausted by Illness, and Doubts
description: Chronic fatigue syndrome causes a host of debilitating symptoms: profound exhaustion, disordered sleep, muscle and joint pain and severe cognitive problems, among others. But what causes the syndrome itself?

title: Struggling Borders to Meet With Publishers
description: The book chain Borders entered 2011 on an unsteady note, telling major publishers last week that it would delay payments owed to them, and stoking fears that it would not be able to recover from declining sales.

title: Japan Is on High Alert as a Virus Infiltrates Bird-Heavy Regions
description: Japanese bird sanctuaries, poultry farms and zoos went on high alert last month after several species of migratory birds in different regions were found dead of what appeared to be H5N1 avian influenza.

title: House to Vote Jan. 12 on Health-Care Repeal
description: Making good on a campaign promise, House Republicans will take a vote to repeal the Obama administrations health care on Jan. 12, the week after their party takes the reins of the House.

title: Democrats Plan Push to Curtail Use of Filibusters
description: WASHINGTON  A band of Senate Democrats signaled on Monday that it would press forward when Congress convenes this week with a proposal to curtail filibusters and other methods of slowing the chambers work, but a bit of procedural sleight-of-hand could delay any floor fight over the contentious rules changes until later in January.

title: On Road to Recovery, Past Adversity Provides a Map
description: Whatever else it holds, this new year is sure to produce a healthy serving of redemption stories, against-the-odds tales of people who bounced back from the layoffs, foreclosures and other wreckage of 2010. They landed better jobs. They started successful companies. They found time to write a book, to study animal husbandry, to learn a new trade: to generate just the sort of commentary about perseverance, self-respect and character that can tempt anyone whos still struggling to throw things at the TV.

title: Just Glad to Grab the Mike
description: JAMIE FOXX

title: This Vale of Tears
description: Q. Is it true that womens tears contain an enzyme that can be released only by crying, meaning they are quicker to cry under emotional stress?

title: Israel: Strike Delays Russian Visit
description: President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia has agreed to postpone a visit to Israel this month because of a strike by Israeli Foreign Ministry staff, a ministry spokesman said Monday. This is not directed against Medvedev or Russia, said the spokesman, Yigal Palmor. But since we are on strike, we are unable to prepare for the visit. It was decided by both sides to postpone it. Mr. Medvedev was supposed to come with a 500-strong delegation. Foreign Ministry workers are striking for more pay and better conditions. Israeli newspapers have carried reports about Israeli diplomats abroad who say they live in poverty and in some cases rely on financial support from their parents back home.

title: Already Tops on TVs, Vizio Eyes Tablets
description: Apples iPad controls the high end of the nascent tablet market, but Vizio seems to have its eyes on the lower end.

title: Imagining a New Skin Thats Able to Repel Ice
description: De-icing aircraft with chemicals is expensive, environmentally unfriendly and time-consuming, as stranded passengers during winter blizzards may be well aware.

title: Competitive Nature That Is Nurtured in Soil
description: Trees have way more roots than they need to capture nutrients from soil, says Ray Dybzinski, a plant ecologist at Princeton University. So what purpose do those extra roots serve?

title: Grasping Anothers Point of View at an Early Age
description: Infants as young as 7 months have the ability to perceive and understand another persons point of view, according to a new study in the journal Science.

title: A Winding Path to the Emergency Room
description: He was the first patient of the day, dropped off at the emergency room by the police or a family member  a man in his 50s, unshaved, stumbling, engulfed in the pungent aroma of alcohol.

title: Detecting Tuberculosis: No Microscopes, Just Rats
description: Researchers have found a new way of testing for tuberculosis that is fast, cheap and widely available: large rats that can smell the bacteria in a sputum sample.

title: Same as It Ever Was: No Word From Pettitte
description: Six weeks from Monday, the Yankees pitchers and catchers report to spring training. Will Andy Pettitte be there? The answer, Brian Cashman said Monday, is the same as it was a month ago.

title: Religious Divorce Dispute Leads to Secular Protest
description: This should have been a good New Years for Aharon Friedman, a 34-year-old tax counsel for the Republicans on the House Ways and Means Committee. He spent time with his 3-year-old daughter, and could have been thinking about the influence he will have starting Wednesday, when his boss, Representative Dave Camp of Michigan, becomes chairman of the powerful tax-writing committee.

title: Son of Former Speaker Has His Prison Term Cut
description: LOS ANGELES  With just hours left in his term, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger commuted the sentence of a former State Assembly speakers son who is in prison for his role in a 2008 killing.

title: Unmappable Mysteries (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Browns Fire Mangini After Second 5-11 Season
description: Remember when everyone thought N.F.L. coaches would not be fired this season because team owners would not want to absorb the dismissed coachs contract while paying a new coach with a lockout looming?

title: Strained States Turning to Laws to Curb Labor Unions
description: Faced with growing budget deficits and restive taxpayers, elected officials from Maine to Alabama, Ohio to Arizona, are pushing new legislation to limit the power of labor unions, particularly those representing government workers, in collective bargaining and politics.

title: Citys Graphic Ad on the Dangers of H.I.V. Is Dividing Activists
description: The advertisement opens like a French film noir, showing portraits of melancholy-looking men standing against a shadowy black-and-white backdrop of menacing New York City streets. When you get H.I.V., the narrator intones, its never just H.I.V.

title: Iran Invites Some Nations, Not U.S., for Nuclear Tour
description: WASHINGTON  Iran has invited Russia, China and several European Union members to visit its nuclear facilities this month, but pointedly snubbed the United States, European diplomats said on Monday.

title: The Lingering Mystery of Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
description: In todays Science Times, David Tuller reports on recent developments surrounding chronic fatigue syndrome, a mysterious illness of unknown cause that may be linked to a virus. In December, a medical advisory panel suggested that the Food and Drug Administration ban blood donations by people with a history of C.F.S., a move that was hailed by many patients as a sign that their illness was finally being taken seriously.

title: Bouncing Back From Hard Times
description: Can adversity make us stronger?

title: Remains of Ex-Officer Are Found in a Landfill
description: WASHINGTON  John P. Wheeler III, a lawyer and former Army officer who helped build the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, was found dead in a Delaware landfill on Friday, in what the authorities ruled a homicide.

title: Fancying Prewar Hats Instead of the Fast Lane
description: LONDON  The woman in the West London cafe looked faintly familiar, like a friend from long ago. In a way, she was: so vivid and achingly believable were Elizabeth McGoverns performances in films like Ordinary People (1980), Ragtime (1981) and Racing With the Moon (1984) that she became part of the fabric of adolescence for a generation of American moviegoers.

title: Navy Captain Is Investigated Over Videos
description: WASHINGTON  Navy officials said Monday that it was unclear whether the commander of an aircraft carrier who had produced and appeared in a series of coarse and sexually explicit onboard videos several years ago would deploy with his ship, the Enterprise, when it leaves to support combat missions in Afghanistan this month.

title: Worth a Reprise at Age 401
description: Almost exactly a year ago, the New York soprano Jolle Greenleaf, the Boston violinist Scott Metcalfe and a couple of dozen close associates from around the country presented the fruit of what they called the Green Mountain Project: a performance of Monteverdis grand and glorious Vespers of 1610, mounted in observance of the works 400th anniversary. A tremendous popular and critical success, the concert might have been the culmination of a one-off labor of love.

title: After 10 Days, Trash Pickup Resumes (Even Outside Manhattan)
description: A welcome chorus of grunts, hisses, crunches and clangs greeted New Yorkers on Monday as lumbering sanitation trucks collected trash for the first time in more than a week, their arrival a promise that tons of city garbage would finally begin moving away from curbs, not toward them.

title: The Link Between Love and Madness, Explored on a Small Stage
description: When Sinfonia New York was founded in 2007, it was meant to be principally a period-instrument Baroque and Classical orchestra. As it has turned out, Sinfonia has become a more flexible enterprise, perhaps of necessity, given the cost of running an orchestra. The Sinfonia Players, a chamber offshoot of the ensemble, presented a striking series of Pergolesi concerts last year, led from the harpsichord by the orchestras conductor, John Scott. And a different configuration, with the superb lutenist Grant Herreid supplanting Mr. Scott as the main continuo player, offered a program of mostly Italian Baroque chamber and vocal works at Bargemusic on Sunday afternoon.

title: Texas: DNA Evidence Clears Man After 30 Years
description: Thirty years after Cornelius Dupree Jr. was imprisoned for rape and robbery, prosecutors in Dallas declared him innocent on Monday in light of new DNA evidence. Mr. Dupree, 51, has served more years in a Texas prison for a crime he did not commit than any of the other 41 people exonerated in the state in recent years. In 1980, Mr. Dupree was convicted along with a second man, Anthony Massingill, of robbing a couple and then kidnapping and raping the woman. But DNA tests completed last year on traces of semen showed that neither man committed the rape. Mr. Dupree was released on parole last summer, weeks before the DNA tests were done. Mr. Massingill, who was convicted in another sexual assault, remains in prison.

title: Hideko Takamine, Lauded Japanese Actress, Dies at 86
description: Hideko Takamine, a Japanese actress who over the course of nearly 200 films developed from an endearing child star into a powerful representative of the Japanese womans search for identity and autonomy in the years after World War II, died on Dec. 28 in Tokyo. She was 86.

title: Georgia: N.A.A.C.P. Says Guards Beat Prisoners
description: The N.A.A.C.P. says three prisoners were beaten by guards in retaliation for a strike, but the prison leadership denies wrongdoing. The N.A.A.C.P. and the inmates families said Monday that they planned to file a lawsuit or a complaint with the federal government after receiving photographs showing the mens injuries. The group says that the men were handcuffed and beaten, including with a hammer, and that one man now needs a wheelchair and another apparently has brain damage. We are a law enforcement agency and do everything possible to uphold, not break, laws, the Georgia Department of Corrections said. Inmates in several Georgia prisons went on strike last month, seeking more food and better living conditions.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,432 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:

title: To Beat Back Poverty, Pay the Poor
description: The city of Rio de Janeiro is infamous for the fact that one can look out from a precarious shack on a hill in a miserable favela and see practically into the window of a luxury high-rise condominium. Parts of Brazil look like southern California. Parts of it look like Haiti. Many countries display great wealth side by side with great poverty. But until recently, Brazil was the most unequal country in the world.

title: Pepsi to Sponsor American Idol Rival
description: THERE are Coke people, and there are Pepsi people. But for Simon Cowell, who is moving from American Idol to The X Factor, that allegiance  which quite often lasts a lifetime  is about to take a turn.

title: Goldman Tops League Table
description: The New York Times

title: Confident Deal Makers Pulled Out Checkbooks in 2010
description: The most significant development in mergers and acquisitions in 2010 may be not what actually happened but what deal makers think happened  a return of confidence.

title: Russians Large Stake in Facebook Grows Larger
description: MOSCOW  What do the Russians want from Facebook?

title: Obama May Bypass Guantnamo Rules, Aides Say
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas legal advisers, confronting the prospect of new restrictions on the transfer of Guantnamo detainees, are debating whether to recommend that he issue a signing statement asserting that his executive powers would allow him to bypass the restrictions, according to several officials.

title: Anonymity and the Dark Side of the Internet
description: In McIntyre v. Ohio Elections Commission (1995) the Supreme Court overturned a statute requiring any person who prints a notice or flyer promoting a candidate or an issue to identify the communications author by name. Justice John Paul Stevens, writing for the majority, grounded his opinion in an account of meaning he takes from an earlier case (First National Bank of Boston v. Bellotti): The inherent worth of . . . speech in terms of its capacity for informing the public does not depend upon the identity of its source, whether corporation, association, union, or individual. Or, in other words, a writing or utterance says what it says independently of who happens to say it; the information conveyed does not vary with the identification of the speaker.

title: New Tangle In Battle Over Court In Trenton
description: In New Jerseys strangest current political soap opera, Mondays episode played out like this: the judge (who refuses to judge) said he was leaving, the governor (who nominates) refused to nominate, and the Senate (which confirms) still refused to confirm. Got that?

title: Touring Schools That Work, Chancellor Says New Approach Is Needed at Those That Dont
description: In the first school Cathleen P. Black visited, students in a fifth-grade classroom had one laptop apiece, from which they received individualized lessons. In the second school, for teenagers who had been on the verge of dropping out, counselors routinely show up at the homes of students if they are absent three days in a row. The third was one of four schools in a building that once housed one; students had violin and dance classes, aside from traditional subjects like history, English and math.

title: Cuomo, Before Seeking a Wage Freeze, Says He Will Cut His Salary 5%
description: Salary cuts for New York State employees will begin at the top, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Monday.

title: Films Open French Wounds From Algeria
description: PARIS  The French colonial experience in Algeria, marked by warfare, terrorism and torture, is a wound that never quite seems to close. Anger and guilt about Algeria infuse some of the anxiety today about the heavily immigrant and Muslim banlieues, or suburbs, about the French concern with national identity, radical Islam and veiled women.

title: Britain: Flu Cases Surge, Straining Some Hospitals
description: Britain is having an unusual surge of flu cases this winter, according to the World Health Organization, and British news media reports said severe cases were straining intensive care units, particularly those for children, at some hospitals. Most cases are of last years H1N1 swine flu pandemic strain, which has now become a seasonal flu. Relatively few Britons got flu shots this year, officials said, ascribing that to skepticism after the swine flu pandemic proved less lethal than feared.

title: Senator Calls for Helmet Safety Investigation
description: A United States senator is formally requesting that the Federal Trade Commission investigate what he called misleading safety claims and deceptive practices among helmet manufacturers and refurbishers.

title: Why Facebook Is Such a Crucial Friend for Goldman
description: 8:50 p.m. | Updated

title: For the Jets, a Daunting Road Ahead
description: Immediately after the regular season ended Sunday, Rex Ryan returned to the same message he delivered nearly two years ago, on his first day as the Jets coach. He wants to win the Super Bowl. He thinks the Jets will win the Super Bowl. Not next season. Not some season. But this season, next month.

title: Caught Sleeping
description: Near Mobile, Ala., Jan. 4, 1861

title: Ratings Rise for Prime Time Winter Classic
description: The Winter Classic in Pittsburgh between the Penguins and the Washington Capitals on New Years Day was seen by an average of 4.5 million viewers on NBC. It was the most-watched N.H.L. regular-season game since a Rangers win over the Philadelphia Flyers in February 1975 attracted 5.5 million viewers.

title: Steele Faces His Rivals in Gentle G.O.P. Debate
description: WASHINGTON  Michael Steele, who has been the subject of considerable criticism during his two-year chairmanship of the Republican National Committee, defended his record on Monday as he made a rare public appearance alongside four rivals who are competing against him to lead the party through the next election cycle.

title: G.O.P. Sets Up Huge Target for Budget Ax
description: WASHINGTON  The incoming Republican majority in the House is moving to make good on its promise to cut $100 billion from domestic spending this year, a goal eagerly backed by conservatives but one carrying substantial political and economic risks.

description: (1) Propriety and good taste in behavior, dress, etc.; (2) an act or requirement of polite behavior.

description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  In 2010, Daphne Joseph, a slim, shy teenager, took a pounding from life.

title: Facebook Deal Offers Freedom From Scrutiny
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In Silicon Valley, going public used to be the ultimate rite of passage for a start-up  a sign it had arrived.

title: Fela May Be Headed Soon to Nigeria
description: The lead producer of the recently shuttered Broadway musical Fela! is in discussions with producers in Lagos, Nigeria, to present the show in late winter or early spring in that African nation, home of the title character Fela Anikulapo Kuti.

title: Mets Go Looking for Pitching Bargains
description: Looking for value among a crop of players coming off injury, the Mets signed the left-hander Chris Capuano and the right-hander Taylor Buchholz to one-year contracts Monday.

title: For Tolstoy and Russia, Still No Happy Ending
description: MOSCOW  A couple of months ago one of Russias elder statesmen set out on a paradoxical mission: to rehabilitate one of the most beloved figures in Russian history, Tolstoy.

title: Adding Furniture to a Home Thats Still Not Quite Full
description: Last fall, Lou Louse Polynice, her two daughters, her father and eight other relatives slept on the floor of their Harlem apartment, wrapped in blankets and huddled together to stay warm.

title: Pete Postlethwaite, an Actor With Broad Range, Dies at 64
description: Pete Postlethwaite, a lanky, craggy-faced character actor whose range stretched from sweet sentimentality to acid menace and who was nominated for an Academy Award in 1994 for his role as the father of a man unjustly accused of terrorism in In the Name of the Father, died on Sunday in Shrewsbury, Shropshire, England. He was 64 and lived on a farm near Bishops Castle, Shropshire.

title: Lottery Numbers
Obama Talks With William Daley About a Job
description: President Obama has approached William Daley, the brother of Chicagos mayor and a former commerce secretary, about the possibility of becoming White House chief of staff as one part of a reorganization plan in the West Wing, according to people familiar with the conversation, which took place around the holidays.

title: 2 Officers Face Sanctions on Tactics in a 2008 Shooting
description: Two New York police officers cleared of department violations in a 2008 fatal shooting of a man in Coney Island will now face a disciplinary trial later this month over their decision-making in the moments before the shooting.

title: St. Johns Finds New Locker Room and New Excitement at Garden
description: The St. Johns mens basketball team stepped off its bus, onto the Eighth Avenue sidewalk and, it hoped, into the future on Monday night.

title: Roasting and Toasting the Deal Makers
description: It is time again for the annual DealBook closing dinner, where we toast and roast Wall Street and its deal makers  and look ahead to make a couple of New Years resolutions.

title: Tuesday: Patrolling the Perimeter
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  When you are in the Solving Zone, by which I mean that a specific corner or section is falling easily for you, do you find that your eye starts to wander over to crossing entries nearby and nudge your brain to start solving those, too? Before you know it, your hand has mysteriously wandered over to those boxes and maybe you even hop to the end of a word, filling it in from the last letter to the first, because after all, thats one way to expand your conquered territory in a crossword puzzle, isnt it?

title: ESPN Disciplines Football Announcer
description: ESPN removed Ron Franklin from the radio broadcast of Saturdays Fiesta Bowl for remarks to Jeannine Edwards, a sideline reporter, during a production meeting for the Chick-fil-A Bowl on Dec. 31. The Web site SportsByBrooks reported that Franklin said, Listen to me, sweet baby, let me tell you something, in a tone that Edwards found condescending. When she protested to Franklin, he reportedly used an obscenity.

title: Giants Depart, and Leave Free-Agency Issues
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  As the Giants stuffed their gear and frustration from an unfulfilled 10-6 season into garbage bags for a long winter, the franchise looked to a future appearing both stable and uncertain.

description: A former Massachusetts congressman is perhaps most famous today for saying all politics is local (or, perhaps, all politics are local; Ive seen it written both ways). Heres the Wikipedia explanation of the saying:

description: To the Editor:

title: Canada Beats United States in World Junior Semifinal
description: BUFFALO  The American fans were about as loud as their Canadian counterparts at the start of the world junior tournament semifinals on Monday night. But Canada came out flying when the puck dropped and the Americans never recovered, falling, 4-1, in the latest edition of this heated rivalry.

title: A Clear Danger to Free Speech
description: Chicago

title: Fidos No Doctor. Neither Is Whiskers.

title: The Achievement Test
description: Unless something big and unexpected happens, 2011 will be consumed by a debate over the size of government. Republicans will launch a critique of big government as part of their effort to cut spending. Democrats will surge to the barricades to defend federal programs.

title: Spider-Man Gets a New Lead Actress
description: The lead role of the villainous spider-woman Arachne in the Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark will now be played by cast member T.V. Carpio, the shows lead producer, Michael Cohl, announced in a statement on Tuesday morning.

title: Get Ready for a G.O.P. Rerun
description: You just cant close the door on this crowd. The party that brought us the worst economy since the Great Depression, that led us into Iraq and the worst foreign policy disaster in American history, that would like to take a hammer to Social Security and a chisel to Medicare, is back in control of the House of Representatives with the expressed mission of undermining all things Obama.

title: Obama Wraps Up Hawaii Trip With Family Outing
description: HONOLULU  After a peaceful 11-day respite that was heavy on morning workouts and afternoon golf, President Obama wrapped up his Hawaiian vacation on Monday with an action-packed afternoon of family activities. He mingled with locals at Island Snow, his favorite spot for Hawaiian shave ice  he caught a clerk off guard when he flashed a $100 bill to pay for the treats  and also took his daughters to the military cemetery where his grandfather is buried and later to the Honolulu Zoo.

title: The Missing Judges
description: The annual report on the federal judiciary by the chief justice of the United States is not a place you would normally go for political agitation. But that is just what Chief Justice John Roberts Jr. offered by using a portion of his year-end review to deplore the acute difficulties created for the justice system by the Senates slowness in approving President Obamas nominees for federal judgeships.

title: Mr. Orban Forgets
description: Hungarians are justly proud of the way their country stood up to Soviet tanks in 1956 and helped breach the Iron Curtain with freer emigration in 1989. But they can take no pride in a new media law that took effect this week, just as Hungary took over the rotating presidency of the European Union.

title: Graphics Ability Is the New Goal for Chip Makers
description: In the good old days, it was all about speed.

title: Black Market Tips
description: As of today, seven people have been charged in an insider-trading investigation focused on investors and consultants connected to Primary Global Research, an expert-network firm. The cases, brought by Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, paint a disturbing picture of how some hedge funds have used this company to illegally procure information and distort the workings of a healthy financial market.

title: Curbside Forest
description: First there was the fresh snow, lying white and undisturbed all across New York. Then  if you were lucky  came the plowing, followed by the big melt last weekend, which turned the city into an archipelago surrounded by slush ponds. Now, where massive mounds of snow once rose, there are rising mounds of black garbage bags awaiting pickup by many of the same trucks that have been busy plowing streets.

title: Word of the Day | procurement
description: procurement \pr-kyur-mnt\ noun

title: Stanford Wins Orange Bowl
description: The Stanford Cardinal took command of the Orange Bowl in the second half, defeating the Virginia Tech Hokies 40-12.

title: Manhattan Real Estate Market Continues Steady Growth, as Luxury Sales Perk Up
description: The 2010 real estate market in Manhattan will be remembered for slow but steady growth, with luxury sales of $3 million and up finally making a strong return in the final months of the year, according to fourth-quarter market reports to be released on Tuesday.

title: Stanford Romps, but Talk Turns to Future of Harbaugh and Luck
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  So spectacular was the Orange Bowl show they had seen, members of the Stanford football traveling party held up cellphone cameras as if they were lighters and roared for an encore.

title: Bloggingheads: Death Panels Reborn?
description: Robert Wright, left, of Bloggingheads.tv and Mickey Kaus of kausfiles debate the so-called death panels.

title: Iran: Scientist Tortured After Return, Web Site Says
description: An Iranian nuclear scientist who said he had been abducted by the C.I.A. has been imprisoned and tortured since his return to Iran in July, an opposition Web site reported Monday. The scientist, Shahram Amiri, spent the past two months in solitary confinement in a military prison and was hospitalized at least once because of physical and psychological pressure, according to the report on IranBriefing.net. Before his imprisonment, Mr. Amiri was subjected to three months of intensive interrogation, the report said. The report could not be verified, and much that has been reported about Mr. Amiris case has been confusing and contradictory. American officials said Mr. Amiri was a C.I.A. informer who voluntarily defected to the United States in 2009. When he returned to Iran, he said he had been abducted and tortured by the Americans, and Iran said he was a double-agent sent to spy on the C.I.A.

title: News Quiz | January 4, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Shut Out of Their Own Futures
description: WHO have taken to the streets in protest in recent weeks because they feel increasingly shut out of their own futures, according to this article?

title: Chinese Wind Turbine Maker Set for $1.4 Billion I.P.O.
description: The Sinovel Wind Group Company, a Chinese wind turbine maker, said on Tuesday that it planned to raise up to $1.4 billion in an initial public offering in Shanghai to finance growth, another sign of Chinas push into alternative sources of energy.

title: Daily Lexeme: Xystus
description: Todays word, in association with the acclaimed Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Clashes Grow as Egyptians Remain Angry After an Attack
description: CAIRO  Thousands of angry rioters broke through police lines, pelting officers with rocks and bottles and beating them with makeshift wooden crosses in a third day of unrest set off by a bomb blast outside a church after a New Years Mass, which killed 21 and wounded about 100.

title: Test Yourself | English, Jan. 4, 2011
description: Test your reading skills with todays question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the article For Kodachrome Fans, Road Ends at Photo Lab in Kansas.

title: Afghan Police Officer Killed by Blast in Downtown Kabul
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A bomb exploded near the Defense Ministry in downtown Kabul during rush hour on Tuesday, killing a police officer and wounding another along with two civilians, the Interior Ministry said.

title: Do Your Relationships Expand You?
description: People today want partners who make their lives more interesting, says a much-e-mailed recent article about happy marriages. The ideas in the article are applicable not only to romantic partnerships, but also to relationships with friends and family. Think about one or several important relationships in your life: Do those people expand you by teaching you new things, introducing you to new experiences, or helping you become a better person? If so, how?

title: Japan to Propose Closer Military Ties With South Korea
description: TOKYO  Responding to recent provocations by North Korea, Japans defense minister will soon visit Seoul with several proposals aimed at strengthening military ties despite South Koreas lingering bitterness over Japans colonial past, Japanese news media reported on Tuesday.

title: Floods Take Toll on Australia Economy
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Churning floodwaters continued to rise across a vast stretch of northeastern Australia on Tuesday as the authorities worked to grapple with the multibillion-dollar economic toll from record inundations that have killed at least nine people.

title: Violence  and Art  in the Afternoon
description: James Hill became the European contract photographer for The New York Times in 1995 and has been based in Moscow and Rome. These photographs were taken last year for the Year of Spain in Russia, a cultural exchange program that is partly financed by the Spanish government. His conversation with James Estrin has been edited and condensed. [EDITORS NOTE: This description has been revised to include the connection to the Year of Spain project, which was omitted from the original version.]

title: Xpert Financial Starts New Trading System for Private Firms
description: Xpert Financial said the Securities and Exchange Commission had approved a new trading platform for the shares of private companies like Facebook, which are tapping nonpublic markets to avoid initial public offerings.

title: Grupo ACS Amasses More Than 30% of Hochtief
description: Grupo ACS, the Spanish construction company, said on Tuesday that its holding in Hochtief, a smaller German rival, had surpassed 30 percent in response to a tender offer the company made last year, clearing a major hurdle as it seeks full control of the company.

title: Putting an Artistic Gloss on a Paris Cast-Off
description: A cultural space that opened this fall was named for its seedy legacy. Back in the roaring 20s, Le Bal was a cabaret, dance club and htel damour (read: brothel). After World War II, the venue was converted into the largest PMU (Pari mutuel urbain, a bar for betting on horses) in France. Vacated and abandoned by 1992, it was re-purchased by the city in 2006 and selected as the spot for a multipurpose art space that includes galleries, a bookstore and a cafe.

title: What They Are Reading: A Question of Command
description: This year At War will profile books, articles and other reading materials that those directly involved in the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq have found valuable in their preparations for working in the field. The first post in this series presented Abdul Salam Zaeefs My Life With The Taliban, an insiders account of the Taliban that is required reading for officers in an Army aviation task force now working in southern Afghanistan.

title: The Early Word: Preparing to Fight
description: In The Times:

title: Does the Colts Gary Brackett Deserve to Be Suspended?
description: If the N.F.L. is looking for an example to suspend a player for making an illegal hit on a defenseless player, the star Colts linebacker Gary Brackett may end up watching Saturdays playoff game against the Jets from the sideline.

title: Obama Talked With JPMorgan Executive About Top Post
description: President Obama has approached William Daley, a former commerce secretary and a senior JPMorgan Chase executive, about the possibility of becoming the next White House chief of staff, Michael D. Shear and Jeff Zeleny of The New York Times reported on Tuesday, citing people familiar with the conversation.

title: Twenty-Five Years, and Im Still Standing
description: Jan. 1 marked my 25th year in business. I resigned from my job as a carpenters helper in November 1985, but it was at the turn of the year that I moved out of my college apartment and set up housekeeping in a new part of town. The plan: become a master furniture maker.

title: Commodity Costs Lift Inflation in Europe, and the Sales Tax Rises in Britain
description: Higher prices for food, oil and other commodities are starting to stoke inflation in the euro area, data released Tuesday indicated, while British residents got their first taste of higher taxes on retail goods and services.

title: Killing of Governor Deepens Crisis in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The assassination of an outspoken secular politician by one of his elite police guards on Tuesday plunged the government deeper into political crisis and highlighted the threat of militant infiltration even within the nations security forces.

title: Obama Predicts Republicans Will Play to Their Base
description: Returning from his Hawaiian vacation on Air Force One overnight, President Obama offered a brief assessment of the Republicans who will return to Washington Wednesday, saying that he expects Republicans to play to their base for a certain period of time.

title: In Soccer, Making It Look Easy Was Never So Hard
description: How easy it is to look upon the modern superstars as men who care less about the game than the wealth and celebrity it brings them.

title: Primus May Bid Again for A.I.G.s Taiwan Unit
description: The battle for the Taiwan unit of American International Group continues.

title: Measuring Blood Pressure With an iPhone
description: The smartphone is already the Swiss Army knife of the digital age, replacing the need for alarm clocks, GPS units and even digital cameras with the flick of a finger.

title: 3rd Quarter Ad Spending Accelerated, Report Finds
description: The recovery in advertising spending gained momentum in the third quarter, according to a report scheduled to be released on Tuesday morning, underlining the belief that Madison Avenue may be poised for continuing gains in the new year.

title: Helped by Facebook Buzz, Mail.ru Shares Rise
description: The Russian internet company Mail.ru Group surged more than 4 percent on Tuesday in trading on the London Stock Exchange as small investors scrambled for a backdoor way to invest in Facebook.

title: Morning Buzz | The Chancellors First Day
description: Tuesday will remain chillier than the weekend, with highs around 40 and skies partly cloudy.

title: A Hilltop Apothecary | 1022 South
description: The Hilltop neighborhood of Tacoma, Wash., is an unlikely cocktail hot spot. While the city has undergone a resurgence over the last decade, spearheaded by the Chihuly Museum of Glass and a vibrant downtown antiques and arts district, Hilltop remains its roughest patch and largely ignored by visitors. But hidden there is 1022 South, home to some of the most fascinating apothecary cocktail work on the West Coast.

title: Tom Coughlin Transcript: He Feels 27 Years Old
description: A partial transcript of Tom Coughlins address to the news media on Monday. The full version is at Giants.com.

title: Fearing (Another) U.S. Debt Default
description: Over the weekend, Austan Goolsbee, the chairman of the presidents Council of Economic Advisers, argued that Congress should raise the debt ceiling. In an interview with ABCs This Week, he said, If we hit the debt ceiling, thats essentially defaulting on our obligations, which is totally unprecedented in American history.
