The impact on the economy would be catastrophic.

title: The Chitchat Patrol
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: The Chitchat Patrol
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: Is Petrobras Seeking a Stake in Galp?
description: Petrobras of Brazil is reportedly in talks with Eni of Italy to buy its one-third stake in the Portuguese oil company Galp for 3.5 billion euros, the Portuguese business daily Diario Economico wrote on Tuesday.

title: The Seattle Seahawks. Deal With It, America.
description: On the day that the Buffalo Bills advanced to their fourth Super Bowl of the 1990s, some fans at Rich Stadium held up a banner that read: Were back. Deal with it, America!

title: Swinton on Love, Hollywood and Fish Pie
description: I Am Love, the art house Italian film starring Tilda Swinton, may have been left out of the statuette race so far, but hey - Quentin Tarantino named it one of the top movies of last year. And come to think of it, so did some critics closer to home. Ms. Swinton is still a long-shot contender for a nomination, but shes made the most of those odds before, by winning an Oscar for best supporting actress (for Michael Clayton) in 2007. The Bagger reached her recently at her home in the Scottish countryside, in the midst of a snowstorm and dinner preparations (fish pie was on the menu), to talk about moviemaking, the director she loves but cant imagine working with (Martin Scorsese), her distance from Hollywood (asked if she was a member of the Academy, Ms. Swinton confessed she didnt know), and winning that Oscar. It was like a sort of theme park, she said of her previous Oscar whirl. I really, really enjoyed it. People wave at me at airports, and thats all fun.

title: The Shyamalan Groan
description: A collective sigh of disappointment which greeted the discovery of M. Night Shyamalans involvement in the movie Devil.

title: Ron Klain Leaving Vice Presidents Staff
description: 10:26 a.m. | Updated Its not just President Obama who is looking for a new chief of staff.

title: A Boffo Year for Broadway
description: For all of the shows closing this month, several at a loss to their investors, Broadway had a financially robust 2010. Brand-name musicals like Wicked, The Lion King, Jersey Boys and The Addams Family sold enough premium-price tickets (on the order of $250 to $350) for 2010 to help set an overall record for Broadways 40 theaters.

title: Iran Invites Some Nations, Not U.S., for Nuclear Tour
description: WASHINGTON  Iran has invited Russia, China and several European Union members to visit its nuclear facilities this month, but pointedly snubbed the United States, European diplomats said on Monday.

title: Tuesday Reading: Rebounding From Job Loss
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Where to Draw a Line on Ethics
description: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard and the author of the forthcoming book Triumph of the City.

title: Vain Glorious | A Buzz-Worthy Facial
description: What: The Paris Rooftop Honey Facial at Six Senses rue de Castiglione, the year-old Parisian outpost of the worldwide chain of holistic spas.

title: Ahmadinejads Peugeot 504: Worth $1 Million?
description: As far as executive rides are concerned, its no 1956 Volga, but a white 1977 Peugeot 504 sedan that belongs to Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad does carry that rarified whiff of high political office  as well as, at last reckoning, a $1 million price tag.

title: Kurdish Rebels in Northern Iraq
description: In Iraq's northern mountains, the controversial Kurdistan Workers' Party shows signs of adjusting its rhetoric in response to the political and economic changes in Turkey and Iraq. Is it enough?

title: The Town Breaks Into Producers List
description: Ben Affleck and The Town grabbed one of 10 best-picture slots from the Producers Guild of America, which announced its nominees on Tuesday morning, possibly advancing the Boston dramas chances to make the big list at the Oscars. The remainder of the nominees were the expected names: The Social Network, Inception, Black Swan, True Grit, The Kids Are All Right, The Fighter, The Kings Speech and Toy Story 3. Left off the feature list were indie wild cards like Winters Bone and Blue Valentine, both of which have drawn praise for their performances. (The producers guild does not nominate actors; its awards go only to the producers of each film.)

title: 48.7 Million: Thats a Lot of Tourists
description: Despite the lingering effects of the recession, more people visited New York City in 2010 than in any previous year, according to an estimate announced by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Tuesday.

title: Aircraft Carrier Captain Is Removed Over His Role in Coarse Videos
description: WASHINGTON  The United States Navy removed the commanding officer of the aircraft carrier Enterprise on Tuesday, citing his profound lack of good judgment for creating and starring in a series of coarse and sexually explicit onboard videos several years ago that were meant as entertainment for the ships crew.

title: Environmental Economist Joins White House Staff
description: Nathaniel Keohane, most recently the chief economist at the Environmental Defense Fund, has moved to the National Economic Council at the White House to help direct environmental and energy policy. He replaces Joseph E. Aldy, who is returning to the faculty at Harvard University.

title: Firefox Leads in Europe, Firm Says
description: BERLIN  For the first time in a decade, Microsofts Internet Explorer is no longer the leading Web browser in Europe, ceding the position to Mozillas Firefox, an Irish research company that tracks Web use said on Tuesday.

title: Morgan Stanley Names a Top Officer
description: Jim Rosenthal has been named chief operating officer of Morgan Stanley, James P. Gorman, the firms chief executive, said in a memo on Tuesday.

title: Chief Justice Roberts Swears In Boehners Staff
description: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. swore in President Obama  twice.

title: Trail Blazers Making Ends Meet Despite Injuries
description: The Portland Trail Blazers chances of climbing into the Western Conference elite deteriorated along with Brandon Roys knees. Still, the 18-16 Blazers have a chance to make something out of their season, even if respectability is a less lofty goal than championship contention.

title: The Doctor and the Kidney Stone
description: Must doctors follow their own advice?

title: Detroit Carmakers Post Sales Gains as Toyota Lags
description: DETROIT  The domestic auto industrys long, slow comeback gained traction in December, as the big car companies on Tuesday reported their best monthly sales rate for 2010 and some raised their forecasts for this year.

title: Debating Home Birth
description: And you thought conversations on Motherlode became heated? Click on over to Babble.com, where flames have been thrown for two weeks and counting.

title: A Pro Atmosphere at the Orange Bowl
description: By all appearances, Stanfords victory in the Orange Bowl was a college event, complete with school colors, festive atmosphere and universities blowing bags of money on what is essentially a big booster road show. But everyone involved knew it was actually an N.F.L. tryout, a coaching and quarterbacking combine with confetti and cheerleaders.

title: Stop Energy Poverty. Great Slogan, So How?
description: With Republicans controlling the House, with

title: Bloomsbury Auctions Reviewing Plans for New York Branch
description: Bloomsbury Auctions, the London company that bills itself as the worlds leading auctioneer of rare books and manuscripts, opened a New York branch with great fanfare three years ago, but it appears to be struggling in an economy that has not been kind to book dealers. Several specialists in the New York office, which fills two floors on West 48th Street, have left for other companies, including Sothebys, Bonhams and Doyle, and no Bloomsbury sales for 2011 are scheduled in New York.

title: What Were Reading
description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.

title: Math That Moves: Schools Embrace the iPad
description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS, N.Y.  As students returned to class this week, some were carrying brand-new Apple iPads in their backpacks, given not by their parents but by their schools.

title: Barrett and Robbins Out at Village Voice
description: Wayne Barrett and Tom Robbins, two muckraking fixtures of the New York City press corps, are leaving The Village Voice. Mr. Barrett was let go; Mr. Robbins quit in protest.

title: On Twitter, Glimpses of a Slain Pakistani Governors War on Religious Fanatics
description: Updated | 1:32 p.m. As my colleagues Salman Masood and Carlotta Gall report, the governor of Pakistans Punjab province, Salman Taseer, was shot and killed by one of his guards on Tuesday.

title: Facebook vs. Time Warner: A Not-So-Rigorous Financial Evaluation
description: Word arrived Monday that Facebook, the burgeoning social media company that surpassed Google last year as the most visited Web site, was worth $50 billion based on a deal done by Goldman Sachs. By way of comparison, our colleagues Andrew Ross Sorkin and Evelyn M. Rusli pointed out that the company was worth more than Time Warner, the large United States media company, which closed the day with a market cap of about $37 billion.

title: French Regulators to Consider Hermess Anti-Takeover Plan
description: A plan Herms adopted to thwart a takeover attempt by LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton will be considered by French regulators on Thursday, said a person with direct knowledge of the matter who was not authorized to speak publicly.

title: Sudans Leader Reaches Out Ahead of a Vote
description: YEI, Sudan  President Omar Hassan al-Bashir, who for so long brutally prosecuted the civil war in southern Sudan, arrived here in the region on Tuesday, offering a conciliatory message five days ahead of a historic referendum for southern independence.

title: Do Public Workers Diplomas Justify Their Pay?
description: Several attentive readers of my post Monday on public workers compensation raised interesting questions that go to the heart of a debate flaring in many statehouses and cities. (And as my colleague Steven Greenhouse reports on Tuesday, it is a debate that is prompting some states to ponder ways to curb the power of public-sector unions.)

title: Volkswagen Extends C.E.O. Martin Winterkorns Contract
description: The executive who has set the goal of turning Volkswagen into the worlds largest automaker by 2018 has job security through 2016, the automaker announced on Monday.

title: Its Quirky, Its Beloved, and Its Closing
description: Updated, 1:05 p.m. | The news began to trickle out just before Christmas via a flurry of horrified Facebook postings and shocked exchanges over lattes and bagels: the Victory Cafe, a tiny hole-in-the-wall coffee shop in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, was being evicted by its landlord. It had until Jan. 31 to vacate the premises.

title: The Rum House Rises
description: The Rum House was a shabby little piano bar off the lobby of the Edison Hotel on 47th Street west of Seventh Avenue, marvelous in its way as a place to stop in before a show for a whiskey sour. Irene Gandy, the legendary Broadway press agent, often held court in one corner. Tyros with musical-comedy in their blood sketched out bits in another. Always, tourists mooned. The bar was a tie to the Rialto of old  an adult-beverage version of the Polish Tea Room next door, where producers gathered to dream and scheme over tuna fish on rye, a scene out of Runyon, a simple place for a drink. And then, in the summer of 2010, after 37 years, it closed.

title: A Novelist Wills Her Dream Home Into Being
description: There are two ways to describe Annie Proulxs memoir, Bird Cloud, an account of her Sisyphean struggle to build her dream house on a remote and striking 640-acre stretch of land in Wyoming.

title: Republicans Trim Millions From Houses Own Budget
description: The budget cutting begins at home.

title: Resolved: Think Less About Money
description: This week, our contributors, along with some of our favorite sources, are writing about their new years financial resolutions. This post is from Bucks artist in residence Carl Richards.

title: Iverson Breaks Media Silence in Turkey
description: Allen Iverson finally spoke from Turkey after dodging the Philadelphia news media, having refused interviews even when reporters came to Istanbul to see him.

title: Wilmington Trust C.E.O. Forfeits $2 Million in TARP Clawback
description: So much for one bankers bonus.

title: Wrong Station, Right Image
description: Maybe it was relief that New York was recovering from last weeks blizzard or elation that the holidays had come to an end. Whatever  Fred R. Conrads picture of a balloon deliverer on a subway platform in Lower Manhattan perfectly captured the sense of the moment in the city and earned itself a berth on the front page of The Times.

title: Designers Family Face to Face With Man Accused in Her Death
description: The family of a fashion designer found dead last month in the Soho House hotel in the meatpacking district saw the man accused of killing her, Nicholas Brooks, for the first time since her death when he was arraigned Tuesday on a second-degree murder charge.

title: New Critic Named for Ebert Movie Program
description: Roger Ebert announced Tuesday that he had chosen a young and relatively unknown Russian-born movie critic, Ignatiy Vishnevetsky, to serve as a host of his new movie-review program, Ebert Presents At the Movies, which will have its premiere Jan. 21 on public television stations around the country.

title: Charges Against Chess Players Dismissed
description: Updated, 3:53 p.m. | A judge dismissed criminal summonses Tuesday morning against two of the six men who were hit with misdemeanor charges for playing chess at a playground in Inwood Hill Park in Upper Manhattan, their lawyer said.

title: Is Technology Driving You Up a Tree?
description: Technology is wonderful  when it isnt driving you up a tree screaming. What Id like to know is, which limb of the tree are you ending up on, and what are you screaming? And which aspects of technology keep you up at night? To paraphrase, happy consumers of business information technology are all alike, but every unhappy consumer of business I.T. is unhappy in his or her own way.

title: Art in America Names New Editor in Chief
description: Lindsay Pollock, a reporter for Bloomberg and the author of The Girl with the Gallery, about Edith Gregor Halpert, has been named editor in chief of Art in America.

title: HuffPo Hangs the Help Wanted Sign
description: Pull up to the bar at any Manhattan media watering hole and you will hear the long, low groans of journos who bemoan the sad state of the industry. But the relative health of the media employment economy really depends on where you are looking.

title: Evidence of Mammals and Legumes, 22 Million Years Old
description: Bonnie F. Jacobs, a paleobotanist at Southern Methodist University, writes from Ethiopia, where she is studying fossils of ancient plant and animal life. The current field season in the Mush Valley of Ethiopia is financed by a grant to Ellen Currano of Miami University, Ohio, from the National Geographic Society Committee on Research and Exploration.

title: Letter Calls on Economists to Adopt Code of Ethics
description: About 300 economists have signed a letter calling on the American Economic Association, the worlds largest professional society for economists, to adopt a code of ethics requiring members to disclose potential conflicts of interest. As I reported last week, the associations executive committee plans to take up the matter this week during the groups annual meeting in Denver.

title: Wilson Jermaine Heredia Returns to Broadway in La Cage
description: Wilson Jermaine Heredia, who won a Tony for Rent in 1996 but hasnt been back on Broadway since, will replace Robin de Jess in the role of the sassy housekeeper, Jacob, in the revival of La Cage aux Folles, the producers announced Tuesday.

title: Special Delivery
description: The photographer Fred R. Conrad wasnt supposed to be at the Chambers Street subway station. He wasnt even supposed to be in Manhattan. But a miscalculation in his travel itinerary left him in a spot where he could take this delightful photograph, which earned a berth on Page 1 of The Times. Our neighbors at Lens have the full story: Wrong Station, Right Image.

title: From Realm of the Stars to Half a Room
description: Pull back the curtain that runs down the middle of the room and look at the clutter by the window: two computer printers that double as fax machines, papers strewn on the bed. But there is also what you cant see: the occupants memories of the night he opened a restaurant and George Harrison came in; the time Keith Richards showed up for dinner, unannounced, with 12 people in tow; the visit from Dan Aykroyd and his wife, Donna Dixon, both hungry. Very hungry. The bill came to $600.51.

title: After Acquittal, Player Gets Senior Season Back
description: SAN DIEGO  Montanas Jimmy Wilson hurled himself into the quarterback with such ferocity that it sent the players helmet flying. It was in that moment, against Cal Poly in the second game of this season, that Wilson knew he could still play football.

title: The Return of the Rum House
description: On the Diners Journal blog, Sam Sifton, the restaurant critic for The New York Times, writes about next weeks reopening of the Rum House, the legendary little piano bar off the lobby of the Edison Hotel on 47th Street.

title: The Grandparent Economy
description: The spending power of the older generation.

title: Ivory Coast Leader Softens Position in Crisis
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  The president who refuses to relinquish power after losing an election has agreed to lift the blockade on his winning rivals headquarters, West Africas political-economic alliance said Tuesday.

title: Climate Bill Failure  the Cartoon
description: Over at Grist, David Roberts and some collaborators (drawings by Thomas Pitilli, lettering by Warp Graphics.) have turned the last stages of the death of a comprehensive bill on climate and energy into a cartoon somewhat reminiscent of Shaun of the Dead. As he explained in an e-mail message, Gotta laugh to keep from crying!

title: The Insider | Alexandre Thumerelle
description: The daily patrons of 0fr (pronounced oh-eff-eehrrr), a family-run intello-chic bookshop in the Marais area of Paris, are a mixed bunch. Our customers always vary, the owner Alexandre Thumerelle says. We usually have locals  students from the fine arts Grande cole across the street, designers, models and artists who live in the area. We have tourists, but the ones who come here are pas mal. Thumerelle, 39, opened his internationally eclectic store in 1995 with his younger sister, Marie. Since then, 0fr has become an indie destination spot for its assortment of vintage and newly released art books and cult fashion magazines. Small but busy, it doubles as a exhibition space for emerging artists (past artist inhabitants have included Will McBride and Mark Borthwick) as well as a publisher for Paris-centric publications (including GuideParis, a yearly manual filled with local favorites). People think Parisians are snobs, but GuideParis and 0fr prove that were not so bad. We dont mind newcomers  most of the time. To celebrate its 15 years in existence, 0fr will be releasing a retrospective book in May. Showcasing all 160 of its publications, the book will include collaborations with other Parisian insiders, such as Purple magazines Olivier Zahm and the designer Agns B.

title: Cantor Says Budget Office Miscounted Health Costs
description: The incoming House majority leader, Representative Eric Cantor, Republican of Virginia, accused the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office on Wednesday of misrepresenting the cost of the recently enacted health care law at the behest of Democrats in Congress.

title: A Portfolios Price
description: It is the brass-tacks question every stock investor asks: What is this company really worth?

title: Birthright Citizenship Looms as Next Immigration Battle
description: NOGALES, Ariz.  Of the 50 or so women bused to this border town on a recent morning to be deported back to Mexico, Inez Vasquez stood out. Eight months pregnant, she had tried to trudge north in her fragile state, even carrying scissors with her in case she gave birth in the desert and had to cut the umbilical cord.

title: Cheney Is Back, With Heart Pump and New Outlook
description: This article is by Helene Cooper, Lawrence K. Altman and Michael D. Shear.

title: Writers Guild Offers Up a Few Surprises
description: It continues to be a good day for Ben Affleck. On top of picking up a Producers Guild nomination for The Town, this drama also received a nod from the Writers Guild of America on Tuesday, and Mr. Affleck stands to take home a trophy himself, as a credited screenwriter on the adaptation of the novel Prince of Thieves by Chuck Hogan. After being overlooked by the Golden Globes and the Screen Actors Guild, the Coen brothers also scored with an adapted screenplay nomination for True Grit. (The Bagger happened to be on the phone with the Coens when the nominations were announced, so we got to give them the good news. They were like, Oh. Cool.) The other guild nominations for that category are 127 Hours, The Social Network, and another surprise, I Love You Phillip Morris, starring Jim Carrey and Ewan McGregor.

title: Deflation Concerns Diminish at the Fed
description: WASHINGTON  Top officials at the Federal Reserve were feeling better about the economy, but not so much that they considered scaling back their $600 billion effort to hold down long-term interest rates and stimulate the recovery by buying government bonds.

title: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Israel, Pakistan and the United States.

title: Beers of The Times: Extreme Beers
description: Though each panel member came to the tasting with a dose of skepticism about extreme beer, they found that the best versions, in which all the elements are well balanced, are highly appealing.

title: Beers of The Times: Oktoberfest Mrzen Beers
description: Toasting both the Bavarian harvest and the return of the brewing season.

title: Ales of The Times: Bitters
description: The tasting panel found that the beauty of these gentle British beers is truly in the drinking.

title: The Hops Harvest
description: Sodbuster Farms in Salem, Ore., harvests its hops over the course of five weeks, setting aside a small amount for brewers who want to use them while they're fresh.

title: St. Johns Gives Fans Something to Remember
description: It was plenty loud inside Madison Square Garden on Monday night when Dwight Hardy of St. Johns electrified the 8,897 fans in the final seconds of a 1-point game with a stutter-step move that could have shaken the common cold. Even with more than 10,000 seats empty, the building sounded a little like 1985.

title: Pakistan Was Deadliest for Reporters Last Year
description: Of the 44 journalists who were killed worldwide while working in 2010, 8 died in Pakistan, making it for the first time the deadliest country for reporters, according to a study released Tuesday by the Committee to Protect Journalists.

title: Calling Steven Cohen. No, Not That One.
description: Steven Cohen is the new secretary to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, among his most powerful aides. So please dont confuse him with Steve Cohen, the Memphis congressman, or Steven A. Cohen the billionaire hedge fund manager.

title: For Many Players the New Year Means a New Jersey
description: The deals that marked the opening of the January transfer period were predictable:

title: State Officials vs. State Employee Unions
description: Last January when the Bureau of Labor Statistics released its annual report on union membership, the report showed that for the first time in American history government employees represented a majority of the nations union members.

title: Investors in Thoroughbred Fund Granted Early Exit
description: David Tepper, the manager of the $3 billion Thoroughbred Fund, is making a magnanimous gesture: he is allowing investors, who committed their money for three years, an early way out.

title: 15-Year Sentence for 1968 Plane Hijacking
description: The takeover of the plane evoked a touch of nostalgia, tracing to an era when political activism and crime sometimes went hand in hand. Three men were accused of hijacking Pan American Flight 281, bound for Puerto Rico but taken to Cuba from Kennedy Airport on Nov. 24, 1968, a time when hijackings, especially to Cuba, seemed commonplace.

title: Qualcomm Is Said to Be Set to Buy Atheros for $3.5 Billion
description: 8:42 p.m. | Updated

title: Many Defibrillators Implanted Unnecessarily, Study Says
description: Doctors are implanting high-tech heart devices in thousands of people who probably do not need them, a new study finds. The procedures cost more than $35,000, involve surgery and anesthesia, and may unnecessarily harm some patients.

title: Voting for Hall Shouldnt Be Guessing Whos Guilty
description: It was just a casual conversation one day in the weight room between Jeff Bagwell and Morgan Ensberg, the corner infielders for the Houston Astros. Bagwell was trying to bench-press his usual 300 pounds, and he mentioned to Ensberg that some players around the game had gotten huge by using steroids.

title: Jeff Bagwell, the Hall of Fame, and the Guessing Game
description: Based on the case of Mark McGwire, who has never gotten more than a quarter of the vote, Hall of Fame voters have signaled that they do not want steroid users in Cooperstown. Its a highly charged argument, worthy of its own debate, but its not the most troubling one.

title: Advocacy Group Responds to N.F.L.s Message to Fans
description: On Monday, N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell spoke to fans. On Tuesday, one segment of the fans talked back.

title: Four Injured Performers Is Just Not Strange, Recovering Spider-Man Dancer Says
description: Two weeks ago, the Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark performer Christopher Tierney was on morphine at Bellevue Hospital Center and wondering, in moments of clarity, whether it would take months or years to recover after falling more than 20 feet at the Dec. 20 performance. Only one week ago Mr. Tierney left intensive care for Manhattans Rusk Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine. But on Tuesday, the long-locked, muscular performer was bounding around the set of ABCs Good Morning, America and smiling for photos by onlookers  the only visible evidence of his serious injuries being a torso brace covered with stencil images of Spider-Man.

title: The Capricious Value of Private Equity Investments
description: It is the brass-tacks question every stock investor asks: What is this company really worth?

title: A New Era for Motorola
description: Sanjay Jha, Motorola Mobilitys chairman and chief executive, discusses Motorolas split into two companies in this video interview with CNBC.

title: After Hibernation, the Office Market Is Waking Up
description: After a two-year hiatus, the investment market for office buildings has sprung back to life, with some properties commanding prices reminiscent of the boom years. Bidding for well-occupied, high-quality buildings in major cities like New York and Washington has been so fierce that some buyers have been priced out of the market.

title: A Coat That Becomes a Tote
description: Traveling in winter comes with a particular packing challenge: namely, what to do with the coat? MaxMaras solution is the Cube, a reversible, convertible, collapsible Siberian goose-down puffer. Should the destination require no more than a bathing suit, the jacket folds up into its own little zippered tote. Or for cold-climate options, the Cube can be restyled with interchangeable hood trims and cuffs (in fabrics like linen and suede) or shortened with the help of hidden buttons. While the winter collection stuck to city-friendly black, the spring line, in stores now, comes in four styles and eight slope-worthy colors, from pink to orange. Prices range from $750 for a vest to $4,350 for a fur-lined coat; extra cuffs and trimmings are $175 to $475. At MaxMara, 813 Madison Avenue; (212) 879-6100.

title: The Future Is Now: Analyzing and Making Predictions
description: Overview | What did historical figures imagine our lives would look like today? How can we make informed predictions about the future? In this lesson, students consider and discuss predictions about life in 2011 that were written in 1931 by prominent thinkers of the day, and then draw on New York Times articles to develop their own predictions about the future.

title: Glee Star Joins PETA Cause
description: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, known as PETA, has long been skillful at attracting the buzzed-about celebrities in the popular culture to support its causes. Now, the organization has enlisted a star of the hit TV series Glee to help in one of its efforts.

title: Notes From a Young American in Congo: A Good Man
description: Paluku was standing at the edge of a patchwork field of sugar cane when it happened. I saw the soldiers catch my wife, he says, recounting what he saw, while in his daughters small pharmacy in a North Kivu village, which is still over-run with soldiers. The metal doors are mostly closed, putting the man in relative darkness, but I can still see the white speckles in his short beard and the flash of his eyes. I saw how my wife screamed.

title: Focusing on Languages (Mainly Mandarin)
description: During her visit to High School for Violin and Dance in the Bronx on Monday, one of the stops in five-borough tour that worked as her formal introduction to her new job, New York Citys schools chancellor, Cathleen P. Black, gathered around a table with students and alumni, discussing career paths, opportunities and plans.

title: Obama Aides Lean Against Bypass of Guantnamo Rules
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas aides, confronting a bill that places new restrictions on the transfer of Guantnamo detainees, are likely to recommend that Mr. Obama sharply criticize the limitations when he signs the legislation, a White House official said.

title: Torontos DeRozan Develops His One Dimension
description: The leagues craving for versatility has all but buried the classic basketball archetype of the one-dimensional scorer. Such players can still be found on struggling teams with few other options, but those with the luxury of choice shy away from shoot-first types with little else to offer.

title: Trouble in the Tubes
description: Im in an undisclosed location, and its great  but our fine subtropical Internet provider is turning out to be a sometime thing. So if there are stretches of silence, its not because I have nothing to say, its because my wit and wisdom cant get through

title: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Israel, Pakistan and the United States.

title: TimesCast | January 4, 2011
description: Republicans take control of the House; a political assassination in Pakistan; and the commander of the U.S.S. Enterprise is removed.

title: Free Phone Calls
description: Look, you might have a problem with advertising. But face it: Ads pay for your free TV, free radio and free Web sites.

title: As Convertible Tops Drop, Risk of Hearing Loss Rises
description: At speeds greater than 55 miles an hour, driving in a convertible with its top down produces sufficient noise to increase the risk of hearing loss, a study has found. Occupants are advised to raise the roof  no matter how many style points that may cost them.

title: The Eco Look
description: Student photographers rove their campuses for The Times. This issue: Earth-friendly clothing. Text by Brian Nichols.

title: A Kindle Case Causes Problems
description: E-readers were big this holiday season, from the Kindle to the Nook. But a some customers who gleefully opened their Kindles on Christmas morning quickly ran into some trouble with the device freezing up, or randomly restarting.

title: Consumer Watchdog Strikes Deal to Police Lenders
description: The new federal consumer watchdog, in a long awaited move, is teaming up with state regulators to oversee the lending industry, including payday lenders, student loan providers and mortgage companies.

title: After a Court Ruling, Turkey Frees 23 Suspected Militants
description: ISTANBUL  More than 20 suspected militants, including members of an extreme Islamist organization, were released from Turkish jails on Tuesday after a Supreme Court of Appeals ruling that limits to 10 years the time detainees can be held without being sentenced.

title: Wine Sales to Benefit (Product) Red AIDS Fight
description: 5:12 p.m. | Updated (Product) Red, the effort to fight AIDS in Africa, is teaming up with its first alcoholic beverage partner, which also happens to be its first marketer partner from Australia.

title: Man Found on Subway Platform During Storm Froze to Death
description: A 66-year-old man died of a combination of hypothermia and underlying disease after being found ailing on a Manhattan subway platform last Monday during the snowstorm, the medical examiners office said.

title: Fill-In | Debutante Ball
Pianist Revels in Scores That Dare the Ear
description: Stephen Clarke, a Canadian pianist who revels in the challenges of difficult new music, played a concert at Le Poisson Rouge on Monday evening to celebrate the release of Giacinto Scelsi: Piano Works 4, his latest contribution to the Mode labels CD series devoted to this idiosyncratic Italian composers music.

title: Smart Blondes
description: The Brooklyn duo Blondes makes shimmering electronic music, but the members Zach Steinman and Sam Haar used to be more interested in guitars than synths. In college we were into Gang of Four and Television, Steinman said, but our tastes evolved through 70s disco and Kraut, and eventually 80s electronic. Its a trajectory that is evident in the sparse vocal samples and economical beats on their well received debut EP, Touched. The pairs creative adventurousness also spilled over into a recent photo shoot for The Moment, for which Steinman and Haar were fittingly dressed in clothes by White Mountaineering, a Japanese label that mixes up American and avant-garde references with the same abandon as Blondes experimenting on their synths. (Yosuke Aizawa, the White Mountaineering designer, honed his chops assisting Junya Watanabe, one of the iconoclasts of Japanese fashion.) Ive definitely never worn a kilt before, Haar said of his outfit. Luckily, in music as in life, Haar and his partner in crime are not afraid of change.

title: An Unguarded Portrait of Haitian Spirit
description: Damon Winter had finished his photo session with Fabienne Jean, a young dancer in Haiti whose lower right leg was amputated in the aftermath of the 2010 earthquake. Overcoming her understandable reluctance, Ms. Jean removed her prosthetic limb in the middle of the shoot and set it to the side so that Mr. Winter could photograph her legs as they are. He shot two rolls of film with his Hasselblad and wound up with a fine, eminently publishable portrait.

title: Want to Get Rid of Congress? Its Gone  Until Tomorrow, Anyway
description: For anybody who has ever been fed up at Washington and wanted to get rid of the United States Congress, todays the day to celebrate. Its gone. Sort of. But better enjoy it fast, because by noon on Wednesday, Congress will be back.

title: Judge Rules Emanuels Name Can Appear on Chicago Ballot
description: CHICAGO  Rahm Emanuel cleared another hurdle in his bid for mayor of Chicago on Tuesday when a Cook County judge agreed with the citys election board that his name should appear on the ballot.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 4
description: The day in sports included hockey in Newark and a newcomer to soccer in Malaga, Spain.

title: Resolved: Buy an Electric Car
description: This week on the Bucks blog, our contributors, along with some of our favorite sources, are posting about their new years financial resolutions. Here, Philip Reed, Edmunds.com senior consumer advice editor, shares his thoughts.

title: Criminal Hearing Begins for Late Pop Stars Doctor
description: LOS ANGELES  Prosecutors on Tuesday began laying out the case that they say will show the personal private doctor for the pop star Michael Jackson caused his death in 2009 by giving him a powerful anesthetic meant only for surgery and not telling the emergency doctors who eventually arrived that he had done so.

title: More Reasons to Dislike Brooklyn
description: Eat it up. Time to indulge in some online linkage.

title: An Oscar Shut-Out for Carlos
description: Lots of film critics (including ours) pointed to the French director Olivier Assayass biopic Carlos, a five-and-a-half hour look at the life of the international terrorist Carlos the Jackal, when it came time to compile their 10 Best lists for 2010. The praise extended to the riveting performance of actor Edgar Ramirez (who played Carlos), the script (co-written by Mr. Assayas and Dan Franck) and the direction of Mr. Assayas. Some critics even maintained that Carlos was the best foreign film of the year.

title: Carnegie Hall Plans 120th Anniversary Gala
description: Carnegie Hall announced on Tuesday that it would celebrate its 120th anniversary on April 12 with a gala event to be hosted by James Taylor, along with a sizable lineup of celebrity guests, including Bette Midler, Sting, Steve Martin and Barbara Cook. The event, to highlight many of the extraordinary musical and cultural events that have taken place on the Halls legendary stages over the past 12 decades, as the institution described it, will also feature members of the Tanglewood Festival Chorus. Proceeds will benefit Carnegie Halls artistic and educational programs.

title: Millesime
description: ANOTHER year, another restaurant keeping up its end of the bargain in an awkward hotel lobby space.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: A sampling of whats making the rounds in the deal-making ecosystem:

title: Reviewing Millesime
Morrison & Foerster Names Partners
description: The law firm Morrison & Foerster announced on Tuesday that it had elected 14 partners.

title: D.C. Officials Protest Proposed House Rule
description: Two District of Columbia officials  Mayor Vincent C. Gray and Eleanor Holmes Norton, the districts delegate in Congress  were on Capitol Hill on Tuesday to protest proposed changes to House rules that would strip Ms. Norton and other delegates of their already-limited voting rights.

title: Young Gazans Rage at Hamas and Israel
description: Weeks after Hamas shut down an internationally-financed youth group in Gaza, eight Palestinian students, fed up with living a nightmare inside a nightmare in the isolated territory have posted a manifesto on Facebook expressing their rage and frustration.

title: Freedom Is No Guarantee for a Happily Ever After
description: If I Want to Whistle, I Whistle, Romanias official submission for the best foreign-language film Oscar, is a study in confinement. Like many other recent Romanian films  Cristi Puius Stuff and Dough, Cristian Mungius 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days or Radu Munteans Boogie  it trails after a young protagonist whose choices are drastically limited and not very promising. Silviu, an 18-year-old inmate at a juvenile prison in a drab rural area, is a few weeks from the end of a four-year sentence, but the idea that his release will bring any kind of freedom seems like a delusion or a cruel joke.

title: MWW, P.R. Agency, Buys Itself Back from Interpublic
description: The MWW Group, a public relations agency that was acquired by the Interpublic Group of Companies a decade ago, has bought itself back in a buyout led by management. The financial terms of the deal are not being disclosed.

title: Arlen Specter to Teach at  Law School
description: Arlen Specter, the veteran Republican senator from Pennsylvania who switched parties and then lost in the Democratic primary, will teach law at the University of Pennsylvania, the school announced Tuesday.

title: Tablet Sales to Spike in 2011, Forrester Says
description: The tablets are coming! The tablets are coming!

title: Delving Into the Broadway Playbook to Stay Open
description: In the face of daunting odds  odds that led nine Broadway shows to close on Sunday  stands Lombardi, the play about the legendary Green Bay Packers coach that is the only brand-new drama to survive the fall season. The producers of Lombardi made the bullish announcement on Tuesday that they would extend ticket sales through June 19, even though the winter is traditionally a graveyard for plays like this one, which lack audience-drawing stars.

title: Would Atheros Be a Deal at $45?
description: Qualcomm may be closing in on a deal to buy Atheros Communications for $45 a share, as DealBook reported on Tuesday.

title: Deal Makers at the Head of the Class
description: 12:12 p.m. | Updated

title: For Videographers, an Upmarket Memory Card
description: Videophiles craving a speed bump in data transfer and a single memory card that can store up to two full days of the kids next birthday party in full high-definition  the cake, the sleepover, the pancakes the next morning  will have another option with Lexars new pro series.

title: A Scientists Call to Renew Both Education and Inquiry
description: James M. Salhany offered an insightful reaction to my post on George Wills column encouraging Republican lawmakers to renew lagging American investment in basic scientific inquiry. Its republished below as a Your Dot contribution.

title: Snow Plowed by City Toppled Gravestones in Brooklyn Cemetery
description: Updated, 6:10 p.m. | On Sunday, Yana Zhuravel and her family went to visit the grave of Ms. Zhuravels grandmother at a cemetery in Brooklyn.

title: Cuomo Picks Open Space Advocate for Environment Chief
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo is receiving plaudits from environmental groups for nominating Joseph Martens as the new commissioner of New York States Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: Dark, Dense Nordic Bread, Made for Butter or Cheese
description: Like many other Finns, Simo Kuusisto, a chef who trained at the French Culinary Institute, is devoted to his native whole-grain rye bread. He began baking it in New York, then went back to Finland to work with a master baker. Though he is still the chef at the Canadian mission to the United Nations, he and his brother, Tuomas (left), turn out their Nordic breads at night, in a bakery in Queens. They are increasing production, which stands at 2,500 breads a week, because of demand on the Internet.

title: Preserved Tomatoes Bring a Fresh Note to Winter
description: A new preserved tomato can go a long way to brighten a pasta sauce or a pizza in the cold months. The exotic piennolo is a large, deeply flavored, fleshy cherry tomato, ripened in clusters, and at once richly sweet and tart. These imports preserved in jars are grown organically in the rich soil of Mount Vesuvius National Park. Unlike the famous San Marzanos, the iconic plum tomatoes from Southern Italy that stand up to long simmering, piennolos have uncommon freshness for a product in a jar and are best with only brief heating. For pasta, simply warm them very gently with olive oil and garlic. They are ideal when quickly baking fish. And lightly crushed, they can go directly onto pizza without being turned into sauce.

title: The Now-You-See-It Restaurant
description: JOHN FRASERS new restaurant is doomed. It may make a splash at the start, but by this time next year it will be over, done with, kaput.

title: Spice Mixer to the Chefs Opens a Store
description: Lior Lev Sercarz, a chef who worked for Daniel Boulud, has been concocting spice blends for chefs for several years. Now he has opened a spare gallerylike space, La Bote  Epice, where he makes and sells 40 blends, often named for a place that inspired them. He will also make custom blends. Why his blends?

title: Mehtaphor
description: 130 Duane Street (Church Street), Duane Street Hotel; (212) 542-9440, mehtaphornyc.com.

title: Off the Menu
description: OPENING

title: Dining Calendar
description: Farmers Market Inside

title: The Humble Plate of Hash Has Nobler Ambitions
description: I WOULD never call myself a meat-and-potatoes guy, said Robert Newton, the chef at Seersucker in Brooklyn, where the country pork hash has a devoted following. But I really like hash.

title: Israeli Military Officials Challenge Account of Palestinian Womans Death
description: BILIN, West Bank  Clashing narratives over the case of a 36-year-old Palestinian woman who died on Saturday are fast making her a new symbol of the enduring conflict here, with the Israeli military anonymously casting doubt on Palestinian accounts  backed by medical documents  that she died from inhaling tear gas.

title: Theres No I in Spurs
description: During the Tim Duncan era, the San Antonio Spurs have come to define the precious N.B.A. commodities of stability, continuity and internal comity.

title: Escaped From Belarus, Actors Raise Voices
description: For most performers invited to this years Under the Radar festival of international alternative theater, which begins Wednesday, getting to New York is simply a matter of boarding a plane. But for the Belarus Free Theater, a politically engaged troupe used to living and working on the edge in an authoritarian state, the long trip from Minsk was a little more complicated.

title: Is Ballet Dying? Sure, Its Died Many Times
description: Each ballet dies with the fall of the curtain. Will it return to real life when next danced? Nobody can be sure. Some dances need occasional periods in cold storage; others  having forever passed their sell-by dates  carry on in some macabre afterlife onstage that feels spectral. For those of us who adored a work in its youth, which alternative is grimmer: never to see it again or to watch it acquire the lines of age and then become one of the dance dead or, worse, undead?

title: Aspiring to Musical Power and Glory
description: To say that the 1960s folk singer Phil Ochs dreamed big is to understate the huge scope of his ambition. As recalled in Kenneth Bowsers respectful, nonmaudlin documentary portrait, Phil Ochs: There but for Fortune, Ochs moved to New York in the early 60s intending to be the best songwriter in the country. After meeting Bob Dylan, Ochs was forced to revise his opinion of his own potential to second best.

title: A Warning on Reining in Filibusters
description: Senator Lamar Alexander derided Democrats efforts to rein in the use of filibusters in the Senate as a brazen power grab and warned of guaranteed retribution when Republicans return to the majority.

title: Congress to Return With G.O.P. Vowing to Alter Rules
description: WASHINGTON  Here is how most people think laws get made in this town: A member of Congress introduces a bill, his colleagues express great love/outrage/urgency about the bill in front of C-Span, and members decide to pass or defeat it in a roll-call vote.

title: Reading Tweets Instead of Tea Leaves
description: Call it a sign of the times. Or a way of looking at the glass as half-full, rather than half-empty.

title: A Turnaround for Anadarko
As a Hot Ticket, Will True Grit Sway the Oscars?
description: LOS ANGELES  As True Grit shows signs of becoming the Oscar seasons first breakout hit, it is reviving a question that has long shadowed the Academy Awards: Does the audience get a vote?

title: Dont Call It a Cracker: Wheat Thins Prefers to Be Billed as a Snack
description: LIKE ready-made pie crusts, crackers are marketed not just on their merits but also on what consumers put on them, so packages often show crackers topped with artfully arranged cheese, diced vegetables and dip.

title: Christie Seeks to Relax Rules on Who Can Lead Schools
description: Gov. Chris Christie is pressing for regulations that would allow some New Jersey school districts to hire superintendents without traditional academic backgrounds or experience, in an effort to change confining state rules like those that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had to surmount to win approval for Cathleen P. Black, his choice for New York City schools chancellor.

title: Taking DNA Sequencing to the Masses
description: Jonathan M. Rothberg fancies himself the Steve Jobs of biotechnology. While much less known than the Apple leader, Dr. Rothberg is also a wealthy entrepreneur with a reputation as a visionary, a masterful promoter and a demanding boss.

title: The Bachelor Returns
description: The 15th edition of the dating series The Bachelor made its debut on Monday night, lifting ABC to second place in the prime-time ratings among the major broadcast networks. According to Nielsens estimates, 9 million viewers tuned in to that reality shows two-hour premiere, down slightly from the 9.5 million who watched the first installment of the series last January. CBS led the night over all with new episodes of its comedy lineup, including Two and a Half Men (15.3 million) and Mike & Molly (12.6 million) in the 9 p.m. hour, after How I Met Your Mother (10.4 million) and Rules of Engagement (9.9 million) at 8 and 8:30. CBSs Hawaii Five-0 won the 10 p.m. hour with 10.8 million viewers, edging ahead of ABCs Castle (9.6 million). Fox was third with reruns of House (4.8 million) and Lie to Me (3.9 million), while NBC ranked fourth, earning an average of 2.8 million viewers from 9 to 11 for a Where Are They Now? retrospective edition of The Biggest Loser following a repeat of Chuck (2.5 million).

title: Daily Show Is Losing an Executive Producer
description: The morning after taping his first Daily Show of the new year, Jon Stewart said on Tuesday that one of his executive producers, Josh Lieb, was leaving that satiric newscast to write a sitcom for Warner Brothers and NBC. At the same time, Mr. Stewart, who along with Rory Albanese is also an executive producer of the show, announced a restructuring. He named three longtime staff members, Steve Bodow, Jennifer Flanz and Jim Margolis, co-executive producers; named Pam DePace a supervising producer; and promoted Tim Carvell to head writer. He did not elaborate on the reasons for the changes. Mr. Lieb had been an executive producer of The Daily Show for two years, and a co-executive producer for three years prior.

title: Republicans Lower Goal for Cuts to Budget
description: WASHINGTON  Many people knowledgeable about the federal budget said House Republicans could not keep their campaign promise to cut $100 billion from domestic spending in a single year. Now it appears that Republicans agree.

title: Resurgent Turkey Flexes Its Muscles Around Iraq
description: ZAKHO, Iraq  A Turkey as resurgent as at any time since its Ottoman glory is projecting influence through a turbulent Iraq, from the boomtowns of the north to the oil fields near southernmost Basra, in a show of power that illustrates its growing heft across an Arab world long suspicious of it.

title: Ab Simon, Chairman of Seagram Wine Unit, Dies at 88
description: Ab Simon, who as the longtime chairman of the Seagram Chateau & Estate Wines Company was a commanding figure in the American wine trade and a leading importer of fine Bordeaux to the United States, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.

title: Part of California Takes On Illegal Hiring
description: MURRIETA, Calif.  Protests erupted across Southern California last year when Arizona adopted its tough immigration law: immigrant rights advocates staged rallies in cities like San Diego and Santa Barbara; Los Angeles severed economic ties with Arizona.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,433 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Tuesday:

title: Kevin Browns Contract: Another View
description: In a recent Keeping Score column, Dan Rosenheck makes the case that the Dodgers did not make out so badly as commonly believed when they signed Kevin Brown to a $105 million, seven-year deal in 1998. In it, he quoted Maury Brown, who runs the Web site Biz of Baseball and who takes a more negative view of the deal. Maury Brown continues the discussion over at his site:

title: Announcers Words Cost Him His Job at ESPN
description: ESPN fired the announcer Ron Franklin on Tuesday, four days after his remarks to a sideline reporter before the broadcast of the Chick-fil-A Bowl caused him to be suspended from calling the Fiesta Bowl on radio.

title: Victory Alone Does Not a Mandate Make
description: WASHINGTON

title: Boomers, at 65, Are ...What, Exactly?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Bearded Dandy of Brooklyn
description: OUIGI THEODORE, the founder of the Brooklyn Circus, a retro-urban fashion boutique and label, has heard it all before: dandy, preppy, Anglophile, fop. Still, he was flummoxed when a customer walked into his boutique a year ago, took one look at the bow ties and straw boaters for sale, and declared it the height of steampunk.

title: Flawed E.P.A. Policies
description: To the Editor:

title: Workplace Workouts
description: To the Editor:

title: How Treasury Licenses Goods to Sanctioned Nations
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuomo Starts Term With Some Top Jobs Still Empty
description: As Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo prepares to unveil an emergency financial reinvention plan for New York State in his address to the Legislature on Wednesday, senior positions remain unfilled throughout the very bureaucracy he is trying to tame, raising questions about the pace of his transition.

title: Milwaukee Archdiocese Seeks Chapter 11
description: The Roman Catholic archbishop of Milwaukee, Jerome E. Listecki, announced Tuesday that the archdiocese had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, saying it would allow the church to continue its ministry while giving fair compensation to the victims of sexual abuse by priests.

title: An Electronics Show That Media Companies Dare Not Miss
description: LAS VEGAS  When ESPN announced a high-definition channel nine years ago, its executives barely knew about the Consumer Electronics Association.

title: G.O.P. Asks Businesses Which Rules to Rewrite
description: WASHINGTON  Companies spend millions of dollars each year complaining to Congress about burdensome laws and regulations, pressing their concerns in public campaigns and in private meetings. They rarely wait for invitations.

title: For Carroll and Bush, Tepid Reunion Awaits
description: Reggie Bush and Pete Carroll will share the field again on a Saturday afternoon. But it will feel little like the sunny days of success at Southern California.

title: Prices Still Soaring in a Toronto District Newly Fashionable
description: TORONTO  Once a hodgepodge of textile factories and auto lots, the fashion district here has rapidly evolved into upscale restaurants and boutiques in refurbished warehouses and residential units in sleek glass structures.

title: Budget Hawk Eyes Deficit
description: Indianapolis

title: On the Way Out, a Governor Takes a Controversial Step
description: A week before leaving office, Gov. Bill Ritter Jr. announced Tuesday that Colorado would participate in a federal background check program devised to catch illegal immigrants who have committed crimes.

title: Colts Follow Strange Path to Usual Spot
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Peyton Manning unintentionally distilled the Indianapolis Colts unorthodox season into a single backhanded compliment on Tuesday. Asked why he kept throwing to Pierre Garcon last Sunday against the Titans, even though Garcon had a few early drops, Manning blurted out a fundamental truth about a team whose season has played out as much on the injured reserve list as in the statistics sheets.

title: The Top 10 Travel Stories of 2010
Wanted: New Chiefs of Staff for Obama and Biden
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. are both looking for new chiefs of staff now. Those are the more prominent changes under consideration for a midterm makeover that so far suggests continuity more than a shakeup.

title: N.F.L. Declined to View Favre Texts, Lawyer Says
description: A lawyer for the massage therapists who sued Brett Favre and the Jets on Monday said N.F.L. investigators looking into a separate sexual harassment allegation declined his offer to view text messages and other documents that he said demonstrated Favres misconduct.

title: How One Police Dept. Reached 2 Rulings on a Shooting
description: In August 2009, a New York Police Department panel, after reviewing evidence and interviews with police officers, school safety agents and a civilian witness, signed off on a decision in the fatal police shooting of a day laborer nine months earlier: Officer Dawn Ortizs use of deadly physical force was within department guidelines.

title: Turkeys Soft Power in Iraq
description: Turkey has been exerting influence in Iraq through culture, education and business.

title: New York Tourism Hit Record High in 2010, Mayor Says
description: Despite the lingering effects of the recession, more people visited New York City in 2010 than in any other year, according to an estimate Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced on Tuesday.

title: The Precarious Position of Lt. Reese
description: Today Disunion begins an occasional series about the lives of individual soldiers during the Civil War  North and South, black and white. Compiled and written by Ronald S. Coddington, author of Faces of the Civil War and Faces of the Confederacy, the series will give readers a sense of the war beyond the headlines and history books, a sense of what it meant to the millions of ordinary men who entered into, and often never left, that great American conflict.

title: Goldmans Mutual Friend
description: Can Goldman Sachs, the profit-seeking missile of high finance, really make money by investing $450 million in Facebook, at a vertigo-inducing price that values the social-networking company at $50 billion?

title: The Mess At Michigan Will Be Hard To Clean Up
description: Firing a college football coach is a lot like getting a divorce. It is almost impossible to imagine a way for things to go smoothly. Both sides have tricky financial issues to deal with, difficult family consequences to overcome and an awkwardness that passes only with time.

title: Pesticides Threaten Ant-Eating Tradition in Brazil
description: SILVEIRAS, Brazil  Jorge da Silva plucked a giant ant from the muddy ground, pulled off its wings, legs and mandible, and tossed it into his mouth like popcorn.

title: A New Fashion Image for Urban America
description: The Brooklyn Circus, a a retro-urban fashion boutique and label, produced a photo shoot featuring friends and employees in the streets of San Francisco and Brooklyn, which will be published in an upcoming book.

title: American Airlines in Fee Battle With Web Agencies
description: A traveler searching two of the four largest online travel agencies, Orbitz and Expedia, is not going to find any listings for American Airlines flights  at least for the moment.

title: Viewership Less Urgent as Bowls Go to Cable
description: All at once this January, the Bowl Championship Series games that were broadcast fixtures were instead on cable.

title: Blizzard Cleanup Is Subject of Inquiry
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn have opened a preliminary investigation into allegations that disgruntled sanitation workers sabotaged the cleanup after the blizzard last week that left some neighborhoods snowbound for days, people who have been briefed on the inquiry said Tuesday.

title: As Boehner Ascends, His Power Comes With Caveats
description: WASHINGTON  Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio is set to complete a remarkable political revival Wednesday when he becomes the 61st speaker of the House, placing him squarely at the crossroads between the desires of conservative activists to reshape Washington and the reality of delivering in a divided capital.

title: A Title Change, but the Tears Will Stay
description: WASHINGTON  It is a habit that Representative John A. Boehner is making no effort to kick.

title: Pomp, and Little Circumstance
description: A theatrical production of unusual pomposity will open on Wednesday when Republicans assume control of the House for the 112th Congress. A rule will be passed requiring that every bill cite its basis in the Constitution. A bill will be introduced to repeal the health care law. On Thursday, the Constitution will be read aloud in the House chamber. And in one particularly self-important flourish, the new speaker, John Boehner, arranged to have his office staff sworn in on Tuesday by the chief justice of the United States.

title: A Brave Man Killed
description: Some twisted person has created a Facebook page in support of Malik Mumtaz Hussain Qadri, the bodyguard accused of assassinating Salman Taseer, the governor of Pakistans Punjab province. Mr. Taseer was a brave man who had called for the repeal of Pakistans outrageous anti-blasphemy law.

title: First, Accident. Then the Landlord. Finally, Bedbugs.
description: The walls of Hortense Bermdezs apartment are lined with her own paintings, many with an autobiographical aspect.

title: There He Goes Again
description: Justice Antonin Scalia has a knack for drawing unflattering light to himself and the Supreme Court. Recall, for example, when he refused to recuse himself from a case involving the energy task force run by Dick Cheney, his friend and duck-hunting companion, when Mr. Cheney was vice president.

title: A New, Safer Life
description: Manaf Hashim did not know who was threatening to kill him in the note left on the front door of his Baghdad home or in a message left on his cellphone two days later. He suspected he was being targeted because his fiance, Farah, was Sunni, and he was Shia. He knew only that it was best to heed such warnings.

title: Boy Whose Treatment Was Delayed by Snow Dies
description: A stricken 3-month-old boy whose medical treatment was delayed last week by unplowed streets in Queens died Tuesday afternoon at Elmhurst Hospital, paramedics said.

title: Lottery Numbers
A Profit Is Forecast in the First Year for Oprahs Network
description: Discovery Communications expects Oprah Winfreys cable channel to achieve profitability in its first year.

title: Worry of Tainted Wafers Scares Church
description: MASSAPEQUA PARK, N.Y.  It was not the first time a health scare had infiltrated the sanctuary of a Roman Catholic church. The bodily contact in certain church rituals has made some people wary of touching hands or sharing chalices of altar wine during every public health emergency, real or imagined, of the last few decades.

title: Selig Is Said to Be Unsatisfied With Unions Stance on Boras
description: Major League Baseballs players union has sent a letter to the commissioners office stating that the agent, Scott Boras, did not violate its regulations when he provided tens of thousands of dollars in loans to a teenage Dominican prospect, according to several people in baseball briefed on the matter.

title: Panel Unveils Ways to Improve New Jerseys Public Universities
description: A task force appointed by Gov. Chris Christie to suggest ways of improving New Jerseys public colleges and universities made dozens of recommendations on Tuesday, including lifting tuition caps and reorganizing the long-troubled University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey.

title: A Spurs Rookie Excels by Being a Man of Mystery
description: Gary Neal is a vital role player for the N.B.A. team with the best record, one of the top rookies in the league and the name most likely to elicit this one-word response: Who?

title: Wednesday: Putting the Cart Before the Puzzle
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  When you sit down to solve a crossword puzzle, where do your eyes fall first?

title: Toward a Nuclear Test Ban: Why a Treaty Is Viable
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Veterans Leave Village Voice
description: What becomes of New Yorks most formidable muckraking paper when two of its greatest muckrakers are gone?

title: Jets Taking Pressure Off Improved Sanchez
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Rex Ryan opened his news conference Tuesday by saying that Mark Sanchez was one of six Jets who did not participate fully in practice, but Ryan added less than two minutes later that Sanchez appeared to do better as practice went on. He can zip it, no question, Ryan said.

title: Iraq: Free Speech Protests in Kurdistan
description: More than a thousand protesters took to the main street in Erbil, the Kurdish regional capital, to condemn a new law requiring all public demonstrations to have government permits. Protesters said the law was part of a broader crackdown on free speech in Iraqs semiautonomous Kurdistan region. In the past six months, the government has sued at least 60 writers or media organizations for publishing work critical of the government, according to the Kurdistan Journalists Syndicate. Aso Karim, a lawmaker with the Kurdistan Democratic Party, said the restrictions were necessary because Iraq is not politically stable.

title: Firs for the Fish (and the Fishermen)
description: For people like Pete Alexander, the best gifts arrive after the holidays.

title: Rockies Continue To Invest In Future
description: No team has spent more money this off-season than the Colorado Rockies. Most of it has gone toward re-signing their core players, and the latest beneficiary is the star outfielder Carlos Gonzalez, who has agreed to a seven-year, $80 million extension. The deal, confirmed Tuesday by a person in baseball with knowledge of the contract, is pending a physical.

title: Borders Discusses Deferred Payments With Publishers
description: Borders began holding talks with publishers on Tuesday, seeking to convert delayed payments into interest-bearing debt as part of a plan to refinance its debt, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: Publisher Tinkers With Twain
description: A new edition of Adventures of Huckleberry Finn is missing something.

title: Israel: An Appeal for a Spys Release
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Tuesday read aloud in Parliament a letter asking President Obama for clemency for Jonathan Jay Pollard, left, the American serving a life term in a United States prison for spying for Israel. The letter, which was sent this week, constitutes the first formal and public Israeli appeal for Mr. Pollards release. Even though Israel was in no way directing its intelligence efforts against the United States, Mr. Netanyahu wrote, its actions were wrong and wholly unacceptable. After 25 years in prison, he added, Mr. Pollard has reportedly served longer in prison than any person convicted of similar crimes, and longer than the period requested by the prosecutors at the time of his plea bargain agreement. Obama administration officials recently indicated that Mr. Pollards release was unlikely.

title: Gerry Rafferty, Songwriter, Dies at 63
description: Gerry Rafferty, a Scottish singer and songwriter who combined a gift for melody, a distinctive voice and a fatalistic worldview to produce 1970s hits like Stuck in the Middle With You and Baker Street, died Tuesday in Dorset, England. He was 63.

title: Argentina: Thieves Tunneled Into Bank
description: Thieves working for at least six months dug a tunnel underneath a bank in Buenos Aires and robbed 143 safety deposit boxes containing an estimated $6.5 million during New Years weekend, a bank official and prosecutor said. At least three robbers entered Banco de la Provincia in the Belgrano neighborhood on Dec. 31 and left on Jan. 3 at 7 a.m., three hours before the bank reopened after New Year, Martn Niklison, a prosecutor, said on television on Monday. The thieves rented a former dentists office nearly 100 feet from the bank and then dug a tunnel that ran about 16 feet underground before reaching the basement of the bank. The banks alarm sounded at least twice during the robbery but the police, lacking keys to the bank, left after not seeing anything from outside the bank, he said.

title: U.S. Arms Dealer Sentenced for Scheme to Ship Prohibited Chinese Ammunition
description: A young Miami Beach arms dealer who admitted to defrauding the Pentagon in a munitions contract was sentenced on Monday to four years in federal prison, bringing a case that embarrassed the Pentagon closer to its end. The dealer, Efraim Diveroli, 25, was president of AEY Inc., a fledgling company that surprised industry insiders in 2007 when the United States Army awarded it a $300 million contract to supply ordnance to Afghan security forces. Mr. Diveroli pleaded guilty to plotting to ship prohibited Chinese ammunition to the war. Four men have been convicted in the scheme. Mr. Diveroli is awaiting sentencing for a separate charge of possessing a firearm while on bail.

title: Jill Haworth, Original Sally in Cabaret, Dies at 65
description: Jill Haworth, a British-born film ingnue in the 1960s who made her only Broadway appearance as the original Sally Bowles in Cabaret, died Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 65.

title: California: Judges Ask for Clarity on Same-Sex Marriage Measure
description: A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, asked the California Supreme Court for guidance on Tuesday on the issue of standing in a federal challenge to Proposition 8, the states voter-approved ban on same-sex marriage. The order, asking for clarification of California law, comes after former Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger and his successor, Gov. Jerry Brown, refused to defend the proposition in court. That has left the defense primarily to conservative legal groups and proponents of the measure. In August, a federal district judge ruled Proposition 8 to be unconstitutional, but that ruling was appealed to the Ninth Circuit panel. Also Tuesday, the panel denied Imperial County, in Southern California, the right to intervene on the behalf of Proposition 8.

title: Massachusetts: Shahs Son Found Dead
description: The youngest son of the former shah of Iran was found dead Tuesday in his Boston apartment, according to his brothers Web site. Prince Alireza Pahlavi struggled for years to overcome his sorrow and in his Boston residence, took his own life, plunging his family and friends into great sorrow, said a note on the Web site of his brother Reza Pahlavi. The prince, 44, died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound, a spokesman for the Suffolk County District Attorneys office said. His father, Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, ruled Iran from 1941 until he was overthrown in 1979; he died in Egypt in 1980. Alireza Pahlavi had studied at Harvard Divinity School.

title: Illinois: Another Ruling Favors Emanuel in Chicago Residency Dispute
description: Rahm Emanuel cleared another hurdle in his bid for mayor of Chicago on Tuesday when a Cook County judge agreed with the citys election board that his name should appear on the ballot this year. The judge, Mark J. Ballard, upheld the boards decision that Mr. Emanuel met the one-year residency requirement for mayoral candidates. Several objectors have said that Mr. Emanuel gave up his residency when he worked in Washington as President Obamas chief of staff until last fall. Opponents plan to appeal.

title: 11 Tricks to Cutting Travel Costs in 2011
description: BARGAIN hunters will need to be craftier when booking a trip if they want to get the best prices this year. Its no secret that airfares are up and added fees for everything from checked bags to exit-row seats are pushing the cost of flying higher. On top of that, hotel bargains are expected to be harder to come by as business travelers begin to return, diminishing the need for hotels to discount rooms in major cities.

title: A Guide to Cheap Buses (Including How to Score $1 Tickets)
description: Im an ideal customer for all of those low-cost bus lines that run from New York to Bostonand Washington and Philadelphia: I dont own a car. Im cheapskate by both nature and by trade. And I have good reasons to visit two of the three cities from my home in New York  my parents live outside Boston and my brothers family lives outside Washington. If a brain injury transformed me into a Phillies fan, Id have the trifecta.

title: The Work of Hortense Bermdez
description: Hortense Bermdezs paintings are often autobiographical, like the one of a woman sleeping, unaware of the insect invaders in her apartment.

title: Boy Is Critically Hurt in Brooklyn Hit-Run
description: A 2-year-old boy was critically injured in Brooklyn on Tuesday night when he was hit by a van whose driver then fled the scene, the police said.

title: Two Tied for Lead of Reggio Emilia Chess Tournament
Knicks Win a Shootout Against a Top Team
description: Tim Duncan wiggled and launched his reliable bank shot through the net. Landry Fields shook free from Manu Ginobili and dunked off a lob from Amare Stoudemire. The first shots of the game began a night of rapid-fire baskets, defense forgotten and offense applauded Tuesday at Madison Square Garden.

title: Mitch Danielss Fiscal Blemishes
description: Mitch Danielss record as a fiscal conservative  the subject of my column this week  has at least two blemishes.

title: U.S. Alters Rule on Paying for End-of-Life Planning
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration, reversing course, will revise a Medicare regulation to delete references to end-of-life planning as part of the annual physical examinations covered under the new health care law, administration officials said Tuesday.

title: Police Officers Killed in Rare Burst of Gun Violence in China
description: BEIJING  Two men wielding a shotgun and a homemade pistol fatally shot three police officers and an assistant and staged a series of carjackings in a city in northeastern China, state news media reported Wednesday, a rare example of gun violence in a nation where average citizens are largely barred from owning firearms.

title: Phys Ed: Does Exercising Make You Drink More Alcohol?
description: Can regular exercise avert or undo some of the harm associated with binge drinking? Perhaps even better, could exercising beforehand pre-emptively reduce your urge to overindulge in alcohol later? Or does exercising actually drive you to drink? Those questions, relevant to any of us whose memories of New Years Eve are fuzzy, have been the subject of a growing number of studies recently, with thought-provoking results.

title: Word of the Day | slapdash
description: slapdash \slap-dash, -dash\ adjective

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Arrested Chess Players Walk Free
description: Two men who decided to fight charges against them for playing chess in a park have had the charges dismissed.

title: Big Paydays for Merriman
description: Shawne Merrimans new year is off to a good start. On Saturday, Merriman, the Buffalo Bills star linebacker, signed a two-year contract extension reportedly worth up to $9 million. On Tuesday, a federal judge in Maryland awarded him $3.8 million to settle a suit he filed against the former Duke basketball players Christian Laettner and Brian Davis. Merriman was trying to recoup the $3 million that he lent to Laettner and Davis, who invested the money in real estate. Laettner and Davis stopped paying back the loan in 2009.

title: News Quiz | January 5, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Oberthur Presses De La Rue for Disclosure
description: De La Rue, a troubled British maker of paper for currency printing, should come clean about the state of an important contract with the Reserve Bank of India, according to the French company that approached it last month with an unsolicited takeover offer, David Jolly reports in The New York Times.

title: Buffett on Berkshire, Succession and America
description: Warren E. Buffett gave Vanity Fair an 11-hour tour of Omaha, talking about his succession plans, Berkshire culture, what he hates most about his job, and the 10 most immortal words in the history of economics.

title: Daily Lexeme: Mere-Goutte
description: Todays word, in association with the exalted Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Floodwaters Surge to a Peak in Northeastern Australia
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Floodwaters appeared to be at or near their peak across much of tropical, northeastern Australia on Wednesday, with inundations affecting 40 towns and cities, as an army general was named to lead efforts to cope with the disaster.

title: 5,000 Dead Blackbirds Over Arkansas
description: WHY was New Years Eve in Beebe, Ark., freakishly disturbing?

title: Test Yourself | Math, Jan. 5, 2011
description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the article Math Puzzles Oldest Ancestors Took Form on Egyptian Papyrus.

title: Communist Party News Site Set for I.P.O.
description: Here is one way of getting the people involved in Peoples Daily, the state-run Chinese newspaper.

title: Out of Sight, Very Much in Mind
description: Marisol Torres, 33, has lived in New York City all her life. She can no longer see it. But that doesnt mean she isnt immersed in its sensations.

title: When Have You Gotten a Lucky Break?
description: A New York Times photographer accidentally got on the wrong train, and as a result, ended up being in the right place at the right time to take a great photograph that ran on the front page of the newspaper. When have you gotten lucky?

title: Chinas Push to Modernize Military Is Bearing Fruit
description: BEIJING  Secretary of Defense Robert M. Gates, on a mission to resuscitate moribund military relations with China, will not arrive in Beijing for talks with the nations top military leaders until Sunday. But at an airfield in Chengdu, a metropolis in the nations center, Chinas military leaders have already rolled out a welcome for him.

title: F.D.I.C. Seeks $2.5 Billion From Executives of Failed Banks
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said on Tuesday that as of mid-December it had authorized lawsuits against 109 directors and officers of failed financial institutions in an effort to recover nearly $2.5 billion.

title: Assessing the Housing Sector
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: All Hands on Deck for London Boat Show
description: An unusual combination of remarkable boats and water-based entertainment, the Tullett Prebon London International Boat Show attracted 100,000 visitors last year. The crowds turned out not only to see expensive and innovative super yachts like the Sunseeker 40M, which cost about 12 million (about $18,350,000), but also to learn about and try numerous water-based activities.
