title: The Early Word: Coming Back
description: In Todays Times:

title: Republicans Set to Wield New Power in Washington
description: 7:27 a.m. | Updated Republicans will lay claim to a broad  if partial  governing mandate at exactly noon on Wednesday, ushering into Washington scores of new conservative lawmakers who promise to challenge President Obamas vision for Americas economic future.

title: How Good Is Peyton Manning? Texans and Jaguars Provide a Clue
description: Chase Stuart contributes to the Pro-Football-Reference.com blog and to Footballguys.com.

title: Q.&A. With Gov. Mitch Daniels
description: Following are excerpts of my recent interview with Mitch Daniels, the Republican governor of Indiana:

title: Youre Really in the Restaurant Business Now
description: Twas the second day after Christmas and all through the front of the house, not a creature was stirring except the guy who was soused. Outside, the snow was two feet and drifting, with patches of ice and treachery. We had 50 reservations confirmed, a handful of walk-ins promised, and a few more tables waiting to hear back from us. But two servers were snowbound, the bartender was stranded, the hostess wouldnt budge, one busboy was missing and another was relying on unreliable public transportation.

title: Assassination Deepens Divide in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The emotional funeral of the assassinated governor of Punjab and the cheering of his killer in court Wednesday highlighted the intensifying struggle between secular and religious forces in Pakistan that has grown nastier than ever in the countrys history.

title: Video: Kurdistans Booming Economy
description: In the Times, Anthony Shadid reports on the growing economic influence of Turkey in northern Iraq.

title: Kurdistan's Booming Economy
description: Businesses are setting up in the flush Iraqi Kurdish region, reports The Times's Anthony Shadid, and keeping an eye on the south of the country.

title: Qualcomm to Buy Atheros for $45 a Share
description: Qualcomm, the wireless technology company, has agreed to buy the chip maker Atheros Communications for $3.1 billion, or $45 a share, in a deal that underscores the growing importance of smartphones and tablet computers.

title: Colts, Jets and History of Playoff Rematches
description: Chase Stuart contributes to the Pro-Football-Reference.com blog and to Footballguys.com.

title: European Agency Sells Billions in Bonds to Rescue Ireland
description: The European Union began issuing bonds on Wednesday to finance its rescue fund for Ireland, even as Portugal was required to pay more to sell short-term debt.

title: Shes Back! Abdul Makes Nice on New Dance Show
description: Dancing was the least competitive element of Live to Dance. The talent contest, which had its premiere on CBS Tuesday night, marks the return of Paula Abdul, who was replaced by Ellen DeGeneres on American Idol last year and is now making a told-you-so comeback that upstaged most of the amateurs who twirled, leaped, tapped and break-danced the night away.

title: Bono Sees Spider-Man for First Time
description: More than five weeks after his musical, Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, began preview performances on Broadway, U2s lead singer, Bono, saw the show for the first time on Tuesday night, gauging audience reaction while assessing for himself what is and isnt working in the $65 million spectacle.

title: Fiscal Shock
description: I see that the Washington Post editorial board is shocked, shocked to discover that the incoming Republicans arent serious about deficit reduction. Who could have suspected?

title: Twitter on Sale! Buy Now!
description: The frenzy over shares of private Internet companies seems to be reaching a fever pitch.

title: Morning Buzz | Sentencing in a 1968 Hijacking
description: Wednesday will be partly cloudy and a touch warmer than the past few days, with highs around 40.

title: In Bay Area Shake-Up, Where Does Harbaugh Land?
description: Tom Cable is out as Oakland coach. The 49ers hired Trent Baalke as their general manager, and now he will look to hire a coach.Could it be Jim Harbaugh? If so, Stanford will be looking for a coach. It all made for a seismic day in Bay Area football.

title: Texas Update
description: Speaking of mythical fiscally responsible Republicans, I see that Matt Yglesias is on to the myth of the Texas balanced budget. I would add that the miraculous Texas immunity to the recession is equally mythical:

title: The Most Wonderful Times of the Year
description: Last year was generally happier and less stressful for Americans than the previous two years were, according to the latest data from the Gallup-Healthways Well-Being Index.

title: Vain Glorious | An Uplifting Little Spritz
description: What: La Prairie Cellular Energizing Body Spray, which originally launched in 2005, is one of our favorite mid-day pick-me-ups that doesnt contain caffeine or sugar.

title: A.I.G. Received $3 Billion Bid for Taiwan Unit
description: American International Group, the insurance giant selling assets to pay back its government bailout, told the Securities and Exchange Commission in November that it had received an unsolicited $3 billion bid for its Taiwan unit, Nan Shan Life Insurance  an offer well above the divisions going price last summer.

title: An Early Wake-Up Call for MoNique
description: The job of announcing the Oscar nominees very, very early on the morning of Jan. 25 will fall to MoNique, the Academy has announced. Last years best-supporting-actress winner, MoNique will share the duties of naming names in 10 of 24 categories with the Academys president, Tom Sherak. (Maybe hell warm up with an appearance on her BET talk show? The Bagger would like to see him do a little something with Waka Flocka Flame.)

title: Gibbs to Leave as White House Press Secretary
description: 10:30 a.m. | Updated Robert Gibbs, the White House press secretary and close confidante to President Obama, said Wednesday that he was stepping down to become an outside political adviser to the president and his re-election campaign.

title: Regression Is Probable for Chiefs, Bucs and Rams
description: Luis DeLoureiro operates NFLStatAnalysis.net and is a contributor to the Cold Hard Football Facts.

title: Wolf Market
description: A volatile financial market characterised by rapid price changes.

title: Anyone Have a  Revival Handy? There Could Be a Tony in It for You
description: It looks more and more likely that only two musical revivals will open on Broadway this season  How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying and Anything Goes  which would leave two slots empty in the category of best revival of a musical at the 2011 Tony Awards in June.

title: U.N. Data Notes Sharp Rise in World Food Prices
description: World food prices continued to rise sharply in December, bringing them close to the crisis levels that provoked shortages and riots in poor countries three years ago, according to newly released United Nations data.

title: Cyberspace When Youre Dead
description: Suppose that just after you finish reading this article, you keel over, dead. Perhaps youre ready for such an eventuality, in that you have prepared a will or made some sort of arrangement for the fate of the worldly goods you leave behind: financial assets, personal effects, belongings likely to have sentimental value to others and artifacts of your life like photographs, journals, letters. Even if you havent made such arrangements, all of this will get sorted one way or another, maybe in line with what you would have wanted, and maybe not.

title: Head of Kennedy Center to Give Management Seminars in Africa
description: Michael M. Kaiser, the president of the Kennedy Center, who doubles as an arts management guru, is taking his show on the road next month  to Africa. Over a week, he will give arts management seminars in five cities: Lagos, Nigeria; Kampala, Uganda; Nairobi, Kenya; Zanzibar, Tanzania; and Harare, Zimbabwe. The one-day sessions will be hosted by local arts leaders who have taken part in the Kennedy Centers Summer International Fellowship program for arts managers.

title: An iPhone Holder Thats Cuckoo
description: I have to admit its cute.

title: Boy Stabbed Outside School in Bronx
description: Updated 4:06 p.m. | A 16-year-old special education student was stabbed in the neck on his way to a school in the Bronx on Wednesday morning, officials said.

title: Barington Seeks Ouster of Amerons Chief
description: Normally known for its quiet efforts to nudge companies to change, the hedge fund Barington Capital Group is taking the gloves off.

title: Wednesday Reading: A Cheap Bus Guide
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Why Facebook is not going public: This is Zuckerbergs company, and hes going to run it.

title: Keeping Women in Science on a Tenure Track
description: More women are obtaining Ph.D.s in science than ever before, but those women  largely because of pressures from having a family  are far more likely than their male counterparts to leak out of the research science pipeline before obtaining tenure at a college or university.

title: Adolph Zukor Is Dead at 103; Built Paramount Movie Empire
description: Adolph Zukor, who made entertainment history in 1912 when he offered the American public its first feature-length film, died at his Century City apartment in Los Angeles yesterday. He was 103 years old.

title: Hanoi Reports Cambodian Capital Conquered By 'Insurgent' Forces; Long Guerrilla Conflict Feared
description: Bangkok, Thailand, Jan. 7 -- The Cambodian capital, Phnom Penh, was captured today, Vietnam and the insurgent front it is backing in Cambodia announced tonight.

title: For Blyleven, Whats the Cap?
description: It is the seventh inning of Game 5 of the 1979 World Series, a potential elimination game for the Pittsburgh Pirates, and with a one-run lead, Bert Blyleven is making the Baltimore Orioles look silly. He strikes out Doug DeCinces on three pitches, and the ABC broadcasters rave.

title: Goldman-Facebook Deal Raises Debate on Investor Pool
description: 7:46 p.m. | Updated

title: The Favorites Show Up in Production Design Nods
description: The Art Directors Guild announced its nominees for excellence in production design today, broken up into three categories  period, fantasy and contemporary film  and guess what? Yogi Bear did not get a single nod, even though it could arguably fit in any of those slots. Among other films not doing that well with the Rotten Tomatoes crowd, Tron: Legacy and The Chronicles of Narnia: the Voyage of the Dawn Treader did earn nominations, in the fantasy category. Theyre joined there by the better-reviewed Alice in Wonderland and Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1.

title: Anti-U.S. Cleric Returns to Iraq, and to Power
description: BAGHDAD  Moktada al-Sadr, the populist cleric who emerged as the United States most enduring foe in Iraq, returned Wednesday after more than three years of voluntary exile in Iran in a homecoming that embodied his and his movements transition from battling in the streets to occupying the halls of power.

title: With Entune, Toyota Plays Catch-Up at C.E.S.
description: For years, the annual Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas has featured an automotive component: a hall dominated by subwoofers the size of pickup-truck beds, blaring loudspeakers, monster amps and product representatives wearing cowboy hats and little else. But the tuner-garage aesthetic has been treated in recent years to a digital refresh from brands like Audi, Ford, General Motors and, most recently, Toyota.

title: Microlenders, Honored With Nobel, Are Struggling
description: MUMBAI, India  Microcredit is losing its halo in many developing countries.

title: Subway Doors Sing an Unfamiliar Song
description: Here is a cool little subway mystery a reader sent in this morning.

title: President Specifies Terms Basis For World Peace; Asks Justice For Alsace-Lorraine, Applauds Russia, Tells Germany She May Be An Equal But Not A Master
description: Washington, Jan. 8 -- The terms upon which Germany may obtain peace were given to the American Congress for the benefit of the whole world by President Wilson today. With scant notice of his coming, notice barely sufficient to enable the Senate and the House to make the necessary arrangements for a joint session, the President appeared at the Capitol, and in an address, brief by comparison to the momentous issues discussed, enumerated the conditions for a cessation of hostilities, the rejection of which will place upon Germany the responsibility for the further bloodshed that must precede the final victory of the allied nations.

title: Emily Balch Dies; Won Nobel Prize
description: Cambridge, Mass., Jan. 10--Emily Greene Balch, a leader of the pacifist movement throughout the world and winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, died here yesterday at the age of 94.

title: The Significance of the Ferrari Personnel Changes
description: Ferrari made some interesting changes to its technical department on Tuesday, particularly the hiring of Neil Martin as head of operations research.

title: The Significance of the Ferrari Personnel Changes
description: Ferrari made some interesting changes to its technical department on Tuesday, particularly the hiring of Neil Martin as head of operations research.

title: Graphic Content | Really Tiny Furniture
description: I do not play with dolls, unless you count Star Wars action figures. Yet I do collect 24-tall miniature men, women and children, and even smaller furniture, which are, as my son chides, kind of like dolls, Dad.

title: Surveyor Lands Gently On Moon
description: Pasadena, Calif., Jan. 9 -- The Surveyor 7 spacecraft made a safe landing on the moon tonight, providing a triumphal conclusion to a seven year program that led to mechanized reconnaissance for a manned landing.

title: The 37th President; In Three Decades
description: To millions of Americans, Richard Milhous Nixon was the most puzzling and fascinating politician of his time. He was a man of high intelligence and innovative concepts whose talents, especially in international affairs, were widely respected by both friend and foe. Yet he was so motivated by hatreds and fears that he abused his powers and resorted to lies and cover-ups.

title: Zimbabwean Dollars Are Finally Worth Something
description: as economic souvenirs. The Associated Press reports that Western tourists visiting this hyperinflation-plagued country are snatching up trillion-dollar Zimbabwean notes for their novelty, not their value as a means of exchange:

title: Talking With the Coen Boys
description: How much of a difference does box office make to Academy voters?

title: UNO Opened; Attlee Asks World Unity
description: London, Jan. 10 -- The fifty-one nations of the greatest war-time coalition in history, representing four-fifths of the people in the world, started today another chapter in man's melancholy search for peace and security.

title: Galina Ulanova Is Dead at 88; A Revered Bolshoi Ballerina
description: MOSCOW, March 21 -- Galina Ulanova, whose uncanny blend of unabashed emotionalism and lyrical restraint made her one of the greatest dancers of the 20th century, died here today. She was 88.

title: First Ladies Obama and Bruni-Sarkozy Will Do Lunch
description: The worlds two most closely watched first ladies  Michelle Obama and Carla Bruni-Sarkozy  will meet at the White House for lunch on Monday, a senior administration official said.

title: In 500-Investor Law, Arbitrary Threshold
description: Goldman Sachs' investment in Facebook shines a harsh spotlight an nearly 50-year-old rule designed to protect investors. Some worry the regulations is easily circumvented.

title: Medicare Backs Away From End-of-Life Discussions
description: The Times reports today that doctors will not be reimbursed by Medicare for discussions about end-of-life care. The original proposal, included in early versions of the health care law, was criticized by conservatives who believed it would lead to the creation of death panels. Robert Pear writes:

title: Mess at Michigan Drags On
description: Today is one of those days when the sports news should be read while sitting down. Thats because it is necessary to pause after nearly every story and say, Huh? a few times before you go back and read it again. Also, it helps to have a free hand to slap your forehead.

title: Cosmo Goes Beyond the Burqa in the Middle East
description: Like Coke and McDonalds, Cosmopolitan is one United States brand that has a significant reach outside American borders. The magazine, which is published by Hearst Magazines and began printing in 1886, now has 61 international editions appearing in 32 languages and 100 countries including, most recently, Mongolia, a development that thrilled even Stephen Colbert.

title: Republican Allen West Joins Congressional Black Caucus
description: The all-Democrat Congressional Black Caucus welcomed its first Republican member in 14 years on Wednesday, with the swearing-in of Representative Allen B. West of Florida.

title: Can You Be Addicted to Foods?
description: Many people tend to think that all obese people have to do to solve their problems is eat less and move more. Alcoholics, on the other hand, need treatment.

title: Signs That Change Has Arrived at the Capitol
description: Change has come to Washington.

title: Sears and Urban Outfitters Circle J. Crew
description: A J. Crew store in Manhattan.

title: N.F.L. Playoff Odds and Oddities, Home and Away
description: Two visiting teams (the Saints and the Ravens) are favored in this weekends wild-card games, and it would not be stunning if the Jets (at Indianapolis) and the Packers (at Philadelphia) also won on the road in the first round. But things will get tougher for the road teams the following weekend, when the conferences top seeds come into play.

title: Ford Soars, Toyota Stumbles in Consumer Reports Survey
description: Ford has matched Toyota and outdistanced Honda in a new survey by Consumer Reports that tries to gauge how positively consumers perceive various brands.

title: Looking to Start Over, Michigan Fires Rodriguez
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  The Rich Rodriguez experiment at Michigan ended Wednesday in the same room where it began, 3 years and 22 losses ago.

title: The Example of Michael Vick
description: Another Christmas-season controversy I missed was the burst of outrage  culminating in some unfortunate hyperbole from Tucker Carlson  over the phone call that Barack Obama made to the Philadelphia Eagles owner thanking him for giving Michael Vick a second chance. If you remember my earlier thoughts on Vicks return to the N.F.L., you wont be surprised to learn that I agree with Michael Gerson, who penned a persuasive column yesterday arguing that Obamas instinct on this issue is entirely correct. While Vick is not representative, Gerson wrote, he is symbolic of the 700,000-odd felons who get out of prison every year and attempt to reintegrate into society. And that symbolism matters:

title: 3-D Without the Glasses
description: LAS VEGAS  For those of you interested in watching 3-D video but who hate those wearing funny-looking glasses (and isnt that most of us?), Toshiba has something to show you at the Consumer Electronics Show  televisions and a laptop that can display 3-D video without requiring the viewer to put on glasses.

title: Why Do So Many Conservatives Like Mitch Daniels?
description: Mitch Daniels presents something of an enigma for conservatives.

title: Asked & Answered | Garrett Hedlund
description: Theres no turning back for Garrett Hedlund. The 26-year-old, who left his parents cattle farm in Roseau, Minn., in 2003 to pursue an acting career in Los Angeles, is bound for Hollywood stardom, thanks to his breakout roles in Tron: Legacy and Country Strong, which opens in theaters this Friday. The Moment met up with the actor in a nondescript Brooklyn diner, the kind of place that Hedlund says he pictured himself working in if the whole acting thing hadnt worked out.

title: Inching Toward Compromise on Commodity Trading
description: As regulators propose hundreds of new rules for banks, hedge funds and other big financial players, trading limits for wheat and corn are proving among the most contentious.

title: An Interview With Alassane Ouattara
description: The president-elect of the Ivory Coast gives his first television interview on France 24.

title: Morocco Says It Foiled Terror Cell in Sahara
description: The Moroccan government arrested 27 people accused of operating a terrorist cell in Western Sahara led by a member of the local branch of Al Qaeda, officials said Wednesday.

title: Private Schools Counsel Out the Unsuccessful
description: Thousands of parents trying to get their children into private schools are now busy mailing thank-you cards to admissions offices and biting their nails while waiting for word back.

title: Eye Specialists Question Nintendos Warning on 3-D Technology and Children
description: Does Nintendo know something about eye development that the worlds elite eye specialists dont?

title: 112th Congress Officially Opens
description: The nations 112th Congress opened officially Wednesday, returning divided government to the nations capital as Republicans took over running the House of Representatives and increased their numbers in the Senate.

title: Reader Idea | Global Poverty and the Guinea Worm
description: Here is another in our Great Ideas From Readers series.

title: Resolved: Limit Coupon Use
description: This week on the Bucks blog, our contributors, along with some of our favorite sources, are posting about their new years financial resolutions. Here, Hal Ersner-Hershfield, a visiting assistant professor of management and organizations at the Kellogg School of Management at Northwestern University, shares his thoughts.

title: Day 1: Let the Festivities Begin
description: David Brooks: Gail, this is going to be a fantastic year. Did you know the Chernobyl nuclear plant is going to be re-opened for official tours this month? Did you know that General Motors will run a Super Bowl ad for the first time in three years, ending our long national nightmare? Did you know that in June, Boston will host an extreme sailing event with huge catamarans that can go faster than the wind?

title: 4 Democrats in State Senate Break With Leaders
description: ALBANY  The chaos-plagued State Senate faced fresh tumult on Wednesday as four Democrats announced they would split from their partys leadership and start their own, independent caucus.

title: Surgery to Force Ozawa to Miss Concerts
description: The conductor Seiji Ozawa, who spent much of last year recovering from esophageal cancer and a back ailment, will miss three concerts in Japan at the end of the month because of surgery to ease pain in his lower back.

title: Studio XXI
description: UNDER cover of night and zebra-print miniskirts, the rowdy expanse of West 21st Street, between Broadway and the Avenue of the Americas, is Chelseas reigning club row. On weekends, there are endless lines of sequin-topped and high-heeled women, snaking toward thudding clubs like Crimson, Taj and Slate. At the westernmost edge is Studio XXI, a second-floor club that opened in December in the small space formerly occupied by Citrine. Those who understand roman numerals call it Studio 21. But others insist the clubs name is pronounced Ess-Ex-Ex-Eye, as in sexy.

title: Post-Midterm Approval Ratings Dont Predict Re-Election Chances
description: Barack Obama got some good news to start his new year: his Gallup approval rating ticked up to 50 percent yesterday, against 42 percent disapproval. Thats the first time it has been at the 50 percent threshold since early June.

title: What Was Most Visited on NYTimes.com in 2010?
description: In 2009 four of the top five were about food.

title: Corcoran Gallery Enlists Help to Overcome Financial Woes
description: The struggling Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington has hired an outside consultant, Lord Cultural Resources, to help it chart a path toward financial health, Artinfo.com reported. The museum also plans to lease an adjacent parking lot, on which it once intended to expand, for roughly $1 million a year to a local developer to build an office tower.

title: Analysis of Cuomos State of the State
description: Were here at the inaugural State of the State address of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, New Yorks chief executive.

title: What Were Reading
description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.

title: Israel Planned to Keep Gazas Economy on the Brink of Collapse, Leaked Cable Says
description: According to a leaked United States diplomatic cable sent to Washington from the American embassy in Tel Aviv in late 2008, Israeli officials told American diplomats on multiple occasions that they intend to keep the Gazan economy on the brink of collapse without quite pushing it over the edge.

title: Procter & Gamble Expands Its Moms Campaign
description: Procter & Gamble, the nations largest advertiser, is further expanding a campaign it introduced last year that declared the maker of household staples to be a proud sponsor of moms.

title: A Bittersweet Farewell to HBOs 24/7
description: On Wednesday at 10 p.m., HBO will show the final episode of its 24/7 series on the Penguins and Capitals Road to the Winter Classic, and hockey fans will be watching as they have the previous three episodes of this superb, engrossing documentary. This episode will be about the New Years night outdoor game, and many at Heinz Field in Pittsburgh last Saturday were already saying they couldnt wait to see it. But when it is over, a lot of fans will be very sad to see it go.

title: And the Winners Are
description: Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio was elected the 61st House speaker on Wednesday and Representative Nancy Pelosi of California was elected leader of the Democratic minority.

title: The Spending That Matters
description: HotAirs Allahpundit has good rundown of why House Republicans are backing off their pledge to cut $100 billion from the federal budget this year:

title: How Six Companies Failed to Survive 2010
description: In business, numbers usually tell the story. If you use them to judge 2010, it was probably a better year for small businesses than 2009. In the first quarter of 2010, for example  the most recent period for which the data are available  there was a net loss of 96,000 companies with fewer than 100 employees, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. In 2009, the loss was 400,000 companies.

title: Swifts Album Stays on Top in Anemic Sales Week
description: The record industrys traditional post-holiday doldrums were reflected in this weeks Billboard album chart as sales of Christmas-related CDs dropped sharply and even nonholiday fare experienced a decline. Taylor Swifts Speak Now continued as No. 1, for the third week in a row, but its sales fell 72 percent, to 77,000, from the previous week. Sales of the records that had been holding down the No. 2 and 3 slots leading into Christmas, The Gift by Susan Boyle and the Glee casts Christmas Album, plunged more than 90 percent, dropping both of those CDs out of the Top 10.

title: Chuck and Doc Step Out
description: FIRST, some words about the Chuck Taylor, a real shrug of a shoe.

title: Video: Boehners Opening Remarks
description: Visit msnbc.com for breaking news, world news, and news about the economy

title: Reader Rejoinders
description: An occasional assemblage of overheard or underappreciated words  generously emailed by co-vocabularists.

title: Judge Allows Wiretaps Against Defendants in Galleon Case
description: A federal judge ruled Wednesday that federal prosecutors could use wiretapped telephone conversations as evidence against six defendants in the insider trading case involving the Galleon Group. The case has spawned a wide-ranging government investigation of suspected insider trading in the hedge fund industry.

title: Boehners First Remarks as House Speaker
description: Following is a text of the speech by Representative John A. Boehner, Republican of Ohio, given after he was elected House Speaker on Wednesday, as released by Mr. Boehner's office:

title: Top 10 Reasons Small Businesses Fail
description: One of the least understood aspects of entrepreneurship is why small businesses fail, and theres a simple reason for the confusion: Most of the evidence comes from the entrepreneurs themselves.

title: Making a True Duck  lOrange
description: Because of certain commitments, it used to be difficult for my wife, Jackie, and me to travel much during the autumn, so we rarely got out of the country at the height of the game season. Now, those commitments are a thing of the past, so we were in London when restaurant menus  and shops  were rich with partridge, hare, woodcock and other wild (or semi-wild) things we rarely see in New York except when theyve been imported from across the Atlantic. When dining out, we took advantage of this state of affairs and even remembered to chew tentatively so as not to chomp down on little balls of metal shot.

title: F.D.A. Orders Tobacco Industry to Disclose Ingredients
description: Federal regulators informed the tobacco industry on Wednesday how to disclose, for the first time, any changes to product ingredients, a crucial regulation under the tobacco law President Obama signed in June 2009.

title: Taking Control, G.O.P. Overhauls Rules in House
description: WASHINGTON  Jubilant Republicans took control of the House on Wednesday and installed Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio as the new speaker before pushing through an overhaul of House rules intended to expedite their drive to dismantle the new health care law, cut federal spending and provide the tax cuts they see as a way to jump-start the economy.

title: Freshmen and Their Children Swarm the Hill
description: The Capitol has been flooded with 7-year-old boys in ties. Many of them struggled Wednesday to free themselves from the premature choke hold of adulthood, but were thwarted by their mothers, many of them draped in something sparkling and knee-length. The mothers swatted at the tiny hands of their sons, smoothed their wayward cowlicks and directed them to use the bathroom before heading to the House floor.

title: Slain Pakistan Governor Is Mourned
description: Supporters of Salman Taseer expressed grief but avoided stirring more emotion with comments on the blasphemy law that he had opposed.

title: Can Jets Pressure Peyton Manning?
description: Mike Chappell of The Indianapolis Star put his finger on a key matchup:

title: In Eco-Jeans, the Green Becomes Harder to Spot
description: TWO years ago, when going green was red-hot in the fashion industry, there were plenty of organic jeans to choose from. Brands including Levis, Banana Republic, Genetic Denim, 7 For All Mankind, Earnest Sewn, Aristocrat, Loomstate, Del Forte and J Brand offered at least one pair made with some amount of organic cotton, which is grown without environmentally threatening chemicals (according to the Sustainable Cotton Project, a nonprofit organization, conventional cotton consumes 25 percent of the worlds chemical pesticides and fertilizers).

title: Alomar and Blyleven Elected to Hall of Fame
description: Roberto Alomar was 9 years old in 1977 when his father, Sandy, was traded from the Yankees to the Texas Rangers. Alomar and his brother tagged along to games at old Arlington Stadium, playing ball in the parking lot with the other players sons, including 4-year-old Todd Blyleven.

title: British Tabloid Editor Suspended Over Phone-Hacking Allegation
description: The British tabloid The News of the World has suspended a senior editor accused of authorizing the illegal interception of the actress Sienna Millers voice-mail messages.

title: State Lawmakers Outline Plans to End Birthright Citizenship, Drawing Outcry
description: WASHINGTON  Conservative legislators from five states opened a national campaign on Wednesday to end the automatic granting of American citizenship to children born in the United States of illegal immigrants.

title: What You Get for ... $775,000
description: ALAMEDA, CALIF.

title: Pentagon Is Poised to Cancel Marine Landing Craft
description: It was supposed to be a tank that swims, a new way for the Marines to storm hostile beaches.

title: Boot Camp
description: By now your utilitarian construction boots have been salt-stained, water-damaged and stripped of their original macho luster, if theyre not completely disintegrated. In the market for a midseason replacement? Consider springing for a pair that is not only built to endure the elements but also has bright laces, buckles and interesting soles, to boot. A pair of chunky rag wool socks completes the look and adds ammunition to your cold-weather defense.

title: John Harwood Interviews Vin Weber
description: John Harwood of CNBC and The New York Times interviewed Vin Weber,  a former Republican representative from Minnesota.

title: Heart Scare Helped Propel Jets Punter
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  On Saturday night in Indianapolis, in another first-round playoff game, Steve Weatherford expects that excitement and emotion will elevate his heart rate. But not too much. Not like last season.

title: Laptop or Tablet? Lenovo Aims to End the Need to Choose
description: LAS VEGAS  Lenovo has responded to a common complaint about tablets  that they are inadequate for people who want to create content, rather than consume it  by making one that transforms into a laptop.

title: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
description: 1. Just started: the 112th Congress, Oprahs network, the downfall of your New Years resolutions.

title: Speech Suggests Pro-Business Approach by Cuomo
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo called for a fundamental realignment of state government on Wednesday, saying New York needs to rethink the services it provides and face up to its overspending problem before it is too late.

title: Exhibitor of Bodies Intends to Contribute His Own
description: PARIS  Gunther von Hagens says he is dying, and he wants to put his preserved corpse on display as part of his popular Body Worlds exhibitions.

title: EBay Takes a Page From the Glossies
description: ABOUT five years ago, Andrea Linett, then the creative director of Lucky magazine, was coordinating a fashion shoot at a resort on the island of St. Croix, when everything went wrong. The photographer got pneumonia. The model didnt show. The hairdresser missed his flight.

title: Homes for $775,000
description: A craftsman in California, a log cabin in Wyoming and a house in Upstate New York.

title: Resolved: Save for What Matters
description: This week on the Bucks blog, our contributors, along with some of our favorite sources, are writing about their new years financial resolutions. Here, Amanda Steinberg, founder of DailyWorth.com, a daily e-mail about money management for women, shares her own plans.

title: New Owners, and New Labor Complaints
description: If some restaurants are cursed with bad locations,maybe others are cursed with bad labor relations. Two years after a federal judge awarded $4.6 million to delivery workers attheSaigon Grill, a Manhattan noodle house, to compensate for theirsevere exploitation, the restaurants new owners face a fresh round of claims of worker discrimination and intimidation.

title: New York City to Examine Reliability of Its Crime Reports
description: Facing questions over whether crime statistics have been manipulated to cast the New York Police Department in a positive light, the police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, announced on Wednesday that three former federal prosecutors would review the departments internal crime-reporting system.

title: Apple iPad 2 Rumors Circulate the Web
description: While almost every technology company in the world descends on Las Vegas this week for the Consumer Electronics Show, one major tech company will be missing: Apple. But even in the absence of Steven Jobs and his iProducts, the technology giants intimidating presence will be felt in every corner of the event.

title: In Phuket, Thailand, a Villa With Ocean Views
description: A four-bedroom private home in the Ayara Hilltop Resort complex near Surin Beach in Phuket, Thailand, is on the market for $2 million.

title: House Hunting in ... Thailand
description: A FOUR-BEDROOM VILLA WITH AN INFINITY-EDGE POOL AND OCEAN VIEWS IN PHUKET, THAILAND

title: A.C.L.U. Weighs In on Guantnamo
description: The American Civil Liberties Union is urging President Obama to adopt a narrow view of proposed restrictions on the transfer of Guantnamo detainees  or to veto a bill containing the limits because they are unconstitutional.

title: Archiving the Civil War
description: With the 150th anniversary of the Civil War approaching, archivists and conservators at the New York Public Library are using modern techniques to reveal 19th-century secrets.

title: TimesCast | January 5, 2011
description: The mood on Capitol Hill as the 112th Congress convenes and John Boehner swears in as speaker of the House; and a preview of the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas.

title: A DAC brings Hi-Fi to the iPhone
description: LAS VEGAS  One of the wonders of the iPhone, iPod and iPad is the ability to hold tens of thousands of songs.

title: French TV Journalist Accused of Plagiarism
description: PARIS  A prominent French television journalist, who has been accused in the past of a faking an interview and receiving embezzled funds, on Wednesday faced a fresh controversy after he was accused of lifting almost 100 pages of material for a new Ernest Hemingway biography from an American author.

title: Floodwaters Nearing Peak in Australia
description: Floodwaters appeared to be at or near their peak across a swath of northeastern Australia on Wednesday, while the country named an army general to lead the recovery efforts.

title: Iomegas Heroic Backups
description: Of all the accessories for iStuff  iPhones, iPods, iPads  expected to flourish at CES this week, theres at least one thats actually useful.

title: For Every Facebook to Toast, There Is an Ampd Mobile to Mourn
description: Silicon Valley is toasting a flurry of mega venture deals.

title: Smells Like 2010
description: FOR fragrance companies, it was a white-knuckled Christmas.

title: Canons Budget Shooters
description: Canons presence at most Consumer Electronics Show conventions gives the company an opportunity to blow out a vast range of still-camera product, but this year its only the budget line that gets revamped.

title: For New Idea Society, a New Dimension
description: The Brooklyn-based indie pop band New Idea Society has been making albums for about five years, but with its most recent release, Somehow Disappearing, theyre finally hitting their stride. The lyrics are earnest and powerful, even in their simplicity; the melodies are hypnotically catchy; and the sound, developed in collaboration with the producer Andy LeMaster, feels very now. On the eve of a big European tour promoting the album, New Idea Societys frontman Mike Law talks about the innovative new 3-D video for the single Thorns.

title: Streisand in Talks to Play Mama Rose in Film Remake of Gypsy
description: 6:24 p.m. | Updated Barbra Streisand has met with Stephen Sondheim and Arthur Laurents to discuss starring as Rose, the mother of all stage mamas, in a film version of their 1959 musical Gypsy, the two men said in telephone interviews on Wednesday. Mr. Laurents, who wrote the book for Gypsy and directed its 2008 revival on Broadway starring Patti LuPone, said that Warner Brothers and Joel Silver were attached as producers, but that no director had been chosen.

title: Just In: Outside-the-Boroughs News
description: Today, we wander outside the five boroughs in search of news, much of which turns out to pertain to the city and its diasporans. Though if youve been looking for that mint-condition Nazi gladiator helmet, look no farther than Queens. [Craigslist]

title: Putting Family Before Work
description: Hypothetical scenario:

title: Bill Daley Visits White House
description: President Obama was scheduled to meet in the Oval Office on Wednesday afternoon with William M. Daley, the former Clinton administration commerce secretary who has emerged as the leading contender for the role of White House chief of staff.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Pakistan, Afghanistan, Washington and Turkey.

title: Reason for Jobs Optimism?
description: The ADP report that tries to predict the monthly change in nonfarm employment doesnt yet have a reliable enough track record to make it deserving of too much trust. But its still a piece of information worth considering, and the latest ADP number suggests that Fridays jobs report may be quite good.

title: Postcrisis, a Struggle Over Mortgage Bond Ratings
description: Two weeks ago, Standard & Poors put out a news release warning that it was poised to lower its ratings on almost 1,200 complex mortgage securities.

title: A Chopin Competition Winner Collects Her Reward
description: Programming Tchaikovskys Nutcracker right after the holidays (and after a Nutcracker-saturated month) seems like serving your guests leftover eggnog in January. But there was nothing stale about the New York Philharmonics vivid performance of the music from Act II on Tuesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, even if it did seem an uninspired choice of repertory for a one-off concert that opened with Chopins Piano Concerto No. 1 in E minor.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Pakistan, Afghanistan, Washington and Turkey.

title: Slicing Up the Camera Roll
With Adult Dramas Raking In Cash, The Social Network Will Resurface in Theaters
description: The adult drama is dead. Long live the adult drama?

title: Guess Where This Is
description: In advance of our annual Places to Go issue this week, were asking readers to guess the location of some of the more scenic destinations that made the cut. Well roll out one a day through Friday.

title: Climate News Snooze?
description: Has media coverage of human-driven climate change gone away, or gone undercover, as was the case for this CBS radio reporter seeking a quiet zone at Copenhagen climate talks a year ago? If so, does this matter?

title: New Works and Oldies (From 20th Century)
description: Lisa Moore and Ashley Bathgate established their reputations as eloquent new-music interpreters through their work with the Bang on a Can All Stars, Ms. Moore as the groups original pianist, Ms. Bathgate as its current cellist.

title: The Circus Tumbles In, to the Sound of the 70s
description: Rock and the circus made a wary liaison when circus acts joined indie-rockers at the Big Apple Circus tent in Damrosch Park on Tuesday night for the Rock & Roll Circus. On Monday, at the end of a free concert in the same tent, fans of the punky Brooklyn band Japanther had swarmed into the ring for moshing and crowd-surfing, so alarming the circuss security people that the show was shut down after three songs.

title: Obama to Speak to Chamber of Commerce
description: President Obama will address the U.S. Chamber of Commerce next month in a high-profile bid to develop a better relationship after their corrosive sparring last fall over the business groups big spending to elect Republicans.

title: Giving Those Old Gadgets a Proper Green Burial
description: This weekend, Josh Mohrer and Petra Cramer are moving to an apartment on Upper West Side of Manhattan, free of the discarded gadgets that have been collecting dust in their East Village closet: a PalmPilot, a first-generation iPhone, an iPod, a BlackBerry and a Texas Instruments graphing calculator.

title: Will Game-Playing Cats Now Dream of Electric Mice?
description: Smartphones and iPads have proved wildly popular among humans, but how will they fare among those with higher intelligence?

title: Browsing: Shopping Snapshots for Jan. 6
description: Questions for Nicole Fischelis, Macys fashion director; Rebecca Minkoffs mens collection for spring; Breitling opens store; and other items.

title: ESPN Discovers a Chess Prodigy. Or Not.
description: ESPN the Magazine has a story in the current issue about a young chess player from Uganda named Phiona Mutesi. The story is titled Game of Her Life with a smaller headline, For 14-year-old chess prodigy Phiona Mutesi, chess is a lifeline.

title: Stoking the Fire Larsson Ignited
description: This is the sound of music, for those who publish mystery novels these days:

title: Comcast to Start Streaming on Tablets
description: LAS VEGAS  Comcast on Wednesday took a step toward television viewing on tablets with two announcements about live and on-demand viewing.

title: Lilly, Iron Lady of U.S. Soccer, Retires at 39
description: She has played in all five FIFA Womens World Cups and three Olympic Games, and after logging a world record 352 international appearances for the United States, Kristine Lilly, 39, announced her retirement from the game on Wednesday.

title: Nominee for a Key Justice Department Post
description: President Obama on Wednesday nominated Virginia A. Seitz, a law firm partner who specializes in appellate litigation to lead the Justice Departments powerful Office of Legal Counsel.

title: Deep in Antarctica, Three Big Challenges
description: Jeff Vervoort, left, an associate professor in radiogenic isotope geochemistry at Washington State University, and John Goodge, a professor of geological sciences at the University of Minnesota-Duluth, are writing from their research expedition in Antarctica.

title: Its All Really One Big Circus
description: Those attending Verdis Traviata at Lincoln Center encountered some unlikely theatergoers by the plaza fountain: young indie-rock fans with uneven dye jobs, skinny jeans and furry animal hats, heading behind the opera house.

title: Cyber Monday Finally Gets Some Respect
description: Cyber Monday finally lived up to its hype.

title: An Allegedly Fake Warhol May Get Its Day in Court
description: A bitter art-world legal battle that has been making its way through the New York courts for five years might finally be going to trial. The poet, photographer and one-time Andy Warhol acolyte Gerard Malanga filed suit in 2005 against the artist John Chamberlain, contending that Mr. Chamberlain sold a 1967 Warhol silk-screen painting that did not belong to him and that he knew was not a real Warhol.

title: Boehner's First Remarks as House Speaker
description: The new speaker of the House, Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, promised a new era of transparency in lawmaking during his televised remarks to the House of Representatives on Wednesday.

title: In a Giants Story, a New Chapter Writ by His DNA
description: He was a giant of a man, 7 feet 7 inches tall, who left his home in Ireland when he was 19 and traveled to London to make his fortune as a freak. There Charles Byrne, known as the Irish Giant, garnered wealth and fame. But, suffering from tuberculosis and an excessive love of gin, he died a few years later, in 1783. A surgeon  John Hunter  bought Mr. Byrnes corpse, boiled it in acid to remove the flesh, and exhibited the skeleton in his museum in London.

title: Is Bangladesh Trying to Take Over Grameen Bank?
description: Very strange things are happening in Bangladesh these days. There seems to be a multi-pronged assault on Grameen Bank and on Muhammad Yunus, who won a Nobel Peace Prize for his role pioneering microfinance.

title: How Modest Is Robert Gibbss Salary?
description: In an interview with The New York Times on Wednesday, President Obama remarked of his outgoing press secretary Robert Gibbs, Hes had a six-year stretch now where basically hes been going 24/7 with relatively modest pay. I think its natural for someone like Robert to want to step back for a second to reflect, retool, and that, as a consequence, brings about both challenges and opportunities for the White House.

title: Blunders Abounded Before Gulf Spill, Panel Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Deepwater Horizon blowout and oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico was an avoidable accident caused by a series of failures and blunders by the companies involved in drilling the well and the government regulators assigned to police them, the presidential panel named to study the accident has concluded.

title: Has Climate Coverage Ebbed?
description: Andy Revkin muses at his Dot Earth blog on how news media coverage of climate change leveled off in many respects last year. Among other indicators, he examines a graph on evening network news coverage generated by Robert Brulle of Drexel University.

title: Celebrating Mamas Rainbow
description: The terms of endearment Mama and Grandma were lavishly sprinkled through Tuesdays opening-night performance of Lorna Lufts warmhearted retrospective tribute Songs My Mother Taught Me: The Judy Garland Songbook at Feinsteins at Loews Regency. Mama is, of course, the name that both Ms. Luft and her older half sister, Liza Minnelli, have always used to refer to Garland, who died in 1969. The youthful voices of Ms. Lufts now-grown children, Jesse and Vanessa, are also heard asking questions about Grandma.

title: Marc Maron's Second Act
description: The comedian Marc Maron's podcast is more than just jokes. His interviews often reveal unguarded moments from humorists like Robin Williams, Dane Cook and Ben Stiller.

title: A Bullish Outlook for Oscar Nights Ad Rates
description: On the heels of a slight spike in ratings last year  buoyed, perhaps, by fans of The Blind Side and other populist fare  ABC is looking for higher fees for commercials for its Oscars telecast, Ad Age reports.

title: New Doubts for a Film That Has Truth Issues
description: When Exit Through the Gift Shop, the artistic conundrum of a documentary wrapped around the street artist Banksy, opened last year, it spawned more than a few critical essays worth of thorny, postmodern questions. Was it a hoax staged by an internationally known cultural prankster or a wry commentary on an overblown art world? Was its putative star, an extravagantly mutton-chopped Frenchman named Thierry Guetta, as crazy as he seemed, or merely crazy like a mutton-chopped fox? Or  wait a minute, was he Banksy? Even as the film has advanced to the documentary shortlist for the Academy Awards, audiences and critics continue to debate whether its authentic, or a commentary on authenticity, or both. Or neither.

title: An Escape From the Bustle of Marrakesh
description: A single-story 1,400-square-foot house with a rooftop terrace in Touggana, Morocco, is home to a jewelry designer and her family.

title: Glenn Beck Hires Former Huffington Post Chief
description: Looking to further expand his growing media presence, Glenn Beck, the conservative talk-show host, has hired a one-time chief executive of the left-leaning Huffington Post to lead his new Web site, The Blaze.

title: Pakistani Lawyers Shower Murder Suspect With Roses
description: As my colleagues Waqar Gillani and Carlotta Gall report from Pakistan, a police officer suspected of killing a prominent secular politician on Tuesday was showered with rose petals by Islamist lawyers on his way in to court in Islamabad on Wednesday.

title: Change to Civil War-Era Building Disputed
description: A building owner has ignored the citys demands to dismantle a fifth story that was added to a landmark mid-19th-century row house in Chelsea that may be the only surviving documented Manhattan station on the Underground Railroad.

title: Errors Multiplied Before Gulf Spill, Panel Says
description: In the latest chapter of its pending report on the causes of the gulf oil spill, a presidential panel has concluded that the disaster was avoidable. It cites a chain of errors and miscommunication by BP and other companies that suggest that the problems were systemic.

title: At One Table, Landing a Slam; At the Other, Going 0 for 13
description: Look at only the South hand. You open one diamond in second position, your left-hand opponent jumps to five clubs, partner doubles, and righty passes. What would you do?

title: Shopping With Georgia Tapert Howe and Caroline Cummings Rafferty
description: The two friends behind the furniture line Carolina George shopped for pieces that serve more than one purpose.

title: Newsweek Hires Publisher
description: After months of staff turmoil including a new owner, editor and chief executive and scores of lower-level departures, the management ranks at Newsweek are beginning to stabilize.

title: Extreme Weather Helps Drive Up Food Prices
description: As my colleague William Neuman reports, the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization announced this week that food prices hit a record high last month. Its Food Price Index was 214.7 for December, the highest level since the organization created the index to measure the price of a standard basket of goods in 1990.

title: Mirror Images in the D.J. Booth
description: THE girl in the gray cocktail dress eyed the D.J.s, a pair of men engrossed in their matching iPads.

title: Abdul Starts Strong
description: The premiere of Live to Dance, CBSs new reality competition with Paula Abdul, below, won its two-hour time slot in the ratings on Tuesday, attracting an average of 10.2 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. CBS led the night over all, including the 10 oclock hour with a rerun of NCIS, which also drew 10.2 million viewers and outperformed its competitors at 10, ABCs Detroit 1-8-7 (5.2 million) and NBCs Parenthood (6 million). NBC ranked second as the premiere of the 11th edition of The Biggest Loser delivered 8.7 million viewers from 8 to 10, along with the nights top ratings among viewers 18 to 49. ABC was third, garnering 6.8 million at 8 for No Ordinary Family and 6.6 million at 9 for the debut of the new season of V. Fox ranked fourth with a rerun of Glee (4.7 million), followed by Million Dollar Money Drop (3.8 million).

title: Footnote
description: Cory Stearns, above, has been promoted to principal dancer at American Ballet Theater, the company said on Wednesday. Mr. Stearns, 25, joined Ballet Theater as an apprentice in 2005.

title: Richard Thomas Set for Timon of Athens
description: Richard Thomas will star in a production of Shakespeares Timon of Athens, the opening work in an effort by the Public Theater to present scaled-down plays by Shakespeare with relatively inexpensive tickets, the theater said on Wednesday. Barry Edelstein, who runs the Publics Shakespeare Initiative, will direct the show, which will run Feb. 15 through March 6. Single tickets, which will cost $15, go on sale on Jan. 18.

title: Ivory Coast Leaders Rival Remains Under Blockade
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  Laundry hangs from balconies, beer bottles remain in the lobby, officials emerge unshaven from darkened corridors after lengthy but inconclusive meetings, and a tent city full of T-shirted United Nations soldiers has sprung up on the steamy grounds of this hotel.

title: A Bonanza in TV Sales Fades Away
description: LAS VEGAS  By now, most Americans have taken the leap and tossed out their old boxy televisions in favor of sleek flat-panel displays.

title: I.R.S. Watchdog Calls for Tax Code Overhaul
description: The various calls to revamp the nations highly complex tax code were joined by a significant new voice on Wednesday  the I.R.S.s own taxpayer advocate, who urged that the system be rewritten for the first time in a generation.

title: Rested Against Bills, Tomlinson Is Set for Colts
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Rex Ryan was already thinking it would be an excellent idea last week to rest running back LaDainian Tomlinson for the Jets regular-season finale Sunday, since the Jets had little incentive to win. Ryan ran the idea past Tomlinson anyway.

title: Raphael Hillyer, Founding Violist of Juilliard Quartet, Dies at 96
description: Raphael Hillyer, the founding violist of the Juilliard String Quartet and a soloist and teacher known for the warmth and expressivity of his tone, died on Dec. 27 in Boston, where he lived. He was 96.

title: With the P.K.K. in Iraqs Qandil Mountains
description: QANDIL, Iraq  It is not easy to visit the mountainous borderlands of northern Iraq where the Kurdistan Workers Party operates, but it is not impossible either.

title: The Importance of Being Astonished
description: LADY BRACKNELL, that unbending arbiter of social correctness, would surely not approve of Brian Bedford, who portrays her in his new production of The Importance of Being Earnest at the American Airlines Theater.

title: Lee Lozano, Surely Defiant, Drops In
description: BY the time Lee Lozano died in 1999, her last high-profile artwork could fairly be judged a success. Drop Out Piece, begun in 1970, had consisted of removing herself from the New York art world, of which she was a highly visible member, and eventually disappearing altogether from the public eye. Her choice of burial, in an unmarked grave outside Dallas, was arguably the works final flourish.

title: Selling a Book by Its Cover
description: IT took Thatcher Wine a year to amass 2,000 well-preserved white vellum and cream-colored leatherbound books for a gentlemans library in the Northern California estate of a private equity manager. Perfectly matched sets of books bound in antique vellum, a pale leather made from goat or sheep skin, are an elusive quarry, especially if they all have to be in English, said Mr. Wine, a former Internet entrepreneur who now creates custom book collections and decorative book solutions, as he puts it, in his Boulder, Colo., warehouse.

title: Health Spending Rose in 09, but at Low Rate
description: WASHINGTON  Total national health spending grew by 4 percent in 2009, the slowest rate of increase in 50 years, as people lost their jobs, lost health insurance and deferred medical care, the federal government reported on Wednesday.

title: Ten Questions for Vin Weber
description: Vin Weber was in the vanguard of conservative change before some Tea Party activists were born; he won a House seat from Minnesota in the 1980 Republican revolution led by then-President Ronald Reagan. He worked alongside Newt Gingrich in the years-long effort to break the Democrats grip on the House. Now a prominent Washington lobbyist, he spoke with John Harwood of The Times and CNBC about the new Republican majority in the House. Heres a condensed, edited version of their conversation:

title: An Antiques Collective Opens Outside Malibu
description: A Beautiful Mess, a new shop in the 1950s-era Whizin Market Square, 10 miles from Malibu, Calif., is an antiques collective. But not a typical one, said Kymberley Fraser, who opened it with six other antiques dealers, all women. A diverse collection of items is mixed to form a cohesive look. There are furnishings created from recycled finds by the Junk Girls; pieces by the designer Marilyn Thompson; primitive American objects from the dealer Karen Chambers; French and American pieces from the designer Victoria Stoehr; American antiques from the dealers Leah Cox and Tina OFlaherty; and items from Ms. Fraser, like an ottoman ($1,800) and wing chair ($2,600) covered in antique German hemp-linen grain bags, above, and a willow basket ($89), left.

title: A Shower Drain Cover for Stylish Soapsuds
description: Wave, a shower drain cover from California Faucetss new StyleDrain line, was created by Christine Miller Kelly, an artist and industrial designer in Palo Alto, Calif. Ms. Kelly, who was a student at California College of the Arts in San Francisco at the time, had two goals: To mimic the rhythmic pattern that water makes in the ocean in an abstract design with a contemporary, geometric line, she said. And to make sure that the opening wasnt so big that someones toe gets stuck.

title: Sales at Angela Adams, Branch, Green Depot and Sam Flax
description: Some Angela Adams rugs are 20 percent off while supplies last (the Jilly rug, above, regularly $425 to $1,950, is $340 to $1,560); (800) 255-9454 or angelaadams.com.

title: Effort to Restore Childrens Play Gains Momentum
description: SARAH WILSON was speaking proudly the other day when she declared: My house is a little messy.

title: The Day He Knew Would Come
description: THE doors to their bedrooms are always shut, their bathroom always empty. On weekends, when you wake up in the morning, the kitchen is as clean as you left it last night. No one touched anything; no one stumbled in after partying till the wee hours to heat up leftovers, or cook a frozen pizza, or leave a mess on the counter while improvising a sandwich. The boys are away now.

title: A Sconce Made of Twisted Vines
description: Catherine Latson, an artist who lives in Tarrytown, N.Y., began making sculptural sconces from Oriental bittersweet two years ago, after collecting lengths of the invasive vine during hikes in the woods. The vine itself is a horrible beast, Ms. Latson said, because it can climb as much as 60 feet and choke trees.

title: Multifunctional Furniture
description: FOR those who have vowed to put their homes in order in 2011, Georgia Tapert Howe and Caroline Cummings Rafferty may be just the ticket. In 2008 these two longtime friends founded Carolina George, a line of furniture in which most of the pieces serve more than one purpose.

title: A Danish Architect Brings His Mountain-Making Ideas to New York
description: Bjarke Ingels, a 36-year-old Danish architect, completed the striking 8 House (below) in Copenhagen late last year. A sustainable, mixed-use project of more than 650,000 square feet, with nearly 500 apartments  the largest private development ever built in Denmark  it is shaped, literally, like a figure eight. Among its more unusual features is a looping public pathway (also in the shape of an eight) that reaches from the street to the 10th floor.

title: Dreams of India, or Your Dorm
description: Some of Anisha Ghoshs customers are drawn to her linens because the prints remind them of college, when practically every bed was covered with an Indian bedspread. But those bedspreads were often mass-produced prints in drab colors  nothing like the designs for cotton bedspreads, curtains, table linens and shower curtains created by Saffron Marigold, Ms. Ghoshs company. Some of the prints (like Spice Route, left) are an interpretation of traditional patterns from her native India, while others (like Lavender Dreams, sprigs on a cream background) are purely her own.

title: Shaping Morocco to Their Needs
description: Touggana, Morocco

title: Books as a Way to Grace a Room
description: Thatcher Wine of Juniper Books creates custom libraries for his clients, wrapping books hes collected in jackets of his own design.

title: TechTalk Podcast: Facebooks Investors
description: Facebook is said to be drawing more page views than Google these days, and its also attracted something else: a $450 million investment from Goldman Sachs that puts the value of Facebook at $50 billion. Bettina Edelstein speaks with Andrew Ross Sorkin, the editor of DealBook, about what the investment does for the social networking giant.

title: Excerpt: 'The Cape'
description: The new superhero series is on NBC.

title: Bills Aim to Relieve Hydrant-Related Parking Headaches
description: Frank Caffiero owns a small restaurant supply business in New York City, which sends him zipping around the five boroughs in his black sport utility vehicle making deliveries several days a week. This means that Mr. Caffiero spends lots of time searching (and searching and searching) for an elusive, precious piece of real estate: a parking spot.

title: After the Hudson, Finding a Home at an Aviation Museum
description: US Airways Flight 1549 may make it to North Carolina after all.

title: Narrowing the Field Before Playing It
description: WHOM do you want to date? A bookworm? A beauty queen? A virgin? A vegan? Whatever youre seeking, chances are theres a niche dating site for you. Yes, even you, mustache fetishists (see StachePassions.com).

title: Rock and Roll Circus Is a Tight Squeeze
description: THOSE attending Verdis Traviata on Tuesday night at Lincoln Center encountered some unlikely theatergoers by the plaza fountain: young indie-rock fans with uneven dye jobs, skinny jeans and furry animal hats, heading behind the opera house.

title: C.E.S Begins Thursday in Las Vegas
description: The Consumer Electronics Show begins on Thursday in Las Vegas, and Sam Grobart is on hand to examine the technological offers and deals on display.

title: Ciscos Vision of Future TV Watching
description: LAS VEGAS  Cisco has a vision  right now just a vague one  for the way TV should be watched in the future.

title: Laundry Products Put Into Yet Another Form
description: CAN lightning strike twice in the laundry room?

title: Former Huffington Post Chief Is Hired to Run Glenn Beck Site
description: Looking to further expand his growing media presence, Glenn Beck, the conservative talk-show host, has hired a onetime chief executive of the left-leaning Huffington Post to lead his new Web site, The Blaze.

title: Motorola Introduces the Xoom, Its Answer to the iPad
description: 6:30 p.m. | Updated  Adding more on the Xoom and other new products.

title: Apple, Though Absent, Is a Presence at Electronics Show
Toyota Wins Case Arguing Ex-Employee Broke Pledge
description: A former lawyer for Toyota who accused the carmaker of hiding damaging information about its vehicles has been ordered to pay Toyota $2.6 million.

title: Keeping Floors So Shiny You Fear to Tread
description: For nearly a quarter-century, Luis Arroyo, 61, has waxed and stripped the 275,000 square feet of floors at the MJHSs Menorah Center for Rehabilitation and Nursing Care in Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn. Mr. Arroyo lives with his wife of seven years in Kew Gardens, Queens.

title: From Samsung, Everything But the Kitchen Sink (Including the Fridge)
description: LAS VEGAS  Samsung executives hit on all the themes floating around Las Vegas at this years International Consumer Electronics Show during a press conference on Wednesday, showing off new tablet computers, announcing mobile media distribution deals and packing Internet connectivity into everything from televisions to point-and-shoot cameras to smart refrigerators.

title: Is The Hall of Fame Too Small?
description: Roberto Alomar and Bert Blyleven were selected for baseballs Hall of Fame this afternoon, becoming the 234th and 235th players so honored.

title: N.F.L.s New Overtime Rule Means Extra Choices
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Peyton Manning said he had forgotten how the new playoff overtime rule would work until Colts Coach Jim Caldwell mentioned it this week.

title: Fed Nomination Is Submitted Again
description: President Obama nominated Peter Diamond, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology professor and winner of the Nobel in economic science, to the Federal Reserve Board on Wednesday.

title: Obama Turning to Experienced Hands as He Remakes Staff
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama closed in Wednesday on a decision to fill two top positions and recharge his administration, stopping just short of naming a new chief of staff and a top economic adviser to guide the White House through a new period of divided government.

title: Auburn Is First in One Ranking, 85th in Another
description: PARADISE VALLEY, Ariz.  In the aftermath of a football academic scandal at Auburn in 2006 that caused two department heads to step down and the N.C.A.A. to investigate, university officials are no longer bragging  or even talking  about the teams once-stellar scholastic record.

title: New Charges of Cheating Tarnish Pepsi Fund-Raising Contest for Nonprofits
description: Pepsi Refresh, the online fund-raising contest with a $20 million giveaway for charitable causes and nonprofit groups, is again receiving complaints that its results are being manipulated.

title: Qualcomm Deal May Spur Takeovers of Chip Makers
description: Qualcomms $3.1 billion deal to acquire the chip maker Atheros Communications is a long-term play on the increasingly wired nature of consumers lives.

title: On Groupon, a Proposal Sealed With a Click
description: Dana Burck says she found the deal of a lifetime on Groupon: a wedding proposal.

title: Sports Replay: Jan. 5
description: The day in sports, including skiing, soccer and football.

title: An OLED Point-and-Shoot From Sony
description: Sony is back at the Consumer Electronics Show with a new OLED screen. But dont plan on hanging this one on the wall; it measures three-and-a-half inches.

title: James Buchanans Activist Blunder
description: President James Buchanans critics rightly condemned him during the secession crisis of 1860-61  but they did so for exactly the wrong reason. The naysayers blasted the president for passiveness in the face of disunion, for failing promptly to reinforce endangered federal forts in the South. True, the president retreated from sending reinforcements  except for a few critical days around the New Year. At that moment, a sudden burst of irresponsible activism shrunk his record of passivity to comparative unimportance.

title: Reading Between the Battle Lines: An Annotated Guide to the Constitution
description: The new Republican majority has ordered that the United States Constitution be read on the floor of the House of Representatives on Thursday, the day after new lawmakers were sworn in. Congressional historians say they believe this has been done only twice before.

title: Running, Jumping and Hardly Aging on the Track
description: MARIETTA, Ga.  Philippa Raschker, the most enduring female athlete youve never heard of, is flying solo, dashing down a track that rings a high school football field.

title: Journals Paper on ESP Expected to Prompt Outrage
description: One of psychologys most respected journals has agreed to publish a paper presenting what its author describes as strong evidence for extrasensory perception, the ability to sense future events.

title: Teams and Owners Find Public Money Harder to Come By
description: The sports world is littered with examples of governments spending hundreds of millions of dollars to host the World Cup or Olympics or to help build stadiums and arenas for privately owned home teams.

title: For Cuomo, PowerPoint as Fireside Chat
description: In the annals of American politics, some chief executives approaches to the art of persuasion stand the test of time: Franklin D. Roosevelts fireside chats; the Johnson Treatment; Ronald Reagans hand-scrawled notes.

title: Before Family and Friends, Passing a Gavel Heavy With Symbolism
description: WASHINGTON  In a contest for the designation of toughest House speaker in history, Nancy Pelosi of California, the first woman to hold the post, is not likely to cede much ground to anyone  neither to predecessors like the legendary Sam Rayburn of Texas, nor to her successor, Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio.

title: Firms Told to Divulge All Changes to Tobacco
description: Federal regulators on Wednesday outlined rules for the tobacco industry that for the first time require disclosure of any changes to their products, and that detail how to seek permission to market new products under the sweeping tobacco control law signed by President Obama in June 2009.

title: A Son Confronts Gender Identity and a Mother Grieves
description: Sharon Weir may not be happy that her son is openly gay and identifies himself as transgender, but she will fight for his right to exist in peace.

title: Summoned by the Court Jester
description: In case you were curious how much it would cost if you were caught drinking a beer on your front stoop and caught again urinating it out on the corner a couple of hours later, Judge Eugene L. Schwartzwald has come up with a handy reminder: Twenty-five on the way in, and 50 on the way out.

title: A Thousand Years of Rock Markings
description: From the Paiute Indians to Peewee and the Nasty Habits Crew, various tribes and gangs have left their marks on Red Rock Canyon, Nev.

title: Elaine Kaufman Leaves Elaines to Her Manager
description: Ever since the death last month of Elaine Kaufman, the voluble restaurateur who for 47 years ran an Upper East Side saloon and literary landmark, speculation has swirled around its future. Who would inherit the establishment she presided over in such a single-minded way?

title: Gene Sperling 101
description: 1:07 p.m. | Updated  to correct titles of position and council.

title: Red Rocks of Nevada Smudged by Less Colorful Graffiti
description: RED ROCK CANYON, Nev.  The jagged pink mountains here glitter, rare instances of natural beauty in a desolate landscape known more for its gleaming casinos. For years, hikers and rock climbers have flocked to Red Rock Canyon for the easily accessible climbs. History seekers come to look at the patch of land where Indian tribes roamed as far back as the 10th century.

title: Pension Fund Losses Hit States Hard, Data Show
description: When total state government revenues across the nation plummeted by a record-breaking 30.8 percent in 2009, the steep investment losses of pension funds proved to be an even bigger drain on state coffers than recession-battered tax collections, according to census data released Wednesday.

title: Players Linked to Steroids Receive Minimal Support
description: The precedent was set four years ago, when Hall of Fame voters first rejected Mark McGwire. The latest round of balloting, which for the first time featured another player directly linked to steroid use, reinforced the new baseball reality: the doors to Cooperstown are closed to those entangled with performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Larkin, McGriff and Other Hall of Fame Nuggets
description: A few thoughts on the Hall of Fame voting results:

title: Speakers Wife Emphasizes Normal, Average Life
description: WASHINGTON  For someone who fashions herself a Washington outsider, Debbie Boehner sure knows how to stay on message.

title: CapitalSource Puts Itself Up for Sale
description: CapitalSource, a commercial lender for small and midsize businesses, has hired JPMorgan Chase to find a potential buyer, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Wednesday.

title: Rangers Add Beltre; Young Becomes D.H.
description: When Cliff Lee turned down the Yankees to sign with the Philadelphia Phillies last month, perhaps the Yankees one consolation was that he also rejected the appeals of an American League rival, the Texas Rangers, his former team.

title: Lottery Numbers
Troubled Youth Gravely Injured in Stabbing Near School
description: The 10th grader at Public School 12 in the Bronx, a school for students with behavioral issues and special needs, had a reputation among his classmates as a bully. He had been in fights over the past year, picking on smaller students, classmates said, and had been so difficult to control at home lately, his mother said, that she had petitioned the courts for extra supervision and foster care.

title: Opening Day at the Capitol
description: The 112th Congress convened for the first time, with Republicans officially taking the helm of the House.

title: Live Traffic Comes to TomTom
description: LAS VEGAS  Virtually instantaneous traffic updates come to TomToms line of GPS devices with the launch of its Go 2505 M LIVE model. The $349 product, which will be available by mid-2011, uses both satellite and GPRS radio signals to update traffic conditions every two minutes, compared with every 15 minutes for the companys other models.

title: Thursday: Going AWOL
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Im surprised at you, Mike Nothnagel. Youve always been this affable, go-with-the-flow kind of guy, and then I see that all this time theres been a rebel inside you, screaming to get out. I will say that you announce your intent to go against the group brilliantly. It took me a bit of staring at the completed grid and the help of another pair of eyes to fully understand what you were doing, but that aha! moment was very satisfying. Nicely done.

title: Bloody Bloody Revival Revival
description: Vampires are rare, opines Dr. Van Helsing, the expert on all things undead, in the revival of the drama Dracula that opened Wednesday night at the Little Shubert Theater. Nature abhors them, the forces of good combine to destroy them, but a few of these creatures have lived on for centuries.

title: Ballet Master in City Draws D.W.I. Charge
description: Peter Martins, the ballet master in chief of the New York City Ballet and one of the citys leading artistic figures, was arrested at a checkpoint on New Years Day and charged with driving while intoxicated, the Westchester County police said Wednesday evening.

title: Uranium Mill in Colorado Gets License
description: DENVER  Colorado regulators on Wednesday approved a license for the first new rock-crushing uranium mill to be built in the United States in more than 25 years to make fuel for nuclear power plants.

title: Contractor and City Settle Overcharges for $5 Million
description: New York City has reached a $5 million civil settlement with a construction management company that is at the center of a federal investigation into allegations of severe overbilling on public projects, city officials announced on Wednesday.

title: After Hockey Score, HBO Seeks New Game
description: The success of HBOs series detailing the Penguins and Capitals run-up to the N.H.L.s Winter Classic has encouraged the network to broaden its programming with other leagues in the heat of their regular seasons.

title: Detained American Says He Was Beaten in Kuwait
description: WASHINGTON  An American teenager detained in Kuwait two weeks ago and placed on an American no-fly list claims that he was severely beaten by his Kuwaiti captors during a weeklong interrogation about possible contacts with terrorism suspects in Yemen.

title: G.M. Plans to Add Wireless Charging Feature to Cars
description: LAS VEGAS  General Motors hopes that products like the Chevy Volt relieve it of its stodgy image among consumers. On Thursday, the company will announce another step in the hipness department.

title: In Russia, Dissent Turns Into a Solo Act
description: MOSCOW  Over the past three days, after the detention of Boris Y. Nemtsov, a prominent opposition figure, at a New Years Eve rally, a cat-and-mouse game has been unfolding on Moscows streets, still festooned with holiday decorations.

title: Rangers Rookie Makes First Goal a Winner
description: There are times when being short can help a hockey player, as Mats Zuccarello, the 5-foot-7 Norwegian rookie, demonstrated Wednesday night with the overtime goal that gave the Rangers a 2-1 victory over Carolina at Madison Square Garden.

title: Greece: Anarchists Claim Court Blast
description: An anarchist group that has claimed responsibility for sending letter bombs to foreign embassies in November claimed responsibility on Wednesday for an explosion that damaged a court building in Athens last week.
