The group, the Conspiracy of the Cells of Fire, said in a statement that the blast was in protest of the coming trial of 13 people suspected of belonging to the group. In the statement, published by the online Indymedia news network, it threatened the judges and vowed that for every year in prison given to our brothers, we will plant a kilogram of explosives in your front yards, in your cars, in your offices.

title: Co-Leaders Pull Away at Reggio Emilia Chess Tournament
Bloggingheads: The Living Constitution?
description: Randy Barnett of Georgetown Law School and Sanford Levinson of the University of Texas Law School debate the open-endedness of the Constitution.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Sony Puts Its Weight Behind 3-D TV
description: LAS VEGAS  Sony put on an elaborate sales pitch for 3-D devices Wednesday and announced new programming for 3NET, the 3-D television network that will start up in a few months.

title: A Transformation in Haiti
description: After 13 months in a local aid program in Haiti, Odecile Jean is starting to turn her life around.

title: Francos Hall Candidacy Is One-Shot Deal
description: Buried at the bottom of the Hall of Fame voting list was a revelation of sorts. Voters gave very little consideration to closer John Francos candidacy; so little, in fact, that he will no longer qualify for the ballot.

title: Home Team
description: THREE years after the mortgage crisis began, there are still 11 million to 15 million homeowners who owe more than their home is worth, meaning that about 25 percent of all mortgage holders are underwater. As a result, foreclosures continue to mount; many homeowners cant make their payments and are tempted to simply walk away from their debt. Meanwhile, the lenders and investors who own the loans are unwilling to work out a deal if, as is usually the case, it means losing money.

title: The Corporate House
description: John Boehner, the new speaker, promised the incoming House members of the 112th Congress on Wednesday to give the government back to the American people. But away from the camera, the chambers new Republican leadership is busy doing the opposite.

title: $65 Million Is Not Enough?
description: To the Editor:

title: Public Workers: The New Scapegoats?
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Wants a 30-Year Mortgage?
description: AS we all move forward with our New Years resolutions, its a good time to remember the promises our politicians have been making about the American mortgage market. The Obama administration, at a conference last August on the future of housing finance, pledged to have, come January, a plan for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the mortgage giants that are now wards of the government. Congressional Republicans, in their recent position paper, made an even bolder resolution: to build a mortgage market that does not rely on government guarantees and does not make private investors and creditors wealthy while saddling taxpayers with losses.

title: Not a Terrorist Group
description: To the Editor:

title: Dear Old Golden Rule Days
description: Theyre back! As has been frequently noted, the first day of a new Congress is very much like the first day of school. Except for the part where its on TV and the fate of the largest economy on the planet hangs in the balance.

title: Governor Cuomos New York
description: Past New York governors usually leaned on lofty rhetoric and vague promises as they gave their annual State of the State speeches in the stuffy halls of the Legislature. Gov. Andrew Cuomo wisely chucked all that on Wednesday in favor of a stark analysis of New Yorks dismal plight.

title: Ladders for the Poor
description: Nearly a year after the earthquake in Haiti, more than one million people are still living in tents and reconstruction has barely begun  and thats a useful reminder of the limitations of charity and foreign aid.

title: Ridding the Hudson River of PCBs
description: To the Editor:

title: Thats Not Twain
description: Next month, you will be able to buy the single- volume NewSouth Edition of Mark Twains The Adventures of Tom Sawyer and Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, edited by Professor Alan Gribben of Auburn University at Montgomery. It differs from other editions of those books because Mr. Gribben has turned the word nigger  as used by Tom and Huck  into slave. Mr. Gribben has also changed Injun to Indian.

title: Under Siege
description: Christians are increasingly under siege in Egypt and Iraq. Over the past year, hundreds have been killed or wounded in attacks, and the violence is further raising political and sectarian tensions in the two countries. All people, regardless of their beliefs, should be outraged.

title: The Farriers Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Unequal Justice at the Supreme Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Prescription Drug Abuse Sends More People to the Hospital
description: The number of emergency room visits resulting from misuse or abuse of prescription drugs has nearly doubled over the last five years, according to new federal data, even as the number of visits because of illicit drugs like cocaine and heroin has barely changed.

title: Microsoft Plans Living Room Takeover With Kinect

title: Should the Racial Epithets Be Removed From Huck Finn?
description: A new edition of Huckleberry Finn removes the 219 uses of the word nigger in the novel and replaces them with slave. The professor who proposed the idea said he did it because he was hesitant to pronounce the word when he was teaching the book, and because he wanted an edition not for scholars, but for younger people and general readers. What do you think about tinkering with a literary classic like this? Have you studied Huck in school? How did your teacher handle the language?

title: A Moment With Larry Fink
description: Larry Fink, born in 1941, started taking photographs as an adolescent. His work has been exhibited at the Museum of Modern Art and the Whitney Museum of American Art, among others, and he was the recipient of a Guggenheim Fellowship in 1976. His books include Social Graces (1984, reissued 2001), Boxing (1997), Runway (2000) and The Vanities: Hollywood Parties 20002009, which will be published this year by Schirmer/Mosel. He is a professor of photography at Bard College. This conversation, with Adriana Teresa, the co-founder of FotoVisura and the publisher of Visura Magazine, has been edited and condensed.

title: Colbert Sells Revised Huck Finn Down the River
description: Earlier at Room for Debate, nine writers including Jane Smiley and Francine Prose pondered the merits of an Alabama publishers revised edition of Adventures of Huckleberry Finn that replaces Mark Twains use of a racial epithet with the word slave on 219 occasions. And on Wednesday night Stephen Colbert added his contrarian voice to the mix, arguing on The Colbert Report that the changes to Huckleberry Finn do not go far enough. Who knows, Mr. Colbert asks, what other words it contains that are O.K. now that someday might be offensive?

title: The Insider | Eric Monkaba
description: Though he started out in advertising in Manhattan, Eric Monkaba has always had a bit of wanderlust. While vacationing in Morocco a few years back, Monkaba shared ataxiin the High Atlas Mountains with a few British tour managers who opened his eyes to a different career path. Soon enough he was leading tours through the deserts of Egypt, Jordan and Morocco. After studying Arabic at the University of Damascus and a stint working with street children inYemen, he started Backpacker Concierge, a personalized travel consultancy specializing in responsible tourism in the Middle East, mainly in Egypt and Jordan.

title: Tarantino Forgets a Friend
description: After all the attention generated by his list of top movies of 2010, Quentin Tarantino is now sheepishly admitting he forgot one: Somewhere, directed by his friend (and ex) Sofia Coppola, which received the Golden Lion at the Venice Film Festival under his watch as president of the jury. The folks at Vulture contacted Mr. Tarantino to ask him about the omission. Im a little embarrassed by it, actually, he told them, explaining that he did not include the films from Venice in his considerations because the world knows how I feel about those films already. Mr. Tarantino was also surprised by how much attention his list generated. If Id known it was going to get out, Id have put it in my top 10, he said.

title: Trend Versus Cycle, Texas Edition
description: I see that various people, including Ryan Avent, are going on about how Texas is a great success story of this recession despite an unemployment rate about the same as New Yorks. I think whats going on is a misunderstanding of the difference between trends and cycles.

title: The Miracle Workers
description: Some of the most compelling first-person accounts of family caregiving Ive ever read come from the Narrative Matters section of the policy journal Health Affairs. Often these stories are written by medical professionals who have found all of their training and expertise useless when faced with responsibility for a parent or spouse. What they thought they knew they didnt, and what they did know got lost in the emotional upheaval of caring for a loved one rather than a patient.

title: Anytime, Anywhere: Robert De Niro to Serve as President of Cannes Jury
description: Yes, Robert De Niro is already a co-founder of the Tribeca Film Festival, but do you want to be the one to tell him he cant be involved in more than one cinematic gala at a time? The organizers of the Cannes Film Festival clearly didnt mind Mr. De Niros other affiliation, announcing on Thursday that he will serve as the president of the jury for its coming 64th annual run, which will be May 11-22. Mr. De Niro, the quintessential New York actor whose films run the gamut from Mean Streets to Little Fockers, served as the president of the Cannes jury twice in the 1980s, and starred in two films that won the festivals Palme dor prize: Martin Scorseses Taxi Driver, in 1976, and Roland Joffes Mission, in 1986.

title: In the South Bronx, Blight Returns to a Rehabilitated Block
description: The four-story wreck that is 920 Kelly Street is a South Bronx time machine for Harry De Rienzo. Its broken windows, garbage-choked halls, mold-mottled rooms and smoky stench remind him of what much of the area looked like nearly 35 years ago, when he first arrived to work at a settlement house.

title: Now Showing | Ezra Stoller
description: An exhibition of the work of the photographer Ezra Stoller opens today at Yossi Milo Gallery. Stoller, who died in 2004 at age 89, was the foremost chronicler of Modernist architecture, using his large-format camera to record seminal 20th-century works like Mies van der Rohes Seagram Building, Frank Lloyd Wrights Fallingwater and Guggenheim Museum, and Eero Saarinens TWA Terminal at Idlewild Airport (now Kennedy). The exhibition of gelatin silver prints includes not just images of these buildings but also of lesser-known midcentury works like the Starkey house in Duluth, Minn., by Marcel Breuer, and the International Style, Skidmore, Owings & Merrill-designed First National City Bank (now Citibank) branch, also at Kennedy  which still stands, albeit in a less pristine landscape than when Stoller trained his deep-focus lens on it. So influential was Stollers approach, which captured a buildings lines in sometimes abstract, often monumental compositions, that a project wasnt considered complete until it had been Stollerized. The exhibition continues through Feb. 12.

title: Russians React Badly to U.S. Criticism on Protests
description: MOSCOW  There are few things that Russian politicians like less than being scolded about democracy and human rights, and over the last week, since the police arrested top opposition leaders at a New Years Eve protest, the news cycle has been dominated by Russians criticizing Americans for criticizing Russians.

Tyson, an aggressive and visionary entrepreneur who dropped out of college and built his fathers Arkansas chicken business into the behemoth Tyson Foods, one of the worlds largest producers of poultry, beef and pork, died on Thursday. He was 80 and lived in Fayetteville, Ark. The cause was complications of cancer, Tyson Foods said.

title: General Motors Licenses Promising Battery Technology
description: General Motors is free to explore a patented car-battery technology developed by Argonne National Laboratory, it was announced Thursday. But even with its freshly inked worldwide licensing agreement, dont expect G.M. to push aside LG Chem, the Korean battery manufacturer responsible for the battery cells installed in the Chevrolet Volt  LG Chem already uses the Argonne technology.

title: Its Iraq but Its Not, Part 1
description: ERBIL, Iraq  On a recent trip to the Kurdistan region in the north of Iraq, duty required us to drive to a place here in its capital that we didnt know. My colleagues and I, all Iraqis, stopped by the first police officers we spotted, naturally enough, to ask for directions. We asked in Arabic, then I tried in English.

title: Contour Adds a Viewfinder, in a Manner of Speaking
description: Back in July I wrote about how to make better videos of your active vacations. I used a ContourHD camera to film rides along a twisty road on a motorcycle. The camera, which is the size of a compact LED flashlight, can stick just about anywhere to get some eye-grabbing high-definition shots. Just one problem. It has no viewfinder, so after reviewing my footage I often had to adjust the camera position and shoot all over again.

description: As lawmakers recited the articles of the countrys founding document on the House floor Thursday, some women found themselves out in the cold  literally.

title: When Insurers Put Profits Between Doctor and Patient
description: Late in 2007 I found myself riveted by a case playing out at the University of California, Los Angeles, the medical center where I trained and had once worked as a transplant surgeon. A 17-year-old girl named Nataline Sarkisyan was in desperate need of a transplant after receiving aggressive treatment that cured her recurrent leukemia but caused her liver to fail. Without a new organ, she would die in a matter of a days; with one, she had a 65 percent chance of surviving. Her doctors placed her on the liver transplant waiting list.

title: 36 Hours in Key West
description: The secret to a great 36 hours on this small island off the tip of Florida is to make friends with the gregarious and outgoing locals.

title: HPs New dm1 Laptop Keeps Its Cool
description: LAS VEGAS  When HP set out to make a cool laptop computer, it was thinking literally. One of the standout features of the new compact sized HP Pavilion dm1 is that it is designed not to heat up while you have it sitting on your lap.

title: 36 Hours in Key West, Fla.
description: KEY WEST, haven to artists and writers, chefs and hippies, is somehow more Caribbean than Floridian. The indie-minded transplants work hard to keep it that way. One-speed bicycles weave their way through colorful village streets, crammed with as many chickens as cars. Happy hour blends into dinner. And everything is oriented around the ocean, from the fish market-driven menus and the nautical-inspired art, to the sunrise worshipers who gather each dawn and the tipplers who wave goodbye at sunset. Be careful or you might just catch what islanders call Keys disease  a sudden desire to cut ties with home and move there.

title: A Weekend in Key West, Fla.
description: Key West, haven to artists and writers, chefs and hippies, is somehow more Caribbean than Floridian. And the indie-minded transplants work hard to keep it that way.

title: Putting Profits Before Patients
description: The inherent conflict of interest in a health care system anchored by for-profit insurers lurks unspoken behind nearly every debate over reform. Few politicians dare to openly address the issue; but over the last year and a half, one unlikely individual has consistently reminded us of this moral dilemma: Wendell Potter.

title: No iPhone, but Star Trek Future From Verizon
description: LAS VEGAS  Those expecting Ivan Seidenberg, the chairman and chief executive of Verizon Communications, to pull out a gleaming iPhone from his pocket during the opening keynote of the Consumer Electronics Show can stop holding their breath.

title: An Open House or Not? Boehner Explains
description: Like the Democrats did before him, Speaker John A. Boehner has promised to run a much more open House and to give the Democratic minority plenty of room to offer amendments on the floor.

title: A Jet Earns Stellar Marks as a Student of the Game
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Bill Callahan conducts meetings for the Jets offensive linemen because he is, after all, the teams offensive line coach. But he invites feedback at these meetings, and one player in particular is apparently not shy about taking on Callahan as if he were a defensive end.

title: Why Did Goldman Unit Pass on Facebook?
description: Before Goldman Sachs bought a stake in Facebook and started offering shares to clients, a powerful investment group within the firm turned down the chance to buy a piece of the social networking site.

title: New Gadgets at C.E.S.
description: Motorola introduced its answer to the iPad, and several other companies also showed off their tablets at the technology industrys largest trade show.

title: Drivers Benefit as City Holds Off on Raising Some Meter Fees
description: Subway straphangers, train commuters, and bus riders endured a stiff fare increase last month, but at a time of skyrocketing transportation costs, drivers in the outer boroughs are getting a rare reprieve.

title: Banksy, Truth and the Third Man
description: Its easy to get lost in a hall of art-house mirrors when thinking (or writing) about Exit Through the Gift Shop, better known as the Banksy documentary. The pseudonymous British street artist has emerged from the shadows a bit to promote the film  but hes expressed surprise that people might think his work is a prank, even though, you know, that sort of comes with the territory of being an internationally known prankster.

title: David G. Trager, Judge in Crown Heights Case, Dies at 73
description: David G. Trager, a federal judge in Brooklyn whose rulings were pivotal in a racially charged case in Crown Heights and in the first civil suit to challenge the Bush administrations practice of sending terrorism suspects to countries that employ torture, died on Wednesday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 73.

title: In Womens Tears, a Chemical That Says, Not Tonight, Dear
description: When we cry, we may be doing more than expressing emotion. Our tears, according to striking new research, may be sending chemical signals that influence the behavior of other people.

title: Israeli Bloggers Question Israels Use of Tear Gas Against Protesters
description: Updated | Saturday | 10:58 a.m. As my colleague Isabel Kershner reported, this week Israels military tried to deflect blame for the death of a Palestinian woman who collapsed after inhaling tear gas fired by Israeli soldiers during a protest against Israels separation barrier in the West Bank.

title: OnStar-Equipped Rearview Mirrors to Be Sold at Best Buy
description: At the Consumer Electronics Show on Tuesday, General Motors announced that it would offer its OnStar safety and connectivity system to owners of non-G.M. cars.

title: New Zeppelin Touches Down
description: The Zeppelin has landed in Vegas.

title: U.S. Protests Assault on Envoy in Vietnam
description: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam  The United States lodged an official protest with the Vietnamese government on Thursday over what news reports called a police assault of an American diplomat who monitors human rights issues as he was trying to visit a dissident priest.

title: Coil Festival: 5 Questions About Rabbi Rabino
description: Fans of contemporary theater have their hands full for the next two weeks. In addition to the Public Theaters Under the Radar Festival, Performance Space 122 is presenting its annual Coil Festival of multimedia dance and theater performances. Over the next week Erik Piepenburg will be interviewing several theater companies with shows in the festivals.

title: Last Chance
description: Tracey Moffatt, Bronx Museum, through 1/9

title: Why Did a Goldman Unit Pass on Facebook?
description: Before Goldman Sachs bought a stake in Facebook and started offering shares to clients, a powerful investment group within the firm turned down the chance to buy a piece of the social networking site.

title: Announcer Says He Wont Respond to Firing
description: Two days after ESPN fired him for making what have been described as condescending remarks to a sideline reporter, Ron Franklin said on Thursday that he was not responding to the dismissal and would continue to take the high road.

title: A Comic-Turned-Comic Interviewer
description: In his podcast Marc Maron interviews many of the friends hes made during a long stand-up comedy career.

title: The Comic Who Explores Comedys Darkest Side
description: HERES a riposte youre not likely to hear in an interview by Jay Leno or Charlie Rose: Youve got to have rage, man. Because I see the posture  your posture is built for rage. Thats Marc Maron talking to Dane Cook, the popular but bland comedian, on an episode of Mr. Marons twice-weekly podcast.

title: City Will Not Raise Recreation Center Fees
description: Fans of the citys recreation centers can breathe easy, at least for the moment: The city has agreed to delay a plan that would have doubled admission fees at 32 centers.

title: ESPN Close to Extending Media Rights With N.F.L.
description: ESPN is close to an extension of its media rights with the National Football League to pay between $1.8 billion and $1.9 billion a year for 9 or 10 years after its current deal ends in 2013, Sports Business Daily reported on Thursday.

title: The Influence of Libertarianism
description: Ezra Klein has a sharp comeback to my post questioning the relevance of extended critiques of a hypothetical libertarian libertopia:

title: Former Assemblyman Seminerio Dies in Prison
description: Former Assemblyman Anthony S. Seminerio, a onetime correction officer who served 30 years as a state lawmaker from southwest Queens before pleading guilty in 2009 to influence peddling, died Thursday at a federal prison hospital, less than a year into his six-year sentence. He was 75.

title: Memo: Keep the Keys From the Prisoners
description: There are thousands and thousands of arrests in New York City in any given year  and occasionally those taken into custody slip their shackles and flee. Sometimes they stay free for enough time for the episodes to become embarrassing black eyes for the New York Police Department. But sometimes, the moments of freedom are so fleeting that the news media never learn of them.

title: Marilyn and the City
description: A look at some of the places Marilyn Monroe spent time when she was in New York City.

title: Mac App Store Opens for Business
description: The Mac App Store officially opened for business on Thursday, with Apple offering customers a new way to instantly purchase and download software for their Mac computers and laptops.

title: Pancake People
description: Description of the Internet generation, whose knowledge is wide but shallow.

title: NPR Executive Who Fired Juan Williams Resigns
description: Ellen Weiss, the senior vice president for news at NPR whose quick firing of the senior news analyst Juan Williams last October ignited a political and public relations firestorm, resigned Thursday at the end of an internal investigation into the dismissal.

title: Business Background Defines Chief of Staff
description: WASHINGTON  He is a top executive at JPMorgan Chase, where he is paid as much as $5 million a year and supervises the Washington lobbying efforts of the nations second-largest bank. He also serves on the board of directors at Boeing, the giant military contractor, and Abbott Laboratories, the global drug company, which has billions of dollars at stake in the overhaul of the health care system.

title: The Mess of Childs Play
description: Play is the work of children, Captain Kangaroo (a k a Bob Keeshan) once said. Its very serious stuff.

title: A Constructive Approach on Energy?
description: Earlier this week I posed questions about the energy goals of the Committee for a Constructive Tomorrow, a group fighting restrictions on greenhouse gases, financing a naysaying blog on global warming and, in theory, aiming to stop energy poverty now.

title: Dark Materials: Reflecting on Dystopian Themes in Young Adult Literature
description: Overview | Are todays young adult novels darker in theme than in years past? Whats behind the current wave of dystopia in young adult literature? In this lesson, students reflect on some of the reasons dystopian and post-apocalyptic stories appeal to young readers by engaging in one of six different activities.

title: Gene Sperling 201
description: In addition to the Gene Sperling links we provided before, Mr. Sperling  the new director of President Obamas National Economic Council  also wrote a 2007 article for the journal Democracy in which he argued for rising-tide economics. He suggested that the central economic problem, at least before the financial crisis, was the disconnect between productivity and incomes. Businesses were becoming more productive, profits were rising, gross domestic product was growing  but many workers werent benefiting:

title: Who Will Win the B.C.S. Title Game?
description: The top two teams in the country, Auburn and Oregon, will play for the national title. Watch a video debate and then vote for the team you think will win.

title: News Corp. Restructures Its Fox Networks Group
description: News Corporation announced a restructuring of its Fox Networks Group on Thursday in reaction to the announcement that Tony Vinciquerra, the chairman of the group, will leave the company in February.

title: Resolved: Distinguish Hindsight From Foresight
description: This week on the Bucks blog, our contributors, along with some of our favorite sources, are posting about their new years financial resolutions. Here, Meir Statman, a finance professor at Santa Clara University who specializes in behavioral finance, and author of What Investors Really Want, shares his thoughts.

title: Obamas Remarks Introducing His New Chief of Staff
description: Following is a text of the remarks made on Thursday by President Obama and his newly selected chief of staff, William M. Daley, as released by the White House:

title: Keeping Score: Blake Griffins Big Impact
description: Justin Kubatko is the creator of Basketball-Reference.com, an online basketball encyclopedia. He is also a statistical consultant for the Trail Blazers.

title: Face Time | Olivia Thirlby
description: Tina Turnbow is a professional makeup artist, who is known for lending her celebrity clients editorial polish.

title: Beijing, Tendering Support to Europe, Helps Itself
description: PARIS

title: Small Ball Serves Boston Well Against San Antonio
description: In a hotly contested game against the team with the best record in the league, Celtics Coach Doc Rivers somehow saw an opportunity for experimentation on Wednesday night. With 5 minutes 22 seconds remaining in the third quarter, Rivers substituted the diminutive Nate Robinson for Shaquille ONeal, dropping 145 pounds and 14 inches of listed height from his on-court lineup.

title: Solar Start-Up Plans Big Factory in South Carolina
description: As American solar companies face intense competition with low-cost Chinese manufacturers, a Silicon Valley photovoltaic cell maker has announced that it will open a huge factory in South Carolina.

title: SmartyPig Cuts Interest RatesAgain
description: SmartyPig customers received a disappointing note when they logged into their accounts this week: the online savings bank cut its interest rate  the second rate cut in less than four months  to 1.35 percent from 1.75 percent.

title: Two Missed Moment to Solemnly Swear
description: Representative Pete Sessions, Republican of Texas, the man who served as chairman of the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee, and can claim a large portion of the credit for helping his party win the majority in the House, somehow managed to miss the Oath of Office on Wednesday. Apparently, so did Representative-elect Mike Fitzpatrick, a Republican from Pennsylvania.

title: Its a Smart Kitchen
description: LAS VEGAS  How do you transform what is seen as a dated somewhat stodgy company into a retailer of cool?

title: Pentagon Seeks Biggest Military Cuts Since Before 9/11
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Thursday that the nations extreme fiscal duress now required him to call for cuts in the size of the Army and Marine Corps, reversing the significant growth in military spending that followed the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Consumer Watchdog Builds Up Its Ranks
description: 5:41 p.m. | Updated

title: A Young Carmen, but Worldly Still
description: If the young Georgian mezzo-soprano Anita Rachvelishvili was nervous about making her Metropolitan Opera debut on Wednesday night in the title role of Bizets Carmen, she did not show it. She brought an ample, earthy voice and sensual lyricism to her performance, winning a hearty ovation. Her Don Jos was the tenor Roberto Alagna, who had sung the role to acclaim opposite Elina Garanca when this Richard Eyre production, effectively updated to Spain in the 1930s, was introduced on New Years Eve of 2009.

title: As Snow Approaches, Mayor Rolls Out New Measures
description: Read the longer version of this article that appeared in Fridays paper.

title: TimesCast | January 6, 2011
description: William M. Daley is named the White House chief of staff; Pakistan reacts to a top politician's assassination; a comedian finds a loyal podcast audience.

title: Kayaking in the Florida Keys
description: Visitors leave the islands behind to explore the area with paddle in hand.

title: Chamber: Daley Tough, but a Very Strong Choice
description: President Obama picked William M. Daley, a former commerce secretary, at least in part, for his ability to speak the language of big business and repair Mr. Obamas bruised relations with corporate America.

title: Light Therapy for Depression
description: Antidepressants like Prozac and Paxil are widely used to treat depression, but a much less costly alternative called bright light therapy, in which a patient sits under an artificial light for a set period of time each day, is not. Light therapy is typically recommended for seasonal affective disorder, the winter blues brought on by shorter days and limited sun. Some psychiatrists prescribe it for this condition, often as a last resort when patients fail to respond to drugs.

title: Porsche Heralds Lower Prices in Canada With Cheeky Ad
description: 12:14 p.m. | Updated

title: Potential N.F.L. Top Pick to Stay at Stanford
description: Andrew Luck will return to Stanford for his redshirt junior season, risking millions of dollars by forgoing the opportunity to be the No. 1 pick in the 2011 N.F.L. draft.

title: Morgan Stanley Reshuffles
description: Morgan Stanleys reshuffling continues.

title: Broads Detail Plans for New Los Angeles Museum
description: The philanthropists Edythe and Eli Broad unveiled plans on Thursday in Los Angeles for the museum that will be named after them and house their substantial collection of contemporary art.

title: Gotham States of Mind In All of Their Tempos
description: An intimate arbitrary iPod shuffle is Barbara Fasanos capsule description of Helluva Town: A New York Soundtrack, the exhilarating new show she and her husband and musical partner, Eric Comstock, have brought to the Oak Room at the Algonquin Hotel.

title: Protesters and Police Clash in Bangkok
description: Antigovernment protesters repulsed an attempt by the military to disperse them in fierce running battles filled with tear gas, gunfire and explosions in the worst political violence in nearly 20 years.

title: Hues of Debussy in a Program Without Him
description: At home in Los Angeles the pianist Gloria Cheng is a celebrity: an invaluable new-music advocate and a preferred collaborator of composers like Pierre Boulez and Esa-Pekka Salonen. A review of a recital Ms. Cheng presented at the Colburn School of Performing Arts in September breathlessly conjured a heady, star-studded scene. But Ms. Chengs copious gifts are scarcely a mystery here, a point proved by the sizable, luminary-filled throng that assembled for one of her too infrequent New York appearances, at Le Poisson Rouge on Wednesday night.

title: E.P.A. Faces First Volley From the House
description: The newly empowered Republicans in the House arent wasting any time making good on their pledge to throttle the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: The Tipsy Diaries: One Last Toast to 2010
description: The following statement sounds as much like an invitation for an intervention as a boast. Ah, well: I had a whole lot to drink last year.

title: Exploring That Old Knee-Slapper, Suicide
description: When Daniel Kitson was about 9, he told his teacher that he was thinking of killing himself. At some point over the next few decades, he forgot this had ever happened, until just over a week ago when his mother reminded him. Asked in an interview if he really was suicidal or if it was just a plea for attention, he said with a merry chuckle, I have no idea.

title: Producers, Not Paparazzi, to Honor Penn
description: Sean Penn will be celebrated for his humanitarianism (towards everyone but paparazzi) by the Producers Guild of America, which will bestow him with the Stanley Kramer Award, the group announced on Thursday. Named for the producer and director who made High Noon, The Caine Mutiny and Guess Whos Coming to Dinner, and was apparently known as Hollywoods Conscience, the prize honors a motion picture, producer or other individual, whose achievement or contribution illuminates provocative social issues in an accessible and elevating fashion. It will be given to Mr. Penn at the guilds ceremony on Jan. 22.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: The Philosopher King  The best-performing hedge fund in 2010 was Structured Portfolio Management, which is run by a former philosophy teacher. The hedge fund, with $2 billion in assets under management, returned 50 percent in the first 10 months of 2010, reports Bloomberg Markets magazine.Bloomberg Markets

title: Babes in Letters
description: My 2-year-old attends birthday parties for her preschool pals. She then receives thank-you notes for the gifts we bring, written by her friends and addressed to her, even though none of them can speak (much less write): I especially loved the markers since I color every day after my nap. I expected to make my kids write thank-you notes once they could write their own names, but should I be writing them in the meantime, in my daughters voice, to kids who cant read?

title: Defrauding Nuns
description: Just try to imagine a securities law violator less likely to find a sympathetic jury.

title: How to Crochet a Cozy for a Charging Bull
description: Your post-lunchtime, pre-supper distraction has arrived.

title: Sara Lee Favors Split After Rebuffing JBS
description: Sara Lee is leaning toward splitting itself into its meats and coffee businesses after rejecting a takeover bid by JBS of Brazil, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Thursday.

title: Facebook Looks Toward 2012 I.P.O.
description: Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook.

title: Guess Where This Is, Day 2
description: Welcome to our second installment of Guess Where This Is.

title: Hungarian Leader Takes On Foreign Critics
description: BUDAPEST, Hungary  Normally, European Union member states start their six-month rotations as holders of the presidency in a political glow, with high hopes of shaping the European agenda and increasing their stature. But for Hungary, which took up the post at the start of the year, the spotlight has been harsher.

title: Weekend Miser
description: At the start of this brand-new year, the Miser took a moment to reflect on all the great parties, game nights, performances and events we were able to share last year and decided: it wasnt enough. So this week we direct you to fellow columnists and Web sites out there working just as hard to keep this city safe for your wallet.

title: Marilyns Manhattan, Both Public and Private
description: A girl on a balcony: when I look out the rear window of my East 60th Street apartment, I see her as if I were watching an outdoor movie on a misty night. The girl I see is not Juliet but Marilyn, and the movie is The Seven Year Itch. A town house whose backyard meets mine appears in that 1955 film, in which Marilyn Monroe played the delicious unnamed Girl subletting an apartment for the summer.

title: In His Own Image
description: MIRRORS, and the people who love them, may have a deservedly bad rap for being as shallow as silver plate. But not every mirror is made of silver and glass. Dont we look for our reflections in all kinds of surfaces without even realizing it? How else can we recognize ourselves?

description: Newark

description: Photographs from Pakistan, Israel, Australia and Sudan.

title: Sushi, With Opera for Dessert
description: TORA YI doesnt always make the best business decisions. Soon after he opened Ido Sushi, the restaurant he runs with his wife, Young, on an overlooked stretch of Seventh Avenue in the West Village, he tore out the bar  usually a restaurants money maker  that dominated the room. He wanted to make space for a piano, a stage and the revolving door of opera singers and musicians who now perform most nights, blasting arias and recitatives across the table tops.

description: Piers Morgan will kick off his new nightly talk show on CNN with the most prominent daily talk show host, Oprah Winfrey, as his first guest.

description: Around Town

title: Sufism Under Attack in Pakistan
description: Sufism, Pakistan's most popular branch of Islam, has seen a rise of attacks against its worshipers at shrines. The bombings are part of an ongoing battle to enforce a more conservative brand of Islam.

title: A Steady Dose of Atmospheric Detergent
description: To start the new year on a hopeful note, here is a piece of good news about the environment. A new study suggests that the level of a substance that acts as a kind of detergent in the atmosphere is a lot steadier than previously believed.

title: First Details of New Irish Arts Festival in U.S. Are Unveiled
description: An operatic version of The Importance of Being Earnest, national tours by the Abbey Theater and the Druid Theater Company and an Irish film series curated by Gabriel Byrne at the Museum of Modern Art are among the highlights of a year-long Irish arts series in the United States that will be funded by the Irish government, press representatives for the series said on Thursday.

title: Sushi, With Opera for Dessert
description: Tora Yi doesnt always make the best business decisions. Soon after he opened Ido Sushi, the restaurant he runs with his wife, Young, on an overlooked stretch of Seventh Avenue in the West Village, he tore out the bar  usually a restaurants money maker  that dominated the room. He wanted to make space for a piano, a stage and the revolving door of opera singers and musicians who now perform most nights, blasting arias and recitatives across the table tops.

title: Spare Times: For Children for Jan. 7-13
description: HIP-HOP SHAKESPEARE

title: Young and Restless, And Ready to Rock n Roll
description: A BRIGHT young man strode to the bar. He leaned in, pausing purposefully. I want a Coke with 10 cherries, he declared, slamming his fist. Leo Lorge, 7, was at the Living Room, a club on the Lower East Side, for a rock show  not for a childrens concert, and certainly not for a plain old Coke.

title: The Everyday Lives of American Slaves
description: WASHINGTON  American slaves managed ingeniously to acquire a few material comforts. They wove their own twine fishing nets and grass baskets, and molded and kilned ceramic bowls with African motifs. On patches of land near their cabins they grew gourds to adapt into banjos, rattles and drums.

title: Blast Awakens Egyptians to Threat From Religious Strife
description: CAIRO  A deadly suicide bomb attack outside a Christian church in Alexandria on Saturday has forced the government and religious leaders here to acknowledge that Egypt is increasingly plagued by a sectarian divide that could undermine the stability that has been a hallmark of President Hosni Mubaraks nearly three decades in power.

title: At C.E.S., the Geekiness Is Palpable
description: LAS VEGAS  Just landed at the Consumer Electronics Show! Already, you can just feel the geekiness emitting like gamma rays from the huge convention centers.

title: Bill OReilly to Interview President Obama
description: President Obamas pre-Super Bowl interviewers have been Matt Lauer, in 2009, and Katie Couric, in 2010. This year hell add to that list  Bill OReilly.

title: The Repeal the Senior-Murdering Secret Muslim President Act
description: I wish I could work up some more outrage about the willingness of Republicans to simply ignore the CBOs verdict that repealing the Affordable Care Act, aka Obamacare, aka Romneycare, would increase the budget deficit. But anyone who had been following the politics here, not just this year, but for the past 15 years at least knew this was coming.

title: On Hiatus From the Swiss Goats
description: Pop-cultural anthropologists have spent ample ink tracking the evolution of the American diva over the last three decades, from the coronation of the melisma queens (Whitney Houston, Mariah Carey) through the rampage of the sex kittens (Britney Spears, Christina Aguilera) to the deification of the love warrior (Beyonc) and on to the current reign of hook-driven power-pop princesses (Lady Gaga, Rihanna, Katy Perry).

title: Spamming Declines, at Least Temporarily
description: Call it a Christmas gift from the cybercrime underground.

title: I Am Woman. Hear Me Sob, YAll.
description: The corn is as high as a mechanical bulls eye in Country Strong, a runny-mascara melodrama about a country-western superstar warbling, weeping and wailing her way back from another stint in rehab to the glare of the stage. Gwyneth Paltrow, working a deep-fried accent and a strategically conspicuous cross necklace, plays Kelly Canter, a high-profile train wreck who, in the wake of a disastrous tour and an alcohol-induced miscarriage, heads back on the road in hopes of setting her life and career straight. As they apparently like to say in Hollywood (still!), the only successful woman is a desperately unhappy woman.

title: Pogues Posts: The Geekiness Is Palpable
description: LAS VEGAS  Just landed at the Consumer Electronics Show here! Already, you can just feel the geekiness emitting like gamma rays from the huge convention centers.

title: The Cat Is Stuffed, but the Bird Is Real
description: Museum curators routinely face all kinds of challenges: delicate works of art that need special attention, fragile artist egos that require careful stroking, unwilling lenders who need convincing. At the Whitney Museum of American Art right now there is a particularly unusual character, requiring attention 24/7. Its Peetie, a blue parakeet that is having something of a star moment on the fifth floor.

title: A Solitary Stroll Gives Way to a Full-Band Excursion
description: For the first stretch of an extended evening at Le Poisson Rouge on Wednesday, Marc Ribot sat curled around his acoustic guitar in a fog of righteous solitude. His opener, Bateau, came on like a cold current of air, with tremulous fingerpicking in a slow-swirling, immaterial tempo. The brittle melody that surfaced, with its classical intimations, was set against a yawning low drone on a slack-tuned open string.

title: City Ballet Creates A Troupe For Touring
description: New York City Ballet is creating a small and nimble touring ensemble in the hopes of broadening its appeal around the country and the world.

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Jan. 7-13
description: Pop

title: A Marriage of Design, Aged in the Wood
description: Yankee ingenuity, visionary imagination and the particular aesthetic of the Arts and Crafts movement are a neat fit in The Artistic Furniture of Charles Rohlfs, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, a small show tucked in among the period rooms in the American Wing.

title: Panel to Advise Regents on Sales by Museums
description: The New York State Board of Regents has named a 16-member advisory group to address the controversial issues surrounding the selling of art and artifacts by museums to cover operating expenses, known as deaccessioning. The list of members, reported on Wednesday at artsjournal.com, includes Thelma Golden, director of the Studio Museum in Harlem; Martin E. Sullivan, director of the National Portrait Gallery; Anne W. Ackerson, director of the Museum Association of New York; and Henry Lanman, associate general counsel of the Museum of Modern Art. The group, the Ad Hoc Advisory Committee on Deaccessioning, has met once so far, on Dec. 15, and is led by Carole Huxley, who for 24 years served as deputy commissioner for cultural education. The Regents really want to hear what the issues are and really want to get it right, said Michael Botwinick, director of the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers. Debate over the question of how to handle deaccessioning prompted the creation of the Regents committee, said Merryl H. Tisch, the chancellor of the Board of Regents, in a telephone interview on Thursday.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: Classical

title: Footnotes
description: Eiko & Koma and members of the Paul Taylor Dance Company are among the performers scheduled to appear next Friday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in honor of the 80th birthday of Charles L. Reinhart, president of the American Dance Festival. The evening is free but reservations are required: (212) 586-1925. ... The Works & Process series is trying something new for its latest installment on Sunday, a performance by members of Pacific Northwest Ballet at the Guggenheim Museum. The sold-out event, featuring excerpts from the companys coming new staging of Giselle, will be live-streamed on the Web. Viewers can also take part in an online chat at the same time. The performance and chat will be at ustream.tv/channel/worksandprocess.

title: Fewer Viewers Honor Peoples Choice Awards
description: As the Modern Family star Eric Stonestreet, below, wrote on his Twitter account on Thursday morning, Beating the Peoples Choice Awards in the ratings is kinda better than winning a Peoples Choice Award. That remark came the morning after Glee bested Modern Family in the Favorite TV Comedy category at the Peoples Choice Awards on Wednesday night, and after the awards show itself was beaten by several other prime-time programs, including Modern Family. A two-hour episode of Law & Order: SVU (10.7 million viewers) helped lift NBC to the top of the ratings on Wednesday night, according to Nielsens estimates, and ABC had strong performances from its comedies The Middle (9.3 million) and Modern Family (11.8 million). CBS was second for the night, but its new reality competition Live to Dance (7.8 million), with Paula Abdul, declined in its second outing, and the networks broadcast of the 37th annual Peoples Choice Awards (9.5 million) was down considerably from last year. ABC ranked third for the night, and Fox finished in fourth place with back-to-back episodes of Human Target (6.3 million).

title: Bony Wings That Went Pow! Smack! Whomp!
description: An extinct bird from Jamaica used its wings as a powerful clublike weapon, according to a new study.

title: A Man With a Cape and a City to Salvage
description: The Gotham of Christopher Nolans Batman movies (The Dark Knight, Batman Begins) is a bleak-looking place where the light is charcoal, and the mood is caught between 1970s Manhattan and Dantes Inferno. Crime rates are high; so too is the general misery index. A sense of grim deterioration is ever present.

title: Movie Listings for Jan. 7-13
description: Movies

title: This Family Restaurant Is All About the People
description: Watching Bobs Burgers, Foxs new Sunday night cartoon, is a good-news, bad-news proposition. The bad news is that the show, the networks latest dysfunctional-animated-family comedy, is at best mildly funny, at least in the first episode (the only one provided to critics). The good news? Its not another grating half-hour from the mind of Seth MacFarlane, who already occupies three of the five slots in Foxs Animation Domination lineup.

title: Toyota Aims to Remain King of the Hybrids
description: TOKYO  As Toyota heads to the Detroit auto show that opens Monday, the company aims to burnish its reputation as a leader in environmental technology  an image increasingly under threat from resurgent rivals.

title: Be There or Be Square, 1830 to the Present
description: IN the 1830s St. Marks Place was one of New Yorks best addresses, a dignified street of chaste Federal-style mansions for the citys first families. Today, just three remnants of the streets golden age still stand, and it is a fair contender for the title of bong capital of the world, with its tumbledown shops for vintage records, punk clothing and drug paraphernalia.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Jan. 7-13
description: Art

title: Under the Radar: 5 Questions About Ameriville
description: Theres not much to sing and dance about when it comes to Hurricane Katrina and the devastating path it took through New Orleans. But thats exactly what happens in Ameriville, a piece written and performed by the company Universes (Gamal Abdel Chasten, Mildred Ruiz, William Ruiz and Steven Sapp) and directed by the playwright Chay Yew. The show, part of the Under the Radar Festival, uses hip-hop choreography and assorted musical genres  blues, gospel, jazz  to examine issues of race and class as they played out across the country after Katrina hit.

title: Jazz Listings
description: Jazz

title: Sadrists Project Confidence in Iraq
description: NAJAF, Iraq  It was fewer than seven lines of handwritten Arabic on a small piece of paper, bearing his stamp. But with it, Moktada al-Sadr, son of a revered ayatollah and scourge of the American occupation, made clear on Thursday that he was in charge again of a group that has begun shaping Iraq as the United States withdraws.

title: Sincerest Forms of Flattery for British Shows
description: Watching Downton Abbey, a thoroughly enjoyable British series on PBS about masters and servants in a stately home on the eve of World War I, is a bit like buying a trunk at Restoration Hardware. Both are copies, of course, but so shrewdly and exactingly recreated that they are almost as gratifying as the original.

title: A Bar Where Everybody Knows Your Pole Dance
description: Heaven, David Byrne likes to sing, is a bar where the band plays your favorite song and everyone leaves the party at the same time. Mostly, though, heaven is a place, a place where nothing, nothing ever happens, which pretty much describes the usual scene at Ray Rubys Paradise Lounge. A gorgeously tawdry nirvana set in Manhattan, Paradise Lounge is an old-school strip club run by a soulful dreamer, Ray Ruby (a wonderful Willem Dafoe), who with love and not enough money is struggling to keep his people and parts in play  a beautiful metaphor for the filmmaking hard times faced by the likes of Abel Ferrara.

title: A Record-Breaking New Years Eve for Twitter
description: It didnt take long for Twitter to break its own record as we rolled into 2011. The company said on Thursday that a mere four seconds after midnight in Japan, users set a new all-time record of the number of Tweets sent per second across the social network.

title: New Sparkle for an Abstract Ensemble
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  In the echo chamber that is the New York art world, where one voice can give the illusion of being many, the crusading cry of late is We need more painting! As if there were a dearth. Is there? Walk through any of the citys art museums, and what do see? Paintings everywhere. Visit contemporary galleries all over town, and what do you find? Theyre painting packed. But still the cry goes on.

title: When Mortgage Rate Locks Expire
description: AS mortgage rates have edged higher, many borrowers have been locking in loan rates for a home purchase or refinancing.

title: Art Made Up of Movies Tells a Story All Its Own
description: The global influence of blockbuster movies on the collective psyche of humanity is awesome, if not terrifying, to contemplate. Much ink has been devoted to analyzing the social effects  usually viewed as pernicious  of popular cinema, and that thinking has spilled over into contemporary art. Andy Warhol, Cindy Sherman, Douglas Gordon and many other artists have made the Hollywood feature an object of skeptical scrutiny.

title: Light Out, Huck, They Still Want to Sivilize You
description: All modern American literature, Ernest Hemingway once wrote, comes from one book by Mark Twain called Huckleberry Finn.

title: Buick Seeks Younger Buyer With Verano Compact Sedan
description: Getting a jump on next weeks Detroit auto show, Buick on Thursday unveiled its Verano, a downsized-yet-upmarket sedan that will give Buick its first compact car since the late, unloved Skylark of 1997.

title: Q & A
description: On the Dotted Line, One More Time

title: Scott Rechler
description: Mr. Rechler, 43, is the chief executive and chairman of RXR Realty, which owns and operates office buildings in the New York area, including 1330 Avenue of the Americas and 340 Madison Avenue.

title: S.E.C. Questions Goldman Sachs on Offering
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has contacted Goldman Sachs about the private offering of Facebook shares to Goldman Sachss clients, according to a document sent to potential investors.

title: Political Theater, Brought to You by the Politically Powerless
description: A playwrights legacy throbs with anguished, enduring life in Being Harold Pinter, a work of harrowing intensity and commitment from the Belarus Free Theater at La MaMa, part of the Under the Radar Festival of experimental theater that began this week. Tracing the relationship between power and violence in the works of Pinter, who died in 2008, this production out of Eastern Europe is both dismaying and extraordinarily heartening.

title: The Recombinant DNA of the Mash-Up
description: Milestones in sonic marriages over the past 104 years.

title: The 373-Hit Wonder
description: Imagine old, bald Pete Townshend shuffling gingerly onstage as a synth burbles up behind him  Let My Love Open the Door. Now imagine the rapper Pimp C already on that stage, in a white fur suit and hat, holding up four fingers to show off his bling. A kick line of girls in black minishorts walks it out for DJ Unk, whos rapping about a kick line of girls, then Levon Helm appears on a drum riser to chirp out The Weight. Also onstage: Jay-Z, Black Sabbath, Rick Springfield, Kesha, Bruce Springsteen, Miley Cyrus, the Ramones and Tupac and Biggie Smalls (both back from the dead) and hundreds more. In the audience are a few thousand fans jammed together beneath a blinding light show, waving their arms as rolls of toilet paper and explosions of confetti fall around them. You sense theyre feeling the same freedom, daring and camaraderie that they might at a house party when someones parents are away. This is pretty much the state of affairs at a Girl Talk show these days.

title: How Do You Make Adobo?
description: On Thursday morning, nytimes.com published my article about cooking the Filipino dish chicken adobo. By Thursday night my inbox was flooded with responses, most of them offering emendations to the recipe that accompanied the column, which was based on the excellent adobo prepared at a Brooklyn restaurant, Purple Yam. You must use peppercorns! You cannot use soy sauce! Fish is best, or chicken, or pork. Its better the next day. Its worse the next day. You must do this to the rice. Or that.

title: Artistic Furniture
description: The designer Charles Rohlfs is the subject of a new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Dance Listings
description: Dance

title: Marshall McLuhan: Media Savant
description: Oh boy, yet another book about yet another modern thinker who suggests that electronic interdependence is the defining aspect of our time. All very ho-hum, except Marshall McLuhan, the subject of this book, figured it out 50 years before anybody ever updated his Facebook page or posted his whereabouts on Twitter.

title: In Nazareth, Human Comedy as Wind Rustles the Olive Branches
description: The Time That Remains is described by its subtitle as the chronicle of a present absentee, a paradoxical formulation that reveals a lot about the temperament of its director, Elia Suleiman. Mr. Suleiman, an Arab born in the Israeli city Nazareth in 1960 and currently living in Paris, has an exquisite eye for the conflicts and contradictions that bedevil his native city, but he examines them without polemics or sentimentality. The Time That Remains has the scope of a historical epic with none of the expected heaviness. It presents a half-century of tragedy and turmoil as a series of mordant comic vignettes. Imagine a heroic poem boiled down to a flurry of witty epigrams, or a martial statue made of origami, and you will have some idea of the improbable way this filmmaker folds big themes into delicate forms.

title: Barnes & Noble Up, Borders Down
description: Unlike its struggling rival Borders, Barnes & Noble, the nations largest book chain, said on Thursday that it finished the holiday season with stronger sales than expected, reporting its highest comparable store sales increase since 1997. That increase was 9.7 percent over the same nine-week period the year before, while overall store sales increased 8.2 percent, to $1.1 billion.

title: The Islam That Hard-Liners Hate
description: KASUR, Pakistan  In Pakistans heartland, holy men with bells tied to their feet close their eyes and sway to the music. Nearby, rose petals are tossed on tombstones. Free food is distributed to devotees.

title: These United States
description: The doldrums between the beginning of the year and the Oscars is often a dumping ground for bottom-of-the-barrel movies that should probably have stayed there. Americatown is no exception: this bizarre sort-of satire featuring insane characters doing incomprehensible things might be forgivable if it were even mildly amusing. Its not.

title: Deserters From the Crusades
description: By this point most of us have stopped trying to figure out Nicolas Cages career logic. With a rsum that encompasses Oscar winner, action star and indie darling, this supremely talented actor continues to confound us with choices like Season of the Witch, a 14th-century road movie with 21st-century cuss words.

title: Apple Approached Blackstones C.F.O. About Potential Job
description: 8:39 p.m. | Updated For a company with little need for Wall Street, its a little unusual that Apple would approach a top executive at a financial firm for a corner-suite spot.

title: Investors Bet on Catastrophe Bonds
description: Investors, still reeling from one disaster, are betting on the likelihood of another.

title: MBIA Fights Banks for Its Life
description: MBIA, an insurance company whose very existence is imperiled because it underestimated the risks involved in mortgage lending, says the banks owe it billions because they lied about the mortgages backing securities that MBIA insured. The insurers financial statements show it is solvent in large part because that money will be coming in.

title: Obama Plan Aims to Ease Mexican Trucking Ban
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration offered a proposal on Thursday to allow long-haul Mexican trucks to move cargo in the United States.

title: Rex Ryan Says Brady Doesnt Study Like Manning
description: First, the Jets would have to beat the Colts. But if they do, Rex Ryan has given a head start to what would be a circus-like week of Jets-Patriots anticipation.

title: Blue Shield of California Plans to Raise Some Rates Up to 59%
description: Blue Shield of California, the insurer, submitted a proposal on Thursday to raise rates on individual policyholders by as much as 59 percent beginning March 1.

title: Geithner Asks Congress to Raise U.S. Debt Limit Quickly
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration warned Congress on Thursday that the government would reach its legal borrowing limit as early as the end of March and no later than May 16 and urged House and Senate leaders to move quickly to raise the debt ceiling to avoid an unprecedented default.

title: A Tablet for Panasonics Television
description: LAS VEGAS  If the two prevailing themes at this years Consumer Electronics Show have been Internet-connected televisions and tablet computers, then Panasonic is aiming to kill both birds with one stone.

title: Financier Is Described as Addicted to Medicine
description: HOUSTON  R. Allen Stanford, the Texas financier accused of defrauding investors in a $7 billion Ponzi scheme, has become addicted to antianxiety medication while in federal detention, and that drug is probably contributing to fits of delirium, according to the testimony of several psychiatrists at a court hearing Thursday to determine his fitness to stand trial.

title: Greeting the New Year for Too Long
description: You have probably said them or heard them dozens of times this past week, three little words that form the seasons main greeting: Happy New Year. What could be more innocuous?

title: WikiLeaks Cables Make Appearance in a Tale of Sunken Treasure and Nazi Theft
description: ATLANTA  The latest twist in the WikiLeaks tale is a plot worthy of a Tom Clancy thriller.

title: The Best Present Money Can Buy
description: Princeton, N.J.

title: General Recommended for Army Post
description: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates announced Thursday that he had recommended Gen. Martin E. Dempsey to be nominated as Army chief of staff. General Dempsey, now overseeing all Army training and doctrine, served two tours during the war in Iraq: as division commander in Baghdad and as senior officer for efforts to train Iraqi security forces. His past assignments include acting commander at the Central Command, which controls all American military forces in the Middle East. THOM SHANKER

title: Ex-C.I.A. Officer Named in Disclosure Indictment
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department on Thursday announced the indictment of a former Central Intelligence Agency officer who is accused of disclosing classified information to a reporter, in the latest example of a crackdown by the Obama administration on leaking to journalists.

title: Pond or Rink, Rangers Create Their Own Winter Classic
description: The invigorating sight of hockey players in their gaudy outfits flitting through the wintry gloom  outdoors  has become an annual ritual on New Years Day, in only four years.

title: Young Chef in a Quest to Become Independent
description: Standing behind a long stainless-steel counter in a commercial kitchen, Diana Rutherford deftly chops a pile of carrots. Her eyes, traced with black liner and lids dusted with powdery blues and gold, are focused. Her teeth grab at a pin that pierces her lower lip as she concentrates on each cut. A tattoo on her hand is a reminder of the past: a teardrop for her deceased brother, five dots for the brothers still living, a cross for her faith, and the letters SL for St. Louis, the city where she made a commitment to a life outside the religious sect of her youth.

title: City to Press for Easing of Civil Service Requirements
description: The Bloomberg administration will call on Friday for far-reaching changes to the states 127-year-old civil service system governing New York Citys work force, including de-emphasizing civil service exams in hiring municipal workers.

title: Medicare Coverage for Breast Cancer Drug Ends in Some States
description: Breast cancer patients in some states may soon lose Medicare coverage for the expensive drug Avastin, after the Food and Drug Administrations decision to revoke the drugs approval for that disease.

title: First South Carolina. Then New York?
description: In the wake of South Carolinas vote to secession in late December 1860, Americans both North and South anxiously wondered which state would be next to leave the Union. Little did they realize that the next call for secession would come not from a Southern state, but from a Northern city  New York City.

title: Last Call at the Bunny Roundup
description: Lets just get this out of the way before the new year is all backed up with highly consequential events of much greater urgency: Hugh Hefner is repulsive.

title: The Downsizing in Detroit
description: WAYNE, Mich.  Ten years ago, the Ford Motor plant here churned out giant Expedition and Navigator sport utility vehicles that got 12 miles to the gallon  and it was one of the most profitable auto factories in the world.

title: Religious Leaders Call for New Efforts to Lower the Citys Chilling Abortion Rate
description: Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan of New York joined other local religious leaders on Thursday in calling for a new effort to reduce the number of abortions in the city. The annual figure has averaged 90,000 in recent years, or about 40 percent of all pregnancies, twice the national rate.

title: Dining Experiences, All Illicit, That Extend Beyond the Palate
description: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen.

title: Frank Bonilla, Scholar of Puerto Rican Studies, Dies at 85
description: Frank Bonilla, an academic who grew up in two of New Yorks poorest neighborhoods, faced segregation in the Midwest and went on to create one of the nations first college-level Puerto Rican studies programs and its first consortium for Latino studies, died on Dec. 28 in Escondido, Calif. He was 85.

title: Stoudemires Knee? So Far, So Good
description: Amare Stoudemire soars, and the hopes of every Knicks fan rise with him. He is airborne for fractions of a second, but in the moment there is elation, anticipation, a breathless, palpable thrill as he flies toward the basket.

title: Marin Agrees to Seek Out Minorities
description: Marin County has agreed to research why it has so few minority residents relative to the rest of the Bay Area and to take specific actions to attract more low-income people and ethnic minorities to the affluent county, which is more than 80 percent white.

title: For House Members Looking to Save Money, a Day at the Office Never Ends
description: WASHINGTON  Hansen Clarke, a newly elected Democrat from Michigan, is coming to Washington with a warriors mentality to help stave off unemployment and foreclosures in metro Detroit. He plans to hole up in his bunker  his Longworth House office, where he will work (practically around the clock), eat (healthy options like microwaved sweet potatoes) and sleep (most likely on a mattress and sleeping bag combination).

title: Guilty Plea in Theft From Drew Archive
description: A college freshman who was accused of taking historic letters and artifacts in the six months that he worked in the library at Drew University pleaded guilty on Tuesday to one count of theft of a cultural object from a museum.

title: Facebook Readies Track for I.P.O.; Goldman Faces Questions
description: Facebook says that it will begin reporting its financial results by April 2012, setting the stage for a likely public stock offering, according to a document sent by Goldman Sachs to potential investors.

title: Lottery Numbers
Two Packages Emit Smoke in Maryland State Buildings
description: Two packages that contained incendiary devices that emitted a brief flame and smoke were opened Thursday in Maryland state office buildings about 15 minutes apart, but caused no serious injuries, the police said. One package was addressed to Gov. Martin OMalley.

title: After Slump, Mannings Season Looks Up
description: INDIANAPOLIS  His arm strength has been questioned. His ability to continue as the starter was dismissed in an angry rant by his teams radio announcer. His brilliant career was ever so slightly sullied by a confounding three-week slump.

title: Behind-the-Scenes Power Politics: The Making of a Mayor
description: On Sunday afternoon, former Mayor Willie L. Brown Jr. made an urgent call to Rose Pak, his longtime political ally and the powerful head of the Chinatown Chamber of Commerce. Word had trickled out that San Franciscos Board of Supervisors had narrowed the list of interim candidates to replace Mayor Gavin Newsom, the lieutenant governor-elect.

title: Christie Signs Tougher Law on Bullying in Schools
description: New Jersey on Thursday enacted the nations toughest law against bullying and harassment in schools, three and a half months after the suicide of a Rutgers University student drew national attention to the issue.

title: Georgia Facing a Hard Choice on Free Tuition
description: ATHENS, Ga.  Students here at the University of Georgia have a name for some of the fancy cars parked in the lots around campus. They call them Hopemobiles. But there may soon be fewer of them.

title: Christie Outlines a Plan to Pay for Transit Work
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey laid out a plan on Thursday to pay for five years of work on the states roads, rails and bridges by borrowing $4.4 billion and asking the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to cover the cost of four projects in the northeastern part of the state.

title: Taurasis Deal Terminated as Test Confirms Violation
description: Diana Taurasis Olympic and professional basketball career grew more uncertain Thursday when the Turkish basketball federation said it had confirmed her doping violation and that her club team in Istanbul had terminated her contract.

title: Diet Companies Promote New Ways to Reduce
description: DIET season is here, and three well-known bulge-busting companies  Weight Watchers, Nutrisystem and Jenny Craig  have made major changes in their programs for consumers looking to shed weight packed on during the holidays, or before.

title: Mayor Says, This Time, City Will Be Ready for Storm
description: A day after the demotion of the Emergency Medical Services chief, two New York City sanitation supervisors were reassigned on Thursday for their performance in the blizzard last week. The mayor vowed that the moves were not the last word on the subject and that the city was ready for the snow forecast for Friday.

title: Goldmans Calculated Risk Won Facebook Deal
description: Goldman Sachss rivals must be kicking themselves. The firms nearly $2 billion investment connection with Facebook is relatively small financially, but its big in franchise terms. After the lumps Goldman took last year, the deal showed the firm could still wrap its tentacles around an important client for mutual benefit.

title: A Showcase of Ethnic Dancing at a Bargain Price
description: For fans of Bharata Natyam (Southern India), Chaoxian (China), Jalisco (Mexico) and other traditional dance styles, the San Francisco Ethnic Dance Festival is a must-see event.

title: With Android Phones, Verizon Is in Position to Gain Lost Ground
description: LAS VEGAS  Five years ago, Verizon passed on the chance to be the exclusive carrier of the iPhone in the United States because it could not agree on the terms of a deal with Apple.

title: Blyleven Is the Hall of Fames Merry Prankster
description: Bert Blyleven waited so long for election to the Hall of Fame that he is basically from another era, before the chemical haze of the 1990s complicated the question of who belongs in Cooperstown.

title: A Shift in Tactics, Not in Ideology
description: WASHINGTON  Most of the talk in Democratic circles on Thursday, after it became known that President Obama had chosen William M. Daley as his chief of staff, was of going back to the 1990s. The consensus was that Mr. Obama, who once held himself out as the clear alternative to the political expedience of the Clinton years, had, in the end, chosen the path of Clintonian centrism over a return to more boldly progressive ideals.

title: C.E.S. 2011: Merging the Internet and TV
description: At this year's Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, numerous companies are showing off the newest technologies that merge television sets with the power of the Internet.

title: Friday: Trickery Afoot
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Just when weve managed to make it through our week and are looking around for some fluffy brain candy, Joe DiPietro hits us with a puzzle that is filled with misdirection and tough cluing, but were not going to WHINE are we? This is a fun, challenging solve, and fun and challenging are the natural order of things on a Friday here at Wordplay.

title: A Sense of Touch, a Sense of Life
description: Lifes darkest terrors and most visceral delights both play a role in A Small Fire, a new drama by Adam Bock that opened Thursday night at Playwrights Horizons. This low-key, quietly moving play features a protagonist who falls victim to a mysterious, debilitating disease  cue the violins  but also features a frank, strenuous sex scene of daring honesty, making for a theatrical combo plate that proves unusually satisfying.

title: FIFA Result Shows Growing Influence of Middle East
description: LONDON

title: Constitution Has Its Day (More or Less) in House
description: WASHINGTON  If you are a member of the House and you plan to read the text of the Constitution on the floor, its probably a good idea to have already taken the oath to support and defend it first.

title: Going to an Event Featuring Cuomo? Take a Coat, or Maybe a Blanket
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said he would bring a fresh breeze to Albany.

title: 2 Bronx Teenagers Arrested in Stabbing Outside a School
description: Two teenagers were arrested early Thursday in the stabbing of a student outside his Bronx high school a day earlier.

title: Questions Emerge About How Panel to Review Crime Statistics Will Work
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kellys appointment of three former federal prosecutors to evaluate the integrity of the Police Departments internal system for recording crime data has posed the panel with a weighty task. But first it faces a more mundane question: how to proceed.

title: Buckle Up for Round 2
description: The health care reform law was signed 10 months ago, and whats striking now is how vulnerable it looks. Several threats have emerged  some of them scarcely discussed before passage  that together or alone could seriously endanger the new system. These include:

title: Exiled by Ike, Saved by America
description: New Haven

title: Republicans Are Given a Price Tag for Health Law Repeal, but Reject It
description: WASHINGTON  The nonpartisan budget scorekeepers in Congress said on Thursday that the Republican plan to repeal President Obamas health care law would add $230 billion to federal budget deficits over the next decade, intensifying the first legislative fight of the new session and highlighting the challenge Republicans face in pursuing their agenda.

title: Cable Channels Over the Internet, on Samsung TVs
description: LAS VEGAS  Samsung made a strong push for its Internet-connected televisions on Thursday, announcing new deals with several companies to provide content on its televisions, smartphones and tablet computers.

title: Helen Thomas Returns, With Smaller Audience
description: As a political reporter and columnist for a half-century, Helen Thomas witnessed her share of career crashes and rebirths in Washington. Now, seven months after being forced from her job over disparaging comments she made about Jews, she can add her own name to that list.

title: Progress for Rutgers Player After Spinal Cord Injury
description: In the days after Rutgers defensive tackle Eric LeGrand was paralyzed below the neck from a spinal cord injury, Coach Greg Schiano and members of the program spoke hopefully about how LeGrand would one day lead the Scarlet Knights onto the field.

title: U.S. Sends Warning to People Named in Cable Leaks
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department is warning hundreds of human rights activists, foreign government officials and businesspeople identified in leaked diplomatic cables of potential threats to their safety and has moved a handful of them to safer locations, administration officials said Thursday.

title: 2 Environment Rules Halted in New Mexico
description: Acting on a campaign promise, New Mexicos new Republican governor, Susana Martinez, has scuttled a state regulation requiring annual 3 percent cuts in greenhouse gas emissions.

title: Lessons Learned, South Korea Makes Quick Economic Recovery
description: SEOUL, South Korea  When the global financial crisis struck more than two years ago, customers disappeared from the Dongdaemun market, a cramped maze of clothing and fabric shops in the shadow of a medieval city gate. But in contrast to the economic conditions in the United States and Europe, business quickly rebounded here and in the rest of this vibrant, technology-driven nation, a resilience that many South Koreans attribute to their bitter experience of having survived an even worse downturn, the currency crisis of 1997.

title: The Texas Omen
description: These are tough times for state governments. Huge deficits loom almost everywhere, from California to New York, from New Jersey to Texas.

title: The United States Consti ...tion
description: Members of the House might have thought they were bringing the Constitution alive by reading it aloud on Thursday. But they made a crucial error by excising its history. When they chose to deliberately drop the sections that became obsolete or offensive, and which were later amended, they missed a chance to demonstrate that this document is not nailed to the door of the past. It remains vital precisely because it can be reimagined.

title: Italy: Pope Favors Design, Not Accident
description: Pope Benedict XVI said Thursday that Gods knowledge, love and inexhaustible creativity  not chance  lay at the origins of the universe. Scientific concepts suggesting the formation of the universe was accidental, like the Big Bang theory, only arrive at a certain point, the pope told worshipers in St. Peters Basilica on Thursday. The church no longer says that the process of evolution violates its teachings, but for the church, God remains the ultimate creator.

title: A Good Place to Start Cutting
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo struck just the right tone on both adult prison reform and juvenile justice reform in his first State of the State address on Wednesday. He said that New York could no longer afford to keep hugely expensive but unneeded facilities open to serve as an employment program for upstate residents.

title: Kazakhstan: Leaders Long-Term Lease
