description: Kazakhstans senate, generally considered a rubber-stamp chamber, voted unanimously on Thursday to ask President Nursultan Nazarbayev to extend his current term in office until 2020 by holding a referendum on continuing his rule rather than a scheduled election. Mr. Nazarbayev, who has already ruled for almost 20 years, would be 80 years old in 2020.

title: Ivory Coast: Election Victor Wants Raid
description: The man recognized by foreign powers as the winner of the recent presidential election here, Alassane Ouattara, called Thursday for a special operations raid to seize the incumbent, Laurent Gbagbo, and take him somewhere else. Mr. Gbagbo refuses to give up power nearly six weeks after an election the United Nations, the United States and African nations say he lost. Meanwhile, the United States Treasury announced it was freezing Mr. Gbagbos assets, and the United Nations said some 31 people had died in Ivory Coast in post-election violence in the last week, bringing the total to more than 200. The United Nations peacekeeping chief in New York called for reinforcements to bolster the embattled mission of close to 10,000 here, which Mr. Gbagbo is seeking to expel.

title: Morris Cohen
description: MORRIS, the name of the online catalog of the Yale Law School Library, is not an acronym. Its a tribute to Morris Cohen, the schools longtime librarian and law professor, who died in December at 83 and was one of Americas great scholarly librarians.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,422 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Thursday:

title: Egypt: A Chat About Arab-Israeli Peace
description: Egypts president, Hosni Mubarak, told Israel on Thursday to review its positions and policies and to adopt tangible confidence-building measures toward the Palestinian Authority in order to allow a resumption of peace talks, an Egyptian official told reporters after talks between Mr. Mubarak and Israels prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu. Mr. Netanyahu asked Mr. Mubarak to try to persuade the Palestinians to return to direct, intensive and serious negotiations, the Israeli government said in a statement. Israeli-Palestinian talks have been stalled since September. Mr. Mubarak also warned Israel not to carry out a new offensive in Gaza, according to Egypts official news agency. The Israeli military said that at least 10 rockets and mortar shells had been fired from Gaza against southern Israel since Jan. 1.

title: Turkey: President Meets With Students
description: Responding to the latest in a series of violent student protests in recent months, President Abdullah Gul met with college youth representatives on Thursday. Urging them to stay away from violence, the President promised that his office would listen to their concerns over what they perceive to be government interference in academia. The protests became more vehement, after a 19-year-old pregnant student was beaten by riot police officers, allegedly causing her to lose her baby in mid-December. Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan has expressed concern that subversive groups hostile to the government have been trying to co-opt the students to destabilize the country.

title: Fox Lands College Football Title Game for the Pac-12
description: Fox Sports announced that it would televise the inaugural football title game for what will become the Pacific-12.

title: Dallass Garrett Has Deal and Final Say on Staff
description: About 10 minutes into his tenure as head coach of the Dallas Cowboys, Jason Garrett had to step aside. The team owner Jerry Jones had something to say.

title: Carbon Dioxide, the Bane of Environmentalists, Is in Demand in the Oil Industry
description: The Obama administration views carbon dioxide as a pollutant that warms the earth, and it imposed new regulations at the beginning of the year to begin to control CO2 emissions. But to Texas oilmen, carbon dioxide is a useful  and scarce  commodity that is vital to extracting hard-to-reach oil reserves.

title: How to Replace Oprah? Theyre Working on It
description: With the collective attention of the television industry centered this week on the launch of OWN, Oprah Winfreys new cable channel, the Chicago television station where it all started was preoccupied with the question raised many months ago: how to replace Ms. Winfrey when her daily show ends in September?

title: Alzheimers, With Care and Devotion
description: To the Editor:

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 6, 2011
description: A look at the day in sports from ski jumping in Austria to tennis in Australia to some mid-winter baseball fun.

title: For G.O.P. Freshmen, Peril Amid Prosperity
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column

title: Bowdlerizing Twain
description: To the Editor:

title: Apocalypse Never Happened, but a Community Did
description: Eighty-five miles south of Chicago, where farmland rolls out to the horizon in every direction, sits the tiny community of Stelle.

title: Whats in a Name?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Efforts to Reduce Errors in Radiation Therapy
description: To the Editor:

title: Failure in the Gulf
description: The document released Wednesday by the presidential commission investigating last springs oil blowout in the Gulf of Mexico is a riveting and chilling indictment of systemic failures throughout the oil business and of the federal agencies that allowed themselves to be captured by the people they were supposed to regulate.

title: Shortfall Gives Hope to Disability Rights Advocates
description: Disability rights advocates try year after year to persuade lawmakers to close Texas state-supported living centers, the large, institutional-care settings that the United States Justice Department has monitored for dangerous conditions. Every time, their efforts have been rebuffed  by the adamant parents who rely on the facilities to care for their loved ones and by the lawmakers who count on the centers as economic drivers in their districts.

title: Financial Trouble Hasnt Slowed the Dallas Stars
description: The Rangers head to Dallas on Friday to face the Stars, one of the more intriguing stories this season in the N.H.L. on and off the ice.

title: Woods and Golf Digest End Long-Running Deal
description: Tiger Woods and Golf Digest parted company Thursday, ending a 13-year relationship between the worlds most visible golfer and the worlds largest golf magazine.

title: A One-Man Blend of Hip-Hop Artist, Provocateur and, No Joke, Lawyer
description: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Volunteers at Planetarium Excel Where Machines Lag
description: When astronomers like Chris Lintott of the Adler Planetarium look for changes in the galaxies, they study images of outer space to detect minute differences between one photo and the next. Computers are of only limited use in this work, so the planetarium is enlisting thousands of volunteers with little scientific training to help.

title: Word of the Day | static
description: static \sta-tik\ adjective and noun

title: U.S. Inquiry Said to Focus on California Pension Fund
description: Federal regulators are investigating whether California violated securities laws and failed to provide adequate disclosure about its giant public pension fund, according to a person with knowledge of the investigation.

title: GTT: Cultural Roundup
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Amid Scrutiny, Mayor Pledges Full Response to Snow
description: With New York City still recovering from a blizzard that immobilized the five boroughs, the Bloomberg administration said it was ready for another blast of snow Friday that could dump up to five inches on the city and its suburbs.

title: Margot Stevenson, Prolific Broadway Actress, Dies at 98
description: Margot Stevenson, a stage actress for more than six decades who appeared on Broadway in Kaufman and Harts You Cant Take It With You in the 1930s and opposite Orson Welles in the radio series The Shadow, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 98.

title: Brenton Harries Dies at 82; Warned of 75 Fiscal Crisis
description: Brenton W. Harries, the Standard & Poors president whose public alarm over New Yorks ballooning debt foreshadowed the citys 1975 fiscal crisis, died Dec. 26 in Poinciana, Fla., where he had retired. He was 82.

title: News Quiz | January 7, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Financier Is Described as Addicted to Medicine
description: R. Allen Stanford, the Texas financier accused of defrauding investors in a $7 billion Ponzi scheme, has become addicted to antianxiety medication while in federal detention, and that drug is probably contributing to fits of delirium, according to the testimony of several psychiatrists at a court hearing Thursday to determine his fitness to stand trial, Clifford Krauss reports in The New York Times.

title: U.S. Inquiry Is Said to Focus on Calpers
description: Federal regulators are investigating whether California violated securities laws and failed to provide adequate disclosure about its giant public pension fund, according to a person with knowledge of the investigation, Mary Williams Walsh and Louise Story report in The New York Times.

title: Miami of Ohio Wins Bowl
description: Austin Boucher threw for 289 yards and 2 touchdowns in his fourth career start, and Miami of Ohio (10-4) capped a turnaround season with a 35-21 win over Middle Tennessee (6-7) in the GoDaddy.com Bowl in Mobile, Ala.

title: Play by Play
description: WHAT have recent studies and statistics been suggesting about the culture of play in the United States?

title: Test Yourself | History, Jan. 7, 2011
description: Test your knowledge of history with todays question about political leadership.

title: With Warrant Issue, A.I.G. Aims at Independence
description: American International Group said late Thursday that it would issue 75 million warrants for its stock at a price of $45 per share, another step toward ending its dependence on the government.

title: Daily Lexeme: Jack-Pudding
description: Todays word, in association with the formidable Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: China Banks Seek Funds to Pad Capital Ratio
description: Two Chinese banks said Friday that they would need to raise money to meet new capital requirements, as the lenders look to buffer their balance sheets against risk.

title: Do You Believe in ESP?
description: The psychology community is engaged in a debate over the appropriateness of publishing studies that appear to show evidence for extrasensory perception in a scholarly journal. Do you think its possible to scientifically study what is by definition extraordinary? And, do you believe in ESP and clairvoyance?

title: Germans Fear Dioxin Has Contaminated Small Farms
description: BERLIN  German officials halted sales from 4,700 small farms on Friday and pulled millions of eggs from the shelves after dioxin was discovered in feed for chickens and pigs and the authorities announced that the contamination might have started months ago. The news set off a scramble in countries that import food from Germany, with two banning the sale of some animal products.

title: Where the Horses Race and Mumbaikars Bet
description: Mahalaxmi Racecourse isnt just home to the most lucrative races in all of India. The racetrack  established under British colonial rule in 1883  is also a pastoral oasis near the heart of this teeming city. The green swath on display from inside the whitewashed grandstand induces a welcome sense of languor, one that is periodically interrupted when the horses approach the starting gate before a race.

title: How Private Is Private Charity?
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

title: How to Find Your Voice
description: Education Life asked four memoirists to share advice on writing the personal essay:

title: A Long-Distance Affair
description: CHANTELLE WELP and Colin Sorensen grew up together in Greeley, Colo. They despised each other in middle school, became friends junior year of high school and, in a twist of romantic irony, turned into a couple over Christmas vacation of their senior year  just weeks before they learned of their very different college destinies.

title: The Early Word: Debt and Jobs
description: From Todays Times:

title: Joe Namaths Advice for Jets Against Colts
description: Joe Namath has had some experience beating the Colts in a big game. In this video, he talks about disrupting Peyton Manning, with blitzes and disguised coverages, and bothering his receivers, by jamming them at the line.

title: Taliban Suicide Bomber Kills Police Official
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber killed a senior border police commander, two other police officers and 14 civilians in an attack on Friday in a crowded bathhouse in the southern city of Spinbaldak, Afghan officials said.

title: Lucks Decision and Carolinas Position
description: Stanford quarterback Andrew Luck announced on Thursday that he would return to Stanford to complete his degree in architectural design. He was all but guaranteed to be the No. 1 pick in the draft. And no team needs a quarterback more than the Carolina Panthers, who happen to have the No. 1 selection.

title: Jets Slauson, First-Time Father, Sleeps Like a Baby
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  For Jets left guard Matt Slauson, the less then glamorous life of new fatherhood should be here: picking up baby food at the store on his way home, 2 a.m. feedings and plenty of diaper purchases and changes. Sprinkle in some playoff football, and Slauson ought to be yawning his way through practice and film study. Instead, he looks bright and fresh despite the birth of Montgomery James a week ago.

title: Britain Raises Terror Alert Level
description: LONDON  The British authorities raised the terrorism alert level on Friday for airports, rail stations and other transportation hubs, but left unchanged the threat level for the rest of the country, security officials said.

title: A Start-Up Soap Maker Starts to Get Traction
description: Last June, we published a case study that explored whether the natural soap maker True Body Products should add a scented offering. Janice Shade, True Bodys chief executive, feared that adding the line might alienate existing customers who are adamantly opposed to scented soaps, sometimes because of allergies. But the suggestion to add the scented soaps came from Ms. Shades North Atlantic region Whole Foods buyer, and Ms. Shade knew that a line extension would give her company the larger shelf presence it needed to increase sales, which were about $45,000 in 2009.

title: Evaluating Eli at 30: Youll Miss Him When Hes Gone
description: Andy Barall writes about pro football history for the Fifth Down. Hes also a Giants fan who watches a lot of tape.

title: At Obama White House, Back to the Future
description: The president hailed William M. Daley first, describing him as a man of rare effectiveness, one who embodies the values of hard work and fair play.

title: Complaint Box | Snow Code
description: The giant snowstorm in December rekindled the irritation that is felt by many homeowners in the New York area, who after spending hours digging their cars out of six-foot-high snowbanks and driving to pick up groceries, return home to find a strange car parked in that just-cleared curb space. This is, perhaps, a minor inconvenience compared with the plight of residents whose cars get snowed in and stay snowed in for days after a storm, but it is nonetheless frustrating on an interpersonal level.

title: JPMorgan and Morgan Stanley Win Approval for China Ventures
description: JPMorgan Chase and Morgan Stanley said on Friday that they had each won approval from Chinese regulators to form joint ventures in the country, potentially giving them a bigger role in Chinas booming securities business.

title: Sperling Returns as Obamas Top Economic Adviser
description: President Obama will name Gene Sperling today to replace Larry Summers as director of the National Economic Council, White House officials said.

title: In Sickness and in Health
description: For several years, the professor and his wife, who has Parkinsons disease, managed in their house in Cambridge, Mass. But two years ago, finding living on their own too difficult, they moved together into an assisted living facility.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MERGERS AND ACQUISITIONS

title: Hold That Megawatt!
description: Frequency regulation, an esoteric but increasingly important element of the electric system, is getting a new competitor.

title: Slow Job Growth Dims Expectation of Early Revival
description: The year 2010 ended on a disappointing note, as the economy added just 103,000 jobs in December, suggesting that economic deliverance will not arrive with a great pop in employment.

title: The Almighty Essay
description: ON a freezing Saturday in February, my wife and I sat through a full-day introduction to college admissions for the parents of 11th graders. This was our first little step on the high-anxiety journey thousands of families trod each year. As parents of twins, we were double-booked. There wasnt a vacation day in the next eight months that one of us didnt spend on a college campus, somewhere.

title: Coughlins Message to Critics
British Shopping Mall Deal Looks Dimmer
description: A tie-up between the British mall owner Capital Shopping Centers and the American developer Simon Property is looking dimmer.

title: N.F.L. Playoffs Q. & A. With Greg Bishop
description: Greg Bishop, in Indianapolis for the Jets wild-card matchup with the Colts on Saturday, answered your questions on Friday afternoon.

title: Regulation Work Wear | Hellers Caf by Warehouse
description: Larry McKaughan, head of the vintage clothing company Hellers Caf, has garnered a cultlike following among heritage-obsessed shoppers on the hunt for authentic, turn-of-the-century clothing. So when J. Crew approached him to collaborate on a capsule collection, he jumped at the chance.

title: Pakistani Government Salvages Coalition, but at a Steep Price
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistans governing party patched its coalition government back together on Friday, barely holding onto power, but at a price that officials in Washington had feared: the collapse of reforms critical to stabilizing the nations economy.

title: The Week in Ted Williams (So Far)
description: How was your day Thursday? Oh really? Because Ted Williams, the mellifluously voiced man discovered on the streets of Ohio by a videographer from The Columbus Dispatch, got job offers to be the voices of the Cleveland Cavaliers and Kraft Macaroni & Cheese; went on the Today show where he got to introduce the program and was interviewed by Meredith Vieira and Matt Lauer; he was reunited with his 90-year-old mother; and popped up on The Last Word With Laurence ODonnell, where it was announced hed be providing voice-over work to MSNBC, too.

title: The Week in Ted Williams (So Far)
description: How was your day Thursday? Oh really? Because Ted Williams, the mellifluously voiced man discovered on the streets of Ohio by a videographer from The Columbus Dispatch, got job offers to be the voices of the Cleveland Cavaliers and Kraft Macaroni & Cheese; went on the Today show where he got to introduce the program and was interviewed by Meredith Vieira and Matt Lauer; he was reunited with his 90-year-old mother; and popped up on The Last Word With Laurence ODonnell, where it was announced hed be providing voice-over work to MSNBC, too.

title: Jailed Sisters Are Released for Kidney Transplant
description: Two Mississippi sisters who had been imprisoned for 16 years were released Friday on the condition that the younger sibling donate a kidney to her sister, whose organs are failing.

title: If You Read This Blog Post, You Will Die
description: Eventually. Of course, if you dont read it youll eventually die, too.

title: Finding the Voice of an (Abdicating) King
description: When Harvey Weinstein promises, he delivers (usually). Just a few weeks ago, he announced to the Bagger that everyone associated with The Kings Speech would turn up for promotional duties eventually; this at a screening with Eve Best and Jennifer Ehle, who worked just a few days on the film between them but were charming to talk to about it nonetheless. Up next on the hype machine: Guy Pearce, who plays Edward VIII, whose abdication to marry Wallis Simpson forced his stuttering brother, George (Colin Firth), to step up to the royal mic more than he wouldve liked. Mr. Pearce lives in Australia but had been flown to Los Angeles by HBO to do some work for its upcoming mini-series Mildred Pierce, and of course the Weinstein Company took advantage of his presence in an American time zone. He spoke by phone with the Bagger for far longer than the 15 minutes a publicist allotted, about why David, as Edward was known to his family, never wanted to be king and how his brother, known as Bertie, resented him forever because of it. There was also some talk about sex, Nazis, and the Queen mum.

title: Comparing Recoveries: Job Changes
description: Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics. Chart by Amanda Cox. Horizontal axis shows months. Vertical axis shows the ratio of that months nonfarm payrolls to the nonfarm payrolls at the start of recession. Note: Because employment is a lagging indicator, the dates for these employment trends are not exactly synchronized with National Bureau of Economic Researchs official business cycle dates.

title: City Says Its Prepared for Fridays Snow
description: Were watching the white flakes come down, and so is the Bloomberg administration.

title: Treasure Trove
description: Keith Otis Edwards e-mails: In the Dec. 12 On Language column, I see that hackneyed phrase treasure trove. Since a trove is defined as a store of valuable or delightful things, isnt treasure trove redundant? Has anyone ever spoken of a garbage trove?

title: How Not To Take Responsibility For a Failed Forecast
description: The House race forecasts issued by Stu Rothenberg and his team on the eve of last Novembers elections performed extremely well.

title: Fear (Again) of Flying
description: In the mid-1970s, women began to take flight.

title: Getting Hired, Thanks to Hash
description: Hash Week continues: Stay At Stove Dad has a guest post from Steve Flax, a journalist who got a job at Harvest, in Cambridge, Mass., based on the strength of his roast beef hash. The secret, he said, was raiding the walk-in refrigerator and commandeering four leftover prime rib roasts. I owed it all to using such great leftovers rather than to any special skill as a chef, he writes. At the bottom of the post, theres a talk-through recipe; Julia Child is mixed up in the tale somewhere, too.

title: Doctors Orders
description: As the United States surgeon general, you just released a report on tobacco smoke that claims, not completely convincingly, that one puff of one cigarette can trigger inflammation and a fatal heart attack. Is that intended as a slogan?  Well, its more than a slogan. The scientific basis is that tobacco smoke is a toxic mix of more than 7,000 chemicals and chemical compounds. When you inhale the smoke, the chemicals can reach your lungs very quickly and enter the bloodstream. Whether its secondhand smoke or if its from a cigarette, it damages the lining of the blood vessels; it makes your blood more likely to clot.

title: Gym Hares
description: Fair-weather and fleeting gym users.

title: Against Headphones
description: One in ve teenagers in America cant hear rustles or whispers, according to a study published in August in The Journal of the American Medical Association. These teenagers exhibit whats known as slight hearing loss, which means they often cant make out consonants like Ts or Ks, or the plinking of raindrops. The word talk can sound like aw. The number of teenagers with hearing loss  from slight to severe  has jumped 33 percent since 1994.

title: Doing What the Company Wants
description: My company now requires all employees to complete a self-directed training course on the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, relevant to our overseas staff but not to my job. This training takes about four hours, time better spent on something more productive, and was not a condition of my employment. Until I transfer into a job that involves me with foreign officials or companies, am I ethically obligated to complete the training? J.H., BOSTON

title: Misunderstanding McLuhan: Flashback to Annie Hall
description: This weekend in the Book Review, David Carr reviews Douglas Couplands idiosyncratic new biography, Marshall McLuhan: You Know Nothing of My Work! As Carr notes, and as fans of Annie Hall will immediately recognize, the books subtitle derives from a line uttered in the film by McLuhan himself.

title: Misunderstanding McLuhan: Flashback to Annie Hall
description: This weekend in the Book Review, David Carr reviews Douglas Couplands idiosyncratic new biography, Marshall McLuhan: You Know Nothing of My Work! As Carr notes, and as fans of Annie Hall will immediately recognize, the books subtitle derives from a line uttered in the film by McLuhan himself.

title: After the Buzzer
description: I rst meet Tim Donaghy on a cold November evening in Sarasota, Fla., a year after he left prison. He looks leaner than he did as an N.B.A. ref, almost gaunt, with a long face and prominent, rabbity teeth. Tonight is family-dinner night  he has chosen an Italian joint in the towns upmarket minimall  and around Donaghy sit his newish girlfriend, Carolyn; her 12yearold daughter; and his own preteen girls, Bridget and Molly. His two other daughters, both teenagers, declined the invitation, wanting nothing to do with their father or this dinner.

title: Sewer-Project Blues
description: Im just a guy in pajamas, chuckling about a Yo Gabba Gabba! episode my year-old daughter and I were watching, when I see a guy with a machete out my window. Hes hacking away at branches near my fence as two other men hammer spikes in my lawn. They undoubtedly work for the city. This type of thing ticks me off.

title: Scott Starrett
description: Scott Starrett came up with the idea for Jorno, a foldable keyboard for smartphones, while traveling for work.

title: Lehman Shows Trans-Atlantic Divide on Derivatives
description: The Lehman Brothers bankruptcy case underscores that while the International Swaps and Derivatives Association, the derivatives industry trade group, provides a single master agreement for use in derivatives trades in the important New York and London markets, the interpretation of that agreement can vary greatly across those two jurisdictions.

title: Apothekers Choices at Hewlett-Packard
description: Another chief executive at Hewlett-Packard means another review of the computer conglomerates big-picture strategy.

title: Aaron LeMieux
description: Aaron LeMieux came up with the idea of a phone charger that runs on kinetic energy while hiking the Appalachian Trail.

title: What Were Reading
description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.

title: Friday Reading: The Latest on Health Insurance
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Ristretto | Is Coffee in Paris Improving?
description: Last year, I wrote a column that wondered why Paris doesnt have better coffee. Or, to quote Duane Sorenson of Stumptown Coffee Roasters, Why does the coffee in Paris suck so bad?

title: Question a President (and Me, Too) About Sudan
description: Update: Read the first round of answers to readers questions

title: Top 10 Composers: Johann Sebastian Bach
description: In the first video of his series, The Times's chief classical music critic, Anthony Tommasini, explains the importance of Bach and his influence on classical music to come.

title: Bernanke Expects a Moderately Stronger Recovery
description: The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, told senators on Friday that he expected the recovery to be moderately stronger this year. He also defended the central banks $600 billion program to stimulate the economy by buying government bonds, and urged Congress to put a credible plan in place to reduce the federal deficit.

title: The Greatest
description: YOU know that a new year has truly arrived when critics stop issuing all those lists of the best films, books, plays, recordings and whatever of the year gone by. These lists seem to be popular with readers, and they stir up lively reactions. Like other critics I enjoy recalling the pieces and performances that struck me as exceptionally good, or exceptionally bad, during the year in classical music.

title: Joyce Theater to Use Grant Money for Dance-Theater Teams
description: Grant money for dance is flowing through the Joyce Theater. The Joyce said on Friday that it would allot $625,000 toward helping 10 choreographers  and possibly more  work on projects. Six will be given partners from the world of theater  directors or dramaturges  to help them embrace new methods of creating work by introducing them to the theater model in which projects go through multiple workshops, the Joyce said. The Rockefeller Foundation, Rockefeller Brothers Fund and Andrew W. Mellon Foundation are giving the grants.

title: Its Time for a Checkup: Vital Signs Seem Stronger
description: BY any conventional measure, the auto show season has been under way for months, with last falls major exhibitions in Paris and Los Angeles showcasing dozens of new vehicles. Yet for many who follow the car industry, the annual cycle of introductions and corporate chest-beating doesnt really start until the Motor City lays out the welcome mat for the worlds automakers.

title: Guess Where This Is, Day 4
description: This week, weve been asking you to identify locations included in our Where to Go 2011 issue, which will be online later today. Many readers correctly guessed the last three: the first, posted on Facebook, was Miami; the second Salonika, Greece; and the third Reykjavik, Iceland.

title: Point: The New England Patriots
description: The Times deputy sports editor, Carl Nelson, backs the New England Patriots, led by Tom Brady, for Super Bowl XLV in Dallas.

title: Hyundai BlueLink Arrives in a Suddenly Crowded Telematics Field
description: LAS VEGAS  BlueLink, Hyundais entry into an ever-growing field of in-car connectivity systems, was introduced on Wednesday at the Consumer Electronics Show.

title: Top 10 Composers: Help Write the List
description: What makes great music great? There are lots of ways to answer. Heres a playful approach: make a list of the Top 10 composers in history. A gimmick? Sure, but one worth using if you have to defend your choices. What goes into a decision to put certain composers on such a list or to keep them off? Should influence matter, or just the works themselves? What about popularity? Are there any objective criteria?

title: American Jews Lead the Happiest Lives
description: On average, Jews have higher levels of well-being than their counterparts of every other major faith in America, according to new data from the Gallup-Healthways Well-Being Index.

title: Counterpoint: The Atlanta Falcons
description: The Times Sports editor, Tom Jolly, backs the Atlanta Falcons to break through this year and earn the N.F.C. berth to Super Bowl XLV in Dallas

title: Some Video Lessons in Grit and Blingatude
description: In case you missed them, here are some videos that have been floating around, ever eager to distract you at the end of the work week.

title: Early On, About One Truck for Every Flake
description: Were looking for the first photo of a city snowplow actually plowing snow. If you see one, snap a pic and send it to cityroom@nytimes.com. Please include time and location. Thanks!

title: Something About Me Makes People Want to Marry
description: INSTANTLY, I earned a title worthy of admiration and respect.

title: After Its Safety Dance, Volvo Learns to Tango
description: VOLVOS boxy years are long gone. But even as the company has bent its 90-degree designs into slinkier shapes, theres something a bit square about its safety obsession.

title: A Talk With the Doctor May Help Patients Afford Care
description: READERS of this column have been advised more than once to negotiate prices with health care providers for things like an M.R.I. scan, surgery and office visits. With patients paying more out of pocket for their health care than ever before  in the form of higher co-payments and co-insurance, high deductibles and uncovered and out-of-network treatments  negotiating with doctors and other providers has become commonplace.

title: How to Haggle With Your Doctor
description: In this weeks Patient Money column, Walecia Konrad asks Dr. Jeffrey Kullgren, an internist at the University of Pennsylvania who researches consumer-driven health care, for advice on how to negotiate with a doctor or other medical provider. Your physician may be just as uncomfortable with these conversations as you are, he said. Thats because  and I can tell you firsthand  doctors are simply not trained for this. I was trained to give the very best care for my patients, regardless of cost.

title: The Second Time Around: New Apatow Comedy Will Revisit Knocked Up Couple
description: The actress Leslie Mann is lucky to have almost a whole year to figure out what to get her husband, the comedy director Judd Apatow, for the 2011 holiday season, because shell need the time to top Mr. Apatows latest gift to her: another movie role. Ms. Mann, who has been featured in all of her husbands films including The 40-Year-Old Virgin and Funny People, is set to reunite with Paul Rudd to reprise the semi-happily married couple they portrayed in Mr. Apatows 2007 hit Knocked Up. Variety reported that the as-yet untitled film, to be written and directed by Mr. Apatow, would be a follow-up of sorts to Knocked Up  in which Ms. Mann played the sister of Katherine Heigls newly pregnant character, and Mr. Rudd, another Apatow regular, played Ms. Manns mushroom-ingesting, fantasy-baseball-obsessed spouse  though not necessarily a direct sequel or prequel to that comedy.

title: 2011 Volvo S60
description: The new S60 sedan plays up, and plays on, the curves.

title: Kindergarten Admission Season Opens
description: Trying to get your preschooler into kindergarten at a popular public school across the street? Wondering whether you will have priority over a former neighbor who moved to a different borough but who already has a child there?

title: Dressing A-Listers for the Red Carpet
description: The effort that goes into dressing a prize-winning red-carpet clotheshorse often feels greater than what one can properly say about the ugly dress or indeed a second-rate event. This weeks Peoples Choice Awards illustrated the problem. After deploying references to Adderall, Xanax, Pride and Prejudice and fancy pillowcases to describe the awfulness of the clothes, Amy Odell of New York magazines The Cut blog received a lecture from readers about her misuse of Jane Austen. There are no milkmaids in Pride and Prejudice, she was told, certainly no slovenly milkmaids. Ms. Odell might wish she had just said cow.

title: The Almighty Essay
description: In the latest edition of Education Life, The Timess quarterly supplement, to be published this weekend, Trip Gabriel wonders why the personal essay is so important to admissions officers. The essay is viewed as the one place where a students own voice can be heard. In his story, The Almighty Essay, Mr. Gabriel writes:

title: Financial Lobbyists Seek Softer Rules on Policing Fraud
description: Top financial trade groups are lobbying regulators to soften new rules that would crack down on fraud and manipulation in the $600 trillion derivatives industry, regulatory disclosure records show  a debate that seems to center on semantics.

title: Genevieve Sheehan and Troy Meyer
description: GAME playing can undermine a relationship, but not in the case of Genevieve Sheehan and Troy Meyer. For this couple, serious fans of the show Jeopardy!, it became much more than a trivial pursuit.

title: Send Us Your Snow Haiku
description: As we watch the criss-crossing strands of snowflakes fall outside our windows, we felt a haiku was the right way to appreciate the moment.

title: Its Mini Coopers vs. Monster Truck  In 3-D
description: Automakers are among the most adventurous marketers when it comes to trying to reach consumers through new media. That is being underlined by a pair of initiatives for the Mini line of cars sold by BMW.

title: Bloggingheads: A Crusade for Marriage?
description: Glenn Loury, left, of Brown University and Rich Lowry of National Review debate a government campaign for marriage.

title: Low Profile of an Heir Reinforces a Mystery
description: SEOUL, South Korea  When he was introduced to the public in September, Kim Jong-un appeared destined to succeed his father, Kim Jong-il, as the leader of North Korea, an irascible, destitute and nuclear-armed nation. But a growing number of experts in Seoul are beginning to question whether he has been fully certified, despite his elevation to a high military rank and the urgency created by his fathers poor health.

title: Tell Us the Best Places to Go in 2011
description: Where do you want to travel this year? Share your recommendations and comments on our global map.

title: FBR to Exit Prime Brokerage Business
description: FBR Capital Markets is shuttering its prime brokerage unit, which the firm opened just 16 months ago, according to people with knowledge of the matter who were not authorized to speak publicly.

title: House Moves Toward Vote on Health Care Repeal
description: The House on Friday approved the terms of debate for a bill that would repeal President Obamas health care law, as the new Republican majority easily surmounted the opposition of most Democrats.

title: Pasta and Seafood, Inspired by Italy
description: Mediterranean cooks have a knack for making meals from small amounts of animal protein, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health. Italians often accomplish this by combining pasta and seafood.

title: The Call of the Bayou
description: My article in Fridays paper, A Son of the Bayou, Torn Over the Shrimping Life, is a coming-of-age story with the BP oil spill as its backdrop.

title: Luck and Money at Stanford
description: Andrew Lucks decision to play another year at Stanford instead of becoming the No. 1 pick in the N.F.L. draft brought out volleys from the two sides of these high-profile stay-or-go decisions, from those who assailed him for risking N.F.L. millions to those furiously shaking their Stanford pompoms.

title: Curb Your Enthusiasm
description: Not the kind of job report that has you jumping for joy. Things appear to have stopped getting worse, but thats about all.

title: A Different, Happy Ending for Diana? Monica Ali Novel Imagines a Future
description: 6:17 p.m. | Updated LONDON  It might seem a curious marriage of author and subject. But the British writer Monica Alis coming novel tells the story of a fictional princess based on Diana, Princess of Wales, and imagines what might have happened had Diana not been killed in a car accident in Paris in 1997.

title: VW Focuses on U.S. Market in Bid to Be World's No. 1 Automaker
description: WOLFSBURG, GERMANY  Volkswagen may be the largest automaker in Europe and a powerhouse in China, Brazil and much of the rest of the world. But for years, it has flirted with irrelevance in the United States.

title: Single, Female, Mormon, Alone (Updated With Podcast)
description: UPDATED: You can now hear this essay read by the actress Justina Machado in Modern Love: The Podcast. Look for the play button below.

title: New Fears of Flying
description: The women who faced down middle age in the 1970s responded by running away from home. They got jobs, got their consciousness raised or got divorced, writes Judith Warner in this weekends New York Times Magazine.

title: Comment Meta
description: Just FYI: since this morning, Ive approved about 320 comments, and rejected I think 10  9 for obscene language, one because it was an advertisement for cheap shoes, or something. No opinions were censored; to be honest, supportive comments are a bit more likely than hostile comments to contain unacceptable language.

title: Something in the Air Is Brewing
description: It seems that no part of Brooklyn can be left untouched by its ever-striving culinary scene, even its microorganisms.

title: Fatal Fire on Lower East Side
description: Update, 2:34 p.m. | A 72-year-old woman died early Friday after a fire swept through the second floor of a tenement building on Manhattans Lower East Side, the authorities said.

title: A Love-Distance Affair
description: Generations of high school sweethearts have stayed together into college, but the connection tended to unravel by Thanksgiving. Thats no longer the case, Abigail Sullivan Moore writes in an article in Education Life. Now, thanks to technology, particularly Skype, campus-to-campus relationships go on, and on, and on. Breaking up is hard to do. Should you?

title: WikiLeaks: The Book
description: In the lull before the media frenzy that will no doubt strike again next week, when Julian Assange returns to court in London to continue his fight against extradition to Sweden, his British publisher is trying to drum up interest in his book, which is due out in April.

title: Nissan and Mitsubishi Among Detroit Auto Shows Notable Absentees
description: Once again, a number of automakers will skip the Detroit auto show, which opens to the press on Monday and to the public on Jan. 15.

title: The Road to the Super Bowl
description: Which N.F.L. team has the right makeup to reach the Super Bowl? After watching our editors debate, vote or make your own prediction.

title: Homeland Revisited
description: In the middle of his accomplished book, India Calling, Anand Giridharadas tells of meeting a Maoist revolutionary in Hyderabad. The city, nicknamed Cyberabad, serves as a base for both the globalized Indian economy and an armed insurgency at war against the countrys inequalities, rooted and new. Indias Maoist  or Naxalite  movement began as a rural struggle against exploitative landlords in a caste-conscious, socialist nation but has now arrayed itself against the forces of global capitalism reshaping India. When Giridharadas pushes the Naxalite  What does one fight have to do with the other?  the man answers with a striking notion: globalization is reducing people to their specific economic task, stripping them of their humanity, just as caste had done. And software engineers in gated communities have become the new Brahmins. Giridharadas follows the curve of this argument, allowing it to seduce us. Then, he reveals that this rebel, although waging revolution by night, reports by day for a newspaper he himself describes as a shill for the multinational transformation of India. I have to earn my lunch, the man explains. Im not a whole-timer for revolution.

title: Shelter Beneath an Open Sky
description: In her early fiction about Wyoming, Annie Proulx rewrote the state with a smash-and-grab intensity all her own. In the story collections Close Range, Bad Dirt and Fine Just the Way It Is, it was as if Proulx had broken the language of classic Wyoming (Owen Wisters novel The Virginian, Jack Schaefers Shane, Mary OHaras My Friend Flicka) and used the shards to make something so subversively new that there was only one word for what she had done: Proulxian.

title: The Formalist
description: Its tough to be a Grand Old Man of  well, anything, really. At this point Joe Paterno must feel less like a person than a physical feature of the Penn State campus, like the Nittany Lion Shrine. In his elegy for Yeats, Auden claims that the poet, upon dying, became his admirers, but it wouldve been more accurate to say that like most Grand Old Men (and not just the ones who actually are men), Yeats had much earlier become shorthand for an array of generalizations. Stick around long enough and, to most people, youre no longer an artist; youre a brand.

title: Up Front: Melanie Thernstrom
description: Melanie Thernstrom is known for her powerful first-person journalism based on her own life, whether the subject is the murder of her best friend (recounted in her first book, The Dead Girl); her own struggles with chronic pain (the inspiration for her latest, The Pain Chronicles); or the birth of her children via a complex process of third-party reproduction, described in last Sundays cover article for The Times Magazine.

title: Power of Recall
description: At the center of Mira Bartoks memoir about her schizophrenic mother is a beautiful metaphor: a memory palace. The idea, she explains, derives from the sixth-century B.C. Greek poet Simonides, who was attending a party at a palace and stepped outside just before the building collapsed. Because he could recall where all the other guests had been standing, Simonides alone could identify the mangled bodies. Inspired by this tale, a 16th-century Jesuit priest recommended a mental technique by which scholars could build an imaginary palace to keep their memories safe, creating a visual image for everything they wanted to recall and creating a particular place for the image inside the mental palace.

title: In Suicides Shadow
description: Linda Gray Sextons first memoir, Searching for Mercy Street, described a childhood dominated by the mental illness of her larger-than-life mother, the poet Anne Sexton. Linda, the older of Sextons two daughters, wrote frankly about her mothers terrifying breakdowns, fugue states and drunken rages, as well as demands for closeness that at times slid into molestation. Linda Sexton grew up intellectually privileged  in high school she had private poetry tutorials with her mothers best friend, Maxine Kumin  but emotionally lost, bound to her glamorous, suffering, overbearing parent in what the first of many psychiatrists called a destructive symbiosis.

title: In Canada, Doubts About Prime Ministers Top Adviser
description: As President Obama names a JPMorgan Chase executive, William Daley, to be his right-hand man, another new chief of staff is creating controversy.

title: Soul Cuisine
description: In one of the personal vignettes that punctuate High on the Hog: A Culinary Journey From Africa to America, the food historian and cookbook author Jessica B. Harris takes a trip with her mother to Houmas House, near New Orleans. One of a string of former plantations along Louisianas River Road, the estate bears witness to a cruel history. Harris, who is black, speculates aloud that much of the place was built by slaves. The remark draws an unexpected response. What artistry, her mother says. What beauty they created for people who thought we were nothing but goods, not even human beings!

title: Nutrition Advice From the China Study
description: Six years ago a small Texas publisher released an obscure book written by a father-son research team. The work, based on a series of studies conducted in rural China and Taiwan, challenged the conventional wisdom about health and nutrition by espousing the benefits of a plant-based diet.

title: Beyond the Edge of the World
description: Sleeping, dreaming, cooking, commuting: much of The Still Point lazes in this register. Julia and Simon, together for 10 years, their marriage veering toward the rocks, have recently moved from London to Julias ancestral country home. When Simon, an architect, leaves for the city, Julia, an unemployed archivist, returns to cataloging the artifacts that fill the house, the remnants of her great-great-uncle, Edward Mackley, and his fatal journey to the North Pole.

title: Between Pain and Peace
description: An aged and dying man, Elias Cole, tells a story about a woman he once loved, as a British psychologist, Adrian Lockheart  who has left behind a wife and daughter to come to Sierra Leone  listens on. This premise alone might have been enough to sustain a book called The Memory of Love, an ambitious new novel by Aminatta Forna. Yet Forna has achieved something more startling and impressive here. Hers is a luminous tale of passion and betrayal, encompassing the political unrest that racked Sierra Leone in the late 1960s and the ruinous civil war of the 1990s, as well as the days of tenuous quiet when those who managed to stay alive struggled to cope with the physical and mental scars of those years.

title: River of Consciousness
description: Near midnight on a Friday in April 1854, Gustave Flaubert wrote one of his many letters to Louise Colet. Flaubert had spent days hidden away in his Croisset retreat, researching theories of clubfoot and discarding pages from the manuscript of Madame Bovary, and he told Colet that he had come to the conclusion that the books from which entire literatures have flowed, like Homer, Rabelais, are encyclopedias of their time. They knew everything. This conception  the novel that knows everything  would come to obsess Europes modernist writers, who dreamed that a narrative of infinite detail and esoteric knowledge could blur the boundaries between traditional genres, with fiction shading into nonfiction, poetry bleeding into history.

title: Jan. 9  15
description: Dance

title: In College, Learning About Money
description: BURLINGTON, Vt.

title: Devils Trade Langenbrunner to Dallas
description: The Devils traded their captain, Jamie Langenbrunner, to the Dallas Stars for a conditional draft choice Friday morning, signaling the end of the Devils hopes for this season and the possible start of a series of rebuilding moves by the N.H.L.s last-place club.

title: Vail Dance Festival Taps TV for Talent
description: Dance on television is hitting the festival circuit. The Vail International Dance Festival, announcing its program for this summer, said on Friday that Super Cr3w would appear on its closing program Aug. 13, an evening devoted to small screen dancing. The group is a past winner of the MTV dance competition series, Americas Best Dance Crews.

title: The Week in Pictures, Jan. 7
description: A selection of photographs from the New York region in the past week.

title: Translating Leopardi
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors Choice
description: THE MEMORY CHALET,  by Tony Judt (Penguin Press, $25.95.) Before the historian died in August, of a disease that left him clearheaded but immobile, he dictated these vivid autobiographical sketches. The best of them recall life in his native England.

title: Latin Rhythms
description: To the Editor:

title: Inside the List
description: BONANZA: Charles Portiss True Grit (1968) has popped up on the trade paperback list  its No. 11 this week  thanks to the Coen brothers film adaptation.

title: Announcing Her Existence
description: Seeing double isnt all that easy, especially when it comes to questions of gender and sexuality. In her excellent study Vice Versa, Marjorie Garber argues that bisexuality isnt a third category but a category that undoes identity categories, and that sexuality itself is a narrative that changes over time rather than a fixed identity, however complex. In her memoir Conundrum, Jan Morris, who was James Morris before a sex-change operation in 1972, writes: I do not mind my continuing ambiguity. . . . I see myself not as man or woman, self or other, fragment or whole. She concludes her autobiography not with a solution, but with a question: What if I remain an equivocal figure?

title: Why We Celebrate
description: To the Editor:

title: Bernhard the Alienator
description: To the Editor:

title: The Buried Past
description: Its 1920 at the opening of A LONELY DEATH (Morrow/HarperCollins, $24.99), the latest of Charles Todds masterly novels about Englands slow and painful recovery from the Great War. Ian Rutledge, the Scotland Yard inspector at the center of this series, is one of the walking wounded who never speak of their experiences but share a silent bond. Its not entirely surprising, then, that Rutledge is so unnerved by the suicide of a friend, a despondent former artillery captain, that he packs a loaded service revolver when he makes his first return visit to the French battlefield where he was buried alive under the bodies of the soldiers he commanded.

title: Paperback Row
description: ON THIN ICE: The Changing World of the Polar Bear, by Richard Ellis. (Vintage, $18.95.) Ellis has written some of the most important natural history books of the past decade, including No Turning Back (a history of extinction) and The Empty Ocean. Here he surveys polar bear history, lore, biology and politics, and the complexity of human-polar bear relations: we love the polar bears seeming cuddliness, admire its strength and are incapable of breaking the carbon-fuel addiction thats threatening its survival as a species. In REWILDING THE WORLD: Dispatches From the Conservation Revolution (Picador, $18), Caroline Fraser follows proponents of rewilding  an ecological idea that stresses the restoration of animal habitats, the importance of migration corridors and the need for large carnivores in healthy ecosystems.

title: The Case of the First Mystery Novelist
description: Reader, never mind whether the butler did it. Heres a real mystery for you: Who wrote the first detective novel?

title: Money Lessons You Wish You Learned in College
description: In the course of reporting this weekends Your Money column, I traveled to Champlain College in Burlington, Vt., to learn more about what it refers to as its financial sophistication program. As far as I know, Champlain is the only college in the country right now to make completion of financial literacy seminars a requirement for all undergraduates. (If you know of others, please let me know in the comments below.)

title: ReTweet | Alt Is In
description: The fashion worlds favorite new parlor game is over. Cond Nast France president Xavier Romatet has confirmed that Alt, the French Vogue fashion director, has been tapped to replace Carine Roitfeld as editor in chief of the magazine. The April issue will be her first on top of the masthead.

title: Make It Relevant, but Make It
description: LIKE other choreographers awarded grants through the Jerome Robbins Foundations New Essential Works Program, Jodi Melnick never applied. And like the others, she received the news out of the blue, delivered in the form of a call  in her case on Skype  by the programs ebullient director, Damian Woetzel.

title: Was Green Hornets Beauty the First of All Supercars?
description: THE Jan. 14 release of The Green Hornet gives occasion to recall that the first roadgoing 200-mile-per-hour car was a 1937 Lincoln-Zephyr. Black Beauty, the automotive star of the cliff-hanging Green Hornet movie serial of the 1940s, scorched Mulholland Drive in Los Angeles as the car of the series masked hero.

title: A Tonic for Dispirited Career-Hunters
description: This post is part of a occasional series profiling Web sites and blogs made in New York. Have a profile suggestion? E-mail NewYorkOnline@nytimes.com.

title: Growling Vans, Sagging S.U.V.s
description: THUMPING all-wheel-drive units in Fords and oil leaks in Hondas are among the mechanical ailments covered in recent technical service bulletins.

title: Silenced Voice, Heard Again
description: TRUTH or fable? The incident shows up neither in the New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians nor in the research materials of the Orel Foundation, dedicated to composers suppressed by the Third Reich, and the parties involved are long gone. But according to family lore, something thrilling happened when a tin-pot thug and demagogue named Hitler called on Walter Braunfels, the composer of the runaway hit Die Vgel (The Birds), in Munich. It was 1923, the year of the Beer Hall Putsch, an early Nazi attempt to overthrow the Weimar Republic, and Hitler wanted Braunfels to write an anthem for the brownshirts on the march.

title: Another Big Break for Tiny Furniture Creator: An HBO Series
description: Were you already jealous of Lena Dunham, the 24-year-old wunderkind writer, director and star of the sleeper-hit comedy Tiny Furniture? Prepare to grow even greener with envy: on Friday HBO announced that it had ordered a full season of a new comedy series that Ms. Dunham created and will star in for that cable channel. HBO said in a news release that the series, called Girls, will offer a comic look at the assorted humiliations and rare triumphs of a group of girls in their early 20s, with a cast that will also feature Jemima Kirke (of Tiny Furniture), Allison Williams (American Dreams), Adam Driver (of the HBO movie You Dont Know Jack) and Zosia Mamet (Mad Men). Lest she be labeled an underachiever, Ms. Dunham also wrote and directed the shows pilot episode, and the series will be produced by Jenni Konner and Judd Apatow (whos keeping plenty busy himself these days). A premiere date for Girls wasnt immediately announced.

title: A Wild Child, Somewhat More Mild
description: TESTED 2011 Mitsubishi Lancer Sportback Ralliart

title: Under the Radar: 5 Questions About Phobophilia
description: Sex, lies and videotape get a 21st-century update in Phobophilia, a multimedia production by Stephen Lawson and Aaron Pollard, who go by the name 2boys.tv. The Montreal-based duo is bringing its first full-length show to the United States as part of the Under the Radar Festival.

title: Painfully Slow Jobs Progress
description: The job market is getting better  but oh so slowly, especially given how far it still has to go.

title: After Blast in Egypt, Many Deride Their Church as Too Timid
description: CAIRO  The worshipers erupted, hundreds of them, loudly chanting No! No! No! and drowning out the priest, making it impossible for him to continue offering thanks to President Hosni Mubarak.

title: Obama Promises Full Recovery for Employment
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama went to a busy window-manufacturing plant near here on Friday to promote his economic policies and his new team of advisers as the monthly jobs report reflected only modest employment growth.

title: The Facebook-Microsoft Parallels
description: A computer prodigy drops out of Harvard and builds one of Americas hottest companies. He brings on an M.B.A. to help him think about things other than programming. He wants to keep his very profitable company private. But as his company grows, he begins distributing shares to his ever-increasing employee base. This gives his company more than 499 shareholders and forces him to consider an initial public offering. The investment bank Goldman Sachs plays a major role in the I.P.O.

title: Reviewing the Volvo S60
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the new Volvo S60, the first new model from the company since Ford sold Volvo to the Chinese automaker Geely.

title: Improving Cellphone Reception in Tall Buildings
description: IN the 19th century, as buildings got taller across New York, engineers struggled to find ways to pump water to the uppermost floors. Now, with the mysteries of water pressure long since resolved, a new quandary is facing the citys tallest residential buildings: poor cellphone reception.

title: After Clerics Return to Iraq, Followers Yearn for a Sighting
description: KUFA, Iraq  From the far reaches of Iraq, they trekked to Friday Prayer in cars, taxis and rickety vans festooned with portraits of a populist cleric whose self-imposed exile ended this week. Many were fervent, some simply curious. And by morning, they had made their way to the hallowed ground of Kufa Mosque, where sun lit the gold domes like a quarter moon.

title: Dueling Rumsfelds: Novel to Appear on Same Day as Memoir
description: On Feb. 8 Donald H. Rumsfelds long-awaited memoir, Known and Unknown, will go on sale, full of recollections from Mr. Rumsfelds long and often contentious time in public service.

title: Small, but Performing Better Than the Big Shots
description: SIZE mattered in investing in 2010. Small was definitely better.

title: Mini Coopers vs. Monster Truck  in 3-D
description: From our colleagues at the Media Decoder blog:

title: Case Is Dismissed, but Signs Remain Seized
description: A Manhattan judge this week ruled against an antiques dealer attempting to get back subway signs that the police seized from him last year in a criminal case that was eventually dismissed.

title: Bank Stocks Slump on Foreclosure Ruling
description: Bank stocks fell sharply on Friday afternoon after the highest court in Massachusetts ruled against Wells Fargo and US Bancorp in an important foreclosure case that could have ramifications for the entire banking industry.

title: Weekend Competition: New Years Linguistic Resolutions
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to share their linguistic resolutions for 2011.

title: Letters: The Lives They Lived
description: I truly enjoyed the anecdotes you presented as a tribute to George Steinbrenner. I laughed the hardest at Al Rosens story about the Boss chewing him out for losing the coin toss for the 1978 Yankees-Red Sox playoff game. But over the years, Rosens recollection, like many a storytellers, has gotten hazy. That game was played not on Yom Kippur but on Rosh Hashana. I know because on game day I was working in a hotel kitchen catering to Orthodox Jews, and if it was as Rosen remembered it, they would have had a lot to atone for.

title: Theres a Canine Conspiracy! Television Reveals It!
description: What in blazes is wrong with this countrys dogs? Such a collection of neurotic, insecure, bitchy, bullying creatures hasnt been seen since whenever the latest episode of Real Housewives was broadcast.

title: Contemplating Congress: Considering the Senate, House and the Role of Speaker
description: The start of the 112th United States Congress on Wednesday brought new and returning lawmakers to Capitol Hill, along with a Republican majority in the House of Representatives  and a new speaker of the House, John A. Boehner.

title: British Bank Regulator Seeks New Powers
description: Adair Turner, the chairman of the Financial Services Authority, Britains equivalent of the Securities and Exchange Commission, says his agency may ask the British government for power to block hostile takeovers in the banking sector.

title: Taking a Leap of Faith Onto the Scale
description: AS we edge into the new year with too many resolutions, I can say I am at least one of the few American women who is not obsessed with her weight.

title: Cherry Angers Canadian War Critics
description: This could be an interesting Coachs Corner segment on the Canadian Broadcast Corp.s venerable Hockey Night in Canada: Don Cherry versus fellow Canadians opposed to their countrys military involvement in Afghanistan.

title: Arbiters of Style See It, Post It and Share It
description: NOT everyone can be a famous couturier. Or a paparazzi-flanked celebrity. But for us mortals, a generation of emerging Web sites could make a legitimate tastemaker of anyone with an eye for whats fashionable.

title: Channeling Churchill, Ryan Inspires His Team
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Late on Dec. 18, mired in a two-game losing streak, his season on the brink of collapse, Rex Ryan gathered the Jets at their hotel in Pittsburgh. He spoke for roughly nine minutes. Anger colored his face crimson. Passion produced tears.

title: Massachusetts Ruling on Foreclosures Is a Warning to Banks
description: The highest court in Massachusetts ruled Friday that U.S. Bancorp and Wells Fargo erred when they seized two troubled borrowers properties in 2007, putting the nations banks on notice that foreclosures cannot be based on improper or incomplete paperwork.

title: High-Tech Help
description: YOU might say it all started with spell-check. In the 1980s, with the introduction of word processing programs like WordPerfect, it became apparent that computerized proofreaders could come to the rescue of struggling spellers and bad typists. Thirty years later, an ever-growing array of assistive technology is available to help students read, write term papers and take tests. From pens that can remember to text that can talk, such technologies are now being held up as important tools for students with learning disabilities like dyslexia, dysgraphia (trouble writing) and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.

title: Rethinking Advanced Placement
description: WHEN Joan Carlson started teaching high school biology more than 30 years ago, the Advanced Placement textbook was daunting enough, at 36 chapters and 870 pages. But as an explosion of research into cells and genes reshapes our sense of how life evolves, the flood of new material has been staggering. Mrs. Carlsons A.P. class in Worcester, Mass., now confronts a book with 56 chapters and 1,400 pages, along with a profusion of animated videos and Web-based aids that supplement the text.

title: Leave No Bubble Blank
description: IF you dont know the answer, guess.

title: The 41 Places to Go in 2011
description: From the beaches of Mexico to the wilds of Kurdistan, the places on this years list take you to the end of the world and back.

title: Does Helping Out Help You?
description: EVEN the most altruistic applicant wants to know how community service looks to colleges: would admissions officers prefer a summer of health care work in Africa, or three years of Sundays spent at the local senior citizen center? Would creating a charitable Web site impress more than campaigning for a local politician?

title: The New Subject-Test Math: 2 = 3
description: THE nations most selective universities have long required three SAT subject tests. But with the introduction of writing sections on the SAT and ACT in 2005, colleges have been gradually reducing the subject-test requirement.

title: When Customer Service Flies Out the Window
description: In the wake of recent and not-so-recent discussions about the difficulty of finding good sommeliers, it occurred to me that problems in wine service go way beyond the individual who recommends the bottle. In fact, the issues are not simply about wine but about restaurant service in general.

title: French Vogue Names New Editor
description: GIVING the fashion world something to talk about is what the fashion world seems to do best. Today, less than a month after Carine Roitfeld announced that she would leave the editor in chiefs job at French Vogue, the magazine named Emmanuelle Alt to succeed her, starting Feb. 1.

title: Apothke Dispute Heads to Mediation
description: After trading words, charges and lawsuits, and attaining star status in the annals of partnership breakups, the celebrity mixologist Albert Trummer and Heather Tierney, his principal partner in the haute bar Apothke, have been ordered into mediation by a state judge.

title: Where to Go in 2011
description: From here to there, travel choices for nomads have never been more compelling.

title: Book Review Podcast: David Carr on Marshall McLuhan
description: This week: The Timess David Carr talks about the media prophet Marshall McLuhan; Anand Giridharadas explores modern India in his new book, India Calling; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Detroit's New Direction
description: After years of trailing overseas rivals, Detroit automakers are using stimulus money to develop electric cars that they hope will boost the bottom line and jumpstart Michigan's economy.

title: Excitement, Begrudged but Building
description: SEATTLE  Among the top news stories around Puget Sound this week was the announcement that Starbucks, the ubiquitous coffeehouse chain based here, updated its green siren logo.

title: Hes Fought His Own Way Back to Work
description: IT would have been different, said the Australian director Peter Weir, whose new film, The Way Back, is his first in more than seven years, if Id changed professions during those years, or done nothing but read and hang about. But since his previous movie, Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World, he has worked on three different projects that fell through, he said: So if I can use the analogy of a pilot, for those five or six years I was constantly inside the simulator, doing a lot of writing, thinking about how to make a story work on the screen. He paused. As is the purpose of the simulator, you create all kinds of difficulties for yourself to overcome, so by the time of the actual flight youve been through it in a sense.

title: An Optimistic Start to Investing in 2011, With Caveats
description: PEOPLE who spend their days studying investment options are optimistic about 2011. After all, 2010 ended on a positive note, from a return perspective, and this year is off to a solid start.

title: A Strong Finish for Hedge Funds
description: December was a big month for hedge funds, thanks in part to a sharp rally in stocks.

title: The Video Q | Elia Suleiman on The Time That Remains
description: It is a form of resistance to laugh, especially when you laugh in the face of oppression and authority, said the Palestinian film director and actor Elia Suleiman in this weeks video interview. But the humor one creates must be subtle and tender like poetry, he explains, adding, Im not Borat.

title: Living Around | Morningside Park
description: A lofty perch in Upper Manhattan used to be saddled with a dangerous reputation, but today there is evidence that decades of community activism have paid off.

title: Weekend Fare
description: New this week: Fedora, where the Montreal chef Mehdi Brunet-Benkritly takes an inventive bistro approach in the longtime Village haunt: 239 West Fourth Street (West 10th Street); (646) 449-9336. Fatty Johnsons is Zakary Pelaccios temporary pop-up bar in the former Cabrito space: 50 Carmine Street (Bedford Street); (212) 929-5050.  And this weekend, Marcus Samuelssons recently opened Red Rooster Harlem (310 Lenox Avenue between 125th and 126th Streets) starts serving brunch from 11:30 a.m. to 3 p.m. A gospel singer will perform live at the restaurant during Sunday brunch.

title: Identifying the N.B.A.s Top Clutch Players
description: Clutch performance in professional basketball has its own distinct mythology. The meaning of every action  each shot, foregone shot, pass and foregone pass  is dissected and analyzed to a ludicrous degree, primarily in an effort to better understand the stuff of which N.B.A. players are made. Does a certain star have nerves of steel or a killer instinct? Are they soft? Weak-minded? Descriptions such as these are thrown around disguised as absolutes, even though clutch play is often hopelessly tainted by perception bias. All it takes is one big shot to create a legend. Once a player establishes a reputation as a clutch scorer, it typically follows him to his grave, regardless of what that pesky legitimate evidence indicates.

title: Federal Judge Makes Harry Potter Plagiarism Suit Disappear
description: A federal judge in New York has dismissed a lawsuit against J.K. Rowling, the author of the Harry Potter series, clearing Ms. Rowling of an accusation that she borrowed plotlines from a book by another British author, Adrian Jacobs.

title: Video: Detroits New Direction
S.E.C. Appoints Head of Accounting Oversight Board
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday named James R. Doty, a white-collar criminal defense attorney and former general counsel at the agency, the nations top accounting regulator.

title: Habitats | Jackson Heights, Queens
description: Afzal Hossain and Julie Nymann, new parents, bought and combined two apartments to better accommodate their live-in baby sitter, her mother.

title: Caserta, Italy
description: THERE is something subversively appealing about the Italian art of desecration  the use, or some would say, misuse of historic places and cultural treasures. So much of Italy is ancient, magnificent, priceless and also serviceable.

title: Lago Todos los Santos, Chile
description: EVEN now, nearly four years after I first stood on its shores, Lago Todos los Santos, abutting the foothills of the Andes in southern Chile, sometimes invades my dreams. More than once, I have awakened with images of the lakes constantly shifting colors and the snow-capped volcanoes and sweet-smelling forests that ring it still vivid in my head.

title: Phnom Penh, Cambodia
description: IT was just a single day in Phnom Penh, one of many, but even now I cant get it out of my head. The genocide was over  Vietnam, the traditional enemy, had ended it by driving out the Khmer Rouge and setting up a collaborationist government. But in 1988, Cambodia was still mourning. So many people had died, and thousands of refugees, including those who had suffered from the Khmer Rouge and those loyal to it, lived in politicized border camps inside Thailand, waiting for a diplomatic settlement that never quite seemed to arrive.

title: Orchids Hotel, Congo
description: AT the tip of an impossibly lush hill, perfectly perched at the mouth of Lake Kivu in eastern Congo, is one of the greatest hidden gems in all of Africa: the Orchids hotel.

title: Lviv, Ukraine
description: IT was the airport in Lviv, of all things, that first charmed me. Regional airports across the former Soviet Union tend to be a dreary lot, with all the appeal of a 24-hour bus station. But the one in Lviv, the largest city in western Ukraine, had wood paneling and ornate columns and the feel of a grand old railway station in a 1950s film.

title: 10 Restaurants Worth a Plane Ride
description: From new offerings by marquee chefs to more modest openings in out-of-the-way spots, here are 10 restaurants around the globe to keep an eye on in 2011, in alphabetical order.

title: Public Advocate Says Spider-Man May Violate Consumer Protection Laws
description: You can add Bill de Blasio, the New York City public advocate, to the list of nemeses that Spider-Man will have to battle en route to his much-delayed Broadway opening. In a letter sent to the citys Department of Consumer Affairs, Mr. de Blasio warned that the Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark may be violating consumer protection laws by not clearly distinguishing its preview period (when the show is still considered a work in progress) from its post-opening performances (when the show is a finished product), and could face fines.

title: Look of the Moment | Colin Firth
description: The Look: Royal Flash: The three-piece suit,a favorite of monarchs and kings of industry alike, reigns again. (Accessorized, naturally, with a Windsor knot.)

title: A Cappellooza
description: COLLEGIATE a cappella is enjoying a moment  perhaps its biggest since the Yale Whiffenpoofs were founded in 1909. It may be fitting that this years Poofs, who have the longest tradition, were eliminated early on this seasons Sing-Off, the hit a cappella version of American Idol. The most popular a cappella belies tradition for pop stylings and beatbox percussion, and stardom is just a viral video away. A few hits:

title: On Filibuster Reform
description: During the health care debate, I wrote a series of posts defending the filibuster  you can find them here, here, and here, with a much later follow-up here  and arguing for the virtues of a supermajority hurdle for controversial, big-ticket legislation. I stand by all of those arguments, but I also agree with Daniel Foster that the filibuster reform proposal the Senate Democrats are putting forward looks pretty reasonable. Essentially, for the filibuster to work as Id like it to work, it needs to be available as a check on temporary majorities without becoming a routine tactic for obstruction, which is how its increasingly employed. Ultimately, restoring this balance requires more collegiality, comity, and good manners: Theres no rule you can change that explicitly limits the filibuster to particularly sweeping and controversial pieces of legislation. (I mean, no reasonable rule, since I suppose you could imagine a provision stating that 60 votes shall only be required for cloture when Gallup shows that a majority of Americans oppose the legislation in question, or something similarly implausible.) But the revisions the Democrats are contemplating  which would limit the filibuster to substantive measures (no filibustering motions to proceed) and require actual speechifying from filibustering senators  would at least make the filibuster feel more extraordinary than it does today. And that seems like a step in the right direction.

title: The Hunt | In the Footsteps of Hamiltons and Tenenbaums
description: Xavier Joly and Emilie Johnson went to Harlem in search of a house like the one they had seen in the film The Royal Tenenbaums.

title: Navigating the Airfare Maze Online Gets Tougher
description: With online travel sites battling with some airlines, where does that leave travelers shopping for flights online? The simple answer is that theyre going to have to do more digging.

description: On the eve of the Detroit auto show, our colleagues at the Wheels blog have posted a video about efforts by the Big Three automakers to plow stimulus dollars into the development of electric cars. Part of the goal is reviving the local economy.

description: After an entertaining Winter Classic, a critically acclaimed HBO series and record high ratings, the N.H.L. is riding high. But is this just a temporary boost for the league, or the start of something more?

title: Diet: Childless Couples Eat Healthier, Study Finds
description: It may be an exaggeration to say that your children are making you sick, but a British study has found that couples with children eat a less healthy diet than those who have none.

title: Israeli Soldiers Kill Palestinian, 65, in His Bedroom
description: HEBRON, West Bank  Israeli soldiers shot and killed an unarmed 65-year-old Palestinian man in his bedroom in this tense city early Friday, in what appeared to be a case of mistaken identity.

title: Pasta in the Rough
description: FEW people make fresh pasta at home, and its not difficult to see why. Who wouldnt be put off by demonstrations that include piles of flour on cutting boards, or pasta-rolling machines spitting out six-foot ribbons of gorgeous dough?

description: Southern Sudan prepares to vote on secession from the North; Coptic Christians in Egypt celebrate Christmas; and a Brooklynite takes a daily swim in Brighton Beach, no matter what.

title: Float Like a Franchise, Sting Like a ...
