title: A Couple of Weeks Without Parking Rules? Try a Couple Months
description: On Sunday, this storm-tossed city will reach an impressive municipal milestone: the 17th consecutive day, stretching back to the bureaucratic observance of Christmas on Dec. 24, that alternate-side parking rules are suspended.

title: Artifacts | Damn White
description: Were so used to the white-cube environment of museums and galleries today that we hardly notice it. Thats the idea. Blank white walls are supposed to make it easier for viewers to focus on the artworks that hang on them. Sometimes that works, mostly for modern and contemporary art, which is often distracting enough. The general thinking seems to be that it wont abide any competition from the institution showing it.

title: To Some Dancers, Black Swan Is a Cautionary Tale
description: CARMELLA IMRIE spent six grueling hours last Wednesday mastering steps like the bris and jet battu for Keith Michaels ballet The Alice-in-Wonderland Follies. But instead of going home to nurse her toes afterward, she and five other dancers with the New York Theater Ballet headed out to see Black Swan.

title: Rocks, Zircon Zapping and a Big Shrimp
description: John Goodge, left, a professor of geological sciences at the University of Minnesota-Duluth, and Jeff Vervoort, an isotope geochemist from Washington State University, are writing from their research expedition in Antarctica.

description: As the securities business booms in China, the countrys government is cracking down on inexperienced reporters who cover the markets.

description: This weeks Minimalist features the easiest homemade pasta recipe I know, one that is completely authentic and delicious.

description: Emily Weinstein, who wrote a series on this blog about learning to cook, is now learning to bake with Dorie Greenspan, a food writer and the author of several cookbooks, including the recent Around My French Table.

description: Wisdom, insights and observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

description: Oversize televisions, undersize Blu-ray players, prescription eyeglasses for 3-D TV, a refrigerator with a touchscreen tablet planted on the door. Samsung covered all of the obvious bases and them some at this years Consumer Electronics Show, but among its most impressive debuts was something as pedestrian as a computer notebook.

title: Fashion Director Is Named New Editor of French Vogue
description: Giving the fashion world something to talk about is what the fashion world seems to do best. Today, less than a month after Carine Roitfeld announced she would leave the editor in chiefs job at French Vogue, the magazine named Emmanuelle Alt to succeed her, starting Feb. 1.

title: Air Products Extends Offer for Airgas
description: Air Products and Chemicals said on Friday that it had extended its tender offer for shares of Airgas to Feb. 4, from Jan. 14.

title: That Postwar Shimmy-Shake
description: IN the early 1940s, as America prepared for war, Rita Hayworth led a revolution. With her co-conspirators Lana Turner (at MGM) and Betty Grable (at 20th Century Fox), Hayworth, who was just emerging as the first star created in-house at budget-minded Columbia Pictures, offered a new shape and shapeliness to Hollywoods feminine ideal.

title: Detroit Auto Show: The Whirlwind Approaches
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Jerry Garrett previews next weeks Detroit auto show, which opens to the press on Monday.

title: Stage Scenes: Brian Bedford
description: A look at some of the actors past performances.

title: Tristano School, Back in Session
description: HAD he enjoyed a different sort of jazz career, you might say that Ted Brown was finally making a comeback. A tenor saxophonist drawn to a light and lyrically swinging style, Mr. Brown turned 83 last month, with just a handful of albums to his name. For the better part of 30 years, from the early 1960s on, he made his living as a computer programmer. Im not good at going out and getting gigs, he said recently, sounding resigned and matter of fact. By his account his last booking in New York as a bandleader was in 1976 at the short-lived Midtown branch of George Weins Storyville club.

title: Melodic Wanderings, Starting in Timbuktu
description: Farewell 2010? Not quite yet. Theres always the nagging-conscience pile: the music that didnt get timely attention as the year rushed by. Here are some stragglers.

title: Game on: More Real Than Reality TV
description: DURING its first three seasons The Game, the dramedy about professional football players and the women who barely tolerate them, overflowed with cameos by black celebrities. There were singers like Musiq, rappers like Soulja Boy, athletes like Chad Ochocinco and more. Robin Givens and Rick Fox played themselves in recurring roles. These appearances added verisimilitude to a series already steeped in it. Few shows on television were as specific to their moment as The Game.

title: Medicare Contractor Will Pay for Avastin During Appeal
description: A regional Medicare contractor that was planning to stop paying for use of the drug Avastin to treat breast cancer has reversed course.

title: Mets Try to Be Brainy With Pitching Staff
description: The new Mets pitcher Chris Capuano graduated from Duke University in 2000 with a 3.86 grade point average, an impressive number he would happily take either as his G.P.A. or earned run average. A 2006 National League All-Star, he was also Phi Beta Kappa.

title: The Risks of Being Too Risk-Averse in Investing
description: Paul Sullivan, in this weeks Wealth Matters column, writes that the professionals who watch the markets are optimistic about investing this year. But he notes that a lot of investors havent forgotten their losses in the recent market collapse and are wary of taking risks.

title: Chic in Review | Obamas Latest Flip-Flop
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Jersey Shore Returns and MTV Rides a Ratings Wave
description: On the third-season premiere of Jersey Shore on Thursday night, it was Deena Cortese, the newest addition to the beach house, who spent the episode repeatedly declaring herself a blast in a glass. But on Friday it was MTV that had cause to celebrate: it said the premiere had been watched by 8.45 million viewers, making it MTVs highest-rated series broadcast to date. The Season 3 debut episode, in which Nicole Polizzi (alias Snooki), Mike Sorrentino (aka the Situation) and their catchphrase-coining pals returned to their abode in Seaside Heights, N.J., saw a ratings increase of 63 percent over the Season 2 premiere in July (when the orange-skinned cast traveled to Miami) and 36 percent over that seasons finale in October. The overall viewership for the latest Jersey Shore premiere at 10 p.m. even exceeded broadcast networks like ABC (which drew 7.8 million viewers for a Private Practice repeat) and NBC (which attracted just over two million for reruns of The Office).

title: Is Facebook Worth $50 Billion?
description: DealBooks Evelyn M. Rusli talks to Scott Kessler, a research analyst at Standard & Poors, about whether Facebook, which just landed $450 million from Goldman Sachs, deserves its huge valuation.

title: House Cleans Up After Swearing-In Snafu
description: As they try to establish their ability to run the House smoothly, the new Republican leadership team obviously could have done without the snafu of two Republican lawmakers missing their swearing in on Wednesday but taking part in floor and committee proceedings anyway.

title: Is Facebook Worth $50 Billion?
description: DealBook's Evelyn M. Rusli talks to Scott Kessler, an equities analyst at Standard & Poor's, about whether Facebook deserves the valuation it received from Goldman Sachs.

The events left some disappointed: Verizon had little new to announce, and in particular, there was no announcement about an iPhone running on Verizon Wireless.

title: Elton John to Perform at Fund-Raiser
description: LOS ANGELES  A private concert at a Beverly Hills mansion by Sir Elton John?

Here they were, engaged in another ritualized activity, beholden to its mores and seeming at once proud, nervous and pleased.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: Why the Massachusetts Ruling Matters Effectively this shows the shortcomings of the fundamental design of the securitization process, of developing a one-size-fits-all process when some states have long-standing law (real estate is very well settled) that is idiosyncratic, says Yves Smith.Naked Capitalism

title: In the Footsteps of Hamiltons and Tenenbaums

Ms. Johnson would have been glad to remain there indefinitely, but Mr. Joly immediately began the hunt for something different.

title: Suddenly, a Brooklyn Skyline
description: THE view north across the East River from a high floor at Oro, a new 40-story condominium tower at 306 Gold Street in Downtown Brooklyn, is eye-popping, a panorama of clouds, bridges, water and skyscrapers in Manhattan. But gazing to the south and west from the same perch reveals a more traditional Brooklyn landscape: here a cluster of bank offices, there a line of cars at a Flatbush Avenue traffic light, set against a distant backdrop of low-rises and brownstones.

title: S.E.C. Says Manager Used Funds to Buy Vacation Home
description: The fund-of-funds manager Stanley Kowalewski seemed to have a penchant for real estate.

title: The Name Evokes Dawn for a Reason
description: FOR decades, in spite of supporters who argued to the contrary, Morningside Park was saddled with a dangerous reputation: a haven for drug addicts, a no mans land separating the ivy privilege of Columbia University, literally lofty on its perch, from the valley of Harlem below. Columbia students knew to avoid it. Lucy Martin-Gianino, an agent with the Corcoran Group who has sold homes along Morningside Drive, recalled crossing the park as a girl. I thought, This is the end of me, because it was dangerous territory.

title: A Winning Combination
description: AFZAL HOSSAIN, a 34-year-old artist and architect who grew up in Bangladesh, has vivid childhood memories of women making kanthas, handmade quilts constructed of layers of fabrics from worn garments and lavishly encrusted with colorful embroidery.

Standard approaches include: building the biggest booth, providing your female employees with the least amount of clothing and serving the freest lunch.

title: If Giuliani Is Back, It Wont Be By Popular Demand
description: Lets not indulge in any equivocation: Mayor Rudy Giulianis 2008 presidential campaign was a flop. Though he was an early front-runner in national surveys of potential Republican primary voters, Mr. Giuliani placed a distant sixth in the Iowa caucus, fourth in the New Hampshire primary, sixth again in both Michigan and South Carolina and then, finally, a distant third in Florida, a state where he had allocated much of his resources. Mr. Giuliani then dropped out of the race and endorsed John McCain.

description: Snowmageddon Two it was not.

description: MY food rut of 2010 was soba. I was complacent, preparing it the same way every time by tossing the slender buckwheat strands with broth, scallions and sesame oil and then throwing a piece of seared salmon on top.

title: A Soundtrack for the Chaos, Light and Dark of Creation
description: Word must be getting around that when Alan Gilbert presents one of his ambitious contemporary-music projects at the New York Philharmonic, like the staged production of Ligetis bleakly comic opera Le Grand Macabre last season, these programs are not to be missed. So it was on Thursday night when Mr. Gilbert conducted the New York premiere of the British composer Thomas Adss In Seven Days (Concerto for Piano With Moving Image).

title: Familial Discord? Enough to Back a Boxer in a Corner
description: WHEN FX executives watched the pilot for Lights Out, their prospective boxing drama, they were mesmerized by the relative unknown Holt McCallany. He plays the former heavyweight champ Lights Leary as he begins a journey back into the ring while being pummeled by family strife, crushing debt, health issues and a deepening identity crisis.

His players carried Harbaugh off on their shoulders, and almost from the moment they set him down, N.F.L. owners and general managers, college presidents and boosters courted him.

title: California Insurers Rate Increase Draws Fire
description: When WellPoint, through its Anthem Blue Cross subsidiary, last year tried to raise insurance rates as much as 39 percent for people with individual policies in California, the health insurer immediately became the poster child for whats wrong with the nations health system.

title: Its Iraq but Its Not, Part 2
description: This is the second of two posts that look at the difference between life in Baghdad and the countrys northern Kurdish region. Read the first post here.

title: Tenet Adopts Poison Pill as It Fights Community Health Bid
description: 8:01 p.m. | Updated Tenet Healthcare, the hospital operator, said on Friday that it was adopting a shareholder rights plan to defend itself against an unsolicited $3.3 billion bid from a rival, Community Health Systems.

title: Envelope Ignites at Mail Facility in Capital
description: An incendiary device ignited at a postal facility in Washington, D.C., on Friday, the police said. There were no reported injuries, and the brief fire went out by itself.

description: The winners of the A/X Swiss Teams on the last day of the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Manhattan last month were Debbie and Michael Rosenberg of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Alison Wilson and Aaron Silverstein of New York.

title: Whats Fair Is Fair, Unless Its Not
description: In a Theater Talkback published on the ArtsBeat blog, Charles Isherwood argued that it made sense for critics to wait until a shows official opening before they delivered their verdict in a review. Here is a selection of readers responses to his argument:

title: Highs and Lows for Qatar
description: Qatar, the new center of the soccer universe, suffered a demoralizing defeat Friday when it lost , 2-0, to Uzbekistan in the opening match of the quadrennial Asian Cup. But it received a boost from the FIFA president, Sepp Blatter, whose public-relations campaign in recent months has had its highs and lows.

title: The Six Degrees of Andy Cohen
description: SOME people say hello when they run into a friend at a restaurant. For Andy Cohen, a Bravo executive and talk show host, hello would be boring. It would be flat. It would not reflect his oversize pleasure in the smallest of surprises, the magnitude of the serendipity, as he sees it.

title: The Impresario Whos Keeping the 80s Spirit Alive Downtown
description: This was New York. 1980. Sweaty, smoky, sexy, coke-y New York. Dangerous New York.

description: pictures

description: You can add Bill de Blasio, the New York City public advocate, to the list of nemeses that Spider-Man will have to battle en route to his much-delayed Broadway opening.

title: Big Deal | A Slow Recovery in the Hamptons
description: Figuring out the state of the real estate market in the Hamptons can be tricky.

title: The Kings Speech Advances and the Coens Ponder Another Remake
description: The Academy Awards arent all celebrity glitz and glam: the Bagger spent all day hanging out at an outer-borough elementary school, and it was still part of the Oscar beat. (Stay tuned to find out why.) Also today, the Academy announced the winners of its technical awards, which appear as a blip on the telecast but get to enjoy what is probably a pretty fun ceremony, usually hosted by a pretty young actress (Jessica Alba is totally scientific, right?). The honorees at the nerd Oscars will include Dr. Mark Sagar, for influential facial motion retargeting solutions, a.k.a. a way to transform motion-capture into a stable of animated characters; Mark Noel and John Frazier, for creating a winch system that allows cars, planes and other large props to be flown on wires; and Eric Tabellion and Arnauld Lamorlette, for the creation of a computer graphics bounce lighting methodology that is practical at feature film scale, as seen in Shrek 2 and described in their paper An Approximate Global Illumination System for Computer Generated Films. What if the Bagger covered these Oscars instead? The mind boggles.

title: Learning With Disabilities
description: RAYNE NELSON, a 21-year-old sophomore at Landmark College in Putney, Vt., does not let her attention deficit hyperactivity disorder throw her off track.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Pakistan, Spain and Sudan.

title: 31 Kinds of Pancakes, All Day
description: If you arrive at the Brownstone Diner and Pancake Factory here right after the breakfast rush, you might see tables strewn with plates of syrup-soaked, half-eaten pancakes.

title: New Street Photography, 60 Years Old
description: Vivian Maier, evidently one of Americas more insightful street photographers, has at last been discovered. The release of every fresh image on the Web causes a sensation among the growing legion of her admirers. (Frankly, Lens is late to the table.) Ms. Maiers streetscapes manage simultaneously to capture a redolent sense of place and the paradoxical moments that give the city its jazz, while elevating and dignifying the people in her frames  vulnerable, noble, defeated, proud, fragile, tender and often quite funny. Harry Callahan is just one of the masters with whom Ms. Maier is already being compared.

title: Guinea Worm in the Sudan
description: The great majority of the remaining cases of Guinea worm are in southern Sudan.

title: Car Tech Gets Up to Speed at C.E.S.
description: Forget, for a moment, the old school car tech  the giant subwoofers, the monster amps, the free T-shirts  at previous Consumer Electronics Shows, where the automotive exhibit felt more like a garage than a cuddly trade show; this year, its a digital festival.

title: Indian Flair That Runs in the Family
description: THE carpeted hall shared by Akbars dining room and its three banquet rooms might feel like a hotel lobby when it is empty, but on two Saturday-night visits, it was electric with crowds caught midcelebration.

title: Another Portable Blu-ray Player. Why?
description: A couple of years ago  make that eons ago in consumer electronics-speak  LG Electronics embraced the Blu-ray format when Blu-ray was locked in formidable battle with a competing (now dead) optical disc video formula called HD DVD. Remember that one? We thought not.

title: Twitter: The New Rules of Engagement
description: HOW to connect with a generation hooked on social media? Teach in 140 characters or less.

title: Straddling Sides
description: IN the seven years since he quit his job as a college counselor at a private high school in Portland, Ore., Lloyd Thacker has become something of a folk hero in admissions circles. In standing-room-only gatherings in high school auditoriums, he has implored families to take back the college admissions process from those entities that, he says, do not always act in their best interests  whether a magazine seeking to drum up sales for its rankings issue or a college trying to boost applications.

title: Too Much Information
description: A FEW weeks after I started a tenure-track job last semester at the State University of New York at New Paltz, an e-mail message landed in faculty in-boxes relaying the news that an online textbook-rental company had requested records for all grades awarded on campus since 2007.

title: Colleges Value Added
description: AT a time when recent graduates, age 24 and under, are experiencing a jobless rate of nearly 10 percent, a new study renews the debate over the value-added component of going to college.

title: A Career Detour
description: WHEN Mary Ellin Arch was called to the human resources department of The Richmond Times-Dispatch in August 2007, she thought she would be discussing a possible hire for the paper's Web site, where she was a news editor and managed a staff of 10.

title: Five Do-Gooders
description: An SAT Savior

title: The Newest College Credential
description: EDUCATION, students are frequently told, is the key to a better job. First, finish high school. Then, go to college and get a degree. For those with higher aspirations, try for a masters.

title: Need to Know
description: WORK in public relations covers a range of industries, with jobs in advertising and P.R. firms, corporations, nonprofit organizations and even college information offices.

title: The Study of Man (or Males)
description: IF you are a college graduate of a certain age, you probably remember that there used to be an all-purpose discipline that studied men and their behavior. It was called history. There was also a subject, called literature, that studied what men wrote. And art examined the pictures men painted.

title: Early Birds Rise
description: EARLY admissions programs allow anxious high school seniors to learn whether they got into their first-choice college ahead of the pack (applicants hear back Dec. 15 to mid-January). But these programs have also sparked debate.

title: War and Peace in 24 Hours
description: THINK of it as an antidote to the electronic era. For 12 continuous hours last spring, 60 students and teachers at Hamilton College in upstate New York read aloud from John Miltons Paradise Lost, which spans a dozen volumes.

title: Cape Wind Is Cleared for Takeoff  Mostly
description: Cape Wind, the wind farm proposed for a 24-square-mile tract of Nantucket Sound off Cape Cod, Mass., got its final government permit on Friday, 10 years after work on the project began, the sponsors announced. They hope to begin construction this year, although they have not yet lined up a market for all of the electricity.

title: To 4G or Not to 4G, That Is the Question
description: The refrain from the phone industry at C.E.S. has been 4G, 4G, 4G.

title: Swing Thats Smoked and Saucy and Will Stick
description: Thursday night, in the basement of Hill Country Barbecue Market, where pork ribs and slices of brisket are eaten off slick butcher paper and the napkins are rolls of paper towels, the smell of Texas was almost as pungent as the sound.

title: An Android Phones Alter Ego
description: LAS VEGAS  This morning at the Consumer Electronics Show here, I spent some time playing with Motorolas Atrix 4G. Its an Android app phone, coming this spring to AT&T  with a huge, towering, brilliant twist.

title: Ford Unveils Focus Electric in New York and Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS  Saying that Ford Motor Company is fully charged, Alan Mulally, the automakers chief executive, unveiled a fully electric version of its 2012 Ford Focus compact car during a keynote address Friday at the Consumer Electronics Show here.

title: Bringing His Baton and Bold Hopes to Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Philadelphia Orchestra with a French accent? The notion is almost as preposterous as that of an Italianate Chicago Symphony.

title: T.C.U. Puts Message for Ohio State in Lights
description: Take that, Ohio State.

description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Building an Alliance to Aid Films by Blacks
description: LOS ANGELES  Ava DuVernay, the filmmaker and publicist, imagines a time when black-theme pictures will flourish in places where African-American film festivals have already found eager viewers.

title: Not Your Typical Luncheonette
description: In the years since the Harvest Caf and Bakery opened, in 1995, it has become a much-loved place. That was apparent several months back when, in need of costly renovations, it attracted 65 volunteers who came with hammers, saws and paintbrushes. It is also evident nearly every day of the week, with customers filling tables from breakfast through lunch.

title: A Transformation of Space
description: IF at first you dont succeed, get a new name and a completely different menu. That seems to be what the brothers Joseph, Michael and Frank Rocco have done, transforming their generous New Canaan space into the Pine Social restaurant, a vast improvement over Roccos Italian Kitchen, their former venture in the same spot.

title: Angry Birds at C.E.S.
description: Angry Birds are showing up everywhere  even on the C.E.S. show floor.

title: Abandon All Nostalgia. The Organizer Is Coming Over.
description: Before Barbara Reich, The Organizer, arrived, I had devoted several frantic hours to pre-organizing. After all, I had spent weeks absorbing her secrets to a clutter-free existence, so I knew something about how to Barbarafy. I also feared that if she saw my childrens playroom in its natural state, she might have deemed the whole place unsalvageable.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 7
description: More Photographs

title: U.S. to Hear Banks Pitches for A.I.G. Offering
description: The Treasury Department will begin taking pitches from major investment banks for leading roles in selling off the first part of the governments stake in the American International Group, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Friday.

title: A Guitar With No Strings Attached
description: As longtime Pogophiles know, Im a not-so-closeted musician. No wonder the Kitara digital guitar ($850) caught my eye.

title: Pogues Posts: A Guitar With No Strings Attached
description: As longtime Pogophiles know, Im a not-so-closeted musician. No wonder the Kitara digital guitar ($850) caught my eye.

title: Tax Charges to Be Added in Espada Case
description: Pedro Espada Jr., a former majority leader of the New York Senate and the states highest ranking Hispanic official before his career unspooled in scandal and a federal fraud indictment, will now also face tax charges, a prosecutor said Friday.

title: F.C.C. Chairman: We Need to Auction Off More Spectrum
description: LAS VEGAS  Mobile phone service is miserable in many places at the Consumer Electronics Show, maybe proving the points made by the Federal Communications Commission chairman, Julius Genachowski, in an appearance on stage Friday afternoon.

title: Sarah Kozlowski, Jeffrey Bartfeld
description: Sarah Kozlowski, the daughter of Ellen Kozlowski and Dr. Jeffrey Kozlowski of Tenafly, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Jeffrey Bartfeld, the son of Sandra M. Bartfeld and Arnold L. Bartfeld of North Caldwell, N.J. Rabbi David-Seth Kirshner officiated at Capitale, an event space in New York.

title: Meredyth Isaac, Michael Romalis
description: Meredyth Isaac, the daughter of Laura Criscione of Fort Lee, N.J., and David Isaac of Hackensack, N.J., was married Saturday to Michael Romalis, the son of Valery Kaplan of Migdal HaEmek, Israel, and the late Natalia Romalis-Reytblatt, who lived in Bridgeport, Conn. Dr. Joseph Chuman, the leader of the Ethical Culture Society of Bergen County, officiated at the Princeton University Chapel in Princeton, N.J.

title: Emily Rubinstein and Igor Zilberman
description: Emily Rebecca Rubinstein and Dr. Igor Zilberman were married Saturday evening at Gurneys Inn in Montauk, N.Y. Rabbi Steven D. Burton officiated.

title: Lindsay Speros, Henry Robbins
description: Lindsay Catherine Speros and Henry Haywood Robbins were married Saturday at Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Alistair Drummond, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Kate Craven, Christopher Nealon
description: Kate Elizabeth Craven and Christopher Paul Nealon were married Saturday afternoon at the University of Virginia Chapel in Charlottesville, Va. The Rev. Stephen P. Alcott, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Maria Harrold and Jeremy Serkin
description: Maria Lynn Harrold and Jeremy Robert Serkin are to be married Sunday in Gainesville, Fla. Rabbi David Kaiman is to officiate at the Sweetwater Branch Inn.

title: Megan Argie and Mathew Cox
description: Megan Marie Argie and Mathew Ryan Cox were married Saturday at St. Paul Shrine in Cleveland. The Rev. William Wiethorn, a Roman Catholic priest, led the ceremony.

title: 50 Cent: Facebook Is Worth $50 Billion, Maybe More
description: Curtis Jackson, more commonly known as 50 Cent, has parlayed his career as a hip-hop artist into a multifaceted business and a tidy personal fortune. His minority investment in Glacau turned into a windfall when Coca-Cola purchased the maker of Vitamin Water for $4.1 billion in 2007.

title: Teknions Magic Charging Lamp
description: I have to admit, I havent been a huge fan of charging mats, those pads that recharge a phones batteries by just sitting it on the pad. One reason was that for them to work, you had to add some kind of clunky case to your phone or whatever you wanted to charge up. Another was, when not in use, the pad worthlessly took up a lot of desk space.

title: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 7
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include New Years Eve, piled-up garbage, and a governors inauguration.

title: Organize This!
description: GLIDING into Susan Hitzig and Ken Yaffes apartment, in a doorman building off Central Park West, Barbara Reich did not waste time ogling the obvious: the sleek kitchen, the view of the American Museum of Natural History, the sophisticated living room bearing no trace of the couples three children. Instead, Ms. Reich peered into a closet, where she found mismatched hangers and decreed, This is wrong.

title: Ask About Getting Organized
description: With the new year, often comes the resolution to toss out the old and get things in order. In this weeks Metropolitan section, Elissa Gootman of The Times writes about Barbara Reich, a professional organizer, who helped her do just that.

title: Egyptian Bloggers Account of a Vigil in Cairo
description: Hundreds of Egyptians attended a candlelight vigil in downtown Cairo on Friday, the Coptic Christian Christmas, to show their solidarity with members of the Coptic community a week after a suicide bomber killed at least 21 people at a church in Alexandria during a New Years Eve Mass.

title: Zaggs New iPad Keyboard
description: One of the chief knocks on the iPad is that while its great for consuming music, movies, and the Web, its crummy for producing anything, even simple documents. Largely that is because of the lack of a physical keyboard.

title: A Day Without Goals
description: To be Henrik Lundqvist is to suit up. When the Swedish-born goaltender of the New York Rangers isnt sporting Blueshirt No. 30, he may wear a dapper three-piece number. On Sundays, though, Mr. Lundqvist, 28  who won a gold medal in the 2006 Winter Olympics blocking pucks for Swedens national hockey team  dresses down, relaxing at the movies or playing his guitar. He lives with his fiance, Therese Andersson, 28, and their 4-year-old Doberman, Nova, in a two-bedroom duplex in the West 50s with a terrace and a hot tub. ELISA MALA

title: America by the Numbers
description: A new report from the Census Bureau reveals data about many vital things, including water, jazz and bowling.

title: C.E.S.: A Bad Time to Introduce a Tech Product
description: As I walk through the corridors of the Consumer Electronics Show, Im frequently stopped by P.R. people hoping for a little journalistic attention.

title: Flex Time Flourishes in Accounting Industry
description: As the peak season for the nations accounting firms begins, David Leedss team at Ernst & Young is once again bracing for two months of 60-hour weeks auditing the books of a major bank in Atlanta.

title: Islam en Espaol: In Conversion, a New Identity
description: AT the North Hudson Islamic Educational Center in Union City, N.J., there are Spanish-language classes on the Koran and an annual Latino Muslim Day. About 35 percent of the centers congregation is Hispanic, and there are frequent conversions in which Puerto Ricans, Dominicans, Mexicans, Cubans and others recite the Shahadah, a declaration of belief.

title: Escort Fighting the App Revolution
description: You may wonder how a company like Escort, the radar detector company once beloved by lead-footed drivers everywhere, is to survive against smartphones. After all, smartphones can be armed with apps like Trapster that let people report speed traps in real time on phones, and whose data can be added to some TomTom and Garmin GPS units.

title: Discussing Art, Amid French Ephemera
description: With its cozy wood paneling and focused menu, Lyon, an ode to the Lyonnaise bouchon, has become a fast favorite in the West Village since it opened last year. Franois Latapie, a former partner at La Goulue on the Upper East Side and a fan of French ephemera, has used his own collection to create an eclectic feel in the former Caf de Bruxelles space on Greenwich Avenue at 13th Street. Old comics wallpaper the bathrooms, an illuminated Michelin man  Mr. Latapies only New York find  perches near the bar, and a peripatetic pig outfitted as a butcher (pale blue jacket, diagonally draped apron) stands in a window over a dining table, for now. On Wednesday, four friends catching up on life and art took it all in. DIANE CARDWELL

title: Small Companies Pursue Big Break at Tech Conference
description: LAS VEGAS  The 2,700 technology companies selling their wares at the Consumer Electronics Show here come in all shapes and sizes. At one end of the spectrum are the likes of Microsoft, Samsung and Sony, with their gargantuan booths on the show floor, where they ply potential business partners and journalists with drinks, food and private meetings with executives.

title: Functions to Make Phones Easier for the Elderly
description: LAS VEGAS  No matter how easy-to-use a manufacturer may believe its tech products are, they may still baffle the elderly.

title: Scope and Pace of Gulf Cleanup Is Criticized
description: BAY JIMMY, La.  Eight months since the Deepwater Horizon oil spill began, the cleanup of the Gulf of Mexico goes on, with over 5,000 people and more than 300 boats still at work. Tar balls are still washing up on beaches. Visible sheen is still showing up in certain places in the wake of motorboats. Oil is being washed out of some areas, where it was buried, only to show up someplace else.

title: Verizon Is Said to Be Planning to Announce iPhone 4 on Its Network
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Verizon Wireless plans to announce on Tuesday that it will soon begin selling Apples iPhone 4, according to a person with direct knowledge of the plans.

title: The Handwritten Letter, an Art All but Lost, Thrives in Prison
description: To the Georgia Department of Corrections he is inmate No. 544319, in prison on a five-year sentence for drug possession. But to the editors of Maxim, he is Mike Bolick, a faithful reader and regular letter writer who has loopy penmanship and an eye for beautiful cover models.

title: There Stays the Neighborhood
description: New York is a place of constant change, an ever-shifting mosaic of immigrants, ethnic groups, strivers who make their mark and move on.

title: Surprise Choice for Immigration Panel
description: The new Republican chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, Lamar Smith of Texas, has passed over an outspoken immigration hard-liner and member of the Tea Party caucus for chairman of the immigration subcommittee.

title: Sauce for the Goose? Take a Gander
description: To this day I dont know what made me do it.

title: Helping the Worlds Poorest, for a Change
description: Tuesdays Fixes column was about conditional cash transfers, a new and highly successful large-scale anti-poverty program. It pays poor women as long as they meet certain responsibilities, like keeping their children in school and taking their families for regular medical care. Its in use in Brazil, Mexico and 38 other countries.

title: Justices to Hear Case on Recusal Laws
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to decide whether states may forbid government officials to vote on matters where they appear to have a personal conflict. The case, which concerns a member of a city council in Nevada, was one of seven the court added to its docket.

title: Class of 1950, Primed for Success
description: FOR most of my life I wondered what had become of them: the pretty girl in the back; the boy who used to be my best friend; the teacher, Mr. Goldman, with his blondish hair and falling pompadour. There were 35 of us in a special class of gifted children  9 S-P  at Junior High School 149 in East New York, Brooklyn. Two little girls who turned boys heads, Faith Hurwitz and Marilyn Bloom, held a sign in our graduation picture reading, June 1950.

title: Under Siege in War-Torn Somalia, a Doctor Holds Her Ground
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia

title: New Measure to Hinder Closing of Guantnamo
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama signed a major defense bill on Friday that includes strict new limits on the governments ability to transfer detainees out of the prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba. He sharply criticized those restrictions, but did not claim that he had the constitutional authority to disregard them.

title: The Toil Index
description: DENVER  If earning $75,000 a year is the key to happiness  unless, of course, you earn less than the median income in your profession  heres another measure of well-being: whether you can afford to live in a good school district.

title: Sanofi-Genzyme Deal Talks Progress
description: Jan. 9, 4:03 p.m. | Updated Sanofi-Aventis confirmed on Sunday that it was in discussions with Genzyme about potentially using contingent value rights to bolster its current takeover offer for the pharmaceutical company.

title: Rookie McKnight Makes Progress With Jets
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Joe McKnight, the Jets rookie running back, got to pack his equipment into a green duffel bag for the teams trip to Indianapolis on Friday, and he seemed to be perfectly fine not knowing how much he will get to play against the Colts on Saturday night.

title: The Constitution, Sort Of
description: Republicans like to think of themselves as the party that gets things done, yet the opening of the 112th Congress on Wednesday didnt bode well in terms of efficiency: two new members apparently voted on and initiated bills before they had been sworn in; the party leadership waffled on its promise to cut $100 billion in domestic spending this year; and Speaker of the House John Boehner was accused of breaking his own pledge to send all bills through a complete committee process. Well, at least there was no way to mess up the much-hyped symbolic measure of the day, a bipartisan reading of the Constitution, right?

title: Queens Block Was Ready for a Storm That Barely Came
description: Daisy Roman dropped her sons off at school on Friday and rushed to the supermarket, just in case. Dawn Frey made sure her groceries were delivered. Five doors away, John Moore gassed up his snowblower and left handy some extra bags of road salt.

title: One Dies in Fire From Stove Used for Heat
description: A longtime resident of a Lower East Side tenement was killed early Friday in a fire that started because she was using her stove to warm her apartment after heat went out in the building, the Fire Department said.

title: Hot-and-Cold Support for a Winter World Cup
description: Sepp Blatter, soon up for re-election as the president of FIFA, has a shipwrecked sailors sense of which way the wind is blowing.

title: Leaving Gangs and Drugs to Earn a Living Honestly
description: When Orlando Garcia was selling crack cocaine, he was making $900 a day.

title: Struggle Forecast for Pentagon and Deficit Hawks
description: Now that the Obama administration has forced the Pentagon to gradually freeze its budget in response to economic pressures, the question in Washington is: How long will the deal hold up?

title: Hands-On Job Has Deputy Mayor Taking His Lumps
description: When Deputy Mayor Stephen Goldsmith announced the demotion of about 100 senior city officials last fall, he emphasized that he would not involve himself in the fine details of how the personnel changes were carried out.

title: Israeli Ex-Spy Predicts Delay for Irans Nuclear Ambitions
description: JERUSALEM  Israels departing intelligence chief said he believes Iran will not be able to build a nuclear weapon before 2015 at the earliest, Israeli news media reported Friday, in a revised and surprisingly upbeat assessment of Tehrans nuclear capabilities.

title: Last Wish of Elaines Owner May Be Illegal
description: Elaine Kaufman, the cantankerous Manhattan restaurateur who died last month, usually got her way, at least inside the restaurant on the Upper East Side that she ran for 47 years.

title: Searching for the Soul to Cleanse It
description: A new year, a new opportunity to cleanse the soul and start afresh. Isnt that what everyone says? Around this time of year, people can get consumed with ambitious resolutions, new gym memberships and spiritual purification. Its never been my experience, though. Im not sure where my soul resides, but wherever it is, its probably a terrible mess.

title: Obama the Centrist Irks a Liberal Lion
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  So how would he grade President Obamas economic policies, and the new team put in place this week?

title: History Channel Will Not Show Kennedys Miniseries
description: 10:21 p.m. | Updated

title: Good Fit for the Packers, as Well as Their Fans
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  The offensive players now do it in meetings. Whenever Green Bay Packers coaches show film of the beefy running back John Kuhn carrying the ball  often on a battering-ram run inside the 20-yard line  Kuhns teammates chant his last name, holding the vowel for several seconds, mimicking the way fans at Lambeau Field salute their newest cult hero. Kooooon.

title: A Shot of Liquid Seduction
description: With holiday mania behind us, we can turn to the simple joys of winter: sledding, skating, snowman-building  and sipping hot chocolate. The last comes first at the Cocoa Chocolate Shop in Larchmont, a tiny storefront boasting huge caloric possibilities in the form of truffles, bonbons, barks and  best of all  criminally smooth hot chocolate that tastes and acts like liquid chocolate pudding.

title: An Open Kitchen Thats Truly Open
description: OPEN kitchens are commonplace these days, but even as they offer a peek into the culinary process, they usually feel separate from the dining area. Chefs and other workers are focused on their tasks, and the view is often only partial, blocked by appliances or someones back.

title: Rift in Arizona as Latino Class Is Found Illegal
description: TUCSON  The class began with a Mayan-inspired chant and a vigorous round of coordinated hand clapping. The classroom walls featured protest signs, including one that said United Together in La Lucha!  the struggle. Although open to any student at Tucson High Magnet School, nearly all of those attending Curtis Acostas Latino literature class on a recent morning were Mexican-American.

title: Mattebellas European Flair
description: The up-and-coming wines of Mattebella Vineyards, in Southold, display a European style, with an Italian inflection; the labels top red is called Old World Blend.

title: A Korean Restaurant With Japanese Detours
description: THE number of Korean restaurants in Nassau and Suffolk Counties can probably be counted on the fingers of one hand. It was therefore cause for celebration when Imperial Seoul opened in New Hyde Park in late October.

title: Obamas Top Aide a Tough, Decisive Negotiator
description: WASHINGTON  Nobody got fired  at least, not outright  when William M. Daley arrived in Nashville in the summer of 2000 to impose order on Al Gores foundering presidential campaign. Aides were bickering, the candidate seemed demoralized and strategy sessions had deteriorated into what Chris Lehane, a Gore adviser, called a salon-like atmosphere of endless talk and no decisions.

title: Just 7 Strips of Green, or a Park Worth Fighting For?
description: All together, the seven strips of greenery hardly seem substantial enough to amount to a park. Someone unfamiliar with Greenwich Village might pass them by as ornamental to their adjoining buildings, like extra-wide hedges.

title: Life Sentence Is Requested in Bomb Case
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan asked a judge on Friday to impose a life sentence on Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani, the former Guantnamo detainee who was tried last fall in the 1998 bombings of two American Embassies in East Africa.

title: Journal Showcases Dying Art of the Research Paper
description: SUDBURY, Mass.  William H. Fitzhugh, the cantankerous publisher of a journal that showcases high school research papers, sits at his computer in a cluttered office above a secondhand shop here, deploring the nations declining academic standards.

title: Events on Long Island
description: Comedy

title: Soldier Faces Court-Martial in Killings
description: An Army sergeant accused of being the ringleader in the killings of three Afghan civilians has been referred to a court-martial, Army officials said Friday.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to the Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Business Group Prepares Plans to Counter Unions
description: It has already changed its name once during its two-month existence and one prominent board member, Richard D. Parsons, the chairman of Citigroup, has already resigned, possibly under pressure from public employee unions.

title: Renaissance for Outspoken Catholic Philosopher
description: Gertrude Elizabeth Margaret Anscombe, the Catholic philosopher whose work on subjects from Aristotelian ethics to the perils of birth control is enjoying a renaissance, died 10 years ago this week in England, at 81. And obituary writers remembered what she wore.

title: Whos Afraid of Microfracture Surgery?
description: In N.B.A. circles, there might not be a more terrifying medical term than microfracture surgery.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: Comedy

title: Sorrow in Brooklyn for Terror in Egypt
description: Flashing lights from two police cars illuminated the red-brick church on Thursday night. Two counterterrorism officers wearing civilian clothes carefully scrutinized the congregants. It was Christmas Eve, one of the happiest days in the Coptic calendar. A church deacon sheepishly checked the bags of people he had known his whole life.

title: An Unexpected Choice for a House Post
description: The new Republican chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, Representative Lamar Smith of Texas, passed over an outspoken immigration hard-liner and Tea Party caucus member for chairman of the immigration subcommittee.

title: Saturday: Changing With the Times
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Todays offering by Will Nediger is a crunchy, clean puzzle full of good stuff, like Swiftly written for SATIRIZED and Result of good middle management?, a brilliant clue for FLAT STOMACH. Its wonderful to see Charles SCHULZ in the grid, and Its the same old story for REMAKE made me smile.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Baby Sitter Is Charged in Death of Infant
description: A 26-year-old baby sitter was charged on Friday with murdering a 3-month-old Queens infant whose widely publicized death was initially tied to delays in medical treatment during a blizzard last month.

title: Tax-Exempt Ministries Avoid New Regulation
description: A three-year investigation into financial improprieties at six Christian ministries whose television preaching bankrolled leaders lavish lifestyles has concluded with the formation of an independent commission to look into the lack of accountability by tax-exempt religious groups.

title: Readers Questions Answered
description: The Heavens Grow Quiet

title: Los Angeles Officials Identify Video Assault Suspects
description: LOS ANGELES  It started with an anonymous package mailed to the Los Angeles County Sheriffs Department, full of some of the most gruesome evidence investigators had ever seen: 100 hours of video footage that showed men sexually assaulting severely disabled women. Some assaults took place at residential care centers.

title: Oklahoma: State Will Challenge Health Care Law
description: Scott Pruitt, a Republican who will succeed a Democrat as attorney general when he is sworn in on Monday, said Friday that he would file an independent lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of the Obama health care law. Two similar federal suits are being pursued by Republican officials elsewhere  in Florida by attorneys general and governors from 20 states, and in Virginia by the commonwealths attorney general. The judge in the Virginia case has ruled against the laws requirement that most Americans obtain insurance, and a decision is expected soon in Florida. Two other federal judges have upheld the law, and the dispute is most likely headed to the Supreme Court. In Oklahoma, Governor-elect Mary Fallin, a Republican, said she supported her states lawsuit, which had been opposed by Gov. Brad Henry, a Democrat. Voters approved a state constitutional amendment in November that seeks to invalidate the insurance mandate, and Mr. Pruitt said that conflict necessitated a separate lawsuit.

title: Ex-Lobbyist Sentenced to Prison in Corruption Case
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va.  Paul Magliocchetti, the once-powerful lobbyist whose PMA Group collapsed after being raided by federal agents two years ago, was sentenced to 27 months in prison on Friday for his role in one of the largest schemes to evade limits on campaign donations ever uncovered.

title: The One-Minute Pitch
description: LAS VEGAS  Mixed in among the Microsofts and the Motorolas at the Consumer Electronics Show are scores of small businesses trying to leave their mark. But the competition for attention is fierce, and time is short. Here, three entrepreneurs give the quick pitches for their products.

title: Powerhouse Writers, Reading at Rutgers
description: WHEN the novelist Jayne Anne Phillips began the Writers at Newark Reading Series in 2007, it was with bold intentions.

title: Idaho G.O.P. Seeks to Close Open Primaries
description: When the national political balance shifted rightward in November, Idaho did not have much room to move. Republicans already overwhelmingly controlled the State Legislature and held every major state office.

title: Theres a Fire! Pick a Photo!
description: YOUR house is burning down, and the people and pets are safe but you have time to grab just one object. What would you rescue?

title: In Battle Over Health Law, Math Cuts Both Ways
description: WASHINGTON  With the health care fight roaring back to life on Capitol Hill, questions that seemed settled last March, when President Obama signed his top domestic priority into law, are once again front and center.

title: Speeding the War Wounded to Care
description: The survival rate of those troops wounded in the Afghan war has improved, both because of the greater availability of evacuation helicopters and in the improvement in equipment and medical procedures.

title: Dealmakers Next Challenge Is to Showcase the Pac-10
description: WALNUT CREEK, Calif.  At the first Association of Tennis Professionals tournament in Qatar in the early 1990s, the countrys head of state, known as the emir, met with the ATPs president, Mark Miles, for a formal exchange of gifts.

title: A Female, but Not Mainly Feminine, Eye
description: The current exhibition at the New Britain Museum of American Art seems to have been devised for the express purpose of reminding viewers of two separate but equal propositions: first, that for all the broad progress made by female artists since the beginnings of the feminist critique in the 1970s, theres still lots of ground to make up, and second, that for all the historic obstacles and restrictions hindering them, female artists have somehow managed to contribute significantly to American art.

title: Dorsett Worried About Damage to Pitt Program
description: The University of Pittsburgh has become the butt of jokes in college football for its poorly handled coaching search, which has featured players publicly supporting their fired coach, and the replacement coach being arrested shortly after winning the new job.

title: In Wider War in Afghanistan, Survival Rate of Wounded Rises
description: KHAKREZ DISTRICT, Afghanistan  Intensified fighting and a larger troop presence in Afghanistan in 2010 led to the highest American combat casualties yet in the war, as the number of troops wounded by bullets, shrapnel and bombs approached that of the bloodiest periods of the war in Iraq.

title: A Space for Music, Paintings and a Few Fire Trucks
description: WEST WINDSOR, N.J.

title: Swimming in the Cold
description: No matter the weather, Gary Atlas, a Brighton Beach resident, runs six miles and takes a dip in the cold ocean water.

title: Knicks Show Suns What They Were
description: PHOENIX  Amare Stoudemire peeked his head around the corner, and first surprise and then satisfaction showed on his face. A large group of reporters had gathered to hear what he had to say in his return here, with a Knicks resurgence under way and the Phoenix Suns still seeking an identity without him.

title: City Board Names First Asian Mayor of San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO  After weeks of debate  and often open verbal combat  the San Francisco Board of Supervisors effectively elected Edwin M. Lee, the city administrator, as its new mayor on Friday, making him the first Asian-American to lead the city.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Gates Packs Familiar List of Issues for Beijing
description: WASHINGTON  In late 2007, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates flew to Beijing bearing pledges of harmony and vows to strengthen the Pentagons ties with Chinas booming military. On Saturday he sets forth on the same journey, but with mostly conflict and suspicion to show for the three years that have elapsed.

title: A U.S. Portrait, in Numbers
description: Forget that adage about death and taxes: since 2000, both the death rate and the tax rate in the United States have declined. But the number of individuals reporting income of $1 million or more rose to 392,000 in 2007 from 240,000 when the decade began. And who knew that most Americans of Armenian ancestry live in the West?

title: Lottery Numbers
Under Pressure, Hungary Softens Tone on Its Media Law
description: BUDAPEST, Hungary  After a warning from the European Union that the controversy over Hungarys broad new media law could undermine the countrys six-month presidency of the bloc, Prime Minister Viktor Orban abandoned his fiery language against the laws European critics on Friday, emphasizing that he would make changes if the law proved incompatible with European legislation.

title: Chile Offers Recognition for a State of Palestine
description: SO PAULO  Chile formally recognized an independent state of Palestine on Friday, becoming the seventh South American country to take such a step in the past month.

title: Southern Sudan Votes
description: On Sunday, southern Sudan is expected to vote to secede from Sudan, creating two states. The referendum is part of a 2005 agreement, which ended two decades of fighting between the Arab Muslim north and the largely Christian south that killed two million people.

title: A New Jersey Reckoning
description: For almost 40 years, the New Jersey Supreme Court has tried to fulfill its duty to enforce the education clause in the state Constitution by compelling the governor and Legislature to provide equal educational opportunity for public school students. In 2009, the court decided the state had finally devised a way to do that, through a formula that would give each student, especially in poor districts, a chance at an unhindered start in life.

title: The Return of a Native Son
description: AMES, Iowa  In the desk of her office at City Hall, the mayor of this community, Ann Campbell, keeps a T-shirt in the cardinal and gold colors of Iowa State. A gag Christmas gift from her brother, it reads The Other Mayor on one side, and 32  Not Fred on the other.

title: The Rule of Law
description: To keep the Defense Department running, President Obama was forced to sign a spending bill on Friday with a particularly harmful provision that bars spending to transfer detainees at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, to the United States for trial. As wrongheaded as this prohibition is, the president was right not to declare his intention to defy it in an accompanying statement. By doing so, he demonstrated a greater respect for the law than did President George W. Bush.

title: Killing at Millard South
description: The new year is barely a week old, but the nation has already recorded its first deadly school shooting.

title: Cubs Deal for the Rays Garza
description: On Oct. 9, when Matt Garza threw his last pitch as a member of the Rays, Tampa Bay used 16 players in its playoff game against Texas. Eight of them are no longer with the organization. That is a lot of turnover for a 96-win team, but hardly unexpected for the Rays, who hold onto talent as long as their limited payroll allows.

title: Writers Create a Haven Away From Home
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y.

title: Religion and Representation
description: Years ago, my oldest son told me that he thought those in our small Baptist church had all been brainwashed. How else could they believe in the unbelievable? At the time, I was shocked.

title: Drawing a Crowd With Positive Pop
description: FARMINGDALE, N.Y.

title: God Save the Debate
description: Next week the House Republicans are going to vote to repeal the health care reform law. Its a symbolic gesture they got the right to make when they won the majority, but it would be nice if they could leave God out of it.

title: Misery With Plenty of Company
description: Consider the extremes. President Obama is redesigning his administration to make it even friendlier toward big business and the megabanks, which is to say the rich, who flourish no matter what is going on with the economy in this country. (They flourish even when theyre hard at work destroying the economy.) Meanwhile, we hear not a word  not so much as a peep  about the poor, whose ranks are spreading like a wildfire in a drought.

title: The First Drafts of American History
description: WHEN the new House of Representatives convened on Thursday, the Republican leadership kept its promise to start the session by reading the text of the Constitution aloud. This break from Congressional tradition had a polemical purpose: Representative Robert Goodlatte, the Virginia Republican who came up with the idea, remarked that lots of my constituents have said that Congress has gone beyond its powers granted in the Constitution.

title: Harness Driver Returns to Meadowlands Racetrack as Symbol of Its Struggles
description: ALLENTOWN, N.J.  Richard Silverman never dreamed of becoming the aerial embodiment of Meadowlands harness racing. He never imagined the six-horse chaos that dislodged him from his sulky and left him in the most precarious of positions, up in the air.

title: Ryne Duren, Yankees Reliever Who Made Batters Nervous, Dies at 81
description: Ryne Duren, the star relief pitcher for two Yankee World Series teams who stared down batters through thick-lensed eyeglasses and then delivered fastballs that might go just about anywhere, died Thursday at his home in Lake Wales, Fla. He was 81.

title: Gen. Vang Pao, Laotian Who Aided U.S., Dies at 81
description: Vang Pao, a charismatic Laotian general who commanded a secret army of his mountain people in a long, losing campaign against Communist insurgents, then achieved almost kinglike status as their leader-in-exile in the United States, died Thursday in Clovis, Calif. He was 81.

description: David Corn, left, of Mother Jones and James Pinkerton of Fox News discuss the revolving door between government and finance.

title: Paul Soldner, Who Created Towering Ceramic Sculptures, Is Dead at 89
description: Paul Soldner, a ceramist who put his own twist on the Japanese firing technique known as raku to create wildly spontaneous sculptural vessels, died on Monday at his home in Claremont, Calif. He was 89.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,434 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Friday:

title: In ESPN Interview, Eric LeGrand Shows Positive Spirit
description: A powerful story by ESPN on Eric LeGrand of Rutgers, who is recovering from a spinal cord injury and believes that hell walk again.

title: Israel: Soldier Killed by Friendly Fire
description: An Israeli soldier was killed in a clash on the Gaza border on Friday by a mortar shell fired by his own forces, an Israeli Army spokesman said, speaking anonymously according to military regulation. Four other soldiers were wounded by the mortar. The episode occurred after Israeli forces spotted a group of Palestinians trying to plant an explosive device at the border, the army said.

title: Stoudemire and Energized Knicks Run Away From Suns
description: PHOENIX  Over the past few days, Amare Stoudemire had expressed contentment with the Knicks surge, revealed his surprise about the Suns rigid stance in the contract negotiations that led to his departure and shared his remorse at having never reached the N.B.A. finals while playing here.

title: Can Harbaugh Bring Back Niners Glory Days?
description: The Cowboys and the 49ers played some of the most memorable playoff games of the last 20 years. This clip shows the opening of the 49ers biggest victory in their 1990s showdowns. But since that 1994 championship season, the 49ers have not been back to the Super Bowl. In recent years, they have barely been relevant.

title: Adding Islam to a Latino Identity
description: Eirini Vourloumis is a freelance photographer who has focused on Islamic communities in the United States. She is now in Greece, where she was born, to cover the economic crisis. Ms. Vourloumis is a graduate of Parsons and the Columbia Journalism School. Her work has been published on Lens and in The New York Times, New York Magazine, FT magazine and The Village Voice. Her conversation with James Estrin has been edited and condensed.

title: Sweat | Workout for a World of Grief
description: As a lifelong resident of Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, Gary Atlas would always enjoy seeing the robust old Russians marching up the beach, dripping and content after a frigid dip in the wintry ocean.

title: BizBuySell Projects More Business Sales This Year
description: BizBuySell.com  one of the most popular online sources of small-business for-sale listings  has released its Fourth Quarter 2010 Insight Report, showing a return to realism by sellers at the end of 2010, and some promising indicators for improvement in the overall marketplace in the coming year.

title: James Harrisons Hit ($75,000 Fine) vs. Gary Bracketts ($35,000 Fine)
description: Was the hit by Pittsburghs James Harrison on Clevelands Mohamed Massaquoi significantly more flagrant than Gary Bracketts blindside block on Tennessees Ken Amato? Ill leave that to Fifth Down readers to decide. (You can see the videos below.) Ray Anderson, the N.F.L.s executive vice president of football operations, thought so. Harrison had his fine reduced to $50,000 from $75,000 on appeal, but that figure is still substantially higher than Bracketts fine.

title: Brady Is Best in Final 2010 Passer Rating
description: Luis DeLoureiro operates NFLStatAnalysis.net and is a contributor to the Cold Hard Football Facts.

title: Russia Defied Expectations at Juniors Tournament
description: Russias remarkable gold medal at the world junior championships in Buffalo this week  three straight comeback victories, including five unanswered third-period goals to beat Canada, 5-3, before more than 18,000 fans at HSBC Arena in the tournament final Wednesday  again put the lie to all the stereotypes that are trotted out at international hockey events.

title: 7 Billion and Counting
description: National Geographic magazine has kicked off a yearlong series of articles related to humanitys remarkable growth spurt, with the first story focusing on the consequences of hitting 7 billion humans later this year and the basics of demography, from Malthus forward. The piece was written by Robert Kunzig, a senior editor there who was a colleague of mine at Discover Magazine in the late 1980s. I caught up with him via Skype a couple of days ago and heres our chat (I hope youll excuse the lag and fuzziness):

title: Bush, the Bubble and the Deficit
description: Wolf Blitzer was kind enough to read a portion of a recent Economix post on CNN this week. Here he is, interviewing Mitch Daniels, Indianas Republican governor:

description: Back in the mid-1960s, decades ago, the foraging forefather Euell Gibbons, Grape Nuts spokesman and author of Stalking the Healthful Herbs, asked millions of Americans if they had ever eaten a pine tree. While Ive never consumed a pine tree per se, I was interested in sampling some pine needles for a wholesome tea.

title: Iraqi Cleric Embraces State in Comeback Speech
description: NAJAF, Iraq  To a rapturous welcome that conflated the religious and political, the populist Iraqi cleric Moktada al-Sadr delivered his support on Saturday for an Iraqi state he had once derided as a traitorous tool of the United States and that his followers had battled in the streets of Iraqs most important cities only a few years before.

title: The Other Overtime Consideration in the Playoffs: Onside Kicks
description: Since the N.F.L. announced that it was changing its overtime format in the playoffs, much of the discussion has involved whether teams might decide to defer the opening possession, especially if they have a strong defense.

title: Renault Espionage Gained No Key Secrets, Official Says

title: Ellis Is the Warriors Warrior
description: In theory, the more minutes a teams most productive player can play per game, the better. The Golden State Warriors seem to be embracing that spirit wholeheartedly with their use of shooting guard Monta Ellis.

description: Alex Ovechkins drop-off in goal scoring this season has inspired criticism, but listen to Washington Coach Bruce Boudreau, speaking after the Capitals Winter Classic victory over the Penguins on Jan. 1.

title: U.S. Subpoenas Twitter Over WikiLeaks Supporters
description: WASHINGTON  Prosecutors investigating the disclosure of thousands of classified government documents by the anti-secrecy group WikiLeaks have gone to court to demand the Twitter account activity of several people linked to the organization, including its founder, Julian Assange, according to the group and a copy of a subpoena made public late Friday.

title: An Accidental Mechanic Hits Hard Times
description: Khalilah El-Amins apartment in Brooklyn is warm and inviting and smells like butter, the result of a batch of chocolate chip cookies she baked earlier. Her sons Emmanuel, 7, and Rakim, 8, play with toy trucks while Ms. El-Amin types on her laptop.

title: Second Sunday: Tell You No Lies
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Mike Nothnagel gave us a run for our money on Thursday (Across Lite, Solution, blog), and hes back today with a diagramless puzzle that I really liked. Ill tell you why.

title: Officials Optimistic About Sudan Vote
description: JUBA, Sudan  Sudanese and American officials said that Sudan appeared well prepared for a historic vote on Sunday on southern Sudans independence.

title: Man Held in Times Sq. Hotel Killing
description: A 20-year-old man was taken into custody a day after the bludgeoned body of a prominent Portuguese journalist was found in a blood-spattered room at the InterContinental Hotel in Times Square, law enforcement officials said.

title: $2.6 Billion to Cover Bad Loans: Its a Start
description: BANK investors cheered the announcement last week that Bank of America would pay $2.6 billion to buy back mortgages it had improperly sold during the housing bubble to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the beleaguered mortgage finance giants. It seemed a sweet deal for the bank, whose Countrywide Home Loans unit had peddled tens of billions of dollars in risky loans to the taxpayer-owned companies.

title: Im Making a Living From My Hobbies
description: IN 1986, I was a 26-year-old college dropout and world traveler who had decided that I didnt want a job, much less a career. What I really wanted was to get paid for my hobbies: writing, gardening and politics. So I made that my goal.

title: Susan Axelrod on Life After Washington
description: For someone who doesnt actually live in Washington, Susan Axelrod has a pretty inside track to the White House. She is, after all, married to David Axelrod, who has been one of the presidents closest advisers since before he even declared his run. The Caucus recently caught up with Ms. Axelrod, a founding member of CURE (Citizens United for Research in Epilepsy) at Commissary, a neighborhood coffee shop a few blocks away from the apartment her husband rents  at least through early February, when he moves back to their home in Chicago. She scanned the menu for cholesterol-healthy options and weighed in on everything from the ups and downs of life in the White House, what it will be like to have her husband back at home, how they met, what she misses about Chicago when shes not there, and her work.

title: A World of Beer
description: I GREW up in Wales, living in the Penywaun council housing estate, or working-class housing, where my parents moved after World War II. The biggest nearby city was Cardiff.

title: House Democrats Rapidly Unleash Sharp Attacks
description: WASHINGTON  After four years of harassment by an aggressive Republican minority, House Democrats evidently absorbed a lesson along with all those political blows: the route back to Congressional power is paved with frontal assaults on the practices and policies of the majority.

description: MA BELL spoiled us.

description: MARILYN COHEN, the founder of Envision Capital Management, manages $300 million in bond portfolios for individual investors. Since early November, she says, she has also taken on the job of running the municipal bond equivalent of the Butterball turkey hot line, fielding calls from investors worried how to handle the sharp fourth quarter sell-off in municipal bonds.

title: I Want My Money Back (on Everything)
description: PART of making money in this topsy-turvy world is to see the opportunities others dont. Back when a single computer filled a whole room, this meant recognizing the potential for a personal computer. And it meant knowing that someday millions of people would reach into the ether with desktop machines of unimaginable power to look at porn and give money to Nigerian princes.

title: Sensible Spending, No Matter Your Age
description: BECAUSE The 10 Commandments of Money: Survive and Thrive in the New Economy (Hudson Street Press, $25.95), by Liz Weston, is such a wonderful basic personal finance book, lets get the few quibbles out of the way.

description: JOHN TEMPLETON may be known as the father of global investing, but the Templeton Growth fund, which he started in 1954, is finding top holdings closer to home these days.

title: Save Your Financial Records, but Maybe Save a Tree
description: MOVING makes you face all the stuff youve accumulated: books, computers, clothing and, of course, reams and reams of financial documents. Before deciding whether to haul all of them to a new home, as I did a few months ago, it is worth asking what really needs to be saved and what can safely be ditched.

title: If Youve Got the Nerve, Silver Is Easier to Buy
description: FOR a metal deemed precious, silver has often been ignored by investors.

title: Three Funds Hit the Jackpot With a Variety of Bets
description: FEAR dominated many headlines in the fourth quarter, as unemployment in the United States, a debt crisis in Europe and inflation in China nagged at investors. But hope for an economic resurgence bubbled up, too, and a variety of market sectors had positive returns.

title: In Wrecking Your Portfolio, Timing Can Be Everything
An Eagle Grabs a Sliver in a Crowded Spotlight
description: PHILADELPHIA  When he is in the Eagles locker room, running back LeSean McCoy is hard to avoid and easy to hear. He bounces from stall to stall, breaking silences with one-liners and boastful statements about his hometown.

title: Laugh Lines
description: JAY LENO

title: Stuck in Traffic, Beijing Puts a Brake on Car Sales
description: Heres one way to tackle traffic congestion. Ban car sales. Thats what China has done temporarily in its capital, Beijing, where the number of cars on the roads has nearly doubled in five years, making driving a nightmare, according to The Christian Science Monitor. The government barred car sales in Beijing from Dec. 24 until later this month, when its new lottery system comes up with the names of the 20,000 lucky applicants who will have the right to buy license plates. About 100,000 people have already put their names in the drawing. New regulations have also increased parking fees in Beijing and banned cars with out-of-city plates from the roads during rush hour.

title: Prime Number
description: 32: The percentage increase in the United Nations world food price index from June to December. Poor grain harvests and weather-related problems have pushed prices close to the crisis levels that provoked shortages and riots in poor countries three years ago. The index measures commodity prices on the world export market, which are generally far removed from supermarket prices in wealthy countries. (Prices in the United States are expected to rise only 2 percent to 3 percent this year.) But the situation is different in poor countries that rely on exports. We are at a very high level, said Abdolreza Abbassian, an economist for the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization. These levels in the previous episode led to problems and riots across the world.

title: Fighting Words
description: One of psychologys most respected journals has agreed to publish a paper presenting what its author describes as strong evidence for extrasensory perception, the ability to sense future events.

title: A Makeover for the Starbucks Mermaid
description: Logomania has been in the air since the chief executive of Starbucks, Howard Schultz, announced another redesign of the Starbucks logo last week.

title: For Chiefs Quarterback, Wistfulness Tempers Joy
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The uplifting story of the Chiefs rebirth is bittersweet for their quarterback, Matt Cassel. In his sixth year as a pro, Cassel led Kansas City to 10 regular-season victories, as many as it had in the previous three seasons combined, and a date Sunday against the Baltimore Ravens in the first round of the N.F.L. playoffs.

title: Mass Animal Deaths: An Environmental Whodunit
description: When 5,000 red-winged blackbirds fell dead on New Years Eve in Arkansas, and 500 more in Louisiana, many people immediately looked for a villain. There was speculation about military tests and pesticides, and a lot of wondering whether the bird deaths and other incidents, including the mass deaths of fish, were linked.

title: Yzerman Shows Skill as Team Builder in Tampa Bay
description: Tampa Bays acquisition of the veteran goalie Dwayne Roloson from the Islanders was another building block in the process of constructing a winner from the ruins of last years 12th-place team. Steve Yzerman is the architect of the Lightnings turnaround.

title: Profits Are Booming. Why Arent Jobs?
description: To gaze upon the world of American corporations is to see a sunny place of terrific profits and princely bonuses. American businesses reported that third-quarter profits in 2010 rose at an annual rate of $1.659 trillion, the steepest annual surge since officials began tracking such matters 60 years ago. It was the seventh consecutive quarter in which corporate profits climbed.

title: Reality TVs New Wave: Trash Picking, With a Smile
description: Our stuff is suffocating us: at least thats what reality television has told us in recent years. Shows like Hoarders and Clean House serve as virtual purges for overconsumers.

title: A Continent Carved Up, Ignoring Who Lives Where
description: The map of todays African nations looks much like the map drawn by Europeans: diverse groups are scattered across many countries with little concern for ethnic links.

title: In Sudan, a Colonial Curse Comes Up for a Vote
description: More than any other continent, Africa is wracked by separatists. There are rebels on the Atlantic and on the Red Sea. There are clearly defined liberation movements and rudderless, murderous groups known principally for their cruelty or greed. But these rebels share at least one thing: they direct their fire against weak states struggling to hold together disparate populations within boundaries drawn by 19th-century white colonialists.

title: Fight in Los Angeles Over an N.F.L. Team That Doesnt Exist Yet
description: CITY OF INDUSTRY, Calif.  Los Angeles has not had an N.F.L. team since the Raiders and the Rams left town 16 years ago. But now it may have the next best thing: a bruising fight over how to reclaim the game.

title: Bodies Found Beheaded in Assaults in Acapulco
description: MEXICO CITY  The once thriving resort area of Acapulco suffered another blow on Saturday with the discovery of 28 bodies, 15 of them headless, from a round of assaults overnight that bore the earmarks of organized crime.

title: Live Blog: Representative Giffords Shot
description: Gabrielle Giffords, a congresswoman from Arizona, was shot in the head on Saturday at a public event held at a grocery store in Tucson, her spokesman, C. J. Karamargin, said. A federal judge, John Roll, who had been involved in immigration cases and had received death threats, was among those killed.

title: Returning Home in Sudan for a Historic Vote
description: Tens of thousands have flocked back to southern Sudan to take part in a referendum on independence, and some analysts warn that the south could be the next Somalia, awash in violence.

description: JUBA, Sudan  Philip Geng Nyuol started fighting for independence with his hands.

description: WASHINGTON  The assassination last week of one of the most moderate politicians in the Pakistani political elite was shocking enough, even in a country known for settling religious and political disputes with a hail of gunfire.

description: When a parent or youth-sports official decides which helmet will protect the head of a young football player, hard information ducks for cover.
