description: The 82nd Texas Legislature convenes in Austin this week, and while its not as much fun as the circus  usually  its more important and does have its share of comedy and drama.

title: Wheels Down in Qatar
description: DOHA, Qatar  Soccer is the biggest sport in Asia and the Asian Football Confederation represents more than half the worlds population. The Asian Cup is the confederations biggest event, held once every four years. It began Friday; in four years, it will be held in Australia.

description: The first week on the job for James Lankford of Oklahoma, one of 87 new Republican members of the House of Representatives.

title: Awed and Eager, Freshmen Tackle Plan to Put Conservative Stamp on House
description: WASHINGTON  Youre new to town, and your dreams and plans are big as the Capitol rotunda. You will do all you can to repeal the new health care law. You will tame the budget deficit. You will make your mark, or at least a very large speck, on American life.

title: The Doc Fix
description: Gotta get my mind off Arizona.

title: Study Finds Family Connections Give Big Advantage in College Admissions
description: A new study of admissions at 30 highly selective colleges found that legacy applicants get a big advantage over those with no family connections to the institution  but the benefit is far greater for those with a parent who earned an undergraduate degree at the college than for those with other family connections.

title: Affordable-Housing Moratorium Questioned
description: AN authority on Connecticuts affordable-housing law says the state Department of Economic and Community Development granted the town of Darien an affordable-housing moratorium based on plainly inaccurate information.

title: A Lot of Jazz. Many More People.
description: I was at Winter Jazzfest Friday night. Im returning tonight. Got to prepare myself for that. I had some good stretches, but spent a lot of time spent obstructed.

title: 2 Groups Seek to Aid Injured Players
description: In November 2002, Chris Canales attended a high school football game for the first time since being paralyzed in one a year earlier. As Canales sat in a wheelchair next to his father, Eddie, he watched Corey Fulbright of Everman High School in Texas lie motionless on the turf, paralyzed after injuring his spinal cord.

title: Health Reform and Social Security
description: Aha: Ive figured out what the Social Security stuff in the GOP attack on health reform is about: the excise tax on high-value plans is expected to shift some worker compensation away from health insurance toward regular pay  which is taxable, both income and payroll. And the GOP wants to assert that increased payroll tax revenue doesnt count because, well, something about how Social Security isnt part of the budget, and the CBO is double-counting.

title: Climb Back to the Top Will Be Harder for Woods
description: The official start of the 2011 PGA Tour season, outlined against the spectacular beauty of the Pacific crashing ashore on Maui, will come and go without Tiger Woods this weekend. This is, of course, not unusual. Woods has not played in the event now known as the Tournament of Champions since 2005.

title: Sunday: Long Story Short
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Sometimes I luck out. Here it is, the end of my first week at Wordplay, and I get to commemorate it with a Patrick Berry Sunday puzzle. And a very good one it is.

title: About That $100 Billion
description: It has been four months since John Boehner, now speaker of the House, first proposed to cut $100 billion from this years budget, an idea that was later elevated to a pledge to America in the 2010 campaign. Last week, Mr. Boehner finally specified his first actual cut: $35 million from House lawmakers office budgets.

title: Digging Deeper at the Pentagon
description: Handing the Pentagon blank checks backed with borrowed money never impressed us as wise. So we applaud Defense Secretary Robert Gates for making clear last week that those profligate days are over. The $78 billion, five-year reduction in projected spending plans he proposed is the biggest dose of austerity to hit the Pentagon since the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.

title: New Tensions in a World Heritage Site
description: Residents of Djenn, Mali, which is a Unesco World Heritage site, complain that the guidelines to maintain that designation are too restrictive.

title: Mali City Rankled by Rules for Life in Spotlight
description: DJENN , Mali  Abba Maiga stood in his dirt courtyard, smoking and seething over the fact that his 150-year-old mud-brick house is so culturally precious he is not allowed to update it  no tile floors, no screen doors, no shower.

description: Live analysis and game tracking of the wild-card playoff game between the New Orleans Saints and the Seattle Seahawks. The Saints (11-5) enter the game as the defending Super Bowl champions. The Seahawks (7-9) enter it over the vehement protests of fans in almost every N.F.L. market except their own.

title: Jiri Dienstbier, Czech Dissident, Is Dead at 73

title: The King James Bible at 400
description: Sometime in 1611, a new English Bible was published. It was the work of an almost impossibly learned team of men laboring since 1604 under royal mandate. Their purpose, they wrote, was not to make a new translation of the Bible but to make a good one better, or out of many good ones, one principal good one. What was published, 400 years ago, was indeed one principal good one: the King James Version of the Bible.

title: Hanging On as the Boundaries Shift
description: FOUR months as public editor has given me a working list, perhaps only that, of the challenges The Times faces and the faults readers find in this most important of American newspapers. As a representative of the reader, Id like to post that list today and invite you to consider it, then add to it as you will.

title: After Decade of War, Top Officer Directs the Military to Take Stock of Itself
description: WASHINGTON  Adm. Mike Mullen, who will almost certainly be the final chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff to have served in the Vietnam War, still carries the scars of how that polarizing era damaged the military and its relationship with the American people.

description: To the Editor:

title: Is Law School a Losing Game?
description: IF there is ever a class in how to remain calm while trapped beneath $250,000 in loans, Michael Wallerstein ought to teach it.

title: Facing Scrutiny, Banks Slow Pace of Foreclosures
description: PHOENIX  An array of federal and state investigations into the way banks foreclose on delinquent homeowners has contributed to a sharp slowdown in foreclosures across the country, especially in hard-hit cities like this one.

title: Final: Jets 17, Colts 16
description: Live analysis and game coverage of the N.F.L. wild-card playoff game between the Jets and the Colts. The game is a rematch of last years A.F.C. championship game, won by the Colts.

title: Mickey vs. Harry
description: ARRIVED ON THE SCENE

title: Psychic Rewards
description: SANTA FE, N.M.

title: The Last Resort
description: Donnelly, Idaho

title: Crafting a Recovery
description: Providence, R.I.

title: Naked Capitalism
description: Dallas

title: Your Comments on China and Chess
description: My Sunday column looks at the rise of China, through the prism of the new womens world chess champion, Hou Yifan. Shes a 16-year-old schoolgirl, and an astonishing phenomenon. Until now, there has only been one woman to crack the top 100 in chess rankings, and thats Judit Polgar, by far the most impressive player in the history of womens chess. Polgar, from an amazing chess-playing Hungarian family, peaked at no. 8 in the world and most recently was ranked 49. But Polgar is 34 and is unlikely to surge to the top of the rankings, while Hou Yifan is young enough that she could end up in the top few players worldwide over the next 10 or 15 years. (While Hou Yifan is the womens chess champion, she still has a lower ranking than Polgar, who does not compete in womens tournaments. Heres the piece by my Times colleague and chess columnist Dylan McClain about Hous triumph.)

title: Smartphones Lure Sticky Fingers in Paris
description: PARIS  Aggravated robberies are up more than 40 percent in the Paris public transport system, and the government places blame for the rise on the attractiveness of smartphones.

title: U.S. Will Counter Chinese Arms Buildup
description: BEIJING  The Pentagon is stepping up investments in a range of weapons, jet fighters and technology in response to the Chinese military buildup in the Pacific, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Saturday on the eve of his visit to Beijing.

title: Loose Lips (Almost) Sink Ships
description: Charleston Harbor, Jan. 9, 1861

title: Looking for Silver Linings
description: The United States economy added 103,000 jobs in December, the Labor Department said Friday  proving that the recovery still cant make up for all the jobs lost during the recession. The Op-Ed editors asked four writers to find out what the economy looks like around the country. Here are their third dispatches.

title: Duke Nears Deal to Buy Progress Energy
description: 8:30 p.m. | Updated

title: A Passionate Politician and a Friend to Colleagues, Bikers and Lost Mayors
description: WASHINGTON  Unusual is a relative term in American political life, but Representative Gabrielle Giffords fits the bill: avid equestrian and motorcycle enthusiast, repository of arcane health care data, successful Democrat elected three times in a Republican Congressional district, French horn player and wife of an astronaut.

title: Carrolls Charm Takes Seahawks Along for the Ride
description: Seattle

title: After Upset, Seahawks Hunger for More
description: SEATTLE  The Seattle Seahawks spent most of the week being derided as the worst team ever to enter the N.F.L. playoffs. History will remember these postseason interlopers for perpetrating one of the games biggest upsets.

title: Bloodshed Puts New Focus on Vitriol in Politics
description: WASHINGTON  The shooting of Representative Gabrielle Giffords and others at a neighborhood meeting in Arizona on Saturday set off what is likely to be a wrenching debate over anger and violence in American politics.

title: Local Intelligence | Sand Dollars
description: Sand dollars are easily collected at Ocean Beach  a far safer hobby than swimming in the treacherous waves. The sand dollar is actually the endoskeleton of a populous sea animal, with 250 species worldwide. The local variety, Dendraster excentricus, is perhaps the strangest.

title: Taking All Questions, the Lakers Jackson Holds Nothing Back
description: EL SEGUNDO, Calif.  The question had been asked. Lakers Coach Phil Jackson saw the bait a mile away, laughed and, for one of the few times this season, punted on the opportunity to needle a rival, provoke an adversary or willingly dip himself into controversy.

title: Some Good Signs Appear in Commercial Real Estate
description: Jonathan Weber writes a column for The Bay Citizen

title: Marijuana Dispensaries Are Facing New Scrutiny
description: Medical marijuana dispensaries try hard to maintain the appearance that they are nonprofit health centers. Customers are referred to as patients, and merchandise as medicine. Yoga classes are often available, along with health-related literature.

title: Gains for Fabian Nez, Personal and in Business, Spark Talk and Questions
description: Former Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger has been a good friend to Fabian Nez. Mr. Nez, a Democrat who served as speaker of the State Assembly from 2004 to 2008, was one of Mr. Schwarzeneggers few reliable political allies.

title: Amid Shock, Recalling Judges Life of Service
description: John M. Roll, the chief federal judge in Arizona, was fatally wounded in the attack near Tucson on Saturday that killed five others and wounded at least 18 people, including Representative Gabrielle Giffords.

title: Arizona Suspects Recent Acts Offer Hints of Alienation
description: WASHINGTON  Jared Lee Loughner had become increasingly erratic in recent months, so much so that others around him began to worry.

title: Fed Vice Chairwoman Defends Debt-Buying
description: DENVER  The Federal Reserves new effort to support the recovery by purchasing $600 billion of Treasury securities will create roughly 700,000 jobs in the private sector, according to a new study by researchers at the central bank.

title: Joan Vass, Designer of Elegant Knitwear Line, Dies at 85
description: Joan Vass, a popular knitwear designer in the 1980s and 90s whose elegantly understated sweaters stood in contrast to her reputation as a bohemian and a provocateur, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 85.

title: Cyril Harris Dies at 93; Fine-Tuned Concert Halls
description: Cyril M. Harris, an acoustical engineer responsible for the sound in many of the most prominent concert halls, theaters and auditoriums in the United States, including the Metropolitan Opera and Avery Fisher Hall in New York, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.

title: Blackhawks Lack Consistency of a Champion
description: Dan McGrath writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative

title: Malangatana Ngwenya, Mozambican Painter and Poet, Dies at 74
description: Malangatana Ngwenya, one of Africas best-known contemporary artists, whose phantasmagoric paintings were inspired by political conditions in his home country, Mozambique, died on Wednesday in Matosinhos, Portugal. He was 74.

title: A Turning Point in the Discourse, but in Which Direction?
description: WASHINGTON  Within minutes of the first reports Saturday that Representative Gabrielle Giffords, an Arizona Democrat, and a score of people with her had been shot in Tucson, pages began disappearing from the Web. One was Sarah Palins infamous cross hairs map from last year, which showed a series of contested Congressional districts, including Ms. Giffordss, with gun targets trained on them. Another was from Daily Kos, the liberal blog, where one of the congresswomans apparently liberal constituents declared her dead to me after Ms. Giffords voted against Nancy Pelosi in House leadership elections last week.

title: Emanuel Says He Favors Reduced Pensions for Current Workers and New Hires
description: In contrast to his main rivals in the mayors race, Rahm Emanuel has told labor leaders that he favors reducing pension benefits for the citys existing work force and not just for new hires.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: When You Need Revenue, Where Cant an Ad Go?
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative

title: Community Policing Is Caught in a Cross-Fire
description: Community policing, a philosophy that emphasizes citizen involvement and preventive action, faces an uncertain future as financing declines and officials debate whether it is an effective strategy that needs to be revitalized or an expensive public relations gimmick that should be phased out.

title: Deadly Shooting in Arizona
description: Representative Gabrielle Giffords, an Arizona Democrat, and 19 others were shot Saturday when a gunman opened fire at a public event outside a supermarket.

title: The Texas Shuffle
description: A roundup of notable new songs from the states great artists.

title: A Wizard Rivals Mickey
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Pottermania is supposed to be winding down. The final 784-page tome in the series has been published. Shooting for the last movie has wrapped up. And J. K. Rowling herself recently sent a text to Daniel Radcliffe, the actor who plays her boy wizard, with a message that was unmistakable: Its over.

title: Tax Cuts From 70s Confront Brown Again in California
description: LOS ANGELES  The last time Jerry Brown was governor of California, voters passed Proposition 13, drastically slashing local property taxes and constraining lawmakers from raising any other taxes. Mr. Brown first fought the proposition but then executed it with gusto and sent billions of dollars from the state to school districts and counties to help offset the lost revenues.

title: Rose Helps Bulls Drive Past the Celtics
description: Derrick Rose scored 36 points, Carlos Boozer added 22 points and 10 rebounds, and the host Chicago Bulls cooled off the Boston Celtics with a 90-79 victory on Saturday night.

title: Vows: Emily and Igor
description: Igor noticed Emily at Columbia University and built up the courage to ask her out. His pursuit was not curtailed by her six-month trip to Tanzania; he called her every day, and she was charmed.

title: Lottery Numbers
Sundays Top Matches in Europe
description: Real Madrid vs. Villarreal

title: Drumming Against Hate at Giffordss Office
description: TUCSON  By 2 p.m. about 40 people had gathered in front of Representative Gabrielle Giffords district office at the intersection of North Swan and East Pima Streets, many holding hand-printed signs, others with hands raised toward the traffic, fingers making peace signs..

title: Hou Yifan: The Face of China
description: Nicholas Kristofs column on Sunday is about how the success of Hou Yifan, the 16-year-old womens world champion, is emblematic of how China is beginning to have an outsize impact on everything in the world  from consumption of the worlds resources to research and development to sports to chess.

title: Space Program Runs in Congresswomans Family
description: Representative Gabrielle Giffords has been one of the biggest champions in Congress of what amounts to nearly a family enterprise for her  space exploration.

title: Jets Narrowly Escape Manning and the Colts
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The Jets spent this season winning late games and close games and overtime games, each victory more stunning, more dramatic than the rest. Apparently, they were training for Saturday night at Lucas Oil Stadium, in another game few expected them to win, in another game it appeared that they had lost.

title: N.F.C. Wild-Card Replay, Jan. 8
description: A look at the Seattle Seahawks surprising 41-36 victory over the defending champion New Orleans Saints in the opening round of the N.F.L. playoffs.

title: Q&A With Earl Monroe
description: In 1971, Earl Monroe was traded to the Knicks from the Baltimore Bullets, now the Washington Wizards. A flashy ball handler known as the Pearl, he joined Walt Frazier to form one of the most talented backcourts in N.B.A. history. They helped lead the Knicks to the championship in 1973. Monroe, whose No. 15 jersey was retired by the team in 1986, was inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame in 1990. He was also named to the N.B.A.s 50th-anniversary team in 1996. Monroe, Junior Bridgeman and George Gervin were honored recently for their service to the National Basketball Retired Players Association and the N.Y.U. Langone Medical Center at a benefit for the hospitals Center for the Study and Treatment of Pain.

title: Injuries and the Jets Have Caught Up to the Colts
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Last week, Colts defensive end Robert Mathis was asked if he had learned anything new about his teammates this season as they scraped and clawed through a book-length injury report to make the playoffs.

title: A.F.C. Wild-Card Replay, Jan. 8
description: A look at the Jets 17-16 victory over the Colts in Indianapolis on Saturday.

title: Southern Sudanese, in a Jubilant Mood, Begin to Vote on Secession
description: JUBA, Sudan  Its not every day that a beleaguered, marginalized and persecuted people get a chance to vote for their own freedom. On Sunday, southern Sudanese did.

title: A Look at Southern Sudan
description: POTENTIAL NAMES

title: A Dallas University Finishes on Top in a Showdown
description: A couple of years ago, college chess could be divided into two tiers. The elite included the University of Maryland, Baltimore County, and the University of Texas, Dallas. The second tier was made up of everyone else.

title: Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam Steps Up Photography Collection
description: While theres a lot to be said for large, comprehensive art exhibitions, theres just as much to be gained from those that are more selective. To wit, the show of 19 great photographs on view in the Philips Wing of the Rijksmuseum, running through Feb. 14.

title: China Suspends Official After Lead Fumes Sicken Children
description: BEIJING  The authorities suspended a local environmental protection official in eastern China after lead fumes from an illegal battery factory sickened 228 children, the state-run news agency Xinhua reported Sunday. Twenty-three of the children were reported hospitalized.

title: Vietnam Confronts Economic Quagmire
description: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam  Hammer and sickle flags are flying here as Ho Chi Minh City, the seemingly irrepressible bastion of Vietnamese capitalism, dutifully marks the start on Tuesday of the Communist Partys National Congress, an event held every five years to chart the course of a country that has witnessed an economic miracle in recent decades.

title: Small Businesss New Man in the White House
description: In her analysis of Gene Sperlings promotion from Treasury Department adviser to head of the National Economic Council, The Timess Jackie Calmes sees a shift in President Obamas emphasis from crisis management to recovery. But Mr. Obama has also chosen for his top economic adviser someone with deep experience in formulating small-business policy.

title: For Cassels, Athletics Are Part of the Family
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  If the Chiefs beat Baltimore on Sunday for their first home playoff victory since the 1993 season,quarterback Matt Cassel will probably have a fountain here named after him. It wont change the fact that hes not, in the strictest sense, the most accomplished athlete in his household.

title: A Snake Invasion? Debating the Risks
description: In Sundays paper, I write about the controversy over the federal governments move to ban imports of nine species of snake and their transport across state lines. Its decision was based largely on a risk assessment by two government scientists of the impact those snakes could have on native ecosystems.

title: Rex Ryan Wins Battle With Manning by Backing Off Blitz
description: It was a key tactical decision, and a personal one.

title: Evidence Points to Methodical Planning
description: TUCSON  Prosecutors charged Jared L. Loughner, a troubled 22-year-old college dropout, with five federal counts on Sunday, including the attempted assassination of a member of Congress, in connection with a shooting rampage on Saturday morning that left six people dead and 14 wounded.

title: Home Fans Give Seahawks (and Reseeding?) a Lift
description: Seattle emergency rooms are swamped with Seahawk fans suffering from severe shock and multiple cuts and bruises caused by repeatedly pinching themselves.  From an e-mail from my father-in-law, who lives on the Olympic Peninsula.

title: Live Blog: Latest Developments on Arizona Shooting
description: Representative Gabrielle Giffords remains in critical condition after being shot in the head at a meet-and-greet in her Tucson-area neighborhood Saturday. Police now say that 20 people in total were shot and that six people were killed in that shooting, including John M. Roll, Arizonas chief federal judge.

title: A Closer Look at the Mostly Unsung Father of Greater New York
description: Andrew H. Green was 15 years old, traveling alone from his familys home in Worcester, Mass., when he got his first taste of the city that he would come to so profoundly define.

title: Born on Sept. 11, Claimed by a New Horror
description: Christina Green was on the student council of her elementary school, so on Saturday her mothers friend thought she might enjoy seeing government in action: the local congresswoman meeting with constituents outside a supermarket near Christinas home.

title: Awkward and Amusing Dolphins Drama
description: You can watch the video of a cringe-worthy news conference at The Miami Heralds Web site, or you can just let Steven Wine of The Associated Press paint the word picture:

title: The Great Mosque of Djenn
description: The Great Mosque of Djenn, Mali, is a magnet for tourists, but it is increasingly difficult for locals to live a normal life around it.

title: Final: Ravens 30, Chiefs 7
description: Live analysis and coverage of the A.F.C. wild-card playoff game between the Baltimore Ravens and the Kansas City Chiefs (10-6). It will be hard to top Saturdays two playoff games for full-on shock and nail-biting drama, but well see.The Ravens (12-4) are favored, not as heavily as the Saints were in Seattle, but their playoff experience and chest-thumping aura make it so. The Chiefs host as champions of the A.F.C. West, the second-worst Western division in football this season, but people have been trying to write them off all year and they merely went out and went 7-1 at home, where the 12th Man rivals Seattles. Maybe, in a weekend of surprises, they still have something to show us.

title: Afghans Strained by Shortages as Iran Tightens Flow of Fuel
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The price of fuel has risen sharply in parts of Afghanistan as an Iranian-imposed slowdown on tanker traffic at key border crossings has stretched into its second month, Afghan officials say.

title: Like His Style or Not, Ryan Is a Keeper
description: It is time to shelve the morality play regarding Rex Ryan. His outsize personality does not exactly seem to be dragging the Jets down, does it?

title: Israeli Demolition Begins in East Jerusalem Project
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli bulldozers demolished part of a landmark building in a predominantly Arab neighborhood of East Jerusalem on Sunday to make way for a Jewish housing project, prompting condemnation from Palestinian officials and symbolic claims to the site from both sides.

title: Young Activists Seek Roles on Energy, Climate
description: A comment contributor in this weekends open discussion over at Climate Progress is seeking help. He describes himself, essentially, as an aspiring, yet despairing, young energy and climate activist who still hopes to make a difference despite his conviction that civilization is imploding.

title: Final: Packers 21, Eagles 16
description: Live analysis and coverage of the N.F.C. wild-card game between the Green Bay Packers and the Philadelphia Eagles. This game is a rematch of a Week 1 meeting won by Green Bay, a game that marked both the beginning and the end of the Kevin Kolb era in Philadelphia. To say things have changed since then for the Eagles and for Kolbs replacement, Michael Vick, would be a massive understatement.

title: Reed Pushes Grief Aside and Provides Stability for Ravens
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The Chiefs were ahead of the visiting Baltimore Ravens in the second quarter of their A.F.C. wild-card game Sunday, and the Arrowhead Stadium crowd was in a frenzy.

title: Peacockery
description: Greg Ip is too kind in this article, in which he questions why Paul Ryan should have received an award for fiscal responsibility. Ip makes it out as if Ryan is a former good guy who has fallen astray; but there was never any reason to take his claims of being a deficit hawk seriously.

title: After Attack, Focus in Washington on Civility and Security
description: WASHINGTON  With the nations capital reeling from Saturdays attack on Representative Gabrielle Giffords of Arizona, in which an aide to the lawmaker and five constituents were killed both parties on Sunday began a wrenching process of soul-searching about the tone of political discourse and wondered aloud if a lack of civility had somehow contributed to the bloodshed in Tucson.

title: Blog and Column Meta
description: Blog meta: Im going to add a new rule: no Nazi references unless theres a seriously good reason. If youre writing about the economic policies of Hjalmar Horace Greeley Schacht, obviously its OK; but Im going to try to hold down the Godwins Law violations.

title: Curtain Down, Heads Up: Readers Respond to Small Fire, Dracula and Streisand
description: A Small Fire sizzles. Dracula has no bite. Barbra Streisand as Mama Rose? Dont get you started.

title: Life Studies
description: In the corner of our dining room, theres an old half-round cabinet on wheels. It has a handsomely decorated front-panel that swings around on a lazy susan to reveal a collection of whiskey glasses and decanters on the other side. Its whats sometimes called a hide-a-bar, though we use it now mainly as a place to charge our cellphones. We keep it prominently displayed because we like it. But it also oddly embodies the split life of my mother-in-law, from whom we inherited it. And it has lately shaped the course of my own life both as a writer and a son-in-law.

title: Lakers Contain Stoudemire and Handle Frustrated Knicks
description: LOS ANGELES  Amare Stoudemire switched time zones, teams and residencies in revitalizing the Knicks and entertaining hopes of eventually bypassing the Lakers, a firm obstacle throughout his career.

title: At Giffordss Synagogue, Prayers for Recovery
description: TUCSON  They spilled into the aisles and the corridor, past the extra rows of folding chairs and the congregants packed into the synagogues corners.

title: Twin Alone, Disconnected but Not Lost
description: The formative event in the composer Allen Shawns life happened when he was 8 years old: His twin sister, Mary, who was mentally disabled, was sent away, abruptly disappearing from his daily life. Allen not only missed her terribly, but he also became terrified of the mental illness that Mary had exhibited, and which had led, or so it had seemed to me as a child, to her being ostracized from the family.

title: Dark Tales Illuminate Haiti, Before and After Quake
description: The setup is familiar for a crime story: a kidnapping, a ransom demand, a briefcase full of money meant to be delivered on a dead-end street. But the details, specific to a section of Port-au-Prince, are what make the story called Rosanna fit snugly into the new anthology Haiti Noir.

title: New-Music Champion Pays a Call
description: Stephen Gosling, a British pianist who came to New York as a student in 1989, has become one of the citys most eloquent champions of new music, both as a soloist and as a member of Ensemble Sospeso and the New York New Music Ensemble. For the most part Mr. Gosling has not been bound to a particular contemporary style, but the carefully balanced, powerfully played recital he offered at Bargemusic on Thursday evening was a concise, cohesive overview of a post-Serialist, post-Minimalist approach to writing for the keyboard.

title: A Man of Confliction Takes on Mideast Conflict
description: Its a mouthful, but the title of Tarek Halabys lecture-performance, which rambles along like a garrulous dissertation topic, was the first wink of the night: An attempt to understand my socio-political disposition through artistic research on personal identity in relationship to the Palestinian-Israeli conflict, Part One.

title: Real Guitar Hero, Through the Years
description: Although Bucky Pizzarelli, the guest of honor at the 92Y Lyrics & Lyricists season-opening program on Saturday, didnt amble onto the stage until the second half of the evening, his voice was heard in recorded sound bites jovially reminiscing about his life and times as a session guitarist.

title: Monday: You Are Getting Sleepy
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  O.K., now I get it. Now I understand how James Tuttle was able to make his debut today. Your former host, Jim Horne, recently wrote a shocking expos of the crossword selection process (which was actually a totally false and hilarious send-up, Your Honor), but this is far more blatant. Thank goodness its such a cool puzzle.

title: Shooting Casts a Harsh Spotlight on Arizonas Unique Politics
description: Arizona is not a world apart, but its political culture has often resided at a distance from much of the nation.

title: A String Ensemble at Play: Body Language and Sheer Exuberance
description: That the East Coast Chamber Orchestra, a conductorless string ensemble formed in 2001 and also known as ECCO, has not yet become a household name among classical music lovers is surely because it appears so infrequently. We all have other, real jobs, the violinist Nick Kendall said from the stage as he introduced the group at its Peoples Symphony Concerts debut, at Washington Irving High School on Saturday night. This is kind of like our playground.

title: Picking Up Where an Artistic Stranger Left Off
description: Since an intervention is a deliberate effort to alter the course of a situation, its clear that the choreographer Wally Cardona is eager for some artistic interference. His Intervention series proposes five-day collaborations with experts in any field other than dance. According to program notes, They enter the studio as strangers, and through their intimate encounter they generate a new work.

title: Changing Sexes, Species and More
description: Pants on Fires Metamorphoses sounds as if its the kind of show that requires you to do a little homework before turning up at the theater. But it isnt. The user-friendliness is terrific, though it also ends up being something of a limitation.

title: Bloodshed and Invective in Arizona
description: She read the First Amendment on the House floor  including the guarantee of the right of the people peaceably to assemble  and then flew home to Arizona to put those words into practice. But when Gabrielle Giffords tried to meet with her constituents in a Tucson parking lot on Saturday, she came face to face with an environment wholly at odds with that constitutional ideal, and she nearly paid for it with her life.

title: A Master of the Squeeze Play Is Remembered
description: Michael Shuman, one of the games true gentleman, died of lung cancer at 79 in his hometown, Los Angeles, on Dec. 16.

title: The Victims of the Shooting
description: Retirees, a federal judge and a 9-year-old girl born on 9/11 were among those killed when a gunman opened fire outside a supermarket in Tucson on Saturday, Jan. 8.

title: Answering Your Sudan Questions, Take 1
description: Thanks for all the terrific questions about Sudan, for former President Jimmy Carter and myself. President Carter is in South Sudan at the moment, observing the referendum there, and Im very grateful that hes taking the time to answer reader questions. This is our first batch of responses  stay tuned for more in the days to come. And theres still time to pose your own questions. Now let me kick this off by asking the first question of President Carter:

title: Library of Congress Gets a Mile of Music
description: The Library of Congress has begun taking possession of a huge donation of recordings, some 200,000 metal, glass and lacquer master discs from the period 1926 to 1948 that have been languishing in the subterranean vaults of Universal Music Group, the largest music conglomerate in the United States.

title: Idiot Welcomes Back a Bad Influence
description: Rock star impersonators are not exactly rare creatures on Broadway today. An imitation Elvis and Jerry Lee and friends are stirring up trouble in Million Dollar Quartet at the Nederlander Theater. Flesh facsimiles of Paul, John, George and Ringo are running through the Beatles greatest hits nightly in Rain at the Neil Simon.

title: Welcome to a New Kind of Tension: Billie Joe Armstrong on His American Idiot Role
description: Billie Joe Armstrong plays many roles in American Idiot, and thats before he even takes the stage at the St. James Theater. Mr. Armstrong, the 38-year-old Green Day front man and guitarist and a co-writer of that Broadway musical adapted from his bands hit album of the same title, rejoined the show on Jan. 1 to resume the role of St. Jimmy, the pugnacious, drug-pushing alter ego of the protagonist, Johnny (portrayed by John Gallagher Jr.). (Charles Isherwoods review of Mr. Armstrong in American Idiot appears in Mondays New York Times.)

title: An Indian Murder Reverberates on Film
description: In 1999 Jessica Lal, a model tending bar at an elite nightspot in New Delhi, was shot dead by a customer who was refused a drink. A trial in 2006 acquitted the man, the son of a wealthy former government minister, but he was later found guilty by the Delhi High Court and sentenced to life imprisonment.

title: Polina Semionova to Dance at the Met
description: Polina Semionova, above, will join American Ballet Theater as a guest artist in two performances during its 2011 season at the Metropolitan Opera House, the company has announced. Ms. Semionova, a principal dancer with the Berlin State Opera Ballet since 2002, will dance the role of Kitri in Don Quixote, opposite David Hallberg, a principal with American Ballet Theater, as Basilio, on May 21. On July 2 Ms. Semionova will dance the dual roles of Odette and Odile in Swan Lake, again opposite Mr. Hallberg as Prince Siegfried. Ms. Semionova has performed both roles for the Berlin State Opera Ballet.

title: Poetry Goes Digital
description: The National Book Foundation, which presents the National Book Awards, has organized a retrospective of its past poetry winners, with daily blog posts by emerging poets about the winners and a series of public programs in New York; Minneapolis; and Portland, Ore., the foundation announced. The blog posts, which will also include a biography of each poet, will begin on Feb. 14 with an original essay about William Carlos Williams, the first winner of the National Book Award for Poetry in 1950. On Feb. 24 Elizabeth Alexander, who was selected to read at President Obamas Inauguration in 2009; Stephen Burt; Tony Hoagland; James Longenbach; Maureen N. McLane; and Susan Stewart will begin the series of programs with the panel discussion Lineage: American Poetry Since 1950, moderated by Craig Morgan Teicher at the New School in Manhattan. They will also read from their own work on Feb. 25 at the Center for Book Arts in Chelsea. The retrospective is financed by the National Endowment for the Arts and will culminate in a digitized literary archive on the foundations Web site, nationalbook.org, that will include curatorial appreciations of the past winners books, images of the original covers, portrait photographs, and related information and links.

title: Merchant of Venice Recoups Investment
description: The Broadway production of The Merchant of Venice has earned back its original capitalization costs of $3.45 million, the producers announced, becoming one of the few Broadway shows during each theater season to turn a profit. Starring Al Pacino as Shylock and Lily Rabe as Portia, this Merchant was first mounted by the nonprofit Public Theater last summer at its stage in Central Park, where tickets were free. Directed by Daniel Sullivan, the play proved hugely popular with critics and audiences, and the Public  along with the producers Jeffrey Richards, Jerry Frankel and others  transferred the production to the Broadhurst Theater for a commercial Broadway run in mid-October. Merchant begins a three-week hiatus this week to accommodate a film commitment of Mr. Pacinos; the play is set to resume on Feb. 1, with the cast largely intact, and run through Feb. 20. Merchant was regularly the top-grossing play on Broadway this fall and winter; one other new production of a play that began on Broadway this fall, Driving Miss Daisy, starring Vanessa Redgrave and James Earl Jones, has recouped its capitalization costs of $2.6 million.

title: Show on Hitler Extended
description: Hitler and the Germans: Nation and Crime, an exhibition that focuses on Adolf Hitler at the German Historical Museum in Berlin, has been extended by three weeks because of high attendance, Agence France-Presse reported. The show features displays of Nazi propaganda, like swastika Christmas decorations and Nazi figurines, alongside a show that highlights the realities of what the Nazis represented, like war and genocide. The exhibition has been billed as the first in Germany to focus exclusively on Hitler since the end of World War II. Rudolf Trabold, a museum spokesman, said that over 170,000 visitors had attended since the show opened in October. It was to close on Feb. 6 but will now remain on view through Feb. 27.

title: Canadian Publisher Halts Production
description: Key Porter Books, a prominent Canadian publishing house in Bolton, Ontario, announced it would temporarily suspend publishing operations, The Globe and Mail of Toronto reported. The company, which releases around 100 books a year, laid off almost two-thirds of its staff members in September and said on Friday that it would halt production of all new titles. It would continue to market and distribute books already in print and would consider restructuring options, according to a company statement. Key Porter Books has played a leading role in giving a voice to the Canadian story, and we will do everything possible to ensure that voice continues to be heard, Jordan Fenn, the vice president and publisher, said in the statement. Several authors and literary agents have expressed concern over the status of their books and frustration with the companys lack of communication. Julie Devaney, who planned to have her first book released by Key Porter in April, told The Globe and Mail that finding as good of a fit with another publisher would be difficult. Key Porter was founded by the author and publisher Anna Porter as a joint venture with Key Publishers in 1979 and acquired by H. B. Fenn & Company in 2004. It has represented authors including Margaret Atwood, Joan Barfoot and Conrad Black.

title: True Grit Sustains Its Oscar Push
description: True Grit (with Jeff Bridges and Hailee Steinfeld, above), a sober western and an Oscar hopeful, continued its tear at North American theaters over the weekend, beating the overtly commercial Little Fockers for first place at the box office. True Grit (Paramount) was No. 1 with about $15 million in ticket sales for a three-week total of $110.4 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office statistics. Little Fockers (Universal) was second with $13.8 million, bringing its three-week total to about $124 million. Season of the Witch, a newcomer starring Nicolas Cage, sold about $10.7 million in third place for Relativity Media. Tron: Legacy (Walt Disney Studios) sold about $10 million in fourth place, bringing its four-week total to about $148 million. Heavy television advertising helped Black Swan (Fox Searchlight) take fifth place. That Oscar hopeful, starring Natalie Portman, sold $8.4 million to lift its six-week total to $61.5 million. The only other new release of note, Country Strong (Sony) with Gwyneth Paltrow, opened quietly in sixth place with $7.3 million.

A fascinating range of drummers, very fine to clunky-passing-as-cool. And other peoples backs.

title: Ghost Writer Makes a Move
description: The Social Network may have continued its sweep of professional opionators on Saturday when it earned the top prize (and more) from the National Society of Film Critics, but there were some surprises among the winners. The group, consisting of 61 writers from publications like Time, The Village Voice and The New Yorker, gave the best supporting actress award to Olivia Williams for her role as a political wife in Roman Polanskis The Ghost Writer. She creamed her competition, getting substantially more votes than Amy Adams and Melissa Leo for The Fighter or Jacki Weaver for Animal Kingdom. The Ghost Writer also placed in the screenplay and director category, which may mean that it has a better-than-a-dark-horse chance at the Oscars (a dappled horse?). The society does reveal its final tally, an unusual openness in the world of trophy-giving. For a closer look at what their numbers mean, check out The Hollywood Reporters take. As Tim Appelo notes there, if Ms. Williams does win an Oscar, she will have to hand it over to Mr. Polanski  as she promised she would  because hes got a pretty clear vision for his performers. He acts the scene for you, she said. And if you dont copy what he does, he goes, No! Like this,  pause, movement, intonation, the works. So the prize for any performance really does go to Roman.

title: 2nd-Degree Murder Charge in Times Sq. Killing
description: The 21-year-old companion of the Portuguese celebrity journalist found murdered in his Times Square hotel room has been charged with one count of second-degree murder in his death, the police said. The body of the journalist, Carlos Castro, 65, was found on the 34th floor of the InterContinental Hotel on Friday evening. He had been sexually mutilated, an official said.

title: On Our Radar: House Republican Vows to Cut E.P.A. Budget
description: The newly appointed leader of a House subcommittee that controls the Environmental Protection Agencys budget, Representative Mike Simpson, Republican of Idaho, says he intends to slash the agencys funding. The E.P.A. is the scariest agency in the federal government, an agency run amok, Mr. Simpson said in a statement on Friday. Its bloated budget has allowed it to drastically expand its regulatory authority in a way that is hurting our economy and pushing an unwanted government further into the lives of Idahoans. [The Hill]

title: Monday Reading: Finding Cheap Flights
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

Loughner, his head shaved bare and his hands and feet in restraints, was led Monday into a federal courtroom, where he agreed not to contest his continued imprisonment but offered no hint of how he would respond to the murder and attempted murder charges linking him to the Tucson shootings that left six dead and 14 injured.

title: The Reluctant Film Composer
description: The Bagger had a much-appreciated chance to let someone else do the heavy lifting on Friday, when we sat in the audience for our colleague Jon Pareless Times Talk interview with Trent Reznor. (The pairing of the Nine Inch Nails frontman with the chief pop critic of The Times drew other music luminaries: Nick Zinner of the Yeah Yeah Yeahs was sitting right behind us.) Mr. Pareles and Mr. Reznor, in a dark suit and blue tie, talked about his score with Atticus Ross for The Social Network. During the conversation, he showed an early clip of the title sequence from the film, originally set to Elvis Costellos peppy Beyond Belief, making it seem like, as he put it, a kids at college tomfoolery type of story. Instead he used haunting piano set amid frayed electronica to give it a much lonelier feel. (Watch the original title sequence in this clip from the Times Talk; it begins at about the 4:40 mark.)

title: NATO Airstrike Kills 3 Police Officers in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A NATO airstrike killed three Afghan police officers in central Afghanistan on Sunday in what Afghan officials said was friendly fire. Two more police officers died Monday in a suicide car bomb attack in the southern Taliban stronghold of Kandahar Province.

That should not come as a surprise: the league is flush with outstanding quarterbacks, particularly those schooled in the pass-intensive spread college offenses that have made their transition to the N.F.L. much easier.

title: Resolved: Make Some Financial Choices
description: This week on the Bucks blog, our contributors, along with some of our favorite sources, are writing about their new years financial resolutions. Here, Lee Badgett, research director of the Williams Institute, a research group that studies sexual orientation policy issues, shares her own plans. She is also a professor of economics and director of the Center for Public Policy and Administration at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

title: Economics and Morality
description: Mark Thoma directs me to Eric Schoeneberg, who argues that the right is winning economic debates because people believe, wrongly, that theres something inherently moral about free-market outcomes. My guess is that this is only part of the story; theres more than a bit of Ayn Randism on the right, but theres also the appeal of simplicity: goldbuggism is intellectually easy, Keynesianism is intellectually hard, as evidenced by the inability of many trained economists to get it.

title: Can This Business Be Sold?
description: Last week, NBC Nightly News featured the story of Ann Price, who is proprietor of Anns Snack Bar in Atlanta and has been struggling to sell her business. While Anns is a beloved regional icon, both the NBC Nightly News feature and this New York Times video that was published in November (along with this article) offer some wonderfully visual examples of classic problems that can make it very hard to sell a small business.

title: Top 10 Composers: The Vienna Four
description: For any attempt to determine the top 10 classical composers in history, like the one we embarked on in the Arts & Leisure section on Sunday, the Viennese Classical period presents a special challenge. If such a list is to be at all diverse and comprehensive, how could 4 of the 10 slots go to composers  Haydn, Mozart, Beethoven and Schubert  who worked in Vienna during, say, the 75 years from 1750 to 1825? What on earth was going on there to foster such achievement?

title: Support for Gun Control Has Dropped in Recent Years
description: In the wake of Saturdays shooting in Arizona, there are likely to be new polls out this week measuring the publics support for stricter gun control laws. Until they surface, it is worth noting that support for stricter gun control has significantly dropped over the last couple of decades, and there is little evidence to suggest that major gun crimes change opinions on the issue.

title: An Extra Serving of Rex Ryan
description: America, you are about to enter a world New York has been stomaching (pun intended) for two seasons now. You are about to get a full plate (pun still intended) of Rex Ryan. The Jets beat the Colts to advance to the American Football Conference divisional playoffs, where they will face the big bad Patriots. Make no mistake, this will be all about Rex. If you think a 45-3 shellacking at the hands of the Patriots in December would quiet the bluster, well, you would be wrong. His every bombastic word will be repeated on every SportsCenter and Internet sports site. You will hear about his dislike for Patriots quarterback Tom Brady, his disdain for everything New England up to and including, we believe, clam chowder.

title: Iran Sentences Human Rights Lawyer to 11 Years in Jail
description: TEHRAN  A human rights lawyer has been sentenced by the Iranian authorities to 11 years in jail for crimes that include activities against national security and propaganda against the regime, family members confirmed Monday. In addition to her jail sentence, the lawyer, Nasrin Sotoudeh, was barred from practicing law and from leaving the country for 20 years, her husband, Reza Khandan, said in a telephone interview on Monday.

title: Even for Chefs, Home Kitchen Can Be Tight Fit

The term conjures up visions of professionals using acres of counter space and island stoves to perfect their braising and baking  like Julia Childs kitchen memorialized in the Smithsonian.

title: Chic Peek | Barneys.com and Givenchy

In this exclusive snippet which appears above, attention-grabbing leopard prints share the spotlight with the Italian model Mariacarla Boscono, as styled by Panos Yiapanis. title: Workplace Flexibility and the Bottom Line

But to some people, the whole notion of workplace flexibility  paid maternity leaves, more flexible schedules, telecommuting  is nice-sounding mumbo-jumbo that might makes employees feel good, but doesnt translate into dollars and cents on the bottom line.

The two men, interviewed as part of The Timess Arts & Leisure Weekend, said they had no definite plans, but Mr. Armstrong rhapsodized frequently about this first experience with theater  creating American Idiot with Mr. Mayer (Spring Awakening) and now performing in the show through late February as the malevolent character St. Jimmy.

title: The Kennedys Will Still Receive Worldwide Broadcast As Producers Seek a New U.S. Home

title: Numberplay: Finger Games
description: Garys surrealist picture above is a depiction, in the spirit of Salvador Dali, of the ancient hand game of morra. Today well explore various versions of this game, such as odd-even morra and guessing morra. The basic game is played in a manner similar to the well-known rock-paper-scissors. Two players face each other, initially concealing their hands. One of them says One, two, three, shoot! and then both players display a number of fingers from some preset range. The number of points or dollars at stake in each round is equal to the number of fingers displayed. In odd-even morra, one of the players (Odd) wins the stakes for the round if the total number of fingers displayed is odd. On the other hand (!), the other player (Even) wins the stakes if the total number of fingers is even.

title: Now Booking | The Shangri-La Paris
description: From the outside, the new Shangri-La Paris channels the Cote dAzur, with snappy green awnings against a pale limestone facade and potted palms swaying on the balconies. But inside its 19th-century Parisian opulence all the way  marble and chintz, mahogany and silk, fluffy couches and sparkling crystal fill the citys first new palace hotel in years.

title: Chilling Out
description: Q. Will you burn more calories sitting at your desk if the thermostat is turned down?

title: Cancer Can Develop in Catastrophic Burst
description: New rapid methods of decoding DNA have brought to light a catastrophe that can strike human cells: a whole chromosome may suddenly shatter into pieces.

title: Farm Bureau Challenges E.P.A. on Chesapeake Pollution
description: In late December, the Environmental Protection Agency put the six states in the Chesapeake Bays 64,000-square-mile watershed on a pollution diet, requiring steep cuts in the urban and farm runoff that has imperiled the health of the bay. The enhanced regulations are to be enforced by the states but could fall under direct federal control if pollution benchmarks are not met, the agency has said.

title: ABC Considers a Wicked Mini-Series
description: ABC is thinking about getting back into the mini-series business, with a deal to consider turning the book that spawned the Broadway musical Wicked into a multipart program.

title: Google Co-Founder Sets Sail on $45 Million Yacht
description: Facebooks Mark Zuckerberg may be the man of the moment, what with the Time Person of the Year award, the most hotly awaited impending initial public offering and a critically acclaimed movie loosely based on his life.

title: The Feds QE2 Traders, Buying Bonds by the Billions
description: Deep inside the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, the $600 billion man is fast at work.

title: The South Sudanese Referendum Wont Depend on the Diaspora
description: The South Sudanese diaspora have played an important, and perhaps indispensable, role in bringing about the referendum on independence from Sudan that is taking place this week.

title: With E-Mails, Palin and Beck Discuss the Arizona Shootings
description: As the nation reacted to the shooting of Representative Gabrielle Giffords and 19 others outside a Tucson supermarket this weekend, former Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska and Glenn Beck, the conservative radio host, took to e-mail on Sunday to have a conversation of their own.

title: Mysterious Tesla Model S Caught in the Buff
description: What is it? It appears to be an exploded Tesla S, which is due to be introduced in about an hour. When it can account for all its parts, the high-performance electric sedan is described by Tesla as the pinnacle of innovation.

title: Google Needs Sex
description: And now for something completely different.

title: The Saga of Pluto
description: Revisiting the trials and tribulations of the former planet, a favorite of schoolchildren that was demoted in 2006 to dwarf planet status.

title: The War of the Worlds, Round 2
description: Six years ago this month, Michael E. Brown, a professor of planetary astronomy at the California Institute of Technology, spotted an object in the night sky that was so bright and so far away that he was sure it was bigger than Pluto.

title: Union Loses Suit Over Teacher-Ranking Data
description: An effort by the city teachers union to block the release of performance rankings for thousands of teachers has failed, a Manhattan judge ruled on Monday.

title: Sneeze-Free Zone
description: Even die-hard road warriors need a comfortable place to recharge after a long day. But for business travelers with allergies, asthma and other sensitivities, hotel rooms can be rife with dust mites, mold, animal dander and other allergens that set off sneezing, itchy eyes, headaches and sleepless nights.

title: Celebrities Galore for Piers Morgans First Week
description: Piers Morgans first week on CNN will feature Oprah Winfrey and a coterie of celebrities, the channel announced Monday, one week before his premiere.

title: Of Home Fires Burning, or Burning Up Homes
description: Siobhan Fallon tells gripping, straight-up, no-nonsense stories about American soldiers and their families. Its clear from her tender yet tough-minded first book, You Know When the Men Are Gone, that she knows this world very well. The reader need not look at Ms. Fallons biography to guess that she, like her books characters, has spent time living in Fort Hood, Tex., watching the effects of soldiers leave-takings and homecomings on men and the wives they leave behind. Married to a man who is on at least his third tour of duty, Ms. Fallon now lives where he is stationed, in the Middle East.

title: ReTweet | Doonan as Barneys Ambassador
description: Looks like Mark Lee, the recently appointed CEO of Barneys New York, is not quite done cleaning house. Lee has announced that Doonan, the impish wit behind the Barneys window displays for almost 25 years, is being replaced by the erstwhile Fairchild Publications creative director. The announcement ended with the emphatic line, No one will be speaking further on the record today, the release stands for itself.

title: Critics' Picks: 'East of Eden'
description: A. O. Scott looks back at Elia Kazan's 1955 film adaptation of John Steinbeck's novel.

title: It Looks a Lot Like Glass, but Its Tough as Steel
description: The moment a crack forms in a piece of glass, it is prone to spread. Thats because although glass is very strong and resistant to deformation, it lacks the toughness that metals like aluminum and steel have.

title: Stritch and Miranda Get Last Laughs at Finales of Night Music and In the Heights
description: Fifteen Broadway shows are closing this month, and for the casts, crews and fans of all of them the last performance is bound to be memorable. But Sundays closing performances of two musicals  A Little Night Music, the revival of Stephen Sondheims bittersweet romance, and In the Heights, which brought a host of new talents to Broadway  were especially raucous. And leave it to the crowd-pleasingly mouthy star of each show to get the last laughs.

title: Analyst Says It May Be Deal Time for JPMorgan
description: Mike Mayo, a banking analyst at Crdit Agricole Securities, thinks JPMorgan Chase is poised to make more acquisitions, quite possibly overseas.

title: TimesCast | January 10, 2011
description: After the assassination attempt of Representative Gabrielle Giffords, the gun control debate is under way; and mistakes in the media during breaking news.

title: The Victims of the Shooting
description: A gunman killed 6 people and wounded 14 when he opened fire outside a supermarket in Tucson while Representative Gabrielle Giffords was meeting with constituents. Victims on that Saturday morning included retirees, a federal judge and a 9-year-old girl born on 9/11.

title: Preventing Heart Risks at the Root: Childhood
description: Two studies published Monday suggest that the road to hypertension and heart disease starts in childhood and that prevention should start there, too.

title: Resellers Make B.C.S. Title Game an Expensive Ticket
description: The Bowl Championship Series title game is the granddaddy of college sporting events, not just because a football champion will be crowned, but also because of how much money fans are willing to spend to attend the game.

title: A TV for Really Big Sports Fans
description: At the Consumer Electronics Show, products ran from the sublime to the ridiculous, to the really ridiculous.

title: Life Span of Early Man Same as Neanderthals
description: Longevity in early modern humans and in Neanderthals was about the same, according to a new study, suggesting that long life was not what helped the population of early modern humans increase.

title: An Editor Goes to Barneys, but Not to Shop
description: Dennis Freedman, the former creative director of W, has a new job: creative director of Barneys New York. As part of the continuing changes made by Mark Lee, the retailers new chief executive, Mr. Freedman will be responsible for overall creative direction of the store, including its photographic and video images, window displays, visual merchandising and store design. He will be free to engage outside window dressers and other collaborators to create Barneys windows, a humorous stage developed by Simon Doonan. He starts next week. Mr. Freedman, who spent 20 years at W, helped shape the look and influence of the magazine through his close contacts with photographers like Bruce Weber, Steven Klein, Juergen Teller and Philip-Lorca diCorcia. He left the magazine last year.

title: An Egg Donors Tale
description: What about the egg donor? many of you asked in the conversation here about Melanie Thernstroms divisive article, Meet the Twiblings, describing the construction of her family.

title: The Danger of Stock Market Forecasts
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog, and other drawings are available on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

title: From Greenpoint, With Spandex
description: This calm moment before the next snowstorm is a good chance to catch up on your online reading.

title: You Might Already Know This ...
description: They should have seen it coming.

title: The Deal Is On: Groupon Closes $950 Million Round
description: The social buying site Groupon has closed a $950 million round of financing, the company confirmed in a statement on Monday. Claire Cain Miller of The New York Times notes on Bits that this is the largest amount of money ever raised by a start-up.

title: Alagna to Pinch-Hit in Tosca Tonight
description: Roberto Alagna will sing the role of Cavaradossi in Monday nights opening performance of Tosca at the Metropolitan Opera House, replacing Marcelo lvarez, who withdrew due to a cold, the Met said. Mr. Alagna has sung the role at many leading opera houses, including the Royal Opera, but never at the Met.

title: Goldsmiths Other Bad Snow Day
description: The man who was in charge of snow removal operations, Stephen Goldsmith, was out of town when the storm caught his city by surprise. A snow emergency was not declared. And after much criticism, he vowed to review what went wrong, and to do a better job the next time.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 10
description: The day in sports included sled-dog racing in the French Alps and soccer in Qatar.

title: DeLay Sentenced to 3 Years in Conspiracy and Money-Laundering Case
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Tom DeLay, the former House majority leader, was sentenced to three years in prison on Monday for money laundering and conspiracy stemming from his role in a scheme to channel corporate contributions to Texas state races in 2002.

title: Groupon Raises a Record $950 Million in Venture Capital
description: Jan. 11, 1:25 a.m. | Updated  Clarified the name of the Russian firm that invested in Groupon after Groupon corrected its press release.

title: Oil Spill Panel to Urge Tougher Oversight of Offshore Drilling
description: The presidential commission looking into the Deepwater Horizon accident in the Gulf of Mexico concludes its work on Tuesday with the release of its final report at 10 a.m.

title: Playing With RNA
description: A demo of the EteRNA game in which players help create a library of synthetic RNA designs.

title: Square Locks In $240 Million Valuation
description: Square, a mobile payments company, announced Monday that it had raised $27.5 million in a new round of financing led by Sequoia Capital.

title: RNA Game Lets Players Help Find a Biological Prize
description: Scientists at Carnegie Mellon University and Stanford University are attempting to harness the wisdom of crowds with the creation of an online video game that challenges players to design new ways to fold RNA molecules.

title: Nothing Conceptual About Honda Civic
description: Introduced on Monday 2012 Honda Civic concept

title: Amid the Shales, Glimpses of an Ancient Forest
description: Bonnie F. Jacobs, a paleobotanist at Southern Methodist University, writes from Ethiopia, where she is studying fossils of ancient plant and animal life. The current field season in the Mush Valley of Ethiopia is financed by a grant to Ellen Currano of Miami University, Ohio, from the National Geographic Societys Committee for Research and Exploration.

title: Creative Team Announced for Stage Musical of Oscar-Winning Once
description: The Irish playwright Enda Walsh (Penelope) and the Scottish director John Tiffany (Black Watch) will collaborate on the stage adaptation of the film Once that is planned for a fall opening on Broadway, the producers announced on Monday.

title: Three Men in a More Upscale Room
description: ALBANY  Goodbye, three men in a room. Hello, three men in a mansion.

title: Obama Avoiding Fingerpointing
description: President Obama is, so far, keeping his distance from the debate over whether vitriolic political discourse contributed to the attack in Arizona that killed six people and wounded 14 people, including Representative Gabrielle Giffords.

title: Mercedes Hedges Its E-Bets With Hydrogen and Batteries
description: DETROIT  For Mercedes-Benz, the pair of cars it displayed here Monday represented healthy green fantasies in sickly yellow paint.

title: Making It Official, Michael White and Chris Cannon Split
description: Michael White and Chris Cannon have officially dissolved their high-flying, high-end restaurant partnership, following two months of silence after blog items and unceasing speculation in the food world fueled the rumors of a breakup.

title: Varied Menus for Sustaining a Well-Fed World
description: On many issues relevant to charting a smooth human journey in this century, arguments are often framed between camps seeking to promote and spread sustainable behaviors and those pushing to advance and/or disseminate better technologies. In such polarized discussions, its hard to find acknowledgment that a variegated world heading toward roughly 9 billion people by 2050 will almost assuredly require all of the above.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: A sampling of whats making the rounds in the deal-making ecosystem:

title: Kepler Finds an Exoplanet, Rocky, Small and Very Hot
description: SEATTLE  In a down payment on riches to come, scientists from NASAs Kepler satellite announced Monday that they had discovered the smallest planet yet found outside our solar system and the first that was unquestionably rocky, like the Earth.

title: Directors Guild Offers Some Oscar Clues
description: Conventional wisdom holds that the best picture Oscar nearly always goes to the best director winner. And Oscarologist wisdom holds that the Academys best director is nearly always the same as the Directors Guild of Americas choice; the two prizes havent matched up only six times in 62 years. So when the D.G.A. announced its nominees on Monday, the following people were probably doubly celebrating: Darren Aronofsky, for Black Swan; Tom Hooper, for The Kings Speech; Christopher Nolan for Inception; David Fincher for The Social Network and David O. Russell for The Fighter.

title: Where Sports News Is Irreverent, and Scores Irrelevant
description: If youre looking for an argument for the continued relevance of print, you could do worse than Onion SportsDome, the latest product of the Onion satire factory.

title: Verizon iPhone Buzz Adds to Apples Shares
description: Wall Street  and everyone else who cared  has known for months that Apples iPhone would be coming to Verizon early this year, ending more than three years of exclusivity with AT&T. Still, the news on Friday that Verizon would announce an iPhone running on its CDMA network at a Tuesday news conference in New York generated plenty of new buzz  and new enthusiasm for Apple on Wall Street.

title: Chief Ousted in Surprise at A.M.D.
description: The chip maker Advanced Micro Devices on Monday pushed out its 49-year-old chief executive, Dirk Meyer, in a move that took industry analysts by surprise.

title: A Higher Profile for Lawrence Tech
description: DETROIT  Lawrence Technological University in nearby Southfield is raising its profile at this years Detroit auto show.

title: Doubt on Anti-Aging Molecule as Drug Trial Stops
description: The pharmaceutical company Sirtris announced last month that it had halted the last of its clinical trials of resveratrol, the minor ingredient of red wine that some researchers see as a drug that can extend life.

title: Three Steps to a More Civil Congress?
description: Third Way, the centrist Democratic group, sent a letter to Congressional leaders on Monday outlining some suggestions to help promote civility in Congress and perhaps help moderate the nations overall political discourse.

title: Newbery Awarded to Debut Author
description: An old-fashioned novel about a scrappy girl searching for the answers to a spy mystery in small-town Kansas won the John Newbery Medal on Monday for the years outstanding contribution to childrens literature.

title: Hyundai Veloster, Wired for Web and Road
description: Introduced on: Monday, Jan. 10

title: An Answer to a Crying Need: King Lear for Children
description: Squeezing one of Shakespeares greatest tragedies into a tight 90 minutes is no simple feat. Equally challenging is transforming said work, which also happens to be one of his more death-ridden and violent, into a show suitable for youngsters.

title: Federal Reserve: Worlds Most Profitable Bank?
description: And you thought Wall Street was astonishingly profitable. Felix Salmon notes that the Federal Reserve earned net income of $80.9 billion in 2010, with a return on assets of 3.3 percent, while its return on equity a jaw-dropping 143 percent:

title: On Adventures Trail, Some Endings Bring a Blush
description: I GUESS my first crazy experience with planes was when I was 18 years old and went sky diving without a tandem. I was instructed to hold onto the wing of the plane and use my hands to scoot to the very edge. My instructor counted to three and told me to release my grip and fall backward. He also said the parachute would self-release. It did.

title: New CDs
description: CAGE THE ELEPHANT

title: The Witch Is Dead? Spider-Man Outgrosses Wicked on Broadway
description: Forget the Green Goblin or the multi-legged villainess Arachne. The most entertaining rival for Spider-Man the web-slinging hero of the Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark  may prove to be Glinda and Elphaba, the witches who defy gravity in the blockbuster show Wicked.

title: Californias Heavy Rains Counter La Nias Ways
description: For meteorologists and climate scientists, the flooding that has affected the Australian state of Queensland has not been unexpected. It is seen as collateral damage from the current La Nia, a lowering of sea-surface temperatures in the tropical eastern Pacific Ocean.

title: With a Life on the Ropes, Seeking Redemption in the Ring
description: If the Cinderella myth is to be believed, women feel oppressed by class, but men seem most daunted by age. Thats why the two sexes cling to such different versions of that fairy tale. For women, it survives as a rescue fantasy  the prince who lifts a young woman up from lower-class obscurity. Men usually prefer a Cinderella Man story, the return of a broken-down has-been who battles ruin and ridicule to win back his honor  and fortune.

title: Loughners Lawyer Is Called a Master Strategist
description: The capital-defense lawyer who will represent Jared L. Loughner in the shootings in Tucson, Judy Clarke, is a well-known public defender who gets life sentences in cases that often begin with emotional calls for the death penalty.

title: Sounds of the World, Sousaphones Included
description: Remember where you come from, the Hawaiian singer Kaumakaiwa Kanakaole said, ending a traditional-style story song. That could be the mission statement for Globalfest, the annual world-music showcase that brought 13 groups to Webster Hall on Sunday.

title: Latest, Three-Team Trade Effort Could Send Anthony to the Nets
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  From the moment he began plotting his exit from Denver, Carmelo Anthony has pursued a consistent, sometimes-conflicting set of goals. He wants to play with other stars, on a better team, preferably in New York and with a $65 million contract extension in hand.

title: In Tucson, Guns Have a Broad Constituency
description: TUCSON  I have a Glock 9 millimeter, and Im a pretty good shot.

title: Lawlessness and Need Survive in Shaken Haiti
description: A question as we reach the first anniversary of the earthquake in Haiti: What is the most fundamental thing that needs to be restored to get the country back on its feet? Water service? Electricity? Medical care?

title: What Were Reading: Best and Worst Jobs
Orchestra Arrives on Big Screen
description: During orchestral concerts in traditional halls, many musicians are often hidden from view, heard but not seen until singled out by the conductor for a solo bow. But woodwind and brass players accustomed to performing in relative anonymity behind a shield of string instruments may have to get used to close-ups if live HD broadcasts like the one offered in movie theaters by the Los Angeles Philharmonic on Sunday afternoon become more commonplace.

title: Goldman Sachs to Fine-Tune Its Practices
description: 8:57 p.m. | Updated

description: Introduced on Monday: 2011 Jeep Compass

title: The Big 4 Of Vienna: One Faces Elimination
description: For any attempt to determine the top 10 classical composers in history, like the one we embarked on in the Arts & Leisure section on Sunday, the Viennese Classical period presents a special challenge. If such a list is to be comprehensive, let alone geographically diverse, how could 4 of the 10 slots go to composers  Haydn, Mozart, Beethoven and Schubert  who worked in Vienna during, say, the 75 years from 1750 to 1825? What on earth was going on there to foster such achievement?

title: Schubert and Beethoven
description: In his series, the chief classical music critic Anthony Tommasini discusses two more of the four giants who worked in Vienna during a 75-year period (part 2 of 2).

description: WASHINGTON  The case before the Supreme Court on Monday concerned a difficult question of securities law, and Justice Antonin Scalia approached it from a novel angle.

description: This week, A. O. Scott looks back at Elia Kazans adaptation of the John Steinbeck novel East of Eden. The film features James Dean in his first major screen role as the troubled son of a farmer who struggles to win his fathers approval and worthiness over his more favored brother.

description: To The Editor:

title: Southwest Adds Complexity to Its Frequent-Flier Plan
description: THE day before New Years, I was having lunch in Tucson with Tom Miller, who writes books about travel and the Southwest. Like many business travelers at the end of the year, Mr. Miller was a little distressed.

title: Pakistan Faces a Divide of Age on Muslim Law
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Cheering crowds have gathered in recent days to support the assassin who riddled the governor of Punjab with 26 bullets and to praise his attack  carried out in the name of the Prophet Muhammad  as an act of heroism. To the surprise of many, chief among them have been Pakistans young lawyers, once seen as a force for democracy.

description: Photographs from Arizona, Sudan and India.
