description: The Environmental Protection Agency has awarded $7 million in grants to researchers to study the cumulative health impact of pollutants like mercury and lead and social factors like stress and poor nutrition in several low-income communities, the agency said Tuesday.

title: Rising Chinese Inflation to Show Up in U.S. Imports
description: BEIJING  When garment buyers from New York show up next month at Chinas annual trade shows to bargain over next autumns fashions, many will face sticker shock.

title: A Kennedy Condemns Atmosphere of Hate
description: It was billed as a commemoration of John F. Kennedys farewell speech to the Massachusetts legislature 50 years ago this month, but a Beacon Hill ceremony on Tuesday was striking for another reason. Joseph P. Kennedy III, a 30-year-old grandson of Robert F. Kennedy, had lawmakers riveted with a speech of his own, condemning what he called an atmosphere of hate in modern politics.

title: For Football, a Season of Record Ratings
description: NBC completed a record-breaking season of National Football League coverage with yet another top Saturday night as its two wild-card playoff games formed the most-watched doubleheader in the history of the Saturday wild-card round.

title: Claude Debussy
description: In his series, Anthony Tommasini discusses the pioneer of modern music, Claude Debussy.

title: Not All Sweetness in a Honeycomb Museum
description: Experience tells us that it would be unwise to build up expectations for Eli Broads proposed new museum, whose design was unveiled at a ceremony in downtown Los Angeles last week.

title: Painting in Deadly Oil
description: Oil-soaked pelicans. Turtles caught midstroke in black ooze. Floating schools of dead fish. And then fishermen throwing out their catch.

title: Going Under the Radar, and Into the Unknown
description: Some international theater festivals have more resources and bigger names. Others may present more radical work. But the reason that I most look forward to Under the Radar, the scrappy January showcase presented by the Public Theater, is that its more likely than any other in the city to present someone exciting I never knew before.

title: Raw View of African Cure for Addiction to Drugs
description: In Im Dangerous With Love, a furtive, aggressively unappetizing documentary, the filmmaker Michel Negroponte explores the theory that ibogaine, a hallucinogenic powder made from an African plant, can break addiction to drugs like heroin with relative ease. It follows a man named Dimitri Mugianis, who says he beat addiction with ibogaine (which is banned in the United States) and who is now part of an underground network that seeks to help others do so.

title: Students Seeking Meaning Crack the Shell of Technique
description: The Juilliard School has found a useful way to keep its music students busy and focused during the winter break. Instead of taking a breather after exams, the players who sign up for ChamberFest spend the weeks rehearsing and coaching in preparation for a week of free public concerts.

title: After Miles Decides to Stay at L.S.U., Michigan Hires Another Ex-Assistant
description: Michigan stayed within its football family Tuesday by handing its head coaching job to a former assistant, Brady Hoke, who led San Diego State to a 9-4 record this season.

title: In House, Security Briefings and Prayer
description: 8:20 p.m. | Updated  House Republicans will meet on Wednesday morning and will receive the first of several security presentations expected by law-enforcement agencies in response to the attempted assassination of Representative Gabrielle Giffords, Democrat of Arizona, that left six people dead and Ms. Giffords and 13 others wounded.

title: The End Is Near; Lets All Exit Laughing
description: Delve into the history of many theatermakers, and they are likely to recall staging elaborate fantasy worlds as children. The difference with the Berserker Residents is their refusal to relinquish that unrefined creative spirit.

title: Cliffs to Buy Consolidated Thompson for $5 Billion
description: Cliffs Natural Resources said on Tuesday that it had agreed to buy Consolidated Thompson Iron Mines for nearly $5 billion in cash, seeking to bolster its presence in Canada.

title: Trading Up: White Dress Shirts
description: The white T-shirts gainfully employed big brother, the white dress shirt has for decades been the leader, color-wise, of the overall dress-shirt market.

title: The Circle of White
description: ZEROING in on the most basic materiel in the mens wear arsenal  white T-shirts, blue jeans, khakis  has made hip and happy campers out of clothing makers and their customers alike. It has done wonders for big companies like Calvin Klein, Ralph Lauren and American Apparel and small players like Jean Shop and Save Khaki, all of which have created items that have, in turn, created repeat customers. In the little-discussed realm of retail known as replenishment or replacement shopping, the goal is to perfect basic garments expressly so that the time-crunched or shopaphobic guy can whiz in and out of a store as if on a jet-fueled sortie, halting only briefly behind enemy lines to grab three/six/nine of his tried-and-true chinos/briefs/socks. In, out, nobody gets hurt.

title: Better Than a Hairnet
description: New York baristas say they have to cover their hair to comply with health codes, but they are choosing headgear that expresses their sense of style.

title: Crowns for Kings and Queens of Coffee Bars
description: ITS a good thing Sam Penix likes his hat.

title: Marina Abramovics Art Doubles as Dessert
description: The latest work of the performance artist Marina Abramovic, above, may be her most ephemeral. Its Volcano Flamb, a dessert prepared by Kevin Lasko, the chef at the seasonally changing Park Avenue Winter. You receive this dessert in front of you and its kind of a mystery, Ms. Abramovic said. Its core of dark chocolate ice cream is covered with meringue, decorated with gold leaf and a swirl of spun sugar, bedded on chocolate cookie crumbs and flambed with rum. The artists booklet of off-beat recipes, Spirit Cooking, and an MP3 player with a talk by her accompany the dessert. Its one of several artist collaborations the restaurant has organized with Creative Time, a nonprofit group.

title: Dining Calendar
description: For Cool-Cat Kids

title: Italian Syrup Delivers Taste of Evergreen
description: Every year in late spring, Eleonora Cunacia trudges through the foothills of the Dolomites in Northern Italy to gather wild herbs, including the buds of a kind of dwarf pine called mugo. She puts them in glass jars in the sun, where they dry and ooze sap, which she collects and cooks down with sugar and water to make Mugolio, a thick syrup fragrant with evergreen. It can be used to drizzle on ice cream, cheese or panna cotta; to enhance a sauce for game meats or fish; or in cocktails. At about a quarter of the price of the finest artisanal balsamic vinegar, it has the same uses, even over strawberries in summer.

title: Rare Cacao Beans Discovered in Peru
description: DAN PEARSON was working in northern Peru two years ago with his stepson Brian Horsely, supplying gear and food to mining companies, when something caught his eye.

title: How the Microplane Grater Escaped the Garage
description: RUSSELVILLE, Ark.

title: Soldier Returns to Pressures at Home and Chaos Within
description: Woyzeck, Georg Bchners 1837 play about a soldier driven to madness and murder by poverty, exploitation and jealousy, is sometimes considered the first modern tragedy and is a primary source of absurdist theater. In recent years the title character has become shorthand for societys brutalized, alienated souls, with some depictions even playful.

title: Knives and Butcher Blocks, Together Again
description: Hand-forged knives made by Joel Bukiewicz, left, are all beautifully finished, limited-edition pieces that have been sold online. Mr. Bukiewicz has now opened his pleasant workshop to visitors who can buy or order the knives, each of which comes with a lifetime guarantee for sharpening and conditioning. Buyers will learn the best way to maintain their knives, which are usually made of carbon steel. Unlike stainless steel, carbon steel can stain and rust, but the upside is that it holds a better, sharper edge than stainless.

title: Point Brazil
description: THERES nothing dainty about an acaraj. Peeled and mashed black-eyed peas are fried in palm oil, after which the fritter (pronounced ah-cah-rah-JEH; $5) is sliced and stuffed. Overstuffed, inevitably, with vatap, a creamy paste flavored with seafood and nuts; caruru de quiabo, an onion-and-ginger-laced okra gumbo; and bacalao salad. Its a taste of Brazilian summer, down to the last licked finger.

title: Off the Menu
description: OPENING

title: A Cult Winemaker Tinkers With Success
description: SEBASTOPOL, Calif.

title: Bess Feigenbaums Cabbage Soup
description: Adapted from The National, Manhattan

title: Cabbages Sweet Side
description: CHEFS praise cabbage. They embrace its sweetness. They delight in its crunch in raw slaws and its melting smoothness in cold-weather braises.

title: For Playoff Parity, Take M.L.B. over N.F.L.
description: I love the N.F.L., and especially the playoffs. Every game is an elimination game, and every game starts at a reasonable hour on the East Coast. Of the 11 N.F.L. postseason games every year, only two begin after 8 p.m. Baseball playoff games tend to start later, and of the last 43 postseason series, stretching back to the 2004 World Series, only five have produced a winner-take-all game.

title: Obama Speech to Focus on Serving Country
description: President Obama will focus his speech at a memorial service in Tucson on Wednesday evening on the victims of the attack and on the idea of service to the country, avoiding any overt commentary on the debate over violence and the nations political culture.

title: Elusive Forger, Giving but Never Stealing
description: His real name is Mark A. Landis, and he is a lifelong painter and former gallery owner. But when he paid a visit to the Paul and Lulu Hilliard University Art Museum in Lafayette, La., last September, he seemed more like a character sprung from a Southern Gothic novel.

title: Gov. Jan Brewer's Speech in Tucson
description: On Tuesday, Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona spoke in Tucson about the shooting there that killed six and left Representative Gabrielle Giffords in critical condition.

title: With Facebook, Debate Renews Over I.P.O. Regulation
description: Harry Campbell

title: Rangers to Send Two to All-Star Game
description: Rangers defenseman Marc Staal and goalie Henrik Lundqvist have been selected by the N.H.L. for the All-Star Game player pool, the league announced.They will go into the draft conducted on the Friday preceding the Jan. 30 game at Raleigh, N.C., and be chosen by either the Eastern or Western Conference captain.

title: Doctors Operating Abroad, With Lots of Body Language
description: Off the Map isnt a very descriptive title for ABCs latest medical drama about do-gooders in a remote jungle clinic  Doctors Without Shirts would be more helpful.

title: The Chardonnays of California
description: The first time I had a Kistler chardonnay was back in the mid-1980s, at the original Rckenwagner, an airy restaurant in Venice, Calif. I had never heard of Kistler at the time, but one of my companions told me the story of how these two young men, Steve Kistler and Mark Bixler, had started a winery and, virtually by themselves, were making chardonnays that were rivaling white Burgundies.

title: Narrowing the Choices, Online
description: WHEN it comes to planning a vacation, travelers can either spend hours online figuring out where to go, which flights and hotels to book, and what to do when they get there, or they can call a travel agent to figure it out for them. Now, a new breed of members-only Web sites is offering something in between.

title: Forsaking Fact for Emotion, Musburger Keeps It Vague
description: Brent Musburger: the name conjures a dramatic, if hyperbolic, voice at big events and drinking games inspired by his verbal idiosyncrasies. His analysts are pardners. His current pardner, Kirk Herbstreit, is Herbie, which Musburger says so often it sounds as if hes played his cassette of The Love Bug to dust.

title: Schwab to Pay $119 Million to Settle Bond Fund Case
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation agreed on Tuesday to pay $119 million to settle federal and state lawsuits in which regulators accused the company of misleading investors in a bond mutual fund that contained risky mortgage-backed securities.

title: More Workers Complain of Bias on the Job, a Trend Linked to Widespread Layoffs
description: In a tough job market, more and more workers are accusing their employers of discrimination, a report from the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said on Tuesday.

title: New York Archdiocese Says It Plans to Close 27 Schools
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York announced on Tuesday that 26 elementary schools and one high school that had received heavy subsidies in recent years because of declining enrollment would be closed at the end of the current school year.

title: Illinois Bill Eliminating Death Row Is Approved
description: CHICAGO  After more than a decade of debate over whether the states system of capital punishment could ever be fair, state lawmakers voted on Tuesday to end the death penalty in Illinois.

title: Millennium Hedge Fund Ends Year Up 13%
description: Millennium Management added nearly $1 billion in assets in December as it ended the year up more than 13 percent, according to two people familiar with the firm.

title: Court Rules on Debtors and Doctors in Training
description: WASHINGTON  Medical residents must pay Social Security taxes, the Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday.

title: Margaret Whiting, Fresh-Faced Singer of Jazz and Pop Standards, Dies at 86
description: Margaret Whiting, a songwriters daughter who as a bright-eyed teenage singer captivated wartime America and then went on to a long, acclaimed career recording hit songs and performing in nightclubs and on television, died on Monday in Englewood, N.J. She was 86.

title: Omnicom Adds to Its Repertoire in Brand Licensing
description: THE Omnicom Group is adding to its holdings in the field of brand and corporate licensing by acquiring a leading company that makes licensing deals for marketers like Procter & Gamble.

title: Does Andruw Jones Make Sense for the Yankees?
description: A 19-year-old Andruw Jones made Yankee Stadium his stage on Oct. 20, 1996, when his two majestic homers in Game 1 of the World Series lifted him into the baseball publics consciousness.

title: Young People Are Heeding Austins Call, Data Shows
description: WASHINGTON  Austin, Tex., drew the largest numbers of young Americans from 2007 through 2009, according to an analysis by a senior demographer at the Brookings Institution, replacing Riverside, Calif., which was the most popular destination for young people in the middle of the decade.

title: A Rising Young Striker Finds New Opportunities
description: It was last October in the tunnel leading to the field at Red Bull Arena when Teal Bunbury found himself standing next to his boyhood idol as the Kansas City Wizards prepared to play the Red Bulls.

title: Auto Show Outsiders Seek Rebirth
description: DETROIT  In early 2010, General Motors kicked its Saab brand to the curb as part of its postbankruptcy reorganization.

title: Zardari Ally to Succeed Slain Official in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  President Asif Ali Zardari has appointed a party loyalist to replace the assassinated governor of Punjab, a move that analysts said was likely to inflame tensions with his political opposition.

title: A Baptism of Blood?
description: On Thursday, March 7, 1850, the Senates all-time greatest orator delivered the most controversial speech of his life. Daniel Websters voice rang out like a trumpet  with a roll of thunder in it, the historian Robert Remini has written; it was powered by a massive chest that sent it hurtling great distances. The Godlike Daniel mesmerized audiences with his large, deep-socketed black eyes  [that] glowed like coals in a furnace.

title: Haitian Quake Survivors Find a Sanctuary in Queens
description: New York is so ethnically diverse that nearly every international calamity has a local dimension. The Southeast Asian tsunami reverberated in Jackson Heights, Queens; hurricanes that hit the Caribbean set East Harlem and Washington Heights on edge.

title: The Real Problem With China
description: WASHINGTON

title: Mental Illness, Guns and Toxic Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Breaking Custom, Seton Hall Picks a Layman as President
description: After a long and frustrating search, Seton Hall University on Tuesday appointed its interim president to be its new leader. In naming the new president, A. Gabriel Esteban, the university broke with its recent tradition of appointing only Roman Catholic priests to the post.

title: Birthright Citizenship
description: To the Editor:

title: Goldman Vows to Be More Open About Its Business
Camby Knows Just What the Knicks Are Missing
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Marcus Camby made the transition long ago from being the mere pogo-stick leaper he was as a Knick. As his points and blocks have dipped, his basketball knowledge has increased and his rebounding remains on par with the N.B.A.s best.

title: Financing Texas Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Terrorism Arrests: More Turmoil in Western Sahara
description: To the Editor:

title: Yahoo Sports Adds an Online Magazine
description: Yahoo Sports has built an audience of more than 50 million visitors on news, commentary and fantasy games. Now it is shifting gears with a product extension: an online magazine.

title: Dja Hear the One About the Guy From Rochester?
description: SKEWERING the city where a comic is playing is one of the oldest tricks in the stand-up handbook. Its also one of the easiest: Philadelphia has crazy sports fans. It rains a lot in Seattle. And in Rochester. ...

title: Wall Collapse Strikes a Family of Brothers
description: They lived together, rode their bicycles to work together and  for at least a week  toiled together at a construction site on Queens Boulevard.

title: Viewership Drops for B.C.S. Game
description: Auburns 22-19 victory over Oregon on Monday night in the B.C.S. title game was seen by an average 27.3 million viewers, down nearly 12 percent from last years game, in which Alabama routed Texas.

title: Staal and Lundqvist Are All-Stars
description: Rangers defenseman Marc Staal and goalie Henrik Lundqvist have been selected by the N.H.L. for the All-Star Game player pool, the league announced. They will go into the draft conducted on the Friday preceding the Jan. 30 game at Raleigh, N.C., and be chosen by either the Eastern or Western Conference captain.

title: U.S. Says New York City Overbilled Medicaid
description: The federal government has accused New York City of overbilling Medicaid by at least tens of millions of dollars by improperly approving 24-hour home care for thousands of patients.

title: First Comes Fear
description: People on the left and right have been wrestling over the legacy of Jared Loughner, arguing about whether his shooting spree proves that the Sarah Palins and Glenn Becks of the world are fomenting violence. But its not as if this is the only data point we have. Heres another one:

title: Legal Strategy Could Hinge on Mental Assessment
description: The disturbing photograph of Jared L. Loughner that was released after his arrest, as well as the writings and statements attributed to him, seemed to point to a man with a mental disorder.

title: Oil Pipeline in Alaska Has Plan to Restart
description: HOUSTON  Worried about the effect of freezing temperatures, the operator of the Trans Alaska Pipeline System said Wednesday that it had temporarily restarted the flow of oil through its 800-mile network, even though repairs had not yet been completed on the leak that forced the shutdown of the system on Saturday.

title: Makeover at Grand Hyatt Sheds the Trump Glitter
description: In the 1970s, Donald Trump devised a plan to rescue the aging Commodore Hotel, at 42nd Street and Lexington Avenue, from the bankrupt Penn Central railroad. The deal, which involved obtaining a generous tax break from the city, then enlisting Hyatt to operate the new hotel, gave Mr. Trump his first major real estate victory.

title: Volt Is First in a Line of Plug-In Hybrids, G.M. Says
description: DETROIT  General Motors plans to introduce two more plug-in hybrid vehicles in the United States based on the Chevrolet Volt in the next few years, its chief executive, Daniel F. Akerson, said Tuesday.

title: Police Say They Visited Tucson Suspects Home Even Before Rampage
description: This article is by Jo Becker, Kirk Johnson and Serge F. Kovaleski.

title: Arming for a Storm
description: Looking to be better prepared this time, New Yorkers equipped themselves for another major snow.

title: A Saving Grace Bounces to Its Feet
description: From the cloud of suspicion and doubt hanging over Auburns Cam Newton to Oregons gaudy uniforms with fluorescent green socks, the Bowl Championship Series title game felt as much like a circus as it did a football game.

title: Rangers, and Their Newest Skater, Fall Short Against Canadiens
description: It could have been a storybook finish for the newest Ranger, Wojtek Wolski, at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night, when he found the puck with 2 minutes 58 seconds left and the tying goal on his stick.

title: Wednesday: Part of the Battle
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  When can you have more than 100 percent of something? In the original version of the film The Producers (a movie that I have pretty much committed to memory because thats how much I love it), Zero Mostel and Gene Wilder cook up a scheme to sell investment rights to their dubious Broadway production to a slew of unsuspecting older women. By the end of the film, they havent really learned their lesson, and we leave them selling more than 100 percent of the rights to everyone in their prison, including the warden.

title: Bit by Bit, a Mexican Police Force Is Eradicated
description: GUADALUPE DISTRITO BRAVOS, Mexico  Her uncle, the mayor who gave her the job nobody else wanted, warned her to keep a low profile, to not make too much of being the last remaining police officer in a town where the rest of the force had quit or been killed.

title: Poll Finds Growing Support for Stronger Gun Control
description: In the wake of the shootings in Tucson on Saturday, the number of Americans who say gun control laws should be made stricter has increased since last spring, but nearly 6 in 10 Americans think stricter laws would have had little effect on preventing the violence which claimed the lives of six people and injured fourteen others, according to a CBS News poll.

title: Governor Strives to Restore Arizonas Reputation
description: TUCSON  Gov. Jan Brewer had intended to use her speech at the Convention Center here on Tuesday to talk about the severe budget shortfall that Arizona faces, after two years in which she had been identified with a series of contentious issues, particularly immigration.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 11
description: Spectators head to the Chilean desert during the Argentina-Chile Dakar Rally, the Grand Sumo Tournament is held in Tokyo and more.

title: Bloggingheads: Exploiting Tragedy?
description: Michelle Goldberg, left, of The Daily Beast and Ross Douthat, Op-Ed columnist for The New York Times, debate liberal reaction to the Arizona shooting.

title: Ivory Coast Forces Crack Down on Opposition
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  The shouts came from the end of the dusty road: Theyre coming, theyre coming!

title: When Congress Was Armed And Dangerous
description: New Haven

title: Opponent Seeks to Block Construction of Downtown Mosque
description: Lawyers representing a firefighter who is suing to block the development of a Muslim community center and mosque in Lower Manhattan filed a motion on Tuesday seeking to block the developers from doing any construction on the site.

title: City Upon a Hill of Scraps: Surviving on Scavenging in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  At the bottom of the economy here, life revolves around that humblest of commodities, garbage.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Ryans Remarks on Patriots Move Jets to Shrug
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  On Tuesday, most of the Jets claimed they had not heard the latest headlines generated by Coach Rex Ryan, despite the national attention his comments generated.

title: Bargain Skiing? Yes, Its Possible.
description: I dont own skis and I havent been on a chairlift this millennium. My winter clothing is so woefully insufficient after spending the last two years in balmy Brazil that the warmest jacket in my possession is a black leather number with a broken zipper. I didnt even own a hat and gloves until a recent knuckle-numbing emergency led me to drop $10 on a Chinatown street corner.

title: American Politics, Seen From Beijing
description: I was struck by some recent remarks by Zhang Guoqing, a Chinese scholar, that I read in Evan Osnoss blog and excerpted in my column today. Here are the full remarks, which originally appeared in The Beijing News:

title: Texas Republicans Savoring Power
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Two years ago, Marva Becks main concern was hauling feed out to cattle on her ranch and trying to avoid getting run over by hungry cows. But on Tuesday she took the oath of office in the Texas House of Representatives, one of a score of conservative neophytes who upset longtime incumbents in November.

title: Impeachment as Intimidation
description: After a strong and well-financed campaign by socially conservative groups, voters in Iowa in November removed three sitting State Supreme Court justices who had participated in 2009s unanimous ruling permitting same-sex marriage. Now several freshman Republican members of the Iowa House are readying a bill calling for the impeachment of the courts four other justices whose terms were not up for renewal.

title: A Hint of Peace
description: We welcome the announcement of a permanent cease-fire by the Basque separatist group ETA. After taking more than 800 lives since the late-1960s, ETAs senseless violence cannot end one day too soon. But what should have been an unequivocal renunciation of terrorism fell far short of what the Spanish, and Basque, people were entitled to expect.

title: The Verdict on the Spill
description: The most important new message contained in the final report of the presidential commission investigating the gulf oil spill is aimed squarely at Congress: If lawmakers hope to win popular support for ramped-up oil drilling in Americas coastal waters then they must make sure that every possible precaution is taken to reduce the chances of another catastrophe like the spill.

title: Playing With the Band
description: Washington

title: Not Just for Lawmakers
description: Representative Peter King, a Republican of Long Island, has proposed a bill that would prohibit the carrying of a gun within 1,000 feet of a member of Congress or other high-profile government official. Thats a worthy notion, so far as it goes. But how about going a step further and prohibiting the carrying of a semiautomatic weapon around 9-year-old girls? Or 79-year-old women? Or any of the other victims who were shot down in the Tucson parking lot on Saturday?

title: Proposed Deal for Anthony Is All About Bad Contracts
description: Like a Hollywood star breathlessly accepting an Oscar, Carmelo Anthony will have many people to thank on the day that he is, at long last, traded to a new team.

title: The Curious Incident of the Dog in Finland Who Was Trained to Give a Nazi Salute
description: BERLIN  The case of the businessman who taught his dog to raise his paw at the command Hitler may never go down in the annals of Third Reich history as consequential, but it has given people here a reason to laugh, not at the nations sinister deeds but at those who were responsible.

title: Australian Floods Rage Through Brisbane
description: BRISBANE, Australia  Worsening what has become one of Australias most devastating natural disasters, more than 30,000 homes and businesses were inundated in the countrys northeast on Thursday as raging floodwaters converged on Brisbane, Australias third-largest city, and the surrounding townships.

title: Alcohol Limits in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  A Turkish regulatory agency has introduced a decree placing severe restrictions on the sale and consumption of alcohol.

title: Adding Up Parts at Goldman Sachs
description: Public opprobrium played a hand in Goldman Sachss decision to disclose more about its trading and investments for its own account, the first fruits of which emerged in a regulatory filing on Tuesday. But the Wall Street firms reorganization of how it reports earnings also serves its own purposes. It makes valuing the firm a bit easier by enabling a better sum-of-the-parts analysis than was previously possible.

title: Did Democrats Give Up in the Gun Control Debate?
description: As The Timess Dalia Sussman noted on Tuesday, Americans have generally become more protective of gun ownership rights in recent years.

title: Measuring Greenhouse Gases
description: A time-lapse animation from Earth Networks shows the measurement of carbon dioxide and methane in Southern California as recorded by a sensor at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography in San Diego.

title: Russia: Nuclear Deal Takes Effect
description: An agreement between Russia and the United States to cooperate more closely on civilian nuclear power took effect Tuesday and was hailed by both sides as a sign that a recent thaw in relations was bearing fruit. The deal, called the 123 Agreement, is intended to ease cross-border investment in nuclear power by resolving issues like liability for accidents.

title: Israel: Airstrike in Gaza Kills a Militant
description: A Palestinian militant from the group Islamic Jihad was killed in Gaza on Tuesday in an Israeli airstrike, according to the Israeli military and the group. The military said in a statement that the target of the strike, Muhammad Najar, 23, was involved in planning a massive terror attack in the heart of Israel, and that the pinpoint killing had disrupted those plans. Islamic Jihad threatened to avenge the Israeli attack.

title: The New Computer Chess Bully on the Screen
Israel: Netanyahu Says Iran Is Undeterred
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Tuesday that international sanctions against Iran had not affected its determination to acquire nuclear weapons, and that to do so the sanctions needed to be materially strengthened and backed by a credible military option led by the United States. The more credible the military threat, he added, the less chance that it would have to be used. At a news conference for foreign reporters, Mr. Netanyahu would not say whether he shared the assessment of Israels recently retired intelligence agency chief that Iran would not be able to build a nuclear weapon before 2015. That assessment pushed back other Israeli estimates by a year or more, based on technical difficulties and other challenges faced by Iran. Intelligence estimates are exactly that  estimates, Mr. Netanyahu said, adding that there was quite a range.

title: Lottery Numbers
Harlem Jazz Fest
description: The Apollo Theater, Jazzmobile and Harlem Stage have banded together to organize the first Harlem Jazz Shrines Festival, scheduled to run May 9 to 15. As the name suggests, the festival will partly pay homage to some of historic Harlem jazz haunts, with events at Mintons Playhouse, the Lenox Lounge, the Alhambra Ballroom and Showmans Cafe. The Apollo Theater will host jam sessions, a jazz-themed Amateur Night and Jazz  la Carte, a program with the trombonist Wycliffe Gordon, above, and guests, including the tap dancer Savion Glover and the singers Carla Cook and Nikki Yanofsky. The Harlem Stage Gatehouse will present the Spanish Harlem Orchestra and two nights of tributes to the fondly remembered club Smalls Paradise, with the bassist-vocalist Meshell Ndegeocello and the pianist Jason Moran. And Jazzmobile, a community outreach, will stock the Alhambra with two nights of big bands  the Jimmy Heath Big Band and the Harlem Renaissance Orchestra  and hold a cutting contest at Mintons, supervised by the drummer T. S. Monk. Among the other partners in the festival are Columbia University, which will host discussions with scholars.

title: Formspring Raises Fresh Cash
description: Formspring, the fast-growing social network that lets people ask each other personal questions and then has others answer them, has hit another major milestone.

title: Word of the Day | reprobate
description: reprobate \re-pr-bat\ noun, adjective and verb

title: At One School, a Push for More Play Time
description: Some kindergarten parents at Public School 101, a graceful brick castle in Forest Hills, Queens, wanted more free play time for their children; so they decided to do something about it.

title: Bobby Robinson, Harlem Music Impresario, Dies at 93
description: Bobby Robinson liked to recall how it all began: with him, a World War II veteran, sitting on a fire hydrant in front of a hat shop in Harlem in 1946. Hundreds of people (potential customers?) walked by.

title: Weather Monitoring Company Turns to Greenhouse Gases
description: The company behind one of the largest networks of weather monitoring stations on the planet  and the purveyor of the ubiquitous WeatherBug application and Web site  is betting that providing greenhouse gas data will also prove to be a lucrative market.

title: Somalia: Sailors on Seized Boat Are Detained
description: The Somali police detained sailors on board a boat carrying charcoal on Tuesday in the capital, Mogadishu, a week after their boat was seized by the Somali Navy, officials said. The boat, which was leased by Somali businessmen and had at least 14 sailors on board, was carrying charcoal to the United Arab Emirates when the navy attacked off the coast of Somalia early this month. The boat had previously been in Merca port, in an area controlled by the Shabab, an Islamist group that has been waging relentless attacks in an effort to overthrow the government. The export of charcoal has been a flourishing business in southern Somalia, but the government banned it last year, citing environmental preservation. Officials said the seizure of the boat was a sign that the navy was becoming more capable, at a time when piracy in Somali waters has been a substantial problem.

title: John Gross Dies at 75; Critic, Essayist and Editor
description: John Gross, the editor of The Times Literary Supplement in London in the 1970s and a book critic for The New York Times in the 1980s who was known for his fluid style and easy erudition, died on Monday in London. He was 75.

title: Jack Oliver, Who Proved Continental Drift, Dies at 87
description: Jack Oliver, whose studies of earthquakes provided convincing proof that Earths continents are constantly moving, died last Wednesday at his home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 87.

title: State of the Union Speech on Jan. 25
description: The House speaker, John A. Boehner of Ohio, on Tuesday officially invited President Obama to deliver a State of the Union address on Jan. 25. The invitation, of course, is a formality, given that the nation has long come to expect the annual address. The invitation is also, however, a reminder that the president and Congress represent separate, coequal branches of government  and that Mr. Obamas appearance in the House chamber is by invitation, not by demand.

title: Turiaf Powers Knicks Past Blazers
description: An opposing teams typical scouting report on Ronny Turiaf can probably be captured in three sentences. He is energetic. He is defensive-minded, even a pest, at times. He is mostly indifferent offensively.

title: News Quiz | January 12, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: The Tigers vs. the Ducks
description: WHO is Cam Newton?To WHOM did Newton cede his star in Monday nights B.C.S. National Championship game?

title: A.I.G. to Sell Taiwan Unit for $2.16 Billion
description: 4:48 a.m. | Updated

title: Questions Persisting as Illinois Raises Taxes
description: CHICAGO  Hours after Illinois lawmakers chose a major tax rate increase to ease this states desperate budget crisis, questions lingered on Wednesday: Would new income and corporate tax rates stunt the growth of businesses and jobs here and, in turn, slow the already stalled revenue picture that has struck so many states? Would the states tax package, which is expected to raise about $6.8 billion annually, be enough to solve the states crisis, which includes a vastly underfinanced pension plan?

title: Hot Line Connecting Koreas Returns to Service
description: SEOUL, South Korea  An important diplomatic hot line connecting North and South Korea went back into service on Wednesday after a lapse of more than seven months.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Jan. 12, 2010
description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Gary Rubinstein at Math for America from the article Weight Watchers Upends Its Points System.

title: Daily Lexeme: Gristbite
description: Todays word, in association with the singular Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Biden Meets With Pakistani Leaders, Stressing Long-Term Ties and Extremist Threat
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. met for talks here on Wednesday with top civilian and military leaders, looking to reinforce a strategic partnership with Pakistan and to reassure a skeptical nation of American intentions.

title: Suicide Bomber Strikes Bus in Afghan Capital
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber apparently singling out Afghan intelligence officers killed two people and wounded 36 on Wednesday in a crowded Kabul neighborhood near Parliaments offices. It was the third suicide assault here in the capital in less than a month.

title: What Might Statistics Say About You?
description: Do you bowl more often than you ride a bike? A recent Times graphic suggests that you do. The graphic breaks down interesting numbers from the Statistical Abstract of the United States, the annual profile of the country published by the Census Bureau.

title: Missing the Fragrance of Everyday Life
description: Pavia Rosati misses the rain on Second Avenue. She misses the crisp fall air on a busy street. She misses her Herms perfume, Jardin sur le Nil.

title: New York City Public Schools Are Open
description: The Department of Education announced early on Wednesday morning that all public schools in New York City would be open despite the winter storm.

title: Bank of China Opens for Renminbi Trade in U.S.
description: Call it liberalization by a thousand cuts.

title: Gates in Tokyo for Talks on North Korea
description: TOKYO  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates arrived in Tokyo on Wednesday night for talks with Prime Minister Naoto Kan and foreign and defense officials focusing on North Koreas nuclear program as well as Mr. Gatess new assessment that Pyongyang would have a missile capable of hitting the United States within five years.

title: Snowy Morning Commute Travel Guide
description: Updated, 7:00 a.m. |  If youre flying this morning, youre probably out of luck, and many trains are canceled on Long Island, but over all, the ground commute is largely churning along. Heres a quick look around the region.

title: Playing With Fire, Literally, in Paris
description: Though the striking and dangerous craft of fire-breathing has made something of a comeback in the last few years, its still a fringe activity. In Paris several years ago, the police shooed practitioners out of Pariss parks, due to safety concerns. The fire breathers, along with flame jugglers and dancers, began meeting at a more out-of-the-way spot long favored by skateboarders: the vast (and treeless) courtyard of the Palais de Tokyo, an imposing, neo-Classical modern art museum built for the 1937 Worlds Fair. Their Saturday night gatherings have become a fixture of Pariss underground life and even spawned an annual party that offers anyone, if only for a night, a view into this glowing world. This years edition, the seventh, is on Jan. 22.

title: Cookie Gilchrist, Punishing Runner Who Took Stand Against Racism
description: Andy Barall writes about pro football history for the Fifth Down. Cookie Gilchrist died Monday at age 75.

title: The Early Word: Assessing and Regrouping
description: From Todays Times:

title: Henderson to Buy Gartmore for $524 Million
description: Henderson Global Investors, the asset manager listed in London and Sydney, said on Wednesday that it had agreed to buy the Gartmore Group in an all-stock deal worth about 335 million.

title: Resignations Deepen Crisis for Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Hezbollah and its political allies withdrew from Lebanons cabinet on Wednesday, toppling a national unity government that had brought a measure of calm to the troubled Middle Eastern country since 2009 and deepening an emerging crisis over a United Nations-backed tribunal investigating the assassination of a former prime minister.

title: Bond Sale a Success in Portugal
description: Portugal won some breathing room Wednesday with a better-than-expected bond auction that fueled a rise in global stock markets and led the government to reaffirm its stance against accepting a bailout.

title: Whose Logo Is It Anyway?
description: When Gap introduced a new logo in October, public response was overwhelmingly negative. With Internet speed, someone created a microsite where readers could render their own Gap-like logo. With the outcry of resistance, the logo was quickly pulled and mea culpas were quickly issued by the retailing giant.

title: Report on Polish Crash Finds Pilot Error, but Says Powerful Passengers Share Some Blame
description: MOSCOW  As Capt. Arkadiusz Protasiuk peered down at a dense fog over the Russian city of Smolensk last April, weighing whether to land an aircraft carrying Polands president and dozens of other government officials, no one told him what to do.

title: After Arizona, How to Return to Politics  and When?
description: The normal course of politics in Washington remains frozen this week, as President Obama travels to Arizona on Wednesday and members of Congress gather to honor the victims of Saturdays shootings and to consider enhancing their own security.

title: Iran Says Time Running Out for Nuclear Deal
description: PARIS  A week before nuclear talks resume with outside powers, a senior Iranian official was quoted on Wednesday as saying that time was running out for negotiations on some parts of his countrys nuclear program because of Tehrans enhanced ability to enrich and manufacture atomic fuel.

title: ITT to Spin Off Its Water and Military Units
description: 7:49 p.m. | Updated

title: Megabytes From the Motor Show
description: DETROIT  Seventeen automakers held press conferences at the Cobo Center on Monday, while five warmed up the teleprompters on Tuesday. Companies, perhaps sensing that journalists pens can write only so legibly, or their feet carry them so quickly, have responded with an enthusiastic embrace of novelty data-storage units.

title: City Officials Greet Storm With Plows and Diplomacy
description: For a city still angry about a blizzard two and a half weeks ago that left some streets unplowed for days, the storm on Wednesday seemed to be much ado about  not nothing, but far less snow than many had feared. The National Weather Service recorded 9.1 inches in Central Park, less than half the total from the two-day storm in December.

title: Can Europe Be Saved?
description: THERES SOMETHING peculiarly apt about the fact that the current European crisis began in Greece. For Europes woes have all the aspects of a classical Greek tragedy, in which a man of noble character is undone by the fatal flaw of hubris.

title: From Ryans Lips to Belichicks Ears
description: Just about everyone has dissected Rex Ryans Monday news conference. It was the usual Ryan bluster, and yet, reading the whole thing can still blow you away.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MERGERS AND ACQUISITIONS

title: Move Over, WALL-E:  Puttering Along Power Lines
description: Inspecting power lines more closely would reduce the number of times the lights go out, but the job is tedious and hazardous for workers and expensive for utilities because the lines often run far from roads and through mountains, forests and deserts. Soon, though, the Electric Power Research Institute hopes to farm the job out, to robots.

title: Palin Calls Criticism Blood Libel
description: 1:13 p.m. | Updated Sarah Palin, who had been silent for days, issued a forceful denunciation of her critics on Wednesday in a video statement that accused pundits and journalists of blood libel in what she called their rush to blame heated political rhetoric for the shootings in Arizona.

title: Morning Buzz | City Accused of Overbilling Medicaid
description: The city was blanketed with up to nine inches of snow Tuesday night, but it appeared to have stopped by Wednesday morning. There is a slight chance for more as the day goes on. The temperature should reach a high of around 30, with partly cloudy skies.

title: Chinese Authorities Raze an Artists Studio
description: BEIJING  The studio would have stood at the heart of an embryonic arts cluster on the outskirts of Shanghai, a draw for luminaries from around the world.

title: Few Takers for the Shingles Vaccine
description: The good news about the shingles vaccine, recommended for all adults age 60 or older with normal immune systems, is that it works even better than scientists first thought.

title: Top 10 Composers: Which 20th-Century Masters Will Make the Cut?
description: Over the next two weeks Anthony Tommasini is exploring the qualities that make a classical composer great, maybe even the best of all time. Watch videos and vote for your own top 10 here and read previous posts here and share your thoughts in the comments field. Mr. Tommasinis final list will be posted on Jan. 21.

title: Demand Media Gives Price Range for I.P.O.
description: Demand Media, the online content publisher, disclosed on Wednesday that it hoped to raise up to $138 million in its planned initial public stock offering.

title: Fincher on Black Swan, Oscar Campaigning and Forced Vacations
description: Sometimes the gods of reporting  otherwise known as the Peggy Siegal planning committee  smile upon you, and you find yourself sitting next to David Fincher at a lunch at the Four Seasons. (Justin Timberlake was apparently not available.)

title: Fabulous Dead People | Beverley Nichols
description: If you are any sort of gardener at all, you know that this is the time of year, when hoar frost is on the twig, that held the greatest charm for Beverley Nichols. The most amusing garden writer of all times, Nichols (1898-1985), who specialized in winter flowers, regularly crescendoed to the point where he could literally have you laughing out loud. Here he is fatally associating cyclamens, those vulgar, obvious plants whose seeds failed to grow for him after 10 weeks in pots, with tiresome women who live in flats with electric stoves and indigestion and a Pekingese snoring in the scullery.

title: Peyton Manning Deserves a Better Coach
description: The Brady/Manning debate has been raging for years. The arguments can be interesting. Peyton has the stats, the M.V.P. awards and a superior Saturday Night Live appearance.

title: Bond, Ad Agency Stalwart, Will Lead Social Media Agency
description: In another sign of the growing role that social media is playing on Madison Avenue, Jonathan Bond, long a leading executive in the realm of traditional agencies, is becoming the head of an agency specializing in social media.

title: Geithner Urges New Start for U.S.-China Relations
description: WASHINGTON  Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner on Wednesday suggested a fresh start in relations between the United States and China, aimed at mutually beneficial economic growth.

title: Other Goalies Help Keep Islanders Net Covered
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Three pairs of leg pads  one orange, one blue, one white  sat in a corner of the Islanders dressing room Tuesday, undisturbed during another morning skate. The pads owner, goaltender Rick DiPietro, is hurt again, this time with a strained groin muscle.

title: Early Doubts About Whether Tax Credits Stimulate Investment
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: ITT, the Ever-Shrinking Conglomerate
description: The news that ITT is splitting into three companies is a coda to what has been perhaps the biggest and longest-running fragmentation of an American corporation ever.

title: Protests Spread to Tunisias Capital, and a Curfew Is Decreed
description: TUNIS  The government of Tunisia scrambled alternately to appease critics and to crush growing unrest on Wednesday as a three-week-old wave of violent demonstrations spread for the first time to the capital, where swarms of protesters called for the ouster of the authoritarian president, Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali.

title: Fitness Goals: Run. Race. Beat the Boyfriend.
description: When I look at a fresh calendar and start penciling in races, a lot of things factor into what makes the cut. Did I run the race last year? Do I want to tackle a challenging new course? Is it close to home, or somewhere I want to travel to? Whats the fee? Does it have a cool medal or T-shirt?

title: Same Street, Different Storm: Plowed
description: If the block of Butler Street in Park Slope, Brooklyn, that feeds off the one-way alley called Gregory Place is any indicator, the city has been a bit more prompt in clearing the snow than it was last month. (See below.)

title: Haiti: The Shattered Year
description: After a year of almost unfathomable hardship in Haiti, more than a million displaced people still live under tents and tarpaulins, and reconstruction has barely begun.

title: Gift Horse
description: The Turkish jeweler Sevan Bicakci was motivated by both myth and hard reality when making this one-of-a-kind pair of sterling, 24-karat gold and diamond earrings. At once a representation of Poseidons magnificent chariot horses and a tribute to Turkeys Mount Ida, which figures prominently in Greek mythology as the site from which the gods watched the Trojan War, the sparkly steeds are also a protest against modern-day mining on the resources-rich site. I know this sounds odd coming from a jeweler, Bicakci says, but the natural treasure of Ida is much more valuable than gold. The earrings are $16,860 at Barneys New York.

title: Wednesday Reading: Bargain Skiing
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: JPMorgan Unit Downgrades Goldman
description: Goldman Sachs is trying to put its best foot forward, with the Tuesday release of a report on ways to improve its disclosure and business practices, but analysts at a JPMorgan unit in London have lowered their rating on the firm.

title: Bill Murray Shows Them How Its Done
description: There was a celebrity pile-up, as usual, at the National Board of Review gala on Tuesday night: Sofia Coppola, Aaron Sorkin and Ben Affleck working the red carpet at the same time, Jon Hamm chatting with Chris Cooper, Hailee Steinfeld and Jennifer Lawrence  the 14- and 20-year-old stars and only representatives from their films, True Grit and Winters Bone  meeting for the first time and bonding across tables. Even among actors, there was gawking to spare: when Bill Murray took the stage, Armie Hammer, the 65 blond star of The Social Network, took photos from his seat.

title: Morgan Stanley Raises Nearly a Billion for a New Debt Fund
description: Morgan Stanley Investment Management announced on Wednesday that it had raised $956 million for a new fund that invests in corporate mezzanine debt, a bright spot for alternative investments over the last year.

title: Snowfall Blankets Region
description: A giant amoeba-shaped storm ripped across the southeastern seaboard Wednesday.

title: A Warning as Markets Cool in Asia
description: MUMBAI, India  Stock markets in India and a handful of other, smaller Asian countries, which surged last year as foreign investors bet on their fast growth, are starting to remind investors of the risks involved.

title: What Were Reading
description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.

title: Boehner Shows Emotion in House Remarks on Tucson Violence
description: 6:35 p.m. | Updated With tears falling and his throat choked with emotion, Speaker John A. Boehner addressed the House on Wednesday, denouncing the violence in Tucson on Saturday that left six people dead and 14 wounded, including Representative Gabrielle Giffords.

title: Mixed Welcome at Michigan for New Coach
description: College footballs wine-and-cheese crowd is staring balefully at the bottom of its collective glass today, aimlessly fingering the last scraps of Brie and muttering to themselves, Brady Hoke? Seriously?

title: Suicide Bomber Strikes in Northwest Pakistan
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A suicide bomber struck in a tribal area of northwestern Pakistan on Wednesday, ramming his explosives-laden vehicle into a mosque adjacent to a police station that has come under frequent attack in the last few months, a security official said.

title: Vain Glorious | A Flawless Entrance
description: What: Clarins Instant Smooth Line Correcting Concentrate

title: Phonemance
description: Term for small business owners (and, presumably, others) who spend more time clasping their phones than the hands of their lover.

title: Live Reunion Planned for Warwick and Her Friends
description: Stevie Wonder, Elton John, Gladys Knight and Dionne Warwick will reunite for a live performance on Feb. 9 of the song Thats What Friends Are For at amfARs New York Gala benefit at Cipriani Wall Street, the foundation has announced. The song, which was a No. 1 single in 1986, was originally written by Carole Bayer Sager and Burt Bacharach and was released by Arista as a benefit single for amfAR, the Foundation for AIDS Research. It raised $3 million for the foundation, after Ms. Warwick gathered the writers and artists, who offered to donate their portion of profits from the recording. Clive Davis, the president of Arista, also agreed to donate all profits. In addition to the special performance next month, amfAR will honor former President Bill Clinton; Diane von Furstenberg; and two of the foundations co-founders, Dr. Mathilde Krim and Elizabeth Taylor.

title: Part 2: Answers to Readers Questions on Financial Aid
description: Now that most students applying to college for next falls freshman class have submitted their applications, they (and their families) will begin to tackle the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, or Fafsa.

title: Geithners China Concerns
description: Timothy F. Geithner, the Treasury secretary, gave a speech on China Wednesday morning that did not contain news but was somewhat feistier in tone than the Obama administration has been in the past. This approach  respectful yet blunt  strikes me as more promising than the deferential stance the administration has sometimes adopted before.

title: Fight Over Obama Hope Image Is Settled
description: The street artist Shepard Fairey and The Associated Press have ended their long-running legal battle over whether Mr. Fairey violated copyright protections in using one of the news cooperatives photographs as the basis for the well-known Hope campaign poster of Barack Obama.

title: Make Your Own 3D Videos
description: Want to double your fun with a new camcorder? Consider a pair of 3D digicams from those dueling rivals, Sony and Panasonic.

title: Amerons Directors Defend Its Chief
Obama Image Copyright Case Is Settled
description: The Associated Press and the artist Shepard Fairey have settled their copyright battle over the unlicensed use by Mr. Fairey of an A.P. photograph of Barack Obama in the memorable 2008 Hope poster. The A.P. announced the settlement on Wednesday.

title: Police Stopped Loughners Car on Day of Shooting
description: TUCSON  Jared L. Loughner had repeated contact with law enforcement officers over the years, and hours before Saturdays shootings was pulled over by a police officer for running a red light as he frenetically prepared to kill a congresswoman, the authorities said Wednesday.

title: Nurse and Doctor, Neighbor and Friend
description: Something there is that doesnt love a wall, begins Robert Frosts poem Mending Wall, about two neighbors who meet to repair the gaps and holes in the stone wall separating their properties. They walk on either side of it, picking up and replacing fallen stones as they go.

title: A (Very Hectic) Day in the Life of Andrew Garfield
description: Accepting his award for best actor at the National Board of Review gala on Tuesday, Jesse Eisenberg revealed that he was intimidated by his co-star Andrew Garfield, who came prepared for the second day of rehearsal for The Social Network with a copy of Business for Dummies. (His character, Eduardo Saverin, was a business major; Mr. Eisenberg, who plays Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg, added that he went out and bought a copy of C++ for Dummies to bone up on coding, and that neither actor read past the introductions.)

title: Archie to Go Digital
description: Archie Andrews, the perpetual teenager from Riverdale, is taking another step into the future. Beginning in April, Archie Comics will offer digital versions of its comics on the same day that the print editions arrive on newsstands. The company will be starting with six monthly titles: Archie, Archie & Friends, Betty, Veronica, Betty and Veronica, and Jughead.

title: Resolved: Be a Smarter Negotiator
description: This week on the Bucks blog, our contributors, along with some of our favorite sources, are posting about their financial resolutions for the new year. Here, Jennifer Saranow Schultz, the lead blogger for Bucks, shares her plans.

title: On Last Field Day, a South Pole Detour
description: Jeff Vervoort, left, an associate professor in radiogenic isotope geochemistry at Washington State University, and John Goodge, a professor of geological sciences at the University of Minnesota-Duluth, are writing from their research expedition in Antarctica.

title: Pyrrhic Bond Auctions
description: Im with Calculated Risk here: it says something about the sheer desperation of the European situation that Portugals ability to sell 10-year bonds at an interest rate of only 6.7 percent is considered a success. If you think about the debt dynamics here  the burden of growing interest payments on an economy that is likely to face years of grinding debt deflation  an interest rate that high is little short of ruinous. But it is, indeed, not as bad as people were expecting last week; hence, success.

title: Rallying for a Bill, With Sermons and Songs
description: When members of the City Council want Speaker Christine C. Quinn to call a hearing on a piece of legislation, they have a few options. They can try to cut a deal; they can issue a few dozen press releases; they can nag.

title: Sleep No More Finds Room in Chelsea
description: The British theater company Punchdrunk plans to bring Sleep No More, its site-specific Hitchcock-Shakespeare mash-up, to the former McKittrick Hotel building on West 27th Street in Chelsea this spring.

title: Quote Unquote | Unplugged
description: The Lanvin designer Alber Elbaz tells New York Magazine how he survives without an e-mail address. Hello Alber, sending you an Evite to 2011 asap.

title: E.P.A. Puts Off Regulating Biomass for Now
description: Acknowledging large unknowns about the atmospheric impact of burning large amounts of plant waste and other biological materials, the Environmental Protection Agency announced on Wednesday that it would delay for three years any greenhouse gas permitting requirements for biomass.

title: Colbert Enlists Bands in Sell Out to Madison Avenue
description: The discussion of whether bands and music acts are co-opted by Madison Avenue when they allow their songs to be used in commercials has evolved over the years.

title: The Political Consequences of Violence
description: I believe that The New Yorkers George Packer has mistaken the meaning of a line in my column this week. He writes:

title: House Honors Victims and Weighs Its Next Steps
description: WASHINGTON  Shaken by the attempted assassination of their colleague, Gabrielle Giffords, and the killing of one of her aides, House members reconvened at the Capitol on Wednesday to honor the dead and the wounded in the Arizona shooting rampage and to begin reviewing security concerns with law enforcement officials.

title: TD Ameritrade Backfield in Motion
description: Joe Moglia, the chairman of the discount broker TD Ameritrade, is switching teams.

title: Cold Case: Burning the Store
description: Bill Frasier recounts what Arthur Leonard Spencer told him about the night he helped burn down Frank Morris's store. Mr. Spencer denies involvement. Footage: Civil Rights Cold Case Project (Copyright 2010). www.coldcases.org

title: Does Moderation Work?
description: Gail Collins: David, we cant not talk about the shootings in Tucson. I know youve been wanting a more moderate and sane political dialogue. But I am sorry to admit that one of my thoughts is that the aftermath of Tucson proves how moderation doesnt work.

title: Better Than Blu-ray?
description: To get the best picture quality from your 1080p-capable HDTV, you need to watch content emanating from a Blu-ray disc; only Blu-ray can deliver the 1080p resolution that your TV can potentially display.

title: Tights, Cape and Shovel. Todays Perfect Superhero.
description: Right around sunrise, Nick Lowe, 31, a senior editor of X-Men comic books at Marvel Comics was shoveling the sidewalk in front of the two-story house his apartment is in on 29th Street in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Tough Options for Family Business in a Tailspin
description: FIRST QUALITY MUSIC is a family-owned supplier of stringed musical instruments, including guitars and mandolins, and parts and accessories. Founded in Louisville, Ky., in 1970, the company also makes banjos and game calls for hunters. The nine-employee operation includes a retail showroom, a small banjo factory and a warehouse with inventory for online and mail-order purchases.

title: Grants Will Spread Work by Living Legends of Jazz
description: Fifteen nonprofit organizations nationwide will receive National Endowment for the Arts grants totaling $250,000 to take living legends of jazz  including Dave Brubeck, Paquito DRivera, Jimmy Heath and Randy Weston  to communities for education and performances. Rocco Landesman, chairman of the N.E.A., announced the grants on Wednesday through the program Jazz Masters Live.

title: ITT Chief: Breakup Plan Didnt Come Lightly
description: Steven R. Loranger, chief executive of ITT.

title: Reporter on Quest to Close 1964 Civil Rights Case
description: ATLANTA  Stanley Nelson writes for a small weekly newspaper in the Louisiana delta. For the past four years, he has been obsessed with one story: who threw gasoline into a rural shoe repair and dry goods shop in 1964 and started a fire that killed Frank Morris?

title: Would You Pay $170,000 for a Consultant?
description: A case study weve just published details the dilemma faced by First Quality Music, which is a family-owned supplier of stringed musical instruments, including guitars and mandolins, along with parts and accessories. Founded in 1970 in Louisville, Ky., the company also makes its own banjos as well as game calls for hunters. The nine-employee operation includes a retail showroom, a small banjo factory and a warehouse that holds inventory for online and mail-order purchases.

title: On Our Radar: A Climate-Change Fingerprint in Australia?
description: Climate change may be partly responsible for the intensity of the floods inundating the eastern Australian city of Brisbane, scientists say. [Reuters]

title: Suspect in Livery Shooting Is Connected to Armed Robberies
description: The suspect in the shooting of a livery driver in Queens last month was charged on Wednesday with six other armed robberies last year that depict a one-man crime wave mostly targeting fast food restaurants throughout the borough in the summer and fall.

title: Compatibility Questions for High-Voltage E.V. Charging
description: Electric cars already on the American market, as well as those arriving soon, all use the same onboard charging port because of SAE International, the professional organization for automotive engineers that approved the reigning J1772 standard. The standard was adopted early last year.

title: Under The Radar Review: Diciembre
description: Even if youre overstuffed and partied-out from last months Yuletide marathon, you should still try to make the acquaintance of one special ghost of Christmas future now haunting the Under the Radar Festival. In the Teatro en el Blancos Diciembre (yes, thats Spanish for December), Guillermo Calderon envisions December 25 in Chile in 2014. And if the view aint pretty, it is highly picturesque  a witty, sharply focused vision of a time well past celebration.

title: Commercializing Greenhouse Gas Data
description: As I noted in Wednesdays Times, the company that brought the world WeatherBug is making what would seem a rather natural move into greenhouse gas monitoring  and pioneering a whole new market in the process.

title: Just One Look | Cline Pre-Fall Collection
description: The Pre-Fall Collections, being shown in New York over the next several weeks, arrive in stores in May to fill the gap between bikinis and furs.

title: Fort Tryon Park, Manhattan, 9:56 A.M.
description: Edwardo Binet, 15, left, who is visiting New York from Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, posed for his friend Alejandro Pontir, 25, in Fort Tryon Park in Manhattan, as proof to his family that he was there for the snowstorm, the second of his life.

title: Does a Bad Job Market Lead to More Discrimination?
description: As I noted in an article today, discrimination charges filed with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission jumped last year, reaching a record high of 99,922.

title: Homes for $330,000
description: A midcentury modern in Arizona, a log home in Kentucky and a Craftsman in Texas.

title: An Islamic View of Parenting
description: InCultureParent.com is an online magazine featuring articles on parenting around the world. It was created because, says founder Stephanie Meade, culture informs parenting choices, priorities and values. Additionally, tradition and religion become more relevant when children enter the picture.

title: Strutting Their Stuff
description: The auto show conveyed a sense of optimism for the industry in the aftermath of the economic downturn.

title: Porsche 918 RSR and Audi A6 Deliver Design Awards Sweep to VW Group
description: DETROIT  The Porsche 918 RSR and Audi A6 won the 2011 EyesOn Design Awards, presented as snow swirled snow outside late on Tuesday afternoon. The awards go to vehicles introduced at the show.

title: What You Get for ... $330,000
description: SCOTTSDALE, ARIZ.

title: In R.N.C. Battle, the Other Barbour Steps Out
description: YAZOO CITY, Miss.  Theres not much left between Henry Barbours house and the horizon. Since the tornado came through here last April, the house has sat on a bare hill, looking out over the meager remains of the surrounding woods.

title: New Emergency Standards Are Recommended for Broadway
description: The New York City Fire Department should work closely with Broadway theater owners, producers, and employees to develop new preparedness and training standards for emergencies like the attempted car bombing last May in Times Square, according to a report [pdf] of the New York State Assemblys subcommittee on workplace safety, chaired by Queens Assemblyman Rory Lancman.

title: Pitti Uomo | Day 1
description: The fall/winter 2011 edition of Pitti Uomo, a biannual mens trade show held in Florence, Italy, started off with a flurry of parties around town, with folks spilling from shopfronts into the citys rain-slicked cobblestone streets.

title: This Coolness Debate Is Brought to You by the Fonz
description: A sprinkling of links for your afternoon reading pleasure.

title: Belarus Intensifies Efforts Against Former Candidate
description: MOSCOW  As Belarussian diplomats scrambled on Wednesday to assuage European concerns about the sweeping crackdown on dissent in their country, the authorities in Belarus were stepping up their campaign against the family of a former presidential candidate whose 3-year-old son they have threatened to seize.

title: F1 Goes High Definition
description: The Autosport Web site broke the story first, and then the BBC confirmed it: Formula One will be broadcast in high definition this year.

title: F1 Goes High Definition
description: The Autosport Web site broke the story first, and then the BBC confirmed it: Formula One will be broadcast in high definition this year.

title: A Year at War: Updates, and a New Voice
description: A Year at War

title: Despite Soft Sales, Taylor Swift Keeps Top Spot
description: Taylor Swifts Speak Now is at No. 1 for the sixth week on the Billboard album chart this week. But the weekly sales figures have earned it what Billboard.com calls the dubious honor of having the lowest sales  52,000 copies  for a No. 1 album since Nielsen SoundScan began keeping track in 1991. The previous low was set by the Dreamgirls soundtrack on the Jan., 27, 2007, chart, with slightly more than 60,000 albums sold. Back to 2011: Nicki Minajs Pink Friday climbed to No. 2 with 39,000, and Bruno Mars moved up a spot to No. 3 with Doo-Wops & Hooligans, which sold 38,000. Daft Punks Tron: Legacy soundtrack is fourth with sales of 34,000, and Eminems Recovery slipped three notches to No. 5, with sales of 33,000.

title: Early Facebook Investor Is Bullish on New York
description: Long before Goldman Sachs sunk hundreds of millions of dollars into Facebook at a soaring $50 billion valuation, an Accel partner, Jim Breyer, made a controversial bet on a Harvard dropout.

title: Remote Access Made Easy
description: Simple and wireless: we love encountering those two words in product description.

title: The Hazards of the Couch
description: Many of us sit in front of a computer for eight hours a day, and then go home and head for the couch to surf the Web or watch television, exchanging one seat and screen for another. Even if we try to squeeze in an hour at the gym, is it enough to counteract all that motionless sitting?

title: 10 Years After 9/11, Deutsche Bank Tower Vanishes
description: The 41-story former Deutsche Bank building opposite the World Trade Center site is now the one-story former Deutsche Bank building.

title: The Flexibility of Meatball Ingredients
description: My wife, Jackie, and I were grinding beef, veal, pork and prosciutto to make meatballs, enjoying the background aroma of finely chopped vegetables sweating in olive oil. There were a number of routes we could take at this point. Meatballs as planned, or meatloaf, or any of various varieties of rag: all could be made from the same blend of meats and the same aromatic mixture of onions, carrots, celery and garlic, with sage and parsley.

title: The Doctrine of Immaculate Transfer
description: Dave Altig at the Atlanta Fed weighs in on Martin Feldsteins much-quoted paper arguing that the United States and China will soon reduce or eliminate their current account imbalances. I think its worth saying a bit more about this, because theres a common fallacy here  not one Feldstein has fallen into, but which many others do. And talking about that fallacy is also a way to see why current yuan policy is a problem for the world.

title: U.A.W. to Renew Organizing Efforts at Foreign-Owned Plants
description: DETROIT  The United Automobile Workers union this year is renewing its effort to organize workers at plants that foreign automakers operate in the United States and will portray companies that resist as human rights violators, the unions president said Wednesday.

title: Moonlight Clan
description: Youths in China who spend all of their monthly salary.

title: Just One Look | Rochas Pre-Fall Collection
description: The Pre-Fall Collections, being shown in New York over the next several weeks, arrive in stores in May to fill the gap between bikinis and furs.Trunk shows for Rochas regularly bring in 25-year-old princesses as well as ladies of a certain age. And it was easy to see how Marco Zaninis 30s-inspired pre-fall collection could charm both ends of the spectrum. Standouts included cocoon coats, jersey dresses with subtle sunburst pleats and a new brocade adapted from a pattern in a very old book of wallpaper samples. I love to add unusual touches to the very French allure of Rochas, Zanini said. This time, why not play a little with Bloomsbury romance?

title: Washington Basketball Player Accused of Sexual Assault
description: Lorenzo Romar, coach of the Washington mens basketball team, acknowledged Tuesday that one of his players was being investigated by the police in Seattle after an accusation of sexual assault by a 16-year-old girl. The police have not identified the player and have not filed charges. Romar addressed the investigation with reporters at his regular weekly news conference, but said he could not provide any specifics.

title: 8 Hotels to Look Out for in 2011
description: THE global economic forecast may be dim, but travelers can look forward to distinctiveness among the class of 2011 hotel openings. In Hong Kong, the citys tallest skyscraper will become home to a hotel. In India, a resort made of box-shaped tents will take shape. And in New York, a Latin import will have its debut. These and three other newcomers aim to inspire travel strictly for the in-house amenities, activities and design.

title: How Cold Is It? Enough to Make Long Johns Stylish
description: IT was one thing, while picking through the detritus of fall fashion for end-of-season bargains, to discover that Club Monaco has been trying to convince men that the latest things to be wearing are long johns. There were waffle-knit thermals, thin-ribbed sweats and, displayed boldly on one mannequin, a very expensive cashmere onesie in a navy-and-white Fair Isle knit.

title: Streaming Video to an iPad
Tunisians Document Protests Online
description: Updated | 10:55 p.m. As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports from Tunisia, protesters there have been using the Web to organize demonstrations and spread news of violent clashes with the security forces in recent weeks.

title: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
description: 1. Tom DeLay gets three years. Cue frantic Tweeting from @TheHammerInTheSlammer.

title: Hero of Ukraine Prize to Wartime Partisan Leader Is Revoked
description: MOSCOW  President Viktor F. Yanukovich of Ukraine announced Wednesday that a national award bestowed on one of the most divisive figures in the countrys modern history  a leader of the Ukrainian partisans during World War II  had been officially revoked.

title: A Photo Finish for Warmest Year on Record
description: 4:35 p.m. | Updated NASA has just come out with its temperature numbers for 2010, and they match the NOAA analysis, showing a tie between 2010 and 2005 for hottest year on record. The NASA analysis can be found here.

title: One Year Later: Studying Post-Earthquake Haiti
description: Overview  | What can we learn from natural disasters like earthquakes, and from the quake that devastated Haiti in 2010? In this lesson, students review the Haiti earthquake, reflect on the changes that have occurred since then and develop personal responses. They engage in one or more projects in which they explore the implications of the disaster from the perspectives of science, engineering, health, history, arts and culture, and the media.

title: Can 140 Characters Matter?
description: I came to appreciate Twitter slowly and grudgingly. Like many I was put off, given the existing fire hoses blasting me with information, by what seemed a conduit for trivia. Thats changed. Ive realized its still early days for this and related experiments that are knitting the world of ideas and eyeballs. Its not the noosphere yet, but

title: General Motors Trucks Investigated for Rusting Brake Lines
description: Expressing concern about rusting brake lines rupturing and causing crashes, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has intensified an investigation into almost 1.8 million General Motors pickups and S.U.V.s.

title: How to Dig Through the Avalanche in App Marts
description: App stores are fine if you trust the stores recommendations on big categories like music or games. But one of the best things about owning a smartphone is the apps for your personal hobbies.

title: Founder of Civility Project Calls It Quits
description: Just as Americans are debating whether untamed political rhetoric inspired the shooting of a congresswoman in Arizona, the founder of a project to promote civility in politics is calling it quits because only three elected members of Congress agreed to sign a rudimentary Civility Pledge.

title: Answers About Getting Organized, Part II
description: Barbara Reich, a professional organizer who was the subject of a recent Metropolitan article by Elissa Gootman, is taking readers questions this week. The following are her second batch of answers to readers questions. You can ask a question here, and find previous and subsequent installments of this Q. and A. here.

title: Directors Honor Oscar-Snubbed Documentary
description: While it wont find a spot in the Oscar nominee list, the documentary Last Train Home is getting some recognition from the Directors Guild of America. Following migrant factory workers who make a harrowing annual journey back to visit their home villages in China, Lixin Fans film is the only feature the D.G.A. nominated for best documentary that is not also on the Oscars shortlist. Last Train Home has, however, made a number of critics year-end lists, including our own.

title: Glenn Beck Weighs In on Spider-Man
description: Radio host, novelist, thriller-writers friend, sure. But Glenn Beck, theater critic?

title: Conan Talks About Ratings, Leno and NBC
description: PASADENA, Ca. Conan OBrien had a brief message on Wednesday about his relocation from NBC to the cable channel TBS: Everything has worked out great for me.

title: Shepard Fairey and The A.P. Settle Legal Dispute
description: The street artist Shepard Fairey and The Associated Press have settled their long-running legal battle over the well-known Hope campaign poster of Barack Obama.
