title: Shopping With Rinat Aruh and Johan Liden
description: The founders of Aruliden, a product design and marketing firm in Manhattan, went shopping in search of hooks and racks for outerwear.

title: TimesCast | January 12, 2011
description: Hezbollah resigns from Lebanon's government; the man who tackled Jared L. Loughner is haunted by memories of the shooting; and Sarah Palin responds to the attack.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: Pumping Stocks Jesse Eisinger asks: Is what 50 Cent did really that different from what happens all day long on CNBC when professional money managers take to the airwaves to praise the stocks of companies they already own?Pro Publica

title: 3D Sound for a 3D TV
description: While 3D TVs were everywhere at the Consumer Electronics Show, the audio software company DTS was demonstrating 3D audio.

title: Why Does Inequality Make the Rich Feel Poorer?
description: Catherine Rampell has a very nice piece about why the objectively rich feel poor, although Brad DeLong is right, a log-income chart is better:

title: The Wow Factor of 3-D Printing
description: People who can take a hunk of wood or lump of clay and fashion something fantastic with their bare hands have powers of creation that I dont quite understand.

title: Real Life Intrudes on The Fighter
description: There is good news and bad news for the folks behind The Fighter today.

title: Google Takes On Yelp With New Mobile App
description: Last year, Google tried to buy Yelp, the local business rating and review site. Since then, it has focused on building its own Yelp competitor with Google Places and Hotpot.

title: Christie Says Palin Needs to Go Unscripted to Contend for 2012
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey says its way too early to handicap the field of his fellow Republicans who might run for president in 2012, but on Wednesday he voiced a few sharp words about the most famous one.

title: To Play Better Against Attractive Women, Men Need to Avert Their Eyes
description: Do men get distracted by and play differently against attractive women than against other opponents? Yes, according to a study by Swedish researchers.

title: Washingtons Young Tests the Hot Hand Theory
description: Nick Young took a prime opportunity - an overtime game against one of the leagues worst defenses - and made a great night out of it. The Wizards barely nudged by the Kings in Tuesday nights game, but that was no fault of Young, who poured in a career-high 43 points on 14-of-22 shooting. Young was insanely efficient (to score 43 points on 22 shots is a ridiculous accomplishment) even though his game was clearly oriented to the perimeter; as is typically the case with Young, he subsisted on long jumpers. The only difference was that on Tuesday night, Young put up a ton of attempts from behind the three-point line (more than twice his season average in three-point attempts), and that regardless of where he shot from, Young made everything.

title: The Arrival of the Verizon iPhone
description: So. Wow. After all these years, after all the pundits cried wolf year after year, Verizon is finally going to offer the iPhone, starting next month.

title: In Nielsens Public Offering, a Bellwether for Buyout Firms
description: Over the next two weeks, executives at the market researcher Nielsen will traverse the United States and Europe to sell big investors on its $1.5 billion offering, putting it on track to become the first major company backed by private equity to go public this year.

title: Tech Show Surprises, and the Stale
description: The star of this years Consumer Electronics Show wasnt even there.

title: Thats Rapide, With an R
description: A campaign to introduce the Rapide, a four-door Aston Martin, is taking an unconventional tack that crosses The Hire, the classic series of Web films for BMW, with The Twilight Zone.

title: National Parks are Free This Weekend
description: The National Park Service is waiving fees this weekend for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. federal holiday and on several other dates this year, the Interior Secretary, Ken Salazar, recently announced.

title: Lady Gaga and Others Come to Android Phones
description: People are watching more and more YouTube videos on their cellphones  200 million a day, to be exact, triple the number they watched a year ago.

title: Expectations Are Made to Be Upended
description: Rene Fleming could fill Carnegie Hall for a song recital no matter what program she offered. She surely knows this. So why not upend expectations, explore exotic repertory and present an unusual selection of songs that suit her distinctive soprano voice and engage her keen musical curiosity?

title: Using Time, and Timeouts, Wisely
description: By some accounts, the turning point of the drum-tight playoff game between the Jets and the Colts last weekend was not a catch or a throw, a run or a kick. It was a misused timeout.

title: Blood Libel in the Pages of History
description: In offering a forceful denunciation of what she called blood libel by pundits and journalists, Sarah Palin tapped into a phrase loaded with religious symbolism and historically fraught with emotional baggage.

title: A Shoe and Fake Punches (but Few Sparks) Fly in a Night of Argentine Tango
description: Instead of achieving sexy, the five couples in the Tango Fire Company of Buenos Aires opt for tricks and shtick. Sensuality, sadly, is out of the question. Here acrobatic lifts are similar to what you might glimpse in pairs figure skating  the dancers may be tenacious, but skill level and flexibility varies  and the costumes are just as tawdry.

title: Pronger Makes a Speedy Comeback
description: Opposing forwards beware: bruising Philadephia Flyers defenseman Chris Pronger is healthy and a step away from returning to game action.

title: The Life and Passions of an American Activist
description: The actor and educator Bern Cohen looks a lot like the political activist Abbie Hoffman, whom he portrays in Abbie, the one-man show he wrote and helped produce, now at the West End Theater. So much so, according to the productions publicity material, that Mr. Cohen, a former high school principal who has acted in feature films, was arrested in the 1970s in Ohio, where he was mistaken for Hoffman. In visual terms, you couldnt ask for a better meeting of subject and performer.

title: Spam Is Back
description: A holiday hiatus for spammers appears to be over.

title: Artifacts | The Veil Lifts
description: Los Angeles is a museum-proud city, and Eli Broads name is all over it. The doors of the Museum of Contemporary Art, which the billionaire philanthropist helped to found in 1979, might not be open today if not for him. The Los Angeles County Museum of Art has a Broad Museum of Contemporary Art within it. Theres the Broad Art Center at UCLA and a Broad Art Foundation in Venice. Even the California Department of Transportations building downtown has the Broad Plaza for public art.

title: Forecast for the Ride Home: Unremarkable
description: Wednesday proved a resilient day for the regions mass transit network, and most afternoon commuters should expect an unremarkable ride home.

title: This Bowl of Cherries Offers Food for Thought
description: A sneak attack: thats what you might call the moment in Christine Ebersoles brilliant new show at the Caf Carlyle when the merriment pauses, and she delivers a riveting dramatic performance of Another Winter in a Summer Town. With music by Scott Frankel and lyrics by Michael Korie, the song is a crushing moment of self-awareness and an acknowledgment of personal defeat by Little Edie Beale, whom Ms. Ebersole portrayed in the Broadway musical Grey Gardens.

title: Pictures of the Day: Australia and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Australia, Haiti, India and Washington.

title: Italy and Others Cited for Illegal Fishing
description: Vessels from six nations, including Italy, engaged in illegal fishing on the high seas in 2009 and 2010, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration reported to Congress on Wednesday.

title: Death of an Art House Means a Start to a Life
description: A Useful Life, Federico Veirojs sneaky second feature, chronicles the death throes of a small independent movie theater in Montevideo, Uruguay, through the sad eyes of Jorge, its longtime programmer. As played by the Uruguayan film critic Jorge Jellinek (who resembles a less scary Alfred Molina), Jorge is portly and indoors pale, a middle-aged slab of calm and competence.

title: Chinaberry Sidewalks
description: Chapter 1

title: Voice and Career That Always Said, It Might as Well Be Spring
description: A largely overlooked pleasure of Nora Ephrons 2009 film Julie & Julia, is the rich, sensual voice of the young Margaret Whiting, singing the Sammy Cahn-Jule Styne standard Time After Time over the end title credits. Immediately after seeing the film I telephoned a friend of Ms. Whitings, who told her about it. Until then she had no idea that her recording was used in the film. The friend reported back her tearfully overjoyed amazement. She hadnt been forgotten. It meant everything.

title: Sad and True Love Story, Worthy of Its Soundtrack
description: Rodney Crowells parents met in 1941 at a Roy Acuff concert in a high school in Buchanan, Tenn. I knew right then and there he was the boy I was gonna marry, Addie Cauzette Willoughby said about J. W. Crowell. I loved Roy Acuff, but I couldnt hear a word he was singin after your daddy showed up, Mr. Crowells mother would tell her son.

title: Increase in Arizona Handgun Checks
description: The F.B.I. said on Wednesday that federal background checks on people in Arizona seeking to buy handguns had increased sharply since Saturdays shooting rampage in Tucson that left six people dead and Representative Gabrielle Giffords fighting for her life.

title: Thats Rapide, With an R
description: From our colleagues at the Media Decoder blog:

title: 'The Importance of Being Earnest'
description: Brian Bedford and David Furr in a scene from the Broadway revival of Oscar Wilde's play at the American Airlines Theater. (Video courtesy of the Roundabout Theater Company)

title: New Names On Jazzs Honor Roll
description: Accepting his 2011 NEA Jazz Masters award at the Rose Theater on Tuesday night, the pianist Ellis Marsalis noted the privilege of standing alongside his fellow honorees, both past and passed on. He paused to reflect on those who died last year  the pianists Hank Jones and Billy Taylor, the singer Abbey Lincoln and the saxophonist James Moody  before joining four of his sons, all accomplished musicians, for a brightly buoyant finale. That transition put an emphasis on continuity, the passing of information from one generation to the next. It was a genuine jazz moment, and fittingly so in an evening full of them.

title: Another Film Bites a Hand In Hollywood
description: LOS ANGELES  You know youve made it in Hollywood when youre skewered on screen. If your behavior is over the top enough to stand out in an industry of wall-to-wall histrionics, its something of a badge of honor.

title: Gilbert to Head Juilliards Conducting Program
description: In one building at Lincoln Center the music director of the New York Philharmonic plies his trade and is by definition at the pinnacle of the conducting profession. Just across 65th Street, eager young conducting students at the Juilliard School toil and dream of big careers on the podium.

title: Looking Back at American Fashions Coming-Out Party
description: IN the annals of fashion smackdowns, few events have attained anything resembling the legendary status of the 1973 Grand Divertissement  Versailles. A stunt benefit ginned up by Eleanor Lambert, the publicist who invented the Best Dressed List, this fabled fashion show, promoted as a Franco-American collaboration, was always destined to be seen as a battle for dominance: the Old World slugging it out with the New, a muscular group of comers with Studio 54 as their shared point of reference taking on the fusty world of the haute couture.

title: Tipping When Service Is Bad
description: In response to recent Bucks guide on holiday tipping, one reader noted, I have never seen tipping guidelines for service personnel who disappoint you.

title: Those Clubs? Maybe Not So Useless After All
description: Playing in a pair event with both sides vulnerable, you pick up:

title: China, in a Shift, Takes On Its Alzheimers Problem
description: SHANGHAI  Last year, an expensive, red-brick residential complex opened here, equipped with a hair salon, cinema, toy-cluttered game rooms and a karaoke suite offering the latest in pop music.

title: Pushing Fashion Boundaries in an Era Without Any
description: THREE times this week Ive heard someone refer to a parallel world. The first was on Sunday, when the wife of a college friend said that she did not pay much attention to the celebrity-media culture. My friend, a real estate investor, and his wife, a doctor, had left Manhattan for Darien, Conn., shortly after 9/11 and were raising two girls in a neighborhood of two-story Colonials and adjoining lawns. I had the distinct sense that she did not mind not knowing who Snooki was (nor did her husband or their elder child, a polite and articulate eighth grader with braids), but also that at one time she did not feel quite so separated from mass culture.

title: The Time Is Right for Breaking Up
description: Another breakup wave is hastening the end for some conglomerates. Motorola, Fortune Brands and possibly Sara Lee are doing the splits. Now the ITT Corporation, an offshoot of a three-way division in 1995, is breaking in three again. The financial benefits of specialization have long been popular. But resurgent animal spirits explain the current swell of activity.

title: Beauty Spots
description: HAIR AND FEEDING This month, Shu Uemura Art of Hair (shuuemuraartofhair-usa.com) introduced a medium-hold styling product called Yokan Craft. Developed for short to medium-length hair, the jellylike substance is made with natural ingredients, including rice, green tea, honey and algae, and features a fragrance with a hint of juniper. Yokan Craft is also claimed to improve texture and sheen ($33).

title: USA Acquires 9/11 Film
description: Add to the list of buyers of arty film festival movies ... the USA Network? That top-rated cable channel stocks its schedule with slick and sexy original dramas (Royal Pains), reruns of popular shows like NCIS and major Hollywood movies. But Bonnie Hammer, the NBC Universal executive who runs USA, plans to announce on Thursday the channels first festival acquisition: The Space Between, a drama starring Melissa Leo as a flight attendant who forms a bond with a 10-year-old Pakistani-American boy traveling by himself on 9/11. (Ms. Leo, now generating Oscar buzz for her chain-smoking mother in The Fighter, is on something of a tear these days.) The Space Between, written and directed by Travis Fine, had its premiere in the spring at the Tribeca Film Festival. The purchase price was not disclosed.

title: Pictures of the Day: Australia and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Australia, Haiti, India and Washington.

title: Coil Festival: 5 Questions About Holiday
description: The Australian company Ranters Theater is making its American debut at the Coil Festival with Holiday. The setting for the show is pretty simple: accompanied by a Baroque score and video installation, two men consider life while sitting in and around a childrens pool.

title: Graying Men Choosing the Touch-Up
description: LIKE bartenders, hairstylists get an earful from regulars about their woes, and during the economic downturn Jeff Swaner, who owns Epic Salon in Los Angeles, has been hearing from middle-age men who lost their jobs.

title: The Fighter Was Rooting for Oregon
description: Chip Kelly, Oregons football coach, found inspiration in his friend and fellow New England native Micky Ward, a former junior-welterweight champion. Early in the season, he showed his team film of Ward in the ring. Ward also met with the players, most recently on Monday night, before the Ducks 22-19 loss to Auburn in the national championship game in Glendale, Ariz.

title: Expanding Vertically in Berlin
description: Karin Sander, a conceptual artist, added two floors an old factory in Berlin to create a flexible living-and-working space.

title: CBS Renews Big Bang
description: CBSs hit sitcom The Big Bang Theory has been renewed through the 2013-14 television season, the network and the shows studio, Warner Brothers, jointly announced on Wednesday. Big Bang, which started in 2007, was the top-rated scripted show on television last season among 18- to 49-year-old viewers, and its ratings are up about 15 percent in that demographic since being shifted last fall to Thursday nights from Monday. The stars of the show, Kaley Cuoco, Johnny Galecki and Jim Parsons, reportedly negotiated new contracts last fall that tripled their salaries, to roughly $200,000 each per episode.

title: NCIS Delivers for CBS
description: CBS dominated the ratings on Tuesday as NCIS delivered its largest audience ever, 21.9 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. The show easily outperformed its combined competitors at 8 p.m., including No Ordinary Family on ABC (5.4 million), Foxs rerun of Glee (4.7 million) and the first hour of The Biggest Loser on NBC, which averaged 8.7 million from 8 to 10. CBS led during the 9 and 10 p.m. hours as well as with NCIS: Los Angeles (18 million) and The Good Wife (12.2 million). NBC was second for the night, ABC was third, and Fox finished in fourth.

title: Sing of the Master Builder
description: A musical about Robert Moses?

title: Jon Robin Baitz on 'Other Desert Cities'
description: The playwright talks about his new family drama at Lincoln Center Theater.

title: A Warning on Raising Federal Debt Limit
description: Preparing for a potential showdown over raising the federal debt limit, two senior House Democrats want to remind lawmakers resistant to a debt increase that they may be putting troops overseas in jeopardy.

title: Prolific Communication From an Isolated Man
description: Daniel Kitsons sentences are like fast-growing mutant super-vines, sending out sticky tendrils that dig into your attention and snake themselves all over it. Burgeoning is a word often uttered by this shaggy British monologist in The Interminable Suicide of Gregory Church, his one-man show at St. Anns Warehouse in Brooklyn. This burgeoning delay, he might say, as well as the more expected burgeoning friendship. And (though I never thought Id use this word in writing about a theater performance), burgeoning is the perfect description for Mr. Kitsons irresistibly overgrown style.

title: Obama Visiting Giffords in Hospital
description: President Obama landed in Tucson on Wednesday afternoon, and immediately headed to the hospital to see Representative Gabrielle Giffords and other people injured in the shooting on Saturday.

title: Arrest in Threat to Kill a Congressman
description: A California man was arrested on Wednesday morning for threatening to kill Representative Jim McDermott, Democrat of Washington State, as the shootings in Tucson sparked impassioned conversation about Congressional security on Capitol Hill.

title: A Swirl of Back Patting on the Statuette Circuit
description: Jean Renoir said, We are artists, and as artists we must dream, Mike Nichols said from behind a lectern. And what we dream of is money.

title: 'Blood From a Stone'
description: Photos from Tommy Nohilly's new play.

title: Promotion Plus Commercial Equals Promercial?
description: By now, it is common for television viewers to watch a segment of a show in which a brand or product is integrated into the plot. The goal among marketers for such branded entertainment, as it is known, is to replace commercials with something that viewers will not zip through or zap.

title: A Rescue, Under Fire
description: C.J. Chivers provides an aerial analysis of the medevac helicopter rescue of Cpl. Zachary K. Kruger in Marja, Afghanistan.

title: Washington Delegation in Tucson
description: Several members of Congress, many of them from Arizona, traveled with President Obama on Wednesday to Tucson for a memorial service for those slain in the assassination attempt on Representative Gabrielle Giffords.

title: Test Unrelated to Gates Visit, China Says
description: BEIJING  One day after China staged a public first flight of its new stealth jet fighter, a counterpoint to a crucial visit by the American defense secretary, this nations state-run media insisted forcefully that the two events were little more than coincidence.

title: Ford Tries to Relieve Range Anxiety for Electric Car Owners
description: Range anxiety, the fear that your all-electric vehicle wont make it to your destination before you run out of power, is thought to be one reason that gives pause to prospective electric vehicle buyers.

title: Browsing: Shopping Snapshots for Jan. 13
description: Milly has a collection for children and a new bag collection; a collaborative effort in NoLIta; colorful ski fashion; and other items.

title: Sarah Palin on the Shooting in Tucson
description: Former Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin issued a forceful denunciation of her critics in a video statement that accused pundits and journalists of "blood libel."

title: On a Denied Snow Day, Beware the Wrath of Schoolchildren
description: This one hurt.

title: Theater Talkback: When Political Theater Feels Truly Dangerous
description: There were moments throughout the Belarus Free Theaters production of Being Harold Pinter, part of the Under the Radar Festival in New York, when an icy shaft of awareness would pierce my thoughts. This wasnt so much because of the artistry and ingenuity of this troupe from Minsk, although that was not to be denied.

title: Coat Hooks
description: RINAT ARUH and Johan Liden, the founders of Aruliden, a product design and marketing firm in Manhattan, spend their days rethinking products that seem ripe for reinvention, and dreaming up concepts for companies like Motorola, Puma and Microsoft. A recent pet project focused on a surprisingly ordinary object  the coat hook.

title: Lofts Painted to Create an Illusion
description: SOME tenants have to beg their landlords to paint their apartments. Not so the occupants of the lofts in a former garage near downtown Los Angeles, where the owner, Joseph Giovannini, has created murals that fool the eye into connecting distinct surfaces.

title: Sales at Apartment 48, Ochre and Design Within Reach
description: Apartment 48 is offering 30 percent to 50 percent off all merchandise, in the store only, through Jan. 31 (Wobbly tumblers, right, originally $8 each, are $5.60; the Hobnail bowl, regularly $98, is $68.60); 12 West 17th Street (Fifth Avenue), (212) 807-1391, apartment48.com.

title: Beth Katleman on Her Ceramic Curiosities
description: Beth Katleman is a ceramic artist who plays with dainty forms and techniques, subverting traditional shapes to her own mischievous ends. Her delicate earthenware reliefs in wild colors recall the 18th-century porcelain rooms of European royalty  except when you look closely, you might see the Campbell Soup kids brandishing a safety razor among the rococo flowers and vines, or the Pillsbury Doughboy tucked inside an ornate doorway.

title: Tamara Magel Opens in SoHo
description: When I was 8 years old, I announced to my parents that one day I would have a store with my name on it, said Tamara Magel, whose childhood prediction came true with the opening of her store in SoHo last week. Ms. Magel, 42, was an auditor for Deloitte & Touche and a software consultant for Price Waterhouse before pursuing her lifelong interest in design. She started her own interior design business nine years ago in Washington; now she is based in New York, and her 2,000-square-foot shop is a showcase for her designs (upholstery, case goods and decorative accessories), along with vintage lighting, 1960s Moroccan carpets and Matouk bedding.

title: A Table Dripping With Red Resin
description: Elias Kababies Pint table looks as if it belongs in a crime scene  albeit a stylish one, with its deep red resin globules dripping precisely toward the floor. Mr. Kababie, a 25-year-old architect, was inspired, he said, by paint on a table (no crime scene involved), and experimented with wood before settling on a Corian-and-resin combination. Corian and resin are really firm when cold, but when you heat them you can do whatever you like, he said. And if you put it outdoors, it will still be in good shape years from now. Available in dining and coffee-table sizes (for about $5,000 and $3,500, respectively), in black, white, red, pink and blue, at KA, Mr. Kababies showroom in Mexico. KA, Juan Vzquez de Mella No. 481, Mexico City; 011-52-55-5280-6679, tienda-ka.com.

title: American Furniture Now Panels at the Museum of Arts and Design
description: The Home Front: American Furniture Now, a series of panel discussions at the Museum of Arts and Design in Manhattan, will make its debut tonight. The five-part series, organized by Dan Rubinstein, the editor in chief of Surface magazine, explores the current state of furniture design.

title: Dont Try This at Home: Adultery in the Marital Bed
description: THE woman who came to see Ken Altshuler, a divorce lawyer, had reason to be enraged: her husband was not only having an affair, he was also having an extravagant, moneys-no-concern, fabled-and-faraway-beaches affair. He had taken his girlfriend to Tahiti, he was sending flowers to her. But what infuriated his wife the most was where he had often made love to his girlfriend: their marriage bed.

title: The Vegetable Garden From Taschen
description: From 1850 to 1895, Vilmorin-Andrieux & Cie, a Parisian seed company, commissioned a series of lavish illustrations as advertisements for its vegetables and fruits. The collection of 46 lithographs, by some of the periods most notable botanical artists, was eventually published as the Album Vilmorin (Les Plantes Potagres), a volume that survives in only a few libraries today. The album showcased the work of the company, started in 1743 by Claude Geoffroy, the daughter of a seed merchant, and Pierre DAndrieux, a botanist to King Louis XV, and the pioneering work done by their heirs, who were among the first to practice the science of seed breeding.

title: Preventing Heat From Sneaking Out of the House
description: LITTLE known fact: your house breathes.

description: 1 tablespoon minced shallot

description: 1 tablespoon ancho chili paste (method below)

title: Field Report: Nut Worth
description: Since this column began two years ago  this one is the last  farming and food-crafting have become the de rigueur Plan B. But those who envision raising hogs for top restaurants or selling their jam at the farmers market seem to skip over the life part of their dream lifestyle. As the men and women who made the leap for less-fashionable reasons will tell them: Growing, making and selling food is a fuller-than-full-time career.

description: Inmet Mining and Lundin Mining agreed on Wednesday to combine in a merger of equals that would create a new company called Symterra, with a market value of $9 billion.

title: 3 Promoted at Discovery Communications
description: Three executives were promoted Wednesday as Discovery Communications added a new layer to its organizational chart.

title: The Buzz
description: A PREVIEW of the must-attend parties, talked-about openings and fashionable nightspots for the week ahead.

description: The graphic designer known for the 1972 New York City subway map, among other iconic designs, turned 80 on Monday.

description: Heres what must be the shortest post ever on Realclimate.org, filed under the headingreporting on climate:

title: Justices Look Again at How Police May Search Homes
description: WASHINGTON  More than 60 years ago, the Supreme Court ruled that the police were not entitled to enter a residence without a warrant merely because they smelled burning opium.

title: The iPhone Effect Strikes Early for Verizon
description: Verizons announcement that it would offer Apples iPhone was met with cheers by many consumers because its network is considered more reliable than AT&Ts. But on Tuesday, Verizon suffered its own slowdown.

title: Luckys Brandon Holley: Dressing for a Revolution
description: BRANDON HOLLEY, the new editor of the beleaguered shopping magazine Lucky, has a complicated relationship with clothes.

title: Figures on Global Climate Show 2010 Tied 2005 as the Hottest Year on Record
description: New government figures for the global climate show that 2010 was the wettest year in the historical record, and it tied 2005 as the hottest year since record-keeping began in 1880.

title: Oregon Sues J.&J. in Motrin Buyback
description: An effort by Johnson & Johnson to buy back defective Motrin pills from store shelves  described as a phantom recall by some members of Congress  has come under fire in a lawsuit filed by the state of Oregon against the company.

title: S.E.C. Charges Add to the Cost of a C.E.O.s Perks
description: 8:05 p.m. | Updated

title: Lacking Leverage, U.S. Grasps for a Solution in Lebanon
description: DOHA, Qatar  Even as tensions over Irans nuclear program seemed to ease a bit, a new Middle East crisis erupted Wednesday during Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clintons Persian Gulf tour, with the collapse of Lebanons government after a walkout by Hezbollah ministers.

title: In Wave2Wave I.P.O., Convicted Swindler Would Get a Payout
description: In December 1997, the former president of brokerage firm A.R. Baron & Company, Andrew Bressman, pleaded guilty to enterprise corruption and grand larceny charges.

title: New Injury Forces Jets Into Switch at Tackle
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The Jets were pushing downfield for a game-winning (not to mention season-saving) field goal late Saturday night, but someone noticed that Damien Woody, the 327-pound right tackle, looked a little wobbly, Coach Rex Ryan said Wednesday.

title: Facebook Joins the Amber Alert Network
description: Facebook on Wednesday joined the volunteer network of organizations that distribute Amber alerts, urgent all-points bulletins issued by law enforcement in serious cases of child abduction.

title: Intimations of Violence
description: Sbastien Van Malleghem, a 24-year-old Belgian photographer, is a graduate of the cole le 75, where he worked on a project about the police in Belgium. He was an intern for Tomas Van Houtryve and participated in the Eddie Adams Workshop. Last summer, he joined the Belgian photo collective Caravane. His conversation with Kerri MacDonald, part of the Turning Point series on young photographers, has been edited and condensed.

title: Hoffmans Talent Was Not Limited To Pitching
description: Most of baseballs greatest closers are known for a devastating pitch. Bruce Sutter had the splitter, Goose Gossage had the fastball, Mariano Rivera has the cutter. Trevor Hoffman, who retired Wednesday, had the changeup. And no matter how many times he showed teammates the grip, the pitch was one of a kind.

title: Cuban Exile Lied to U.S., Prosecutor Tells Texas Jury
description: EL PASO  A prosecutor told jurors Wednesday than an elderly Cuban exile lied repeatedly under oath about how he entered the United States and about his role in terrorist attacks in Havana.

title: Coach Promises a Selfless Restoration at Michigan
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  When David Brandon, Michigans athletic director, introduced his new football coach Wednesday afternoon, one of the first qualifications he cited was that Brady Hoke could sing The Victors.

title: Creepy, Very Hostile: A College Recorded Its Fears
description: TUCSON  Officials at Pima Community College, where Jared L. Loughner was a student, believed that he might be mentally ill or under the influence of drugs after a series of bizarre classroom disruptions in which he unnerved instructors and fellow students, including one occasion when he insisted that the number 6 was actually the number 18, according to internal reports from the college.

title: Mentoring Program Turns Cameras on Its Young Clients
description: FOR the first time in its more than 100-year history, Big Brothers Big Sisters of America is actively seeking donations, through a nationwide campaign, to underwrite its work with children at risk.

title: Auto Work Force Gets Dividend From Industrys Rebound
description: DETROIT  The sweeping overhaul and surprising recovery of the American auto industry is about to pay off handsomely for the blue-collar workers at Ford and General Motors.

title: An Outrage Even Snow Cant Cool
description: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y.

title: As the Web Turns
description: Hey, fellas, want to spice things up with your lady? Procter & Gamble, the consumer products giant, has some ideas.

title: Weekly Conference Calls Give N.F.L.s Key Figures a Chance to Say Little
description: For a little while Wednesday, the Patriots and the Jets were models of cooperation. Their respective headquarters in Massachusetts and New Jersey were connected via telephone hookups so that their vastly dissimilar head coaches could speak to reporters from each city.

title: Surrounded by Cancer, and Then Needing Help Herself
description: Disease seems to be stalking Norma Hedgepeths family.

title: David Nelson, Son in Ozzie and Harriet, Dies at 74
description: David Nelson, the elder son of Ozzie and Harriet Nelson, the brother of Rick Nelson and the last surviving member of the television family that perhaps more than any other stood for the Eisenhower-era middle-class American dream, died at home in Los Angeles on Tuesday. He was 74.

title: Obamas Remarks in Tucson
description: Following is a text of President Obamas prepared address on Wednesday to honor those killed and wounded in a shooting on Jan. 8, as released by the White House.

title: Detained American Says F.B.I. Pressed Him
description: WASHINGTON  An American teenager detained in Kuwait said he underwent a heated interrogation by F.B.I. agents for several hours on Wednesday, in a case that has renewed debate over the Obama administrations expansion of the no-fly list after the attempted bombing of a passenger plane bound for Detroit in 2009.

title: Obama Urges Civility in Public Discourse
description: TUCSON  President Obama called Wednesday for an end to the political finger-pointing that has erupted in the aftermath of the gunmans rampage here five days ago, urging Americans not to use the tragedy that took six lives to turn on one another.

title: 5 Candidates Casting Nets for Votes in G.O.P. Contest
description: WASHINGTON  The race for chairman of the Republican National Committee is a popularity contest, but it can also be wildly unpredictable, with 168 members casting round after round of ballots until a victor emerges. The balloting can seem interminable, as the voting continues until one candidate attracts 85 supporters.

title: A Defensive Anchor Walks a Spiritual Path
description: PITTSBURGH  Steelers safety Troy Polamalu opened his red leather-bound playbook to a dog-eared page. The life of a man hangs by a hair, he began reading in a voice as soft as falling snow. At every step our life hangs in the balance.

title: A Phrase With Roots in Anti-Semitism
description: The expression blood libel, used by Sarah Palin in her denunciation of pundits and journalists, has its origin in a charge against Jews that took hold in the Middle Ages in a period of rising anti-Semitism.

title: From War to Volleyball, Then the Lexus Lot
description: As a girl growing up in the Bosnian war zone, Ivana Bosika, 27, spent more time hiding with her mother in the basement of their home in bomb-battered Brcko than strategizing about her dream career. But Ms. Bosika was always determined to study business. Eventually, her volleyball skills earned her a scholarship to Long Island University, where she received an M.B.A. in 2007. A sales associate at Lexus of Queens since August 2009, she lives in Ridgewood, Queens, with her husband, George, who installs and refinishes wood floors.

title: Ghailani Prosecutors Challenge Defense Request for Dismissal
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan say the recent conspiracy conviction of Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani in the first civilian trial of a former Guantnamo detainee was based on an abundance of evidence and should not be overturned.

title: Amid Sadness, Applause and Cheers
description: The memorial service for the victims of the Arizona shooting was given a more upbeat tone by the presence of thousands of college students at the University of Arizona on Wednesday night.

title: Oleg Grabar, Historian Who Studied Islamic Culture, Dies at 81
description: Oleg Grabar, a historian of Islamic art and architecture whose imposingly broad range and analytical subtlety helped transform the Western study of Islamic culture, died Saturday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 81.

title: Charter School Cries Foul Over a Decision to Close It
description: When the city provided a home five years ago for the Ross Global Academy, a charter school founded by the widow of a media executive, its opponents complained about what they considered preferential treatment for a member of the moneyed elite.

title: Governor Thrusts New Jersey to Fore on Education
description: Gov. Chris Christies tough-on-schools approach in a state that has zealously protected its public schools  and its teachers  has already put him at loggerheads with legislative leaders, unions and some parents in New Jersey.

title: After Tucson, Emotions Run High
description: To the Editor:

title: Flashbacks and Lingering Questions for Survivors
description: TUCSON  Randy Gardner had stopped by Representative Gabrielle Giffordss community event on Saturday to thank her for supporting the health care overhaul when he heard the boom, pop, pop, pop and the cries of the wounded. Ducking for cover, he found the scene more than terrifying. He found it unbelievably familiar.

title: Surgeon and Sudden Celebrity, and Trying to Balance the Roles
description: TUCSON  Dr. Peter Rhee steps before a bank of television cameras each morning to tell the world the latest on the progress of Congresswoman Gabrielle Giffords. He uses phrases like 101 percent chance of survival and seems to take a certain pride in saying that medically, bullets are easy, car crashes are hard.

title: Lottery Numbers
A Possible Purchaser Checks Out the Sabres
description: The Buffalo Sabres may soon have a new owner. Terry Pegula, an oil and gas drilling executive, is looking at the clubs books and is in discussions with team executives.

title: Rangers, Lagging at Home, Face a Test
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Rangers fans finally got what they wanted from General Manager Glen Sather and Coach John Tortorella: a young, largely homegrown team that works hard, fights (fourth in the N.H.L.), comes from behind (No. 1 in points after trailing at the second intermission) and does other gritty things well (No. 1 in hits, No. 3 in blocked shots, tied for No. 1 in road points).

title: Obama Calls for a New Era of Civility in U.S. Politics
description: TUCSON  President Obama offered the nations condolences on Wednesday to the victims of the shootings here, calling on Americans to draw a lesson from the lives of the fallen and the actions of the heroes, and to usher in a new era of civility in their honor.

title: The Gift That Wont Be Returned: Cash
description: To the Editor:

title: As We Mourn
description: It is a presidents responsibility to salve a national wound. President Obama did that on Wednesday evening at the memorial service in Tucson for the six people who died in last weekends terrible shooting. It was one of his most powerful and uplifting speeches.

title: Obama Brings It Home
description: Maybe President Obama was saving the magic for a time when we really needed it.

title: Palin Joins Debate on Heated Speech With Words That Stir New Controversy
description: WASHINGTON  Sarah Palin broke her silence on Wednesday and delivered a forceful denunciation of her critics in a video message about the Arizona shootings, accusing commentators and journalists of blood libel in a frenzied rush to blame heated political speech for the violence.

title: Last Chance for Compromise
description: The term compromise has paradoxical connotations. We applaud the spirit of compromise but shame those who have compromised their principles. This dual meaning captures the central problem of our nations early history. From the three-fifths compromise embedded in the Constitution, to the Missouri Compromise of 1820 (which divided future Western states between slave and free), to the Compromise of 1850 (which, among other things, created the Fugitive Slave Act), slavery demanded a series of adjustments in order to satisfy two increasingly antagonistic sections.

title: Problems of Democracy
description: On the first day of law school, my constitutional law professor gave the class a homework assignment: go home tonight and read the Constitution.

title: As New York City Defends Medicaid Approvals, Fear of Suits Fallout Grows
description: Medicaid fraud conjures up images of shady doctors, pharmacists and businessmen being led away in handcuffs by federal agents as photographers snap away and television cameras roll.

title: Chandlers Emergence Puts an Anthony Trade Up for Debate
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Wilson Chandler could and did play through a nose injury during another lost season last year, when the games did not matter but his maturation did. He could and did endure an ankle injury. Finally, he gave out, when a groin injury ended his season with 15 games left.

title: First Firefighter to Die Since Signing of 9/11 Health Law Is Recalled as a Leader
description: At first, his firefighter colleagues were wary when Roy W. Chelsen, the physically imposing leader of Engine Company 28, told them to run for it. One of the twin towers was gone, and they were in the one still standing. Firefighter Chelsen remembered saying, Lets just get these people, and lets get out of here.

title: Cashman: Status Quo on Pettitte
description: Say this for iconic Yankees of the championship years: they dont fade away easily. In 2007, Bernie Williams kind of, sort of, but not officially, stopped playing baseball. Now, four years later, Andy Pettitte is in the same situation. Hes retired  kind of, sort of, but not officially.

title: Its Not St. Johns Night in 2 Losses at Garden
description: In a corridor inside Madison Square Garden, members of the Syracuse mens basketball team greeted the University of Connecticut womens players. The Orange stopped to hug and shake hands with the Huskies and to obtain their autographs.

title: Thursday: Weeper of Thebes
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Its always great to see a puzzle by Liz Gorski. Her grids are clean, her themes are fun and her fill highlights her vast knowledge of music, among other topics. Todays puzzle, Im happy to say, is no different.

title: Discord Dished Up at Every Meal
description: Every unhappy family may be unhappy in its own way, as Tolstoy wrote, but not all of those ways are necessarily interesting. This truth is borne out by the worthy but wearying new play Blood From a Stone by Tommy Nohilly, a New Group production that opened Wednesday night at the Acorn Theater.

title: Facing Challenge, Obama Returns to Unity Theme
description: TUCSON  When President Obama took the stage here Wednesday to address a community  and a nation  traumatized by Saturdays killings, it invited comparisons to President George W. Bushs speech to the nation after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, and the memorial service President Bill Clinton led after the bombing of a federal office building killed 168 people in Oklahoma City in 1995.

title: Save Energy, Save Our Troops
description: Arlington, Va.

title: Cast Change for Law & Order: Los Angeles
description: NBC will make a major cast change in Law & Order: Los Angeles the newest entry in the networks long-running Law and Order franchise, moving out the actor Skeet Ulrich in order to provide more air time for the better-known actors in the series, Alfred Molina and Terrence Howard.

title: Advice in New York: Stay Out of the Sewers
description: To the Editor:

title: Pelosi on Hand When Giffords Opens Eyes
description: 11:12 p.m. | Updated  TUCSON Nancy Pelosi, the House minority leader, was in Gabrielle Giffords hospital room when she opened her eyes for the first time since being shot in the head last Saturday, Obama administration and congressional aides said.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Bloggingheads: Paging Dr. Wal-Mart
description: Mickey Kaus, left, of kausfiles and David Frum of FrumForum debate the cost-effectiveness of American health care.

title: James Sends Wrong Message
description: It is possible that LeBron James was merely inviting a theological discussion, an examination of Eastern philosophy and monotheism vis--vis professional sports in the Internet age.

title: Pride in Batsmen and Bowlers Breaks Through Britains Winter Gloom
description: LONDON  In the bleakest winter Britain has known in years, it has been, for millions, the source of unbridled good cheer. In the pubs, untold tankards of beer have been washed down in celebration. Keeping abreast of it has kept the prime minister up into the predawn hours, glued to the television, then taking his BlackBerry to bed to get regular updates through the night.

title: Executive Consolation
description: In moments of tragedy, here are the words some presidents have used as they tried to unite the country.

title: Hezbollahs Latest Suicide Mission
description: THE collapse of Lebanons government on Tuesday signaled the final stage in Hezbollahs rise from resistance group to ruling power. While Hezbollah technically remains the head of the political opposition in Beirut, make no mistake: the Party of God has fully consolidated its control in Lebanon, and will stop at nothing  including civil war  to protect its position.

title: Hoke Has Reputation as a Players Coach
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  If you were a Michigan football player running late, Brady Hoke used to be your best friend.

title: Why Not Regulate Guns as Seriously as Toys?
description: Jared Loughner was considered too mentally unstable to attend community college. He was rejected by the Army. Yet buy a Glock handgun and a 33-round magazine? No problem.

title: Autism Fraud
description: The report that first triggered scares that a vaccine to prevent measles, mumps and rubella might cause autism in children has received another devastating blow to its credibility. The British Medical Journal has declared that the research was not simply bad science, as has been known for years, but a deliberate fraud.

title: Tunisia Seethes
description: For 23 years, President Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali of Tunisia has kept a tight clamp on his countrys political life, marketing Tunisia as a tourist oasis while dangerous tensions built up beneath the surface. Now deadly riots have erupted over the bleak economic prospects facing the countrys young people. Mr. Ben Alis response has been to clamp down even harder, a course sure to lead to more unrest and bloodshed.

title: The Three Burials of Alston Anderson
description: Alston Anderson was buried on Saturday for the second time  or the third, if you count the slow sinking that constituted his long but unrewarded life. He was an African-American short-story writer, poet, novelist and jazz critic. He spent three years in the Army in World War II and three months of 1955 at Yaddo, the writers colony in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. He studied philosophy at Columbia and the Sorbonne.

title: A Few Reflections on Obamas Speech in Tucson
description: President Obamas speech in Tucson tonight seems to have won nearly universal praise. I suspect it will be remembered as one of his best moments, almost regardless of what else takes place during the remainder of his presidency.

title: South Korea Raises Rates As Inflation Stirs Concern
description: HONG KONG  South Korea unexpectedly raised interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point Thursday and announced measures intended to curb rising prices, the latest sign that policy makers in Asia and other emerging markets were increasingly concerned about inflation.

title: About Those Fancy Launch Parties
description: Greta Van Susteren of Fox News took note on Wednesday of the fancy party at Tina Browns Upper East Side home to celebrate Piers Morgans debut at CNN and pointed a crooked finger at the event.

title: A Cub Returns to Tiger, Taking a Top Post
description: Gil Caffray, the former chief trader at the hedge fund Tiger Management, will rejoin his old firm as chief investment officer.

title: Germany Sentences 2 Libyan Spies
description: Two Libyan citizens were sentenced in a Berlin court for spying on members of the Libyan opposition living in Europe from August 2007 until they were arrested in May 2010. A 43-year-old officer for the Libyan intelligence service, identified as Abdel A., was sentenced to two and a half years in prison while his accomplice, Adel Al., 47, was sentenced to a term of one year and 10 months. Abdel A. was convicted of overseeing a network of informal collaborators who systematically spied on Libyan opposition members living in Germany and Western Europe. Adel Al. worked as one of these informers reporting to Abdel A.

title: Is the iPad a Time Machine for Reading?
description: When devices became untethered and Web content began to be consumed anywhere, it was assumed that leisure reading would take a beating as people just skipped across content while on the go. But according to Read It Later, an application that allows consumers to mark content to catch up when and where they want to, users may come across a lot of things they want to read in the middle of the day, but they actually get back to them much later in the day.

title: Obama Offers Condolences in Memorial Service
description: President Obama offered the nations condolences to the victims of the Tucson shootings at a memorial service at the University of Arizona.

title: Sports Replay: Jan 12
description: A view of the day in sports, with big blocks, big crowds, hard hits and a long drive through Argentina.

title: Touring Camelot, Without Having to Leave Home

title: No Defense Means No Victory for the Knicks

title: Floods Peak, Leaving Ruin in Australian City
description: BRISBANE, Australia  Floodwaters peaked here on Thursday, swamping tens of thousands of homes and businesses as officials began to count the cost of a natural disaster that has inundated vast sections of the countrys northeast and killed at least 15 people in the past week.

description: Martin Cohen went from being a starstruck commoner in the court of the Mambo Kings to the chronicler of legends. You may have seen his name on any number of bongos, congas, cowbells and timbales manufactured by Latin Percussion, the company he started in the early 1960s with little more than a fanatics devotion to the music.

description: Kodak, the company that brought photography to the masses, as well as the ability for amateurs to develop and print pictures at home, is now bringing 3-D to the standard pictures you print from your digital camera.

title: Spain Passes Debt Test With Bond Sale
description: MADRID  Spain and Italy had strong results for their bond auctions on Thursday, easing immediate concerns about the ability of the euro zones weakest members to raise money to meet debt obligations.

title: In London, an Art Fair for Collectors and Novices Alike
description: Attending the London Art Fair (Business Design Center, Islington; www.londonartfair.co.uk), which runs this year from Jan. 19 to 23, is a terrific way to familiarize yourself with some of the best of modern and contemporary British art. Established artists like Ben Nicholson, L.S. Lowry and Leon Kossoff will be represented, as well as some exciting newcomers.

title: Giffordss Friends Narrate the Moment She Opened Her Eye
description: Just a few hours after attending a memorial service in Tucson, a giddy Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand of New York and Representative Debbie Wasserman-Schultz of Florida came back to the press cabin aboard Air Force One to tell reporters about the moment when their friend, Representative Gabrielle Giffords, opened one eye for the first time since she was shot in the head on Saturday.

title: Mailbag: Readers on Criticism
description: Our Jan. 2 issue on Why Criticism Matters drew a large number of letters from readers, and we wanted to share more than the few we were able to publish in print. The letters here touch on several themes: the critics ability to connect with readers, the writings of James Joyce and Northrop Frye, and the contributions of contemporary critics.

title: Clinton Bluntly Presses Arab Leaders on Reform
description: DOHA, Qatar  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton delivered a scalding critique of Arab leaders here on Thursday, saying their countries risked sinking into the sand of unrest and extremism unless they liberalized their political systems and cleaned up their economies.

title: Behind Tunisia Unrest, Rage Over Wealth of Ruling Family
description: HAMMAMET, Tunisia  This ancient Mediterranean hamlet, advertised as the Tunisian St.-Tropez, has long been the favorite summer getaway of President Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali and his large extended family, many of whom have built vast beachfront mansions here with the wealth they have amassed during his years in power.

title: European Central Banks Keep Rates Steady
description: The European Central Bank and the Bank of England kept their main interest rates unchanged Thursday, as inflation concerns were overshadowed by debt tensions and the fear that government spending cuts could crimp economic growth.

description: While Wall Streets earnings season will not officially begin until Friday morning when JPMorgan Chase reports its fourth quarter performance, the outlook on banks seems to be improving.

description: Wednesday was bookended by two remarkable and remarkably different  political performances that demonstrated the vast expanse of Americas political landscape.

title: Comedic Stylings of Ryan and Belichick
description: David Waldsteins article this morning  examines the wildly divergent styles of Bill Belichick and Rex Ryan on conference calls.

title: Spread of Deadly Virus Tied to Forest Decline
description: Around 2004, large numbers of aspens in the West began dying off, and with no immediately identifiable cause, scientists dubbed the phenomenon sudden aspen decline. Ultimately the die-back was pinned on a severe 2002 drought and heat wave that left aspens vulnerable to pests, cankers and fungi.

title: Divisional Round Probabilities: Is Atlanta Overrated?
description: Brian Burke, a former Navy pilot who has taken up the less dangerous hobby of N.F.L. statistical analysis, operates Advanced NFL Stats, a blog about football, math and human behavior.

description: My magazine piece on the euro is online.

title: Prudential Invests $500 Million in Chinese Buyout Fund
description: Prudential Financial, which bought two Japanese businesses from the American International Group last year, said on Thursday that it would put $500 million into a buyout fund controlled by the Chinese conglomerate Fosun Group.

title: Investors Say Expert Networks Need to Change Their Ways
description: In the wake of a string of arrests in the federal investigation of insider trading, there is mounting pressure for change in the expert network industry.

title: Just One Look | Louis Vuitton Pre-Fall Collection
description: The Pre-Fall Collections, being shown in New York over the next several weeks, arrive in stores in May to fill the gap between bikinis and furs.Marc Jacobs flirted with the Art Deco diva for pre-fall, evoking an era when a woman, armed with her liberated wardrobe, could set out to conquer the world while enjoying the luxuries of her newfound freedom. The tweed coats in particular  this one inspired by the textile designs of Louise Bourgeois  and printed flapper dresses are for a woman not afraid to wear her art on her sleeve. But lest we should forget, freedom comes with a hefty price tag. These are clothes to go for broke.

title: Part 3: Answers to Readers Questions on Financial Aid
description: As families of prospective college freshmen begin to tackle the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, or Fafsa, Mark Kantrowitz, a financial aid expert and founder of the Web sites finaid.org and fastweb.com, is answering questions from readers of The Choice this week.

title: A Quick Study on the Awards-Season Circuit
description: Lesley Manville had no idea what the National Board of Review was when she learned she had won its best actress award for her work in Mike Leighs Another Year. She confided this to the Bagger, and to the roomful of attendees, at the National Board of Reviews gala on Tuesday night. Though she is a veteran actress and a veteran of Mr. Leighs films  it is her sixth collaboration with the maverick British director, who famously drafts no scripts or characters before he begins working on his films  it is her first time at the awards slog. Shes a quick study, though. (She has to be: Mr. Leighs films are all improvised.)

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

title: Exco Board Weighs Chiefs Buyout Offer
description: The board of Exco Resources, an oil and gas producer based in Dallas, said on Thursday  that it was considering a buyout offer made by Douglas H. Miller, the companys chief executive officer, which values Exco at $4.35 billion.

title: Europe Inquiry Focuses on Google Business Practice
description: BRUSSELS  European antitrust investigators are asking advertisers whether Google suggested they increase spending with the company in return for improved visibility in its Web search results. The investigators are also examining whether Google stymied companies who had tried to move their business elsewhere.

title: Morning Buzz | Ghailani Prosecutors Rebut Defense Motion
description: The city is getting back to its regularly scheduled program this morning. We are expecting clear skies ahead and a high in the upper 20s.

title: Wikipedia Marks 10 Years of Edit-It-Yourself
description: An untested idea  allowing regular people to create an online encyclopedia  went live on Jan. 15, 2001, with no fanfare. No one knew whether people would contribute to such a project, and if so, whether the information they submitted would be reliable.

title: Praise for Obama, From the Right and Left
description: 10:39 a.m. | Updated Reaction to President Obamas speech at the memorial service in Arizona on Wednesday night has been almost uniformly positive, even from some of his sharpest critics.

title: Pre-Oscar Parties
description: Attendees and honorees at two awards parties this week in New York.

title: Vantage Point: The Challenges of Small-Unit Patrolling in Afghanistan
description: Carrying small digital video cameras on patrols and other military missions covered by The New York Times over the years, I have amassed a few bricks worth of footage of the Afghan war  shuras and firefights, long walks and short dashes, helicopter flights and convoys, the routines of fire base life and an accidental visual inventory of the Afghan countryside. I often keep the video camera on as a notebook, absorbing sights and sounds that I might refer to later when I write. It aids with accuracy. Many times I also find that the camera has soaked up dialogue or recorded visual details that that I didnt hear or see in real time. Its a priceless tool, even if it adds to the work after each assignment, when the footage must be downloaded, labeled and archived.

title: Museum of Modern Art Acquires Video Withdrawn From Smithsonian Exhibition
description: The Museum of Modern Art has acquired the David Wojnarowicz video that was removed from a show at the National Portrait Gallery in Washington after drawing criticism from a religious organization and some congressional Republicans. The museum acquired both the original 13-minute version of the video, titled A Fire in My Belly, and a separate 7-minute excerpt made by the artist; the two are now being shown in a loop as part of a display of contemporary art from the museums collection that will remain up until May 9.

title: Northern Star | Montreal
description: With its perennially happening night life and laissez-faire attitude, the Paris of the North is usually thought of as a party city, but it does have its quieter pockets. Little Burgundy, a k a La Petite Bourgogne, a working-class neighborhood thats been slowly gentrifying over the past 10 years, isnt as flashy as the better-known Plateau Mont-Royal, but its relaxed vibe and excellent dining options make it an ideal place for a lazy autumnal amble. More

title: Remedies: Chewing Gum for Heartburn
description: More than a third of American adults use some form of complementary or alternative medicine, according to a government report. Natural remedies have an obvious appeal, but how do you know which ones to choose and whether the claims are backed by science? In this occasional series, Anahad OConnor, the New York Times Really? columnist, explores the claims and the science behind alternative remedies that you may want to consider for your family medicine cabinet.

title: Insider Information That Wasnt
description: There is insider information, and then there is nudge-nudge, wink-wink.

title: Kanda Satyagraha
description: Term given to a boycott of onions in Mumbais suburbs by way of protest against their soaring price.

title: Thursday Reading: Help with the Heating Bill
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Poetry Pairing | Jan. 13, 2011
description: In our weekly Poetry Pairing series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poems themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

title: Answers About Getting Organized, Part III
description: Barbara Reich, a professional organizer who was the subject of a recent Metropolitan article by Elissa Gootman, took readers questions this week about getting organized. Her third and final set of answers are found below, and previous installments in this Q. and A. can be read here.

title: Awaiting Upbeat Bank Earnings
description: DealBook reporter Ben Protess speaks to Jason Goldberg, a senior U.S. banks analyst at Barclays Capital, about the outlook for bank earnings in the fourth quarter.

title: Tyler Perrys Awards Extravaganza: Nominations Galore From N.A.A.C.P.
description: Film and television projects by Tyler Perry dominated the nominations for the N.A.A.C.P.s 42nd annual Image Awards, announced on Wednesday, while Halle Berry, Smokey Robinson, Denzel Washington and Kanye West were among the nominees in acting and music categories.

title: Agency Revokes Permit for Major Coal Mining Project
description: WASHINGTON  The Environmental Protection Agency revoked the permit for one of the nations largest mountaintop-removal coal mining projects on Thursday, saying the mine would have done unacceptable damage to rivers, wildlife and communities in West Virginia. It was the first time the agency had rescinded a valid clean water permit for a coal mine.

title: E.P.A. Revokes Controversial Mine Permit
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has revoked the permit for Arch Coals Spruce No. 1 mountaintop-removal coal mining project in West Virginia, saying that the operation would damage communities and wildlife.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Verizons iPhone
description: On this weeks show, J.D. Biersdorfer chats with Jenna Wortham, a New York Times technology reporter, about Verizons iPhone. The Timess personal technology editor, Sam Grobart, joins in to reflect on last weeks Consumer Electronics Show.

title: Just One Look | Stella McCartney Pre-Fall Collection
description: The Pre-Fall Collections, being shown in New York over the next several weeks, arrive in stores in May to fill the gap between bikinis and furs.

title: A Starbucks Venture in Tea-Drinking India
description: MUMBAI  Starbucks, the coffee chain based in Seattle, wants to move with a sense of urgency to capitalize on the rising demand for coffee in fast growing India, its top executive said Friday.

title: In Las Vegas, Hit the Jackpot, Get a Tesla
description: The telephones on-hold music for the new Cosmopolitan hotel and casino came courtesy of the Talking Heads. A recent addition to the Las Vegas Strip, the Cosmopolitan projects a trendsetting image, which translates to very little Wayne Newton. It presented the rising indie-pop group Best Coast in a four-night stand in the lounge, but perhaps more telling of its ambitions to lure the young, culturally progressive and affluent, its slot machines offer a Tesla Roadster as a grand prize.

title: Europes Odd Couple
description: SHE MAKES FUN, in private, of the way he walks and talks, of his rapid, jerky gestures and facial grimaces. He mocks her deliberation, her reluctance, her matronly caution. She has compared him to Mr. Bean and to the French comic Louis de Funs, with his curly hair and large nose. He sometimes calls her La Boche, the offensive French version of Kraut, and goes out of his way to give her an embrace and a double-cheeked kiss in the French fashion, the kind of contact that he knows very well, aides say, she cannot stand.

title: Death Toll Mounts in Brazilian Deluge
description: NOVA FRIBURGO, Brazil  Dozens of people lined up outside an elementary school here on Thursday, clutching family members under umbrellas, as they braced themselves for news about loved ones feared lost in devastating landslides that have produced Brazils most deadly natural disaster.

title: Cromartie Gives Namath a Laugh
description: I spoke to Joe Namath for about 15 minutes Thursday morning for another article, and, of course, the conversation eventually turned to Jets cornerback Antonio Cromartie and the vulgar name he called New England quarterback Tom Brady on Wednesday in The Daily News.

title: A Quota by Any Other Name
description: On Aug. 30, Gov. David A. Paterson took direct aim at the policing powers in New York City, expanding the states anti-quota statute by outlawing them for tickets, summonses, arrests and stop-question-and-frisk encounters.

title: Belarus Issues Warning to Rights Group Amid Crackdown
description: MOSCOW  The authorities in Belarus have issued a warning to a prominent human rights group, accusing it of unlawfully distorting information about the situation in the country amid a continued crackdown on opponents of President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko.

description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.
