description: Ms. Culbertson is the post graduate coordinator at Cherry Creek High in Denver, which is the subject of a school-year-long series on The Choice.

title: Audi Sets Stage for Its Super Bowl Spot
description: Super Bowl XLV on Feb. 6 is going to be crowded with commercials from carmakers. Perhaps as many as eight brands will be vying for viewers in what the trade publication Advertising Age is already calling a traffic jam.

title: Answering Your Sudan Questions, Round 3
description: This is a historic week in Sudan, with a referendum underway on secession for the south  and a process that is likely to lead to a new nation of South Sudan (although it may choose a different name for itself). Former President Jimmy Carter is on the ground there, monitoring the voting, and he has been answering questions from readers with me. Read the first and second batches of answers, and heres the third and last installment.

title: Style Without End
Duke Proves Beatable
description: It is either charming or a sign of insanity that sports fans go through this particular cycle so often. Some really good team comes along, piles up an impressive winning streak and suddenly it takes on mythical qualities. Stronger than Atlas. Has the smartest coach ever. Can leap tall buildings with a bunny hop. These teams are juggernauts, impervious, absolutely unbeatable ... until theyre not.

title: A Globes Check-In and a Crusade for Credit
description: LOS ANGELES The Bagger has landed in the city of arts and entertainment, as a billboard at the airport read, as well as the town of celebrities self-involved enough to sign off on their own parodies, never-ending 24-hour donut shops and homeless people who are worried about your karma. Today marks the start of a whirlwind few days of festivities for the Golden Globes, and, like last year, the Bagger has come prepared.

title: Broad Racial Disparities Seen in Americans Ills
description: White people in the United States die of drug overdoses more often than other ethnic groups. Black people are hit proportionately harder by AIDS, strokes and heart disease. And American Indians are more likely to die in car crashes.

title: Metropolitan Opera, Settling Lawsuit, Will Increase Wheelchair Access
description: The Metropolitan Opera will now be more wheelchair accessible. The opera company on Thursday settled a civil rights lawsuit in Manhattan federal court that had been brought against the Met for failure to comply with the Americans With Disabilities Act. The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York announced that it had filed, and simultaneously settled, the lawsuit against the Met.

title: Brady: A Leader They Swear By
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  So far this week, Tom Brady has been variously described as a dork (a compliment) and as something else entirely (unprintable and definitely not a compliment). His choice of entertainment options was assailed, his study habits questioned, his in-game deportment scrutinized.

title: 2 New Publishers Named at Cond Nast
description: 3:19 p.m. | Updated Every January, speculation sweeps the halls of the Cond Nast Building that a January surprise is in the works, with major changes coming at the Cond Nast Publications magazines.

title: Cruise Passengers Provide a Jolt to Tourism Spending
description: Cunard is staging another group departure of its cruise ships in New York Harbor on Thursday night, and if the passengers are typical they will be leaving a significant amount of money behind.

title: What to Tell Children About Tucson
description: This little girl was just like you. She was shot by a bad man for going to the mall.

title: Studying Microbes in Antarctica?
description: [8:34 p.m. | Updated  The first couple of paragraphs have been revised to clarify that the focus of the work is on water and sediments, not soil.]

title: In Target Deal, a Canadian Bet Begins to Pay Off
description: For the discount chain Target, it is a big move into Canada and its first expansion outside the United States. For a New York private equity investor, it is something of a vindication.

title: Audi Sets Stage for Its Super Bowl Spot
description: From our colleagues at the Media Decoder blog:

title: Connecticut School Official, Objecting to Racial Term, Wants to Block Wilson Play
description: The schools superintendent in Waterbury, Conn., is seeking to shut down a production of one of August Wilsons great dramas, Joe Turners Come and Gone, because some of the teenage actors would have to utter the word nigger as called for in the script, according to a report in the citys Republican-American newspaper.

title: 2012 Mercedes-Benz SLK Aims for Mini-Me Effect
description: Mercedes-Benz unveiled a lightly refreshed C-Class sedan and a retina-searing SLS AMG E-Cell during the recently concluded Detroit auto show press previews, but the German automaker held one last card in its pocket.

title: Ellen Stewart of LaMaMa Has Died at 91
description: 1:20 p.m. | Updated Ellen Stewart, an ever-optimistic force for avant garde theater nationally and at her landmark spot in New York City, La MaMa Experimental Theater Club, died on Thursday morning at Beth Israel Hospital, her press agent Sam Rudy said. She was 91.

title: Obama in Arizona
description: I dont have much to add to the litany of praise that the presidents memorial service performance has earned, deservedly, from his political opponents. The peculiar atmosphere of the event notwithstanding, the speech was everything it needed to be: A moving eulogy for the dead, a sober, religiously-inflected reflection on the mystery of iniquity, and an explicit rebuke to partisan readings of this tragedy which will close the book, one hopes, on a weeks worth of inappropriate and increasingly implausible attempts to portray Jared Lee Loughner as a Tea Partier in spirit. Everything Obama did right during his presidential campaign he did right last night: It may not have been the best speech of his life, but it was the best speech of his presidency.

title: Should E-Mail and Letters Have Equal Legal Protection?
description: Over the weekend, we reported that the government had ordered Twitter to turn over private information about users associated with WikiLeaks.

title: Defy the Elite! Wait, Which Elite?
description: SOME people renounce liquor or sweets. My New Years resolution for 2011 was to give up meta: no panels on the State or Future or Death of Criticism; no trolling the Internet looking for fights over first principles; no thumb suckers for the Sunday paper on the history or the essence of the critical profession. Enough of all that! Instead, a renewed commitment to the basics. For 12 months or more phrases like politique des auteurs, Pauline Kael, received wisdom, reflexively contrarian and formalist hack would not pass my lips or issue from my keyboard, no matter how much I was provoked.

title: Vacancy in Justice Departments National Security Branch
description: Another vacancy is opening up at the Justice Department, already hamstrung by the difficulty of getting the Senate to confirm administration nominees. David S. Kris, the assistant attorney general for the departments national security division, announced on Thursday that he is resigning, effective March 4.

title: Video: On the Awards Circuit With Colin Firth
Your Snowstorm Videos Here
description: Wednesday was an unofficial snow day for many. Lets revisit.

title: An Art Fair in Brooklyn
description: Verge, the folks who organize satellite fairs for emerging artists in places like Miami Beach, are starting what they say is the first-ever Brooklyn art fair. Called Art Brooklyn, it will be timed to coincide with the Armory Show and will take place in multiple locations throughout the DUMBO neighborhood March 3-6. The aim of the fair is to promote Brooklyn as a cultural hub that will attract artists and collectors from around the world.

title: A Long Journey Into the Ecuadorean Forest
description: Anthony Di Fiore, a primate biologist at New York University, writes from Ecuador, where he is using GPS technology and camera traps to study the behavior of male spider monkeys.

title: Ellen Stewart, Off Off Broadway Pioneer, Dies at 91
description: Ellen Stewart, the founder, artistic director and de facto producer of La MaMa Experimental Theater Club, a multicultural hive of avant-garde drama and performance art in New York for almost half a century, died Thursday in Manhattan. She was 91.

title: How to Pick a Tax Preparer
description: Since youre legally responsible for whats on your tax return even if someone else prepares it, the Internal Revenue Service recommends choosing carefully when picking a tax preparer.

title: Soros Bets the Farm
description: An agriculture company backed by the billionaire George Soros on Thursday filed to go public in an offering of more than $400 million.

title: Concur Takes Off With TripIt Deal
description: Concur Technologies, a provider of trip and expense management software, announced Thursday that it had agreed to buy TripIt, a mobile trip manager, in a deal that could be worth as much as $120 million.

title: A Guy Thing? Not That Kind. And Not That Kind Either.
description: If you have seen the ubiquitous advertisements and trailers for The Dilemma, you might be forgiven for expecting a semistupid, semisweet, semioffensive guy comedy. It is entirely possible that Imagine Entertainment and Universal Pictures want you to expect just that. The movies stars, Vince Vaughn and Kevin James (of Couples Retreat, Paul Blart: Mall Cop and much else) seem to grin from every billboard and bus shelter, promising beefy and boisterous wintertime high jinks of a kind moviegoers have learned to love, or at least tolerate.

title: Doctors Call Giffordss Progress Remarkable
description: TUCSON  Five days after she was shot in the head at close range, Representative Gabrielle Giffords is able to keep her eyes open for as long as 15 minutes and can move her legs and hands, although her right hand has only slight movement, doctors at University Medical Center here said on Thursday.

title: Renault Files Criminal Complaint of Industrial Espionage
description: PARIS  The automaker Renault filed a criminal complaint on Thursday in an industrial espionage case in which it asserts that a foreign company sought to obtain secrets related to its electric car program.

title: F.D.A. Plans New Limits on Painkillers
description: WASHINGTON  The government announced Thursday that it would sharply restrict some of the nations most popular prescription painkillers, saying they cause many patients to poison themselves with overdoses of the drug acetaminophen.

title: Take My Company, Please
description: Chief executives who can expect a golden handshake dont negotiate as hard as others when their companies are on the block, a study by Cass Business School at the City University of London found.

title: Central Park, Wednesday, 1 A.M.
description: You probably think youre sick of snow, but perhaps youre just sick of municipal snow-clearing controversies. There was not a plow in sight when reader Adam Garelick, a lawyer for the federal Department of Labor, snapped this in Central Park in the high 70s. Thank you, Mr. Garelick.

title: Breaking the Cycle of Violence
description: At the end of every year, in what was one of our grimmest rituals during training, the other young doctors and I would huddle over the local newspaper and read through the obituary year-in-review section. We would pick out the names and faces we recognized, recall their stories and marvel over the lives they led outside of the hospital.

title: A Doctors Mission to End Violence
description: As we are reminded not just this week but every day in the news, violence remains a major public health issue in the United States. While advances in trauma surgery, critical care and emergency medicine have allowed doctors to save more victims of violence, these advances have done nothing to deter repeat violent crimes or the hospitalizations and death that often follow. Homicide remains the 15th leading cause of death over all and the leading cause of death among African-American males age 15 to 34.

title: Carey Mulligan to Star in Through a Glass Darkly
description: Despite at least three major film projects in the works, the Academy Award nominee Carey Mulligan (An Education) is finding time to return to the New York stage. Ms. Mulligan is set to star in the United States premiere of Through A Glass Darkly, a stage adaptation of the 1961 film by Ingmar Bergman about a mentally ill young woman who, while on a tense vacation with her family, grapples with a tenuous hold on reality and with otherworldly voices, one of which may be Gods.

title: Advance Notice: Examining the Focus and Value of the A.P. Program
description: Overview | Why is the College Board revamping the Advanced Placement program? What do students and teachers need to know about future A.P. tests? In this lesson, students discuss the coming changes to the Advanced Placement program as well as some of their own thoughts on what might make college preparatory learning more effective.

title: Best in the (North)West: Kornblatts Deli, Portland
description: The gourmet coffee and thriving food cart cultures of Portland, Ore., are hardly starving for attention, but the city is also quietly home to Kornblatts Delicatessen, one of the truly great New York delis outside the five boroughs.Located in the Northwest 23rd shopping district, this displaced ode to New York deli counter culture strives for authenticity (Nova lox, pickles and meats imported from New York City), and yet it cant help but reflect the differences between Manhattan and Portland. For starters, there are four local beers on tap, including Deschutes Black Butte Porter and Cascade I.P.A., as well as a spacious, relaxed dining room and a vegetarian Reuben option, both unheard of at, say, Katzs or Eisenbergs in New York. Theres even locally made organic chicken basil sausage on the brunch menu.

title: The Worst and Best Credit Cards of 2010
description: The editors of credit card comparison site CardRatings.com recently announced their take on the worst and best credit cards of 2010.

title: Afghan Panel and U.S. Dispute Wars Toll on Property
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  An Afghan presidential commission has determined that military operations in the Kandahar area have caused more than $100 million in damage to homes and farms over the past six months, its chairman said in an interview on Thursday.

title: C.F.T.C. Proposes Curbs on Speculative Commodity Trading
description: 7:41 p.m. | Updated

title: Colleges Policy on Troubled Students Raises Questions
description: TUCSON  Many people had a glimpse of the deep delusions and festering anger of Jared L. Loughner, but none seemed in a better position to connect the dots than officials at Pima Community College.

title: First, the Bad News
description: Two announcements this week. Two big bummers. Two good things gone.

title: Patience Paying Off for Pistons Monroe
description: Though plenty of rookies see their first N.B.A. playing time on opening night, our real introduction to each years batch of neophytes is a gradual unveiling. Hotshots like Blake Griffin, John Wall, and Landry Fields make an immediate impact. Other rookies take longer to acclimate to the pacing, style, and physicality of the big leagues. The N.B.A. is different from every other basketball league on the planet, and a period of adjustment should be expected; those who succeed immediately are the exceptions that prove the rule.

title: Poland Objects to Russias Report on Fatal Air Crash
description: MOSCOW  Polands prime minister said Thursday that a Russian-led investigation of the crash that killed the Polish president and dozens of other top officials in April was incomplete and that his government would not accept a unilateral account of the crash.

title: Broadways Memphis to Be Shown in Movie Theaters
description: Memphis, the 2010 Tony Award winner for best musical, will be filmed next week in high definition and then released in movie theaters starting in the spring, press representatives for the show said on Thursday.

title: Hutchison Will Not Seek Re-Election
description: Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, Republican of Texas, said on Thursday that she would not seek re-election next year, a move that had been expected after her failed bid for the Republican nomination for governor last year.

title: House Is Moving, Carefully, to Resume Work
description: Republicans are carefully trying to return the House to normal business, announcing on Thursday that lawmakers next week will consider the health care law repeal that was pulled from the agenda after the weekend shooting rampage in Arizona.

title: Ford Reintroduces the Global Focus Family
description: Introduced on Monday: The Ford Focus range. Although most of Fords global Focus C-segment automobiles were seen at multiple shows worldwide in 2010, they were reintroduced as a more complete family of automobiles here.

title: Target Moves Into Canada By Buying Store Chain
description: OTTAWA  The Target Corporation said on Thursday that it would make its first move outside of the United States by acquiring up to 220 Zellers department store locations from the Hudsons Bay Company for $1.8 billion.

title: Mel Gibson Film Chosen for South by Southwest
description: LOS ANGELES  Mel Gibson may be sweating it out in the legal system here, but his next movie will find a happy home in Texas.

title: Just One Look | Balenciaga Pre-Fall Collection
description: The Pre-Fall Collections, being shown in New York over the next several weeks, arrive in stores in May to fill the gap between bikinis and furs.

title: Pill Brokers
description: Individuals who buy over-the-counter cold medications to sell on to methamphetamine producers.

title: Phone Condoms (Order in Bulk)
description: Since I wrote the distracted driving series in 2009, Ive been pitched on all kinds of technologies to help motorists focus on the road not their mobile devices. At last, one with a prurient name.

title: New European Banking Regulator Will Conduct a Stress Test on Lenders
description: PARIS  The European banking regulator said on Thursday that it would conduct another round of stress tests on lenders this spring, a move that investors hope will offer more clarity on the health of balance sheets than previous exercises.

title: Automatic Immunity for Berlusconi Revoked
description: ROME  Italys highest court revoked automatic immunity for Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi on Thursday, a move that could restart three criminal cases against him and further jeopardize his tenuous hold on power.

title: Eodromaeus Timelapse Reconstruction
description: Time-lapse showing the making of the flesh rendering of the head and neck over replica bones of the skull and neck of a newly discovered dinosaur.

title: Aging: Mediterranean Diet as Brain Food
description: The Mediterranean diet  heavy on vegetables, fish and olive oil, with moderate amounts of wine  may be associated with slower rates of mental decline in the elderly.

title: Bits Pics: The Computer History Museum
description: Jan 14, 12:36 p.m. | Updated  Heres an article about the reopening of the museum.The Computer History Museum in Mountain View, Calif., which opened its doors to robots and people in 1996, finally finished a two-year, $19 million renovation and reopened to the public this week.

title: Under the Radar: 5 Questions About Bonanza
description: Bonanza, a work in the Under the Radar Festival by the Belgian theater company Berlin, consists of five video projections and a large, hanging scale model of a small town. No actors. No costumes. No makeup. No set.

title: Twins Uphill Battle With Facebook and Zuckerberg
description: Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss are likely to lose the battle to undo their legal settlement with Facebook and Mark Zuckerberg, the social networks co-founder.

description: President Obama, yesterday:

description: The City of Light could soon become the city without S.U.V.s.

description: Movies

title: Wishful Thinking on Health Costs
description: Opponents of the health law sometimes like to suggest that cutting health costs would be easy, if only wed be willing to try common-sense ideas. But thats wishful thinking. The law does include most of the common-sense ideas supported by health economists ranging from Mark McClellan (the former Bush administration official) to David Cutler (a former Clinton and Obama adviser). Theres just no getting around the fact that reducing the growth rate of health costs will be difficult.

description: Pop

title: Jazz Listings for Jan. 14-20
description: Jazz

title: For Gay Arabs, a Place to Dance, and Break Down Walls
description: Around midnight, upstairs in a small club on Avenue of the Americas, the pitch-black dance floor resounded with the rapid stomps and warbling, high-energy cries of the dabke, an Arab folk dance performed at weddings and other celebrations.

title: Neighborhood Joint | Butcher Block
description: A shop in Sunnyside, Queens offers candy, biscuits, breads, baby food and other products from Ireland.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for Jan. 14-20
description: Classical

title: Sympathy for the Academy
description: LOS ANGELES What makes an Academy movie? (Aside from having a screener and a few dozen For Your Consideration ads, of course.) Story, casting and directing all factor in, naturally, but Oscar pundits often point to more ephemeral measures: can you root for the characters? Do you leave the theater feeling good? As of a few weeks ago, the Baggers colleagues on the race beat were still hotly debating the notion of likability with respect to The Social Network, sometimes considered too anti-heroic but now a best picture frontrunner.

title: Meals for a Mensch and the Discerning Sports Fan
description: The mail brought, among other things, questions of religious difference and requests for reservation advice and for a place to watch television while eating well. I tried my best to answer. As ever, you can send your own questions to dinejournal@nytimes.com.

title: At Schwab, Unkept Promise To Investors
description: Claiming to be holier than thou is not a prescription for winning friends among the thous. But it can be an effective marketing strategy in a business where public confidence is less than solid.

title: Study Finds Lack of Disclosure Among Advocacy Groups
description: Updated:  Some health advocacy groups that say they are speaking for patients interests before legislatures, regulatory agencies or public forums fail to disclose their funding from drug makers, a new study from Columbia University says.

title: Fresh Video of Tunisian Protests
description: On Thursday, as protests continued across Tunisia, bloggers and eyewitnesses posted more video of the demonstrations online, including graphic images of protesters who have been gunned down on the streets.

title: Defections Fuel a Complicated Rivalry
description: This is going to sound like heresy, but for sheer intrigue, bombast and bad vibrations, the feud between the Jets and the Patriots is surpassing that cute little rivalry between the Yankees and the Red Sox.

title: A Step Toward Car Fuel From Wood Waste
description: Almost everybody likes the idea of cellulosic ethanol, or ethanol made from the nonfood portion of crops and from waste like wood scraps or paper. But so far nobody is producing bulk amounts.

title: Palin to Do TV Interview Monday
description: Sarah Palin is scheduled to sit for her first extended interview since the Tucson shooting rampage on Monday night, on the Fox News Channel.

description: Dance

title: Letters: Hanging On as the Boundaries Shift
description: Here is some reader response via e-mail to my most recent column from last Sunday, Hanging On as the Boundaries Shift.

title: TimesCast | January 13, 2011
description: Social media sites help stoke deep unrest in Tunisia; Republicans prepare to vote for new party leadership; and in Tucson, a thousand tiny bells connect a community.

title: Love, Bacon, and a Bit of Ireland
description: THERE are two entrances to Butcher Block. Open the door on the right and you will see a long butchers counter. At the end of it is a sign: We Sell Boiling Bacon. Open the other door, just a few feet away, and you quickly pass a wall  probably 10 feet high and 20 feet long  made up entirely of British potato chips and candies, with names like Wispa, Drifter, Catch, Topic.

title: Gorman Shakes Up Morgan Stanleys Leadership
description: Brendan McDermid/ReutersGregory J. Fleming will run Morgan Stanleys wealth management operation.

title: In Iraq, Biden Reaffirms Deadline for Troops Exit
description: BAGHDAD  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. told officials here Thursday that the United States remained committed to the agreement that calls for all American troops to leave Iraq by the end of the year.

title: Cracking the Guest List on Golden Globe Weekend
description: The Golden Globes are all about the partying. As Helen Mirren confirmed to us last year, the shindig thrown by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association is much more loosey-goosey fun than the Oscars. And even if you arent a bold-faced name, a little sleuthing  and a lot of money  can get you and a plus-one seats at the event and your names on some very exclusive guest lists at the accompanying parties.

title: Spare Times for Jan. 14-20
description: Around Town

title: Rita Ackermann and Harmony Korine
description: Swiss Institute

title: Resolved: Shift to a Savings-Oriented Budget
description: This week on the Bucks blog, our contributors, along with some of our favorite sources, are writing about their New Years financial resolutions. Here, Tara Siegel Bernard, a personal finance reporter for the Times, shares her own plans.

title: Teresa Hubbard and and Alexander Birchler
description: Tanya Bonakdar

title: Graphic Radicals: 30 Years of World War 3 Illustrated
description: Exit Art

title: Cocaines Son
description: CHAPTER 1

title: Done With Drugs, But the Legacy Is Unfinished
description: In the summer of 2005 New York magazine published Cocaines Kid, an unflinching essay by Dave Itzkoff about the addiction of his father, Gerald, a needy, hot-tempered, obsessive, yet nevertheless endearing merchant in the fur trade. The author had already discussed his dad in the ribald memoir, Lads: A Memoir of Manhood, which concerned his own misadventures in the magazine world, but this essay zeroed in on the effects that his fathers addiction had on his own life. It concluded with Mr. Itzkoff doubting whether he or his father, then 65 and purportedly clean, would ever truly be healed of the addictions impact. This is the part of the story where I run out of events to relate, Mr. Itzkoff writes in the last sentence of his essay, but I dont know that I can honestly call it the end.

title: Yurp Too
description: The comments on my euro piece are actually kind of amazing: so many Europeans convinced that any criticism must stem from American desire to see Europe fail. I guess were not so different after all.

title: Intel Reports Record Profit and Exudes Confidence
description: Intel set records for profit and revenue in its latest quarter, offering evidence that businesses were gaining confidence and investing more heavily in technology.

title: Asked & Answered | Mandy Coon
description: Mandy Coon nabbed one of this years Ecco Domani fashion awards for her structural, dark, moody and much buzzed-about designs, but her talents dont stop there. She occasionally moonlights as a D.J. and a model, and it turns out she is also something of a film buff. Her newest side project is called the Fashion in Film-Designer Inspiration movie night. First up for the private event is Ingmar Bergmans beautifully confusing psychological thriller Persona. The film stars Liv Ullmann as Elisabeth, a successful actress who becomes suddenly mute, and Bibi Andersson as Alma, a young nurse who is supposed to care for Elisabeth but falls into an even more twisted and fragile mental state than her patient. The films costumes are more straightforward than the plot  black turtlenecks, a great pleather trench, a monochromatic suit. Its not hard to see why Coon would be drawn to it.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Jan. 14-20
description: Art

title: Drawings in a Museum, Using Bodies
description: I can no longer go along with being the token Minimalist dancing girl.

title: Spare Times: For Children for Jan. 14-20
description: BRAINFEST!

title: Immersed in Images and an Age of Blurred Boundaries
description: For those familiar with the old Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, stepping into the new addition will feel like Dorothy landing in a digital 3-D version of Oz.

title: 36 Hours in Bali
description: MAYBE it was the topless women that the German painter Walter Spies captured in his lush landscapes of Bali during the 1930s. But ever since, foreigners have come to undress. Shirtless Australians, surfboards strapped to the side of their motorbikes, cruise around for the best waves. At five-star resorts, bronzed Italian women in tiny bikinis while away the days with wine. Farther inland, spiritual seekers wrapped in body-skimming sarongs commune in temples. The natives dont go topless anymore, but that doesnt stop the throngs of sunbathers who let it all hang out on Balis busiest beaches.

title: Streetscapes | Central Park
description: One of the most fabulous structures in Central Park, if not the entire city, is Jacob Wrey Moulds sheepfold. For many years the home of Tavern on the Green, it now awaits its next assignment.

title: A Red-Tailed Hawk in Our Midst
description: On Wednesday, City Room watched as a stunned bird rested in The Times's atrium. Video by Erik Olsen/The New York Times.

title: When Pictures Leap to Other Screens
description: Why have a Museum of the Moving Image at all? is the question that readily comes to mind before visiting the new, improved, expanded incarnation of this venerable institution in Astoria, Queens, which reopens its doors on Saturday after a $67 million face-lift that might even put Hollywood cosmeticians to shame.

title: Love, Bacon, and a Bit of Ireland
description: There are two entrances to Butcher Block. Open the door on the right and you will see a long butchers counter. At the end of it is a sign: We Sell Boiling Bacon. Open the other door, just a few feet away, and you quickly pass a wall  probably 10 feet high and 20 feet long  made up entirely of British potato chips and candies, with names like Wispa, Drifter, Catch, Topic.

description: Photographs from Brazil, Ivory Coast, Australia and Afghanistan

title: Whining Winners, Self-Referential Edition
description: A lot of people seem to have liked this post on how people near, but not at, the top manage to feel miserable. I suddenly remembered that I once wrote about the same phenomenon in a 1993 (I think) autobiographical essay, not with regard to money but with regard to academic prestige:

title: Democrats Embrace Mixed-Party Seating for State of the Union
description: Democratic leaders in the House and Senate are embracing the idea of seating lawmakers without regard to party for this months State of the Union address, officials said on Thursday.

title: Favored by Sheep and Other Celebs
description: AT midwinter Central Parks old Tavern on the Green looks empty and forgotten, but this is just the time to go see it. There are no more fancy parties, no limos, just a temporary visitors center and a few food trucks where lights used to twinkle over one of the most popular tourist restaurants in town. Built as a shelter for sheep when they were lawn mowers, it has been cleared of the worst of the restaurant accretions by the Department of Parks and Recreation, restoring to view much of the spectacular Victorian polychromy. Now the 1871 structure is awaiting... what?

title: Assessing Corporate Liability for Insider Trading
description: The plea agreement of Bob Nguyen, who was charged with fraud in the governments investigation of insider trading, puts a very different light on the role of his former employer, the expert consultant firm Primary Global Research.

title: Pictures of the Day: Brazil and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Brazil, Ivory Coast, Australia and Afghanistan

title: Stricter Lending Guidelines for Condos
description: STELLAR credit and steady income will go a long way in helping borrowers secure a home mortgage, but they may not be enough when it comes to buying or refinancing in certain condominium buildings.

title: Q & A
description: Putting Up a Parking Lot

title: Bar Trivia Quiz Nights at Brooklyn Pubs
description: A GROWN man leapt to his feet and screamed. Sean Crowley had just announced that Snooki, one of the exquisitely tanned stars of MTVs Jersey Shore, would not be descending to earth in a transparent ball in Times Square on New Years Eve. (The event was moved to New Jersey.) This meant that the answer to a question Mr. Crowley had posed was false. The mans compatriots whooped and strutted; the rest of the room exchanged dejected shrugs. So go the triumphs and tragedies of bar trivia, a tumultuous emotional journey for even the best of us.

title: Weekend Miser
description: Sometimes getting a good deal means planning ahead. This week, a look at some programs and events that cost little more than the time it takes to fill out an application.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: The $15 Million Man Back in 2001, Jack DiMaio, who will be leaving Morgan Stanley, was known for earning $15 million while at Credit Suisse and having his salary guaranteed for three years. New York Observer

title: House Tour: Roxbury, N.Y.
description: WHAT Three-bedroom house.

title: Artifacts | Doting on Dots: Jennifer Bartletts Recitative
description: An installation view of Recitative, at the Pace Gallery, 2009-2010.  Photo courtesy the artist and The Pace Gallery

title: A Bird Collision in Our Midst
description: After 5,000 red-winged blackbirds fell from the sky in Arkansas on New Years Eve, many Americans awakened to a reality that had not necessarily been on their radar: many birds die as a result of collisions with buildings. Accurate numbers are hard to come by: the federal government estimates anywhere from 97 million to 976 million fatal bird strikes occur annually in the United States.

title: Charles Ryskamp Bequeaths Work to Frick and Morgan
description: A LIFE OF COLLECTING

title: Mobs in Ivory Coast Attack United Nations Vehicles
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  Mobs loyal to Laurent Gbagbo, the president who refuses to give up power after losing an election, burned and stoned five United Nations vehicles on Thursday, including an ambulance, a United Nations spokesman said.

title: For Michael John LaChiusa, A Giant Year of Musicals Awaits
description: 2011 already has a quickening beat for Michael John LaChiusa, the Tony-nominated composer and lyricist of such challenging works of musical theater as Broadways Marie Christine and The Wild Party.

title: Lotus Evoras James Bond Connection Only Skin Deep
description: A one-of-a-kind James Bond Lotus Evora can be yours for a mere $70,894.69. Considering the auction prices commanded by other cars Mr. Bond used to battle evildoers, thats an amazing deal, right?

title: Dymaxion Cars, Americana Auctions and French Gilded Art
description: R. Buckminster Fuller, the architect and philosopher, helped cobble together three car prototypes shaped like zeppelins. They were named Dymaxion, short for Dynamic Maximum Tension. A few clients placed orders around 1933, including Amelia Earhart and the conductor Leopold Stokowski.

title: For Hezbollah, Claiming Victory Could Be Costly
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  With Hezbollahs toppling of the Lebanese government, the militant Shiite Muslim movement entered what may prove to be one of the most dangerous chapters in a 30-year history that has made it reviled in the West and popular in the Arab world: At the moment seemingly of its greatest power, the path facing it could unveil its most glaring weaknesses.

title: J. Henry Fair: Abstraction of Destruction
description: Photographs of environmental pollution from an exhibition at the Gerald Peters Gallery.

title: An Artful Environmental Impact Statement
description: The vivid color photographs of J. Henry Fair lead an uneasy double life as potent records of environmental pollution and as ersatz evocations of abstract painting. This makes Abstraction of Destruction, his exhibition at the Gerald Peters Gallery, a strange battle between medium and message, between harsh truths and trite, generic beauty.

title: Everyones 15 Minutes In a Culture of Celebrity
description: Sometimes an art exhibition can be smart and informative even if its contents are, as in The Talent Show, variously quaint, silly, disingenuous and fatuous.

title: Vantage Point: Saving a Marine's Eyes
description: C.J. Chivers embeds with a medevac team in Afghanistan as it treats wounded soldiers.

title: My Wives Dont Understand Me
description: The culminating season of Big Love  the fifth, which will begin on Sunday on HBO  feels less ripped from the headlines than exhumed from the notebooks Marilyn French used when writing The Womens Room. Steeped in the spirit of 1970s social commentary, this show examines more acutely than ever before the psychic price women pay when their drive, intelligence and energy are arrogated to male ambition. By women here we refer, of course, to the three increasingly alienated wives of the polygamist Bill Henrickson (Bill Paxton), who, by the end of the erratic fourth season, had won a seat in the Utah State Senate and came forward with his unusual domestic arrangement.

title: One Mans Losing Fight Against Ladies Nights
description: A Manhattan lawyer who has filed a series of antifeminist lawsuits in recent years - with little success  has suffered his latest defeat: the United States Supreme Court refused to hear what he calls his ladies night lawsuit.

title: A Pet-Size Dinosaur With Really Big Descendants
description: Researchers have discovered a small but ferocious dinosaur that lived 230 million years ago, just as dinosaurs were beginning to emerge.

title: Have Cool Car and Mask (and Sidekick), Will Travel for Justice
description: The Green Hornet, based on an ancient and much-adapted radio serial, with Seth Rogen in the title role and Michel Gondry behind the camera, is quite a bit less than the sum of its appealing parts.

title: On Our Radar: Pandas Like Old Trees
description: Giant pandas thrive in pristine old-growth forest, new research shows. The findings are revealed shortly before Chinese officials must decide whether to renew a 12-year logging ban throughout the pandas range. [BBC]

title: Rocking a Cradle of Experimental Theater
description: It was almost exactly 16 years ago that I made my first visit to La MaMa in a professional capacity, as a new theater critic for The New York Times. Id been there before as a civilian, usually under the influence. (I believe it was where I first saw a foghorn-throated drag queen named Harvey Fierstein.) But even then La MaMa had for me the whiff of another time, the patchouli scent of the 1960s, when downtown theater was longhaired, renegade and rude.

title: Scraping By in Appalachia
description: So often in the small theaters of New York, it seems as if life stops at 30, so its great to see a multigenerational cast on the stage at the ArcLight Theater in Hillbilly Women. The play, directed by Sondra Lee and staged by the Bleecker Company, has its problems, but it also has one particularly attention-getting performance that leaves you hoping that some casting directors make the trip uptown to see it.

title: Keeping Score: N.B.A.s Haves and Have-Nots
description: Justin Kubatko is the creator of Basketball-Reference.com, an online basketball encyclopedia. He is also a statistical consultant for the Trail Blazers.

title: Taxis for the Future
description: See ideas for the taxis of tomorrow by the artist and inventor Steven Johnson, a self-described conjurer of ludicrous ideas.

title: From the New York Island To California, a Songbook
description: When devising a program for a collaboration between the Juilliard School and the New York Festival of Song, Michael Barrett and Steven Blier, the festivals artistic directors, encouraged the students to scour the map and find material for a concert called Road Trip: An American Travelogue in Song.

title: Israeli Press Office Apologizes for Bra-Gate
description: The head of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahus press office apologized on Thursday for the intensive security screening several journalists were subjected to before a cocktail party they had been invited to by the government.

title: Close to Home, an Avian Emergency
description: 8:58 p.m. | Updated There was a dramatic avian emergency in Midtown on Thursday afternoon, and City Room did not have to go far to report it: a juvenile red-tailed hawk smashed into the five-story glass atrium at The New York Times Building, fell to a fourth-floor landing, then fell again to the courtyard four stories below.

title: Theater Listings: Jan. 14  20
description: Theater

title: How Wireless Networks Fared at CES
description: As my colleague Jenna Worthams article pointed out on Monday, the success of Verizons iPhone offering will depend largely on the Verizon network ability to deliver where AT&T has sputtered, which is reliability.

title: If Its Not One Thing, Its Another
description: It is useful to know that Richard Levine, the writer and director of Every Day, was one of the brains behind that guiltiest of depraved TV pleasures: Nip/Tuck. In the movie his presumed surrogate, Ned (Liev Schreiber), is a writer for a popular New York-based medical drama whose creative team sits around at meetings making wisecracks like sex with ones dog is the new sex with ones cat while dreaming up outrageous plot turns involving cannibalism, bestiality and castration.

title: Fifty-Six Years Later, Giants Bringing Trophy to New York
description: On Oct. 2, 1954, before almost 80,000 fans at Cleveland Stadium, the Indians Dale Mitchell popped out against Johnny Antonelli to give the New York Giants their fifth World Series championship. There is no footage of Willie Mays and friends hoisting the commissioners trophy in triumph. Back then, there was no such thing.

title: Sports Replay: Jan. 13
description: A look at the day in sports, from snowy peaks to waterlogged courses.

title: Life Sentence for Chinese Driver for Evading Tolls
description: BEIJING  Like most drivers around the world, Shi Jianfeng did not like to roll down his window at toll booths. In fact, Mr. Shi, a farmer from Henan Province in central China, was so averse to toll collectors, he evaded more than $550,000 in road fees during eight months of highway driving, according to the provincial court that convicted him.

title: In China, You Cant Fight City Hall
description: The right of the people to petition the Government for a redress of grievances, as the First Amendment to the United States Constitution phrases it, would seem to be a basic feature of the relationship between citizen and state. Even nondemocratic systems acknowledge the principle that the rulers should listen to the complaints of the ruled. Zhao Liangs Petition, a brave and wrenching new documentary from China, takes a bottom-up view of the cruel and absurd ways that lofty ideal is put into practice on the streets of Beijing.

title: U2 Album Producer to Work on Spider-Man Music
description: Steve Lillywhite, the Grammy-winning record producer who counts U2 as among his most frequent clients, has come aboard Spider-Man: Turn Off The Dark, the $65-million Broadway musical featuring music by Bono and the Edge, the bands chief songwriters.

title: Music in Review
description: THE KNIGHTS

title: When a Former Life Beckons
description: SINCE tattoo shops were illegal in South Carolina, where I was living at the time, I drove to Savannah, Ga., to get my first ink. I was 22, drunk on Jack Daniels, and I chose the image from a display at the shop based on what I could afford. Thirty dollars bought me a tiny black flower. Brash and audacious, I lifted my skirt and hopped onto the table.

title: In States of Undress, Mental and Physical
description: With four films behind him (three as both a writer and director), Jeff Lipsky, a co-founder of the independent distribution companies October and Lot 47, has been a vigorous creative force in the independent-film movement. As a maturing filmmaker, he has a style as distinctive as that of John Cassavetes, the independent-movie god who was his forerunner in the distribution business.

title: From the First Lady, Advice for Parents
description: First Lady Michelle Obama on Thursday urged parents to hold up the lives of Christina Taylor Green and other victims of the Tucson shooting as examples for their children, and to speak with their children about tolerance in wake of the tragedy.

title: The Game Plan? Returning to What Works
description: A POPULAR Super Bowl campaign is being revived, although it never really went away.

title: Jude Law, Eddie Redmayne Will Help Michael Grandage Bow Out at Donmar
description: For Michael Grandages final season as artistic director of the Donmar Warehouse, one of Londons premier theater companies, Jude Law (Hamlet) will play Mat Burke and London theater actress Ruth Wilson will play the title character in Eugene ONeills classic Anna Christie, the theater announced on Thursday night. The production, directed by Rob Ashford, is set to run Aug. 4-Oct. 9.

title: Latest Celebutante Satire Already Out of Date
description: Repo Chick

title: AOL Outsources in Health and Sports
description: AOLs turnaround effort under Tim Armstrong, its chief executive, focuses on a few areas of strength: technology news and local news along with products like e-mail and instant messaging. Inevitably, some other services will get less attention.

title: Breaking Records Wont Win Celebrity for Peculiar Elite
description: The only significantly false note in Breaking and Entering is its overly clever title, which doesnt give you much of a clue that its a film about people obsessed with getting their names in the Guinness Book of World Records. Otherwise, Benjamin Fingerhuts documentary is a brisk and absorbing tour of the human ego.

title: East Texans Bad Health and Bad Habits Promote a Stroke Belt
description: PALESTINE  The proof of Anderson Countys live-hard, die-young culture is in the bread pudding  and the all-you-can-eat fried catfish, the drive-through tobacco barns and the dozens of doughnut shops that dot this East Texas county of about 57,000.

title: Referendum Logos Accent Challenges Facing Sudan
description: JUBA, Sudan  Michael Kwol, who said he fought for nearly 40 years through two civil wars only to be shot in the side by bandits, slipped out of the clinic where he undergoes physical therapy, limped through the memorial grounds dedicated to the liberation leader John Garang, threw his crutches to the side and hopped up to the voting booth.

title: Celluloid Critique of Plastics Perils
description: From pantyhose to Porta Potties, plastic  the catch-all term for a wide variety of synthetic materials  has infiltrated virtually every aspect of modern life. For the Austrian filmmaker Werner Boote, its personal: plastic is, quite literally, in his blood. As we discover in Plastic Planet, its probably in ours, too.

title: Subjects and Verbs as Evil Plot
description: Even before the Tucson shootings, Jared L. Loughner acted weirdly and darkly in so many ways that singling out any one aspect may defy sense. Nonetheless, for bizarreness, his rants about grammar stand out.

title: Spider-Man Opening Delayed Until March 15
description: Spider-Man: Turn Off The Dark has delayed its opening for the fifth time, with a new opening night of March 15, the $65-million musicals lead producers announced late Thursday.

title: Tucson Pauses in Grief for the Youngest Victim
description: TUCSON  The first funeral in the aftermath of Saturdays shooting rampage might turn out to be the most heart-wrenching.

title: For Democrats, a Texas-Sized Challenge
description: Texas, because of its growing Hispanic population, is sometimes thought of by Democrats as representing the next frontier in the partys electoral aspirations. So far, however, the party has been able to make only a few inroads.

title: Where the Coaches Let Their Guard Down, a Bit
description: Before each N.F.L. game, a ritual is observed: the network production meeting, where announcers and producers try to ask coaches about their strategies, personnel packages, gadget plays and their injured players actual health status.

title: Humanity Under Layers of Grit and After Years of Crime
description: Like its glum antihero, A Somewhat Gentle Man takes a little time to find its feet. Until it does, you may struggle to care about Ulrik (Stellan Skarsgard), a middle-aged murderer newly released from prison. Beefy and slow-moving, quiet and ponytailed, Ulrik seems content to observe freedom rather than embrace it. His former boss (a strutting Bjorn Floberg) expects him to kill the snitch who put him away for 12 years, but Ulrik is done with violence  or so he thinks.

title: Vatican: Envoy to Vietnam Appointed
description: Pope Benedict XVI appointed an envoy to Vietnam on Thursday, a step toward normalizing diplomatic relations. The Vatican has no formal diplomatic ties with Vietnam, which has about six million Roman Catholics, but relations have been improving recently. The new papal representative in Vietnam, Msgr. Leopoldo Girelli, is currently Papal Nuncio to Indonesia.

title: A Duane Reade in Brooklyn With a Beer Bar
description: When Duane Reade opened a new store a few months ago in Brooklyn, it faced opposition from residents loyal to a local pharmacy. So it decided to include something in the store that the neighborhood did not have: a bar that specializes in beer.

title: Judge Defies Prosecutors on Pornography Sentence
description: A man whose conviction on child pornography charges won him an unusual champion  the trial judge, Jack B. Weinstein  was sentenced on Thursday to five years in prison, the minimum sentence required by law.

title: Lead Plays Himself in Drama on Scandal
description: NEW ORLEANS  On Friday night, the Anthony Bean Community Theater, an 11-year-old institution on the second floor of a church office building, will be putting on a world premiere. Much of the city already knows the plot by heart, as it is based on a true story. The play concerns the downfall of a popular city councilman named Oliver Thomas who is caught taking bribes, betraying the city that supported him.

title: Judge Accepts Guilty Plea by Guidant
description: A judge accepted a guilty plea by Guidant, on charges that it hid defects in heart defibrillators, and placed the company on three years probation to deter similar conduct.

title: Former Student Sues College Over Stay in a Mental Ward
description: She had come to New York from Nigeria after being admitted to the City University of New Yorks most elite honors program, which gives students full tuition, a laptop and a $7,500 stipend.

title: All Tomorrows Taxis
description: Sometime early this year, New York Citys taxi and limousine commission will announce the winner of its Taxi of Tomorrow competition. Or it wont. The project was begun in 2007, and in December 2009 a request for proposals went out to automotive manufacturers and designers. The bar wasnt set all that high: the Taxi of Tomorrow was meant to be safe, fuel-efficient, accessible, durable, and comfortable. A look at the three finalists announced in November 2010 confirms they are perhaps all of those things. They are also, well, dull. Boxy. Lacking in imagination. (Not that New Yorks current cab, the Ford Crown Victoria, was one to inspire much.)

title: A Tale of Two Moralities
description: On Wednesday, President Obama called on Americans to expand our moral imaginations, to listen to each other more carefully, to sharpen our instincts for empathy, and remind ourselves of all the ways our hopes and dreams are bound together. Those were beautiful words; they spoke to our desire for reconciliation.

title: Dimons Options Include Patience
description: JPMorgan Chases chief executive, Jamie Dimon, faces a luxury problem. The bank, which reports earnings on Friday, predicts it will generate up to $50 billion in excess capital over the next three years. The question is what should Mr. Dimon do with this windfall.

title: Uncle Sam Wants His AAA Rating
description: Is Wall Street listening to the Tea Party?

title: Stanford Promotes Coordinator
description: No program in college football executed a more stunning turnaround in the past five seasons than Stanford. The Cardinal surged from one win in 2006 to 12 victories this season, including one in the Orange Bowl.

title: S.E.C. Looking Into Deals With Sovereign Funds
description: 12:08 p.m. | Updated

title: Talking to North Korea
description: After two years of threats and attacks, North Korea may be pulling back from the brink. Or not. North Koreas leadership is so erratic  its not even clear who is in charge right now  that it is impossible to tell.

title: Groupon Advances on I.P.O. That Could Value It at $15 Billion
description: 9:40 p.m. | Updated

title: Cleveland and Denver Choose Coaches
description: After a tumultuous and embarrassing season, the Denver Broncos opted for no surprises and the potential of a fast turnaround Thursday, hiring John Fox, the former longtime Carolina Panthers coach.

title: Wont You Be My Wireless Neighbor?
description: FOR a long time, I relied on my Brooklyn neighbors generosity  that is, their unsecured wireless networks  every time I connected to the Web.

title: Auditors See Rising Defaults in Rural Loans
description: Seeking to buoy a strained rural economy in the midst of the recession, Congress ordered up a huge increase in federal mortgage guarantees for small-town home buyers as part of the 2009 economic stimulus package.

title: In Tucson Case, a Federal Judge Both General and Traffic Cop
description: The judge named to preside over the federal trial of Jared L. Loughner is a no-nonsense jurist who will keep the proceedings moving and focused, colleagues said.

title: Facing Gang Threats and Family Ills
description: Charisma Massey and her friend did not feel threatened when a black car pulled up alongside them as they walked to the corner store in their Crown Heights, Brooklyn, neighborhood one day in October. Not until they heard the gunshots.

title: Illinois and Capital Punishment
description: Eleven years after gross injustice compelled a moratorium on capital punishment in Illinois, the State Legislature has concluded that the only way to guard against execution of the innocent is to outlaw the death penalty. Gov. Pat Quinn, who has sent mixed signals in the past, should quickly sign the legislation into law.

title: The Last Gasp of Australian Tenniss Golden Era
description: On the night he beat Ken Rosewall to reach the final of the 1976 Australian Open, Mark Edmondson took the tram home, just like all the fans leaving the Kooyong Lawn Tennis Club.

title: The Anosmia Case
description: After the financial meltdown, is it really possible a company argued at the Supreme Court that too much information for investors is as bad as too little?

title: Spam, a Lot
description: For a moment, it seemed as if the new year might just deliver us from spam. Last summer, spam volumes started declining around the world, from about 250 billion messages a day in July  almost 40 for each woman, man and child in the world  to about 100 billion a day in November. Then, on Dec. 25, the Rustock botnet, the biggest spam generator, vanished from the Internet. (Two other smaller ones dropped off, too, a few days later.) Volume plummeted to fewer than 30 billion a day.

title: The Transatlantic Slave Trade and the Civil War
description: The conclusion of the historian David Brion Daviss most recent book, Inhuman Bondage, traces the significance of the United States Civil War in the ending of slavery elsewhere. It implicitly poses the question: What if the Confederacy had won recognition from Britain in 1862 and had survived the war? Our rather frightening answer is that the three great centers of slavery in the Americas, the United States South, Cuba and Brazil  plus the smaller plantation economy of Dutch Suriname  would not have abolished slavery when they did.

title: Looking to 2012, G.O.P. Is Set to Select a New Leader
description: OXON HILL, Md.  The Republican National Committee was poised to select a new leader on Friday to prepare for the 2012 presidential election, a challenge that begins by paying off a $20 million debt and navigating divisions between the partys establishment and a newly invigorated grass-roots movement.

title: Computers Get Permanent Hall of Fame
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Silicon Valleys shrine to the computer has finally upgraded to version 2.0.

title: Obama in Tucson: A Call for Healing
description: To the Editor:

title: 15-Year Sentence for Conspirator in Airport Plot
description: A Guyanese man who admitted that he had taken part in a plot to detonate fuel tanks at Kennedy International Airport was sentenced Thursday to 15 years in prison.

title: Futile Drug Prohibition
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 on Parole Board Resign in Wake of Officers Death
description: BOSTON  Five of the seven members of the Massachusetts Parole Board resigned Thursday amid growing public outrage over the fatal shooting of a police officer last month by a parolee with a long criminal record.

title: Pakistani Fundamentalists
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Ex-Officers on Trial in Obstruction Case
description: Three former Pennsylvania police officers went on trial Thursday on charges of obstructing justice in the beating death of a Mexican immigrant in 2008, a prosecution that Hispanics have come to view as a national test case for treatment of Latinos.

title: Making New York Police Data Public
description: To the Editor:

title: Lactation Rooms on Capitol Hill
description: To the Editor:

title: Lottery Numbers
Accused Soldier in Brig as WikiLeaks Link Is Sought
description: WASHINGTON  Julian Assange, the flamboyant founder of WikiLeaks, is living on a supporters 600-acre estate outside London, where he has negotiated $1.7 million in book deals and regularly issues defiant statements about the antisecrecy groups plans.

title: Tree of Failure
description: President Obama gave a wonderful speech in Tucson on Wednesday night. He didnt try to explain the rampage that occurred there. Instead, he used the occasion as a national Sabbath  as a chance to step out of the torrent of events and reflect. He did it with an uplifting spirit. He not only expressed the countrys sense of loss but also celebrated the lives of the victims and the possibility for renewal.

title: How the G.O.P. Can Cut and Survive
description: THE new Congress is less than two weeks old, but pundits from across the political spectrum are already urging the newly empowered Republicans to take on Medicare and Social Security.

title: Report Says Excessive Risk Remains After Bank Bailout
description: WASHINGTON  Citigroup, the giant financial services company bailed out by the government in November 2008, is still too big to be allowed to fail, a situation that could make future bailouts of big banking companies a necessity, a report by a government watchdog said Thursday.

title: Banks Poised to Pay Dividends After 3-Year Gap
description: Investors in bank stocks are about to get a big cut of the profits again.

title: A Clamor for Gun Limits, but Few Expect Real Changes
description: TUCSON  The National Rifle Association has gone uncommonly dark since the weekend shootings here. A posting on its Web site expresses sympathies for the victims of the violence, and N.R.A. officials said they would have nothing to say until the funerals and memorial services were over.

title: Christie Hopes to Lure Businesses Fleeing Illinois Taxes
description: Watch out, Illinois: New Jersey wants your businesses.

title: Ruth Cavin, Editor Known to Cultivate Promising Writers, Dies at 92
description: Ruth Cavin, a widely respected editor and publisher known for discovering talented mystery writers and nurturing them during the early stages of their careers, died on Sunday at her home in White Plains. She was 92.

title: Jack Towers Dies at 96; Remastered Jazz Recordings
description: Jack Towers was an expert at remastering early jazz recordings for definitive collections by the Smithsonian Institution and Time-Life. But he may be best remembered for an original recording he made in 1940, a rarity that sat in his basement for 38 years, heard by almost no one.

title: Joe Gores, Crime Writer in Dashiell Hammett Mode, Dies at 79
description: Joe Gores, a crime writer whose spare, chiseled sentences and deadpan dialogue put him squarely in the Dashiell Hammett tradition and persuaded Hammetts daughter to let him write a follow-up to The Maltese Falcon, died on Monday in Greenbrae, Calif. He was 79 and lived in San Anselmo.

title: Welkers Trash Talk Is a Study in Subtlety
description: For overt trash talking, it would be hard to top what the Jets have unleashed on the Patriots this week.

title: A President, a Speech and a Point of Law
description: Did President Obamas speech at the memorial service in Tucson complicate the federal case against the man charged in the shootings, Jared L. Loughner?

title: Girls Death Hits Home for Obama
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is not known for showing a surplus of emotion in public, but toward the end of his speech at the University of Arizona, he paused for 51 seconds and appeared to gather himself.

title: Funeral for Christina-Taylor Green
description: The funeral for Christina-Taylor Green, a nine-year-old girl who was killed in last Saturdays shooting in Tucson, took place at St. Elizabeth Ann Seton Church on Thursday.

title: No-Prison Deal Revoked, Trial Starts for Ex-City Worker Accused in Sexual Assault of Girls
description: When Tony Simmons sat in a Manhattan courtroom about four months ago, he was agreeing to what some viewed as a sweetheart deal: no prison and 10 years probation in exchange for pleading guilty to sexually assaulting three girls who were under his supervision in Family Court.

title: Spider-Man Wont Open Until March 15
description: Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark has delayed its opening for the fifth time, with a new opening night of March 15, the musicals lead producers announced late Thursday.

title: In Document, Peek at City Plans to Replace Schools
description: The Department of Education is planning to put two new charter schools in the place of the closing John F. Kennedy High School, the troubled behemoth in the Bronx that used to enroll as many as 5,000 students at a time.

title: Ellen Stewart, Theater Pioneer
description: Ellen Stewart, the founder, artistic director and de facto producer of La MaMa Experimental Theater Club, died in Manhattan.

title: With More Luxury Lines in City, Cruise Passengers Spending Rises 54%
description: Judging by the amount of pomp and circumstance that city officials lavished on the Cunard Line on Thursday, an observer might guess that the cruise industry had become a critical part of New Yorks tourism industry.

title: Once Allies, Two Miami Leaders Are Now Anything But
description: MIAMI  Odd political dramas are almost as commonplace as palm trees in this town.

title: Drowning in Domestic Denial in the Sands of Palm Springs
description: The only problem with the gorgeously acted Lincoln Center Theater production of Other Desert Cities, Jon Robin Baitzs seriously satisfying new play, is that you probably need to see it five times. Thats because there are five members in the cast of this ripping family drama of politics, domestic and otherwise, and you never want to take your eyes off a single one of them.

title: A Stylish Monster Conquers at a Glance
description: Within seconds of sweeping onstage, and with a wordless gesture as funny as it is subtle, the great actor Brian Bedford proves beyond question that gender is of no importance whatsoever in portraying the imposing Lady Bracknell in Oscar Wildes greatest comedy, The Importance of Being Earnest.

title: Friday: O, Say Can You Solve?
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Oh oh. Its Friday, and you know what that means. More white squares, tougher cluing. But where the constructor taketh away in terms of gimmes the constructor will also giveth, with unique, long entries and exciting fill. Does that maketh sense?

title: Ibsens Big Chill, With Soul Mates Frozen in Time
description: Baby, its cold inside. Anyone expecting shelter from the chills of January at the Harvey Theater in Brooklyn is asking for disappointment. The visiting Abbey Theater of Ireland has set up its own snow-piled ice palace at this outpost of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, a thaw-proof production of John Gabriel Borkman, Ibsens penultimate play and a work described by no less an authority than Edvard Munch, the painter who gave us The Scream, as the most powerful winter landscape in Scandinavian art.

title: Sporting News Will Take Over AOL FanHouse Content
description: Sporting Newss reinvention as a Web property continued Thursday with a deal to license the AOL FanHouse name and take editorial control of its content. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Among Women in Congress, a Bond of Friendship
description: WASHINGTON  Two arrived at Capitol Hill together, giddy and singled out as women to watch. Another congresswoman was a welcoming face who showed them the ropes in a place where there was not even a ladies room near the floor where they would vote.

title: Borders Said to Be Close to Securing Refinancing
description: In a meeting with publishers on Thursday, Borders laid out a more detailed proposal for moving the troubled company forward, including asking publishers to provide money for a large portion of the companys debt as a loan, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: For Falcons, Only Thing Flashy Is Their Record
description: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga.  Watching his flat-screen TV lately has frustrated Ovie Mughelli, not just because of loud commercials and the recent spate of midseason reruns.

title: Healthy Welker Helps Patriots to Reconnect
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  A year ago, when Tom Brady was being hounded and harassed by the Baltimore Ravens defense in a playoff game, Wes Welker was watching helplessly from the owners box at Gillette Stadium. He was unable to provide Brady with the kind of target that has made him one of the most valuable receivers in football the past four years.

title: House Republicans Edge Back to Business as Usual
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans are carefully trying to return to normal business in the House, announcing on Thursday that lawmakers will next week consider the effort to repeal the health care law that was pulled from the agenda after the Saturday shooting rampage in Arizona.

title: Foreign Missions Hamstrung by New U.S. Banking Rules
description: UNITED NATIONS  Foreign diplomatic missions here and in Washington face the prospect of stuffing their cash into their mattresses as American laws to combat money laundering and terrorism have prompted banks to refuse their accounts.

title: Yankees Sign Soriano for Bullpen
description: Snubbed by Cliff Lee and discouraged by the lack of attractive available starters, the Yankees improved their pitching staff Thursday night by working backward. They strengthened their bullpen by agreeing to a three-year, $35 million contract with Rafael Soriano, whose 45 saves for the Tampa Bay Rays last season led the American League.

title: U.S. Agencies Out of Sync on Flooding in Nashville
description: A series of communication breakdowns and a lack of coordination between government agencies led to low forecasts in the crucial first days of the catastrophic flooding in Nashville last May, a National Weather Service report has found.

title: Newton Declares for N.F.L. Draft
description: After winning the Heisman Trophy and leading Auburn to a 14-0 record and the national title, quarterback Cam Newton announced Thursday night that he would enter the N.F.L. draft.

title: Haiti: Quakes Toll Rises to 316,000
description: The government has raised the death toll for the January 2010 earthquake to 316,000, a substantial increase from the more than 250,000 deaths previously reported. Officials did not explain the change and did not respond to inquiries about it on Thursday. But Prime Minister Jean-Max Bellerive, at a news conference on Wednesday marking the first anniversary of the disaster, suggested it had increased at least in part because additional bodies had been pulled from the rubble.

title: Another Justice Department Vacancy
description: The Department of Justice, already hamstrung by the difficulty of getting key nominees through the Senate confirmation process, is about to have another vacancy in a crucial position. David S. Kris, the assistant attorney general for the departments national security division, announced Thursday that he is resigning, effective March 4. The division, which was created after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, coordinates federal law enforcement work involving matters like terrorism and espionage. Mr. Kris is taking a position with Intellectual Ventures, a Bellevue, Wash., firm that invests in inventions and patents, a department official said.

title: Heavy-Lift Rocket Behind Schedule
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration cannot develop a heavy-lift rocket by the end of 2016 within the budget provided, the space agency told Congress this week. The blueprint specifying NASAs mission for the next three years, which was signed into law by President Obama, called for the development of a rocket that was capable of lifting at least 70 tons into orbit and that was based on technologies from the space shuttle and the smaller, soon-to-be-canceled Ares I rocket. In response, leaders of the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation, which oversees NASA, reiterated that they expected NASA to find a way to fit a rocket design into the specified schedule and budget. In a letter sent to NASA on Thursday, two committee members, Bill Nelson, Democrat of Florida, and Kay Bailey Hutchison, Republican of Texas, wrote that the NASA blueprint is not an optional, advisory document: it is the law.

title: Hutchison Wont Seek Another Term
description: Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, Republican of Texas, said Thursday that she would not seek re-election next year, a move that had been expected after her failed bid for the Republican nomination for governor last year. When her term expires, she will have served for 19 years in the Senate. Her decision gives hope to Democrats and the White House, which believes that the growth in the states Hispanic population is inexorably making the state more open to electing Democrats.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: China: Gates Sees Disconnect Between Military Leaders
description: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Friday in Tokyo that the United States had seen signs of a disconnect between Chinas civilian and military leadership in episodes over the last several years, including when President Hu Jintao appeared to be unaware this week of the test flight of a new Chinese stealth fighter. Mr. Gates said the gap was a worry, but held out the possibility that some incidents might have been the result of bureaucratic mistakes. Over all, he said he remained confident that Mr. Hu, who is to meet with President Obama in Washington next week, is in control of the military.

title: Stoudemire on Pace to Become an All-Star
description: By Amare Stoudemires lofty standards, he had a below-average trip, and the bandages wrapped around his aching shoulder after Wednesdays loss in Utah did not add much comfort. He did, however, find an encouraging development when he returned to New York on Thursday.

description: A whos who of stallions await the champion mare after a thrilling career on the racetrack.

title: Looking for Zenyattas Mr. Right
description: VERSAILLES, Ky.  Zenyatta has had her nails done and been visited by Capone, a teaser stallion with a not very romantic name. He will never have her, though. She is destined for a more pedigreed mate and, as in all arranged weddings, the days before will be fraught with the anxiety and stomach-turning expectations usually directed at the union of British royals.

title: Rangers Are at Their Best Against N.H.L.s Best
description: The Rangers put together a marvelous performance on Thursday night, beating the best team in the N.H.L., the Vancouver Canucks, 1-0, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Kings Center Doubles as Voice for Native Haiti
description: After the earthquake had leveled Port-au-Prince, toppling buildings, taking lives and unleashing a horrific humanitarian crisis, Samuel Dalembert reached out to his father and made a sensible plea: Leave Haiti. Come to the United States. I can take care of you here.

description: Texas produces more law school graduates than it has jobs for. But that has not stopped some lawmakers from proposing that the state build a public law school in the Rio Grande Valley.

description: Exhale, a nonprofit organization based in Oakland, offers free counseling to any woman who has had an abortion. For years, however, the group has tried to distance itself from the polarizing debate surrounding the issue.

description: Devon Reid, an aldermanic candidate in the 26th Ward, said that only one person had slammed the door in his face as he has campaigned for a City Council seat. He said the abrupt dismissal was not because of his views but because of his age: 18.

title: Afghans Case Highlights a Complication of War
description: Assad John Ramin and Tahir Ramin came to New York from Afghanistan as teenagers in 1987, and spent the ensuing years working long hours at family businesses that included a car service, fast-food restaurants and a small hotel near Coney Island.

title: Tunisia Leader Flees and Prime Minister Claims Power
description: TUNIS  Tunisias president, Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, fled his country on Friday night, capitulating after a month of mounting protests calling for an end to his 23 years of authoritarian rule. The official Saudi Arabian news agency said he arrived in the country early Saturday.

title: Toyota Tries to Be More Entertaining
description: While you want to keep your cars wheels firmly in touch with the ground, if you drive a new Toyota later this year, you may find your entertainment system routed in the clouds.

title: Where to Party During Berlin Fashion Week
description: Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week returns to Berlin from Wednesday to Saturday, and with it, plenty of opportunities to party. The overly saturated schedule of parallel events, including temporary showrooms, cocktail receptions and pop-up gourmet canteens, ensures that the fashion week fanfare goes further than the catwalk.

title: How Efficient Is Private Charity?
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

title: Forgotten Game: Jets Victory Over Patriots in September
description: The Jets ability to overcome adversity has been a central theme this season. Recovering from their 45-3 loss to the Patriots and going on to beat the Steelers in Pittsburgh two weeks later is one example. Tuning out issues related to off-the-field shenanigans  some self-inflicted  has been another.

title: Citis Bailout: Ad Hoc Rescue for an Unwilling Bank
description: The agency charged with overseeing the government bailout of Citigroup said in a report published Thursday that the Bush administrations decision to save the financial behemoth was strikingly ad hoc, and that its offer was accepted against the advice of Citigroup insiders who considered the governments terms too expensive.

title: Business Owners Talk Technology
description: Last week I invited you to put in your two cents about the dark side of information technology, along with any praise that came to mind. Thanks much to the many of you who did so. There were a lot of great comments  too many, unfortunately, for me to be able to single them all out or otherwise address them here. Though Im going to dedicate this post to selectively recapping the comments and seeing what perspective we can wring out of them, it wont be my last word on the subject. And some of the comments I neglect here will influence future posts.

title: John Lennons First Car? A Ferrari, and an Auction Standout
description: If John Lennons toilet could fetch $15,000, imagine what his first car might be worth.

title: 2010 Online, by the Numbers
description: Think your e-mail in-box is overflowing because you get dozens of e-mails a day? Thats nothing: Internet users collectively sent 107 trillion (yes, thats with a t) messages in 2010.

title: How Permissive Are Your Parents?
description: Perhaps the most talked-about story in parenting circles this week is Amy Chuas essay in The Wall Street Journal titled Why Chinese Mothers Are Superior,  writes Lisa Belkin on the Motherlode blog. Chinese parents, according to Ms. Chua, set very high standards for their children and refuse to compromise those standards. Read the examples Ms. Chua gives below, then tell us how permissive, or how strict, you think your own parents are. What do they demand of you? Do you think their demands are reasonable? Why or why not?

title: Complaint Box | Calendars
description: It may seem ungrateful of me to lodge this complaint around the time of Martin Luther Kings Birthday. We are, after all, in a purported postracial era. But a cherished annual ritual, finding calendars to organize and inspire me during the coming year, was lost to me this past holiday season, and I cant help wondering if its because race is pass now, in these tough-but-equal times.

title: The Subject Is Slams
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  The worlds greatest tennis players  minus diva-in-chief Serena Williams  have arrived in Melbourne for the years first major tournament, which starts Monday. But there has also been a related surge of activity in the southern California beach community of Carlsbad, where the Aussie expatriate Rod Laver is back to fielding phone calls from far and near. Phone calls with a Grand Slam theme.
