title: Republican Party Poised For New Direction
description: If Republicans reject Michael Steele as chairman of their party Friday afternoon, as seems likely, it will represent a 180-degree turn from their approach just two years ago.

title: Smith & Nephew Says Its Not in Merger Talks
description: Smith & Nephew, the British orthopedics company, denied on Friday that it was having discussions on a sale of the company.

title: Kenen, Mundell, and Europe
description: In my euro article I managed to avoid even using the phrase optimum currency area, but as some readers no doubt realized, OCA theory (pdf) is at the heart of the piece. In the course of writing the article, however, my views shifted at least a bit.

description: Retail sales rose in December, contributing to a quarter of stronger consumer spending during the holiday shopping season, economists and government reports said on Friday.

title: Banca Leonardo to Buy Swiss Advisory Business
description: The Italian investment bank Gruppo Banca Leonardo said Friday that it would acquire the Swiss corporate advisory arm of Sal. Oppenheim for an undisclosed sum.

title: Dispatch | Troncones, Mexico
description: In the years since Julian Schnabel and Damien Hirst started coming to Troncones, Mexico, a fishing village on the Pacific Coast, the town has managed to ward off the glitz thats crept into nearby Ixtapa and Zihuatanejo, just 40 minutes away. Not that things havent changed, of course  theres now a French restaurant to feed the die-hard surfers  but thankfully this is still a one-road town. Here are a few highlights.

title: John Paul II to Be Beatified in the Spring
description: VATICAN CITY  Pope Benedict XVI moved his beloved predecessor one step closer to sainthood on Friday, confirming a miracle by John Paul II and setting May 1, the first Sunday after Easter, as the date of his beatification.

title: Monetary Morality
description: A further thought inspired by the meditations that led me to todays column: I think I now understand the otherwise weird resurgence of paleomonetarism in the midst of a prolonged liquidity trap. Its not really about analysis, its about morality.

title: Police Describe Busy Hours Before a Gunmans Attack
description: TUCSON  Investigators revealed that Jared L. Loughner appeared to pull a frantic all-nighter last week to prepare for the shooting that killed six people, including a federal judge.

title: Payola and Kickbacks Alleged in Golden Globes Lawsuit
description: LOS ANGELES Selling tickets to the afterparties is nothing. In a suit filed in Superior court in Los Angeles on Thursday, a former publicist for the Golden Globes alleges that the organizations members engaged in payola, accepting money and gifts from studios in exchange for nominating their films; sold red carpet space and media access at a profit; and received payment from studios to lobby their fellow Hollywood Foreign Press voters towards (or against) movies.

title: Workplace Flexibility: Less Than Meets the Eye?
description: In late November, I attended an excellent conference on workplace flexibility that was sponsored by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, which began championing that issue after its former president, Ralph E. Gomory, concluded that something just wasnt adding up. Mr. Gomory, once the chief of research at I.B.M., began embracing the cause decades ago when he saw a huge change in the American work force  millions more women were entering the workplace.

description: About 10 percent of young adults in a large study who tested positive for a sexually transmitted disease reported that they had been abstinent for the past year, and half of those said they had never had sex at all.

description: DETROIT  Denso Corporation officials said here Tuesday that the time was ripe for North American vehicles to adopt start-stop technology.

title: Friday Reading: Rising Postal Rates
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: The Will to Drill
description: Oilmen are optimists, by creed if not always by nature, and early last spring things looked, as those in the industry like to say, prospective. The deepwater rigs in the Gulf of Mexico were steadily drilling, with no suggestion of any impending calamity, and oil was flowing from the vast finds in offshore Brazil. Circumstances looked particularly prospective to a geophysicist named Jim Farnsworth, who works for Cobalt International Energy, a company that held a group of leases 50 miles from the mouth of Angolas Cuanza River basin. It was at that site, he had come to believe, that an enormous basin of oil lay, beneath an obscuring layer of salt, in rocks deep below the bottom of the sea. The industry had been over this territory a decade earlier; a few scattered wells were drilled into the Cuanza basin, and then, having found little oil, the companies plugged them. In seismic images, you could still see the pipes, running through the sediment of the ocean floor.

title: Exploring Space From Inside Out
description: DETROIT

title: Belarus Accuses Poland, Germany of Takeover Plot
description: MOSCOW  Belarus accused Poland and Germany on Friday of plotting to overthrow President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko and impose a puppet government with the aid of paid provocateurs from the Belarussian opposition.

title: New York Harbor, 6:50 P.M. Thursday
description: For the benefit of passengers on the Queen Mary 2, the Queen Victoria, the Queen Elizabeth, and anyone else who happened to be watching, there was a fireworks display Thursday night as the three cruise ships converged (but did not collide) near the Statue of Liberty.

description: Television

title: Sam Chandan
description: Dr. Chandan, 37, is the global chief economist for Real Capital Analytics, a market research firm in Manhattan that tracks commercial real estate sales and trends worldwide. He joined the company about a year ago, after his firm, Real Estate Econometrics, was acquired by Real Capital.

title: Oscar Pool Intelligence: The Editors Speak
description: LOS ANGELES Ladies and gentleman, its almost time to call it. The American Cinema Editors announced its nominees on Friday, and because an editing award is considered a must for a best picture win  no film has received the top prize without at least an editing nomination since 1981  and because ACE has a lot of crossover with Academy in its membership, its choices are an excellent predictor. Heres who to favor in your Oscar pool: Black Swan, The Fighter, Inception, The Kings Speech and The Social Network.

title: The Mom Blog Jinx
description: I wonder periodically if there is some sort of mom-blog jinx. I was already an avid reader of blogs even before I was asked to create Motherlode, and now scrolling through several dozen of them each day is my professional routine. When you read so many you cant help noticing that very bad things have happened to a striking number of their authors. Some of this, of course, is because the Internet is now the place to turn when parents are struggling. That would explain many of the blogs that were started after  after a father was paralyzed, or a mother died in childbirth or a husband drowned.But what strikes me is the number of times that tragedy found a blogger who just happened to be blogging. Stephanie Nielsen wrote mostly about life as the mother of four children until she and her husband were nearly killed, and Stephanie was horrifyingly burned, in a plane crash.Heather Armstrong was writing about work when she was blindsided by postpartum depression and blogged her way through a psychiatric hospitalization. The comicDaphne Brogdons blog was about her blended family, until she lost her life savings to Bernie Madoff.

title: Falcons Have an Identity. Its Called Winning.
description: Paul Johnson is a longtime Fifth Down commenter. He answered a request to assess the Falcons, the perception of the Falcons and the mood of the Atlanta area. He lives in Decatur, Ga.

title: The Irrational Awe of China
description: With Chinas President, Hu Jintao, coming to the United States next week, Andrew Kohut of the Pew Research Center reports:

title: Heating/Cooling Unit as Elephant in the Room
description: THE Pencil Factory, a new condominium building in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, has many selling points. Its public spaces include a crisply contemporary lobby, a spacious gym and a roof terrace with views across the East River to Manhattan that elicit gasps.

title: As Turner Soars So Do the Falcons
description: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga.  The contents of the Atlanta Falcons game plan against the Green Bay Packers do not have to be complicated. It should really be a simple procedure: hand the ball to running back Michael Turner, spring him to the second level of the defense against one-on-one tacklers, and enjoy the bounty.

title: Electrics in the Real World
description: DETROIT

title: As Economy Sagged, Online Sports Ticket Market Soared
description: One old saw debunked recently was that pro sports are impervious to recessions. During the past few years, attendance has fallen in nearly every league, several franchises declared bankruptcy and a few more were sold for less than expected. Teams cut ticket prices, sold hot dogs for $1 and did anything they could to get customers in the door.

title: Poparazzi | Carpet Diem
description: If the Romans had wanted to model a gladiatorial event on the traditional wedding reception receiving line, they might have come up with something like the awards-ceremony red carpet. In this brutal contest, two opposing teams face off against each other with competing agendas, borrowed tuxedos and tight smiles concealing deep animosities.

title: Opportunities at Entry Level of Collectibles
description: OVER $172 million in collector cars sold last August in auctions around Monterey, Calif., with 33 classics bringing $1 million or more. By all indications, the Chteau Lafite Rothschild end of the collector car market is doing quite well.

title: Rivals Team Up on Baffinland Bid
description: Richard Perry/The New York TimesSteel plates being produced at an ArcelorMittal plant.

title: What Were Reading
description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.

title: Mines an Astronaut
description: Every time my friend mentions that her husband is a doctor, I want to point out that hes a dentist. Would that be petty?

title: Why Your Next Place May Cost More
description: AT the height of the real estate boom in Manhattan, it seemed a new glass-walled apartment tower was unveiled every week and sold out before the next one even got its Web site up. Now, as the market plods along in a slow but steady recovery, brokers and developers are saying the city will soon face a shortage of new development projects.

title: Homes for Returning Veterans
description: ON an 80-by-60-foot lot between houses in Sound Beach, Mark Baisch, the president of Landmark Properties of Rocky Point, is ready to pour the foundation for a 1,100-square-foot house.

title: Renter Concessions Fading Out
description: AS the new year rolled in, the days when landlords routinely offered one months free rent on a one-year lease began to fade out  if they werent gone already.

title: N.F.L. Playoffs Q. and A. With Judy Battista
description: Judy Battista, who covers the N.F.L. for The Times, answered questions from readers on Friday.

title: Vantage Point: Protecting the Eyes That Face Explosions
description: Late in the afternoon on May 27, 2010, a Marine and Afghan foot patrol working in the scrub and dunes along the Helmand River in Afghanistan unknowingly walked up to a hidden bomb. The description of what happened next will be familiar to anyone who has closely followed the war, or walked Afghanistans rural provinces with Western troops for any length of time.

title: The Week in Pictures, Jan. 14
description: A look back at the past weeks events in New York City and the region.

title: Spill Report Accuses Jindal of Showboating
description: Jockeying by Gulf Coast officials for limited oil spill-fighting resources and the construction of a massive chain of sand barriers to block oil offshore  a key priority of Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana  did little to protect the coastline and often hampered the more effective actions of federal responders to the 2010 oil spill, according to the final report by the presidential panel investigating the spill.

title: Spec Builders Test the Waters
description: AS the high end of the Westchester market shows tentative signs of rallying and the inventory of houses for sale is finally being absorbed, a handful of spec builders are re-entering the field  though more cautiously than during the real estate boom.

title: Cam Newtons Decision to Turn Pro
description: In todays least surprising development that still qualifies as news, Auburn quarterback Cam Newton will announce he is making himself eligible for the N.F.L. draft (some will prefer the term going pro for obvious reasons and a raft of ensuing jokes about Cecil Newtons cut), but this is clearly a decision that came with the degree of difficulty of say, inhaling. Becoming eligible for the N.F.L. draft requires raising his hand, while staying eligible at Auburn might involve superhuman feats and perhaps mass hypnotism. He won a national championship and a Heisman trophy despite a cloud of controversy. The only cloud involved in entering the N.F.L. draft is created by Mel Kiper Jr.s hairspray.

title: Thanks, but No Thanks: St. Johns and Lawyer Disagree
description: Is St. Johns University botching its handling of a lawsuit that could bring in more than $40 million for the school?

title: Missed Calls Leave Players, Coaches Fuming
description: Some N.H.L. players and fans are asking a familiar refrain today, namely, Can I Get a Witness?

title: Emily Ross and Ryan Hubbard
description: THE plot lines of their romance have the makings of a screwball comedy.

title: Clinton Veteran Will Be Bidens Chief of Staff
description: With each passing day, the Obama administration is looking more and more like the Clinton administration.

title: Talya Oberfield and Ari Lucas
description: Talya Danis Oberfield, a daughter of Naomi Danis of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Gil R. Oberfield, is to be married in Roslyn Heights, N.Y., Sunday to Ari Shalom Lucas, the son of Edy Haber Lucas and Rabbi Alan B. Lucas of Roslyn Heights. The bridegrooms father is to perform the ceremony at Temple Beth Sholom, where he is senior rabbi, with Rabbi Gerald C. Skolnik taking part.

title: An Identity Dyed in the Wool
description: A PLEASING cityscape appears in the wraparound windows of Elizabeth Penberthys 11th-floor loft apartment in the garment district on the West Side of Manhattan: pointed buildings; glassy buildings; the Hudson River.

title: Stories From an Irish Master
description: Why does the short story lend itself so naturally to the muted but still shattering sentiments of yearning, nostalgia and regret? How many William Trevor tales focus on the moment when a heart is broken or at least badly chipped? Though Mavis Gallants work bristles with barbed wit and trenchant social observation, her most moving stories often pivot on romantic ruptures and repressed attraction.

title: Gryphon
description: The Next Building I Plan to Bomb

title: Charles Baxters Midwest
description: Reflecting our dazzlingly diverse culture, the contemporary American short story is virtually impossible to define. Where once the well crafted short story in the revered tradition of Henry James, Anton Chekhov and James Joyce was the predominant literary model  an essentially realist tradition, subtle in construction and inward rather than dramatic  now the more typical story is likely to be a first-person narration, or monologue: more akin to nonliterary sources like stand-up comedy, performance art, movies and rap music and blogs. Such prose pieces showcase distinctive voices as if fictional characters, long restrained by the highly polished language of their creators, have broken free to speak directly and sometimes aggressively to the reader  as in boldly vernacular stories by Junot Daz, Chuck Palahniuk, Edwidge Danticat, George Saunders, John Edgar Wideman, Denis Johnson and T. C. Boyle, among others. (Yet Edgar Allan Poe, as long ago as 1843, brilliantly gave voice to the manic and utterly convincing murderer of The Tell-Tale Heart  perhaps genius is always our contemporary.)

title: Up Front: Roxana Robinson
description: Roxana Robinson, who reviews Edith Pearlmans collection Binocular Vision as part of our cover package this week, has written three story collections of her own, to go along with four novels and a biography of Georgia OKeeffe.

title: Stories of Dislocation and Relocation
description: Why in the world had I never heard of Edith Pearlman? And why, if you hadnt, hadnt you? It certainly isnt the fault of her writing, which is intelligent, perceptive, funny and quite beautiful, as demonstrated in Binocular Vision: New and Selected Stories. In the world of literary fiction Pearlman is hardly unknown: shes the author of three previous collections, Vaquita, Love Among the Greats and How to Fall; she has won several prizes; and her work has appeared repeatedly in Best American Short Stories. So she should be known all over the place.

title: Two Guys From Paris
description: One way to read this book, a dialogue between two famous French authors, is as a comic novel, a brilliant satire on the vanity of writers. Michel Houellebecq, who won last years Prix Goncourt, Frances highest literary award, for his latest novel, La Carte et le Territoire, is well known for his provocative black humor. Bernard-Henri Lvy (also known as BHL), though less noted for his wit, likes to play up to his reputation as a comic figure, popping up here, there and everywhere in his fine white shirts, opened halfway down his chest, holding forth on everything from Jean-Paul Sartre to jihad in Pakistan, and generally acting out the role, in a somewhat theatrical fashion, of the great Parisian Intellectual.

title: Womans Work
description: If novels were textbooks, this highly original one might be called America in the 1950s: A Time of Existential Anxiety and Busywork for Women. Robb Forman Dew covers both the cosmic and the quotidian as she follows a formidably intermingled group of people in the town of Washburn, Ohio. The novel, which resides mostly in the 1950s until an acceleration near the end yanks everyone all the way up to 1973, beautifully chronicles the experiences of a widowed schoolteacher, Agnes Scofield, and those in her midst.

title: Following the Scent
description: Each 30-milliliter bottle of Chanel No. 5 is packed with the essence of a thousand jasmine flowers, the fragrance of a dozen May roses from Grasse and a heaping dose of aldehydes, the molecules that early on gave the scent its modern edge. But as Tilar J. Mazzeo points out in The Secret of Chanel No. 5, these are only a few of the many ingredients that turned a perfume into a 20th-century obsession. Into the brew went Coco Chanels warm memories of tallow soap and her anguish over lost love, as well as the perfumer Ernest Beauxs nostalgia for imperial Russia and the Arctic breezes of the White Sea. The result: alchemical magic and unprecedented sales that have led industry insiders to refer to No. 5 as le monstre  the monster.

title: An Addict in the Family
description: Dave Itzkoff was 8 years old when he discovered that the father he could never rely on  brimming with loquacious energy one moment, losing his temper the next  was in fact a drug addict. Hes been addicted to cocaine almost your whole life, his mother informs him at last, explaining why shes filing for divorce.

title: Graphic Books Best-Seller Lists: Vampire Love
description: With so much loving going around for vampires, this collected edition was kind of inevitable: at No. 1 on the hardcover list this week is the first volume of the Vampirella Archives, published by Dynamite Entertainment. The earliest adventures of Vampirella, a good creature of the night who combats evil bloodsuckers, are contained within and date back to 1969. Her very first cover was by Frank Frazetta and the writers and artists who chronicled her stories are the best of the best: Archie Goodwin, Bernie Wrightson, Wally Wood, Neal Adams and more.

title: Determined to Strike
description: For years, I tried to read every new novel about how 9/11 affected our lives. Some were very thoughtful, but I always came away unsatisfied, feeling that the authors had worked hard but had somehow fallen short. As I read the stunning first section of Peter L. Bergens new book on the war between the United States and Al Qaeda, I realized I had been looking in the wrong genre. None of the novels were as effective or moving as The Longest War, which is a history of our time.

title: The View From Lazy Point
description: Prelude

title: Delicate Planet
description: This has been a dismal year for the health of our planet. Evidence of human-caused catastrophe mounts daily with grim reports from sea, sky and land: disappearing species, the collapse of fisheries, deforestation, the shrinking ozone layer, higher concentrations of atmospheric carbon dioxide, oceanic dead zones, warming temperatures, extreme weather, rising sea levels, depleted aquifers, melting glaciers, thawing permafrost. We have already crossed into an unimaginable new epoch, but we seem unable to unite behind efforts to change, or even slow, our disastrous course.

title: Pixars Cars 2 Is Previewed at Detroit Auto Show
description: After Detroit auto show press previews conclude, the AutoWeek Design Forum commands the spotlight.

title: Pig With Passport
description: If pigs could fly, theyd vacation in Italy. Or at least Olivia would. After a hiatus of several years, Ian Falconers rambunctious, curly-tailed heroine is back, and  look out, world!  this time she has a passport. In her latest escapade, Olivia Goes to Venice, the piglet leads her family on a spree through the City of Bridges, with frequent pit stops for gelato. They wander among palazzos and canals. They enjoy a gondola ride. They get mobbed by a Hitchcockian flock of pigeons in the Piazza San Marco. Through it all, Olivia runs the show, until her search for the perfect souvenir quite literally brings down the house.

title: Curses in the Air
description: Ive suffered a loss, a man says in Plain Kate, a historical fantasy for teenagers by Erin Bow. Truly, madly, deeply felt loss saturates the novel, scarring its characters, none more so than Bows orphaned heroine, Plain Kate.

title: Rhythms of a New Land
description: I was a 9-year-old philistine. Sure, as a dance student I knew my Tchaikovsky and my Petipa. Id even heard of Stravinsky and Balanchine. But Id never heard of Martha Graham  not until the day I was made to enter a studio, bare my feet, plant my derrire firmly on the floor and contract my stomach, intensely and repeatedly, in a bout of abdominal torture. After that experience? I wasnt sure I wanted to know this Graham person.

title: The Deadliest Book Review
description: Its easy to imagine how a novelist might use a real person as a basis for a fictional character. Its equally easy to imagine how such a person could notice the similarities and perhaps become offended. After all, the fiction writer has pledged an oath to serve a calling higher than mere feelings. Why should F. Scott Fitzgerald worry over the sensitivities of Max Gerlach in creating Jay Gatsby?

title: Editors Choice
description: MARSHALL MCLUHAN: You Know Nothing of My Work!,  by Douglas Coupland (Atlas, $24.) Coupland takes a pop-culture approach to the man known for the phrase The medium is the message, a deep thinker who ended up popularized almost in spite of himself.

title: Inside the List
description: DEEP THOUGHTS: Hubert Dreyfus and Sean Dorrance Kellys All Things Shining lands at No. 22 on the hardcover nonfiction extended list  not bad for two philosophy professors who aim to restore meaning to contemporary life through close encounters with classic Western texts.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE SELECTED WORKS OF SAMUEL BECKETT,  edited by Paul Auster (Grove, $65.) First published in April 2006 to commemorate the 100th anniversary of Becketts birth, this four-volume set gathers his major works in fiction, drama, poetry and criticism, including The Unnamable, Waiting for Godot and essays on Proust and Joyce. What one will find between the covers of these four volumes are the works on which Samuel Becketts reputation rests, Paul Auster writes in the introduction, everything that qualifies him as one of the great literary artists of our time. . . . Open anywhere and begin reading.

title: Bailouts and Confidence
description: There is celebration that Portugal paid only 6.7 percent when it sold long-term bonds, and that Spain and Italy were able to access the bond markets. Never mind that the rates would have seemed outrageously high a year ago. If you expect disaster, anything else can seem to be good news.

description: If youre mulling ways to get more grains into your diet, think soup, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health.

title: Appalachian Spring': From Page to Screen
description: Appalachian Spring was one of the great triumphs of Martha Grahams career. In The New Yorker, Joan Acocella once called it the loveliest piece she ever made. The story of a pioneer couple newly arrived on the American frontier, it had its premiere in 1944 at the Library of Congress and became an instant treasure. Critics called it a valentine to this country.

description: Appalachian Spring was one of the great triumphs of Martha Grahams career. In The New Yorker, Joan Acocella once called it the loveliest piece she ever made. The story of a pioneer couple newly arrived on the American frontier, it had its premiere in 1944 at the Library of Congress and became an instant treasure. Critics called it a valentine to this country.

description: A plane splash-landed in the Hudson River one surreal January afternoon two years ago, and all 155 people aboard survived. The improbable, incongruous events of Jan. 15, 2009, have since become ingrained in our citys consciousness.

The tentatively titled Barefoot Stories, to be published by Hyperion, is a string of tales about Ms. Spaceks childhood in the South and her rise to fame as the star of films including Coal Miners Daughter and Carrie.

title: Voting Begins for RNC Chairman

description: The Look: Pretty in plum!

title: Some More Unusual Company for Admiral Nelson

title: Pushing Petals Up and Down Park Ave.
description: THE first sign of spring this year in New York may be the work of Will Ryman, whose site-specific art installation, The Roses, will be unveiled on Jan. 25. It will cover 10 blocks of Park Avenue with an unseasonable crop of giant pink and red rose blossoms.

title: For Matthews Clan, N.F.L. Is All in the Family
description: Brodie Matthews may or may not become part of an unprecedented fourth generation of N.F.L. players from his family. He is only 2 months old.

title: A Conversation With Barry Eichengreen
description: This post starts a series on Economix called Book Chat. Each installment will be a short conversation, typically conducted by e-mail, with the author of a recent or imminent book on economics. As usual, we will define economics quite broadly.

title: Penguins Harmed by Tracking Bands, Study Finds
description: Bands attached to penguins flippers have helped scientists track their movement and migration for 50 years. The small identification tags are visible to researchers through binoculars from 100 feet away. Now, a new study reports that the seemingly innocuous bands have a significant effect on penguin mortality.

title: Watch Me, Read Me
description: A deep fantasy of most readers is that their books will one day come to life. Of course theres the college-reader hope that reality itself will come to shimmer with the intense meaningfulness of books. But you get over that. The wish that remains is less romantic: the longing for a byte of audio here and there, among the pages of text, so you could hear what Uriah Heep really sounds like when he says,  Umble to this person, and umble to that in David Copperfield, or a video clip so you could get a sense of Jack Ryans appearance in Patriot Games. What if you could give your imagination a break and watch a clip of Harrison Fords Jack Ryan and be done with it?

title: The Crazy Lady Upstairs
description: Before we took the apartment on Rialto  a palm-tree-and-bougainvillea-lined avenue a few blocks from the Pacific  the landlord told me about her. He said there was a kind of daffy older lady whod be living above us. He said she was like the concierge of the building and had been there a few decades but sometimes drank too much and every so often would yell. I was desperate for an apartment in Venice Beach, and I wanted our lives to start rebounding from our disastrous relocation from Maine, but that stopped me in my tracks.

title: Tragic Artifacts
description: Traveling in Poland, I visited antique stores offering Jewish items  menorahs, mezuzas  that seemed more than 65 years old, suggesting that they were looted in the Holocaust. I saw things I wished to make part of my own Jewish home but found myself unable to pay for what was probably stolen property. Part of me wishes I had stolen (liberated?) some of them. Would that have been justified? RANDY MALAMUD, ATLANTA

title: Branding Transparency
description: What image comes to mind when you think of WikiLeaks? Some see it as heroic, others as destructive. Either way, the release of formerly classified documents and diplomatic cables over the last six months have helped transform the site and its founder, Julian Assange, into known entities. But while thinking of Apple or Facebook or even the 2008 Obama campaign calls up certain aesthetic associations or shorthand imagery, WikiLeaks mostly brings to mind the image of Assanges wan face and silver hair. Perhaps, as Daniel van der Velden of the design studio Metahaven argues, WikiLeaks ought to re-evaluate its visual identity. Does it matter what it looks like? he asked in a talk sponsored by the Graphic Design Museum in the Netherlands. Maybe it does.

title: What Happens in Vegas
description: After nearly 12 years as the mayor of Las Vegas, you hardly need to be reminded that what happens in Vegas stays in Vegas. That is, except for families. Nevada has the highest home-foreclosure rate in the country, and the median home price in the Las Vegas area has fallen to $138,000, from $317,000 in 2006. Im the kind of guy who makes lemonade out of lemons, and I think its a terrific opportunity. Im not sure what you can get for that amount, but you can certainly get a beautiful home with a swimming pool in a gated community for under $200,000.

title: Letters: My Futuristic Insta-Family
description: Melanie Thernstroms account of her difficult road to creating a family was truly heartwarming. For those of us blessed with easy conception, the grief endured by infertile couples is unknowable. Having lost a child to an accident early in my childbearing years, I dont know how I would have coped if I had not been able to conceive again. Thernstrom was able to give voice and feeling to something that most people cannot imagine. I applaud her openness and her ability to have us see both the clinical and emotional sides of reproductive technology. She has done a great service to all couples valiantly working toward becoming parents.

But lately, Barcelona has taken a page from the New York bar scene, with newly fashionable hotel bars attracting stylish Barcelonans in addition to guests. No longer lonely hangouts mostly populated by jet-lagged travelers, the bars and lounges at luxury hotels are now among the citys most desirable drinking destinations.

title: Restaurant Review: Island Creek Oyster Bar, in Boston
description: Island Creek Oyster Bar brings a special twist to the trend of farm-to-table restaurants: the small farms carefully listed next to each dish on Oyster Creeks menu specialize in aquaculture, the raising of seafood and shellfish. But thats not all: the restaurant itself is an extension of Island Creek Oysters, a farm founded in 1992 in nearby Duxbury, Mass. So its no surprise that though the menu is long and varied, at Island Creek, which opened in October, oysters take pride of place.

title: On the Size of Chinas Economy, a Dissenter
description: In my post on China and the United States earlier today, I was careful to say that, by most measures, the United States still has by far the largest economy in the world. The International Monetary Fund, for instance, estimates gross domestic product in the United States to have been about $14.6 trillion last year, while Chinas was $10.1 trillion. The World Bank estimates a similar gap.

title: N.B.A.s New Commercial Misfires
description: The N.B.A.s latest marketing foray not only lacks the charm of previous endeavors, but actually borders on creepy in its attempt at capturing the surreal. At the risk of oversimplifying, it doesnt seem to have much of a point. We, the viewing audience, dive into Kevin Durants past to watch an apparent time traveler pretend to inform Durant of his eventual N.B.A. fate. In the lack of real purpose, were left to focus solely on the commercials aesthetic, which is as bizarre as it is false.Its silly to ask how we - along with our mystery traveler - are transported to Rockville, Maryland circa 2005. After all, beyond a typical suspension of disbelief that accompanies the commercial medium, television ads are typically constructed in a serialized manner. In Television Culture, media scholar John Fiske described the serialized form as an infinitely extended middle, and in a sense, thats where these spots take (and leave) us. The year 2005 isnt a beginning in any sense for Durant, and were not privileged to see the process by which our traveler makes his way into Durants past. Theres also no real attempt at ending or closure, marking the images we see as some sort of enduring middleness, a journey which we join in progress. If nothing else, such a structure reinforces that this tale were witnessing is hardly our own.

title: Christie Will Be Keynote Speaker at Republican Dinner
description: As if any more confirmation were needed that Republicans see Chris Christie as a national star, New Jerseys governor will be the keynote speaker at the National Republican Congressional Committees annual dinner, the committee announced on Friday. The dinner will be held March 30 at the National Building Museum in Washington.In July, when Mr. Christie had been in office for less than six months, the National Governors Association named him to its nine-member executive committee. Over the summer and fall, video clips of him dressing down his critics became YouTube hits. In the stretch run of last years campaigns, he was one of the most sought-after surrogates, stumping for Republican candidates around the country.

title: Just One Look | Derek Lam Pre-Fall Collection
description: The Pre-Fall Collections, being shown in New York over the next several weeks, arrive in stores in May to fill the gap between bikinis and furs.Derek Lam is from California, where the change of seasons is often a nonevent, and he approached pre-fall with a seemingly light hand. There was no shortage of workmanship in his peplumed dresses (designed to look like a top and a skirt) and sharp riding jacket. But depending on which coast you call home, its quietly stylish pieces like his guncheck shift dress  photo printed on silk crepe de Chine  or this shirt dress and fur vest that will weather the transition from summer to fall or even see you clear through to December.

title: New Yorks All-Time Best Restaurants: An Alternate Take
description: It would be easy enough to start a fight by proposing the 10 best New York restaurants of the past decade. Robert Sietsema is just begging for a brawl by daring to name the 10 best of the past two centuries. Point number one (the obvious): we have no idea what the food tasted like at Delmonicos in 1858, or even what the raw ingredients tasted like, for that matter. Try naming the 10 greatest tenors before the era of recorded sound. We know who the most famous ones were, and we have written descriptions of something that cannot, in the final analysis, be put into words. But thats it.
