description: SAN FRANCISCO  Few chores are as unpleasant as doing taxes. But filers can avoid some of the drudgery by turning it over to their mobile phones.

title: Verizon Deal May Expose iPhone Flaws
description: With this weeks announcement that Verizon Wireless is going to begin selling the iPhone  something its customers have been panting for ever since AT&T got that first, exclusive iPhone contract four years ago  its time for me to face the music. Nobody really cares that the iPhone is flawed. After this column, Im going to stop caring too. I swear it.

title: Australian Towns Band Together for Flood Cleanup
description: GRANTHAM, Australia  For Allan Marshall, this tiny Australian town has always been a tightly knit place, never more so than in days since a surging, flotsam-filled torrent hit the town, smashing apart homes and sweeping neighbors to their deaths.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 14
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: The Revamped O.E.D. Online
description: Language lovers might want to check out this weeks Bits: Tech Talk podcast, which features a conversation with John Simpson, the chief editor of the Oxford English Dictionary.

title: The Revamped O.E.D. Online
description: Language lovers might want to check out this weeks Bits: Tech Talk podcast, which features a conversation with John Simpson, the chief editor of the Oxford English Dictionary.

title: When TV Makes Your Diner Shine
description: TO prepare for the first showing of a segment about his tiny Venezuelan restaurant on the Food Network show Diners, Drive-Ins and Dives, Michael Young, owner and chef of Valencia Luncheria in Norwalk, said his staff prepped for a week.

title: Nearly One in Four Teachers Stymied By Snow
description: While fewer than half of the citys 1.1 million school children made it to school through the snow on Wednesday, their teachers didnt earn a gold star for attendance, either.

title: Just One Look | Valentino Pre-Fall Collection
description: The Pre-Fall Collections, being shown in New York over the next several weeks, arrive in stores in May to fill the gap between bikinis and furs.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 14
description: More Photographs

title: Beethovens Varied Descendants
description: In 2008 the young German composer Jrg Widmann wrote Con Brio, a concert overture, to open a program by the Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra that was to proceed to Beethovens Seventh and Eighth Symphonies. Mr. Widmann used the same instrumentation called for in those Beethoven works. And if there are no exact quotations from the symphonies, Mr. Widmanns overture is run through with Beethovenian riffs, flourishes and humor.

title: Matters of Faith, Prayer And Physical Exertion
description: So much art slides out of your mind as soon as you see it: it demands nothing, it gives nothing. Such empty performances engender a particular type of desperation, especially for those who see a lot of shows. At a certain point, trapped in a theater, all you can hear are the seconds ticking away.

title: Cajun-Spiced Food, in a Nonprofit Setting
description: PATRICK PIERRE-JEROME made a name for himself in the 90s, earning raves at his Montclair bistro, Yves, and later at Stage Left in New Brunswick, where he was executive chef. Then, after a tough divorce, he disappeared, cooking in country clubs for several years. His return to the public eye came in an unlikely setting: a nightclub and restaurant, run by a nonprofit group, where live music shares the stage with a succinct menu of moderately priced Cajun-spiced Southern food.

title: A Focus on Cheese
description: When Maria Tisdall cooked for the Benedictine nuns at the St. Walburga Monastery in Elizabeth during the 1990s, she became enough of an expert to write a cookbook, The Convent Cook: Divine Meals for Families Large and Small (Ten Speed Press) in 2002.

title: Cardamom-Scented Oatmeal Pancakes With Apricots and Almonds
description: Time: 30 minutes with cooked oatmeal

title: For Whole-Grain Pancakes, Try a Little Tenderness
description: FAR be it from me to attack an icon (and anyway, Ive eaten my share), but the common pancake is little more than a vehicle for maple syrup. Without that and careful browning in butter, its a total bore.

title: Reruns Work for CBS
description: Despite a lineup of mostly reruns, consistency carried CBS over rival ABC to top the ratings in prime time on Thursday. According to Nielsens estimates the networks repeats of CSI and The Mentalist earned 9.7 million and 10.3 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m. while a new episode of $#*! My Dad Says at 8:30 garnered 10.2 million viewers after a repeat of The Big Bang Theory at 8 (10.4 million). ABC ranked second on the night despite leading during both the 8 and 9 p.m. time slots with Wipeout (10.5 million) and Greys Anatomy (12.2 million). But at 10 a rebroadcast of the premiere of ABCs new show Off the Map garnered just 6 million viewers, down from this medical dramas original debut on Wednesday (7.6 million). Fox was third and NBC a distant fourth. President Obamas speech in Tucson on Wednesday drew a total of 30.8 million viewers, according to Nielsens calculation of the television audience watching the four main broadcast networks and three cable news channels.

title: Orchestra Up to Date in Kansas City
description: A meaty season is planned for a new hall in Missouri. The Kansas City Symphony will move into Helzberg Hall in the new Kauffman Center for the Performing Arts in September, and on Friday the orchestra announced ambitious programming for the 2011-12 season. Michael Stern, the music director, will lead three premieres: new works by Chen Yi, Stephen Hartke and Dan Kellogg. The orchestra will also play Respighis Pines of Rome; Brahmss German Requiem; Mahlers Symphony No. 2 (Resurrection); Beethovens Symphony No. 9; Saint-Sanss Symphony No. 3, which will include the halls new pipe organ; and works by Messiaen and Schnittke. The musicians should come ready to rehearse: 28 percent of the works in the non-pops season, officials said, are either newly composed or new to the orchestra. The orchestra is also springing for major soloists, including Emanuel Ax, Yo-Yo Ma, Yefim Bronfman, Joshua Bell and the Kansas City native Joyce DiDonato.

title: Dont Expect References to Literary Giants
description: From where I am sitting, writing this review, in a cafe in the white-hot center of brownstone Brooklyn, the phrase Brooklyn Kinda Love has a connotation very different from the one that Playboy TV executives intended when they created a series bearing that name.

title: Market Shopping, From Home
description: Farmers markets have become so popular that many are staying open  or just beginning operations  in the winter. Now, in a further adaptation, one off-season market in Westchester County is offering a new service: home delivery.

title: Lawyer Enters Guilty Plea in Galleon Case
description: A lawyer who was ensnared in the insider trading case involving the Galleon Group pleaded guilty on Friday to charges that he leaked nonpublic information about mergers and acquisitions that his firm was working on. The plea was entered in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Setting Leadership Aside For Collective Control
description: A bolt of bracing indeterminacy shot through the trumpeter Tomasz Stankos late set at the Jazz Standard on Thursday night. Tempos lurched and buckled, or mysteriously dissolved. Melodic lines snaked quickly through oblique intervals, defying resolution. Mr. Stanko framed his solos in long, searching arcs, each note sharply articulated but unpredictable in its aim. His engagement with the other musicians in the band suggested a kind of collective bargaining rather than the resolute charge of a leader and his men.

title: Recipes for Pancakes, Sweet and Savory
description: Cardamom, oatmeal, ricotta, zucchini, carrot and other worthy additions to the batter.

title: Laid-Back and Indulgent
description: OPEN for almost three months, Arrosto, in Port Chester, joins a growing number of urban-chic restaurants in the county. The place is a beauty, intelligently designed to suit the open, cavernous space. At its center is a work station, the front dedicated to the preparation of appetizers and the back a serious cooking stage with a wood-burning oven and a grill, for firing pizzas and roasts.

title: The Tiger Mother Speaks
description: Amy Chua wants you to know she was misunderstood.

title: Where the Food Leans Toward the Healthful
description: JANUARY, when the echoes of New Years resolutions are still ringing in ones ears, is a good time to visit Miraj Healthy Grill in Williston Park. As the name suggests, this nine-month-old spot serves the kind of food we are supposed to be eating. It features Persian and Mediterranean cuisines, which translate to grilled meats, big salads and vegetable-laden appetizers.

title: Scotch Eggs With Much Less Mess
description: LETS start with the kicker: everything tastes better fried.

title: A.I.G. Repays N.Y. Fed and Looks to Big Stock Sale
description: 8:33 p.m. | Updated

title: A. O. Scotts Take on the Golden Globes
description: How much do the Golden Globes serve as a predictor of the Oscars? What films have the best chance of winning? Who is the Hollywood Foreign Press Association? And does our co-chief movie critic even care?

title: Britains Labour Party Wins By-election
description: LONDON  The first electoral test for Britains coalition government since it took office eight months ago produced a clear-cut win on Friday for the opposition Labour Party and a collapse in the vote for the Conservatives.

title: Forget Dancing With Wolves; He Runs Up Elephants
description: Ong Bak 3 begins with a recap of the events of Ong Bak 2, which means that the best moment of 2  when the star, the Thai martial-arts god Tony Jaa, runs up the face of an elephant  is also the best moment of 3.

title: Room to Feed 20 or Play With 2
description: WHEN Victoria Robinson, a lifelong product of Manhattans Upper East Side, announced that she and her partner, Nicole Eisenman, were planning to buy a house in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, her mother couldnt have been more dismayed.

title: Covering China, 1992
description: Nicholas D. Kristof and Sheryl WuDunn on the obstacles and rewards of reporting from China in 1992. (Video produced by Patrice Samara)

title: When Covering Means Losing, Try Ducking
description: Any juniors who are hoping to win this years Richard Freeman Junior Deal of the Year award from the International Bridge Press Association should study the diagramed deal, which occurred during the 5th World University Championships in Kaohsiung City, Taiwan, last August.

title: Improvising Concert Into Rousing Sermon
description: NEWARK  Dr. Kings legacy says to us, dont you throw in the towel, Shirley Caesar admonished at about the 10th minute of a short and brilliant performance at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center on Thursday night. She was already in gear: her kind face had set into fierce muscle. Dont you give up, she said. Dont you accept everything a doctor says to you.

title: From the Vaults, Vintage Heroics of All Kinds
description: The Black Pirate

title: Spider-Man Producers Say Delay Is Justified
description: The producers and director of Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark defended on Friday their decision to postpone the musicals opening by another five weeks, saying that a show of this unprecedented complexity could not unfold according to Broadway tradition. New productions usually have four weeks of preview performances to work out kinks and not the record-setting 15 of Spider-Man before critics review it.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to the Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: In an Online Game Forum, Tucson Suspect Lashed Out
description: Logs of Jared L. Loughners conversations with fellow players in an online game of strategy show a young man who has become frustrated by his inability to find a job, who views his early education as tantamount to slavery, and who has frequent run-ins with his college professors.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Illuminating Thoughts on Power
description: One of the pleasures of writing a column about creative problem solving is that readers typically write back with practical, rather than ideological, critiques as well as suggestions for other solutions to highlight. The comments from this weeks Fixes column on Husk Power Systems were enlightening  and provided rich fodder for future columns.

title: Spider Monkey
description: A video from Anthony Di Fiore, a primate biologist at New York University, who is studying the behavior of male spider monkeys in Ecuador.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: A Rare Interspecies Frolic Among Spider and Woolly Monkeys
description: Anthony Di Fiore, a primate biologist at New York University, writes from Ecuador, where he is using GPS technology and camera traps to study the behavior of male spider monkeys.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Warring Relatives and Joking Rabbis
description: Two of New Yorks most important experimental theater festivals, Under the Radar and Coil, have been running concurrently in January. Following are reviews of shows in the festivals. Information on Under the Radar: www.undertheradarfestival.com; for Coil: www.ps122.org/performances/coil_2011.html.

title: Breakfast Eggs (15 Ways) by a Soprano
description: Anna Netrebko made her stage debut with the Kirov Opera at 16 as the rear end of a firebird; now the soprano, a global celebrity at 39, is starring this season as  the seductress Norina in Donizettis Don Pasquale at the Metropolitan Opera. Ms. Netrebko is engaged to the Uruguayan baritone Erwin Schrott, with whom she has a 2-year-old son, Tiago. She divides her time among Vienna; St. Petersburg, Russia; and an apartment on the Upper West Side. ROBIN FINN

title: Fire Dept. Revamps Approach to Emergencies on the Citys Waterways, or Nearby
description: With the nature of threats evolving far beyond typical building fires, the New York Fire Department is nearing completion of an effort over the past decade to overhaul and expand its maritime operations.

title: Delicious, and Healing
description: Pnina Peled, executive chef at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, is on the front line of a revolution in hospital food.

title: Theres a New Sheriff in Politics
description: In his speech in Tucson Wednesday night, President Obama called on Americans to expand their moral imaginations and remind ourselves of all the ways that our hopes and dreams are bound together. Well, never hurts to aim high. For now, at least, the president seems to have put an end to the endless blame game over whose political rhetoric apparently forced a violent lunatic to shoot a woman hed been fixated on for years.

title: For Healing, Meals Made to Order
description: JULIEN COLLOT, who is 8 and has had leukemia, has been on a low-microbial diet since his two bone-marrow transplants, in 2006 and 2007. When he developed diabetes last year, he had to go low-fat and low-sugar as well.

title: Youre Young and Jewish: Discuss
description: ON a cold Saturday morning in May 2007, Nicola Behrman, a playwright from Los Angeles, stood in a bare conference room at a ski lodge in Park City, Utah. She was surrounded by 60 strangers, tucked shoulder-to-shoulder in a circle  all members of a group called Reboot, which since 2002 has conducted an annual conference for young, affluent Jews to discuss their ethnic and religious identity, in between spa treatments and walks among the ponderosa pines of the Wasatch Mountains.

title: For Lebanese, Crisis Has Become a Way of Life
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  With a swagger as haughty as his jeans were tight, Samir Khalaf deflected a question about Lebanons crisis with a question of his own.

title: City Critic: Summer Simulation
description: Though snow coats the streets outside, its a day in the park at a NoLita events space.

title: Gunmen Kill Policewoman and Relatives in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Gunmen stormed the house of a female police officer in northwestern Pakistan on Friday, killing her and five members of her family.

title: Officials in Afghanistan Begin Investigation Into Possible Fraud at Troubled Bank
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghan officials have begun an investigation into possible fraud at Kabul Bank, four months after irregularities there led to a weeklong run on the bank by depositors.

title: Battling in Davis Cup, and Then Teaming Up
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  It has been more than six years since Nenad Zimonjic and Michael Llodra played a doubles match on the same side of the net, and yet they should be among the favorites for the title when they rejoin forces at the Australian Open.

title: Talk About a Close Shave: Goldman Barber Moves In-House
description: Goldman Sachs is taking haircuts. Its not on the credit-default swaps of A.I.G. or any other investment, however. The Wall Street firm is bringing its favorite barber in-house.

title: The Grass Is Fake, but the Splendor Real
description: Last Wednesday, the day of the snowpocalypse  or was it the snowmageddon, or the snow-my-God or whatever else the weather-fatigued headline writers had resorted to  Central Park was awash in white. Prospect Park in Brooklyn was a freezing no mans land. And Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx was almost invisible under all that the wind had delivered.

title: As Award Season Begins, So Does the Second-Guessing
description: If youre betting on who will wear what, there are several factors to consider. See if your predictions match those of Eric Wilson, fashion reporter.

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: THE EZ PAWN STORE came to 46th Street and Queens Boulevard, near the Sunnyside Arch entrance to a major shopping corridor, to some objections.

title: The Max Fish Magic: Will It Travel Well?
description: BACK in the 1990s, Max Fish was more than just my favorite bar. It was an essential part of my central nervous system. It was my go-to place to calm down, where I had my Dewars rocks with a splash before performing with my band. While the singer, Julie, drank kombucha tea to soothe her throat, I downed Scotch so my hands wouldnt shake on the drums in front of a milling mob of friends and strangers. To seal the deal, Julie and I would have a Parliament or two. Yes, this was when you could still smoke in a bar.

title: Skills Honed in Mets Dugout to Be Used in a City Hall
description: While it is hardly unusual for someone to enter public service from the sports world (think Bill Bradley) or from show business (Ronald Reagan, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Al Franken et al.), it is uncommon for celebrities to hold office and work at another job at the same time. Clint Eastwood is that rare example of an actual moonlighting politician, having gotten himself elected mayor of Carmel-by-the-Sea, Calif., in 1986 even as Heartbreak Ridge, his shoot-em-up about the invasion of Grenada, was in theaters.

title: Putting a Stamp on New Yorks Architecture
description: WHAT do the Century Associations clubhouse, the Judson Memorial Baptist Church, Columbia Universitys Low Memorial Library, the Brooklyn Museum and the late, lamented Pennsylvania Station have in common? Charles McKim, William Mead and Stanford White.

title: Concern Over Law on Apartments as Hotel Rooms
description: When Albany passed a law last summer preventing landlords of rental buildings from using their apartments as hotel rooms, neighborhood activists on the Upper West Side, where many of the conversions had taken place, were ebullient.

title: Lawyers for Bonds Trying to Chip Away at Evidence in Case
description: With Barry Bondss trial on federal perjury charges nearly two months away, his lawyers are making a renewed effort to exclude more of the governments evidence from the case against him.

title: Solar Panel Maker Moves Work to China
description: BEIJING  Aided by at least $43 million in assistance from the government of Massachusetts and an innovative solar energy technology, Evergreen Solar emerged in the last three years as the third-largest maker of solar panels in the United States.

title: Untouchable, Until Yankees Say Otherwise
description: The 31st overall pick in the baseball draft, which the Yankees lost to the Tampa Bay Rays on Thursday by agreeing to terms with reliever Rafael Soriano, has not been a place to find top prospects. In the 30 drafts between 1977 and 2006, only 12 players picked in that spot reached the majors. Only one was a future All-Star.

title: Epic Mickey Sales Please Disney, Despite Late Start
description: LOS ANGELES  The highly publicized video game Epic Mickey, which showcases the Walt Disney Companys central character in an unusually dark manner, had a solid but not spectacular debut in stores  a likely reflection, analysts said, of a release strategy that missed important retail opportunities.

title: Differences in Federal and State Systems Could Complicate Prosecution
description: TUCSON  The investigation into the bloody attack here last weekend is virtually certain to rank among the highest-profile criminal cases of the year, with as many as 250 federal law enforcement officials and dozens of sheriffs deputies and detectives operating under blanket news media scrutiny. But the paradox is that it has also turned out to be among the simplest of cases to investigate, with the answers to most questions clear within hours.

title: Tucson Shootings Add to Glocks Notoriety
description: New York City police officers carry Glock pistols, and rappers wax eloquent about them. Movie stars brandish Glocks, too.

title: The Marrying Kind: Born or Made?
The Hellcat
description: It was not quite a full-blown temper tantrum, but Mary Todd Lincolns outburst during a mid-January shopping trip raised eyebrows at a time when her husband did not need any more problems. And it signaled that the president-elect would have his hands full governing his own household, on top of everything else.

title: Fashionably Chic for Library Life
description: SLOANE CROSLEY, 32, is the author of the essay collections I Was Told Thered Be Cake, a best seller, and How Did You Get This Number, which will appear in paperback this spring. Currently working on a screenplay and a novel, Ms. Crosley recently left the publicity department of Vintage Books to write full time. She lives in Chelsea but can often be found at the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street.

title: Acquittal After Reporting Black Doll Head on Police Car
description: A record producer who complained that he saw the head of a black baby doll on the antenna of an unmarked police car in Harlem was acquitted on Friday of charges that he had later obstructed the police and resisted arrest.

title: Your Beautiful, Creative Son and Daughter (and You, Too)
description: ONE wonders how many parents are aware that aside from being food critics, amateur psychologists, human alarm clocks and ruiners of financial health, children are  have to say it  powerful romantic magnets. People with kids in tow get lots of attention from the opposite sex, at least according to the following poems found last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; the titles are the subject headings. ALAN FEUER

title: Jets Ryan Keeps Talking but Injuries Are a Worry
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Other than designating the Jets playoff game Sunday against the Patriots as the second-biggest game in the history of the franchise, Coach Rex Ryan was much more prudent Friday, particularly when discussing injuries.

title: Theyre Off! Let the Second-Guessing Begin
description: AT the conclusion of the 68th annual Golden Globe Awards tonight, there will still be nine days to wait until the announcement of nominees for the Academy Awards. But after that, there will only be about five seconds of anticipation until  spoiler alert!  the probable victors are divined by any number of movie critics and entertainment news sites.

title: From a Boy in a Revolt to the Patriots Punter
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  About the same time the Jets were throwing obscenities around their locker room this week, a few New England Patriots players were engaged in discussions on scholarly subjects like biodiversity and genetics. Linebacker Jerod Mayo and punter Zoltan Mesko were discussing the human genome when Mesko revealed that his father, Michael, was a pro bowler.

title: Jets G.M. Follows His Binder to Success
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The binder that explains Mike Tannenbaum is filled with dozens of pages, with spreadsheets and data analysis and a comprehensive report of every free agent signed during the 1994 off-season.

title: Britain Reopens Its Inquiry of Phone Hacking Reports
description: The Crown Prosecution Service said Friday that it would reopen the investigation into allegations of phone hacking by the newspaper The News of the World.

title: Amid Rift, Imams Role in Islam Center Is Sharply Cut
description: Long-simmering tensions between co-founders of the proposed Islamic center and mosque near ground zero led to a parting of the ways on Friday that sharply reduced the role of one: the imam Feisal Abdul Rauf, long the projects public face.

title: Anatomy of a School Crisis
description: THE auditorium at Columbia Secondary School was packed one evening last month. In the balcony, students held placards calling for the return of Dr. M  the founding principal, Jos Maldonado-Rivera, who had been dismissed the day before. Below, parents spilled over into standing room. One rose to speak in favor of the dismissal, only to be shouted down. Another rebuked the acting principal for reading from notes.

title: The Bear Wars
description: Stockton, Calif., Jan. 16, 1861

title: For Water Tunnels, Age Is Just a Number
description: IT took seven years for workers to build the 8,558-foot Holland Tunnel in the 1920s. Bernard Daly and a team of 150 have spent the last four years digging three tunnels that together span 8,881 feet in the northern Bronx. And while the Holland Tunnel was built for cars, Mr. Dalys tunnels are for something more basic: water.

title: The Vehicle of Street Food Is Getting an Overhaul
description: LOS ANGELES  Chef Hugh Schick has cooked in some of the finest kitchens in the land. He took classes at the Culinary Institute of America, studied under the Italian food expert Marcella Hazan and served as a private chef for the likes of the writer Christopher Hitchens and the venture capitalist David Cowan.

title: From Bloody Scene to E.R., Lifesaving Choices in Tucson
description: TUCSON  The moment Tony Compagno stepped off his fire engine, frantic people spattered with blood began running up to direct him to gunshot victims.

title: 18 Journeys Forged in Communism
description: Art can be very good at illuminating history, showing how shifting geographies, ideologies and violent upheavals have real but often hidden effects on individuals. That, in a sense, is what the exhibition After the Fall, at the Hudson Valley Center for Contemporary Art in Peekskill, sets out to do. The show features 18 artists from six countries in Eastern and Central Europe, most of whom were born under Communist rule but came of age after the fall. Its a great premise, but in the end a very academic show.

title: Apologizing, M.T.A. Admits Blunders During Blizzard
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority on Friday acknowledged serious failures in its response to the blizzard last month, saying it was too slow to heed severe-weather warnings and fell victim to a blurred chain of command.

title: Joey Cupcakes Is Taken Down, From Raos Wall
description: There is a story behind every photograph that goes up on the walls at Raos, that uniquely New York restaurant where celebrities, mobsters, politicians and judges have crossed paths for generations.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Abstract and Expressionistic, Yet Based in Grim Reality
description: Boris Sveshnikov was a 19-year-old art student when he was arrested in 1946, held in Moscow prisons for a year, and finally sentenced to eight years hard labor in the northern Ural Mountains. His crime and sentence were suitably Kafkaesque. Apparently a classmate had written in a notebook, which he intended to leave out to impress a girl, that he was involved in terrorist activities and wanted to eliminate Stalin; Mr. Sveshnikov was named as the designated executioner. Unfortunately, the notebook fell into the hands of the Ministry of State Security.

title: String Meets Steel to Build Harmony
description: IN a fitting tribute to Martin Luther King Jr., the Haven String Quartet will be forging new cultural relationships on Monday by sharing a bill  and, at some points, a stage  with its neighbor on Whalley Avenue in New Haven, St. Lukes Steel Band.

title: U.S. Bills States $1.3 Billion in Interest Amid Tight Budgets
description: As if states did not have enough on their plates getting their shaky finances in order, a new bill is coming due  from the federal government, which will charge them $1.3 billion in interest this fall on the billions they have borrowed from Washington to pay unemployment benefits during the downturn.

title: Teacher Training, Taught by Students
description: Syidah OBryant scribbled notes in a composition book, trying to keep up with a lesson about why teenagers are so sleepy in the morning.

title: Want Legal Advice? Just Ask the Actors
description: Hempstead, N.Y.

title: Answers Scarce, Anthony Tires of Questions
description: DENVER In the summer of 2006, LeBron James, Dwyane Wade and Chris Bosh signed three-year contract extensions with the option of extending them another year.

title: Groups Demand Withdrawal of Medicaid Fraud Lawsuit
description: The Legal Aid Society and scores of other organizations representing the elderly and disabled banded together on Friday to demand that the United States attorney in Manhattan withdraw a lawsuit charging New York City with Medicaid fraud through its personal care program.

title: Remembering Baseballs First Black Players
description: UNLIKELY as it may seem with snow on the ground, baseball season is under way in Elmont.

title: Milestones: Gabrielle Giffords
description: Gabrielle Giffords went from Arizona to Mexico and New York and back  and finally, to Washington.

title: Cuomo Crisscrosses New York, Repeating His Call for Action
description: JAMESTOWN, N.Y.  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo leaned forward at the lectern, his gaze hardening on the audience in front of him, his right arm jutting forward, his forefinger extended like a spear. For a half-hour on Thursday, he chronicled the ills of Albany: the taxes that were crippling businesses and driving away residents, and the politicians too corrupt to care.

title: Asian Cup: Australia and South Korea in a Stalemate
description: DOHA, Qatar  South Koreas young team (average age 24) got the better of Australias older and more experienced Socceroos (average age nearly 30) for much of Fridays Group C first-round match of the Asian Cup. But a goal by Mile Jedinak in the 62nd minute canceled out Koo Ja Cheols goal in the first half of the 1-1 tie. The teams are tied on points at the top of the group with one match to play. Australia faces Bahrain, which defeated India, 5-2, while the South Koreans have an easier route with a game against winless India.

title: Saturday: Stuck in the Middle With You
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  I dont know about you, but this was a clockwise solve for me. I started in the northwest, barreled right around the outside of the puzzle, finished up in the southwest. Then I got completely stumped in the middle. WUPATKI, Barry? Really?

title: In Pittsburgh, a Quarterback Split
description: PITTSBURGH  Between sales of goat Cheddar, David Sunseri gave his seal of approval to another big cheese this week. Sunseri, an owner of the Pennsylvania Macaroni Company, which is as much a local institution as the Steelers, named quarterback Ben Roethlisberger as his favorite player.

title: For Giffords, Tucson Roots Shaped Views
description: TUCSON  Gabrielle Giffords grew up in an old house filled with old things at the edge of a city being remade by the new. While strip malls and subdivisions were rising everywhere else, her rambling brick residence was surrounded by 18 arid acres of cactuses and mesquite trees and decorated with Mexican art and Southwestern relics.

title: Sacrificing Microcredit for Megaprofits
description: Dhaka, Bangladesh

title: Quick Return to Constituents, in Tribute and Also Defiance
description: From Las Vegas to Connecticut, Congressional Democrats stepped into vegetable aisles, parking lots and office lobbies Friday to meet with constituents, less than a week after Representative Gabrielle Giffords was critically wounded in a shooting rampage at an informal gathering outside a supermarket in Tucson.

title: Lottery Numbers
Man Charged as Stalker of Kennedy Grandchild
description: Early in 2008 a middle-aged stranger began sending notes, flowers, balloons and e-card greetings to Caroline Kennedys family, focusing on the middle of her three teenage children, Tatiana Schlossberg, the authorities said Friday.

title: An Assist for a Woman Who Usually Helps Others
description: Teria McGhee has been steadily employed for the last three decades, raising four children  and, beginning last month, a foster child  largely on her own. They were getting along fine, until her bladder prolapsed.

title: Mementos or Mess? Deciding to Save or Toss
description: To the Editor:

title: Crowd Reminds Knicks of What Theyre Missing
description: The discontent came in stages  anxious murmurs followed by a wave of boos and then louder boos and finally a chanted request: We want Melo!

title: G.O.P. Retreat Becomes Pep Rally for Fiscal Plan
description: BALTIMORE  House Republicans sought to build momentum for their effort to cut spending and confront Democrats over fiscal issues as they gathered for a policy retreat in the aftermath of the Tucson shootings, which have overshadowed their debut as the new majority party.

title: Did Your Horoscope Predict This?
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Astrologers, not surprisingly, say they knew this would happen.

title: For Some Students in the South, a King Day Lacking That Holiday Feature
description: ATLANTA  Put yourself in the shoes of Michael Murray, the associate superintendent of a small school district in the North Carolina foothills.

title: Maine Governor Gets Testy With N.A.A.C.P.
description: Gov. Paul LePage of Maine directed a graphic insult at the states N.A.A.C.P. leaders on Friday after they questioned his decision to pass on attending Martin Luther King Birthday events in Bangor and Portland.

title: Homeland Security Cancels Virtual Fence After $1 Billion Is Spent
description: The Department of Homeland Security on Friday canceled a project to build a technology-based virtual fence across the Southwest border, saying that the effort  on which $1 billion has already been spent  was ineffective and too costly.

title: Documentary Filmmaker Doesnt Qualify for a Journalists Privilege, a Court Says
description: A federal appeals court has ruled that Joe Berlinger, a filmmaker who was ordered to hand over footage from his 2009 documentary Crude to the Chevron Corporation, cannot invoke a journalists privilege in refusing to do so because his work does not constitute an act of independent reporting.

title: Bloggingheads: Responsible for Violence?
description: Adam Serwer, left, of The American Prospect and Michael C. Moynihan of Reason debate Glenn Beck and responsibility for political acts of violence.

title: An Almost Ambassador Encounters a Congressional Dead End
description: For most of her 53 years, starting in childhood playing basketball against boys, the Rev. Suzan Johnson Cook has had the habit of defying barriers. It served her well starting college at age 16. It fortified her in becoming a television news producer as a young black woman. And it proved especially necessary when, in her mid-20s, she felt called to ministry.

title: California: Charges in Taco Truck Extortion
description: Two men said to be members of the 18th Street gang were charged Thursday with trying to extort taco truck owners in South Los Angeles. The police say that the practice of charging rent to owners of the growing fleet of the trucks so they can do business has become widespread, and that the 18th Street gang, one of the largest in Los Angeles, has singled out small Hispanic businesses. The extortions fixate on the Hispanic community because people fear being deported or having to testify, so they dont want to report anything, Sgt. Alma Burke of the police said. Erin Glenn, executive director of a union that represents truck owners, said extortion had been a problem for years, but she had started to hear more complaints recently.

title: Biden Chooses a Chief of Staff
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said Friday that his new chief of staff would be Bruce Reed, who worked for former President Bill Clinton, first as his assistant for domestic policy planning, then as deputy domestic policy adviser and finally as chief domestic policy adviser. Mr. Reed, who has led the moderate Democratic Leadership Council, will succeed Ron Klain, who will run Case Holdings, the parent company of the investment company of the former AOL chief Steve Case. Most recently, he was executive director of the National Commission on Fiscal Responsibility and Reform.

title: Presidential Primary Book Club
description: This is the time when presidential candidates start poking their little noses up through the snow, and making soft, trilling noises. I know you think its too soon, even though Mitt Romney made his intentions clear on the family Christmas card. But as a public service, I am going to start providing summaries of the latest books from the potential Republican nominees so well all be well educated by the time the debates begin.

title: Abortion and the Bishops
description: To the Editor:

title: First the Oath, Then the Checks
description: It was bad enough that Representative Mike Fitzpatrick, a Republican of Pennsylvania, skipped the oath-taking ceremony for the new Congress and still cast votes after he showed up in the chamber. Six of his votes were nullified, as were some from Pete Sessions, a Republican of Texas, who also ducked the swearing-in.

title: A Demolition in Jerusalem
description: To the Editor:

title: Haiti, Going Forward
description: It has been an agonizing year since Haitis earthquake. Despite all of the pledges of help, and vows to do things differently, there are more than a million displaced people still living in camps and a cholera epidemic rages. An immense relief effort has saved tens of thousands of lives, but reconstruction is only just beginning.

title: The Tucson Witch Hunt
description: Tragedy in Tucson. Six Dead. Democratic congresswoman shot in the head at rally.

title: Bid for Impunity
description: In an ugly power play against justice and accountability, Hezbollah has withdrawn from Lebanons cabinet, bringing down the unity government of Prime Minister Saad Hariri. It must be resisted by all responsible Lebanese politicians and Arab governments, with strong support from the international community.

title: Prison Suicides
description: The New York State prison system has greatly improved mental health services since 2007 when it settled a lawsuit that had accused it of mistreating mentally ill inmates. A troubling increase in prison suicides suggests that all of the problems have not been solved.

title: Helpless in the Face of Madness
description: The second semester French class began a little after 9 on the morning of April 16, 2007. The weather that day was unusually cold for April. A light snow was falling.

title: Timid on Gun Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking to the Future in Sudan
description: To the Editor:

title: Release Sought for Soldier Held for Leaks
description: The lawyer for Pfc. Bradley Manning, 23, the Army intelligence analyst accused of leaking classified material to WikiLeaks, said in a blog post that he had submitted a request to the military that Private Manning be released from pretrial detention at Quantico Marine Base in Virginia. The lawyer, David E. Coombs, said he had received no response from the military to an earlier demand that restrictions on Private Manning in the military brig be eased.

title: Matthew Lipman, Philosopher and Educator, Dies at 87
description: It was during the contentious years of the Vietnam War that Matthew Lipman, a philosopher and educator, found that many Americans were having trouble presenting their views about the conflict cogently, and it distressed him.

title: New Jersey Police Officer Is Shot Dead During an Encounter With a Pedestrian
description: A 27-year-old police officer in the central New Jersey township of Lakewood was shot in the head and killed Friday afternoon by a man he had stopped for routine questioning, the authorities said.

title: Eric Pliner, Jonathan Bloom
description: Eric Adam Pliner and Jonathan Zvi Bloom were married Friday in Darien, Conn. Mary C. Pugh, a Connecticut justice of the peace, officiated. On Sunday, Rabbi Melissa Heller is to perform a religious ceremony at the Galapagos Art Space in Brooklyn.

title: Danielle Masor, Joseph Stember
description: Danielle Paulette Masor and Joseph Nathaniel Stember, both medical students, are to be married Sunday evening at Congregation Etz Chaim in Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Yisroel Stone is to perform the ceremony.

title: Margaret Butterfield, Michael Kassatly
description: Margaret Leslie Butterfield and Michael David Kassatly were married Saturday afternoon at the First Congregational Church in Stockbridge, Mass. The Rev. Katherine A. Shaner, a Lutheran minister, led the ceremony.

title: Charu Chaudhry and Salil Mehta
description: Charu Chaudhry, the daughter of Neelam Chaudhry and Vinod Kumar Chaudhry of Edison, N.J., was married Friday to Salil Mehta, the son of Sharda Mehta of Addison, Ill., and the late Suresh Mehta, at the Superior Court of the District of Columbia. Deena Whittington, the acting section supervisor of the marriage bureau there, officiated.

title: Elizabeth Raskin, Benjamin Warlick
description: Elizabeth Harris Raskin and Benjamin Julius Warlick were married Saturday evening at the W Union Square hotel in New York. Rabbi Marcia Rappaport officiated.

title: Avery Easley, Trenholm Boggs
description: Avery Easley and George Trenholm Boggs Jr. were married Saturday in Austin, Tex. The Rev. Andrew T. P. Merrow performed the ceremony at All Saints Episcopal Church.

title: Patience Smith and Sam Bloom
description: Patience Smith and Sam W. Bloom are to be married Sunday at the Yale Club in New York. Mary Louise Liberty, a minister of the Universal Life Church, is to officiate.

title: Claire Villaverde, Benjamin Ramos
description: Claire Maureen Villaverde, a daughter of Maureen Villaverde and William Villaverde of Westbury, N.Y., was married Saturday to Benjamin Matthew Ramos, a son of Sharon A. Ramos and Dr. Benjamin R. Ramos of Farmington Hills, Mich. Msgr. Robert T. Ritchie performed the ceremony at St. Patricks Cathedral in New York.

title: Christina Zervoudakis, Adam Hopkins
description: Christina Zervoudakis is to be married Sunday to Adam Hopkins at the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York. The Rev. Dr. Frank Marangos, the cathedrals dean, is to perform the ceremony.

title: Lauren Tortoriello and Jason Ertel
description: Lauren Elyse Tortoriello, the daughter of Robert L. Tortoriello of Montclair, N.J., and the late Margaret Ann Tortoriello, was married Saturday to Jason Ryan Ertel, the son of Susan J. Ertel and James E. Ertel of Marilla, N.Y. The Rev. William R. Dailey, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of Notre Dame in New York.

title: Deborah Levenson, Steve Adelman
description: Deborah Hilibrand Levenson and Dr. Steve Adelman are to be married Sunday at Penn Hillel at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia. Rabbi Benjamin J. Samuels is to perform the ceremony.

title: Lara Devgan, Patrick Verdonck
description: Dr. Lara Lakshmi Arya Dixit Devgan and Patrick Karel Andries Verdonck were married Saturday afternoon at St. Patricks Cathedral in New York. The Rev. Robert C. Carroll, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Allison Markowitz, Joseph Moroni
description: Allison Lynn Markowitz and Lt. j.g. Joseph Lorenzo Moroni were married Saturday evening at the C. V. Rich Mansion, an event space in White Plains. Rabbi Jill Hausman officiated.

title: On the Street | Men on the Move
description: This winter, stylish men seem to be eschewing exotic designer looks, expressing personal style instead through the manner in which familiar pieces are put together.

title: Hudson River Rescue Still Defines Upgrade of Fire Dept.s Marine Unit
description: Capt. Richard Johnson and Firefighter Tom Sullivan were having coffee in the kitchen with six other members of their fire company, Marine 1, on that frigid Jan. 15 afternoon two years ago when the electronic alarm blared insistently through the firehouse on the pier.

title: Restrictions on Travel to Cuba Are Eased
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Friday eased restrictions on Americans travel to Cuba in an effort to encourage more contact between people in both countries, while leaving intact the decades-old embargo against the islands Communist government.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 14
description: A look at the day in pictures from mountain climbing in Germany to ski jumping in Japan.

title: A Leading Diplomat Is Remembered With Affection and Humor
description: WASHINGTON  There are not many people who can pack a Kennedy Center hall with 1,100 people  including five world leaders  and not only personally know just about every single one of them, but have all of them believe that they have a personal relationship with him.

title: Haiti Weighs Move After Observers Reject Vote Results
description: MEXICO CITY  The political crisis in Haiti showed little sign of easing on Friday as the countrys president, Ren Prval, weighed a report from international observers rejecting the results of the presidential election in November and a protest ended with one person dead and several under arrest.

title: The Eye of an Indian Hurricane, Eager to Topple a Political Establishment
description: Calcutta

title: Embassy Bombing Suspect Was Told of Plot, Filing Says
description: Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani told American interrogators before he was brought into the civilian court system that a plotter in the 1998 bombing of the United States Embassy in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, had told him about the plans about a week before it was bombed, the government said in a filing late Friday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Russia: $50 Million Art and Gem Theft
description: The owner of a chain of jewelry stores lost about $50 million worth of paintings, diamonds and antiques in one of the more brazen recent thefts at country homes of the wealthy outside of Moscow. The burglars tied up security guards, retrieved keys from a caretakers house and made off with paintings by the 19th-century Russian masters Ilya Repin, Ivan Shishkin and Ivan Aivazovsky, Russian television news reported. Their owner, Aleksandr Tarantsev, said the paintings were insured.

title: China: Toll Evader to Get New Trial
description: A truck driver sentenced to life in prison for evading $550,000 in road tolls will be offered another trial, a court ruled Friday. The Pingdingshan Intermediate Court in Henan Province said it would retry the man, Shi Jianfeng, citing what it described as new evidence of an accomplice who helped him defraud toll collectors over an eight-month period. In a posting on its Web site on Friday, the court said intense media attention to the case persuaded it to question the defendant again, revealing that he had not acted alone. Mr. Shi, a farmer who had turned to hauling construction material, evaded the tolls on his two trucks during more than 2,300 trips.

title: China: Inquiry on Tainted Milk Powder
description: Police officers have detained 96 people on suspicion of illegally using tainted milk powder that should have been destroyed after a food scandal that angered and frightened parents across China in 2008, state news organizations reported Friday. That year at least 22 dairy companies were found to have sold products tainted with melamine, an industrial chemical that can be toxic to infants; at least six babies died of kidney problems and 300,000 children fell ill. Among the 96 people detained, 17 have been convicted on criminal charges and 2 have been sentenced to life in prison. Thirty-eight others are awaiting trial and 41 are being investigated.

title: The Tough Task of Defining Sudans North-South Border
description: The north-south border in Sudan will be contentious.

title: Mets Are Close to Signing a Player Who Has Tormented Them
description: The Mets are close to signing outfielder Willie Harris to a minor league deal, which means that as long as he stays in their organization, he cannot torment them with more acrobatic, game-saving catches.

title: Why Carmelo Anthony Is the Ultimate Team Player (and What Advanced Stats Miss About Him)
description: Carmelo Anthony, whom the Knicks are considering acquiring in a trade, is sometimes thought of as a selfish player. Indeed, he is the center of the Denver Nuggets offense: when he is on the court for them, about 30 percent of their possessions end in Anthony shooting, going to the foul line, or committing a turnover. Nor is Anthony much of a passer: over his career, hes accumulated 3.1 assists per 36 minutes played, considerably less than that of other high-volume scorers like Kobe Bryant (4.6 assists per 36 minutes) or LeBron James (6.2).

title: Diddy Did It: Rappers Guest Role at The Chris Gethard Show
description: Sometimes it seems like good things can only occur in Chris Gethards life if they are balanced out by other inauspicious events. On Friday afternoon, Mr. Gethard, 30, a boyish comedian with a gentle disposition, was playing basketball when another player collided with him, breaking his glasses, cutting his nose and sending him scrambling to LensCrafters for some emergency repair work.

title: The Weekend Word: Passing the Gavel
description: From Todays Times:

title: In Tunisia, Clashes Continue as Power Shifts a Second Time
description: TUNIS  Tanks, police officers and gangs of newly deputized young men wielding guns held the deserted streets of Tunis Saturday night after a day of sporadic rioting and gunfire. Power changed hands for the second time in 24 hours, and the swift turnabout raised new questions about what kind of government might emerge from the chaos engulfing Tunisia.

title: Is Jets-Patriots Turning Into a Ravens-Steelers-Type Rivalry?
description: When it comes to Ravens-versus-Steelers, what moments do you think of? Is it Bart Scotts crushing hit on Ben Roethlisberger, from Nov. 26, 2006? The collision between the Steelers Ryan Clark and Baltimores Willis McGahee in the closing minutes of the A.F.C. championship game in 2009? How about the hit by Ravens linebacker Ray Lewis that broke the shoulder of Steelers running back Rashard Mendenhall in 2008.

title: Strategy for Underdogs: Jets Against the Patriots
description: If youre the underdog in a football game, what is the best strategy to pursue?

title: Is the Cupcake Bubble Still Inflating?
description: In November 2009, we ran an article that explored the difficult economics of opening a cupcake shop, and we asked this question: Are cupcakes a viable business? This week we got an answer  at least for one cupcake chain, Crumbs Bake Shop. Crumbs, which is based in New York, announced plans to go public in a $66 million deal. It claimed 2010 revenue of $31.1 million with earnings of close to $2 million.

title: Bigger Trade Deficits Coming?
description: Joseph Gagnon is worried. Mr. Gagnon, a former Federal Reserve economist now at the Peterson Institute, contends in a new paper that the worlds financial imbalances  such as Chinas trade surplus and the United States trade deficit  will probably return to record levels in coming years. He argues that the imbalances have narrowed recently only because of the recession (which, for example, has reduced American demand for Chinese exports).

title: At a Gun Show and a Safeway, Tucson Looks for Normalcy
description: This article is by William Yardley, Michael Luo and Sam Dolnick.

title: Now Screening | Burberry
description: The Fall/Winter 2011 mens collection from Burberry at Milan Fashion Week.

title: Laugh Lines
description: JAY LENO

title: Prime Number
description: 66: The percentage increase in the individual income tax rate approved by Illinois lawmakers last week. The business tax rate will also rise, by 46 percent. Illinois is facing a deficit of $13 billion and a plummeting bond rating. Our state was careening towards bankruptcy and fiscal insolvency, Gov. Patrick J. Quinn said. Neighboring states welcomed the news. Wisconsin promptly issued a call to businesses in Illinois to move north, resurrecting an old slogan, Escape to Wisconsin.

title: Back Then: 2001
description: Wikipedia, the free online encyclopedia written and updated by thousands of volunteers around the world, turned 10 years old this month. Today, with 3.5 million articles in English, it is the first stop for tens of millions of people looking for information. But its success was uncertain in its early days, as Peter Meyers reported in The Times in September 2001:

title: If You Smoke, Dont Vacation in This Kingdom
description: The Himalayan Kingdom of Bhutan banned the sale of tobacco in 2005 in its drive to become the worlds first smoke-free nation. But the effort has made little headway against smugglers from neighboring India. So now the Buddhist nation is getting tough, according to Reuters. A police dog is being trained to sniff out tobacco, and authorities have been empowered to enter homes in search of illegal cigarettes. Sentences of up to five years await shopkeepers caught selling tobacco and smokers unable to provide customs receipts for imported cigarettes. Smoking in private is not illegal, but smokers may only import 200 cigarettes a month. Widespread grumbling has accompanied the crackdown. Its a new year. And I have a New Years wish: that the first person to be caught and jailed under the Tobacco Control Act is a member of parliament, wrote Tshering Tobgay, the opposition leader, on his popular blog.

title: ZIRP and ZMP
description: From my point of view, the current slump is just about what we should have expected given that we had a nasty financial crisis and continue to have a lot of over-leveraged players in the system. Ken Rogoff once said that the United States is having a garden-variety severe financial crisis  indeed, anyone who read Reinhart and Rogoff on the aftermath of crises more or less expected a prolonged period of weak employment. And Ive been warning about a protracted liquidity trap, in which even a zero interest rate policy (ZIRP) isnt enough to raise demand sufficiently, for more than a decade.

title: Vatican Welcomes First Anglicans Converting Under New Rules
description: ROME  The Vatican on Saturday welcomed the first group of traditionalist Anglicans who plan to convert to Roman Catholicism through a new structure the Vatican created to facilitate such group conversions.

title: Exchange Rates and Economic Strength
description: While were looking at Reagan-era data, a thought for those who believe that the strength of a currency is a measure of the strength of a nations economy: did the U.S. economy surge during Reagans first term, then decline in his second?

title: Fighting Words
description: Tom DeLay, a former Republican majority leader in the House, was sentenced to three years in prison last week for money laundering and conspiracy stemming from his role in a scheme to channel corporate contributions to Texas state races in 2002.

title: Second Sunday: Worms or Viruses
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Sometimes, all you need is a toehold.

title: Teams Warned to Keep Trash Talk Off the Field
description: Think the recent trash-talking between the Jets and the Patriots was all good fun?

title: G.O.P. Leaders Promise: Humility and Hard Work
description: WASHINGTON  For Reince Priebus, the new chairman of the Republican National Committee, politics has long been more than simply a hobby. It provided the entertainment for the first date with his wife.

title: A Ukrainian Immigrant Reconnects With His Roots
description: Alex Bebeshkos early life was not easy. He said his mother was a drug addict, and other addicts would come to their apartment in Odessa, Ukraine, to buy a hit of rastvor, an opium derivative, and shoot it up, sometimes in front of him.

title: Roots of Bitterness in a Region Threaten Sudans Future
description: ABYEI, Sudan  There is a place in Sudan where Africa and the Arab world meet, where one thatched roof hut carries a roughly-hewn cross at the top and next door an identical hut flaunts a crescent moon, where heavily armed nomads sweep in for raids and heavily armed villagers fight back.

title: After Tucson, Is the Anger Gone?
description: WASHINGTON  For anyone who hoped that the tragedy in Tucson might jolt the political class into some new period of civility and reflection, suddenly subduing all the radio ranters and acid bloggers, the days that followed brought a cold reality.

title: Mark Sanchez and Tom Brady: Peers in Style, Not in Results
description: When Nic Screws, the fashion market editor at Esquire magazine, analyzed Tom Brady and Mark Sanchez, she saw more than two quarterbacks who will meet Sunday in the N.F.L. playoffs. From two men as at ease in suits as in shoulder pads, she saw comfort urban style (Brady) compared with fancy sunglasses and shiny ties (Sanchez), along with good hair (both).

title: Not the Greatest Show on Turf, but No Longer Playing Like the Worst
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill.  When Chicago Bears Coach Lovie Smith hired his former St. Louis Rams colleague Mike Martz as his offensive coordinator last February, two questions made the N.F.L. rounds. Could Martz, one of the games most creative offensive minds, reinvent the staid Monsters of the Midway as another pass-happy Greatest Show on Turf? And would the stubborn Martz clash with the talented yet petulant quarterback Jay Cutler?

title: Despite Injured Hip, Hasselbeck Carries Seahawks on Back
description: RENTON, Wash.  The wounded left hip of Matt Hasselbeck looked as if it were the result of a car accident or a bike wreck, not something from the football field. When Nathanael Hasselbeck saw his older brothers injury for the first time, he swallowed the shock and asked to snap a picture for Twitter.

title: Looking Behind the Mug-Shot Grin
description: This article was reported by Jo Becker, Serge F. Kovaleski, Michael Luo and Dan Barry and written by Mr. Barry.

title: A Horse for the Ages Should Be Horse of the Year
description: Its a match race, a fiercely contested one, for Horse of the Year: the great racemare Zenyatta versus the talented colt Blame, the only rival ever to finish in front of her. A noisy debate over who is more deserving has raged on.

title: Spartans Lucas Is Back, but Recovery Is Not Yet Complete
description: EAST LANSING, Mich.  The epiphany hit Michigan State basketball Coach Tom Izzo a few weeks ago while he was reviewing game video.

description: Time out, people. This Jets-Patriots feeding frenzy has gotten out of control.

title: Hezbollahs Rise Amid Chaos
description: In three decades, the Shiite Islamist movement known as Hezbollah has become a kingmaker and spoiler in Lebanons politics, as well as in decisions of war and peace. Here is a short history.

title: In Peril: The Arab Status Quo
description: BEIRUT  The past few weeks have been bad ones for the old Arab order.

title: Yankees Chamberlain Could Be Odd Man Out
description: Joba Chamberlain began last spring as a candidate for the Yankees rotation. By the home opener, he was their setup man. By late July, he had lost his job. By September, he did not have a defined role. And by the playoffs, he was an afterthought.

title: Recession Special: Cleaner Air
description: The previous Congress failed to pass climate change legislation, and the new House is openly hostile to the idea. But what the government has not mandated, the economy is doing on its own: emissions of global warming gases in the United States are down.

title: Boehner Ends Retreat With Warning About Spending Illness
description: BALTIMORE  House Speaker John A. Boehner closed down the Republican retreat here Saturday with a final declaration that the new House majority is serious about reducing federal spending.

title: Quakes, Tectonic and Theoretical
description: And yet it moves ... Galileo is said to have muttered to himself after recanting his heretical notion that the Earth orbited the Sun.

title: 3 U.S. Service Members Killed in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Three American soldiers were killed and one wounded in Iraq on Saturday, raising to five the number of service members from the United States killed here since the beginning of the year.

title: Kirk Douglas Steals the Show
description: LOS ANGELES The luncheon thrown by the American Film Institute to honor the best TV and movies of the year is, many attendees told the Bagger, one of their favorite events of awards season.

title: Bears After Luckman: Monsters of the Middling
description: The Bears revolutionized professional football when they drafted Columbia quarterback Sid Luckman in 1939: they modified the T-formation to suit Luckmans talents, all but inventing the modern passing game.

title: Wireless, but Leashed
description: Americans were liberated from AT&T last week.

title: Renault Fires 2 Men Accused of Selling Corporate Secrets About Electric Vehicles
description: PARIS  Renault has formally fired two of the men it has accused of espionage, their lawyers said Saturday.

title: Early Social Security Projections
description: This post by Bruce Webb sent me looking briefly at some early Social Security Trustees reports, to firm up my answer to something that has been bugging me for years.

title: From the Road to the Runway
description: I WAS born in my parents car on their way from their home in Long Island to the hospital. They were passing through a town called Gibson at the time, so they chose that as my middle name.

title: Arbitration, Litigation, Aggravation
description: WHEN investors file complaints against their brokers, the matters are almost always heard by an arbitration panel rather than by a judge or jury. Arbitration forums like those run by the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority typically adjudicate cases more quickly than the courts and less expensively, because costs associated with discovery and extensive legal filings are minimized if not eliminated.

title: Architects Find Their Dream Client, in China
description: IT was an unusual commission, unlike anything that Stuart Silk, a Seattle architect, had been offered in his quarter-century of practice: design three high-end custom homes for clients he would never meet. Although there were some specifications for functions and dimensions  total square feet, for example, and the number of bedrooms and baths  there wasnt a clue as to style or a construction budget.

title: Say Anything, but Phrase It the Right Way
description: This interview with Robin Domeniconi, senior vice president and chief brand officer for the Elle Group,  was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Can Your Camera Phone Turn You Into a Pirate?
description: MY wife and I sat cross-legged on the floor of a local Barnes & Noble store recently, surrounded by several large piles of books. We were searching for interior design ideas for a new home that we are planning to buy.

title: The Spirit of the Mensch
description: WHAT is it about businesspeople and self-help books? Is there any other field where so many people read so many books about how to do better, manage better, lead better, sell better, speak better, tan better and turn somersaults better? O.K., I made those last two up, but you see the point.

title: What Obama Should Say About the Deficit
description: BY the time President Obama gave his State of the Union address last year, the speech felt like an old friend. It had been part of my life  from the brainstorming sessions in late November 2009 to the last minute fact-checking. I knew when all of my favorite lines were coming. That led to an awkward moment during the address when I sprang to my feet, applauding the presidents tacit endorsement of the free-trade agreement with South Korea, before noticing that the only other person cheering seemed to be Ron Kirk, the special trade representative.

title: Give Me a P. Give Me an E. What Does It Spell? Trouble.
description: STOCK market bulls have at least two reasons for optimism: Corporate earnings have continued to climb, and sentiment on Wall Street has improved sharply in the last several weeks.

description: To the Editor:

title: Letters: Fleeting Ownership
description: To the Editor:

title: Quiet Wilfork Anchors a Defense on the Rise
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  As a younger player, Vince Wilfork watched Rodney Harrison practice. Harrison spent 15 years as one of the most feared safeties in the N.F.L., and by the time Wilfork joined him on the New England Patriots in 2004, Harrison was already close to becoming one of the elder statesmen of a veteran-laden team.

title: A Look at Abyei
description: Abyei straddles the disputed border between north and south Sudan, and two rival ethnic groups claim the right to belong there.

title: A Weekend in Bali
description: Mystical, hedonistic, rugged yet polished, Bali is a place to unwind amid striking natural beauty.

title: Cables From American Diplomats Portray U.S. Ambivalence on Tunisia
description: Cables from American diplomats in Tunisia portray a deepening ambivalence toward the rule of President Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, expressing alarm about popular resentment of the blatant corruption of the countrys first family but also gratitude for Mr. Ben Alis cooperation against terrorism and the stability he long imposed.

title: Getting Back on The Water
description: The London International Boat Show, held this month, featured used boats in addition to new ones as the rich  and formerly rich  sold their yachts during the recession.

title: Are You Cut Out for Management?
description: Q. Youre very good at your job and although you didnt ask for it, you have been promoted into a management position for the first time. How different will it be from your current job?

title: With New Software, Headsets Are Outsmarting Phones
description: HEADSETS are staples for call-center workers, travel agents and many other people who have to talk frequently on the phone. With a headset to listen and speak through, both hands are free to work, and a shoulder neednt stiffen to cradle the phone.

title: Jets Special Teams Have Been Just That
description: The Jets special teams have been among the best in the league this season and played a significant role in their playoff victory over the Colts.

title: At Burberry Prorsum Show, Label Invokes the Elements
description: MILAN  An artificial rain shower ended the Burberry Prorsum show Saturday evening, pelting the models in their flasher-ready, see-through slickers and splashing all the front-row types, who had to pull up their knees. It called to mind the horror of a character Mink Stole played in John Waterss Desperate Living. You know I hate nature! she shrieked to her housekeeper, who had made the error of driving the family Mercedes through a Baltimore park.

title: Suspect Is Charged in Killing of New Jersey Officer
description: LAKEWOOD, N.J.  Even as the authorities expanded their search for a man wanted in the killing of a police officer in this central New Jersey town, charges were filed against the suspect on Saturday.

title: Part 5: Answers to Readers Questions on Financial Aid
description: As families of prospective college freshmen begin to tackle the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, or Fafsa, Mark Kantrowitz, a financial aid expert and founder of the Web sites finaid.org and fastweb.com, is answering questions from readers of The Choice this week.

description: At least five teenagers were left wounded when gunshots erupted Friday night as spectators were streaming out of a basketball game at Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School in Brooklyn, the authorities said.

title: Final: Steelers 31, Ravens 24
description: Live analysis and coverage of the N.F.L. Mid-Atlantic championship game between the Baltimore Ravens and the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: Who Should Be Horse of the Year?
description: In an article today, Joe Drape makes the case that Zenyatta should be voted Horse of the Year over Blame, who defeated her in the Breeders Cup Classic. Blames record, he writes, with three Grade I wins, is underwhelming, and a vote just off his victory in the Classic would ignore Zenyattas greatness. He concludes:

title: Nigerias Promise, Africas Hope
description: AFRICA has endured a tortured history of political instability and religious, racial and ethnic strife. In order to understand this bewildering, beautiful continent  and to grasp the complexity that is my home country, Nigeria, Africas most populous nation  I think it is absolutely important that we examine the story of African people.

title: Can Johnson & Johnson Get Its Act Together?
description: LITTLE red flags jut out from the shelves at a CVS drugstore in suburban Boston, alerting shoppers to shortages of nearly a dozen Johnson & Johnson products. Among them are Motrin, Rolaids, childrens Tylenol liquid and adult Tylenol, Mylanta, Pepcid AC and even some Neutrogena skin care products.

title: Choice Words From Joan Rivers at Suspense-Free Awards
description: LOS ANGELES Unlike last year, there were no surprises  or news-making liplocks  at the Critics Choice Awards on Friday night. The show, broadcast live on VH1, briskly doled out prizes from the Broadcast Film Critics Association to all the expected winners: Colin Firth for best actor (The Kings Speech); Natalie Portman for best actress (Black Swan); The Fighter for best ensemble; Melissa Leo for supporting actress in that film; her co-star Christian Bale for supporting actor; Aaron Sorkin for best adapted screenplay (The Social Network); David Seidler for best original screenplay (The Kings Speech); David Fincher for best director, and The Social Network for best picture.

title: If Quakes Werent Enough, Enter the Superstorm
description: SACRAMENTO  California faces the risk not just of devastating earthquakes but also of a catastrophic storm that could tear at the coasts, inundate the Central Valley and cause four to five times as much economic damage as a large quake, scientists and emergency planners warn.

title: Send Huck Finn to College
description: Madison, Wis.

title: G.O.P. Rally Ends With Call to Cut Spending
description: BALTIMORE  Speaker John A. Boehner closed down the Republican retreat here on Saturday with a declaration that the new House majority was serious about reducing federal spending.

title: Fast Start in Wijk aan Zee
New Influx of Haitians, but Not Who Was Expected
description: Miami

title: Darkness on the Edge of the Universe
description: IN a great many fields, researchers would give their eyeteeth to have a direct glimpse of the past. Instead, they generally have to piece together remote conditions using remnants like weathered fossils, decaying parchments or mummified remains. Cosmology, the study of the origin and evolution of the universe, is different. It is the one arena in which we can actually witness history.

title: Meteoric Rise for One Who Had Turned Away
description: Players earn ratings through their performances, and the easiest way to gauge improvement is to chart a rating over time.

title: In South Los Angeles, New Fast-Food Spots Get a No, Thanks
description: LOS ANGELES  Driving along Crenshaw Boulevard, it is not difficult to find a place to grab a bite. At some intersections, there is a fast-food joint on each corner.

title: Sunday: Something Punny Happened on the Way to the Blog
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Full disclosure here: Im a sucker for puns.

title: Chinas Winning Schools?
description: BEIJING

title: Russians Death Inflames Ethnic Strife
description: MOSCOW  Yegor Sviridov was killed in an unremarkable place  a bus stop surrounded by housing blocks, a grove of scraggly birch trees and a store called Fruit Heaven.

title: Stampede Near India Shrine Kills 100
description: NEW DELHI  More than 100 people were killed late Friday night when a stampede broke out among 100,000 pilgrims walking to a southern Indian Hindu shrine.

title: 5 Years After Katrina, Teacher Tills Soil of Lower 9th Ward
description: NEW ORLEANS  For an embattled former New York public school teacher and six young African-American men, a wrecked grocery store here has become a place of second chances.

title: The Truth and Consequences of Repeal
description: Get ready for more theater on Capitol Hill. House Republicans plan to push through legislation this week to repeal the health care reform law.

title: Vote on Secession in Sudan Comes to a Close
description: JUBA, Sudan  After the last voters in southern Sudans weeklong election on independence had trickled to the polls and cast their ballots, the polls closed and electoral officials quietly got down to the business of tallying the results. While a small crowd gathered at the memorial for the liberation leader John Garang, some bowing at his tomb, the counting was expected to carry on through the night.

title: Guns and the Border
description: In December, the Obama administration signaled a welcome new resolve to block the torrent of illegal guns moving into Mexico and the hands of the drug cartels.

title: Israeli Test on Worm Called Crucial in Iran Nuclear Delay
description: This article is by William J. Broad, John Markoff and David E. Sanger.

title: Student Pays Tuition One Dollar at a Time
description: While tuition increases in Britain prompted violent protests last month, rising college fees rarely elicit more than shrugs among most students in the United States.

title: Time, the Enemy
description: JIM ROBERTS, the assistant managing editor who has helped create todays NYTimes.com, likes to call it the 1440/7 news cycle  1,440 minutes every day, seven days a week, each one of those minutes demanding news for delivery to a networked world.

title: On the Border, Long Lives Despite Dismal Statistics
description: EDINBURG  Many of the longest lives in Texas are lived in an unlikely place: along the states impoverished border with Mexico. Despite conditions that often have the opposite consequences  desperately low incomes, a widespread lack of health insurance and poor rates of high school graduation  the predominantly Hispanic residents of Hidalgo County live on average to be 80, two years longer than the United States or Texas averages.

title: No One Listened to Gabrielle Giffords
description: OF the many truths in President Obamas powerful Tucson speech, none was more indisputable than his statement that no one can know what is in a killers mind. So why have we spent so much time debating exactly that?

title: Tourists Mimic Polar Pioneers, Except With Planes and Blogs
description: When the British explorer Robert Falcon Scott arrived at the South Pole only to find that he had been beaten there by Roald Amundsen and his team of Norwegians, he was despondent. Great God! This is an awful place, he lamented in his diary.

title: Mayor Lee Leads Growing Asian-American Clout
description: The Asian Law Caucus was a fledgling civil rights organization when Edwin M. Lee began there as a law clerk more than three decades ago.

title: A January Pause
description: The house is laden with icicles. Looking out my office window, I feel as though Im living in the maw of some fabulous fanged beast readying to devour the rest of the day.

title: Heres an Easy One
description: Vows by Congressional Republicans to slash billions from the federal budget at a time when joblessness is high and the economy needs stimulus are reckless. But here is one big-ticket saving that all members of Congress should get behind: cutting the billions of dollars in farm subsidies that distort food prices, encourage overfarming and inflate the price of land.

title: Judy Bonds, an Enemy of Mountaintop Coal Mining, Dies at 58
description: Ankle deep in the stream by the house where his coal-mining family had lived for generations, Judy Bondss 6-year-old grandson, Andrew, scooped up fistfuls of dead fish one day back in 1996.

title: A Tucson Victim Is Arrested at a TV Forum
