title: Melting in Andes Reveals Remains and Wreckage
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia  In the haunts of this city where climbers gather over plates of grilled llama and bottles of Pacea beer to swap tales of mountaineering derring-do, they feign boredom when talk turns to the 19,974-foot-high Huayna Potos, a jagged Andean peak that looms over La Paz.

title: Rosie the Riveter Memorial
description: Women who served as military industry workers during World War II are commemorated by a sculpture in Richmond at the former Kaiser Shipyard No. 2. Twenty thousand Rosie the Riveters labored in defense factories here as Richmonds population quadrupled during the war years. HANK PELLISSIER

title: Redevelopment Agencies Lie in Cost-Cutters Sights
description: Jonathan Weber writes a regular column for The Bay Citizen

title: Governors Budget Cuts Will Not Affect Those With the San Franciscos Universal Health Care Plan
description: Tens of thousands of San Franciscans will be insulated from state budget cuts, thanks to the Healthy San Francisco, the citys plan to provide health care to all its residents, local officials said.

title: Labor Laying Ground for Gains in Council Races
description: Organized labor is planning to spend millions of dollars and deploy thousands of volunteers across Chicagos wards in the coming election to expand its influence at City Hall.

title: Man Shot in Tucson Rampage Is Arrested at a TV Taping
description: TUCSON  A victim of the shooting spree here that killed six people and wounded 13, including Representative Gabrielle Giffords, was arrested Saturday after he spoke threateningly at a televised forum intended to help this stricken city heal, the police and witnesses said.

title: Romulus Linney, Wide-Ranging Playwright, Dies at 80
description: Romulus Linney, a playwright who roved along many intellectual paths, exploring the Southern Appalachian culture of his upbringing, refashioning classical works for modern times and adapting contemporary novels for the stage, died on Saturday at home in Germantown, N.Y. He was 80 and also had a home in Manhattan.

description: To most die-hard Bears fans, a fumble may be a good enough reason to throw the corn chips at the television. But for Arnold Horween III and his son Nick, the frustration of a fumble can be personal, especially if the announcer makes an offhand remark about a slippery football.

title: When a Rapper Runs for Alderman: Connections, Talent and a Grammy Never Hurt
description: Che Smith is a newcomer to politics, but his celebrity as the Grammy Award-winning rapper Rhymefest has brought widespread media attention to his bid for alderman of the 20th Ward and the sort of high-profile campaign events typical of national elections.

title: Live Analysis: Packers 48, Falcons 21
description: Live analysis and coverage of the N.F.C. divisional round playoff game between the Green Bay Packers and the Atlanta Falcons. The Falcons earned the N.F.C.s top seed; the Packers reached tonights game with a run-dominated win in Philadelphia last week.

title: Baghdad Raids on Alcohol Sellers Stir Fears
description: BAGHDAD  Eight men carrying handguns and steel pipes raided a Christian nongovernmental organization here on Thursday night, grabbing computers, cellphones and documents, and threatening the people inside, according to members of the group.

title: Wisconsin Sounds Off, but Misses the Point
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative

title: Steelers Beat Ravens to Advance to A.F.C. Title Game
description: PITTSBURGH  There were 65 yards between the Steelers and the end zone in their A.F.C. divisional playoff game against the Baltimore Ravens, which was tied with less than four minutes remaining when Ben Roethlisberger entered the huddle.

title: Vows: Patience & Sam
description: Sam and Patience attended high school together but shared only  hellos, one dance and a photograph that Sam kept for 25 years. When he joined Facebook, he remembered the photo and reconnected.

title: Chinas Education System
description: My Sunday column is about Chinas education system  and its a challenging topic. You see, Americans (me included) tend to be quite admiring, and Shanghais success in the PISA tests would seem to ratify that. But the Chinese education system does have one important group of detractors: the Chinese themselves. As I noted in the column, so many Chinese whom I respect are deeply critical of their school system as too regimented and stifling, even though they do acknowledge that the Confucian reverence for education is deeply embedded and very positive.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Jan. 16
description: Lawmakers and others affected by the shooting rampage in Tucson gather on the Sunday talk shows to discuss the questions raised by the shooting and the lessons they have learned.

title: Amid Cuts, Public Colleges Step Up Appeals to Alumni
description: As state legislatures cut back support for higher education, public colleges and universities across the country are turning to their alumni, hat in hand, as never before  hiring consultants, hunting down graduates and mobilizing student phone banks to raise private money in amounts they once thought impossible.

title: Flo Gibson, Grande Dame of Audiobooks, Dies at 86
description: Flo Gibson, who for decades read soothingly to Americans as they toiled at the gym, behind the wheel or over housework, died on Jan. 7 at her home in Washington. Mrs. Gibson, the universally acknowledged grande dame of audiobooks, was 86.

title: Political Focus on Jobs in Health Fight
description: WASHINGTON  As Republicans choreograph a House vote to repeal President Obamas health care overhaul this week, no charge has stung Democrats more than the argument that the new law will kill jobs in an economy wobbling back to life.

title: Lottery Numbers
As a Morality Play, Flacco vs. Roethlisberger Falls Flat
description: Pittsburgh

title: Hawks Favorite Year
description: Through the Hawks first five games in 2011, it seemed the team couldnt lose and that shooting guard Jamal Crawford couldnt miss.Unfortunately, all good things come to an end. Atlantas five-game winning streak was snapped by the Houston Rockets on Saturday night, and with it went a hot stretch in which Crawford put up 27.4 points a game and a 51.2 field-goal percentage.

title: Clippers Show Some Life
description: The Los Angeles Clippers started the season with one victory in their first 14 games. After a 105-91 loss to Philadelphia on Dec. 15, the Clippers were 5-21 and among the worst teams in the league. The rookie forward Blake Griffins ferocious dunks (usually coming in losses) were the lone highlights for a team that seemed to be going nowhere.

title: A.F.C. Divisional Replay: Steelers 31, Ravens 24
description: Pittsburgh used a 65-yard drive in the final minutes to top the Ravens and advance to the A.F.C. title game.

title: Ethel Merman, Queen of Musicals, Dies at 76
description: Ethel Merman, the musical-comedy star whose belting voice and brassy style entertained Broadway and movie audiences for 50 years, was found dead in her Manhattan apartment yesterday.

title:
U.S. AND ALLIES OPEN AIR WAR ON
IRAQ; BOMB BAGHDAD AND KUWAITI
TARGETS; 'NO CHOICE' BUT FORCE,
BUSH DECLARES
description: WASHINGTON, Thursday, Jan. 17 -- The United States and allied forces Wednesday night opened the long threatened war to drive President Saddam Hussein's army from Kuwait, striking Baghdad and other targets in Iraq and Kuwait with waves of bombers and cruise missiles launched from naval vessels.

title: N.F.C. Divisional Replay: Packers 48, Falcons 21
description: Green Bay used five straight touchdowns in the second and third quarters to break open the game.

title: Rule Book Allows Shootout Showiness
description: When Edmontons Linus Omark, in his first N.H.L. game last month, pulled a spin move just after picking up the puck at center ice, skated over the blue line, pump-faked, then slapped the puck past Tampa Bay goalie Dan Ellis, the hockey world went nuts.The Lightning players were furious, criticizing Omark for what they considered a showboat move that disrespected the game. But others said that the Lightning had been merely sore losers and that the shootout  a skills contest tacked onto what was otherwise a tie game  was meant to entertain fans. Omarks move, they argued, was entertaining. And besides, it worked.Since then, more shootout attempts have incorporated spin moves, most right in front of the goalie, and the controversy has not subsided.

title: Hasek Aging Well
description: Dominik Hasek, who turns 46 on Jan. 29, just keeps on rolling.

title: With Rodgers on Target, Packers Toss Falcons Away
description: ATLANTA  Seeded at the bottom of their conference, with an ineffectual rushing attack and a defense crippled by three starters on injured reserve, the Green Bay Packers glided within a whiff of the Super Bowl on Saturday by displaying their mastery of a simple childhood activity: pitch and catch.

title: The Best Tactic for Working Out for Less
description: If your resolution for 2011 is to stay in shape but also save money by dropping your gym membership, a recent Patient Money column, Burning Calories, but Not a Hole in Your Wallet, offered some advice to help you achieve those goals.

title: Jets-Patriots: Nothing Left but to Play the Game
description: The time for talking is done. Well, almost. We leave the last word to Joe Namath, who flashes his Super Bowl ring in these videos and says the Jets will have to play their best game of the season to win.

title: Military Backs New Leaders in Tunisia
description: TUNIS  New battle lines appeared to take shape in traumatized Tunisia on Sunday as the military backed the nascent interim government in what state media portrayed as a fight against security forces loyal to ousted President Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, blaming them for the violence and rioting that has engulfed the country since protests forced him from power 48 hours earlier.

title: The Education of a Newbie
description: LOS ANGELES Jennifer Lawrence, the 20-year-old star of Winters Bone (and the forthcoming X-Men: First Class), has been on our must-talk-to list ever since the National Board of Review gala, when she described working with Oliver Platt on X-Men as like having a puppy lick your face  a line she later said her manager told her not to use.

title: Too Little, Then Too Much in Australia
description: CARPENDALE, Australia  The smashed remains of Kapernicks Bridge  with its bent guardrails and a hanging concrete slab where road once was  are as sure a sign as any that the Lockyer Valleys decade-long drought is finished.

title: Last Night
description: We didnt actually hear these specific players  but we went to an early music concert by Grant Herreid and Tom Zajac. Awesome  even the bagpipes.

title: Wages and Employment, Again (Wonkish)
description: I occasionally mention here that recognizing the reality of wage stickiness is a key part of demand-side economics, but Ive also argued a number of times that cutting wages now would probably make the slump worse, not better. Is there a contradiction here?

title: Ryan Cedes the Floor to Dennis Byrd
description: BOSTON  For all of Rex Ryans motivational methods, he saved perhaps his best for Saturday night, on the eve of the Jets playoff game against New England. Earlier in the week, Ryan called that game, the third between the teams this season, the second-most important in Jets history  behind Super Bowl III.

title: Introduction by the Author
description: All modesty is false.

title: Milan Fashion Week | Day 1
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#360", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: A Sunday of Song for Obamas
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama  and their daughters, Malia and Sasha  attended morning services at Metropolitan AME church on Sunday, joining several hundred parishioners to listen to a sermon by the Rev. Ronald E. Braxton that recalled the example set by Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Le Pens Daughter Elected to Lead His Far-Right Party
description: PARIS  Jean-Marie Le Pen handed control of the far-right party he founded 38 years ago, the National Front, to his daughter Marine on Sunday.

title: Green Hornet a Hero for Sony Pictures
description: The Green Hornet was No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend with about $34 million in ticket sales  proof that a studio, in this case Sony Pictures Entertainment, can fix a troubled movie on the fly. After a sneak peak for The Green Hornet was greeted with ridicule from fanboys last summer, Sony performed triage. The film, based on the 1930s radio serial and 1960s television show, was re-edited, new scenes were shot and the advertising plan was reworked. The upshot: While sales were on the squishy side for a 3-D release costing at least $110 million, The Green Hornet is far from the flop that many expected.

title: Final: Bears 35, Seahawks 24
description: Live analysis and coverage of the N.F.C. divisional round playoff game between the Seattle Seahawks and the Chicago Bears.

title: A Family Speaks in Someone Elses Words, but at Least It Chooses the Best
description: Eleanor Browns debut novel begins charmingly, narrated by three sisters who speak as a single entity. They will explain the event that sets The Weird Sisters in motion, but first we have to explain how our family communicates, and to do that, we have to explain our family. After that: Oh, man.

title: Before Australian Open, a Focus on Something Bigger
description: MELBOURNE  It was a sharp contrast. Down below, on a luminous blue court, star tennis players like Novak Djokovic, Andy Roddick and Caroline Wozniacki were in a playful mood, preparing to entertain a sellout crowd in Rod Laver Arena.

title: A Different Ending for 127 Hours
description: LOS ANGELES James Franco might think of 127 Hours as a Beckett play, as he previously told the Bagger, but it couldve been a much more traditional Hollywood story. At a party for W Magazine at the Chateau Marmont on Friday, the Bagger spoke with Simon Beaufoy, a writer of the film (and of the Oscar juggernaut Slumdog Millionaire, along with his partner, the writer-director Danny Boyle), and he revealed to us that 127 Hours, a Golden Globe nominee this evening for best screenplay and for Mr. Francos performance, nearly had an altogether different finish, even after the scene that everyone watches through splayed fingers.

title: Part 6: Answers to Readers Questions on Financial Aid
description: As families of prospective college freshmen begin to tackle the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, or Fafsa, Mark Kantrowitz, a financial aid expert and founder of the Web sites finaid.org and fastweb.com, is answering questions from readers of The Choice this week.

title: Live Analysis: Jets 28, Patriots 21, Final
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The Jets defeated the Patriots, 28-21, on Sunday to advance to the American Football Conference championship game with a strong defensive effort and an opportunistic offense.

title: In Sudan, Early Results Strongly Lean to Secession
description: JUBA, Sudan  Southern Sudanese election officials posted early results on Sunday indicating that perhaps more than 95 percent of voters in this regional capital voted to secede from Sudan.

title: Dr. King and New York City
description: The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. is identified mostly with Washington and the South, but he was officially an honorary New Yorker and the city plays a not insignificant role in his biography.

title: Scenes From a (Very Crowded) Party
description: LOS ANGELES You really get to know people real well here, Jack McGee, who plays Melissa Leos husband in The Fighter, told the Bagger as he squeezed by us for three seconds at the Paramount party at the Chateau Marmont on Saturday night. The space was jammed as usual, with an array of statuette contenders, other familiar TV and movie faces and those unicorns of the awards season, older Academy members. Stay out of trouble, Mark Wahlberg, as always a big draw for fans, told a teenage boy after posing for a photo with him. On this Golden Globes weekend, there was Michael Keaton and Chace Crawford  not together, sadly  Jeff Bridges and the Coen brothers, David O. Russell, Paul Haggis (who told us that Ron Burkle wrote his charity a $100,000 check after their party the other night), the writer-director Mike White in a striped ski hat, and Jason Segel, who charmed us with his down-to-earthness. (He walked to the Chateau from his nearby home.)

title: When Logic and Proportion Have Fallen
description: This, on the other hand, is for tomorrows column.

title: Young Voices Rise in American Opera
description: Serious New York opera gourmands know that offerings from the citys three main conservatories  the Juilliard School, the Manhattan School of Music and Mannes College the New School for Music  are a vital part of any healthy diet. Sinners and Saints, mounted by the Mannes Opera in the Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College on Friday evening, proved the point in several ways, any one of which would have argued strongly for attention from aficionados and neophytes alike.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 16
description: A view of the day in sports, with mishaps on ice and a fund-raiser Down Under.

title: The Quick Choice May Not Be the Right Choice
description: There are certain plays that we make almost without thinking  then soon realize that we have made a mistake. This is an example (see Diagram 1):

title: Bears Sweep Aside Seahawks and Gain Duel With Packers
description: CHICAGO  By the time the Bears bolted to a quick and insurmountable lead against the Seattle Seahawks in Sundays N.F.C. divisional playoff game, snow was sticking to Soldier Fields frozen grass. During timeouts, workers used brooms and leaf blowers to clear the yardage lines, making more progress than the Seahawks offense for most of the game.

title: N.F.C. Divisional Replay: Bears Eliminate Seahawks
description: Chicago jumped in front quickly and won the N.F.C. divisional game, 35-24.

title: A Band No Halftime Ever Saw
description: What is a marching band to do this time of year if it doesnt have a bowl game to accompany? An eccentric variant, the Symphonie des Dragons, playing mostly Baroque oboes and bassoons, set up shop on Thursday evening at the Morgan Library & Museum for a concert in the series presented by the Boston Early Music Festival, From the Court to the Stage: The Rise of the French Oboe Band.

title: Verdi and Wagner
description: In his video series, Anthony Tommasini contrasts the dynamic duo of 19th-century opera: Verdi and Wagner.

title: With Some Friends to Help, a Songwriter Reveals His World
description: The theater songs of the up-and-coming composer Lance Horne, performed by a cast of his friends at the Allen Room on Friday evening, exemplify the blunt melodic style that has become the new normal of Broadway musicals.

title: Bowing and Plucking to Honor a Festival
description: Chamber Music America is devoted to keeping the machinery of music making well oiled. One way it does that is by holding an annual conference in New York at which musicians, managers, concert presenters, publishers and record company executives mingle. This years took place Thursday through Sunday, and among the highlights was a 60th-anniversary tribute to the Marlboro Music Festival in Vermont, a fountainhead of chamber music in America, on Saturday evening at Symphony Space. (The concert honored Marlboros administrators, Anthony P. Checchia and Frank Salomon, who received the organizations Richard J. Bogomolny National Service Award.)

title: How a Club Becomes a Salon for a Night
description: Thomas Bartlett, who performs as Doveman, doesnt hog the spotlight. Alongside his solo albums he has worked as a keyboardist and arranger for the National, Bebel Gilberto, Antony and the Johnsons, and others whose music is infused with pensive drama, and he applies his classical piano training for atmosphere and delicacy, not acrobatics.

title: Squad Cars, Sirens and Gangs, and the Cameras That Love Them
description: In May, during a police raid in Detroit, a 7-year-old girl, Aiyana Stanley-Jones, was shot in the head and killed as she slept on a living-room couch. It was an undeniable tragedy, and might have remained a local one but for an unusual circumstance: The police officers involved in the shooting were accompanied by cameras from The First 48, the reliably engrossing A&E show that documents the early stages of homicide investigations. Last month the girls family filed suit against A&E Television Networks, alleging that filming the raid was tantamount to encouraging it.

title: Behind a Hedgerow, Talking True Grit
description: LOS ANGELES The Bagger is in place on the red carpet at the Golden Globes  well, were sitting on the floor near it, anyway, eating a cheese sandwich we brought from home; dont hate us because were glamorous  so lets take a moment to acknowledge the films that were overlooked by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association. There are so many  where to start? Well, the group doesnt have a documentary category at all, for example. And as has been much noted, it entirely snubbed True Grit, the Coen brothers Western. Maybe they just have it in for the Coens? Last years A Serious Man was also nearly ignored.

title: Performers Unions Approve Contract
description: The members of the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, which jointly represent more than 137,000 performers, have ratified a new three-year agreement with film and television studios and producers that calls for a 6 percent raise in wages and a 1.5 percent increase in employer contributions to retirement and medical plans. Ken Howard, president of the screen actors group, described the result, in which 93 percent of those voting favored the accord, as a huge boon for members at a time when the film and television industries are experiencing a sharp retrenchment. The Directors Guild of America has also reached a tentative agreement with the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers, with final approval by members expected as early as this month. But the situation of the Writers Guild, which late in 2007 began a three-month strike that affected production timetables, continues to be uncertain. That groups contract is scheduled to expire on May 1, but negotiations have not yet been scheduled. In a statement the producers alliance praised the performers groups for their commitment to industry stability.

title: Benefit Performance For Belarus Troupe
description: The Public Theater and LaMaMa are sponsoring an encore benefit performance on Monday night of Being Harold Pinter, the play that the Belarus Free Theater has been performing at the Under the Radar festival, which ended on Sunday. Tom Stoppard and Tony Kushner will host the event, at the Public, which is meant to draw attention to the plight of the Belarussian troupe (including Yana Rusakevich, above), whose members have been subjected to arrest and harassment by the government of Belarus, a former Soviet republic now ruled by Aleksandr G. Lukashenko. Readings by celebrity guests will also be part of the event, which will be followed on Wednesday by a noon protest in front of Belaruss mission to the United Nations and another evening benefit celebrating the group and its commitment to freedom of expression, this one at Le Poisson Rouge and featuring Mr. Stoppard and the novelists E. L. Doctorow and Don DeLillo.

title: Dying for Discovery
description: Almost 20 years ago now, in western Ecuador, I traveled with a team of extraordinary biologists studying a remnant of forest as it was being hacked down around us. Al Gentry, a gangling figure in a grimy T-shirt and jeans frayed from chronic tree climbing, was a botanist whose strategy toward all hazards was to pretend that they didnt exist. At one point, a tree came crashing down beside him after he lost his footing on a slope. Still on his back, he reached out for an orchid growing on the trunk and said, Oh, thats Gongora, as casually as if he had just spotted an old friend on a city street.The teams birder, Ted Parker, specialized in identifying bird species by sound alone. He started his work day before dawn, standing in the rain under a faded umbrella, his sneakers sunk to their high-tops in mud, whispering into a microcassette recorder about what he was hearing: Scarlet-rumped cacique  a fasciated antshrike  two more pairs of Myrmeciza immaculata counter-singing. Dysithamnus puncticeps chorus, male and female

title: For Byrd, Reconnecting With Jets Is Special
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Last week, Rex Ryan tweaked Tom Brady and set himself as the protagonist versus New England Coach Bill Belichick. So on Saturday night, on the eve of the Jets American Football Conference divisional playoff game against the Patriots, Ryan allowed someone else to get his team motivated for the latest iteration of the rivalry.

title: Romantic 1950s Rock With a Big Appetite
description: The video for Listen to Your Love, the first single by the Nashville band Mona, teems with context. Crammed tight are clips of drag-racing muscle cars, buxom real-life Vargas girls in their underwear, Marilyn and Elvis and more. In between are shots of the band members getting their slick hair just so, roughhousing and wearing perfectly tight black jeans: rebels out of time.

title: In the Bronx, a Church on the Mend
description: A year ago, the Glory of Christ Church was left in shambles by vandalized who set it afire. But its pastor and congregation are proving resilient.

title: Relocated to America, Still Bloodthirsty
description: The popular British series Being Human, about a werewolf, a vampire and a ghost sharing a run-down house in Bristol, isnt great television, and its use of scary monsters as a metaphor for adolescent (or in this case, 20-something) alienation has been old hat for well over a decade. (Yes, Buffy was that long ago.)

title: The Law? Shell Do It Her Way, Thank You
description: It is at least a little amusing to think of Harriet  Harry  Korn as Ally McBeal several decades later, having never shed her menopausal weight gain and only ballooning further, thanks to a diet of grease and packaged cupcakes. Played by Kathy Bates with a likable cynicism, Harry is the fatigued and disaffected lawyer at the center of Harrys Law (beginning Monday on NBC), a woman who has clearly worked too hard at the expense of any real fulfillment, only to conclude that her job was no more thrilling than sorting mail.

title: Houstons Jazz Stars, Celebrated in TriBeCa
description: In music circles, around the turn of the new century, the phrase from Houston started to mean something by consensus. Not just in hip-hop and R&B  that was the time of Swishahouse Records, DJ Screw, UGK and Destinys Child  but, strangely enough, in jazz.

title: Monday: Guided Missiles and Misguided Men
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Confused by todays title? Its part of a quote by a man whose leadership and strength we are celebrating today. The full quote, meant to highlight the folly of our national priorities, is, We have guided missiles and misguided men.

title: The Social Network and Glee Dominate at Golden Globes
description: On Sunday night the Hollywood Foreign Press Association handed out its Golden Globe awards at the Beverly Hilton Hotel. Melena Ryzik (a k a The Carpetbagger), Cathy Horyn, the Hollywood reporters Brooks Barnes and Michael Cieply and the television critic Mike Hale covered the red carpet and the ceremony live. Related Article | List of Winners and Nominees  | Red Carpet Slide Show | More Awards Season Coverage

title: A Former Dictator Reappears in Haiti
description: MEXICO CITY  Haitis political crisis took a stunning turn on Sunday when Jean-Claude Duvalier, the dictator known as Baby Doc who was overthrown in 1986, arrived unexpectedly in the capital from exile in France.

title: Egypt Sentences Muslim to Death in Killings of Christians
description: CAIRO  An Egyptian court sentenced a Muslim man to death Sunday for killing six Christians and a Muslim police guard outside a church in a drive-by shooting more than a year ago.

title: Inadequate Fight Against Drugs Hampers Russias Ability to Curb H.I.V.
description: MOSCOW  They look like addicts anywhere in the world: tattered and vacant-eyed, they circle Moscow pharmacies known to sell prescription drugs illicitly, looking for something to inject for a quick high.

title: China Leaders Limits Come Into Focus as U.S. Visit Nears
description: BEIJING  With President Hu Jintao at the helm, China has become a $5 trillion industrial colossus, a growing military force, and, it sometimes appears, a model of authoritarian decisiveness, navigating out of the global financial crisis and sealing its position as the worlds fastest rising power.

title: Red Carpet at the 2011 Golden Globes
description: A look at the fashions on the red carpet of the Golden Globe awards.

title: Better Approaches to Home Loans?
description: To the Editor:

title: Efforts to Rein In the Power of Unions

title: Giffordss Condition Is Upgraded to Serious
description: Representative Gabrielle Giffordss condition has been upgraded to serious from critical, according to a statement from University Medical Center in Tucson, where Ms. Giffords has been hospitalized since the shooting on Jan. 8 in which six people were killed and Ms. Giffords and 12 others were wounded.

title: Last Word Goes to Jets
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The Jets sprinted through the tunnel at Gillette Stadium, arms extended, as if flying. They shouted. They screamed. They yapped the way they yapped throughout the past week, the way they yapped throughout this season, the way they plan to yap all the way to the Super Bowl next month.

title: Irish Leader Rejects Push to Resign as Party Chief
description: LONDON  Resisting pressure from a senior minister and some of his own backbenchers, the Irish prime minister, Brian Cowen, said Sunday that he would not resign as leader of the governing Fianna Fail party. Instead, he called a secret ballot of the partys parliamentary bloc on Tuesday to decide the issue.

title: After Deadly Mudslides in Brazil, Concern Turns to Preparedness
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Unrelenting rains for much of the weekend complicated the search for scores of people still missing after violent floods stirred mudslides that ripped through hillside communities around Rio de Janeiro, killing more than 600 people since last week.

title: Declining War, Rejecting Peace
In an Online Gaming World, Tucson Suspect Gave Hints of Problems
description: Among the many traces that Jared L. Loughner, the young man charged with killing six people and wounding 13 others in a shooting spree in Tucson, left on the Internet were forum postings that reveal a deeply troubled individual struggling to make sense of his life and circumstances.

title: Four Lead Tata Steel Chess Tournament
Lily's New Hip
description: While hip replacement surgery for larger dogs has been around since the mid-1970s, hip replacement surgery for smaller dogs like Lily who weigh between 6 and 30 lbs, only became available in 2006.

title: Politically Confident, Iran Cuts Subsidies on Prices
description: TEHRAN  After months of false starts, dire warnings and political wrangling, Iran has embarked on a sweeping program of cuts in its costly and inefficient system of subsidies on fuel and other essential goods that has put a strain on state finances and held back economic progress for years.

title: At a Church Set Afire, a Spirit Unextinguished
description: A table full of debris holds a place of honor in the Rev. Raymond Talaveras office. Charred chunks of wood, the molten tips of flagpoles and a ragged patch of red carpet rest atop a soot-tinged tablecloth. They are reminders of the fire set by vandals who destroyed what they could not steal inside the Glory of Christ Church a little more than a year ago.

title: Joint Replacements Keep Dogs in the Running
description: In November 2006, Dr. Melvyn Pond performed total hip-replacement surgery on a patient who had been hobbled from years of exercise and competition.

title: Any White House Run Will Wait, Christie Says
description: Amid continued speculation about his presidential aspirations, Gov. Chris Christie denied again on Sunday that he would run in 2012, saying that he was not ready to be president. He hinted, however, that he might consider a run later on.

title: France Seen Wary of Interfering in Tunisia Crisis
description: PARIS  France, slow to express support for the Tunisian demonstrators who overthrew its longtime ally, President Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, is moving to try to pick up the pieces in a country where Paris has deep economic, personal and historical ties.

title: Support Expected for Plan to Beef Up Afghan Forces
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan government and its international partners are set to approve a plan that would expand the nations army and police forces to up to 378,000 personnel by October 2012, a 42 percent increase over the current level, Western and Afghan officials say.

title: With Playoff Win, Cutler Alters the Story Line
description: CHICAGO  How Jay Cutler would fare in the first playoff game of his five-season N.F.L. career was one of the dominant story lines leading to Sundays N.F.C. divisional matchup between his Bears and the Seattle Seahawks at Soldier Field.

title: Mourning a Woman Who Shared a 9/11 Miracle
description: The story of her improbable rescue by New York City firefighters was among the most enduring to emanate from the horror of Sept. 11, 2001. It was told and retold: how a weary woman, Josephine Harris, was coaxed and carried to safety by six men from Ladder Company 6 in Chinatown who had rushed to the World Trade Center that morning.

title: Cunning, Care and Sheer Luck Save Rare Map
description: It was rolled up among other yellowed maps and prints that came off a delivery truck at the Brooklyn Historical Societys stately office near the East River. Carolyn Hansen, the societys map cataloguer, began to gently unfurl the canvas.

description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Last year, when the Baltimore Ravens demolished the Patriots in a first-round playoff game, it was easy to assign blame.

description: PARIS  Economic growth is an elixir for struggling economies, but in Europe its likely to come slowly to the countries that need it most.

title: St. Johns Changes Direction in the Blink of an Eye
description: Notre Dame guard Ben Hansbrough finished off a fast break with a dunk, and a St. Johns lead that had been 12 points less than a minute earlier had melted to 6 on Sunday. But D. J. Kennedy, a senior forward for the Red Storm, did not even sneak a quick peek at the scoreboards at Madison Square Garden.

title: Redefining How to Beat the Buzzer
description: Twenty years and one-tenth of a decade ago, on Martin Luther Kings Birthday at Madison Square Garden, the Knicks experienced a holiday miracle. Trent Tucker scored a basket that should not have counted, could not have counted, but was allowed, anyway, to make frustrated and historic losers of Michael Jordan and the Chicago Bulls.

title: The War on Logic
description: My wife and I were thinking of going out for an inexpensive dinner tonight. But John Boehner, the speaker of the House, says that no matter how cheap the meal may seem, it will cost thousands of dollars once you take our monthly mortgage payments into account.

title: Big Retailers Fill More Aisles With Groceries
description: For dinner tonight, pick up some sushi and salad  at Walgreens. Or maybe some Target chicken.

title: For Californias Budget Examiner, an Ease With Diplomacy and Dollar Signs
description: SACRAMENTO  If the California budget process sometimes resembles an extremely expensive food fight, with the name-calling, hair-pulling and that $25 billion deficit, Mac Taylor is the adult in the room.

title: The Social Network Dominates Golden Globes
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  What can be the silliness of the Golden Globes matched up with the seriousness of the critics on Sunday night as The Social Network took the prize for best drama, Colin Firth was named best dramatic actor for The Kings Speech and Natalie Portman danced away with the award for best actress in a drama at the entertainment industrys second-favorite awards show.

title: Scenes From a Marriage
description: In every twisted, wretched, ruinous relationship, there are moments so grim, flare-ups so appalling, that they offer both parties a chance to step back, take inventory, and realize that its time  far past time, in fact  to go their separate ways.

title: Lawmakers Aiming to Increase Civility
description: WASHINGTON  A leader of the Senate Democrats and one of the Senates most conservative Republicans will sit together at the State of the Union speech next week in a gesture of unity.

title: Illinois Wakes Up
description: For years, Illinois, like so many states, pretended that it had not fallen off a budgetary cliff. It was spending too much and taking in too little revenue, but every year it would kick its problems into the next. Unable to pay its bills, it finally accepted reality last week and raised taxes on incomes and businesses  a first step toward getting its house in order.

title: Hezbollah Vows Defense in Inquiry
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Hezbollahs leader warned Sunday that his Shiite Muslim movement would defend itself against indictments, expected soon from an international tribunal, naming its members in the assassination of a former prime minister, whose death plunged the country into the most prolonged crisis since the end of its 15-year civil war.

title: Arizona, in the Classroom
description: Last weeks memorial service in Tucson, which began with a blessing by a professor of Yaqui Indian and Mexican heritage, showcased Arizonas rich diversity as well as the love and tolerance of many of its citizens.

title: A Joy to Be Free
description: During his 30 years in prison, Cornelius Dupree Jr. twice rejected his chance for freedom because an admission of guilt for rape and robbery was the price of parole. Whatever your truth is, you have to stick with it, Mr. Dupree explained this month after a Texas judge exonerated him of the 1979 crime on the basis of DNA evidence kept in long-term county storage.

title: They Could Be Subtler
description: Bankers would love nothing more than for the rest of the world to move on and forget about the financial meltdown that tipped us into the deepest economic trough since the 1930s.

title: Lawsuit Loans Add New Risk for the Injured
description: Larry Long, debilitated by a stroke while using the pain medicine Vioxx, was facing eviction from his Georgia home in 2008. He could not wait for the impending settlement of a class-action lawsuit against the drugs maker, so he borrowed $9,150 from Oasis Legal Finance, pledging to repay the Illinois company from his winnings.

description: Move over Liv Tyler, make room for Gemma Arterton.

title: 7-Year Fight to Reclaim a House Stolen in the Wave of a Pen

He was told that the debt had already been paid.

title: Criticism of Aaron Rodgers Sparks Furious Response
description: Mike Florio of ProFootballTalk.com stirred up a bit of a hornets nest on Sunday afternoon when he criticized Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers after a local television station report showed Rodgers blowing past an autograph-seeking fan at the airport before the team flew to Atlanta last week.

title: In Inaugural Speeches, Warnings of Rough Road Ahead
description: Opening addresses of incoming governors in recent days show that upbeat visions have often been eclipsed by worries about jobs, money and budget gaps.

description: When military investigators looked into an attack by American helicopters last February that left 23 Afghan civilians dead, they found that the operator of a Predator drone had failed to pass along crucial information about the makeup of a gathering crowd of villagers.

title: Arrest Made in New Jersey Officer Shooting
description: CAMDEN, N.J.  The police raided an apartment early Sunday morning and arrested a 19-year-old man accused of murdering a police officer in Lakewood on Friday, ending an exhaustive manhunt, officials said.

title: Nonprofits Are Buying More Air Time
description: Governmental agencies, labor unions and nonprofit groups bought 41.7 percent more radio spots in 2010 than they did in 2009. They were the fifth-largest buyers of radio time last year, up from No. 10 in 2009.

title: Susannah York, British Actress, Dies at 72
description: Susannah York, an Academy Award-nominated actress known for her portrayals of exquisite, often fragile young women in British and American films of the 1960s and 70s, died on Saturday in London. She was 72 and lived in London.

title: Radio Ban Elicits Protests

description: President Obamas speech after the Tucson shootings earned plaudits for framing the nations aspirations through the eyes of a fallen child.

title: Remmy Ongala, Tanzanian Musical Star, Dies at 63
description: In 1990, as the AIDS epidemic was gathering strength in Africa, the Tanzanian songwriter, singer, guitarist and bandleader Remmy Ongala released an ebullient dance track called Mambo Kwa Soksi (Things With Socks). Its lyrics called for men to use condoms (socks) to prevent AIDS, and it stirred up controversy; Radio Tanzania refused to play it.

title: Liu Huaqing Dies at 94; Oversaw Modernization of Chinas Navy
description: Gen. Liu Huaqing, a military commander who oversaw the modernization of the Chinese Navy, died on Friday. He was 94.

title: For a Second Week, the Jets Make an Elite Quarterback Look Ordinary

title: A Globes Full of Conventional Wisdom
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. The Golden Globes has weathered its share of scandals and ridicule, from bribery charges to the suggestion that The Tourist is a comedy. (The shows host, Ricky Gervais, not to mention some of the honored, didnt shy away from poking fun.) And the Hollywood Foreign Press Association is not always a great predictor of future statuettes for the hopefuls that populate the accolades circuit. (See: Avatar last year.) But this year, the winners hewed closely to the conventional wisdom of awards-watchers, honoring the same performers, writers and directors who have been marching up red carpets and fine-tuning their thank-you speeches for weeks. (Im trying to mix it up, Lee Unkrich, the director of Toy Story 3, said.)

title: Capone Dead At 48; Dry Era Gang Chief
description: MIAMI BEACH, FLA., Jan. 25 --Al Capone, ex-Chicago gangster and prohibition era crime leader, died in his home here tonight.

title: In Paris, a Bar and Music Venue With Style to Spare
description: Tucked away on a quiet street in the 10th Arrondissement, Le Pompon is anything but timid. A former synagogue, the space has been converted into a speakeasy-style bar, a secret smoking salon and a concert venue. Since opening in October, the spot (39, rue des Petites curies; 33-1-53-34-60-85; www.lepompon.fr) has steadily been attracting crowds of trans-European hipsters, French fashionistas and just about anyone who enjoys dancing.

title: The Temporary Vegetarian: Vegan Vegetable Tempura
description: Masato Nishihara, the executive chef of Kajitsu, an elegant vegan Japanese restaurant in the East Village, created a vegan vegetable tempura, one without eggs in the batter. He believes that tempura batter, originally, was just flour and water, and that when you go back in history, at some point someone added eggs, said Chiaki Takada, who interpreted for Mr. Nishihara. The chef said that the differences between the two tempuras  one with eggs, the other without  are not big.

title: Curtain Down, Heads Up: Readers Respond to Other Desert Cities and Earnest

description: Analysis of the A.F.C. and N.F.C. championship matchups for the right to face off in Super Bowl XLV in Arlington, Tex., on Feb. 6. Before the teams kick off Sunday, check back for detailed analysis and discussion, and add your comments.

title: Column Comments
description: Some readers are weighing in with questions and complaints about the moderating process for comments on my column (as opposed to this blog). So what you need to know is that this is not my department: I dont play any role in that process. The public editor had a nice piece about how all that works. I do worry a bit that given the timing at which columns are posted, European commenters may have a head start; I dont know what can be done about that.

title: The Early Word: Honoring Dr. King, Anticipating Chinas President
description: In The Times:John Harwood writes about how President Obamas call last week for a country that lives up to our childrens expectations resonates on this Martin Luther Kings Birthday for black children, whose life prospects remain significantly diminished compared with white childrens.

title: Tunisia Unrest Stirs Passions Across North African Region
description: TUNIS  Passions unleashed by the revolution in Tunisia resonated throughout the region on Monday as an Egyptian and a Mauritanian became the latest of six North Africans to set themselves on fire in an imitation of the self-immolation that set off the uprising here a month ago.

title: Weekend Roundup: The Best Political Quotes and Clips
description: Miss all those great political tidbits over the weekend? Heres our roundup of some of the best ones.

title: Big-Business Deadbeats
description: Writing in The Washington Monthly, Jeffrey Leonard  chief executive of an investment firm  offers a new theory for why small businesses are struggling. Big businesses, Mr. Leonard says, arent paying their bills on time to their small-business vendors.

title: Just One Look | Bally Pre-Fall Collection
description: The Pre-Fall Collections, being shown in New York over the next several weeks, arrive in stores in May to fill the gap between bikinis and furs.

title: Underestimating the Jets, Year 2, Continued
description: So where do the Jets go from here? In Rex Ryans world, they are only halfway home. His road to Truthville has already traveled through outposts called Outrageousville and Sarcasticville. But with Superville not far down the road, Ryan had better be careful. Because if he can keep flooring the gas pedal of the Jets bandwagon, he just may end up getting his sweater vest retired into the Jets ring of honor next to the No. 12 of Joe Namath, the Jets most famous prognosticator.

title: Monday Morning Skate: Quiet Rumor Mill; OReilly Scare; Penguins Staal Shines
description: Seven things you should know about the weekend in the National Hockey League:

title: Jobs Takes Sick Leave at Apple Again, Stirring Questions
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Steven P. Jobs, the visionary co-founder and chief executive of Apple, is taking a medical leave of absence, a year and a half after his return following a liver transplant. The leave raises questions about both his long-term prognosis and the leadership of the worlds most valuable technology company.

title: Ex-Banker Gives Data on Taxes to WikiLeaks
description: LONDON  A former senior Swiss bank executive said on Monday that he had given the WikiLeaks founder, Julian Assange, details of more than 2,000 prominent individuals and companies that he contends engaged in tax evasion and other possible criminal activity.

title: Video Exclusive | Gang Gang Dance and Jules Marquis
description: New York favorites Gang Gang Dance will release their highly anticipated (at least by the art-rock set) fifth album this spring on the 4AD label. As the band gears up for the big date, it is planning a slew of shows, among them tonights private after-party for Capsule, a hip-enough fashion trade show held regularly in New York. Curated by Sean Hanratty, the nights bill includes Light Asylum as an opening act and a video installation by the artists Daniel Turner and Colin Snapp. The two recently began collaborating under the name Jules Marquis; this past December they debuted their joint work with a well-received show at the Martos Gallery in Chelsea. (And for those traveling to Milan in the next few days for mens fashion week, Turner has a solo show titled Britannica opening January 19 at the Pianissimo gallery on Via Ventura 6.)

title: Where News Is Power, a Fight to Be Well-Armed
description: WASHINGTON  Bobby Maldonado has the morning routine of a well-trained marathoner.

title: This Weeks Health Industry News
description: After a weeklong hiatus, House Republicans are expected this week to vote to repeal the health care reform law enacted last year.

title: Baraks Break With Party Shakes Up Israeli Politics
description: JERUSALEM  Israels defense minister, Ehud Barak, broke away Monday from the left-leaning Labor Party he had led and formed a smaller centrist faction that will stay in the governing coalition under a new name. The surprise move shook up Israeli politics but was expected to have little impact on its policies.

title: Euro Slips Against Dollar, and Futures Lose Ground
description: The euro fell on Monday, ending a five-day rally against the dollar, and Spanish bonds dropped as the regions ministers debated a bailout plan. United States stock futures declined abroad after Apple said that its chief executive, Steve Jobs, was taking a medical leave of absence.

title: Fashion Has a Moment at the Golden Globes
description: Many of the Golden Globe winners Sunday night are talented, but theyre also very glamorous. Most of the female nominees and presenters are regularly among the top fashion vote-getters  Angelina Jolie, Anne Hathaway, Nicole Kidman, Scarlett Johansson, Amy Adams  and some of them have had contracts with major fashion houses, as Natalie Portman, who won for Black Swan, does with Dior. And I expect to see all their Globes pictures splashed across European gossip magazines next week during the Paris couture shows. Thats the payoff that the Hollywood Foreign Press Association expects.

title: Just One Look | Givenchy Pre-Fall Collection
description: The Pre-Fall Collections, being shown in New York over the next several weeks, arrive in stores in May to fill the gap between bikinis and furs.

title: What Were Reading
description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.

title: Duvalier Meets With Advisers as Haiti Holds Its Breath
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  One year after Haiti was hit by a devastating earthquake that killed more than 200,000 people, the country grappled on Monday to absorb yet another potentially destabilizing blow: the surprising return of the former dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier, whose emergence from nearly a quarter-century in exile prompted condemnations from around the world and ignited new fears of conflict.

title: The Claim: Eating Ginger Helps Reduce Muscle Pain and Soreness
description: THE FACTS

title: Pancakes With Real Flavor
description: Whole grain pancakes are not only possible, and not only good: Theyre also far more varied and interesting than those made from white flour, more than simply a vehicle for maple syrup. Check them out in this weeks Minimalist column.

title: Henins Elbow Passes Its First Test
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  With temperatures cool enough for sweaters, it was an odd opening day for an Australian Open, the Grand Slam of the legionnaires cap and the extreme-heat policy, but there would have been chills running down Justine Henins spine no matter what the weather.

title: Glaxos Legal Problems Lead to New $3.4 Billion Charge
description: The British drug maker GlaxoSmithKline announced Monday that it was setting aside $3.4 billion  wiping out fourth-quarter profit  to pay for United States government investigations and product liability cases over its marketing of the diabetes drug Avandia.

title: J. Crew Go Shop Ends With No New Bids
description: Its final sale time at J. Crew.

title: Well, at Least I Got One Right
description: After publishing an interactive red-carpet feature over the weekend that included my guesses of which designers nine celebrities might be wearing this award season, including at the Golden Globes on Sunday, I heard some impassioned responses from a number of readers and friends who had their own theories. And it looks as if Ill be paying for dinner for quite some time.

title: Food Photography: Shooting Smoke, Steam and Flames
description: Andrew Scrivani (@Andrew Scrivani) is a freelance photographer who contributes to The New York Times. He writes the blog Making Sunday Sauce.

title: A Conversation With Carl Walter
description: In their new book, Red Capitalism: The Fragile Financial Foundation of Chinas Extraordinary Rise (John Wiley & Sons), Carl E. Walter and Fraser J.T. Howie paint a troubling portrait of Chinas economy and its financial system. Despite the nations mind-boggling growth and images of gleaming skyscrapers and luxury cars, the authors say Chinas growth model is flawed and fragile, and they warn about substantial risks accumulating in its banking system.

title: Scorecard | Jil Sander Wins!
description: Its Scorecard season again! The fall 2011 mens-wear shows kicked off in Milan on Saturday, so as ever were here reading the deluge of reviews so you dont have to. Early observations: January showers may bring February flowers, because critics are feeling that defining and refining your signature is totally cool.(Just see Raf Simonss masterful play across the gender line of couture volumes and Technicolor from his last womens collection at Jil Sander.) But be wary not to get stuck in a disco groove.

title: Monday Reading: Vacation Club Giveaways
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Officials Say Theyre Satisfied With Updated Spider-Man Promotion
description: 1:40 p.m. | Updated

title: Borders Gives Publishers a Deadline
description: Publishers have been given until Feb. 1 to decide whether they are willing to accept a proposal from the Borders Group to turn overdue payments into a loan, several people briefed on the situation said on Friday.

title: A Singular Approach and an Exceptional Victory
description: You can almost hear that noise in the background: the N.F.L. copy machine shutting down. For years it has been churning out copies of the Patriots franchise game plan and mimeos of the sour genius head coach in clearance-rack clothing (although a pure reproduction of the charisma vacuum that is Bill Belichick has proved elusive), but sometime in the middle of the Jets dismantling of New England on Sunday, someone hit the off button. And there will be a significant pause before a restart because, as much as the N.F.L. loves its copy machine, is it really possible to create another Rex Ryan? And if you could, would all that hot air evaporate the oceans?

title: Health Care Basics
description: Update: The pie chart only shows that part of health care paid for by insurance. The rest is out-of-pocket spending, which happens even in single-payer systems, public health spending, and a grab-bag of other stuff. Source is here (pdf).

title: Big Love Watch: The Consequences of Honesty
description: The fifth and final season of Big Love began on Sunday night on HBO. Well be following the wind-down here each week and hope youll join us for a continuing conversation about the Henricksons polygamous household. A broad-scope review of the series appeared last week, but here well get down to the nitty gritty.

title: Goldman Limits Facebook Investment to Foreign Clients
description: 8:55 p.m. | Updated

title: Cutting Jokes, on Schedule
description: LOS ANGELES The talk of the parties at the Beverly Hilton Hotel after the Golden Globes was the barbed performance of the host, Ricky Gervais.

title: Qaddafi Sees WikiLeaks Plot in Tunisia
description: Updated | 2:58 p.m. As Tunisians struggle to create order from the chaos that has followed the fall of a dictator, the countrys neighbors are engaged in a different kind of fight: over how to interpret and even what to call the events that led to the flight of Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, after weeks of street protests.

title: Porsche Cajun S.U.V. Could Be Built in China
description: In a Monday edition of the German magazine Focus, Porsche chief executive Matthias Mueller said that the automakers current production capacity at its Stuttgart-Zuffenhausen factory was insufficient to meet worldwide sales targets, particularly in emerging markets like China. But as Porsche integrates more fully with its parent company, the Volkswagen Group, the brand might locate production of future models  among them an S.U.V., the Cajun, which will be smaller and less expensive than the Cayenne  in either China or North America.

title: Fete Accompli | T Party in Los Angeles
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#108", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Soothing Sore Muscles With Ginger
description: Can a dose of ginger help you recover after a workout?

title: Investing With the Herd
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog, and other drawings are available on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

title: Numberplay: Honoring Martin and Ben
description: Today is Martin Luther King day, a federal holiday. Martin Luther King Jr. was actually born on Jan. 15, 1929, but we celebrate his birthday today, guided by the great American principle that states, No holiday shall be wasted by falling on a weekend! Coincidentally, Jan. 17 is the birthday of another great American hero, Benjamin Franklin, who was born on this date in 1706 by the modern Gregorian calendar.

title: Bingo Smith, the Cavaliers Loyal Superstar, Perseveres
description: Its hard for younger basketball fans to imagine, but the Cleveland Cavaliers had flashy scorers long before some guy named LeBron James played there.

title: High Peaks, High Drama in 2011 Dakar Rally
description: After driving nearly 6,000 miles over frigid high Andean plains and coastal dunes, up rock-gorged gullies and across boundless grasslands, a hearty cadre of truckers, four-wheel A.T.V. drivers, motorcyclists and car pilots were fted with confetti and champagne on Sunday in Buenos Aires, having wrapped the 2011 Dakar Rallys 15th and final stage on Saturday, just outside the Argentinian capital.

title: A Google Worry Recedes, for Now, as Italy Ends Investigation Into News Service
description: The Italian antitrust authority said Monday that it had ended an investigation into Googles Internet news service after the company took steps to ease newspaper publishers concerns about control over their content and the sharing of advertising revenue.

title: TripAdvisor Debuts Airline Rating System
description: For more than a decade, TripAdvisor.com has been a popular Web site for users to rate hotels, restaurants and activities. Now it has added airlines to the roster of ratable items. The new feature, which debuted last week as part of TripAdvisor Flights, the sites online flight search tool, allows travelers to add feedback on airlines in eight categories, as part of their booking process.

title: Changing Channels With Corey Hertzog, Red Bulls Top Draft Pick
description: It is now time for Corey Hertzog, the former Penn State striker and future Red Bulls player, to relax and enjoy the next couple of days. Just do not expect to find Hertzog rooted to his couch watching games from Europe, or anywhere else.

title: At Cavalli, a New Generations Take on the 70s
description: Milan

title: Iran Says It May Drop Womans Stoning Sentence
description: TEHRAN  Iranian officials said Monday that a woman convicted of adultery and sentenced to death by stoning may now face only a prison sentence for acting as an accessory to the murder of her husband.

title: Big-Business Deadbeats
description: Writing in The Washington Monthly, Jeffrey Leonard  chief executive of an investment firm  offers a new theory for why small businesses are struggling. Big businesses, Mr. Leonard says, arent paying their bills on time to their small-business vendors. On the Economix blog, David Leonhardt offers a closer look.

title: The Long Ordeal of Landing a Short-Term Rental
description: Eduardo Espirito Santo, a sociable graduate of the University of Richmond who comes from a prominent Portuguese banking family, would seem like a stable enough tenant. Even in a slow economy, he landed a summer internship at the Atlantic Council in Washington and this month started a second internship at a financial firm in New York City.

title: Whats Missing From Our Cognitive Toolkit?
description: This is your brain on words. Its clearly a pretty hard-wired system. But can we find ways to use whats locked in our skulls to better effect? Ill be writing more soon on that broad question, with a hint of my thoughts provided in a recent Tweet. Some variant on noosphere is clearly nigh.

title: No. 1s Out as Sixth Seeds Celebrate
description: The 2010 N.F.L. season was played with a fun-house mirror effect: down was up, up was down, parity was alive and so was a 7-9 division champion. But in a season of anomalies  19 overtime games, the Detroit Lions winning  none stood out quite like this: one year after both No. 1 playoff seeds advanced to the Super Bowl, the top seeds were eliminated in their first game, and both sixth-seeded teams advanced to the conference championship games Sunday.

title: Keep Your Voice, Even at the End of Life
description: The specter of death panels was raised yet again this month, prompting the Obama administration to give in to political pressure a second time in its effort to encourage end-of-life planning.

title: When Self-Knowledge Is Only the Beginning
description: It is practically an article of faith among many therapists that self-understanding is a prerequisite for a happy life. Insight, the thinking goes, will free you from your psychological hang-ups and promote well-being.

title: Productivity Over the Business Cycle (Wonkish)
description: Alex Tabarrok wonders what I think about a subject that has been obsessing Brad DeLong lately: the apparent shift toward a regime in which productivity growth, which used to decelerate in recessions as firms hoarded workers, now rises instead.

title: Self-Immolation Protests Spread Across North Africa
description: CAIRO  The self-immolation of a 26-year-old Tunisian man a month ago that set off a popular uprising is inspiring similar acts of gruesome protest across North Africa.

title: Winter Root Vegetables
description: Food writers tend to be exuberant about spring and summer vegetables, but a bit muted about cold-weather produce. Maybe its because summers offerings are fleeting in comparison to winters enduring, staid roots and tubers. Thats too bad: There are plenty of delicious, comforting dishes to be made with vegetables like kohlrabi, turnips, rutabaga, celeriac, carrots and turnips.

title: Embedistan: Outside the Wire, Off the Message
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  At the end of his trip to Kabul in late March, President Obama declared after a high-profile military offensive that the Marines had pushed the Taliban out of the Afghan region of Marja, one of its major strongholds. But even as the president spoke those words, the Marines in Marja were telling a different story to an embedded reporter: The Taliban had retaken the momentum in much of Marja and stymied the troops strategy to win hearts and minds. Soon, high-ranking American officials began to acknowledge that Marja was not going nearly as well as hoped.

title: Pitti Uomo | Group Hug
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#297", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: A Winner for Best Party Production Design
description: LOS ANGELES  The Bagger didnt make it to every party after the Golden Globes last night, but of the four we did attend, the Weinstein Company/Relativity bash earned the highest marks for production design. Drawing on its nominated films, The Kings Speech and Blue Valentine, the party at the Beverly Hilton Hotel was decorated to look like a British/suburban drawing room, complete with carpeting, vintage-looking tufted couches, chests of drawers painted with the Union Jack and decorated with photos from the movies. (All the extra production work that the director Derek Cianfrance did on Blue Valentine, having his actors live together in an upstate New York house for a month, paid off in decorating savings.)

title: Coffee on Camera
description: The photojournalist Dima Gavrysh, who has chronicled Uganda, Chernobyl and Afghanistan, chose a more languid locale for his latest project  the coffee bars of New York. The Lens blog has a slide show of some of the most appealing places he photographed, including Abrao Espresso, Stumptown Coffee Roasters and Blue Bottle Coffee, pictured here.

title: Heavy Doses of DNA Data, With Few Side Effects
description: When companies tried selling consumers the results of personal DNA tests, worried doctors and assorted health experts rushed to the publics rescue. What if the risk assessments were inaccurate or inconsistent? What if people misinterpreted the results and did something foolish? What if they were traumatized by learning they were at high risk for Alzheimers or breast cancer or another disease?

title: 6 Coffeehouses, 2 Weeks, 50 Cups
description: Still feeling sluggish on this holiday Monday? These pictures might help you wake up.

title: A Weather Hobbyist Predicts More Snow  Much More
description: Updated, Jan. 21 | Stephen Fybish is worried that you might think he thought this up after the December snowstorm that caught the city by surprise, or the smaller ones last week and the week before.

title: Last of 7 Parts: Answers to Readers Questions on Financial Aid
description: As families of prospective college freshmen begin to tackle the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, or Fafsa, Mark Kantrowitz, a financial aid expert and founder of the Web sites finaid.org and fastweb.com, has been answering questions from readers of The Choice over the last week.

title: Lopez Scoring, but Fighting Rebounding Woes
description: After a rough start to the new year, the Nets Brook Lopez seems to be back on track. January hadnt been kind to Lopez; in each of the months first five games, he scored at a below-average rate by his seasons standards, and Lopez even scored in single digits twice during that stretch. The Nets two latest games have been a different story though, as Lopez dropped a pair of incredibly efficient, high-scoring performances against the Lakers and the Blazers. The momentary snag in Lopezs per-game scoring didnt provide any real cause for alarm, but its nice to see him reverse course with such prolific efforts.

title: Lebanon Delays Talks on New Government
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Lebanese president on Monday postponed talks to form a new government as regional leaders convened in Syria to find a way out of one of Lebanons worst crises in years.

title: Trial in a Vacuum: Study of Studies Shows Few Citations
description: Science, so the story goes, is a meticulously built edifice. Discoveries balance on ones that preceded them. Research is stimulated by studies that went on before.

title: Embedistan: Monsters Everywhere
description: Doing an embed puts you in such a weird situation as an Iraqi. It creates this contradiction inside you.

title: Close Look at Orthotics Raises a Welter of Doubts
description: Benno M. Nigg has become a leading researcher on orthotics  those shoe inserts that many athletes use to try to prevent injuries. And what he has found is not very reassuring.

title: Do Orthotics Really Help?
description: In the Personal Best column in Tuesdays Science Times, Gina Kolata asks Benno M. Nigg, a professor of biomechanics at the University of Calgary, whether orthotics, those inserts that athletes and others slip in their shoes, really help to prevent injuries and improve mechanical alignment.

title: When All Isnt Enough to Foil Alzheimers
description: My father knew it was coming.

title: Where to Buy Eyeglasses
description: An article in The New York Times on Monday, Defying Conventional Wisdom to Sell Glasses Online, describes how a start-up e-commerce site, Warby Parker, is trying to change the way people buy prescription glasses.

title: A New Wave of Protests in Tunisia
description: The popular response was immediate after the prime minister announced a new unity coalition cabinet with members of ousted President Zine el-Abidine Ben Alis ruling party in all the most significant posts.

title: Resisting Alzheimers
description: In Tuesdays Science Times, the writer Nancy Stearns Bercaw describes her fathers decades-long preoccupation with preventing Alzheimers disease, which had killed her grandfather. Alzheimers was the reason her father became a neurologist in the first place, she writes: he knew it was coming.

title: Feeling Blue  and White
description: If winter is already starting to look long and chilly to you, maybe a little home retail therapy will help. Normann Copenhagens Mormor ceramic dinnerware  by Gry Fager, a 2008 graduate of the Danish Design School  is covered with a cheery blue-and-white windowpane check that was inspired by a dish towel and by old-school kitchens in general. (Mormor is Danish for grandmother.) In addition to Mormor Blue, the pieces are available in two textured white finishes: Mormor Ribbed and Mormor Square, which are also textile-inspired, but with a knitted look. The milk jug ($26) and sugar bowl ($23) give your breakfast table an easy update, and the buttering boards ($26 and $36) make you want to linger over that second slice of toast.

title: Uganda: Male Circumcision May Help Protect Sexual Partners Against Cervical Cancer
description: Male circumcision, which has been shown to decrease a mans risk of contracting the virus that causes AIDS, also appears to help protect his sexual partners against cervical cancer.

title: For the Obamas, a Day of Service
description: President Obama took his family to a local middle school to participate in a painting project to help celebrate Martin Luther King Jr. Day, calling attention to service projects around the nation in honor of the slain civil rights leader.

title: Conspiracies Dont Kill Birds. People, However, Do.
description: At the beginning of this month when about 5,000 red-winged blackbirds fell from the sky in one night in Arkansas, biologists were called on to put a damper on public speculation about pesticides and secret military tests by reminding everyone how many birds there are and how many die. They often do so as a result of human activity, but in far more mundane and dispiriting ways than conspiracy buffs might imagine.

title: Makeshift Memorials Pop Up in Tucson
description: This article was reported by Marc Lacey, Jennifer Medina and Denise Grady and written by Mr. Lacey.

title: Conflict on Afghan Efforts to Tax Foreign Contractors
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  To parse Ben Franklin, the only thing certain about life in Afghanistan is death. Taxes are another matter.

title: G.E. to Share Jet Technology With China in New Joint Venture
description: This article was reported by David Barboza, Christopher Drew and Steve Lohr and written by Mr. Lohr.

title: Giri Smashes Carlsen, but Nakamura Leads Tata Steel Chess Tournament
Support Grows for Larger European Rescue Fund
description: BRUSSELS  Support was rising Monday for plans to increase the lending power of the rescue fund for the debt-laden euro zone countries, though it remained unclear whether a package of wider changes could be approved next month or would be delayed until March.

title: Building on Momentum, Spain Changes Course on Bonds
description: PARIS  Spain said Monday that it had decided to cancel an auction of long-term bonds and instead distribute debt through a group of banks as it sought to sustain momentum generated by a bond sale last week during a time of market anxiety.

title: Interfering With Flight?
description: The announcement over the planes speaker seems as much a part of the routine before takeoff as the demonstration of how to buckle a seat belt: Please turn off all electronic devices.

title: Quote Unquote | The (Extremely) Odd Couple
description: Chloe Sevigny comments on rumors that she is dating Jersey Shores Pauly D. If only

title: Bending and Stretching Classroom Lessons to Make Math Inspire
description: FARMINGDALE, N.Y.  At the aptly named Tiny Thai restaurant here, a small table, about two and a half feet square, was jammed with a teapot, two plates of curry, a bowl of soup, two cups of tea, two glasses of water, a plate with two egg rolls, a plate of salad and an iPhone.

title: Stoudemire in Technical Foul Trouble
description: The goggles were up, and his eyebrows along with them. Amare Stoudemire was questioning and complaining for what seemed like the 10th time. Another call had gone the wrong way, and his face was drenched with exasperation.

title: FitTV to Become Discovery Fit and Health
description: The Discovery Health Channel is coming back to cable, sort of.

title: Sleeping and Healing
description: Q. A doctor once told me that the body heals faster during sleep. If I slept a couple of extra hours each day, would my broken foot heal faster?

title: Before Trip, Make Plans for a Dearth of Medicine
description: Along with many thousands of other holiday travelers, I found myself stranded in a far-off airport as blizzards swept the Northeast two days after Christmas. But I was lucky, or so it seemed: I was in San Juan, P.R., looking at four extra beach days. This kind of hardship I could deal with.

title: Remembering Ellen Stewart, 11:35 a.m. Monday
Resveratrols Role (1 Letter)
description: To The Editor:
