title: The Leadership of Rex Ryan
description: What Rex Ryan said immediately after the game (above).

title: Helpful Strangers, the Upside of Travel Calamities
description: IM a lucky traveler. My luggage has been lost only three times, and Im the person who can leave a wallet in a cab and get it mailed back with all the cash still in it.

title: Al Qaeda and the U.S., Still Battling
description: By now there are already dozens of books  a few of them, groundbreaking works of reportage  about Al Qaeda and 9/11, the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, and the Bush and Obama administrations management of national security.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 17
description: The day in sports included Asian Cup soccer in Doha, Qatar, and sled dog racing in the French Alps.

title: Toasting a Vintage, With Few Quibbles
description: THE critics have weighed in from every conceivable angle, and the results seem to be unanimous. The 2008 vintage for Oregon pinot noir is superb.

title: Just One Look | Alexander Wang Pre-Fall
description: The Pre-Fall Collections, being shown in New York over the next several weeks, arrive in stores in May to fill the gap between bikinis and furs.If you are already feeling overwhelmed by the riot of color and pattern on the horizon for pre-fall, then Alexander Wang is your man. His largest pre-fall collection to date takes a lighter hand to his now signature staples, most notably a deconstructed suede biker jacket, a tough leather shirtdress with a sheer back, great slouchy trousers (we like this wide, slightly cropped version with the slit at the knee) and a variety of cool knits. And they all come in your favorite shade of black.

title: Sit. Stay. Parse. Good Girl!
description: Chaser, a border collie who lives in Spartanburg, S.C., has the largest vocabulary of any known dog. She knows 1,022 nouns, a record that displays unexpected depths of the canine mind and may help explain how children acquire language.

title: The Globes Party Report: Fire, Chocolate and Bad Romance
description: O.K., well admit it: the Bagger had fun at the Golden Globes afterparties. This is not a foregone conclusion; sometimes the evening amounts to chasing a good time at events that resemble a higher production-value convention. But this year, helped by our crew of intrepid party-hoppers, we managed to make the scene on multiple dance floors.

title: A Pink-Ribbon Race, Years Long
description: By the time Suzanne Hebert realized that her doctor was wrong and that the hard lump in her breast wasnt a normal part of breast-feeding, the tumor was the size of a stopwatch and the cancer had spread to her spine.

title: LeBron James and His Alter Egos Star in an Internet Animated Series
description: What does LeBron James dream about, other than sliding that first National Basketball Association championship ring onto his finger and perhaps riding in luxury automobiles with more generous leg room? How about donning a different kind of uniform and becoming a superhero?

title: New CDs
description: BRAIDS

title: Recalling a Fallen Stars Legacy in High-Energy Particle Physics
description: The machine known as the Tevatron is four miles around. Bison graze nearby on the 6,800 acres of former farmland occupied by the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory in Batavia, Ill. Occasionally, physicists run races around the top of it.

title: Gridiron Tops Globes
description: NBCs coverage of the 68th annual Golden Globe Awards drew about 17 million viewers, an audience virtually identical in size to last years show, according to Nielsens estimates. Even so, the awards show, which was hosted by Ricky Gervais, above, for the second consecutive year, left NBC in second place for the night, trailing CBS, which led over all largely because of an overrun of its afternoon football playoff coverage. That game, between the New York Jets and the New England Patriots, attracted more than 40 million viewers in the 7 p.m. hour, boosting CBSs 60 Minutes at 8 (17.3 million). At 9 and 10, CBS broadcast new episodes of Undercover Boss (13.3 million) and CSI: Miami (10.3 million). ABC ranked third, garnering its most viewers for Desperate Housewives at 9 (10.1 million), while Fox placed fourth with new episodes of its animated comedy lineup.

title: Exploring Complex Works, Before Youve Even Had Your Coffee
description: Informal concerts at unconventional times are increasingly popular with audiences. One such series, the Sunday Morning Coffee Concerts at Lincoln Center, presents 60-minute programs at the Walter Reade Theater at 11 a.m. The audience gathers afterward for coffee and muffins and a chance to meet the artist.

title: Cheney Considering Heart Transplant
description: Former Vice President Dick Cheney said he has not decided whether to seek a heart transplant for what he called his end-stage heart failure but said he will make that decision at some point.

title: One Composer, Many Productions
description: The new year already has a quickening beat for Michael John LaChiusa, the Tony-nominated composer and lyricist of challenging works of musical theater like Broadways Marie Christine and The Wild Party. Last week the Public Theater and others held a developmental workshop for his new musical, Giant, adapted from Edna Ferbers epic novel about love, oil, and ranching among Texas alpha males and the women who love them. The Public and the Dallas Theater Center had already announced that they were pursuing a co-production of Giant, which had its world premiere at the Signature Theater in Arlington, Va., in 2009. Oskar Eustis, artistic director of the Public, said in an interview that Dallas Theater Center was planning to mount its production of Giant next winter. How fast well go from Dallas to New York City depends on how much progress we make on the show between now and then, Mr. Eustis said. It seems safe to say that 2012 is likely for the New York run of Giant. Mr. LaChiusa wrote the music and lyrics, while the book is by Sybille Pearson (a Tony nominee for best book for the 1983 musical Baby). Michael Greif (Next to Normal, Rent) is the director. In addition to Giant, the Off Broadway theater company Transport Group is preparing to start performances in March for a revival of Mr. LaChiusas Hello Again, a musical featuring a series of interconnected love stories through the 20th century. And Transport Group also plans to stage the world premiere of another LaChiusa musical, Queen of the Mist, starting in October. That show centers on a real-life woman who survived a plunge over Niagara Falls. The two-time Tony nominee Mary Testa (On the Town, 42nd Street) is set to star. Both shows will be directed by Jack Cummings III.

title: Primary Stages Lineup Leads With a Seder Play
description: After donning a nuns habit for his play The Divine Sister, Charles Busch, the writer and actor, will turn to the familiar Jewish rite of the Passover seder for a new work called Olive and the Bitter Herbs, which will open the 2011-12 season of Primary Stages, that Off Broadway theater company said on Monday. In Mr. Buschs new play, the title character, Olive, finds herself reluctantly hosting a seder for the neighbors in her apartment building while contending with what she thinks is a ghost that she sees in her mirror. Press representatives for Primary Stages said Olive would begin preview performances at 59E59 Theaters on July 26, with an opening night of Aug. 9; its limited run is to end on Sept. 3. Other productions planned by Primary Stages for its new season include The Morini Strad, a play written by Willy Holtzman about the concert violinist Erica Morini and her Stradivarius. Directed by Casey Childs, that play will begin previews on March 20, 2012, with an opening night of April 3. Another play, called In Mother Words, conceived by Susan R. Rose and Joan Stein, and featuring family stories written by Leslie Ayvazian, David Cale, Jessica Goldberg, Beth Henley, Lameece Issaq, Lisa Loomer, Michele Lowe, Marco Pennette, Lisa Ramirez, Theresa Rebeck, Luanne Rice, Annie Weisman and Cheryl L. West, is scheduled for this fall. No casting for the productions was immediately announced.

title: Simply Shakespeare, No Tangled Web
description: Have Julie Taymor and the rest of the team for Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark taken a look at whats happening right next door to their beleaguered extravaganza? At the tiny New Victory Theater  which sits baby cheek by giants jowl to the Foxwoods Theater (lair to the opulent Spider)  a plucky little (and I mean little) troupe is addressing and breezily overcoming many of the same problems that appear to be plaguing Ms. Taymor and company.

title: Milan Fashion Week | First Impressions

title: Dramatizing Camelot
description: A promotional trailer for The Kennedys, a multimillion-dollar mini-series prepared for the History channel, suggests it will offer a sweeping inside look at the backrooms and bedrooms of that political clan. There are stylized re-enactments of the life of President John F. Kennedy and his family, and a title card that reads, Behind the public image lies the story of an American dynasty.

title: After Hints of Genius, a Muse Is Expelled
description: As Keith Jarrett began each piece of his solo concert on Sunday night at Carnegie Hall, hed sit at the piano, lean over it like someone genuflecting, and cock his ear to the keyboard as if listening to what it might suggest. In his solo concerts since the 1970s, Mr. Jarrett has committed himself to spontaneous improvisation, to ideas that surface in the moment. But on this night the muse was stingy, rarely offering him more than miniatures. And Mr. Jarrett grew increasingly cranky.

title: Safety First? All Signs Point to No
description: Presumably PBS calls its new monthly magazine edition of Frontline a fast turnaround version of that venerable public-affairs program because somewhat less slow turnaround didnt test well with target audiences. Certainly the two opening reports of Tuesdays three-segment premiere (the only parts provided for review) dont exactly scream breaking news.

title: It Sure Wasnt Pretty | A Golden Globes Recap
description: Last nights Golden Globe awards had the drama of an episode of This Old House. David Fincher and Aaron Sorkins The Social Network swept the ceremony winning best director, screenplay and picture, while favorites Colin Firth and Natalie Portman took the honors in acting. The only real surprise came on the red carpet. Outside of a few young things wearing neutral tones, it looked as if Los Angeles was in the grips of a stylist strike. Whats with the butterfly sleeves? And the French knots? And that gimmicky neckline on one to be forever nameless redhead that made her look like she was wearing half a Snuggie without sleeves. While we were thrilled to see emerald green make a resurgence on the red carpet, wouldnt it have been nice if the dresses looked a little less like upholstery? Overall, the women looked kind of matronly  ironic in a town known for its desperate attempts to look young. With the Academy Awards about a month away, lets hope that sartorial slapfest is a little more exciting.

title: A Grab Bag of Celebrity Reaction
description: LOS ANGELES As the storm over Rickygate continues  Philip Berk, the president of the Hollywood Foreign Press and a target of Mr. Gervaiss jokes at the Golden Globes, said that Mr. Gervais definitely crossed the line in a way that was, oh right, true to form for the comedian, and just happened to slightly bump the ratings  the Bagger would like to offer up a grab bag of quotes and moments from the press room to distract you from the brewing comedy non-troversy.

title: Just One Look | Giambattista Valli Pre-Fall Collection
description: The Pre-Fall Collections, being shown in New York over the next several weeks, arrive in stores in May to fill the gap between bikinis and furs.

title: Starbucks Workers Celebrate, and Protest
description: Each year since 2008, members of the Industrial Workers of the World Starbucks Workers Union had demonstrated on Martin Luther Kings Birthday, protesting that the companys baristas who worked on the holiday were not given holiday wages.

title: Mets Reach Agreement With Chris Young
description: In November, 2006, Chris Capuano and Chris Young, two well-educated young pitchers, were teammates on a major league All-Star team traveling in Japan. The two bonded on that trip, have remained friends since, and are now close to being reunited in Flushing on what could be baseballs smartest pitching staff.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,446 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It recently confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

title: A Door Into Top Kitchens for French North Africans
description: SARCELLES, France  In some ways, it is just a drop of costly olive oil in a turbid lake, but for 15 women from this poor Paris suburb, it is a chance for a stable and nourishing, if difficult, career.

title: Apple Needs a Stronger Transfer of Power
description: Apple needs to delegate Steve Jobss power more formally to someone else. Mr. Jobs, Apples chief executive, is handing day-to-day control to the companys chief operating officer, Tim Cook, because of health issues. Yet he retains his chief executive title. This is the third such move, and this time the handover is indefinite. However painful, a more formal transfer to an acting chief executive would have been better.

title: Leading in 3-D TV, Breaking Japans Glass Ceiling
description: TOKYO  It is the Achilles heel of 3-D television: the clunky glasses that viewers must wear to see images pop out in 3-D.

title: Bart Scotts Mother Reacts to His Rant
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  When Bart Scott went all WWE, with an anger-non-management tirade exchange with the ESPN reporter Sal Paolantonio on Sunday night, his teammates noticed. His coaches noticed. His mother noticed.

title: Fishing Museum Is Symbol of Waste in Georgia
description: PERRY, Ga.  Every weekend, Michael Morris and his 2-year-old son, Jacob, visit this small towns enormous new $14 million fishing museum. They watch bream and bass swim in aquarium-size tanks. They play with an interactive model of a fishing boat and try to catch fish on a computer simulation using a rod and reel connected to a video screen.

title: Maine: Governor Clears Schedule for Holiday
description: Gov. Paul LePage changed his Monday schedule to attend a Martin Luther Kings Birthday breakfast in Waterville, days after he directed a graphic insult at N.A.A.C.P. leaders who questioned why he had declined invitations to other such events. Mr. LePage, a Republican, was the mayor of Waterville before being sworn in as governor this month. The breakfast was sponsored by a local Rotary Club and a social services group, not the N.A.A.C.P. On Friday, Mr. LePage said N.A.A.C.P. leaders could kiss my butt after they expressed concern that he had turned down several invitations from them. He cited scheduling conflicts.

title: High Marks for Cuomo in New Poll
description: As Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo prepares to go to battle over the states budget, more New Yorkers view him favorably than at any time since he announced his bid for governor, according to the results of a new poll released Monday.

title: H.P. Updates TVs Old Product Demos
description: A mainstay of early television  live commercials demonstrating products like Polaroid cameras and Timex watches  is making a comeback, updated for a new century by migrating to new media.

title: Under Pay Model, Little Effect Seen on Papers Web Traffic
description: While newspapers around the world are anxiously asking themselves what would happen if they started charging readers to view articles online, a few answers have started to emerge.

title: Raising Children Alone With Her Husband in Jail
description: Twice a week, Olguita Rosado bundles up two of her three sons and boards two trains and a bus to Rikers Island to visit her husband, Jos, who is serving an eight-month sentence for burglary.

title: Meetings, Not Talks, for Players and Owners

title: For Patriots, Subdued Words and More Questions
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Bill Belichick was his usual surly self in his year-end assessment of his team, clipped and terse as ever. In the New England locker room, the only sounds came from rustling garbage bags. Even for the say-less, do-more Patriots, it was a quiet afternoon here.

title: Sudan: Secession Likely, Monitors Say
description: Election observers in southern Sudan said on Monday that the regions referendum on independence last week was transparent and credible and that southern independence was likely. The referendum process to date is broadly consistent with international standards for democratic elections, said the Carter Center of Atlanta, based on election monitoring. On Sunday, early polling results released in the capital, Juba, showed voters choosing independence from the north by an average margin of over 95 percent, with a 95 percent voter turnout. Southern independence would take effect July 9.

title: Exceptionalism, Faith and Freedom: Palins America
description: In her Facebook reflections on the events in Arizona, Sarah Palin observes that our government was not designed for perfect men and women. It is because we are not angels, she says , that we require a system of government that acknowledges the inevitable conflicts produced by our imperfect passions and yet provides mechanisms  free speech, vigorous debate  that allow us to settle those conflicts without resorting to dueling pistols. That, she declares, is the system the Founders designed, and it is part of why America is exceptional, an assertion she makes twice.

title: Jets Mark Sanchez Starts to Lead by Not Losing
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  For most of the last two seasons, the Jets trotted Mark Sanchez onto the field with a simple if somewhat odd directive for a franchise quarterback and the highest-paid player in team history: do not screw this up.

description: PATROL BASE BARIOLAI, Afghanistan  If the battlegrounds of Afghanistan are the tip of the spear, as Marines like to say, then the remote district of Sangin in Helmand Province may be its very point: the deadliest spot in the hardest-fought province for Marines leading the American offensive in Taliban territory.

description: This year, the United States will release nearly three-quarters of a million people from prison, a record high. Nationally, 2.3 million people are in prison in the United States, and 95 percent of them will, at some point, get out and go home.

description: WASHINGTON  Pakistans refusal to attack militants in a notorious sanctuary on its northwest border may have created a magnet there for hundreds of Islamic fighters seeking a safe haven where they can train and organize attacks against NATO forces in Afghanistan. title: Lincolns Mexican Visitor
description: Matias Romero arrived in Springfield, Ill. on the evening of Jan. 18, 1861. Though late in the day, he figured it would be easy to find a room in this sleepy midwestern town. But there were no rooms available at his first choice, the American Hotel, or anywhere else: all the hotels in town were full of friends, patronage seekers and the merely curious who had come to meet President-elect Lincoln. Travelers packed into guesthouses three to a room with strangers sharing beds, while others settled for sleeper cars parked in the rail yard.

title: The Wheels Are Turning for the Jets

title: Amy Chua Is a Wimp

title: How Many Deaths Are Enough?
description: On April 22, 2008, almost exactly one year after 32 students and faculty members were slain in the massacre at Virginia Tech, the dealer who had sold one of the weapons used by the gunman delivered a public lecture on the schools campus. His point: that people at Virginia Tech should be allowed to carry concealed weapons on campus.

title: President Hu Comes to Washington
description: There has been a lot of hype, for a long time, about a rising China. There is now no question about Chinas growing economic power or its military ambition. Over the past year, relations between Washington and Beijing have become increasingly tense and mistrustful.

title: Indianas Answer to Prison Costs
description: For states that are serious about trimming deficits, out-of-control prison costs are a good place to start cutting. The expenses of housing and caring for more than one million state prison inmates has quadrupled in the last decade from about $12 billion a year to more $52 billion a year. This, in turn, has squeezed budgets for essential programs like education.

title: Taxation Without Representation, Indeed
description: The long suffering, and underrepresented, taxpayers of the District of Columbia are properly worried about their shrinking role in the new Republican-controlled House. Tucked into the changes enacted by Speaker John Boehner is a rule depriving the district of its one bit of token voting power in Congress.

title: The Insanity Defense, Post-Hinckley
description: As the country struggles to find meaning in the horrific Tucson shooting, another heated national debate over gun violence comes to mind: the furious reaction to the acquittal, by reason of insanity, of John Hinckley Jr., the man who tried to kill President Ronald Reagan.

title: How Much Do College Students Learn, and Study?
description: While The Choice tends to focus on the process of applying to college, we also consider it within our mission to ask how much learning and studying students generally do once they enroll.

title: T. A. Watson Dead; Made First Phone
description: ST. PETERSBURG, FLA., Dec. 14 -- Thomas A. Watson, manufacturer of the first telephone instrument and first to hear a human voice over the device, that of its inventor, Alexander Graham Bell, died suddenly of heart disease here last night at his Winter home on Pass-Grille Key. He was 80 years old.

title: In Hong Kong, Flowers for Chinese New Year
description: For the Chinese, flowers and plants in the home add not only beauty, but also good fortune. Just before the start of Chinese New Year, which this year falls on Feb. 3, its imperative to gather some fresh, lucky arrangements to display through the festive season. And so the Hong Kong government organizes many bustling flower markets in the week leading up to the first day of the new year.

title: Medicare and Health Reform
description: Many attacks on health reform involve assertions that the laws proposed Medicare savings cant possibly materialize, that the Democrats just made stuff up. So its worth looking at where those savings are supposed to come from. The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities has a nice summary of the laws financing; heres the Medicare table:

title: Boeing Again Delays Delivery of Dreamliner
description: The Boeing Company on Tuesday pushed back the first delivery of its 787 Dreamliner to the third quarter, hoping that the delay will give it enough time to finish a jetliner that is more than three years behind schedule.

title: He Is Spartacus: Liam McIntyre Talks About Taking Over in Season 2 of Blood and Sand
description: On Monday Liam McIntyre received some of the most exciting news of his career, and some of the most difficult: he learned that he had just been cast in the title role in a cable series  but as the replacement for Andy Whitfield in Spartacus: Blood and Sand.

title: Now Showing | Juergen Teller in Berlin
description: Juergen Teller has not one but two exhibitions in the German capital these days. Paradis, at Johann Knig Galerie in Berlin Kreuzberg, shows large-format prints of a naked Charlotte Rampling with an equally naked Raquel Zimmermann, rambling about the Louvre and posing alongside the Mona Lisa and a marble Napoleon. Originally published in the French magazine Paradis in 2009 and shown at Lehmann Maupin in New York the same year, the images have lost none of their beauty or inherent shock factor. Tellers other, much smaller, show in Berlin is equally revealing. Located in an ingeniously designed third-floor space run by the Berlin-based 032c Magazine, the exhibition comprises new work that Teller has simply called Men and Women. An image of a naked Vivienne Westwood, broadly grinning and with her legs splayed, presides over the show like a regal cross between Annie Sprinkle and Marie Antoinette, while next to her the photographer William Eggleston, photographed at home in Memphis, and Tellers own 9-year-old son, Ed, photographed in the gym of a hotel in the Maldives, seem goofily adrift. Its really a show about impotence, remarked a guest at the opening on Saturday night. In the middle you have Vivienne, all powerful and sexual, and to the left and to the right you have an old man who cant really do it anymore, and a young man who cant do it yet. No word from Teller himself whether he subscribes to the same interpretation  when pressed for a quote during dinner after the opening, Teller simply pointed to a David Hamilton photograph on the wall and said, I like those breasts.

title: A Phrase We Love Too Much
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: A Phrase We Love Too Much

title: Off the Menu: Niko
description: Given its location  in the former Honmura An  and the chef at its eight-seat sushi bar  Hiro Sawatari formerly of the highly esteemed Sushi Yasuda  Niko has generated a lot of interest.

title: Moelis Opens Dubai Office
description: Moelis & Company said on Tuesday that it had opened an office in Dubai, its seventh office worldwide.

title: The Recent History of the Dollar
description: Some commenters seem to believe that there has been a massive depreciation of the dollar since Ben Bernanke began QE2, or more broadly since he began rapidly increasing the monetary base. But nooooo! [/end Belushi] The dollar briefly surged during the oh-God-were-all-gonna-die period of the financial crisis, then fell more or less back to where it was at the start of the recession. And all of these movements were small compared with the long dollar slide during the Bush years  a slide, by the way, which was never part of my critique of that era.

title: J. Crew Settles Lawsuit Over $3 Billion Deal
description: 12:21 p.m. | Updated J. Crew announced its settlement with the plaintiff shareholders and set a meeting to vote on the TPG leveraged buyout for March 1.

title: Afghan Official Expects Court to Void Election
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistans attorney general expressed hope on Tuesday that a special court appointed by the president to look into election fraud would throw out the results of the countrys parliamentary elections, and predicted that the court would delay this weeks planned inauguration of a new Parliament.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

title: More Officials Quit in Tunisia Amid Protests
description: TUNIS  The new unity government of Tunisia tottered Tuesday as at least four cabinet members resigned after street protests erupted over its continued domination by members of the ruling party of the ousted dictator, Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali.

title: British Academy Swoons for The Kings Speech
description: LOS ANGELES The British Academy of Film and Television Arts, the Old Country version of the Academy, announced its nominees for the Orange British Academy Film Awards on Tuesday morning, and The Fighter swept. Nope, not at all. The highest honors went, of course, to The Kings Speech, the most British of films. In a rare accolades-season setback for The Social Network, it earned only six nominations; The Kings Speech got 14, including best picture, best actor, best director, best supporting actress and actor, best cinematography, best screenplay, best score and best British film. Black Swan also did well, earning 12 nods, and Inception received 9. The Bafta winners have coincided with the Oscar best-picture winner four times over the last decade. For the full list of hopefuls, look here. The winners will be announced on Feb. 13 in London.

title: On Our Radar: Cyclists Flock to Londons Bike-Lane Superhighways
description: The London transit authority reports that rush-hour cycling traffic has doubled on two downtown thoroughfares since the creation of bike-lane superhighways on the streets last year. Over all, bike traffic on the streets is up 70 percent. The two-way lanes, which radiate out from the city center, are painted bright blue and feature safety mirrors, signals at intersections and bicycle parking spaces. [Road.cc]

title: Summer Fun Day | Its a Scorcher Out There
description: Out there in the City Room alternate universe, that is. As an antidote to the faceful of raw sleet you got when you stuck your head out the front door this morning, we will be recreating an actual city summer all day long, with the hottest hits from our archives.

description: Aha. A not-too-technical paper I wrote about the dollars international role back in 1984  one that still holds up pretty well, as far as I can tell  is available online (pdf).

description: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously shared James Bond film titles, villains, henchmen, Bond girls and groan-worthy puns.

description: President Obama, intensifying his courtship of the business community, announced Tuesday that he is issuing an executive order that aims to free companies of unnecessary regulatory burdens and promote economic growth.

title: Regis Philbin to Leave Live with Regis and Kelly
description: Regis Philbin, a star of morning television for a generation, made a surprise announcement at the start of Live with Regis and Kelly Tuesday morning, telling viewers that he intended to step down sometime later this year.

title: Asian Cup: Big Game, Small Stadium
description: DOHA, Qatar  Host Qatar, runner-up in Group A, will play Japan, winner of Group B, in 20,000-seat Al Garafa Stadium instead of 40,000-seat Khalifa Stadium, used for the opening ceremony, when the two teams meet in an Asian Cup quarterfinal match on Friday.

title: Tuesday Reading: New York Short-Term Rentals
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Schumer Criticizes Christies Plan to Divert Tunnel Funds
description: Updated, 12:44 p.m. | New Yorks senior senator, Charles E. Schumer, sharply criticized New Jerseys governor, Chris Christie, for his decision to halt the construction of a commuter rail tunnel under the Hudson River and to try to divert some of the money for that project to fix roads and bridges in New Jersey.

title: What Were Reading
description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.

title: Kent Conrad Will Retire From Senate
description: Senator Kent Conrad of North Dakota on Tuesday became the first Democrat to announce he would not run for re-election in 2012, handing Republicans an early pickup opportunity in a state where they grabbed the other Senate seat and lone Congressional seat last November.

title: Gordon Murray, Former Investment Banker, Dies at 60
description: Gordon Murray, the investment banker whose conversion to passive investing was the subject of my Your Money column last Nov. 26, died on Saturday at his home in Burlingame, Calif. He was 60 years old and had suffered from glioblastoma, an aggressive form of brain cancer.

title: Tunisian Blogger Joins Government
description: Updated | 3:26 p.m. Less than two weeks ago, Slim Amamou, a Tunisian blogger and activist, was using his @slim404 Twitter feed to let friends know that the police had been to his house. Later the same day, after he was arrested, the 33-year-old computer programmer managed to turn his phone on and log on to Google Latitude to broadcast his location: inside the countrys feared ministry of the interior.

title: Joke-Seeking Apatow Takes to Twitter
description: LOS ANGELES The comedy impresario Judd Apatow (Knocked Up, 40-Year-Old Virgin), who is hosting the Producers Guild Awards on Saturday, has spent a lot of his time since the Golden Globes Sunday night soliciting material on Twitter that would be better than Ricky Gervaiss. If anyone has any jokes that they think are better than Ricky Gervaiss, post here, and I will read the winners and say your name at P.G.A. awards, he wrote. He then apparently stayed up until 3 a.m. on Tuesday collecting replies, including gems like The P.G.A. Awards are so cheap even the host had to crowd-source material and Inception is really about Hollywood. everyones constantly trying to ruin your dreams so they can make a buck. Finally: @CreepyCreeper: @JuddApatow is the Ricky Gervais of comedy. We have a winner. Good night.

title: Summer Fun Day | Its (Finally) Too Darn Hot
description: This article first appeared on Aug. 17, 2009.

title: Modano Eyes Quicker Return Than Expected
description: Veteran Detroit Red Wings center Mike Modano fully understands how lucky he is right now.

title: Chinas Leader Has Message of Harmony, but Limited Agenda
description: BEIJING  For the Obama administration, the four-day visit by President Hu Jintao of China may offer a platform to try to make progress on issues troubling their countries: currency, the trade imbalance, human rights and Chinas military stance. But Mr. Hu arrives with a comparatively low-key message, intoning his favorite idea: harmony.

title: Retiring Favre Backs the Packers
description: You might have noticed that the N.F.L. playoffs so far have been dusted with a little green and gold glitter. Its the pixie dust that has seemed to follow the Green Bay Packers. Yes, cheese headwear is definitely fashionable again. The team is riding high after two impressive playoff victories and heads into the National Football Conference championship game in Chicago knowing the Bears really wanted to knock them out of the playoffs in the final regular-season game and couldnt. Aaron Rodgers might be the best quarterback in the playoffs (O.K., so he really only has to beat out Ben Roethlisberger for that distinction) and for the first time in the history of Brett Favre retirements, they really dont have to care. Nirvana!

title: Don Kirshner, Rock Producer and Promoter, Dies at 76
description: Don Kirshner, who guided the course of Brill Building and bubblegum pop in the 1950s and 60s as a music publisher and promoter, and later served as an Ed Sullivan for 1970s artists like Bruce Springsteen, Pink Floyd, Kiss and the Ramones with his weekly program Don Kirshners Rock Concert on television, died on Monday in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 76. The cause was heart failure.

title: Senator Lugar Will Seek Re-election
description: Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana reaffirmed his commitment Tuesday to seek re-election to a seventh term, saying that he will not be deterred by a frustrated electorate that is intent on trying to defeat well-established Republican incumbents in their primary elections.

title: Scorecard | Bottega Veneta Wins!
description: Lime green trousers and tangerine jackets as a statement on modern man  isScorecard in Milan or Paris? On the second day of the fall 2011 season, critics were more feeling Tomas Maiers conceptual use of prismatic color than the usual Italiante swagger. Meanwhile, the jurys still out on just how perverse were Miuccia Pradas boys who sparkle in the sun.

title: Delta Warns That Higher Fuel Costs Could Erase Gains
description: Delta Air Lines, the nations largest carrier, said Tuesday that it had a profit in the fourth quarter but warned that rising fuel prices could erase its narrow gains this year.

description: A play-by play of one commuters journey to Midtown from Brooklyn on the F line, which began its newly altered weekday route to accommodate construction on the Culver Viaduct. By her estimates, she will have to budget an extra 10 to 12 minutes (weather-depending) to get to work on time.

description: NEWARK  Joseph N. DiVincenzo Jr., the Essex County executive, flips open his ringing cellphone and says Hey, Gov, raising a finger to pause an interview as he steps from the room. We talk a lot, he says later, grinning broadly, when asked about Chris Christie. A lot.

description: The title and subtitle of Paul Clemenss new book, Punching Out: One Year in a Closing Auto Plant, are so misleading that they nearly constitute literary fraud. If Id paid $25.95 for it  book critics get free advance copies  Id consider calling, or inventing, the Better Nonfiction Bureau.

title: Strengthening Older Muscles
description: My grandmother, who lived to be almost 102, was what our family referred to as a healthy eater. She enjoyed a good meal, most of all in a restaurant, where she read the menu with gusto before settling on her standard constellation of broiled fish and a couple of vegetables.

title: On Responding to Imprecise Climate Risks
description: [Jan. 19, 9:25 a.m. | Updated Due to my misinterpretation of an e-mail from the Climate Q&A Service, I incorrectly wrote that the input below on the readers questions was from the group of four scientists. In fact it was almost entirely from one of those researchers, Vincent P. Gutschick. Jim Bouldin sent a note this morning providing his independent reaction to the readers questions. Its appended at the bottom of the post.]

description: In todays Washington Post, Howard Schneider has an excellent profile of one American company trying to grow its business in China:

title: Fill-In | N.F.L. Playoffs
Sherlock Holmes to Resume Winding His Way Down Baker Street
description: Ready for a whole new set of adventures featuring Londons most famous consulting detective? No, not Guy Ritchies Sherlock Holmes movies, in which Robert Downey Jr. plays a slightly dandified take on the famous investigator. And no, not Mark Gatiss and Steven Moffats BBC series Sherlock, in which Benedict Cumberbatch plays the brilliant if socially maladroit master of deduction as he might have existed in the modern era. You know, the Sherlock Holmes you imagine in your own mind after reading words on the pages of a  whadayacallit?  book?

title: As Car Industry Evolves, a 90-Year-Old Cowboy Abides
description: Cal Worthington, the California auto dealer whose My Dog Spot television ads made him a cultural icon and something of a celebrity, turned 90 recently. He continues to appear on television, wearing his trademark Stetson and loud Western wear, hawking used cars and extolling their low, low prices.

title: Pure of Winter Vegetable Soup
description: Living in France, I was always impressed by the bags of mixed vegetables, called soupe, sold in farmers markets and supermarkets alike. The bags usually included an onion, carrots and celery, a leek, a turnip or two and a bouquet garni consisting of a bay leaf, a sprig of thyme and another of parsley. Ive added root vegetables to this ginger-scented soup, which is inspired by the many simple suppers I enjoyed in the homes of French friends.

title: Smithsonian Chief Defends Withdrawal of Video
description: The top official of the Smithsonian, G. Wayne Clough, who has been sharply criticized for his decision late last year to remove a video from an exhibition at the National Portrait Gallery, defended that decision in a telephone interview on Tuesday morning. He said it was in the interest of protecting the exhibition as a whole, as well as protecting the Smithsonians larger educational mission and its ability to make a strong case to Congress for federal support.

title: Video Games and the Depressed Teenager
description: Theres been a lot of buzz about whether video games are habit-forming, and whether parents are exaggerating when they say their teenagers are addicted to game playing. Now new research on children who are heavy gamers suggests parents may have something else to worry about: depression.

title: Del Potro Returns, With Much to Do
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Since July 2005, only two men not named Roger Federer or Rafael Nadal have won a Grand Slam singles title.

title: Tracing the N.F.L.s Oldest Rivalry
description: Highway 50 is sometimes considered the 50-yard line in the rivalry between the Bears and the Packers. Squatting at that spiritual midfield  if not exactly the geographical one  is the Brat Stop, a sprawling restaurant/bar/concert hall/cheese shop just off Interstate 94 at the edge of Kenosha, Wis.

title: Celery Root, Potato and Apple Pure
description: Classic celery root and potato pures combine two parts potatoes with one part celery root. Ive reversed the proportion here for a lighter pure that also incorporates apple  the secret ingredient." Rather than milk, I usually use the broth from the celery root and apples.

title: Former Haitian Dictator to Face Charges
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Haitian prosecutors presented formal charges of corruption and embezzlement against the former dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier on Tuesday, raising the level of uncertainty surrounding his abrupt emergence from exile this week.

title: Fairholme Sells General Growth Stake to Brookfield
description: The Fairholme Fund, an investment fund run by Bruce Berkowitz, said on Tuesday that it had sold its entire stake in General Growth Properties to Brookfield Asset Management, valuing the holdings at $1.7 billion.

title: Stuff Happens
description: Joe Romm has some fun with the Texas Attorney General, who declares himself opposed to regulation of CO2 on the grounds that

title: Arab Leaders Keep a Wary Eye on Tunisia
description: CAIRO  From the crowded, run-down streets of Cairo to the oil-financed halls of power in Kuwait, Arab leaders appear increasingly rattled by the unfolding events in Tunisia and elsewhere in the Arab world, where men continued to set themselves on fire  two more in Egypt on Tuesday, and a third who was stopped.

title: Q&A: Romantic Inn About 4 Hours From New York
description: My husband has a major birthday coming up in March. To celebrate, I would like to take him for a long weekend within about four hours drive from New York City. I am looking for a romantic inn with a comfortable lounge and fireplace and good food at a rate of less than $300 a night. We prefer small places rather than large resorts. We dont ski but would like to be close to some good hiking (providing there is not too much snow) or some interesting place to visit. Do you have any suggestions?

title: When a Child Does Not Sleep
description: Two-year-old Ava Vander Schaaff has not been sleeping well for months. Actually, she has not slept all night for most of her life, but over the last few months the problem has gotten desperate.

title: Jobss Departure Overshadows Apple Earnings Report
description: Apples shares showed some resilience on Tuesday after the chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, announced he was taking a medical leave of absence just ahead of the release of the companys quarterly earnings.

title: Wiretaps of Berlusconis Teenage Friend Emerge
description: ROME  A tabloid tidal wave washed over Italy on Tuesday as newspapers published eye-popping wiretapped conversations from a nightclub dancer who said she had dallied with Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi as a minor, but whether it would sweep the wily prime minister out to sea was still anyones guess.

title: Yum Puts Long John Silvers and A&W on the Block
description: Yum Brands, which has been prospering abroad, announced on Monday that it planned to sell a pair of domestic-focused businesses, Long John Silvers and A&W All-American Food.

title: The Coming of Age of Oregon Pinot Noirs
description: The wine panels tasting of 2008 pinot noirs from the Willamette Valley in Oregon was exciting. The wines were delicious, and we were all pleased to find so many of them in a lovely, restrained style that invited rather than overpowered. These, I would like to think, are the sorts of wines that inspired those far-sighted pioneers back in the late 1960s and 1970s who imagined that Willamette would be a great place to grow pinot noir.

title: Now Nibbling | Music to Your Mouth
description: At the beginning of December, I checked out the John Dorys new digs. It was 10 p.m. and I was meeting a good friend, who happens to be a chef, for a celebratory dinner  a three-year-long project had finally come to fruition. We were hungry, and we werent going to settle for anything less than excellence. We pulled up to the actual oyster bar in the back of the boisterous seafood saloon, ordered some champers and perused the menu. Under the Snacks heading, I read Carte da Musica. What was that? I asked my pal the chef. She didnt know. So we interrogated one of the able shuckers manning the bivalve station in front of us. The term, he said, refers to an Italian cracker that is named for its resemblance to sheet music (i.e., carte da musica)  its that thin and delicate. At the John Dory, he followed up, these crackers provide the foundation for a sandwich of butter and bottarga.

title: Gen. Robert E. Lee
description: Intelligence was received last evening of the death at Lexington, Va., Of Gen. Robert E. Lee, the most famous of the officers whose celebrity was gained in the service of the Southern Confederacy during the late terrible rebellion. A report was received some days ago that he had been smitten with paralysis, but this was denied, and though it was admitted that he was seriously ill, hopes of his speedy recovery seem to have been entertained by his friends. Within the last two or three days his symptoms had taken an unfavorable turn, and he expired at 91/2 o'clock yesterday morning of congestion of the brain, at the age of sixty-three years, eight months and twenty-three days.

title: Strong Ratings for Piers Morgans Debut
description: CNNs Piers Morgan Tonight premiered to 2.1 million viewers on Monday, according to preliminary ratings from the Nielsen Company.

title: Federico Fellini, Film Visionary, Is Dead at 73
description: Federico Fellini, whose deeply personal films were vivid, sometimes bizarre portraits of the human condition, died yesterday at the Umberto I Hospital in Rome. He was 73.

title:
Reagan Takes Oath As 40th President;
Promises An 'Era Of National Renewal'
description: Washington, Jan. 20 -- Ronald Wilson Reagan of California, promising "an era of national renewal," became the 40th President of the United States today as 52 Americans held hostage in Iran were heading toward freedom.

title: Despite So-So Year, Hedge Funds Gain Favor
description: Hardly chastened by a year of modest gains by hedge funds, the majority of institutional investors are planning to increase the money they allocate to them, according to a new study.

title: California Tobacco-Free Campaign
description: California's public health department introduces a new antismoking ad campaign.

title: The Roots of Overheated Rhetoric
description: Along with a host of pointless arguments about Sarah Palin, the aftermath of the Arizona shootings has inspired an interesting intra-liberal debate about how polarized America really is. Noam Scheiber, of instance, watched the presidents speech lastweek and came away thinking that Obama underplayed the reality of Americans ideological divisions. After all, he writes, the reason the country is so polarized is that we disagree pretty strongly about what would strengthen our democracy (say, a richer social safety net versus greater reliance on the free market and individual responsibility).

title: Need to Belong Sends a New Jersey College West
description: NEWARK  The New Jersey Institute of Technology is most assuredly in the Western Hemisphere and is more specifically a few miles west of Manhattan. But sending its intercollegiate athletic teams to compete in the Great West Conference required a leap of geographic logic that sounds wholly antithetical to a respected research institution.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: California Revamps Its Campaign Against Smoking
description: It is easy to create advertising that sells a product. It is more difficult to create advertising that un-sells a behavior.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
description: Amp Agency, part of Alloy Media and Marketing, completed the sale of its offices in Los Angeles and New Jersey, which specialize in experiential marketing, to the Bright Media Group, which will operate under the name of Bright Promotions. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: For Wall Street, Antibribery Inquiry Is Cause for Concern
description: The Securities and Exchange Commissions inquiry into Wall Streets dealings with sovereign wealth funds for possible violations of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act is another expansion in the use of the antibribery law. Over the past few years, the act has been used more frequently against multinational companies, and there is no reason why financial firms should avoid scrutiny.

title: What Teachers Reveal When They Blog
description: When she started a blog, she saw it as a venue to chronicle her daily dealings as a teacher, a kind of diary with no lock and key. She settled on a pseudonym, Miss Brave, because when I tell people I teach in a New York City public elementary schools, many of them say, Whoa, youre brave,  she explains on her site.

title: Theater Hall of Fame Names New Members
description: The Theater Hall of Fame, which this year is celebrating its 40th anniversary honoring lifetime achievement in American theater, has announced its new inductees. They are the directors Michael Blakemore, musical director Paul Gemignani, the playwright Caryl Churchill, the actors Linda Lavin, Brian Dennehy and Fritz Weaver, the director and librettist James Lapine and, posthumously, the director and writer Joseph Chaikin.

title: Blackstone Joins the Twitter Age
description: Blackstones Stephen A. Schwarzman, in his pre-Twitter days.

title: Mapping Discord: Creating a Primer on the Arab World
description: Overview | Why is there much turmoil in the Arab world right now? What are the key issues facing the nations in that part of the globe? In this lesson, students create an annotated map of the Middle East and North Africa that includes information about five countries in the Arab world and then synthesize what they discover.

title: Comcast-NBC Deal Wins Federal Approval
description: 6:00 p.m. | Updated  The proposed combination of Comcast and NBC Universal was approved by the Federal Communications Commission and the Justice Department on Tuesday, smoothing the way for the deal to close by the end of January.

title: Piracy Reached Record Level in 2010, Monitors Say
description: Despite an international effort to ensure safe passage through the worlds most treacherous waters, pirates escalated their attacks in 2010 for the fourth straight year, striking more ships and taking more hostages last year than in any year on record, according to an annual report on piracy.

title: Ford Foundation to Put Up $50 Million for Documentaries
description: Documentarians, rejoice! The Ford Foundation on Tuesday announced a five-year plan to pour $50 million into documentaries - defined broadly, including online-only efforts - that are focused on social issues.

title: N.B.A.s Best Lineups Are Falling Apart
description: Weve reached the midway point of the N.B.A. season, a time at which evaluations of teams across the league become concrete. The fortunes of any team can still change, but the half-season of precedent weve just witnessed will be the grounds on which claims for contention are made. This is the time during which we realize how far some teams and players have come and how quickly success can be taken away.

title: Pictures of the Day: Haiti and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Haiti, Tunisia and Italy.

title: Just One Look | Chanel Mtier dArts Collection
description: The Pre-Fall Collections, being shown in New York over the next several weeks, arrive in stores in May to fill the gap between bikinis and furs.For some years now, Karl Lagerfeld has taken pre-fall as an opportunity to keep all of the petits mains of Paris busy. His Mtier dArts Collection showcases the talents of embroiderers and makers of feathers and lace and buttons and bows and trims  occasionally all in a single look. This season took, as its leaping-off point, Mademoiselle Chanels Gripox jewelry, making its way to fifth-century Byzantium by way of swinging London.

title: BankUnited Increases Plans for I.P.O.
description: 5:14 p.m. | Updated BankUnited on Tuesday ramped up its plans for an initial public offering, saying it could raise $630 million  more than double what the bank expected when it first filed for an I.P.O. last year.

title: A Look at White House Views on Scientific Integrity
description: Joseph A. Davis, a freelance writer who among many things edits the Society of Environmental Journalists daily roundup of environmental stories, has completed a detailed four-part examination of White House Scientific Integrity Guidelines issued by President Obamas science adviser, John Holdren, in December.

title: Summer Fun Day | From One Extreme to the Other
description: While youre dodging foot-deep slush puddles and running from the gray icy spray of buses and cars, we bring you reader-submitted images from July, when normally sane New Yorkers and their pets were lulled into submission by the heat.

title: Tips for Drafting Your All-Star Team
description: The N.H.L. All-Stars have been announced, and the team captains will be named this week. That means were closing in on the first ever All-Star Fantasy Draft, in which the 42 players will be divided up with a school-yard style draft.

title: Bloggingheads: More Guns, Less Crime?
description: Glenn Loury, left, of Brown University and Ann Althouse of the University of Wisconsin Law School debate the link between gun ownership and violent crime.

title: Is This the Last Surviving Public Image of Saddam Hussein in Iraq?
description: BABYLON, Iraq  Hidden away on the reverse side of a roadside plinth leading to the historic ruins of Babylon, this huge bullet-scarred image of Saddam Hussein was still intact on a visit to the ancient site in early December.

title: A Dress Code For Russians? Priest Chides Skimpiness
description: MOSCOW  A top official for the Russian Orthodox Church on Tuesday proposed creating an all-Russian dress code, lashing out at women who leave the house painted like a clown and confuse the street with striptease.

title: Her Name Is Jimmy: Melissa Etheridge Will Join American Idiot Cast For One Week
description: In the Broadway musical American Idiot, the character of St. Jimmy is a wild force of nature who thrashes around the stage like an adrenaline-charged rock star  which is partly why the role has suited Billie Joe Armstrong, the front man of the punk rock band Green Day, who is playing the part off and on this winter (and whose bands music provides the shows score). Now the producers are going to give another rocker a try at St. Jimmy: Melissa Etheridge will take over the role for one week, Feb. 1 to 6, in between Mr. Armstrongs appearances Tuesday to Jan. 30 and Feb. 10 to 27.

title: European Inflation Targets
description: Jean-Claude Trichet is sounding hawkish about inflation again  and this is very bad news for the European periphery. Let me offer a stylized example to explain why.

title: Sponsorship of This Series Is No Drag
description: As the television audience continues to fragment, more cable channels are being created. Or is it that as more cable channels are introduced, the viewing audience continues to fragment? Either way, it is a trend that Madison Avenue is taking part in more frequently.

title: Milan Fashion Week | Jimmy Choo for Men
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#164", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: First Trade Center Officers Will Be in Place Soon
description: The first wave of officers from a new World Trade Center command will be in place by the opening of the sites memorial on Sept. 11, 2011, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said on Tuesday.

title: Genentech Appeals Avastin Decision
description: Genentech on Tuesday formally asked the Food and Drug Administration to overturn last months decision revoking the approval of the drug Avastin as a treatment for breast cancer.

title: The King at Abbey Road
description: LOS ANGELES Among the many Britishisms honored with a Bafta nod today was the score for The Kings Speech. Of course, the composer, Alexandre Desplat, is French, but lets not dwell on that. Mr. Desplat - a veteran of creating music for award-season movies, including The Curious Case of Benjamin Button, The Ghost Writer, Fantastic Mr. Fox, Julie & Julia, and many others - recorded the score for the Colin Firth vehicle at Abbey Road studios in London, he told the Bagger the other day.

title: Jasmine Revolt
description: Term for anti-government protests in Tunisia; Jasmine is the countrys national flower.

title: The Witch Is Alive! Wicked Regains Top Spot As Broadway Box Office Sputters
description: The winter doldrums have arrived at most of Broadways box offices, as they usually do this time of year. Many musicals and plays had swaths of empty seats last week, and 19 of the theater districts 40 houses were dark because of shows closing or being on hiatus. Broadway productions grossed a total of $14.9 million last week, compared with $20.8 million the week before and $17.6 million for the comparable week in January 2010. The slowdown in ticket sales traditionally sets in mid-January, with the end of holiday vacations and the resumption of school, and often lasts until the advent of spring vacations and new productions.

title: Protecting Mail From Identity Thieves
description: As employers and banks mail out your year-end and tax documents this month, you shouldnt just be thinking about preparing your taxes. You should also be thinking about how to protect your mail from identity thieves.

title: Girl on Bear Rug, (Lily Kwong, c. 2011)
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#371", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Remnant of an Industrial Past, Now Gone
description: 9:44 p.m. | Updated Many New Yorkers are attached to their citys gritty industrial past, especially when it is juxtaposed with newer gleaming luxury structures.

title: Analysis: Nalbandian Survives Hewitt
description: The first game of the match between David Nalbandian and Lleyton Hewitt foreshadowed what would unfold over the next 4 hours 48 minutes of this gorgeous, gutsy first-round match. With Nalbandian serving, Hewitt played with brio to gain four break points.

title: Tiny Flower Saved from Extinction
description: The Maguire daisy, a dime-size wildflower found in sandstone canyons and atop mesas in Utah, was removed from the endangered species list this week after a 25-year effort to rescue it from extinction, the Interior Department said Tuesday.

title: A Step to Deal With Prosecutors Misconduct
description: The Justice Department on Tuesday announced the creation of a unit that will decide how to discipline career officials who commit acts of prosecutorial misconduct, including whether to refer them to state bar associations for punishment.

title: Wall Street Pay May Rise, by One Measure
description: Wall Street pay is front and center again, with big banks reporting earnings this week. Will there be a quiet reformation of compensation? The pool at Goldman Sachs, which reports results on Wednesday, is likely to be up, although pay per employee could be down. CNBC talks to Brad Hintz, a senior analyst at Sanford Bernstein.

title: Milton Rogovin, Photographer, Dies at 101
description: Milton Rogovin, an optometrist and persecuted leftist who took up photography as a way to champion the underprivileged and went on to become one of Americas most dedicated social documentarians, died on Tuesday at his home in Buffalo. He was 101.

title: Summer Fun Day | Triumph of the Egg
description: This article first appeared on July 6, 2010.

title: Clinton Campaigns for Emanuel in Chicago
description: CHICAGO  As the race for mayor of this city has intensified, the usual low-key announcements of endorsements  from various business leaders, preachers and members of Congress from Chicago  have churned forth. Then came Rahm Emanuel, who on Tuesday raised the ante a bit when it came to endorsers (the campaign equivalent of show-and-tell), standing on a stage beside his old boss, former President Bill Clinton.

title: Safina, in Free Fall, Shows Little Fight in Loss
description: Not getting a single game in a match is called a bicicleta in Spain, and a double bagel in English-speaking countries. Whatever you want to call it, Dinara Safinas 44-minute loss to Kim Clijsters was another sad chapter in her decline. Her brother Marat (they are the first brother and sister to be ranked No. 1 in the world) also failed to live up to his potential.

title: CarWoo: Demystifying the Art of the Deal
description: For those starting the new year looking for a new car, an online service proposes to remove hassles.

title: Top 10 Composers: The Female Factor
description: Anthony Tommasini has been exploring the qualities that make a classical composer great, maybe even the best of all time. Watch videos and vote for your own top 10 here and read previous posts here and share your thoughts in the comments field. Mr. Tommasinis final list will be posted on Friday.

title: Notes From the Underground | Joey Arias in Concert
description: Last October, Joey Arias in Concert played to sold-out audiences at the Abrons Arts Center. This past week, Arias gave a one-night-only repeat performance at Le Poisson Rouge. The downtown legend glided across the stage in impossibly high heels, opening with his now infamous Billie Holiday number, followed by a lineup of covers that spanned several decades. In between songs, Ariass mix of remarkably feminine, deftly honed vocals and raspy trash talk set the tone for two costume changes  one involving full lingerie. An adoring crowd fueled him with vodka shots.

title: Replicating the Brough Superior
description: It was a miracle that all this docile strength waits behind one tiny lever for the pleasure of my hand, wrote T.E. Lawrence, better known as Lawrence of Arabia, in praise of his Brough Superior motorcycle in the mid-1920s.

title: Cargill to Split Off Mosaic Unit in Complex Deal
description: 8:39 p.m. | Updated Cargill said on Tuesday that it planned to spin off its 64 percent stake in the Mosaic Company, a big producer of important ingredients in fertilizer, leaving Mosaic open for a possible sale at a time when mining and agriculture giants are on the prowl for acquisitions.

title: Pushing the Energy Envelope With China
description: Concurrent with the visit of President Hu Jintao, top Chinese and American officials are in the midst of a day-and-a-half strategic forum on clean energy cooperation, with the Brookings Institution playing host.

title: TimesCast | January 18, 2011
description: President Hu Jintao of China arrives in Washington; Haiti's former dictator returns after a 25-year exile; and in Brooklyn, a Haitian radio station reacts.

title: Medvedev Visits West Bank, Lifting Palestinian Spirits
description: JERUSALEM  President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia met on Tuesday with the president of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas, in the West Bank oasis town of Jericho and reaffirmed his countrys support for a Palestinian state with its capital in East Jerusalem.

title: Cantor Says House Wont Raise Debt Limit Without Serious Cuts
description: The majority leader, Eric Cantor of Virginia, put the Obama administration and the capital markets on notice Tuesday that the Republican-led House would use its leverage to avoid a vote to raise the federal debt ceiling if spending cuts were not made first.

title: Vatican Letter Warned Bishops on Abuse Policy
description: A newly disclosed document reveals that Vatican officials told the bishops of Ireland in 1997 that they had serious reservations about the bishops policy of mandatory reporting of priests suspected of child abuse to the police or civil authorities.

title: Obama Asks for Review of Rules Stifling Jobs
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Tuesday ordered a governmentwide review of federal regulations to root out those that stifle job creation and make our economy less competitive, but he exempted many agencies that most vex corporate America.

title: Tell Us the State of Your Block
description: The president gives the State of the Union, the governor the State of the State and, on Wednesday, the mayor will deliver the State of the City. These addresses tend to follow a similar outline. The official in question lists recent accomplishments, outlines future challenges, and implores everyone  invariably, and often with brow furrowed  to do more with less.

title: Deciding to Hire a $170,000 Consultant
description: Last week, we published a case study about the challenges facing First Quality Music, a family-owned supplier of stringed musical instruments, including guitars and mandolins, along with parts and accessories. Founded in 1970 in Louisville, Ky., the nine-employee company also makes its own banjos as well as game calls for hunters.

title: For Devotees of Wind Power, a New Product Label
description: Consumers already face a blizzard of labels on store shelves appealing to the better angels of their nature, from fair trade coffee and dolphin-safe tuna to chocolate bars whose makers pledge to devote part of their profits to saving endangered species.

title: Photos of the Moment | High-Top High Jinks
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#773", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: ODonnell Forms ChristinePAC
description: Christine ODonnell, who lost her bid for the Senate from Delaware last year, has filed paperwork to form her own political action committee, ChristinePAC, so that she can remain involved in the political process.

title: Pictures of the Day: Haiti and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Haiti, Tunisia and Italy.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: Miles to Go on Volker Rule Whether the Volcker Rule will be effective depends on the definitions, the Economics of Contempt blogger writes.  If the definitions of market-making-related activities, risk-mitigating hedging activities, and trading account are too broad, then banks probably wont have any trouble avoiding the tripwires. If the definitions are sufficiently narrow, and somehow dont provide banks with multiple opportunities for evasion, then a multi-level tripwire system could very well work. Economics of Contempt

title: N.H.L. in 360
description: The Sabres produced an experimental video installation as part of a special exhibition at the Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo.

title: DDB Sends Contest Winner to 9 Countries in 99 Days
description: A student is embarking on a worldwide trip to hunt trends, courtesy of a leading advertising agency.

title: While You Were Out: Apples Years With and Without Steve Jobs
description: Sam Grobart reviews Steven P. Jobss time at Apple.

title: Hotel Review: Maison Moschino, in Milan
description: BASICS

title: Apples Strong Holiday Season Lifts Revenue 70%
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The holidays were really good to Apple.

title: Some Cheer for Former Haitian Dictator
description: Updated | Wednesday | 7:59 p.m. As my colleague Ginger Thompson reports, Haitis former president for life, Jean-Claude Duvalier, heard some cheers before he was taken into custody in the Haitian capital on Tuesday, two days after his unexpected return to the country he fled more than 24 years ago.

title: Student Meets a Mentor She Has Met Before
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  Biology is destiny, and destiny is biology  specifically evolutionary biology  in The How and the Why, a new play by Sarah Treem having its premiere at the McCarter Theater Center here. A contentious, knottily plotted drama about the challenges women face in negotiating careers in the academic sciences, the play provides a nice showcase for Mercedes Ruehl, who gives a lively, nuanced and crisply funny performance as a professor whose long history of distinguished research comes under fire from an unlikely quarter.

title: Pfizer in Deal With Theraclone for Antibody Drug Research
description: Pfizer, the worlds largest drug company, has agreed to pay up to $632 million to Theraclone Sciences in a research collaboration on antibody drugs for cancer and infectious disease, the companies said Tuesday.

title: Vocal Physicians Group Renews Health Law Fight
description: A small professional group of doctors involved in the effort to repeal the new health care law has a history of opposing government involvement in medicine, including challenging President Bill Clintons attempts to overhaul health care in the 1990s.

title: Just One Look | Mulberry Pre-Fall Collection
description: The Pre-Fall Collections, being shown in New York over the next several weeks, arrive in stores in May to fill the gap between bikinis and furs.The design team at Mulberry trotted out to the English countryside for inspiration and returned to breathe some fresh air into 70s-era classics. The showroom, which was decked out for the occasion as an enchanted forest, provided a lively backdrop for snug jackets and kicky skirts in indigo denim and Prince of Wales check as well as blouses and dresses in new prints like rumpled roses and feathered friends. The total look was polished off, natch, with a new lineup of bags, including Taylor (shown here).

title: McCarthy Will Introduce Bill to Limit Ammunition Clips
description: Seizing on the shooting in Arizona that killed six and critically injured Representative Gabrielle Giffords, Representative Carolyn McCarthy of New York, a long-time gun control advocate, said Tuesday she would introduce a bill next week that would ban high-capacity ammunition magazines. The bill would be carried in the Senate by Senator Frank Lautenberg.

title: Mexican Gang Kingpin Arrested
description: MEXICO CITY  A man who helped start one of Mexicos most notorious criminal organizations has been arrested, adding to the list of high-profile kingpins the police and the military have arrested or killed in the past year.

title: Lieberman Will Not Run for Re-election
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman will announce on Wednesday that he will not seek a fifth term, according to a person he told of his decision.

title: Upton Sinclair and the Wonk Gap
description: Jonathan Chait bemoans the wonk gap:

title: Portraits From a Job-Starved City
description: A tour through the stores, factories and offices of Rockford, Ill.

title: West Virginia Court Orders Special Governor Election
description: A state Supreme Court ruling in West Virginia has apparently cemented a new annual trend there: three years, three elections, three governors, as one local political blogger put it.

title: From Whales to Apes, Small Conservation Steps
description: The latest whale rescue, details below, goes in same category of small victories as the recent detection of a live tiger cub hidden in luggage flowing through Bangkoks airport and last weeks confiscation of dozens of chimpanzee and gorilla body parts by authorities in Gabon.

title: Taxi, Take Me to the Bedbug Lecture. And Step on It.
description: In which we really, truly offer something for everyone.
