description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#674", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: A.I.G. and Treasury Pick 4 Banks for Big Stock Sale
description: 7:20 p.m. | Updated The American International Group and the Treasury Department have selected four big banks to lead the first sale of the governments extensive stock holdings in the bailed-out insurer, people briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

title: Inefficiency Isnt Bad for Everyone
description: Each year Americas labyrinthine tax code costs taxpayers billions, in dollars, hours and headaches. But it also has one giant beneficiary: Americas tax preparation industry.

title: Inefficiency Isnt Bad for Everyone
description: Each year Americas labyrinthine tax code costs taxpayers billions, in dollars, hours and headaches. But it also has one giant beneficiary: Americas tax preparation industry.

title: R. Sargent Shriver, Peace Corps Leader, Dies at 95
description: R. Sargent Shriver, the Kennedy in-law who became the founding director of the Peace Corps, the architect of President Lyndon B. Johnsons war on poverty, a United States ambassador to France and the Democratic candidate for vice president in 1972, died on Tuesday in Bethesda, Md. He was 95.

title: Hu Arrives to Begin State Visit
description: President Hu Jintao of China arrived here Tuesday afternoon for a two-day state visit that is expected to tackle a wide range of issues between the worlds biggest economic power and its biggest economic rival.

title: Joseph Lieberman Will Not Seek Re-election
description: Senator Joseph Lieberman of Connecticut, who was the Democratic vice presidential nominee in 2000 but later left the party after losing the Democratic Senate primary, has decided to retire.

title: In Murray Hill, the College Life Need Never End
description: New York can be an intimidating place for young people fresh out of college. Some find they need to bed down for a few years in something more challenging than a dorm, though not much more.

title: This Year, Sundance Will Savor Its Homegrown Projects
description: LOS ANGELES  Elgin James has an eyebrow archer of a life story. A childhood spent in an abusive home, where an abundant marijuana crop grew out back. A wooden bat attack in college that left him with brain damage. A period of homelessness that led to membership in a violent Boston street gang.

title: Gang Leader Turns Sundance Director
description: LOS ANGELES After two quiet years, prompted by the recession and a retrenchment in the independent film business, the froth appears to be returning to the Sundance Film Festival, which runs Thursday through Jan. 30 in Park City, Utah.

title: A Standing O? Oprah Says Shes Excited About Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark
description: First Glenn Beck urged his radio listeners to see the new Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, even if tickets cost them a kidney. Now Oprah Winfrey is making a similar exhortation  sans body parts  in the February edition of O: The Oprah Magazine as part of an interview she conducted in the fall with the shows director, Julie Taymor.

title: Two Tests Could Aid in Risk Assessment and Early Diagnosis of Alzheimers
description: Researchers are reporting major advances toward resolving two underlying problems involving Alzheimers disease: How do you know if someone who is demented has it? And how can you screen the general population to see who is at risk?

title: Middle-Aged Campers, Rock n Roll Dreams
description: Attendees of Rock n Roll Fantasy Camp practice and perform under the tutelage of real rock stars.

title: Rock Stars for a Night, and for a Price
description: Long before they became doctors and lawyers or C.E.O.s and real estate developers, they played in garage bands and maybe even dreamed of becoming rock stars. Thats why they signed up for Rock n Roll Fantasy Camp, and thats how they ended up on the stage of B. B. Kings Blues Club and Grill on Monday night, dressed in leather and tossing their drumsticks and guitar picks to a cheering crowd.

title: Spider Monkeys New Look: A High-Tech Radio Collar
description: Anthony Di Fiore, a primate biologist at New York University, writes from Ecuador, where he is using GPS technology and camera traps to study the behavior of male spider monkeys.

title: Self-Portrait of the Artist as a Suicide
description: Family dynamics examined through the prism of art: The Woodmans, C. Scott Williss compelling documentary study of an artistic clan whose comfortable life was shattered by the suicide of its youngest member, asks profound questions to which there really are no answers.

title: Stop the Jets
description: Much of New York is going crazy over the New York Jets. (If you havent followed football, they have scored two playoff upsets and will go to the Super Bowl if they come up with another one in Pittsburgh this Sunday.)

title: Stop the Jets
description: Much of New York is going crazy over the New York Jets. (If you havent followed football, they have scored two playoff upsets and will go to the Super Bowl if they come up with another one in Pittsburgh this Sunday.)

title: Googles Chrome OS: Putting Everything in the Browser Window
description: 6:38 p.m. | Updated to reflect that it is not possible to use Skype on Chrome, and that the device does have a fan.

title: Festival Where Boundary-Defying Musicians Mix and Mingle
description: For the dozens of artists who participated in the opening marathon concert of the Ecstatic Music Festival at Merkin Concert Hall on Monday, the event was less a defining breakthrough moment than the establishment  temporary or not  of an uptown beachhead for a flourishing alliance normally encountered in downtown and Brooklyn spaces like Le Poisson Rouge, Galapagos Art Space, Issue Project Room and Joes Pub.

title: 'On Stage in Fashion'
description: Images from an exhibition at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts.

title: Last Chance: On Stage in Fashion
description: Mary Martins curtain-fabric dirndl from the Broadway production of The Sound of Music was meant to look homemade for a reason. In the show, the governess Maria, played by Martin, dresses the von Trapp children in clothing made from curtains.

title: His Dad Left a Conspiracy; Youre Invited to the Hunt
description: Watching Zenith, a self-described retro-futuristic steampunk thriller, can make you feel like the confused hero of Memento  that is, someone unable to form new memories. Skittering back and forth between two time periods and a small group of nut cases, this bewildering collision of noir narration and purple paranoia may be long on atmosphere but is woefully short on sense.

title: Capturing Shifts Between Ecstasy and Anguish
description: The Diotima Quartet, based in Paris, looks as if its members were not long out of the conservatory and plays with the energy and passion of a newly minted ensemble. But it has been building its reputation for the last dozen years, largely through its new-music performances and an eclectic discography.

title: A Laugher for CBS
description: CBSs block of comedies delivered their best ratings of the season on Monday night, lifting the network to No. 1 on the night among the major broadcast networks. According to Nielsens estimates, 15.6 million viewers tuned in at 9 p.m. for Two and a Half Men while 13 million watched Mike & Molly at 9:30. At 10, CBSs Hawaii Five-0 earned 10.6 million viewers but lagged slightly behind the premiere of Harrys Law (11 million), NBCs new legal drama. Fox ranked second for the night, with NBC and ABC finishing in a virtual tie for third.

title: Songs in Several Languages, Wisecracks Spread Throughout
description: Little is sacred to Michael Garin and Mardie Millit, a smirking musical comedy team whose show, Sleepless in September, has been playing intermittently at the Metropolitan Room for the last four months. A whirlwind world tour in several languages, it begins in South Africa (Pata Pata) and ends on Route 66, after visits to Italy, South America, France and Israel.

title: Parting Glance: Milton Rogovin, 101
description: Milton Rogovin, an empathetic social documentarian who  like Jacob Riis  put a face on the faceless poor, died Tuesday, a month after celebrating his 101st birthday. Benjamin Genocchio has written the obituary for The New York Times. Mr. Rogovin himself narrated an audio slide show of his pictures, The Compassionate Eye, which appeared in April 2009 on Lens, accompanying Voices Silenced, Faces Preserved, with text by Randy Kennedy and pictures by Fred R. Conrad, in the Arts & Leisure section.

title: A Test to See if the Parts Are Worth More Than the Whole
description: ITT, Fortune Brands and Marathon Oil have all recently announced breakups, and Sara Lee is said to be contemplating one. Cargill announced on Tuesday that it would spin off its Mosaic unit. Market analysts contend that these businesses are too diverse and that separating them will allow the market to fully recognize each companys inherent value. The real question, though, is whether this will really create that extra value.

title: Buttermilk (the Real Thing)
description: Real buttermilk, the liquid thats left after butter is separated from cream, is a rarity. Its not as thick or as tangy as whats sold in supermarkets as buttermilk, which is just milk with added cultures. At Animal Farm in Orwell, Vt., the owner, Diane St. Clair, hand-skims the cream that naturally rises to the top of her Jersey cows milk, and cultures and churns it for her butter, which she does not make in hot weather. Now she has started selling the buttermilk that remains, in Vermont and New York. Take out that biscuit recipe, consider pancakes or waffles for the weekend, or plan on fried chicken and coleslaw, for it provides a subtler grace note for cooking and baking than supermarket buttermilk. Before you know it, a quart will be gone, especially if you discover how pleasant it is to drink.

title: Jeffreys Grocery
description: 172 Waverly Place (Christopher Street), Greenwich Village, (646) 398-7630, jeffreysgrocery.com.

title: Lani Kai
description: 525 Broome Street (Sullivan Street), SoHo, (646) 596-8778.

title: Bieber! Gaga! PopDust Wafts Into Crowded Territory
description: How important is the fact that Justin Bieber, teen fetish object, tweeted from his hospital bed after an allergy attack last week?

title: City Inspections Reveal New A-List for Restaurants
description: YOU might think the six-seat Garden City Cafe at West 40th Street and Ninth Avenue in Manhattan, with its cheerful, snow-schmutzed awning and its prominent A.T.M. sign, is a greasy spoon. But you could not be more wrong. There, in its window, shimmers an 8-inch-by-10-inch blue A from the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, the beacon that certifies the ultimate attainment of kitchen purity.

title: Off the Menu
description: NIKO This individualistic 75-seat Japanese restaurant has taken over the former Honmura An space. The sushi chef, Hiro Sawatari, above, an alumnus of the much-esteemed Sushi Yasuda, will name the source for each seafood species on the menu. In the interest of conservation, he will not serve bluefin tuna, but will offer a sustainable omakase menu. James London and Marina Schulze are in the kitchen preparing more-substantial fare that depends on Japanese ingredients but sometimes takes a Western approach, like short ribs braised with a mustard glaze in a beef jerky dashi, and octopus seared on a plancha with watermelon radish. Cobi Levy is an owner along with, among other partners, the chef Josh DeChellis. (Opens Monday): 170 Mercer Street (Houston Street), (212) 991-5650.

title: A City-Owned Marketplace in East Harlem Gets a Makeover
description: La Marqueta, a city-owned marketplace, has been an East Harlem fixture for decades. Now, following the successful revitalization of the Essex Street Market on the Lower East Side, the city has renovated this uptown market. It kept a number of the existing tenants, added new ones, and has room for more.

title: Enjoying Citrus Peels, Fresh and Candied
description: Citrons, known also as etrog, the traditional fruit for the Jewish harvest festival of Sukkot, are not for eating. They are used for their peel. Now, giant citrons from California have arrived in some stores. Stripping one with a vegetable peeler will yield about a cup of peel that keeps well, can be frozen for later use in baking and drinks, and can be candied.

title: A Sniff of Home Cooking for Dogs and Cats
description: ORIONS appetizer was a giant carrot.

title: Smugs Out, Talents in at Idol
description: On Wednesday night, when Foxs American Idol begins its 10th season, the spotlight will be fixed on the two new judges, Jennifer Lopez and Steven Tyler.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Skating and Supper

title: Moving in With the Folks, Who May Not Be Thrilled
description: As proof that this sitcom business isnt easy, we offer Retired at 35.

title: Lyon
description: CAN a restaurant succeed without a signature dish? Lyon, in Greenwich Village, is trying.

title: Reviewing Lyon
A Pet Salad With That Mouse?
description: WHEN you first see it among the vegetables at a grocery store, you might leap to the assumption that Pet Salad is some sort of gag gift. Has our national obsession with all things organic progressed to where someone is now selling a gourmet version of the Chia Pet?

title: Downtowns Pioneering Stage Mama
description: ELLEN STEWART, who died on Jan. 13, was in her early 40s when she founded La MaMa Experimental Theater Club in 1962. At an age when some people settle into complacency, she built one of New Yorks most influential cultural institutions. Half a century and more than 3,000 productions later, she leaves behind a legacy that includes pioneering the Off Off Broadway movement, importing international theater work before it was popular, and providing a home in the East Village for experimentation. While an era has ended, her theater and its vast population of artists and admirers carry on. A few of them were asked by Jason Zinoman to recall the woman known as Mama. Here are excerpts from their responses.

title: The Curious Career of David Auburn
description: WHEN you write one of the most produced plays of the decade at the age of 30, you can presumably shift your focus to whatever you want. But for David Auburn, who earned that distinction (on the basis of subsequent professional stagings) with his 2000 play, Proof, a chunk of the last 11 years has been spent doing what others have asked him to.

title: Q. and A. with a Pet Nutritionist
description: Dr. Joe  Joseph J. Wakshlag  a clinical nutritionist at the Baker Institute for Animal Health at Cornell University, is answering readers questions about pet food.

title: Two Are Charged With Fraud in iPad Security Breach
description: NEWARK  Federal prosecutors arrested two men on Tuesday on charges of fraud and conspiracy in obtaining and distributing the e-mail addresses of 114,000 iPad 3G owners.

title: After Tucson, a Time for Reflection
description: To the Editor:

title: Rare Reprises for an Unlikely Collaboration
description: HESPER ANDERSON remembers the path that ran through the woods between her familys home and that of Kurt Weill and Lotte Lenya, in the hamlet of New City, in Rockland County, N.Y., in the 1940s.

title: Beyond Hezbollah: Whats at Stake in Lebanon
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Workers in Japan: An Official View
description: To the Editor:

title: In Comcast-NBC Conditions, a Victory for Bloomberg
description: Embedded in the rules that the government is imposing on Comcasts acquisition of NBC Universal is one that specifically benefits Bloomberg L.P., the financial news giant that owns Bloomberg Television.

title: Screening for Alzheimers
description: Researchers have made further progress on two tests designed to detect Alzheimers disease, The Times reported on Tuesday. An advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration this week will determine whether one of these tests, a brain scan, should be marketed for widespread use. The other screening tool, a blood test, is still in the earliest stages of development.

title: Lauded Abroad, Indian Leader Is Besieged at Home
description: NEW DELHI  Few leaders are more respected globally than Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India. President Obama has described him as a historic figure, close friend and valued adviser. (So, for that matter, did President George W. Bush.) When Newsweek ranked world leaders, Mr. Singh ranked first, winning praise for his modesty and incorruptibility. He was described as the leader that other leaders love.

title: The Community of Joyous Knitters
description: To the Editor:

title: In Tucson, a Staff Mourns While Asking, What Would Gabby Do?
description: TUCSON  They still greet every visitor. They still help veterans file for disability benefits and retirees sign up for Medicare. They still send out press releases, though now they are signed by the chief of staff instead of the boss.

title: Red Bulls Top Draft Pick, Productive Striker and Casual Fan
description: It is now time for Corey Hertzog, the former Penn State striker and future Red Bulls player, to relax and enjoy the next couple of days. Just do not expect to find him rooted to his couch watching games from Europe, or anywhere else.

title: Brazil to Step Up Plans for Disaster Preparedness
description: BUENOS AIRES  The Brazilian government said Tuesday that it would accelerate efforts to devise a national system for preventing disasters and alerting the population quickly when they occur, in response to the deadly landslides in the state of Rio de Janeiro last week that killed at least 710 people.

title: Promise for Apollo in New Prospectus
description: Apollo Global Managements I.P.O. plans have aged well. Last week, Apollo, Leon D. Blacks buyout shop, filed the sixth iteration of its prospectus, three years after the first. The latest version contains signs buried in its 1,000-plus pages that should encourage prospective investors. Apollo looks ready to move from the dark corners of a private Goldman Sachs exchange, where it trades at a steep discount, to the public markets bright lights.

title: Writers Are Asked Not to Talk About Author of O
description: The publisher of O, an anonymously written novel about a 2012 presidential campaign, made a brazen request of journalists and other writers in an e-mail on Tuesday: if anyone asks whether you are the author, please decline to comment.

title: Comcast to Give Up NBCs Management Role at Hulu
description: In its successful bid to acquire NBC Universal, Comcast was not forced to sell off any assets. It did agree, however, to give up NBCs management role in Hulu, the premier online TV Web site, while retaining a financial stake.

title: A Dog, Nouns and Verbs
description: John W. Pilley, a psychologist, taught his dog, Chaser, 1,022 nouns and three verbs.

title: Hockey as You Have Never Seen It
description: To mark the 40th anniversary of the Buffalo Sabres, the club and the Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo mounted Forty: The Sabres in the N.H.L., a special exhibition that ran from Nov. 7 to Jan. 9.

title: Lebanon Shows Shift of Influence in Mideast
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  In Lebanons worst crisis in years, whose resolution may determine whether Hezbollah controls a government allied with the United States, American diplomacy has become the butt of jokes here. Once a decisive player here, Saudi Arabia has all but given up. In their stead is Turkey, which has sought to mediate a crisis that, given events on Tuesday in Beiruts streets, threatens to turn violent before it is resolved.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,425 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Teenager Held in Kuwait May Be Able to Return to U.S. Soon
description: WASHINGTON  Government lawyers told a federal judge in Virginia on Tuesday that they were trying to expedite the return of an American teenager detained in Kuwait, and that they expected him back in the United States by the end of the week.

title: After Long Fight, Farmworkers in Florida Win an Increase in Pay
description: IMMOKALEE, Fla.  After fighting for more than a decade for better wages, a group of Florida farmworkers has hashed out the final piece of an extraordinary agreement with local tomato growers and several big-name buyers, including the fast-food giants McDonalds and Burger King, that will pay the pickers roughly a penny more for every pound of fruit they harvest.

title: Christie Says 23 Schools Get Charters
description: Following through on his promise for more charter schools, Gov. Chris Christie announced Tuesday the approval of 23 new charter schools across New Jersey, including ones with single-sex classes or an emphasis on online learning or character-building.

title: Parenting by Gays More Common in the South, Census Shows
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  Being gay in this Southern city was once a lonely existence. Most people kept their sexuality to themselves, and they were reminded of the dangers of being openly gay when a gay church was bombed in the 1980s. These days, there are eight churches that openly welcome gay worshipers. One even caters to couples with children.

title: Sargent Shriver, Former Peace Corps Director, Dies
description: R. Sargent Shriver, the Kennedy in-law who became the founding director of the Peace Corps, the architect of President Lyndon B. Johnsons war on poverty, the United States ambassador to France and the Democratic candidate for vice president in 1972, died Tuesday.

title: The Growling Gourmet, a 1970s Dog Cookbook
description: As I researched this weeks article about homemade pet food, Pete Wells, the Dining sections editor, pointed out this gem of a book, The Growling Gourmet by Ellen Graham, published in 1976. Its a fabulous compendium of famous people with their pets and the food that they are fed.

title: Nets Pursuit of Anthony Reaches a Critical Juncture
description: Mikhail D. Prokhorov, the Nets majority owner, will attend Wednesday nights home game against Utah and witness the organizations Evening of Russian Culture, which will include Russian-themed entertainment.

title: First Trade Center Officers to Be in Place by Sept. 11
description: The first wave of officers in a new command will be in place at the World Trade Center when the sites memorial opens on Sept. 11, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said on Tuesday.

title: N.F.L.s Popularity Rises Along With Lockout Concerns
description: ATLANTA  N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell was asked at the conclusion of an owners meeting Tuesday to account for the surge in the games popularity. Goodell said it was not just one story line driving the soaring television ratings and fan interest, but many.

title: Steelers Ready for Big Game Thats Just a Game
description: PITTSBURGH  Down the hall on the way to the Steelers offices are the shiny silver totems of a franchise. Their standard is so simple that when Coach Mike Tomlin was asked what it meant to play like a Steeler, he could sum it up in one word: Win.

title: Gaming Senate Fights in Connecticut and North Dakota
description: Tis the season for retirements from the United States Senate.

title: Jets Fan Should Be Remembered for Good Life, Not Unusual Death, Friends Say
description: It was the sort of wrong-place, wrong-time news that spread far from that snowy driveway on Staten Island with unreal haste, in send-button time, and turned a familys tragic loss into a sports-bar punch line.

title: Can Apple Find More Hits Without Its Tastemaker?
description: Shortly before the iPad tablet went on sale last year, Steven P. Jobs showed off Apples latest creation to a small group of journalists. One asked what consumer and market research Apple had done to guide the development of the new product.

title: Panel Begins to Set Rules to Govern Financial System
description: WASHINGTON  The new regulatory board charged with overseeing the stability of the financial system took its first big steps on Tuesday to set out tentative guidelines to limit trading by banks for their own accounts and to restrict the growth of the biggest financial companies.

title: Now at Starbucks: Buy a Latte by Waving Your Phone
description: 12:14 p.m. | Updated  to clarify that there is no Android app for payments at Starbucks on mobile phones, although the company said it was working on one.

title: The Woman Who Saved the Union?
description: Washington, D.C., Jan. 19, 1861

title: Sharing the Burden of Peace
description: Have you braced yourself for the Pentagon spending cuts recently unveiled by Secretary of Defense Robert Gates? Dont bother. Though many journalists used that term to describe the Gates budget, Gates himself conceded that this is really all about a reduction in the rate of growth in spending.

title: In Annual Speech, Mayor Will Try to Put 3rd-Term Troubles Behind Him
description: In recent weeks, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has been mocked as a Manhattan elitist on Saturday Night Live, booed for his educational policies and accused of ignoring far-flung corners of New York City paralyzed by snow.

title: Video Captured Calculated Gunman in Tucson
description: TUCSON  The chief investigator for the sheriffs department here has for the first time publicly described the brief and gory video clip from a store security camera that shows a gunman not only shooting Representative Gabrielle Giffords just above the eyebrow at a range of three feet, but then using his 9-millimeter pistol to gun down others near her at a similarly close range.

title: Losing Wife, Man Becomes Cook and Caretaker to His Sons
description: Most of the time, Jose Ventura, 53, is unflappable. A building superintendent who presides over 86 apartments in Inwood, he fields calls from tenants day and night and battles for turf with gangs that sometimes leave their drugs and guns behind. Mr. Ventura also looks after his two young sons.

title: France Fetes Chinas Bank Giant
description: PARIS  As President Hu Jintao kicked off a four-day visit to Washington on Tuesday highlighting Chinas rising economic might, the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China was busy flexing its muscle on the other side of the Atlantic.

title: Poverty and Recovery
description: In 2008, the first year of the Great Recession, the number of Americans living in poverty rose by 1.7 million to nearly 47.5 million. While hugely painful, that rise wasnt surprising given the unraveling economy. What is surprising is that recent census data show that those poverty numbers held steady in 2009, even though job loss worsened significantly that year.

title: Coach Inhabits Ryans Shadow on Defense
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Four days before Peyton Manning tangled with the Jets in a first-round playoff game Jan. 8, he made sure to hurl compliments at Jets Coach Rex Ryan in a conference call with reporters. Manning called Ryan an excellent football coach.

title: Appearing Virtually at a Store Near You ...
description: SEXY may not be the first word that comes to mind to describe Barnes & Noble, but the sex appeal of the bookseller rose considerably this week among some readers of Esquire magazine.

title: Friends of the Court?
description: The Roberts court is hearing a larger share of cases about economic activities that matter to big business than the Rehnquist court before it. A recent study done by scholars for The Times documents that, compared with other Supreme Courts since 1953, this one is significantly more likely to produce a conservative decision in those cases.

title: Riders in the Mist
description: It has been an atmospheric 24 hours in New York City. The subway trains have been running fine. But when they tunneled into their stations on Tuesday, they seemed to be carrying their own fog with them.

title: Tax Leak Consequences Depend on Details
description: The individuals and companies whose offshore account information may be detailed in Swiss banking documents disclosed to WikiLeaks could face American prosecutors  or go untouched, senior tax lawyers said on Tuesday.

title: Obama Benefits in Having Palin as His Foil
description: WASHINGTON

title: In the Dominican Republic, Caribbean Solitude for a Song
description: About midway between Santiago and Monte Cristi in northwestern Dominican Republic, lush tropical cover gives way to scrubby brush and flat-topped trees, the livestock of choice switches from cows to goats, and all-inclusive-resort tourists are supplanted by Dominicans.

title: Lottery Numbers
Jones to Finish Season With Blackburn
description: Jermaine Jones will have a golden opportunity to brush up on his English now that terms of his six-month loan to Blackburn Rovers of the Premier League were completed on Tuesday.

title: U.S. Shifts Focus to Press China for Market Access
description: WASHINGTON  A year ago, the fight over how Chinas cheap currency was hurting American companies in marketplaces at home and abroad was shaping up to be the epic battle between the worlds biggest power and its biggest economic rival.

title: Basic Questions, Elusive Answers on Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  As the fight over health care returned to the House floor on Tuesday, the debate could largely be stripped down to four questions that are relatively simple to ask, if not to answer:

title: $10 Million to Provide Extra Help in Schools
description: The city announced on Tuesday that it had set aside $10 million to give extra help to tens of thousands of students who failed standardized exams last year after the state raised the standards for passing.

title: A Look at Goldman, on the Brink of a Windfall
description: Goldman Sachs executives have long been among the most richly paid on Wall Street in the best of times. They are now poised to reap a windfall that was sown in the dark days of the financial crisis in 2008.

title: Cuomo Campaign Aides Receive 5-Figure Bonuses
description: ALBANY  Just weeks before Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced that his senior staff would take pay cuts as a gesture of solidarity with weary taxpayers, he handed out five-figure bonuses from his campaign account to many of them, according to records disclosed on Monday.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 18
description: From the snow and cold on the slopes in Spain to the heat of the tennis hardcourts in Australia.

title: Anand Wins and Leads Tata Steel Chess Tournament With Nakamura
BPs Exploration Plans in the Arctic of Russia Draw Opposition From Partners
description: MOSCOW  The British petroleum giant BPs new deal to explore the Russian Arctic in partnership with a state-owned oil company has drawn protests from a group of private Russian investors with whom BP has a separate partnership.

title: In China, Traffic Jam Benefits Enterprising Villagers
description: HETAOCUN, China  Compared with some of the more spectacular recent traffic jams in China, among them a 60-mile snarl last summer that paralyzed a major artery outside Beijing for two weeks, the thousands of travelers who spent the night trapped on a snow-coated highway in southwest Guizhou Province on Monday did not even warrant a mention in the local news media.

title: Diplomatic Dangers Lurk in the State Dinner
description: WASHINGTON  It has been more than 13 years since a Chinese president has been the guest of honor at the most lavish party any White House can give, a state dinner. As host of such an affair Wednesday night for his Chinese counterpart, Hu Jintao, President Obama is walking into a danger zone of protocol and international diplomacy.

title: Office Work Space Is Shrinking, but Thats Not All Bad
description: HILLSBORO, Ore.  Intel was never one of those technology companies where employees had beanbag chairs, designer desks and pinball machines. Its offices were known for their endless rows of gray cubicles, low ceilings and fluorescent lighting. For decades it resisted any changes to its office environment.

title: Chinas Publicity Ads Arrive in Times Square
description: China has established an extra large, extra red beachhead in Times Square. In an advertising push the state news agency Xinhua described as a public diplomacy campaign that coincides with President Hu Jintaos visit to the United States this week, China is running a 60-second video on a series of billboard-size screens on Broadway. Some of the screens stay red  with Chinese characters in white  while the video is playing on the other screens with images of Chinese celebrities like the martial-arts movie star Jackie Chan; the basketball player Yao Ming; the astronaut Yang Liwei; and the pianists Lang Lang and Yundi. Xinhua said the video would be shown 15 times an hour, 20 hours a day, through Feb. 14, and on CNN through Feb. 13.

title: Cashman Has Some Explaining to Do
description: Rafael Soriano will be introduced on Wednesday at Yankee Stadium as the newest member of the team and as the most expensive setup man in baseball.

title: Wednesday: Getting the Gimmick
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Good news. The theme of todays puzzle is great, and the gimmick made me grin.

title: Getting Someone to Psychiatric Treatment Can Be Difficult and Inconclusive
description: TUCSON What are you supposed to do with someone like Jared L. Loughner?

title: Bad Boy Guarantees Snarl Billions in Real Estate Debt
description: The commercial real estate market is being hobbled by billions of dollars in distressed debt, and some experts are pointing to a provision in many loans  a so-called bad-boy guarantee  that they say is to blame for a large part of the backlog.

title: Governor Cuomos Disclosure Pledge
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York has made transparency a very big deal. In his inaugural speech, he said that New Yorkers cannot be expected to trust their state government without real transparency and real disclosure and real accountability and real ethics enforcement. Tell that to the Committee to Save New York.

title: A Night in Tunisia
description: Tunis

title: No Fifth Term for Lieberman
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, the Democratic vice-presidential candidate in 2000 who later became deeply alienated from his party, will announce on Wednesday that he will not seek a fifth term, according to people he told of the decision.

title: Banks Underlying Problem Is Revenue
description: The nations banks are posting runaway profits for 2010, in a drastic reversal from 2009, when the prospect of widespread loan defaults forced them to set aside billions of dollars to cover losses.

title: Mother Sees Hopeful Signs for Giffords
description: TUCSON  In an exuberant e-mail to family and friends Tuesday, the mother of Representative Gabrielle Giffords described remarkable progress by her daughter. According to the e-mail, Ms. Giffords scrolled through photographs on her husbands iPhone, tried to undo his tie and shirt and even began to look at get-well cards and pages of large-print text taken from a Harry Potter book.

title: University Provost Is Sued Over Faculty Shootings
description: ATLANTA  The spouses of two people killed at a faculty meeting at the University of Alabama in Huntsville last year have filed wrongful death lawsuits against the university provost.

title: The Golden Ticket at Goldman Sachs
description: Goldman Sach's partners are its highest executives and its biggest stars. An examination of filings by The New York Times reveals the power and wealth of this secretive group.

title: Military Study Finds Benefits in Mental Health Screening
description: Soldiers who were screened for mental health problems before deploying to Iraq were less likely to report suicidal thoughts, be evacuated for mental health reasons or require care for combat stress, a study published on Tuesday has found.

title: Bomb Is Found in Backpack Before March Honoring King
description: SEATTLE  A suspicious backpack found Monday along the route of a march honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., in Spokane, Wash., contained a live bomb that was likely capable of inflicting multiple casualties, federal investigators said Tuesday.

title: In Knotty State Secrets Case, Justices Ponder Telling Litigants to Go Away
description: WASHINGTON  It has been almost 60 years since the Supreme Court last had a hard look at the state secrets privilege, which can allow the government to shut down litigation by invoking national security. In the years since the attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, the government has invoked the privilege frequently to scuttle cases, saying they would frustrate its efforts to combat terrorism.

title: Yemen Sentences American-Born Cleric in Absentia
description: WASHINGTON  A judge in Yemen sentenced the radical American-born Muslim cleric Anwar al-Awlaki in absentia on Monday to 10 years in prison on charges of incitement to murder and belonging to a terrorist group.

title: Where Cyberspace Meets Cap Space
description: The two men sat in a dull gray room  one on a couch, the other on a rolling desk chair  and began the negotiation that would transform a franchise.

title: Don Kirshner, Shaper of Hit Records, Dies at 76
description: Don Kirshner, the music publisher of Brill Building hits like Will You Love Me Tomorrow and Youve Lost That Lovin Feelin, who later served as a deadpan Ed Sullivan for Kiss, the Ramones and others with his 1970s television show, Don Kirshners Rock Concert, died on Monday in Boca Raton, Fla., where he lived. He was 76.

title: Official Is Optimistic About Iran Talks
description: The talks scheduled for Friday between Iran and the five permanent Security Council members plus Germany should lead to comprehensive cooperation to address regional problems, Mohammad Khazaee, the Iranian ambassador to the United Nations, said at a news conference. Although previous Iranian attempts to shift the focus away from its nuclear program prompted objections from other negotiators, Mr. Khazaee said the talks, in Istanbul, could lead to cooperation on problems like disarmament and the Arab-Israeli conflict. Mr. Khazaee said the West and other powers should stop making the mistake of ignoring Irans status as the regional heavyweight.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Ireland: Backing for Cowen
description: The Irish prime minister, Brian Cowen, won a confidence vote among lawmakers for the governing Fianna Fail party on Tuesday, virtually assuring that he will lead the party into a general election that is expected to take place by the end of March. Uncertainty over the party leadership has grown since the Cowen government accepted harsh terms in December for a $113-billion international bailout of Irelands debt-ridden economy. After the ballot, Mr. Cowen accepted the resignation of Micheal Martin, the foreign minister, who had demanded over the weekend that Mr. Cowen resign.

title: Working-Class Hero
description: Images of Milton Rogovin, the revered social documentary photographer, in his home in Buffalo.

title: After Scrutiny by New Jersey, College Names a New Leader
description: A year after settling a lawsuit brought by the State of New Jersey, Stevens Institute of Technology announced Tuesday that it had named Nariman Farvardin, the provost at the University of Maryland, to be its seventh president.

title: Help With Financial Aid as Reimagined by the MTV Generation
description: One is an interactive game in which students seeking scholarships would be represented by avatars that would guide them through each step of the financial aid process.

title: Feeling New York Citys Restless Pulse
description: When he leaves home to make his way around the city, Martin Greeenberg wears a badge. Its the simplest way to let other pedestrians know he is both deaf and blind. Mr. Greenberg, 58, is an accountant who now teaches American Sign Language classes. He was born and raised in New York City, and has fond childhood memories of the subway  rush hour and the underground lights. In his mind, the trains represented freedom.

title: In Wreckage of Lost Jobs, Lost Power
description: Alone among the worlds economic powers, the United States is suffering through a deep jobs slump that cant be explained by the rest of the economys performance.

title: Crash Study Highlights Need for Better Side-Impact Protections
description: The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, in a new analysis of side-impact crashes, on Wednesday said its crash simulations showed that drivers of vehicles that received the consumer groups Poor rating would be three times as likely to die in a similar real-world crash as drivers of vehicles that received a Good rating.

title: Phys Ed: Brains and Brawn
description: It has long been a clich that muscle bulk doesnt equate to intelligence. In fact, most of the science to date about activity and brain health has focused on the role of endurance exercise in improving our brain functioning. Aerobic exercise causes a steep spike in blood movement to the brain, an action that some researchers have speculated might be necessary for the creation of new brain cells, or neurogenesis. Running and other forms of aerobic exercise have been shown, in mice and men, to lead to neurogenesis in those portions of the brain associated with memory and thinking, providing another compelling reason to get out at lunchtime and run.

title: Code Words for 2011: Play Happy
description: Midfielder Yael Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., native by way of the University of North Carolina, will be contributing to the Goal blog in the runup to the third season of Womens Professional Soccer and as the United States womens national team prepares to the FIFA Womens World Cup in Germany later this year. Now, she checks in from China, where the U.S. is getting ready to face Sweden on Friday in the Four Nations Tournament.

title: Word of the Day | diffident
description: diffident \di-f-dnt, -dent\ adjective

title: Arguing Over the Jobs Slump
description: The debate in the blogosphere over the the American jobs slump  the subject of my column this week  is a disagreement about causes.

title: Comcast Receives Approval for NBC Universal Merger
description: Comcast received government approval Tuesday to acquire NBC Universal, emerging from a lengthy review with a list of conditions, the most important aimed at preventing the new media conglomerate from thwarting competition in online video.

title: Midwest Democrat Rules Out Senate Re-election Bid in 12
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Kent Conrad of North Dakota on Tuesday became the first Democrat to announce he would not run for re-election in 2012, handing Republicans an early opportunity to gain a seat in a conservative-leaning state.

title: Giffordss Husband Heard His Wife Had Died in Tucson
description: While racing to his wifes side, Mark Kelly, the husband of Rep. Gabrielle Giffords, heard from erroneous television news reports that his wife had been killed when she was shot outside of a Safeway supermarket in Tucson on Jan. 8, he said in a televised interview on Tuesday evening.

title: Georgia: Atlanta Schools Are Placed on Probation
description: Atlantas public school system was warned on Tuesday that it could lose accreditation this year if feuding school board members do not resolve their differences. An independent accreditation group, AdvancED, announced that it was placing the high schools in the 49,000-student school system on probation, giving the board nine months to make improvements or face further punishments. Losing accreditation affects students ability to apply to college or receive scholarships. The announcement followed months of public power struggles between two groups of board members for control of the board. Atlanta is the second largest school system that the accreditation group has ever placed on probation, according to its spokeswoman, Jennifer H. Oliver.

title: Autism in Somali Children Will Be Investigated
description: Whether or not ethnic Somali children in Minneapolis have unusually high rates of autism will be investigated by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the National Institutes of Health in conjunction with Autism Speaks, an autism research organization, the centers and Autism speaks announced Tuesday. Somali parents in Minneapolis have complained for years that many of their children, regardless of where they were born, are autistic, and want an explanation. Im so happy to be in a country where one voice can make a difference, said Idil Abdull, who has an autistic son and has for years asked for an investigation.

title: New Justice Department Office Will Discipline Prosecutors
description: The Justice Department announced on Tuesday the creation of a unit that will decide how to discipline career officials who commit prosecutorial misconduct, including whether to refer them to state bar associations for punishment. The unit will review cases whenever the departments internal ethics watchdog, the Office of Professional Responsibility, finds that a prosecutor intentionally or recklessly violated the rules to which he is subject. Cases in which office investigators conclude that prosecutors merely made a mistake or had poor judgment would, however, still be handled by their supervisors. Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. appointed Kevin Ohlson, who until recently was his chief of staff, to be chief of the new unit.

title: A Look at Sundance
description: Images from some of the films appearing at the 2011 Sundance Film Festival.

title: News Quiz | January 19, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Threats to Lawmakers Rarely Lead to Charges
description: WASHINGTON  In September 2009, a Veterans Affairs caseworker reported that a man had threatened to kill Senator John Cornyn, a Republican, and Representative Ciro Rodriguez, a Democrat, both of Texas, for failing to help him in a dispute over his retirement benefits.

title: Banks Underlying Problem Is Revenue
description: The nations banks are posting runaway profits for 2010, in a major reversal from 2009, when the prospect of widespread loan defaults required them to set aside billions of dollars to cover losses, Eric Dash reports in The New York Times.

title: Joseph I. Lieberman's Life and Career
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut built a career following a moderate line that often angered the liberal wing of the Democratic party.

title: Panel Begins Setting Financial System Rules
description: The new regulatory board charged with overseeing the stability of the financial system took its first big steps on Tuesday to set out tentative guidelines to limit trading by banks for their own accounts and to restrict the growth of the biggest financial companies, Edward Wyatt reports in The New York Times.

title: Karzai Postpones Seating Parliament, Deepening Afghan Crisis
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai ordered a months delay in seating a new Parliament on Wednesday, heightening a constitutional crisis that threatens to fuel bitter infighting and potentially even violence among the countrys rival factions.

title: The White House Looks for Work
description: Three days before Christmas, President Obama gathered his economic team in the West Wings Roosevelt Room to review themes for his State of the Union address. The edge-of-the-cliff crisis he inherited had passed, but with more than 14 million Americans still out of work, he was looking for bold ways to bring down unemployment. The ideas presented to him, though, seemed familiar and uninspired. You know, guys, he said, according to someone in the room, Ive told you before, I want you to come to me with ideas that excite me. Nothing he was hearing excited him.

title: Former Dictator Returns to Haiti
description: WHO is Jean-Claude Duvalier, also known as Baby Doc?

description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the article A New Roof That Works for a Living.

title: Rockfords Group Portrait, in Five Days
description: The challenge was formidable: Create a photographic quilt of a small American city, with more than 150,000 potential subjects.

description: Todays word, in association with the commendable Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Polo Grounds Replay
description: A look at the stadium in Harlem, a home to baseball, football, boxing, auto racing and much more from the 1880s to the 1960s.

title: Polo Grounds, and Its Former Tenants, Emerge From the Shadows
description: When a ballpark dies, and its concrete and steel are smashed to bits, it survives in memories: attending a first game there; smelling the mix of grass, hot dogs and beer; rising with thousands of others to watch a home run take flight; and catching a foul ball (finally!).

title: Have You Ever Sent an Odd Message Because of Autocorrect?
description: Using a smartphone or word processing software with an autocorrect feature for e-mail, texting and writing often leads to confusing, surprising, upsetting or hilarious errors. Have you ever sent or received a strange message, courtesy of autocorrect? Do you take the time to proofread your messages and papers before you hit send?

title: Bomber Uses Ambulance to Hit Iraqi Police Headquarters
description: BAGHDAD  For the second time in two days, Iraqi security forces came under attack by a suicide bomber when an ambulance packed with explosives blew up outside a police headquarters on Wednesday in Diyala Province, north of Baghdad.

title: The Early Word: Face to Face
description: In Todays Times:

title: Poetry Is King at Eliot Prize Readings in London
description: On the belief that poetry is indeed a growing, expanding art form, this year, Southbank Center will host its annual T.S. Eliot Prize Readings festival in larger digs: the Royal Festival Hall.

title: Mike Tomlin and Rex Ryan Like Each Other
description: Rex Ryan started it off Monday by saying that Mike Tomlin was one of his favorite coaches: Were similar. You look at our backgrounds, were similar. Were defensive guys. We both have incredible opportunities. We know that. I just want to win a Super Bowl like he has. Talk about respect, I have a huge amount of respect for Mike Tomlin.

title: Housing-Sector Profitability
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Indonesia Sentences Tax Official to 7 Years
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  A former government official at the center of a corruption scandal that has shocked the country was sentenced to seven years in prison on Wednesday, the latest chapter in a case seen as a crucial test of the countrys uncertain progress in fighting graft.

title: Insight Into Aaron Rodgerss Early Years as a Packer
description: Andrew Brandt, who writes for The National Football Post, has insight into the Packers because he was a former executive for them. In a blog post Tuesday, he offered a glimpse of Aaron Rodgerss early years with Green Bay, when he was an understudy to Brett Favre:

title: Labor Speech Previews Clash With Business in 2012
description: Richard Trumka, the president of the AFL-CIO, says Washington politicians are living in an Alice in Wonderland political climate that ignores the needs of workers struggling to survive in a difficult economy.

title: Hong Kong Authorities Seize Cocaine Bound for Mainland China
description: HONG KONG  Hong Kong Customs announced on Wednesday that it had seized 640 pounds of high-grade cocaine concealed in two shipping containers that arrived from Chile and were scheduled for shipment to mainland China, the latest sign of what experts describe as Chinas growing problem with recreational drug use.

title: The Top 10 Composers: The Romantics
description: Anthony Tommasini has been exploring the qualities that make a classical composer great, maybe even the best of all time. Watch videos and vote for your own top 10 here and read previous posts here and share your thoughts in the comments field. Mr. Tommasinis final list will be posted on Friday.

title: Al Daviss Odd  News Conference
description: It was supposed to be a news conference to introduce Hue Jackson as the Raiders coach. But soon enough, the news conference became about Al Davis, the Raiders principal owner. And then it became about Tom Cable, as Davis criticized him harshly and listed the many reasons he did not retain him as coach.

title: Whats Wrong With Executive Limousines Web Site?
description: Executive Limousine operates a fleet that includes town cars, stretch limos and party buses. The company, which is based in Bellmore, N.Y., offers travel options that range from airport transportation to bachelor parties and winery tours.

title: Tunisian Opposition Pushes for Coalition Changes
description: TUNIS  Tunisias interim leaders scrambled Wednesday to distance themselves further from the government of the ousted leader as opposition officials weighed whether to mount an effort to push out most of the cabinet members from the old ruling party.

title: Indias Prime Minister Shuffles His Cabinet
description: NEW DELHI  Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, facing public anger over corruption scandals and the lagging performance of his government, shuffled his cabinet on Wednesday, demoting if not firing several ministers who had been either brushed by scandal or criticized for poor work.

description: The Gerova Financial Group, a reinsurer based in Bermuda, said on Tuesday that it had hired the investigative agency Kroll to look into possible market manipulation and collusion that might have contributed to a decline in its stock price.

title: Catalan Savings Bank Sells Stake in Repsol
description: CatalunyaCaixa, a Spanish savings bank, said on Wednesday that it had sold a stake in the oil producer Repsol for about 448 million euros, days after reports emerged that the bank would seek to raise capital.

title: Before Facing Steelers, the Jets Fix-It List
description: Most football experts said the Jets had to play the perfect game to beat the Patriots, but that turned out not to be true. The Jets dominated most of the game and survived some costly mistakes.

title: Its Yiddish for Whole-Wheat Pancakes
description: Traditionally, Jewish cooking isnt seen as health food. But we were never traditional Jews.

title: Former D.E. Shaw Manager to Start Credit Fund for Golub Capital
description: The former head of D.E. Shaws multibillion-dollar credit investing business, Daniel Posner, is headed to Golub Capital to start a credit hedge fund

title: And The Campy Award Goes To
description: Here is a category we wish we would see more of: the HitFix blog points us to the Gay and Lesbian Entertainment Critics Association, a group of writers from publications like The Advocate and Us Weekly, which has announced that the winner for Campy  Intentional or Not  Film of the Year is Burlesque. (Or as the organization puts it: um, winner.) It beat out worthwhile contenders like Sex and the City 2 and Piranha 3-D. The win was especially notable because Steven Antin, the director of Burlesque, only recently told the Bagger that he didnt care for the films reception. It really wasnt what I was aiming for, the camp, he said of the film starring Cher and Christina Aguilera. I wanted to make a fun film that was a throwback to Hollywoods golden age of musicals, and people perceived it as camp for obvious reasons. I was surprised it was perceived that way.

title: Martin Sheen and Emilio Estevez Plan a Memoir
description: Given recent events it is sometimes easy to forget that there are members of the Sheen family besides Charlie, and that they also live and work and contribute to the artistic community. But there are, and two who have lately avoided the glare of the headlines are collaborating on a memoir. Martin Sheen, the Apocalypse Now and West Wing star and Sheen family paterfamilias, and his son Emilio Estevez, the Breakfast Club actor and Bobby director, will write a book called Along the Way for the Free Press imprint of Simon & Schuster, the publisher said in a news release. The memoir, which is planned for publication around Fathers Day 2012, is said to chronicle the physical and spiritual journey of Mr. Sheen and Mr. Estevez, along the Camino de Santiago, Spain, the 1,000-year-old pilgrimage path, which traverses Galicia, the area from which Sheens father emigrated to the U.S., and to which Estevezs own son has returned. The book, written with Hope Edelman, will celebrate their profound bond, give candid insights into the actors lives and relationship, examine the triumphs and challenges and inner and outer stages of the journey of a father and son. (It will also discuss The Way, a coming film directed by Mr. Estevez and starring Mr. Sheen.) The release from the Free Press did not immediately mention if Along the Way would also address that other, prodigal Sheen sibling.

title: Goldmans Eileen Rominger to Join the S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has announced that Eileen Rominger, the global chief investment officer of Goldman Sachs Asset Management, has been named its director of investment management.

title: Great Leaps Backward
description: Ive been watching with sympathy as David Beckworth and Scott Sumner discover that their updated monetarism actually puts them on my side of the great ideological divide  cast into the outer darkness along with John Maynard Keynes and Milton Friedman.

title: Europes Troubles Offer Opportunities to Tourists
description: For more than a year, the weakest economies in Europe have been struggling: Greece and Ireland have already received bailouts, and Portugal and Spain may be next. Lucky for travelers, the economic woes of these countries can mean opportunities for those who want to visit them. While the weak euro, which recently fell below the $1.30 mark, makes the entire Euro Zone cheaper for Americans, some of the best bargains can be found in the hardest-hit countries. Ireland, Greece and Portugal, in particular, are offering what amount to fire-sale prices as hotels and tour operators slash rates.

title: Brooklyn Philharmonic Hires Artistic Director and Aims for New Era
description: The ailing Brooklyn Philharmonic is hanging in there. Having halted most of its orchestra concerts over the last two seasons and cut staff because of money problems, it said on Wednesday that it had hired a new artistic director, Alan Pierson, and promised a new era. Mr. Pierson is the artistic director and conductor of the contemporary-music ensemble Alarm Will Sound.

title: Training With Federer in Dubai
description: Ever wonder how Roger Federer trains? I spoke with Jeremy Bayon, a Frenchman who played college tennis at Mississippi State and is now the assistant coach of the mens team at the University of Florida, about his experience watching Federer train in Dubai with Jesse Levine, a young American player Bayon coaches. (In the second round of the Australian Open on Wednesday, Federer survived a five-set match against Gilles Simon of France, 6-2, 6-3, 4-6, 4-6, 6-3.)

title: Obama and Hu Cite Mutual Aims Amid Trade Deals
description: 10:47 a.m. | Updated Declaring that China and the United States have an enormous stake in each others success, President Obama welcomed President Hu Jintao of China to the White House on Wednesday with an elaborate color-guard ceremony that included a colonial fife-and-drum band and a 21-gun salute.

title: The Output Gap
description: Menzie Chinn has a useful post reminding us just how much output we could and should have been producing is being lost to the slump. He includes this picture:

title: Video Shows Gas Explosion in Philadelphia
description: Video shot by a local news crew in Philadelphia on Tuesday night captured the moment a natural gas pipe exploded, killing one utility worker and injuring six other people.

title: Directors May Be Underpaid, Wachtell Lipton Tells Its Clients
description: DealBook has read stories about how Americas teachers are underpaid. Weve heard arguments that federal judges are underpaid. But weve never seen a suggestion that directors of public companies in the United States are underpaid.

title: Ballads, From Literary To Wry to Confessional
description: An acute awareness of time passing is an ever-present theme in the songs of Mary Chapin Carpenter, who gave a quietly spellbinding concert on Saturday evening at the Allen Room as part of Lincoln Centers American Songbook series. The music of Ms. Carpenter, 52, is an unclassifiable hybrid of pop, folk and country that she performs in the low, steady voice of someone confiding her thoughts in a journal.

title: For Greece, Buyback of Bonds Is Floated
description: Analysts said on Wednesday that having Greece buy back its own devalued bonds could be an important step toward solving Europes sovereign debt crisis.

title: Wednesday Reading: The Health Care Law Debate
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Hawk on the Mend, but Still Grounded
description: A brief update on the juvenile red-tailed hawk who smashed into a window in the glass-walled atrium of The New York Times Building last week: An X-ray showed that his wing is not broken and his prognosis remains good, but six days after the collision, he is still not flying, said the rehabilitator on Long Island who is caring for the bird.

title: Growing Criticism of Labor Leader Who Doubled His Salary
description: Two years after Jack Ahern won the presidency of the New York City Central Labor Council on the strength of his pledges to clean up the troubled labor coalition, the council has fallen into disarray, with top aides leaving and union leaders expressing growing frustration over Mr. Aherns leadership.

title: Hawk Survives but Is Not Yet Flying
description: The red-tailed hawk that crashed into the atrium of The New York Times headquarters last week is on the mend, the City Room blog reports.

description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.

title: Unemployment Does Not Equal Poverty
description: Perhaps the most surprising part of the new Gallup study of unemployment around the world is that poorer countries dont tend to have higher jobless rates. After surveying workers in 129 countries, Gallup concludes that there is no significant relationship between unemployment rates and GDP per capita. The relevant chart, which shows basically no pattern:

title: Congresswoman Cites Hero of Arizona Shooting in Opposing Health Care Repeal
description: In her defense of the health care law, Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz, Democrat of Florida, said Wednesday that the woman who grabbed the second magazine out of the hands of the gunman accused of shooting Representative Gabrielle Giffords and 19 others had come to see Ms. Giffords in Tucson that day to urge her to fight Republican efforts to repeal the law.

title: A Better Yardstick for Solar Cycles
description: With 2010 tying 2005 for the warmest year on record, and 10 of the last 13 years ranking as the 10 warmest ever, it becomes ever more difficult to sustain an argument that global warming is not occurring. So the question becomes more of a whodunit. Is it man, or nature, or both, and in what measure? In making their argument for natural causes, many climate skeptics tend to focus attention on the sun.

title: Vanishing Planet in 140 Amusing Characters
description: Heres another reason I engage on Twitter: Laughter.

title: Orlando Executive Boyce Discusses Beating Lifes Odds
description: At 31, Lucas Boyce is one of the N.B.A.s youngest executives. His role as the OrlandoMagics director of multicultural insights, cause marketing and government affairs comes after he served in the White House during George W. Bushs administration.

title: Al Daviss News Conference Takes a Detour
description: No matter what team you root for, in whatever sport, you may pause for a moment today to be thankful that it is not run by Al Davis. Sure, Cleveland Cavaliers fans have it pretty bad (it doesnt take much imagination to picture the owner Dan Gilbert, with a few more years and a few track suits, as Davis-in-training) but Oakland Raiders fans are truly deserving of our sympathy. Davis resurfaced Tuesday to remind everyone what unhinged looks like.

title: Foreign-Language Hopefuls, on Pins and Needles
description: For film directors, producers and distributors around the world, today is a day to cross your fingers and hope for the best. The 65 countries that each submitted a nomination for the Oscar for best foreign-language film will be whittled down to nine in two stages, and if past experience is any guide, some highly regarded films may be overlooked in Wednesdays announcement.

title: Software Piracy in China
description: Intellectual property is one of the big economic issues between China and the United States. American business executives and government officials believe Chinese companies steal large amounts of intellectual property from foreign companies. China does have laws against such piracy, but they are often not enforced.

title: Buy Robot
description: Chrissie Morris, a London-based shoe designer, was in a sci-fi frame of mind when she created her Priscilla platform. Named after one of the research robots in the Humanoid Project in Sweden, the showy shagreen and leather shoe combines a strong architectural heel and chunky hardware with soft grass and strawberry hues. Says Morris, Theres a certain toughness, but the colors celebrate the delicacy of what will bloom come springtime. The sandal is $1,135 at kirnazabete.com or call (212) 941-9656.

title: Ambassador to China at the White House After Hinting at 2012 Run
description: 2:26 p.m. | Updated Of all the White House visitors in from China on Wednesday, one may be having a particularly awkward day: Jon Huntsman.

title: The Voices of Rare Diseases
description: Kylynn Welsh, 21, was in and out of the hospital as a child. She had frequent episodes of swelling all over her body that no one seemed to understand.

description: Updated | 1:39 p.m. As protests continued on the streets of Tunisian cities, a former dissident who joined Tunisias interim government on Tuesday defended the new cabinet, which is led by senior officials who served the deposed president, as a short-term compromise with the old regime.

title: Shift in Vietnams Leadership as Party Boss Apologizes
description: HANOI, Vietnam  The ruling Communist Party ended a major congress Wednesday with the announcement of several changes in the countrys hierarchy, and what amounted to an apology by the partys chief for the performance of the nations leaders over the past five years.

Over the last few decades, as the citys economy and that of neighboring mainland China has expanded, visibility in the region has plummeted as air pollution has worsened.

The box was found in the late morning at an 11th-floor office of Bank Hapoalim, an Israeli bank, at 1177 Avenue of the Americas near 46th Street, the police said.

description: Mazda announced on Tuesday that it would introduce its new Minagi compact crossover sport utility vehicle concept at the Geneva auto show in early March. While this curvaceous S.U.V. is not scheduled for production, it would give Mazda a contender in a growing category.

title: Obamas Clinton White House

title: Roles of Anne Hathaway and Tom Hardy Revealed in Dark Knight Rises
description: Batman has found a nemesis for his next cinematic adventure  and, it appears, a love interest, too. On Wednesday, Warner Brothers Pictures announced a new cast member and the role of another in The Dark Knight Rises, the third Batman movie to be directed by Christopher Nolan, the Inception and Memento filmmaker. Joining Christian Bale, who returns as Batman and his daytime alter ego, Bruce Wayne, is Anne Hathaway (of Love and Other Drugs) who will play Selina Kyle; the film will also feature Tom Hardy, a co-star of Inception, as the villain Bane.

title: About Face: Turkish Federation Offers to Organize Event It Dropped
description: Late last month, the Turkish Chess Federation withdrew as host of the 2011 European Womens Championship. The reason given by Ali Nihat Yazici, the federations president, was that he and the federation had been treated badly by the European Chess Union, the governing body of the game in Europe.
