description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg delivered his 10th State of the City address on Wednesday, saying the city had weathered the worst of the economic crisis but that tough choices were ahead.

title: Deconstructing a Bestiary of Malthusian Miserabilists
description: Last week I received a promotional e-mail from spiked, the often-biting British publication fond of puncturing all manner of ideological balloons, touting a broadside against warnings about overpopulation. The piece, The definitive guide to modern-day Malthusians, by Brendan ONeill, had a predictably provocative summary:

title: Crops of Bacteria, Farmed by Amoebas
description: Humans are not the only farmers. Other animals, like ants and termites, grow food, and now a new study reports that a species of amoeba, one of the simplest of organisms, also farms.

title: For Lieberman, an Exit Forged in Alienation
description: Perhaps no one could claim credit for Senator Joseph I. Liebermans decision not to seek a fifth term more than Markos Moulitsas, the founder of the liberal blog Daily Kos. In 2006, Mr. Moulitsas mobilized like-minded Democrats to try to unseat Mr. Lieberman as punishment for supporting the Iraq war and for being too accommodating to President George W. Bush.

title: Reader Response: Software Piracy
description: Ari in Ithaca asks whether the gap between sales of computer hardware and software in China is really evidence of widespread software piracy:

title: Noam Chomskys Video Plea to Iran on Behalf of Detained Americans
description: Noam Chomsky, an American academic best-known to viewers of Iranian television for his criticism of American foreign policy, made a personal appeal to Irans government to release two detained Americans in a video message posted online on Wednesday.

title: For Edwards, Productivity and Patience Take Hold
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The more Braylon Edwards talked, the more he sounded humbled, sounded changed. He called 2010 his best season and said he traded statistics for team unity in hope of shifting the perceptions that have shadowed him.

title: Venus Williams Hobbles Off, Then Roars Back
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  It could have been another day at the Australian Open of frivolous themes, with the focus on Venus Williamss latest risqu tennis dress. But then Williams screamed in pain as she lost the last point of the first set, limped to her chair and hobbled off the court for treatment.

title: A Shortlist, and the Usual Snubs
description: The nine films that will move on to the next stage of competition for the Oscar for best foreign-language film were revealed on Wednesday, and as is typical, there were surprises  and snubs. The highly regarded French submission, Of Gods and Men, about Christian monks trying to keep their monastery going amid Islamist conflict in Algeria, was left off the list, but an Algerian film about that countrys struggle to break free from French rule, Outside the Law, was included. So were two other films that address cultural conflicts between the West and Islam: Canadas Incendies and Denmarks In a Better World, which won the Golden Globe for best foreign-language film last weekend.

title: Justices Uphold Background Checks
description: WASHINGTON  Employees of government contractors, including scientists and engineers who work on government space programs, must submit to intrusive background checks if they want to keep their jobs, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously on Wednesday.

title: Rose Dwarfs Other Improvements With Defense
description: Derrick Roses ongoing most valuable player campaign is often unfairly boiled down to his superior shooting this season, but Roses increased range is far from his most compelling improvement.

title: Heart of Glass | Kiki van Eijk
description: Last month at Design Miami, the Dutch designer Kiki van Eijk showed a collection of seven objects for Venice Projects, an Italian gallery that commissions contemporary artists to work with traditional Venetian glass techniques. The collection is now available at veniceprojects.com. Van Eijks fanciful, craft-intensive and extravagant objects (Love, shown here, is $19,200) invest everyday items like a cooking pot or a watering can with emotional resonance by virtue of juxtapositions (a stack of glass pillows topped by an hourglass in Rest) and color (red for passion in Love). Van Eijk and her partner, the designer Joost van Bleiswijk, will also be part of the exhibition Glasstress 2011, which opens June 3 to coincide with the Venice Biennale.

title: Suzanne Malveaux to Anchor CNN Newsroom
description: CNN continues to tweak its weekday lineup, this time by naming a new lunchtime anchor.

title: Wilfrid Sheed, Writer of Gentle Wit, Dies at 80
description: Wilfrid Sheed, the wittily satirical man of letters who drew upon his Anglo-American background to write bittersweet essays, criticism, memoirs and fiction about cultural life on both sides of the Atlantic, died early Wednesday in Great Barrington, Mass. He was 80.

title: But Will It All Make Tiger Mom Happy?
description: There are all these new books out there portraying Asian mothers as scheming, callous, overdriven people indifferent to their kids true interests, Amy Chua writes. She ought to know, because hers is the big one: Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother, a diabolically well-packaged, highly readable screed ostensibly about the art of obsessive parenting. In truth, Ms. Chuas memoir is about one little narcissists book-length search for happiness. And for all its quotable outbursts from Mama Grisly (the nickname was inevitable), it will gratify the same people who made a hit out of the granola-hearted Eat, Pray, Love.

title: Mayor Promises a Plan for Fewer Restaurant Fines
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced a reduction in the fines that restaurateurs are likely to encounter while navigating the citys new letter-grade sanitary inspection system.

title: What Becomes of the Cars of Deposed Leaders?
description: The historical record shows that despotic heads of state with exotic-car fetishes generally meet ignominious ends. But after the fall, where do their cars go?

title: France Seeks More Open Commodity Markets Among G-20
description: PARIS  Rising prices for basic commodities could derail the fragile economic recovery by pushing up inflation in developed countries and stoking social tensions in developing ones. But could the recent escalation in energy and food prices actually be a boon to the world economy by leading to greater security of supply, better regulation and more transparent pricing?

title: Just One Look | Proenza Schouler Pre-Fall Collection
description: The Pre-Fall Collections, being shown in New York over the next several weeks, arrive in stores in May to fill the gap between bikinis and furs.Pattern boldness, a recurring theme of the pre-fall collections, gets taken to a whole new level at Proenza Schouler. Continuing to play fast and luxe with collegiate staples, Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez turned out chunky, eye-scorching, Peruvian-inspired knits as well as knee-length shorts, blouses and dresses in vibrant ikat and tribal prints. And yes, they are meant to be mixed and matched.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: Goldmans Golden Elite: Theo Francis of Footnoted.com, who helped DealBook crunch data on Goldman Sachs partnership, has more on the firms curious hybrid.  Footnoted.com

title: How to Make Your iPhone Gently Weep
description: Verizons announcement that it will begin offering the iPhone next month has left a lot of Android users wondering whether they, too, should jump on the Apple bandwagon.

title: Podcast: Nadal Aims for History
The Pros and Cons of Genetic Data: Debating Personal DNA Testing
description: Overview  | What is personal DNA testing and how does it work? Why are some doctors and health professionals concerned over the growing availability of these tests for consumers? In this lesson, students review current technologies for DNA testing. They explore the reliability of these tests and debate the medical and ethical issues surrounding personal genetic testing.

title: Balenciaga Show Draws Top Designers
description: WHAT a great coat, said Hamish Bowles, the European editor-at-large of Vogue magazine, to Mary Ann Restivo, a designer of fine American sportswear for nearly five decades.

title: From Hedge Fund Star, a Plea to Help Feed the Hungry
description: Billionaire hedge fund managers are parking some of their money in a different sort of bank: the Community Food Bank of New Jersey.

title: Full Speed Ahead on Deepwater Drilling
description: The ink is barely dry on the White House commissions investigative report into the Deepwater Horizon accident in the Gulf of Mexico pointing to industrywide deficiencies, but signs are emerging every day that deepwater drilling is expanding around the world.

title: Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother
description: This is a story about a mother, two daughters, and two dogs. Its also about Mozart and Mendelssohn, the piano and the violin, and how we made it to Carnegie Hall.

title: A Note on Aggregate Demand and Aggregate Supply
description: Just a brief note: one thing that keeps appearing in comments is the notion that because we had a bubble, in which some people were borrowing too much, the economic growth of 2000-2007 wasnt real  that it was all a figment of our imagination.

title: Nintendo Says New Device Will Take 3-D Mainstream
description: Nintendos new portable 3-D gaming system is in a category of one, said Reggie Fils-Aime, president and chief operating officer of the companys American operation, at an event in New York on Wednesday in which he laid out the details of the products introduction. But he acknowledged that even the most novel of gaming devices is now pitted against a range of competitors extending far beyond the traditional gaming world. He said that Nintendo saw the device as more than a hand-held gaming console, and stressed the importance of the devices ability to display 3-D video without the need for glasses, and its ability to function as a 3-D camera.

title: Obama Pushes Hu on Rights but Stresses Ties to China
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Wednesday gently but pointedly prodded China to make progress on human rights, but he sought to focus most of the attention during a closely watched state visit with President Hu Jintao on the expanding economic relationship between the United States and its biggest economic rival.

title: Getting a Student Rate When Youre Not a Student
description: Updated | to remove methods of misrepresentation (which we dont recommend).

title: Goldman Sachss Navel-Gazing Comes Up Short
description: The New Year is a time for reflection, so it was heartening to see Goldman Sachs come out with 63 pages of resolutions.

title: Reids Comments About Chinas President Could Make Meeting Awkward
description: Senator Harry Reids description of President Hu Jintao of China as a dictator  which he quickly withdrew could lead to some uncomfortable moments Thursday when the two are scheduled to meet on Capitol Hill.

title: Doctor Is Charged in Killing of Newborns
description: An abortion doctor who served minority and immigrant women in his clinic in Philadelphia was charged with multiple counts of murder on Wednesday in the deaths of a woman and seven newborn babies whose spinal cords had been cut with scissors, the district attorneys office said.

title: Another New Low Atop Billboard Chart
description: For a stark illustration of how record sales have changed in recent years, take a look at Billboards charts this week for albums and track downloads.

title: Eight Things to Talk About This Weekend
description: 1. Rejiggered astrology signs. The worlds worst pickup line gets needed freshening.

title: Industry Bar Hells Kitchen
description: HAS the dark, industrial vibe of Berlin come to the bright-eyed Glee-loving playground of Hells Kitchen? Thats the sense you get from Industry Bar, a 4,000-square-foot gay hangout that opened in early December and aims to translate the raw, stripped-down allure of Berghain, the legendary Berlin megaclub, into a smaller, Gaga-friendly package.

title: LivingSocial Gets Attention for Amazon Discount
description: The daily deal sites Groupon and LivingSocial say they are all about local businesses. They say they can bring mom-and-pop shops new customers in exchange for shifting their advertising budgets online.

title: Big Hair and Denim Dreams
description: Photos from the new Broadway musical Rock of Ages.

title: ReTweet | Venus as Alice
description: Follow T on Twitter

title: Times Names New Metro Editor
description: Carolyn Ryan, who helped lead The New York Times to a Pulitzer Prize for its coverage of the downfall of Eliot Spitzer when he wasgovernor of New York, has been named the papers metropolitan editor.

title: Hanging With a (Mostly Nice) Don Rickles
description: SAN FRANCISCO The Bagger has left behind the sunshine and sweet rides of Los Angeles and is spending a few days around the sunshine and sweet bicycles of San Francisco, visiting the Pixar campus for lunch, which we imagine will be served by elves and talking animals, or at least marketing tie-ins.

title: States Weigh Cuts in Hollywood Subsidies
description: LOS ANGELES  Preparing to deliver his first State of the State address last week, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey was looking at a $10.5 billion budget gap, a collapsing pension fund and a probable cut in Medicaid spending.

title: Cameron Seeks Vast Changes in Englands Health Service
description: LONDON  Prime Minister David Cameron on Wednesday proposed a radical reorganization of Englands health care system, introducing legislation that would hand responsibility for most of the countrys health budget to its 42,000 general practitioners and, his political opponents say, open the door to private competition that could threaten the foundations of socialized care.

title: TimesCast | January 19, 2011
description: President Obama appeals to President Hu Jintao of China; David Herszenhorn answers reader questions about the House vote to repeal the health care law; and a look at "American Idol."

title: More on Moving
description: A middle-aged son and his mother  she in her late 80s, eager for life but tired of driving and cooking and feeling isolated  find a sun-drenched studio unit in a beautiful, service-laden independent- and assisted-living facility. Theyre both thrilled and relieved, until a couple of weeks before move-in day, at which point the mother suddenly balks.

title: Inside Look at Obamas Economic Team
description: My colleague Peter Baker has delved into the world of economic policy-making in President Obamas White House for an article this Sunday in The New York Times Magazine.

title: Parity? The N.B.A. Already Has It
description: With the N.B.A.s collective bargaining agreement set to expire in the summer, negotiations for a new one are not going very well.

title: Joan Rivers Says Palin Joke Cost Her Fox News Booking
description: 5:07 p.m. | Updated

title: Just Tell Them, Its Mugler
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#709", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: E.U. Closes Emissions Trading System After Thefts
description: BRUSSELS  The European Commission suspended trading in greenhouse gas emissions permits on Wednesday for at least a week after the theft of permits worth millions of euros via online attacks.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 19
description: The day in sports included surfing in South Africa, golf in Abu Dhabi and tennis at the Australian Open.

title: A Court Rules Dad Is Too Strict
description: I promise (well, I hope . . .) this will be the last mention of Amy Chua and Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother, at least for a while. But in light of the debate the book has caused over how strict is too strict, a bit of news out of Australia. A father of three has been told by the Federal Magistrates Court in Melbourne that he was too rigid and obsessive in his parenting, according to The Herald Sun newspaper. Among his methods: requiring them to write reports on their daily activities, do extra homework above their grade level and read to him nightly over the phone.

title: Untangling the Myths About Attention Disorder
description: As recently as 2002, an international group of leading neuroscientists found it necessary to publish a statement arguing passionately that attention deficit hyperactivity disorder was a real condition.

title: Support for Belarus Theater Troupe Includes Rally, Benefits and a Chicago Engagement
description: On December 19, a presidential election in Belarus that international observers said was fraudulent sent protesters into the streets, including members of the Belarus Free Theater. The troupe managed to evade the official repression that put down the protests and leave their country, and after a widely-praised two-week run at the Under the Radar alternative theater festival, they have remained in New York, where on Wednesday, to mark one month since the questionable vote and crackdown, they led another protest, this one outside the Belarussian mission to the United Nations.

title: Newly Released Books
description: The publishing industry has had its share of woes, but writing books, apparently, has not lost its allure. This month a television producer, a short-story writer, a film critic and a screenwriter whose first draft was her journal all deliver their debut novels. Bradford Morrow has been at it longer, writing both fiction and poetry. And then theres Alice Hoffman, who clocks in with her 28th (!) work of fiction.

title: For New Social Networks, Sharing Can Be More Focused
description: With Facebooks membership approaching 600 million, and more features and apps continually being added to the site, it sometimes seems as if its the only social network around. But its not the only one, even if its dominant. Specialized networks are catching on with users who prefer a more focused way to share photos, videos or music, or who simply dont want everyone on Facebook looking at their pictures.

title: Year At War: Combat
description: An update in our yearlong series on the First Battalion, 87th Infantry during its deployment to Afghanistan.

title: City Ballet Returns
description: New York City Ballet opened its winter season on Tuesday at the David H. Koch Theater.

title: BP Used Boutique Firm as Adviser on Partnership With Rosneft
description: LONDON  In the energy business, companies usually think big. But for a cross-border, multibillion-dollar deal, BP went small, selecting a little-known boutique firm as its sole adviser.

title: Giffords to Move to Rehabilitation
description: TUCSON  Representative Gabrielle Giffords, who survived a gunshot through her head on Jan. 8, is likely to leave a hospital here on Friday and move to the TIRR Memorial Hermann rehabilitation hospital in Houston to continue her recovery, a spokesman for Ms. Giffords said Wednesday.

title: Barnes & Noble Fires Executives
description: Barnes & Noble dismissed several executives on Wednesday, including Robert Wietrak, the director of merchandising, a longtime employee who was responsible for important book-buying decisions for the company.

title: Fate of Connecticut High Schools Joe Turner May Be Decided Wednesday Night
description: Does August Wilsons play Joe Turners Come and Gone pose too great a burden for high schools to perform because its characters use the word nigger in conversation?

title: Pictures of The Day: Washington and Elsewhere
description: Pictures from Washington, Sudan, Tunisia and Nepal.

title: Scorecard | Umit Benan Wins!
description: 2011 marks the 90th anniversary since a Florentine craftsman by the name of Guccio Gucci founded a small leather goods house, so Scorecard thinks it seems somehow fitting that alongside the labels current creative director, Frida Gianinni, designers were casting a long glance back on Monday. Though money may never sleep, with his sly references to American Pyscho, the inaugural Who Is on Next? winner Umit Benan provided a helpful gloss on the proceedings: sometimes the past teaches us how to move on.

title: Ross IAC Aims to Go Public This Year
description: 9:01 a.m. | Updated The International Automotive Components Group, the big auto-parts maker owned by Wilbur L. Ross Jr., plans to hold an initial public offering later this year, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Wednesday.

title: New-Music Champion Inches Toward the Standard Repertory
description: Miranda Cuckson has quickly become one of a handful of go-to musicians for chamber groups that need a violinist who can play thorny works with undeniable musicality. And though she rarely performs standard repertory, when she does  in the Argento Ensembles chamber version of Schumanns Second Symphony last season, for example  she plays with such beauty and assurance that you wish she would do it more often.

title: Analysis: How Federer Survived Simon
description: After coming back from a two set deficit to force a fifth set, Gilles Simon looked brazenly confident as he outhit Roger Federer from the baseline. He kept the ball deep to Federers backhand, and when Federer changed direction and went down the line, the quick Simon laced into a forehand cross-court that moved Federer hard to his right, and also opened up the backhand side again. He had the tactical hook deep in Federers side, and the momentum was on his side.

title: Free Money and Endangered Parrots
description: The wild parrots of Pelham Bay Park were rendered homeless when the parks department took down the light poles where they nest, but theyre hanging in there. [Brooklyn Parrots]

title: Drug-Fueled Rants From a 50s Film
description: Lets get this right out of the way: The full title of Daniel Fishs new work is Tom Ryan Thinks Hes James Mason Starring in a Movie by Nicholas Ray in Which a Mans Illness Provides an Escape From the Pain, Pressure and Loneliness of Trying to Be the Ultimate American Father, Only to Drive Him Further Into the More Thrilling Though Possibly Lonelier Roles of Addict and Misunderstood Visionary. Sounds kind of like fun, doesnt it? And youd think a 53-word title might say it all, right? Well, it isnt always, and it doesnt, quite.

title: In Austria, an Artist's Home in a Police Station
description: Nives Widauer spent five months renovating her apartment in a 19th-century Austrian mansion that now houses the police.

title: Tribes Meet: The Female and Male
description: If you have seen a movie by Judd Apatow or Todd Phillips  which is to say, if you have so much as swiped a pinky across the frosting of popular culture this millennium  then you know that there is an oceanic divide between the sexes, and that it has nothing to do with glass ceilings, wage gaps or other benighted concerns of the 1970s. What keeps men and women at war is male laziness, stupidity, buffoonery, disorganization, bad taste and fantasy baseball. Women are competent, dull models of efficiency  like human versions of Staples. The model of marriage portrayed is pure old-school sitcom as though the institution had evolved not a millimeter since The Honeymooners.

title: Your Headline Here
description: Heres your chance to play editor. This afternoon, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg delivered his State of the City speech, 6,796 words of proposals, observations and exhortations  see below. The media and others are doing their spin thing. But if it were up to you, what headline would you put on the mayors speech? Keep it clean, please. And thanks.

title: Headphones That Produce Quiet and Side Effects
description: Q. I want to get some noise-reducing headphones to block out the background sounds around me, but Ive read that these can cause a queasy feeling. Is this true?

title: The Etiquette of State Dinner Invitations
description: 9:22 p.m. | Updated The official guest list for Wednesdays state dinner is out, offering a peek at those invited and their spouses.

title: On Our Radar: Senator Seeks Ban on Frankenfish
description: An Alaskan senator plans to reintroduce a bill to ban the sale of genetically altered fish  which he calls Frankenfish  for human consumption. Such fish threaten wild stocks and their habitat, endanger food safety and could harm the livelihoods of Alaska wild-salmon fishermen, he says. [The Hill]

title: More Than a Place to Practice
description: The Jets' new $75 million, 27-acre training facility is both swankier than the old one and better able to meet the needs of a 21st-century sports team.

title: Criminals, Addicts, Misfits: Thats Entertainment
description: Emily, a slate-eyed 17-year-old with an insolent charisma and an attitude problem, has her dark moments: the time she got so drunk she passed out in a driveway and a car nearly ran her over, the times she hits her mother, the time she put her fist through a double-paned window. Shes spent a couple of months in juvenile hall.

title: Europeans Suspend Trade in Emissions Permits
description: The European Commission has halted trading in greenhouse gas emissions permits after the theft of permits in online attacks.

title: Tunisia Casts Shadow Over Arab Summit Meeting
description: CAIRO  Arab leaders, meeting for the first time since the public revolt in Tunisia toppled its autocratic president, heard one of their own, a consummate insider, warn that the Arab soul is broken by poverty, unemployment and general recession.

title: Addicted and Adrift in Post-Soviet World
description: The title of Levan Koguashvilis promising debut feature, Street Days, is a reference to the difficult period in his native Georgia after the collapse of the Soviet Union. In his portrayal its a time of middle-aged men wandering the streets looking for drugs and angry women trying to keep the social fabric from completely unraveling.

title: Chinese President Receives Regal Welcome
description: President Obama welcomed President Hu Jintao of China to the White House on Wednesday with a display of pomp and circumstance.

title: Oscar Nominations? Let the Guesses Begin
description: Judd Apatow is scouring Twitter for material, Ricky Gervais has self-inflicted early retirement: right now the producers of the Oscar telecast are probably grateful they did not hire comedians to host their show. (They hired wholly untested actors, James Franco and Anne Hathaway.)

title: Milan Mens Fashion: A Low-Key Approach
description: Suddenly, blending into a crowd looks pretty desirable.

title: Designers Anonymous
description: Milan

title: Winds of Jazz: Energies of a Cyclone and an Ebullient Breeze
description: Jazz drumming is a proudly adaptive discipline, consistent in its aims but malleable in its form. Jeff (Tain) Watts and Lewis Nash have been two of its guiding forces over the last 25 years or so, each standing for a particular kind of excellence. By happenstance, theyre both headlining in New York this week. Their opening sets on Tuesday night, which I caught one after the other, created a handy opportunity for comparison, highlighting the clear distinctions  tactical, foundational, maybe ideological  between them.

title: Trailer: 'These Amazing Shadows'
description: The trailer for a documentary premiering at Sundance and on demand about films selected for preservation by the National Film Registry.

title: Rurbanisation
description: Introducing urban conveniences, and opportunities, to rural areas in an attempt to stem migration.

title: Dr. Smiths Back Room
description: My family has deep roots in New York City, and a number of my relatives kept written accounts of the events and people around them. My great-grand-aunt Maritcha Lyons, for example, reminisced in her memoir about a particularly popular meeting place for politically active blacks in the 19th century. The store had a back room which was a rallying center, she wrote, it had a library and in there were held discussions and debates on all the topics of the day. The visitors had public spirit which had much to do in bringing about a more favorable state of things affecting the colored people of the state.

title: Italian Parliament Slows Berlusconi Inquiry
description: An Italian Parliamentary panel said on Wednesday that it would wait until next week to consider a request from prosecutors in Milan for permission to search the office of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconis accountant.

title: 'American Idol' Remade
description: David Carr and Brian Stelter discuss the upcoming 10th season of "American Idol," which includes Steven Tyler and Jennifer Lopez as new judges.

title: Nice-Guy Bloggers Neednt Finish Last
description: THE glittery party for the Hollywood jeweler Lorraine Schwartz last November drew a small mob of carat-starved celebrities to Lavo in Midtown. Kim Kardashian held court by the dance floor, dressed in black velvet and satin. Beyonc Knowles arrived two hours late and spent the evening behind a cordon of bodyguards. Blake Lively, resplendent in Versace, sat quietly in the corner.

title: Pondering an Idol Overhaul
description: Related: Smugs Out, Talents in at Idol

title: Convertible Clothing Is a New Twist for the Cost-Conscious
description: CALVIN TRAN was darting around his shop on Mott Street the other day, fiddling with a fan-shaped slice of wool. You can wear this as a poncho, a dress, a kimono or a hooded cape, Mr. Tran said as he pulled the fabric over his head. With a high-pitched laugh, he added, See, when you go to Iraq, it becomes a burqa!

title: House Votes for Repeal of Health Law in Symbolic Act
description: WASHINGTON  The House voted Wednesday to repeal the Democrats landmark health care overhaul, marking what the new Republican majority in the chamber hailed as the fulfillment of a campaign promise and the start of an all-out effort to dismantle President Obamas signature domestic policy achievement.

title: From the Lederer Memorial, a Look at a Long-Card Oddity
description: All the top British players hope to be invited to the Lederer Memorial Trophy, named for Richard and Tony Lederer, father and son. Over the final weekend of October eight teams competed in the event. The main difference from previous years was the lack of foreign teams.

title: Reintroductions on a Winters Eve
description: Life in New York just is more complete when New York City Ballet is in residence and dancing Balanchine. Let me add a few immediate qualifications to that. Like any of the companys followers, I have my grumbles: I certainly dont mean to imply that the company should dance nothing but Balanchine; yes, I sometimes see  mainly outside New York  other companies that dance Balanchine as well or better; and there are many other forms of dance and art that I crave. But in its wealth of Balanchine repertory City Ballet has an unmatchable asset, and to renew acquaintance with these ballets can be among the great and regular joys of living in New York.

title: Kelly Interview Ratings
description: ABCs interview with the astronaut Capt. Mark E. Kelly, the husband of Representative Gabrielle Giffords, generated only modest interest in prime time on Tuesday: according to Nielsens estimates 6.2 million viewers tuned in to the special edition of 20/20 at 10 p.m. In contrast, The Good Wife on CBS led the hour with 11.3 million viewers, and CBSs NCIS won the night with 21 million at 8. Earlier, excerpts from the interview did provide a boost to ABCs World News With Diane Sawyer, which attracted an average of 9.1 million viewers, the newscasts largest audience in almost a year. CBS led the night over all, also garnering 17.3 million at 9 for NCIS: Los Angeles. NBC placed second with The Biggest Loser, from 8 to 10 (8.2 million), followed by Parenthood (5.6 million). ABC, in third, averaged 5.7 million at 8 and 9 with No Ordinary Family and V, while Fox ranked fourth with a rerun of Glee at 8 (4.4 million) and Million Dollar Money Drop at 9 (5.3 million).

title: Makeup From Japan to Your Mailbox
description: YOUNG women in Japan have long used makeup to transform themselves into plastic dolls or anime princesses come to life. Brands homegrown there, like Mellish and Dolly Wink, make the spidery fake eyelashes, doe-eyed contact lenses and eyelid tape that help them with this metamorphosis.

title: Beauty Spots
description: ITS mid-January and for some of us, pastiness is starting to seem like a permanent condition. Fortunately there are some affordable self-tanning options. They might not rival the experience of sitting on a Caribbean beach, but they do avoid the unpleasant side effects of sun exposure.

title: Sweet, Dreamy Nibbles From Band With Teeth
description: There was Cullen Omori  in a shapeless sweater, possibly in need of a sandwich, hair swallowing his face  holding his guitar tenderly onstage Tuesday night at the Glasslands Gallery in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Behind him his band, Smith Westerns, was playing with a straight face, possibly a bit tentatively. All of the emotion fell to Mr. Omori, then, who was happy to be a ham, dreaming about love that wont ever end, holding notes until they decayed.

title: In Twist, Jeff Koons Claims Rights to Balloon Dogs
description: The artist Jeff Koons has developed a distinctive style, and made a lot of money, by appropriating pop-culture imagery and mass-produced objects, from inflatable toys to vacuum cleaners and kitschy greeting cards. Over his three-decade career that approach, while helping to make him famous, has also brought accusations of exploiting other peoples copyrighted images. He has been sued for copyright violation four times, losing three of the cases.

title: Kris Jenkins Dreaming of Jets-Packers Super Bowl
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Kris Jenkins spent all but one game this season on injured reserve. He will not play in the A.F.C. championship game Sunday against Pittsburgh. Nor will he play in the Super Bowl should the Jets advance that far for the second time in franchise history.

title: A Primer for the Wholesome, Happy Home
description: WALKING down a residential street in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., several years ago, I was stopped in my tracks by the beauty of a backyard clothesline hung with well-made, well-loved cotton things: embroidered pillowcases, hand-sewn aprons, cloth napkins and unstained tablecloths, secured on a white rope with wooden clothespins, waving before a wall of pine trees. It actually brought tears to my eyes; it was like stumbling on a time capsule full of lost femininity  all that stuff that was abandoned in the 1970s for being too contaminated by patriarchal social engineering. But there was something so careful, patient, constructive and good about that beautiful laundry. It was a genuine example of homemaking as a verb  a creative act that reifies the idea of home.

title: Nets End Their Bid to Obtain Anthony
description: NEWARK  The Nets spent months tying up phone lines from here to Russia, discussing possibilities with the teams majority owner, Mikhail D. Prokhorov, by which they could obtain the Denver Nuggets Carmelo Anthony.

title: Mike Pelfrey to Start for Mets on Opening Day
description: With Johan Santana, the Mets ace, expected to begin the season on the disabled list after having shoulder surgery, Mike Pelfrey will start on opening day and become the de facto ace of a rotation rife with uncertainty.

title: Harry & David Turns to Advisers for Debt Help
description: 8:50 a.m. | Updated Harry & David unwrapped an unwelcome bit of news on Tuesday: With sales falling sharply over the past year, the company has hired restructuring advisers to help reorganize its strained finances.

title: Tycoons Case Hurt Russia, Adviser Says
description: MOSCOW  A senior economic adviser to President Dmitri A. Medvedev acknowledged Wednesday that the criminal conviction of the former oil tycoon Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky last month had harmed Russias image and ability to attract foreign investment.

title: Brooklyn Bowl Fried Chicken
description: Vegetable oil, for frying

title: Cajun Seasoning
description: cup kosher salt

title: Cooking With Dexter: Tastes Like Chicken
description: During the opening salvos of the Christmas blizzard that would buckle New York City, I drove to the nearest decent butcher to buy beef for a classic French daube. On a night when swirling snow raked against the windows, who could resist egg noodles topped with melting meat, carrots and onions? A 3-year-old, thats who. When I filled his bowl with noodles, Elliot, my younger son, called out with joy, Psghetti! And then, as I ladled on the stew, he rebelled.

title: Shopping With Suzanne Tick
description: The New York textile designer shopped for woven goods, hoping to find unusual techniques and creations.

title: Antique Frames on Exhibit
description: One hundred years ago, frames were considered as important as the artwork they contained. Frame makers of the Arts and Crafts period became interested in frames as an art form, even signing them, said Lisa Wyer.

title: Secret Spaces, Far From Strife
description: I WAS 9, my brother, Jeb, was 8, and maybe if wed been born in a city we would not have started building treehouses and forts, igloos and tepees, even digging a hole in the ground that we covered with thick branches of pine, oak and maple. Or maybe if our mother and father did not fight most every night, their yelling rising up the stairwell like some poisonous vapor to us and our two sisters, Jeb and I would not have gone looking for the scrap lumber we found under the closed summer camps near our rented house in southern New Hampshire  two-by-fours and two-by-sixes, warped plywood and long planks of rough spruce.

title: The Light Bulb as Art Form
description: In his paintings and limited-edition toys, Brian Donnelly, a Brooklyn-based artist who goes by the name of KAWS, frequently riffs on cartoon characters like Mickey Mouse, SpongeBob SquarePants, and the Simpsons, crossing out their eyes with Xs. For his latest project, Mr. Donnelly set his sights on a more utilitarian target: the incandescent bulb.

title: Home Tech: Five Universal Remotes
description: As electronic gadgets have grown, so has the desire to consolidate their functions in one all-purpose remote.

title: Sales at the Future Perfect, Gracious Home and Others
description: The Props for Today sale continues through Saturday (a Le Corbusier black leather lounge chair, originally $1,400, is $413; an antique leather-top desk with brass trim, regularly $2,900, is $750); 330 West 34th Street (Ninth Avenue), propsfortoday.com.

title: The Love Affair With the Fireplace Cools
description: WINSOME BROWN, an actress and writer, and her husband, Claude Arpels, own an enviable apartment in TriBeCa worthy of a spread in an interior design magazine. The apartment  which is, in fact, being considered for an issue of Elle Dcor  has maple floors, casement windows and all the character one would expect to find in a building that was once a factory.

title: A Bathroom in a Box
description: Designing a bathroom takes an inordinate amount of time, said John Crowley, a designer in Berkeley, Calif. You have to get different pieces from a lot of different vendors.

title: A Growth Chart With a Decorative Touch
description: Like many parents, Athena Calderone thought a growth chart would make a nice decorative addition to her sons room. But Ms. Calderone, an interior designer based in Brooklyn, also wanted a piece that would work in her Dumbo loft, a modern space made less austere with organic wood. Jivans room is visible from the entire space, she said, referring to her son. I wanted what was happening in the living room to flow throughout, not get dumbed down in his room.

title: Woven Goods
description: FOR Suzanne Tick, a New York textile designer, there are few things more enjoyable than weaving. The best part of my day is when everybody has left the studio, and I can go downstairs and weave for the evening, said Ms. Tick, who has a loom in the basement of her East Village town house, where she lives and works with her life and business partner, Terry Mowers.

title: Joan and Melissa Rivers
description: As happens with even the shyest and most self-effacing grandparents, the comedian Joan Rivers decided the distance separating her in New York from her daughter, Melissa, and grandson, Cooper, in Los Angeles was too great. So last summer she moved in with them, taking along copious luggage and an equally copious reality TV camera crew.

title: Universal Remotes: Not Remotely Possible
description: THE universal remote control is one of the modern worlds great ideas, right up there with the automatic dishwasher, Wi-Fi and flush toilets. The theory behind this gadget is simple and sublime: In an increasingly automated and connected world, wouldnt it be wonderful if we could manage all our blinking machines from a single super controller?

title: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
description: Pictures from Washington, Sudan, Tunisia and Nepal.

title: A Liberated Joao Silva Takes In the Sights
description: Can a photojournalist who has been to some of the more remote corners on earth find happiness on the National Mall and at a Mexican restaurant on Seventh Street N.W.?

title: An Apartment in a Viennese Police Station
description: VIENNA

title: Shopping Snapshots for Jan. 20
description: Bow ties are making a comeback in clip-ons and tie-ons; four questions for Jeff Goldstein, owner of Blue & Cream; and other items.

title: Scouting Report
description: SALES

title: The Eve of War: Four Days of Diplomacy
description: The history of the Persian Gulf War has been well documented, but the release of declassified transcripts of Saddam Husseins deliberations on Feb. 24, 1991, the first day of the land war, provide gripping new details.

title: University of Texas Will Create Its Own Sports Network With ESPN
description: The University of Texas announced Wednesday the creation of a statewide sports network that will carry games plus academic, cultural and arts programming. The unnamed channel will focus on the Longhorns, unlike the Big Ten Network, which has a broader, conference-wide focus.

title: Rethinking the Mugler Man
description: Its been more than 20 years since I squeezed my way into a Thierry Mugler show, enduring the high-handed manner of the house publicists, and tonight I suppose I was a little wistful for the groupies and the attitude when I arrived for the debut showing of Nicola Formichetti, the new creative director of Mugler. There was a small throng of young people at the door, but not much greater than youd find outside most shows in Paris, and the PR handlers moved the guests along and offered them glasses of Champagne. Everything is professional now. Shows start on time.

title: U.S. Officials Reportedly Said WikiLeaks Revelations Were Not Damaging
description: According to a Congressional aide who spoke to Reuters, State Department officials concluded late last year that the publication of leaked United States diplomatic cables obtained by WikiLeaks was embarrassing but not damaging.

title: Softball Players Choose Pro League Over U.S. Team
description: As a member of the United States softball team, Jessica Mendoza has competed against the best players in the world, winning a gold medal at the Athens Olympics in 2004 and a silver medal in Beijing in 2008.

title: Mayor Focuses on Small Things in His State of City Speech
description: There was barely any nod to Manhattan. Nor any mention of the economic virtues of Wall Street, or much talk about national politics.

title: Hussein Wanted Soviets to Head Off U.S. in 1991
description: WASHINGTON  As the American-led ground offensive in the first war with Iraq got under way on Feb. 24, 1991, Saddam Hussein directed his frustration at an unlikely target: the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Mr. Hussein had dispatched his foreign minister to Moscow in an 11th-hour bid to head off a ground war.

title: State Dinner Guests
description: The following is a list of guests expected at the presidents State Dinner honoring President Hu Jintao of China, as provided by the White House:

title: Saddam Hussein Sought Soviet Support Before 91 Gulf War
description: Michael R. Gordon reports on the release of three extraordinarily candid transcripts of conversations that Saddam Hussein had with his advisers in the early days of the 1991 Persian Gulf war.

title: Plan Offered to Overhaul Discipline of Teachers
description: Teachers accused of misconduct should have their cases decided within a speedy 100 days by a special examiner and not be cast into an interminable limbo of waiting, said Kenneth R. Feinberg, the arbitration expert, who investigated teacher discipline at the request of the American Federation of Teachers.

title: U.S. Sees Success in Immigration Program for Haitians
description: A year after the devastating earthquake in Haiti, the American government has received more than 53,000 applications from Haitians seeking temporary legal status in the United States, and it has approved the vast majority, a top immigration official said Wednesday.

title: Pilgrims Progress
description: Im one of the lucky ones.

title: Michelle Obamas Signals in a Red Dress
description: Michelle Obamas gown for the state dinner for President Hu Jintao of China sent out a number of signals. Fortunately, they were not mixed.

title: Venture Capitalists Desperate Search
Business Leaders Make Cut at State Dinner With Hu
description: WASHINGTON  Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter made the cut. So did Bill Clinton and his wife, the secretary of state. The heads of Microsoft, Boeing, Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase and Walt Disney were on the list. So were the singer Barbra Streisand, the ice skater Michelle Kwan, the cellist Yo-Yo Ma, the architect Maya Lin and the fashion designer Vera Wang.

title: Grading New York Restaurants: Whats in an A?
description: Late last summer, the New York City Department of Health began releasing the results of new restaurant inspections, and assigning letter grades based on compliance with the city Health Code and the state Sanitary Code. The letter grades have become ubiquitous in restaurant windows throughout the city. But what do they really mean, and how seriously should we take them in choosing a place to eat?

title: Advocacy Group Says Justices May Have Conflict in Campaign Finance Cases
description: WASHINGTON  When the conservative financier Charles Koch sent out invitations for a political retreat in Palm Springs later this month, he highlighted past appearances at the gathering of notable leaders like Justices Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas of the Supreme Court.

title: Smile When You Say It: Same Old Jets
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.

title: Restaurants Reach Out to Customers With Social Media
description: RESTAURANTS and bars thrive on repeat business, but customers increasingly expect more than just good service, food and drinks. They want to be engaged and entertained, and some food establishments are turning to location-based social media to help keep customers happy and loyal.

title: As the Oscars Approach, New Releases Are Few
description: LOS ANGELES  Hollywoods message for moviegoers this month: Eat your peas, or no dessert.

title: An Evening of Russian Candor
description: NEWARK

title: Swimming With Sharks, to Benefit Research
description: At the University of Miami, where he majored in biology, Hans Walters did research on lemon sharks that included swimming with them. After a stint as a singer in a rock band, Z Toyz, Mr. Walters returned to biology when the Wildlife Conservation Society hired him in the 1980s as a bird keeper at the Bronx Zoo. He is now an animal department supervisor and a shark researcher at the societys New York Aquarium, on Coney Island.

title: Solar Firms Frustrated by Permits
description: Ken Button, the president of Verengo Solar Plus, a residential solar panel installer in Orange, Calif., says his company  and his industry  are being strangled by municipal red tape.

title: Gun Fans Gather in Las Vegas
description: The nations largest gun trade show began, in the wake of a shooting of an Arizona congresswoman and others in Tuscon that has resurrected calls for more gun control.

title: One Body Found on Long Island Beach Is Identified
description: One of the four women whose bodies were found on a Long Island barrier beach last month was identified by Suffolk County officials on Wednesday as Megan Waterman, a Maine woman who had been missing since the spring.

title: 9/11 Firefighters to Attend Funeral of Woman They Once Saved
description: The cloth interior of her blue steel coffin will be custom-embroidered with the image of a firefighter in full gear, walking hand in hand with an angel. Her prayer cards will display her smiling face on one side and the words of the Firemans Prayer on the other.

title: Lesson Learned, the Bears Tice Is Teaching Again
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill.  Mike Tice, fired as Minnesota Vikings head coach five years ago with the team in tumult, has no problem tracing the arc of his career.

title: In an Ocean of Firearms, Tucson Is Far Away
description: LAS VEGAS  In a sea of rifles, handguns, knives and ammunition, thousands of gun enthusiasts gathered here Wednesday for the annual Shot Show, the nations largest gun trade show, where the conventions sponsors decried gun laws and said there was something else to blame for the Jan. 8 deadly shooting rampage in Tucson: the mental health system.

title: For 2 Senators, Similar Paths Up and Down
description: You can begin the list of similarities with the way that both men achieved the kind of longevity that approximated those long-tenured Southern senators of old  Christopher J. Dodd, the longest-serving senator in Connecticut history, first elected in 1980, Joseph I. Lieberman in 1988.

title: Bloggingheads: Who's Next After Tunisia?
description: Shadi Hamid, left, of The Brookings Institution and Issandr El Amrani of The Arabist debate whether other Arab regimes may collapse.

title: A Racy Show With Teenagers Steps Back From a Boundary
description: MTV executives have a new hit drama on their hands, featuring the sexual and drug-fueled exploits of misfit teenagers. They also have something else  a fear that coming episodes of the show may break the law.

title: U.S. Prepares to Lift Ban on Guantnamo Cases
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is preparing to increase the use of military commissions to prosecute Guantnamo detainees, an acknowledgment that the prison in Cuba remains open for business after Congress imposed steep new impediments to closing the facility.

title: Newark Schools Chief, Whose Contract Wasnt Renewed, Will Step Down Next Month
description: Newarks school superintendent, Clifford B. Janey, who is to step down early next month, said Wednesday that he wanted to pursue other career opportunities without having to worry about giving less attention to his duties.

title: Higher Taxes Wouldnt End Some Deficits
description: As state governments struggle with the fiscal damage caused by the recession, an income tax increase has become a rarely used remedy.

title: City Opens Inquiry on Grading Practices at a Top-Scoring Bronx School
description: When report card grades were released in the fall for the citys 455 high schools, the highest score went to a small school in a down-and-out section of the Bronx called Theater Arts Production Company School.

title: As Lockout Looms, N.F.L. Players Go to Washington
description: WASHINGTON  With a potential lockout just weeks away, more than a dozen former and current N.F.L. players donned pinstripe suits Wednesday and took their talking points to Capitol Hill, where they told lawmakers their side of an increasingly acrimonious labor dispute.

title: What I Learned From Sargent Shriver
description: The Irish are still mesmerized by the mythical place that is America, but in the 60s our fascination got out of hand. I was not old enough to remember the sacrifices of the great generation who saved Europe in the Second World War, or to quite comprehend what was going on in Vietnam. But what I do remember, and cannot forget, is watching a man walk on the moon in 1969 and thinking here is a nation that finds joy in the impossible.

description: There is a special bond between Maria Espada and her teenage daughter, Destiny Sanchez.

description: On Wednesday, Senator Joe Lieberman of Connecticut announced that he wont be a candidate for re-election in 2012. Normally people look particularly appealing when theyre promising to go away. This time, not so much.

title: The Last Christians of Habbaniya Cece
description: In a small Iraqi town in a province with a recent history of sectarian violence, the last Christian man keeps his churchs doors open.

title: Last Christians Ponder Leaving a Hometown in Iraq
description: HABBANIYA CECE, Iraq  The last Christian man in town goes to church each morning to clean the building and to remember the past. Romel Hawal, 48, was born in this town in Anbar Province back when most of the population was Christian. Now, he said, his 11-year-old son knows no other Christians and has no memory of attending a church service.

title: The Rise of Chinese Cheneys

title: Soriano on Board; Cashman, Too
description: Rafael Soriano wore a light gray suit, held up his pinstriped No. 29 jersey and shook hands with Manager Joe Girardi during his introduction on Wednesday as a new, and lavishly paid, member of the Yankees bullpen.

title: Subtle Signs of Progress in U.S.-China Relations
description: WASHINGTON  The Chinese have striven to lend this weeks state visit by President Hu Jintao the aura of a fresh start, from feel-good displays of friendly Chinese in Times Square to a Washington newspaper insert that declared on Wednesday that his meeting with President Obama could open a new chapter in a relationship between the worlds two economic giants that had been troubled.

title: Woman Abducted as Infant in 1987 Meets Family
description: It was an abduction that made headlines and stunned the authorities: A 3-week-old infant, taken to a Manhattan hospital in August 1987 for treatment of a fever, was snatched by a woman dressed in nurses clothes and never heard from again.

title: Beyond the Happy Visuals
description: A few Congressional Democrats and Republicans will be sitting next to each other on Tuesday night during the State of the Union address, straying from their glowering bunkers on opposite sides of the aisle. Its a lovely idea, intended to show that ideological divisions do not require personal rancor. But it is essentially a gesture to the cameras, and it should not obscure what remains a wide and fundamentally deep aisle between the parties.

description: The Rangers had to take the bad with the good from Wednesday nights 7-0 rout of the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden.

title: The Last Thing Haiti Needs
description: Haitis troubles turned even more surreal over the weekend when the former dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier, known as Baby Doc, showed up in Port-au-Prince after nearly 25 years of exile. After two nights in a hotel, surrounded by sycophants and unanswered questions, Mr. Duvalier was taken into custody for four hours on Tuesday and then officially charged with embezzlement and corruption  an encouraging development, although theft was only one of his many crimes.

title: Missing Mandate From Rome

description: BEIJING  Chinas economy continued to accelerate in the fourth quarter, as inflation is easing only slightly, showing that a series of cooling measures by Beijing over the last year have had only a limited effect.

title: Israeli Soldier Discharged Over Killing of Unarmed Palestinian
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli military announced Wednesday night that a soldiers military career had been terminated after the fatal shooting of an unarmed 65-year-old Palestinian man in his bed during an arrest last week in the West Bank city of Hebron.

title: Aristide Says He Is Ready to Return to Haiti, Too
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Days after Haitians watched an exiled dictator come home, a former president issued a statement on Wednesday that fueled rumors that he, too, was angling to return.

title: Swiss Weigh Future Role of Bunkers in the Alps
description: GSTAAD, Switzerland  The mountain didnt look quite right. Up close, its rock face was the giveaway, with its fading makeup of camouflage paint that seemed not to have been retouched since the cold war. The guard seemed out of place, too, standing sentry in his black uniform over a quiet clearing near this Swiss ski resort better known for its free-range billionaires.

title: Approaching Civility (if Perhaps Falling Short of Eloquence) in Debate
description: WASHINGTON  The Webster-Hayne debate it was not. But in the end, the floor fight over the bill to repeal the health care overhaul  predetermined both to pass the House and ultimately fail to become law  by and large demonstrated the ability of Republicans and Democrats to debate a public policy matter civilly.

title: Freaks at Yale
description: New Haven, Conn., Jan. 20, 1861

title: Cosmos: No Longer Looking for Eric
description: Fourteen years after he last kicked a ball in anger, and 16 years after his kung-fu kick (in anger, of course), Eric Cantona is back in soccer  improbably as the director of soccer for the reborn New York Cosmos.

title: Judges Take Another Look at Ex-Alabama Governors Conviction
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  Three federal appeals court judges seemed ready on Wednesday to see the convictions of former Gov. Don E. Siegelman of Alabama and the man accused of bribing him in a new light.

title: Whats Good for G.M. Is Good For Homeowners
description: We have been fully conditioned by now to expect that the rich and powerful will get the biggest slice of whatever pie is being served, while those less fortunate  and less well connected  will get the crumbs. But it still rankles when we witness time and time again how big corporations get deals the little guy can only dream about, especially when a little creative thinking could alter the status quo.

title: Anthony Spotlight Now Turns to Knicks
description: HOUSTON  The name had escaped Mike DAntonis lips before he even realized it, and he immediately regretted the subconscious slip. If there is one player who should not be mentioned in casual conversation, it is Carmelo Anthony.

title: Their Minds on Denver, Knicks Fall in Houston
description: HOUSTON  It is surely too soon to call the Knicks distracted, hopeful or in any way emotionally invested in the concept of Carmelo Anthony. All they knew Wednesday, as they reached the midpoint of a transformational season, is that another transformation could be coming.

title: Drug to Fight Melanoma Prolonged Life in Trial
description: Advanced melanoma patients taking an experimental drug aimed at a particular mutation in their tumors lived longer than patients who did not receive the drug in a decisive clinical trial, the drugs manufacturer, Roche, said Wednesday.

title: Fatal Mine Blast Was Preventable, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  The West Virginia coal mine disaster last year that killed 29 miners was a preventable accident caused by a relatively small flare-up of methane gas that touched off a huge coal dust explosion, federal mine safety officials said Wednesday.

title: Cousins Under the Skin
description: We continue to learn more about our ancestral past. With every, mostly fragmentary, addition to the physical evidence, the picture changes. The mysteries, and the fascination, seem only to keep growing.

title: Court Weighs Whether Corporations Have Personal Privacy Rights
description: WASHINGTON  The claim that corporations have personal privacy rights met with widespread skepticism on Wednesday during a lively Supreme Court argument.

title: Move to Double Capacity of a Shelter Raises Fears
description: For decades, Tests Barber Shop in Brooklyn has faced the Sumner Avenue Armory, a hulking castlelike building that towers over the modest four-story brownstones in Bedford-Stuyvesant. Through the storefront window, barbers watched the armory change from a bustling community center into a shelter for homeless men.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,426 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,447 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Ivory Coast: U.N. to Send More Peacekeepers
description: The United Nations Security Council unanimously approved sending an additional 2,000 peacekeepers to the Ivory Coast, citing the lack of security facing the more than 9,000 troops and police officers already there. So many soldiers are required to protect the Golf Hotel, home to Alassane Ouattara, the recognized president, as well as senior United Nations officials, that there are none to spare elsewhere in the country. The new troops are expected to deploy by June. Raila Odinga, Kenyas prime minister, announced after two days of meetings that the latest African attempt to resolve the crisis had failed.

title: The Vatican: Pope Names Leaders of Financial Monitor
description: Pope Benedict XVI on Wednesday appointed the president and the governing board of a new financial watchdog aimed at overseeing the Vaticans finances and helping it comply with international policies against money laundering and the financing of terrorists. Benedict announced the new agency in December and on Wednesday appointed Cardinal Attilio Nicora, left, already the Holy Sees de-facto finance minister, as its president. The four board members, all laymen, have backgrounds in accounting, law and finance.

title: Afghanistan: 18 Are Killed by Roadside Bombs
description: Thirteen civilians crammed into a motorized rickshaw were killed by a roadside bomb in eastern Paktika Province on Wednesday, according to the provincial governor, Muhibullah Samim. The rickshaw was taking the group to visit a clinic in Khoshamand District when it set off the bomb. Also on Wednesday, five border policemen were killed in the Shemolzo District of Zabul Province, close to the Pakistan border, when their vehicle struck a roadside bomb.

title: New High School Is Approved for Park Slope
description: The Panel for Educational Policy approved a plan on Wednesday night to open an offshoot of a high-performing high school in the heart of Park Slope, Brooklyn, a neighborhood where families have shunned the local high school because of its poor academic performance.

title: Bullish Blue Dogs Oppose Health Care Repeal
description: Its no surprise that Republicans, who voted unanimously against approving the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act last year, also voted unanimously today to repeal it.

title: Spider-Man Musical Adds an Airborne Finale
description: A creative hole was filled on Wednesday in the $65 million Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark with the addition of a technically ambitious finale, after seven weeks during which the show was playing for audiences with a temporary ending in place.

title: Lebanon Condemns Israeli Settlements in Resolution
description: Lebanon on Wednesday introduced a draft resolution in the Security Council condemning Israeli settlement expansion on West Bank territory occupied since 1967. No vote is expected soon because the United States criticized the resolution, arguing that the Council should not be the forum for addressing knotty Arab-Israeli issues. A veto would be awkward because the language used in the resolution, which attracted some 120 co-sponsors, echoes previous statements that Washington has endorsed condemning settlements, diplomats said.

title: Wal-Mart Shifts Strategy to Promote Healthy Foods
description: WASHINGTON  Wal-Mart, the nations largest retailer, will announce a five-year plan on Thursday to make thousands of its packaged foods lower in unhealthy salts, fats and sugars, and to drop prices on fruits and vegetables.

title: Word of the Day | sheaf
description: sheaf \shef\ noun

title: Cuomo Considers Cutting Up to 15,000 State Jobs
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is considering reducing the state workforce by up to 15,000 workers in his budget, the largest cut to the government payroll in recent years, two people briefed on the plan said Wednesday night.

title: DeRozan to Enter Dunk Contest
description: The N.B.A. will add DeMar DeRozan to the slam dunk competition, which will be held during All-Star weekend. He will assume the spot vacated by Brandon Jennings, who is returning from a fractured left foot. DeRozans selection is expected to be announced on Thursday.

title: Michael Langham, Classical Theater Director, Dies at 91
description: Michael Langham, a classical theater director who honed his craft in a Nazi prisoner-of-war camp and went on to become the artistic head of the Stratford Shakespeare Festival in Ontario, Canada, and the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis and to direct Shakespeare and Molire on Broadway, died on Saturday at his home in Kent, England. He was 91.

title: Video of Man Rescued in Brazil After Being Buried Alive in Landslides
description: Buried face-down beneath 13 feet of mud for 16 hours, Marcelo Fonseca was about to become yet another fatality in the landslides in Brazil, which have led to hundreds of deaths.

title: University of Texas Creates Network
description: The University of Texas announced Wednesday the creation of a statewide sports network to carry games as well as academic, cultural and arts programming. The unnamed channel will focus on the Longhorns, unlike the Big Ten Network, which has a broader, conference-wide focus. ESPN will own and operate the network and pay $300 million over 20 years, two-thirds of it to the university and one-third to IMG College, which already owns some of the universitys rights.

description: We recently published an update on True Body Products, a case study subject, and learned that the natural soap maker, which had 2009 sales of just $45,000, has made a lot of progress. With a new product on retailers shelves, a national distributorship agreement, and $400,000 from investors, Janice Shade, chief executive, projected 2011 sales of at least $800,000.

description: American Idol is supposed to allow young people to live their wildest dreams. The shows 10th season, which began Wednesday on Fox with new judges, looked more like an older womans fantasy  a Nancy Meyers movie about the revenge of the scorned first wife.

description: Iberdrola, the Spanish energy giant, said on Thursday that it had agreed to buy Elektro Eletricidade e Servicos of Brazil for $2.4 billion.

title: Tunisia Takes Step Toward Allowing Exiles to Return
description: TUNIS  Tunisias interim government struggled Thursday to placate protesters demanding the eradication of the countrys former ruling party. The government announced steps toward an amnesty for political exiles, including Islamists. Several cabinet ministers said they were resigning from the old ruling party. And demonstrators outside the party headquarters were met by soldiers who said the building now belonged to the people and who eventually helped pull down the partys name from the facade.

title: Growth in the Naughties

My point was that this doesnt mean that the growth was somehow fake; real output of goods and services did indeed rise, even if the legacy of that growth was debt that create macroeconomic problems now.

title: A Very Banksy Acceptance Speech
description: SAN FRANCISCO For those still wondering about the legitimacy of the Banksy film Exit Through the Gift Shop, the Cinema Eye documentary award the film just won might help. The pseudonymous British artist even worked up an acceptance speech for the ceremony  although Banksy did not, of course, turn up to read it. That fell to the movies producer, Jaimie DCruz. Might have been a good thing, too, as Banksy went a little Gervais in mocking his fellow filmmakers.

Less than a week after gracing the Golden Globes broadcast in a rose-bedecked gown and collecting an award for her work in Black Swan, Ms. Portman pops up on Friday on the big screen in a pre-Valentines Day romantic comedy with an instantly forgettable title.

title: Car Bombings Kill Dozens on Pilgrims Route in Iraq

description: The financially troubled Washington National Opera is merging administrative functions with the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, the two organizations announced this morning. The move is intended to stabilize the opera company, which in recent years has reduced its season and borrowed against its endowment.

description: Mike Mayo, the maverick bank analyst of Crdit Agricole Securities, is not exactly Mr. Popularity on Wall Street.

title: From Mitsubishi, 3-D Writ Large
description: The goal of 3-D TV is to make pictures that have depth, but at Mitsubishi the goal apparently is also height and width. The company, which says it makes the largest 3-D TV (82 inches diagonal) is going to super-size it with a 92-inch 3-D TV due on the market this summer.

title: Your Ranking? The Nemesis Doesnt Care
description: Some tennis players just like seeing certain opponents on the other side of the net.

title: Regulators Seek More Data on Bucyrus Deal
description: Antitrust regulators have stepped up their scrutiny of Caterpillars proposed $7.6 billion acquisition of Bucyrus International.

title: South Korea Agrees to Low-Level Talks With North
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea said Thursday that it had agreed to hold low-level defense talks with North Korea. The talks would be the first dialogue between the Koreas since a deadly North Korean artillery attack on a South Korean island in November seemed to push the peninsula to the brink of war.

title: Poetry Pairing | Jan. 20, 2011
description: In our weekly Poetry Pairing series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poems themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

title: A Dishy Take on the 2012 Race, by ... Somebody
description: Well, now we know why the author of this much gossiped about, heavily marketed new book wanted to remain anonymous: O: A Presidential Novel is a thoroughly lackadaisical performance  trite, implausible and decidedly unfunny.

title: French Fury Over Academy Shortlist
description: Even in ordinary circumstances, the failure of Frances Of Gods and Men to make the Oscar shortlist for best-foreign language film announced Wednesday would have been controversial, especially in France. The film received rapturous reviews there, was a box office success and has won numerous awards, including that of best foreign-language film of 2010 as voted by the National Board of Review in the United States. Grand prize winner at the last Cannes festival, Xavier Beauvoiss Of Gods and Men doesnt even qualify for the preliminary list, was the incredulous reaction of the magazine Paris Match on its Web site.

title: Thursday Reading: Convertible Clothing for the Cost-Conscious
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Seeing Things | Marriage by Design
description: Over the course of their more than 50-year design partnership, Evelyn and Jerome Ackerman created ceramics, tiles, wood carvings and textiles (among many other design items for the home) that helped shape what we now know as midcentury California modernism. While many of us grew up with the Ackermans work, the couple was less well known (although no less productive) than their contemporaries Charles and Ray Eames. The Ackermans and their work will be celebrated when a long-overdue retrospective, featuring more than 200 examples of their work, opens on Jan. 23 at the Craft and Folk Art Museum in Los Angeles.

title: Fired Sportscaster Sues ESPN
description: Ron Franklin, the sportscaster fired last month by ESPN for remarks he made to a sideline reporter in a hotel lobby before the Chick-fil-A Bowl, filed a wrongful termination lawsuit in a Texas county court Wednesday saying that he could be dismissed only for a failure to perform his job.

title: Tough Climate Math in the Face of CO2 and Energy Forecasts
description: Its hard to find projections for both global energy demand and emissions of carbon dioxide from fuel burning that dont have a sustained upward trajectory for decades to come. The latest such forecasts were issued on Wednesday by Exxon Mobil, at the World Future Energy Summit in Abu Dhabi, and by BP. Ill focus more on the BP report because its posted online, while Exxons is still awaiting publication.

title: Music Service Spotify Closes Deal With Sony
description: In what could be a breakthrough for the next phase of digital music, Sony Music Entertainment has signed a deal with Spotify, a sleek British online service, for distribution in the United States. Spotify, which streams music and has a smartphone app, has been a hit in Europe but its move across the Atlantic has been long delayed. Sony is the first major label group to sign for American distribution.

title: Why People Arent Screened for Colon Cancer
description: Is fear holding you back from a potentially lifesaving screening test?

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Evolving Relationships and Privacy
description: Technology can make it easier for people to connect with others, but it can also take a toll on relationships. On this weeks Tech Talk show, J.D. Biersdorfer chats with Sherry Turkle, a professor at M.I.T. whose new book is Alone Together: Why We Expect More From Technology and Less From Each Other. Ms. Turkle, the founder and director of the M.I.T. Initiative on Technology and the Self, says that hyperconnectivity can make people feel lonely.

title: New Orleans Jazz Festival Adds More Pop and Rock
description: The 42nd edition of the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival will take place over two weekends this spring, from April 29 to May 1 and May 5 to 8, and its lineup continues a long trend toward ever-more-mainstream rock and pop. The headliners include Bon Jovi, Kid Rock, Arcade Fire, Jimmy Buffett, John Mellencamp, Tom Jones, Wilco, the Strokes, Robert Plant and John Legend and the Roots, festival organizers announced on Thursday.

title: Facebook Co-Founder Backs Start-Up
description: The first check he wrote to an entrepreneur turned him into a billionaire and a lead character in a Hollywood blockbuster.

title: Crosbys Injury Renews Focus On Hits to Head in the N.H.L.
description: While Sidney Crosby, one of the N.H.L.s biggest stars, is recuperating from a concussion that may prevent him from playing in the All-Star Game, some team executives are willing to widen the scope of a rule that bans blindside hits to the head.

title: Old-Time Short-Time Work
description: On Wednesday, I mentioned the idea of short-time work policies, in which workers and companies avoid layoffs during tough times by cutting everyones work hours. Alex Keyssar, author of one of the definitive histories of unemployment, points out that the debate over short-time work is nothing new.

title: Broadcasters Announced for N.C.A.A. Tournament
description: CBS and Turner Sports unveiled their announcer lineup for this years N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament, their first since acquiring the rights for $10.8 billion over 14 years.

title: Growing Without Driving
description: V.M.T., in the chart above, stands for vehicle miles traveled. So what changed in the early 1990s to cause the growth of driving to fall behind the growth of gross domestic product?

title: Mothers Lies
description: Always tell the truth, mom says.

title: Dior, 52, Creator Of 'New Look,' Dies
description: MONTECATINI, Italy, Thursday, Oct. 24--Christian Dior, for many years the leader in the world of fashion design, died here early today of a heart attack. His age was 52.
Moscow, Jan. 22 -- Nikolai Lenin died last night at 6:50 o'clock. The immediate cause of death was paralysis of the respiratory centers due to a cerebral hemorrhage.

title: States Budget Crises Cut Deeply Into Financing for Mental Health Programs
description: TUCSON  Unlike many of her fellow governors, Jan Brewer of Arizona knows well the inner workings of her states mental health system: her son has schizophrenia and was committed to a state hospital more than 20 years ago after being found not guilty by reason of insanity of sexual assault and kidnapping.

title: Sargent Shrivers Christian Politics
description: From a moving remembrance by Scott Stossel, Shrivers biographer:

title:
High Court Rules Abortions Legal the First 3
Months
description: Washington, Jan. 22 -- The Supreme Court overruled today all state laws that prohibit or restrict a woman's right to obtain an abortion during her first three months of pregnancy. The vote was 7 to 2.

title: Vinson Excelled In Federal Posts
description: Fred M. Vinson enjoyed a noteworthy career in each of the three branches of the Federal Government--legislative, executive and judicial. In twelve years in the House of Representatives he won wide renown as a tax and fiscal expert. Then, in World War II, he served in top administrative posts, as Economic Stabilizer, Federal Loan Administrator, Assistant President, and Secretary of the Treasury. Finally, in 1946, he was appointed by President Truman as Chief Justice of the United States.

title: Report Says Militants in Pearl Killing Still at Large
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Nine years after the American reporter Daniel Pearl was captured and killed by operatives of Al Qaeda in Pakistan, more than a dozen of the militants involved in his murder remain at large, a testament to the lack of will by Pakistani authorities to prosecute the cases, according to a report released Thursday.

title: Hats Off to Cinema
description: The Milan exhibition "Cinema with a Hat. Borsalino & other stories" highlights the often iconic and emotional role hats have played in cinema.

title: Celestial Come-Ons and Other Booze-Selling Ploys
description: For weeks  months, actually  I could do little more than stare at it, this ostensibly precious nectar with an outrageously precious name.

title: Connecticut School Will Perform Wilson Play Despite Officials Objection
description: Joe Turner will indeed come to Waterbury, Conn. After three hours of discussion on Wednesday night and testimony from community members and other interested parties, including the dean of the Yale School of Drama, the Waterbury Board of Education allowed a public schools production of the August Wilson play Joe Turners Come and Gone to proceed in February.

title: Obama Will Move Political Operations to Chicago
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will close the office of political affairs at the White House in preparation for the establishment of his re-election headquarters, which will open its doors in Chicago by late March to concentrate on building a national fund-raising and grass-roots operation to rival his first campaign, aides said.

title: Tucson Survivor Describes Chaos of Rampage
