description: TUCSON  Since the shooting, Ronald Barber has retold his memory of the scene over and over  to his family, to a psychologist friend and to investigators. The vivid images of a pool of blood on the ground, the pop-pop-pop sound of a gun and seeing bullet casings on the ground.

title: Murphy Will Run for Liebermans Senate Seat
description: Representative Christopher S. Murphy, a popular three-term Democrat from Connecticut, announced on Wednesday that he would be a candidate in 2012 for the seat being vacated by Senator Joseph I. Lieberman.Mr. Murphy emerged from an already crowded field of possible candidates in both parties who are giving thought to entering the race to replace Mr. Lieberman, an independent who on Wednesday formally announced his plans to retire when his term ends in January 2013.

title: Quote Unquote | Fast Fashion
description: Michael Kors tells the Los Angeles Times about his dream collaboration. You want fries with that, Michael?

title: Dementia Patients Hospitalized Too Often, Study Finds
description: Perhaps no group of nursing home residents is more vulnerable than those with advanced dementia: unable to speak for themselves, suffering the physical as well as the cognitive effects of their terminal disease, prone to confusion or fear when subjected to blood tests or trips in screaming ambulances.

title: What Were Reading
description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.

title: Mr. Rubensteins Big Week in Washington
description: David Rubenstein, the billionaire boss of the Carlyle Group, has always been the Zelig of private equity. In the last week, however, hes been playing the same role in Washington.

title: 2010 a Record Year for Voluntary Recalls
description: The auto industry recalled about 20.3 million vehicles last year, and three of the five automakers with the most recalls were Japanese, according to figures released by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration on Wednesday.

title: Take Away Celebratory Gunfire? From My Cold, Victorious Hand.
description: BAGHDAD  Jubilant Iraqi soccer fans ignored government orders and lit up the Baghdad night sky with gunshots on Wednesday, after the national team beat North Korea 1-0 in the Asian Cup tournament to qualify for the quarterfinals.

title: Even Bloomberg Cant Escape Complexity of Immigration
description: On Meet the Press, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg declared, We have to go and get the immigrants here. To a group of business leaders in Brooklyn, he extolled the economic power of immigration. And in his State of the City address on Wednesday, he interrupted a litany of local issues to urge Americans to fix our broken immigration system.

title: Kings, Nazis and the Oscars
description: SAN FRANCISCO You know a film is a front-runner when the charges of smear campaigns begin. The latest victim? The Kings Speech, the subject of an email circulated a few weeks ago in which the writer claims the film is losing Academy voters because of its subjects apparent anti-Semitic and pro-Nazi proclivities. The email, from a person who claimed Academy membership, was sent last month to the blogger Scott Feinberg, who published it after checking its sources, which ultimately led back to a 2002 article in The Guardian. (Mr. Feinberg was unable to determine if the letter writer was in fact an Academy member.)

title: Idol': Fewer Bad Singers, Fewer Viewers
description: The big question looming over the new season of American Idol has been: How much will Simon be missed? The initial answer: A lot.

title: Planning for the Unfathomable
description: The frenzied violence unfolded abruptly, on a Saturday morning, at a suburban shopping center in Tucson. But it has happened elsewhere: aboard a Long Island Rail Road train; at a beverage distributor in Connecticut; at a cable television network in Maryland; on a college campus in Virginia.

title: As Lawmakers Meet Chinas Hu, Some Can Only Listen
description: 2:13 p.m. | Updated There was not much give and take as President Hu Jintao of China met with House members this morning, according to those who were in attendance. Representative Kevin Brady, a Republican of Texas, called it mostly speechifying.

title: Managing Online Accounts After Death
description: In a recent New York Times magazine article, Cyberspace When Youre Dead, the writer Rob Walker mentioned three Web sites that help ensure consumers still have a say in what happens to their online presences after they die.

title: Idol Debut Ratings Down
description: For the start of its 10th season on Wednesday night, American Idol gained two new judges in the form of Steven Tyler and Jennifer Lopez. But that monolithic Fox singing contest lost about 14 percent of the total number of viewers who tuned in for the debut of Season 9, drawing 26 million this year versus 30 million last year. Is ex-judge Simon Cowell smiling somewhere? Bill Carter has more at Media Decoder.

title: More Students Seek Avenues to Gay-Friendly Colleges
description: Bloggers Note: The following article was prepared through the New York Times Student Journalism Institute, a workshop that was recently held in Miami. Mr. Candido is a student at Florida Atlantic University. Jacques Steinberg

title: ONeal Turns Back the Clock, For a Night
description: Once, Shaquille ONeal was the most feared basketball player on the floor. He was a catastrophic, 7-foot-1 wrecking machine, blocking shots, throwing down rim-rattling dunks, and doing it all with a wink.

title: Closing the Door on Carmelo Anthony
description: You do have to hand it to the N.B.A. Just when it concluded one big off-season divafest that everyone thought could not be topped for sheer audacity and narcissism, it simply rolled on to a big in-season divafest. What the Carmelo Anthony story lacks in hourlong television debacles, it gains in dragging an oligarch all the way from Russia to proclaim the situation a circus.

title: New Report on Daniel Pearls Murder Reveals Forensic Analysis of Killers Veins
description: After studying the pattern of the veins on his hand, American investigators concluded that Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, a senior operative for Al Qaeda, wielded the blade that killed Daniel Pearl, a Wall Street Journal reporter who was kidnapped and executed before a video camera in Pakistan in 2002, according to a new report.

title: Photo of the Week
description: An entrance into Tiananmen Square in Beijing, China.

title: Paris Fashion Week | Rick Owens and Juun.J
description: In some ways, a Rick Owens show changes little from season to season, and youll occasionally hear grumblings of this from editors. But then, men change their style little from season to season anyway. And Owens does have a distinct idea that he constantly pushes further along. One significant aspect of that idea is the dropped, skirtlike waistline  often created with multiple draped layers of fabric. Occasionally an actual skirt appears, but usually some variation of a long shirt hem shows below the bottom edge of a suit jacket. Sometimes it just shows in the back, approximating the visual effect of wearing a shirt tied around the waist  an easy jumping off point for understanding how a skirt can look masculine on a guy.

title: Whats Not to Love? Jackie Mason Waits for Spider-Man to Break His Dubious Record
description: When (or perhaps if) Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark opens on March 15, it will be a day of emotion and fulfillment for that long-delayed musicals cast, creative team and producers, and also for Jackie Mason.

title: Video: A Little Time With Oscars-Bound School Choir
S.E.C. Approves New Rules for Asset-Backed Securities
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission approved new regulations on Thursday aimed at curbing the risks posed by asset-backed securities.

title: New Figures Confirm That 2010 Was a Hot Year
description: New figures issued on Thursday in Britain show that 2010 was the second-warmest year in the historical record. That comes on the heels of reports last week from two American agencies that 2010 was tied for the warmest year in the record books.

title: O: A Presidential Novel
description: August 2012

title: Doctor Cautions That Rehabilitation Process for Giffords Is Likely to Be a Long One
description: TUCSON  In the nearly two weeks since a gunshot passed through her brain, Representative Gabrielle Giffords has continued to make what doctors say is remarkable progress and is now able to distinguish particular colors and bear her own weight on her feet.

title: Australian Makes Some Noise on Mens Side
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  The hardware is in impressive shape at the Australian Open: two stadiums with retractable roofs and a third one approved as part of an expansion project financed by the government at a projected cost of $357 million.

title: Oops, E-Mail Has Done It Again
description: Rogue e-mail is becoming the biggest danger to banks underwriting business.

title: Excerpt: 'Parks and Recreation'
description: The NBC small town comedy starring Amy Poehler returns for its third season on Jan. 20.

title: Podcast: Wheres the Major Upset?
description: Our reporter in Melbourne notes that despite a depth of players, seven of the top eight womens seeds and 15 of the top 16 mens seeds remain in the tournament.

title: Broadways Fat Pig Finds Its Title Character
description: Probably every plus-size woman has a story like Helens in the Neil LaBute play Fat Pig, says the actress Heather Jane Rolff. Helen is courted by another character, Tom, who is much thinner, only to have their deepening relationship founder because he cant man up with his friends, who mock her for being overweight. Ms. Rolffs variation on such ugly reality involved arriving to perform at a dance recital at age 13, only to be told by her instructor, You look fat in that costume, and Im not allowing you to go onstage.

title: Car Rental Companies Add No Smoking Signs
description: Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group announced this month that it would ban smoking for travelers renting cars at all United States Dollar and Thrifty corporate-owned locations and participating franchise locations.

title: Del Potro Shows Rust in Return
description: It is a truism on the tennis tour that no amount of practice and training can replace match play, and this was borne out in Marcos Baghdatis four-set victory over Juan Martin Del Potro.

title: Not Taking Thank You for an Answer
description: I think were finished now. Thank you. Thank you.

title: How the Doctor Almost Killed Her Dog
description: The week before Christmas, I nearly killed my German shepherd.

title: Education Still Pays
description: The Bureau of Labor Statistics is out with a new report today showing that pay trends in 2010 were not as good as they had been in 2009. In 2009, real weekly pay had risen for every educational group  high-school dropouts, high-school graduates, people with some college and four-year college graduates. In 2010, pay fell for every group.

title: 2 Miami Officers Killed in Shootout
description: Two police officers and a murder suspect died in a shootout in Miami on Thursday while the authorities were trying to serve a homicide warrant, officials said.

title: Amy Poehler on the Return (Finally) of Parks and Recreation
description: The NBC small-town comedy Parks and Recreation returns for its third season on Thursday night after a long break. NBC opted to hold the comedy out of its fall lineup, which struck some as a puzzling choice for a show that was just starting to gain momentum in its second season.

title: G.M. Names New Leader for Global Development
description: DETROIT  General Motors shuffled several executives this week as the automaker, two months removed from its public stock offering, works to build on recent momentum.

title: Scorecard | Z Zegna Wins!
description: Head spinning from four days of nonstop fashion in Milan? Paris is still to come. But not to fear: Scorecard is here to cut through the shades of gray  and blue-gray and grayish-green  for you. Though the Caten brother duo surprised critics by going back to black, it was Alessandro Sartori who proved through his non-flannel suits for the experimental line of the 100-year-old Ermengildo Zegna mens fashion empire that the presence of the past can be felt in techno tailoring.

title: T-Mobile Tries to Counter the iPhones Spread
description: One of the big questions lingering in the wake of the news that Verizon Wireless would begin selling the iPhone is how the smaller wireless carriers in the United States, like Sprint and T-Mobile, will fare without it.

title: Tata Nano: A Peoples Car, Piece by Piece
description: Its North American sales prospects remain as nebulous as New Delhis evening smog, but the Tata Nano has made some notable stateside cameos: at the Detroit Science Center during that citys 2010 auto show; at New Yorks Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum shortly thereafter; and now, as the marquee attraction at a Cornell University exhibition in Ithaca, N.Y.  albeit in heavily modified form.

title: Poll: Congresss Top Focus Should Be Job Creation
description: Even though Congresss first order of business under Republican control was Wednesdays vote to repeal the health care law, most Americans said that they do not understand how the law affects them, and the public thinks job creation rather than health care should be the top priority for Congress, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: As Winter Nears, Leaving the Ice
description: Jeff Vervoort, an associate professor in radiogenic isotope geochemistry at Washington State University, and John Goodge, a professor of geological sciences at the University of Minnesota-Duluth, are writing about their research expedition in Antarctica.

title: Warren Buffett to Leave Washington Post Co. Board
description: 2:56 p.m. | Updated Warren Buffett, the investor whose guidance is considered gospel by many on Wall Street, is leaving his long-held position on the board of the Washington Post Company.

title: In Speech, Hu Calls for Closer Cooperation With U.S.
description: President Hu Jintao of China called for closer cooperation with the United States in Southeast Asia and the Pacific Rim in a speech on Thursday, offering an olive branch in a region where Chinas increasing influence and military presence have roiled relations between the two powers.

title: Day 5 Preview: Henin vs. Kuznetsova
description: Two Grand Slam champions square off in a marquee third-round match today in the Rod Laver Arena. Justine Henin, whose sterling play so far suggests that her elbow woes are behind her, faces Svetlana Kuznetsova in a match that could easily be a semifinal.

title: Beneath Citys Falling Jobless Rate, a Less Rosy Reality
description: New York Citys unemployment rate fell below 9 percent in December to its lowest level in 20 months, but not because more residents found work at the end of the year.

title: Iran Talks Set to Resume
description: ISTANBUL  The United States and other world powers go into another round of talks with Iran here on Friday with low expectations, but with Iran indicating that it would like to make progress on a fuel-swap arrangement originally designed by Washington as a confidence-building measure.

title: Blackwater Founder Said to Back Mercenaries
description: WASHINGTON  Erik Prince, the founder of the international security giant Blackwater Worldwide, is backing an effort by a controversial South African mercenary firm to insert itself into Somalias bloody civil war by protecting government leaders, training Somali troops, and battling pirates and Islamic militants there, according to American and Western officials.

title: A Year at War: Updates and Questions
description: A Year at War

title: A Provocateur Who Talks to Strangers
description: ITS a little like sneaking around your old school, Laurel Nakadate said, flashing a conspiratorial grin as she led a visitor up a staircase to the second floor of the repurposed school building that houses MoMA P.S. 1 in Long Island City, Queens. Closed and quiet on a mid-December day, that exhibition complex would soon display Ms. Nakadates first major museum show  Only the Lonely, opening Sunday  and she had just moved into a temporary studio there, across the hall from the galleries where the 10-year survey of her film, video and photography projects would be installed.

title: Mob Arrests
description: The targets of a massive New York area mob sweep ranged from reputed small-time book makers and crime-family functionaries to six alleged senior mob figures from three crime families.

title: Cuomo Warns of Pain but Doesnt Detail Scale of Cuts
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y.  Following news reports that he is considering cutting thousands of state jobs, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo repeated on Thursday his warning that the budget he will unveil at the start of February will cause great pain.

title: For This Season, The Broadway Landscape Is Dry For Other Desert Cities
description: This is how Broadway works nowadays: Lincoln Center Theater producers have a new critically acclaimed play, Other Desert Cities, in their Off Broadway space, the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater. The producers want to capitalize on the strong reviews and transfer the play this spring to a Broadway house, where visibility will be far greater, more money stands be made, and Tony Awards are a possibility. (Off Broadway shows dont qualify for Tonys.) But at this point Lincoln Center Theater will have to wait until the fall of 2011 to transfer the play, rather than this spring, because the 40 Broadway houses are all booked, according to executives involved with the transfer discussions.

title: About A.I.G.s Stock Price
description: Shares in the American International Group plunged more than 14 percent on Thursday, hitting $43.80 in midafternoon trading.

title: Milan Fashion Week | Post Mortem
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#507", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Billions of Entangled Particles Advance Quantum Computing
description: In a step toward a generation of ultrafast computers, physicists have used bursts of radio waves to briefly create 10 billion quantum-entangled pairs of subatomic particles in silicon. The research offers a glimpse of a future computing world in which individual atomic nuclei store and retrieve data and single electrons shuttle it back and forth.

title: Inevitable Comparisons for Washingtons Point Guard
description: SEATTLE  The Washington mens basketball team, all speed and spurts, was rolling past another Pacific-10 opponent. In the final minutes of a runaway victory over Oregon a couple of weeks ago, the brash and bold 5-foot-9 junior point guard, wearing No. 2, stole the ball and dunked it at the other end. He pumped his palms in the air. Raise the roof, people.

title: Michael Kinsleys Utopianism
description: Various bloggers keep quoting this line from Michael Kinsleys column about Tucson as though it contains some special wisdom:

title: With Chiesi Gone, Will Rajaratnam Fight On?
description: Danielle Chiesis guilty plea to three counts of conspiracy to commit insider trading leaves the Galleon Group founder, Raj Rajaratnam, as the last of the seven defendants from this case fighting the governments charges. His trial is scheduled to start on Feb. 28 and the deal with Ms. Chiesi shows that prosecutors are taking a hard line that may make any offer to resolve the case unacceptable to him.

title: Vocabulinks
description: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

title: Inspired by Father, Nantz Takes Role in Alzheimers Research
description: Jim Nantz had a master plan: his father would retire from his furniture business and join him on the road at N.F.L. games, golf tournaments and college basketball arenas. The elder Nantz, who was also named Jim, would help manage and organize his sons busy life on the road.

title: Irish Prime Minister Calls for Early Elections
description: LONDON  Brian Cowen, the embattled Irish prime minister, on Thursday announced an earlier-than-expected general election for March 11, the latest development in a political meltdown for the governing Fianna Fail party.

title: Insurers Reporting Healthy Profits
description: Despite the weak economy, health insurers seem to be doing all right.

title: Buffett to Step Down From Washington Post Board
description: Lucas Jackson/ReutersWarren E. Buffet, chairman of Berkshire Hathaway.

title: Choosing Someone to Sell Your Business
description: Last week, I wrote a post featuring a small-business owner, Ann Price, whose restaurant in Atlanta has been getting lots of press. Unfortunately, the attention has been focused less on the quality of her food and more on the fact that no one wants to buy her business.

title: Premier Defies Hezbollah as Talks on Lebanon Fail
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Lebanons worst crisis in years escalated dangerously on Thursday as a last-ditch effort to negotiate a solution ended in failure and the American-backed caretaker prime minister struck a defiant note toward Hezbollah and its allies, which brought down his 14-month-old national unity government this month.

title: Fired Renault Executive Blames Tricks by a Rival
description: PARIS  An executive of the French automaker Renault who was fired over accusations that he had sought to pass on secrets of the companys electric-car program said Thursday that he believed the company had been the victim of a dirty trick by a rival.

title: Reader Idea | Trees and Transcendentalists
description: Here is another in our Great Ideas From Readers series.

title: The State of the City, Block by Block
description: On Tuesday, as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg prepared to give his State of the City address, we asked you to address us on the state of your block. Several dozen of you wrote in, some with remarkable thoughtfulness and care. Here are 11 of your responses, with some edits. Thank you.

title: To Really Learn, Quit Studying and Take a Test
description: Taking a test is not just a passive mechanism for assessing how much people know, according to new research. It actually helps people learn, and it works better than a number of other studying techniques.

title: Photos of Shot Kenyans Spur Calls for Police Reform
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Three Kenyan police officers were suspended and placed under investigation on Thursday after a newspaper published photographs that it said showed undercover officers murdering three men who had surrendered in the middle of a busy Nairobi highway.

title: Viewpoints: Has Compensation Changed?
description: DealBook's Andrew Ross Sorkin talks to Rob Cox, the U.S. editor of Reuters Breakingviews, about new approaches to compensation on Wall Street. Are financial institutions changing the way they pay?

title: Viewpoints: Has Compensation Changed?
description: DealBooks Andrew Ross Sorkin talks to Rob Cox, the United States editor of Reuters Breakingviews, about new approaches to compensation on Wall Street. Are financial institutions changing the way they pay executives?

title: The Craigslist Gym
description: Heres one way to save on gym costs: set up your own home gym filled with used equipment bought from Craigslist.

title: Airbus Tanker Loses Part of Refueling Boom in Midair Accident
description: WASHINGTON  A large part of a midair refueling boom broke off of an Airbus plane during a training exercise, the company said Thursday, adding a possible complication to the Air Forces effort to award a $35 billion contract for new tankers.

title: Paris Mens: Fashion Hams and the Home Front
description: Louis Vuitton will open a new store in Place Vendme sometime soon. That made me breathe a sigh of relief. Its latest mens collection, designed by Paul Helbers and shown at the start of the Paris fall collections this week, may look austerity-minded in its drab tones and dense layers, but we all know the customer for this kind of deluxe understatement isnt affected by the European Unions troubles, though maybe thats an optimistic statement.

title: Theater Listings: Jan. 21  27
description: Theater

title: Digital Music Sales Are Starting to Slow, Report Says
description: Sales of digital music now account for 29 percent of record companies global revenue, but digital growth is slowing even as new online services continue to proliferate throughout the world, according a new report by the music industrys international trade group.

title: An Affordable Way to Buy Fuel-Cell Power
description: Taking a page from the solar industry, Bloom Energy on Thursday unveiled a service to allow customers to buy the electricity generated by its fuel cells without incurring the capital costs of purchasing the six-figure devices.

title: 36 Hours in Valencia, Spain
description: FOR the last decade, Valencia, best known as the birthplace of paella, has been steadily inching onto the radar of savvy travelers. Since 2005  when work was completed on Santiago Calatravas futuristic museum complex, the City of Arts and Sciences  and 2007, when Spains third-largest city played host to the Americas Cup, Valencias Moorish-accented neighborhoods have been filling up with boutiques, restaurants and night spots. Last month, a new train line on the AVE, Spains high-speed rail service, linked the city to Madrid, about 200 miles away, making it even easier for travelers to visit this seaside city, which is cooking up a lot more than rice.

title: A Weekend in Valencia
description: Since 2005, Valencias Moorish-accented neighborhoods have been filling up with boutiques, restaurants and night spots.

title: Riffing on the Guitar as Only Picasso Could
The Art of the Pump Fake
description: PITTSBURGH  There are times when Hines Ward, the Pittsburgh Steelers receiver, finds himself unexpectedly uncovered while running his route. He looks around and sees nothing unusual amid the traffic of a football game, except a safety heading the other way. After 13 seasons in the N.F.L., Ward is still bewildered when it happens.

title: Dear FloFab: They Slurp! They Slouch! They Shovel! They Smack!
description: Each week, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

title: E.P.A. and Chrysler Link Up for Hybrid Technology Test
description: The Environmental Protection Agency and the Chrysler Group announced on Wednesday that they would work together to develop a light-duty hydraulic hybrid vehicle. Current plans call for the system to be installed in the Chrysler Town & Country minivan.

title: Executive Director of Baryshnikov Arts Center Is Leaving
description: Stanford Makishi will step down as executive director of the Baryshnikov Arts Center on Feb. 28, the center said on Thursday. Mr. Makishi, 45, a Harvard-educated former dancer, has held the post for three years, serving as the right-hand man of Mikhail Baryshnikov, the founder and artistic director.

title: Even on the Wagon, Not Ready for a Close-Up
description: Art imitates life in Applause, though usually it just imitates incomparably greater art. A Danish movie unwisely under the influence, it turns on an alcoholic actress, Thea Barfoed (Paprika Steen), struggling with her boozing ways, estranged children, former husband, fleshy neck and apparently brilliant career. I was great, she says after one performance. Ill have to take her word for it.

title: McEwan Wins Jerusalem Prize
description: Ian McEwan, the author of Amsterdam, Atonement and Saturday, among other books, is the 2011 winner of the Jerusalem Prize, Israels highest literary award for foreigners. The award, $10,000, is granted every other year during the Jerusalem International Book Fair, and will be given to him on Feb. 20th. The prize has gone to authors including Bertrand Russell, Susan Sontag, Milan Kundera, Mario Vargas Llosa and Haruki Murakami. It honors writers whose work promotes the idea of freedom of the individual in society.

title: Google Shake-Up Is Effort to Revive Start-Up Spark
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google made the biggest management shake-up in a decade on Thursday, handing the reins of the company to one of its co-founders in an effort to rediscover its start-up roots.

title: More Transparency for Variable-Rate Loans
description: CHANGES to the Truth in Lending Act have helped make loan documents more understandable for many borrowers, but some people with more complicated, fluctuating mortgages may still struggle to grasp all the terms.

title: Taking Up With a Maid Might Upset the Family
description: Sex, power, class and money  these are the forces swirling around an opulent but hauntingly austere South Korean household in The Housemaid, a lurid cocktail of titillation and betrayal that never quite lives up to its intoxicating potential. An admiring, clever remake of Kim Ki-youngs legendary film of the same title from 1960, this version, directed by Im Sang-soo, is at once more explicit than the original and less kinky. Rather than sweep, with Buuelian mischief, from melodrama to black comedy to surrealist pastiche, it hesitates among those possibilities, as if unable to calculate the proper ratio of sincerity to camp.

title: TimesCast | January 20, 2011
description: Large scale arrests in a crackdown on organized crime; a preview of an upcoming Times poll; and how is the Chinese press reporting President Hu's trip to Washington.

title: Death Be Not Predictable
description: How do you think he looks? Better? the dying mans wife asks a visitor to his hospital room. The hopefulness in her voice is unmistakable. But the gaunt 38-year-old patient is clearly not long for this world. Still, his wife babbles on about his future, using words as a wall to hold back her despair and support her denial.

title: Condo Plans Go Online, Easing a Burden
description: WHEN Richard H. Rothman moved into his two-bedroom condominium at the Centurion, a high-rise on West 56th Street designed by Pei Partnership Architects, he discovered to his dismay that the walls had been primed but not painted.

title: The High Low | Timex for J. Crew
description: What: Timex for J. Crew watch

title: Former Beer Warehouses Returning to Residential
description: Patchogue

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Jan. 21-27
description: Pop

title: A Small, Cozy Studio to Call Her Own
description: BACK when Alexa Battista and two roommates rented a place at 95 Wall Street, the rent seemed like a great deal. That was in the summer of 2009, and they were given four free months on a 16-month lease. But at the end of 16 months, they gave us the normal price for the apartment, Ms. Battista said. Her share, effectively $1,450 a month, was to rise to $1,850.

title: Neighborhood Joint | Boom Boom Brow Bar
description: In the West Village, a waxing boutique geared toward eyebrow perfection is a favorite beauty spot for locals.

title: Need a Ride? There Are Apps for That
description: Think of all those empty seats in cars headed to school or work in cities around the world. The idea that filling them is a communal good goes back at least to World War II, when the Office of Price Administration put out a poster proclaiming, When You Ride ALONE You Ride With Hitler!

title: Pictures of The Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Pictures from Afghanistan, Iraq, Tunisia and Pakistan.

title: Hey, Kids, Lets Put on a Reading!
description: NEW Yorkers love nothing more than to boast, I was there first, whether its getting a reservation at a buzzworthy restaurant, snatching up the latest handbag or seeing a new film before the rest of the country.

title: Hewlett-Packard Shakes Up Its Board
description: Hewlett-Packard announced Thursday afternoon that it was adding five new members to its board, including Meg Whitman, the former chief executive of eBay and most recently the unsuccessful Republican candidate for governor of California. But four other board members will not stand for re-election.

title: The Librarys Extremely Useful Predecessor
description: AS its dingy marble facade is cleaned and repaired, the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street has been shrouded at times under gauzy, other-worldly construction netting, making it appear almost as if the library was not there. Which, in the 19th century, it wasnt; the land was occupied by the huge, brooding Egyptian-style Croton Reservoir, built in 1842 as the focal point of the citys first central water system.

title: Readings Around Town
description: Images from readings of new plays by Stephen Adly Guirgis and Andrew Hinderacker.

title: Spare Times: For Children, for Jan. 21-27
description: HIBERNATORS BALL

title: The Adventures of Spartacus Sixpack
description: Like AMCs Mad Men the latest series on Starz is a period drama in which the patriarchy dominates, the class system is rigidly delineated, and the cultural attitude toward drinking has yet to fall under the punishing heels of recovery and restraint. As its name suggests, Spartacus: Gods of the Arena (beginning on Friday) is set well before the advent of Alcoholics Anonymous but right during the high moment of extreme sports. Specifically we are in the late 70s B.C. in the ancient city of Capua at a Roman gladiatorial campus where dorm life leaves the shenanigans at the Big Ten looking fairly pathetic.

title: Where Wax (Rip! Ouch!) Is Queen
description: MALYNDA VIGLIOTTI opened her waxing salon, the Boom Boom Brow Bar, in the spring of 2008, the same week the financial markets began their drastic downturn. And her potential customers, a species of well-maintained New Yorkers who operate under a No Follicle Left Behind edict, stayed home.

title: Googles Management Shift: What Now for M.&A.?
description: Paul Sakuma/Associated PressEric E. Schmidt, Googles chief executive, will become executive chairman.

title: Jazz Listings for Jan. 21-27
description: Jazz

title: Palin Inches Toward 2012 in Iowa, Nevada
description: Sarah Palin may be inching toward a presidential run in 2012 as she heads next week to Nevada for two speeches and her advisers quietly begin talking to Republican activists in Iowa.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Pictures from Afghanistan, Iraq, Tunisia and Pakistan.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for Jan. 21-27
description: Classical

title: Dont Just Skewer News, Go Make Up Your Own
description: Has it seemed to you lately that the fake-news business has run out of gas? That Jon Stewart and certainly Weekend Update on Saturday Night Live have grown predictable, even a little desperate? Hang on; theres a jump-start coming. The real question is whether your brain can handle the surge.

title: Saying I Dont to Release the Anger
description: THE bathroom door really said it all. There was a crack in the center, which I had papered over and painted on the outside. From the inside, however, the crack was still visible.

title: Dance Listings for Jan. 21-27
description: Dance

title: Theater Talkback: Stepping From the Rock Arena to the Broadway Stage
description: Rock is mostly retro on Broadway, where the jukebox musical has taken up firm residence. The notable exception is American Idiot, which received a heady injection of pop excitement this month with the return of Green Day front man Billie Joe Armstrong to the role of St. Jimmy. (Of course, rumor has it theres a score for some new show by a rock band called U2, but I havent heard a lick of it yet. Some distant day, perhaps.)

title: H.P. Replaces 4 on Its Board in Wake of Chiefs Dismissal
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Hewlett-Packard announced a major boardroom shake-up on Thursday in the aftermath of the forced resignation of Mark V. Hurd as its chief executive.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Jan. 21-27
description: Art

title: Return to Civility, With Wit and Rhyme
description: While watching Steve Ross, the dapper, well-mannered singer and pianist, go through his paces at Tuesdays opening-night performance of Rhythm & Romance, his new show at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel, I imagined what the cast of Jersey Shore might make of it.

title: Movie Listings for Jan. 21-27
description: Movies

title: Photos of the Moment | Thierry Mugler
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#405", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Prominent British Muslim Assails Prejudice
description: Stirring a potentially explosive debate over faith and politics, the first Muslim woman to serve in the British cabinet said on Thursday that prejudice towards the countrys Islamic minority is so prevalent that it is seen by many as normal and uncontroversial and has passed the dinner table test.

title: Keeping Score: The Bad Contract
description: Justin Kubatko is the creator of Basketball-Reference.com, an online basketball encyclopedia. He is also a statistical consultant for the Trail Blazers.

title: Where Wax (Rip! Ouch!) Is Queen
description: Malynda Vigliotti opened her waxing salon, the Boom Boom Brow Bar, in the spring of 2008, the same week the financial markets began their drastic downturn. And her potential customers, a species of well-maintained New Yorkers who operate under a No Follicle Left Behind edict, stayed home.

title: Mechanics and Grace Found in Small Tasks
description: There are so many ways to talk about the cultural differences between the performance and visual art worlds (and curators seem at pains to do so, emphasizing which context an artist should be seen in, so we poor huddled masses might better direct our gazes). Comparing and contrasting the consumer mores of each world is one of the more enjoyable methods for framing the conversation. Which group tends to be titillated by nudity and which bored, for example, or which will spend lots of time to see something but not lots of money, and vice versa?

title: Spare Times for Jan. 21-27
description: Around Town

title: When Luck Plays a Role in Selling a Home
description: WITH the last year such a dismal and confusing period for so many home sellers in New Jersey, some inevitably decided along the way to drop one agent and try another.

title: D.C. Firm Signs On to Represent Former Ivory Coast Prime Minister
description: Covington & Burling, one of Washingtons blue-chip law firms, has signed on to represent Alassane Ouattara, the former Ivory Coast prime minister, in his widely supported effort to claim the west African nations disputed presidency.

title: Need a Ride? Theres an App for That
description: From our colleagues at the Green blog:

title: Warily, Newtown Weighs New Housing
description: TEN years ago, when Newtown residents voted to buy the former state psychiatric institution at the center of town, their primary aim was to head off housing developers eying its 185-acre campus.

title: In This Cubicle World, Actions Speak Loudest
description: Its tempting to say that Room 17B is like a lot of offices in Manhattan, especially the ones in the financial district: whatever work is being done in there is mysterious and produces no tangible product or benefit. But thats only partly true. While its not clear what line of work the four inhabitants of Room 17B are in, they do generate something of value: laughter.

title: Q & A
description: Transferring Shares to an Adult Child

title: When War Begins, Nothing Is Normal
description: War teaches you the value of an onion, one character explains while preparing dinner in the harrowing but credulity-straining Honey Brown Eyes. And while the promising young playwright Stefanie Zadravec makes it clear that such values can be almost meaningless in a world where soldiers discuss the relative sexual merits of 10- versus 12-year-old girls, her shrewd juxtaposition of domesticity and atrocity very nearly overcomes the plays narrative faults.

title: Michele Kleier
description: Ms. Kleier is a co-president of Gumley Haft Kleier, a boutique brokerage firm that specializes in luxury properties and developments in Manhattan.

title: Child Soldiers on an Adult Rampage
description: Like a rifle butt to the head, Johnny Mad Dog leaves you reeling. Shot in Liberia but set in Anyplace, Africa, Jean-Stphane Sauvaires morally complex, visually horrifying tale of child soldiers on an adult rampage never lets up.

title: Love Versus Class Barriers
description: My muse, my whore, my beloved: thats what Arun, a gloomy artist, calls Bombay in Kiran Raos Dhobi Ghat (Mumbai Diaries). (Despite the titles Mumbai, everyone here says Bombay.) Its certainly Ms. Raos muse: she seems mesmerized by its hurly-burly and has tried to find a narrative that can contain its multitudes.

title: Life Among the Young and Confused
description: Lawrence Michael Levines Gabi on the Roof in July, with a title that evokes Eric Rohmer and a creative process that resembles Mike Leighs long-term structured improvisations, is a kind of negative argument in favor of the auteur theory. Talented performers have developed credible characters and realistic scenes of life among the young and confused in bohemian Brooklyn, but there doesnt seem to have been anyone involved who could shape the material, give it a point of view and a pulse, and make it add up to something more than a sharply observed acting exercise. The shock of recognition dissipates, to be replaced by the glance at the wristwatch.

title: A Haunting Tour, One Room at a Time
description: The main attraction at the Whitney Museum of American Art right now (after the Edward Hopper show) is a parakeet named Peetie. This live, chirping bird, the only replaceable component of Edward Kienholzs 1964-65 assemblage The Wait, animates a comically morbid tableau of old bones, faded photographs and musty wallpaper. An elderly woman  her thin frame fashioned from a cows skeleton  holds a taxidermic cat on her lap; above her is a portrait of a young man, a dear departed husband or absent son.

title: A Paragon of Hard Living
description: In the worlds of hard rock and heavy metal, Ian Fraser Kilmister, the singer, bassist and central piston behind the band Motrhead, is not only a musical influence but also a paragon of hard living, like Keith Richards, only without the pretty-boy band mate, Top 40 hits and hippie associations. No, Lemmy  as he is known, the subject of this diverting if hagiographic documentary with an unprintable subtitle  specializes in industrial crunch served at missile velocity, a sound that once flourished in the factory precincts of Birmingham, England; and Detroit.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: Who Took $1 Billion Out of Man? Man Group, the publicly traded London-based hedge fund giant, disclosed on Thursday that a single investor withdrew $1 billion. The client, who was not identified, did not want to be exposed to European stocks any longer, the company said. Still, Man did not seem too concerned, noting that the money was in long-only funds, a very low margin business for the company. Bloomberg News

title: Letters: Time, the Enemy
description: Here is some reader response via e-mail to my most recent column from last Sunday, Time, the Enemy.

title: An Addition to the Giant-Robot Genre
description: Evangelion: 2.0: You Can (Not) Advance is the fourth movie to pick over the bones of the Japanese television series Neon Genesis Evangelion. That 1995 anime revolutionized the giant-robot genre and spawned a billion-dollar franchise, which may be why the films keep being released in the United States, even though the adult-oriented story never made much of an impression here.

title: Cravaths Woolery to Join JPMorgan as Senior Deal Maker
description: JPMorgan Chase said on Thursday that it had hired James C. Woolery, one of the top deal lawyers at Cravath, Swaine & Moore, as one of its senior mergers bankers, marking the latest big shift by a lawyer into banking.

title: So Much Time to Smell the Roses
description: Oh, to have free time  the things you could do! Search for a cheaper, larger apartment. Put in some hours at the gym, maybe. Finally organize your closet and give away a few bags of clothes to charity.

title: DEBORAH LUSTER: Tooth for an Eye
description: Jack Shainman Gallery

title: Liebermans Legacy on Accounting
description: Gail Collins, who has known Joe Lieberman since he was a local politician in Connecticut, ends her column about his decision not to seek re-election with a threat to write a book entitled, Everything Bad Is Joe Liebermans Fault.

title: VIVID and PAVERS
description: Schroeder Romero & Shredder

title: DAY JOB
description: The Drawing Center

title: PIOTR UKLANSKI: Discharge!
description: Gagosian

title: Winter Swims, With Views, in New York City
description: IT seems counterintuitive to want to jump in a pool when New York feels like a meat locker. But I do. Especially in pools under skylights, which make me feel as if Im swimming in an urban greenhouse.

title: Palestinian Authority Blocks Tunisia Rally
description: The Palestinian Authority refused to grant permission for a rally to celebrate the overthrow of Tunisias authoritarian president on Wednesday in Ramallah, the administrative capital of the West Bank.

title: House Tour: Pleasantville, N.Y.
Weekend Miser
description: It has been said that each time history repeats itself, the price goes up. Well, not so with this weeks events.

title: Experiments in the Aggressive and Supernatural
description: Dance Theater Workshops Dance Docents program, in which employees are available to answer questions from the audience about the work being performed, has prompted no small amount of eye rolling among the organizations generally sophisticated fan base. But on Tuesday night I had my first inquiry appropriate for the docent: Why on earth was the workshop presenting Sidra Bell Dance New York and Andrea Millers Gallim Dance? And was this a sign of things to come at New York Live Arts, the entity created by the recent merger of the Dance Theater Workshop and the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company?

title: Classical-Pop Border, No Guards in Sight
description: After kicking off with an exciting eight-hour marathon on Monday, the Ecstatic Music Festival, devoted to collaborations by young artists working on the increasingly permeable border between classical music and pop, began in earnest on Wednesday evening with a concert by the Chiara String Quartet at Merkin Concert Hall.

title: 1930s Childrens Art on Display in SoHo
description: The Works Progress Administration kept artists employed during the Great Depression, teaching the masses. In New York City about 50,000 people a week, mostly children, took free painting and drawing classes at community centers.

title: When Art Dallied With Poetry on 53rd Street
description: I dont believe in golden ages, but I do believe in golden moments. Culturally speaking, New York City has had its share, and one began at the end of 1950 when Tibor de Nagy Gallery opened on 53rd Street near Third Avenue in Manhattan.

title: Paris Mens: Local Heroes
description: Mens fashion owes a lot to uniforms, military and civilian, and contemporary designers seem to love both the traditions as well as the sense of heroism. Dries Van Noten presented his fall collection on Thursday night in a sculpture museum, where the figures were suitably larger than life. White cotton trousers, peacoats with rough fur-trimmed lapels, and chunky fisherman sweaters alluded to the sea, while wide-leg flannel suits and top coats pointed to an elegant urban uniform.

title: Agassi Selected to Hall of Fame
description: When his wife, Stefanie Graf, was inducted into the International Hall of Fame in 2004, Andre Agassi gave a memorable, emotional speech introducing her, giving himself a tough act to follow now that he has been inducted himself.

title: Verizon Challenges New Net Rules
description: The legal challenges to the Federal Communication Commissions net neutrality order have begun.

title: Artifacts | The Curse of 57th Street
description: The opening this week of a new gallery in Midtown has generated unusual confusion in the worlds of art and fashion. Because the gallerys name is fordProject, it has been promoted as a division of Ford Models, and many of us who have seen fashion climb on the back of art  and vice versa  to broaden its audience naturally assumed that the gallery was an offshoot of the agency.

title: Hot Licks
description: Models backstage at Rick Owens with their hair slicked into little wings.

title: U.S. Warning to China Sends Ripples to the Koreas
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama warned President Hu Jintao that if China did not step up its pressure on North Korea, the United States would have to redeploy its forces in Asia to protect itself from a potential North Korean strike on American soil, a senior administration official said Thursday.

title: Pushing the Limits of Endurance
description: The Way Back, a heroically minded survival story from Peter Weir, tells the possibly true tale of a group of prisoners who fled a Soviet gulag in 1940 and walked, wandered and all but crawled to freedom. For months a veritable league of national types, united by desperation and the English language, push through the cold and the heat, slipping through forests and across mountains and deserts. Surviving on moldering provisions and precious scraps of protein, dodging predators, two-legged and four-, the travelers embody a besieged humanity that might have been more stirring if their torment were in a rather less exquisite frame.

title: A Familiar Story of Boy Meets Girl, but in Yiddish
description: In Shakespeares tragedy, Romeo is so steeped in love poetry that Juliet accuses him of kissing by the book. By contrast, Lazer Weiss, who plays the lead role in the new film Romeo and Juliet in Yiddish, didnt understand the concept of romantic love until he was in his 20s.

title: A Smorgasbord of Fine Art, the Strange and the Old
description: It is Everything Old Is New Again Week in New York, with antiques fairs and exhibitions popping up all over Manhattan. This weekend, three of the most lavishly expansive are displaying collectibles of almost every conceivable kind, from ancient Egyptian sculpture to midcentury modern dcor. Each has a distinctly different appeal.

title: ABC Gives Jimmy Kimmel a Midnight Boost
description: ABC will give its late-night star Jimmy Kimmel a significant boost by moving up his starting time to midnight starting Feb. 4.

title: Tibor de Nagy Painters & Poets
description: Images from the new exhibition.

title: Mad Women
description: Halfway through A Strange Stirring, the social historian Stephanie Coontz  parsing the reception of The Feminine Mystique, Betty Friedans 1963 examination of middle-class female repression and despair  confesses to feeling some ambivalence over Friedans project, and hence her own.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Jan. 15 through 19 with 1,036 adults throughout the United States.

title: Willie Mays's Harlem
description: In 2011, Willie Mays and the San Francisco Giants toured New York with the teams 2010 World Series trophy. William Rhoden, a Sports of The Times columnist, went in search of the Harlem that gave Mays his start in the 1950s.

title: The Walk Across America for Mother Earth
description: Images from the new comedy by Taylor Mac.

title: Poll Finds Wariness About Cutting Entitlements
description: As President Obama and Congress brace to battle over how to reduce chronic annual budget deficits, Americans overwhelmingly say that in general they prefer cutting government spending to paying higher taxes, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Fashion Channel
description: Call it extreme quilting, but a number of designers fancy a beefed up version of the techniqueat Mugler, Jean Paul Gaultier and Louis Vuitton. Some of the coats at Vuitton had a channeled flap that offered a built-in cushion. Imagine all the football fans who would appreciate something like that on a cold day.

title: What It All Means
description: By the time they contemplate an application to graduate school, philosophy students have learned that it isnt merely tacky to display an interest in questions about the meaning of life; its a major professional risk. For many decades, British and American students were urged to turn their attention instead to the meaning of language, while European philosophers were engaged in more portentous-sounding but equally arcane diversions. There were occasional, notable exceptions  Stanley Cavells work showed how the meaning of ones words and the meaning of ones life might coincide  but then Cavell was long considered to stand outside the real business of philosophy. Even more fatally, students were introduced to the history of philosophy as a series of epistemological puzzles decontaminated from troubling concerns about what it means to be human, a question that had moved the great philosophers of the canon as surely as any thoughtful 18-year-old.

title: The Philosophical Novel
description: Can a novelist write philosophically? Even those novelists most commonly deemed philosophical have sometimes answered with an emphatic no. Iris Murdoch, the longtime Oxford philosopher and author of some two dozen novels treating highbrow themes like consciousness and morality, argued that philosophy and literature were contrary pursuits. Philosophy calls on the analytical mind to solve conceptual problems in an austere, unselfish, candid prose, she said in a BBC interview broadcast in 1978, while literature looks to the imagination to show us something mysterious, ambiguous, particular about the world. Any appearance of philosophical ideas in her own novels was an inconsequential reflection of what she happened to know. If I knew about sailing ships I would put in sailing ships, she said. And in a way, as a novelist, I would rather know about sailing ships than about philosophy.

title: Lives of the Philosophers, Warts and All
description: If the proof of a pudding is in the eating, and the proof of a rule is in the exceptions, where should we look for the proof of a philosophy?

title: Up Front: Sarah Bakewell
description: These days, the question of how to live a meaningful life seems to have been banished from philosophy departments. But as it happens, the cover of this weeks issue features two new books  by academics, no less  arguing that philosophy still has much to say about real life, and vice versa.

title: Limits Are for Testing
description: The artist Laurel Nakadate negotiates the margins of loneliness and sexual tension.

title: Capt. Mark E. Kelly Speaks at Conference
description: Capt. Mark E. Kelly, the husband of Representative Gabrielle Giffords, spoke at a news conference on Thursday in Tucson. (Video: MSNBC)

title: Regulator to Lower Threshold for Agricultural Trading
description: Small farmers could be coming soon to a trading floor near you, if the Commodity Futures Trading Commission has its way.

title: Poll Responses on How to Cut the Deficit
description: Results of a New York Times/CBS News poll about the federal budget deficit.

title: Feathering Their Nests In Plastic to Get Ahead
description: Fast cars and big homes might be stereotypical status symbols in American society, but in the world of black kites, its all about the white plastic.

title: The Deficit We Want
description: We have come to believe a story about the deficit that is largely not true.

title: Warner Music Plan: Buy or Be Bought
description: 7:55 p.m. | Updated

title: Far Fewer Schools Earn Performance Bonuses
description: Teachers at just 26 city schools will receive schoolwide bonuses this year, down from about 160 schools last year, as far fewer schools met their performance targets on state standardized tests.

title: Lia Batkin and Seth Kaplan
description: IF, as legend has it, soul mates are bound by an invisible thread, then by the time Lia Batkin and Seth Kaplan discovered each other, their lives had already been woven into a dense tapestry.

title: Warner Music Puts Itself Up for Sale
description: Tim Arango and Andrew Ross Sorkin have the story and our friends at DealBook give all the details:

title: The Critter Himself
description: When the bohemian sculptor with the unlikely name moved into Springfield, Ill., in the closing days of 1860, his intended subject, the towns most famous resident, was getting ready to move out of the office he had occupied there for seven months. The approaching Illinois legislative session meant President-elect Abraham Lincolns space would be re-claimed by the governor. Arranging formal sittings would not be easy.

title: Paul the Octopus: A Cephalopod Out of Water
description: The ode to Paul the cctopus is complete. Talismanic is certainly an overused word (have you ever seen it used more than in soccer stories, mostly from across the sea?), but it seems it applies to Paul, at least in the mind of soccer-crazed Germans.

title: The Risks and Rewards of Petrobras
description: Petrobras, Brazils energy giant, will pay bond investors about a percentage point more in yield than the government that controls it. With sovereign bond yields so low and Brazilian inflation flaring up, bond buyers interested in the South American country could be better off lending to its oil-backed corporate proxy.

title: Mitsubishi to Discontinue Eclipse and Galant
description: Looking to jump-start its stalled American car sales and meet environmental targets around the world, Mitsubishi is placing a big bet on electricity. Under a global plan announced Thursday, the company plans to offer six new plug-in hybrid and battery-electric models by 2015.

title: Reynolds Price, a Literary Voice of the South, Dies at 77
description: Reynolds Price, whose novels and stories about ordinary people in rural North Carolina struggling to find their place in the world established him as one of the most important voices in modern Southern fiction, died on Thursday in Durham, N.C. He was 77.

title: App Smart Extra: GuitarJack
description: This weeks App Smart column features apps that turn your iPhone, iPod Touch or iPad into a special effects studio for guitarists. They work best with hardware accessories that cost around $30.

title: Like a Banner in Defeat
description: With this first sentence of his novel A Long and Happy Life, published in 1962, Reynolds Price made one of the most arresting debuts in contemporary American fiction:

title: For Small Hedge Funds, Success Brings New Headaches
description: The hedge fund manager Grange Johnson of LaGrange Capital Partners had a banner year in 2010. His two portfolios returned nearly 70 percent in a period when the average hedge fund gained about 10 percent.

title: Why Parents Fear the Needle
description: Wellesley, Mass.

title: As U.S. Patients Await Organ Transplants, Potential Donors Struggle for Visas
description: The clock is ticking for Dr. Gabriel Danovitchs patient. Dr. Danovitch, a transplant surgeon at the David Geffen School of Medicine at the University of California, Los Angeles, is treating an immigrant from Mexico in his 40s whose kidneys have failed. The patient is a good candidate for a transplant and has a donor, his brother.

title: Yanks Add Andruw Jones; Newest Met Discusses Injuries
description: The Yankees and the free agent Andruw Jones agreed to terms on a one-year, $2 million contract Thursday, all but eliminating the possibility of Johnny Damons return to the team. Jones, a right-handed hitter once considered the most gifted center fielder in baseball, will serve as a backup outfielder.

title: Dress Code, Not Strict, Is Adopted for Cabbies
description: The revised dress code for New York City cabdrivers is officially on the books.

title: Scots Tell London, Hands Off Our Clocks
description: INVERNESS, Scotland  The question was time, and whether to support legislative efforts in London to move it around in order to bring more light to the afternoons. The answer was no, said Jean Kaka, 67, a resident of this city far to the north.

title: Missing Inventory Plagues Dept. of Public Safety, but Only Some of It Is Theft
description: A 24-foot boat. A $74,000 piece of radio equipment. More than 150 handguns and rifles.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for

title: Lack of Transmission Lines Is Restricting Wind Power
description: Texas is in the midst of a wind-power boom, and at the heart of it lies a conundrum: While plenty of ranchers are eager to host wind turbines, few want the unsightly high-voltage transmission lines needed to carry the power to distant cities running through their property.

title: At Google, a Boost From E-Commerce
description: Googles strong fourth-quarter earnings proved that it is now firmly ensconced in e-commerce, and also showed that, with its Android operating system and related apps, it is smoothly transitioning to the mobile world.

title: Rumblings of Change at Top of the Ladder
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

title: An NBC Departure Before Comcast Takeover
description: Angela Bromstad, who has led the prime-time program development at NBC as the president of the Universal television studio, became the latest executive casualty of the coming takeover of NBC Universal by Comcast when she abruptly told her staff on Thursday she was leaving the company.

title: F.D.A. Sees Promise in Alzheimers Imaging Drug
description: An advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration recommended unanimously Thursday that the agency approve the first test  a brain scan  that can show the characteristic plaques of Alzheimers disease in the brain of a living person. The approval was contingent on radiologists agreeing on what the scans say and doctors being trained in how to read the scans.

title: Traffic Survey Shows Movement in Rankings, if Not on Roads
description: ATLANTA  Traffic is Atlantas Godzilla, a monster of gigantic proportions that seems too big to defeat.

title: Chicago: Crossroads, or Parking Lot?
description: CHICAGO  As a truck driver who braves the freeways here every day, Jerry McNamara did not need a study to tell him that this city has the worst traffic congestion in the country.

title: Brazil: Toll Rises Again in Mudslides
description: More than a week after torrential rains caused mudslides in mountain towns north of Rio de Janeiro, the death toll has risen to at least 747 people, while rescue workers struggle to locate an additional 333 people who are still missing. A Red Cross helicopter involved in the rescue effort crashed in strong winds in Nova Friburgo, where the bodies of eight family members were found and carried out, above, on Thursday. A military spokesman said the crew and passengers suffered only light injuries.

title: Jets Running Game to Collide With Steelers Defense
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The Jets want to run the ball against the Pittsburgh Steelers, want to showcase their ground-and-pound philosophy, want to control the clock.

title: Paul Picerni, Actor in Untouchables, Dies at 88
description: Paul Picerni, a prolific television and screen actor best known as Agent Eliot Nesss right-hand man in the hit 1960s series The Untouchables, died on Jan. 12 at his home in Llano, Calif. He was 88.

title: Afghanistan: Soldier Killed by Afghan
description: An Italian soldier who had been reported killed by insurgents in western Afghanistan this week was instead killed by an Afghan soldier, the NATO-led coalition said Thursday. NATO had initially reported that two soldiers, identified by Italian officials as Italians, were killed in an insurgent attack in the Bala Murghab district of Badghis Province on Tuesday. On Thursday, the coalition amended the report, saying the two soldiers were cleaning their weapons when an Afghan soldier approached them with an M-16 rifle and asked to use their equipment to clean his weapon. The Italians noticed that the Afghan soldiers rifle was loaded and asked him to unload it. The Afghan soldier reacted by shooting the Italians and then fleeing the outpost, NATO said. One soldier was killed and the other wounded.

title: In Nashville, Debate Over Racetrack Pits Nostalgia and Change
description: NASHVILLE  Shannon McCullough has a favorite lullaby, and it begins with the revving of a carbureted V8 engine. From her house on Merritt Avenue she could hear it most of her life, the hypnotic, oscillating drone as the stock cars approached and receded, approached and receded.

title: Volcker Rule May Work, Even if Vague
description: Paul A. Volcker is a giant of financial history. He played a behind-the-scenes role when the United States abandoned the gold standard in 1971. He restored credibility to the Federal Reserve and slew inflation a decade later.

title: Report Warns City Is Yoked to Maker of Payroll System
description: An independent report warns that New York City could be too reliant for the foreseeable future on the company that has built the troubled and expensive CityTime automated payroll system.

title: Teams Are Unknown, but Super Bowl Spots Line Up
description: PEOPLE who plan to watch Super Bowl XLV on Fox on Feb. 6 are likely to be, to borrow a word from the gossipmonger Walter Winchell, infanticipating.

title: Advanced Micro Devices Predicts Strong Quarter
description: Advanced Micro Devices, the second-largest maker of processors for personal computers after Intel, says sales this quarter will be higher than analysts estimates. Intel this month also indicated that demand for personal computers was improving.

title: In Sperling, a Political Strategist Known for Getting It Done
description: WASHINGTON  Weeks ago, President Obama told confidants that Gene Sperling, a counselor at the Treasury Department, was indispensable. Yet the president wrestled with whether to name him as the chief White House economic adviser, even knowing Mr. Sperling might leave if passed over.

title: Jets Fans Jam Times Square
description: A noisy green interlude descended upon Times Square during rush hour Thursday evening.

title: A Short-Circuit to Distracted Driving
description: Cellular carriers, having spent years trying to blanket the nation with phone service, are now working on ways to stop people from getting calls and texts when they are behind the wheel.

title: Banks Want Pieces of Fannie and Freddies Business
description: As the Obama administration prepares a report on the future of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, some of the nations largest banks are offering a few suggestions.

title: 50 Years After the New Frontier Dawned, a Toast to Kennedy
description: WASHINGTON  Old habits die hard, even five decades later.

title: A Path Is Sought for States to Escape Their Debt Burdens
description: Policymakers are working behind the scenes to come up with a way to let states declare bankruptcy and get out from under crushing debts, including the pensions they have promised to retired public workers.

title: Verizon Sues F.C.C. to Overturn Order on Blocking Web Sites
description: WASHINGTON  Less than a month after the Federal Communications Commission adopted an order aimed at keeping Internet service providers from blocking access to certain Web content or applications, Verizon asked a federal appeals court on Thursday to overturn the new rule.

title: Myth of the Hero Gunslinger
description: PHOENIX  To many gun owners, the question of whether to arm even more people in a country that already has upwards of 300 million guns is as calcified as a Sonoran Desert petroglyph. Its written in stone, among the fiercest of firearms advocates, that more guns equals fewer deaths.

title: Even Bears Players Are Wary of Soldier Fields Slippery Turf
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill.  It has been called Chicagos Soldier Field since the 1920s as a memorial to World War I armed forces, which may surprise some recent opposing football teams who thought it was so named because an army marched across it  with tanks in tow.

title: Charting a Winding Job Path, With a Smile
description: When a woman responsible for hiring at Amtrak asked her what sort of work she could do, Katawba Battersbee had an answer ready. Well, she said, Im personable.

title: G.O.P. Bloc Presses Leaders to Slash Even More
description: WASHINGTON  House Republican leaders confronted pressure from conservatives on Thursday to take more aggressive steps to cut federal spending, with a large group of lawmakers calling for outlays to be slashed by $2.5 trillion over the next decade, far more than the party has sought so far.

title: Jets Fans Unite!
description: The workweek hasnt officially ended yet, but several thousand very excited fans of the New York Jets gathered for a pep rally in Times Square Thursday evening, in anticipation of Sundays big A.F.C. championship game against the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: House Republicans Plan Their Own Health Bills
description: WASHINGTON  Less than 24 hours after voting to repeal the new health care law, House Republicans said Thursday that they would pass discrete bills to achieve some of the same goals, but with more restraint in the use of federal power.

title: At Midpoint, the Knicks Are Assessing Their Needs
description: SAN ANTONIO  The loading dock doors lifted, and a frigid breeze swept across the AT&T Center court, turning the final minutes of a midday practice into a spontaneous hand-warming session. Players scurried to the team bus, temporarily shielding themselves from the January chill.

title: Sundance Is Selling, but Prices Are Down
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Hollywood is back in the mood to buy indie films  even if not at the old prices that came with inflated expectations.

title: China Goes to Nixon
description: With Hu Jintao, Chinas president, currently visiting the United States, stories about growing Chinese economic might are everywhere. And those stories are entirely true: although China is still a poor country, its growing fast, and given its sheer size its well on the way to matching America as an economic superpower.

title: Turkeys Rules
description: In the fall of 2009, relations between Serbia and Bosnia  never easy since the savage civil war of the 1990s  were slipping toward outright hostility. Western mediation efforts had failed. Ahmet Davutoglu, the foreign minister of Turkey, offered to step in. It was a complicated role for Turkey, not least because Bosnia is, like Turkey, a predominantly Muslim country and Serbia is an Orthodox Christian nation with which Turkey had long been at odds. But Davutoglu had shaped Turkeys ambitious foreign policy according to a principle he called zero problems toward neighbors. Neither Serbia nor Bosnia actually shares a border with Turkey. Davutoglu, however, defined his neighborhood expansively, as the vast space of former Ottoman dominion. In six months, Davutoglu told me in one of a series of conversations this past fall, I visited Belgrade five times, Sarajevo maybe seven times. He helped negotiate names of acceptable diplomats and the language of a Serbian apology for the atrocities in Srebrenica. Bosnia agreed, finally, to name an ambassador to Serbia. To seal the deal, as Davutoglu tells the tale, he met late one night at the Sarajevo airport with the Bosnian leader Haris Silajdzic. The Bosnian smoked furiously. Davutoglu, a pious Muslim, doesnt smoke  but he made an exception: I smoked; he smoked. Silajdzic accepted the Serbian apology. Crisis averted. Davutoglu calls this diplomatic style smoking like a Bosnian.

title: Judge Suggests Evidence in Terror Case Supports Conviction
description: A federal judge in Manhattan suggested on Thursday that he believed there was strong evidence to support the conviction last fall of a former Guantnamo detainee on a single count of conspiracy stemming from the 1998 bombings of two American Embassies in East Africa.

title: Questions Remain in Case of Abducted Baby Who Turned Up 23 Years Later
description: As news came that a baby girl abducted from a Harlem hospital 23 years ago was alive, an array of people in her life began absorbing how the closing of the case was resolving at least two mysteries.

title: Queens Power Plant Receives Final Approval for Construction
description: State utilities regulators gave final approval on Thursday for the construction of a $1.4 billion power plant in Astoria, Queens. Now, the company that plans to build it needs to find a buyer for the electricity it will generate.

title: Lottery Numbers
Pilot Program of Teacher Bonuses Is Suspended
description: New York Citys Education Department said Thursday that it was suspending one of the signature experiments of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs control of city schools, a multimillion-dollar program that awards annual bonuses to teachers based on student performance.

title: A Most Valuable Democrat
description: In the spring of 2008, John McCain asked Joe Lieberman to speak on his behalf at the Republican National Convention. If I look back, I wonder about it, Lieberman now says. But it seemed the natural way to help the man he deemed most qualified to be president.

title: A Losers Desert for New York Fans
description: It has been 42 years since the Jets won a championship, but their fortunes are not exactly distinctive. The records of the Knicks, Mets and Rangers have been disappointing for the proud and loud New York sports fan.

title: Asian Cup: Plenty of Good Seats Still Available
description: Sepp Blatter, the FIFA president, put himself figuratively on the hot seat two weeks ago when he suggested that it would be too hot in Qatar during the Northern Hemispheres summer months to play the 2022 World Cup.

title: Weighing In on State Bankruptcies
description: Prominent economic and political leaders state their views on establishing a bankruptcy procedure for states.

title: New York: A Champ When It Comes to Losing
description: It has been 42 years since the Jets won a championship  four decades of failure and fiasco that, with any luck, might come to an end with a victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers on Sunday and another in the Super Bowl in Arlington, Tex., on Feb. 6.

title: Letter: Questions for Regina Benjamin
description: I was aghast when Deborah Solomon asked Benjamin how her brother contracted AIDS. I thought we had moved well beyond the day when people cared how somebody contracted the disease. In the early days of the epidemic, the questions about how somebody acquired H.I.V. or AIDS were asked to find out if the person living with it was an innocent victim or somebody who deserved what he (most frequently at that point) got. Thus, if the person acquired the virus because he was a homosexual or a drug user, it was thought to be his fault for engaging in risky behavior. However, if somebody  like Ryan White  acquired the virus through tainted blood, our hearts ached, even if we kept them at a distance. To ask that question now harks back to that dark day in a most distasteful way.

title: Some See a Cash Motive in Duvaliers Return
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  When Jean-Claude Duvalier suddenly emerged from exile last weekend, saying he was here to help his devastated homeland, fears immediately spread across the country that the former dictator had come to stake a new claim to power.

title: Letters: The Medium
description: While I appreciate any article that seeks to educate the public about hearing loss and its possible causes, I was dismayed to see the word deaf used to describe the slight to severe hearing loss that headphones can cause in Virginia Heffernans column Against Headphones. Deafness, versus any hearing impairment short of that, signifies an inability to hear anything at all; for those of us who can hear certain sounds but are unable to distinguish others (the author cites the plinking of raindrops as an example), hearing-impaired or hard of hearing are the proper descriptive terms for our condition. While attention-grabbing, the subheadline that headphones may be making you deaf is not only unnecessarily alarmist, it is terminologically inaccurate as well.

title: Candidates Question the Ways Tax Increment Financing Is Used
description: Nearly 300 church members, community activists and other area residents gathered in the auditorium of a Rogers Park school last Sunday to celebrate the legacy of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.  and to rally around a proposal to create a special taxing district that would finance neighborhood rental housing exclusively.

title: Letters: Fear (Again) of Flying
description: Is Judith Warner really going to equate upper-middle-class white womens doing yoga to the struggles of the 1970s feminist movement? Women, like my single mother, who fought to build communities of equality are not the same as women who do yoga to find a better self.

title: Letters: Things to Do in Cyberspace When Youre Dead
description: Unlike some of the people in Rob Walkers article on Internet existence after death, Im not too concerned about the information floating around the Web. I would like my hard drive and backup to delete themselves upon learning of my death. And I would like this to happen immediately, as news of my ceasing to breathe is received. This needs to be remote and wireless, of course, and automatic. And when I buy this off-the-shelf solution that someone will create, I will set the preferences to protect certain files (financial mainly) for my executor. Im hoping someone will soon be able to say, Theres an app for that.

title: Friday: Basis of Growth
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Is it me, or is Pete Mitchell trying to tell me something? Mind you, I dont believe for a second that people are trying to send me messages through their puzzles. Because that would sound deranged, right?

title: Protesters Armed With Wigs and Sequins
description: What to wear when youre about to chain yourself to a bowling alley to protest the nuclear arms race? Why, sequins, of course. Head to toe!

title: Debit Card Predators
description: Congress outlawed many of the credit card industrys most abusive practices in 2009. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which regulates about 4,800 state-chartered banks, recently did the same thing with the debit card industry. The banks, which are predictably crying foul, should not be allowed to evade the rules by switching to a less rigorous federal regulator.

title: Opposition in Tunisia Finds Chance for Rebirth
description: TUNIS  Ali Larayedh was imprisoned and tortured for 14 years for his role as a leader of the outlawed Islamist movement here, then hounded for the past six years by the omnipresent Tunisian secret police.

title: Tunisia, After Ben Ali
description: Tunisias people have achieved something rare and inspiring. Through a month of grass-roots protests, they overthrew a dictator, Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali. At a crucial moment, the Tunisian Army leader, Gen. Rachid Ammar, ordered his troops not to fire on their own people and then resisted the temptation to seize power for himself.

title: Bronx Schools Top Ranking Stirs Wider Doubts About Rating System
description: One of the trademarks of New York Citys school accountability system is an equation that assigns every school a letter grade, A through F, based on a numerical score from 1 to 100.

title: A Clear No for the Spruce Mine
