description: If the Obama administration stays the course, the Environmental Protection Agencys decision last week to revoke a permit for one of the nations biggest mountaintop-removal mining projects could be the beginning of the end of a mining practice that has caused huge environmental harm across Appalachia.

title: Capturing Chicagos Neighborhoods, One Face at a Time
description: Through the viewfinder of a camera, two artists, Adam Novak and Sara Collins, have seen a pair of Chicago police officers moonlight as bagpipe players, a fistfight break out on Milwaukee and Division, and an impromptu block party begin in Englewood when residents dragged a man-size speaker onto the street and started blasting Lee Oskars Haunted House.

title: Bloomberg Seeks to Show That He Cares
description: How can New Yorkers living in the outer boroughs  a terrible phrase sorely in need of reinvention  not feel the love emanating from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg? He has delivered 10 State of the City addresses, and all but one of them were in locations outside Manhattan.

title: Chinese Presidents Visit Proclaims a Rising Chicago
description: President Hu Jintao of China displayed pitch-perfect timing in making Chicago his only stop outside Washington. Arriving Thursday, he got our distilled essence: glum weather, a vibrant political campaign and, of course, The Game.

description: To the Editor:

title: Super Bowl Reshuffle
description: The Black Eyed Peas will perform at the Super Bowl halftime show, and as the frontman of the group, you presumably have been asked to choose songs that are relatively wholesome.I assume youre not playing your salacious hit My Humps. Were not playing that. Its a club song. Its like when I get around my mom, all my cuss words are deleted from my vocabulary. Automatically, they just leave. Super Bowl, yes, the words are not going to exist in my vocabulary.

title: The Pulse: Soup and Sociability, for a Worthy Cause
description: When Martha Bayne started bartending at the Hideout, she quickly realized she had to do something to combat the boredom and bad tips associated with her midweek shifts.

title: The Pulse: Name that School, Trim That Deficit
description: With Chicagos financially ailing public school system struggling to improve academic performance at its 675 public schools, education has emerged as a central issue in the municipal election.

title: Health Care Repeal Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Q & A With Jeanie Buss
description: Jeanie Buss may perform the most unique balancing act in sports. As the Los Angeles Lakers executive vice president of business operations, she influences one of the N.B.A.s most-storied franchises and lends a voice and an ear in the leagues ongoing labor negotiations. She also dates Lakers Coach Phil Jackson, who is in his final season coaching the team. Buss recently released Laker Girl, with Steve Springer, formerly a Lakers beat writer for The Los Angeles Times.

title: The Starbucks Logo
description: To the Editor:

title: Gordon Murray, Retired Wall St. Executive, Dies at 60; Wrote Investment Guide
description: Gordon S. Murray, a former Wall Street executive who chose not to go quietly into the night, writing and publishing himself a popular paperback guide for ordinary investors while he was struggling with terminal cancer, died Saturday at his home in Burlingame, Calif., days before his book was scheduled to come out in hardcover. He was 60.

title: President Karzais Latest
description: It took particular audacity for President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan to order Parliament to delay this weekends opening session while an unconstitutional court he appointed re-investigates charges of fraud in last falls parliamentary vote.

title: Band of Brothers Mark Gulf War Anniversary
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex.  The first President Bush, now 86, walked unsteadily to his seat on the stage. Former Vice President Dick Cheney, who was Mr. Bushs defense secretary, spoke as a mechanical device pumped his failing heart. The others were grayer, balder or bearers of the scars of fresher wars.

title: King of Big Waves Puts Attention Back on Paddle Surfing
description: Greg Long plans his life and surfing adventures from a spartan garage apartment in San Clemente, Calif., about a mile from his boyhood home. On a recent afternoon, Long, a fit and wiry 27-year-old, tracked a major storm on his laptop in order to time a trip to Hawaii.

title: The Vatican: Concern on Italy Scandal
description: The Vatican is watching the sex scandal engulfing the Italian prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, with concern, its secretary of state, Cardinal Tarcisio Bertone, said Thursday, the news agency ANSA reported. The cardinals remarks are a sign of Mr. Berlusconis growing political weakness a week after prosecutors began investigating whether he compensated a significant number of women, including a minor, for sex. The prime minister denies all wrongdoing. According to ANSA, Cardinal Bertone said the Roman Catholic Church urged greater morality and legality in public life, especially from those holding public office. His remarks were seen as lending support to centrist politicians who seek to oust Mr. Berlusconi. In a television interview on Wednesday, the minor, Karima el-Mahroug, denied that she had sex with Mr. Berlusconi or asked for money in exchange for her silence, as wiretapped phone conversations published in the Italian news media this week suggested.

title: Rethinking Evaluations When Almost Every Teacher Gets an A
description: Grade inflation  a term normally associated with students  is widespread among Bay Area teachers, who receive so many favorable evaluations that it is impossible to tell how well they are performing, some educators say.

title: In the Angry Arena of Tax Appeals, a Would-Be Mayor Sees Success
description: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen.

title: Bonus Payments to City Retirees Are Drawing Ire
description: As San Francisco struggles under ballooning pension and health care costs, the citys retirees will receive unexpected cost-of-living bonuses totaling $170 million. The citys anticipated budget deficit for the coming year is $360 million.

title: Music Groups Turn to Fans to Underwrite New Works
description: When the Bay Area flutist Meerenai Shim ran out of interesting music to play with her chamber ensemble, she did not content herself with repeating existing repertoire.

title: At the Kennedy Center, Gratitude to a President Fond of the Arts
description: President Obama and performing arts luminaries gathered at the Kennedy Center Thursday night to pay tribute to President John F. Kennedy on the 50th anniversary of his inauguration, with many paying homage to the inspiration they drew from the slain president.

title: Emanuel Raises $10 Million in Mayoral Bid
description: CHICAGO  Rahm Emanuel, the former White House Chief of Staff, has raised more than $10 million in his quest to become mayor of Chicago.

description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y.  President Obama will name Jeffrey R. Immelt, the chief executive officer and chairman of General Electric, on Friday to run his outside panel of economic advisers, replacing Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman, who is stepping down, the White House said.

title: News Quiz | January 21, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Garry Kasparov: Playing for ING
description: Garry Kasparov, the former world champion, retired from chess in 2005, but he has kept busy. He became a leader of the opposition in Russia, he has become a popular speaker and he has written many books, mostly on chess.

description: As the Obama administration prepares a report on the future of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, some of the nations largest banks are offering a few suggestions, Louise Story reports in The New York Times.

description: HOW many people attended Wednesday evenings state dinner?

title: At Iraq Inquiry, Blair Offers Regrets for Loss of Life
description: LONDON  A year after he first testified before Britains official inquiry into the invasion of Iraq, Tony Blair, the former prime minister, returned on Friday to revisit his reasons for going to war and, he said, to do something he did not do the first time around  express his regret for the loss of life.

title: Little Progress Is Seen in Iran Talks
description: ISTANBUL  Talks between Iran and six world powers made little progress on Friday, with a late-night plenary session becoming tense and even acrimonious before an agreement to meet again on Saturday, senior Western diplomats said.

title: Private Equity Drives Calpers Gains
description: The California Public Employees Retirement System, the largest American public pension fund, said Thursday that its investments had brought in a return of 12.5 percent last year, bringing its assets to $225.7 billion despite persistent losses in real estate.

title: American Idols Second Night Was Tolerable at Best
description: So much angst about the new season of American Idol  will the new judges, Steven Tyler and Jennifer Lopez, blend well with the holdover from Idol 1.0, Randy Jackson? Will the show be able to finally mint another bona fide pop star, not a mope-rocker who moms want to cuddle? Will Ms. Lopez be barred from performing on stage? Who does Jimmy Iovines teeth?

title: Life Partners Confirms Investigation
description: Life Partners Holdings on Thursday acknowledged it was under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission, confirming a story in The Wall Street Journal.

description: Todays word, in association with the scholarly Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: What News Stories Have Surprised You Recently?
description: In the New York Region section of The Times this week, there was a story headlined Woman Abducted as Infant in 1987 Meets Family. In the Science section there was a story about a dog who knows 1,022 nouns. In the National section there was an article titled Parenting by Gays More Common in the South, Census Shows. Do any of these surprise you? What other news have you heard, read or seen in the last month that has surprised you for some reason? Why?

title: Stuffed, Bearded, Tattooed and Mop-Topped
description: Yvette Marie Dostatni, 39, is hooked on conventions. Whenever she isnt in class at the Art Institute of Chicago, earning her B.F.A. in photography  or on assignment for The Times in northwest Indiana and the southeast Chicago suburbs, where she has worked since she was 17  Ms. Dostatni scours newspapers and the Web to find gatherings from banal to bizarre.

title: South Korea Rescues Crew and Ship From Pirates
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korean special forces staged a daring early morning rescue on a hijacked freighter hundreds of miles off the coast of Somalia on Friday, killing eight pirates and rescuing all 21 hostages, the South Korean military said.

title: Bears and Packers in Postseason: A History of Missing Each Other
description: The Chicago Bears and the Green Bay Packers are two of the storied franchises in the N.F.L., with 21 championships between them and a rivalry that dates to the early 1920s. So how have they gone 70 years without meeting in the playoffs?

title: Surveying Madrids Culinary Landscape
description: Though Madrid Fusion, which runs Jan. 25 to 27, is the more established and exclusive event, this year, for the second time, theres an accompanying event intended to examine the relationship between food and wine and the rest of the cultural spectrum. From Jan. 24 to Feb. 6, Gastrofestival celebrates all aspects of the culinary landscape of Madrid, including food and wines relationship to art, cinema, theater, fashion and literature, in venues around the city.

description: From Todays Times:

title: Reviewer Spotlight: Rebecca Traister
description: This weekend in the Book Review, Rebecca Traister reviews Stephanie Coontzs latest book, A Strange Stirring: The Feminine Mystique and American Women at the Dawn of the 1960s. As a senior writer for Salon, Traister has spent the past few years covering women in politics and the media. She is the author of Big Girls Dont Cry: The Election That Changed Everything for American Women, which grew out of her experience covering the 2008 presidential election.

description: This weekend in the Book Review, Rebecca Traister reviews Stephanie Coontzs latest book, A Strange Stirring: The Feminine Mystique and American Women at the Dawn of the 1960s. As a senior writer for Salon, Traister has spent the past few years covering women in politics and the media. She is the author of Big Girls Dont Cry: The Election That Changed Everything for American Women, which grew out of her experience covering the 2008 presidential election.

title: Top Cameron Aide Quits Over Phone-Hacking Scandal
description: LONDON  In an embarrassing blow to Prime Minister David Camerons coalition government, Downing Streets communications director, Andy Coulson, resigned on Friday amid continued questions about his possible involvement in the illegal hacking of celebrity telephone messages when he was editor of the tabloid newspaper The News of the World.

title: Mortgage Woes Lead to $2.2 Billion Loss at Bank of America
description: Brendan Hoffman/Bloomberg NewsBrian Moynihan, chief executive of Bank of America.

title: Bucyrus Shareholders Support Caterpillar Deal
description: Bucyrus, the mining equipment maker set to be acquired by Caterpillar for $7.6 billion, said Thursday in a regulatory filing that shareholders had voted to approve the deal.

title: Mr. President, Say This on Tuesday Night
description: With four days until President Obama gives his State of the Union address, interest groups have buried the White House with a barrage of unsolicited advice about what they want him to say.

title: G.E. Profit Rises 51%, Topping Forecasts
description: General Electric said on Friday that it closed the books on 2010 with strong earnings and a backlog of new orders that position the company for growth in 2011.

title: Previewed: New York International Motorcycle Show
description: What do the housing industry and the motorcycle industry have in common these days? Its a buyers market.

title: Travel Day
description: Probably no posting, unless we get stranded in some airport somewhere.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

title: The Greatest
description: HERE goes. This article completes my two-week project to select the top 10 classical music composers in history, not including those still with us. The argument, laid out in a series of articles, online videos and blog posts, was enlivened by the more than 1,500 informed, challenging, passionate and inspiring comments from readers of The New York Times. As often as I could, I answered direct questions online and jumped into the discussion.

title: New Japanese Fashion: LED Lights for Your Teeth
description: 12:36 p.m. | Updated to clarify that the accessories are not commercially available. The LED lights were made for an advertising campaign, and there are no plans at this time to produce them for sale.

title: Test Yourself | History, Jan. 21, 2011
description: Test your knowledge of history with todays question about the death of a Russian revolutionary.

title: Williams Team Contemplating Going Public
description: The Williams Formula One team, the third most successful in the series history behind Ferrari and McLaren, announced on Friday that it was contemplating going public with the company in order to ensure its long-term future.

title: Williams Team Contemplating Going Public
description: The Williams Formula One team, the third most successful in the series history behind Ferrari and McLaren, announced on Friday that it was contemplating going public with the company in order to ensure its long-term future.

title: Positional Revolution Turns to Small Forwards
description: With each passing season, the need to reclassify basketballs positional system becomes more obvious. Waves of unique players come into the N.B.A. every year, and many pay the price for its reluctance to adapt; some of the leagues most intriguing talents are poorly utilized, buried deep on the bench, or cast off because they dont fit neatly into the games positional molds. The lines that separate positions are arbitrary and limiting, and though a willingness to cross those lines is sometimes lauded (Hedo Turkoglu can run an offense!), just as often a cross-positional player is maligned for some transgression against the game (Monta Ellis isnt a real point guard! Burn him at the stake!).

title: Alzheimers Test Clears a Hurdle
description: An advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration recommended unanimously Thursday that the agency approve the first test able to diagnose Alzheimers disease in the brain of a living person, The Times reports this morning.

title: Morning Buzz | Case Not Closed, 23 Years Later
description: Grumble grumble winter wonderland grumble grumble. Heres the news.

title: French Court Convicts Executives in Vivendi Case
description: The media tycoons Jean-Marie Messier and Edgar Bronfman Jr. were convicted Friday of criminal charges and given suspended sentences in a case stemming from their tenure at the top of the French conglomerate Vivendi Universal and its near collapse eight years ago.

title: Coral Bleaching Prompts Thailand to Close Diving Sites
description: Some of Thailands most popular diving sites are now off-limits to tourists: Thai officials announced on Thursday that they were restricting access to seven marine national parks for up to a year to prevent further harm to coral reefs severely damaged by a long period of elevated sea temperatures last year.

title: Complaint Box | Powerless in Brooklyn
description: Of the boroughs outside Manhattan, Brooklyn gets the most buzz  as a tourist attraction, a hipster brand and an incubator of art and artisanal products. That has provoked a backlash from longtime Brooklynites and others wary of smugness from the boroughs Brownstone Belt.

title: GE Capital Bounces Back
description: Yuriko Nakao/ReutersGeneral Electrics Jeff Immelt.

title: Its Bobby Fischer Season
description: Bobby Fischer, the mercurial former world chess champion, died nearly three years ago, but lately his story is making a comeback.

title: New Lives for Dead Suburban Malls
description: The suburban shopping mall has fallen on hard times, and Ellen Dunham-Jones, co-author of Retrofitting Suburbia: Urban Design Solutions for Redesigning Suburbs, is thrilled, frankly.

title: Out and About | Cruising the Caribbean
description: My latest adventure at sea  a cruise around the eastern Caribbean with my partner aboard the Celebrity Eclipse  taught me two valuable lessons. First, some people are just addicted to cruising. We met several passengers who were well beyond their 25th voyage, a milestone we may never get to. But this cruise, which began in Miami and had ports of call in Puerto Rico, St. Maarten and St. Kitts, whetted our appetite for more. Which brings me to Lesson No. 2: Cruise-ship food doesnt have to be bad. In fact, the Eclipses was quite memorable.

title: Belarus Wont Take Custody of Leaders Son
description: MOSCOW  Authorities in Belarus have backed off a threat to seize custody of the 3-year-old son of an imprisoned opposition leader there, ruling that the boys grandmother was fit to take care of him.

title: Pulling Strings for an Oscar Performance
description: Park City, Utah As adorable as the P.S. 22 chorus is  and if you havent watched the school kids sing Katy Perry and Bon Jovi, prepare to be overwhelmed with cuteness  its forthcoming trip to sing at the Academy Awards almost didnt happen. As with everything Hollywood-related, it was all about who you know.

title: Detroit Signs Nabokov, But Doesnt Have Him Yet
description: Now that his agent has finalized a deal with the Detroit Red Wings, Evgeni Nabokov is close to returning to the N.H.L. However, theres a good chance the 35-year-old Russian will not get to tend goal for Detroit.

title: Sundance Kicks Off, Commerce Tentatively in the Air
description: PARK CITY, Utah The Bagger has landed at the Sundance Film Festival, where we hope to discover some of the films well be writing up next year. As our colleague Brooks Barnes writes in Fridays Times, executives expect a perkier marketplace than in recent years, though nowhere near the irrational exuberance of the years before the Great Recession (when the likes of Hamlet 2 went for $10 million). This year, along with a focus on even indier films that were born out of the Sundance Labs, also may see tickets harder to come by because of renovations putting one theater out of commission.

title: Obama Picks G.E. Chief for Board as Focus Turns to Jobs
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y.  President Obama is traveling here on Friday to name Jeffrey R. Immelt to run his outside panel of economic advisers, succeeding Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman, who is stepping down, the White House said. Mr. Immelt is chairman and chief executive of General Electric, the giant conglomerate with deep roots in this somewhat battered industrial city near Albany.

title: Documentary Shows Rare Look at Dissent in Myanmar Military
description: BANGKOK  It is the most vilified army in Southeast Asia, known for crushing pro-democracy demonstrations in Myanmar and for its brutal suppression of ethnic groups seeking self-rule in the regions longest-running civil war.

title: Friday Reading: Ride-Sharing Apps
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Looking to the Affordable Care Act For Help
description: Now that 2010 is complete, I can see what kind of help Obamacare  sorry, the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act  will give me with my health insurance bills. I mentioned in a previous post that my insurance rates for 2011 were a little lower than they had been in 2010 (although I expect them to resume their regular upward march next year). I own a small, struggling manufacturing company that has been providing health care to my people even though its a stretch. Surely the Affordable Care Act will come to my rescue! But the devil is always in the details, particularly when Congress decides to help. So the first thing to check: Am I eligible for the tax credit? Heres what I found in the guidelines issued by the Internal Revenue Service:

title: The Jets, Set to Music, With Hard Knocks on the Way
description: I poked around the Web to find a video that could capture what weve witnessed the last few weeks. This one has good highlights, a hot tune, with a little bit of Bart Scott mixed in. Let me know what you think.

title: French Trotting
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#139", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Ghailani Terrorism Conviction Affirmed
description: Updated, 4:33 p.m. | A federal judge in Manhattan refused on Friday to overturn to overturn the conviction of Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani on a sole count in a trial stemming from the 1998 bombings of two United States Embassies in East Africa, which killed 224 people.

title: A Stubborn Link Between Jobs and Traffic Jams
description: Arguments that environmental goals conflict with economic growth are a constant concern for those whose top priority is cleaner air and water and lower carbon dioxide emissions. It will be interesting to see, once the economy recovers, whether advances in clean technologies will change the tendency for pollution to rise in fat years and decline in in lean ones.

title: Many Dishes From One Pot of Beans
description: Here is what I have done, so far, with my latest pot of beans, a pound of cannellini pressure-cooked with aromatic vegetables, rosemary and olive oil. Listing these dishes reminds me of how useful it is to have a container of cooked beans in the fridge.

title: Is New York Loserville?
description: With the Jets on the verge of reaching their first Super Bowl in 42 years, Richard Sandomir makes the case that the Jets are hardly alone in New York when it comes to losing.

title: Taiwanese Companies Shine at Computex
description: No longer content to lurk in the background, some Taiwanese manufacturers are developing reputations as tech leaders.

title: For Politicians, Big Games Mean Odd Bets
description: The playoff ritual has become a political staple: Days before a big game, mayors or governors feel compelled to make wagers distinctive of their cities or states.

title: Hoodies, Corsets and Avian Transformations
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Hoodies and corsets, sweats and power suits are all being celebrated as the years best cinematic outfits by the Costume Designers Guild. The group announced its nominees on Friday and there were more nominees in the contemporary film category than either period or fantasy. The Academy usually favors period fare, so maybe it will take a page from the guild  the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, Local 892  and nominate The Fighter, The Kings Speech or True Grit. The contemporary hopefuls are Black Swan, the not-at-all campy Burlesque, Inception, The Social Network (go hoodies!) and Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps. The fantasy films are Alice in Wonderland, Tron: Legacy and The Tempest.

title: Giuliani Considering a 2012 Run? Absolutely
description: 6:16 p.m. | Updated Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former mayor of New York City, is floating the idea that he might once again be a candidate for president.

title: Cannot Be Underestimated
description: Allen Pinsky e-mails: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo used the phrase cannot be underestimated twice in his inaugural address. My interpretation of this is the reader/listener couldnt possibly think lower of the situation or person. As he was referring to the degree of economic suffering, shouldnt he have said either cannot be overestimated or should not be underestimated in this context?

title: Obama May Find Useless Regulations Are Scarcer Than Thought
description: WASHINGTON  There is a federal regulation that dictates that place names on new highway signs must be spelled with just one capital letter  like This, not THIS.

title: New Mother, New Word
description: There are no words.

title: African Wings, With Nowhere to Fly
description: On the Kinangop Plateau in Kenya, birds that have adapted to life at high altitudes are coming under new threats from global warming and destruction of their habitats.

title: Paris Fashion Week | An Old Lapel Is New Again
description: At Dries Van Noten, plenty swirled beneath the opaque surface of the designers intent, from Bowie glam to aristocratic refinement. But clear understanding could be found in the left lapel of the collections jackets. These were doubled: a white, navy or fur second layer buttoned to the inside of the jacket and folded around on top, duplicating the true left lapel. Graphically, the effect was a contrasting sweep across the chest, almost a sash, reminiscent of military regalia. According to Van Noten, this sort of construction has its origins in the military uniforms for which lapels were first invented. Often one would be buttoned across the neck for extra warmth, but because that interrupted the shape (particularly a problem if any battle medals happened to be hanging there), a second lapel was needed to cover the chest.

title: Cotchery Provides Calm in Jets Storm
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Jerricho Cotchery has played football for 21 years, since he was 7 in Birmingham, Ala., and to do something for that long, especially at a high level, requires a lot of emotion. Still, he loves football.

title: A Packers Cornerback Is Overlooked No Longer
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  There is no longer doubt that Tramon Williams, the dynamic cornerback of the Green Bay Packers, has the skills to succeed in the N.F.L.: athletic ability, great instincts, smarts and a willingness to work. Williams demonstrated those attributes in the last two weeks, intercepting three passes, one for a touchdown, to help the Packers reach the N.F.C. championship game against the Chicago Bears on Sunday.

title: France Speaks of Its Resolve in Afghanistan After a Threat
description: PARIS  An audio message attributed to Osama bin Laden warned Friday that the fate of French hostages held by Islamic militants would hinge on the withdrawal of French forces from Afghanistan. In response, the French government promptly reaffirmed its commitment to the military mission there.

title: Naming Dumb Regulations
description: President Obama ordered federal agencies Tuesday to weed out regulations that conflict, that are not worth the cost, or that are just plain dumb. He offered the example of saccharin, a sweetener often used in coffee that until recently also appeared on the federal list of substances regarded as toxic waste.

title: We Want Your Cruise Questions
description: Planning a cruise? Cant decide on a destination? Looking for something unusual? Never been on one and dont know where to start? We want to hear your cruise queries. (Reader questions and responses may be published in a coming special issue.)

title: Riverdale, the Bronx, 8:47 A.M.
For Many Species, No Escape as Temperature Rises
description: KINANGOP, Kenya  Simon Joakim Kiiru remembers a time not long ago when familiar birdsongs filled the air here and life was correlated with bird sightings. His lush, well-tended homestead is in the highlands next to the Aberdare National Park, one of the premier birding destinations in the world.

title: Hip Injury Forces Venus Williams to Withdraw
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  The Williams sisters have won Grand Slam titles, won this very tournament, with aches, strains and wraps around their legs. But there will be no mind over matter run to the trophy, or even the second week, this time.

title: Detained Teenager Questioned by F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON  An American teenager who was detained for several weeks in Kuwait and placed on an American no-fly list landed Friday morning at Dulles International Airport, where he was briefly questioned by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and then released to his family.

title: As Snowstorms Go, This Was a Breeze
description: It is tempting to say something like its all over but the shoveling.

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: MOURNING DIARY  Oct. 26, 1977  Sept. 15, 1979.  By Roland Barthes. Translated by Richard Howard.  Hill & Wang, $25.

title: Inside the List
description: HEAR ME ROAR: Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother, Amy Chuas paean to take-no-prisoners hyperparenting, cruises to No. 5 on the hardcover nonfiction list this week, trailing charges of stereotype-baiting, shameless hucksterism and worse. An excerpt that appeared in The Wall Street Journal under the fire-breathing title Why Chinese Mothers Are Superior generated more than 7,000 comments, more than any other article in the history of that papers Web site. Since then, Chua  a second-generation Chinese-American and Yale law professor previously known for scholarly volumes like Day of Empire: How Hyperpowers Rise to Global Dominance, and Why They Fall  has been backpedaling hard, insisting that readers, along with The Journals headline writers, had missed her self-mockery. The novelist and self-described Bad Mother Ayelet Waldman certainly didnt see any. Waldman delivered a counterblast on The Journals Web site, though she found a silver lining in her two teenage childrens outraged response to Chuas article. I say with confidence that neither of my children has ever before bothered to read a single word of The Wall Street Journal, she wrote. I dont think that I could have screamed or threatened them into doing so, not even if Id tossed them outside in the middle of winter, to cower barefoot and freezing on the front step. So to Ms. Chua I express my gratitude. It seems to take a Chinese mother to force my Western kids to read the paper.

title: Editors Choice
description: GRYPHON: New and Selected Stories,  by Charles Baxter (Pantheon, $27.95.) Beneath the shadowless Norman Rockwell contours of Baxters Midwest lurks something like the chilling starkness and human isolation in the bleakly beautiful work of Edward Hopper.

title: Paperback Row
description: AMERICAN BABYLON: Notes of a Christian Exile,  by Richard John Neuhaus (Basic Books, $16.95.) In these posthumously published essays Neuhaus (1936-2009), a Roman Catholic priest and the founder and editor of the conservative journal First Things, states the case for a natural-law approach to politics and morals, which he insists are inextricably linked. From Roe v. Wade to questions of atheism and citizenship,  American Babylon displays Neuhaus in all his virtues  elegantly argued and written, fair-minded and with a formidable range of reference, Charles R. Morris wrote in the Book Review.

title: Marshall McLuhan
description: To the Editor:

title: Common Values
description: To the Editor:

title: By the Banks of the Tigris
description: I thought this book might test my ability to make an assessment on the merits  the cardinal rule of reviewing  since the author is the daughter of Ahmad Chalabi, the Iraqi politician who, she acknowledges on the very first page, is accused of being a charlatan, a triple agent and the source of faulty intelligence that led the United States into war in Iraq. I reported on his activities during the war and met Tamara (briefly) in the desert outside Nasiriya during the early days of the American invasion. Father and daughter arrived on a plane full of Iraqis who were not politicians but a ragtag group of fighters named the Free Iraqi Fighting Force. The Special Forces unit in which I was embedded as a war correspondent for U.S. News & World Report was instructed by its command to train, arm and field these forces to put an Iraqi face on the American-led invasion.

title: Is Pink Necessary?
description: The princess phase. So inevitable is this period in the maturation of girls today that it should qualify as an official developmental stage, worthy of an entry in Leach or Brazelton: first crawling, then walking, then the urgent desire to wear something pink and sparkly. Whether we smile indulgently or roll our eyes at the drifts of tulle and chiffon that begin accumulating in our daughters rooms around age 4, participation in these royal rituals has come to seem necessary, even natural.

title: Guilty Hearts
description: In the preface to this mesmerizing story collection, Ferdinand von Schirach recalls his uncle, a judge who lost his left arm and right hand in World War II. The uncle, he tells us, began his own stories by stating, Most things are complicated, and guilt always presents a bit of a problem. This line also began his suicide letter.

title: Lazard Hires Mandelson as Senior Adviser
description: Andy Rain/European Pressphoto AgencyPeter Mandelson.

title: Whats in a Dimension?
description: In deciding whether to buy one of the new, ludicrously cool 3-D TVs  some of which wont even require special glasses  ask yourself a serious question: Do you like your entertainment in front of you, inside your body or all around you?

title: What Were Reading
description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.

title: Paul Ryan to Deliver State of the Union Response
description: 2:36 p.m. | Updated Representative Paul Ryan of Wisconsin, chairman of the House budget committee and the point person for the Republican efforts to cut spending, will give his partys official response to President Obamas State of the Union address next week.

title: A Last Look at Mush Valley
description: Bonnie F. Jacobs, a paleobotanist at Southern Methodist University, writes from Ethiopia, where she is studying fossils of ancient plant and animal life. The current field season in the Mush Valley of Ethiopia is financed by a grant to Ellen Currano of Miami University, Ohio, from the National Geographic Societys Committee for Research and Exploration.

title: Late Style
description: The question of old-age art is mysterious and perennially fascinating. Creative artists who continue to work late in life so often seem to undergo a sea change: a distillation, a new intensity, a sloughing off of excess and ornament in favor of deep essentials. W. B. Yeats, himself a notable example of the phenomenon, provided an image for it: Though leaves are many, the root is one; / Through all the lying days of my youth / I swayed my leaves and flowers in the sun; / Now I may wither into the truth.

title: Giffords Arrives at Rehabilitation Facility in Houston
description: HOUSTON  Nearly two weeks after a gunman shot her in the head at an outdoor meeting with voters, Representative Gabrielle Giffords was transferred by air Friday to Memorial Hermann hospital here to begin what is likely to be a long and arduous rehabilitation.

title: Jets Keep Things Interesting
description: It being Friday, almost everyone has run out of things to say about the teams in the N.F.L. conference championship games on Sunday. Yes, the buildup between games is part of the N.F.L.s charms, but, by Friday, charm is showing some signs of fatigue. Can you read another article about how Pittsburgh is slowly embracing Ben Roethlisberger? Have you had it up to here with how much Bears and Packers fans hate each other?

title: Warner Music Shares Surge on Deal Hopes
description: In one stroke Edgar Bronfman Jr. is more than $9 million richer, by another, he is nearly $7 million poorer.

title: Michelle Obama Is Going on Oprah
description: Michelle Obama, the first lady, is traveling on Friday to her hometown of Chicago, where she will tape an episode of the Oprah Winfrey Show to discuss her plans to start a comprehensive national campaign to support military families, the White House said.

title: Jan. 23  29
description: Television

title: A Full-Circle Mentor Moment
description: AND go! shouted the choreographer and director Susan Stroman, as the New York City Ballet dancer Amar Ramasar pushed a wide-eyed Tiler Peck over the edge of a low platform. Ms. Peck flipped nimbly on her side and rolled under the platform, emerging a few moments later laughing and brushing dust from her leotard.

title: Habitats | Chelsea
description: George Ranalli and Anne Valentino combined two apartments into a place almost entirely of Mr. Ranallis own space-saving design.

title: G-14
description: Name given to a group of 14 prominent Indian citizens who signed a letter denouncing corruption.An open letter from a group of 14 eminent citizens, quickly labelled the G-14 and blaming corruption as one of the biggest threats to Indias growth story, may be a case of a glass half empty, half full, Alistair Scrutton wrote on Reuters:

title: China and U.S. Businesses See Gains in Deeper Ties
description: WASHINGTON  American corporate leaders took away from Chinas president this week a partly comforting, partly maddening view on which both sides could agree: like it or not, they will increasingly depend on each other.

title: Lost Boy
description: In 1962, Carlos Eire found himself, at age 11, in a refugee camp for Cuban children on the edge of the Florida Everglades, staring at a chicken sandwich. It was a pallid, perfectly bisected square. Where are the feathers? he wondered. Where are the feet, or the beak, or the blood and offal? Who dismembered this lumpy, clucking creature and turned it into a geometry lesson?

title: Roddick Grinds On to the Fourth Round
description: For two sets on Friday, Robin Haase of the Netherlands overpowered the No. 8 seed Andy Roddick. Taking advantage of Roddicks tentative, defensive play, a fearless Haase was rewarded for his aggression.

title: A Jigsaw Puzzle That Sleeps 4
description: IN 1895, a handsome brick and limestone building with soaring oak-framed windows was erected on the corner of 15th Street and Sixth Avenue. The five-story structure, one of dozens of stately cast-iron concoctions that lined the Ladies Mile, spent much of its life as a furniture factory, with a showroom on the ground floor.

title: Only Bitterness Remains
description: The opening passages of David Vanns swift and beautifully written first novel, Caribou Island, introduce Gary and Irene, a long-married couple who have decided (well, Gary has decided) to build a cabin on an island in the middle of a remote Alaskan lake. The mood grows uneasy as they encounter a progression of small mishaps: a threatening storm, an overloaded hull, an accident near the start of the trip that sends a steady stream of water into the struggling boat. Gary pushes on nevertheless, and the boat lunges through the water farther and farther from shore.

title: Van Gundy Takes Blame for Arenass Struggles
description: Its never easy being the new person at work, trying to fit in and figure out your role.

title: Williamsburg, Toddlertown
description: Families are discovering that Williamsburg is not just for arty 20-somethings. And developers are paying attention, with child-oriented amenities.

title: Putting Civic Pride Where Their Mouths Are for the Big Game
description: Updated, 4:55 p.m. | When Rudolph W. Giuliani was mayor of New York and the citys first fan, he couldnt wait to make bets with Democrats, Republicans, small-town mayors and big-city counterparts alike, just as long as a New York team was in the playoffs.

title: Photos of the Moment | Rick Owens
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#820", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: A Conversation With Richard McGregor
description: Todays Book Chat is with Richard McGregor, who spent much of the last decade in China as a correspondent for The Financial Times and recently became the newspapers Washington bureau chief. His recent book, The Party, tries to do what few if any other English-language books have done before: profile Chinas ruling body, the Communist Party.

title: French Minister Pelted With Eggs in Gaza
description: GAZA  Several dozen Palestinians confronted Frances foreign minister as she entered Gaza from Israel on Friday, throwing eggs and shouting angry slogans at her armored motorcade over a comment falsely attributed to her about an Israeli soldier being held in captivity here since 2006.

title: How to Plan For and Handle the Cost of Braces
description: BRACES. Few words strike more fear into a parents heart.

title: The Costs of Perfecting a Smile
description: A childs smile may be priceless, but sometimes it seems that nothing costs more than the braces needed to make that smile well aligned.

title: South Sudanese Vote Overwhelmingly for Secession
description: JUBA, Sudan  Nearly 99 percent of southern Sudanese voters have chosen to split off from northern Sudan and form their own country, according to preliminary results of an independence referendum conducted this month.

title: An Ailing Mother Eases Her Daughters Pain, and Conscience
description: Last month, the thrill of my acceptance to Knox College and Mills College was cut short by my mothers diagnosis of multiple sclerosis.

title: We, Robots
description: In 1995, Sherry Turkle, a professor of the social studies of science at M.I.T., published a book about identity in the digital age called Life on the Screen. It was a mostly optimistic account, as Turkle celebrated the freedom of online identity. Instead of being constrained by the responsibilities of real life, Turkle argued, people were using the Web to experiment, trying on personalities like pieces of clothing. As one online user told her, You are who you pretend to be.

title: Gallery Challenges Jeff Koonss Balloon Dog Claim
description: You may not have realized that the balloon dog you bought for a buck from a street clown might be a collectors item. But the artist Jeff Koons, who constructed a 10-foot tall Balloon Dog that has been exhibited in the Metropolitan Museum of Art and elsewhere, sent a cease-and-desist letter to a Canadian manufacturer and San Francisco gallery for producing and selling Balloon Dog bookends. Now the gallery, Park Life, has asked a federal court for a declaratory judgment that states the canine shape cannot be copyrighted, according to Courthouse News Service. As virtually any clown can attest, no one owns the idea of making a balloon dog, and the shape created by twisting a balloon into a dog-like form is part of the public domain, the gallery says in its federal complaint. Any similarities between the Balloon Dog Bookend compared with the Balloon Dog Structure are driven by the wholly unprotectable idea of depicting the shape of a balloon dog in a solid form.

title: How to Tell Fossils Sex? Well, the Egg Is a Clue
description: Scientists have found a 160-million-year-old preserved fossil of a pterosaur, along with one of its eggs. Pterosaurs were flying reptiles of various sizes that coexisted with dinosaurs from the late Triassic to the Cretaceous period.

title: A Fractured Bobby Fischer
description: The documentary filmmaker Liz Garbus has taken on some dark and difficult topics in her work, including prisons (The Farm: Angola U.S.A.) and brain injuries (Coma). Her latest subject, Bobby Fischer, was in many ways no different.

title: The Orientalists
description: A hot dusty complicity between Lady, maid and manservant  this is the tantalizing dynamic Kate Pullinger places at the center of her novel The Mistress of Nothing. The lady is a figure from real life, the Victorian author Lucie Duff Gordon, best known for her Letters From Egypt. Stricken with tuberculosis and in search of a more benign climate, she left her husband and family back in Esher, England, and traveled to Egypt with her maid, Sally Naldrett, whom Pullinger has chosen as her narrator. Little is known about Sally, save for the fact that she became pregnant and that the childs father was said to be an Arab man. Duff Gordons response to the birth was to try to separate Sally from the child and send her back to England.

title: Reckless Abandon
description: In this story collection, Joyce Carol Oates, master of the American gothic, revisits territory she has long claimed as her own, a fictional realm where mild-mannered men turn into monsters and the maternal embrace is more often crushing than comforting. Her effusive, exclamatory prose can be  and has been  mocked, but theres little doubt that Oates is a well-practiced storyteller. Too well practiced, perhaps: the impact of these precisely turned tales of violation and violence tends to be more mechanical than visceral.

title: U.S. Bank Hints at Checking and Debit Card Fees
description: The days of the free debit card may be coming to an end at some banks.

title: No. 1? No Doubt. Predictable? No Way.
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  The burdens of being No. 1 can be enough to make even a young woman nicknamed Sunshine a little gloomy, particularly when that No. 1 player, Caroline Wozniacki, has yet to win a Grand Slam tournament and has started the season with a new racket and some uninspiring performances.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Manga Romance and Honors from GLAAD
description: The fourth volume of Stepping on Roses, published by VIZ Media, enters our manga list at No. 8 this week. At the center of the series is Sumi Kitamura, who is having immense financial troubles. Her prayers seem to be answered when she meets the wealthy Soichiro Ashida, who offers her money to marry him and enter high society. Stepping on Roses asks, can Sumi pass as a member of the elite and is the sham marriage worth it? Vol. 2 featured a childhood friend of Soichiro stirring up feelings in Sumi; the latest volume has someone from her husbands corporation spying on the household. Will somebody eventually find out the truth?

title: Its Not the Money, Its the Principle
description: Lawyers, not surprisingly, are competitive people.

title: Williamsburg, Toddlertown
description: MICHAEL MOSHAN bought his first condo in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, in 2003. A few years later he persuaded his girlfriend, Shana Liebman, to move there from the West Village. She was skeptical  she didnt want to be surrounded by 20-somethings just out of school. But over the years the neighborhood, with its restaurants, bars and galleries, grew on her.

title: 2011 Nissan Leaf
description: Here comes the peoples electric car, America, ready or not.

title: The Peoples Electric, Ready to Claim Power
description: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif.

title: Little Bundles of Reality TV Terror
description: Motherhood, at least the way it is depicted on cable reality shows, is a menacing, grotesque fate that is mostly ill-timed.

title: Murkowski Questions Senate Republicans Focus on Health Care Repeal
description: Senator Lisa Murkowski is back, but that does not mean she is on message.

title: Guess Whos Going to Davos?
description: The World Economic Forum is known for drawing an array of the rich and the powerful  presidents, private equity moguls and the like. But it appears that the allure of the conference, held in Davos, Switzerland, is now too powerful for one of finances more publicity-shy figures to resist.

title: ... And Baby Makes Reality TV
description: DEATH is scary, but its not nearly as frightening as birth.

title: Spinning for the Spin Doctor
description: A statement issued on Friday by Andy Coulson, the chief media adviser to Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, to explain Mr. Coulsons reasons for resigning contained something rare in such remarks: a joke.

title: Ferrari FF, an All-Wheel-Drive Shooting Brake
description: The newest entry in Ferraris legacy of V-12-powered coupes is not a coupe.

title: Union Membership in U.S. Fell to a 70-Year Low Last Year
description: The number of American workers in unions declined sharply last year, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported on Friday, with the percentage slipping to 11.9 percent, the lowest rate in more than 70 years.

title: At Retreat, House Democrats Talk of Recapturing Majority
description: House Democrats said Friday that they had officially begun their bid to recapture the majority, calling it Drive for 25, referring to the 25 seats they need to regain control.

title: Taco Bell Pulls Ads From MTVs Skins
description: Risqu scenes on the hit MTV drama Skins have caused one company to remove its commercials from the program and have spurred a call by a TV watchdog group for a federal investigation.

title: Theoni  V. Aldredge, Costume Designer for Chorus Line and Annie, Dies
description: Theoni V. Aldredge, the designer of the fabulously feathered transvestites in the original stage version of La Cage aux Folles and Little Orphan Annies red dress on Broadway, died Friday morning in Connecticut, said her husband, Tom Aldredge. She was 88.

title: Pep Boys Auto Parts Chain Weighs Sale
description: Pep Boys-Manny, Moe & Jack is considering a sale of the company, according to a person with direct knowledge of the matter.

title: The Coverage of Sarah Palin
description: I see that Nate Silver has brought his usual statistical acumen to bear on my suggestion, in this weeks column on the medias dysfunctional relationship to Sarah Palin, that a majority of Americans are neither Palinoiacs nor Palinistas. Not so fast, he writes, citing a recent Politico survey on American attitudes toward various public figures:

title: Cowgirl Country
description: Whether or not you believe there is any connection between the first assassination attempt ever made on an American female politician and the gun-slinging rhetoric of the first Republican woman ever nominated for the vice presidency, whats undeniably true is that despite the vast philosophical and intellectual chasms between them, Representative Gabrielle Giffords of Arizona and the former Alaska governor Sarah Palin have something in common: they are both cowgirl politicians. In this, they are symptomatic of the too-narrow ways in which the United States is willing to accept women as leaders.

title: If Your Life Were a Movie
description: Brock Enright rents a studio in an old Catholic school in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, a former classroom that is hard to navigate without stepping on a drawing or kicking a sculpture, but he makes much of his art beyond his studios walls  in bars, fast-food joints, Chinatown shopping plazas, rooftops and other locations throughout Manhattan. One evening not long ago, I joined him at the Sixth Ward, a bar on the Lower East Side, to watch him work on a new piece.

title: A Wasting Woman
description: The woman mumbled and ran a shaking hand through her dark mass of tangled curls. Her husband could barely make out what she was saying over the din of the emergency room at the John Muir Medical Center in Walnut Creek, Calif. Rewind it, she said, raising her voice, looking at her husband. Rewind it, she pleaded. Her husband squeezed her hand and forced a smile. Over the last four months she often repeated this phrase when she was confused. He wasnt sure what she meant, but he wished they could rewind their lives and return to the way they were half a year earlier, before his previously healthy 64-year-old wife became sick.

title: A Brief Electronic Affair
description: He friended me just after Thanksgiving, Week 13 of regular-season football this year. He wanted to know if I was the same Lisa who studied marine science at a certain East Coast college for a summer semester back in the early 80s. I was. I am.

title: Swiping Supplies
description: My elderly aunt became ill and phoned me, a physician, to ask if she should call an ambulance. I surmised that she was severely dehydrated. From my hospital, I took a bag of saline, IV tubing, an IV lock and a needle. An unsuspecting nurse handed me the tape that secures the needle. I gave my aunt these fluids at home, and she soon felt better, as did I: my stealing $50 worth of medical supplies saved the taxpayers more than a thousand dollars for an E.R. visit. Did I do right? E.G., NEW YORK

title: New Cityscape, in Search of Green Space
description: THE bad news first: Walking down the northern stretch of Fourth Avenue in Brooklyn, you will still have to squint very hard to see it as the boroughs version of Park Avenue in Manhattan. That comparison, which boosters have been making in recent years as the corridor has come to life, is still aspirational  especially so against the backdrop of taxi depots and gas stations that still make up much of the streetscape.

title: Consumer Advocates Want Obama to Name Watchdog Agency Chief
description: Six months after Congress created the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, top consumer advocates praised the significant progress made by the watchdog bureau, while calling on President Obama to appoint a director of the agency.

title: Fifth Third May Be Ready to Deal, Analyst Says
description: As Fifth Third Bancorp moves to repay its bailout money, the Cincinnati lender may be ready to make some deals.

title: Chinese Leader Gets Ride on Chicagos Big Shoulders
description: CHICAGO  President Hu has left the building.

title: Aging: Shingles Vaccine Shows Promise for Older Adults
description: The herpes zoster vaccine, which has already proved effective for preventing shingles in a large clinical trial, may be even more effective in broad clinical practice.

title: Giving Root Vegetables Their Due
description: Food writers tend to be exuberant about spring and summer vegetables, but a bit muted about cold-weather produce, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health. Thats too bad: There are plenty of delicious, comforting dishes to be made with vegetables like kohlrabi, rutabaga, celeriac, carrots and turnips.

title: Stock Option Accounting, Again
description: When I wrote the preceding post criticizing Senator Joe Lieberman for his efforts to block stock option accounting, I had no idea that there are still people who deem it bad accounting to expense the value of stock options. (As opposed to those who quarrel with how we estimate the value, which is a subject where there is plenty of room for argument.)

title: Vision: Making Inroads in Macular Degeneration
description: In 2004, scientists at the National Eye Institute predicted that as the population aged, the rate of macular degeneration, an incurable eye disease with no known cause, would increase substantially. They appear to have been wrong.

title: Regimens: Antidepressant May Help Quench Hot Flashes
description: A new study suggests that a widely prescribed antidepressant may provide at least some relief for women with hot flashes.

title: Two Catholic Schools on West Side Will Merge
description: Two Roman Catholic grade schools on the West Side of Manhattan will merge in September as part of a broad reorganization plan that calls for the closing of 27 schools at the end of the current academic year, the Archdiocese of New York announced Friday.

title: Remedies: Peppermint Oil for Irritable Bowel
description: More than a third of American adults use some form of complementary or alternative medicine, according to a government report. Natural remedies have an obvious appeal, but how do you know which ones to choose and whether the claims are backed by science? In this occasional series, Anahad OConnor, the New York Times Really? columnist, explores the claims and the science behind alternative remedies that you may want to consider for your family medicine cabinet.

title: Courtyard Canteen
description: Few contemporary architects have earned more prestigious and prominent commissions in Berlin than the British-born David Chipperfield. His office in Mitte is currently working on at least three projects in the German capital, in addition to another dozen or so in different parts of Germany, Austria and Switzerland. With so much on their plate, Chipperfield and his team barely have time for lunch every day, let alone for deciding where to eat. Which is why Chipperfield has leased out part of his Berlin offices courtyard space to a restaurant aptly called Kantine (canteen).

title: Housing Preservation Commissioner Leaving Post
description: Rafael E. Cestero, commissioner of the city Department of Housing Preservation and Development, is leaving his job for a private-sector post. Mr. Cestero, who has served two stints in city government but spent most of his career in the private sector, will become managing director at L+M Development Partners, a developer of affordable and market-rate housing nationwide. Mr. Cestero will be involved only in projects outside of New York City, the housing preservation department said.

title: A Daring Rescue
description: Photographs from the operation led by South Korean to free the crew of a freighter hijacked in the Arabian Sea.

title: From Dr. Spock to the Tiger Mother: Studying Parents and Families
description: The hubbub over the Tiger Mother Amy Chua has spawned a robust national conversation about being a parent. Her memoir, which chronicles her strict approach to parenthood, has provoked commentary by parents, children (including Ms. Chuas older daughter) and various experts.

title: Best Weekend Matchups
description: The outstanding matchups this weekend in soccer.

title: At Wesleyan, a Program for Performance Art Curators
description: As the Institute for Curatorial Practice in Performance at Wesleyan University says, performance art is first and foremost a social experience that happens on a person-to-person level. That has not stopped the institute from creating a new professional certificate program in curating performance art that primarily occurs off-campus. The nine-month program, the first of its kind, is scheduled to begin this summer and is targeted at professionals with one to five years of experience. The course involves three short residencies. Danspace Project in New York City collaborated on the design and implementation of the program.

title: Weekend Competition: Aphorisms Hint at the Possibility of Certainty
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to compose aphorisms  short, pithy sentences that encapsulate some general truth.

title: E.P.A. Approves Use of More Ethanol in Gasoline
description: WASHINGTON  The Environmental Protection Agency said on Friday that cars and light trucks from the 2001 model year onward can safely use a blend of 15 percent ethanol mixed with gasoline, up from the 10 percent standard now in effect in much of the country. The decision expands the pool of vehicles that could use such a fuel to about 62 percent of the total on the roads.

title: Shares of Facebook and Other Private Companies Still on Fire
description: SecondMarket, the leading exchange for trading shares of private companies, released a report this morning that makes clear what DealBook has told you over the last month: The market for private shares, while still small, is on fire.

title: Will Apple Put the iPhone on Other Carriers?
description: Nick Bilton/The New York TimesAmong the several impressive numbers that Apple shared in its latest quarterly earnings report on Tuesday was the sale of more than 16 million iPhones over the quarter. Next month sales will surely continue to rise as Apple starts selling the iPhone on the Verizon network. But if Apple wants to fend off the iPhones rivals, will it have to sell its signature mobile device on other networks as well? Some analysts say yes.

title: Q. and A. with a Pet Nutritionist
description: Dr. Joe  Joseph J. Wakshlag  a clinical nutritionist at the Baker Institute for Animal Health at Cornell University, is answering readers questions about pet food. He is no longer taking questions.

title: Harrison Plays On, but Fines Still Sting
description: PITTSBURGH  The letter from the N.F.L. is taped to the wall beside James Harrisons locker, an olive branch that gives no solace.

title: In New N.Y.U. Plant, a Collateral Carbon Benefit
description: People concerned about global warming talk about how to force generators of heat-trapping gases to shoulder the expense of cutting their emissions. But some cuts come easy, at no cost beyond spending that was planned anyway for other purposes.

title: Charter School Loses Bid to Stay Open
description: Ross Global Academy is one step closer to extinction.

title: Surface Thrills: Remembering the Costumes of Theoni V. Aldredge
description: Theoni V. Aldredge, who died on Friday, created clothes that required sunglasses. I dont mean as an accessory for those who wore them; I mean for the people looking at them. (A slide show of costumes designed by Ms. Aldredge is here.)

title: Poll Shows Emanuel Ahead in Chicago Mayors Race
description: With just over a month to go until the mayoral election in Chicago, Rahm Emanuel , the former White House chief of staff, holds a two-to-one advantage over his closest competitor in the race, former Senator Carol Moseley Braun, according to a citywide Chicago Tribune/WGN poll. But the poll did not find Mr. Emanuel capturing the 50 percent threshold needed to avoid a runoff election in April.

title: Photos of the Moment | Jean Paul Gaultier
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#509", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Data Shows Less Buying of U.S. Debt by China
description: FOR eight years after the United States resumed running large budget deficits in 2002, China was the largest lender, buying a fifth of the new Treasury securities sold during that span  an expenditure of more than $900 billion. During 2006, China financed more than half the American deficit. When the financial crisis struck hardest, China spent more than $100 billion on Treasuries over the two-month period of September and October 2008.

title: The Week in Pictures, Jan. 21
description: A look back at the weeks events in New York City and the region.

title: With Retirement Savings, Its a Sprint to the Finish
description: What would you do if your financial planner prescribed the following advice? Save and invest diligently for 30 years, then cross your fingers and pray your investments will double over the last decade before you retire.

title: Tales of Lives Richly Lived, but True?
description: I have tried to keep diaries before, John Steinbeck writes in a giant ledger book filled with his methodical script, but they didnt work out because of the necessity to be honest.

title: Family-Court Counselor Convicted of Sex Assaults
description: A juvenile justice counselor was convicted Friday of sexually assaulting two girls under his care at the Family Court building in Lower Manhattan.

title: First of the Big-Time Trash Talkers
description: During the famed upset in Super Bowl III, Jets cornerback Johnny Sample intercepted a pass, stopping a Baltimore Colts drive 2 yards from the end zone. Then he tapped the ball on the helmet of the intended receiver and said, Is this what youre looking for?

title: No Need to Call a Sitter, Playwrights Horizons Has Done It
description: Any parent of small children knows that the cost of hiring a baby sitter is often higher than the cost of tickets to a play. So now Playwrights Horizons is offering affordable, professional child care during three of its Sunday matinees. The combined cost of theater tickets and child care is the factor most often cited by people with young children as the reason they rarely attend the theater, Leslie Marcus, the managing director, said in a statement. Our hope is that this program will become a model for other performing arts organizations in New York. The program, called Playtime!, will be available on Feb. 27, March 20 and April 2 during the afternoon performance of Kin, a new play by Bathsheba Doran. While parents are watching the show, their children (4 to 12) will be upstairs in a rehearsal space and watched by Sitters Studio, a baby-sitting company made up of working artists. The service is free for members and $15 for non-members. The Theater Subdistrict Council, a nonprofit corporation, is helping to finance the project.

title: U.S. Men Set for 2011 Debut
description: Habla TeleFutura?

title: Protesters Say Ruling Party in Tunisia Must Dissolve
Obama Sends Pro-Business Signal With Adviser Choice
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y.  President Obama, sending another strong signal that he intends to make the White House more business-friendly, named a high-profile corporate executive on Friday as his chief outside economic adviser, continuing his efforts to show more focus on job creation and reclaim the political center.

title: Toyota Prius Headlight Failure Sparks Class-Action Suit
description: About 220,000 Toyota Priuses are included in the tentative settlement of a class-action suit in which claimants say their hybrids high-intensity discharge headlights function intermittently and then fail.

title: This Is Not a Post About Sarah Palin
description: Updated | 5:10 p.m. The news that Osama bin Laden, or someone impersonating him, released a new audio message on Friday has been greeted with as little fanfare as reports on Thursday that Terry Jones, the pastor of a Florida microchurch, was denied permission to enter Britain to address 30 fans of his work.

title: Hornets Staying Relevant With Defense
description: The N.B.A. season is not unlike the lunar cycle in that it exists as a series of phases during which portions of the whole rotate through periods of high visibility. Teams essentially take turns in a position of prominence, while the rest of the league goes about its business in semi-obscurity. The news medias obsession with up-to-the-minute sports coverage (which is the chicken and which is the egg Ill leave you to decide) and basketball fans hungry for the hottest team in the game have created a system that anoints kings for a day, if only so they can be dethroned and replaced in short order.

title: A Revamped Tokyo District Stays Up Later
description: With new shops and restaurants, and most recently a low-rise complex called Marunouchi Brick Square, Tokyos Marunouchi district is no longer just for office workers.

title: Borneos City Streets and Jungle Trails
description: Plunge into the jungle to see orangutans then return to the city for a bed and a meal.

title: In Borneo, City Pleasures and Jungle Adventure
description: A SNOW-WHITE fortress in the style of the English Renaissance, garnished with crenellations, pepper pot turrets and an octagonal keep, is not quite what youd expect to find on a steamy bluff overlooking an equatorial river in Malaysian Borneo. But Fort Margherita, built in 1879 by Charles Brooke, the second White Rajah of Sarawak, is just one of the many charms of Kuching, a gracious and kaleidoscopically diverse city of about 600,000 just an hour and a half by air from Singapore.

title: Restaurant Review: Saturne, in Paris
description: In Paris, a cave  manger is generally a place to get a glass of wine and a plate of saucisson sec. But in some cases, its also where you go for some of the most satisfying food in the city: the profound braises at Le Baratin, the perfect clams at Le Verre Vol, the vegetables at Racines, plucked from the garden of Alain Passard, the chef at the three-star LArpge.

title: In India, Luxury Arrives in a Himalayan Haven
description: THE little boy in the maroon robe had me at Jul. As his friends flitted about pouring yak-butter tea into tourists bowls, he limped toward the back of the windowless Thiksey monasterys prayer hall, heavy copper pot trailing behind him. He offered a small serving of the creamy broth, a flash of Chiclet-like baby teeth and that Ladakhi greeting. Then he slipped back into his row and began to sway to the rhythm of the surrounding chants.

title: Beyond Cheese Steaks: A Tour of Philadelphia Restaurants
description: THOUGH tourists still mob Philadelphias famous cheese-

title: Art Meets Food in Berlin
description: IN Berlin, artists collaborate with dancers and fashion designers  and, perhaps more surprisingly, with chefs. For the most part, food is a character actor in these joint efforts, a sensual diversion from a performance, but at Zagreus Projekt, a gallery space and restaurant in Mitte, it plays a starring role.

title: Norwich, England  a Getaway for Book Lovers
description: ON a rainy night in September, all the shop fronts in the city center of Norwich, England, were dark and shuttered except for one. With each swing of the door, an expectant hum escaped from the Book Hive, an independent bookstore that opened in October 2009, as patrons eagerly awaited the arrival of the British-born Australian author Alex Miller.

title: For Investing Big Bonuses, Boring Is In
description: WALL STREET is about to be flush with bonus money. And while there will certainly be the highfliers who blow it on fast cars and other flashy toys, the reality is that most bankers will put their bonuses into rather mundane investments.

title: What Sign Are You? Down Goes Brown Does Astrology
description: You probably heard the recent news about the traditional zodiac signs being shifted around, including the addition of a brand new sign. It seems like everyone has spent the week wondering, How does this change affect me?

title: Shakespeares Globe Theater to Present the Writers Canon in 38 Languages
description: Shakespeares Globe Theater will present a familiar array of the writers plays in 2012 but in some unfamiliar languages. The reconstructed theater, in the Southwark section of London, announced what it calls a Cultural Olympiad, in which all of the plays will be performed, each in a different language. The idea is to present a theatrical counterpart to the Olympic games which are scheduled to take place in London that year.

title: Turiaf Returns to Knicks Starting Lineup
description: Mike DAntonis search for answers - to a losing streak, a defensive slump and a punchless bench  has led him back to Ronny Turiaf, and a lineup change that he hopes will be permanent.

title: J. Crew Buyout Settlement Still Leaves Questions
description: Lawyers for J. Crew shareholders have agreed to a settlement in the litigation in Delaware Chancery Court over the $3 billion buyout of the retailer by two private equity firms, TPG Capital and Leonard Green & Partners. Though the settlement does not include a substantial monetary element, it does in some measure cure the process deficiencies in this troubled buyout.

title: Debating the Causes of Joblessness
description: Brad DeLong is skeptical that structural unemployment is a problem at all right now:

title: More Executives Move From Sony to Universal
description: A month after Universal Music Group hired away a top executive from Sony Music Entertainment, its chief rival, the company is making several changes in senior management positions and cutting about 60 lower-level jobs.

title: The One Big Catch With Retirement Investing
description: This weeks Your Money column looks at the frightening realities of investing for retirement. The conventional advice usually goes something like this: Save a respectable amount of your income, invest in a diversified portfolio, and you should be able to comfortably retire.

title: A Strong Night for Idol  and its Rivals
description: For the competition, the best news from the first week of American Idol is that the juggernaut is no longer plowing under everything in its path.

title: France Seeks to Let Icons Light Up Once More
description: PARIS  France may count more than its share of iconic chain-smokers  from Jean-Paul Sartre to Alain Delon  but for two decades the country has been systematically removing cigarettes from their fingertips or lips in any advertisements that use their likenesses. This week, though, a parliamentary committee approved a bill that would give back the tobacco products those celebrities held so dear, and by which they came to be known.

title: Former Senator Bayh Joins Apollo Global
description: Evan Bayh, the former senator from Indiana, has joined Apollo Global Management, the New York private equity firm.

title: I Resolve. World, Dont Fail Me Now.
description: GAZING into the camera, a smoky-eyed teenager known as glamourista16 confessed to the YouTube masses: My friend got me addicted to chipotle and I cannot stop.

title: Book Review Podcast: Philosophy Edition
description: This week: the philosopher Sean Dorrance Kelly, co-author of All Things Shining, on the classics of Western literature; James Ryerson talks about novelists who are trained philosophers; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Scottsdale Hosts Panels on Women in Motor Sports
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Research by The Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn, Mich., indicates that women have been racing cars since at least 1901, meeting with success in everything from the nations drag strips to IndyCar racing. And yet, were still trying to change opinions, said Melanie Troxel, who is among the few racers  male or female  with victories in both of the National Hot Rod Associations Top Fuel and Funny Car categories.

title: The Lunch Tote Has Acquired a Sense of Taste
description: CONCEPTUALLY, the lunch tote is nothing new: reusable versions of the brown paper bag have been around for several years, often insulated and made with spill-resistant material for easy cleanup.

title: You Think Houses Are a Slow Sell? Try a Yacht
description: What is tougher than having one sleek mega-yacht for sale in a glutted market? The answer, for the moment at least, is having two mega-yachts on the market.

title: The Times Names New Op-Ed Editor
description: Trish Hall, whose two-decade career at The New York Times has spanned the business, real estate, styles and food sections, where she has been both a reporter and an editor, will become the papers next Op-Ed editor.

title: Give Me Your Heart
description: Dear Dr. K,

title: Rockabilly Queen Prolongs Her Party
description: THE crowd was rockabilly through and through: girls in pegged jeans and crimson lipstick, boys in flattops and pompadours, shrunken leather jackets. When Wanda Jackson, 73, took the stage with her guitar for a sold-out show at the Knitting Factory in Brooklyn recently, it was all cat growls, howls and hip swivels  and that was from Ms. Jackson herself. The audience followed suit, with a chorus of fans joining in on her song I Gotta Know. She first recorded it in 1956, not long after she met and began dating Elvis Presley.

title: For Women, Sundance Is Sunnier Than Hollywood
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Somewhere in the 600 or so miles between this mountain town, host to the Sundance Film Festival, and the movie factories of Hollywood, female filmmakers seem to vanish.

title: N.F.L. Playoffs Q. and A. With Greg Bishop
description: Greg Bishop, who covers the Jets for The Times, answered reader questions on Friday about the American Football Conferenece championship game between the Jets and the Steelers on Sunday. That game follows the N.F.C. championship game between the Packers the Bears. (Readers questions and the answers are in the comment section below.)

title: Finding Deep Pockets to Help a Jewish Center
description: Few nonprofits groups have dared embark on a capital campaign since the financial crisis started.

title: Big Deal | The Sheffield Leaves Chaos Behind
description: Sometimes things that happen in the world of New York City real estate, even in just one building, are so bizarre that one might wonder: Is this a hallucination?

title: Will It Be 1995 All Over Again?
description: With the Democrats still in control of the Senate and Barack Obama in the White House, there is little that the new Republican majority in the House of Representatives can do before 2013 to enact legislation. The health care overhaul will not be repealed, and social welfare programs will not be cut  at least, not unless Mr. Obama wants them to be, or until a Republican occupies the White House.

title: The Diary: Three Centuries of Private Lives
description: A new exhibition at the Morgan Library & Museum highlights a diverse array of private journals culled from the museums archives.

title: Obamas Corporate Makeover
description: True or false? Business leaders should provide expertise in service of our country.

title: Feeling Empowered for One Oil-Free Weekend
description: BOSTON

title: E.P.A. Approves Increased Ethanol in Auto Fuel
description: As Matthew L. Wald reported Friday in The New York Times, the Environmental Protection Agency has approved ethanol formulations of 15 percent in unleaded gasoline, up from the 10 percent standard that is used in most of the country.

title: What Modern Family Says About Modern Families
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Computer Code an Increasingly Precious E.V. Commodity
description: BATTLES over the ownership of innovations and product designs have raged in the auto industry since the first horseless carriages sputtered out of inventors garages. In 1911, Henry Ford won a highly publicized eight-year court battle with George Selden, who tried to patent the automobile even though he had never sold one.

title: New Commercial Van From Nissan
description: NISSAN entered the North American market for full-size commercial vans on Thursday as it began production in Mississippi of the 2012 NV series.

title: Betting on Green, Mitsubishi to Park 3 Models
