description: LOOKING to jump-start its stalled American car sales and meet environmental targets around the world, Mitsubishi is placing a big bet on electricity. Under a global plan announced Thursday, the company will offer six new plug-in hybrid and battery-electric models by 2015.

title: Look of the Moment | Cate Blanchett
description: The Look: the Great Kate  the sharp jacket and wide-legged pants give props to Hepburn. (Remember 2004s The Aviator?)

title: In California, E.V. Charging Isnt So Cheap
description: IN the state of California, which of these cars would be the most economical to own and operate?

title: Making Hollywood Films Was Brutal, Even for Fritz Lang
description: MAKING movies in Hollywood has never been easy, though maybe it should have been for the Austrian genius with a monocle screwed into his right eye and a dark, forbidding Weltanschauung lodged deep in his head. But life is cruel and filmmaking can be nearly as brutal, and so it was for Fritz Lang (1890-1976). I always fought very hard in Hollywood, he said in 1970, sounding like the embattled veteran he became. Late in life he said that the main theme in all his movies was the fight against destiny, against fate, and its hard not to wonder if he was thinking about his own fortunes as a Hollywood director.

title: Fritz Lang in Hollywood
description: Images from some of the movies appearing in Film Forums series on the director.

title: A Sunnier Sundance for Women
description: PARK CITY, Utah Female filmmakers, almost nonexistent in the mainstream movie factory, are having a banner year at the Sundance Film Festival. Of the 117 features playing at this years festival, 27 come from women, the best showing in years. Over two dozen shorts were also directed by women.

title: Book Review Podcast: Philosophy Edition
description: This week: the philosopher Sean Dorrance Kelly, co-author of All Things Shining, on the classics of Western literature; James Ryerson talks about novelists who are trained philosophers; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Book Review Podcast: Philosophy Edition
description: This week: the philosopher Sean Dorrance Kelly, co-author of All Things Shining, on the classics of Western literature; James Ryerson talks about novelists who are trained philosophers; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

title: Book Review Podcast: Philosophy Edition
description: This week: the philosopher Sean Dorrance Kelly, co-author of All Things Shining, on the classics of Western literature; James Ryerson talks about novelists who are trained philosophers; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

title: Pictures of the Day: Albania and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Albania, Tunisia, Brooklyn and California.

title: Enter the Teacher to the Dragon of Martial Arts Films
description: NEARLY four decades after his death, Bruce Lee remains one of the most potent symbols of Hong Kong cinemas golden age. The original crossover martial artist, a local child star turned celebrated creator of Jeet Kune Do, the art of the intercepting fist, Lee made only a handful of films after his international breakthrough. (He died in 1973 at the age of 32.) But kung fu classics like Fist of Fury (1972) and Enter the Dragon (1973) are the stuff of countless homages and imitations, and Lees life and career have been chronicled in dozens of books and films. While the Hong Kong martial arts drama has long been in decline, its only fitting that the latest stirrings of a revival are connected to Lee: the most popular kung fu screen hero of the moment is none other than Lees mentor, Ip Man.

title: How a Hotel Case May Affect Buyouts
description: Steven M. Davidoff, the Deal Professor, talks to Ethan Klingsberg, a partner at Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton, about the standards for management buyouts.

title: Photos of the Moment | Louis Vuitton
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#215", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Blair Sits Before Iraq Inquiry, This Time With Regrets
description: The former British prime minister Tony Blair appeared, for a second time, before Britains official inquiry into the invasion of Iraq on Friday. During four hours of testimony, Mr. Blair tried to shift the debate from Iraq to Iran  the former, a subject on which he was taken to task for during his appearance in January 2010. On Friday, he accused Tehran of supporting terrorist groups in the region and seeking to block Middle East peace efforts, even saying that they facilitate a situation in which that region cannot embark on the process of modernization it urgently needs.

title: Kathleen Turner Returns to Broadway in High
description: Shes a foul-mouthed alcoholic nun, Kathleen Turner said of Sister Jamison Connelly, the character she portrays in High, a new play coming to Broadway this spring. What I love is that she hasnt made these choices about her religion lightly, Ms. Turner said in her familiar deep-throated growl. It makes me think of how much we operate every single day on faith and belief, regardless of any connection to organized religion.

title: Modern Family Is Us?
description: Television cameras are often mirrors, reflecting back the message of the times. In an article in the Styles section this weekend, my colleague Bruce Feiler looks at the hit show Modern Family through that lens, asking what does Modern Family say about modern families?

title: Pictures of the Day: Albania and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Albania, Tunisia, Brooklyn and California.

title: Faith, Family, Immigration and Homicide
description: Santa Monica. Calif.

title: Q&A With Hofstras Charles Jenkins
description: The Hofstra senior guard Charles Jenkins, a two-time winner of the Haggerty Award as the best college basketball player in the New York metropolitan area and the defending Colonial Athletic Association Player of the Year, has raised his game this season under the first-year coach Mo Cassara. Jenkins recently passed Loren Stokes for third place on the Hofstra career scoring list and is getting closer to Antoine Agudios record of 2,276 points. But he has more than individual honors on his mind. Showcasing his desire to finally get his team to the N.C.A.A. tournament, hes averaging almost 6 points more after halftime  when games are won and lost  than in the first half. In addition, his second-half shooting tops 63 percent.

title: Samuel Fuller, Eccentric Stylist of Poverty Row
description: IN the early 1960s, after spending more than a decade working for major studios, the director and writer Samuel Fuller found himself back where he had started in Hollywood, working for one of the small, budget-minded studios collectively known as Poverty Row.

title: A Warning to Obama on Guantanamo
description: A powerful Republican congressman has told President Obama not to unilaterally issue an executive order establishing a parole board-like system for periodically reviewing the cases of Guantanamo detainees.

title: Make It Funny, Make It Work, Make It Quickly
description: BURBANK, Calif.

title: Labor Worries About New Head of Obama Jobs Panel
description: President Obamas choice of Jeffrey Immelt, the chairman and chief executive of General Electric, to lead the countrys efforts to stoke job growth is the latest in a string of worrisome developments in the eyes of organized labor.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: Mystery Banker in Galleon Case A letter from federal prosecutors says a Morgan Stanley banker tipped an unidentified person to Advanced Micro Devices pending acquisition of ATI Technologies in 2006. The banker is not identified in the redacted letter that was sent to lawyers for Raj Rajaratnam, who goes on trial in the insider trading case next month.Bloomberg News

title: Jeffrey Immelt 101
description: Today the chairman and chief executive of General Electric, Jeffrey R. Immelt, was named as the chairman of President Obamas Council on Jobs and Competitiveness. He was already serving on the Presidents Economic Recovery Advisory Board under Paul A. Volcker.

title: Facebook Completes $1.5 Billion Fund-Raising Round
description: 8:30 p.m. | Updated

title: TimesCast | January 21, 2011
description: Lebanon's fragile future; the British Prime Minister's communication director resigns; and the Jets and the Steelers face off for a chance in the Super Bowl.

title: Citi Gives Pandit a Raise
description: Talk about a raise.

title: For China, Relief After a Successful Trip
description: BEIJING  As President Hu Jintao completed his groundbreaking trip to the United States, the sense of relief here over how well it went was almost palpable.

title: How a Hotel Case May Affect Buyouts
description: Steven M. Davidoff, the Deal Professor, talks to Ethan Klingsberg, an M&A partner at Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton, about the standards for management buyouts.

title: A Carefully Honed Image as a Master of the Ukulele
description: Not so long ago, Jake Shimabukuro might have seemed like an exotic and fleeting talent. He was a ukulele virtuoso. He was a YouTube star. He was big in Japan. All of which is still true, and a lot less inherently intriguing now. Durability is the bane of novelty, and Mr. Shimabukuro has been nothing if not durable in recent years, steadily refining his craft, trusting that his fan base, and his media profile, will keep up.

title: Chic in Review | Those Silly Kardashians
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Another Ratings Record for Jersey Shore
description: MTVs Jersey Shore set yet another viewing record Thursday night and once again crushed every competitor in television in terms of reaching younger viewers.

title: Keeping Indie Rock Short and Kind of Sweet
description: On Thursday night you could have done this: left someone at home in northern Manhattan with a movie starting, traveled almost the length of the borough to the Bowery Ballroom, seen the new English band the Vaccines, returned before the A train started running local, and gotten back in time for the credits.

title: Wage Growth, or Lack Thereof
description: The San Francisco Fed put together this handy (if depressing) chart showing how hourly wages changed in each industry last year, in comparison to how they changed in the year and a half preceding the financial crisis:

title: Rocks, Ice and Science in Antarctica
description: Geologists John Goodge and Jeff Vervoort brought home rocks  and photographs  from their research expedition in Antarctica.

title: West Presses Karzai on Delay in Seating Parliament
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The United Nations, supported by the United States, the European Union and Canada, released a strong statement late Friday expressing deep concern and surprise at President Hamid Karzais decision to delay seating a new Parliament on Sunday.

title: Reality TV? Not Really, the Capital Says
description: WASHINGTON

title: A Bare-Bones Soup Recipe
description: SEVERAL years ago, while flipping through a Junior League cookbook, I came across a recipe for ham bone soup. The book, a vintage specimen passed down by a friend of my mothers, was one of those tattered spiral-bound volumes you see at yard sales, chock full of fuss-free recipes that people actually cooked every day.

title: Coaxing One Opponent Into Squeezing the Other
description: The Mid-Atlantic New Years Regional took place in North Charleston, S.C., from Dec. 27 to Jan 2.

title: A Risky Season to Be Near a Manhole
description: After the storm comes fire. Or, more exactly, fires.

title: Conservatory Is to Cut Ties to Childrens Music Project
description: BOSTON  The classical music worlds latest Big Idea  a movement to marry music education to social work  has been jolted in this country by the rocky divorce between the efforts fledgling national organization and the New England Conservatory here.

title: Believing in Peace, Even After the Unthinkable
description: Working as the lone Palestinian gynecologist at an Israeli hospital had its fraught moments for Izzeldin Abuelaish.

title: Paris Mens: All That
description: Junya Watanabes men seemed decidedly antimodern, or perhaps they were just in love as they paused on chipped green park benches and pondered life. One of them actually took a pen and paper from his breast pocket and wrote a little note. No iPad? Another model brought a newspaper to read. It seemed a curious artifact, as did Mr. Watanabes knitted variations on patch-pocket blazers, varsity jackets, snowflake sweaters and slightly shrunken trousers, all in faded autumn colors. The clothes were technically accomplished and all that, but something of the stale air of a boys bedroom lingered over the preoccupied men and their folksy classics.

title: Ruling on Witnesses Is a Blow for Bonds
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A federal judge ruled on Friday that she would allow testimony from athletes linked to the Bay Area Laboratory Co-operative steroids case in Barry Bondss perjury trial, denying an attempt by Bondss lawyers to bar those witnesses.

title: Wearing You Out
description: My teenage daughter is a good girl  an excellent student and musician  and she rarely causes us an ounce of trouble. But lately shes begun wearing tight, revealing clothes that are a little trampy. Weve already had lots of unpleasantness over this, but were not getting anywhere. How to proceed?

title: States Face Shortage of Key Lethal Injection Drug
description: The sole American manufacturer of an anesthetic widely used in lethal injections said Friday that it would no longer produce the drug, a move likely to delay more executions and force states to adopt new drug combinations.

title: Photos of the Moment | V&R
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#767", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 23
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 21
description: More Photographs

title: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 21
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include an indoor pop-up park, a restored map, and the State of the City.

title: Republicans Battling in New Hampshire
description: A fierce power struggle between mainstream and insurgent factors of the ascendant Republican Party in New Hampshire will be decided Saturday, when members of the partys state committee choose a new leader at their annual meeting.

title: Balanchines Riffs on Petipa, and Tchaikovskys Riffs on Mozart
description: No doubt there will be complaints about New York City Ballets winter season. Its second and third evenings, however, chiefly gave more cause for the admiration that had begun on opening night.

title: Teacher With Sex-Worker Past Resigns
description: Melissa Petro, the elementary school art teacher who was brought up on charges by the city for writing openly about her past as a sex worker, has agreed to resign rather than face a hearing that could lead to her dismissal, the city announced Friday.

title: Who Is the Morgan Stanley Banker in the Galleon Case?
description: Federal prosecutors say a Morgan Stanley banker leaked information about a coming acquisition by Advanced Micro Devices in May 2006.

title: Scorecard | Dries Van Noten Wins!
description: Gaga, oh la la! Scorecard is now in Paris, where Wednesday night, to the custom soundtrack of the Lady herself, Nicola Formichetti made his much-anticipated debut as creative director of another outrHaus  Thierry Muglers. Yet from behind all the smoke and mirror-trimmed styling, critics came to the surprising consensus that a really well-cut lapel never looked so transgressively chic.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Pots of beans and sausages will be simmering Saturday at Jimmys No. 43, 43 East Seventh Street (Third Avenue) when more than a dozen chefs and amateurs battle in a cassoulet cook-off. From 1 to 4 p.m., there will be a tasting for $20. A panel of judges will name the winners, but attendees can also vote for their favorites. All the competitors use ingredients from the Greenmarkets and proceeds benefit GrowNYC, which sponsors the markets.

title: Improvisatory Responses To Post-Punk Chirping
description: Deerhoof

title: Phyllis K. Robinson, a Top Copywriter, Dies at 89
description: In the late 1940s, it was rare to find a woman in senior management at an advertising agency. But when Doyle Dane Bernbach opened its doors on June 1, 1949, its chief copywriter was Phyllis K. Robinson, who went on to help create memorable campaigns for Polaroid cameras and Levys rye bread as DDB achieved legendary status in the industry.

title: For a Club Impresario, the Beat Goes On
description: IN the village of Roslyn, under the viaduct, music history was made from 1971 to 1987. There, performers who would later sell out stadiums  Bruce Springsteen and Billy Joel among them  played for far smaller crowds at a nightclub called My Fathers Place.

title: Aspiring Singer Finds Mentors Behind Ivy League Walls
description: PRINCETON, N.J.

title: A Visit From Europes Do-It-All Artist
description: Jan Fabre is a monumental artistic personality, a distinctly European type that hardly seems to exist in America. He had an exhibition of his drawings, sculptures and installations at the Louvre; he covered the Hall of Mirrors in the Royal Palace in Brussels with the wing cases of nearly a million beetles; and he was an artistic adviser to the Avignon Festival. He has toured the Continent in the various guises of theater director, opera director, choreographer, performance artist and playwright.

title: Christy Martin, Boxer, Takes Another Shot
description: AS a boxer, Christy Martins signature color was pink: pink shorts, pink robe, sometimes even pink boots. Pink was her color when she fought on the undercard of a Mike Tyson fight in Las Vegas in 1996, the blood dripping onto her shorts; pink was her color when she became the only woman boxer to make the cover of Sports Illustrated the following month; pink was her color after her career and womens boxing had both fizzled, when she fought her last fight a year and a half ago, at a New York State fair. The guys in her corner hadnt liked the pink at first, she said, but after that Sports Illustrated cover, they were all asking if they could wear the pink.

title: White-Lipped Peccaries in Ecuador
description: A video from Anthony Di Fiore, a primate biologist at New York University who is studying spider monkeys in Ecuador.

title: Morgan Stanley Chief to Make Less Than in 2009
description: James P. Gorman may now be the chief executive, but apparently the job does not come with a pay increase.

title: This Time, a Baritone as a Verdi Baritone
description: Last season at the Metropolitan Opera, Plcido Domingo had an improbable late-career triumph as the title character in Verdis Simon Boccanegra, a touchstone baritone role. Yet for all the vigor and richness of his singing, he still sounded like a tenor. So the performance came across as an intriguing experiment.

title: Cyclist Calls for Legalized Doping
description: Updated | 7:31 p.m. Calling the fight against doping in his sport futile, Floyd Landis, the American cyclist who retired this week, suggested that riders should be allowed to use performance-enhancing drugs in the future.

title: A 20-Year-Old Unapologetically Playing as if It Were 300
description: THE Baroque ensemble Rebel (pronounced with the accent on the second syllable) is, as its name suggests, not partial to the polite style of presentation favored by its more conventional counterparts.

title: Go for Broke | T. Anthonys Alligator Calf Collection
description: Since 1946, T. Anthony has provided the upper crust with an alternative to its French rivals with equal parts luxury and versatility. That isnt to say that the old guard doesnt have a fondness for the finer things  at a price, of course. T. Anthonys latest luggage pieces, the alligator calf collection, blends the other halfs need for long-lasting quality luggage (the leather is from a tannery in Italy) with rich yet tastefully understated style. Embossed to mimic alligator hides in a deep chocolate, the prices  ranging from $895 for a classic duffel to $2,200 for a 31-inch wheeled packing case  wont make you shed any crocodile tears. Think of the collection as a guaranteed first-class upgrade the next time you travel.

title: Opera and Orchestra Team Up on Butterfly
description: RICHARD RUSSELL has not been general director of Opera New Jersey in Princeton very long  he was hired in April  but he has reason to believe that what he calls his first baby, Opera New Jerseys performances of Puccinis Madama Butterfly on Feb. 4 and 11, will be a hit.

title: Hamlet (and Others) as the Strong, Silent Type
description: WASHINGTON  For their first attempt at wordless Shakespeare  thats right, wordless Shakespeare  the husband-and-wife leaders of the Synetic Theater company chose to apply their physical-theater aesthetic to Hamlet, counting on audiences familiarity with the plot.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: On Eve of Auction, Doubts Surround J.F.K. Ambulances Authenticity
description: 10:53 p.m. | Updated

title: Abortion: Easy Access, Complex Everything Else
description: Congratulations, New York City, did you hear the news? Fire-and-brimstone predictions from across the country have been confirmed. This is officially the abortion capital of America. A health department report released last month proves it: about 40 percent of all pregnancies in the city end that way, an average of about 90,000 a year in recent years.

title: A Day to Explore, After Brushing
description: Dr. Irwin Smigel, a pioneer of aesthetic dentistry, is responsible for many a famous smile. One of his first celebrity clients was Elizabeth Taylor, in 1981. Dr. Smigel, who has his own Supersmile oral hygiene line and is the founder and chairman of the American Society of Dental Aesthetics, gives his age as in my 70s but in no way professionally pass. He lives on the Upper East Side with his wife, Lucia; they have two children and six grandchildren. ROBIN FINN

title: Photos of the Moment | Dries Van Noten
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#116", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Baldness: Put a Crown on It
description: OF all the details surrounding Prince Williams April marriage to his longtime girlfriend, Kate Middleton, few seem to have garnered as much attention as his rapidly receding hairline.

title: Share Your Thoughts: Nissan Leaf
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Jerry Garrett evaluates Nissans purely electric Nissan Leaf hatchback.

title: The Way We Were, Beijing, 1992
description: I recently stumbled across a video the Times made in 1992, showing how the paper gets made. It includes this clip of my wife (Sheryl WuDunn) and I as Beijing correspondents for the newspaper:

title: Rebel Yoga
description: TARA Stiles does not talk about sacred Hindu texts, personal intentions or chakras. She does not ask her yoga classes to chant. Her language is plainly Main Street: chaturangas are push-ups, the sacrum the lower back. She dismisses the ubiquitous yoga teacher-training certificates as rubber stamps, preferring to observe job candidates in action.

title: The Times Names a New Op-Ed Editor
description: Trish Hall, whose two-decade career as a reporter and an editor at The New York Times has spanned the business, real estate, styles and food sections, will become the papers next Op-Ed editor.

title: In Second Run as Coach, Lavin Finds Better Way
description: Steve Lavin is no longer the manic 30-something coach who 10 years ago gave as good as he got to his critics. Then, he was the besieged wunderkind at U.C.L.A. who led a roster of underclassman blue chips known as the Baby Bruins.

title: Taking the Food Court Concept Out of the Mall
description: With a space-age look courtesy of Syd Mead  who was a designer on Blade Runner, Aliens and the original Tron  this food court at the Eventi Hotel in Chelsea offers a dining experience not unlike, if a cut or two above, say, Chick-fil-As and Master Woks at the Paramus Park Mall. One of several such smorgasbords that have recently popped up, the spot has four counters  The Press (coffee), 3Bs (bacon, burgers and beer), Fornetti (Italian) and RedFarm Stand (Asian)  from which customers can build and pay for a meal using a single touch-screen kiosk. Sitting on Avenue of the Americas between 29th and 30th Streets, it has been pulling in a mix of office workers and passers-by since opening in October. On Wednesday, a couple and their young sons grabbed a bite after a potentially career-making appointment. DIANE CARDWELL

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,449 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Questions About New York
description: Q. How do you make a right-hand turn on a street where theres a bus lane? Are you supposed to pull into the bus lane and make the turn? Or are you supposed to stay in the lane just to the left of the bus lane and make the turn from there?

title: What to Expect of Mob Arrests? 08 Roundup May Hold Clues
description: Given that hundreds of local, state and federal law-enforcement officers fanned across the region this week, arresting 125 reputed mobsters on a buffet tables worth of charges that included money laundering, extortion and murder, the events of Feb. 7, 2008, seem, in retrospect, uncannily familiar.

title: On L.I., Celebrating a Barroom Bard
description: Seaford, N.Y.

title: Photos of the Moment | Alexis Mabille
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#977", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: An Infusion of Science Where the Arts Reign
description: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.  Liza Batkin, a first-year student at Bard College, is a dancer whose academic interests run to philosophy and literature. But here she was in a laboratory on a snowy day in January  while many of her peers across the country were still on winter break  inserting a piece of DNA into bacteria with a micropipette.

title: On Upper West Side, Hurdles for Charter School
description: The guests sipped wine and nibbled sushi, guacamole and Gruyre  lawyers, bankers, preschool teachers, managers and consultants of various kinds, bound by the anxious decision they must confront in the months ahead: where their 4-year-olds will go to school in the fall.

title: Owner of Steelers Urges Quick End to Labor Talks
description: PITTSBURGH  Dan Rooney, the Pittsburgh Steelers chairman emeritus, arrived from Ireland on Friday afternoon and, in some of the strongest words by a team owner in months, expressed concern about the labor strife that looms over the N.F.L.

title: Citys Housing Chief, Advocate for Affordability, Is Resigning
description: Rafael E. Cestero, who as commissioner of the city Department of Housing Preservation and Development had the task of protecting and building low-cost housing during the real estate crash, will leave his job in March for a private-sector post, the mayors office announced on Friday.

title: Shamed Into Altering a Mortgage
description: In physics, the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle states that the process of observing subatomic particles affects their behavior. We have a similar principle in journalism: the process of reporting a story can sometimes affect the behavior of those being reported on. Last Wednesday, the Heisenberg Journalism Principle was on full display in a courtroom at the Queens County Courthouse, in New York.

title: Quiet Jets Make Time to Laugh With Scott
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The Jets are just about done laughing at linebacker Bart Scotts expense. They have all howled at his testosterone-soaked on-field interview with ESPN after the Jets beat the Patriots. Scott began the interview by imitating a jet plane and ended it screaming Cant wait! at the mention of going to Pittsburgh.

title: No Sneak Preview From Obama
description: President Obama joined House Democrats at their issues retreat in Cambridge, Md., on Friday night, but he did not give a speech. He joked that he had a big one coming up on Tuesday (the annual State of the Union address) and was not about to give up any of his best lines, according to people who attended the event.

title: Mayors See No End to Hard Choices for Cities
description: WASHINGTON  Despite having one of the highest crime rates in the nation, Camden, N.J., laid off nearly half its police force this week after failing to win concessions from its unions. On the other side of the country, Vallejo, Calif., was filing a bankruptcy plan that proposed paying some creditors as little as a nickel or 20 cents on each dollar they are owed.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to the Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: G.O.P. Grants Reprieve to House Ethics Office
description: WASHINGTON  Before the 2010 midterm elections, speculation was rampant that if the Republicans took over the House, they would kill the fledgling Office of Congressional Ethics, an independent body that investigates complaints of misbehavior.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Across Country, Lawmakers Push Abortion Curbs
description: Newly energized by their success in Novembers midterm elections, conservative legislators in dozens of states are mounting aggressive campaigns to limit abortions.

title: Ad Change Underlines Influence of N.F.L.
description: A mother worried about my son playing football. Two children colliding helmet-to-helmet  with superimposed crashing sounds and force lines rippling from their heads  drove home her fears.

title: Teaching Civil War History 2.0
description: The Civil War Sesquicentennial is upon us. Over the next four years Americans will be reminded of and engage in debates about every aspect of a war that fundamentally transformed the nation and that set us on a path we are still working to come to terms with. America went through the same process at the centennial. Whats different this time around is the focus on race and slavery, both of which have the potential to divide Americans and obscure the boundaries between the present and the past; that, and the ability for anyone to access millions of pages of information about the war, its causes and consequences through the Internet.

title: A Top Overseer of City Schools Plans to Retire
description: A deputy schools chancellor who was one of the last old-guard educators to hold a top position at the Education Department and commanded several elements of the systems reform efforts announced on Friday that he would retire at the end of the month.

title: Statement from Viacom
description: About 90% of the 2010 compensation is long-term equity awards that align our executives interests with those of our stockholders. The majority of 2010 compensation is one-time equity grants related to the previously announced long-term extensions of employment agreements, which vest over the life of those agreements. In 2010 Viacom achieved outstanding operational and financial results, including double-digit growth in operating income, adjusted net earnings and total shareholder return. Viacom shares appreciated 33% during calendar year 2010, versus the S&P 500 gain of 12%.

title: A Farm-to-Table Menu That Plays the Edge
description: IN early January, a friend called to say that he had bailed off of Interstate 684 in a snowstorm and wondered what the name of that restaurant in Armonk was  the one Id mentioned to him a few weeks ago. Restaurant North, I said. You are a lucky man.

title: Many Choices on the Menu of Religious Fasts
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  After last Sunday nights service at Celebration Church, where a 10-piece band played Christian rock for 1,600 worshipers, Stovall Weems, the pastor, met me in his green room and offered nibbles from a tray of kiwi, pineapple and melon slices.

title: The Russians Are Coming (Again?)
description: John Galliano revisited the familiar territory of the Russian Revolution, this time with Rudolf Nureyev in tow. Dont ask me how Mr. Galliano got from 1917 to 1961, the year that Nureyev defected (in Paris), but he did, and you sort of go along with the reconstructed history and the homage to the ballet star. But it was strange: Once the show dispensed with the Russian migrs and their tired coats, the models faces acquired the waxy perfection of mannequins or Rudy lookalikes.

title: Removing the Roadblocks to Rehabilitation
description: What works and what doesnt work to solve a social problem is often no mystery. The mystery is why we so often persist in doing what doesnt work. The topic of Tuesdays column  prisoner re-entry into the community  offers myriad examples. One is the practice of dropping people getting out of jail or prison right back into the neighborhoods where they got in trouble in the first place. Intuition tells us that this is a bad idea: the old street corners and the old friends seem like a recipe for the old troubles. Research on this idea is rare and hard to do  its tough to get around the problem that the person who chooses not to go home may have other qualities that make him successful.

title: Bears Plan For Recovery Included Stimulus
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill.  It was almost exactly a year ago and Lovie Smith was having a colder-than-usual January in Chicago. After a third successive non-playoff season  the 2009 schedule ended with a 7-9 record  Smith was considered a lame-duck coach.

title: On the Street | A Stretch of Leg
description: The look that dominates high fashion in New York is a long stretch of leg, ankle boots and a new posture.

title: Weld Flaws Found on Gas Pipe in Blast
description: WASHINGTON  The natural gas pipe that burst in San Bruno, Calif., on Sept. 9, killing eight people and destroying nearly 40 houses, had numerous flaws in its welds, the National Transportation Safety Board said in a report released Friday.

title: Spotlight From Glenn Beck Brings a CUNY Professor Threats
description: On his daily radio and television shows, Glenn Beck has elevated once-obscure conservative thinkers onto best-seller lists. Recently, he has elevated a 78-year-old liberal academic to celebrity of a different sort, in a way that some say is endangering her life.

title: Homemade From Way Back
description: When Judies European Bakery opened 35 years ago, spongy white bread was the statewide norm. Thus, the bakerys claim to be the home of Connecticuts original handcrafted bread contains more than a kernel of truth.

title: Cozy for Asian Cuisine, if You Can Get a Seat
description: SEARCHING for an inexpensive place to eat Chinese, similar to the neighborhood restaurants that abound in the city, I was pleased to discover Shanghai Gourmet China Bistro in Orange, a small, family-run place that serves good, comforting food prepared with quality ingredients in an inviting atmosphere.

title: Mayor Bloomberg, Back-Seat Driver
description: NEW YORK CITYS taxi industry is by no means a perfect animal. But earlier this week when Mayor Michael Bloomberg announced a proposal to install meters in livery cabs and permit them to pick up street hails in areas of the city that see few yellow cabs, like Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx, Staten Island and Upper Manhattan, he managed to take a bad situation and make it worse. While its true that those areas are flagrantly underserved by yellow cabs, the new rule would hurt the taxi industry more than it would help the public.

title: Elizabeth Turchyn and Joshua Halpern
description: Elizabeth Whelan Turchyn and Joshua David Halpern were married Saturday evening at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York. William D. Wall, a magistrate judge for the Eastern District of New York, officiated, with Phillip Rothman, the executive and educational director of the Brotherhood Synagogue, taking part by leading Jewish elements of the ceremony.

title: Leigh Barker, Jeff Gardner
description: Leigh Barker and Jeff Gardner were married Saturday in Tenafly, N.J. The Rev. Craig Rule performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church at Tenafly.

title: Margaret Klarberg and Bruce Kennedy II
description: Margaret Gawthrop Klarberg and Bruce Lee Kennedy II were married Saturday evening in New York. The Rev. Craig D. Townsend, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Jamess Church, where he is the vicar.

title: Anne Rubin and Aaron Karp
description: Anne Merrill Rubin, a manager with Facebook, and Aaron Benjamin Karp, a manager with Google, were married Saturday evening at the River Caf in Brooklyn. Rabbi Sheila Goloboy officiated.

title: Bethany Eppner, Eric Goldberg
description: Bethany Lynn Eppner, and Eric Steven Goldberg were married Saturday evening at Battery Gardens, a restaurant in New York. Rabbi Joshua Strom officiated.

title: Karen Alinauskas and Nathan Love
description: Karen Ann Alinauskas and Nathan Louis Love were married Monday evening in New York at the home of Nizza and John Heyman, who are friends of the bride. The Heymans daughter, Dahlia H. Heyman, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Elyse DiPierri, Paul Southwell
description: Elyse Anne Francesca DiPierri, a daughter of Denise DiPierri of Manalapan, N.J., was married Saturday in Brooklyn to Paul Andrew Charles Southwell, a son of Christine Southwell and Barry C. Southwell of Dinas Powys, Wales. John E. Hull performed the ceremony at St. Patricks Roman Catholic Church, where he is a deacon.

title: Becky Kirkham, James Clippard III
description: Dr. Elizabeth Ann Kirkham and James Henry Clippard III were married Saturday afternoon at St. Johns Episcopal Church in Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas E. Nicoll, the churchs rector, performed the ceremony.

title: Mets Sign More Bullpen Help
description: The Mets signed relief pitchers Blaine Boyer and Tim Byrdak to minor league deals with invitations to spring training.

title: Putting the Art in Cakes
description: Andrea Lekberg, who owns the little bakery and cafe behind the Century 21 department store in Morristown with her mother, Frances Davidson, calls it the Artist Baker, not the Artistic Baker.

title: The Week of Speaking Pleasantly
description: Congress really has been looking a little more civil. Not quite Athens in the age of Pericles, but its very possible that this year well get through the State of the Union address without anybody jumping up to scream insults at the president.

title: Big Paydays Return With Big Profits at Wall St. Banks
description: Talk about a raise.

title: Artist Playing Cat-and-Mouse Faces Russias Claws
description: KIEV, Ukraine

title: A Cozy Spot for Sushi Done Simply
description: THERES plenty to like at happy little Mo C Mo C Japanese Cuisine, tucked into a storefront along a side street in Princeton. Theres the cozy atmosphere that fosters conversation between the closely spaced, cheerful laminate tables. Theres the friendly and responsive service. Theres the intensely floral and aromatic jasmine tea. And theres the restraint on the plate that allows the simple green of snow peas and the dusky orange of salmon to star.

title: A Vibrant Force Lost, While an Arts Scene Mourns
description: Tajeme Sylvester was a carpenter, a handyman and a poet. He was known as an impressive craftsman, whether renovating a brownstone or constructing a set for an Off Broadway theater. After hours, he was a fixture on the party circuit, dancing to house music, hip-hop and whatever else moved him. On Jan. 10, he became a statistic: the seventh homicide victim of 2011. His murder, which remains unsolved, stunned a community that saw him as a vibrant force on the Brooklyn arts scene.

title: The Loss of a Good Man
description: It was like reading fiction. Scott Stossel, in his book, Sarge: The Life and Times of Sargent Shriver, described a harrowing World War II sea battle that erupted off Guadalcanal on the night of Nov. 14, 1942:

title: A Creator Prepares to Take the Reins at Google
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Things that get Larry Page excited: tossing around programming lingo with engineers, picking the brains of scientists and championing ideas that belong in science-fiction novels, like cars that drive themselves.

title: Olbermann Leaves Countdown on MSNBC
description: 12:05 a.m. | Updated  Keith Olbermann, the highest-rated host on MSNBC, announced abruptly on the air Friday night that he was leaving his show, Countdown, immediately.

title: Redefining the Morning Meal
description: AMITYVILLE, N.Y.

title: High-Powered Laser Pointers Pose Risk to Pilots
description: The laser guru, as he is known among colleagues, tinkers with the tools of the trade in the basement of his suburban Philadelphia home. Of the pile of parts on which he works, Samuel Goldwasser, 56, says, You dont ask how sausage is made.

title: In Tucson, Solace From Relatives of Past Killers
description: TUCSON  Few visitors make their way past the cactus garden and into the dark ranch-style home where Randy and Amy Loughner have spent much time grieving alone. The rampage in which their troubled 22-year-old son is accused opened a fault line between them and the rest of this recovering city.

title: Feeling Pulled and Tugged, Even While Away at Camp
description: Sometimes a single moment can sum up a lifetime of difficulty.

title: Juvenile Justice Counselor Is Guilty of Sexual Assault
description: A juvenile justice counselor was convicted on Friday of sexually assaulting two girls under his care at the Family Court building in Lower Manhattan.

title: Mays, at Home in Harlem, Connects With Its Children
description: Harlem has had so many magical days; Friday offered yet another, when the great Willie Mays came back home.

title: Obamas Gun Play
description: President Obama is under renewed pressure from his base to demonstrate that he is, indeed, a principled man of unwavering conviction rather than a pliant political reed willingly bent and bowed by ever-shifting winds.

title: Give Back New York City
description: In the mid-1970s, New York City was in such deep financial trouble that the state basically took charge. Albanys lawmakers mandated important reforms, including modernizing the city budget system so that it is clear, transparent and professional. They decided against such changes for their own operations, which helps explain why the state is now the one in big trouble.

title: Lottery Numbers
How a Single Match Can Ignite a Revolution
description: WHAT drives an ordinary man to burn himself to death?

title: Slap to a Mans Pride Set Off Tumult in Tunisia
description: SIDI BOUZID, Tunisia  Mohamed Bouazizi spent his whole life on a dusty, narrow street here, in a tiny, three-room house with a concrete patio where his mother hung the laundry and the red chilis to dry. By the time Mr. Bouazizi was 26, his work as a fruit vendor had earned him just enough money to feed his mother, uncle and five brothers and sisters at home. He dreamed about owning a van.

title: The World This Week
description: A discussion of Tunisia's Jasmine Revolution.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Saturday: Stick With It
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Was this a tough one for you? Saturdays are the cruellest day for me, to paraphrase T.S. Eliot. Its very difficult for me to get even a toehold in Saturday puzzles, but perhaps with more practice things will get easier.

title: Maybe Japan Was Just a Warm-Up
description: IN the 1980s, the United States faced an unnerving challenge from a rising economic powerhouse and export dynamo. It was an impressive challenger, to be sure, but one that often bent rules of global competition unfairly to its advantage by handing out financial subsidies to domestic companies, discriminating against foreign suppliers in government contracts, pilfering Western technology and keeping its currency cheap.

title: U.N. Urges Inquiry of Migrants Disappearance in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  The United Nations top human rights official pressed Mexico on Friday to investigate the disappearance of 40 Central American migrants last month and determine whether the military and the police were complicit.

title: Chinese Bank to Buy Stake in U.S. Arm of Bank of East Asia
description: The Industrial and Commercial Bank of China signed an agreement on Friday to obtain an 80 percent stake in the American arm of the Bank of East Asia, according to a person briefed on the agreement. The deal, if approved by regulators, would mean that for the first time, a state-owned Chinese bank would have a controlling stake in a United States financial institution.

title: Pay Doubles for Bosses at Viacom
description: Viacom presents: Big Payday II  the sequel.

title: A Newly Cooperative China
description: After months of rancor, China is suddenly talking up cooperation on North Korea, the economy, and other difficult issues. There are several possible explanations for the change in tone  and, we hope  substance.

title: No Sign They Get It
description: The final report from the presidential commission investigating the gulf oil spill rightly warns that government regulation alone cant prevent another such disaster. The blowout reflected industrywide weaknesses, not just BPs, it said. And what is needed is a fundamental transformation of industry practices putting a far higher premium on safety.

title: The Tevatron
description: In Batavia, Ill.  just west of Chicago  you can walk along trails through a thousand-acre restored prairie filled with rare species like compass plant and rattlesnake master. From the edge of the prairie, you can see, as well, a four-mile ring of concrete and steel. That is the berm above the Tevatron, a high-energy subterranean racetrack for particle beams and the heart of the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, or Fermilab.

title: Bank and Telephone Records Are Planned in Clemens Case
description: Prosecutors in Roger Clemenss federal perjury case notified a court Friday that they intended to use bank, telephone, hospital and other business records as evidence against him. The prosecutors also asked a judge to hold a hearing on whether Clemenss lawyer, Rusty Hardin, should be prevented from cross-examining a key witness, Yankees pitcher Andy Pettitte, because Hardin briefly represented both men.

title: DAntoni Shuffles Lineup in Hope of Stabilizing Knicks
description: SAN ANTONIO  Mike DAntonis search for answers  to a losing streak, a defensive slump and a punchless bench  has led him back to Ronny Turiaf, and a lineup change that he hopes will be permanent.

title: Pistons Can Be Example, Not Trade Partner, for Nets
description: NEWARK  The Nets and the Detroit Pistons exchanged Eastern Conference supremacy in the first half of the last decade, appearing in the N.B.A. finals twice each. Through ownership changes, coaching changes and the cyclical nature of professional basketball, the teams have now sunk to the bottom of the conference and are currently trying to emerge from Carmelo Anthony-induced stupors.

title: Sundance Gets a Taste of Iranian Politics
description: PARK CITY, Utah After the Sundance premiere Friday of The Green Wave, a brutal depiction of repression and government-sanctioned violence in Iran, the Iranian filmmaker behind the documentary, Ali Samadi Ahadi, struck a surprisingly hopeful chord. Not about human-rights violations in his homeland  the soft-spoken Mr. Ahadi, who lives in Germany, thinks those will continue. But he was upbeat about whether Iran was listening to the outrage that followed its jailing last month of the celebrated director Jafar Panahi.

title: After Tucson, a New Focus on Guns
description: To the Editor:

title: As Senator Lieberman Exits, a Balance Sheet
description: To the Editor:

title: Haiti Leader Faces Pressure in Fight Over Runoff Race
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  President Ren Prval of Haiti faced increasing pressure on Friday to drop his preferred candidate from a coming presidential runoff election.

title: Maintaining the Safety Net
description: To the Editor:

title: Zimbabwe: Voters May Be Dead
description: As President Robert Mugabe, 86, pushes for elections this year, a civic group reported Friday that its audit of the voter rolls found that 27 percent of those registered were dead. It also found that more than 2,000 registered voters were over 100 years old in a nation where life expectancy is 47 years. The Zimbabwe Election Support Network, which researched the voter rolls, concluded they were vulnerable to fraud and needed an overhaul.

title: Bail Out the States?
description: To the Editor:

title: Healthful Chicken
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Relations With Cuba
description: To the Editor:

title: Illinois: Ex-Police Commander Sentenced
description: A former Chicago police commander was sentenced Friday to four and a half years in prison for obstruction of justice and lying about torturing murder suspects. The man, Jon Burge, 63, was found guilty in June of lying under oath in a 2003 civil court case about the torture of suspects in custody during the 1970s and 1980s. More than 100 black men accused Mr. Burge and other officers under his command of subjecting them to electrocution, beatings and other acts of torture to gain confessions in murder cases.

title: Lawyer Protests Status of Soldier in Leaks Case
description: The lawyer for Pfc. Bradley Manning, the Army intelligence analyst detained on charges of leaking classified information to WikiLeaks, accused the military on Friday of abusing Private Manning by placing him unnecessarily on suicide watch. The lawyer, David E. Coombs, said psychiatric reviews had determined that Private Manning was not a suicide risk and should even be taken off the less restrictive prevention of injury watch and put on normal status at the jail at the Marine Corps base at Quantico, Va. Instead, on Tuesday and Wednesday, Private Manning was placed on the stricter suicide watch, eliminating his daily hour of exercise and stripping him of all clothing except underwear. After Mr. Coombs protested, Private Manning was returned to prevention-of-injury status.

title: As Anthony Waits Out Uncertain Future, So Does Hamilton
description: NEWARK  In a parallel universe, Richard Hamilton teamed with Carmelo Anthony and Chauncey Billups for the Nets on Friday against the Pistons, finally bringing the trio together after Detroit bypassed the chance to draft Anthony in the 2003.

title: Bloggingheads: Talk to Ahmadinejad?
description: Heather Hurlburt, left, of the National Security Network and Eli Lake of The Washington Times debate U.S.-Iran nuclear negotiations.

title: Nakamura Wins and Rejoins Anand in the Lead of Tata Steel Tournament
Knicks Shuffle Lineup, but Result Doesnt Change
description: SAN ANTONIO  Mike DAntoni changed his lineup Friday night, a reasonable, rational attempt to make the Knicks bigger, sturdier, more defensive-minded and, if all went well, successful again.

title: Theoni V. Aldredge, Costume Designer, Dies at 88
description: Theoni V. Aldredge, who designed the costumes for hundreds of Broadway and Off Broadway productions, including Annie, A Chorus Line and La Cage aux Folles, and who won an Academy Award for her work on The Great Gatsby, died on Friday in Stamford, Conn. She was 88.

title: Learning the Ropes at Sundance
description: PARK CITY, Utah The two-headed creation of Sundance was in full swing at the opening night parties on Thursday, equal parts indie movie fawning and ambush (or symbiotic, depending on your perspective) marketing.

title: Getting Injured Players Back on the Field
description: As an orthopedic surgeon who specializes in sports medicine, one of the most common requests I hear from patients is, Doctor, please treat me like one of your professional athletes.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 21
description: The day in sports included tennis in Australia and snowboarding in Spain.

title: Excerpt: 'Prometheus -- Landscape II'
description: Excerpts from the dance and theater piece presented at Montclair State University. Video by Johannes Holub.

title: Previously Unseen Portraits of Bobby Fischer by Harry Benson
description: When Liz Garbus began researching her documentary Bobby Fischer Against the World, which had its premiere at the Sundance Film Festival on Friday, she contacted the photographer Harry Benson because Benson had covered the 1972 world championship match between Fischer and Boris Spassky for Life magazine. (Benson originally became famous for his photographs of the Beatles during their first American tour.) Garbus hoped that she might be able to use some of the photographs for the film.

title: Blue Jays Ship Wells to Angels
description: The Los Angeles Angels acquired the All-Star center fielder Vernon Wells from Toronto in exchange for catcher Mike Napoli and outfielder Juan Rivera. Wells has four years and $86 million left on his seven-year, $126 million contract. Neither team would say if any money was included to offset Wellss salary.

title: Talks on Irans Nuclear Program Close With No Progress
description: ISTANBUL  Two days of talks between Iran and six world powers ended in failure on Saturday, with Iran refusing to engage on any concrete proposals to build confidence that its nuclear program is only for peaceful purposes and with no date set for another meeting.

title: The Weekend Word: Show Me the Jobs
description: From Todays Times:

title: Perils of N.F.L. Forecasting
description: An N.F.L. season, like life and the occasional takeout order, is full of regrets. Jerry Jones probably regrets his slow hook on Wade Phillips. Mike Shanahan might lament his premature one on Donovan McNabb. And Matt Dodge, well  lets just leave him alone for a few months.

title: Where Wall Street Bonus Money Is Going
description: Paul Sullivans Wealth Matters column this week notes that bonus season on Wall Street always evokes the image of highfliers blowing their bonus money on fast cars and penthouse apartments. But, he writes, while that certainly happens, most of the bonus money has long been split between the boring and exotic.

title: A Carbon Storage Leak?  Not So Fast, Experts Caution
description: Has the worlds largest carbon-capture project sprung a leak?

title: Reader Response: Dumb Regulations
description: On Friday, we asked you to name dumb regulations. Some of the policies you described in response certainly would seem like excellent candidates for a second look by rule makers. We havent tried to verify these accounts, nor have we asked the agencies for comment. These are simply three notes that piqued our interest.

title: Racket Strings and Topspin
description: There was an advertisement in the 1970s that featured the Argentinian Guillermo Vilas touting a brand of tennis string. It appeared in tennis magazines, and, perhaps to lend it some authenticity, was written in an awkward, broken English. My friends and I found it funny enough to commit to memory.

description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#338", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: For Ducks Koivu, a Return to Montreal
description: The Anaheim Ducks were headed to Montreal for a rare visit Saturday night, but more significant for Canadiens fans is the return of Saku Koivu, the Canadiens former captain.

title: Competitiveness
description: Sigh. So it appears that President Obama is going to make competitiveness his main economic theme. To be fair, he could (and may well) do worse. But this is hackneyed stuff, and involves a fundamental misconception about the nature of our economic problems.

title: Urban Forager | A Green Queen in Winter
description: Blizzards, snowstorms and freezing temperatures have no effect on springy, delicate-seeming chickweed, which for the past few months has been growing stealthily across the city. Even when most plants are lying dormant, one can often find this tenacious plant thriving under a blanket of snow.

title: High Price for Indias Information Law
description: KODINAR, India  Amit Jethwa had just left his lawyers office after discussing a lawsuit he had filed to stop an illicit limestone quarry with ties to powerful local politicians. That is when the assassins struck, speeding out of the darkness on a roaring motorbike, pistols blazing. He died on the spot, blood pouring from his mouth and nose. He was 38.

title: Whos No. 3? Roethlisberger or Rodgers?
description: Brady vs. Manning? Who cares.

description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#963", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Tods to Help Fund Colosseum Restoration
description: ROMETods, the Italian luxury group, pledged $34 million on Friday toward the restoration of the Colosseum. The workwhich includes cleaning and reinforcing the exterior of the nearly 2000-year-old monument, its circular galleries and some underground spaces currently off-limits to the publiccould begin by the end of the year and is expected to last between two and three years. The Colosseum will remain open during the restoration, which will be monitored by the Culture Ministry.

title: Answering Questions About Antarctica
description: John Goodge, left, a professor of geological sciences at the University of Minnesota-Duluth, and Jeff Vervoort, an isotope geochemist from Washington State University, recently returned from their research expedition in Antarctica.

title: Photos of the Moment | Kris Van Assche
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#172", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Has the World Run Out of Spare Capacity?
description: Samuel Brittan points us to John Kemp suggesting that global growth is hitting supply-side limits. The argument is that while high unemployment and low inflation may prevail in advanced economies, the rest of the world is facing accelerating inflation, together with rising commodity prices. And that is, indeed, a fair picture of whats going on.

title: Eurosclerosis, Then and Now
description: Updated with an additional figure at end

title: Variety: Cryptic Treasure Hunt
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  If you were born and raised in the United States, odds are good that you have not had a lot of exposure to cryptic crosswords. I fall into that group, but Ive resolved to fix that. American-style crosswords are wonderful, but just look at the variety of puzzles we have available to us every Sunday in The New York Times. Sometimes the brain needs a little something different on which to nosh, no?

title: Bleeding Green
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  For 11 seasons, Shaun Ellis made Jets history, felt Jets history, lived Jets history. He played home games at a stadium named after another team. He practiced in a place that symbolized the franchise, underwhelming and outdated. He knows something about Jets heartache.

title: Video That Set Off Tunisias Uprising
description: As my colleague Kareem Fahim reports, Tunisias uprising began in the impoverished town of Sidi Bouzid, where a street vendor whose wares were confiscated by the police set himself on fire outside of a government building in December.

title: Overcoming Effects of Virus May Become Nadals Next Big Test
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Attempting to become the first man since Rod Laver to hold all four Grand Slam singles titles would presumably be enough to make any tennis star sweat. But on Saturday night at the Australian Open, Rafael Nadal was sweating as if he were playing a match in the heat of midday instead of a night match on a cool summer night in the Southern Hemisphere.

title: Obama Urges U.S. Competitiveness Ahead of Speech
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, declaring that the United States can outcompete any other nation on earth, called on Saturday for a new era of American innovation and competition, using his weekly address to deliver a pro-growth, pro-trade message that is likely to be at the heart of the State of the Union speech he gives to Congress on Tuesday.

title: Irish Prime Minister Quits as Party Leader but Holds on to His Office
description: LONDON  After a week in Irish politics that some in the press have described as a circus, Irelands prime minister, Brian Cowen, announced Saturday that he was abandoning his fight for political survival and resigning as leader of the governing Fianna Fail party. But he coupled his move with a pledge to remain as prime minister until after an election in March.

title: Wizards Without Wands
description: The N.B.A. may be a league of superstars, but it can be fun to root occasionally for the home team to win. With that in mind, fans may want to circle their calendars for when Washington comes to town.

title: Heartwarming Documentaries Invade Sundance
description: PARK CITY, Utah Sundance is known for showcasing gritty documentaries, and this years festival is no exception. How to Die in Oregon, about assisted suicide for the terminally ill, opens with a cancer patient literally dying on camera. Enjoy!

title: A Bond Lasting Decades Is Challenged by Illness
description: Nathan Wiener, 82, and Robert Bartlett, 78, are soul mates.

title: Karzai Agrees to Seat New Afghan Parliament
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai backed down on Saturday from his plan to put off the inauguration of a new Parliament by another month, agreeing to convene it this week after intense pressure from legislators and the international community.

title: Static on the Citadel Radio Dial
description: EXECUTIVES who run public companies, and the directors who oversee them, are supposed to operate with the shareholders best interests at heart. If a capitalist society like ours is to function, that has to be a bedrock principle.

title: How to Shape the DNA of a Young Company
description: This interview with Jeremy Allaire, chairman and chief executive of Brightcove, an online video platform for Web sites,  was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant. The New York Times Company owns a small stake of less than five percent in Brightcove.

title: Please, Just Tell Me When Im Nearing My Limit
description: CELLPHONE bills bring surprises of only one kind: unpleasant ones.

title: Adding Clarity to Health Care Reform
description: NOW that House Republicans have voted to repeal health care reform, in full knowledge that their bill has no chance of passing in the Senate, much less avoiding a presidential veto, it is time for constructive action. There is an opportunity to improve health care and reduce uncertainty, a Republican mantra.

title: Chasing the China Bandwagon
description: CHINESE tanks and missiles rolled past the reviewing stand in Tiananmen Square, where I sat as a member of the foreign press corps in early October 1984. It was the annual National Day parade, and a phalanx of soldiers marched smartly by. So far, nothing out of the ordinary.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Tortorella Takes Stand Against Leafs Orr
description: The Toronto tough guy Colton Orr was so out of control in the Maple Leafs 7-0 loss to the Rangers on Wednesday that John Tortorella, the Rangers coach, sat his top defensemen, Marc Staal and Dan Girardi, for much of the third period.

title: Walt Michaels, Ex-Jet, Still Has Coachs Mind
description: Walt Michaels has a lot in common with Rex Ryan.

title: Packers Rodgers Handles Pressure With Ease
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  Once a week or so, Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers strolls into Cheese Cake Heaven, a delicatessen and bakery near Lambeau Field popular with Packers players and their wives. Deb Katers, who works the register at lunchtime, said Rodgers often chose the build-your-own sandwich option  a turkey avocado kind of thing, she said  and exchanged playful banter with the counter staff.

title: Dont Just Complain. File the Appeal.
description: YOU come for the blood sport.

title: Product Placement, Turned Inside Out
description: PARK CITY, Utah

title: How My Assistant Saved the Day
description: IN May 2008, I started Urban Planet Mobile, which provides English language lessons over cellphones. Our customers include people whose first language is Mandarin, Hindi, Japanese, Thai, Arabic or Bengali, among others. In the United States, we offer test preparation over cellphones, and other companies hire us to offer health tips and so forth by phone.

title: The Gender Non-Issue
description: GROWING up, I spent many weekends on my grandparents farm an hour from us in Oklahoma. I remember digging potatoes and visiting the newborn piglets. My grandfather had eight brothers, and I learned to be comfortable around men at an early age. You had better be smiling or youd be teased.

title: Growing Grapes as Part of a Real-Life Script
description: ONE way to understand Emilio Estevezs backyard vineyard might be to recall a scene from Close Encounters of the Third Kind. Remember Richard Dreyfuss, after a run-in with a U.F.O., obsessively fashioning mountains out of mashed potatoes and shaving cream? Except for the U.F.O., thats kind of how Mr. Estevez is about growing grapes.

title: Tunisias Inner Workings Emerge on Twitter
description: TUNIS  Tunisias interim government was holding its first meeting since the ouster of the dictator Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali.

title: Quarterback for a Team of 1,900
description: WE are at war! DeMaurice Smith yelled.

title: A Cautionary Tale of Buzz Run Amok
description: PARK CITY, Utah Its hard to keep your head on straight amid the whip and whirl of Sundance, especially if you are a reporter getting besieged by breathless emails from squadrons of publicists. Whats real buzz and whats fake buzz? Who knows, really. But heres a one-word warning about hopping too quickly on any bandwagon: Hesher.

title: As State of the Union Nears, Congress Plays Musical Chairs
description: WASHINGTON  Mary from Louisiana asked Olympia from Maine because they are BFFs, but had a backup in Bob from Tennessee in case she was rebuffed. Kirsten from New York went the Sadie Hawkins route and asked John from South Dakota, and thus the deal between two members of the Senate with seriously good hair was sealed.

title: Distant and Fading Memories of First Bears-Packers Playoff Game
description: On Sunday at Soldier Field in Chicago, the Green Bay Packers and the Bears will play for the 182nd time. It will be their second postseason meeting.
