description: To the Sports Editor:

title: It Was Houdini Over Rybka in Computer Chess Challenge
Ward Has Hands, and Comments, You Can Count On
description: PITTSBURGH  When the Steelers season began, Ben Roethlisberger waited nervously behind smoked glass doors, preparing to face fans for the first time at training camp. Just as he was about to step into the unknown after an off-season of troubling behavior and damaging publicity, his teammate Hines Ward appeared beside Roethlisberger and said he would walk out with him.

title: Olbermanns MSNBC Exit Was Weeks in the Making
description: On Thursday, NBCs news division staged an elaborate presentation for advertisers, seeking to sell commercial time in NBCs news programs over the next year. All the members of MSNBCs prime-time lineup spoke at the lunch with one exception: Keith Olbermann, the networks biggest star.

title: Nepal Takes Command of Ex-Rebels
description: CHITWAN, Nepal  In a major step forward in Nepals tortured peace process, Maoist political leaders on Saturday formally relinquished control of their 19,000-member army to a special governmental committee.

title: Two Weeks After Rampage in Tucson, Survivors Struggle With What If?
description: TUCSON  What if he had not had that second cup of coffee? What if he had not asked the cashier about the two-for-one special on cigarettes? Maybe he would have been there a minute, or just 30 seconds, earlier. Maybe that would have been enough.

title: In This Lengthy Match, No Celebration for Isner
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  If anyone else had been involved, it would have felt like a marathon, but John Isner was part of redefining the parameters of a tennis match last year and perhaps forever.

title: Man Is Accidentally Shot in Raid, Police Say
description: A New York police officer whose father was killed in the line of duty nearly 30 years ago fired an errant shot on Saturday during a drug raid in the Bronx and wounded a suspects 76-year-old father, the authorities said.

title: Childhood Stories From the Inside of a Dynasty
description: I was 10 and a half years old and having dinner with my father, who covered the Green Bay Packers as a sportscaster, and Marv Fleming, the rangy, elegant tight end Bart Starr would calmly seek out when the dirt-stained jerseys of the Bears or the Giants writhed in front of all his other options.

title: Former Spy With Agenda Operates a Private C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON  Duane R. Clarridge parted company with the Central Intelligence Agency more than two decades ago, but from poolside at his home near San Diego, he still runs a network of spies.

title: Sundances Go-To Bad Guy
description: PARK CITY, Utah Walking up Main Street here on Friday afternoon, John Hawkes was recognized by some fans and happily posed for a few photos. Mr. Hawkes has always been a Sundance darling, but now the rest of the world is taking note. As the menacing addict and familyman Teardrop in Debra Graniks Ozarks drama Winters Bone, hes received awards buzz and nominations, the most attention of a career that has included roles in Deadwood and Miranda Julys 2005 Sundance hit, Me and You and Everyone We Know. Mr. Hawkes is back at Sundance with two films: Martha Marcy May Marlene, in which he plays a cult leader; and Higher Ground, Vera Farmigas directorial debut. (He also voiced a talking cat in Ms. Julys second feature, The Future, which had its premiere here on Friday, though she eventually replaced him with her own voice.)

title: Hes 20. Is Rubios Fine Future in the Past?
description: Rarely would a 20-year-old basketball player be considered over the hill.

title: No Better Southern Man
description: The featureless flat plains of West Tennessee seemed an unlikely locale to harbor a Southern Black Republican. But his political opponents routinely hung this epithet  and worse  on Rep. Emerson Etheridge. Thats because, unlike many Southern antisecessionists in early 1861, Etheridge continued to proclaim unconditional loyalty to the Union. Even worse, he ridiculed the idea that the Republican Party intended to interfere with slavery. Secessionists and Southern Rights supporters sputtered in frustration. Etheridge, they said, had fallen into the depths of disgrace and infamy. He appealed only to the ignorant and blind lick-spittles rather than to the slaveholding and enlightened portion of the people.

title: N.F.L. Offers Tickets to Super Bowl Party Outside Cowboys Stadium
description: The N.F.L. is stretching the meaning of a ticket to the Super Bowl, the most prized ticket in sports.

title: Tea Party Activist Takes Over New Hampshire G.O.P.
description: DERRY, N.H.  A fight to lead the New Hampshire Republican Party through next years presidential race ended Saturday with an upset victory by a conservative candidate backed by members of the Tea Party and other grass-roots groups.

title: The One-Eyed Man Is King
description: A month before John Wayne won the 1969 Best Actor Oscar for True Grit, Richard Nixon wrote him a Dear Duke fan letter from the Oval Office: I saw it in the W.H. with my family and for once we agree with the critics  you were great! Some four decades later, his rave was echoed by another Republican warrior, this time in praise of the True Grit remake with Jeff Bridges in the role of the old, fat, hard-drinking, half-blind 19th-century United States marshal Rooster Cogburn. Shortly after New Years, Liz Cheney told The Times that her parents saw True Grit at the Teton Theater in Jackson, Wyo., and gave it two thumbs up.

title: Saner Gun Laws
description: It is widely believed in Washington that there is no chance the gun lobby and the new Republican majority in the House would ever permit passage of the modest ideas for tightening Americas absurdly lax gun laws that have surfaced since the massacre in Tucson.

title: Legacy of a Fence
description: I fell in love withJanet Napolitano before I ever met her, back in 2005, when she was governor of Arizona and had this to say about the proposal in Washington to build a fence along the Mexican border:

title: Housing and a Chance
description: If the federal government is going to end homelessness among veterans in five years, as Veterans Affairs Secretary Eric Shinseki has vowed to do, then it will have to find a way to help the hard cases. These are the long-term street people  men mostly, many fragile in mind or body, often addicted to alcohol or drugs. They shuttle from shelter to street to emergency room, burning up caregivers energy and social-service dollars.

title: Watergate? Whats That?
description: In the Republicans thumbs up-or-down version of lawmaking, the House majority leader, Eric Cantor, is targeting for extinction the publicly subsidized presidential campaign finance system adopted in the wake of the Watergate scandals.

title: Incumbent Senators Weigh Options
description: WASHINGTON  As veteran members of the Senate contemplate the future, they find themselves pondering a question memorably and musically posed by the Clash: Should I stay or should I go?

title: Hallowed Ground
description: In Commack, on Long Island, a little graveyard lies surrounded by chain-link fence and buried in snow. Inside are nine headstones, some from the 1800s, many cracked and tilted, under spindly trees. Now fades the glimmering landscape on the sight, and all the air a solemn stillness holds  save where the orange work cart clatters by, laden with Sheetrock and tubs of joint compound.

title: A Necessary Clash of News and Advertising
description: Views from readers, responses from the staff and thoughts from Arthur S. Brisbane, the public editor.

title: Adventures of a Challenging Book
description: To the Editor:

title: Sargent Shrivers Values
description: To the Editor:

title: Beware, Spider-Man
description: To the Editor:

title: California Runner-Up Bypasses Review of Race
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  Every four years, the minds  left and right  that brought you the California governors race get together for a collegial post-mortem at the University of California, Berkeley, on what they did right and wrong in the campaign. Coffee is served, as is  usually  political dish.

title: H.I.V. in Russia
description: To the Editor:

title: Farm Policy, Sugar Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Sundance Embraces the Latest It Girl
description: PARK CITY, Utah The romantic drama Like Crazy packed em in on Saturday afternoon at Sundances Eccles Theater. It wasnt just the driving snow outside. The chatter among festival programmers has been that the films female lead, a young British actress named Felicity Jones, is this years Carey Mulligan (An Education).

title: Lawsuit Loans
description: To the Editor:

title: Undecided on Olympics
description: A year ago, Evan Lysacek won the gold medal in the mens figure skating competition at the Vancouver Olympics. He was the first American to win the event since Brian Boitano in 1988. These days, besides headlining the Stars on Ice tour, he is a member of the board of Figure Skating in Harlem, which teaches girls academic and life skills through ice skating, and serves on the celebrity board of Ronald McDonald House Charities, which aims to improve the health and well-being of children. He will be honored at the Thurman Munson Awards dinner on Feb. 1 by the AHRC New York City Foundation, an organization that benefits handicapped children. JOE BRESCIA

title: One Small Revolution
description: THE West stands captivated by Tunisia, where a month of peaceful protests by secular working- and middle-class Arabs has toppled a dictator, raising hopes that this North African country of 10 million will set off democracy movements throughout a region of calcified dictatorships. But before we envision a new Middle East remade in the manner of Europe 1989, it is worth cataloguing the pivotal ways in which Tunisia is unique.

title: Squalid Abortion Clinic Escaped State Oversight
description: PHILADELPHIA  For years, state health officials missed some unsettling patterns at the three-story brick abortion clinic on Lancaster Avenue.

title: Omert May Be Dead; the Mafia Isnt
description: QUITE a coincidence: In January 1961, Robert F. Kennedy, newly appointed as attorney general of the United States, orchestrated the first concentrated attack on the American Mafia. Almost to the day 50 years later, the government swept up more than 120 people in a smorgasbord of racketeering indictments, mainly in the New York area.

title: Nakamura Is Again Leader of Tata Steel Chess Tournament
Plains Giants Have Foothold on Tables
description: DENVER  The nations buffalo ranchers have no catchy marketing slogan about whats for dinner, and no big trade association budget to pay for making one up.

title: Blogs Interrupted
description: My Sunday column is a show-and-tell of an experiment I conducted in Beijing to look for the boundaries of what is permissible on the Chinese Internet. A Chinese editor I much admired, Qin Benli, taught me a wonderful expression in Chinese, , or cabianqiu, meaning a ping pong ball that just nicks the edge of table. Its legal, but with no room to spare. Qin told me that that is exactly what a good Chinese journalist aims to do with each article. So I tried to construct a blog and micro-blog (the Chinese equivalent of Twitter) to find out where the cabianqiu are. Below are pictures of a micro-blog and blog that I started in Beijing in December:

title: Sunday: Next Time Wont You Sing With Me
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Not that you asked, but when I became a mother for the first time, I realized that I was hideously unprepared. When you rock your baby to sleep, a good mother should automatically have a whole repertoire of soothing melodies to croon, shouldnt she?

title: Trying to Break Logjam, Scholar Floats an Idea for a Palestinian Map
description: WASHINGTON  It speaks to the paralysis in the Middle East peace process that the most noteworthy development of the past week came when a mild-mannered analyst at a pro-Israel think tank unfurled three color-coded maps.

title: Jets Strategy Works Wonders  So Far
description: In their two playoff victories, the Jets flooded the secondary with defensive backs, forcing Peyton Manning and Tom Brady out of their comfort zones.

title: Friendship Between Cutler and Rodgers Takes the Week Off
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill.  Although Chicago Bears quarterback Jay Cutler and his Green Bay counterpart, Aaron Rodgers, are friends, they have spent the past week avoiding their usual exchanges of text messages as each prepares for Sundays N.F.C. championship game.

title: Cilic Awaits Nadal in Round of 16
description: Rafael Nadal went into his semifinal match at the Beijing stop on the ATP Tour in fall 2009 in seemingly fine form again. He had vanquished Marcos Baghdatis and James Blake in tight early-round matches then thrashed Marat Safin in the quarterfinals with the loss of only four games.

title: In Mideast Activism, New Tilt Away From Ideology
description: CAIRO  Egypts most powerful and proscribed opposition movement, the Muslim Brotherhood, has decided that it will not participate in an antigovernment demonstration this week for a curious reason: The protest conflicts with a national holiday honoring the police.

title: French Chess Federation Accuses Its Own Players of Cheating
description: An announcement on Friday on the French Chess Federations Web site accuses three of its own players of cheating during last years Chess Olympiad in Khanty-Mansiysk, Russia.

title: A Gay Agenda for Everyone
description: Im not an idiot: Now that the Republicans hold the House, only wishful thinkers and the deeply delusional expect to see any movement on the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender legislative agenda this year or next. Nevertheless, President Obama should address gay rights in his State of the Union speech this week, and he should tackle the biggest, most meaningful right of them all: the right to marry.

title: Recover Our Spending Power
description: P RESIDENT OBAMA will have to devote a big part of his State of the Union address to the economy, but which economy?

title: Gun Control Without a Ban
description: WITH the Tucson shootings still in the news, theres a good chance President Obama will discuss gun control in his speech. How he does it could mean progress or stalemate on the issue.

title: Keep All the Top Teachers
description: THE past year was a sobering one for American educators, as we learned that the United States is falling farther behind in international student rankings. To his credit, President Obama put forward a plan for change that hit the mark, a brilliant stroke that even the abolish the Department of Education crowd had to admire. Race to the Top, the competitive grant program that harnesses stimulus dollars to drive reform, convinced a surprising number of governors and legislators from both parties to pay the entrance fee by proving they could strengthen their education laws.

title: Create Jobs Not Deficits
description: PRESIDENT OBAMA must use his State of the Union speech to make clear his commitment to two economic imperatives: accelerating job growth and controlling the federal deficit. He must persuade Americans that we do not have a choice between the two. We have to do both, and we have to get the timing right.

title: Energy for the Economy
description: FACING a public focused on economic revival, a hostile House and the lowest level of voter concern in a long while on human-driven climate change, President Obama could easily punt on energy this Tuesday. But this would actually be the ideal time for him to introduce an energy quest as a keystone 21st-century American imperative. Only by expanding our menu of nonpolluting energy choices can we hope to ameliorate a variety of social, geopolitical, climatic and economic risks facing the country and the world.

title: The Final Health Care Debate
description: G IVEN the deep divide on health care reform in the courts, the Congress and the country, the long-term viability of this historic achievement depends in part on President Obamas ability to reduce the tension and seek common ground. In his State of the Union message, he should say something like this:

title: Less Engagement, More Democracy
description: THE revolt in Tunisia has thrown both that nations dictator, Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, and the Obama administrations democracy-promotion policy onto the ash heap of history. The revolt undermined  indeed, destroyed  two years of effort in Washington to move toward a policy of engagement with hostile and repressive regimes.

title: Banned in Beijing!
description: BEIJING

title: The State That Went Bust
description: AS the states dream up budget plans for a new year, some find themselves staring at deficits in the billions of dollars, vanishing federal stimulus funds, mounting health care costs, their own struggling cities and a canyon of underfunded pension liabilities ahead.

title: Prime Number
description: 11.9: The percentage of American workers in unions last year, the lowest proportion in more than 70 years, according to the governments Bureau of Labor Statistics. The number of workers in unions fell by 612,000 last year, to 14.7 million. About 20 percent of workers were in unions in 1983; the figure was 35 percent during the mid-1950s, according to labor historians. Last year was a very tough year for unionized workers, said John Schmitt, a senior economist with the Center for Economic and Policy Research in Washington. Were seeing declines in the private sector, and were seeing declines in the public sector.

title: Obama to Press Centrist Agenda in His Address
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will outline an agenda for winning the future in his State of the Union address on Tuesday night, striking a theme of national unity and renewal as he stresses the need for government spending in key areas and an attack on the budget deficit.

title: Back Then: 1986
description: Haitis former dictator, Jean-Claude Duvalier, returned unexpectedly last week for the first time after being forced to flee in 1986. He was quickly arrested on charges of embezzlement and corruption. Following Mr. Duvaliers overthrow in 1986, mobs ransacked his estates. One of them was an Alpine-style retreat visited by The Timess James Brooke shortly after it was looted.

title: The Grist
description: Hong Kongs most striking feature  the skyline of skyscrapers silhouetted against Victoria Peak  is getting harder and harder to see, reports Bettina Wassener on The Timess Green blog. Over the last few decades, as the citys economy and that of neighboring mainland China has expanded, air pollution in the region has worsened and so has visibility. And the obscured view is not the only concern. A study released last week by the University of Hong Kong Li Ka Shing Faculty of Medicine reported that the air pollution was linked to 1,200 deaths in the city annually from 2007 to 2010.

title: Laugh Lines
description: JAY LENO

title: Fighting Words
description: Glenn Beck has taken to criticizing Frances Fox Piven, the liberal sociologist, for her radical plan, published 45 years ago, to help poor people. Some liberals have come to her defense, saying she has received death threats. Fox News said Mr. Beck had quoted her accurately and never threatened her.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Jan. 23
description: President Obamas planned State of the Union address is the focus of the Sunday television talk shows, as lawmakers and former presidential advisers discuss their expectations for the speech and the next two years. Republican efforts to repeal the health care law are also a big topic on the Sunday shows.

title: Federal Research Center Will Help Develop Medicines
description: The Obama administration has become so concerned about the slowing pace of new drugs coming out of the pharmaceutical industry that officials have decided to start a billion-dollar government drug development center to help create medicines.

title: Sit! Fetch! Practice!
description: I suspect that many dog lovers are struggling with last weeks news that a border collie named Chaser learned the names of more than 1,000 objects and can retrieve them on command.

title: Bears and Packers: To Call Them Rivals Is Understatement
description: If you had been on holiday in Siberia last week, you might not know that one of the longest-running, most hotly contested rivalries in sports has been kicked up to Defcon 9 levels in the area. It has been in all the papers, unblushingly described as the biggest game in Chicago history.

title: Eavesdropping Laws Mean That Turning On an Audio Recorder Could Send You to Prison
description: Christopher Drew is a 60-year-old artist and teacher who wears a gray ponytail and lives on the North Side. Tiawanda Moore, 20, a former stripper, lives on the South Side and dreams of going back to school and starting a new life.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Burge Case Ends With a Prison Sentence and No Little Bit of Wondering
description: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Where Budget Gaps, and People, Are Few
description: Among all the bad news about state budgets, there are four bright spots: North Dakota, Alaska, Arkansas, Wyoming. Those are the only states  home to less than 2 percent of the nation's population  that say they can balance their budgets for the 2012 fiscal year without slashing spending or raising revenues.

title: Gates Co-op Houseboats
description: For more than a half-century, low-rent pirates have inhabited ramshackle floating homes in Richardson Bay, just north of Sausalito. The last remnants of this independent seaside tribe are the inhabitants of 38 houseboats at Gates Co-op, a community stranded at low tide in the mud at Waldo Point Harbor.

title: For Vallejo, Bankruptcy Isnt Exactly a Fresh Start
description: Jonathan Weber writes a regular column for The Bay Citizen

title: Whither Young Offenders? The Debate Has Begun
description: Joaquin E. DiazDeLeon, a former Fresno gang member, spent two years inside Californias juvenile prison system. What he found there, he said, was no better than the streets he came from.

title: With Patience and Cunning, an Entrepreneur Snags One of San Franciscos Legendary Bars
description: Dennis Learys takeover of the House of Shields, one of San Franciscos coolest old bars, was as artful as a classic cocktail  stirred by hand, and ever so slowly.

title: If Budget Cuts Are Made, Districts May Have to Decide on Fate of Unused Schools
description: Texas public schools are facing what could be $10 billion less in state financing  a stark prospect that could empty school buildings across the state as districts consolidate campuses to reduce costs. One proposal under consideration by the Austin Independent School District, the states fourth largest, suggests closing eight elementary schools and one middle school.

title: Damon and Ramirez Are Close to Reuniting With Rays
description: In 2004, Johnny Damon and Manny Ramirez were two of the main actors on the rambunctious and resilient Boston Red Sox team that made a historic comeback in the American League Championship Series and then went on to win the franchises first championship in 86 years.

title: Houses Grim Budget Sounds the Alarm
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

title: Vows: Elyse and Paul
description: Three days after moving to New York City, Paul met Elyse. He was her new boss. He was downhearted by her initial lack of interest in him. After one year, things changed.

title: A Great TV Series Set in Texas? Sorry, Youre Canceled
description: It was supposed to be a watershed season for television production in Texas. While the Austin-based NBC drama Friday Night Lights was wrapping production on its final season, four new series set in the Lone Star State got network green lights, including three whose productions would be based in the Dallas-Fort Worth area.

title: U.S.-Mexico Trucker Dispute Takes a Step Forward
description: A proposal by the Obama administration that would grant Mexican truckers greater access to Texas roadways  and far beyond  would be a boon to businesses in the state, supporters say. But unions, the Teamsters in particular, say the plan would cost American jobs.

title: Surreal: A Soap Opera Starring Berlusconi
description: ROME

title: Superpower and Upstart: Sometimes It Ends Well
description: WASHINGTON  For a superpower, dealing with the fast rise of a rich, brash competitor has always been an iffy thing.

title: S.F. Giants Return for Fans They Left Behind
description: Warren Bellefond, a 72-year-old retired postal worker from Washington Heights, held up a clear plastic cube with a dirty, brown, smudged baseball in it, and described to Willie Mays how Mays hit the ball to him during batting practice on Sept. 29, 1957, the last game the Giants ever played at the old Polo Grounds.

title: Obama Marks Anniversary of Roe v. Wade
description: President Obama reaffirmed his support for abortion rights on Saturday, the 38th anniversary of the Supreme Court decision in Roe v. Wade that established a womans right to an abortion.

title: The Presidents Speech
description: With President Obama poised to deliver his second State of the Union address on Tuesday, the Op-Ed editors asked politicians, journalists and experts in various fields what they would like to hear him say.

title: Lottery Numbers
The Thorny Path to a National Black Museum
description: In the late 1970s, when Lonnie G. Bunch III had his first job at the Smithsonians National Air and Space Museum, veterans of the Tuskegee Airmen, the all-black squadron, accused the museum of playing down their contributions during World War II. In response, the museum asked some of the African-Americans on staff to allow their faces to be used on mannequins, increasing the black presence in its exhibits.

title: Georgia Carroll, Singer in Kay Kysers Band, Dies at 91
description: Georgia Carroll, who enjoyed short-lived stardom as the featured vocalist in Kay Kysers popular big band before marrying Mr. Kyser and retiring from show business in her late 20s, died on Jan. 14 in Chapel Hill, N.C. She was 91.

title: Chess Blindness Can Strike Even the Most Skilled Players
description: Everyone makes mistakes in chess. But even the best players on the planet  and by that I mean computers  are not infallible.

title: Product Placement, Meta Version, Comes to the Cineplex
description: PARK CITY, Utah Morgan Spurlocks new documentary, a humorous look at product placement and advertising called The Greatest Movie Ever Sold, was shrouded in an abnormal amount of secrecy before its Sundance screening on Saturday. Some reporters figured out what was going on, but a superheroic effort by Mr. Spurlocks publicity firm, Ginsberg/Libby, kept the most crucial secret just that.

title: Durants 3-Pointer Beats Buzzer, Sending Knicks to 6th Loss in Row
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  Before Saturday nights game in Oklahoma City against the Thunder, Knicks Coach Mike DAntoni never let go of the smile he was doing his best not to force.

title: Fifth Avenue and Carroll Street, Brooklyn, 4 P.M.
description: Nothing like looking out your window to see a hawk ripping the sinew out of a bird on top of your air conditioner. Still photo below.

title: Sports Photo Replay, Jan. 21
description: A look at the day in college basketball, the NHL and winter sports.

title:
Vietnam Accord is Reached; Cease-Fire
Begins Saturday; P.O.W.'s to be Free in 60
Days
description: Washington, Jan. 23 -- President Nixon said tonight that Henry A. Kissinger and North Vietnam's chief negotiator, Le Duc Tho, had initialed an agreement in Paris today "to end the war and bring peace with honor in Vietnam and Southeast Asia."

title: Sergei Eisenstein Is Dead In Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 11 -- Sergei Eisenstein, famous Russian film director and producer, died last night.

title: Oversight Group Vows to Pursue Updates to Football Helmet Standards
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  With officials from the federal Consumer Product Safety Commission lending an air of urgency, the board that oversees athletic equipment safety finished its annual meeting Saturday vowing to pursue several updates to football helmet standards.

title: Kings Speech Takes Producers Guild Award
description: LOS ANGELES Oscar prospects brightened for The Kings Speech, as the films producers  Iain Canning, Emile Sherman and Gareth Unwin  won the top award for makers of a theatrical motion picture from the Producers Guild of America on Saturday night. The prize is generally an indicator of strength in the Academy Awards race, because many of the guilds voting members also belong to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, which grants the Oscars. Last years top film award from the producers went to The Hurt Locker, which went on to win the best picture Oscar.

title: Six Killed in Wave of Baghdad Bombings
description: BAGHDAD  Shattering the relative calm that had prevailed in the capital for months, five car bombs exploded in different neighborhoods here on Sunday morning, killing at least 6 people and wounding 30. The military defused another three bombs.

title: Goldin Pays Tribute to Berlins Creative Underground
description: Although the European Month of Photography officially ended at the conclusion of November, Berlins keystone exhibition of the biennial arts festival, Nan Goldin: Berlin Work, remains on view at the Berlinische Galerie, through March 28.

title: This Week, Today
description: Other heads will talk, and SOTU will mine.

title: The Troy Polamalu Factor
description: Its not hard to see Troy Polamalus importance to the Steelers, whether youre poring over advanced statistics or reclining on your couch watching the games. (In the videos above and below, Polamalu does a fair impression of Jimmy Superfly Snuka  without the benefit of jumping off the top rope.)

title: After Nearly 5 Hours, Italian Wins Epic Match
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  It was not the emotional summit of Francesca Schiavones career. That came last June when Schiavone kissed the red clay at the French Open in Paris after becoming the first Italian woman to a Grand Slam singles title.

title: Do You Have Confidence in Mark Sanchez?
description: PITTSBURGH  Whether the Jets like it or not, a lot of the burden of returning to the Super Bowl after a four-decade drought is on Mark Sanchezs shoulders. Sanchez is a victory away from the most playoff road wins by an N.F.L. quarterback. But he evokes strong emotions from Jets fans, some of whom see the promise but are unsettled by his uneven performance.

title: 100 Years Ago, the Shot That Spurred New Yorks Gun-Control Law
description: Nothing spurs talk of gun-control legislation quite like a highly publicized crime committed with the aid of a handgun.

title: China Grooming Deft Politician as Next Leader
description: BEIJING  President Hu Jintao of China returned home this weekend after a trip intended to repair relations with the United States. But the next time the White House marches out the honor guard and polishes the crystal for a Chinese leader, it is unlikely to be for Mr. Hu.

title: Its Your Obama Moment. What Do You Say?
description: I was invited to contribute to a roundup for the Sunday Op-Ed page of views on how President Obama could approach various issues in his State of the Union address on Tuesday.

title: Photos of the Moment | Bernhard Willhelm
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#660", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Israeli Panel Rules Flotilla Raid Legal
description: JERUSALEM  An Israeli commission that examined the deadly raid on a flotilla bound for Gaza last May concluded Sunday that Israel had acted in accordance with international law when its military enforced its naval blockade by intercepting the ships in international waters.

title: Nobody Expects the Macroeconomic Inquisition
description: A correspondent directs me to this article:

title: Photos of the Moment | Dior
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#393", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: The Market Begins to Move at Sundance
description: 10:29 p.m. | Updated PARK CITY, Utah And on the fourth day, the deals started to pick up steam. As Sundance awoke to a particularly frosty morning on Sunday  9 degrees by our thermometers estimation  word broke that Paramount and Lionsgate had both snapped up movies overnight. Paramount paid about $4 million for Like Crazy, a giggly romantic drama starring Anton Yelchin and Felicity Jones. Reigning indie queen Jennifer Lawrence (Winters Bone) has a supporting role in the film, which directed by Drake Doremus. About 50 percent of the movies dialogue is improvised.

title: Amish Fashion Week
description: Five years ago Dior Homme was hyper-cool boys in the latest wispy jeans and haircuts. For fall 2011, the clothes are soft, draped, plain, and the boys are wearing flat, wide-brimmed hats. I had a sudden flashback to Alexander Godunov as an Amish dreamboat farmer in Witness, though some of the loose monochromatic suits and unadorned double-faced coats also made me think, on second thought, of vintage Yohji Yamamoto and more recent Phoebe Philo of Cline her influence anyway.

title: In China, Plugged In, but Unplugged
description: Midfielder Yael Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., native by way of the University of North Carolina, will be contributing to the Goal blog in the runup to the third season of Womens Professional Soccer and as the United States womens national team prepares to the FIFA Womens World Cup in Germany later this year. Now, she checks in from China, where the U.S. is getting ready to face the hosts in the Four Nations Tournament.

title: Analysis: How Wozniacki Keeps Winning
description: Caroline Wozniacki wins in such a workmanlike, undramatic way that many tennis observers overlook what she does do well. She wears down her opponents with consistency, calm, and a complete understanding of what she can and cant do on a tennis court. If playing a tennis match is akin to managing money, Wozniacki would earn you a solid return, year in and year out, but she would never stand out.

title: Senate Republicans to Oppose Obamas Spending Plans
description: The Senates top Republican, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, said on Sunday that his party will vigorously oppose the spending initiatives President Obama plans to include in his State of the Union address on Tuesday because its not a time to be looking at pumping up government spending.

title: Gehry Design Plays Fanfare for the Common Man
description: MIAMI BEACH  Can an architect save classical music? That seems to be what Michael Tilson Thomas, the artistic director of the New World Symphony, was counting on when he hired Frank Gehry to design him a new music center.

title: Somalia Is Likely to Cut Ties to Mercenaries, Official Says
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  The minister of information for the transitional federal government here said Sunday that Somalia was likely to end its relationship with Saracen International, a private security company in which South African mercenaries and the founder of Blackwater Worldwide are said to be involved.

title: Photos of the Moment | Damir Doma
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#514", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Photos of the Moment | Herms
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#158", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Final: Packers 21, Bears 14
description: The Green Bay Packers are headed back to the Super Bowl after beating the Chicago Bears, 21-14, in the N.F.C. championship game at Soldier Field. But before their trip to Dallas was sealed, they had to withstand a rally attempt led by perhaps the most unlikely figure in championship game history. Caleb Hanie, the Bears third-string quarterback, was forced into action after Jay Cutler and Todd Collins were both knocked out with injuries. Hanie threw a 35-yard touchdown to Earl Bennett with 4:43 remaining that pulled the Bears within 7 points, but his inexperience showed. He threw one interception that was returned B.J. Raji 18 yards for a score and he was picked off by Sam Shields with about 40 seconds left, a play that sealed the Packers victory.

title: Paris Mens: Nip It, Bud
description: The jacket is getting roughed up this seasonnipped, shortened, tweaked. At Lanvin on Sunday morning, the jackets looked leaner for fall; some were pilled with black puffer jackets, and the collection included wide trousers, the narrow ones looked more in step with the rest of the urban line.

title: Egypt Links Palestinians to Attack at Church
description: CAIRO  Egypts interior minister charged Sunday that a Palestinian extremist group with links to Al Qaeda was behind the Dec. 31 bombing outside a church in Alexandria that killed 21 people and set off days of sectarian rioting around the nation.

title: A Whimsical End to Writers Block
description: PARK CITY, Utah Miranda Julys second feature, The Future, opens with a talking cat, and gets cuter, weirder and darker from there. Ms. July, the artist, writer and performer, had a Sundance hit in 2005 with Me and You and Everyone We Know, which went on to win a Camera dOr at Cannes for best first feature, and her next film was eagerly awaited. But in a directors statement, Ms. July wrote that she so dreaded making a follow-up that she was nearly paralyzed with writers block. That turned out to be her inspiration.

title: New World, New Home
description: Photos of Frank Gehrys design of the New World Center in Miami Beach.

title: Coach Leaves the Bench, but Not the Team
description: Last year, in a post about four college basketball coaches getting fired during the season, I expressed doubt that any of their interim replacements would be hired permanently, though I did speculate that Penns Jerome Allen could be, as he eventually was.

title: To Life! Song-Studded Remembrance for the Fiddler Composer Jerry Bock
description: Friends and colleagues will gather on Monday to celebrate the life and work of Jerry Bock, who wrote the music to some of the most memorable songs in musical-theater history. The public is invited, too.

title: Tunisia Shuts Down Private TV Channel
description: TUNIS  Tunisias interim government abruptly shut down the countrys oldest and most popular private television network on Sunday evening, in an apparent violation of its pledges to respect freedom of expression after the ouster of the authoritarian president Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali.

title: Woman Arrested in 87 Kidnapping Case
description: A woman who the authorities believe took a 3-week-old baby girl from Harlem Hospital 23 years ago and raised her as her own child was arrested Sunday on federal kidnapping charges, the United States attorney in Manhattan said.

title: Photos of the Moment | Raf Simons
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#529", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: For U.S., Mixx and Dax to the Max
description: The United States opened its 2011 schedule Saturday night with a 1-1 draw against Chile at the Home Depot Center in Carson, Calif.

title: Design Picked for Wildlife Crossing
description: WASHINGTON  At a picturesque spot in the mountains near the ski resorts of Vail and Breckenridge, Colo., two streams of traffic converge: people driving east and west on Interstate 70, and animals  black bears, cougars, bobcats, elk and deer  headed north and south to feed and mate. When they collide, the animal is almost always killed and the vehicle badly damaged, even if the driver is lucky enough to escape injury.

title: The Guide: Raf Simons
description: Nearly six years ago, in a review of a Raf Simons show, I wrote that the Belgian designer deserved a Swiss bank. The reference was to the Swiss Textile Award that Mr. Simons had won that year and the difference the prize money made in his future-minded collection. Since then, many people have said I favor Mr. Simons, both in his mens line and the womens collections he does for Jil Sander. Look, I just think Mr. Simons consistently turns out interesting collections, and in 2005, I looked at videos and photographs of all his shows and presentations going back to the mid-90s, to see what I had missed  which was a lot.

title: Giffords Remains in Intensive Care
description: HOUSTON Representative Gabrielle Giffords is likely to remain in an intensive care unit until the end of the week because of a slight buildup of spinal fluid in her brain after her transfer by air from Tucson to Memorial Hermann hospital here, hospital officials say.

title: Sara Lee Weighs Future After Receiving Takeover Interest
description: 10:56 p.m. | Updated

title: Heroic Naturalists or Imperialist Dogs?
description: What does it mean to discover a species? Who should get the credit for it? Why did early naturalists think it worth risking their lives, and often losing them, to ship home the first specimens of a previously unknown butterfly or bat? These turn out to be tangled questions, and it is easy to get stuck on the thorns.

title: Southern Sudan Nears a Decision on One Matter: Its New Name
description: JUBA, Sudan  Southern Sudan, which recently carried out a referendum on seceding from the north, will be named the Republic of South Sudan upon independence, officials here in the regional capital said Sunday.

title: More Words About Ellen Stewart
description: Space and deadline constraints kept some voices out of Sundays Arts and Leisure piece on Ellen Stewart, the guiding force behind the East Village performance space La MaMa and an Off Off Broadway pioneer who died on Jan. 13. Here, a few more theater-world figures remember Ms. Stewart as a figure of contradictions  at once easygoing and hard-nosed, opinionated and indulgent. Jason Zinoman, a critic for The New York Times, collected the recollections:

title: Green Party Quits Irish Government
description: LONDON  Irelands political turmoil deepened on Sunday when the Green Party abandoned the governing coalition with the Fianna Fail party of Prime Minister Brian Cowen, raising fresh doubts about Mr. Cowens ability to cling to office beyond the next few days and prompting new questions about Irelands commitments under the $114 billion bailout plan for its economy negotiated with international lenders.

title: Live Analysis: Final: Steelers 24, Jets 19
description: The Jets battled back from a 24-0 second quarter deficit, but it wasnt enough. The Steelers held off their comeback to win the A.F.C. championship game by 24-19.

title: Fianc, Tied in Poetic Knots
description: Beggars cant be choosers. This was the clich with which I tried to comfort myself Thursday night at the Gramercy Theater, at the opening of Repertorio Espaols production of Federico Garca Lorcas As Que Pasen Cinco Aos (Once Five Years Pass). This mysterious, intimate play, which depicts a young mans lengthy engagement, its traumatic end and out-of-time aftermath, is rarely performed and is here presented in the original Spanish. If youre not proficient in that language, your experience of what seems to be a vibrant and muscular rendering by this company and its artistic director, Ren Buch, will be filtered through a live English translation (courtesy of headphones).

title: A Life of Design
description: Photos of costumes designed by Theoni V. Aldredge, who died Jan. 21.

title: A Jazz Man Returns to His Past
description: What should a Chick Corea retrospective concert sound like? Theres so much there, so many different causes and curiosities: cooled-out electric funk with singers, nearly classical solo-piano tudes, blizzarding jazz-rock, Afro-Cuban rhythms, straightforward extensions of Bud Powell and the jazz mainstream. Beyond Mr. Coreas own keyboard touch, springy and clear with controlled flourish and just about perfect time, its hard to find a clean aesthetic line through what he does.

title: Pianist at Last Has Carnegie All to Himself
description: The thoughtful American pianist Jonathan Biss has played on the main stage at Carnegie Hall as a soloist with several orchestras. His vibrant account of Schumanns Piano Concerto with James Levine and the Met Orchestra in 2008 comes to mind.

title: Down on the Dacha, Farmers Showing Off Expressive Footwork
description: WASHINGTON  It was a surprise to enter the Kennedy Center, which is currently presenting an exhibition commemorating the presidency of John F. Kennedy, and find, across the Opera House proscenium arch, the hammer and sickle insignia of Soviet Russia. In June the same hammer and sickle will hang in the Metropolitan Opera House in New York. Weve come a long way since the cold war  but how?

title: The Dancers Line and the Artists Line Intersect in the Sand
description: In 1981 Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker, a young Belgian student at New York Universitys Tisch School of the Arts, presented her first professional work of choreography at a festival in Westchester County in New York. It was a solo, set to Steve Reichs Violin Phase, in which Ms. De Keersmaeker moved in circular patterns with strict repetitions of a single turning, twisting phrase that brilliantly played off the musics formalism and drama.

title: Embracing the Modern With Tone Clusters, Not Dissonance
description: The Juilliard Schools annual Focus! Festival provides a significant service for New York concertgoers by shining a light, sustained and searching, on a tightly defined subject. Usually the themes are geographical, and Joel Sachs, the festivals director, has made a point of assembling programs that balance familiar names with composers most Americans will not have encountered. You invariably come away from these free concerts with a sense of having discovered something.

title: From a Chair, Not a Bench, Exploring Brahmss Poetry
description: Many classical and operatic works that are now repertory standards were glumly received at their premieres because of substandard performances, bafflement at audacious musical gestures or simply the audiences inability to appreciate the worth of a new piece immediately. During one of its first performances, Brahmss Piano Concerto No. 1 in D minor, now popular, was greeted with widespread hissing from puzzled listeners.

title: Relishing and Playing With Reverberations of Schubert
description: Writing about Schubert inevitably begins with how hard it is to understand him. His biography is ambiguous, his musical style unclassifiable: no longer Classical but not yet Romantic, and looking ahead toward decidedly modern harmonies and rhythms.

title: Buying Your Way Into the Credits
description: PARK CITY, Utah Docbuster is what Morgan Spurlock calls his product placement documentary The Greatest Movie Ever Sold  excuse us, Pom Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (as our colleague Brooks Barnes told us yesterday). In the film, Mr. Spurlock, the stunt documentarian behind Supersize Me, doesnt address whether (or how well) marketing sponsorships and tie-ins work on consumers, but at the premiere of the film on Saturday, it was kind of clear. Appearing at the Q&A wearing a suit adorned with the logos of the corporations that funded his movie  Pom pomegranate juice, JetBlue Airways, Ban deodorant, etc.  Mr. Spurlock brought the company executives, a k a his cast, up front with him for a resounding round of applause. He began drinking a bottle of Pom. Im 40 percent happier, suddenly, he said.

title: Jets Season Comes to an End, but Ryan Is Unbowed
description: Pittsburgh

title: Monday: Puzzle Sweeter Than Whine
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Lets talk about flavor.

title: Splish Splash: Fantastical Fish Tales
description: If you have one of those precocious, somewhat creepy preschoolers who read at a 10th-grade level and build life-size, working reproductions of the space shuttle out of Legos, expect the child to have a few questions if plunked down in front of Bubble Guppies. This new animated show from Nickelodeon, which stars six perky fish and has its premiere on Monday morning, may not mesh well with the kids overly logical brain.

title: Mark Twain, Now a Career for the Mustachioed
description: INCLINE VILLAGE, Nev.  McAvoy Layne climbed the stage chomping on an unlighted cigar, his shock of spray-painted white hair bright in the spotlights. You cant beat an audience thats been waiting 100 years, he said to the crowd.

title: Odd, Odd Case of Bobby Fischer
description: Its no exaggeration to call Bobby Fischer both one of the most admired and one of the most reviled figures in American history. The admiration is prompted by his precocious rise to the pinnacle of the chess-playing world and his galvanizing 1972 cold-war-era triumph over Boris Spassky, the Soviet champion. The vilification stems from the monstrousness he exhibited in later years. On Sept. 11, 2001, he told a radio interviewer, Yes, well, this is all wonderful news, and, Its time to finish off the U.S. once and for all. Thanks to the Internet, those comments will live forever.

title: S.E.C. Study Recommends More Oversight of Brokers
description: WASHINGTON  Investment advisers and stockbrokers should be subject to the same fiduciary standard of conduct  putting a customers interests above their own  rather than the different governance regimes that currently apply to the two groups, the Securities and Exchange Commission recommended on Saturday.

title: This Space for Rent: In Europe, Arts Now Must Woo Commerce
description: PARIS  On the Left Bank of the Seine, the facade of the glass-roofed Beaux-Arts building that houses the Muse dOrsay is draped with a huge advertisement for Chanel No. 5.

title: A Well-Executed Finesse, but Was It Worthy of a Prize?
description: Few top tournaments award brilliancy prizes these days. But the Lederer Memorial Trophy in London last October did. (The event is named for Richard and Tony Lederer, father and son. The Official Encyclopedia of Bridge says that Richard was perhaps the first great figure of British bridge.)

title: More Movie Gold for Natalie Portman
description: When youre hot, youre hot. Natalie Portman, steaming toward the Academy Awards for her disturbing portrayal of a deranged ballerina in Black Swan, helped power the romantic comedy No Strings Attached from Paramount Pictures to No. 1 at the North American box office over the weekend. The movie, which also stars Ashton Kutcher (above with Ms. Portman), sold an estimated $20.3 million in tickets, an unexpectedly firm performance. All of the others in the top five were holdovers. The Green Hornet (Sony Pictures Entertainment) was second with about $18 million for a two-week total of $63.4 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office statistics. The Dilemma, a buddy comedy from Universal Pictures, sold about $9.7 million in its second weekend ($33.4 million total) for third place. The Kings Speech (the Weinstein Company) was a close fourth with roughly $9.2 million ($58.6 million total), while True Grit (Paramount) chugged away in fifth place with $8 million, lifting its five-week total to $138.7 million.

title: Prize Nominations for Best-Selling Authors
description: Best-selling authors crowded the list of finalists for the National Book Critics Circle awards, announced on Saturday at the Jerome L. Greene Performance Space in the South Village. The finalists for fiction included Jennifer Egan for A Visit From the Goon Squad and Jonathan Franzen for Freedom, books that were conspicuously overlooked in the National Book Awards last year. Other fiction finalists were David Grossman for To the End of the Land, Hans Keilson for Comedy in a Minor Key and Paul Murray for Skippy Dies. In the autobiography category, Patti Smith was a finalist for Just Kids, a memoir that won the National Book Award for nonfiction in 2010. Other categories were biography, criticism, nonfiction and poetry. The annual awards will be presented on March 10 at The New School in Manhattan.

title: Goddard Furniture Lifts Americana Sales
description: John Goddard, a Rhode Island furnituremaker who died bankrupt in 1785 after British troops had driven off his clientele, brightened the weekends Americana sales. Despite a longtime decline in demand for what the trade calls brown furniture, lots attributed to Goddard carried six- and seven-figure prices. At Sothebys, the dealer Leigh Keno, on behalf of an unnamed collector, paid $230,500 for two of Goddards mahogany side chairs with flared legs, petal carvings and spiny claw feet, above. Christies took in $5.682 million for a kneehole mahogany desk that Goddard apparently made as a wedding gift for his daughter Catherine, one of his 16 children. According to Maine Antique Digest, the buyer was the Pennsylvania dealer C. L. Prickett, on behalf of an unnamed collector. The price is the fourth highest for American furniture at auction, the estimate was just $700,000 to $900,000, and the desk brought $940,000 at Sothebys in 2004.

title: An Ad Agency for NBC Sports
description: 11:33 a.m. | Updated NBC Universal will announce on Monday that John Miller, who led all of NBCs marketing efforts for 25 years until last summer, is coming out of semi-retirement to set up and head the NBC Sports Agency.

title: When States Try to Balance the Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: CQ Press to Introduce Specialized Data Service
description: The race to build the biggest, most comprehensive and specialized cache of at-your-fingertips information and analysis on the business of Washington has added one more combatant.

title: MTVs Naked Calculation Gone Bad
description: What if one day you went to work and there was a meeting to discuss whether the project you were working on crossed the line into child pornography? Youd probably think you had ended up in the wrong room.

title: An Irreverent Campaign From Bon Apptit
description: ADVERTISERS have long used cheeky entreaties to pique the curiosity of consumers. For example, Doral cigarettes urged smokers to Taste me, the Preakness horse race asked bettors to Get your Preak on and current ads for Celebrity Cruises proclaim, X the rules.

title: Economic Reports for the Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Scheduled for this week include the S.& P./Case-Shiller home price index for November and consumer confidence for January (Tuesday); new home sales for December (Wednesday); durable goods orders for December and pending home sales for December (Thursday); and gross domestic product for the fourth quarter and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for January (Friday).

title: Europes Museums Face Financial Squeeze
description: European arts institutions are being forced to seek new revenue sources.

title: Afghan Report Revives Concerns About Scrutiny of Private Security Firms
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan government is putting new scrutiny on private security companies, raising concerns among Western officials that President Hamid Karzai may be accelerating efforts to push them out of the country.

title: Golden Globes Lawsuit May Thwart Next Years Show
description: LOS ANGELES  Never mind Ricky Gervais. There may not even be a Golden Globes ceremony next year if things dont get moving in court here.

title: Potters Field
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Packers Head to Super Bowl
description: CHICAGO  Nearly 70 years had passed since the N.F.L.s oldest rivals played each other in a postseason game. In 1941, George Halas roamed the sideline for the Chicago Bears. Vince Lombardi was nearly two decades from coaching the Green Bay Packers to a series of championships, including the first two Super Bowls.

title: Anti-Abortion Groups
description: To the Editor:

title: Still Fighting Russia, This Time With Words
description: TBILISI, Georgia  The new teacher who arrived recently at School No. 161 could barely speak a word of the Georgian language, knew little about local customs and easily got lost in the crazy-quilt streets of this hilly capital. But she was at the forefront of one of the most notable educational initiatives  if not social experiments  being attempted in the former Soviet Union.

title: Profiting From Microloans
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.S. in Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: The Understudy Takes the Stage at Apple
description: On an 18-hour flight from California to Singapore a few years ago, Timothy D. Cook, Apples chief operating officer, had little time for small talk with a colleague. Glued to his business class seat, Mr. Cook had his nose in spreadsheets, preparing for a thorough review of Apples Asian operations.

title: Belgians Press Politicians to Form Government
description: BRUSSELS  Defying the normal conventions of protest politics, more than 30,000 Belgians rallied here on Sunday not to try to get rid of a government, but to press their squabbling politicians to form one.

title: Turning the Focus to Governance
description: The BRIC acronym for the worlds biggest emerging economies, created by the Goldman Sachs economist Jim ONeill a decade ago, became a somewhat self-fulfilling prophecy. It arguably diverted billions of investment from elsewhere to his chosen markets of Brazil, Russia, India and China.

title: No Win for Bears, No Super Bowl for Obama
description: So much for that Super Bowl trip President Obama might have been planning.

title: Showdown in Georgia
Despite Distinctions, Los Angeles Times Loses Standing at Home
description: LOS ANGELES  Big-city newspapers all across the country have suffered one indignity after another in the last few years. But few of them have been as hard hit  or gotten as much grief for it  as The Los Angeles Times.

title: F.D.A. Is Studying the Risk of Electroshock Devices
description: Federal regulators are weighing whether to downgrade the risk classification of electroshock devices, reinforcing what many psychiatrists consider a deepening acceptance of electroshock in modern therapy.

title: Art Exhibit Stirs Up the Ghosts of Zimbabwes Past
description: BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe  The exhibit at the National Gallery is now a crime scene, the artwork banned and the artist charged with insulting President Robert Mugabe. The picture windows that showcased graphic depictions of atrocities committed in the early years of Mr. Mugabes 30-year-long rule are now papered over with the yellowing pages of a state-controlled newspaper.

title: Hezbollah Seeks to Ease Misgivings Before Talks
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Hezbollahs leader promised Sunday that his movement would respect Lebanons institutions of state and tradition of consensus if it succeeded in deciding the shape of the next government.

title: Israel Approves Doubling of Taxes on Oil and Gas Extraction Profits
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli government on Sunday approved a near doubling of the profit tax on gas and oil extracted from its territory, a move of considerable significance in the wake of recent offshore gas discoveries expected to be worth tens of billions of dollars.

title: Build a Bigger House
description: WITH the Senate preparing to debate filibuster reform, now is a good time to consider a similarly daunting challenge to democratic representation in the House: its size. Its been far too long since the House expanded to keep up with population growth and, as a result, it has lost touch with the public and been overtaken by special interests.

title: Olbermann Split Came After Years of Tension
description: MSNBC never had any doubt about what it was getting when it made Keith Olbermann the face of the network in 2003: a highly talented broadcaster, a distinctive and outspoken voice and a mercurial personality with a track record of attacking his superiors and making early exits.

title: Increasingly Confident Fed Is Set for First Meeting of 2011
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve will use its first policy meeting of 2011 this week to revisit its economic projections amid a climate of modest but increasing confidence about the recovery.

title: Uniquely Qualified to Coax the Best Out of the Great
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Pete Sampras was on the phone or the screen or whatever one is on these days, and Paul Annacone was keeping his friend and former employer informed, his thumbs typing an Australian Open update.

title: Not Quite a Reporter, but Raking Muck and Reaping Wrath
description: Daniel Cavanagh was nervous.

title: One Woman Makes a Home for Many
description: When Adelaida Perez was struggling to find customers for her traditional Dominican cakes, her sister, Pura Espinal, prayed that business would improve.

title: Against All Odds, a Beautiful Life
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.

title: At Davos, Long List of Problems Awaits World Leaders
description: FRANKFURT  Leaders in business, politics and academia from around the world will gather in Davos, Switzerland, this week to try to rescue the planet. Its a safe bet that, for the 41st year in a row, they will fail.

title: Seeking a Warm Place on Citys Coldest Night
description: Gregory Sanders and his partner, Keisha Washington, had just arrived at Pennsylvania Station in New York from Pennsylvania Station in Newark on Saturday night. The trip was beside the point. Mr. Sanders, 47, and Ms. Washington, 39, were homeless, and they needed a place to stay as a fierce winter cold gripped the region.

title: Can a City This Self-Serious Take a Joke?
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  The first episode of Portlandia, a new television show that pokes at this Northwest confections urban preciousness, includes a scene in which a couple at a restaurant interrogates a waitress about the quality of the life lived by a chicken they hope to order.

title: Ailing Cutler Exits, Raising Questions About Toughness
description: CHICAGO  The leather satchel with the bottle of aspirin tucked into a side pocket was worn and battered, not unlike its owner. Bears quarterback Jay Cutler slung the bag over his left shoulder Sunday night after his last workday of the season and walked stiffly out of the Soldier Field locker room.

title: Lottery Numbers
For a Son of Chicago, a Nostalgic Dish of Crow
description: CHICAGO

title: Willing to Spend Online, to a Point
description: For years, the willingness of Internet users to pay for information has been the subject of much anxiety, speculation and investment on the part of companies. A recent study finds that consumers have been willing to spend, although the sums spent are relatively low.

title: A New Chance for Mr. Obama
description: President Obama unveiled a promising new theme on Friday when he toured a factory in Schenectady, N.Y., and began talking about the desperate need to foster competitiveness and innovation in the pursuit of American jobs. The real test of his commitment to that cause in the second half of his term will come on Tuesday in his State of the Union address. He will have to make his case in the face of a newly strengthened and shrill Republican Party, determined to dismantle governments most fundamental role in fighting the recession.

title: For a Police Family in New York, Yet Another Test
description: When Detective Andrew McCormack fired an errant shot that wounded a 76-year-old man during a drug raid in the Bronx on Saturday, it brought back layers of memory for the detectives family.

title: Small Bookstores Struggle for Niche in Shifting Times
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  Get on Twitter. Add a wine bar. Do as one bookstore owner did and rent out space for birthday parties.

title: Shot in the Head, but Getting Back on His Feet and on With His Life
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex.  Mark Steinhubl does not remember being shot. The bullet tore into his skull just above the right eye and cut through the right side of his brain. The slug obliterated some memories.

title: An Evolving Court
description: During oral argument about Montana v. Wyoming this month, the Supreme Court was doing something rare: it was in session as a trial court and its task was to decide how to divvy up water from tributaries to the Yellowstone River.

title: Reform and the Teachers Unions
description: Education officials across the country are increasingly focused on the two critical reform tasks: developing more effective teacher evaluation systems and speeding up the glacial pace of disciplinary hearings for teachers charged with misconduct. The American Federation of Teachers, the countrys second-largest teachers union, has wisely chosen to work with state legislatures and local school districts to help shape these new systems rather than try to block them.

title: Time Banditry
description: Time zones are laid out longitudinally and, with a few exceptions, the clock changes by an hour for every 15 degrees you move east or west. But the length of the day  the time the sun spends above the horizon  varies by latitude and the farther north you go in winter, the less daylight there is. That explains why many Scots are upset with a bill making its way through Parliament that could institute permanent daylight saving time throughout all of Britain.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: American Voices, Far From Home
description: The former Soviet republic of Georgia is trying to improve the quality of the English instruction in its classrooms with a program that has hired 1,000 people from the United States, Canada and other English-speaking countries to teach in its schools. Here are three teachers observations so far.

title: 4 Detroit Police Injured in Shootout
description: DETROIT  Four police officers were slightly wounded and their assailant killed on Sunday after a man walked into a police precinct and began shooting indiscriminately, a spokeswoman for the mayor said.

title: Unlikely Allies Fight Cuomos Plan for Property Tax Cap
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has vowed to rein in New Yorks taxes, declaring them a burden to residents and businesses, and proposing help in the form of a state-imposed cap on property taxes.

title: Reforming the Reform
description: Last week, the Republican Party proved that it has the votes to repeal health care reform  but only in the House of Representatives. (Unfortunately for conservatives, the Senate and the White House also have a say in the matter.) The House vote on Wednesday may be remembered as a first step toward actual repeal, or as a futile exercise in fist-shaking. It all depends on whether Republicans can find a strategy for undoing the health care legislation that doesnt involve an immediate frontal assault.

title: The Competition Myth
description: Meet the new buzzword, same as the old buzzword. In advance of the State of the Union, President Obama has telegraphed his main theme: competitiveness. The Presidents Economic Recovery Advisory Board has been renamed the Presidents Council on Jobs and Competitiveness. And in his Saturday radio address, the president declared that We can out-compete any other nation on Earth.

title: A Miami Beach Event Space. Parking Space, Too.
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla.  For her wedding over the weekend, Nina Johnson had worked through a predictable checklist of locations in town: hotel ballrooms, restaurant halls and catering outfits.

title: 2 Top Package Companies to Merge
description: RockTenn said Sunday that it had agreed to buy Smurfit-Stone, a maker of packaging products that emerged from bankruptcy protection last year, for $3.5 billion in cash and stock.

title: George Allen to Announce Plans for Senate Bid on Monday
description: Former Republican Senator George F. Allen of Virginia will announce Monday that he will seek to avenge his narrow loss in 2006 at the hands of Senator Jim Webb, two senior Republicans in Virginia told The Caucus.

title: Verbal Sparring Over Potential Senate Vote on Health Care
description: WASHINGTON  Democrats and Republicans in the Senate waged a war of words on Sunday over efforts to force what would most likely be a symbolic vote on repealing the Obama administrations health care law.

title: Word of Palestinian Concession in 2008 Roils Mideast Debate
description: JERUSALEM  Despite longstanding protests against the construction of Jewish developments in contested areas, Palestinian negotiators agreed to cede large tracts of Jerusalem to Israel during peace negotiations in recent years, according to a set of documents Al Jazeera says it has obtained.

title: Nakamura Loses and Is Again Tied for First With Anand at Tata Steel
Crazy? Just Like a 337-Pound Fox
description: CHICAGO  Desmond Bishop, the middle linebacker of the Green Bay Packers, cannot easily be conned. So every time nose tackle B. J. Raji talked himself up as a great athlete, Bishop would look at the 337-pound Rajis jiggling belly and try not to laugh.

title: Conspirators Path From Poverty as a Boy in Zanzibar to bin Ladens Side
description: Around 2000, Osama bin Laden was visiting a guesthouse in Kandahar, Afghanistan, when one of his aides approached a Tanzanian man who was staying there.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Brash Jets Hit Familiar Wall in Pittsburgh
description: PITTSBURGH  Throughout this season, the Jets reinforced their status as the most talkative team in football, a boastful bunch who, with a series of last-second victories, backed up their big talk. But Sunday, the loudest team in football shuffled around its locker room in silence, stunned, still processing a second straight Jets season that reached the doorstep of the Super Bowl and ended there.

title: Where Football Takes a Back Seat, Even in Winter
description: On Sunday night the big game was on nearly all the wall-mounted televisions at one Manhattan restaurant, and the eyes of many beer-drinking patrons never left them.

title: Positives With Roots In Tragedy On Campus
description: In a 12-month period from 2003 to 2004, six New York University students committed suicide. These were very public suicides. They were all jumping from buildings, as opposed to quietly hurting themselves in their rooms, said Zoe Ragouzeos, the universitys director of counseling and wellness.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Jack LaLanne, Founder of Modern Fitness Movement, Dies at 96
description: Jack LaLanne, whose obsession with grueling workouts and good nutrition, complemented by a salesmans gift, brought him recognition as the founder of the modern physical fitness movement, died Sunday afternoon at his home in Morro Bay, Calif. He was 96.

title: The Search for the Next Little Thing
description: PARK CITY, Utah Last year, Sundance decided to start a new section of the festival called Next, dedicated to low- and no-budget films. It didnt go so well. Filmmakers placed in the section hated being called out for their shoestring shoots and the films turned out to be, well, not that great.

title: While House Is Abuzz, Senate Hits Snooze Button
description: WASHINGTON  In its first few weeks of official business this year, the House of Representatives voted to undo President Obamas health care overhaul, pondered cuts to large swaths of the government and stood silently beneath flags flying at half-staff to honor a fallen Congressional aide and his critically wounded boss.

title: Sanchez Grows Again, but Its Not Enough
description: PITTSBURGH  The education of Mark Sanchez has featured questions of development alongside flashes of brilliance. But each of his first two seasons ended in the same place: the A.F.C. title game.

title: Steelers Win the Way Theyve Always Won
description: PITTSBURGH  Back in September, Pittsburgh Steelers Coach Mike Tomlin had just arrived home from a road game when he contemplated the importance of the quarterback to his team. Ben Roethlisberger had been in league-mandated exile  the reclamation project for his reputation just beginning  and both of his primary backups were injured, yet the Steelers started 3-0 anyway.

title: Dagmar Wilson, Anti-Nuclear Leader, Dies at 94
description: Dagmar Wilson, the founder of Women Strike for Peace, a cold war movement that helped organize demonstrations around the world calling for nuclear disarmament, died Jan. 6 in Washington. She was 94 and lived in Leesburg, Va.

title: John D. Kendall, Early Suzuki Method Advocate, Dies at 93
description: John D. Kendall, who half a century ago helped revitalize string playing in the United States by introducing Americans to the Suzuki method, a system of instruction that lets very young children learn to play instruments before they can even read music, died on Jan. 6 in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 93 and lived in Ann Arbor.

title: In the Streets, Mumbai Celebrates the Arts
description: In the general absence of parks and open spaces, the street is the nucleus of communal life in Mumbai. Its where meals are sold and eaten, where groceries are purchased on the commute home and where neighbors gather every evening for a chat. But until recent years, art and culture remained off the citys streets, strictly confined to galleries and theaters frequented by the elite. The debut of the Kala Ghoda Arts Festival (KGAF) in 1999 changed that. This years version will take place Feb. 5 to 13, spread over several streets in Mumbais tiny but beautiful colonial-era art district.

title: National Arts Index Shows Struggles
description: The health of the American arts sector reached a 12-year low in 2009, according to a report from Americans for the Arts, a national advocacy group. The 2010 National Arts Index, which strives for a comprehensive picture of how the arts fared during the recession, shows that the vitality of the arts sector dropped a record 3.6 points, to 97.7. The losses from 2007 to 2009 were nearly double the gains made from 2003 to 2007, according to the report. At the same time, the number of nonprofit arts institutions grew by 3,000 during that period. As a result, the United States arts sector now includes 109,000 nonprofit organizations, 550,000 for-profit businesses and 2.2 million artists. But more organizations and individuals have struggled to make ends meet; in 2009, 41 percent of nonprofit arts organizations reporting to the I.R.S. failed to achieve a balanced budget, up from 36 percent in 2008.

title: Together Onstage: Marsalis and Clapton
description: Wynton Marsalis and Eric Clapton are expected to team up for three Jazz at Lincoln Center concerts in April, according to a publicist for the event. Titled Wynton Marsalis and Eric Clapton Play the Blues, with a seven-piece band drawn largely from the ranks of the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra, the collaboration is to start with the organizations annual fund-raising gala on April 7, followed by regular ticketed concerts at Rose Hall on April 8 and 9. The two musicians performed together during a Jazz at Lincoln Center gala in 2003, and Mr. Marsalis appeared on Mr. Claptons recent album, Clapton, but the April performances are to be their first full concerts together. Tickets are at jalc.org.

title: Criticizing Cutler
description: If ever there was an advertisement for the value of a good public image, Bears quarterback Jay Cutler is it. You could design an entire college public relations course about what happened to Cutler on Sunday: leaving Sundays N.F.C. championship game with a knee injury, Cutler did not appear hurt at all. He walked along the sideline. He put on that oversize football overcoat, stood there and looked bored. He never limped. Trainers were not fussing over him. He wasnt offering advice to his replacements or cheering his defense. The back story was Cutler having spent his five N.F.L. seasons crafting his image as aloof, arrogant, indifferent to the world outside his own skull. The result on Sunday: instant vilification.
