description: Archie Gottesman is a pet lover and the chairwoman of Animal Haven, a shelter for cats and dogs. She spends her spare time looking for homes for pets, to save them from being euthanized.

title: Tucson Attack Reawakens Pain From Virginia Tech
description: BLACKSBURG, Va.  In the parlance of trauma, Jerzy Nowak considers himself a secondary victim. His wife, Jocelyne Couture-Nowak, a French teacher, was one of the 32 people killed at Virginia Tech here on April 16, 2007, by a crazed gunman who then killed himself in the worst campus shooting in American history.

title: Whistling Past the Graveyard: A Musical Version of Death Takes a Holiday
description: Looks like it might be time for the Grim Reaper to put down his scythe and pick up a pitch pipe. A musical version of Death Takes a Holiday, the much-revived Alberto Casella play that tries to put a human face on the relentless pale rider, is being prepared by a team of creative heavyweights who will bring it to life for the Roundabout Theater Company this summer.

title: Documents Open a Door on Mideast Peace Talks
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli-Palestinian peace talks over the past 17 years have operated at two levels, one public, the other behind closed doors. To the world and their own people, each side spoke of sacred, nonnegotiable demands, while in the Jerusalem hotel suites where the officials met those very demands were under negotiation.

title: Eurofile | Slovakia Off-Piste
description: Theres some travel advice you never forget. The Tatras are the most beautiful place in Europe, I was told in a cafe in Prague 20 years ago. The Alps are like an old mans teeth. The Tatras are sharp, intense and wild, said my Czech friend.

title: George Allen Seeks to Recapture Virginia Senate Seat
description: On the morning of Aug. 14, 2006, Senator George Allen of Virginia was expecting to easily defeat his Democratic challenger, Jim Webb, for re-election and had his eye planted firmly on the 2008 Republican presidential nomination.

title: When They Cannot Eat
description: Jean Minarick has had a tough few weeks, grappling with one of the crossroads decisions that family members so often shoulder for ailing elders. Ive been a wreck, she said.

title: Citing Options, Iran Rejects Uranium Deal, Diplomat Says
description: PARIS  At the talks between Iran and six major powers in Istanbul over the weekend, Iran said it was no longer interested in a fuel-swap deal proposed by Washington and the others, a senior Western diplomat said Monday.

title: Mystery of an Anti-Israel E-Mail
description: UPDATE: 5:30 P.M. This article has been updated with additional information.

title: Is the Term Lifestyle Business an Insult?
description: The week of January 10 offered something of a theme here at Youre the Boss. Both Paul Downs and I wrote posts (heres Pauls post, heres mine) addressing various aspects of owning what is commonly referred to as a lifestyle business. After more than 50 comments combined, Ted in Tacoma Park finally asked for a definition of the term.

title: Google and Mozilla Announce New Privacy Features
description: Add two more Internet browser makers to the list of companies planning to offer Web users new ways to control how their personal data is collected online.

title: Mittal Heiress Buys Stake in Roc Capital
description: Vanisha Mittal Bhatia, the only daughter of the worlds fifth-richest man, Lakshmi N. Mittal, ArcelorMittals chief executive, recently purchased a sizable stake in the quantitative hedge fund Roc Capital, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Bloomberg and Relatives of Shooting Victims Push for Stricter Gun Control
description: A man whose son was among the students killed at Columbine High School stepped up to the microphone at City Hall on Monday wearing the boys sneakers. A pastor recalled a former congregant who was one of the people shot this month outside a supermarket in Tucson. And a woman told the story of her son, who died in 2007 in East Harlem.

title: A Pets Fair Price for a Home?
description: In this weeks Appraisal column, we tell of one downtown landlord who also runs an animal shelter and requires cat and dog owners to get their pets spayed or neutered if they want to live in her apartment building, the Ludlow, on the Lower East Side. The policy, a reflection of the owners concerns about all the unwanted cats and dogs put to sleep each year, doesnt seem to have upset many of her tenants, who largely share her sentiments. But that doesnt mean it wouldnt bother other pet owners.

title: Questions on European Welcome of Uzbek Leader
description: BRUSSELS  President Islam A. Karimov of Uzbekistan was given the red-carpet treatment on Monday during meetings here with top European leaders, his warmest reception in the West since his government massacred several hundred protesters in 2005.

title: For Obama, Getting Message Out Online Is a Challenge
description: WASHINGTON

title: Call for Tougher Measures Against Ivory Coast Leader
description: DAKAR, Senegal  The international effort to isolate and dislodge Laurent Gbagbo, who lost a presidential election in Ivory Coast last year but refuses to step down, continues to mount, with West African leaders moving to cut off vital sources of cash and renewing threats of military intervention.

title: Chia Seeds for Weight Loss
description: Can the plant made famous by the Chia Pet, the terra-cotta figurine that sprouts fuzzy green hair, help you lose weight?

title: Paper Company Wants Printers to Go the Flo Way
description: In the brave new world of media  or the brave world of new media  turnabout is most definitely fair play. Google, for instance, advertises itself in newspapers and trade publications. And now a leading paper company is promoting one of its products with a series of online video clips.

title: What Africa Brought to the Table
description: You hear a lot of jazz about soul food, Eldridge Cleaver wrote in Soul on Ice, his 1968 prison memoir. Cleaver didnt want that stuff on his plate every night. The people in the ghetto want steaks. Beef steaks. I wish I had the power to see to it that the bourgeoisie really did have to make it on soul food.

title: Unusual Wave of Violence Strikes Police Officers
description: MIAMI  As thousands of law enforcement officers gathered inside the American Airlines Arena here Monday morning for a funeral for two slain Miami-Dade police officers, news quickly spread that two more officers had been shot and killed a few hours earlier  this time in St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: Building Bridges Between French and American Artists and Scholars
description: The French have never lacked confidence in their cultural creations or intellectual abilities, but Americans may be missing out on what Gallic artists and researchers have produced, which explains a new yearlong initiative aimed at strengthening collaborations between scholars and artists from the two nations.

title: Court Says Rahm Emanuel Not Eligible to Run for Mayor
description: CHICAGO  An Illinois appeals court panel has ruled that Rahm Emanuel, the former White House chief of staff, does not qualify to run for mayor of Chicago in next months election.

title: Titi Monkeys and White-Lipped Peccaries
description: Anthony Di Fiore, a primate biologist at New York University, writes from Ecuador, where he is using GPS technology and camera traps to study the behavior of male spider monkeys.

title: If You Build It, Will They Charge?
description: From our colleagues at Green:

title: Photos of the Moment | Thom Browne
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#85", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Blunders by Top Chess Players
description: Sundays Chess column looked at some recent blunders at the Tata Steel chess tournament in the Netherlands.

title: Indianas Hibbert Is Most Improved No More
description: Early in the season, Roy Hibbert was a no-questions-asked candidate for the leagues most improved player award. Pacers Coach Jim OBrien had elected to run his offense with Hibbert as the focal point, and the natural progression of Hibberts basketball skills made that decision a wise  if unexpected  one.

title: States Help Ex-Inmates Find Jobs
description: Faced with yawning budget gaps and high unemployment, California, Michigan, New York and several other states are attacking both problems with a surprising strategy: helping ex-convicts find jobs to keep them from ending up back in prison.

title: Woman Admits to Kidnapping Baby in 1987
description: The details of that summer day in 1987 remind New Yorkers of what a different place the city was then. Murders were trending toward a historic high, with street crime ingrained as a fact of life.

title: Ruling Blocks Emanuels Bid in Chicago Run
description: CHICAGO  With only a month to go until Election Day, more than $10 million in campaign money and an overwhelming lead in the polls, Rahm Emanuel, the former White House chief of staff, was disqualified on Monday from appearing on this citys ballot for mayor.

title: Onetime Taliban Handler Dies in Their Hands
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A founding patron of the Taliban in Afghanistan died in the hands of a younger generation of militants in the tribal badlands of Pakistan in the last few days, a victim of the vicious forces he helped create, Pakistani officials said Monday.

title: High on the Hog
description: CHAPTER I

title: Tighter Fiscal Union in Europe? Not So Fast, Says French Finance Minister
description: PARIS  If the countries that share the euro are moving toward a tighter fiscal union to support the currency, as some observers indicate is needed, France is reluctant to say so.

title: Harnessing the Brains Right Hemisphere to Capture Many Kings
description: When inexperienced chess players sit down to play against experts, they probably wonder what it is that makes the experts so good that it seems they are almost playing a different game. New research suggests that one difference is that the experts use more of their brains.

title: At New Joe on Campus, Coffee Brewed One Cup at a Time
description: Joe opened a new cafe Monday on the campus of Columbia University. The sixth branch of this Manhattan-based coffee company is Joes largest endeavor (it seats 100), and the most design-minded. The coffee shop occupies a vast, light-filled landing clad with slabs of Portuguese marble in a 14-story interdisciplinary science building by the architect Jos Rafael Moneo. (Although the coffee shop is on the second floor, where it overlooks the intersection of Broadway and West 120th Street, its open to the public.)

title: Deadly Blast at a Moscow Airport
description: According to Russian authorities, a bomber set off an explosion in the arrival hall of Domodedovo airports international terminal on Monday afternoon, killing at least 35 people and wounding at least 168.

title: Sundance Swag, With an Exclamation Point!
description: PARK CITY, Utah Lest anyone start focusing too much on films at the Sundance Film Festival, a small army of publicists is here to help, sending email blasts to reporters every few minutes to hype everything from bottled water to running shoes. Often! With! Exclamation! Marks! Heres a small sampling:

title: Audi Partners With Colleges for Urban Mobility Project
description: Imagine your car reserving a parking spot as you drive to your destination or sending you a text message that instructs you to leave a little early because of road work along the planned route.

title: For First Lady, Speech Guests From Tucson
description: A number of people who assisted or survive the victims of the Arizona shootings will join Michelle Obama in her gallery box in the House chamber on Tuesday night to watch President Obama deliver the annual State of the Union address.

title: Sticking Our Necks Out
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#944", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: An Uncharacteristically Upbeat General in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Triumphalism is not supposed to be in the prayerbook of the American militarys Church of Coin these days, but last Wednesday, Jan. 19, proved to be something of an exception. At the morning standup that day, Gen. David H. Petraeus, the top American commander in Afghanistan, was uncharacteristically jubilant. Weve got our teeth in the enemys jugular now, and were not going to let go, General Petraeus exulted after being briefed on the military operations of the past 24 hours, according to two senior officers who saw the classified standup that day.

title: Hezbollah Chooses Lebanons Next Prime Minister
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A prime minister chosen by Hezbollah and its allies won enough support on Monday to form Lebanons government, unleashing angry protests, realigning politics and culminating the generation-long ascent of the Shiite Muslim movement from shadowy militant group to the countrys pre-eminent political and military force.

title: Solitaire Chess Anyone?
description: ThinkFun, a maker of puzzle and game software, has developed a chess application for the iPhone, iPad and iTouch. Called Solitaire Chess, the application presents a series of problems with chess pieces on a four-by-four grid. The challenge is to eliminate all but one piece through a series of captures. The problems vary in difficulty from easy to expert. There is a demonstration Web site for people to test out the application.

title: NASAs Hansen Presses Obama for a Carbon Cost and Nuclear Push
description: Jan. 26, 10:35 p.m. | Updated below.

title: Medium Ends With Emotional Farewell
description: For seven seasons, first on NBC and then on CBS, Medium put across some of prime times most outlandish story lines by grounding them in one of televisions most believable marriages. So it was fitting that the series, a combination of paranormal murder mystery and domestic dramedy, crossed over to the TV hereafter on Friday night with a series finale that was narratively challenged but emotionally satisfying. It didnt take a medium to predict that there would be tears.

title: A Young Life Passes, and a Ritual of Birth Begins
description: My hands trembled as I grasped the tiny sleeve of skin with my forceps and separated it from his pale, still penis. He lay weirdly motionless on a utility table, which I had draped with a slate-blue operating-room towel.

title: Virginia Woolf Believed Dead
description: LONDON, April 2--Mrs. Virginia Woolf, novelist and essayist, who has been missing from her home since last Friday, is believed to have been drowned at Rodwell, near Lewes, where she and her husband, Leonard Sidney Woolf, had a country residence.

title: Caffeine Concerns
description: Q. Can too much caffeine kill you?

title: Overdiagnosed
description: Introduction

title: When to Sell Your Stocks
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog, and other drawings are available on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

title: India a Republic, Prasad President
description: New Delhi, Jan. 25 -- The proclamation of the Republic of India and the induction of the first President, Dr. Rajendra Prasad, will be marked by a two-day national holiday.

title: Commander of Armies That Turned Back Japan Led a Brigade in World War I
description: General of the Army Douglas MacArthur served his country as a soldier for more than 60 years. He achieved the highest acclaim for his exploits as a grand strategist in World War II and in Korea and then held the center stage in one of the bitterest civil versus military controversies in the history of the nation.

title: A Pound of Prevention Is Worth a Closer Look
description: Make no mistake about it: modern medicine is a religion. For all the complicated science, the bottom line is that either you believe in the science or you dont. If you are an average citizen and have your doubts, then you can just go about your business. But suppose you are a doctor and have your doubts. Then what?

title: Martin Peretz Is Not Sorry. About Anything.
description: THE WINTER LIGHT was fading to gold near the Western Wall when a young Orthodox Jew with curls the color of Jerusalem stone approached an elderly pilgrim clad in suede boots and a Gucci leather jacket. The boy tried to tie a teffilin  a black leather box with Torah verses inside  around the Americans arm. The gesture was not necessarily altruistic; he was hoping for a donation in return. The man resisted. The boy tried another approach.

title: Industry Groups Self-Depiction Raises Eyebrows
description: At first glance, the Waters Advocacy Coalition could be mistaken for a typical environmental group. The home page of its Web site, protectmywater.org, features a banner reading Protect the Clean Water Act across a photo slide show of flowing streams and clear mountain lakes.

title: Pakistan: Short Training for Women Workers Goes Far in Saving Newborns Lives
description: A new study suggests that lady health workers, as Pakistan calls them  women trained as part of a government program to give care to poor people in rural areas  can make a difference in saving the lives of newborns.

title: Reader Idea | Grammar Clubs
description: Here is another in our Great Ideas From Readers series.

title: Loving CoCos
description: The Financial Times reported today that Barclays is considering putting a substantial part of its bonuses for senior bankers into contingent convertible bonds, known as CoCos to jargon-happy Wall Street.

title: Long and Short of Calcium and Vitamin D
description: The new daily recommendations for calcium and vitamin D, issued in November by the Institute of Medicine, have left many people wondering whether they are getting enough, or perhaps too much, in their diets and supplements.

title: Are You Getting Enough Calcium and Vitamin D?
description: Many people are confused about whether they are getting enough  or maybe too much  calcium and vitamin D through their diets and supplements, writes Jane Brody in this weeks Personal Health column.

title: Hey, Mr. Critic!
description: The mailman brought in a devilish question about breakfast bagels, and a sweet one about marriage and birthdays. Someone wanted to know where to get a drink and a bite after seeing The Merchant of Venice on Broadway. I tried to answer these queries and more. As always, you can send questions about where to go or what to eat in New York to dinejournal@nytimes.com.

title: Photos of the Moment | Paul Smith
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#380", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Chief of Tunisian Army Pledges His Support for the Revolution
description: TUNIS  The general who may be both the most powerful and the most popular figure in Tunisia spoke publicly Monday for the first time since the ouster of the former dictator, Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, pledging to uphold the revolution and urging patience until the interim government can hold new elections.

title: G.M. Plans to Add 750 Jobs at Pickup Truck Plant
description: FLINT, Mich.  General Motors said on Monday that it would add 750 jobs so that it can increase production of pickup trucks, welcome news in this economically depressed city.

title: Quarterfinals Preview: Berdych vs. Djokovic
description: Tomas Berdych overpowered Novak Djokovic in their Wimbledon semifinal last July. The tall Czech served well and outhit Djokovic in a match that was surprisingly one-sided. Time and again, Berdych turned a point his way with a huge inside-out forehand, generating tremendous force with seemingly little effort.

title: Big Love Watch: Women Under Pressure
description: It seemed deliciously timely that Sunday nights episode of Big Love turned Nicki Grant into a kind of fundamentalist Mormon Tiger Mom. The final season is distinctly headed toward exploring the effects of an insidious strain of patriarchy on the lives of the women featured.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: 3 Crisis Reports Coming Heidi N. Moore, during her DealBook stint, once likened a paper by some Republican members of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission to a game of political Rashomon. But as Jeremy Irons, playing Claus von Bulow, drawled in Reversal of Fortune, You have no idea. For come Thursday, we will be getting not just two views of the financial crisis, but three. Kevin Drawbaugh and Dave Clarke of Reuters say that the six Democrats will release a report focusing on the greed and power of Wall Street Republican commission member Peter Wallison will offer his dissent, while three other Republicans will offer an account that focuses on global factors. Reuters

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 24
description: The day in sports included handball in Sweden and ice dancing in Switzerland.

title: When Competing With Big Banks, Smaller Can Be Better
description: Last September in a restaurant on Israels Mediterranean coast, Zeev Goldberg, a partner at the boutique investment bank Compass Advisers, listened to Ren Jianxin, the chairman of China National Chemical, explain how he turned a paltry 10,000 renminbi loan (about $1,500) into a $24 billion company.

title: Lovie Smith Defends an Embattled Cutler
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill.  Chicago Bears Coach Lovie Smith pushed back on Monday against the perception that quarterback Jay Cutler bailed out on his Chicago Bears team in Sundays loss to the Green Bay Packers.

title: TimesCast | January 24, 2011
description: Online eyewitnesses give accounts of the Moscow attack; Mahmoud Abbas fires back at documents revealing Palestinian concessions; the office of the artist Al Hirschfeld moves.

title: That (Other) Olsen Girl
description: PARK CITY, Utah Elizabeth Olsen has an ear infection. The perils of being a Sundance It girl  or at least trumpeted as one by agents, managers and publicists  is such that Ms. Olsen, the 21-year-old star of two films here, Silent House, and Martha Marcy May Marlene, has suffered through a whirlwind schedule of promotion; after a trip to nearby Salt Lake City for a screening, she wound up feeling sick enough to visit a doctor, who diagnosed her. But that didnt stop the whirlwind.

title: Russia Seeks Foreign Investment to Fill Budget Gap
description: MOSCOW  A few years ago, Vladimir V. Putin, as president, compared the energy riches of Siberia to a piece of candy held tightly by Russia, as if in a sweaty fist. However much investors might want it, it was off limits.

title: A Ros Can Bloom in Winter, Too
description: IF you look really hard, you will find them condemned to a dusty back shelf underneath a few cobwebs, or perhaps looking forlorn on the half-price rack, their once brilliant colors dulled by neglect.

title: Obama Selects Donald Verrilli as Solicitor General
description: President Obama is preparing to nominate a White House deputy counsel and prominent litigator, Donald B. Verrilli Jr., to be solicitor general of the United States, the White House confirmed on Monday. The position has been vacant since Elena Kagan became a Supreme Court associate justice last year.

title: The Sweeping Gestures of a Swiveling Maestro
description: James Levine devoted the Met Orchestras concert at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon to two works, but they were big, demanding ones. Mozarts Posthorn Serenade (K. 320), despite a title that suggests a light entertainment, is as grand as most of his symphonies and, at 45 minutes, twice as long as most of them. And Das Lied von der Erde, Mahlers monumental setting of ancient Chinese poetry, is a symphony disguised as a song cycle.

title: Is the Hostile Takeover Sexy Again?
description: Steven M. Davidoff, the Deal Professor, speaks to Chris Young, the head of takeover defense at Credit Suisse, about shareholder activism and what the Airgas deal might signify for broader merger and acquisition activity.

title: A Test Drive for the All-Electric Leaf
description: In a review in Sundays paper, our automotive colleagues took the all-electric Nissan Leaf for a weekend test drive. Their verdict? The mildly futuristic hatchback is the peoples electric car, Jerry Garrett writes, but a lack of charging infrastructure and the cars limited range and battery capacity present significant drawbacks.

title: Titrologues
description: Term used in Ivory Coast for those who read only the title of newspaper articles.

title: Brother of Juilliard Quartet Founder Endows Two Chairs in His Name
description: Ah, brotherly love. The brother of Robert Mann  a founding member of the Juilliard String Quartet and a major figure in American chamber music  has donated $6 million to endow chairs in Mr. Manns name. The money will establish chairs at the Manhattan School of Music, where Mr. Mann, 90, has taught since 2006, and at the Thornton School of Music at the University of Southern California.

title: Birth Control Update, in Thousands of Interviews
description: To find out what American women are doing about birth control these days, the National Center for Health Statistics conducted some painstaking research: 80-minute interviews with each of 7,356 women ages 15 to 44.

title: Nonprofits Turn to Out-of-State Options for Bonds
description: Nonprofits based in New York are turning to other states for help in issuing tax-exempt bonds.

title: The War on Demand
description: Something really strange has happened to the debate over economic policy in the face of the Great Recession and its aftermath  or maybe the real point is that events have revealed the true nature of the debate, stripping away some of the illusions. Its a bigger story than any one point of dispute  say, over the size of the multiplier, or the effects of quantitative easing  might suggest. Basically, in the face of what I would have said is obviously a massive shortfall of aggregate demand, were seeing on all-out attack on the very notion that the demand side matters.

title: A D.J. Has a Play List in Case of Turbulence
description: IM usually mellow, but Ive become a bit of a travel diva. I use a ton of different Web sites and frequent-flier upgrades and even choose to fly out of specific airports if I can  all to make the travel experience less of a hassle.

title: Hearing Delayed for Consultant Charged With Defrauding Bloomberg
description: A state judge on Monday postponed by two weeks oral arguments in the case against John F. Haggerty Jr., a Republican political consultant who is accused of stealing $1.1 million from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg during the 2009 campaign.

title: State Bankruptcies? Ludicrous, He Says
description: Californias state treasurer, Bill Lockyer, denounced on Monday continuing efforts to establish a new framework for states to restructure their debts, saying no state wanted or needed to declare bankruptcy.

title: (Finally) Getting Some Sleep
description: Sarah Vander Schaaff has been sleeping. And reading. And worrying a bit about her husband, who has been taking the night shifts for a week and now looks like a bedraggled lumberjack  unshaven and tired, she reports in an e-mail, adding, Ill give him a break soon.

title: As Doctors Age, Worries About Their Ability Grow
description: About eight years ago, at the age of 78, a vascular surgeon in California operated on a woman who then developed a pulmonary embolism. The surgeon did not respond to urgent calls from the nurses, and the woman died.

title: A Hezbollah-Run Lebanon, but No Panic in Israel
description: JERUSALEM  For Israel, the prospect of a government in Lebanon backed by Hezbollah, one of Israels worst enemies, seemed to be the realization of a nightmare. Yet some analysts here said it was not necessarily an immediate cause for alarm.

title: When Older Doctors Put Patients at Risk
description: A third of the physicians in the United States are over 65, and many continue to work with competence into their 70s and beyond. Yet what happens if a doctors cognitive or physical skills begin to slip because of early Alzheimers, a subtle stroke or another illness, putting the patient at risk? Thats a question explored by Laurie Tarkan in this weeks Science Times.

title: Blackstone Sues Founder of InfoUSA
description: The Blackstone Group has sued the founder of InfoUSA, the database company, over a $6.8 million banking fee.

title: The Politics of Star Wars
description: If you want to read a serious rebuttal to Michael Linds recent argument that America needs a political party that unites techno-optimism, secular utopianism, and a commitment to restoring the mid-century nexus of big government, big business and big labor, I recommend Walter Russell Meads recent post on the limits, moral and otherwise, of precisely the political and social model that Lind is pining for. For my part, I want to focus on Linds case against Star Wars:

title: Suicide Bombing at Moscow Airport
description: A suicide bomber strode into the international arrivals hall at Moscows busiest airport and set off an enormous explosion, killing more than 30 people, Russian officials said.

title: City Says 57 Percent of Graded Restaurants Have Gotten As
description: In the matter of its new letter-grade system that rates the cleanliness of restaurants, the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene has given itself an A.

title: With Poem, Broaching the Topic of Death
description: FORT DEFIANCE, Ariz.  Mitzie Begay, an elegant 76-year-old Navajo, can interpret the nuances of her language and traditions with contemporary verve and understated wit  qualities that make her a good fit for a job that could hardly have been imagined in the Navajo Nation a generation ago.

title: Critics Picks Video: Billy Liar
description: This week, A. O. Scott looks back at Billy Liar, John Schlesingers 1963 drama about a young daydreamer (Tom Courtenay), who escapes from the boredom of his life into a fantasy world. Mr. Scott appreciates the film for its pathos and comedy, which stems, he says, from the tension between two different kinds of imagination. One kind involves making up things that arent true. The other kind, which is no less creative, involves recognizing the world for what it is. Have you seen Billy Liar? Please share your thoughts.

title: Keeping Up With Arizona Muse
description: Last season the model Arizona Muse clocked 26 runway shows  and could have done more had she not had an exclusive with Prada in Milan. This season, you can bet the 22-year-old Muse, a recent mom, will be practically ubiquitous. Four cities (New York, London, Milan and Paris) and about 100 shows per  well, you do the math. Fashion Week is the busiest time of each season, she told us as she geared up for New York. Whether or not I actually get any free time beforehand remains to be seen, ha! Right now, she fills her idle hours with running and Pilates. If shes lucky, she will be able to take a short break between cities. I plan to spend some time in London, she says. (She is from New Mexico, but her mom is English.) I have dear dear family and friends there. More than anything, she tells us that shes ready for the shows to get going. I like how busy it is, running around from one place to another. Its quite exhilarating, she says. I know that it will end. And when it does I think Ill go home to Santa Fe, where I grew up, and eat lots of green chili. Hot stuff.

title: Outside, Seeing a Glass as Half Full (Yes, Its Still Ice)
description: A curious phenomenon swept the frigid streets of New York City today, where temperatures plummeted to 8 degrees: people looked where they were going. The lure of warm destinations, the primal urge to rush indoors and a deep reluctance to expose tender fingers to the brutal cold meant that iPhones, Blackberrys and other P.D.A.s were tucked away. Strolling the streets, seeing so many people untethered to various electronic distractions or jabbering away in halfalogues, one could be forgiven for thinking it was 2002 all over again.

title: Next Years Globes? No Worries
description: LOS ANGELES  The Hollywood Foreign Press Association says not to worry, the Golden Globes ceremony will happen next January, no matter what its lawyers say.

title: Police Say Slain Women Worked as Prostitutes
description: All four women whose bodies were found scattered over a desolate quarter-mile of grassy dunes on Long Island last month had worked as prostitutes, the police said Monday, noting that a serial killer was probably responsible for their deaths.

title: Loughner Pleads Not Guilty in Tucson Shooting
description: PHOENIX  Jared L. Loughner, who the police said was responsible for the shooting rampage outside a Tucson supermarket on Jan. 8, pleaded not guilty on Monday to charges that he tried to murder Representative Gabrielle Giffords and two of her aides.

title: Pictures of the Day: Moscow and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Russia, Hong Kong, and New York.

title: Pity Molires Poor Sap, Falling for All That He Despises
description: Molire is one of the greatest comic writers in the theatrical canon, but I have rarely seen actors performing his work who appear to believe it. They often strain and bellow and gesticulate in a way that suggests they suspect they need to make up for the material.

title: Canine Tumor Fuels Up by Stealing Parts From Host, Report Says
description: When humans domesticated dogs at least 10,000 years ago, an apparent side effect was a bizarre new kind of parasite. A canine cancer gained the ability to spread from one dog to the next, creating new tumors along the way.

description: To the Editor:

title: High PCB Levels Found in Another N.Y. School
description: As expected, spot inspections of school buildings in New York City continue to turn up leaks of the toxic chemicals known as PCBs from old fluorescent light fixtures.

description: Hotel owners and management companies are breathing a sigh of relief.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paulson Recaps Big Bets in Year-End Letter
description: Coming off strong returns, John Paulson, in his 2010 year-end letter to investors, tracks the next phase for several large bets at his firm, Paulson & Company, which famously profited from the subprime mortgage crisis.

title: City Picks Entrepreneur to Lead Digital Efforts
description: A week after Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said the city would create an online forum to solicit suggestions and complaints from New Yorkers, city officials hired an Internet entrepreneur to be New Yorks first chief digital officer.

title: U.N. Chief Too Quiet on Rights, Group Says
description: UNITED NATIONS  World leaders have been operating behind a smokescreen of quiet dialogue to avoid publicly singling out nations that abuse individual rights, Human Rights Watch said in its annual report released Monday, criticizing in particular Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, for failing to speak out more forcefully.

title: Picture This: Joan Rivers, Retiring Type?
description: Its possible, but not optimal, to enjoy the frivolous WE reality show Joan & Melissa: Joan Knows Best? without having first seen the quite serious 2010 documentary Joan Rivers: A Piece of Work.

title: Unflinching End-of-Life Moments
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Most screenings at the Sundance Film Festival here are mob scenes  half-frozen film lovers in a mad dash for limited seating, reporters skittering around in search of news nuggets, agents pacing the aisles.

title: More to a Smile Than Lips and Teeth
description: In the middle of a phone call four years ago, Paula Niedenthal began to wonder what it really means to smile. The call came from a Russian reporter, who was interviewing Dr. Niedenthal about her research on facial expressions.

title: Sundance Deals Come Fast and Furious
description: PARK CITY, Utah And the money keeps rolling in. A flurry of Sundance deals closed on Monday, with Fox Searchlight, Magnolia Pictures, Participant Media, Sundance Selects/IFC Films, and National Geographic all snapping up movies.

title: Fragments of Egyptian Statuary Set Stage for Songs of Fragmentation
description: Nearly two years have passed since the Brooklyn Philharmonic fielded a full complement of players in a concert of its own. That this institution, long a feisty steward for offbeat repertory and unorthodox programming, had disappeared almost completely made its continued community-outreach programs seem poignant and slightly quixotic. Until last week, that is, when the orchestra announced the appointment of a new artistic director: Alan Pierson, leader of the vital chamber ensemble Alarm Will Sound.

title: Lack of Sex Among Grapes Tangles a Family Vine
description: For the last 8,000 years, the wine grape has had very little sex. This unnatural abstinence threatens to sap the grapes genetic health and the future pleasure of millions of oenophiles.

title: Pictures of the Day: Moscow and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Russia, Hong Kong, and New York.

title: Network Trouble for Verizon Wireless in Virginia
description: Many Verizon Wireless customers turned to social networks and message boards on Monday to complain that they were unable to make calls or use data applications on their phones and other devices.

title: Republicans Try to Abolish Arts Groups
description: A group of Republican lawmakers has called for the elimination of the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities, each of which received $167.5 million in the last federal budget. The group, called the Republican Study Committee and comprising about 165 House Republicans, also called for eliminating the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, which got $430 million. The proposal, made Thursday, is part of the Spending Reduction Act of 2011, which aims to reduce federal spending by $2.5 trillion over 10 years. Senator Jim DeMint, above, a South Carolina Republican who is chairman of the Senate Steering Committee, said in a statement that the bill begins the difficult task of shrinking the federal bureaucracy that threatens our future prosperity. Robert L. Lynch, president of Americans for the Arts, a lobbying group, said in an interview on Monday that the arts provide 5.7 million jobs in the United States that generate about $30 billion in taxes, nearly $13 billion of which goes to the federal government. If theyre serious about jobs and theyre serious about income, they would invest more in the arts, Mr. Lynch said.

title: Footnote
description: Alfred E. Mann, the brother of Robert Mann  a founding member of the Juilliard String Quartet  has donated $6 million to endow chairs in his brothers name. The money will establish chairs at the Manhattan School of Music, where Robert Mann, 90, has taught since 2006, and at the Thornton School of Music at the University of Southern California.

title: CBS Wins
description: CBS dominated the ratings on Sunday as the American Football Conference championship game delivered its highest ratings in 24 years. Although Nielsens final audience figures were not available on Monday, CBS said the preliminary overnight estimates for the Pittsburgh Steelers victory over the New York Jets were roughly 10 percent higher than those for last years A.F.C. title game. That broadcast, in the late afternoon, attracted 46.9 million viewers when final ratings were released. CBS capitalized on its high ratings on Sunday with a special 10 p.m. broadcast of its new series Hawaii Five-0, which drew an impressive 19.2 million viewers, the crime shows highest ratings of the season. Fox ranked second on the night with mostly new episodes of its comedy lineup, followed by ABC and NBC.

title: Low-Power FM Radio to Gain Space on the Dial
description: OPELOUSAS, La.  When John Freeman turned on his car radio one recent day and tuned to KOCZ, the voice he heard was a 2-year-old girls.

title: Bad Asset Purchase Program Turning a Profit
description: Wall Streets trash has become a treasure for select asset managers, and perhaps even taxpayers.

title: A Celebration of the Song Recital, and of the Potential of 4 Young Voices
description: In February 1961, Marilyn Horne, a young mezzo-soprano, made her Carnegie Hall debut in Bellinis Beatrice di Tenda opposite a rising Australian soprano named Joan Sutherland. The debut was unexpected: the productions final two performances were moved to Carnegie because of the extraordinary demand for tickets after its premiere at Town Hall.

title: Music in Review
description: TALEA ENSEMBLE

title: For NASA, Longest Countdown Awaits
description: Where to next? And when?

title: A.I.G.s Chief to Stay Until 2012
description: Robert H. Benmosche, the American International Groups chief executive, plans to stay at the company until next year after receiving an encouraging prognosis for his cancer treatment.

title: Twitters Advertising Plan Could Be Paying Off
description: Twitter has 200 million users, $360 million in venture capital and a valuation of $3.7 billion.

title: Proof That Chess Experts Brains Work Differently
description: Two new studies, one in Science and one in PLoS One, which were released in the last few days, delve into how experts at chess and other board games process information and generate the ideas for their moves.

title: British Announcers Suspended for Sexist Comments
description: Two guys walk into a broadcast booth, start talking as if theyre in a locker room, forgetting that their microphones are live.

title: An I.R.S. App Lets You Track Your Tax Refund
description: People using the Internal Revenue Services new mobile phone app cannot avoid taxes, but they can at least track their refund.

title: Scorecard | Givenchy Wins!
description: Oh fashion, you fickle beast. On the second day of Paris fashion week, the premier matre de ballet John Galliano outdid himself with more than the usual four grand acts of love, death, regret and absolution. Yet Scorecard knows that Riccardo Tisci then went and let the dogs out  and made streetwear look the height of chic.

title: And Now Couture
description: Not even 24 hours after the Paris mens shows had ended they were a dim memory. The women had moved in for the spring haute couture shows, like a temperance league. The tent for Dior today was so big, set up behind the Muse Rodin, you could have run three mens shows simultaneously. I saw writers who had sprawled easily on benches at the mens shows now squeezed delicately into gold spindle chairs. The mood became tense, watchful. And you have the clients and the paparazzi, who must get the same pictures every year but dont seem to care. Its kind of like family. You show up out of a mixture of duty and curiosity  and fear, fear that someone will get a bigger bowl of porridge.

title: In Camcorder Megapixels, Can Less Be More?
description: If there were an award for marketing bravery, I would give it to Canon.

title: A Bonanza of Oscar Predictions
description: PARK CITY, Utah O.K. folks, we know what youre thinking: enough with the ambush marketing and It girl reports, lets get back to the race. The Oscar nominations are just hours away, so the Bagger took a tour of our fellow prognosticators predictions (you can see ours here).

title: Obama and the State of the Union
description: To the Editor:

title: West 123rd Street, 3 P.M.
description: On the theory that you cant have too much of a good thing, and in the wake of our Saturday hawk-eats-bird video post, here we go again. This time the victim is readily identifiable as a pigeon. Video below.

title: In News Conference, Rex Ryan Is Willing to Admit Flaws
description: Below is the transcript of Coach Rex Ryans news conference with reporters Monday, as provided by the Jets:

title: Conversations About the Unspeakable
description: In Tuesdays Science Times, Dr. Ben Diaz describes a unique effort to help elderly Navajos in northeastern Arizona come to grips with a complex and culturally fraught issue: end-of-life medical care.

title: Justice Scalia Goes to Capitol Hill
description: Representative Michele Bachmann played hostess Monday to Justice Antonin Scalia of the Supreme Court in the first of what she said would be several constitutional seminars for members of the House.

title: After the Bombing, Its Business as Usual
description: MOSCOW  Just hours after a suicide bomber struck at the international arrivals terminal at Moscows busiest airport on Monday afternoon, passengers coming off flights from abroad were being ushered through the very same terminal where bodies had only just been removed.

title: Jets Hope Their Road Leads Home Next Season
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Mark Sanchez, wearing a black Jets cap and a green Jets T-shirt, walked to his locker Monday afternoon and tried to slap a happy face on another Jets season, as he had after another tough loss 365 days earlier.

title: By Nature, Airports Have Risks
description: How do you fully secure something as big and sprawling as an international airport against a terrorist bombing like the one on Monday at Domodedovo Airport in Moscow?

title: The Injured
description: Eight months after Bangkok was crippled by weeks of violent protests, there has been little progress in investigating who should be held responsible for the injuries of nearly 2,000 people.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,451 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Thai Inquiry Into Violence Falters
description: BANGKOK  A zookeeper was shot and killed as he was leaving work. An antigovernment demonstrator who sought shelter in a Buddhist temple was shot five times but lived, possibly because a coin in his satchel deflected a bullet. A soldier who rushed to help a fallen comrade after an explosion suffered severe brain damage from a second blast.

title: In Hirschfelds Studio, Packing Up a Well-Worn Chair
description: In the course of his storied career, Al Hirschfeld churned out thousands of pen-and-ink caricatures of celebrities  the final half-centurys worth while sitting in an old barber chair at a worn drafting table in the fourth-floor studio of his townhouse on East 95th Street.

title: Bloggingheads: Repeal and Don't Replace?
description: Bill Scher, left, of the Campaign for America's Future and Kristen Soltis of The Winston Group debate health care reform and "repeal and replace."

title: Usually Elite, A.C.C. Receives a Harsh Lesson in Mediocrity
description: As the defending N.C.A.A. mens basketball champion and pre-eminent team in the Atlantic Coast Conference this season, Duke has been fixed in the national spotlight. But the prominence of the Blue Devils cannot disguise the malaise that is afflicting the other teams in the league.

title: Al Jazeera Reporters Harassed in West Bank for Publishing Leaked Documents
description: After a senior Palestinian official angrily denounced Al Jazeera on Monday for publishing more than 1,600 leaked Palestinian records of peace negotiations, a small group of protesters tried to break in to the networks office in the West Bank city of Ramallah.

title: As Haiti Recovers: A Report From the Field
description: To the Editor:

title: Debt Schemes
description: It seems that the big idea in Europe right now is some kind of scheme in which somebody buys up sovereign debt at a discount, and thereby engineers a haircut through the back door. (Whoah! Mixed metaphors! But I like it!)

title: Backman to Manage Mets Class AA Team
description: The Mets passed over Wally Backman as their major league manager this off-season, hiring Terry Collins instead. But Backman was a finalist for the job and remains on track to possibly manage in Flushing someday.

title: Uncertainty Over Economy Clouds Obama Speech
description: A year ago, the economy looked as if it were speeding down the runway, only to stall out in the spring.

title: Cavaliers At Nets? Priceless (Almost)
description: For slightly less than the $2.50 cost of a single-ride MetroCard, a basketball fan could have treated himself and 21 of his friends to an N.B.A. game Monday night in Newark.

title: At Spanish Border, Toll Threatens Rapprochement
description: GIBRALTAR  It seemed for a while that this British territory with its famous rock was settling in for a period of dtente with its Spanish neighbors to the north.

title: A 2nd I.R.S. Amnesty for Offshore Accounts
description: The Internal Revenue Service said on Monday that it would soon announce a new amnesty program aimed at encouraging wealthy Americans with hidden offshore bank accounts to come forward, declare their money and pay taxes owed.

title: Comment Reminder
description: Just a few things: obscenities, even mild ones, are not allowed; and if I see a clear falsehood, such as a stark misrepresentation of something I or someone else wrote, I will block it. Some things will slip through; those dont count as precedents.

title: When Talking Toughness, Aikman Believes in Cutler
description: One of the leading story lines in Green Bays 21-14 win over the Bears in the N.F.C. championship game Sunday was Chicago quarterback Jay Cutlers knee injury. Cutler said he could not pinpoint the late second-quarter play on which he was hurt, yet after he went to the sideline, Foxs camera often showed him standing.

title: Turkey Says Israelis Used Excess Force in Flotilla Raid
description: ISTANBUL  Turkey released details on Monday of its own report about the seizure last year of a Turkish aid ship bound for Gaza by Israeli commandos. The government contended that two of the activists who were killed on the ship had been shot by Israeli forces from a helicopter before the commandos landed on the vessel.

title: Clinton Voices U.S. Support of Mexico in Trip
description: GUANAJUATO, Mexico  More than a month after the disclosure of cables in which American diplomats questioned progress in Mexicos drug war, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton came here on Monday to deliver a message of solidarity with President Felipe Caldern and to rebut public doubts about persistent violence.

title: Thomas Cites Failure to Disclose Wifes Job
description: WASHINGTON  Under pressure from liberal critics, Justice Clarence Thomas of the Supreme Court acknowledged in filings released on Monday that he erred by not disclosing his wifes past employment as required by federal law.

title: Fiancs Firing Is Ruled an Illegal Reaction to a Discrimination Claim
description: WASHINGTON  Firing a workers fianc in retaliation for a sex discrimination claim filed by the worker is itself unlawful, the Supreme Court ruled on Monday.

title: December Blizzard Will Cost Over $68 Million
description: The enormous blizzard of Dec. 26 embarrassed the mayor, stranded buses and cars, and left hundreds of subway riders stuck on frozen trains in the outer reaches of New York City.

title: Ireland: Agreement Reached on Austerity Measures
description: After a week of political turmoil, Irelands main political parties reached agreement on Monday on steps needed to stabilize the economy and move to a general election, probably on Feb. 25. Finance Minister Brian Lenihan said the parties had agreed to set this Saturday as a deadline for passing legislation required to implement a $25 billion package of austerity measures needed to secure a $114 billion international bailout for the countrys battered economy. Prime Minister Brian Cowen, whose efforts to cling to office had precipitated a crisis, did not attend the Dublin talks, and his Fianna Fail party said it would choose a new leader by Wednesday. Left undecided was who will serve as prime minister during the election period, a role Mr. Cowen has earmarked for himself. The agreement followed a statement by the European Commission saying it was crucial for Irelands stability and credibility that the austerity package be approved before the election.

title: SAC Takes a Slice of Dominos
description: Steven Cohens hedge fund, SAC Capital, disclosed on Monday that it had acquired a 5.3 percent stake in Dominos Pizza.

title: Italy: Bishop Cites Moral Unease Over Public Figures
description: The head of the Italian bishops conference said Monday that Italians felt a moral unease toward their public figures, an indirect reference to a sex scandal in which magistrates accuse Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of compensating a significant number of women for sex. Whoever accepts a public position must understand the sobriety, personal discipline, sense of measure and honor that come with it, Cardinal Angelo Bagnasco said. His remarks were a sign of the rising pressure on Mr. Berlusconi. The Vatican secretary of state said last week that the Vatican was watching the scandal with concern, and the head of the leading industrialists organization said Sunday that she would support Finance Minister Giulio Tremonti as a possible replacement for Mr. Berlusconi. Mr. Berlusconi denies all wrongdoing and has vowed to fight on.

title: Stroke of Pen Altered Date, and a Tale of Lincoln, Too
description: Just hours before Abraham Lincoln put on his hat and headed for Fords Theater, on April 14, 1865, the president is said to have spared a mentally incompetent Army private the death penalty for desertion.

title: The Bright Side of Blight
description: Philadelphia

title: William Schreyer, 83, Merrill Chief, Dies
description: William A. Schreyer, a former chief of Merrill Lynch who led the big brokerage house into the age of global financial markets, died on Saturday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 83.

title: A Fighting Spirit Wont Save Your Life
description: GABRIELLE GIFFORDSS remarkable recovery from a bullet to her head has provided a heartening respite from a national calamity. Representative Giffordss husband describes her as a fighter, and no doubt she is one. Whether her recovery has anything to do with a fighting spirit, however, is another matter entirely.

title: 2 Big Investors Get Their Say at J.C. Penney
description: The hedge fund manager William A. Ackman has placed a big bet on J.C. Penney. Now it appears that the retailer will let him have a say in how to fix it.

title: Super Bowl Comeback on Wheels Signals Optimism
description: THE two teams that will play in Super Bowl XLV on Feb. 6 are the Packers and the Steelers. But perhaps for a day they ought to be renamed the Porsches and the Siennas or even, given their old-school roots, the Packards and the Studebakers.

title: City Universitys 23 Campuses Are the Latest to Ban Smoking
description: Last summer, the University at Buffalo banned smoking on its three campuses. Last month, Columbia University approved a measure that prohibits smoking within 20 feet of buildings.

title: Wave of Violence Strikes Law Enforcement
description: Thirteen officers have been shot in the United States since Thursday, four fatally and several others critically wounded.

title: The North of the South
description: First African Baptist Church was among the largest and best-known religious institutions in Richmond, Va., during the mid-19th century. By 1861 its congregation numbered over 3,000  a megachurch by even 21st-century standards. A quarter of the citys total black population, free and slave, belonged to what one white observer deemed the largest Protestant church in the world.

title: Despite Cold Weather, Abortion Opponents Rally in Washington
description: Thousands of abortion opponents marched in downtown Washington on Monday to protest the 1973 Supreme Court decision, Roe v. Wade, that established a womans right to an abortion.

title: The Predator State
description: I mentioned a while back that we saw something too big to be a fox behind our house, and learned that there are indeed coyotes in the vicinity. Well, this afternoon a big Eastern coyote  sort of reddish, and as big as a medium-sized dog, I think  trotted right under my home study window, clearly visible in the snow.

title: A Hefty Price for Entry to Davos
description: Andrew Harrer/Bloomberg NewsThe town of Davos, Switzerland, an expensive place to go.

title: Training Youths in the Ways of the Workplace
description: The most frustrating economic news of 2010 wasnt that the recession had worsened  it was that things had improved markedly for corporations, but not for the labor force. Even Alan Greenspan expressed concern that the U.S. is evincing fundamentally two separate types of economy  one in which big companies and high earners thrive, the other in which millions struggle to find jobs and make ends meet. One group that has been particularly hard hit by the recession is youth. Among workers aged 16 to 24, the unemployment rate is almost 20 percent. For young Latinos, its over 24 percent, and for young African Americans, its over 32 percent. Some 4.4 million youths are currently unemployed.This is of serious concern to a country with a rapidly aging population. And while todays best jobs require post-secondary schooling, 30 percent of U.S. public school students fail to graduate from high school (pdf), and more than half of those who enroll in higher education fail to earn a degree or credential within eight years.

title: Food Makers Devise Own Label Plan
description: Starting in the next few months, the front of many food packages will prominently display important nutrition information, including calorie, fat and sugar content. The industrywide program was announced Monday by food makers and grocers.

title: Bush White House Broke Elections Law, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Bush White House, particularly before the 2006 midterm elections, routinely violated a federal law that prohibits use of federal tax dollars to pay for political activities by creating a political boiler room that coordinated Republican campaign activities nationwide, a report issued Monday by an independent federal agency concludes.

title: A Night of Food and Song
description: Perhaps youve been invited to a Burns Supper Tuesday, an annual feast given to celebrate the birth of the Scottish poet Robert Burns on Jan. 25, 1759. We have never experienced a Burns supper in Scotland, where the traditional entree, haggis  a sheep sausage encased in a sheeps stomach  is a delicacy. In America, when the haggis makes its entrance, guests reach for the whiskey, which is also traditional at Burns suppers.

title: Jets May Change, but Ryan Says He Wont
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.

title: Browner Leaving Climate-Change Job
description: Carol Browner, who has served as President Obamas top environmental adviser in the White House, will leave the administration soon, a senior White House official said Monday night.

title: Republicans Budget Man Draws Fire
description: WASHINGTON  He is the guy with the piercing blue eyes, love for heavy metal on his iPod and a reputation among Democrats, including President Obama, as a Republican who has put forward budget ideas that are thoughtful and serious, if not in sync with their own.

title: Obama Nominates a Deputy Counsel for Solicitor General
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Monday nominated a White House deputy counsel and prominent litigator, Donald B. Verrilli Jr., to be solicitor general, one of the most important positions on the administration legal team.

title: Pitch for Rebuilding Infrastructure Carries Political Challenges
description: When President Obama uses his State of the Union address on Tuesday to rally America to outbuild other nations, he will face an unusual challenge: getting Republicans to embrace public works projects again as the kind of worthy bacon they have traditionally fought to bring home, and not as wasteful pork that should be spurned.

title: Cavaliers at Nets? Priceless (Almost)
description: For slightly less than the $2.50 cost of a single-ride MetroCard, a basketball fan could have treated himself and 21 of his friends to an N.B.A. game Monday night in Newark.

title: Tortilla Factory Worker Falls Into a Dough Mixer and Dies
description: The steel gates on the Tortilleria Chinantla tortilla factory in Bushwick, Brooklyn, were drawn down on Monday morning, a telltale sign that something at the usually bustling seven-day-a-week plant was amiss.

title: Bears Protect Their Quarterback
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill.

title: Lottery Numbers
Senate Nears Compromise to Ease Slowdown Tactics
description: WASHINGTON  Senate leaders are nearing agreement on rules changes intended to ease the procedural logjam on the floor after rising complaints from Democrats that Republicans were abusing the filibuster and other tools to slow action.

title: A Hot Topic for Davos: Chinas Big Challenges
description: SHANGHAI  The seemingly unstoppable rise of China has long been high on the agenda at the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. This year, though, the discussion is likely to include a greater focus on major challenges facing the country.

title: Split Up Oil Companies to Unlock Their Value
description: Big oil companies could unlock big value for shareholders. But to do so they need to slaughter an industry sacred cow: the integration of the exploration and production business with refining and other activities. This model worked for decades but today accords a conglomerate discount to the likes of Exxon Mobil, Shell and BP. Splitting up, as the smaller Marathon is doing, could add tens of billions of dollars to shareholders portfolios.

title: With Defeat, No Super Bowl for New Jersey
description: Lets look on the bright side. Yes, it is a shame that the Jets will not be headed to the Super Bowl. That is the price they pay for failing to internalize the concept of football as a game to be played in all four quarters, not just the final two. But at least we will be spared more weeks of trans-Hudson nyah-nyahing over whether the team belongs to New York or, as reality would suggest, New Jersey.

title: Tuesday: Command to a Doberman
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Wow. I cant say too much about this theme without giving it away, but lets just say that for what it is, it sure is fresh. And it couldnt have been an easy task to be that fresh four times in an international setting. Very nicely done, Mr. Hartman.

title: Fighting for Her Familys Education, and Needing a Home
description: Chaos reigns at Sandra Perezs apartment on Staten Island. Visitors are expected, including one loaded with cameras, and the family is rushing to get ready.

title: Director of Policy on Climate Will Leave, Her Goal Unmet
description: WASHINGTON  Carol M. Browner, the White House coordinator for energy and climate change policy, will leave the administration shortly, officials confirmed Monday night. Her departure signals at least a temporary slowing of the ambitious environmental goals of President Obamas first two years in the face of new Republican strength in Congress.

title: Striker Continues His Rise, Leaving Goals in His Wake
description: He certainly does not have the pedigree or the press notices of goal scorers like Cristiano Ronaldo, Lionel Messi and Carlos Tvez, but even if you have not heard the name Marc Janko, scouts for some of the top European club teams certainly have.

description: To the Editor:

title: For Funerals Too Far, Mourners Gather on the Web
description: In an age of commemorating birthdays, weddings and anniversaries on Facebook and Twitter, it was perhaps inevitable that live Web-streaming funerals for friends and loved ones would be next.

title: Stretched Thin in Busy Week, Rangers Slip Past the Capitals
Extreme Weather Events

title: The Talent Magnet
description: President Obama will be talking about economic growth and competitiveness in the State of the Union address Tuesday night. It will be interesting to see if he talks about it in the standard way or in a visionary way.

title: Raising False Alarms
description: If theres a better government program than Social Security, Id like to know what it is.

title: He Never Left
description: Duane Clarridge burst onto the public stage in the mid-1980s for his role in the Iran-Contra scandal. The scheme involved selling weapons to Iran and using the proceeds to fund rebels trying to overthrow the Nicaraguan government. A career officer in the Central Intelligence Agency, Mr. Clarridge, known to virtually everyone as Dewey, was indicted for lying to Congress about the operation but was pardoned by President George H.W. Bush before his trial was finished.

title: What Comes After No?
description: The Republicans have vowed to repeal and replace President Obamas historic health care reform law. Now that House Republicans have muscled through a symbolic repeal bill, they will have to deliver their own alternative plan. Dont expect much.

title: Tactical Secrets
description: At the Supreme Court last week, Justice Antonin Scalia summed up what he and other justices seemed to consider the least bad outcome in a difficult case: It seems to me you call the game off.

title: Amgen Buys a Cancer Drug Maker
description: Amgen said it agreed to buy BioVex, a closely held maker of experimental cancer drugs, for $425 million and as much as $575 million in milestone payments.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Edgar Tafel, Wright-Trained Architect, Dies at 98
description: Edgar Tafel, an architect who was among the best known of Frank Lloyd Wrights many apprentices, died on Jan. 18 at his home in Manhattan. He was 98.

title: Out and Onward: Moments That Made the Game
description: LOOKING BACK

title: Chandler Regains His Touch, and Knicks End Their Skid
description: Wilson Chandler spotted up, released and missed his first shot, a normal occurrence during the Knicks six-game slide. The rim also spat out Chandlers second, third and fourth attempts. When the next chance came, he hesitated  usually a surefire way for a shooter to miss. Instead the ball went in and Chandler celebrated in his own quiet way with a fist pump and by turning his attention to defense.

title: Panel Investigating Financial Crisis Is Said to Refer Cases to Justice Dept.
description: WASHINGTON  The panel appointed by Congress to investigate the causes of the financial crisis referred a handful of cases involving potential wrongdoing to the Justice Department, a person close to the investigation said Monday evening.

title: A Nonprofit Newport
description: The concert promoter George Wein is to announce on Tuesday that this year he will stage the Newport Jazz Festival, set for Aug. 5-7, and the Newport Folk Festival, July 29-31, as nonprofit events, under the direction of the new Newport Festivals Foundation. The point of going nonprofit is to perpetuate what weve created there since 1954, Mr. Wein said. The festivals he helped create in Newport, R.I.  both started more than 60 years ago  suffered a major setback after Mr. Wein sold his concert-production business to Festival Network, a company that had financial troubles in 2009. Subsequently, Mr. Wein took back the festivals. After the last two editions of the Newport Jazz Festivals, which he deemed artistic and popular successes, he described his main focus as perpetuating the legacy of the festivals. He has built a new board to carry out that task, and he will continue to seek corporate sponsors, he said. The festivals will announce their full schedules in the coming weeks.

title: Word of the Day | tranquillity
description: tranquillity \tran-kwi-l-te, traN-\ noun

title: A Republican Majority in the White House
description: Not since George W. Bush inhabited the White House have Republicans so outnumbered Democrats at a social event there as they did on Monday night.

title: Alternative Fuels Dont Benefit the Military, a RAND Report Says
description: The United States would derive no meaningful military benefit from increased use of alternative fuels to power its jets, ships and other weapons systems, according to a government-commissioned study by the RAND Corporation scheduled for release Tuesday.

title: Brian Rust, Father of Modern Discography, Dies at 88
description: Brian Rust, a discographic detective who compiled comprehensive guides to recorded jazz and other popular music, in the process setting the standard for the modern field, died on Jan. 5 in Swanage, in southern England. He was 88.

title: Cromartie Criticizes Both Sides in N.F.L. Labor Dispute
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Using the same salty language as he had two weeks earlier to describe New England quarterback Tom Brady, Jets cornerback Antonio Cromartie lashed out at the players union and the league for the lack of progress on a new collective bargaining agreement. You dont get no information about nothing from the union or the owners, he said.

title: News Quiz | January 25, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Financial Crisis Panel Said to Refer Cases to Justice

title: Violent Clashes Mark Protests Against Mubaraks Rule

title: Ousted Lebanese Leader Swallows Rivals Bitter Pill
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  There is a hint of Shakespeare in it all, if Lebanese politics did not feel like the pulp fiction of Raymond Chandler, where the loftiest principles soon get mired in the muck of corruption, prevarication and opportunism cast in the sincerest of words.

title: Six Justices to Attend State of the Union
description: WASHINGTON  Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr., who mouthed a dissent at last years State of the Union address, will not attend this year. But six justices will be present for this years address, according to a court spokeswoman. She would not say which ones.

title: Fantastic Four No More
description: The first family of Marvel Comics  the Fantastic Four  will lose one of its team members to the Grim Reaper in an issue that is to be released Tuesday. Fantastic Four no. 587, written by Jonathan Hickman and illustrated by Steve Epting, is part five of a storyline whose title, Three, tipped off an impending change in status for the famous quartet. Fans of the series have been endlessly speculating which of the heroes would go. Stop reading now if you do not want to know. Ready?

title: Documents Open a Door on Mideast Peace Talks
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli-Palestinian peace talks over the past 17 years have operated at two levels, one public, the other behind closed doors. To the world and their own people, each side spoke of sacred, nonnegotiable demands, while in the Jerusalem hotel suites where the officials met those very demands were under negotiation.

title: Panel Backs Plan to Develop Site on Lower East Side

title: Frigid Winters and the Polar Vortex
description: In Tuesdays paper, I write about the weakening of the polar vortex that keeps cold air penned up in the Arctic, a change that has contributed to two bitter winters in a row in Europe and the United States. In the piece, I mentioned that several scientists were pursuing ideas about how the drastic decline of sea ice in the Arctic might be playing a role in this pattern.

title: Academy Award Nominations Announced
description: Sorry, Burlesque fans: the 10 films that will be vying for best motion picture at the 83rd Academy Awards are Black Swan, The Fighter, Inception, The Kids Are All Right, The Kings Speech, 127 Hours, The Social Network, Toy Story 3, True Grit and Winters Bone, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences announced on Tuesday morning. The nominees for best director are Darren Aronofsky (for Black Swan), David O. Russell (The Fighter), Tom Hooper (The Kings Speech), David Fincher (The Social Network) and Joel and Ethan Coen (True Grit). The Kings Speech led the pack with 12 nominations total, including Colin Firth (nominated for best actor), Helena Bonham Carter (best supporting actress) and Geoffrey Rush (best supporting actor).

title: Should Teams Be Penalized for Challenging Bad Calls?
description: N.F.L. Rule, Section 9 Instant Replay, Coaches Challenge In each game, a team will be permitted two challenges that will initiate Referee Replay reviews. Each challenge will require the use of a team timeout. If a challenge is upheld, the timeout will be restored to the challenging team. A challenge will only be restored if a team is successful on both of its challenges, in which case it shall be awarded a third challenge, but a fourth challenge will not be permitted under any circumstances. No challenges will be recognized from a team that has exhausted its timeouts. A team that is out of timeouts or has used all of its available challenges may not attempt to initiate an additional challenge.

title: Animal House | Solange Azagury-Partridge
description: Solange Azagury-Partridge was born in the Chinese Year of the Ox, which by definition means shes not only incredibly strong-willed but a firm believer in tradition. Her 12 hand-carved and painted lacquer critters set on 18-karat-gold bands and pendants share a similar dualism, serving double duty as conventional commemorative gifts for the coming Chinese New Year and as unconventional tokens of love for Valentines Day, which falls in the same month. You can feel love emanating from these sweet creatures, and they are incredibly personalized, Ms. Azagury-Partridge says of the designs, which start at $2,450 and include a plump purple poodle for those born in the Year of the Dog. I definitely like unconventional gifts. Admirers, take note.

Only two of the five finalists, Denmarks In a Better World and Greeces Dogtooth, hail from Europe, which traditionally dominates the category.Two of the other finalists are from North America (though obviously not the United States): Mexicos Biutiful and Canadas Incendies. And the remaining slot goes to an African film, Algerias Outside the Law.

description: PARK CITY, Utah  Did I have a gut feeling? Or a stomach ache? said Lisa Cholodenko, who predicted early in the awards season that her film The Kids Are All Right would earn some statuary. Whatever her bodily reaction, she was right; the film received a spot on the best picture list, as well as nods for best actress, best supporting actor and best original screenplay.

title: Notes from the Underground | Light Asylum
description: In a bizarre twist of rock and roll history, one of New Yorks favorite underground (read: unsigned) bands, Light Asylum, performed in the basement of what used to be the legendary venue CBGBs. The two man act, made up of the keyboardist Bruno Coviello, and the vocalist Shannon Funchess, knocked out an hour-long set laden with heavy rhythms, new wave-ish synth and Funchesss impossibly deep bravado. Complete with a fog machine and colored lights, the show was a voyage into the depths of Funchesss tortured visions  and the future of New York dance music.

title: In New Video, Images of Pawlenty the Patriot
description: In the latest Web video for Tim Pawlenty, the former governor of Minnesota and a likely Republican candidate for president in 2012, there is not a single awe-inspiring, patriotic image that is left out.

title: A True Grit Triumph and Other Surprises
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Those unlikely box office champs and self-declared outsiders the Coen brothers are waking up a little more canonized this morning. True Grit, snubbed by many other awards groups, had a great showing with the Academy, earning 10 nominations over all  second only to The Kings Speech  and placing in key categories like best adapted screenplay and best director. Does that advance its cause for best picture? The film didnt earn a best editing nomination, traditionally a bellwether for the eventual top winner, but that didnt stop experts like Roger Ebert from banking on it for a surprise win.

title: Brown to Deliver State of the State on Monday
description: SACRAMENTO  Since his election in November, Gov. Jerry Brown has made few public appearances: among them, the release of his budget, his inauguration and some chance encounters with reporters as he moved through the halls of the state Capitol. Mr. Browns aides say he has been consumed with coming up with a plan to close the states $25 billion budget shortfall; whatever the case, the contrast with his predecessor, Arnold Schwarzenegger, has been notable.

title: Palestinian Police Are Said to Have Participated in Protest Against Al Jazeera

title: The Demand-Side Temptation
description: Nick Rowe makes a good point: most of the time, in market economies, sellers feel constrained while buyers dont. Im somewhat surprised that he doesnt mention why: its because perfect competition is actually rare, because oligopoly or monopolistic competition  in which prices exceed marginal cost  is actually the norm.

title: Now Drinking | The Grilled Cheese and Tomato Soup Martini
description: At Clives, a popular craft cocktails joint in Victoria, British Columbia, the scene is pure hotel lounge kitsch: swirling dark carpets, white leather panels on the walls, fantasia lamps, high-backed banquettes and an unavoidable marble bar. The dcor may be stuck in the 1970s, but Shawn Soole, a crack bartender from Brisbane, Australia, transcends these trappings with a dedication to innovation and craft, most notably with his Cold Night In, an original creation that fuses childhood comfort food and molecular mixology. The result is what he calls a grown-up cocktail equivalent of a toastie (an Australianism for a grilled sandwich) and tomato soup.
