description: Dont cry in your green beer, Jets fans. Youre not the first to suffer with your team on a treadmill to get to the Super Bowl.

title: Product Recalls Weaken J.& J. Sales
description: Shares of Johnson & Johnson dipped in Tuesday trading after the company reported that its fourth- quarter sales in 2010 decreased 5.5 percent to $15.6 billion. Full-year sales for 2010 decreased 0.5 percent to $61.6 billion.

title: On Frozen Pond: Playing Up a Hockey Legacy
description: CONCORD, N.H.  When Chris Brown, 40, laces up his skates and pulls on his Concord Budmen jersey on Friday, he will be reconnecting with the hockey gods who have smiled on New Hampshires capital for almost 130 years. The Budmen are among 50 teams, more than 30 of them from this city of 42,000, that will participate in the first 1883 Black Ice Pond Hockey Championship, a celebration of Concords singular ties to hockey played in the elements.

title: Sealy Adopts a Simmons Technology, and a Mattress Battle Erupts
description: What if Coke copied the Pepsi formula, or Chevrolet began using Ford engines?

title: N.R.A. Stymies Firearms Research, Scientists Say
description: In the wake of the shootings in Tucson, the familiar questions inevitably resurfaced: Are communities where more people carry guns safer or less safe? Does the availability of high-capacity magazines increase deaths? Do more rigorous background checks make a difference?

title: In Firearms Research, Cause Is Often the Missing Element
description: Ultimately, the conundrum in firearms research comes in establishing what scientists call causality.

title: Is Fair Value in Retreat?
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board backed down  but perhaps not by much  when it met Tuesday to discuss fair value accounting.

title: The Future of Algae Fuels Is  When?
description: As I write in Tuesdays Times, a new study from the Rand Corporation, the global policy think tank based in Santa Monica, Calif., and formed more than 60 years ago to advise the American government on military issues, suggests that Department of Defense is wasting its time exploring alternative fuels.

title: Cavaliers Lay Claim to Leagues Worst
description: On Monday night, the Cleveland Cavaliers fell, 101-103, to the Nets, losing their 17th straight game. Losing is a way of life in Cleveland these days; the most surprising part of the Cavaliers most recent defeat wasnt the result, but the fact that the game was close at all. Cleveland has become so spectacularly awful that even competitive games are a rarity. In fact, prior to last nights game, the Cavaliers hadnt lost a game by fewer than five points since the day after Christmas. This Cleveland team doesnt just lose. Theyve raised incompetence to high art, and use each contest as a creative outlet through which to uniquely express their profound failures as a basketball team.

title: Street Scenes: Angle Parking
description: Union City, N.J., nearly a month after the great blizzard of 2010.

title: Davos, 9 Years Into the Future
description: Imagine it is January 2020.

title: The Life, Death and Life of Superheroes
description: So the Human Torch, one quarter of the Fantastic Four, is dead today. And while Jonathan Hickman, the writer of Fantastic Four, had fans feverishly wondering which member of the quartet would meet his or her end, the smarter question is, how long before the deceased returns?

title: Couture Scorecard | Bouchra Jarrar Wins!
description: Hooray, couture is back! (And Scorecard doesnt just mean because Christian Lacroix is designing for Desigual.) With daughters of Dubai a calling, Monday John Galliano hauled out the old wasp-waists from the Dior atelier to an 800-seat marquee on the grounds of the Muse Rodin. Meanwhile former Balenciaga studio director Bouchra Jarrar went beyond the veil with a pared-down vision of haute minimalism  that turned out to be a new look critics could fully support.

title: Expanding, or Maybe Shrinking, the Social Safety Net
description: Was last years health care reform the final stitch needed to secure Americas social safety net? Jim Kessler, vice president for Third Way, has given an emphatic yes, but Lane Kenworthy, a University of Arizona professor who studies inequality, begs to differ.

title: Obama Calls for Bipartisan Effort to Fight for U.S. Jobs
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama challenged Americans on Tuesday night to unleash their creative spirit, set aside their partisan differences and come together around a common goal of outcompeting other nations in a rapidly shifting global economy.

title: Working Wealthy Predominate the New Global Elite
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  The next 10 years is going to be the most exciting time in our lives! said Tejpreet Singh Chopra, an Indian entrepreneur. The Indian economy will double! It will be incredible!

title: Realitys Near-Collision With 127 Hours
description: PARK CITY, Utah Looks like rejecting a conventional Hollywood ending paid off for Danny Boyle and Simon Beaufoy of 127 Hours, which nabbed best adapted screenplay, best picture, best actor and other nods from the Academy. Of course, as with any film based on a true story, reality nearly intruded on the tale the filmmakers wanted to tell.

title: Stories to Tell: Curating an African-American History Exhibition
description: Overview | Given that history is composed of many interwoven stories, how do curators and other historians decide which stories to tell? How can key historical events, people, places and themes best be represented in a meaningful, engaging exhibition to teach others? In this lesson, students consider the messages sent by artifacts and then develop an African-American history exhibition.

title: How Charities Used Donations for Haiti
description: Last January, after the devastating earthquake struck in Haiti, Bucks published a number of posts about how to help the victims, including tips for safe and efficient giving, how to have your donation doubled and how to donate reward points.

title: Election Bill Erodes Decorum in House of Lords
description: LONDON  It was nearly midnight on Day 12 of the most grueling debate in recent House of Lords memory, and not all the Lords present were, strictly speaking, awake. But the Right Honorable Lord Davies of Oldham was warming to the question of the hour: a proposal to change may to should on Page 10, Line 7, of the Parliamentary Voting System and Constituencies Bill.

title: Con Ed Manager Charged With Taking $4 Million in Kickbacks
description: Updated, 5:01 p.m. | A Consolidated Edison manager has been charged with accepting some $4 million in kickbacks from a contractor, federal prosecutors announced on Tuesday.

title: Some Iraqis See Symptoms of Regions Tumult at Home
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs new government has been in office for just over one month, but already it has seen the toppling of governments in Tunisia and Lebanon, antigovernment protests in Egypt, and a rise in violence and unrest at home. On Tuesday, as Iraqis watched televised street demonstrations from Lebanon, some here wondered how far they were from destabilizing conditions of their own.

title: In a Wikileaks Era, Balancing Public and Private
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  At a meeting of the World Economic Forum in China last year, Adrian Monck, the groups chief spokesman, moderated a panel on social networking. Because the Internet can be a sensitive topic in China, he asked the audience whether the discussion should be kept private, to promote a freer exchange.

title: TimesCast | January 25, 2011
description: Protests erupt across Egypt, while protests in Tunisia continue; Rahm Emanuel is back on the Chicago ballot, for now; and a look ahead to President Obama's State of the Union address.

title: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Lebanon, Egypt, Romania and Russia.

title: The Hard Slog to Writing Gratification
description: Michael Arndt won an original screenplay Oscar in 2007 for Little Miss Sunshine and now finds himself nominated again, for best adapted screenplay for Toy Story 3. But, as he said on Tuesday morning, writing remains a mysterious, difficult process. One of the few things that works for him: He starts by writing the end of the story and figuring out how he wants the audience to feel.

title: A January Deadline Met, but the Applications Continue
description: As time goes on, I only look back and exclaim, How nave I was.

title: Student Innovators Featured During State of the Union Speech
description: The White House blog has posted some details about four young innovators who will sit with the first lady as President Obama delivers his State of the Union message tonight.

title: Asked and Answered | Swampy
description: For the bootleg artist known as Swampy, the world is an endless living canvas. Variations on his signature swampdonkey tag  the skull of some imaginary tusked creature  can be found in almost every imaginable setting across America: dilapidated skyscrapers in Oakland, Calif.; train trestles in Ciudad Juarez, Mexico; gallery walls in Atlanta or Brooklyn. Though hes best known for his graffiti, Swampys output varies wildly and incorporates a kaleidoscope of materials, styles and settings. His studio is almost entirely mobile, his materials are liberated as needed from large art supply chains, and he travels entirely for free by hopping freight trains. Trains, and train hopping, are a central theme in the hundreds of works he displays on Flickr and at swmpdnky.com. T caught up with Swampy, who had just spent several months traveling by train through Mexico taking photos for a new book, from his home in Oakland. This is his first published interview.

title: To Add Appeal, Olympics Borrow (Again) From X Games
description: For 15 years, the Winter X Games have acted as an incubator for hip, new Olympic sports that tend to lure larger and younger television audiences. Although officials at the International Olympic Committee do not credit the X Games directly with influencing what winds up in their program, many recent additions  and the athletes who star in them  earned their start at the Winter X Games, which begin Thursday on Buttermilk Mountain in Aspen, Colo.

title: Iraqi Refugees in Jordan
description: The Iraqi middle class who fled to other parts of the Middle East are now finding it difficult to make ends meet.

title: Tea Party Response to Air Live on CNN
description: 6:36 p.m. | Updated Michele Bachmann and the Tea Party will get the full treatment of a live official response to the State of the Union Address on CNN tonight, though the other two national cable news channels say they will not carry her remarks live on television.

title: An Iron Mans Life of Might-Have-Beens
description: Strongman, Zachary Levys lump-in-the-throat portrait of an aging muscleman, is an outsider tale of unforced rawness and lilting poignancy. Not that Stanley Pleskun, a k a Stanless Steel, is in any way clapped out: he can hoist 10,000-pound trucks with his legs and three adults with a single finger. Its the emotional heavy lifting that does him in.

title: Setting the Stage at Davos
description: The World Economic Forum is about to begin in Davos, Switzerland. DealBooks Andrew Ross Sorkin talks about what to expect from the meeting of business, financial and political leaders this year.

title: Burned! A London Vacation Rental Scam
description: I was stressed, rushing to make last-minute lodging arrangements for a three-stop writing trip to Europe, when it appeared on Craigslist: the perfect apartment for my first stop in London. A tiny studio in Notting Hill for just 45, or $73, a night.

title: Quarterfinals Preview: Kvitova vs. Zvonareva
description: Petra Kvitova faces Vera Zvonareva in an intriguing quarterfinal match Wednesday in Melbourne. While Zvonareva, the second seed, has worked her way through her part of the draw with little fanfare, Kvitova has advanced with two big upsets over veteran players.

title: Prospect Park Lake, 8:20 A.M.
description: When the going gets cold, the birds huddle together and even, in the case of one enterprising American coot and an accommodating mute swan, atop one another. Some coots really enjoy the swan boats in this weather, reports Anne-Katrin Titze, the park-watcher who snapped this picture. Her lakefront census today logged 648 waterfowl, including 17 coots, 6 mute swans, 215 mallards and a hooded merganser.

title: In China, an Encore With Meaning
description: Midfielder Yael Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., native by way of the University of North Carolina, will be contributing to the Goal blog in the runup to the third season of Womens Professional Soccer and as the United States womens national team prepares to the FIFA Womens World Cup in Germany later this year. This is here final posting from the Four Nations tournament in China, which the United States won on Tuesday.

title: Financial Crisis Was Avoidable, Inquiry Finds
description: WASHINGTON  The 2008 financial crisis was an avoidable disaster caused by widespread failures in government regulation, corporate mismanagement and heedless risk-taking by Wall Street, according to the conclusions of a federal inquiry.

title: An Aversion to Awards Hoopla
description: PARK CITY, Utah Did Jesse Eisenberg, a best actor hopeful for The Social Network, watch his nomination unfold?

title: Setting the Stage at Davos
description: The World Economic Forum will start tomorrow in Davos, Switzerland. DealBook's Andrew Ross Sorkin talks about what to expect from the meeting of business, financial and political leaders this year.

title: Industry Boos Oscar Nod for Gasland
description: Gasland, a film that turns a harshly critical eye on the perils of natural gas drilling, has earned an Academy Award nomination for best documentary.

title: Last Call for Cabaret Nights in Cuba
description: Ever attend a party only to learn that you missed out on a much better time across town? Try Havana on New Years Eve, 1958, the last hurrah of the Fulgencio Batista regime before Fidel Castros rebel troops entered the capital.

title: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Lebanon, Egypt, Romania and Russia.

title: The State of the Union: What to Watch
description: President Obama delivers his State of the Union address tonight at 9 p.m. Eastern time, and The Caucus will be live blogging it, starting an hour ahead. Come back here at 8 p.m. for the latest reporting about what we expect Mr. Obama to say. And then stay with us as we offer context to his speech and take note of the atmospherics.

title: House Orders Budget Trimmed
description: The House voted on Tuesday to direct the chairman of the Budget Committee to cut federal spending to 2008 levels on a broad array of programs, as they sought to play offense in what is expected to be a long battle with the Obama administration on fiscal policy.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: Do Wall Streeters Read? Well, other than DealBook, of course. But Elizabeth Minkel on The New Yorkers Book Bench blog notes that while there are a few examples of financial fiction in recent years, finding fiction readers in finance may be rarer. Some investment bank recruiters are apparently reluctant to hire someone seen as a bookworm. Still, she finds evidence of intellectual activity elsewhere, including a hedge fund where people suggest reading Heidegger. (Being and Time as trading manual?) The New Yorker

title: Dispute Over Confinement of WikiLeaks Suspect Echoes Guantnamo Chaplain Case
description: WASHINGTON  The controversy over the harsh confinement the military has imposed on Bradley Manning, the Army private accused of leaking hundreds of thousands of classified documents to WikiLeaks, holds echoes of a similar dispute over the pretrial detention of a Muslim Army chaplain at the prison in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, seven years ago.

title: Four Tied for the Lead of Tata Steel Chess Tournament
Volkswagen Previews Refreshed 261 M.P.G. XL1 Prototype
description: 2:55 p.m. | Updated

title: YouTube Video of Protests in Egypt
description: Updated | 5:32 p.m. As my colleagues Kareem Fahim and Mona El-Naggar report, thousands of Egyptians took to the streets of cities across Egypt on Tuesday, calling for an end to three decades of autocratic rule by President Hosni Mubarak.

title: ArcelorMittal Moves Ahead With Bid for Arctic Miner
description: Richard Perry/The New York TimesSteel plates being produced at an ArcelorMittal plant.

title: Murderer Is Executed in Georgia After Losing Stay
description: ATLANTA  A convicted murderer in Georgia whose lawyers argued that the painkilling drugs used to help execute him might be ineffective lost an 11th-hour appeal to the Supreme Court on Tuesday night and was put to death shortly before midnight.

title: Big Hair, Strong Will and an Oscar Nomination
description: Amy Adamss supporting actress nomination for her role as the tough girlfriend in The Fighter is her third Oscar nod, but Ms. Adams said Tuesday she has not lost any of her wonder about the movies or the Academy Awards. But her first words were to praise the man who got the film made, roping in a wary Paramount, and watching major stars drop out of the project along the way.

title: Scorecard | Lanvin Wins!
description: It may be the middle of couture fashion week, but as somehow always seems to happen with these things, this morning critics were still filing their reviews from the weekends final Paris mens-wear shows, so today Scorecard doubles your fun with one more recap for the gents. At the end of a season of polarizing dichotomies  wide-legged trousers or jeggings? top hat or Stetson? heteronormative or not-so? lime green or tangerine? Alber Elbaz and Lucas Ossendrijver offered a playfully performative suggestion: Why not just pile it all on in a choose your own adventure kind of way?

title: David Changs Latest: An iPad App and a Journal
description: Cant get enough of the Momofuku chef, David Chang? Soon youll be able to carry him around with you. In late April, he plans to release Lucky Peach, a quarterly iPad app and print journal.

title: Better Spirits, Especially for the Better-Off
description: 8:14 p.m. | Updated  to clarify index benchmark and income groupings.

title: French Railway Formally Apologizes to Holocaust Victims
description: PARIS  The head of Frances national railway company, known as the S.N.C.F., on Tuesday made the companys first formal public apology directly to Holocaust victims. The regrets came just a few months after American lawmakers, survivors and their descendants moved to block the company from winning contracts in the United States if it did not acknowledge its role in the shipping of thousands of Jews to Nazi death camps and make amends.

title: Two Lotus Teams Race It Out in Court and in the Media
description: The Formula One season competition has already begun for two of the teams, both of which have the name Lotus in their title. Team Lotus andLotus Renault GP were in London High Court on Monday in a battle over the right to use the Lotus name.

title: Two Lotus Teams Race It Out in Court and in the Media
description: The Formula One season competition has already begun for two of the teams, both of which have the name Lotus in their title. Team Lotus andLotus Renault GP were in London High Court on Monday in a battle over the right to use the Lotus name.

title: MSNBC Ratings Rise on First Night Without Olbermann
description: MSNBC received some gratifying ratings news from the first night of its new prime-time lineup as it showed increases in the 8 p.m. and 9 p.m. hours, even in the absence of its previous leading man, Keith Olbermann.

title: Protesters Call for End of Mubaraks Rule
description: Thousands in the Egyptian capital called for an end to the rule of President Hosni Mubarak, in the most serious civil unrest in Egypt in recent memory.

title: Man Is Questioned After Traffic Stop Reveals Possible Bomb Ingredients
description: A man whose vehicle was stopped for a traffic violation on Tuesday was being questioned by the police after they found tablets of ammonium nitrate in a glass bottle, metal shavings and a motorcycle battery in the vehicle, materials that could be used to make a bomb, a law enforcement official said.

title: Arms Treaty Takes Crucial Step Forward in Russia
description: MOSCOW  The lower chamber of the Russian Parliament easily ratified the New Start nuclear arms control treaty, a key foreign policy goal of the Obama administration.

title: Financial Crisis Avoidable, Inquiry Panel Concludes
description: The panel appointed by Congress to investigate the causes and consequences of the financial crisis has found that there plenty of blame to go around, The New York Timess Sewell Chan reports.

title: The Making of Halo 3
description: Behind the scenes of the video game, Halo 3, by Bungie Studios.

title: Higher Income but Tepid Growth at Yahoo
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Anyone looking for signs of a Yahoo turnaround will have to wait a bit longer, after a lackluster fourth quarter and a disappointing forecast.

title: How Djokovic Survived Berdych
description: While Novak Djokovic looked convincing in the first and third sets against Tomas Berdych last night, he was vulnerable throughout the second set. In the tie-breaker, however, he battled his nerves by playing long, high-percentage points, baiting Berdych to overhit after several sustained rallies.

title: Vonns Role in Chase for Title Is Reversed
description: Despite Maria Rieschs commanding 145-point lead in the overall World Cup Alpine standings, Lindsey Vonn said Tuesday that she had not given up the chase for a title she has won the last three years.

title: Harlem Is Nowhere
description: 1: A Colony of Their Own

title: ABC and Fox Split Night
description: With CBS broadcasting comedy reruns on Monday, ABC and Fox finished in a virtual tie for first place in the nights ratings, according to Nielsens estimates. Lifting ABC for the night, The Bachelor delivered 9.2 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m. while Fox earned comparable ratings if slightly fewer viewers on average over that time period with new episodes of House at 8 (10.4 million) and Lie to Me at 9 (7.7 million). CBS ranked third with repeats but still managed to attract the nights largest audience with a rerun of Two and Half Men at 9 (11.4 million). NBC finished fourth but won the 10 p.m. time slot with its new series Harrys Law (10.4 million), which outperformed ABCs Castle (9.1 million) and CBSs rerun of Hawaii Five-0 (6.5 million). Earlier, NBC drew 6.2 million at 8 for Chuck and 5.9 million at 9 for Chase.

title: Bachmanns Speech Will Push Tea Party Goals
description: It is a Washington tradition that on the night the president gives his annual address to Congress, a member of the opposition gives a formal response. Tonight, there will be a response to the response.

title: A Thumbs Down for Gasland
description: The nomination for best documentary truly thrilled the makers of Gasland  the producer Trish Adlesic was crying so hard when she called the films director, Josh Fox, with the news, that he had trouble understanding her. But there was one constituency that was not so happy. As Green, our sister blog, writes, the natural gas industry gave a thumbs down to the documentary about the perils of natural gas drilling, or fracking. While its unfortunate there isnt an Oscar category for propaganda, this nomination is fitting, as the Oscars are aimed at praising pure entertainment among Hollywoods elite, said Lee Fuller, executive director of Energy In Depth, a pro-drilling group.

title: U.S. Is Gaining in Afghanistan, General Writes
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Just hours before President Obama gave his State of the Union address, his commander in Afghanistan, Gen. David H. Petraeus, offered what amounted to his own state of the war address, one noticeably more upbeat than a White House assessment issued late last year.

title: A New Song and Dance With Every Performance
description: How long does it take to write, polish and produce an epic, action-packed musical filled with battles, a geek chorus, supervillains and a theme about the relationship between, say, great power and great responsibility? The producers of Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark have said they needed years of planning and over three months of previews. But Baby Wants Candy, performing on Saturday nights at SoHo Playhouse, pulled off this feat in one giddy hour.

title: A New Face in an Old Fight
description: Schools Chancellor Cathleen P. Black skipped the pleasantries, ignored the boos and did not stray from the message as she presided over her first public meeting last week. Never mind that the audience was made up primarily of the same people her words would focus on: veteran teachers, whom she wants to be made easier to fire, and union loyalists, who oppose the move.

title: Davos One Crazy, Exciting Circus
New Studio Harks Back to a Musical Golden Age
description: Jungle City Studios, a new recording studio perched above the High Line in Chelsea, seems to be a vision out of New Yorks glorious musical past. Packed with the kind of gear that makes sound engineers salivate, like an extremely rare 1960s recording console by EMI side-by-side with the latest gleaming digital equipment, it is not the kind of place you would expect for an era of pirated music and GarageBand. And thats before you notice the Louis Vuitton-patterned fabric on the walls.

title: A Cab-Ride Celebration
description: PARK CITY, Utah Danny Boyle, the Oscar-winning director of Slumdog Millionaire and newly minted multiple nominee for 127 Hours, is currently in the midst of directing an adaptation of Frankenstein at the National Theater in London. So when he got word of his Academy honors, he decided to treat himself to a cab after rehearsal. I normally get the Tube home, Mr. Boyle said, from the back of the cab. But I cant do any phone calls on the Tube. And its a pretty exciting day, I thought Id get a taxi home to celebrate.

title: Female Spider Monkeys
description: A video from Anthony Di Fiore showing three female spider monkeys, a mom and two daughters, hanging out in the trees over a mineral lick.

title: During Super Bowl, Whetting Appetites for Products to Come
description: REMEMBER when movie theaters called the trailers they showed previews of coming attractions? Many of the glitzy, big-budget commercials that are scheduled to run during Super Bowl XLV on Feb. 6 will offer previews of coming products and services.

title: Thread of the Union
description: The Thread has lined up a number of Opinionator columnists and guest experts to weigh in over the course of the State of the Union message this evening, with breaking updates throughout. And, as always on the Thread, well be rounding up the most interesting opinions to be found around the blogosphere before, during and after the speech.

title: For Decemberists, a Time to Shift Gears
description: We do short songs now, Colin Meloy of the Decemberists said during his bands concert on Monday night at the Beacon Theater, starting a three-night stand there to open its United States tour. That statement sums up the latest turn in his songwriting for the band.

title: Who Invests in Low-Income Housing? Google, for One
description: Melbourne Apartments is a new 84-unit building in Des Moines, where a three-bedroom apartment rents for $775 a month but comes with restrictions  a family of five, for example, can earn no more than $47,460 a year. What is remarkable about this otherwise modest project is that the equity came from the search-engine giant Google, whose Mountain View, Calif., headquarters are more than 1,500 miles away.

title: On the Market: Elaine Kaufmans Longtime Home
description: Its not the place where the regulars framed book jackets filled the walls and newcomers looking for the mens room were told, Take a right at Michael Caine. But it too was Elaines  the late Elaine Kaufmans apartment.

title: Following a Contemporary Palette as It Ranges From Peru to China
description: For a program on Monday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, the Da Capo Chamber Players, celebrating their 40th anniversary this year, decided to mingle works from their early days with pieces written in the last decade.

title: In Britain, Separation of Art and State
description: LONDON  For all the talk about one big, globalized art world, the trans-Atlantic gulf reasserted itself the other evening via a small but telling event. An overflow crowd of several hundred people, young and old, men and women, gay and straight, packed Starr Auditorium at the Tate Modern here to pay tribute to David Wojnarowicz, the artist and AIDS activist who died, at 37, from AIDS, in 1992.

title: In Birminghams Lakeview District, a Revival Is Planned
description: A descendant of the Alabama citys founders, trained in urban planning, has bought up properties with the goal of creating a design-centered district.

title: Daughter of Birmingham Plans Revival
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  This city was founded, quite deliberately, in the late 19th century by a group of industrialists who wanted to capitalize on proximity to vast deposits of coal, iron and limestone. But after a period of prosperity and growth, Birmingham was brought to its knees by the Depression and wracked by the end of segregation.

title: Is Jeters Future in Center Field?
description: Should Derek Jeter move to center field? Readers are invited to join the conversation in the comment section below. Ben Shpigel, who covers the Yankees, responded to some of the questions and comments on Wednesday.

title: The Benefits of Anxiety
description: PARK CITY, Utah I was awake at 5:30 in the morning New York time, the veteran producer Scott Rudin said. Why? I was anxious, what do you think?

title: A Mystery in Black and White on Biscayne Bay
description: NORTH MIAMI, Fla.  From the shore, it looks like an oddly shaped buoy. But as residents here have discovered on closer inspection, it is in fact a grand piano perched upright on a narrow sand bar in Biscayne Bay  a sight that has inspired wordsmiths to compete to name South Floridas newest curiosity (piano bar seems to have won).

title: Stricter Oversight Urged for Defibrillators
description: A federal advisory panel on Tuesday called for stricter oversight of the defibrillators available in many schools, gyms, lobbies and other places that are used by the public to try to save victims of major heart attacks.

title: Video Gallery: The Minimalist's Greatest Hits
description: Twenty of Mark Bittmans most-watched cooking videos from 2006 onward.

title: The Minimalist Makes His Exit
description: TODAY marks the exit of The Minimalist from the pages of the Dining section, as a weekly column at least. There may be return appearances, but the unbroken string of more than 13 years and nearly 700 columns ends here. (Im not leaving the Times family; more about that in a minute.)

title: The Best Minimalist Video? Just Ask the Guy Who Shot Them
description: This week marks the last weekly appearance of the Minimalist column by Mark Bittman. Since 2006, Gabe Johnson, a video journalist with The New York Times, has shot and produced all the videos that accompany the column  more than 200 of them. (The Times has compiled some of the most watched.) He also sampled each and every recipe Mr. Bittman cooked on camera. There will be more Minimalist videos in the future, drawing on recipes from the Times archives, but Diners Journal asked Mr. Johnson to talk about the best thing hes tasted so far.

title: The Minimalist Chooses 25 of His Favorites
description: Picking 25 favorites out of more than 1,000 recipes from The Minimalist  the last weekly column appears this week  is an awesome task. But each of these, listed in order of appearance, represents something special either to me or to regular readers of The Minimalist, or in a couple of cases  most notably Jim Laheys bread  to a wider audience. Its a list that will make you want to cook, I think. What are your favorites?

title: Nonfiction: Nabokov Theory on Butterfly Evolution Is Vindicated
description: Vladimir Nabokov may be known to most people as the author of classic novels like Lolita and Pale Fire. But even as he was writing those books, Nabokov had a parallel existence as a self-taught expert on butterflies.

title: Fanfare and Ridicule for Japans Common Man
description: Japan Society is holding what it says is the first major retrospective of the movies of Hiroyuki Tanaka, who goes by the nom de film Sabu, and you can picture the people responsible for Japans image overseas quietly gritting their teeth. They would probably like to keep under the radar Sabus distinctive take on the modern Japanese man: paralyzed by feelings of inadequacy, in thrall to cartoonish yakuza fantasies and only coming alive when hes drunk beyond the point of memory or volition.

title: PGA Adjusts Tee Times to Match Star With Star
description: SAN DIEGO  Rocco Mediate feigned surprise Tuesday when he heard about his coincidental pairing with Tiger Woods in the first two rounds of this weeks Farmers Insurance Open.

title: Does Test-Taking Help Students Learn?
description: To the Editor:

title: After UConn Picks Coach, Donor Asks for His Money Back
description: A major donor to the Connecticut football program has demanded that the university return $3 million and remove his name from a building because it did not consult with him enough before hiring its new head coach.

title: Housing for Veterans
description: To the Editor:

title: Photographer Attacked by Police in Tunisia
description: Wednesday, 12:00 p.m. | Updated

title: An Institutes Views
description: To the Editor:

title: Nielsen Offering Price Set to Exceed Estimate
description: 8:50 p.m. | Updated

title: Nixon in China, the Dinner, Is Recreated
description: WHEN President Richard M. Nixon made his momentous trip to China in 1972, it followed years of diplomacy and advance work. When Michael Tong brought his interpretation of the visit to his Manhattan restaurant, Shun Lee Palace, it took less than 24 hours.

title: F.D.A and Dairy Industry Spar Over Testing of Milk
description: Each year, federal inspectors find illegal levels of antibiotics in hundreds of older dairy cows bound for the slaughterhouse. Concerned that those antibiotics might also be contaminating the milk Americans drink, the Food and Drug Administration intended to begin tests this month on the milk from farms that had repeatedly sold cows tainted by drug residue.

title: Live Blog: President Obama Delivers State of the Union
description: President Obama delivered his second State of the Union address on Tuesday tonight. He focused on five major themes  innovation in energy and technology, improving education, building better infrastructure, reforming government and reducing deficits  all of which were wrapped in the larger idea of increasing Americas competitiveness in the world.

title: Obamas Second State of the Union (Text)
description: Following is the transcript for President Obamas second State of the Union address on Tuesday, as released by the White House:

title: Cut Waste or Invest? Try Both
description: Washington

title: Alternative Rock Festival Is Moving to Jersey Shore
description: When All Tomorrows Parties, a British alternative music festival known for its connoisseur taste and noncorporate, mom-and-pop leadership style, came to the New York area in 2008, its organizers chose an unusual spot: Kutshers Country Club in Monticello, N.Y., one of the last old Catskills resorts, whose aging facilities brought some charm and kitsch to louder-than-loud shows by bands like My Bloody Valentine and Sunn O))).

title: States Lawmakers Turn Attention to the Dangers of Distracted Pedestrians
description: Many joggers don earbuds and listen to music to distract themselves from the rigors of running. But might the Black Eyed Peas or Rihanna distract them so much that they jog into traffic?

title: Chanel: Eat Fast, Walk Fast
description: Sometime in the early 1920s, Marie Laurencin, a painter and illustrator in Paris, was asked by Coco Chanel to paint her portrait. According to one Internet site, Chanel rejected the portrait, saying it didnt look like her. Im inclined to agree with her, but theres something very pretty about the soft, watery pastels with a graphic element of black.

title: $100 Million Suit Planned Over Former Deutsche Bank Building
description: The last chapter in the tortured tale of the former Deutsche Bank building near ground zero will play out in court now that the 41-story office tower has finally been dismantled.

title: A Growth Agenda for World Economic Forum
description: The global economy is not as healthy as it looks. The International Monetary Fund now predicts 4.4 percent growth for 2011. But inflation has reared its ugly head across the globe, suggesting that many economies are growing faster than can be sustained without structural changes. Spurring on reform should be the main focus of the annual World Economic Forum gathering this week in Davos, Switzerland.

title: Is College Tuition Too Low?
description: My column this week looks at ways to cut wasteful spending on higher education and redirect the money more productively. Another way to keep colleges in decent financial shape during tough economic times, of course, is to raise tuition.

title: The Alzheimers Disaster
description: To the Editor:

title: Glamorous Mug Shots From Dior
description: I loved these pictures from the Dior runway, and, of course, they brought to mind the great models of the 1950s. The makeup was done by Pat McGrath and the hair by Orlando Pita and their teams.

title: Buying Wine in New York State
description: To the Editor:

title: Yesterdays Gadfly, Todays Political Boss
description: DERRY, N.H.  Until last weekend, one of Jack Kimballs biggest claims to political fame was the eye-catching conservative messages he would post on a sign outside his office-cleaning company. Lets All Stop Paying Our Mortgages, read one as the subprime crisis raged. Obama Hands Off Our Healthcare, barked another as the contentious federal health care law was being debated.

title: A Call for Calm in Tunis
description: TUNIS  After days of antigovernment protests, dozens of Tunisians marched in the capital on Tuesday to demonstrate their patience with the interim government that replaced the ousted dictator Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, pleading with their fellow citizens to give the temporary leadership time to hold elections.

title: A Playwrights Voice, Silenced in a Flash of Terrorism in Moscow
description: MOSCOW  Anna Mashutina hated compliments. When praised for her plays, she would look down in embarrassment, or respond by listing their shortcomings. She was so bashful about her success that she sometimes seemed to be apologizing for it.

title: E-Mail About Book Questioning the Holocaust Shakes a School
description: The e-mail list of the Public School 290 PTA is a useful source on matters like fund-raising, after-school programs and the rules for the talent show coming up. It is not known to provoke strong feelings.

title: Protests Erupt in Egypt
description: Mona El-Naggar reports from Cairo, where thousands of protesters are calling for the end to the rule of President Hosni Mubarak.

title: After What Seemed Like One Miracle, She Is Praying for Another
description: All around Mirna B. Lpezs modest one-bedroom apartment in Bushwick, Brooklyn, are reminders of God.

title: New Details on Troubled F-35 Fighter
description: Shortly before making a final push to ensure that the Marine version of the F-35 fighter was not canceled, the services commandant, Gen. James F. Amos, called in a former Marine corporal for a frank talk.

title: Illinois Plan for Pensions Questioned
description: Federal regulators are examining disclosures by Illinois about its unorthodox pension funding method, trying to determine whether the state misled bond investors about the risks.

title: For a Medicaid Cost-Cutter From Wisconsin, a More Complicated Job in New York
description: ALBANY  Two years ago, Gov. James E. Doyle of Wisconsin knew that he needed to cut hundreds of millions in Medicaid spending in his state.

title: The John Dory Oyster Bar
description: MAYBE there is something democratic about having a no-reservations policy at a restaurant as otherwise terrific as the John Dory Oyster Bar. Perhaps there is some benefit to having patrons come early and wait late.

title: No Reservations
U.S. Doubts 99 Jet Debris Gave China Stealth Edge
description: WASHINGTON  Pentagon officials said Tuesday that they were unsure if some of the technology in Chinas prototype stealth fighter jet had come from the wreckage of a first-generation American stealth fighter shot down over Serbia in 1999, but they expressed doubt that much could have been gleaned from the debris of a plane developed in the 1970s.

title: Good News From the Middle East (Really)
description: Washington

title: Packers Coach Has Fans in a Small Slice of Steelertown
description: PITTSBURGH  Down at the bottom of the hill, not far from the river and near where a steel mill buzzed for generations, the place has not changed much in the years since it was called Joe McCarthys. There is still a long bar on the left, a pool table in the middle and Steelers posters decorating the walls.

title: Make Them Work for It
description: Senate Democrats now have a rare opportunity to reduce the abuse of the filibuster and increase the chances that the peoples work actually gets done. Instead, they are close to an agreement on a watered-down package of changes that will have only a modest effect on the chambers gridlock.

title: A Regions Unrest Scrambles U.S. Foreign Policy
description: WASHINGTON  As the Obama administration confronts the spectacle of angry protesters and baton-wielding riot police officers from Tunisia to Egypt to Lebanon, it is groping for a plan to deal with an always-vexing region that is now suddenly spinning in dangerous directions.

title: A Case for Accountability
description: A court hearing this month in Manhattan turned on a subject that has mostly been missing in the legal response to former President George W. Bushs abusive detention policies: some measure of accountability.

title: Gottscheer Hall Tap Room
description: GOOD spirits make for rousing dinners, but on the evening of the annual Jaegerball, they nearly crowded out our kassler rippchen and baked spaetzle. The local rod and gun club, joined by hundreds of friends and family, had assembled for dinner and dancing in the main ballroom of Gottscheer Hall. But many lingered in the public taproom, clustering near the television  and nearly screening off the server from our table  to follow football.

title: Read On
description: News that Borders, the nations second-largest book chain after Barnes & Noble, is teetering on the brink of a bankruptcy filing has made book publishers even more nervous about their online future.

title: A Short Stay  and a Long Jump
description: West Point, N.Y., Jan. 26, 1861

title: The Republican Response
description: Following is the prepared remarks of Representative Paul Ryan of Wisconsin, who was expected to give the official Republican response to President Obama's second State of the Union address, as released by the House speaker's office:

title: Proposal to Revamp Judicial-Conduct Agency Draws Fire
description: New York judges have long seethed privately about the New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct, the state agency that disciplines and removes them for offenses like fixing cases, jailing people illegally and awarding excessive legal fees to friends.

title: The State of the Union
description: This nation faces huge problems  putting millions of Americans back to work, investing to compete in a 21st-century global economy and wrestling down a long-term budget deficit that threatens everyones future.

title: Bloombergs Gun-Limits Coalition Grows, but Finds a Hard Sell in Washington
description: In the spring of 2006, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and 14 other mayors from across the country stood at Gracie Mansion and announced that they would take up the fight for stricter gun regulation, vowing to raise the pressure on a volatile national issue.

title: In Soup, Jersey Tomatoes Last Through the Year
description: At the Central Valley Farm stand in the Union Square Greenmarket, big jars of tomato soup are tempting on a frigid morning. Ed Huff, the owner, is justifiably proud of the soup, a straightforward rendition made with the New Jersey tomatoes he grows, and has cooked and canned in season. The other important ingredient is Parmesan cheese, he said. Its the expensive kind from Italy, Reggiano. Consider a few quarts of the soup to fill mugs for your Super Bowl party. And in summer, try it chilled.

title: Despaa Opens a Wine Shop
description: The newest expansion of the Spanish food store Despaa, owned by Angelica and Marcos Intriago, pictured, is a compact but extremely well-stocked wine shop next door. Its a no-frills but appealing installation with floor-to-ceiling shelves holding some 400 different wines grouped according to region, about 30 sherries, more than 30 sparkling wines and several ciders. Prices start at around $8, with more than 60 percent of the wines selling for less than $25. At the high end, up to $695, are bottles of Pingus and Vega Sicilia Unico. The adjacent food shop makes it easy for the Intriagos to provide tastings with cheeses, cured meats and other tidbits.

title: Board Backs Development of Site on Lower East Side With Housing
description: After sitting fallow for 43 years as the Lower East Sides popularity soared, a desolate stretch of parking lots along Delancey Street is closer than ever to being transformed into housing and shops, marking the end of a long and bitter stalemate over the future of the sites.

title: Hariris Supporters Take to the Streets
description: After Najib Miqati, the Hezbollah-backed leader, was named as the prime minister designate of Lebanon, supporters of the former prime minister, Saad Hariri, demonstrated.

title: Off the Menu
description: Openings

title: The Long Pull of Noodle Making
description: IN an open kitchen in NoLIta, two solemn young men work together in virtual silence up to 16 hours a day, their destinies yoked by noodles.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Bordeaux Fest

title: Bernd Eichinger, Screenwriter and Producer, Dies at 61
description: Bernd Eichinger, a German screenwriter and producer who made films in Germany and Hollywood, including the childrens fairy tale The NeverEnding Story, the Resident Evil series derived from video games, and Downfall, a movie about the last days of the Third Reich that raised hackles for humanizing Adolf Hitler, died in Los Angeles on Monday. He was 61.

title: New Arena for the Nets Is Sprouting in Brooklyn
description: Jason Kidd was the Nets All-Star point guard when he attended the naming ceremony for the organizations new arena in Brooklyn four years ago. Since then, Kidds home has changed, and so has the Nets since they vacated the Izod Center in the Meadowlands after last season.

title: Coppa Piccante With a Spicy Swagger
description: At La Quercia, an American producer of cured pork from heritage breeds, Herb Eckhouse keeps coming up with new temptations. He has just introduced his version of coppa piccante, a well-marbled, deep mahogany hunk of pork shoulder with a brash swagger thanks to cumin and smoky Spanish paprika. Thin slices make a handsome addition to an appetizer platter, and dicings can go into a salad or provide the underpinning of a stew.

title: Daniel Bell, Ardent Appraiser of Politics, Economics and Culture, Dies at 91
description: Daniel Bell, the writer, editor, sociologist and teacher who over seven decades came to epitomize the engaged intellectual as he struggled to reveal the past, comprehend the present and anticipate the future, died on Tuesday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 91.

title: Nanotechnology Gets Star Turn at Speech
description: The presence of Amy Chyao, a 16-year-old from Richardson, Tex., in Michelle Obamas box during the State of the Union speech puts a spotlight, as it were, on using nanotechnology and light to kill cancer.

title: Wednesday: As Good as a Mile
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  The last time we saw David Murchie was in 2005, when he made his debut with a very punny offering (Across Lite, Solution). Today, hes back with a fun grid that is straightforward in terms of fill, but has some tricky cluing. All in all, a typical Wednesday puzzle, but watch out: Mr. Murchie says we may not be as on target as we think. Youll have to finish the puzzle to see what I mean.

title: Evidence Is Elusive on Charge of a Blizzard Slowdown
description: The story rocketed around New York City when streets went uncleared after the Dec. 26 blizzard: Sanitation workers, angry about job reductions, had deliberately staged a work slowdown.

title: What Is Your Reaction to Obamas Second State of the Union Address?
description: In his second State of the Union speech, President Obama focused his remarks on the economy and innovation with a plan to win the future, declaring that it is imperative that the United States rise to meet the challenges of the world. What did you think of Mr. Obamas speech?

title: Bruce Gordon, TV Mobster, Dies at 94
description: Bruce Gordon, a granite-faced, gravel-voiced character actor famous for playing heavies, most memorably the mob boss Frank Nitti on the classic television series The Untouchables, died on Thursday. He was 94 and lived in Santa Fe, N.M.

title: SOTU
description: So, Ive read the text, and find it hard to extract any theme. Were going to invest in the future  but were also going to freeze domestic spending. So mixed signals  and although there were no numbers, given the further assurance that the freeze wont affect anything important, this has to mean that the investment plans are small change.

title: Obama Sets Stage for Clash of Governing Ideals
description: WASHINGTON  At a moment when the momentum in Washington is driving toward slashing budgets and shrinking government, President Obama argued on Tuesday evening that the politics of austerity, mindlessly applied, would amount to a pre-emptive surrender to China, India and a raft of smaller competitors who are investing while Americans are cutting.

title: Strange Bounce Wipes Out Rangers Late Rally
description: The Rangers found out the hard way how important luck can be Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Questions for David Leonhardt on the State of the Union
description: 4:20 p.m. | Updated

title: Britains Economy Stalls, in Setback for Cameron
description: LONDON  Prime Minister David Camerons coalition government received a sharp political jolt on Tuesday with the release of official figures showing that Britains economy contracted slightly in the last three months of 2010, prompting some economists to warn that the country was at increased risk of a double dip recession after four consecutive quarters of modest growth.

title: Computer (Chess) Pioneer Wins Prestigious Japan Prize
description: Ken Thompson and Dennis Ritchie, the inventors of the Unix operating system and C programming language more than 40 years ago, have been awarded the Japan Prize, according to the San Francisco Chronicle. The prize goes each year to people whose work aims to promote the advancement of science and technology for the peace and prosperity of mankind. The award is for $600,000. Ten previous recipients have also won Nobel Prizes.

title: Obama Counters G.O.P. With Plan to Extend Spending Freeze
description: WASHINGTON  By proposing a two-year extension to the three-year domestic spending freeze he called for a year ago, President Obama sought to quickly counter Republican demands for deeper cuts to shrink government and reduce annual budget deficits.

title: France Sells Assault Ships to Russia
description: President Nicolas Sarkozy said Tuesday that France had concluded a deal with Russia to sell it four Mistral assault ships. The deal, which has now been signed, according to a joint French-Russian statement on Tuesday, was criticized by the United States and NATO allies in the Baltics for providing Russia with a modern carrier for helicopters or tanks.

title: China: Dissident Is Reported Beaten
description: He Depu, a prominent Chinese democracy advocate who had been jailed for eight years, was beaten by police officers on Monday, just after he was released from jail, according to a report by Human Rights in China. The report, which cited a witness, said that Mr. He had been beaten when he resisted being shoved into a police vehicle. He was given rules to abide by in the next two years, the report said, including not criticizing the government. Mr. He took part in the 1989 movement that ended in the Tiananmen Square massacre and helped form the now-banned China Democracy Party in 1998. After his release on Monday, Mr. He told a friend about being tortured while in prison, the report said.

title: The Ryan Response
description: was as bad as you might expect. Lots of breast-beating about deficits; youd never know that no leading Republican, Ryan very much included, has offered a serious proposal to cut the deficit. Some cooked statistics about federal spending. And then there was this curious assertion:

title: How to Fight Back When Your Flight Is Canceled
description: AS thousands of passengers who were caught up in the latest bout of snowstorms along the East Coast can attest, when weather disrupts the system, travelers are basically on their own. Just getting someone on the phone to confirm a new flight was a major headache for travelers who had been stranded for days in cities up and down the East Coast during the holidays.

title: Two G.O.P. Responses Point to Potential Fault Lines
description: WASHINGTON  The crosscurrents inside the Republican Party were on fresh display Tuesday evening with the unusual sight of two lawmakers delivering responses to the State of the Union address.

title: Canada: Albertas Premier to Resign
description: Ed Stelmach said on Tuesday that he would step down as the premier of Alberta, blaming U.S.-style, negative-attack politics for his decision. His party is expected to name a successor soon after he makes a formal announcement.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Rwandan Rebel Handed Over to Court
description: The French police on Tuesday handed over a Rwandan rebel leader to the International Criminal Court in The Hague, which wanted him on charges of rape, murder, torture and other atrocities committed during a terror campaign against civilians in the Democratic Republic of Congos Kivu region. The rebel, Callixte Mbarushimana, who fled Rwanda, was living in Paris as a political refugee until the French police arrested him in October.

title: New Seating Chart, but Same Divides
description: WASHINGTON  It was a new day in Congress. Or at least a new night. In a powerful break with tradition, lawmakers crossed party lines to sit Republican and Democrat, side by side, as the president addressed them.

title: Video of Open Door on Moving Train Shakes Metro-North
description: Icy weather can be a challenge for the decades-old commuter trains that run along Metro-Norths New Haven Line. Brakes freeze; motors struggle. Cancellations and delays are common.

title: Lottery Numbers
The Politics of Evasion
description: If you were a visitor from Mars, watching tonights State of the Union address and Paul Ryans Republican response, you would have no reason to think that the looming insolvency of our entitlement system lies at the heart of the economic challenges facing the United States over the next two decades. From President Obama, we heard a reasonably eloquent case for center-left technocracy and industrial policy, punctuated by a few bipartisan flourishes, in which the entitlement issue felt like an afterthought: He took note of the problem, thanked his own fiscal commission for their work without endorsing any of their recommendations, made general, detail-free pledges to keep Medicare and Social Security solvent (but without slashing benefits for future generations), and then moved swiftly on to the case for tax reform. Tax reform is important, of course, and so are education and technological innovation and infrastructure and all the other issues that the president touched on in this speech. But it was still striking that in an address organized around the theme of American competitiveness, which ran to almost 7,000 words and lasted for an hour, the president spent almost as much time talking about solar power as he did about the roots of the nations fiscal crisis.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 25
description: The day in sports from Australian Open tennis to Asian Cup soccer.

title: Some Difficulties Unnoted, And Some Facts Shaded
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas State of the Union address was chock-full of the sort of simple declarative statements that make him one of the most engaging political orators of his generation. But gauging the accuracy of those statements is not quite so straightforward, and some of the points in his speech shaded facts to help deliver his desired political message.

title: Who Sat Where: The State of the Union Seating Chart
description: Many lawmakers broke the tradition of sitting with their own parties at the State of the Union address.

title: Phys Ed: Does Platelet-Rich Plasma Therapy Really Work?
description: Tiger Woods, Chris Canty (a defensive tackle for the New York Giants)and the Phillies pitcher Cliff Lee have in the past year or so greatly boosted the popularity of a controversial therapy by employing it to combat a sore knee (Woods), hamstring (Canty) and abdomen (Lee). The treatment, platelet-rich plasma therapy, or P.R.P., involves centrifuging a persons own blood until it contains a concentrated mix of plasma cells and growth factors and then injecting the resulting substance directly into the injured tissue. In theory, the distilled growth factors (a protein or substance that helps stimulate growth) should speed healing and improve the tissues health, which has happened in the lab. When scientists surgically created lesions in animal tendons and other tissues, P.R.P. therapy nudged the injured tissues to rapidly create new collagen and blood vessels. Meanwhile, testimonials from professional athletes suggested that the shots work in humans as well. Today, recreational athletes reportedly clamor for P.R.P. to treat everything from tennis elbow to back pain, even though the procedure rarely is covered by insurance and can cost $1,000 a shot. It has buzz, said Dennis Cardone, a clinical associate professor at New York Universitys Langone Medical Center who has written about the use of P.R.P. in sports medicine.

title: The Six-Year Blueprint
description: Date night, they called this State of the Union address. Here was a chance for a large and unruly freshman class to make a good first impression, for jaded seniors to hold hands across the aisle, and for the skinny president to prove hes more than a nerdy know-it-all.

description: RENO, Nev.  Here in Harry Reids Nevada, President Obamas speech was greeted with avid applause and a last-moment standing ovation by a partisan crowd who said they were sick of the tenor of legislating some 2,275 miles to the east.

description: Images from President Obamas 2011 address to Congress and the nation.

title: Remarks That Touch Not Just One City
description: TUCSON  The shooting rampage here drew an early mention in Tuesdays State of the Union address, with President Obama saying, Tucson reminded us that no matter who we are or where we come from, each of us is a part of something greater  something more consequential than party or political preference.

description: Doctors on Tuesday night upgraded Congresswoman Gabrielle Giffordss medical condition from serious to good, and announced they planned to move her from intensive care to a rehabilitation unit as early as Wednesday morning.

description: Mark Bittman shows how to make no-knead bread.

description: OMAHA  A recall attempt has become something of a rite of passage for those chosen to lead this city, where voters have sometimes treated the mayoralty like a temp job.

description: TOKYO  Toyota will fix about 1.7 million vehicles globally in two separate recalls over defective fuel lines and high-pressure fuel pumps, the Japanese automaker said Wednesday, drawing renewed attention to the quality of the companys products.

description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Kari Kokka at Math for America from the article Joint Replacements Keep Dogs in the Running.

title: Lehman Brothers Amends Bankruptcy Plan
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings proposed a new plan for divvying up billions of dollars among its creditors and offered a bigger payment to bondholders, provided they sign on, Reuters reports.

title: Protesters in Egypt Defy Ban as Government Cracks Down
description: CAIRO  The Egyptian government intensified efforts to crush a fresh wave of protests on Wednesday, banning public gatherings, detaining hundreds of people and sending police officers to scatter protesters who defied the ban and demanded an end to the government of President Hosni Mubarak.

title: Flavors Seen but Untasted
description: Alan Wang has always considered New York a place best explored through its food. Its a canvas of ethnic neighborhoods, home to thousands of restaurants, thousands of flavors.

title: Davos: Questioned, but Well Attended
description: A certain weariness is discernible in the tone of reports filed from the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, this week.

title: As Europe Toils on Debt, U.S. and Japan Watch Nervously
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  The fiscal crisis in Europe may be only the beginning.

title: China Leader Encourages Criticism of Government
description: SHANGHAI  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao is known for his populist approach and near constant presence in Chinese headlines. He often races to the scene of natural disasters to comfort survivors. On state-run television, he can be seen eating with the poor in rural villages. Though often stage-managed by Chinese news media, his common touch has earned him the nickname Grandpa Wen.

title: Q. and A. With Running Back DeMarco Murray
description: DeMarco Murray burst onto the national scene his freshman year at the University of Oklahoma with his big-play athleticism. Although a torn hamstring as a sophomore and minor injuries as a junior forced Murray to miss six games as well as a chance to play in the B.C.S. title game, he still ranks sixth in career yardage among Oklahoma runners and he owns the schools all-purpose yards record. Murray sat down with the Footballguys.com staff writer Matt Waldman after the first day of Senior Bowl practices this week to talk about the craft of playing running back.

title: In Paris, a Gathering of Circus Greats
description: The International Circus of Tomorrow at Cirque Phnix (Pelouse de Reuilly; 33-1-45-72-10-00; www.cirquephenix.com), from Jan. 27 to 30, offers an enormous display of dazzling acrobatic feats and hilarious clown acts, performed by hundreds of young artists from around in the world.

title: After Months of Turmoil, Karzai Opens Parliament
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In a victory for lawmakers, President Hamid Karzai inaugurated the National Assembly on Wednesday, ending months of delays but only partly settling the controversy and recriminations over the September parliamentary elections, which were fraught with charges of widespread fraud.

title: Glencore Weighs I.P.O. in London and Hong Kong
description: Glencore International, the global commodities trader, is considering an initial public offering in the first half of this year with a dual listing in London and Hong Kong that could amount to as much as $10 billion, a person with knowledge of the matter said on Wednesday.

title: As Protests Mount, Tunisia Delays Cabinet Reshuffle
description: TUNIS  A standoff between street protesters and the Tunisian authorities deepened on Wednesday as officials first promised and then postponed a reshuffling of the interim government that has been clinging to power since the ouster of the former dictator, Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali.

title: A Guide to Houses No Gentleman Would Dare to Frequent
description: Encyclopedic in breadth but compact enough for the vest pocket of a 19th-century gentleman on the go, the book was an insiders guide to Manhattan, easily picked up at the newsstand before a night on the town, much the way tourists and local residents now consult a guidebook when they are in the mood for a memorable restaurant or meal.

title: An Incubator That Turns Laid Off Workers Into Entrepreneurs
description: Terri Maxwell uses the term reluctant entrepreneurs to describe the budding business owners she coaches through Succeed on Purpose, the business incubator she founded in Las Colinas, Tex. The incubator is intended for former employees, most of them forced from corporate jobs by layoffs, looking to recast themselves as entrepreneurs. The transition requires them to embrace a new mindset, said Ms. Maxwell, who has long enjoyed being her own boss.

title: Fantasy Football Accuracy Rankings for 2010
description: Sara Holladay is the Fantasy Football Librarian.

title: TV Watch: Michele Bachmanns Rogue Rebuttal Defies Unity Theme
description: Representative Michele Bachmann, a Tea Party leader, didnt bring a prom date to the State of the Union address, she didnt wear the ribbon corsage and she crashed the after-party known as the official Republican response. When Ms. Bachmann, Republican of Minnesota, addressed the nation with her own, more alarmist assessment of its state, she seemed almost like the telekinetic high school heroine of Carrie.

title: For Andy Murray, Shes More Than Just a Mother
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Judy Murray was there in the front row for her son as he advanced to the Australian Open semifinals on Wednesday, just as she was there at the beginning when Andy Murrays tennis matches were often played against his older brother in the living room of the family home in Dunblane, Scotland.

title: California, U.S. Agree on Emissions-Standards Announcement Date
description: The Environmental Protection Agency, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration and the California Air Resources Board  the three agencies with primary responsibility for setting the next round of standards on fuel economy and greenhouse gas emissions for cars and light-duty trucks  have agreed to announce their proposals for 2017-25 model-year vehicles by Sept. 1, 2011, according to an E.P.A. press release issued on Monday.

title: Loss Ends Nadals Bid to Hold All Four
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  It would have been tough enough to win a fourth consecutive Grand Slam title if Rafael Nadal had remained the picture of health.

title: Q&A: Imperiled Birds on a Warming Planet
description: A few days ago I wrote about the risk of mass extinctions from impending climate change over the next century, especially among animals that live high on mountains or in the tropics. They will have difficulty moving themselves to cooler climates, either because they cannot move up in altitude or because the distance from the tropics to a cooler habitat is simply farther than they can travel.

title: Last Word From Welker on Ryan Remarks: Regret
description: The Jets appeared to win the battle of words with New England before their upset victory in the divisional round, and Patriots receiver Wes Welker has now admitted as much.

description: The Dow Jones industrial average rose above 12,000 for the first time in nearly three years on Wednesday  for a moment or two, at least.

title: Importance of Being Earnest To Run Through July 3
description: Lady Bracknell would consider this decision quite proper indeed. Roundabout Theater Company is extending the run of The Importance of Being Earnest on Broadway by an unusually long 17 weeks, until July 3, following wide critical acclaim for the production, directed by and starring Brian Bedford as Lady Bracknell, an imperious arbiter of British taste and manners.

title: HighNote App Spruces Up Messages
description: Mobile phone users who want to stay in touch with friends and share their favorite song often find e-mail, instant messaging and texting to be imperfect choices. Each has its shortcomings, whether it is an overloaded in-box or a Spartan appearance.

description: Something, be it snow, rain or ice pellets, will fall from the clouds on Wednesday, and temperatures should hover around the mid-30s. Be ready for a rough commute this evening.

description: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn on Wednesday extended his offer to buy Dynegy  by two weeks after finding little support among the energy companys shareholders during the initial period.

title: The Non-Nurturing Approach to Childrens Art

title: Tiger Mother in Stephen Colberts Den
Tiger Mother in Stephen Colberts Den
description: It was only a matter of time before Amy Chua, the author of Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother and proponent of a much discussed method of child rearing that emphasizes hard work, limits social interaction and includes the occasional threat to burn a stuffed animal, made her way onto The Colbert Report. On Tuesdays broadcast the host, Stephen Colbert, recapped for his audience the controversy that has swirled around Ms. Chuas book and offered some advice to viewers who might be the children of tiger mothers. (Get back to that Mendelssohn concerto before she drowns your bunny!)

title: Profit Slips as Boeing Delivers Fewer Planes
description: Boeing predicted that its profit in 2011 would fall below analysts estimates, mainly because of higher pension expenses and delays in finishing the 787 Dreamliner, setting off a 3 percent decline in its share price.

title: Separated at Birth?

One of my commenters claims that Representative Ryan is a dead ringer for the evil representative of The Phone Company from The Presidents Analyst (one of my favorite good-bad movies too). [It explains your utter lack of hostility. You can vent your aggressive feelings by actually killing people! Its a sensational solution to the hostility problem. ]

title: British Regulator Fines Barclays

title: Defeated Ivory Coast Leader Moves to Seize Banks
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Openly defying its West African neighbors, the government of Laurent Gbagbo, the Ivory Coast strongman who is increasingly short of cash in the face of international sanctions, says it will seize local branches of the regions central bank.

title: In Queens, a Lament That the Borough Is Shortchanged

title: The Value of the Oscar Bump
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Just how much is an Oscar nomination worth? Filmmakers, artists and publicists might answer that its priceless in terms of reputation. But studio heads, agents and producers would prefer to put a very specific figure on it. The research firm IBISWorld crunched the numbers and found that the average best Picture Oscar winners over the last four years saw a bump of 22.2 percent (or $20.3 million) in box office revenue after they were named a nominee and an additional 15.3 percent (or $14.0 million) following their win at the award show, according to data the firm put out. (Simon Beaufoy was right: a nomination is more significant, financially, than a win.)

title: The President as College Counselor
description: In his State of the Union address, President Obama occasionally adopted the tone of national guidance counselor in advocating for high school and college students and their families.

title: Passengers Pulled to Safety From Smoldering Hudson Ferry
description: Updated, 1:31 p.m. A Hudson River ferryboat that helped rescue passengers from a ditched jetliner needed some rescuing itself on Wednesday when it began smoldering shortly after leaving the dock at Edgewater, N.J.

title: Writer-for-Hire Gets a Book Deal to Write About Helping Students Cheat
description: When an anonymous pen-for-hire wrote a tell-all article in The Chronicle of Higher Education about his booming career writing papers for cheating undergraduate and graduate students it caused a stir across college campuses. Now Bloomsbury USA has signed the writer, who lives on the East Coast and uses the pen name Ed Dante, for a book about cheating in higher education. He has quit his job to work on the project and plans to reveal his identity when the book is published in 2012.

title: SMARTwheel Earns N.H. Children a Beltway Audience
description: Tackling distracted driving is a matter of national debate, but few would expect six home-schooled children from Londonderry, N.H., to propose a solution so promising theyve already met with President Obama and Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood.

title: The Insider | Olivia Chantecaille
description: By all appearances, Olivia Chantecaille is living a charmed life. A society fixture, the 36-year-old divides her time between New York, East Hampton, Paris, Capri and other envy-inducing locales. In 2009, she wed a hedge fund trader named Warren G. Grady III on St. Barts, wearing a custom-made Giambattista Valli gown. When shes not bouncing around the social circuit or promoting her familys botanical-based cosmetics in stores around the world, Chantecaille is engaged in a variety of charitable pursuits, many of which are in support of the arts. And her privileged perch has informed her taste  in everything from finding the best coffee in Amagansett, N.Y., to avoiding super-shiny face on the red carpet.

title: Obama Ducks and Covers on Climate
description: The C-word, climate, appears to have become to the Beltway whatthe P-word, population, has been in climate treaty negotiations for a long time  unmentionable.

title: The Professional Oddsmakers Move In
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Only moments after the Oscar nominations were announced the Baggers fellow pundits began speculating about who would prevail. Original Screenplay: its over, people. The Kings Speech wins, the blogger Sasha Stone wrote on Twitter. She also predicted that Inception, whose director, Christopher Nolan, was snubbed in his category, will win for art direction, visual effects, sound and sound editing, and that, among documentaries, another category with a lot of cold-shoulders, Inside Job would triumph. Cake walk, she wrote.

title: Man (In This Case, Picasso) Paints Dog
description: When forgotten Picassos arent turning up in the most unlikely places, theyre depicting the most unlikely subjects. A piece of dinnerware he painted on and gave to the photojournalist David Douglas Duncan, which Mr. Duncan has donated to the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas at Austin, may not compare to the cache of nearly 300 works that a French electrician says he was given by Picassos second wife. But the plate is noteworthy for what it depicts: a dachshund named Lump, owned by Mr. Duncan in the 1950s.

title: After 60 Years, a Promise Kept to Sinclair Lewis
description: CARPINTERIA, Calif.  The last time Barnaby Conrad saw Sinclair Lewis, three years after he served as Lewiss personal secretary, they were at a bar in Paris and, by Mr. Conrads account, Lewis was thoroughly drunk. But not so drunk that he couldnt chastise his former secretary for failing to execute a book idea that Lewis had handed him one morning at breakfast: a novel based on the conceit that John Wilkes Booth had escaped capture after assassinating Lincoln and had embarked on a secret life in the American frontier.

title: Anti-Semitic Comments Found Under a Chess Organizers Name

Among the most vitriolic suggested that the time is ripe to build more ovens in EVERY country in the world for the D-DAY.

Included are portions of the Codex Sinaiticus, a handwritten manuscript of the Christian Bible written in the middle of the fourth century; Galileos letters; Leonardo da Vincis notebooks; the original version of Alices Adventures in Wonderland, and Jane Austens teenage writings.

Nixon electrified the world by visiting the vast, mysterious Communist bastion of Mao Zedongs China in 1972, Malraux said it would take 50 years to sort out what had happened there.

title: Language of the Union
description: President Obamas state of the union speech was eloquently prosaic. The rhetoric did not soar; and the speechs force was carried by short, repeated phrases that served to tie together themes and exhortations. Win the future served both as an organizing device and a call to arms. But the arms were, in the grand scheme of things, small  high-speed railways, more teachers, a better and faster Internet. These are not inconsiderable goals, but they dont have the ring of bringing peace to the Middle East, a hope not even mentioned.

title: At Resorts, Spas Just for the Kids
description: Spas at huge winter resorts are nothing new. But dont be surprised if the next time you walk into the one at Stowe Mountain Resort in Vermont, you see a youngster getting a massage. In late December, Stowe (802-253-3560; stowemountainlodge.com) opened the Chillax KidSpa, a relaxation room for children inside the 21,000-square-foot (adult) spa. Children of any age are allowed treatments at the spa proper, when accompanied by an adult.

title: In Hubbles Lens, Signs of a Galaxy Older and Farther Than Any Other
description: Leapfrogging into the past with the refurbished Hubble Space Telescope, a team of astronomers says it has detected what may be the most distant and earliest galaxy yet found. It is a smudge of light only a tiny fraction of the size of our own Milky Way galaxy, and it existed when the universe was only 480 million years old. Its light has been on its way to us for 13.2 billion years, making it the long-distance champion in an expanding universe.

title: Powder Trip | Alta, Wyo.
description: Alta, Wyo., near the Idaho border, is home to the Grand Targhee ski resort, just about an hour from its more famous neighbor, Jackson Hole. The distinction between the two resorts is a bit like the Montauk and Hamptons divide Targhee is more rustic and lacks the high-wattage lodging of Jackson Hole. While the Four Seasons and the Amangani are both in Jackson, the most deluxe sleeping option near Targhee is the Teton Springs Resort (877-787-8757, 10 Warm Creak Lane) in Victor, Idaho.

Bradley Manning  the Army intelligence analyst who is accused of leaking hundreds of thousands of classified documents to WikiLeaks  on suicide watch.
