title: Dealing With Assange and the WikiLeaks Secrets
description: This past June, Alan Rusbridger, the editor of The Guardian, phoned me and asked, mysteriously, whether I had any idea how to arrange a secure communication. Not really, I confessed. The Times doesnt have encrypted phone lines, or a Cone of Silence. Well then, he said, he would try to speak circumspectly. In a roundabout way, he laid out an unusual proposition: an organization called WikiLeaks, a secretive cadre of antisecrecy vigilantes, had come into possession of a substantial amount of classified United States government communications. WikiLeakss leader, Julian Assange, an eccentric former computer hacker of Australian birth and no fixed residence, offered The Guardian half a million military dispatches from the battlefields of Afghanistan and Iraq. There might be more after that, including an immense bundle of confidential diplomatic cables. The Guardian suggested  to increase the impact as well as to share the labor of handling such a trove  that The New York Times be invited to share this exclusive bounty. The source agreed. Was I interested?

title: Arthur Rubinstein Dies in Geneva at 95
description: Arthur Rubinstein, one of the greatest pianists of the century, died quietly in his sleep at his home in Geneva yesterday. He was 95 years old.

title: Jerome Kern Dies; Noted Composer, 60
description: Jerome Kern, the composer, died yesterday at 1:10 P.M. of a cerebral hemorrhage in Doctors Hospital. His age was 60. At the bedside were his wife, Eva Leale Kern; his daughter, Elizabeth Kern, former wife of Artie Shaw, the bandleader, and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, producer and song writer, who was closely associated with Mr. Kern in his career. Shortly after Mr. Kern's death Irving Berlin called at the hospital.

title: Henin Says She Is Retiring for Good With Elbow Injury

Robert Frost Dies At 88; Kennedy Leads In
Tribute
description: Boston, Jan. 29 -- Robert Frost, dean of American poets, died today at the age of 88.

title: President M'Kinley's Illustrious Career
description: William McKinley, the twenty-fifth President of the United States, was born in Niles, Trumbull Country, Ohio, on Jan. 29, 1843. His father, William McKinley, Sr., came to Ohio from Pennsylvania. The family was Scotch-Irish, and the President's forefathers came to America 150 years ago.

title: Hong Kong Denies Entry to 2 Tiananmen Protesters
description: HONG KONG  Two leaders of the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests said Wednesday that they had been denied entry to Hong Kong to attend the funeral on Saturday of Szeto Wah, a founder of the territorys democracy movement.

title: Jackie Robinson, First Black in Major Leagues, Dies

title: Closing Schools Have Most Challenging Demographics

title: Can India Leapfrog China?

The country has brought the single biggest delegation to Davos and ads for its Inclusive Growth slogan could be seen not just in the conference center but on public buses in Davos.

title: Category Confusion, Cleared Up
description: PARK CITY, Utah  The top questions that the Bagger received after the Oscar nominations were announced yesterday were not Dear lord, whatever will you wear? and What would it look like if children acted out the best picture nominees? Rather, they were Why is Hailee Steinfeld nominated as a best supporting actress, and not best actress, and Why was Toy Story 3 considered for best adapted screenplay, and not for best original screenplay?

title: After Hit-Run, Man Is Found Stuffed in Car Trunk

title: Fed to Continue Bond-Buying Program
description: WASHINGTON  Federal Reserve policy makers voted unanimously on Wednesday to continue the central banks $600 billion plan to spur the recovery by buying government bonds.

title: New Investigation of Tabloid Phone Hacking
description: Updated | 3:36 p.m. Citing significant new information obtained from Rupert Murdochs News International on Wednesday about allegations that journalists at a British tabloid newspaper, The News of the World, had illegally hacked into the voice mail accounts of celebrities in 2005 and 2006, Londons Metropolitan Police Service announced that it had begun a new investigation of the matter.

title: New York State Seizes Finances of Nassau County
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  A state oversight board on Wednesday seized control of Nassau Countys finances, saying the county, one of the nations wealthiest and most heavily taxed, had nonetheless failed to balance its $2.7 billion budget.

title: Common Application Wont Add Questions on Sexual Orientation
description: The online publication Inside Higher Ed is reporting that the board overseeing the Common Application has rejected a proposal to add optional questions on sexual orientation and gender identity.

title: Artifacts | Kai Althoffs Crash Pad
description: The Barbara Gladstone Gallery has vanished. Well, not really. Its still at its usual location in Chelsea, but now its a walk-in painting.

title: Warily Eyeing Egypt, Israelis Feel Like Spectators
description: JERUSALEM  After the Tunisian revolution and the emergence of a Hezbollah-backed government in Lebanon, Israelis are confronting another jolt to the system as mass protests rock Egypt, the partner in Israels oldest and most important Middle East relationship.

title: Dutch Lawmakers Question Shell on Oil Pollution in Nigeria
description: Royal Dutch Shell officials faced tough questions from Dutch lawmakers on Wednesday over pollution from its oil operations in Nigeria at a conference convened in the Netherlands to shed light on the oil giants dealings in the West African country.

title: Metropolitan Museum Purchases Work By Student of Raphael
description: A large and intricate Renaissance drawing by Perino del Vaga, one of Raphaels pupils, was bought by the Metropolitan Museum of Art at Sothebys on Wednesday morning.

title: Critiquing Executive Limousines Web Site
description: Last week, we asked, Whats Wrong With Executive Limousines Web Site?

title: Born Yesterday Has a Theater and Sets an Opening Night
description: The Broadway revival of Born Yesterday, starring Jim Belushi and Nina Arianda, will start previews on March 31 at the Cort Theater, with opening night set for April 24, the shows producers announced today.

title: Comments by Imprisoned Russian Tycoon Challenge Medvedev
description: MOSCOW  The rebuttal to this years keynote speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, by President Dmitri A. Medvedev seemed to come from behind bars back in Russia.

title: An Argument for Pet Self-Insurance
description: Keeping a pet healthy can be expensive. But is it worth buying insurance to cover those expenses?

title: How to Choose an Incubator
description: IN 1956, a hardware store manager named Joseph Mancuso converted an abandoned 850,000-square-foot manufacturing complex in Batavia, N.Y., into a new kind of facility he called the Batavia Industrial Center.

title: Full-Service Gyms Feel a Bit Flabby
description: IS the gym pass?

title: Even More Productive Than Americans
description: There are enough different definitions of productivity that President Obama can claim, as he did last night, that American workers are the most productive in the world. The International Labor Organization, for instance, reported that the United States had the highest labor productivity  measured as economic output per employed person  of any country in 2008.

title: Looking for Cheaper Gasoline, Without the Drive
description: Years ago, I stopped driving around in search of better gasoline prices because the treks cost more money in wasted gas than they were worth.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Egypt, Afghanistan, Tunisia and Haiti.

title: A Blot on Lincoln Historians
description: These facts remain true: on April 14, 1864, President Abraham Lincoln sent a routine, one-sentence, handwritten order to Joseph Holt, the judge advocate general, pardoning a California soldier, Private Patrick Murphy, who had been sentenced to be shot for desertion. This man is pardoned, and hereby ordered to be discharged from the service, the president wrote.

title: Chamber of Commerce and A.F.L.-C.I.O. Praise Obama
description: Two men who hardly agree on anything  the president of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, Tom Donohue, and the president of the A.FL-C.I.O., Richard Trumka  have issued a joint statement praising President Obamas call for new infrastructure.

title: Court Reverses New Mexico Governor on Environmental Rules
description: The New Mexico Supreme Courts rebuke to Susana Martinez, the states new governor was blunt. No one is above the law, the states chief justice, Charles W. Daniels, said Wednesday morning as he announced the high courts decision to reinstate two environmental regulations that the governor had unilaterally blocked upon taking office earlier this month.

title: Banks Prepare to Compete for Ally Financial Stock Sale
description: Another week, another bake-off for a company majority-owned by the government.

title: Theater Talkback: A Master Class With Christine Ebersole, a Singer of Many Voices
description: Ever since last Saturday night  well, around the time Saturday night turned into Sunday morning  Ive been hearing voices. One of them is a clear, righteous soprano that recalls Joan Baez, the balladeer of my childhood; another is a lilting, silvery curlicue like that of the soubrette in an operetta from the gaslight era; then theres the sassy Hello, boys trumpet of a girl singer with a big band; and, most hauntingly, theres the glasslike voice that seems to exist expressly as a container for the shimmering pain within.

title: When Childrens Art Takes Over the Home
description: Parents who resist clutter make the tough call in throwing away their childrens artwork.

title: All Smiles: Studying the Science of Smiling and Related Behaviors
description: Overview  | What is a smile, and what can scientists learn from studying smiling? In this lesson, students learn about the science of smiling and explore related research in cognitive science and evolutionary biology. They experiment with interpreting different types of smiles and then design experiments of their own to further explore how people use and respond to communicative expressions and gestures.

title: Skins Loses Advertisers  and Viewers
description: The second episode of MTVs Skins suffered a dramatic drop in the ratings this week, to 1.6 million viewers from 3.3 million the prior week, as a half-dozen advertisers publicly distanced themselves from the provocative new drama series.

title: Gabriel Stulman, Restaurateur, and a Bit of Wisconsin
description: NEW York has a Little Italy, a Little Tokyo, even a Little Pakistan. And if the restaurateur Gabriel Stulman gets his way, there may soon be a Little Wisco  as in Wisconsin  added to the mix.

title: Palins PAC Raised $279,000 in Late 2010
description: SarahPAC, the leadership committee of former Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska, said in its latest fund-raising report on Wednesday with the Federal Election Commission that it brought in $279,000 from Nov. 23 to Dec. 31, 2010.

title: Stirring Up a Family From Scratch
description: LAST year the writer Jon Robin Baitz removed his five-character family drama Other Desert Cities from Broadways 2010-11 lineup and took it off Broadway to Lincoln Center Theater, which had produced several of his works, including The Substance of Fire and Ten Unknowns. Among the reasons? He and his director, Joe Mantello, could choose the actors they wanted rather than face the Broadway pressure of casting household names.

title: Next Premier of Lebanon Tries to Steer Own Course
description: BEIRUT  Najib Mikati, a billionaire backed by Hezbollah to become prime minister of Lebanon, promised on Wednesday to forge good relations with the United States and declared that he would not interfere with an international tribunal expected to accuse members of Hezbollah of involvement in the assassination of a former prime minister.

title: Lion Meat Tacos Will Not Be on the Menu
description: Last week The Arizona Daily Star reported that a Tucson restaurant that specializes in exotic meats was taking pre-orders for African lion tacos that would be served in mid-February.

title: France Replaces Envoy to Tunisia
description: FRANCE REPLACES ENVOY TO TUNISIA

title: Pitcher Spurns $12 Million, to Keep Self-Respect
description: The guaranteed contract is a fundamental principle of Major League Baseball, as much a part of the game as balls, strikes and outs. No matter how a player performs, or how his body holds up, he must be paid in full. Only in rare cases  an injury sustained off the field, gross personal misconduct  does a player forfeit his paycheck.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Egypt, Afghanistan, Tunisia and Haiti.

title: Quote Unquote | Black and Blue is the New Black
description: Diane von Furstenberg tells W.W.D. about the skiing accident that left her with a broken nose. At least she doesnt look like Mike Tysons opponent.

title: Ask Baghdad Bureau: Reader Q. and A.
description: Steven Lee Myers, The Timess Baghdad bureau chief, is leaving his post after two years. He is taking questions from readers, looking at the changes he has seen in Iraq and weighing in on the scheduled December 2011 deadline for the withdrawal of American troops, the fragility of the Iraqi coalition government and the future role of key players like Moktada al-Sadr. He also addresses the mood on the ground among an Iraqi populace disenchanted with its own political leaders, witnessing political turmoil in the region around them. Here, he and Alissa J. Rubin, the Kabul bureau chief, discuss President Obamas State of the Union address, as seen from Baghdad and Kabul. Post questions for Mr. Myers in the comment section below.

title: TimesCast | January 26, 2011
description: Protesters in Egypt oppose President Mubarak, an American ally for three decades; President Medvedev of Russia makes a quick trip to Davos after the suicide bombing; and the costume designers behind "Black Swan."

title: For Your Files, Lots of Room In the Cloud
description: In the old days of computing, you could carry only as many files as you had floppy disks. Then came hard drives and thumb drives, allowing those so inclined to carry entire digital encyclopedias in their pockets. Finally, thanks to new services that store data in the cloud, yet another stage of storage evolution (maybe the final one) has been reached: the celestial hard drive, a storage medium that exists solely in the electronic ether.

title: Days of Raptor Rapture
description: Perhaps weve become hawk-obsessed on City Room, but were not alone. A few days after we wrote about the juvenile red-tailed hawk who injured his wing banging into the glass-walled atrium at New York Times headquarters, a reader sent us a video of a red-tailed eating an unidentified bird. Our new intern Jason Tomassini followed suit with a hawk-vs-pigeon video on Tuesday (spoiler: hawk wins).

title: Packers Have the Statistic of the Year
description: Jason Lisk of the Big Lead unearthed this nugget earlier this week: The Packers havent trailed by more than 7 points at any point this season.

title: Concerns Persist Over Europes Debt Crisis
description: Virginia Mayo/Associated PressNouriel Roubini of New York University sees big risks in the euro zone.

title: A Filmmakers View of the Runway
description: WHAT Miuccia Prada said she saw on the runway of her spring Miu Miu collection was a pervasive cultural obsession with becoming famous, to which she made pointed reference by playing audio snippets from American Idol and Dancing With the Stars.

title: Steam-Powered Racer to Make Run at Land-Speed Record
description: On Tuesday, Cyclone Power Technologies of Pompano Beach, Fla., announced that it would attempt to break the land-speed record for an unlikely race class: steam cars.

title: The David in the Foreign-Language Race
description: To look at the companies behind the five films nominated for best foreign-language film is to see a study in contrasts. At one extreme is Sony Pictures Classics, which has a long and savvy history of discovering, distributing and marketing Oscar nominees and winners, among them The Lives of Others. This year it has corralled two of the five slots: the Danish entry In A Better World and Incendies from Canada.

title: What Does a Donors Money Buy at UConn?
description: The University of Connecticut finds itself in a very public fight with a major donor to its football program, who has demanded the return of $3 million in donations because he is furious that he was not consulted enough on the search for a new coach.

title: Tucson Suspect Studied Assassins, Officials Say
description: TUCSON  Jared L. Loughner, the man accused of opening fire outside a Tucson supermarket on Jan. 8 in what the authorities consider an attempted political assassination, researched famous assassins, the death penalty and solitary confinement on the Internet before the shooting, an official close to the investigation said Wednesday.

title: Asian Cup: Bad News for Japan, Worse News for Dortmund
description: 4:52 p.m. | Updated  On Thursday, Dortmund said that Kagawa would indeed miss the rest of the Bundesliga season after an examination in Duisburg revealed he will require an operation on his injured foot.

title: Beauty Spots
description: RED MENACE Those with pale or sensitive skin (or both) usually have facial redness at some point, because of dryness, the cold, nerves or allergies. SkinMedica Redness Relief CalmPlex ($80), available next month at skinmedica.com and in some dermatologists offices, is said to improve this condition, as well as overall skin tone, with ingredients like vitamin B-3, jojoba oil and squalane.

title: Fixing Reminders in Microsoft Outlook
BBC, Facing Budget Cuts, Will Trim World Service and Lay Off 650
description: LONDON  Facing a 16 percent reduction in its budget, the BBC World Service said on Wednesday that it would close 5 of its 32 language services and reduce its work force by about a quarter, cutting around 650 jobs over the next three years.

title: At Forum, Medvedev Seeks to Reassure Foreign Investors
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia on Wednesday defended his efforts to modernize the country, in a speech intended to reassure foreign investors after a deadly attack at a Moscow airport renewed concerns about social unrest.

title: Gil Meches Legacy
description: Lou Piniella was the Seattle Mariners manager in the summer of 1999, when Catfish Hunter died. Piniella took leave from the team to attend Hunters funeral in North Carolina, and while he was there, he asked his old teammate Ron Guidry about a 20-year-old pitcher on Piniellas staff.

title: Face Time | Lily Rabe
description: Tina Turnbow is a professional makeup artist, who is known for lending her celebrity clients editorial polish.

title: C.B.O. Director Appointed for Full Term
description: The director of the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office, Douglas W. Elmendorf, has been appointed to a full four-year term by the House speaker, John A. Boehner of Ohio, and the Senate president pro tempore, Daniel K. Inouye of Hawaii, officials announced on Wednesday.

title: Jean Paul Gaultier: Black Magic
description: From his first haute couture collections, in the mid-90s, Jean Paul Gaultier has given a name to each outfit, usually indicating the mood we might expect. Today, when I looked at his run-of-show and saw names like Le Chat Noir, Punk Is Not Dead and Moulin Rouge, naturally I figured we were in for a punk moment with nicer fishnets.

title: Oil Dispersants Lingered in Deep Ocean, Scientists Say
description: A crucial component of the chemical dispersant applied to oil gushing from BPs blown-out well in the Gulf of Mexico last year did not break down as fast as scientists initially expected and probably remains at detectable levels in the deep ocean, scientists said on Wednesday.

title: Multidimensional Europe
description: One thing I tend to see in comments  especially from our resident troll, but from others as well  is an insistence that economies must be either all good or all bad. They seem to think that you cant say good things about European employment performance and technology, on one side, and talk about the monetary and fiscal mess, on the other.

title: Army Trauma Units Woes Detailed
description: The Army units created to provide special care for wounded soldiers after the Walter Reed Army Medical Center scandal continue to struggle with short staffing, inadequate training and an overabundance of prescription medications, a report by the Army inspector generals office said.

title: Q&A: A Mid-Priced Cruise With High-End Service
description: Cruising has always seemed fascinating to us because of the elegant meals and treatment advertised by the top cruise lines. However, we are daunted by the prices charged by these top-of-the-line carriers and would prefer something a little less expensive. Our problem is that the less expensive cruise lines seem to feature huge size, very active sports programs and dance-all-night activities. In other words, they are not so elegant. Could you suggest some middle-priced cruise lines that dont cost an arm and a leg but manage to provide high-end dining and service? We are willing to go anywhere: Caribbean, Mediterranean, Asia.

title: Ins and Outs of Calling via the Net
description: This weeks e-mail bag brought a note that echoes the sentiments of many others:

title: Stay One Minute Longer to Get the Picture
description: Diana Markosian was born in Moscow and lived there until she was 9. She graduated from the University of Oregon and was a freelance journalist in China and Russia. In 2009, at the Columbia Journalism School, a professor introduced her to photography. Her pictures have since appeared in The Guardian and Vanity Fair and on Reuters. Now 21, she is back in Moscow. Her conversation with Kerri MacDonald for Turning Point has been condensed.

title: Haute Couture: Jean Paul Gaultier
description: This was one of the most imaginative, uplifting Gaultier performances weve been treated to in a while.

title: A Golden Age of Foreign Films, Mostly Unseen
description: ONE of the few surprises at the Golden Globes two weeks ago  youll be forgiven if youve already forgotten about that odd little broadcast  was the award given to Carlos, the French director Olivier Assayass five-hour-plus reconstruction of the life and career of the notorious terrorist of the 1970s and 80s Carlos the Jackal. The award represented a high point of cosmopolitanism at a predictably parochial event: 11 languages spoken on screen; dozens of locations across Europe and the Middle East; a polyglot cast led by a Venezuelan star, dgar Ramrez, who has the potential to become an international sex symbol. What more could you want from a foreign film?

title: Britain Proposes Easing Detentions in Terror Cases
description: LONDON  For years, Britain has struggled with its own version of the American debate over the prison at Guantnamo: how best to deal with individuals regarded as terrorist threats who cannot readily be brought to trial, usually because of concern that relevant evidence would compromise intelligence sources.

title: Shopping for Wall Coverings With Barbara Bestor
description: The architect and author of Bohemian Modern shopped for wall coverings with warm colors and bold patterns.

title: Ripples From the Cellphones Splash
description: The cellphone is beginning to have the kind of impact on industry that has been seen with only a few products, like the car or big kitchen appliances. The ripple effect showed up this week in a number of corporate earnings reports.

title: Backstage at 'What the Public Wants'
description: A look at the design of the Mint Theater's new production of Arnold Bennett's play. (Video courtesy of Joshua Paul Johnson)

title: Trump Says He and Union Have a Deal on Tavern on the Green
description: Donald J. Trump and the head of the powerful union that represented the 400 workers at Tavern on the Green say they have come to an agreement that could revive the shuttered landmark restaurant that is now home to a food-truck court and a visitor center.

title: Trumps Big Plans for Tavern on the Green
description: Donald J. Trump and the head of the powerful union that represented the 400 workers at Tavern on the Green say they have come to an agreement that would revive the shuttered landmark restaurant in Central Park that is now home to a food-truck court and a visitor center.

title: Sundance Kickstarts Audience Connections
description: LOS ANGELES The Sundance Institute is expanding its efforts to help filmmakers use the Web to find funding and distribution for their work. On Wednesday the organization, best known for its film festival, announced partnerships with Facebook and Kickstarter.com a relatively new site that aids aspiring movie directors, musicians, playwrights and other emerging artists find funding. The goal: to help connect Sundance artists with audiences.

title: Decemberists Reign on Billboard Chart
description: At least three camps will be very happy that the Decemberists, the indie-folk band from Portland, Ore., known for its high-concept songs and SAT-level vocabulary, has reached No. 1 on the latest Billboard album chart: the band and its record company; its fans; and the hand wringers and observers of the music industry who have recently seen two historic lows in an important sales statistic. The Decemberists latest, The King Is Dead (Capitol), sold 94,000 copies in its first week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, sending the album straight to No. 1. Thats a much healthier number than any other album has had recently. Last week the band Cakes Showroom of Compassion (Upbeat) set a record for the fewest sales for a No. 1 album, with 44,000. It beat the record set the week before by Taylor Swifts Speak Now (Big Machine), which had 52,000. The next four slots on the Top 200 this week are taken up by new albums. Kidz Bop 19 (Razor & Tie), the latest album in the Kidz Bop franchise of family-friendly versions of pop hits, opened at No. 2, with 70,000; and Science & Faith (Epic), by the Irish alternative-rock band the Script, bowed at No. 3, with 49,000. Social Distortion, a Los Angeles band that plays rockabilly-tinged punk rock, has reached the Top 10 for the first time in its long career with Hard Times and Nursery Rhymes (Epitaph), at No. 4, with 46,000; and Gregg Allmans new solo album, Low Country Blues (Rounder), bows at No. 5, with 36,000. (Cakes album plunged to No. 25 this week with 15,000 sales, a 67 percent decline.)

title: Footnotes
description: The Roundabout Theater Company is extending the run of The Importance of Being Earnest on Broadway by an unusually long 17 weeks, until July 3, following wide critical acclaim for the production. As a result of the extended run, Roundabout announced that its new musical The People in the Picture, which was to have followed Earnest into the American Airlines Theater this spring, would now be mounted at Studio 54, one of the companys three Broadway houses. ... The Broadway revival of Born Yesterday, starring Jim Belushi and Nina Arianda, is to start previews on March 31 at the Cort Theater, with opening night set for April 24, the shows producers announced.

title: Reclaiming Your Refrigerator: Ideas for Displaying Childrens Art
description: WHY hang childrens art on the refrigerator door? Because its there. And as an exhibition venue, its better than nothing.

title: Couture Scorecard | Chanel Wins!
description: Hey there, Upper East Siders, Scorecard here with further proof that the design values of the Chambre Syndicale members are a-changing. On Tuesday, Riccardo Tisci played curator of his own retrospective before his exquisite 4,000-hours-apiece-to-produce dresses even got off the hanger. Meanwhile, over on the Rue Cambon, Karl Lagerfeld got streetwise, pairing boucltweeds with couture skinny jeans. Blake Lively shall inherit the earth.

title: Oscar Snubs, but Still Room for Surprise
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Ten seems like an awful lot. We dont want to take anyone elses.

title: Onstage or Backstage, a Kiss for Paris
description: Paris

title: Inspired Beauty at the Couture Shows
description: Couture shows this season have been pretty much in touch, with energy and a modern sense of ease.

title: Drawing an Escape From the Chill of Winter
description: January may be the cruelest month for people with serious art gallery habits. It snows, it freezes, it daunts. Still, this week brings alternatives. The Winter Antiques Show is in full swing at the Park Avenue Armory, and armchair art lovers can log onto the VIP Art Fair  which bills itself as the worlds first online version  although apparently its system is so taxed that digital browsing has been at times a challenge.

title: Why Derek Jeter Will Never Leave Shortstop
description: Robin Yount played his last game at shortstop on Sept. 7, 1984, a week before he turned 29 years old. He shifted to the outfield in 1985, when he was still in the prime of his Hall of Fame career.

title: Master Drawings New York 2011
description: The annual show, now in its fifth year, consists of roughly two dozen drawing exhibitions in galleries mostly on or near Madison Avenue.

title: Prone to Subframe Rust, 425,000 Ford Windstars Recalled
description: Ford is recalling about 425,000 of its 1999-2003 Windstar minivans because a front-subframe rust problem could cause steering problems.

title: The Permanent Collection May Not Be So Permanent
description: On Thursday at Sothebys in New York, the Cleveland Museum of Art is putting 32 old-master paintings up for auction, and the J. Paul Getty Museum is offering 15. In the meantime the Pennsylvania Museum of Fine Arts and the Carnegie Museum of Art are selling five paintings each, and the Art Institute of Chicago is selling two Picassos, a Matisse and a Braque at Christies in London. Last week the New Jersey Historical Society sold 17 items at Christies in New York, including a 120-piece dinner service used to entertain President Martin Van Buren that went for $17,000.

title: 2011: Grilled Prime, Dry-Aged Rib-Eye Steak With Savory Crust
description: By Harold Dieterle, the chef and owner of Kin Shop and Perilla in Manhattan.

title: 1966: Rib Roast of Beef
description: This recipe appeared in The Times in an article by Craig Claiborne. Recipe adapted from Ann Seranne, a former editor of Gourmet.

title: Recipe Redux: Rib Roast of Beef, 1966
description: Cooking beef to the right doneness, especially a wildly expensive cut like rib roast, while also tending to guests, ranks with kitchen anxieties like unmolding a tarte Tatin or killing a lobster. But Ann Seranne, a food consultant and the author of more than a dozen cookbooks, solved this problem back in the 1960s. Craig Claiborne wrote that her technique is so basic, so easily applied and so eminently satisfactory in its results, the astonishing thing is it is not universally known. As it still isnt, I will reprint it here once more. Please tell all your friends the news, so that rib roast can finally have its no-knead-bread moment.

title: Breast Implants Are Linked to Rare but Treatable Cancer, F.D.A. Finds
description: Breast implants may cause a small but significant increase in the risk of an extremely rare but treatable type of cancer, the Food and Drug Administration said on Wednesday.

title: A Long-Dead King Sets Out to Upgrade His Brands Image
description: Poor King Aethelred of England. Plagued by intrigues in his court, disunity among his subjects and frequent attacks by the Vikings, he had a long but miserable reign, from 978 to 1016. After his death he was saddled with the epithet the Unrede, which is generally rendered the Unready in modern English, though it actually meant the Ill Advised. And he is the subject of a one-act comic opera by Richard Wilson, who toys with that mistranslation and Aethelreds unfortunate reputation.

title: In Refrains, Echoes of Political Strife
description: Much of the breezy score for Knickerbocker Holiday, the 1938 Broadway show by Kurt Weill (music) and Maxwell Anderson (book and lyrics), effervesces like a Gilbert and Sullivan operetta. To hear it vibrantly performed by the Collegiate Chorale and the American Symphony Orchestra (conducted by James Bagwell) at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening was to be returned to a quaint, lilting musical-theater ethos in which frivolity trumps gravity.

title: Egypt Cracks Down on Protesters
description: The Egyptian government intensified efforts to crush protests on Wednesday, decreeing a new ban on public gatherings and sending police equipped with clubs, tear gas and armored carriers against demonstrators voicing opposition to the 30-year rule of President Hosni Mubarak.

title: Brian Bistrong Closes Braeburn and Returns to Bouley
description: Brian Bistrong, who, as Eater reported, closed his restaurant Braeburn  in Greenwich Village over the weekend, says he has gone back to working with David Bouley. He had worked with Mr. Bouley for seven years before taking jobs at the Harrison and elsewhere, and then opening Braeburn.

title: Shopping Picks for Jan. 27
description: Versatile long-sleeve styles; hidden in an alley on the Bowery, Extra offers chinos, blankets and even a vintage rain parka; and other items.

title: Multiple-Universe Theory Made, Well, Easier
description: It would not be fair to describe the experience of reading the renowned physicist Brian Greene as a battle of wits. Its no battle. Most of the wits are on one side, no matter how nicely Mr. Greene tries to soft-pedal his brilliance. After all, he is the scientist who has written so enticingly about superstring theory, Calabi-Yau manifolds and the goings-on at the Large Hadron Collider. You are the one who gets agitated when Mr. Greene makes reference to conformally invariant supersymmetric quantum gauge field theory and such.

title: On Location | Inside a Modern Scottish Country House
description: A couples rural home north of Edinburgh has provoked some strong reactions among locals.

title: In a Shed, Seeds of a Scottish Farm
description: MEIGLE, Scotland

title: Photos That Preserve Beloved Objects
description: Christian Jaillite, the managing director of Elizabeth Eakins, a rug and fabric company, explained how a 45-by-60-inch photo of a much loved stuffed toy came to hang in his suburban New York dining room, above: Most kids have a blanket or toy that they attach themselves to, he said. For my son, Hippo is it. I thought that one day we may want to remember Hippo, so I decided to photograph it.

title: A Timeless Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Julio Lizarazo, General Manager of the Gracious Home Flagship
description: Last summer, Gracious Home, the go-to spot for Schonbek crystal chandeliers, Miele vacuum cleaners and Flexible Flyer plastic toboggans, filed for bankruptcy protection. By December, the family-owned company, which was started in 1963, had been bought by an investor group and given a stay of execution, saving its 250 employees, according to the new owner, the Americas Retail Flagship Fund.

title: Sales at the Shade Store, the MoMA Design Store and Others
description: The Shade Store is offering 10 percent off all energy-saving products, through Feb. 3 (30- by 54-inch solar shades, originally $148, are about $133; 30- by 54-inch Roman shades, originally $252, are about $227); 480 Broome Street (Wooster Street), (212) 645-2424, theshadestore.com.

title: Wall Coverings
description: IM not big on pretty stuff, said Barbara Bestor, chairwoman of the new graduate program at the Woodbury University School of Architecture in Los Angeles, and the architect whose 2006 book, Bohemian Modern, identified a certain brand of eccentric modernism instantly recognizable to anyone who has spent time in Southern California. Im into graphic or funny.

title: Old Smokey
description: To the Editor:

title: Furniture Exhibitions in Manhattan and Washington
description: When the Italian company GD Cucine opened its first North American showroom in Chelsea last year, its intent was to be more than just another space selling kitchens and bathrooms. The 8,000-square-foot, bilevel showroom was also designed to house exhibitions.

title: Scouting Report
description: ONLINE

title: House Numbers, Inspired by the Eameses
description: The prolific midcentury pioneers Charles and Ray Eames designed many things, but not type. Instead they used off-the-shelf stencils to label packaging and blueprints. They also had a fascination with the bulbous lettering of Victorian circus posters and wood type.

title: Snow Forecast? Set Up the Patio
description: IN the cycle of the seasons, now is a time of longing  for backyard sunbathing, for cocktails on the patio, for puttering in the garden, and for the distant time when all those activities will be possible again.

title: Gray Fired and Keys Resigns in Sexism Scandal
description: The controversy surrounding the British soccer commentators Andy Gray and Richard Keys, who were suspended Monday by Sky Sports for making disparaging remarks about women in the game, has now cost both men their jobs.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Carriers Tackle Distracted Driving
description: Its widely known that driving while talking, texting or otherwise engaging with gadgets can be dangerous, but lots of people still do it. Now cell carriers are starting to offer ways of automatically turning off phones when theyre in moving vehicles. Bettina Edelstein talks to Matt Richtel, a Times reporter who has written extensively about distracted driving, about how this fledgling technology works and why carriers are embracing it. Because of changes in the cell business, Mr. Richtel says, carriers avidly compete to offer new services for which they can charge monthly fees.

title: Feeding Dreams of a Better Life
description: Paris

title: Nielsens I.P.O. Isnt an Omen for Its Peers
description: Nielsen Holdings may be the market leader in gauging consumer behavior. But it probably shouldnt be relied on as a bellwether of investor sentiment.

title: From the Amazon to New York: Paiche
description: In this excerpt of a video from the company marketing paiche, the giant freshwater fish is seen being harvested.

title: Mens Shows in Paris: Plainly Put
description: Photos from the mens wear shows in Paris, including Thom Browne, Givenchy, Raf Simons and Yves Saint Laurent.

title: HSBC Is Said to Be the Focus of a Tax-Evasion Investigation
description: Federal authorities are considering whether to serve a broad legal summons on HSBC to ascertain whether it sold tax-evasion services to scores of wealthy American clients, people briefed on the matter said Wednesday.

title: Yankees Hope Bartolo Colon Can Recapture Old Form
description: From Catfish Hunter to Dwight Gooden, Jack McDowell to Roger Clemens, David Cone to Randy Johnson, the Yankees have a rich history of acquiring Cy Young Award-winning pitchers. They failed this off-season to add Cliff Lee to that stable, but on Wednesday they signed Bartolo Colon, the winner once traded for him.

title: Card-Reading Confidence From the Player of the Year
description: The American Contract Bridge Leagues 2010 player of the year is Brad Moss of San Anselmo, Calif. He gained more platinum master points than anyone else last year, points that can be won only in the top-ranked events.

title: Seneca Pre-Emptively Rejects Dynegy Offer at $6 a Share
description: Seneca Capital, the second-largest shareholder of Dynegy, said on Wednesday that it would reject a $6 a share offer for the energy company  should such a bid materialize.

title: Paris Couture: Valentino
description: The spring haute couture shows, which ended tonight with Valentino, revealed a creative energy that ought to give pause to designers of ready-to-wear. Not that the two worlds really have anything in common, except a respect for craft and beauty and certain high-profile clients. But ready-to-wear has had more and more limitations placed upon it, like the availability of fabrics, pricing issues and competitive pressures from fast-fashion chains. Haute couture has none of these concerns, and it has enough masters  Karl Lagerfeld, John Galliano, Jean Paul Gaultier  and, of course, sympathetic corporate owners to create exceptional, even relevant fashion.

title: Protesters Defy Egypts Government
description: Reporter Mona El-Naggar describes the second day of rioting in Cairo.

title: In High School and Alone in a Homeless Shelter
description: Using the accepted social metrics of teenagers in this country, Thakane Masondo should have plenty of friends.

title: A Bookworm Finds His True Calling
description: An insatiable reader, Stephen C. Barr, 25, is a junior literary agent at Writers House. When he is not searching the slush pile  the trove of unsolicited submissions  for hidden masterpieces, Mr. Barr searches blogs for worthy book projects. A 2007 graduate of the University of California, Los Angeles, he switched his career objective from editor to agent early on, winning internships first at Hotchkiss and Associates and then at Writers House, where he was promoted to junior agent from agent assistant last year. Mr. Barr lives in Hells Kitchen.

title: Stanford Ruled Incompetent to Stand Trial
description: A federal judge ruled on Wednesday that the jailed Texas financier R. Allen Stanford was incompetent to stand trial at this time on charges that he ran a $7 billion Ponzi scheme.

title: Semifinal Preview: Li vs. Wozniacki
description: Li Na plays top-seeded Caroline Wozniacki in the first womens semifinal. The two played in the Round of 16 at the Australian Open last year, with Li Na winning convincingly by outhitting Wozniacki. She dominated Wozniacki from the first point, playing with sustained aggression and controlling court positioning throughout her straight-set victory. In that match, Wozniacki came up with a meager three winners, while Li Na struck 21 outright winners.

title: British Tabloid Dismisses Editor Over Hacking Scandal
description: LONDON  The News of the World tabloid said on Wednesday that it had dismissed its assistant editor for news, Ian Edmondson, after finding material evidence linking him to allegations that the newspaper illegally intercepted celebrities telephone messages.

title: Voting on Recall
description: Five of the last six mayors in Omaha have faced organized ouster campaigns. Mayor Jim Suttle is the latest.

title: The Long U.S. Relationship With Mubarak
description: In Egypt, protests call for an end to President Hosni Mubarak's rule,  putting the U.S., his staunch ally for decades, into a diplomatically difficult position.

title: Dissenters Fault Report on Crisis in Finance
description: WASHINGTON  The government commissions account of what caused the 2008 financial crisis offers a broad indictment of regulatory weakness, Wall Street avarice and corporate incompetence. But that narrative is competing with alternative views by the Republicans on the panel, who released their dissenting reports on Wednesday.

title: Did We Mention That It Tastes Good?
description: WHAT sets adult cereal apart from most other foods is that, oddly, it is rarely advertised primarily on the promise of tasting good. Special K, for example, is marketed as a dieting aid for women who eat it throughout the day, while Wheaties promises to fuel athletic performance and Fiber One promotes the digestive benefits of a high-fiber diet. Although popular adult cereals make secondary claims about being toothsome, of course, the primary pitch is for healthfulness.

title: A Little Less Drama at NBC
description: On Thursday, from Studio 6B in Rockefeller Center, home of Late Night With Jimmy Fallon, the NBC anchor Brian Williams will officially introduce the networks newest boss, Stephen B. Burke, in a closed-circuit presentation to the entire company.

title: Semifinal Preview: Clijsters vs. Zvonareva
description: A day after winning their quarterfinal matches, Kim Clijsters faces Vera Zvonareva in the Australian Open semifinals on Thursday. Clijsters trounced Zvonareva in the United States Open final last September, in a match that clearly showed Zvonareva had rattled nerves on the big stage. The Russian tried to outhit Clijsters in that match, and never really put Clijsters under any pressure.

title: G.O.P. Splits Over Plans to Cut Defense Budget
description: WASHINGTON  To hear the Republican leadership tell it, the once-sacred Pentagon budget, protected by the party for generations, is suddenly on the table. But a closer look shows that even as Speaker John A. Boehner and Representative Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, insist on the need for military cuts, divisions have opened among Republicans about whether, and how much, to chop Pentagon spending that comes to more than a half trillion dollars a year.

title: Millrose to Give a Spotlight to Decathletes
description: Right about now, everybody in New York needs to come in from the cold.

title: Plants That Earn Their Keep
description: DENVER  Could airport security gardens be the wave of the future? (Please have photo ID and boarding pass ready and walk past the rhododenrons.) How about a defensive line of bomb-sniffing tulips in Central Park in New York, or at the local shopping malls indoor waterfall, or lining the streets of Baghdad?

title: Dispute With Parliament Leaves Afghan Leader Isolated
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  As the long luncheon for newly elected Afghan members of Parliament wound to a close over tea and fruit last weekend, it became clear that President Hamid Karzai was outnumbered and outmaneuvered.

title: Nascar Straightens Curves With Its New Points System
description: Nascar eliminated one of its most charming and quirky traditions  the 36-year-old points system that was introduced on a stack of napkins at a bar in Daytona Beach, Fla.  as the sanctioning body announced changes Wednesday in how it would determine a stock-car champion.

title: A School Far From No. 1, but a Leader in Science
description: OSSINING, N.Y.

title: To Expand, Airports May Need Radical Alterations, Report Says
description: The New York regions two largest airports, already choked with crowds and delays, may need to be radically reconfigured so they can make way for vitally needed additional runways that would help accommodate a projected increase of almost 50 million air travelers per year within two or three decades, according to a new study.

title: Nakamura and Anand Again Separate Themselves From the Pack at Tata Steel
Will Ferrell Gets a Temp Gig on The Office
description: The Scranton, Pa., branch of Dunder Mifflin, better known as the setting for NBCs Office, will get an extra helping of comedic talent just before the departure of its series regular Steve Carell: Will Ferrell, the Saturday Night Live alumnus turned star of Talladega Nights and The Other Guys, will join The Office for several episodes later this season, NBC said on Wednesday evening.

title: Mets Introduce Their Newest Foreign Import
description: While introducing Chin-lung Hu on Wednesday at a Citi Field news conference that drew great interest from the Chinese-language press corps, Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson twice stated that the decision to sign Hu was based on his talent  a baseball decision as he put it.

title: Obama, in Wisconsin, Picks Up Addresss Refrain
description: MANITOWOC, Wis.  President Obama loves sports metaphors, and they were flying on Wednesday when he came to Green Bay Packers country to tour three factories and expand on the winning the future theme of his State of the Union address the night before.

title: Knicks Defiant in Face of Heats Star Power
description: For all Miamis star power and success, there will be one thing lacking when the Heat plays the Knicks on Thursday night: fear.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 26
description: A view of the day in sports, with lots of action on ice.

title: Spanish Officials Propose One-Year Ban for Contador
description: Spanish cycling officials have chosen to be lenient on Alberto Contador in punishing him for testing positive for a banned drug at last years Tour de France, proposing that he be barred for one year instead of the usual two-year sanction for a first-time offense.

title: With Issa Leading, Oversight Panel Eagerly Begins Its Work
description: WASHINGTON  If Representative Darrell E. Issa, Republican of California, gets his wish, he will have only two years to serve as a chief tormenter of the Obama administration. So he was understandably eager to get started on Wednesday with his first hearing as chairman of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform.

title: Lottery Numbers
Full Presidential Speech Got an Unscripted Leak
description: For a White House that prides itself on being fairly leak-free, this one had to hurt.

title: Old Hickorys Ghost
description: Americans have always obsessed over their nations history, even when there wasnt much to obsess over. The founding generation had barely passed on before politicians began scrambling to claim their legacy  and at no time was that more true than during the Secession Crisis. Secessionists claimed to be emulating the revolutionaries struggle for liberty against a tyrannical central government, while Northerners were determined not to let disloyal rebels tear down the noble republic the founders had created.

title: Best Guess Adds Flavor to Hockey All-Star Game
description: Hockey fans stopped caring about the N.H.L. All-Star Game long ago, so the league turned to Brendan Shanahan, its go-to guy for fixing whatever ails the game. His solution: take a page from the schoolyard pick-up handbook. Make fans wonder who will be picked first  and last.

title: Record Level of Stress Found in College Freshmen
description: The emotional health of college freshmen  who feel buffeted by the recession and stressed by the pressures of high school  has declined to the lowest level since an annual survey of incoming students started collecting data 25 years ago.

title: Senate Democrats Drop Campaign to Limit Filibuster
description: WASHINGTON  Democratic advocates of an overhaul of Senate rules to curb the filibuster abandoned that effort on Wednesday, clearing the way for a bipartisan agreement to institute less sweeping changes to ease procedural gridlock.

title: Your Questions for George Clooney
description: Editors note: In light of the events in Cairo, we are holding the next part of this series (the answers to readers questions) for a few more days.

title: House Ethics Committee Clears 3 of Conflict of Interest
description: WASHINGTON  The House ethics committee, in one of its first official acts since the start of the new Congress, dismissed cases involving three members accused of creating an appearance of a conflict by holding fund-raising events with financial industry executives and lobbyists in the days before major votes on legislation revamping the nations financial regulations.

title: Federal Reserve Statement on Monetary Policy
description: The following is the full text of the statement released Wednesday by the Federal Reserve:

title: Deficit Forecast Nears $1.5 Trillion, Fueling Partisan Battle on Federal Spending
description: WASHINGTON  The governments budget deficit will soar to nearly $1.5 trillion this year, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office said Wednesday, an anticipated but politically galvanizing calculation that further intensified the partisan battle over the nations fiscal future.

title: A Bittersweet Homecoming
description: The Iraq war veteran James B. Hurley's home was illegally foreclosed on and resold while he was overseas serving in the military.

title: New Mexico: Court Overrules Governor on Pollutants
description: The State Supreme Court on Wednesday reinstated two environmental rules that Gov. Susana Martinez blocked upon taking office last month. In a unanimous decision, the court ordered that the rules  one requiring annual 3 percent cuts in greenhouse gas emissions and another aimed at controlling waste discharges from dairies  must be published in the states register, which will make them effective. Ms. Martinez had forbidden the register from publishing the rules. No one is above the law, the states chief justice, Charles W. Daniels, said as he announced the decision. The dairy industry had opposed a rule by the New Mexico Water Quality Commission requiring that all manure lagoons incorporate a synthetic liner to keep contaminants from leaching into the groundwater. Officials of the states Environment Department have estimated that two-thirds of such ponds have contaminated groundwater beneath them.

title: A Reservist in a New War, Against Foreclosure
description: While Sgt. James B. Hurley was away at war, he lost a heartbreaking battle at home.

title: Virginia: Quick Ruling Promised on Challenge to Health Law
description: A federal appeals court in Richmond, Va., announced Wednesday that it would expedite its consideration of a lower court ruling against a key provision of the Obama health care act. The Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit said it would hear arguments between May 10 and May 13 in the Obama administrations appeal of a ruling last month by Judge Howard E. Hudson of Federal District Court in Richmond. Judge Hudson ruled that Congress had exceeded the boundaries of the Commerce Clause of the Constitution by requiring citizens to obtain commercial insurance. He allowed the law to remain in effect pending appeals, which are likely to end at the Supreme Court. Two other federal judges have upheld the insurance requirement, while a fourth judge, in Florida, is expected to rule soon.

title: Highlights of Davos, Day 1
description: The World Economic Forum is well known for its profusion of discussions and events  so much so that it is overwhelming and confusing to observers. Here to help is DealBooks handy slide-show guide to the highlights of Davos, Day 1. Click through and explore  without the headaches of information overload.

title: After Decades, Charges in 2 Manhattan Murders
description: One victim, Cornelia Michel Crilley, was a Trans World Airlines flight attendant who was raped and strangled in her Upper East Side apartment in 1971; the other, Ellen Jane Hover, an aspiring orchestra conductor who disappeared one summer day in 1977  and whose remains were found nearly a year later on the Rockefeller estate in Westchester County.

title: Candidates, and Chicago, Await Ruling
description: CHICAGO  The candidates for mayor, scores of election workers, and, perhaps most of all, this citys confused voters received no new clarity on Wednesday on whether Rahm Emanuel would be permitted to run for mayor.

title: Cashman Pours Drinks and Talks Yankees
description: Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman donned his spiked hair/bandana hairpiece and assumed his celebrity bartender persona  Hard Cash  at Foleys Pub and Restaurant on Wednesday to pour drinks and help raise money to fight cancer (his father-in-law died of the disease).

title: Egyptian Youths Drive the Revolt Against Mubarak
description: For decades, Egypts authoritarian president, Hosni Mubarak, played a clever game with his political opponents.

title: In N.F.L. Labor Fight, Battlefield Moves Online
description: On Wednesday morning, N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell sent an internal memo to his staff telling it that he would take a $1 salary if owners lock out players. His promise to slash his compensation from about $10 million was reported on Twitter by an NFL Network reporter, provided by the league to the Sports Business Journal, then reported and posted on Twitter by other outlets, including NFL.com.

title: Bloggingheads: Obama's Address
description: John McWhorter, left, of The New Republic and Benjamin Zimmer of The New York Times discuss the State of the Union address.

title: Currywurst on the Street
description: Michael Slackman, The Times's Berlin Bureau Chief, looks into the city's obsession with a popular street dish that combines sausage, ketchup and curry powder.

title: The Packers and the Steelers Broke the Hearts of the Cowboys
description: PITTSBURGH  The meeting of the Pittsburgh Steelers and the Green Bay Packers in Super Bowl XLV will be many things. A matchup of two of the N.F.L.s most storied franchises. A throwdown between dominant defenses. A road trip extraordinaire to Dallas for devoted fans bearing Terrible Towels and Cheeseheads.

title: Thursday: Outrageous Fortune
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Patrick Blindauer is a man of many talents, and among them is the ability to produce some of the most innovative crossword puzzles in the business. One of my favorites first appeared at Will Shortzs Westchester Crossword Puzzle Tournament in 2008, and made its appearance in The New York Times the following week (Across Lite, Solution).

title: Love in City of Intemperate Mores
description: Cosmetic surgery  as the celebrity tabloids and society pages make clearer every day  is not always a fortunate undertaking. Under the homogenizing hands of certain doctors, a creature of eccentric charms can be made to look positively plain. This, by the way, is known to happen not only to desperate, perfection-seeking people but also to aged, overweight plays.

title: From Bullets to Megabytes
description: STUXNET, the computer worm that last year disrupted many of the gas centrifuges central to Irans nuclear program, is a powerful weapon in the new age of global information warfare. A sophisticated half-megabyte of computer code apparently accomplished what a half-decade of United Nations Security Council resolutions could not.

title: 25 Years of Digital Vandalism
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia

title: Glaxo and Avandia
description: To the Editor:

title: Tussling Over Jesus
description: The National Catholic Reporter newspaper put it best: Just days before Christians celebrated Christmas, Jesus got evicted.

title: In Tunisia: I Have a Dream
description: To the Editor:

title: Realism Without the Bitterness
description: With his lips pursed, body tense and applause sparing, John Boehner was restless in the speakers chair during President Obamas State of the Union address. A few minutes after it was over, Mr. Boehner made his impatience explicit with a statement accusing Mr. Obama of having accelerated the job-destroying spending spree in Washington.

title: Mr. Mubarak Is Put on Notice
description: We sympathize with the frustration and anger that is drawing tens of thousands of Egyptians into the streets of Cairo and other cities this week, the countrys largest demonstrations in years. Citizens of one of the Arab worlds great nations, they struggle with poverty  40 percent live on less than $2 a day  rising food prices, unemployment and political repression.

title: Utahs Gun Appreciation Day
description: This week in Washington, Senator Frank Lautenberg of New Jersey introduced three very modest gun regulation bills, including one making it more difficult to sell guns to people on the terror watch list.

title: In Japan: Its Our Territory
description: To the Editor:

title: Influence in Albany
description: To the Editor:

title: One Nation, Indivisible
description: Fifteen years ago, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit flouted Supreme Court law when it struck down affirmative action at the University of Texas Law School. Last week, in an act of redemption, the appellate court upheld an admissions plan for undergraduates at the University of Texas at Austin that takes race into account to encourage diversity. The plan was adopted after the Supreme Court again approved affirmative action in higher education in 2003.

title: So Was It a Good Year?
description: With the exception of Bank of America, the big banks were profitable in 2010, according to year-end reports filed earlier this month. But even standout results  like JPMorgan Chases profit surge or Citigroups first full-year profit since the financial crisis  were underwhelming on closer inspection.

title: National Dish Comes Wrapped in Foreign Flavoring
description: BERLIN  There is no shortage of contradictions when it comes to this city. Like the rest of Germany, Berlin demands conformity to certain rules (think twice about crossing against the light), but leaves moral judgments up to the individual (no problem with nude bathing in public parks or gambling in storefront casinos).

title: Woods Says Hes Ready to Return to Tour, and to Winning
description: SAN DIEGO  Tiger Woods returned to familiarity on Wednesday, to the fairways and greens of Torrey Pines Golf Course, comfortable confines that are etched in his mind like the layout of his childhood home some 90 miles north in Cypress.

title: Israel: 4 Palestinians Charged in Killing of U.S. Woman
description: Four Palestinians were charged on Wednesday with the murder of an American tourist, Kristine Luken, who was killed in a forest outside Jerusalem in December. Ms. Luken, an evangelical Christian in her mid-40s, had been hiking with a friend who was also stabbed, but survived. Micky Rosenfeld, a police spokesman, said that the attackers came from the West Bank, and that they were suspected of at least one other murder. One of the group said that the attacks began as revenge for the killing of a senior Hamas official in a Dubai hotel room a year ago, Mr. Rosenfeld said.

title: Russia: Transit Police Official Fired in Wake of Bombing
description: President Dmitri A. Medvedev on Wednesday dismissed the federal transit police official in charge of the Moscow region, seeking to shake up the security apparatus for failing to stop the suicide bombing at the capitals busiest international airport on Monday. I believe that in general, transport security  and not just because of the terrorist act that occurred  is unsatisfactory, Mr. Medvedev said. He did not directly criticize any of his own top security aides, instead continuing to focus blame on the lower ranks. Police officials in charge of security at the airport itself were also dismissed. Investigators continued to search for the organizers of the bombing, which killed at least 35 people and wounded scores of others.

title: Colombia: Coal Mine Explosion Kills as Many as 20
description: An explosion at a coal mine in northeastern Colombia killed as many as 20 miners and left six injured, according to a statement from the Colombian Institute of Geology and Mining. The disaster was caused by the release of methane gas that led to a blast and a cave-in. Dozens of people were killed in similar accidents last year in Colombia, South Americas largest coal producer. More than 30 miners died at the same mine, called La Preciosa, in 2007.

title: Dennis Oppenheim, a Pioneer in Earthworks and Conceptual Art, Dies at 72
description: Dennis Oppenheim, a pioneer of earthworks, body art and Conceptual art who later made emphatically tangible installations and public sculptures that veered between the demonically chaotic and the cheerfully Pop, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 72.

title: Breast Implants Linked to Rare Cancer
description: Breast implants  both saline- and silicone-filled, and whether for reconstruction after cancer surgery or for cosmetic enlargement of the breasts  may cause a small but significant increase in the risk of an extremely rare type of cancer, writes the New York Times health reporter Denise Grady.

title: Tullia Zevi, Who Led Italian Jewish Community, Is Dead at 91
description: ROME  Tullia Zevi, who fled Fascism as a teenager and led Italys Jewish community during a period of improving relations with the Vatican, died on Saturday in Rome. She was 91.

title: Bishop Samuel Ruiz Garca, Defender of Mexicos Mayans, Dies at 86
description: Bishop Samuel Ruiz Garca, an impassioned defender of the Mayans in southern Mexico and a mediator in peace talks between Indian rebels and the government, died on Monday in Mexico City. He was 86.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Moodys to Factor Pension Gaps in States Ratings
description: Moodys Investors Service has begun to recalculate the states debt burdens in a way that includes unfunded pensions, something states and others have ardently resisted until now.

title: Endowments at Universities See Gains After 2009 Losses
description: The value of university endowments increased an average of 11.9 percent for fiscal 2010, making up most of the ground lost in the previous year, according to the comprehensive Nacubo-Commonfund Study of Endowments, released Wednesday. In the previous fiscal year, endowments were down an average of 18.7 percent.

title: Word of the Day | cohesion
description: cohesion \ko-he-zhn\ noun

title: Zenyatta Has a Date With Bernardini
description: Jerry and Ann Moss announced Wednesday that Zenyattas first date in the breeding shed will be with Bernardini, who was the champion 3-year-old in 2006 and whose first crop of runners last year produced the most graded stakes winners among freshman sires.

title: Forecast Sees Muslim Population Leveling Off
description: A new report forecasts that the number of Muslims around the world will grow over the next 20 years at twice the rate of non-Muslims, but that the rapid growth will level off. With more Muslim women getting educations and jobs, people migrating to cities, and living standards improving, the report says, the birthrate in majority-Muslim countries will come to more closely resemble the pattern in other nations.

title: This Winter, New York City Is the New Buffalo
description: There was the recently familiar annoyance  at the buses that did not come, at the thigh-high stoops that had to be shoveled.

title: News Quiz | January 27, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: American Idol': Notes on Pity
description: When Simon Cowell was waiting at the end of the judges table, waiting to render judgment, any goodwill accumulated on the way wasnt generally long for the world.

title: Daily Lexeme: Cample
description: Todays word, in association with the oustanding Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Protests in Egypt
description: WHO is protesting in Egypt?WHO has ruled the country for more than 30 years?

title: What Would a TV Show About Your Town Spoof?
description: A new show about Portland, Ore., makes fun of that citys liberal ways and deliberate differentness  from the ubiquitous bicyclists to the feminist bookstores to the ways many parts of Portland feel like one big group hug. If there were a television show about your town, city, region or even neighborhood, what would it show? What kinds of characters and settings would probably appear? What would be mocked? What serious issues might be addressed?

title: Test Yourself | English, Jan. 27, 2011
description: Test your vocabulary skills with todays question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the article Sit. Stay. Parse. Good Girl!

title: Sony Reveals New Hand-Held Device and PlayStation Games for Phones
description: TOKYO  Sony will start selling a new hand-held game device by the end of the year and will offer its PlayStation games on a range of portable devices, including smartphones, the company said on Thursday.

title: ProLogis in Merger Talks With AMB Property
description: ProLogis, the American warehouse operator, confirmed on Wednesday that it was in talks with a rival, AMB Property, about a possible merger.

title: S.&P. Downgrades Japan as Debt Concerns Spread
description: TOKYO  Standard & Poors, the credit ratings agency, downgraded Japans long-term sovereign debt on Thursday, a sharp reminder of the heavy burden plaguing the worlds third-largest economy at levels that stand out even in an increasingly debt-ridden world.

title: See, Officer, I Can Too Take That Picture
description: Friday, 12:45 p.m. | Updated

title: Davos Roundup: Wives, the G-Zero and the Next Crisis
description: Gary Cohn of Goldman Sachs has stepped up to warn that tighter regulation on banks is moving risky activity beyond regulators grasp, toward hedge funds and other obscure corners of finance, which may result in another crisis, The Financial Times reports.

title: Obama and Business May Get On Well, but When Will That Produce Jobs?
description: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of 13 Bankers.

title: Moelis to Expand in Asia With Acquisition
description: Moelis & Company said on Thursday that it had agreed to buy Asia Pacific Advisers, a boutique firm in Hong Kong, as part of its plan to expand in Asia.

title: Is Apple the Smartest Company at Davos?
description: RIA Novosti/ReutersRussias President Dmitri Medvedev using an iPad at Davos.

title: Q. and A. With N.F.L. Talent Evaluator Russ Lande
description: Russ Lande is the Sporting News N.F.L. draft expert responsible for insider content, writing scouting reports on college players. He is also the author of the annual GM Jr Draft Guide, which is available to the N.F.L. and the general public. Lande gained his experience as a former scout and front-office executive. Before joining The Sporting News, he spent three years as a college scout for the Cleveland Browns. The Footballguys.com staff writer and Rookie Scouting Portfolio author Matt Waldman sat down with Lande after Day 3 of Senior Bowl practices to discuss the craft of talent evaluation and what he has observed with this class of players in Mobile, Ala.

title: Exploring Ancient Czech Legends in Prague
description: Interactive exhibitions for children are a rarity in Prague, so it was with great relish that a group of boys and girls took a recent run around the National Museum with a taxidermic boar on their backs.

title: Ugandan Who Spoke Up for Gays Is Beaten to Death
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  David Kato knew he was a marked man.

title: How Often Can You Send E-Mail Promotions?
description: Last week I sat around with six important people in my business and discussed our marketing plan for 2011. We determined that we need to get more e-mail addresses from our customers so that we can send them promotions more efficiently. We want to avoid the printing and postage costs of direct mail promotions, which will be good for us, for the customers and for the environment. Sorry, printers.

title: Senior Bowl, Day 3: Risers, Fallers and Steady as They Go
description: Cecil Lammey is a senior staff writer for Footballguys.com and the NFL Insider for the Front Range Sports Network. Matt Waldman is a staff writer for Footballguys.com and the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, an online publication devoted to play-by-play film analysis of NFL prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver and tight end. You can see more of their draft coverage at Draftguys.com.

title: Morning Commute Outlook: Poor
description: Updated, 11:07 a.m. | Mass transit is slowly recovering from the snow, which wiped out bus service in much of the region this morning and closed airports. Heres the latest:

title: Battling for a Stadium in London
description: LONDON

title: Mideast Private Equity Activity Starts to Revive
description: DUBAI  The regional private equity scene in the Middle East is beginning to show signs of a revival after nearly two years of a standstill, analysts say, but many challenges continue to present hurdles for the growth of the industry. They include a stalled market for initial public offerings, slow deal flow and transparency issues.

title: Q.&A.: Deleting Mac App Store Apps
description: Q.

title: Pressures of High School and Economy Weigh on College Freshmen
description: 12:46 p.m. | Updated For tips from my colleague Michael Winerip on how to evaluate the mental-health offerings of particular colleges, click here.

title: For Generations of Runners, the Ultimate Test
description: The snow blanketing the Parade Grounds at Van Cortlandt Park lends the landscape a tone of pastoral tranquillity, even if generations of schoolboy runners know better. To them, the scene is more like a battlefield temporarily stilled by nature.

title: Thousands in Yemen Protest Against the Government
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Yemen, one of the Middle Easts most impoverished countries and a haven for Al Qaeda militants, became the latest Arab state to witness mass protests on Thursday, as thousands of Yemenis took to the streets in the capital and other regions to demand a change in government.

title: PepsiCo Deal Wins Approval From Russian Regulators
description: PepsiCos acquisition of Russias leading food and beverage maker won approval from local antitrust authorities, paving the way for countrys biggest deal on record to close by early February.

title: Li Beats Wozniacki to Gain Womens Final
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  As Li Na saved a match point and burst through barriers in Rod Laver Arena on Thursday, it was easy to let the mind drift to another, much newer, tennis stadium with a retractable roof.

title: Opposition in Egypt Gears Up for Major Friday Protest
description: CAIRO  Mohamed ElBaradei, the Nobel laureate who has become a leading opponent of President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, returned to Cairo on Thursday in an attempt to galvanize youth-led street protests that extended into a third day across the country.

title: Obama Used Speech to Address Americas Greatness  and His Critics
description: According to Sarah Palin and other conservatives, President Obama does not recognize Americas greatness. Among his failings, they say, is a tendency to talk the country down, minimize its place in the world and underestimate its uniqueness.

title: Did the Jets Have a Successful Season?
description: They went 11-5, but they didnt win the division.

title: Sonos Finds Its Missing Link(s)
description: Its easy to forget that Apples iPod was not an instant success. First offered in 2001, and compatible with the Mac only, it was not available for Windows computers until 2002, and then as a separate model. Apples iTunes Music Store, which gave consumers access to millions of songs, came into existence only in mid-2003. And ultimately it was the store that gave the iPod the ammunition it needed to become the center of popular culture.

title: For Excess Solar Flow, a Veg-O-Matic for Voltage
description: Until very recently, the solar industry was mainly concerned with getting a toehold in the production of electricity at a utility-level scale. Now a New Jersey company is looking for its niche in a different field  how to handle a system that is saturated with solar energy, sometimes enough to destabilize the electric grid.

title: Camera Traps Catch Lots of Monkeys
description: Anthony Di Fiore, a primate biologist at New York University, writes from Ecuador, where he is using GPS technology and camera traps to study the behavior of male spider monkeys.

title: Stop Picking on Bankers, JPMorgan Chief Says
description: Scott Eells/Bloomberg NewsJamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase offered a spirited defense of bankers.

title: Portugal Telecom Buys $5 Billion Stake in Oi of Brazil
description: Portugal Telecom announced on Wednesday that it had signed a deal to take a 22.38 percent stake in the Brazilian telecommunications company Telemar Norte Leste, also known as Oi.

title: Corporate Tax Code Proves Hard to Change
description: WASHINGTON  Large trucking companies paid the government more than 30 percent of their income in 2009. Biotechnology companies paid less than 5 percent.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

title: Despite Politics, Oil Companies Are Lured by Russian Petroleum
description: MOSCOW  Exxon Mobil once was poised to acquire a stake in Russias largest private oil company, only to have the deal fall apart when the Kremlin arrested the owner and the company went bankrupt.

title: Russian Investors Seek to Block BP-Rosneft Deal
description: MOSCOW - Ten months after the disaster in the Gulf of Mexico, BP seemed ready to start a new chapter in its corporate history and struck a sweeping deal with Russias state-run Rosneft to exchange shares and jointly explore offshore in the far north.

title: Plowed or Unplowed?
description: You know the drill by now, citizen reporters. Has your street  primary, secondary or tertiary  been cleared of snow yet? Let us know.

title: Best of Both Worlds Dept. | Olivier Theyskens for Theory
description: Shortly after presenting his first collection for Theory, Olivier Theyskens, a veteran of Nina Ricci and Rochas, shocked  or make that thrilled  the fashion world when he announced he would become a permanent fixture at the company, overseeing a higher-end Theyskens Theory collection as well as the labels more accessible main line. The collection is for cool girls that like to wear clothes that are visionary, while still being right for today, Theyskens says. These clothes are what I would wear if I were a girl. Look forward to wardrobe staples like a sharp, fitted wool blazer and a variety of knits and printed silk dresses along with more of-the-season pieces like silk palazzo pants, cropped blouses and sexy bodices. (Prices range from $90 to $1,150). Whichever way you slice it, hes back.

title: Video: The Costumes of Black Swan
Is a Multinational C.E.O. the Best Jobs Czar?
description: In the wake of Jeffrey Immelts ascent to the chairmanship of President Obamas jobs council, some commentators have questioned whether the leader of General Electric, a company that has sharply reduced its United States payrolls over the years, is the best person to be orchestrating a jobs revival.

title: Video of Protests in Yemen
description: Updated | 2:53 p.m. As my colleagues Nada Bakri and David Goodman report, the wave of protests against autocratic governments in the Arab world has now spread to Yemen, where thousands of people took to the streets of the capital Sana on Thursday.

title: Dating Game Killer Charged With Two Murders From the 1970s
description: No school for the citys students, but commuters should check transportation advisories before heading out the door.

title: Wheelies: Ghosts of Industrys Past, Present and Future Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Another Delay for The Hobbit as Jackson Recovers From Ulcer Surgery
description: If youd recently taken on the weighty assignment of directing two movies adapted from J. R. R. Tolkiens Hobbit, then defended that project during a potentially catastrophic labor crisis, you might be under some stress, too. So have sympathy for Peter Jackson, who will likely take some time off from that mammoth fantasy franchise after undergoing surgery for a perforated ulcer. Melissa Booth, a publicist for Mr. Jackson, told Agence France-Presse that the filmmaker had been experiencing stomach pains and on Wednesday night was admitted to Wellington Hospital in New Zealand, where doctors gave him the diagnosis and operated on him.
