Mr. Jackson, the Academy Award-winning director of the Lord of the Rings movies, stepped in last year to direct the Hobbit films after Guillermo del Toro withdrew, then fought a pitched battle against labor unions in New Zealand and Australia over hiring practices, with Mr. Jackson warning he could move the films out of New Zealand if the unions did not back down.

title: My Father at 100
description: Introduction

title: Ronald Reagan as Dad, a Sunny Stranger
description: Ronald Reagan, the politician, has been enshrined as a heroic visionary by the right, celebrated for ending the cold war and reducing the size of government, and invoked as a touchstone for all things conservative. At the same time, hes been caricatured by the left as the dunderheaded godfather of a red-state America, promoting lower taxes for the rich, higher deficits and a more fragile social safety net.

title: Romney Calls Obama Cavalier on Lost Jobs
description: Watch the latest video at video.foxnews.com

title: Small Explosion at Davos Hotel Shatters Glass and Calm
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  A small explosion caused some broken glass but no injuries on Thursday morning at a four-star hotel in Davos, not far from the main meeting center of the World Economic Forum.

title: Doing the Super Bowl Shovel?
description: For those who supported the awarding of the 2014 Super Bowl to New Meadowlands Stadium .

title: Amazonian Giant Comes to New York
description: One of the oldest, largest freshwater fish in the world  which breathes air and can spring out of the water  has landed in New York restaurants.

title: Not In Davos
description: Every year at this time the great and the good  and a lot of bankers, too  gather in Davos for the World Economic Forum. I do it on rare occasions, but mostly not; I was supposed to be at the MIT 150th Anniversary conference, but Amtrak let me down, and Im about to straggle back to New Jersey from New York.

title: Speculation Over Mandelas Hospitalization
description: JOHANNESBURG  Nelson Mandela, the beloved but increasingly frail hero of South African democracy, remained hospitalized for a second day here on Thursday for what his foundation called routine tests.

title: Defending the Euro at Davos
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  There is no shortage of euro skepticism at the World Economic Forum this year, but the beleaguered single currency had its defenders as well on Thursday, ranging from President Nicolas Sarkozy of France to Jamie Dimon, chief executive of JPMorgan Chase.

title: Snail Houses
description: Term in China for cramped housing. (Also translated as narrow dwellings.)

title: A Capsule Summary
description: While dispatches were pouring in from the mens shows in Europe announcing fur and color as big trends for fall, we perused the racks at the biannual trade show Capsule here in New York for a taste of what to expect in stores. There are some crossovers (hunting gear, Fair Isle, an aristocratic influence, among them), but for the most part, designers favored a pared-down aesthetic punctuated with rich knits. Here, our favorites, in an interactive display.

title: A Bit of the Disco Era Has Rolled Back Into Town
description: STATEN ISLAND had been without a roller rink for 22 years when Joe Costa opened RollerJam USA in Tottenville in 2007. He said he was simply trying to meet demand, but he also found that for many of his customers, it was as if he had opened a dusty photo album from the attic, welcoming back a flood of memories.

title: A Few Regrets for Kings Speech
description: LOS ANGELES The Bagger is back in the warm, smoggy embrace of the city of angels, to report all your awards news without the distraction of earnest first-time filmmakers or hot tubs in the snow. Heres some of the latest:

title: Poetry Pairing | Jan. 27, 2011
description: In our weekly Poetry Pairing series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poems themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

title: The Ketchup on the Rye: J. D. Salingers Favorite Hamburger Revealed
description: Hows this for a fast food slogan: Have It Your Way, Even if Youre the Reclusive Author of What Some Would Argue Is the Greatest Novel of the 20th Century. It might not fit on a Burger King wrapper, but the Home of the Whopper can now also bill itself as the sometime home of J. D. Salinger, who expressed his preference for that hamburger chain in letters that were recently made public by the University of East Anglia in Britain, The Guardian reported.

title: Prada Plans I.P.O. in Hong Kong
description: Prada, the Italian fashion group, will go ahead with plans for an initial public offering in Hong Kong, the company said on Thursday, hoping that an outreach to investors that has been delayed for almost a decade will finally succeed.

title: Thursday Reading: A Guide to Internet Calling
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Crisis Panels Report Parsed Far and Wide
description: WASHINGTON  Behind closed doors, Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, called it the worst financial crisis in global history, including the Great Depression.

title: Astaire The Artist, Even in Blackface
description: HOW should we react today to Bojangles of Harlem, the extended solo in the 1936 film Swing Time in which Fred Astaire, then at the height of his fame, wears blackface to evoke the African-American dancer Bill Robinson? No pat answer occurs.

title: Famed Ghosts And Their Diligent Keeper
description: LOOK toward the ceiling from your seat in the Kaufmann Concert Hall at the 92nd Street Y, and you encounter a roll call of heroic names, etched in gold on the walnut paneling along the top edges of the walls. David, Moses and Isaiah appear over the stage. To the right, Jefferson, Shakespeare, Dante, Goethe and Maimonides. To the left, Washington, Lincoln, Beethoven, Bach and Brahms. Behind you, Emerson, Einstein and Spinoza. The list is a constant reminder of the mission of the Y, which was founded in 1874 as a nonprofit Jewish community and cultural center.

title: What Were Reading
description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.

title: The Man Behind the Facebook Deal
description: DealBooks Andrew Ross Sorkin talks with the man behind the Facebook deal, Yuri Milner, the chief executive of DST. Mr. Milner discusses the valuation of the social networking giant, and his stakes in other Internet companies.

title: McCain Aide Is Said to Be Author of O
description: 12:53 p.m. | Updated Has Anonymous been outed?

title: Prospects for Private Health Insurance
description: One of the major concerns about the new health care law is whether it will usher in the demise of employer-based coverage, which is the source of insurance for the bulk of working Americans today.

title: Winners and Losers Under the U.S. Corporate Tax Code
description: My colleague Binyamin Appelbaum has an article today on the challenges of reforming the corporate tax code, which currently presents a wide disparity in its treatment of different industries and individual companies.

title: Popcast: The Return of Wanda Jackson and a New Destroyer Album
description: This week on Popcast, The Timess weekly music podcast, Melena Ryzik discusses her Arts & Leisure profile of Wanda Jackson, the 73-year-old Queen of Rockabilly. Ms. Jackson started her career alongside her onetime boyfriend Elvis Presley, became a born-again Christian and now  still growling and swiveling her hips onstage  has a new album produced by Jack White that she hopes will introduce her to a new audience. You cant hardly name anything that I havent experienced somewhere along the way, she told Ms. Ryzik in her interview.

title: Popcast: The Return of Wanda Jackson and a New Destroyer Album
description: This week on Popcast, The Timess weekly music podcast, Melena Ryzik discusses her Arts & Leisure profile of Wanda Jackson, the 73-year-old Queen of Rockabilly. Ms. Jackson started her career alongside her onetime boyfriend Elvis Presley, became a born-again Christian and now  still growling and swiveling her hips onstage  has a new album produced by Jack White that she hopes will introduce her to a new audience. You cant hardly name anything that I havent experienced somewhere along the way, she told Ms. Ryzik in her interview.

title: Chinese Journalist Who Defied the Censors and Wrote About Corruption Is Fired
description: SHANGHAI  A prominent newspaper columnist who challenged government censors by writing about corruption and political reform was dismissed Thursday by the Southern Daily Group, publisher of some of the countrys best-known newspapers.

title: Remedies: Tea Tree Oil for Acne
description: More than a third of American adults use some form of complementary or alternative medicine, according to a government report. Natural remedies have an obvious appeal, but how do you know which ones to choose and whether the claims are backed by science? In this occasional series, Anahad OConnor, the New York Times Really? columnist, explores the claims and the science behind alternative remedies that you may want to consider for your family medicine cabinet.

title: Sara Lee Said to Weigh a Breakup, Not a Sale
description: 7:13 p.m. | Updated

title: U.S. Official Shoots Two Pakistanis to Death
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  An American official shot and killed two men on a motorcycle who apparently threatened to rob him at gunpoint while he was driving his car in the city of Lahore on Thursday, according to senior police officials there.

title: More Video of Protests in Egypt
description: Updated | 5:53 p.m. As my colleagues report from Cairo, protesters in the Egyptian capital are planning another large demonstration against President Hosni Mubaraks government on Friday, to build on momentum generated by street protests on Tuesday and Wednesday.

title: YouTube: A State of the Union Tradition
description: Add one more to the list of State of the Union traditions  YouTube.

title: Jailed for Choosing a Better School?
description: Kelley Williams-Bolar got out of jail yesterday, having served 9 days of her 10-day sentence. Now she faces two years of probation and 80 hours of community service.

title: Poppa Neutrino, Trans-Atlantic Adventurer, Dies at 77
description: David Pearlman, an itinerant philosopher, adventurer and environmentalist widely known as Poppa Neutrino, who founded his own church, crossed the Atlantic on a raft made from scrap and invented a theoretically unstoppable football strategy, died on Sunday in New Orleans. He was 77.

title: Power Shift in Mens Tennis?
description: It took mere seconds after the final point of Roger Federers loss in the Australian Open semifinals Thursday for the idea to grab hold that an era had ended. No, Federer didnt announce his retirement after the match, but his defeat, coming only a day after Rafael Nadal was bounced from the tournament, seemed ominous. After all, having Federer or Nadal in a Grand Slam final was always so dependable. They were like the furniture. Its never normal when you wake up to find your couch missing.

title: Piano on a Sandbar: Mystery Solved
description: MIAMI SHORES, Fla.  The marine patrol officers and fish and wildlife agents made an onshore visit Thursday to the home of one Nick Harrington, 16, to deliver an ultimatum: Remove the grand piano from Biscayne Bay within 24 hours or face felony charges, a $5,000 fine or, perhaps, worse.

title: Gates Says Budget Impasse Threatens Readiness
description: OTTAWA  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates, escalating his budget battle with Congress, has issued an unusually passionate warning that the impasse over this years federal spending package threatens the militarys readiness to fight.

title: Pawlowski Interview 2
description: Interview update with Pfc. Bradley Pawlowski

title: The Worst of Them All
description: LOS ANGELES The Kings Speech was, of course, the top nomination-getter for the Academy Awards, but in all the Oscar fanfare you might have missed an equally rarefied award: the Razzies, (dis)honoring the worst films and performances of the year. Leading the pack for the Feb. 26 awards show is M. Night Shyamalans The Last Airbender, which earned worst director, worst picture, worst remake, worst screenplay, worst screen couple/ensemble (the entire cast) and a brand-new category, worst eye-gouging misuse of 3-D. The rest of the worst films were: The Twilight Saga: Eclipse; the parody Vampires Suck; Sex and the City 2 (alas, not a parody); and The Bounty Hunter.

title: Olmert Memoir Cites Near Deal for Mideast Peace
description: JERUSALEM  Ehud Olmert, the former prime minister of Israel, says in new memoirs that he and Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, were very close to a peace deal two years ago, but Mr. Abbass hesitation, Mr. Olmerts own legal troubles and the Israeli war in Gaza caused their talks to end. Shortly afterward, a right-wing Israeli government came to power.

title: Djokovic in Top Form Ousting Federer
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  In professional tennis, which bristles with entourages and agendas, postmatch consensus can be as elusive as a great drop shot. But when the mens semifinal between Roger Federer and Novak Djokovic finished Thursday night, there was no debate.

title: Photographing a Federal Building From a Public Space? Youre Not Breaking Any Laws
description: Most street photographers  amateur and professional  have probably had the run-in at least once: theyre taking pictures of building exteriors from a public way and someone wearing a uniform comes up and tells them to stop. (Can I help you? are among the more chilling words a photographer can hear these days.) After Antonio Musumeci was arrested for doing just that, the New York Civil Liberties Union filed a lawsuit. The case was settled in October when the government agreed that the public had a right to photograph the exteriors of federal buildings from public spaces. Now, the civil liberties union has received a copy of the federal directive that puts this finding in force and has shared it with the public. Having a print-out in hand may save you some hassle the next time youre taking pictures. The full story is on Lens.

title: Egg and Cheese on a Bagel: The Quest for the Best
description: The mail brought a devilish question about breakfast bagels, while someone wanted to know where to get a drink and a bite after seeing The Merchant of Venice on Broadway. I tried to answer these queries and more. As always, you can send questions about where to go or what to eat in New York to dinejournal@nytimes.com.

title: Herbert Obama?
description: David A. Rosenberg, the chief economist and strategist at Gluskin Sheff, noticed some eerie parallels between President Obamas State of the Union speech and some statements by Herbert Hoover, who presided during the early years of the Great Depression. From Mr. Rosenbergs client note today:

title: Ristretto | First Look at the Kava Cafe
description: Kava Cafe opened earlier this month on a quiet stretch of Washington Street one block south of the High Line, where the Meatpacking District fades into the West Village. Its not just one of New Yorks newest coffee bars, its one of the citys most striking. 803 Washington Street; (212) 255-7495; kavanyc.com.

title: Colin Quinns Broadway Show Will Become an HBO Special
description: If this was how Colin Quinn and Jerry Seinfeld planned to get themselves back on television, they certainly picked a roundabout way of doing it: Colin Quinn Long Story Short, Mr. Quinns one-man show about the ascent and decline of civilization, which is also Mr. Seinfelds Broadway directorial debut, will be taped by HBO to be shown as a special in April, the cable network announced on Thursday.

title: Walk-Away Barge Is Corralled on Hudson River
description: Update, 12:59 p.m. | The city can rest easy: a barge floating free down the Hudson from Tarrytown has been stopped. As of 12:30, the barge is corralled, said Charles Rowe, a spokesman for the Coast Guard. The barge had traveled only about a mile south of the Tappan Zee Bridge. The tug got it under control and is taking back to its original mooring.

title: G.M. Drops Application for Federal Energy Loan
description: DETROIT  General Motors said on Thursday that it was withdrawing its application to borrow $14.4 billion from a pool of federal money intended to help automakers build more fuel-efficient vehicles.

title: Plan to Upgrade New Jersey Jail Into Model for Immigrant Detention Centers
description: For officials of Essex County, N.J., it promises to be a potential moneymaker in struggling Newark: a proposed upgrading and extension of the county jail so it would hold hundreds more immigrants than it does now.

title: From Heineken, Insights on Emerging Markets
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  The World Economic Forums annual meeting takes place in Europe, but the real economic action is in emerging markets. So on Thursday executives got advice from a veteran on how to do business in those markets, an urgent question when growth in Europe and America remains tepid.

title: Betting on Chess
description: London oddsmakers allow wagering on everything else, so it is probably not surprising that they also take bets on chess.

title: Senate Tea Party Caucus Holds First Meeting
description: Some of the Tea Partys most prominent candidates never made it to Washington (think Christine I am not a witch ODonnell of Delaware), but the movement that perhaps best embodied the anti-incumbent sentiment of 2010 has nonetheless gained a toehold in the upper chamber of Congress. And on Thursday it became official: Senator Jim DeMint of South Carolina, the Tea Party patron, and the freshmen senators Rand Paul of Kentucky and Mike Lee of Utah held the first official gathering of the Senate Tea Party Caucus.

title: Chief Risk Officer, Hollywoods New Sex Symbol
description: PARK CITY, UTAH  Chief risk officers have long held one of Wall Streets most thankless and unglamorous jobs. In good times, they get derided as Chicken Littles. In bad times, they get blamed for being too slow to take the punch bowl away at the party.
