title: Australian Open Update: Power of Threes
description: It was good to be a No. 3 seed on Thursday at the Australian Open.

title: Gran Turismo 5 Awaits New Challengers
description: After its much-anticipated  and delayed  arrival, Gran Turismo 5, the racing simulation series for the Sony PlayStation 3, hit the streets in late November. Over the last couple of months, Sam Schembari  our resident racing game aficionado, and a son of James Schembari, an editor for the Automobiles section  has been unraveling the layers of the game.

title: Photo of the Week
description: A vegetable seller walks in the Brahmaputra River in Guwahati, India.

title: In Cactus Flower Revival, Jenni Barber Gets the Role That Made Goldie Hawn a Movie Star
description: Casting is complete for the first major New York revival of Cactus Flower, the Abe Burrows romantic farce that had 1,234 performances on Broadway from 1965 to 1968 and netted Goldie Hawn a career-making Best Supporting Actress Oscar for the 1969 film version.

title: How the U.S. Can Compete Better
description: In an interview with DealBooks Andrew Ross Sorkin at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, Michael Porter, professor at Harvard Business School, offers insight on how to make the United States more competitive.

title: Tricks to Keep Thieves Away From Your Home
description: If you dont have a burglar alarm, or even if you do, you may set your lights to timers to make it appear that someone is home as a way to help keep thieves at bay.

title: Letters: Eurotrashed
description: I read with great interest Paul Krugmans review of the issues facing the euro. What he failed to point out, however, was that many of the policies that got Europe and its currency into so much trouble are in the process of being repeated by the Obama administration  deficit spending on runaway government expenditures, unaffordable social programs, unfunded public pension funds, among others. Shouldnt Europes problems be a siren call for the United States to return to a policy of living within its means and of individual responsibility?

title: Letter: How Deep Is Their Love?
description: Steven Erlangers article told us how the sparks fly between Nicolas Sarkozy and Angela Merkel as each tries to press his or her vision of Europes future on the other. Pictures of the two leaders show them apparently bickering in an alleyway and strolling amicably at the Deauville waterside. A very informative piece, but with one tantalizing fact omitted: in what language do they converse?

title: New Leader for State Development Agency
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo appointed one of the states top business lobbyists on Thursday as chief executive of the Empire State Development Corporation, the quasi-independent agency that traditionally leads New Yorks economic development efforts.

title: Letters: No More Mrs. Nice Mom
description: In response to Judith Warners question, Is the iron hand of Chinese parenting the future for Americans raising their kids? my answer is a resounding no  it shouldnt be. Perhaps Im biased, being a Chinese-American daughter myself, but doesnt that give me a voice on this issue?

title: Letter: Watch Me, Read Me
description: Virginia Heffernans Medium column misses the mark. Do we really need a break from the hard mental labor of reading books? Does my affinity to books without the bells and whistles of insta-scenes and audible voices make me a television-hater? Surely our imaginations dont need a break when our attention spans are shrinking by the moment in this fast-paced world of Internet, e-mail, texts, Twitter and the rest. Apparently the Vook is distinctive from an overdesigned book or the Web because when you read/watch/listen to the Vook, you are uninterrupted by the constant flow of gaudy video, graphics, music, clocks. Fair enough, but wouldnt a real book be the true antidote?

title: Letter: Nut Worth
description: Christine Muhlkes Food column on hazelnut farming can be a lesson for thousands of people who own a bit of land and are not afraid of hard work. While it is rare to find those who can make their livelihood exclusively from growing nuts, it is common to find those who have planted a few trees in their backyards, on school campuses or as a fence row to their properties who delight in the food they have grown with their own hands. As the worlds population increases, the need for planting perennial nut and fruit crops becomes more obvious.

title: Letters: The Crazy Lady Upstairs
description: Reading Caitlin Shetterlys Lives column, my reaction was one of deep sorrow. My story, fortunately, has a happy ending. When my younger sister went out to California in the 1970s to live and work, she had a secretarial job and an apartment and was, for the most part, self-sufficient. Then slowly things started to go awry. She lost her job and became unrealistic in her approach to her life and her day-to-day living. She stopped answering her phone and never left her apartment until she was evicted. When she came to live with my husband and me, it was four years before we could get her all the necessary help she needed. She is now 66 years old, content and happily settled in a wonderful home facility not far from us with a caring staff. How very sad that the deeply troubled lady upstairs from Shetterly wouldnt or couldnt allow someone in her life to help her.

title: Letter: Things to Do in Cyberspace When Youre Dead
description: The richness of narratives in physical form has been going through a vanishing act for some time. The scarcity of instant outlets of expression like Twitter, Facebook, text messages and even regular e-mail perhaps allowed room for greater introspection and reflection to the pre-Internet generation to a degree that makes my generation, the so-called millennials, seem shallow. But the banality and ubiquity of tweets, posts and online communication gives back our humanity, wrapped in humility. Its still precious. Rob Walkers article (Jan. 9) reminded me that our digital preserves/selves need more care and thought than I imagined.

title: News Corporation to Release The Daily Next Week
description: One year to the day after Steve Jobs unveiled the iPad, the News Corporation said it was ready to unveil its iPad newspaper, The Daily.

title: Treasury Hires Perella Weinberg to Advise on Ally I.P.O.
description: The Treasury Department has hired Perella Weinberg Partners to advise the government on Ally Financials impending initial public offering, according to a contract posted online on Thursday.

title: Corporate Taxes: More Winners and Losers
description: There is a wide variation among industries in the share of income paid in federal taxes, as I noted in an article this morning about the presidents call for an overhaul of the corporate tax code. The article includes a few examples, but the longer list of industries and effective tax rates also makes for fascinating reading.

title: Senate Reaches Deal to Limit Blocking Tactics
description: The Senate leadership agreed on Thursday to temper some of the procedural tactics that have tied up the chamber for the past two years, and to institute other changes intended to ease gridlock.

title: Ozawa Cancels Carnegie Hall Dates After Back Surgery
description: Seiji Ozawa, whose health problems have forced him to cut back on performing for the last year, is canceling his spring appearances at Carnegie Hall. Mr. Ozawas doctors believe he will not have recovered enough from recent back surgery to repair herniated discs, Carnegie said. The concerts were scheduled for April 1 and 2. Mr. Ozawa was to have conducted his youth orchestra, the Seiji Ozawa Ongaku-juku, as part of Carnegies JapanNYC festival, of which he is the artistic director. The hall said ticket holders would be reimbursed for the canceled concerts. Mr. Ozawa scaled down his appearances with the Saito Kinen Orchestra during the festivals December portion because of his ailments, which included esophageal cancer and chronic back problems.

title: Koch Industries Unamused by Climate Spoof
description: From the sometimes bizarre front lines of the climate-change culture wars: It seems the brothers Koch, proprietors of the giant, Kansas-based industrial conglomerate and well-heeled supporters of Tea Party causes, have now set their sights on a group of anonymous pranksters who spoofed a Koch Industries press release last month  one that suggested the brothers were having a change of heart on climate change.

title: Quiet Off-Season for Yankees, Not for Cashman
description: For the better part of a memorable decade, Brian Cashman was the stealth operator in an organization fronted by a sainted manager and a combustible owner.

title: Despite Obamas Call, No Rush in R.O.T.C.s Return to Campus
description: In his State of the Union address on Tuesday night, President Obama called for college campuses to open their doors to our military recruiters and the Reserve Officer Training Corps.

title: Another Snowstorm Buries the Northeast
description: The region dug out from another round of snow on Thursday.

title: Franzenfreude
description: Twitter tag coined to express frustration with literary critics apparent preference for works by white male authors, such as Jonathan Franzen.

title: Celtics Perkins, the Some-Stats All-Star
description: In a seminal piece here at The Times, the esteemed Michael Lewis once dubbed Shane Battier - a defensive specialist and limited offensive wing player for the Houston Rockets - as the No-Stats All-Star. In a way, the distinction was fitting; the traditional box score has never been kind to Battier, due to his lack of impressive point totals, superhuman rebounding performances, or gaudy assist numbers. Even on the defensive end, Battiers style is more conducive to contested shots than outright steals or blocks, leaving little statistical trace of his on-court impact in the box score.

title: Insiders Guides to Overcoming Eating Disorders
description: Reading is an inestimable resource in just about any undertaking, especially so when one discovers a work that performs a real service and is written with passion, accuracy and pragmatism. Such is the case with two unflinching personal narratives on eating disorders, Portia de Rossis Unbearable Lightness: A Story of Loss and Gain and the 25th anniversary edition of Bulimia: A Guide to Recovery, by Lindsey Hall and Leigh Cohn.

title: Appendix: Apps for Free Calls to Regular Phones
description: In my Times column today, I tackled the complex and rapidly shifting topic of free Internet phone calls. I pointed out that these so-called VOIP apps (for voice over Internet Protocol) generally offer poor sound quality, audio delays and longer connection times  but they can save you a ton of money.

title: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Yemen, Egypt and New York

title: Everyone Was to Blame, Crisis Commission Finds
description: The blow-by-blow chronicle of the Wall Street recklessness that led to the financial crisis is reminiscent of a legendary house party.

title: Putting Personality on Paper: Writing About People Using Times Models
description: Overview | How does a writer get beyond basic facts and events to write about people in a captivating yet concise way? What elements and details make for an interesting profile? This lesson offers some examples of ways you can use The New York Times as a model for writing about people.

title: Staten Island Ferry Terminal, 8:02 A.M.
description: Commuters exiting the Staten Island Ferry Terminal.

title: Notable Quotes From Obama, Palin, Bachmann and Reid
description: The past couple of days have been full of noteworthy comments from political figures. Here are some of our favorites:

title: In a Fathers Footsteps, Into the Police Force and on the Track
description: Derek Powers will not be passing the baton to his son Erek on Friday. He already passed his shield to him years ago  the same badge Dereks grandfather wore a half-century ago in the New York Police Department.

title: Yemens Opposition Goes to Code Pink
description: The protesters who filled the streets of Sana, the Yemeni capital, on Thursday demanding the resignation of the countrys authoritarian leader claimed inspiration from similar large antigovernment protests that have rattled Egypt and toppled the government in Tunisia this month.

title: Getting Chicken Crisp Outside, Moist Inside
description: When eating in a restaurant, I try to learn things that I can apply to my home cooking. What I mostly learn, of course, is how much better the professionals are, but still

title: Tools Suggest Earlier Human Exit From Africa
description: A cache of stone tools found on the east coast of the Arabian Peninsula has reopened the critical question of when and how modern humans escaped from their ancestral homeland in eastern Africa.

title: About Faces | Genevas Watch Fair
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#636", 592, 430, true, chameleonData);

title: Few Signs of United Approach to Financial Regulation
description: 6:45 p.m. | Updated

title: Kava Cafe, Coffee With Class
description: On the Ristretto blog, Oliver Strand reports on Kava Cafe, on a quiet stretch of Washington Street one block south of the High Line. He calls it one of the citys most striking coffee bars.

title: Attorney General to Bolster Anti-Fraud Efforts
description: The New York attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, in his first official press conference, announced on Thursday that he would bulk up his offices unit that takes on Medicaid fraud and create a new group to tackle fraud in other areas, like taxes, pensions and government contracts.

title: They Came, They Saw, They Smushed: A Vision of Jersey Shore in Italy
description: Next Media Animation, the Taiwanese company that delights us with its off-kilter, computer-rendered interpretations of American popular culture, turns its attention to the recent news that the Jersey Shore cast will be headed to Italy, and the resulting video (which we were pointed to by the good folks at Gothamist) is, to coin a phrase, a blast in a glass. Whoever digitally reproduced the Sistine Chapel so that it could be defaced in animation by what appears to be a Jersey Shore cast member (Pauly D? Vinny?) is clearly the Michelangelo of this nascent art form.

title: Globe-Trotter Clinton Makes Davos Stop
After Bombing, Iraqis Direct Anger at Police
description: BAGHDAD  Anger at Iraqs security forces boiled over Thursday after a suicide bomber detonated a car bomb beside an outdoor funeral service, killing dozens and sending residents storming into the street, some firing warning shots at the police they said had failed to protect them.

title: American Idol Dominates the Competition
description: American Idol flexed its ratings muscles in the second week of its latest edition, exhibiting overwhelming dominance over its competition, with an audience that surpassed 25 million.

title: Eboni Marshall and Rossie Turman III
description: ON the Saturday night in June that Rossie Turman planned to propose to Eboni Marshall, he was shocked to discover that the restaurant where he wanted to do it  Asiate in the Mandarin Oriental Hotel  had booked him for the following Saturday. He made frantic calls to the restaurant and was told he would be called back if they could accommodate him.

title: Guy Velella, 66, Politician Brought Down by Ethical Lapses, Dies
description: Guy J. Velella, a former Republican state senator from the Bronx and an influential figure in Albany until he pleaded guilty to bribery conspiracy seven years ago, died Thursday at a hospice in the Bronx. He was 66.

title: Island Birds + Invading Boa = Trouble in Paradise
description: For thousands of years, human mobility has brought all manner of species to isolated islands and regions, with the result being powerfully disrupted ecosystems. As Ive said before, in recent decades weve become something of a Waring blender for biology, for better or worse.

title: French Leader Scales Back Ambitions for New Monetary System
description: 05:02 a.m. | Updated DAVOS, Switzerland  When President Nicolas Sarkozy of France addressed the worlds elite here last year, he proclaimed a grand vision of a new economic and monetary order  a new Bretton Woods, no less.

title: Theater Listings: Jan. 28  Feb. 3
description: Theater

title: Divisions on the Right Over Gays in Its Ranks
description: A bitter dispute over whether a gay conservative group should co-sponsor the conservative movements largest gathering of the year has led some prominent supporters to withdraw from the event next month.

title: Pledge on Sharks Proved Hollow, Report Says
description: Many of the worlds top shark-fishing nations have yet to develop plans to manage and conserve dwindling shark populations, despite a 2001 pledge to do so, a new report from two conservation groups says.

title: Harsh Words for Regulators in Crisis Commission Report
description: The Congressional commissions scathing account of the financial crisis casts regulators in a rather unflattering light, as the sheriff who didnt stop Wall Street from becoming the Wild West.

title: Altering a Mouse Gene Turns Up Aggression, Study Says
description: For some genes, either the fathers version or the mothers version is active, but not both. Which version of the gene works is determined before conception, as the sperm and egg are developing, in a process called imprinting. By mimicking that process in the lab, and turning off a gene in mice, scientists have produced a change in social dominance behavior. In laboratory tests, mice with the paternal version of the gene known as Grb10 inactivated were more aggressive in their behavior, according to new research in the journal Nature.

title: On Bravo, Dating Advice from a Guy
description: Bravo, which has found success with a live late-night talk show hosted by Andy Cohen, is trying out another one.

title: For Housing, a Quick Fix 0r Less Risk
description: What can be done with Frannie? We love her and we need her. But we have to get along without her, or at least learn to live without relying on her so much.

title: A Voyage of Discovery As a New Hall Sets Sail
description: MIAMI BEACH  Many orchestra halls and opera houses are just too big. Even if the acoustics are good, the music can sound far off, and the audience can feel too separated from the performers.

title: A More Private Budgeting Tool
description: Some consumers are wary of using online budgeting sites like Mint.com  for fear of having to share their personal account information numbers and passwords.

title: TimesCast | January 27, 2011
description: Thousands protest in Yemen; the Senate Tea Party Caucus meets for the first time; and it's the snowiest January on record for New York City.

title: Outtakes From the Crisis Commission Report
description: The Financial Crisis Inquiry Commissions report into the financial crisis is rather dense at 500-plus pages. So we at DealBook have pulled together some of the best outtakes. Heres what the Congressional commission had to say on various topics:

title: U.S. Approves Genetically Modified Alfalfa
description: Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack announced on Thursday that he would authorize the unrestricted commercial cultivation of genetically modified alfalfa, setting aside a controversial compromise that had generated stiff opposition.

title: Zipcar Adds Toyota Prius Plug-In Hybrids to Fleet
description: On Thursday, eight plug-in Toyota Prius hybrids became available to members of Zipcar, the car-sharing service that began in the Boston area 11 years ago. The plug-in Prius will not be made available to individual customers until 2012.

title: 36 Hours in Lisbon
description: CHEAP. Thats the label usually slapped across the forehead of the Portuguese capital. Around the Continent, the waterside city is mostly seen as the charmingly faded seat of a centuries-gone trade empire where you can plunk down some coins to ride an old yellow cable car, visit Baroque churches and squares, fill up on cut-rate seafood meals, sip 2-euro glasses of Portuguese red and retire to your budget hotel. But Lisbon is getting fancier every month. By day, ambitious upstart museums and renovated industrial districts offer an infusion of contemporary art and design. By night, a fledgling wave of neo-Portuguese restaurants, stylish night spots and innovatively designed hotels provide happening places to play. The best part? The city remains a terrific bargain.

title: Afternoon Commute Outlook: Somewhat Improved
description: Many New Yorkers headed home from work on Thursday will barely notice the aftereffects of Wednesday nights snowstorm: the vast majority of the citys subway system, along with the PATH train (latest info ) and New Jersey Transit (latest info ) , will operate close to a normal weekday schedule.

title: As China Evolves, So Does an Artist
description: The Beijing artist Wang Qingsong, born at the beginning of the Cultural Revolution, has seen China morph from an insular, rural society to a globally engaged dynamo. His art has evolved just as rapidly, from Gaudy Painting (a Chinese variation on Pop) to giant photographs staged in movie studios and short, performance-based videos. All of these works regard recent changes in Chinese culture  the proliferation of McDonalds, overcrowded cities, even a booming art scene  from an ironic stance that needs no translation.

title: The Missing Ingredient in Accountable Care
description: This past week while spending time with nonmedical friends, I found myself referring to what health care experts have been touting as the systems best hope for the future. My friends, eager to learn more and always game for any clarification of the health care system, leaned in to hear me expound on accountable care organizations, or A.C.O.s.

title: Making Patients Part of Accountable Care
description: Accountable care organizations, or A.C.O.s, are quickly becoming the it girl of the health care overhaul, garnering admiration from policy makers, researchers, third-party payers and politicians of all stripes.

title: Artifacts of an Imagined Time
description: Legions of modern artists have been attracted to things prehistoric, archaic and primordial. Gauguin painted fantasies of a South Pacific Eden. Picasso drew inspiration from African masks, which, misguidedly or not, he took for signs of timeless human ferocity. A traveler happening on Robert Smithsons Spiral Jetty could mistake it for a ceremonial maze built by ancient pagans.

title: Falling in Love, Longing and Leering
description: Cloud Nothings

title: Prized Chinese Crafts, Delicate and Detailed
description: Chinese emperors so highly prized cloisonn enameling that only certain eunuchs were deemed trustworthy enough to transport the objects between palace rooms. When the government sent cloisonn gifts outside Peking, bureaucrats from the imperial household traveled with them.

title: Jay Carney to Become White House Press Secretary
description: 5:19 p.m. | Updated Jay Carney, the spokesman for Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., will replace Robert Gibbs as the White House press secretary, the White House announced.

title: Curbing Closing Costs
description: BORROWERS have some weapons for keeping closing costs down, the result of recent guidelines requiring lenders to disclose certain fees, but perhaps the most underutilized consumer tool simply involves old-fashioned haggling.

title: A Rainy, Snowy Night Creates Chaos Along the East Coast
description: WASHINGTON  The storm that tormented the East Coast delivered its knockout punch here in the nations capital, where almost 200,000 people remained without electricity on Thursday, and disruptions across the metropolitan area caused some of the worst commuting delays on the Eastern Seaboard.

title: Analysis: How Li Rallied Past Wozniacki
description: When you have the match in hand - as Caroline Wozniacki did in Thursdays semifinal against Li Na  and then go on to lose it after having a match point, theres a tendency to focus on that one lost opportunity when you do a postmortem on the match.

title: Before His Death, Ugandan Gay Rights Activist Explained Hostile Climate
description: Updated | 4:55 p.m. Before he was beaten to death with a hammer on Wednesday, David Kato was the most outspoken gay rights advocate in Uganda, where homophobia is so widespread that Parliament is considering a bill that would provide for the execution of homosexuals, as my colleague Jeffrey Gettleman reports.

title: A Possible Silver Lining for Hot Flashes
description: Do hot flashes have a silver lining?

title: Stranded on the N Train, Without Much of an Ordeal
description: Dozens of passengers were stranded early Thursday morning on an N train that was parked overnight at the Coney Island-Stillwell Avenue station. But the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said the incident was far different from the stranded A trains in the Rockaways that became a symbol of governmental bungling during the big December snowstorm.

title: Old Wheels Get New Life
description: Roller rink owners in New York say they have seen more customers lately.

title: Standoff in a Frigid Circle of Hell
description: The ever-changing light on the desolate Arctic island where two meteorologists operate a weather station is as fluctuating as the tense relationship between the men in Alexei Popogrebskys gripping survival drama, How I Ended This Summer.

title: At Sothebys Sale, Titian Draws One Bidder
description: Despite the snow, all the usual suspects were present at Sothebys New York salesroom on Thursday morning to watch the fate of Titians Sacra Conversazione: The Madonna and Child With Saints Luke and Catherine of Alexandria.

title: Egypts Leader Uses Old Tricks to Defy New Demands
description: CAIRO  Political protests may be rocking Egypt with a new, nonideological force, but President Hosni Mubarak and his allies have not veered from a playbook they have followed through nearly three decades of one-party rule.

title: Neighborhood Joint | Cynthia King Dance Studio
description: At a dance studio in the Windsor Terrace section of Brooklyn, vegan ballet slippers are part of the dress code.

title: Because Summer Is for Barbecues
description: IN the summer of 2009, Rob Carlo and some partners opened a bar called Lucky Dog, on Bedford Avenue in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Mr. Carlo was also an owner of the East Village Tavern in Greenwich Village, but he took to Williamsburg in a way he hadnt to the Village.

title: Pli Time for Tots in Tights
description: FIVE minutes before the afternoons first class, the waiting room, chilly from the outside air as the storefronts glass door swung open and shut, hummed with activity and talk. Snow boots were exchanged for ballet slippers, sweaters for leotards, jeans for colored tights. Wayward strands of hair were tucked away.

title: Robert D. LiMandri
description: Mr. LiMandri, 45, is the commissioner of the Department of Buildings, which oversees nearly a million properties in New York City, by enforcing various building codes and laws. He was appointed in 2008, after the resignation of Patricia J. Lancaster, following a series of construction accidents, including a crane collapse in Manhattan that killed seven people.

title: Hit Man Is Back, Teaching the Tricks of the Trade
description: Sleek as a bullet, the action star Jason Statham jaw-clenches his way through The Mechanic, a sputtering remake in need of a more powerful recharge. A contempo update of the 1972 Charles Bronson vehicle of the same name (alternately titled Killer of Killers), the story pivots on one of those professional assassins in the employ of one of those hush-hush organizations in which men murmur murderous instructions into phones so that other men can die. For a hit man like Arthur Bishop (Mr. Statham), this makes for an isolated if lucrative life that comes with a swank pad, a vintage muscle car and paid nights with the local talent.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: The Invisible Women at Davos The Davos column that is burning up the blogosphere is one by Anya Schiffrin, wife of the economist Joseph Stiglitz, who writes about how wives and girlfriends are treated at the World Economic Forum. The most revealing sign of our lowly status is that we are forced to wear the ultimate badge of shame  the white name tag, she writes. White name tags reveal only the ones name  rendering the wearer for the most part invisible in Davos. Reuters Davos Notebook

title: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Yemen, Egypt and New York

title: LinkedIn Files Papers to Go Public
description: 8:31 p.m. | Updated

title: Quote Unquote | The Jokes On Her
description: Helena Bonham Carter discusses what it feels like to be compared style-wise to Lady Gaga.

title: Perspective Gained From One Seniors Hardship
description: As students jockey for spots in top colleges and fret over not getting into their dream schools, a bit of perspective can be welcome.

title: Q & A
description: Showing an Apartment Before a Lease Ends

title: A Mind Where Picasso Meets Looney Tunes
description: The American artist George Condo made a splash in New York in the early 1980s with a line of surrealist-style figure paintings. It was tasty, erudite stuff, freaky but classy, a Mixmaster version of old master, with a big glop of Pop tossed in. Then he went to Europe, found an avid audience and stayed for a decade, mostly in Paris. To the New York art world, myopic and memoryless, he might have moved to Mars.

title: Keeping Score: The Cavaliers Decline Is on Record Pace
description: On the morning of Dec. 2, the Cleveland Cavaliers had a record of 7-10. While that record was nothing to brag about, at the time it was good for eighth place in the Eastern Conference, and Cleveland fans were cautiously optimistic about the teams prospects.

title: Debut of Game Device and Strength in Business Sales Lift Microsoft
description: Microsoft rode strong sales of its new Kinect game device and its mainstay software products to deliver robust quarterly profits and sales.

title: Addressing the Issue of Home Affordability
description: Garden City

title: Web Book Moves to Print
description: HarperCollins will publish a young-adult book that was originally submitted on Inkpop, its Web site for teenage writing. The book, a debut novel by Leigh Fallon, a South African living in Ireland, is scheduled for release in the fall, the publisher said on Thursday. Ms. Fallon first contacted literary agents about her novel, The Carrier of the Mark, a paranormal romance, but was unsuccessful in getting it published. She submitted it on Inkpop in December 2009, and it was quickly voted one of the top five manuscripts on the site. HarperCollins followed up a few months later with an offer of a book contract  its first for a work published on the site. Susan Katz, the president and publisher of HarperCollins Childrens Books, called the novel an outstanding project.

title: As Inventory Rises, More Towns Make the Cold List
description: REMEMBER when brokers used to say the sales pace in a particular town, neighborhood or ZIP code had turned white-hot or was sizzling?

title: Giulietta of the Spirits
description: Sofia Sizzi looks blissed out, a bit nervous, possibly on the edge of tears. She is talking about her still-unfinished debut collection, which will premiere under the name Giulietta on February 14 as part of New York Fashion Week. She has invited The Moment into her design studio on Grand Street in SoHo, when the conversation suddenly shifts from classic Italian films to a much more personal place. I dont think Ive experienced such happiness since I was a five-year-old girl in Italy, she says about her clothes, welling up.

title: End of the World? Maybe. First, Sex.
description: Smith, the bisexual Southern California college student whose misadventures  some possibly in his own head, many in other peoples beds  are at the center of Kaboom, is a cinema studies major. This fact in itself may not be enough to establish him as an alter ego for the director, Gregg Araki, but it does allow Mr. Araki to offer some hints about what he is up to in this chaotic, trifling, oddly likable film.

title: Asian Cup: Redemption for Australia?
description: DOHA, Qatar  Australia Day was special this year because the Socceroos have made it to the championship game of the Asian Cup, after trouncing Uzbekistan, 6-0. Australia will play Japan for the title on Saturday.

title: Wagering Art Loans on the Superbowl
description: Impressionism and the Super Bowl might seem like strange bedfellows, but they will be getting a little bro time together this year in the spirit of the game. Continuing an art tradition that began last year, the Carnegie Museum of Art in Pittsburgh and the Milwaukee Art Museum (the closest museum to Green Bay, Wisc., home of the Packers), have agreed to make a gridiron bet. If Green Bay wins, the Carnegie will send Pierre Renoirs Bathers with a Crab from the 1890s to Milwaukee as a temporary loan. If the Steelers win, the Carnegies patrons will get a brief visit from a Gustave Caillebotte, another water-focused scene titled Boating on the Yerres from 1877.

title: Writing the Play His Curiosity Led Him To
description: MATTHEW LOPEZ is ready for the question but continues to refine the answer. How did he, a self-described foxhole Episcopalian from the Florida Panhandle, the son of a Puerto Rican father and a Polish-Russian mother, come to write a play about a Jewish Confederate soldier and two former slaves raised as Jews who, in the charred wreck of a Virginia home after the Civil War, celebrate Passover together?

title: What They Are Reading: Different Accounts of the Afghan War
description: Todays look at reading materials in circulation among those who work in Afghanistan covers two different accounts of the Afghan war.

title: Mike Pence Will Not Run for President
description: Representative Mike Pence of Indiana announced Thursday that he would not be a Republican candidate for president in 2012, but he left the door open to running for governor.

title: George Condo: Mental States
description: Images from the New Museums exhibition.

title: This Martial Artists Fists Never Leave His Body
description: The dynamo at the center of Ip Man 2: Legend of the Grandmaster doesnt leap over buildings in a single bound, but he comes entertainingly close to superhero status.

title: Israeli Journalist Reports Death Threats Over Gaza War Film
description: Nurit Kedar, an Israeli documentary filmmaker, told Channel 4 News of Britain on Thursday that she had received death threats following the broadcast of her latest film, a report on Israeli soldiers who expressed regrets over their own conduct during the war in Gaza two years ago.

title: Works to Challenge an Audience, or Not
description: As I watched David Parsonss Sleep Study on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater, I felt a growing sense of incredulity. This 1987 piece has a single conceit: six dancers roll around the floor  curling up, stretching out, piling over one another  while a seventh sleeps motionless at the front of the stage, waking at the final moment. If the piece had been conceived by my third graders dance class and presented at the end-of-year school recital, my indulgent smile would have faded after five minutes.

title: The Cheeriness of Those Gershwin Boys
description: An unquenchable joie de vivre buoyed by an antic humor that wells up like spring water: the impulse to feel good is a driving force in the songs of George and Ira Gershwin, perhaps more so than in the work of any other major 20th-century songwriting team. No wonder everyone loves the Gershwins.

title: Parting Glance: Lucas Mebrouk Dolega, 32
description: Hundreds of friends, family members and colleagues gathered at Pre Lachaise Cemetery in Paris Thursday to remember Lucas Mebrouk Dolega, a photographer for the European Pressphoto Agency. Mr. Dolega, who was 32, died Jan. 17 from an injury suffered three days earlier while he was covering violent street protests in Tunis. He was hit by a tear gas grenade launched by a police officer at close range.

title: FIA BACKSTROM/Christian Philipp Mller
description: Murray Guy

title: On Hollywood, HIV, Alcohol and Warming
description: David Roberts has posted an interesting Grist interview with Sandra de Castro Buffington, who directs the Hollywood, Health and Society program at the University of Southern California.

title: TOM THAYER: Scenographic Play
description: Tracy Williams

title: Spare Times for Jan. 28-Feb. 3
description: Around Town

title: LESLIE THORNTON: Binocular
description: Winkleman Gallery

title: PATRICK HILL: Clumsy Angels
description: Bortolami

title: Spare Times: For Children, for Jan. 28-Feb. 3
description: VELMA GRATCH & THE WAY COOL BUTTERFLY

title: A Textured Palette Without Much Paint
description: Sergej Jensens shy, luminous, physically scant paintings, often made of little more than scraps of linen and other found fabrics, are tightrope walkers that travel light. Balancing gracefully between reverence and irreverence while deftly eluding irony, they jettison so much of paintings traditional baggage that they almost question themselves out of existence. But not quite.

title: Turns Out Sundance Thrives on More Than Just Money
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Thirty years ago Raiders of the Lost Ark was riding high at the box office, and American independent filmmaking was still an anomalous pursuit rather than a community, a recognized passion, a mark of cool. That year Charles Burnett won prizes at the Berlin Film Festival and the US Film Festival for Killer of Sheep but was unable to secure an American distributor for that masterpiece. The US Festival moved from Salt Lake City to this Utah ski town and was soon taken over by the Sundance Institute, founded by Robert Redford to support independent filmmakers.

title: BankUnited Prices I.P.O. at $27 a Share
description: BankUnited is set on Friday to become the latest company to exceed expectations with its public stock offering.

title: U.S. Company, in Reversal, Wants to Export Natural Gas
description: CAMERON PARISH, La.  The oil patch is a world of risk takers, but few are as daring as Charif Souki, the chairman and chief executive of Cheniere Energy.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Jan. 28-Feb. 3
description: Art

title: Recording as a Road to Recovery
description: INTERVIEWED in November 2006, the French pianist Hlne Grimaud spoke of her recent recovery from a series of dire illnesses  pneumonia, leading to chronic fatigue syndrome and an infection that spread from her lungs to her heart  and of her new Deutsche Grammophon recording, Reflections: a mixed bag of orchestral, vocal and chamber works by Robert and Clara Schumann and their prodigious protg Brahms.

title: If a No-Show Shows
description: I hosted a dinner-dance for my husbands 40th birthday. With two weeks to go, Id heard from all 80 invitees, except one couple. A few days before the party, I ran into the wife. Meant to call, she said. We cant make it. I was taken aback, but thanked her. Then the husband showed up to the seated dinner. I created a place, and the party went swimmingly, but I continue to be stunned. Thoughts?

title: With a Simple Snow Day, a Mayors Image Is Reborn
description: Surely, it is one of the most dramatic reversals of fortune in the annals of modern politics.

title: Movie Listings for Jan. 28-Feb. 3
description: Movies

title: Dance Listings for Jan. 28-Feb. 3
description: Dance

title: Need Any Help? Go Ask Mary
description: IN 1956, the year Dwight Eisenhower was re-elected to the presidency, Elvis Presley was burning up the airways and Clairol was posing the question, Does she or doesnt she?, an Italian-American couple named Zachary and Mary Sansone bought a modest two-story attached brick house in Borough Park, Brooklyn.

title: I Call Your/His Name
description: I FIRST met Tim Donohue on the set of a movie we both had been working on in upstate New York. We didnt start dating until three years later when we met again on another film set in Massachusetts, but I always knew our time would come. Tim Donohue and I were meant to be.

title: A Duet, Delicately Spun And Formally Elegant
description: Whenever Ralph Lemons inevitable (and deserved) retrospective opens at the Museum of Modern Art, curators will have their pick of videos, drawings, sculptures, words and performances from his richly varied career.

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Jan. 28-Feb. 3
description: Pop

title: Old Boys Network? Hardly. How About Lots of Tired Geezer Channels?
description: If living well is the best revenge, then women get theirs in the end. Not only do they tend to live longer than men but on television, at least, they seem to have a richer and more rewarding old age.

title: iEverything at Macworld Expo
description: Youve heard of iMac, iPod, iTunes, iPhone and iPad. Its time to meet iGrill.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for Jan. 28-Feb. 3
description: Classical

title: At William Beaver House, Unsold Condos Now for Rent
description: THE William Beaver House, at the intersection of William and Beaver Streets in the financial district, is an eye-catching 47-story building, its facade flecked with panels of yellow brick that, architecturally speaking, give it the look of a taxicab amid a fleet of limousines.

title: Jazz Listings for Jan. 28-Feb. 3
description: Jazz

title: Court Allows Emanuel on Ballot for Chicago Mayor
description: CHICAGO  Rahm Emanuels bid to become mayor of this city may proceed, the Illinois Supreme Court ruled on Thursday, ending a week that had turned this citys politics upside down, then back again.

title: Verizon to Buy Terremark for $1.4 Billion
description: Verizon Communications on Thursday announced it would buy I.T. services provider Terremark Worldwide for $19 a share, in a deal valued at $1.4 billion.

title: Court Allows Emanuel on Ballot for Chicago Mayor
description: CHICAGO  Rahm Emanuels bid to become mayor of this city may proceed, the Illinois Supreme Court ruled on Thursday.Read article

title: In Japan, Young Face Generational Roadblocks
description: TOKYO  Kenichi Horie was a promising auto engineer, exactly the sort of youthful talent Japan needs to maintain its edge over hungry Korean and Chinese rivals. As a worker in his early 30s at a major carmaker, Mr. Horie won praise for his design work on advanced biofuel systems.

title: Chilean Judge Orders Investigation Into Allendes Death
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  A Chilean judge has opened the first official investigation into the death of former President Salvador Allende, the democratically elected Socialist who died during the 1973 military coup led by Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

title: Weekend Miser
description: John Kander and Fred Ebb; teenagers and social networking sites; chocolate and peanut butter: this weeks events continue the tradition of interesting collaborations in entertainment, with the added benefit of being terribly cheap.

title: Laughing Off the Pounds
description: AS the owner of a fitness studio in Brooklyn, Elizabeth Pongo recognizes the humor and humiliation inherent in shaping up: the ill-fitting shorts, the mystifying gym contraptions, the tiny sacks of cookies portioned to deliver just 100 sad calories. Now Ms. Pongo is using her gym expertise and her stage experience as a stand-up comic to take back some dignity with a comedy night devoted entirely to laughing it all off.

title: House Tour: Woodstock, N.Y.
description: WHAT Three-bedroom house on three acres.

title: Giving the Devil His Possessive Due
description: What did you expect? Spinning heads? Pea soup? Father Lucas Trevant (Anthony Hopkins), a Jesuit who has performed thousands of exorcisms, inquires sarcastically of Michael Kovak (Colin ODonoghue), an earnest young American seminarian in The Rite.

title: A Slick Keyboard for the iPad
description: Feb. 8, 2011 | Updated to reflect that the Writer is not yet available for sale, but will go on sale in early March.

title: When Two Cultures Collide Under One Roof
description: When We Leave, the first feature written and directed by Feo Aladag, is a somber, sometimes powerful and frequently schematic drama about a woman trying to free herself from the emotional and physical violence of a cruel, patriarchal system. The violence is present from the very first shot, in which a young man (we will eventually learn that he is one of the main characters brothers) points a gun at a woman walking with her child. What follows flashes back from that moment, tracing a path of brutality, oppression and stifled individuality leavened by a few glimmers of tenderness and grace.

title: Interview With an Egyptian Blogger
description: Gigi Ibrahim, a recent graduate of the American University in Cairo, uses Twitter to document and share information about street protests.

title: Interview With an Egyptian Blogger
description: Gigi Ibrahim, an Egyptian blogger and activist  known as Gsquare86 on Twitter  spoke to The Lede via Skype from an Internet cafe in Cairo on Thursday evening.

title: Mixed Americas Family Trees
description: Examine the mixed-race family trees submitted by readers and listen to them describe their families, then submit your own.

title: Union Square, 12:52 P.M.
The Other Clippers
description: Its become something of a sports media ritual to pay daily tribute to Blake Griffin, and with the resurgent Clippers now winning their fair share of games, the importance of Eric Gordon has become a bit more celebrated. Together, Griffin and Gordon comprise a nucleus with enormous promise; both players are top-15 scorers on a per-game basis (and very nearly on a per-minute basis, where Gordon ranks 10th and Griffin 16th among all players with at least 500 minutes played), and their overall efficiency creates a stable foundation on which the Clippers can build. For the first time in a long while, Los Angeles other team can be approached with optimism.

title: Game Theory
description: Defense doesnt win championships. Teamwork isnt what its cracked up to be. Momentum is a myth. And the Chicago Cubs arent cursed; they just stink.

title: A Big Boost for National Emergency Network
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration will press Congress to allocate a coveted block of wireless telecommunications airwaves for the building of a nationwide emergency communications network, administration officials said Thursday, a reversal that is likely to cement support for an issue that has been the subject of disputes since Sept. 11, 2001.

title: An Ill-Advised Love Affair
description: A cautionary tale on the inadvisability of dating without background checks, Sebastin Corderos Rage (Rabia) turns an ill-advised love affair into a voyeuristic study of masculine obsession and class persecution.

title: Boston Crowded With Snow Farms
description: BOSTON  Clearing the streets, it turns out, is the easy part.

title: A Verdict Replies to Terrorists, and to Critics
description: In the 48th minute of his State of the Union address the other night, President Obama got around to talking about terrorism. As we speak, Al Qaeda and their affiliates continue to plan attacks against us, the president said, adding that the United States is responding to the challenge in ways that include respect for the rule of law.

title: 2 Bronx Girls Collapse in Idling Car
description: Two Bronx girls collapsed from carbon monoxide poisoning on Thursday when their mother left them in the back of an idling car while she shoveled snow to get out of a parking space, the police said.

title: Borders Gets $550 Million Loan Commitment
description: Borders Group, the struggling bookseller, said on Thursday that it had received a commitment from GE Capital for $550 million in refinancing  so long as the company meets several requirements, including signing up agreements with publishers to convert delayed payments into loans.

title: Extortion Gone Awry
description: Blackmail Boys is basically about just that: a young gay couple and their ill-fated attempt to coerce a famous figure into paying them to keep his gay identity from view. Sam (Nathan Adloff), a part-time student in Chicago, has been turning tricks to make ends meet, but what he really wants is enough money to marry and go on a honeymoon with his live-in boyfriend, Aaron (Taylor Reed).

title: Lost in the Comcast Takeover? A Logos Peacock
description: On the eve of the Comcast-NBC Universal marriage, some people were perturbed by the party favors. Specifically, they were worried about what was missing  a peacock.

title: McCain Ex-Aide Suspected as Anonymous O Author
description: In 1996, it took six months, one enterprising professor and an independent handwriting analysis to nail down the journalist Joe Klein as the anonymous author of Primary Colors.

title: Google Shows Ads With Images in Gmail
description: Googles display ads, or ads with images, have been showing up across the Web and even in Times Square. Now they are bound for Gmail.

title: Up Front: Paul Berman
description: Paul Bermans 1974 masters thesis at Columbia University was on a magazine, The Modern Quarterly, a predecessor of Partisan Review.

title: Fire in Newfoundland Diverts Atlantic Flights
description: A fire at an air traffic control center in Newfoundland forced air traffic controllers in New York and Portugal to handle dozens of additional airliners over the Atlantic on Thursday morning. Many planes had to be detoured hundreds of miles, to their destinations in the United States, the Caribbean or South America, according to air traffic officials.

title: Irving Kristols Brute Reason
description: Irving Kristol, who died in 2009, is sometimes called the godfather or even father of neoconservatism, and the patriarchal honorific, like a well-worn hat, sits comfortably atop The Neoconservative Persuasion: Selected Essays, 1942-2009. The book is strictly a family enterprise. It has been lovingly edited by Kristols widow, the historian Gertrude Himmelfarb, and carries a prefatory funeral eulogy by their sorrowful son, the Republican journalist William Kristol. Even the selection of essays reflects a uniquely familial degree of intimacy.

title: In Citys Teeming Heart, a Place to Gaze and Graze
description: KOLKATA, India  It is not precisely clear when, how or by whom it was decided that goats could graze in the heart of the Old City here. One local historian traces the decision back nearly three centuries, to the early days of the British East India Company. A different explanation says the goats were liberated to graze when India was liberated from Britain in 1947.

title: Third Day of Protests in Egypt
description: Mohamed ElBaradei, the Nobel laureate who has become a leading opponent of President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, returned to Cairo in an attempt to galvanize youth-led street protests that extended into a third day across the country.

title: College Champion, Fledgling Pro
description: At 19, Queen Harrison was the youngest member of the United States track and field team at the 2008 Beijing Olympics. Two years later, she became the first woman to win N.C.A.A. titles in the 100- and 400-meter hurdles in the same year. On Friday she will continue her elevation as an elite athlete when she makes her professional indoor debut in the 60-meter hurdles in the Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden.

title: Power Brokers Ties Complicate the Ballot Process
description: Before Thursdays dramatic ruling by the Illinois Supreme Court to keep Rahm Emanuel on the mayoral ballot, much of the chatter in local politics centered on one of the courts seven justices, Anne M. Burke, and the political relationship between her husband and a key opponent of Mr. Emanuel.

title: The South Rises Again  and Again, and Again
description: Washington, D.C., Jan. 28, 1861

title: Pli Time for Tots in Tights
description: Five minutes before the afternoons first class, the waiting room, chilly from the outside air as the storefronts glass door swung open and shut, hummed with activity and talk. Snow boots were exchanged for ballet slippers, sweaters for leotards, jeans for colored tights. Wayward strands of hair were tucked away.

title: Snow Stalls Testimony in Allegation of Slowdown
description: Daniel J. Halloran III, the city councilman at the center of investigations into whether a union slowdown left neighborhoods buried after the blizzard on Dec. 26, said Thursday that investigators were facing difficulties proving the allegations he first brought forward.

title: Fear of Vaccines: Is It Warranted?
description: To the Editor:

title: Exit Olbermann
description: To the Editor:

title: Cables Show Delicate U.S. Dealings With Egypts Leaders
description: WASHINGTON  It was Hillary Rodham Clintons first meeting as secretary of state with President Hosni Mubarak, in March 2009, and the Egyptians had an odd request: Mrs. Clinton should not thank Mr. Mubarak for releasing an opposition leader from prison because he was ill.

title: At Hearing, New Details on Military Disc Switch
description: It was hardly the 18 1/2 -minute gap of Watergate lore.

title: The Governor Wrings His Hands on the Death Penalty
description: While Rahm Emanuel was undergoing a political near-death experience Thursday, Gov. Pat Quinn confronted death itself. Or thats what hed have us believe.

title: U.S. Role in the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: Republicans and the Arts
description: To the Editor:

title: Jon Stewart Is Appointed to 9/11 Museum Board
description: Jon Stewart, the satirical host of The Daily Show who used his television program to push for federal money for the health care of first responders at ground zero, was appointed on Thursday to the board of the foundation building the Sept. 11 museum and memorial.

title: The Single-Sponsor Approach Reappears in Prime Time
description: A MAINSTAY of the early days of television  prime-time programs that were brought to you by single sponsors, like the Colgate Comedy Hour and Texaco Star Theater  is returning on Sunday, when NBC will present a show in which all the national commercial time is being sold to one advertiser.

title: Taxi Fares in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Seizing a Moment, Al Jazeera Galvanizes Arab Frustration
description: The protests rocking the Arab world this week have one thread uniting them: Al Jazeera, the Qatar-based satellite channel whose aggressive coverage has helped propel insurgent emotions from one capital to the next.

title: Treating Mental Illness
description: To the Editor:

title: Governor Works to Build Rapport at Home
description: ALBANY  On the menu for the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, and the State Senate majority leader, Dean G. Skelos, was a tossed salad, chicken and a sober conversation about the states grim financial prognosis.

title: For Desperate on Staten Island, a Worker of Last Resort
description: For emergencies, there is 911. For noise complaints, there is 311. For those in dire straits on Staten Island, there is Devorah Weiss, a social worker whose cellphone number is passed on as a last resort.

title: Sharp Rise in Suspensions at Citys Schools Is Cited
description: The number of New York City student suspensions more than doubled in the six years after Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took control of public schools and as the city moved toward a zero-tolerance approach toward misbehavior, according to a report released on Thursday.

title: If Munis Are Perilous, What About Treasuries?
description: The budget shortfalls gripping many states have rattled the $3 trillion municipal bond market. Yet even with unfunded pensions added, their debt burdens are dwarfed by those of the federal government. There are big structural differences, but the evidence suggests investors should worry less about munis and more about Treasuries.

title: Their Own Private Europe
description: President Obamas State of the Union address was a ho-hum affair. But the official Republican response, from Representative Paul Ryan, was really interesting. And I dont mean that in a good way.

title: Texas: Missionary Shot to Death
description: An American missionary couple was ambushed by gunmen on a highway in Mexico about 70 miles from the border on Wednesday, and the woman was fatally wounded, according to the police in Pharr, Tex. The gunmen opened fire when Samuel L. Davis refused to stop his pickup truck at an illegal roadblock near the town of San Fernando. His wife, Nancy, was shot in the head. Mr. Davis sped to the border and raced across the international bridge at Pharr, going the wrong way against traffic, to deliver his wife to the American authorities. It was too late. Ms. Davis, 59, died at a hospital in McAllen. The couple live in a rural hamlet northeast of Pharr and had done missionary work in Mexico for years. They maintained a second home in Mexico.

title: Is This Lebanons Final Revolution?
description: Beirut

title: Brooklyn College Revokes Instructors Appointment to Teach Mideast Politics
description: Last fall, it was an assigned book that brought the Israeli-Palestinian conflict home to Brooklyn College. A wealthy alumnus said he was cutting the college out of his will because all incoming freshmen had been asked to read How Does It Feel to Be a Problem? Being Young and Arab in America, by Moustafa Bayoumi, a professor there.

title: Obama Nominee for Judge Could Be First Openly Gay Man on the Federal Bench
description: President Obama has nominated a former Clinton administration lawyer to be a federal judge in Manhattan; he could become the first openly gay man to serve on the federal bench in the United States.

title: New White House Press Secretary Part of Makeover
description: WASHINGTON  Jay Carney, the spokesman for Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and a former Washington bureau chief for Time magazine, will become White House press secretary as part of a final flurry of personnel changes in a months-long makeover of the West Wing.

title: A Car Sale Gone Wrong, Then a Grim Discovery
description: The two men met through the Internet, fate and a 2008 BMW. The car was an M3 coupe, a fully loaded speedster with an eight-cylinder engine and an Interlagos Blue Metallic exterior.

title: In Chicago Race, a Fight Over the Meaning of Reside
description: CHICAGO  The fight over Rahm Emanuel may have revved up a broader war in Chicago over whether the residency rules for city workers should be relaxed. One teacher, Francine Greenberg-Reizen, said Mr. Emanuel should have followed the same rules she lives by. Mr. Emanuel wants to serve our city, and he hasnt lived here, she said.

title: Waves of Unrest Spread to Yemen, Shaking a Region
description: Thousands of protesters on Thursday took to the streets of Yemen, one of the Middle Easts most impoverished countries, and secular and Islamist Egyptian opposition leaders vowed to join large protests expected Friday as calls for change rang across the Arab world.

title: Snowstorm Forces Cancellation of Regents Exams in City and Suburbs
description: At Bronx Lab School in Williamsbridge, students studying for the United States history and government Regents exam took special prep classes and came in for extra help on Saturdays. At Millennium High School in Manhattan, administrators found money in a tight budget to pay for Regents test tutoring after school.

title: Most Members of Old Cabinet in Tunisia Step Down
description: TUNIS  Tunisias interim government on Thursday purged almost all the cabinet ministers left over from the government of the ousted dictator Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, bowing to two weeks of mounting street protests against the cabinets continued dominance by the old governing party and resolving an impasse that had threatened to bog down the new government.

title: Guy J. Velella, State Senator From Bronx, Dies at 66
description: Guy J. Velella, a former Republican state senator from the Bronx and a formidable figure in Albany until he pleaded guilty to bribery conspiracy seven years ago, died on Thursday in the Bronx. He was 66 and lived there, in the Morris Park section.

title: Stoudemires All-Star Nod Adds Luster to Knicks
description: The honor bestowed upon Amare Stoudemire was largely ceremonial, but his appointment as a starter for the Eastern Conference All-Star team serves as a status symbol in his goal of leading the Knicks to the N.B.A.s forefront.

title: John Horan, Former Chief of Merck, Dies at 90
description: John Horan, who led Merck as it expanded its portfolio of pharmaceuticals and became the worlds largest drug maker, died on Saturday in Princeton, N.J. He was 90 and lived in Sea Girt, N.J.

title: Gladys Horton, Marvelettes Lead Singer, Is Dead
description: Gladys Horton, who gathered some of her high school friends into a singing group that became the Marvelettes and then sang lead vocals on Please Mr. Postman, which became Motown Records first No. 1 hit, died on Wednesday in Sherman Oaks, Calif.

title: With Muslim Brotherhood Set to Join Egypt Protests, Religions Role May Grow
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt  Demonstrators in Egypt have protested against rising prices and stagnant incomes, for greater freedom and against police brutality. But religion, so often a powerful mobilizing force here, has so far played little role.

title: Talk of Bipartisan Progress Fading in Arizona
description: PHOENIX  As the days pass since the Tucson shooting spree, all that talk of bipartisan handholding, toning down the decibel level and working shoulder-to-shoulder for the betterment of the voters is losing some of its edge here as Arizona appears to be slipping back into its old ways.

title: F.B.I. Warrants Into Service Attacks by WikiLeaks Supporters
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Bureau of Investigation said it had executed more than 40 search warrants in the United States on Thursday as part of an investigation into an international group of computer hackers who attacked corporate Web sites last year in a show of support for WikiLeaks.

title: New Film Disrupts Turkeys Holocaust Day
description: ISTANBUL  Turkeys first officially sanctioned commemoration of the Holocaust was held in a synagogue here on Thursday, reflecting government efforts to assuage the Jewish minority in the face of increasingly strained ties with Israel. But the event was overshadowed by the scheduled premiere on Friday of the latest installment in a series of popular Turkish-made adventure films that depict Israelis as evil.

title: Obama and Corporate America
description: President Obama is smart to extend an olive branch to American businesses. Our economic success depends on businesses investing, growing and creating new jobs. From expanding exports to improving infrastructure, government and businesses share important goals.

title: Memphis to Vote on Transferring School System to County
description: MEMPHIS  Upon returning to his hometown after more than a decade away, Martavius Jones began spending his evenings at school board meetings.

title: Mr. Mikatis Choice
description: Lebanons next prime minister, Najib Mikati, owes his job to Hezbollah. That is regrettable and dangerous. It will heighten Lebanons divisions, antagonize Western donors (including the United States) and complicate the work of the international tribunal set up to try the killers of Rafik Hariri, a former prime minister.

title: Haitis President Urges His Candidate to Drop Out, Officials Say
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  President Ren Prval and his party, bowing to pressure from regional leaders, including the United States, have begun to encourage their candidate for the coming presidential runoff to drop out, according to party officials.

title: Lethal Injection and the F.D.A.
description: Capital punishment means lethal injection. The administration of a barbiturate as part of a fatal dose of drugs is meant to render a convict unconscious before other drugs stop his or her breathing and heart so the execution can somehow be construed by a judge as being neither cruel nor unusual.

title: Gates Says New Military Policy on Gays Can Start Soon
description: OTTAWA  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said that the military could be ready this year to carry out the repeal of a ban on gay men and lesbians serving openly in the armed forces, and that he has accelerated efforts to revise training and regulations.

title: Lottery Numbers
Jury Delivers Mixed Verdict for 3 Officers
description: WASHINGTON  A federal jury on Thursday convicted a former Pennsylvania police officer of the most serious charge against him in what prosecutors said was a cover-up of the beating death of a Mexican immigrant. But the jury delivered a less severe verdict against a second officer and acquitted a third.

title: Senate Approves Changes Intended to Ease Gridlock
description: WASHINGTON  In an effort to ease persistent Senate gridlock, the leadership on Thursday promised to temper the procedural warfare that has consumed the chamber in recent years and increased partisan tension.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 27
description: Photos from the day in sports.

title: California: Charge Dropped Over Wrestling Move
description: A high school wrestler in suburban Fresno was cleared of criminal wrongdoing on Thursday, after being accused of sexually assaulting a younger wrestler during a 2010 practice. Preston Hill, 17, had been charged with misdemeanor sexual battery in relation to using a wrestling move to injure the younger boy. The maneuver involves grabbing the haunch of an opponent to gain leverage. But that charges was dismissed after he and his 14-year-old accuser attended a tolerance training course last week, according to Stephen Quade, Prestons lawyer. Mr. Quade said Preston had maintained his innocence, and was still fighting his expulsion from school.

title: Mr. Hamilton and Mr. Burke
description: Every Thursday my gurus, Mr. Burke and Mr. Hamilton, get together at the Heavenly Rest to drink and talk politics. Mr. Burke prefers a whiskey and water, while Mr. Hamilton likes a good strong Sex on the Beach. This week, they ended up talking about President Obama.

title: The Authorized Sleuth
description: At a mid-January meeting of the Sherlock Holmes Society in London  held in the Members Dining Room at the House of Commons, no less  the English writer Anthony Horowitz announced that he has been commissioned by the Conan Doyle Estate to write a new novel featuring the venerable detective. According to Mr. Horowitzs publisher, the title is a closely guarded secret and the prologue is under lock and key.

title: N.F.L. Finances, as Seen Through Packers Records
description: Every year, the Green Bay Packers do something unique in the N.F.L.: they release a financial report. The document is brief but revealing, telling the story of a small-market team that benefits enormously from the leagues huge television deals and the devotion of its fans.

title: Friday: Like the Bay of Rainbows
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Ready for this?

title: The Rembrandt of Riyadh
description: The thing about being a painter, Andrew Vicari, who has claims to being the most lavishly rewarded painter in the world, was saying, is that every night you go to bed thinking the work you have done that day is fabulous. And then you wake up the next morning and look at your canvas and think it is worthless, a piece of junk, and you start again.

title: Showdown at the Italian Villa, Easels Drawn
description: NEW HAVEN  Simon Grays drama The Old Masters, which is having its American premiere at the Long Wharf Theater here, could be described as the quintessential middlebrow West End play. The attributes of this durable genre include characters drawn from the learned classes, preferably by way of the history books; dialogue thats sophisticated, amusing and well turned without being too vulgar or, well, challenging; swanky sets and period costumes capable of inspiring reveries about antiquing; and nothing in the way of innovation. A scene featuring the serving of tea is preferable, if optional.

title: Fighting Suits Saves Money for Chicago
description: After a Chicago police officer fatally shot Beverly Thurmans dog, Roscoe, after getting a call about a loose pit bull, Ms. Thurman filed a lawsuit alleging that the officer had acted wrongfully.

title: Reality Finally Caught Up to the Bears. Now, Moving On.
description: So Caleb Hanie can play, maybe, and Todd Collins cannot, beyond all shadow of any doubt. The Bears were hoping for more than that tepid revelation from Sundays heralded showdown with the Green Bay Packers, what with the N.F.C. Championship and a trip to the Super Bowl on the line, but on the bright side, the backup quarterback discovery kept their 21-14 defeat from being a total loss.

title: At Mississippi State, Troubles Overshadow a Big Center
description: ATHENS, Ga.  Renardo Sidney resembled a standby, somebody to call into action every once in a while, just not on every possession. Listed at 6 feet 10 inches and 275 pounds, but appearing heavier, he looked as if he might not get a rebound that did not hit the ground first.

title: If Deadline Is Missed, Millions May Be Lost
description: The N.F.L. and its players stand to lose hundreds of millions of dollars if they fail to reach a labor agreement before the current deal expires on March 3, Jeff Pash, the leagues chief negotiator, said Thursday.

title: The Governors Wife and the Line of Propriety
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

title: New Details Emerge in Italian Prime Minister Scandal
description: ROME  New details of alleged sexual escapades at Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconis private villas were leaked on Thursday after prosecutors presented documents to Parliament in an effort to gain permission to search the prime ministers properties.

title: USA Hockey Is Considering Proposals to Increase Safety
description: A measure banning body checking for boys under 13 is being considered by USA Hockey, the governing body for the sport at the amateur level in the United States, the organization announced Thursday.

title: Thousands of Rape Kits Sit Untested for Decades, but Change Would Be Costly
description: When rape victims come into DAn Anderss office, they are traumatized and emotional. After enduring a devastating assault, they have also spent hours being prodded and swabbed in a hospital emergency room, providing evidence that they hope will help track down their attacker.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for

title: Still Healing, but Back at X Games as Spectator
description: ASPEN, Colo.  On a cold and sunny morning, Kevin Pearce stood at the bottom of the massive halfpipe at Buttermilk Mountain wearing a grin and black-framed glasses with thick lenses as his friends and former competitors practiced their runs for the Winter X Games. Riders kept zipping up the wall of the 22-foot pipe Thursday and launching into a bright, blue sky, working their way toward Pearce.

title: Emphasis on Native Plants Gains Favor Across State
description: Bill Neiman got into the landscaping business in 1973 at age 19, determined to create beautiful gardens for his high-end, suburban clients. Seven years later, a terrible drought struck, followed by a deep freeze that wiped out his North Texas nursery.

title: A Wobbling Effort to Accommodate Cyclists
description: Scott James writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

title: At This Garage Sale, the Goal Is Freedom
description: Standing in the doorway of his garage on Tuesday, Rudy Corpuz Jr., a former San Francisco gang member, worked Howard Street like a 19th-century crier peddling miraculous tonics.

title: Trading a Gun Scope for a Wide-Angle Lens
description: One might imagine that James Lee, a former Marine who has spent the past three-plus years photographing conflict zones in Afghanistan and Iraq, would take a lot of pictures of American soldiers.

title: Titans Cut Loose Fisher After 16 Seasons
description: In a surprising move, the Tennessee Titans have parted ways with Jeff Fisher, who just completed his 16th full season as the N.F.L.s longest-tenured coach.

title: At Debate, Emanuel Returns to the Fray
description: CHICAGO  A few hours after this city finally and belatedly sorted out the landscape of its mayoral election, there they were: the four best-known candidates to replace Mayor Richard M. Daley sat on stage, side by side, discussing (not surprisingly) the Illinois Supreme Courts decision to allow Rahm Emanuel to stay on the ballot.

title: World Chess Federation Issues Letter Supporting the Turkish Federation
description: Two weeks ago, 18 of the women who played in the Womens World Championship tournament in Antakya, Turkey, wrote a letter to the World Chess Federation complaining about the quality of the organization of the event.

title: Rookie Helps Knicks Solve James and Heat
description: When the Knicks and the Miami Heat tangle, it is usually a veteran, versatile All-Stars who decides the game. On Thursday night, it appeared that the game would be won or lost by a veteran, versatile, goggle-wearing All-Star.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Cutting Redevelopment Funds Could Affect a Lot More Than Redevelopment
description: Seventeen police officers in Oaklands worst neighborhoods have an unusual and potentially doomed employer: the city redevelopment agency.

title: Word of the Day | bemused
description: bemused \bi-myz, be-\ adjective

title: Uncharacteristically, a Subpar Performance From James at the Garden
description: Whether the hero in Cleveland or the villain from Miami, LeBron James has long tantalized New York fans. James has seemed to play his best when he steps onto the court at Madison Square Garden.

title: Vince Young, at Knicks Game, Is Surprised by Firing of Fisher
description: There was a cast worthy of the Hollywood Walk of Fame at the Knicks 93-88 win over the Miami Heat on Thursday at Madison Square Garden. Howard Stern was at center court alongside the actor Tracy Morgan. There was Woody Allen and Kanye West.

title: News Quiz | January 28, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Despite Politics, Oil Giants Lured by Russian Petroleum
description: Exxon Mobil once was poised to acquire a stake in Russias largest private oil company, only to have the deal fall apart when the Kremlin arrested the owner and the company went bankrupt.

title: Spanish Bank to Group Assets for Share Listing
description: La Caixa, the leading savings bank in Spain, said Thursday that it would pool all its banking assets into a listed entity, just days after the government urged the countrys financial institutions to tap more aggressively into private financing to bolster their capital.

title: Mubarak Orders Crackdown, With Revolt Sweeping Egypt
description: CAIRO  With police stations and the governing partys headquarters in flames, and much of this crucial Middle Eastern nation in open revolt, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt deployed the nations military and imposed a near-total blackout on communications to save his authoritarian government of nearly 30 years.

title: Test Yourself | History, Jan. 28, 2011
description: Test your knowledge of history with todays question about a space shuttle explosion.

title: Nelson Mandela Returns Home From Hospital
description: JOHANNESBURG  Nelson Mandela, South Africas frail elder statesman, returned home Friday after spending two nights in a hospital where he was treated for an acute respiratory infection. Officials said the former president joked with them and teased his wife, Graa, before his discharge.

title: Indonesia Investigates Deadly Ferry Fire and Train Collision
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  At least 16 people were killed and scores injured on Friday in an almost simultaneous ferry fire and train collision in Indonesia, highlighting the poor safety record of the sprawling archipelago nations rickety transportation system.

title: A Year at War: Panoramic Views From Kunduz
description: The geographic world of every deployed soldier or Marine is defined in large part by Hescos: the dirt-filled, wire-mesh containers that form the protective outer walls of most American bases in Iraq and Afghanistan. To say one is going outside the wire means leaving the confines of the Hesco barriers topped with concertina wire that mark the end of a combat outpost and the beginning of the world beyond.

description: Ah, Davos, little village of mountainous contradictions.

title: Deadly Attack by Taliban in Kabul Sought to Kill Head of Blackwater
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Taliban claimed responsibility for a suicide bomb attack on Friday at a supermarket in the capital frequented by foreigners. They said the strike was aimed at killing the head of the private security company Blackwater.

title: Are You a Saver or a Tosser?
description: Many children  and their parents  are having trouble trying to decide what arts and crafts to save and what to throw out. Do you usually save the arts, crafts and projects that you create? Why or why not?

title: Moscow Mayor Promises Business-Friendly Russia
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Singing from the same hymn sheet as President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia a few days earlier, Sergei S. Sobyanin, the mayor of Moscow, promised on Friday to transform the city into a business-friendly financial center free of corruption and red tape.

title: Japanese Leader Creates Stir With Remark on Debt Rating
description: TOKYO  Prime Minister Naoto Kan of Japan may have a lot of explaining to do this weekend at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, not least of all being what he meant when he told reporters he was ignorant in matters concerning Japans freshly downgraded debt rating.

title: When Two Brands Are Better Than One
description: Heres another way to expand your market awareness and market share: find a business that matches your entrepreneurial mindset, has good brand equity, sells complementary products or services and offers exposure to new audiences. Then brand a product together  and have fun doing it. Thats what East Coast lifestyle-clothing store Vineyard Vines and West Coach vintner St. Francis Winery recently did. Not only did the venture produce nice results, it yielded new friendships.

title: Bold Coaching by Tomlin and McCarthy
description: In a blog post on Thursday, Brian Burke of Advanced NFL Stats, a regular contributor for the Fifth Down, pointed out that two of the most notable strategic decisions of 2009 were made by this years Super Bowl coaches, Mike McCarthy and Mike Tomlin.

description: DETROIT  A successful turnaround without government assistance has lifted the Ford Motor Companys reputation and raised expectations about the company on Wall Street.
