description: LAHORE, Pakistan  An American official appeared in court here on Friday on murder charges in the shooting deaths of two Pakistanis who he said tried to rob him.

title: Complaint Box | Obscenities
description: As a student and a teacher of language, I appreciate curses and other vulgarities: they can add color and emphasis to our vernacular. But like all stylistic flourishes, the audience has to be taken into consideration.

title: As Carney Replaces Gibbs, a New Voice for the White House
description: On his second day as White House press secretary, Robert Gibbs found out one thing about the job: there is no honeymoon.

title: Geithner Optimistic, Despite High Unemployment
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  If Timothy F. Geithner were the fifth Beatle, he have would strutted on stage here Friday morning and belted out: Its getting better all the time!

title: Updates on Fridays Protests in Egypt
description: The Lede followed protests across Egypt of Friday, as demonstrators demanding an end to the autocratic rule of President Hosni Mubarak took to the streets following the end of Friday Prayers. For a summary of the latest events, see the main news article on this site with reports from my colleagues inside Egypt. Readers who are in Egypt and want to share information with us can write in the comment thread below or send photographs to pix@nyt.com.

title: Will Court Battle Hurt Emanuel With Chicago Voters?
description: CHICAGO  With an Illinois Supreme Court ruling in his favor and a phone call from President Obama (presumably congratulatory), Rahm Emanuel declared the back-and-forth battle over his qualifications to be mayor of this city over. But as Chicago awoke to a newly clear ballot picture, a question remained: For the candidates, what will be the fallout from this peculiar chapter, one in which, in a dizzying week, Mr. Emanuel was ordered off the ballot, then back on again?

title: Tip of the Week: A Files Properties
description: In Windows, right-clicking on a file or folder and choosing the Properties item from the pop-up menu opens the items Properties box, which can tell you all sorts of helpful information about the file, like when it was created or how much hard drive space it is currently taking up. If you do not want to deal with menus, there is another way to get to the Properties box right from the keyboard. Just click on the file or folder to select it and press the Alt + Enter keys on the keyboard to pop open the same box.

title: In Davos, Cameron Joins Innovation Bandwagon
description: The drive among Western nations to keep the lead in innovation by investing more seems to be heating up as emerging economies leap ahead.

description: Snow, what a novel concept. A dusting to an inch Friday and Saturday. Also starring: black ice. Be careful.

title: Super Bowl Advertisers Are Super Busy
description: Each year, it seems that the efforts by marketers to gain attention for what they are doing on Super Bowl Sunday start earlier than the year before. It is not unlike how reporters write each year that retailers seem to be starting the Christmas shopping season earlier than the year before.

title: Strains for Hispanic Caregivers
description: Fabiola Santiago lives in the Miami suburbs, two miles from her 81-year-old mother and 87-year-old father, whom she looks after. As the single mother of three grown daughters, she might live in the city or in Miami Beach if she had no family responsibilities  but to her, thats like saying shed fly if she woke up tomorrow with wings. Its a fantasy.

title: Honeywell Sells Consumer Auto Products Business
description: Honeywell announced on Friday that had agreed to sell its automotive consumer products group to the Rank Group, a New Zealand private investment firm, in cash deal valued at $950 million.

description: Athletes have been known to complain that reporters misquote them or spin their statements.

title: Brazilian Dam Clears Hurdle
description: A significant hurdle in the construction of a huge dam on a tributary of the Amazon river was removed this week when Brazilian authorities approved the clearing of hundreds of acres of forest at the dam site and the construction of new roads to service the project.

title: Sara Lee Confirms Plan to Split
description: Sara Lees board announced Friday the company will split its food and beverage businesses into two separate companies, a deal they expect to close by 2012.

title: Obligatory Steve Carell-Meets-Ricky Gervais Office Crossover Post
description: I resisted that for a very good reason. I thought it would look a bit in-jokey or desperate. But now I think its a safe environment to pop up in. -Ricky Gervais, in a 2007 Time magazine interview, replying to a reader who asked if he would ever appear on the American version of The Office.

title: U.S. Economy Grew at 3.2% Rate in the 4th Quarter
description: With a little more money in their wallets and a little less fear in their hearts, American consumers helped pull the economy up by its bootstraps in the final months of last year.

description: LOS ANGELES Since it became the frontrunner by picking up a dozen Oscar nominations, it seems all the awards news has been about The Kings Speech. The latest to enter circulation is a video showing rare footage of the real King George VI speaking.

title: So Lost Is Over: Now Whats to Be Found?
description: LAST summer I went hiking with my teenage daughter in the Swiss Alps. On the first day we left the small village of Wengen and climbed above the timberline to a mountain outpost, Kleine Scheidegg, where we stopped to catch our breath. As I was drinking some water and taking in the awesome panorama, I noticed a hiker approaching. He was bearded and sunburned, wearing a kerosene-stained Swiss mountaineering pack and using trekking poles. I thought he was going to warn us of some danger. Instead he walked up to me and in German-accented English asked, Are you Carlton Cuse, from Lost? Startled, I answered, Yes.

title: FRED Goes Global
description: Long ago I took to heart Issawis Law on the conservation of evil, which says that the total amount of evil is a constant. I havent found a link, but Issawi also asserted that most things get steadily worse; this isnt a contradiction, because some things get much better. (A particular example: most people get worse as they grow older, because they become more like themselves.)

title: Vain Glorious | Hero Product
description: Hot on the (red, pleather) heels of NBCs announcement that it has picked up David E. Kelleys Wonder Woman-based television pilot, M.A.C. cosmetics just opened a pop-up store on Spring Street to exclusively sell its new Wonder Woman-inspired collection, a partnership with Warner Bros. Outfitted with giant renderings of the character and reproductions of vintage comic books, the space is the only place to shop the limited-edition line until Feb. 10, when it hits M.A.C. locations nationwide. Pick up a nail polish matched to the shade worn by the superhero, false lashes, reflex glitter pigments or a supersize Lipglass, all bearing the Wonder Woman logo. Theres something about Wonder Woman that speaks to a lot of generations, says the creative director and senior vice president of M.A.C. worldwide, James Gager, pointing out that the character graced the premiere cover of Ms. Magazine. Shes an icon.

description: 11:12 a.m. | Updated  Responding to my post about efforts to use Hollywood to boost public engagement on global warming, Redmond Clark, an entrepreneur and business owner from Barrington, Ill., expressed with clarity and force some themes Ive pursued here far less fluently, so I give him the floor this morning in a Your Dot contribution. title: Approval Ratings and Re-Election Odds
description: Earlier this month, we posted the simple version of a finding, based on the historical record, that is worth keeping in mind when you read articles about how Barack Obamas presidency has (or has not been) been revitalized: Its just too soon for his approval ratings to tell us very much about his re-election prospects for 2012.

title: App Smart Extra: Auto-Management
description: You can save a few pennies per gallon (or maybe much more) with the apps featured in Thursdays App Smart column. But drivers who are diligent enough to shop around for gas will likely find even greater use in a pair of more comprehensive auto-management apps for iPhone and Android users.

title: Big Themes in Small Packages
description: With all the hoopla over Oscar nominations for The Kings Speech and True Grit, the nominees in the shorter film categories may have escaped your attention, but not that of movie executives. For one thing, a nominated film can launch a career. Consider John Lasseter, who received a nomination for best animated short in 1987 for Luxo Jr., about a young lamp and his father, which was Pixars first attempt at animation, or Taylor Hackford, who won the live action short in 1979 for Teenage Father and went on to a successful career and Oscar nominations for best picture and direction for Ray.

title: Obamas CREEP Problem
description: As an aging baby boomer, I remember the 1970s; and one of the things I remember is that it was the era of unfortunate acronyms. Nixon had the Committee to Re-Elect the President, which everyone, and I mean everyone, referred to as CREEP. Ford had the Council on Wage and Price Stability, which everyone referred to as COWPS, pronounced phonetically.

title: 100 Ways to Celebrate the 100th Day of School With The Times
description: Depending on when you started the academic year  and how many snow days youve had so far  the 100th day of school should be coming up any day now.

title: Murray Beats Ferrer to Reach Final
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Andy Murray and Novak Djokovic were 13 when they first played tennis against each other. It was in the southern French city of Tarbes in the junior tournament called Les Petits As. Murray won in a hurry.

title: From Estonia With Love: A Sculpture Honoring Sean Connery
description: There is, apparently, a distinction even rarer than being granted a license to kill by Her Majestys Secret Service, and that is having a bronze sculpture of your likeness displayed in the Estonian capital, Tallinn. Sean Connery is now that most exceptional of actors who can claim both honors: on Thursday, a bust depicting the well-preserved star of seven James Bond films (not to mention The Hunt for Red October, Highlander and The Untouchables) was unveiled outside Tallinns Scottish Club, an organization for Scottish expatriates and admirers of all things Scottish in Estonia, The Associated Press reported. Peter Carter, Britains ambassador to Estonia, said at the unveiling of the $14,000 sculpture that Mr. Connery was without a doubt, an icon, adding: He is variously known as James Bond or the sexiest man of the century. Hes a great British actor, a great Scot actor and a great symbol for Scotland.

title: Carrier Bus Air-Conditioners Are Recalled After Fires
description: After receiving reports of fires, the Carrier Corporation is recalling almost 45,000 air-conditioning units used on school and shuttle buses.

title: Near Newspaper Row of Years Gone By, the Media Return
description: In the late 19th century, a cluster of buildings along or near Park Row, close to those busy news engines, City Hall and the citys courts, housed almost every daily newspaper in town  The Herald, The Sun, The Tribune, The World, The Journal and The Times.

title: Parenthood, Not Abortion, Linked to Mental Illness
description: The New England Journal of Medicine has taken on one of the pillar arguments in the abortion debate, asking whether having the procedure increases a womans risk of mental-health problems and concluding that it doesnt. In fact, researchers found, having a baby brings a far higher risk.

description: So much of sports success is all about timing and although we long knew that the Titans owner Bud Adams was challenged in that regard (his hair being from the Pleistocene Era and all), that it took until yesterday to figure out Jeff Fisher wasnt returning as coach was a debacle even by Adamss standards.

description: O.K. luv  following Andy Gray and Richard Keys of Sky Sports out the door, Sven is bounced from Special 1 TV.

title: Couture Scorecard | Jean Paul Gaultier Wins!
description: Scorecard knows this has been a fashion week that saw couturiers anguished by the question of whether those who do made-to-measure extravagance can continue to maintain their cultural relevance, in ways that dont involve flashbulb-friendly sparkle. Leave it to fashions perennial enfant terrible Jean Paul Gaultier to pastiche a very classically post-war run of show on the closing day with  astonishingly elegant  numbered placard carrying faux-hawked Crazy Horse dancers. That sent out a resoundingrallying cry: Yes We Can-Can.

title: Revamping, Home Depot Woos Women
description: In the spring, Home Depot hopes to turn a womans fancy toward redecorating.

description: Were back.

title: Doubting Others Job Performance
description: My recycling is collected weekly, almost always by the same driver. I actually watch the pickup about 50 percent of the time, as I have two young boys who like to watch the truck. The driver frequently stops to talk on his cellphone  one time talking for five minutes in the truck while it idled in front of my house  and has taken magazines from my recycling and spent a minute or two reading them. Should I report this to the carting company, or is it none of my business how he gets his job done? M.S., HIGHLAND PARK, ILL.

title: Gridiron Girls
description: When the N.F.L. season began this past September, it appeared as if the sports cultural prominence  no other league is anywhere close to as popular or rich  might be in jeopardy. The league was plagued by scandal. The Pittsburgh Steelers, for one, were forced to play their first four games without quarterback Ben Roethlisberger, who was disciplined after being accused of sexually assaulting a college student in the bathroom of a bar. The New York Jets, meanwhile, were busy hooting at the television journalist Ins Sainz on the field and in the locker room  a flap that, in hindsight, seems charming relative to the lewd text messages that onetime Jets employees received from former quarterback Brett Favre (reportedly involving a photographed penis) and the supposed foot-fetishism of the Jets current head coach, Rex Ryan.

title: The iPod Gets the Dick Tracy Treatment
description: Last September, at one of those periodic events where Apple offers up a new product with much fanfare, Steve Jobs invited the audience to join him in admiring the latest iteration of the iPod Nano. With the touch-screen interface associated with the iPhone and the iPad, the music player had shrunk to a square, weighing less than an ounce and almost comically wee. Some observers took it for a joke when Jobs said an Apple board member intended to sport the thing as a watch. Others didnt laugh; they sprang into action.

title: A Steady Hand
description: As a partner at Goldman Sachs and one of the best-known market analysts in this country, youre surely aware that women continue to be thinly represented among the senior ranks on Wall Street. Why is that? Lets think about it in the following way: We can only deal with the pool of young women who make themselves available and express interest in investment banking.

title: Scratch-Me-Not
description: You never know what will hit a nerve with technophiles. The screen protector  a filmy, staticky sheet that covers the screen of a tablet or smartphone  would seem to be a fairly noncontroversial accessory. But people who love their smartphones and tablets are divided over it. The screen protectors, manufactured by companies like Zagg and Splash, really bring out the emotions in gadget fans, especially those of ardent devotees of a certain hallowed tech company based in Cupertino, Calif.

title: A Commie-Pinko in Cancn
description: My wife has always tried to persuade me to spend a winter vacation on a tropical island. Id never been to a tropical island because I never wanted to go. I never wanted to go because the prospect of lounging around on a beach while being waited on by foreign poor people with dark skin made me feel uncomfortably rich and white  and American. As the son of communist parents, one Iranian and one Jewish American, who taught me to eschew most forms of pleasure and all forms of imperialist ostentation, I told my wife when we married that she had a long and torturous battle ahead of her with trying to get me to go.

title: Capitals Sign Semin to One-Year Deal
description: WASHINGTONAlex Ovechkin may get most of the attention, but the Washington Capitals also have another Russian Alex on whom they are counting to revive their offense.

title: Night Soul and Other Stories
description: No Mans Land

title: Topological Fiction
description: Theres a problem with the way Joseph McElroys fiction reaches the contemporary reader. While McElroy comes packaged as a postmodern novelist, the reader who picks up one of his books looking for the superficial imprint of his contemporaries  black humor? joke names?  will be confused by the classification. Although his work certainly feeds off late-20th-century energies, McElroys cosmopolitan, erudite fiction needs to be received on a wider bandwidth that also registers signals from other disciplines and earlier literature. The sudden shifts between his paragraphs, for instance, recall Braque and Picassos collage techniques, while many of his thematic obsessions overlap with those of modernists like Woolf, Bergson and Nietzsche. Reading Night Soul  a collection of 12 clever and oblique short stories  is, in fact, a little like being a member of Marlows audience in Heart of Darkness. We listen in a foggy void, and try to puzzle out the significance of a narrators inconclusive experiences.

title: Womens Finals Preview: Li vs. Clijsters
description: Kim Clijsters and Li Na play for the womens singles title in Melbourne Saturday evening in a battle of aggressive baseliners. The two play remarkably similar games, with flat, bruising groundstrokes off of both sides.

title: For First-Time Buyers Drawn to Yesteryear
description: AFTER three years living with her parents in Garden City, Carla Loeven and her husband, Rich, felt they had saved enough money to go house shopping. What they found close to home was too expensive, especially with the high property taxes. In Franklin Square, where Mr. Loeven grew up, the yards were too small for the price. While they loved Huntington and Centerport, they found that their $375,000 would go a lot further 15 minutes away in the village of Farmingdale, at the eastern edge of Nassau County.

title: About That McQueen Dress
description: O.K., Im a little slow; I admit I didnt grasp the point of all the drum-beating this week in Womens Wear Daily. Ive been in Paris covering shows. But this morning all was illuminated when I went to wwd.com and saw the headline Michelle Obama Puts Kara Ross on World Stage. The article stated that Ms. Ross, a jewelry designer, had been called up to the major leagues by the prime placement of earrings on Mrs. Obama, most recently at the State of the Union speech.

title: Mark Whitaker to Leave NBC News for CNN
description: In another sign of its often-stated commitment to hard-news journalism, CNN announced Friday that it had hired Mark Whitaker, the NBC Washington Bureau chief and former editor of Newsweek magazine, to a newly created position of executive vice president and managing editor.

title: A Vanished World
description: Every so often, a book shocks you into realizing just how much effort and sheer luck was required to get it into your hands. Panorama was the first novel written by H. G. Adler, a German-speaking Jewish intellectual from Prague who survived a labor camp in Bohemia, Theresienstadt, Auschwitz and a particularly hellish underground slave-labor camp called Langenstein, near Buchenwald. Adler wrote the first draft in less than two weeks in 1948, three years after he had walked back to Prague from Langenstein and a few weeks after he had fled Prague just before the Communist coup. He wound up in England, but couldnt find anyone willing to publish the book until 1968, 20 years and two drafts later. The book is coming out in English for the first time only now.

title: 2011 Hyundai Sonata
description: Before Hyundai stuffed the new Sonata, it built a great shell.

title: In Alexandria, Protesters Rout the Police, for Now
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt  For one day, in this historic Mediterranean city, the protesters won outright.

title: Where Vigilance Never Sleeps
description: It was the most memorable contest of last years United States Open: an argument, a slap and then bodies tumbling down the rows of Arthur Ashe Stadium. But the combatants might have stayed in their seats had they known that their audience included not just gawking tennis fans with cellphone cameras but also the counterterrorism forces of the New York Police Department, armed with high-powered sniper rifles and ready to take out troublemakers from the stadiums rim.

title: BankUnited Shares Rise 5% on First Day
description: BankUniteds public offering received a warm reception on Friday morning, as shares rose nearly 5 percent to around $28.25 in the first few hours of trading.

title: A Hybrid Made for the Highway
description: HIGHWAY driving is not where hybrids shine. Typically, their fuel economy gains are most impressive in town, where low-speed driving is powered by electricity and efficiency is aided by a regenerative braking system.

title: The Problem With Memoirs
description: A moment of silence, please, for the lost art of shutting up.

title: Boys to Men
description: Oh, the infectious nature of a we narration, the perils of a collective voice. Almost by its very nature this is a point of view infused with nostalgia, looking back to a time when we were not yet the individual I the adult world demands we become. Faulkners we in the story A Rose for Emily conjures up a South long gone. And in Jeffrey Eugenidess novel The Virgin Suicides, which circles around a tragic event  five sisters have killed themselves when the book opens  the communal reflection on childhood veils these harrowing deaths with a gauzy filter.

title: The Anchor
description: The CNN reporter Soledad OBrien is the daughter of a white Australian father and a black Cuban mother. This heritage bequeathed her an immigrants ideals about Americas promise, as well as a striking appearance that has shaped her experience of the land of possibilities. Both these themes  her roots and her looks  run through OBriens memoir, The Next Big Story, as she charts her lifelong effort to forge a singular identity out of her biracial background. Her account, written with Rose Marie Arce, is also a reporters reflection on the television news business, which in the span of her 22-year career has swung from largely ignoring issues of race to often stoking prejudice with bombastic, personality-driven coverage.

title: A Lion in the Undergrowth
description: The men of old, reported Socrates, saw madness as a gift that provides knowledge or inspiration. It was when they were mad that the prophetess at Delphi and the priestesses at Dodona achieved so much; . . . when sane they did little or nothing. Today, insanity can still bring the gift of knowledge, but in a different manner. Much of what we know about the brain comes from seeing what happens when it is damaged, or affected in unusual ways. If the Delphic seer were to turn up tomorrow, neuroscientists would whisk her straight off into a brain scanner.

title: Hot Off the Presses
description: In the midst of the current economic chaos, our faith in that most modest of financial instruments  the dollar bill  has remained unchanged. Not the mass dollar, that abstract plurality, ebbing and ebbing again, but the Federal Reserve notes in your pocket. Your dollars may lose value, but at least they are real.

title: Mayor in No Rush to Respond to Trumps Tavern on the Green Plan
description: At a news conference on Thursday, as reported in The New York Post, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg threw cold water on Donald J. Trumps plans to run Tavern on the Green. Tavern is now a visitors center with a few food trucks, and Mayor Bloomberg said that might be what it remains.

title: Walled City
description: Hassan, the storyteller of Joydeep Roy-Bhattacharyas new novel, is more than just a narrator: he is a guide, a witness, a showman, a chronicler of Moroccan legend and lore. His stage is the central square of Marrakesh, Djemaa el Fna, where the myriad wonders of this great, red-walled city surround and inspire him. All around me the city spreads out its wares  its many narratives  and I survey them as if from a high place, he proclaims. Indeed, his vantage point allows him to draw freely the raw materials of his craft: It is a landscape filled with allegories, where the imagination is law, and storytellers can spend entire days resuscitating mysteries.

title: Pursuing Cars That Wont Be Outdated
description: COMPUTERS can be upgraded with software and peripherals, and smartphones are able to add new functions by downloading an app. So why not a similar capability for the device that wields more processing power than either of those?

title: Snowdrifts
description: A time-lapse video from one of Roland Kays's camera traps showing the accumulation of snow over two weeks. Notice the sparkly ice that formed in a storm on Jan. 18.

title: Deer and Coyote
description: Camera trap images from the wild site showing the difficulty of deer and coyotes walking through deep snow compared with the ease of dancing over the ice crust that was there from Jan. 18-20.

title: New Events the All-Star Game Should Consider
description: If youre one of the many fans who feels like the annual all-star weekend has become stale, this year has brought good news and bad news. On the one hand, the new fantasy draft is a fun idea that will liven up the team selections. On the other hand, once the draft is done the rest of the weekend is shaping up to be the same old story.

title: Sweet Potatoes With Tang, Spice and Sweetness
description: Americans commonly confuse sweet potatoes with yams, explains Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health:

title: Borders Shares Surge After Loan Commitment
description: The prospect of bankruptcy  even a remote one  is often enough to cause shareholders to scurry for the exits.

title: Buyers Spread the Wealth at Arizona Collectible Car Auctions
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.

title: Vision Airlines Takes Off With a Sale
description: Vision Airlines, a charter carrier, recently announced that on March 25 it would begin commercial service to 23 destinations, many of them in the South and along the Gulf Coast. The airline chose to focus on that region because it is underserved by major airlines, which often offer regional jets, long layovers and high fares, said Bryan Glazer, Visions spokesman.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: An Adaptation of Robert Jordans New Spring
description: The work of the fantasy novelist Robert Jordan gets a graphic novel adaptation in New Spring, part of the authors Wheel of Time series. The graphic novel is at No. 2 on our soft cover list this week. Robert Jordan was a pseudonym used by James Oliver Rigney Jr., who died in 2007. In his obituary, Margalit Fox wrote that the Wheel of Time series was known for its epic sweep, intricate plotting and large cast of complex characters. And that the series focused on Rand alThor, a humble messianic figure who must stave off the forces of evil that threaten to overtake the faraway land in which he lives. Along the way, there are perils and portents, fair maidens, fantastical deeds and the like.

title: London Underground | Map It Your Way
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#795", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Thy Neighbors Wealth
description: Who needs to keep up with the Joneses? What people really care about is keeping up with the Rockefellers. Thats the main theme of The Haves and the Have-Nots, an eclectic book on inequality that attempts to document the long history of coveting by the poor, and the grim consequences of that coveting.

title: New York Floats Rules for Cleaner Heating Oil
description: Buildings in New York City would burn cleaner heating oil and emit far less pollution under proposed rules announced on Friday.

title: Egypt Cuts Off Most Internet and Cell Service
description: Autocratic governments often limit phone and Internet access in tense times. But the Internet has never faced anything like what happened in Egypt on Friday, when the government of a country with 80 million people and a modernizing economy cut off nearly all access to the network and shut down cellphone service.

title: A Fraternitys Fight Could Lead to Its End
description: A century-old fraternity locked in a legal battle over the actions of its national executives filed for Chapter 7 bankruptcy this week.

title: Diminished Expectations
description: Gideon Rachmans Zero-Sum Future is slightly misnamed. Rachman, the chief foreign affairs columnist for The Financial Times, seems to believe that this future  an Age of Anxiety  is already here.

title: Reopening the Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Its the Art That Matters
description: To the Editor:

title: One Small Step Backward
description: To the Editor:

title: Life Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: A Formal Virtuoso
description: To the Editor:

title: The Perils of Literary Profiling
description: Its probably time to update the list on my Facebook profile for the books I like. If you think that liking a book is a fairly nebulous and meaningless concept, youll get no argument from me. I made the list a couple of years back and jotted down the first few titles that came into my head (Gravitys Rainbow, The Big Sleep, More Pricks Than Kicks and The Anatomy of Melancholy, if you must know). They werent selected entirely at random  theyre all books I think are great  but I didnt spend much time pondering the selection, and on another day I might well have chosen four completely different titles.

title: Court of Corruption
description: The cold, hard truth about historical mysteries comes down to this: If you cant trust the history, you wont enjoy the mystery. C. J. Sansom, a British lawyer with a Ph.D. in history, proved himself the most trustworthy of authors with Dissolution, a mystery set during the tumultuous period when Henry VIII was dismantling Englands great monasteries and systematically pillaging their earthly treasures. Sansom has gone on to write additional historically persuasive Tudor mysteries featuring Matthew Shardlake, a hunchbacked lawyer prone to melancholy humors, whose official court duties are interrupted by the investigations he conducts for influential patrons.

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: THE HARE WITH AMBER EYES  A Familys Century of Art and Loss.  By Edmund de Waal.  Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26.

title: Inside the List
description: UPWARD TIGER: Amy Chua, whose Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother climbs to No. 2 on the hardcover nonfiction list in its second week, remains Topic A in many circles. Chua recently got the obligatory roasting by Stephen Colbert, who warned any children in his audience, Get back to that Mendelssohn concerto before she drowns your bunny!

title: Editors Choice
description: EXAMINED LIVES: From Socrates to Nietzsche,  by James Miller (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $28.) Miller shows philosophers becoming ever more inclined to reflect on their own petty failings, and suggests this makes their lives more, not less, worth studying.

title: Paperback Row
description: NOAHS COMPASS,  by Anne Tyler (Ballantine, $15.) In a succession of novels (The Accidental Tourist, A Patchwork Planet), Tylers male protagonists have become instantly recognizable: lonely and defeated, lost souls whose lives have stalled. Liam Pennywell, the hero of Tylers 18th novel, is a retired teacher who realizes that despite two marriages and three daughters, he has experienced only the most glancing relationship with his own life. After he is attacked by an intruder in his Baltimore home, Liam becomes fixated on recovering a few hours of lost memory.

title: Jane Austen, Transmigrated To Modern-Day East L.A.
description: From Prada to Nada, a rueful, occasionally touching and entirely predictable romantic comedy with a terrible title, recasts Jane Austens Sense and Sensibility as a contemporary story of Chicana empowerment. When their fathers death forces Nora and Mary Dominguez to leave the family mansion, they dont land in a country cottage, they move into their ta Aurelias East Los Angeles Victorian.

title: Volunteering Rate Fell in 2010
description: The volunteering rate  as measured by the portion of Americans who volunteered through or for an organization at least once over the course of a year  fell 0.5 percentage points in the year ended September 2010, to 26.3 percent, according to a Labor Department report released this week.

title: Voices From Davos
description: At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, DealBooks Andrew Ross Sorkin chatted with attendees like the economist Nouriel Roubini and Barry Silbert, chief executive of SecondMarket, about their thoughts on important issues raised at the conference.

title: Trustee Faults Mets Owners Over Madoff Fraud
description: The trustee representing the victims of Bernard L. Madoffs multibillion dollar Ponzi scheme is seeking hundreds of millions of dollars from the owners of the Mets, alleging that they, as longtime and successful investors, knew or should have known Madoff was operating a fraud, according to two lawyers involved in the case.

title: The War Presidents
description: One of the chief roles of the philosopher, from the time of Socrates, has been to discomfit citizens by forcing them to think about matters from which they would prefer to avert their eyes. Stephen L. Carter, a professor of law at Yale as well as a successful novelist, has written a book about just war theory in which he concludes that Barack Obama, a president he clearly admires, has prosecuted the war on terror with no more regard for the theorys ancient principles than George W. Bush (whom many of Carters readers no doubt consider a war criminal). The really discomfiting part is that Carter doesnt advance this claim as a criticism, but rather as an acknowledgment of the way Americas leaders fight wars, and are quite likely to continue fighting this one.

title: Russia Adopts Color-Coded Terror Alert System
description: MOSCOW  Under intense pressure to ratchet up security measures after the terrorist attack Monday at the airport here, Russian lawmakers on Friday fast-tracked the introduction of a color-coded alert system similar to the one adopted by the United States after the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Weekend Competition: Whiskers on Kittens
description: This weekend, as the doom and gloom of ice and cold begin to take a toll, co-vocabularists are invited to submit a few of their favorite things.

title: Pneumonia DNA Morphs To Dodge Vaccines
description: Researchers from seven countries have collaborated to analyze how a single strain of Streptococcus pneumoniae bacteria has morphed over 30 years and spread across the world, in an attempt to overcome the development of antibiotics and vaccines.

title: New Rules Would Phase Out Two Dirty Heating Oils
description: Two of the dirtiest types of heating oil would be phased out under city rules proposed on Friday: No. 6, the cheapest but most viscous type pumped into aging boilers, and another heavy oil, No. 4, which is only slightly less noxious. Both exacerbate asthma and emphysema and increase the risk of heart attack and premature death. The fuels are currently used by about 10,000 buildings in New York: Read about the move toward cleaner oil on the Green blog.

title: A Life Lesson Learned in Medical School
description: It was in my second year of medical school that I learned one of the most important lessons of my career: That it can be hard to distinguish truth from a perfectly good answer. Certainty was what I craved the most back then, poised as I was on the threshold of my medical career. But my first patient would cure me of certainty forever.

title: Obamas Climate Speech
description: Bill Becker, who has run a years-long effort to shape a presidential plan on climate and energy, crafted an imagined followup speech and event for President Obama should he choose to dig in on the case for climate action, which he left out of his State of the Union message.

title: Weighing the Best Vehicles For Philanthropic Giving
description: KEN NOPAR, who advises others about philanthropy, will face his own decision on charitable giving when his parents die. Should he and his brother keep their parents private foundation going or transfer the assets into a donor-advised fund, where they have less control over how the money is invested and given away?

title: TV Crews Struggle in Egyptian Chaos
description: 2:22 p.m. | Updated Television crews in Cairo fought to stay on the air on Friday as protests enveloped major cities in Egypt.

title: Germany Plans Start of Troop Withdrawal
description: BERLIN  With the public increasingly opposed to the war in Afghanistan, the German Parliament voted on Friday to begin withdrawing the 4,900 soldiers serving there by the end of this year and to complete the withdrawal by 2014, the first time Germany has set a time frame for bringing troops home.

title: After Illness, Levine Cancels Carnegie Hall Performance
description: A viral infection has forced James Levine to cancel a performance at Carnegie Hall on Sunday. Mr. Levine was to have led the Met Chamber Ensemble, made up of members of the Metropolitan Opera orchestra, in a challenging program of works by Brahms, Lukas Foss, Leon Kirchner and George Perle.

title: Egyptians Fury Has Smoldered Beneath the Surface for Decades
description: Standing before a joint session of Parliament in 2006, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt told lawmakers what most in attendance had already assumed: He planned to stay in power until the day he died.

title: To Increase Production, Jeter Tries Subtracting a Step
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Kevin Long needed a place to demonstrate Derek Jeters retooled hitting mechanics, so the bar area of a Bonefish Grill on Thursday night had to suffice. Long nudged aside a coffee table, assumed the hitting position  legs flexed, body squared, arms bent and out front  and moved his front foot up and down. As he pretended to swing a bat, a waitress bumped into him. Long, so engrossed in his explanation, did not seem to notice.

title: S.E.C. Staff to Brokers: Clients Should Come First
description: The intense debate over whether brokers should be required to put their customers interests before their own is far from over, but its moving in the right direction.

title: Obama Cautions Embattled Ally Against Violence
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Friday put Egypts embattled leader, Hosni Mubarak, on notice that he should not use his soldiers and the police in a bloody crackdown on the protests in Egypt, edging away from a close American ally whose cities have erupted in protest.

title: Style Map | Mumbai
description: Mumbai is Indias melting pot, jampacked with a diverse population all seeking to live the countrys new economic dream. And the citys newest hot spots for dining, shopping and pampering are a jumble, too, bringing together colorful clothing boutiques, opulent palace hotels and minimalist galleries with concrete floors  sometimes within blocks of each other. Its all part of Mumbais invigorating chaos.

title: GDP Per Capita, Here and There
description: Ive been writing a fair bit about the US-European comparison; one comment that often arises here is that Europe must be doing something wrong, because it has much lower GDP per capita. And its true: French GDP per capita, adjusted for purchasing power, is only about 3/4 the US level.

title: Blame Madoff: Wilpon Needs to Sell Part of the Mets
description: 2:09 p.m. | Updated

title: What Is the Beijing Consensus?
Big Deal | The Price of Bragging Rights
description: Moguls and mansions, conquests and prizes, prestige and social status  this is the language of the blood sport that is big-money New York City real estate. And the word trophy, as in trophy apartment, trophy building or trophy sale, gets tossed around a lot.

title: Charlie Callas, Zany Comedian, Dies at 83
description: Charlie Callas, a rubber-faced comedian who cavorted on television and the nightclub circuit in the 1960s, 70s and 80s, often punctuating punch lines with sound effects emanating from his motormouth, died on Thursday in Las Vegas. He was 83.

title: Predators Get Snowed In Too
description: Roland Kays, curator of mammals at the New York State Museum and author of Mammals of North America, writes from Albany, where he is comparing the behavior of fishers in urban and wild settings.

title: Does Facebook Make Someone Social Offline?
description: THE GIST Facebook makes people more social in their lives offline.

title: Spotify Close to a Deal With EMI
description: Spotify, a digital music service that has been popular in Europe but met roadblocks in its plans to enter the American market, is inching closer to its goal. A week after it signed an arrangement with Sony Music Entertainment for distribution in the United States, the company is very close to closing a deal with EMI Music, according to a person with knowledge of the negotiations but who was not authorized to discuss them.

title: Book Review Podcast: Paul Berman on Irving Kristol
description: This week: Paul Berman discusses the career of Irving Kristol, the godfather of neoconservatism; The Timess Bruce Weber talks about some persistent but mistaken sports myths; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Using Yoga to Help Cabdrivers Relax Body and Mind
description: Thomas Lowery clomped down the hallway in his jeans and Timberland boots, 6-feet-2 and 290 pounds and 54 years old, until he reached the classroom. It was an improbably delicate place, a dance studio with blond wood and mirrored walls. Mr. Lowery cut down his strides to pick a path between the nine purple mats arranged on the floor.

title: At Davos, Global Leaders Call for Trade Pact
A Decent Bed, and With Luck a Dry Towel
description: The philanthropist Darius Ogden Mills built three Mills Hotels, lodging houses for working men, in New York City. One, Mills Hotel No. 3 on Seventh Avenue and 36th Street, is now up for landmark designation.

title: Jody Williams Turns From Italy to France
description: Jody Williams has been cooking Italian food in New York for years at Giorgione, Gusto, Morandi and Gottino. Now this spunky chef is trying her hand at French at Buvette.

title: The Buzz Is Back, but Are the Knicks?
description: Howard Beck, who covers the Knicks, responded to comments and answered readers questions on Friday afternoon. Join the conversation in the comment section below.

title: Putting a Price on Star Power
description: PHOENIX

title: Juniors Watch: Previewing the Finals
description: Read more about juniors tennis at Colette Lewiss blog, zootennis.com.

title: Winning Bids in the Bargain Bin
description: BUYERS of entry-level cars in Arizona seemed to be a mix of heavy hitters picking up consolation prizes and more earthbound collectors who simply grew tired of sitting on their hands for a couple of years. The affordable collector cars featured in these pages on Jan. 14 all sold for within (and in some cases above) their presale estimates. Here are the sales results including the buyers premium:

title: Fehr Denies a Hiring Was Meant as a Message
description: Donald Fehr, the new executive director of the N.H.L. Players Association, said Thursday that a newly hired assistant who has opposed the N.H.L. over franchise relocations was not the shot across the bow it has been described as in some quarters.

title: Letter: India and Bird-Watching
description: To the Editor:

title: Letter: Reasons to Go to Oahu
description: To the Editor:

title: Extreme New Zealand, a Thrill-Seekers Playground
description: CONSIDER how the average adventure sport gets started: one person does something that seems to invite death  or at least mangling injury  like jumping off a bridge while attached to a rubber band or rolling down a hill in a giant hamster ball. A second, slightly saner person asks, How can I make it so people can do this safely but still feel like theyre inviting death or mangling injury? And hordes of young thrill-seekers come running.

title: Restaurant Review: Gauthier Soho in London
description: Gastronomy just might be the strongest modern link in the entente cordiale between France and England. The English remain avid fans of French cooking, and France repays the compliment by supplying them with a continuously renewed brigade of culinary talent. By any measure, London has the most impressive constellation of French chefs of any European city outside of France.

title: My Go-To Places for Regional Italian Food in San Francisco
description: ABOUT 20 years ago a friend took me to Caffe Trieste in San Franciscos North Beach for an espresso. It wasnt easy to find a stand-up espresso in those pre-Starbucks days, but  more to the point  it helped me to recognize the strength and authenticity of that citys not-especially-large Italian community.

title: Modern Art Amid Ancient Stone in Cuenca, Spain
description: BLAME it on Toledo. If youve never heard of Cuenca, the historic, picturesque hilltop Spanish town a two-hour drive east of Madrid, its most likely because the historic, picturesque hilltop town of Toledo is just an hours drive (or a half-hour train ride) from Madrid. For visitors looking for an excursion, Toledo has always triumphed.

title: In Nevada, the Viewing Has Begun From the Hoover Dam Bypass Bridge
description: FOR Derrick Jepsens 37th birthday in December, his wife, Theresa, treated him to a trip to Las Vegas.

title: Floridas Newest Dal Museum
description: WHEN a Cleveland-based art-collecting couple put word out that they needed a home for their extensive Salvador Dal holdings back in the 1970s, St. Petersburg, Fla., heeded the call. The city made an impressive offer  to build a museum for Eleanor and A. Reynolds Morses trove of works by the Surrealist master. That museum opened in 1982 and has played a large part in making the city a destination for culture vultures from around the world.

title: Hotel Review: Postcard Inn on the Beach in St. Pete Beach, Fla.
description: BASICS

title: Logan Squares Time Comes Round in Chicago
description: Restaurants, coffee shops and bars helped revive a neighborhood thats now become a magnet for creative types.

title: San Franciscos Italian Flavor
description: There have been better-than-average Italian restaurants in San Francisco for ages, but at no time have there been more than there are right now.

title: License to Thrill
description: Sure, the landscape is dramatic, but why does it compel people to rip about in boats, roll down hills in plastic balls and jump off bridges?

title: Landesman Comments on Theater
description: Count on Rocco Landesman to stir the pot. Speaking at a conference about new play development at Arena Stage in Washington on Thursday, Mr. Landesman, the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, addressed the problem of struggling theaters. You can either increase demand or decrease supply, he said. Demand is not going to increase, so it is time to think about decreasing supply. His comment reverberated through the blogosphere. What does he mean theres too much supply?!? wrote Trisha Mead, the public relations and publications manager at Portland Center Stage in Oregon. What does he mean we cant increase demand?!? Who determines which theater companies are wheat and which are chaff?!? In another post, Durango Miller, a playwright and director, said: Why not just increase funding? Maybe the N.E.A. is outdated and should be replaced by another system for funding the arts in the United States. Or maybe the people who are running the N.E.A. should be replaced.

title: Focus Gets into the Sundance Game
description: LOS ANGELES Focus Features, all but invisible at Sundance this year (especially in contrast to rival Fox Searchlight), finally popped up on Friday with an acquisition in the $800,000 range. Focus, which may or may not be for sale itself, bought worldwide rights to Pariah, a coming-of-age story centered on a 17-year-old black girl trying to come to terms with her homosexuality. Dee Rees directed the film; as part of the deal, Ms. Rees will write another script for Focus with the goal of directing it.

title: The Fehr Interview: Looking to Civil Talks, and No Shots Across the Bow
description: In his first in-depth interview since announcing his candidacy for the job last summer, Donald Fehr, the new executive director of the N.H.L. Players Association, said that last weeks hiring by the union of a Toronto lawyer who has opposed the N.H.L. in previous battles over franchise relocations was not the shot across the bow it has been described as in some quarters.In a wide-ranging discussion before he left New York for Raleigh, N.C., on Friday to attend the N.H.L.s All-Star weekend, Fehr traced his ascendancy to the job, stressing his admiration for the N.H.L. players he has met since coming over from the directorship of the Major League Baseball Players Association, a post he held for 26 years until stepping down in 2009.

title: My Personal Baggage
description: YOU need to declare independence from stuff, my boyfriend, who travels with a single carry-on bag, one change of clothes and a lone paperback that he leaves behind on the plane, recently announced. We were standing in the street, and I had asked him to hold my store-bought cup of tea, so I could mine for my cellphone in the rubble at the bottom of my distended bag, while clutching a stack of mail with the armpit of my bagless arm.

title: Violent Clashes on the Streets of Cairo
description: Demonstrations against the rule of President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt began anew on Friday, growing increasingly violent as protesters clashed with police.

title: (Insert Year): Now That Was a Winter!
description: It is one of the great clichs of time  life was tougher or better, bigger or badder, sweeter or scarier, in the old days. Ah, yes, yesteryear  rattling trolley cars, yammering party lines, bustling factories in SoHo and deeper, much deeper, snowfalls.

title: A Decent Bed, and With Luck a Dry Towel
description: THE dour, run-down office building at Seventh Avenue and 36th Street looks little different from its gritty garment center neighbors. But it is earlier than almost all of them by a decade, built in 1907 by Darius Ogden Mills as a model lodging house for working-class men, and now it appears headed for landmark designation.

title: Dressed to Style, Tress by Tress
description: THE hairstylist Sally Hershberger, 49, became well known after the wispy shag cut she gave to Meg Ryan in the 1990s, and continues to be a top choice of fashion and film directors. Civilians who cant afford her personal service, which starts at $600, can try less-expensive employees at her salons in New York and Los Angeles (in February, shell add one in Beverly Hills, Calif.) or her two product lines.

title: Artifacts | Tick, Tick, Tick
description: We all know how time can fly and that a watched pot wont boil any quicker than one left to its own devices. But watching Christian Marclays latest film, The Clock, is like wearing a Timex that takes a licking and keeps on ticking for 24 straight hours of viewing pleasure.

title: Longtime Ad Critic to Curate Pop Culture
description: Barbara Lippert, who was the advertising critic for the ad trade publication Adweek for more than two decades before her dismissal last month, has landed an unusual new job at a prominent agency.

title: WindMade May Soon Join Other Feel-Good Labels
Protests Unsettle Jordan While Most Other Neighbors Stay Calm
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Thousands of protesters gathered in Jordan, but Yemen and other restive locales in the Middle East stayed relatively quiet Friday as the regions focus turned to Egypt, the Arab worlds most populous country, where tens of thousands staged an unprecedented challenge to the 30-year rule of President Hosni Mubarak.

title: Teaching Children to Help Neighbors, With or Without Reward
description: BACK in the early 1970s, my parents neighbors offered to pay my sister, who was 8 years old at the time, to take care of their cats for a weekend.

title: No Clear Strategy to Save the Euro
A Son of the South With Many Accents
description: TIMOTHY OLYPHANT may embody the steely-eyed, white-hatted hero on Justified, the backwoods crime drama on FX based on stories by Elmore Leonard, but Walton Goggins supplies the shows tortured soul.

title: Looking Glasses
description: Whats the next best thing to owning a classic Chanel bag? Why, quilted-lambskin Chanel sunglasses, of course. And  surprise  one side lifts up to reveal a discreet mirror thats ideal for surreptitious postlunch lipstick checks. Theyre $740 at Ilori and Chanel boutiques nationwide.

title: Daddy Discrimination
description: Do we assume men are predators? We have discussed that question here on Motherlode periodically, and earlier this monthLenore Skenazy asked it in an essay in The Wall Street Journal.

title: Frances First Lady
description: Photos from President Nicolas Sarkozy and Carla Bruni-Sarkozys trips around the globe.

title: Ferraris With Celebrity Cachet Not Always Solid Auction Bets
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, I write about how a vintage automobiles association with a celebrity, known in auction parlance as celebrity provenance, can help or hinder the vehicles prospects on auction day. Few rules apply in this area, which is governed largely by bidders upwellings of nostalgia  especially where Ferraris are concerned.

title: TimesCast | January 28, 2011
description: Rioting continues into the night in Cairo; America's diplomatic stakes with Egypt; and the impact of the protests throughout the Arab world.

title: Citi Shuffles Its Tech, Energy and Chemicals Banking Groups
description: Citigroup on Friday shuffled the organization of some of its investment banking groups, including by naming its top deal maker, Mark Shafir, as the new co-head of the technology, media and telecommunications group, according to an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook.

title: How Do You Solve a Problem Like Mubarak?
description: UPDATED BELOW, 11:50 a.m. Saturday:

title: Behavior: Another Good Reason to Sing a Lullaby
description: Children who sleep less than their peers may be at greater risk for abnormal blood glucose levels and other metabolic problems.

title: Diet: Bigger Breakfast, Bigger Daily Calorie Count
description: Dieters are sometimes told to have a substantial breakfast, because it reduces the amount of food consumed during rest of the day. Not so, a new study reports.

title: Disparities: Racial Gaps Seen in Chlamydia Screening
description: All sexually active women under 25 are supposed to be screened for chlamydia. But a new analysis finds that black and Hispanic women are screened at significantly higher rates than white women, and this could help explain why minority women have higher reported rates of the disease.

title: The S.&P. Meanders Back to 1,300
description: The Standard & Poors index of 500 stocks first reached 1,300 nearly 12 years ago. This week, it did it again.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Kings County Distillery in Williamsburg, 35 Meadow Street (Bogart Street), bottles its moonshine in clear flasks with white labels adorned with typewriter fonts. On Saturday, watch this small producer make its unaged corn whiskey from 1 to 6 p.m. Admission is free and tastings are $3.

title: Unrest Worries Credit Raters. So Does Calming It.
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  As the turmoil gripping much of the Arab world reached a critical pitch in Egypt on Friday, the possible economic fallout was on the minds of credit ratings agencies monitoring the situation from thousands of miles away, and they did not like what they saw. But the warnings they issued are themselves raising eyebrows.

title: An Indie Gumshoe in Oregons Gloom
description: COLD WEATHER, the third feature by the young filmmaker Aaron Katz, begins in the modestly introspective vein of many a low-budget American indie. On an indefinite break from college, Doug has returned home to Portland, Ore., where hes staying with his sister, Gail. The film appears poised to explore their shared history and private uncertainty, the simultaneous distance and closeness that sometimes defines adult sibling dynamics.

title: On the Street | Snow, Cont.
description: Down coats and enormous down hoods enveloped people and dogs.

title: An Oscar Snub for Designing Women
description: LOS ANGELES If youve seen Kate and Laura Mulleavy, the sisters behind the fashion line Rodarte, discussing how they painstakingly hand-crafted all the ballet costumes for Black Swan  spending months making multiple versions of the feather-bedecked white and black swan tutus, going through fitting after fitting as the body of their hard-training star, Natalie Portman, changed  you may wonder why they were not nominated for a costume design Oscar. The Bagger wondered too, especially after we donned one of the outfits (the bad guys, of course).

title: Mine Operator Says That Huge Seep Caused Blast
description: WASHINGTON  The company that operates a West Virginia coal mine on Friday disputed a preliminary federal finding that poor mining practices and improper equipment maintenance led to an explosion that killed 29 miners last year.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: A Crazy Night in Davos Sean Parker, who helped build Napster and Facebook, had to be rushed to the hospital in Davos on his first night there after he had an allergic reaction to nuts. Henry Blodget has a compelling, if rambling, account. Business Insider

title: Ireland, Mired in Crisis, Will Dissolve Parliament
description: LONDON  Two months after Ireland joined Greece in accepting an international bailout for its debt-wracked economy, the political reckoning for the Dublin government entered a decisive phase on Friday with the announcement that Parliament would be dissolved on Tuesday ahead of a general election.

title: Look of the Moment | Thandie Newton
description: The Look: Minty fresh. The pale print and brief hemline are signs that spring  or maybe just spring fashion  is in the air.

title: Book Review Podcast: Paul Berman on Irving Kristol
description: This week: Paul Berman discusses the career of Irving Kristol, the godfather of neoconservatism; The Timess Bruce Weber talks about some persistent but mistaken sports myths; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

title: Book Review Podcast: Paul Berman on Irving Kristol
description: This week: Paul Berman discusses the career of Irving Kristol, the godfather of neoconservatism; The Timess Bruce Weber talks about some persistent but mistaken sports myths; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

title: Book Review Podcast: Paul Berman on Irving Kristol
description: This week: Paul Berman discusses the career of Irving Kristol, the godfather of neoconservatism; The Timess Bruce Weber talks about some persistent but mistaken sports myths; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

title: Weekend in Lisbon
description: Lisbon offers upstart museums and renovated industrial districts by day and happening places at night.

title: Filling Out the N.C.A.A. Tournament Field
description: The expansion of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament to 68 teams this season means there are three more at-large bids to be had.

title: Deciding Between Donor-Advised Funds and Private Foundations
description: In this weeks Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan explores a question that many philanthropy-minded people are pondering: should we keep the private foundation going, or switch to a donor-advised fund?

title: Pictures of the Day
description: Photographs from Cairo, Johannesburg, and Uganda

title: Black Swan Magic and Other Oscar News
description: LOS ANGELES Moviemaking is a technical feat, as any James Cameron movie can tell us, as well as an emotional one, as the director himself likes to say. (That was just a not-so-smooth segue to this side note: Mr. Cameron just joined Twitter. I never tweeted before because Im a long winded blowhard, and they dont allow enough characters, he wrote in one of his first posts. And in reply to the inevitable fan follow-up question  When are we going to have the first Tweet in 3D?  he wrote: 3D handhelds and laptops are available now.)

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: Foreign Film Snubs, Life After Lost, Walton Goggins and More
description: My complaint, really, is about the peculiar and growing irrelevance of world cinema in American movie culture, which the Academy Awards help to perpetuate.A. O. Scott in an essay about how the Academys capricious selection process marginalizes foreign films.

title: Pictures of the Day: Cairo and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Egypt, South Africa and Uganda.

title: The Rise and Fall of Desiree Rogers
description: Party crashers at a state dinner dealt the final blow to Desire Rogers position as White House social secretary. But tension had been brewing well before.

title: A Guy as Keeper of the National Guest List?
description: WASHINGTON

title: Nakamura Wins Again and Seizes Lead of Tata Steel Chess Tournament
Attention aux Franais
description: Lets see now: cheveux, nuage and poulet.

title: Indie Rock Embraces an African Invasion
description: THE indie record company Sub Pop first earned a reputation as a tastemaker in the late 1980s, when it signed and recorded the Seattle bands Nirvana and Soundgarden and other exponents of what came to be known as grunge. But one of its best-received recent releases is I Speak Fula, by Bassekou Kouyate & Ngoni Ba, an ensemble that plays small lutelike instruments and sings in various West African languages.

title: The Guy Under the Seats Rises Again
description: HERES an entry from Chris Elliotts file of What Might Have Been:

title: For a Filmmaker, the Green Things in Life Are Free
description: PARIS

title: The Apocalypse Served Straight Up
description: WHEN the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences presented Roger Corman with an honorary award in 2009, the citation didnt mention the more than 50 films he directed. Instead the Academy praised him for his rich engendering of films and filmmakers  a phrase that distractingly evokes a champion racehorse in retirement but evidently refers to Mr. Cormans stunning track record as a producer.

title: The Sounds of the Vibraphone Summon Audiences in Miami
description: MIAMI BEACH  Just about every concert hall or opera house has some kind of recorded chime tones, or chime melody, or bell fanfare, or something that is played in the lobbies to let the audience know that the performance is about to start or an intermission is about to end.

title: Earlier Hormone Therapy Elevates Breast Cancer Risk, Study Says
description: Growing evidence about the risks of breast cancer and other serious illnesses posed by hormone therapy for menopause has led many women to give up the drugs, and many doctors to stop recommending them.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 28
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: The Man Behind the Ace Empire
description: WALK into the Ace Hotel, on the corner of Broadway and 29th Street, at any given time, and here is what you may find: The band Jc might be playing in one corner of the vast lobby, their horn-and-accordion tunes bouncing off the century-old mosaic floor, the dark wood paneling, the 17 1/2-foot white columns. In one of the red-suede sofa nooks, under a huge American flag bought at the Brimfield Antique Show, a motley crew of friends from Washington  a womens-wear designer, a tour guide, a defense contractor  might be striking up a conversation with the British pop-soul singer Edei. In the middle of the lobby, the long library-style black tables have been colonized by MacBooks.

title: Goldman Sachs Gives Blankfein a Big Raise
description: 8:30 p.m. | Updated

title: State Shuts Tortilla Factory Where Worker Died
description: The Brooklyn tortilla factory where a Guatemalan worker died on Monday after he fell into an industrial dough mixer has been shut down by the state because it has been without workers compensation insurance for nearly a year, state officials said Friday.

title: City Ballets Winter Season
description: This week the troupe performed works by George Balanchine, Christopher Wheeldon and Jerome Robbins.

title: From Rage to Uplift in a Matter of Minutes
description: The Finnish soprano Karita Mattila last appeared in New York in 2009 at the Metropolitan Opera, in Luc Bondys production of Puccinis Tosca. There she gamely tried to adapt her penetrating voice to the Italianate lines of the title role, without ever sounding really at ease.

title: Hirshhorn Trustees Denounce Decision to Pull Video
description: The Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden has broken ranks with its parent, the Smithsonian Institution, to denounce the Smithsonians decision to remove a video by David Wojnarowicz from an exhibition at the National Portrait Gallery.

title: Hirshhorn Trustees Denounce Decision to Pull Video
description: The Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden has broken ranks with its parent, the Smithsonian Institution, to denounce the Smithsonians decision to remove a video by David Wojnarowicz from an exhibition at the National Portrait Gallery.

title: New Concerns About Hormone Therapy
description: The Times reports on Friday that a large of study of women in the United Kingdom has found that those who used hormone replacement therapy at menopause suffered an elevated risk of breast cancer, compared with women who used hormones only in the years following menopause.

title: Intel Spreads Its University Research Bets
description: Computing in general is increasingly applying the old engineering dictum, divide and conquer. Look at the engines behind cloud computing  vast, distributed armies of server computers. Even at the chip level, the wave of the recent past and the future is, as they say in the industry, multicore  microprocessors with multiple data-processing cores, for lower-power consumption and better performance.

title: Dinosaurs, Politicians, Oil and Water
description: Attending a show at Dance New Amsterdam has become a little like stepping back in time. For Splice, two choreographers share a program in a series that brings to mind Dance Theater Workshops former Split Stream series with one uncomfortable difference. Splice also requires participants to collaborate on a piece, and Clarinda Mac Low and Jordana Che Toback, performing on Thursday night, dont exactly brim over with artistic simpatico.

title: Egyptian Military Chiefs Cut Pentagon Visit Short
description: WASHINGTON  Senior Egyptian military commanders cut short a visit to the Pentagon on Friday and were headed back home Friday, American military officials said, as the Egyptian Army was deployed on the streets of Cairo and other cities to back up state security forces who had confronted mass protests around the country throughout the day.

title: Hyundai Kia Overtakes Ford, While G.M. Threatens Toyota in 2010 Global Sales
description: High placement on the global best-seller list may not have the same immediacy for vehicles as it does for books, but it brings bragging rights and probably influences sales to some degree.

title: Crumpets and Marmalade on Super Bowl Sunday
description: I DONT know a field goal from a touchdown, and spend most Super Bowl Sundays wishing a pigskin were a crunchy fried snack. But there is one thing I love about the day: Every year I can snag last-minute tickets to sold-out movies or make reservations at perpetually booked restaurants.

title: Can the Asian Boom Save Room for Tigers?
description: These days, to maintain the health and balance of scattered tiger populations, its sometimes necessary to move animals long distances. Sometime there are other reasons. The tiger in the video below, injured after it wandered into a hotel in a Nepali tourist town last September, was fitted with a radio collar and this month trucked from one national park to another:

title: A Conclusion on Occlusion
description: In my Times column Thursday, I quoted a reader who asked: Would you mind clearing the steadily occluding waters of Skype, Google Voice, Line2, and so on?

title: Not Quite Metal, but Packing Weight
description: Ambient yelling at the Kylesa concert on Wednesday night at Santos Party House:

title: New Years Treats
description: The Chinese New Year, a celebration that lasts from Thursday to Feb. 17, makes this a good time to visit Golden Village in Scarsdale or Kam Sen in White Plains. Both markets are now particularly well stocked with reasonably priced foods that in name, color, homonym or shape represent the holidays good wishes: for happiness, prosperity and wealth.

title: Afghan Accents for a Western Palate
description: RAFT BISTRO has lots of panache  sparkling chandeliers hanging from rustic beams, paper place mats replaced with every course, citrus slices in the water carafes, even a miniature winterscape decorating the dividers between the bar and dining areas. Like a piece of stage set by Cocteau, it is so lavish with candles, whitened twigs, white pin lights and shimmery crystals that patrons can easily forget its icy white counterpart outside.

title: Gennie Chen, James Stewart
description: Gennie Yu Chen, a daughter of Mei Yu Ku and David Chen, both of Anaheim, Calif., was married Saturday to James Robert Stewart, a son of Sandra Paine Stewart and William R. Stewart of Shaker Heights, Ohio. Sarah J. Ritchie, a minister of the Universal Brotherhood Movement, officiated at the bride and bridegrooms apartment in New York.

title: Leigh Meixell, Matthew Schopp
description: Leigh Margaret Meixell, a daughter of Mary J. Meixell and David D. Meixell of Glastonbury, Conn., was married Saturday to Matthew James Schopp, the son of Cathy K. Schopp and Kenneth D. Schopp of West Milford, N.J. The Rev. James H. Coen, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Kirkpatrick Chapel at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J.

title: Denise Choquette, Michael Leber
description: Denise E. Choquette and Michael D. Leber were married Saturday evening at Manning Chapel on the campus of Brown University in Providence, R.I. The Rev. Robert Cole, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony, with Rabbi Douglas Krantz taking part.

title: Jessica Brooks and Joseph Holman
description: Jessica Phyllis Brooks and Joseph Holman were married Saturday evening at the Pratt Mansions, an event space, in New York. Rabbi Ari L. Fridkis officiated.

title: Geremy Kawaller and Edward Ackerman
description: Geremy Kawaller and Edward Toll Ackerman were married Friday in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Patricia Ackerman, an Episcopal priest and Mr. Ackermans aunt, officiated at the Greenwich Town Hall. On Saturday evening, Rabbi Hara E. Person performed another ceremony at the Bowery Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Wentworth Caldwell, John McGovern III
description: Wentworth Caldwell and John Edward McGovern III were married Saturday evening at St. Georges Episcopal Church in Nashville. The Rev. R. Leigh Spruill, the churchs rector, performed the ceremony.

title: Elizabeth Scott, Cameron Breitner
description: Elizabeth Lauren Scott and Cameron Eliot Hargreaves Breitner were married Saturday evening at Capitale, an event space in Manhattan. Sarah Ritchie, a Universal Brotherhood Movement minister, officiated.

title: Lisa Bienstock and Gregory Zilin
description: Dr. Lisa Beth Bienstock and Gregory Max Zilin were married Saturday evening at the Phoenician, a resort in Scottsdale, Ariz. Rabbi Marty Scharf led the ceremony.

title: Chic in Review | Kardashian Cocktail
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Whats to Like About Williamss Release by Orlando?
description: It has been a complicated career for Jason Williams, the point guard known to some as White Chocolate, who has morphed from troubled youngster in Sacramento, to reborn star in Memphis, to key championship cog in Miami to struggling veteran in Orlando.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 28
description: More Photographs

title: Reviewing the Hyundai Sonata
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, John Pearley Huffman reviews the 2011 Hyundai Sonata in its three forms: hybrid, above; conventional gasoline; and turbocharged versions. Mr. Huffman found lots to praise in the all-new Sonata:

title: Not Quite a One-Woman Show
description: Memories of her familys farm and vineyard in Calabria, in southern Italy, prompted Claudia Purita to buy a 28-acre potato farm in Southold in 2002. Mrs. Purita had spent 14 years working in the kitchens of Long Island restaurants that she and her husband, Frank, owned, including Paradiso, in Rockville Centre.

title: In Their Minds, an Ocean Keeps Them Apart
description: Flipzoids, Ralph B. Peas empathetic dissection of the Filipino immigrant experience, manages the neat trick of being both elegiac and stirring. These seemingly contradictory qualities stem partly from Mr. Peas uneven script, but primarily from a towering performance by Ching Valdes-Aran, the actress at its center.

title: Brazil to Rebuild Houses Lost in Rains
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Brazils president has committed the government to building 6,000 homes for displaced residents of the hillside communities devastated by landslides that killed at least 842 people this month.

title: A Spot to Share Dishes and Romance
description: YOU dont have to wait until Feb. 14 to have a romantic dinner out. At Swallow, which opened in Huntington in October, every day is Valentines Day.

title: Adrenaline in New Zealand
description: In Queenstown, New Zealand, a high demand for extreme sports has created a booming industry for adrenaline junkies.

title: Serious Rite, Sultry Tango and Skillful Solos
description: Ranking artists is a risky and contentious sport. When The New York Timess chief music critic, Anthony Tommasini, thoughtfully and painstakingly created a list of the 10 greatest composers recently, reader delight and outrage were fairly evenly mixed. A similar furor erupted in 2008 when the British classical-music magazine Gramophone ranked the top 20 orchestras in the world. After all, orchestral playing is a mix of chemistry and chance; ensembles have on and off nights in good halls and bad, and sound different depending on who is on the podium.

title: Bush Says Hes Done With Politics
description: President George W. Bush says he has left politics for good and has no plans to raise money and work for Republican candidates.

title: The Focus Is on Families
description: The Wood Creek Bar and Grill occupies a prominent place in the Royal Arcanum Building, a 100-year-old brick gem and one of Norfolks most distinctive structures. Rustic, dark-stained pine banquettes and window casements, globe-shaped sconces and walls decorated with a smattering of French bistro art all contribute to the convivial, pubby atmosphere. Yet the outfitting of white-paper-covered tables with fresh flowers and crayons underscores the family-friendly nature of the establishment.

title: Idol, as Usual
description: Even with CBS and ABC broadcasting mostly reruns on Thursday, NBC and its new three-hour comedy block struggled to gain much traction in the ratings as Fox and American Idol easily topped the night. According to Nielsens estimates, Idol led over all with 22.3 million viewers at 8 p.m., boosting Foxs Bones into the lead at 9 with 12.2 million viewers. CBS ranked second. Although NBC fared better than CBS and ABC in the demographic of viewers 18 to 49, it trailed in third place in total viewers, tied with ABC.

title: Fire in the Hearth and a Nautical Theme
description: IM sure I wasnt the only one saddened by the closing of the River Cat Grill last March  or gladdened by the opening of Sails American Grill in the same spot less than nine months later. This new restaurant in Rowaytons center has a freshly painted, crisp white interior; an understated nautical motif; and a new owner, Arthur Hooper. But Nathan Kramer, the former River Cat chef, is back at the tiller.

title: A Band Updates Some of Its Favorite Things
description: The harmony of the Jackson 5s hit song ABC is instantly recognizable as a falsetto-like voice starts a buh-BUH buh buh-BUH, echoed by a male chorus. But then little Michael Jackson and his brothers give way to another group of family singers, the seven Von Trapp children and their governess, Maria, and the lyrics from the Swiss Alps plow into those from Gary, Ind.:

title: Uncle Ernie Takes a Bow
description: LOS ANGELES On Sunday, the Screen Actors Guild will honor Ernest Borgnine for career achievement and humanitarian accomplishment. Mr. Borgnine, who just turned 94, has been acting for nearly 70 years, most recently appearing in RED opposite Bruce Willis and Helen Mirren; he won an Oscar in 1955 for Marty. He spoke to the Bagger from the kitchen of his home in Beverly Hills, punctuating nearly every answer with avuncular laughter, but became circumspect when discussing how the experience of movie-making has changed over the years. Everything became money-oriented, he said. Hurry up, hurry up, hurry up, we dont have any time for gaiety or anything else, lets make the picture, make the picture and thats it. Its changed from being a family kind of thing to everybody trying to make a buck.

title: Two and a Half Men on Hiatus as Sheen Enters Rehab
description: 8:52 p.m. | Updated

title: For Cooks Who Compete, the Challenges of Fame
description: KEVIN SBRAGA, the last chef standing on last seasons installment of the Bravo cooking series Top Chef and, until recently, executive chef at Rats Restaurant at the Grounds for Sculpture art park in Hamilton, likes being a winner.

title: Moses Does Brooklyn, Burning Bush Included
description: The composer Yoav Gal has been working for about a decade on Mosheh, his compellingly idiosyncratic meditation on Moses and his relationship to the women in his life and to God, in that order. The opera was commissioned by Merkin Concert Hall, where Mr. Gal offered a weird but tantalizing excerpt in 2003, and since then, bits of the work have turned up at Galapagos, Makor and other halls, and at New York City Operas Vox showcase in 2009.

title: Roasted Mushrooms With Garlic
