description: Adapted from Josh Blakely, Macao Trading Company, Manhattan

title: Mushrooms Fill In the Blanks for the Meat-Free
description: WHEN he was a boy and his father hunted game in the woods of Alsace, Jean-Georges Vongerichten would tag along and forage for mushrooms.

title: Taking Flight: A Season of Revival
description: On Wednesday both George Balanchines Symphony in Three Movements (1972) and Christopher Wheeldons Polyphonia (2001) returned to New York City Ballet repertory. Other works by choreographers dead and alive have also been revived this winter season, but these two have been outstanding.

title: Veterans Groups Criticize Bachmann Plan to Cut Benefits
description: For years, federal spending on the military and veterans affairs seemed nearly as sacrosanct as Social Security. But with some House Republicans now talking about cutting the Pentagon budget, veterans groups have grown nervous that the Department of Veterans Affairs will be next. And so today, a number of groups took preemptive action, vigorously blasting a proposal for V.A. budget cuts that came from a Tea Party leader, Representative Michele Bachmann, Republican of Minnesota.

title: When a Tree Smiles
description: Brad Bateman, a 31-year old real estate agent and artist, created with the help of friends a Snowtree Alley along a path in Central Park north of the Delacorte Theater on Thursday. To make the snow stick to the trees, Mr. Bateman and his confederates simply warmed it in their hands.

title: Inquiry Is Missing Bottom Line
description: There was something almost comical about the way the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission released its report on Thursday morning.

title: Arctic Waters Warmer Than in 2,000 Years
description: Water flowing from the North Atlantic into the Arctic Ocean is warmer today than at any time in the past 2,000 years, a new study shows.

title: B & Bs Winter Bait: Its a Crime, Really
description: WHEN the proprietors of three bed-and-breakfasts in Cape May  the Henry Sawyer Inn, Twin Gables and the Victorian Lace Inn  approached Gayle Stahlhuth, the artistic director of the East Lynne Theater Company there, about staging murder mysteries as a way to lure out-of-town guests this winter, they struck gold.

title: Cashmere Shawls, From 2 Realms
description: GREENWICH, Conn.

title: Many Faces of Schubert, and of a Hall
description: MIAMI BEACH  From its inception, the concert hall at New World Center was designed to be an uncommonly versatile space. It will mainly be used for concerts of the New World Symphony, the excellent orchestral academy for select young musicians, based here since it was founded in 1987 by the conductor Michael Tilson Thomas. The hall was officially inaugurated with an orchestral concert on Wednesday.

title: Iran Sees Rise of Islamic Hard-Liners
description: TEHRAN  Hopeful that the protests sweeping Arab lands may create an opening for hard-line Islamic forces, conservatives in Iran are taking deep satisfaction in the events in Tunisia, Egypt and Yemen, where secular leaders have faced large-scale uprisings.

title: Angry Birds Go Hollywood
description: Angry Birds, the cellphone game that has turned into a cultural phenomenon with 75 million downloads and counting, is lending its wings to a 20th Century Fox movie.

title: A Town Divided by the Residue of War
description: There are grounds for believing that David Gutersons popular 1994 novel, Snow Falling on Cedars, could make good theater. Set in 1954, in a Puget Sound community divided among fishermen and farmers, whites and Japanese, it is at once a courtroom drama, a mystery, a love story and, in flashbacks, a social history freighted with the angry residue of World War II and the Japanese internment camps.

title: A U.S.-China Odyssey: Building a Better Mouse Map
description: SHANGHAI

title: A Stage Where the Dictionary Is an Old Friend
description: Little Marcy Park speaks six languages and does everything well, from Mozart to rugby, so she has an excellent chance of winning the spelling bee. (Winning is a job, Olivia Oguma sings joylessly as Marcy.) But William Barfe (Will Blum)  whose surname, he insists, rhymes with parfait  has a secret weapon: his magic foot, with which he spells out words on the floor. Leaf Coneybear (Lyle Colby Mackston) cannot believe he is at the county competition at all; he came in third in his school contest, but the winner was having his bar mitzvah, which the runner-up also had to attend. Those are only half of the colorful contestants in the Paper Mill Playhouses eminently likable, sweetly entertaining production of The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee.

title: Palestinian Is Shot in Head in Clash With Israeli Settlers
description: HEBRON, West Bank  A 15-year-old Palestinian was fighting for his life on Friday in a hospital in this city in the southern West Bank after being shot in a brush with armed Jewish settlers.

title: Allowing Players to Assume the Ultimate Role: Game Creators
description: Theres someone out there on Sonys PlayStation Network who goes by the name Urbandevill. Ive never met him. (I assume its a he because the online avatar sports yellow eyes, green skin and a long, green beard). I dont know what country he lives in. In fact, I dont know anything about him.

title: Photography, in the Family Way
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y.

title: Oceanic Passions in a Chamber Setting
description: The songwriter Shara Worden, who majored in opera singing for her bachelors degree, took her Lincoln Center headlining debut seriously. She spent three months working on new songs for her concert as part of Lincoln Centers American Songbook series on Thursday night at the Allen Room. She even had a song that she said was inspired by the rooms gigantic window onto 59th Street and Central Park. The new songs thoroughly recast her style, exchanging the rock beat and oceanic billows of her band, My Brightest Diamond, for lapidary chamber-pop.

title: Car-Pooling Declines as Driving Becomes Cheaper
description: Maps showing trends in carpooling.

title: Violent Clashes on the Streets of Cairo
description: Demonstrations against the rule of President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt began anew on Friday, growing increasingly violent as protesters clashed with police.

title: A Little Place That Finds Itself Receiving Big Money
description: Parshall, a town of about 1,000 in the vast empty of western North Dakota, has been invaded time and time again in recent years.

title: Protesters in New York Area Take Aim at U.S. Position on Egypt
description: JERSEY CITY  Waving Egyptian flags, chanting slogans in English and Arabic and setting fire to a photo of President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, about 100 men, women and children gathered Friday afternoon here in Journal Square to support the tens of thousands of protesters on the streets of Egypt pressing for an end to Mr. Mubaraks 30-year rule.

title: A Night of Acoustic and Electronic Exploits
description: The mixing of acoustic instruments and electronic sounds was not always as easy and natural as it can seem nowadays. Certainly, adventurous composers were drawn to the limitless palette of sounds made possible by recording technology and computers. But not until digital sampling and the versatile laptop computer arrived did it become relatively easy to exploit all the unusual timbres and unnatural juxtapositions promised by electronics.

title: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 28
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include rebel yoga, winter weather, and a funeral for a guardian angel.

title: Spare Vocals Illuminate Emotions Underneath
description: As jazz singers go, Rebecca Martin exudes the plainest sort of poise, almost radical in its utter lack of flash. When she wasnt cradling an acoustic guitar on Thursday night at the Cornelia Street Caf, she held her arms clasped behind her back, as if to make sure they wouldnt be a distraction. She sang quietly, favoring slow tempos.

title: Winning Play Was Found From a Pause in the Bidding
description: NEC, the Japanese computer company, hosts an annual international bridge tournament. This years will take place in Yokohama City from Feb. 8 to 13. Play can be followed at Bridge Base Online. The diagramed deal was interesting in the tournaments 2007 final, in which Ton Bakkeren, Huub Bertens, Leon Jacobs and Maarten Schollaardt from the Netherlands, defeated Cezary Balicki and Adam Zmudzinski, from Poland, and Alexander Dubinin and Andrei Gromov, from Russia.

title: Ruling Lets Starbucks End a Deal
description: A federal judge on Friday sided with Starbucks in its messy divorce from Kraft Foods, refusing to block Starbucks from breaking a longstanding supermarket distribution deal with Kraft.

title: J.&J. Unit Is Told to Pay $482 Million to New Jersey Doctor in Patent Case
description: A jury told Johnson & Johnson on Friday to pay $482 million to a New Jersey radiologist for infringing on a patent on devices to prop open heart arteries.

title: In This Show, Art Imitates Art
description: In an old cartoon I saw many years ago, a wealthy-looking codger gleefully defaces a series of old portraits as two museum guards look on with dismay. The caption says something like, Theres not a thing we can do  this is the Brown Collection, and thats Mr. Brown.

title: A Nobelist Has an Unfamiliar Role in Protests
description: CAIRO  Mohamed ElBaradei, an Egyptian who won a Nobel Peace Prize for his work to promote nuclear nonproliferation, never made a very likely revolutionary leader. But there he was Friday, in a soft leather jacket and clip-on sunglasses, standing toe-to-toe with a line of hundreds of riot police several blocks long.

title: Egypt
description: I dont know anything, have no expertise, havent even ever looked at the economic situation. Hence, no posting. If there comes a point when I have something to say, I will.

title: Al Jazeera Covers Protests Despite Hurdles
description: WASHINGTON  As street protests raged across Egypt on Friday, with the future of the Arab world seeming to hang in the balance, rapt viewers across the region  and the globe  watched it unfold on Al Jazeera, which kept up an almost continuous live feed despite the Egyptian governments repeated efforts to block broadcasts.

title: Yankees Levine Scolds Rangers Greenberg
description: When the Texas Rangers owner, Chuck Greenberg, criticized Yankees fans on the day of his teams final World Series game, on Nov. 1, the Yankees front office stayed quiet.

title: The New West Wing
description: A look at President Obamas new circle of advisers.

title: From ArtsBeat: Two and a Half Men on Hiatus
description: Dave Itzkoff and Bill Carter write about CBS and Warner Brothers Televisions announcement on Friday that their sitcom Two and a Half Men would take a production hiatus, as co-star Charlie Sheen enters a rehabilitation center. In a brief statement issued by the network and the studio, as well asChuck Lorre, the comedys creator and executive producer, they said, We are profoundly concerned for his health and well-being, and support his decision. The statement did not disclose the reason for Mr. Sheens entering rehab. On Thursday, the actor was taken by ambulance to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. His publicist said at the time that Mr. Sheen had severe abdominal pains resulting from a hernia condition, and a friend of the actors said he had been laughing too hard at a television show.

title: The Wal-Mart Decade
description: Ive been putting some material together for textbook revision, and found myself looking at European versus US productivity performance over the past couple of decades. I sort of knew the facts here, but this recent paper by Bart van Ark (pdf) seemed to me to make the points especially clearly, and I found myself rolling my own versions of some of his numbers.

title: In the Mideast, Days of Tumult
description: To the Editor:

title: F.D.A. Panel Is Split on Electroshock Risks
description: A federal advisory panel was sharply divided on Friday about whether to recommend that regulators designate electroshock devices as high risk. The change could increase oversight on a controversial treatment used by about 100,000 Americans a year.

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: SALLY DIMICELIS CAREER began 49 years ago at the Helen Keller Services for the Blind on Willoughby Street in Downtown Brooklyn, when, at age 18, she got a job as a cashier. She worked in that capacity until 1994, when she was promoted into the fund-raising and development position she has now.

title: Q. and A. With Louisvilles Bilal Powell
description: Louisville running back Bilal Powell emerged on the college football scene as a senior, gaining 1,405 yards and averaging 6.1 yards per carry in his first year as a full-time starter. As physical as he is on the field, hes equally soft-spoken away from the game. The Footballguys.com staff writer and Rookie Scouting Portfolio author Matt Waldman thought Powell was one of the more impressive runners during Senior Bowl practices in Mobile, Ala. This is his interview with Powell for Draftguys.com.

title: Finishing 13th, White Misses Slopestyle Final
description: ASPEN, Colo.  Shaun White last competed in a slopestyle event two years ago, and it showed Friday.

title: Emanuel, Back in the Race, Is Also Back on the Trail
description: CHICAGO  The candidates for mayor of Chicago were back on the campaign trail on Friday, arguing about tax policy, a day after the Illinois Supreme Court ruled that Rahm Emanuel, the former White House chief of staff, could be included on the ballot.

title: Beyond the Business Suit
description: Earlier this week, I wrote about Year Up, an organization that is unusually successful at preparing young adults from disadvantaged backgrounds for jobs in big companies like banks, investment houses, health care providers and technology firms. What became clear to me while researching the story was that workforce development no longer means giving people job skills; it means giving them the ability to navigate a career in a professional environment. This isnt knowledge youre born with. You pick it up from family and friends and, if youre lucky, from mentors. Oddly, for something so important, it receives little emphasis in schools and colleges; many job training programs gloss over it.

title: Contador Questions Process and Says Hell Appeal Ban
description: Alberto Contador, the Tour de France champion from Spain, said Friday that he would challenge any punishment  including being stripped of his Tour title  for failing a drug test last summer. He continued to say that he was not at fault for ingesting the banned substance and said he intended to appeal the one-year suspension.

title: Earlier Hormone Therapy Elevates Risk of Breast Cancer, Researchers Say
description: Growing evidence about the risks of breast cancer and other serious illnesses posed by hormone therapy for menopause has led many women to give up the drugs, and many doctors to stop recommending them.

title: No Permit? No Touching the Pistols
description: You dont find a lot of retail businesses that officially turn away buyers. But when I visited the John Jovino Gun Shop, the citys oldest, the mildest inquiry elicited a swift and gruff response. Show me your police identification, I was told, or goodbye. The store does not sell to civilians.

title: Pfizer Told to Pay $142.1 Million Over Marketing of Epilepsy Drug
description: Pfizer, the drug maker, has been ordered to pay a total of $142.1 million in damages for violating federal racketeering laws in the marketing of its epilepsy drug Neurontin.

title: Dead Man on Ballot: An Election Mystery
description: DEAD people have a history, much of it apocryphal, of mucking up elections. There is the story of an Ohio man dead for two decades who voted in the 2004 election, and the tale of a woman from Guam who donated thousands, from the grave, to the Tea Party.

title: Agencies in Cost-Cutting California Told Not to Buy New Cars
description: SACRAMENTO  In another salvo in his battle to tame Californias money problems, Gov. Jerry Brown announced Friday that he would stop any new cars from being purchased by government agencies and order the return of many already used by state employees.

title: A Leisurely Day to Learn Her Lines
description: Since receiving her big break (and bagging the first of her two Tony Awards) in The Real Thing, in 1984, Christine Baranski has carved a career across theater, film and television. Ms. Baranski is currently taking a dramatic turn as a partner in the Chicago law firm at the center of The Good Wife on CBS. She lives with her husband, the actor and writer Matthew Cowles, in Washington, Conn., where they raised their daughters, Lily and Isabel. While working in New York, Ms. Baranski, 58, stays in their Upper East Side apartment. DAVID ROONEY ON THE TOWN Happily, now after years of commuting to L.A. and trying to do the whole bicoastal thing, The Good Wife shoots in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. Our kids are grown up and in graduate school, so I have this life where I can enjoy the city and not worry about racing home to Connecticut.

title: Willi Dansgaard Dies at 88; Read Climates in Old Ice
description: It is said that every breath we take contains molecules breathed by Socrates, Jesus and Abraham Lincoln  a notable exception being the ancient air that the Danish geophysicist Willi Dansgaard and his colleagues found trapped deep in the ice of Greenland.

title: As Republicans Resist Closing Prisons, Cuomo Is Said to Scale Back Plan
description: ALBANY  Nearly a month ago, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo made a call to close some prisons an emotional capstone of his first annual address to the Legislature, vowing, to sustained applause from fellow Democrats, that underused prisons would no longer be an employment program for upstate New York.

title: Excerpts From the Ethnic Press
description: DURING the past month, a newspaper aimed at the citys South Asian population reported on the diversification of the New York police force, a Chinese-language paper explored the heated rivalry among passenger van companies, a Pakistani paper publicized the mysterious death of a woman, and a Korean paper wrote about the reverse migration to South Korea. KIRK SEMPLE

title: France: Gay Marriage Ban Upheld
description: The constitutional council upheld longstanding legislation on Friday that effectively bans marriage for same-sex couples. The council ruled that civil code references to marriage as a union between a man and woman were not contrary to the Constitution, and said the legislature could change the law if it saw fit. The principle of equality prohibits neither that the legislature regulate differing situations in differing manners, nor that it depart from equality for reasons of general interest, the decision said. Gay couples in France are allowed civil unions, which advocates say do not afford the same rights as marriage.

title: The Wrath of Grapes
description: And now, back to our story.

title: Jets General Manager Looks Back and Begins Process of Moving Forward
description: As his teammates cleaned out their lockers Monday, Mark Sanchez said his injured right shoulder felt so much better that he thought he could avoid surgery. General Manager Mike Tannenbaum said Friday he was not so sure about that.

title: Republican Congressman Proposes Tracking Freedom of Information Act Requests
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Darrell Issa calls it a way to promote transparency: a request for the names of hundreds of thousands of ordinary citizens, business executives, journalists and others who have requested copies of federal government documents in recent years.

title: Social Security and Welfare Benefits Going Paperless
description: A rooster is crowing, and an alarm clock chimes. Wake up, wake up, wake up, its the first of the month, the rap song by Bone Thugs-n-Harmony goes. To get up, get up, get up, so cash your checks and get up.

title: Attack on BMW Seller Shows Hazards of E-Commerce, Police Say
description: Since its beginnings, the Internet has been praised as an easy way to bring buyers and sellers together, for inexpensive household trinkets, high-end diamonds or even $46,000 sports cars. But with this convenience have come dangers  as demonstrated when Akeem Ajimotokan was found Wednesday, stabbed and stuffed in the trunk of his BMW M3 coupe.

title: For Land Barons, Acres by the Millions
description: John C. Malone, a media mogul who is on the verge of buying nearly one million acres of timberland in Maine, could soon become the largest private landowner in the United States, catapulting him ahead of Ted Turner on the list of those who accumulate earth the way others accumulate, say, bison.

title: Egyptian Hopes Converged in Fight for Cairo Bridge
description: CAIRO  The battle had gone on for hours on Friday, and the end of the bridge was in sight. Somewhere past the green armored cars and through the smoke was Liberation Square. For miles the protesters had marched peacefully, shouting at balconies for their neighbors to join them.

title: New York Bar Seeks Limits on Investigations of Judges
description: The New York State Bar Association recommended on Friday that the state adopt sweeping changes in the judicial-discipline system that could make it more difficult for judges to be removed from the bench. The 77,000-member bar association has no legal authority, but its action is expected to begin a contentious battle over the issue in Albany.

title: Court Rejects Judges Assertion of a Child Pornography Gene
description: A federal appeals court in Manhattan overturned a six-and-a-half-year sentence in a child pornography case on Friday, saying the judge who imposed it improperly found that the defendant would return to viewing child pornography because of an as-of-yet undiscovered gene.

title: The Citys Future That Never Was
description: Planners and visionaries of the 20th century offered lofty plans, many of which never came to fruition, for their projections of what New York City should be.

title: Chevron Reports Disappointing Sales
description: The Chevron Corporation reported fourth-quarter sales and refining profits that failed to meet analysts estimates on Friday. Chevron said profit rose to $5.3 billion, or $2.64 a share, compared with $3.07 billion, or $1.53 a share, a year earlier. Sales rose to $54.03 billion, from $48.68 billion, but fell short of the $58.8 billion analysts had expected. The companys refineries in the United States performed worse than expected, contributing less to the bottom line than anticipated, said Paul Cheng, an analyst in New York at Barclays. Profit in Chevrons worldwide oil- and gas-production business rose 16 percent, to $4.85 billion, compared with a year earlier, the company said. Earnings from the units operations in the United States fell 13 percent, to $930 million.

title: Finding Success, Passionate Followers in Tow
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.

title: Shoot Him on the Spot
description: Montgomery, Ala., Jan. 29, 1861

title: The Ferrari 150 Unveiled
description: Maybe it is a statement. Ferrari today unveiled its new car, the first of the new crop to be made public. Designated the Ferrari F150, to commemorate the 150 years of the unification of Italy, it also shows off the tricolor of the Italian flag.

title: The Ferrari 150 Unveiled
description: Maybe it is a statement. Ferrari today unveiled its new car, the first of the new crop to be made public. Designated the Ferrari F150, to commemorate the 150 years of the unification of Italy, it also shows off the tricolor of the Italian flag.

title: The Name Rings a Bell
description: MANY people would dream of being fawned over by Rene Zellweger. Not, apparently, Raphael De Niro.

title: At X Games, Battle for Sponsors Is Also Fierce
description: ASPEN, Colo.  In snowboarding, they call this the Olympic hangover year. And for Torah Bright, a gold medalist in snowboard halfpipe at the Vancouver Games and a Mormon who does not drink, it has been a time to nurse ailments.

title: Rwanda: Grenade Attack in Capital
description: Three people were killed in a grenade attack in the capital, Kigali, on Friday night, witnesses said. Witnesses said a man riding a motorcycle tossed the grenade into a crowd and sped off. More than 25 people were wounded. Three suspects have been arrested. Violent crime is rare in Rwanda, though politics are getting turbulent. The government has blamed previous grenade attacks on rebel groups.

title: Indelible Name Added to a Roster of Regrets
description: The Mets are seeking a partner, in the name of liquidity. They say it is normal to search for somebody nice who can pump money into a franchise, to spread the fun around.

title: Albania: Tens of Thousands Protest
description: Tens of thousands of antigovernment protesters marched down Tiranas main street on Friday, despite appeals from Western officials to reduce the political tension. The demonstration commemorated the deaths of three protesters killed by National Guard officers last week. Protests begun over the disputed 2009 elections flared into violence last week after the deputy prime minister was implicated in a corruption scandal.

title: How Bad Is the Snow? Depends Where You Live
description: Leo Martinez spent a backache-inducing 40 minutes on Thursday clearing 19 inches of snow from the roof and windows of his S.U.V., in the winter wonderland that was East Tremont in the Bronx. It was hard work, but it was costing him, too: He had to pay the two men helping him dig out his car $10 each.

title: China and Vietnam to Talk on Sea Dispute
description: Nguyen Van Tho, the Vietnamese ambassador to China, told Chinese reporters on Thursday that China and Vietnam would hold a new round of talks on their territorial dispute in the South China Sea this year, Chinese news organizations reported Friday. He declined to name a specific date, but said, I am optimistic about this issue, the reports said. Both countries and other Asian nations claim parts of the South China Sea, which has potentially large oil and natural gas deposits. The territorial dispute is one of the thorniest diplomatic issues between China and Vietnam. They also take different approaches to trying to resolve the dispute: Vietnam prefers multilateral negotiations, with all the countries at the table, while China prefers bilateral talks. Last July, the United States surprised China when it said it had national interests in the area and wanted China to abide by a declaration of conduct that China had reached in 2002 with other Asian nations.

title: Egypts Military Is Seen as Pivotal in Next Step
description: Even as armored military vehicles deployed around important Egyptian government institutions on Friday for the first time in decades, it remained difficult to predict what role the armed forces might play in either quelling the disturbances or easing President Hosni Mubarak from power.

title: Gays Seeking Asylum in U.S. Encounter a New Hurdle
description: Romulo Castro considered attending his asylum interview in Rosedale, Queens, dressed as Fidela Castro, a towering drag queen in six-inch stilettos, a bright green poodle skirt and a mane of strawberry blond hair. In the end, Mr. Castro, 34, opted for what he described as understatement: pink eye shadow, a bright pink V-neck shirt and intermittent outbursts of tears.

title: N.F.L. Linemen Tip the Scales
description: When B. J. Raji nimbly intercepted a pass and shimmied in the end zone last Sunday, helping to put Green Bay into the Super Bowl, the feat was remarkable given that Raji is a nose tackle and, at 337 pounds, is thought to be the largest player to score a postseason touchdown in N.F.L. history.

title: Once Popular, Car Pools Go the Way of Hitchhiking
description: WOODBRIDGE, Va.  Remember the 1970s? Watergate, disco, oil embargoes and, of course, car-pooling. Many big companies organized group rides for their employees, and roughly one in four Americans who drove to work shared a ride with others.

title: Burned Out of Their Home in the Bronx, but Grateful to Be Together
description: Last Aug. 29 was supposed to be a night of celebration. But when Chaka and Carina Gathers returned from the hospital with their newborn son Cason, their third child, they found their Bronx apartment building in flames.

title: For Governors, Medicaid Looks Ripe for Slashing
description: Hamstrung by federal prohibitions against lowering Medicaid eligibility, governors from both parties are exercising their remaining options in proposing bone-deep cuts to the program during the fourth consecutive year of brutal economic conditions.

title: Bet on Gold Nets Paulson $5 Billion
description: John A. Paulson made $4 billion betting against newfangled mortgage investments. But he made even more betting on an old-fashioned investment: gold.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Lottery Numbers
For Media Veteran, a Tricky Transition to the White House He Once Covered
description: WASHINGTON  A veteran Washington reporter once made an observation about the tricky job of the White House press secretary  an observation that Jay Carney might want to heed when he steps into the role next month.

title: Mets May Want a Sale, but Whats in It for a Buyer?
description: Fred Wilpon, who said Friday that he was looking to sell a minority stake in the Mets, has been talking to friends and business associates about it for several weeks. He has been unable to find any takers, which prompted him to cast the net wider, according to several sports bankers.

title: This Land Is Their Land
description: John C. Malone

title: Alpha to Buy Massey in $7.1 Billion Deal
description: 3:57 p.m. | Updated

title: Kindnesses Are Revealed From Day Lincoln Died
description: An amateur historian accused of forging the date on Abraham Lincolns pardon of a Union Army deserter has been permanently barred from the National Archives. His scheduled award next month from the New York Civil War Round Table has been rescinded. And the disclosure of the forgery has touched off a kerfuffle among Lincoln aficionados over whether the president was pardon-happy or a ruthless wartime commander.

title: Boosting America, in Her Own Fashion
description: THERES the State of the Union address, and then theres the State of the Union dress. Does anyone care if the president wore a suit by the presidential tailor Georges de Paris on Tuesday night? Of course not. His speech, and issues like job creation, tax cuts, climate change and gun control, are more pressing than his fashion choices.

title: Michelle Obama, American Style
description: Op-Ed contributor Kate Betts describes the impact of Michelle Obamas fashion choices.

title: Saturday: They Can Make People Break Up
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  What dont you know? And why is it that we can read a puzzle clue that makes perfect sense to us and still not know the answer?

title: President Is Likely to Discuss Gun Control Soon
description: WASHINGTON  Administration officials say that President Obama, largely silent about gun control since the Tucson shooting carnage, will address the issue soon, potentially reopening a long-dormant debate on one of the nations most politically volatile issues.

title: Washington and Mr. Mubarak
description: Both President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, in power for three decades, and Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen, in power for 23 years, should have seen this coming. They didnt  or didnt care. Both countries share similar pressures: huge numbers of young people without jobs, growing outrage over abusive security forces, corrupt leaders, repressive political systems.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to the Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events on Long Island
description: Film

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Media Decoder: Angry Birds Go Hollywood
description: Angry Birds, the cellphone game that has turned into a cultural phenomenon with 75 million downloads and counting, is lending its wings to a 20th Century Fox movie.

title: Suits on Same-Sex Marriage May Force Administration to Take a Stand
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has balanced on a political tightrope for two years over the Defense of Marriage Act, the contentious 1996 law barring federal recognition of same-sex marriages. Now, two new federal lawsuits threaten to snap that rope out from under him.

title: Mile Run Delivers Upset Amid Twists at Millrose
description: The tone of the 104th Millrose Games was established early Friday night at Madison Square Garden, when the Velveteen Playboys, a shimmying, sharply dressed rock band, took the stage  or, in this case, the track  to jam their way through a multi-song set.

title: Ethnic Studies in Arizona
description: To the Editor:

title: The Big Tank That Couldnt
description: The Republicans fervor for saving the taxpayers dollars doesnt extend to one of the Pentagons costlier failures  the Marine Corps new Expeditionary Fighting Vehicle, a hybrid landing craft and battle truck.

title: Ending Malnutrition
description: To the Editor:

title: The Foreclosure Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Hard-Knock (Hardly Acknowledged) Life
description: President Obama made history on Tuesday.

title: An Argument for Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Give and Take in Omahas Democracy
description: It is a relief to know that there are still some politicians out there willing to take the risk of doing the right thing. The mayor of Omaha, Jim Suttle, is one. He barely survived a recall vote last week after he dared to fully confront the deficit mess he inherited when he took over City Hall 14 months ago.

title: What Oil Spill?
description: William Reilly and Bob Graham, co-chairmen of the presidential panel on the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill, went to Capitol Hill last week to sell their final report. The detailed document endorses deep-water drilling while urging a series of reforms to make it safer. But Republicans on the House Natural Resources Committee reacted as if they had called for an end to the oil industry.

title: Dont Know Much About History
description: Is Michele Bachmann the new Sarah Palin?

title: Behaving Like Children
description: Oklahoma City

title: The Hidden Half of an East Texas Town
description: On entering Jasper, Texas: The Community Photographs of Alonzo Jordan at the International Center of Photography in Manhattan, one first sees an array of high school graduation portraits, individually framed, three rows deep, three columns wide. Nothing could be more ordinary.

title: Gay and Seeking Asylum
description: When Romulo Castro sought asylum in the United States based on his sexual orientation, he had to fit the profile for immigration officials.

title: Fight Adds to Knicks Frustration
description: ATLANTA  Shawne Williamss comeback is a Hollywood story, a resurrection as much as any in the Knicks return to relevancy. He was out of the league last season, his career derailed by a number of off-the-court issues, and he made the Knicks as the last player on the roster.

title: Bloggingheads: Crazy Talk
description: Robert Wright, left, of Bloggingheads.tv and Glenn Loury of Brown University discuss Glenn Beck and political extremism.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 28
description: The European Figure Skating Championships, a German speedskater crashes and more photos from the Millrose Games.

title: David Frye, Perfectly Clear Nixon Parodist, Dies at 77
description: David Frye, whose wicked send-ups of political figures like Lyndon B. Johnson, Hubert H. Humphrey and, above all, Richard M. Nixon, made him one of the most popular comedians in the United States in the late 1960s and early 1970s, died on Monday in Las Vegas, where he lived. He was 77.

title: Egyptians Defiant as Military Does Little to Quash Protests
description: CAIRO  President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt struggled to maintain a tenuous hold on power on Saturday as the police withdrew from the major cities and the military did nothing to hold back tens of thousands of demonstrators defying a curfew to call for an end to his nearly 30 years of authoritarian rule.

title: The Early Word: A Blunt Warning
description: From Todays Times:

title: Clijsters, While Not at Her Best, Is Still Too Much for Li
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Kim Clijsters won her first Australian Open singles title Saturday, which was not quite the first that Li Na and Chinese tennis fans had in mind.

title: Classic Ad: Hyundai Excel
description: You can say one thing for Hyundai in the 1980s: it didnt lack for nerve.

title: Q. and A. With Nevada QB Colin Kaepernick
description: Nevada quarterback Colin Kaepernick impressed evaluators at Senior Bowl practices with his live arm, athleticism and decision-making. Kapernick spoke with several reporters during media night, including the Footballguys.com staff writer and Rookie Scouting Portfolio author Matt Waldman, who was there covering the practices for Draftguys.com.

title: Words of Remorse at Davos, Sort Of
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Im a banker and I feel remorse.

title: Protests Continue in Egypt
description: Crowds of protesters calling for the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak was gathering in the streets and squares of downtown Cairo Saturday afternoon, making clear they reject promises of reform and a new government offered by the embattled leader trying to hang on to power.

title: Never Again?
description: The final judgment of the official inquiry into the 2008 financial crisis  that it was an avoidable disaster, brought about by regulatory neglect and Wall Street recklessness  was an admonition to the government never to let it happen again.

title: Coast to Coast: A Conversation With Michael Tilson Thomas
description: MIAMI BEACH  From his office at the New World Center  the new Frank Gehry-designed home of the New World Symphony, the orchestral academy here that grooms select young musicians for professional careers  the conductor Michael Tilson Thomas has a great view of the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Updates on Saturdays Protests in Egypt
description: The Lede followed the continuing protests in Egypt on Saturday, as demonstrators demanding an end to the autocratic rule of President Hosni Mubarak return to the streets following the dramatic events of Friday. For a summary of the latest events, see the main news article on this site with reports from my colleagues inside Egypt. Readers who are in Egypt and want to share information with us can write in the comment thread below or send photographs or video to pix@nyt.com.

title: Protests Continue in Egypt
description: Protesters calling for President Hosni Mubarak to relinquish power gathered in Cairo on Saturday, making clear they reject promises of reform and a new government.

title: With Egypt, Diplomatic Words Often Fail
description: WASHINGTON  Two different White Houses, two different speeches.

title: Spotlight Again Falls on Web Tools and Change
description: WASHINGTON  Fear is the dictators traditional tool for keeping the people in check. But by cutting off Egypts Internet and wireless service late last week in the face of huge street protests, President Hosni Mubarak betrayed his own fear  that Facebook, Twitter, laptops and smartphones could empower his opponents, expose his weakness to the world and topple his regime.

title: Commodities: This Time is Different
description: Ive been getting a fair bit of correspondence insisting that political unrest, in the Arab world and elsewhere, is being caused by  Ben Bernanke. You see, quantitative easing is responsible for rising food prices, which leads to riots, which  OK, there are a lot of broken links in that chain. But it surely is time to take a look at food prices and commodity prices more broadly.

title: MHLAMF in Davos
description: From the FT:

title: Microcredit Pioneer Faces an Inquiry in Bangladesh
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  Any other year Muhammad Yunus, the Nobel Peace Prize laureate and a pioneer of microcredit, would be in Davos, Switzerland, this week. For years he has been celebrated at global gatherings like the World Economic Forum there for helping move millions of impoverished women toward a better life through tiny but transformational loans.

title: In Haiti, Return of Duvalier Reopens Old Wounds
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  The remains of the cells at Fort Dimanche, where political prisoners were once crowded in their own excrement, are now being used as a school, though without electricity or running water, much less books.

title: China Might Force Visits to Mom and Dad
description: BEIJING  On the eve of the Lunar New Year festival, when Chinese flood train stations, bus terminals and airports to reunite with loved ones, one Chinese ministry is proposing that the government mandate closer families.

title: Who Is Marrying Whom
description: Patterns in interracial and interethnic marriages in the United States.

title: Mexicos Universal Health Care Is Work in Progress
description: YAUTEPEC, Mexico  When her twin girls were born seven weeks early, Azucena Mora Daz did not have to worry about how she would pay for expensive hospital care, even though her husband has only a low-wage job as a construction workers assistant.

title: Business News in Pictures
description: Photos reflecting news and features from last week in the business world.

title: An Eco-Friendly Vacation Site Debuts
description: Travelers seeking a sustainable getaway have a new resource in the Web site Green.travel.

title: U.S. Seeks Release of Official in Pakistan
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  The United States on Saturday demanded the release of an American official charged in the shooting deaths of two Pakistanis in this city two days ago, and now being held in police custody.

title: Yearning for Respect, Arabs Find a Voice
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  In Yemen, the chants invoked Tunisia, a continent away. A Lebanese newspaper declared that all of the Middle East was watching Egypt. A long-dead North African poets most famous poem has become the anthem of a moment the most enthusiastic call revolutionary.

title: 30 Seconds With Drew Brees
description: New Orleans quarterback Drew Brees, the most valuable player in last years Super Bowl, is in Honolulu to participate in Sundays Pro Bowl. Last week, he teamed with Procter & Gamble on Oahu to help build a playground at the Leeward Y.M.C.A., one of five community service projects of the 2011 N.F.L. Play 60 Community Blitz, which promotes youth health and wellness.

title: Afghan Family Dies in Attack on Market
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Twenty-four hours after a Taliban suicide bomber attacked the Finest Supermarket here, the familys silver Toyota Corolla was still parked in front.

title: Variety: Acrostic With Oddly Paired Words
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE

title: Judge in Britain Halts Deportation of Ugandan
description: LONDON  A 29-year-old Ugandan woman who says she is a lesbian won a last-minute stay of deportation on Friday night from a British High Court judge who heard her lawyers plead that her life would be at risk if she was forced to return to her homeland.

title: Cairo: The Morning After
description: Egyptians awoke Saturday morning to the aftermath of Friday's violent protests. President Hosni Mubarak's regime is still there, but its authority has been openly flouted.

title: A Longtime Volunteer Helps Others Cut Red Tape
description: Seven years ago, when Maria Castro was told she had breast cancer, she was terrified by more than the thought of death; she was afraid her illness would put her in financial jeopardy. A native of the Dominican Republic, she did not speak English, and the pain from her tumor and subsequent mastectomy prevented her from continuing her duties as a packer at a factory and from completing her cosmetology training. She had zero dollars, she said.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Drug Bust Shows Argentina-Europe Trafficking Ties
description: BUENOS AIRES  A major cocaine bust in Spain is highlighting the growing drug-trafficking ties between Argentina and Europe and causing headaches for the government of Argentinas president, Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner.

title: In Moscow, a Bomber Is Identified
description: MOSCOW  Russian authorities on Saturday announced that they had identified a 20-year-old native of the North Caucasus region as the suicide bomber who killed 35 people at Domodedovo Airports international arrivals hall  a location chosen specifically because it gave the opportunity to kill foreigners.

title: For N.F.L., Lockout Would Be a Risky Strategy
description: The N.F.L. has never been more popular. Both conference championship games last Sunday drew more than 50 million viewers, or twice the number who tuned into the season debut of American Idol. The N.F.L. has never generated more revenue  commanding $4 billion from its broadcast partners and raking in nearly $9 billion in 2010 for what is inarguably the nations favorite sport.

title: Afghans Plan to Stop Recruiting Children as Police
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistan is expected to sign a formal agreement with the United Nations on Sunday to stop the recruitment of children into its police forces and ban the common practice of boys being used as sex slaves by military commanders, according to Afghan and United Nations officials.

title: Bryans Win Doubles Again
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  The American singles players all lost in the first week of this Australian Open.

title: Calling for Restraint, Pentagon Faces Test of Influence With Ally
description: WASHINGTON  The officer corps of Egypts powerful military has been educated at defense colleges in the United States for 30 years. The Egyptian armed forces have about 1,000 American M1A1 Abrams tanks, which the United States allows to be built on Egyptian soil. Egypt permits the American military to stage major operations from its bases, and has always guaranteed the Americans passage through the Suez Canal.

title: Point/Counterpoint: Super Bowl XLV
description: Tom Jolly explains why the Pittsburgh Steelers will win the Super Bowl

title: Point/Counterpoint: Super Bowl XLV
description: Carl Nelson explains why the Packers will win the Super Bowl.

title: Milton M. Levine, Inventor of Ant Farm, Dies at 97
description: Milton Levines Eureka moment came in 1956, when he spotted a mound of ants during a Fourth of July picnic at his sisters poolside in Southern California.

title: A Bank Crisis Whodunit, With Laughs and Tears
description: TRULY startling revelations were few in the voluminous report, published last Thursday by the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission on the origins of the financial panic. This is hardly a shock, given the flood-the-zone coverage and analysis of the crisis since it erupted four years ago.

title: Hey, Rock Stars: Take Your Show Someplace Else
description: This interview with Michael Lebowitz, founder and C.E.O. of Big Spaceship, a digital marketing and communications agency, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Messages From the Wilderness, via Satellite
description: AH, wilderness. The great outdoors, the fresh air  and the spotty cellphone coverage. But hikers, adventurers and others in remote places who want to send messages now have a new alternative when the signal vanishes: they can send texts using a satellite network instead.

title: Barely Lifting a Finger to Get Super Bowl Rings
description: Not every player with multiple Super Bowl rings is a superstar like Ben Roethlisberger or Tom Brady. If the Pittsburgh Steelers win Super Bowl XLV, quarterback Charlie Batch will receive his third Super Bowl ring. Batch did his part this season, helping win two games during Roethlisbergers suspension, but three Super Bowl rings would be hefty compensation for 184 passes scattered across nine years.

title: Egyptians Wonder Whats Next
description: CAIRO  Liberation Square was liberated Saturday.

title: Innovation Is Doing Little for Incomes
description: MY grandmother, who was born in 1905, spoke often about the immense changes she had seen, including the widespread adoption of electricity, the automobile, flush toilets, antibiotics and convenient household appliances. Since my birth in 1962, it seems to me, there have not been comparable improvements.

title: Stocks and Bonds, Parting Ways
description: SINCE the financial crisis, bad news for the bond market has generally meant trouble for stocks.

title: Letters: Beyond Mandates in Health Care Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters: Of War and Peace in N.F.L. Contracts
description: To the Editor:

title: Im Lucky to Have a Twin
description: THERE are two sets of twins in my family. My own twin, Shane, is the creative director of our company. And we have a set of younger twin brothers, Eric and Derrick.

title: A Sign of Hope for More Hiring
description: WILL businesses ever start hiring again? The numbers from last month  with unemployment at a painful 9.4 percent  didnt seem to offer much hope.

title: Political Blogs Are Ready to Flood Campaign Trail
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Tim Pawlenty, the former Minnesota governor who is flirting with a bid for president, has none of the usual campaign accoutrements. No tour bus, campaign manager or yard signs. Few Americans, in fact, even know his name.

title: Giffordss Husband Faces Decision on Shuttle Flight
description: As Representative Gabrielle Giffords settles into a rehabilitation hospital in Houston, a major question remains for her husband, the astronaut Mark E. Kelly: Will he fly or not?

title: Of Wealth and (Un)Happiness
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  The chief executives and top politicians at the World Economic Forum were generally upbeat about economic growth this year. But are they happy?

title: A $60 Million Palace for Texas High School Football
description: ALLEN, Tex.  From his office window, Steve Williams surveyed the chaos of construction. His view consisted of rocks and dirt beneath bulldozers and cranes, but where others might see excess, he saw something brazen, bold and gloriously Texan.

title: Timeline: Trying to Whip Us Into Shape
description: Jack LaLanne opened his first health club in 1936, but mass fitness really took off after he began appearing on television.

title: The Ripped and the Righteous
description: It is Jack LaLanne you can thank, or curse, for all the gyms: in exurban strip malls, suburban manses, downtown hotels. The health club he opened in Oakland, Calif., in 1936 was one of their seeds and templates, an endorphin emporium that pointed the way.

title: Whats Broken in Greece? Ask an Entrepreneur
description: KOMOTINI, Greece

title: Google Finds It Hard to Reinvent Philanthropy
description: JUST before Google first sold its shares to the public in 2004, Larry Page, one of its founders, excited the nonprofit world with a bold commitment to philanthropy.

title: Booster Has Second Thoughts; UConn Probably Doesnt
description: In the past week, Robert G. Burton has been portrayed as the flawed face of highly commercialized intercollegiate athletics.

title: The Power of the Platform at Apple
description: SIZE is the enemy of growth. It is one of the unwritten laws of business, a matter of simple percentages. After all, when a company has $1 billion in yearly sales, an extra $1 billion doubles its size. Add $1 billion in new business to a $10 billion-a-year company, and it amounts to just 10 percent growth. The size-growth tradeoff seems inevitable, an inescapable force like gravity.

title: Tortured Under 'Baby Doc'
description: The return to Haiti of the former dictator Jean Claude "Baby Doc" Duvalier has encouraged former political prisoners to file charges for illegal imprisonment and torture.

title: Remembering David Kato, a Gay Ugandan and a Marked Man
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  It was late at night and totally dark when I first met David Kato. He had been described to me as the most out gay Ugandan and the countrys leading gay rights crusader, reviled by many, revered by a small few  but definitely well known. So I was a bit surprised when he suggested that we conduct our interview in an empty lot behind a disco, down a dark gravel road.

title: White Is Adapting to Less Than Perfect
description: ASPEN, Colo.  In the wider world of sports, Shaun White is the second most powerful athlete, ahead of Tiger Woods, Tom Brady and LeBron James, according to Bloomberg BusinessWeek. Only Peyton Manning ranked higher than White, a two-time Olympic gold medalist, in the magazines annual Power 100 survey published last week.

title: And Now, the Cheerleader in Chief
description: WASHINGTON   Hours before President Obama delivered his State of the Union address, a senior adviser to the president confided that his tone would be self-consciously optimistic. And so it was.

title: Andrews Faces Questions About a Deal With Reebok
description: When ESPNs Erin Andrews reported that Texas Christian players were slipping in their new Nike cleats during the Rose Bowl on New Years Day, the detail seemed typical of the colorful tidbits that sideline reporters often provide to viewers.

title: For Medvedev, From Davos to Reality
description: MOSCOW  Last week was to have heralded a defining moment for Russias forward-looking, Obama-admiring, iPad-toting president, Dmitri A. Medvedev. He would escape the shadow of his bare-knuckled mentor, Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, by giving the keynote speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. What better way for Mr. Medvedev to show that his country had an alluring future, while also burnishing his own credentials as a reformer?

title: Laugh Lines
description: JAY LENO

title: Back Then: 1986
description: Twenty-five years ago on Friday, on an unusually cold morning, the space shuttle Challenger exploded shortly after liftoff, killing all seven astronauts. Richard Feynman, the Nobel Prize-winning physicist and a member of the presidential commission investigating the disaster, quickly zeroed in the cause: a failure of the O-rings, seals designed to prevent hot gases from leaking through the joint on the rocket booster. Heres how he did it, as The Timess Philip M. Boffey reported two weeks after the accident.

title: Prime Number
description: 11,500: The average annual number of people treated in hospital emergency rooms from 1990 to 2006 for injuries suffered while shoveling snow, a study in this months issue of The American Journal of Emergency Medicine reports. Men were most frequently hurt. Injuries to the lower back accounted for slightly more than one-third of emergency room visits. Twenty percent of the injuries were the result of slips and falls; 15 percent, from being struck by a shovel. Nearly 7 percent of the visits were  cardiac-related,: including all 1,647 deaths.

title: Fighting Words
description: Scientists and government officials involved in studying gun use say the influence of the National Rifle Association has all but choked off money for such work.

title: Remaking a B-Movie in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES  When it comes to the N.B.A., this is a Lakers town, practically painted in purple and gold.

title: Returning From Gunshot and Motivating Seton Hall
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J.  In his first three seasons at Seton Hall, Jeremy Hazell established a reputation for his shooting range but not necessarily his resilience, even though he never missed a game or visited a hospital.

title: Big Sexy Paying Big Dividends for the Bulls
description: Kurt Thomas played in only five of the Chicago Bulls first 24 games and on many nights he was on the bench in a suit rather than on the floor in a uniform. Then on Dec. 15 Joakim Noah was injured and was expected to be out six to eight weeks with a torn ligament in his thumb. Suddenly, Thomas was starting at center.

title: If Only Leno Could Play Left Wing
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  This All-Star weekend will be remembered as the first in which the N.H.L. players chose sides in a live, televised fantasy draft. But it may also be remembered for something else, best expressed in the form of a question: when did hockey players get so funny?

title: Gretzky, Somehow, Is Out of Hockey
description: Wayne Gretzky turned 50 last week. For those who recall his youthful assault on the record book and his Stanley Cups with Edmonton in the 1980s as the skinny player with the strange No. 99 whom teammates called the Kid, that milestone seems unthinkable.

title: Hit-and-Run Driver Injures Cyclist Near Times Square
description: A food deliveryman was seriously injured by a hit-and-run driver who struck his bicycle from behind near Times Square about 10:15 p.m. Friday, the police said.

title: Twitter, as a Helpmate, Goes to Capitol Hill
description: WASHINGTON  Adam Sharp fits in well in the Beltway political scene where he used to work  first in the office of Senator Mary L. Landrieu, and then as the executive producer for digital services at C-Span. But his new job, as Twitters Washington liaison, requires a slightly different skill set.

title: USA Hockeys Proposed Rule Changes for Body-Checking, Head Shots and Fighting
description: Below, the full set of rule changes proposed at USA Hockeys Winter Meeting last weekend in Colorado Springs. The proposals seek to raise the minimum age for body checking in boys hockey from 11-12 to 13-14, make all contact to the head-and-neck area illegal at all age levels and, in those classifications in which fighting does not result in immediate expulsion, provide for extra penalties when one player tears off an his own helmet or an opponents helmet during a fight.

title: Moroccan Wins U.S. Title
description: Winter Sports

title: The Tea Party Wags the Dog
description: ANY lingering doubts about Barack Obamas determination to appropriate Ronald Reagans political spirit evaporated just before the State of the Union. No American brand is more associated with Reagan than General Electric, and it was that corporations chief executive, Jeffrey Immelt, who popped up as the presidents new wingman when the White House rolled out its latest jobs initiative on Jan. 21. Obamas speech on Tuesday, with its celebration of the nations can-do capitalist ingenuity, moved him still closer to Reagans sweet spot as a national cheerleader. The president even offered a remix of the old Reagan-era G.E. jingle We bring good things to life  now traded up to the grander We do big things.

title: Arab Executives Predict Regime Change in Egypt
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  The unrest engulfing Egypt caught business and political leaders at the World Economic Forum off guard, but it became the hottest topic among the Arab elite here. Most of those leaders tuned in to the dramatic events from iPads and BlackBerrys and huddled to debate how the uprising would affect the rest of the Arab world.

title: No Axe to Grind
description: WASHINGTON

title: A Marathon on Ice
description: McMURDO STATION, Antarctica  A hulking orange all-terrain bus emblazoned with the words Ivan the Terra Bus rumbled to the starting line of the 13th annual McMurdo Marathon, and 17 runners and 6 skiers stepped onto the ice shelf. On this Sunday morning, Jan. 16, the temperature was a balmy 28 degrees, with a nearly cloudless sky and a strong sun.

title: Serious in Singapore
description: Singapore

title: Watch Out! The Assault Vehicle Is Loose!
description: Americans are infatuated with guns. And when youre infatuated, you sometimes cant think straight. Maybe thats why, three weeks after the Tucson shootings that shook the nation, were still no closer to banning oversize magazines like the 33-bullet model allegedly used there. Maybe it will help clarify issues if we imagine an alternate universe  one in which Americans exhibit their toughness not with assault weapons but with assault vehicles, a world in which our torrid libertarian passion is not for our guns but for our cars. That alternate universe might look like this:

title: With One Round to Go, Nakamura Holds Lead at Tata Steel
A Chicken Chains Corporate Ethos Is Questioned by Gay Rights Advocates
description: ATLANTA  The Chick-fil-A sandwich  a hand-breaded chicken breast and a couple of pickles squished into a steamy, white buttered bun  is a staple of some Southern diets and a must-have for people who collect regional food experiences the way some people collect baseball cards.

title: Eleanor Galenson, Expert on Childrens Sexual Identity, Dies at 94
description: Dr. Eleanor Galenson, a psychoanalyst whose research demonstrated that children are aware of sexual identity in infancy, even earlier than Freud had propounded, died on Jan. 15 at her home in Manhattan. She was 94.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Jan. 30
description: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton appears on five of the Sunday television talk shows to discuss tensions in Egypt as the Obama administration ponders its next move in the fragile country.

title: Sunday: Doctors Orders
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE

title: New Advanced Placement Biology Is Ready to Roll Out, but U.S. History Isnt
description: While the College Board plans to unveil a sweeping revision to Advanced Placement biology courses on Tuesday, it is delaying similar changes in United States history by a year to address concerns from high school teachers.

title: In California, a Proposed Cut Angers Local Officials
description: LOS ANGELES  Nobody around here doubts that the pie is getting smaller. With the state facing a $25 billion budget gap, cuts have to come from somewhere.

title: The Two Abortion Wars: A Highly Intrusive Federal Bill
description: House Republicans are preparing to push through restrictions on federal financing of abortions far more extreme than previously proposed at the federal level. Lawmakers who otherwise rail against big government have made it one of their highest priorities to take the decision about a legal medical procedure out of the hands of individuals and turn it over to the government.

title: At Trial of Cuban Exile, a Rebuffed Venezuela Sits Quietly on the Sidelines
description: EL PASO  Perhaps the most frustrated person in the courtroom the last two weeks at the perjury trial of Luis Posada Carriles, the Cuban militant and former C.I.A. operative, was the sad-eyed lawyer who represents Venezuela.

title: Mens Finals Preview: Murray vs. Djokovic
description: Andy Murray and Novak Djokovic, friends since junior days, face off in the mens singles final of the Australian Open on Sunday (3 a.m. Eastern). For Djokovic, this is his second straight trip to a Grand Slam final (he lost in four sets to Nadal at Flushing Meadows), while Murray again finds himself in the finals of the Australian. He lost last year in straight sets to Roger Federer. While the two know each other well, they have only met seven times on the tour. Djokovic holds a slight edge 4-3, but Murray has won their last three meetings.

title: Netizens Gain Some Privacy
description: Pressure by regulators is having an effect on consumer privacy on the Internet.

title: We Never Got Down to Blue
description: Well before the end, the governments color-coded alert system was eroding into a macabre laugh line for the modern age of terrorism. Were people standing beltless in their socks actually hearing the airport announcements when the risk estimate mostly shuttled between yellow (Elevated) and orange (High)?

title: Washingtons Financial Disaster
description: San Diego

title: A Year in Iraq and Afghanistan
description: IN 2010, the United States and its allies continued to shift the military focus from Iraq and to Afghanistan. American troop levels in Iraq fell by half, from more than 100,000 troops in January to under 50,000. In Afghanistan, a surge of mainly United States troops brought numbers to roughly 140,000, from near 100,000 at the beginning of the year. As shown in the chart (based on data from the Pentagon, icasualties.org and American allies), in 2010 there were 696 fatalities in Afghanistan and 56 in Iraq.

title: Lincolns Other Mother
description: On the evening of Jan. 30, 1861, a slow freight train chugged into the small hamlet of Charleston, Ill., having completed a 12-mile run from Mattoon. Or nearly 12 miles  the train didnt quite make it all the way to the station. A few people straggled out of the caboose and trudged through slush and ice toward the depot, where a gaggle of townsfolk loitered. To their astonishment, they realized that the tall man coming toward them, wearing a shawl, was Abraham Lincoln.

title: Spokes | Two Wheels, No Fear, in Slush or Powder
description: Pascal Sauvayre hopped his front tire through several inches of freshly fallen powder, stopping in front of a small group of cyclists gathered in the morning darkness at the southeast end of Central Park.

title: Massey Energy Is to Be Sold to Alpha Natural Resources
description: Massey Energy, the embattled coal mine operator, agreed on Saturday to sell itself for about $7.1 billion in cash and stock in a deal that will create a new giant in coal production  and could help Massey shed legal burdens arising from a marred safety record that includes the explosion last year at the Upper Big Branch mine in West Virginia.

title: Choice of Suleiman Likely to Please the Military, Not the Crowds
description: The story goes that Omar Suleiman rose to favor when he saved President Hosni Mubaraks life in 1995 by demanding the president ride in an armored car in Ethiopia. A gunman opened fire on the vehicle, and still Mr. Mubarak escaped unharmed.

title: Milton Babbitt, a Composer Who Gloried in Complexity, Dies at 94
description: Milton Babbitt, an influential composer, theorist and teacher who wrote music that was intensely rational and for many listeners impenetrably abstruse, died on Saturday. He was 94 and lived in Princeton, N.J.

title: Health Law Response Goes 2 Ways
description: One House Republican wants to create the state health insurance exchange required by the federal health care overhaul law for fear that the federal government will do it for Texas otherwise. Another has filed a bill that would make his colleagues efforts  really, those of anyone trying to carry out Obamacare in Texas  illegal.

title: Legislative Emergencies, Real Ones and the Governors
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

title: Speed and Credibility
description: NPR was reporting definitively that Representative Gabrielle Giffords had been shot dead, but The Associated Press was holding off. The lines into the A.P. offices, recalled A.P.s executive editor, Kathleen Carroll, were buzzing with complaints: where was The A.P. on this story? How could it let NPR beat it?

title: Art, Food and Shops Away From the Super-Size Crowds
description: Though Arlington may be the center of the action next weekend, even Super Bowl fans cannot survive on hot dogs and yard markers alone. So if youll be at the big game, or if you just happen to be in the area and want to avoid the crush of Packers and Steelers fans, head east or west on Interstate 30 to get your arts and culture fix in one of two up-and-coming neighborhoods.

title: Revitalizing the Arts Scene in an Effort to Rejuvenate the Town
description: Disclosure: My great-grandfather was in the movie business.

title: Do Emotions Play a Role in Illness?
description: To the Editor:

title: Anti-Choice Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Vacant Lots in Two Cities
description: To the Editor:

title: A Center to Develop Medicines
description: To the Editor:

title: Housing for Veterans
description: To the Editor:

title: Egyptian Protests Extend to Streets of New York
description: There were Egyptian flags fluttering in the chilly air. There were chants calling upon President Hosni Mubarak to resign. There were placards that read Down With Mubarak or Leave and Let Live. There were even a few singalongs of the Egyptian national anthem.

title: Obama Presses for Change but Not a New Face at the Top
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas decision to stop short, at least for now, of calling for Hosni Mubaraks resignation was driven by the administrations concern that it could lose all leverage over the Egyptian president, and because it feared creating a power vacuum inside the country, according to administration officials involved in the debate.

title: The Two Abortion Wars: State Battles Over Roe v. Wade
description: Away from Washington, another ominous anti-abortion battle is accelerating in the states. Anti-abortion forces have been trying to take advantage of the 2007 ruling in which the Supreme Court upheld a federal ban on a particular method of abortion.

title: Corrections
description: EDITORS' NOTE

title: After a Year, Chirp Radio Has Made Gains, but Is Still Awaiting Its Own Frequency
description: The Local Community Radio Act, signed into law this month by President Obama, would seem a fitting first birthday present for Chirp Radio, a Chicago community radio project, except that the law does not help groups hoping to be awarded frequencies in the countrys biggest radio markets.

title: Vows: Jessica & Joe
description: Sometimes there's a silver lining to unemployment.  For Jessica, that was having the time to travel with Joe and fall in love.

title: Tea Party Gets Early Start on G.O.P. Targets for 2012
description: Leaders of more than 70 Tea Party groups in Indiana gathered last weekend to sign a proclamation saying they would all support one candidate  as yet undetermined  in a primary challenge to Senator Richard G. Lugar, the Republican who has represented the state since 1977.

title: Businessman Signals Interest in Mets; Dickey Gets a Deal
description: Mike Repole had three dreams growing up as a young boy in Queens: own an important racehorse, become the basketball coach at St. Johns and be the general manager of his beloved Mets.

title: New Life in Old San Juan
description: Old San Juan is a microcosmic vision of the post-Columbian Americas, and arguably the most vibrant city in the Caribbean today.

title: For Americans Stranded in Egypt, No Quick Exits
description: Sharon Romey, who lives on a ranch in South Dakota, cannot help but worry about her son, Kade Klippenstein, a college freshman, who is stuck in Cairo. But even as images of violent protests flash across the television screen, she said, she felt that he was safe and that he was getting an extraordinary history lesson.

title: Cairo: After Curfew
description: Protesters ignored a nighttime curfew on Saturday and carried on after President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt appointed the intelligence chief, Omar Suleiman, as vice president.

title: Rejecting the Color Lines
description: Multiracial and biracial students use the strength in their growing numbers to affirm roots that were once portrayed as tragic or pitiable.

title: New Chants in Cairo
description: Protesters shouted a new chant after President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt appointed the intelligence chief, Omar Suleiman, as his vice president.

title: Guarded Game Lifts Mickelson as Woods Fades
description: SAN DIEGO  After three rounds of acclimating to unseasonably perfect conditions at Torrey Pines Golf Course, Bill Haas, Phil Mickelson, Bubba Watson, Hunter Mahan and Anthony Kim  the five golfers clustered within two strokes of the lead after Saturdays third round of the Farmers Insurance Open  will start the real tournament Sunday.

title: At 79, Viktor the Terrible Outsmarts an 18-Year-Old
description: The games mental and physical toll eventually forces most top players to stop competing. And those who continue to play tend to avoid the elite tournaments where the pressure is greatest.

title: Schott Op-Chart: It Takes Years
description: In his State of the Union address, President Obama challenged America to look ahead to what the next big industry will be or where the new jobs will come from  noting that 30 years ago, we couldnt know that something called the Internet would lead to an economic revolution.

title: Few Californians Understand the States Tax System. Fact.
description: Jonathan Weber writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

title: A Night Out, Counting the Homeless
description: Thank you, Ali Schlageter, a policy analyst with San Franciscos Homeless Coordinating Board, told hundreds of volunteers who crowded into the Department of Public Healths hearing room Thursday night.

title: Illegal Craft Saves Surfers Life, Renewing the Attack on a Ban
description: Matt Krizan was paddling his kayak through an ocean lagoon Jan. 22 when he saw a wave the size of a condominium crash over surfers at Mavericks, the famous surf spot near Half Moon Bay.

title: Grotesques
description: Gargoyles? No. The eight monsters circling Grace Cathedrals central spire cannot spout water, a requirement for the form. The Episcopal institution on Nob Hill received the decorative bestial figures, termed grotesques, when the spire was installed in 1963.

title: Black? White? Asian? More Young Americans Choose All of the Above
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md.  In another time or place, the game of What Are You? that was played one night last fall at the University of Maryland might have been mean, or menacing: Laura Woods peers were picking apart her every feature in an effort to guess her race.

title: N.H.L. Reports Increase in Total of Concussions
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  Preliminary statistics indicate concussions in the N.H.L. are on the rise this season, Commissioner Gary Bettman said at a news conference here Saturday.

title: Lottery Numbers
A Suspension Strains the Knicks Lineup
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  For the next few days, the complexion of the Knicks lineup could be altered because of Atlanta Hawks forward Marvin Williams.

title: As the Transfer Window Closes
description: The transfer window will close at the start of the week across Europe, meaning teams have less than 48 hours to make major changes for a Cup or title run, to right the ship and avoid relegation, or merely to cash in on someone elses desperation.

title: A Debate Worthy of the Student Council
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Cigarettes for $2.70 a Pack, but You Have to Help
description: The small group that gathered at lunchtime inside a strip-mall storefront in Skokie had not come to eat. They had come to Smokes & Such to admire the new $30,000 machine that spits out a carton of custom-made cigarettes in eight minutes flat  at $27 a carton. Thats $2.70 a pack, or about a third of what smokers would pay at the CVS pharmacy across the street.

title: Crime Dominates Talk in 46th Ward Campaign
description: Though crime is declining in much of Chicago, recent high-profile episodes of violence have made neighborhood safety a hot-button issue in the municipal election campaign, and there are few areas where the debate on crime and police staffing is more impassioned than in the 46th Ward.

title: Alderson Is Perfectly Suited to Steer the Mets
description: When Sandy Alderson was hired by the Mets in October to be their new general manager, some wondered if he was overqualified for the job. He had already been the chief executive of the San Diego Padres, an executive vice president of Major League Baseball, and, most recently, Commissioner Bud Seligs point man in baseballs efforts to attack the issues plaguing the development of teenage prospects in the Dominican Republic.

title: Sundance Embraces Both Romance and Suicide
description: LOS ANGELES The Sundance Film Festival announced its awards on Saturday night, so with no further ado here are the winners: Like Crazy, a romance directed by Drake Doremus (and purchased by Paramount Pictures and Indian Paintbrush), won the grand jury prize for an American dramatic film, and Peter D. Richardsons How to Die in Oregon, a searing look at assisted suicide, won the grand jury prize for an American documentary.

title: Antarctic Marathon Replay
description: A look at the 13th annual McMurdo Marathon, held Jan. 16 at a research base in Antarctica.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 29
description: Skating and stretching, sliding and smiling, from Alabama to Australia.

title: Czisny Glides Effortlessly to Her Second U.S. Title
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  After two years of ups and downs, Alissa Czisny lifted herself back to the top of figure skating in the United States on Saturday, performing elegantly and nearly perfectly to win her second national championship.

title: Mark Zuckerberg Does Some Networking on Saturday Night Live
description: If you guys were the inventors of Facebook, a fictionalized version of Mark Zuckerberg says in The Social Network, youd have invented Facebook. So, will the real Mark Zuckerberg please stand up?

title: Opposition Rallies to ElBaradei as Military Reinforces in Cairo
description: CAIRO  Egypts powerful Muslim Brotherhood and the secular opposition banded together Sunday around a prominent government critic to negotiate for forces seeking the fall of President Hosni Mubarak, as the army struggled to hold a capital seized by fears of chaos and buoyed by euphoria that three decades of Mr. Mubaraks rule may be coming to an end.

title: In London, a Century of British Sculpture
description: England has produced some of the greatest sculptors of the last 100 years, so it is only fitting that one of Londons most prominent galleries, the Royal Academy of Arts (Burlington House, Piccadilly; 44-207-300-8000; www.royalacademy.org.uk), should hold one of the first comprehensive exhibition of their work. Henry Moore, Barbara Hepworth, Jacob Epstein and Anthony Caro are just a few of the major artists whose sculptures will be on display through April 7.

title: Djokovic Wins Second Australian Open Title
description: Back and forth, the two punched and counterpunched like heavyweights. If the Australian Open mens singles final between No. 3 Novak Djokovic and No. 5 Andy Murray resembled a grueling boxing match, each lightning-quick jab met with an exquisite parry, it was also a master chess duel.

title: Jets and Patriots? Cant Wait
description: A reader, Tom Darling of Vermont, put his finger on it: The countdown to the first Patriots-Jets game next season has already begun.

title: Federer and Nadal ... and Djokovic
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Into the stands went the shirt. Into the stands went the shoes. Into the chair plopped Novak Djokovic, looking weary  very weary  yet fulfilled.

title: Updates on Day 6 of Egypt Protests
