description: The Lede is following the continuing street protests in Egypt on Sunday. For a summary of the latest events, see the main news article by my colleagues in Egypt. There is a stream of Twitter updates by bloggers and journalists were following to the right. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from other Web sites and eyewitness accounts, video and photographs posted on social networks. Readers who want to share information with us can write in the comment thread below or send photographs or video from Egypt to pix@nyt.com.

title: Clinton Urges Egyptian Dialogue
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton on Sunday urged Egyptians to take up a national dialogue that would lead to free and fair elections this fall and, while not explicitly distancing the United States from the embattled President Hosni Mubarak, said that the United States stood ready to help with the kind of transition that will lead to greater political and economic freedom.

title: An Upset for Kings Speech at Directors Guild Awards
description: LOS ANGELES Tom Hooper, the director of The Kings Speech, picked up the top prize at the Directors Guild of America awards on Saturday night, a surprise victory that scrambled the prognostications of the Oscar experts. The win came at the expense of another front-runner, David Fincher, the director of The Social Network, and followed a similar upset at the Producers Guild of America awards when the British period drama took the top honor. (David O. Russell (The Fighter), Darren Aronofsky (Black Swan) and Christopher Nolan (Inception) were the other nominees last night.)

title: Key European Leaders Urge Restraint in Cairo
description: BERLIN  With the European Union yet to form a common response to the mass demonstrations in the Arab world, leaders of three of its diplomatic heavyweights appealed for free and fair elections in Egypt over the weekend.

title: Singing the Perfectionist-Folkie Blues
description: In 1961, as a young graduate student at an ethnomusicologists meeting, John Szwed caught the eye of the master: Alan Lomax, the man whose tremendous body of work allowed previously unheard folk recordings to become universally well known. Seemingly apropos of nothing, Lomax remarked Pygmies are a baseline culture. Then he went on his way.

title: This Age of Rubber
description: The latest IMF World Economic Outlook update has, as usual, a lot of useful information. I was especially struck by the chart on commodity prices, which highlights something I only sort of appreciated before: the big runup this year has been neither in food nor in energy, but rather in agricultural raw materials:

title: Tony Geiss, Writer for Sesame Street, Dies at 86
description: Tony Geiss, who entertained generations of children by putting words in the mouths of Big Bird, Kermit the Frog, Elmo and other characters on Sesame Street, helping the show win 22 daytime Emmys for scriptwriting and songwriting, died on Jan. 21 in Valhalla, N.Y. He was 86 and lived in Manhattan.

title: The Kitchen Test
description: Tyler Cowen argues that technological change since the early 1960s hasnt been as transformative for ordinary peoples lives as the change that went before.

title: The Final: The Asian Game Comes of Age
description: DOHA, Qatar  The Asian Cup final Saturday night between Australia and Japan was tied 0-0 after 90 minutes of regulation play and the first 15 minutes of extra time at Khalifa Stadium in Doha. Then Tadanari Lee came on as a substitute for the Blue Samurai, and within three minutes drove an airborne volley from Yuto Nagatomo past Mark Schwarzer into the back of the Socceroos net. The Aussies had a final chance to tie the game in the 119th minute when David Carney had a free kick on goal deflected, securing the 1-0 victory for Japan. Keisuke Honda was named the tournaments most valuable player.

title: Ron Patterson, Renaissance (Fair) Man, Dies at 80
description: Ron Patterson, who nearly half a century ago helped found the countrys first Renaissance fair, which inspired a thriving nationwide industry of jousters and jesters, hawking street vendors and brave men in doublets and tights, died on Jan. 15 in Sausalito, Calif. He was 80.

title: Henry Cavill is Cast as Superman in New Movie
description: In the mythology of comic books, Superman is the survivor of a dying alien planet who is sent to earth to become its protector. For his new Superman movie, the director Zack Snyder did not have to search quite as far to cast his title character, but in the tradition of previous installments of the franchise, he has settled on a relative unknown to take up the mantle of the Man of Steel.

title: Israel Shaken as Turbulence Rocks an Ally
description: JERUSALEM  The street revolt in Egypt has thrown the Israeli government and military into turmoil, with top officials closeted in round-the-clock strategy sessions aimed at rethinking their most significant regional relationship.

title: Clinton Calls for Orderly Transition in Egypt
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton called on Sunday for an orderly transition to a more politically open Egypt, stopping short of telling its embattled president, Hosni Mubarak, to step down but clearly laying the groundwork for his departure.

title: Civic Engagement Trumps Shhh!
description: There may be no better example of the worrying state of American architecture than the career of Steven Holl.

title: Cairo Photographer Sees Hope in Turmoil
description: Scott Nelson, 40, is a freelance photographer who works regularly for The New York Times. Hes from Denver but has been based in Cairo for a decade. For this post, he spoke with James Estrin late Saturday and followed that by elaborating on his experiences and expectations as a photojournalist and as a Cairo resident.

title: Mohamed ElBaradei Speaks
description: Egyptian opposition leader Mohamed ElBaradei addressed protesters in Cairo's Tahrir Square saying we "cannot go back" and demanding "the end of the regime." (Video: Reuters)

title: A Digital Future for the Founding Fathers
description: Justice Antonin Scalia of the Supreme Court visited the Capitol last week to lecture representatives about the Constitution, at the invitation of Representative Michele Bachmann, the Minnesota Republican and Tea Party leader. Some people may be interested in seeing what the founders themselves had to say, and thanks to digital technology, an increasing number of original documents can be found online.

title: Chinese Man Who Bragged of Privilege Gets Six Years
description: SHANGHAI  A Chinese court on Sunday sentenced a 23-year-old man to six years in prison for killing one young woman and injuring another in a drunken-driving accident that drew public outrage in China.

title: Facing Sanctions, Belarus Frees Seven Political Prisoners, but a Dozen Remain in Jail
description: MOSCOW  Belarus has begun releasing opposition political figures in what appears to be a last-minute attempt to mollify European leaders who are preparing to impose sanctions this week against the nations president, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, and his government.

title: To Happen Upon City Landmarks, by Way of an App
description: Steven Romalewski stood at the intersection of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard and West 181st Street in the Bronx the other day and peered at an old church across the street. In the cold, his right thumb slid across the screen of his black Palm Pre phone.

title: Oh, You (Red) Devils
description: The fifth round of the English F.A. Cup offers a romantic, if mind-boggling matchup between two teams called the Red Devils: mighty Manchester United and minor league Crawley Town.

title: Vintage Comedy Recounts Old-New Tale of Journalism
description: If theres one thing you learn by going regularly to the Mint Theater, which specializes in forgotten dramas, its that the world has changed less than you think.

title: For Many Fleeing Egypt, a Long Wait
description: CAIRO  Andrea Bosch had been waiting for hours Sunday at Cairo International Airport for a flight to whisk her and her young daughters away from the maelstrom that Egypts capital had become.

title: Recessions Under the Gold Standard
description: One of the discouraging features of economic debate today  maybe it was always thus, but it seems especially intense now  is how much of it rests on facts that arent, but which become articles of faith. Ive been surprised, for example, to encounter assertions that Fannie and Freddie held a third of subprime mortgages, which I knew wasnt remotely true. Where did that come from? Mike Konczal points us to James Kwak, explaining that the source for that number is a consultant to the mortgage industry who made up his own definition of subprime  one that bears little resemblance to the standard definition, and which happens to produce a vastly inflated number for Fannie/Freddie.

title: Sustain What?
description: During a recent visit to the University of Connecticut, I was interviewed by Bob Wyss, an associate professor of journalism, for a climate issue of Wrack Lines, the magazine of the Connecticut Sea Grant College Program.

title: Hailing a Cab Is Only Half the Battle
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Sixth Day of Protests
description: Tens of thousands of protesters flooded central Cairo on Sunday for the sixth day, defying yet again the governments nationwide curfew.

title: Transformational Technologies
description: Just a quick followup on my kitchen post: some commenters argue that the really transformative change came in the 19th century. Theres a lot to that.

title: The Brittle-Stars Danced. The Stingray Smoked a Pipe.
description: When my children were small, we often read them Edward Lears The Jumblies, a not very edifying book of nonsense that we all loved. The Jumblies were wildly impractical souls who

title: St. Johns Stuns Duke From Start to Finish
description: Jogging onto the Madison Square Garden floor on Sunday afternoon, the Duke Blue Devils were greeted by the St. Johns student rooting section with the inhospitable chant of overrated. By late in the second half of a nonconference shocker, what had sounded like the overstatement of deluded youth resonated more as reasonable assertion, if not point of fact.

title: A Composer Who Rolled the Dice
description: In most classical works written after the Baroque era little is left to chance, with the composer specifying notes, tempos, dynamics and phrasing. In aleatoric, or chance, music, on the other hand, some elements of the score are more spontaneous.

title: An Otherworldly Wildness This Way Comes
description: The Irondale Center is a gorgeous place to take in a performance. For the past two weekends this former Sunday school in the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, has been home to FLICfest (Feature-Length Independent Choreography), a new festival of dance created by Jeramy Zimmerman. But on Friday night the generous, romantically dilapidated room was thrown into darkness when the Bessie Award-winning Layard Thompson performed his solo Spellin Flashhhh Lightsssss. As the title  typical of Mr. Thompsons eccentric spelling  indicates, flashlights, wielded by Mr. Thompson, provided most of the illumination. They cast jagged beams or big, eyelike circles on the green, peeling walls and warm wood floor, serving as a counterpoint to the night sky, rimmed by the large, graceful windows along the balcony.

title: Flamenco With Soulfulness and a Burst of Springtime
description: Rebeca Toms has the kind of ingnue appeal that brings out the joyful and festive side of flamenco. In other words, if you like your flamenco infused with tragedy, look elsewhere: her soulfulness, at best, is forcefully fresh and poetically tender. On Friday night she returned to Theater 80 St. Marks, a scrappy, intimate space that retains a quirky element of the East Village  the curtain was delayed as an usher went on a spider hunt  with her group of dancers and excellent musicians, led by Pedro Corts.

title: After a Weak Two-Bid, to Lurk or to Jump In?
description: Look at the South hand in the diagramed deal. You are vulnerable against nonvulnerable opponents. East opens two spades, a weak two-bid. What would you do?

title: At City Ballet, a New Work Looks to Ellington for That Swing
description: Determinedly jolly, Susan Stromans new ballet, For the Love of Duke, is trite on purpose. Its premiere took place on Friday night, but nothing about it felt new. It peddles clichs.

title: The Manila Parallel
description: I am not writing about Egypt for tomorrows paper; Ive done a bit of homework on the economy, but really dont feel that I have much to contribute  besides, other stuff is happening in the world, and someone should be writing about it.

title: Thomas Friedman on 'Meet the Press'
description: On Meet The Press, The Times's opinion columnist Thomas Friedman talks about how Egypt got to this point. (Video: MSNBC).

title: Slow and Roomy, With Space for Contemplation
description: Charles Lloyds name alone might sell tickets as a symbol of integrity and spiritual health and every-man-has-his-season. A saxophonist and bandleader, he was a friendly and popular face of post-Coltrane jazz in the 1960s. Then he retreated for much of the next two decades, and came out the other side an elegant older man with a stronger, softer art.

title: An Aural Monument to Beethoven
description: A year after Beethovens death in 1827, plans emerged to erect a statue of him in Bonn, Germany, where he was born. The effort languished for more than a decade until the composer and pianist Franz Liszt pledged his influential support.

title: Unrest in Egypt Unsettles Global Markets
description: On Wall Street, it is what is known as an exogenous event  a sudden political or economic jolt that cannot be predicted or modeled but sends shockwaves rippling through global markets.

title: Bells and Whistles Turn Up the Volume
description: Sam Beam, the songwriter behind Iron and Wine, brought a large band to Radio City Music Hall on Saturday night. Sometimes it was too large.

title: The Future Arrives at Rutgers, Again
description: On Friday in the library of St. Peters Prep in Jersey City, N.J., some Rutgers supporters believe that the future of the football program was established. The verbal commitment by running back Savon Huggins, a five-star recruit according to ESPN.com, is seen as a pivotal moment for the Scarlet Knights. Huggins has been on the national stage for four years, and is considered of the nations elite running backs and a true workhorse, which Rutgers has not had since Ray Rice left for the N.F.L. in 2007.

title: Inflation in China May Limit U.S. Trade Deficit
description: HONG KONG  Inflation is starting to slow Chinas mighty export machine, as buyers from Western multinational companies balk at higher prices and have cut back their planned spring shipments across the Pacific.

title: Monday: Is It Soup Yet?
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Hungry for a good Monday puzzle? Come and get it. Andrea Carla Michaels is serving up memories of our childhood.

title: The Dutchman Flies Right Off the Wall
description: MIAMI BEACH  On Friday night at the New World Center here the New World Symphony, a top-notch training orchestra, presented its first free Wallcast concert. Remember that name, Wallcast, because it is going to catch on.

title: In India, a Busy Fair and a Spirited Art Scene
description: NEW DELHI  The third India Art Summit, an art fair that ended last week, took up more than 90,000 square feet of Pragati Maidan, the main public exhibition hall here in Indias capital. Eighty-four galleries were represented, showing the work of 500 mostly Indian modern and contemporary artists. Organizers reported 128,000 visitors over the fairs three-day run, and millions of dollars changed hands, with a couple of buyers each taking home more than $2 million in art.

title: Sundance Films Honored
description: Like Crazy, a romance directed by Drake Doremus and starring Felicity Jones, above, (and purchased by Paramount Pictures and Indian Paintbrush), won the grand jury prize for an American dramatic film at the Sundance Film Festival awards, announced on Saturday night. Peter D. Richardsons How to Die in Oregon, a searing look at assisted suicide, won the grand jury prize for an American documentary. In the world categories Anne Sewitskys drama Happy, Happy, about a homemaker who struggles to keep her emotions in check, and Danfung Denniss Afghanistan documentary Hell and Back Again won the jury prizes. The audience awards for American films went to Maryam Keshavarzs Circumstance, a look at a teenage lesbian in modern-day Iran, and Cindy Meehls Buck, a documentary about the cowboy who was the real-life inspiration for the 1998 drama The Horse Whisperer.

title: Unknown Hammett Story Sees the Light of Day
description: So I shot him. That is the first line and the title of a 19-page unpublished short story by Dashiell Hammett that Strand Magazine is planning to publish next month. Despite being a thriller, this story has some psychological elements that are not seen in a typical Hammett, said Andrew F. Gulli, the Strands publisher, who found 15 unpublished Hammett stories in the archives of the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas, Austin. Hammett, who died in 1961, is best known for hard-boiled thrillers like The Thin Man and The Maltese Falcon, which were made into Hollywood movies. Mr. Gulli specializes in finding unknown works by writers; in the past two years he has published stories by Mark Twain, P. G. Wodehouse, Graham Greene and Agatha Christie.

title: The Rite Has a Solid Opening at the Box Office
description: The horror film The Rite, starring Anthony Hopkins, left, as an exorcist, was the top performer at the North American box office over the weekend with about $15 million in ticket sales. Unlike some horror movies, the film mostly attracted viewers over the age of 25, The Associated Press reported. No Strings Attached, starring Natalie Portman and Ashton Kutcher, was second with sales of roughly $13.7 million for a new total of $39.7 million, according to Hollywood.com, which tracks box office results. The Mechanic and The Green Hornet tied for third place with $11.5 million in sales. Other films got a bump from last weeks Oscar nominations, including The Kings Speech, which earned $11.1 million in its 10th week of release for a new total of $72.2 million; the film was shown in an additional 900 theaters. And True Grit, another Oscar hopeful, sold $7.6 million in tickets as it approached a total of $150 million.

title: Obamas Tucson Speech Is Published as E-Book
description: Anyone who missed President Obamas speech at the Tucson memorial service on Jan. 12 can read it online, watch a video clip on YouTube or listen to snippets on NPR. And those glued to their Nooks and Kindles can now download it as an e-book. St. Martins Press, part of Macmillan, has converted the speech into e-book form, making it available through Amazon, BN.com and other retailers for 99 cents. A spokesman for St. Martins said the e-book, for sale on Monday, would be the only downloadable version of the speech, which is in the public domain and available to any publisher. St. Martins has decided to name the e-book What Is Best in America, after Mr. Obamas description of the people who were killed by a gunman on Jan. 8. The six people who lost their lives on Saturday, Mr. Obama said in the speech, they too represented what is best in America. Publishers have experimented in recent months with shorter digital offerings in e-book form, including essays and short stories.

title: Rodgerss Town Has History of Success
description: CHICO, Calif.  The Chico native Aaron Rodgers isnt the only former Pleasant Valley High School quarterback to have graced an N.F.L. roster.

title: Manhattan Wins, From Way Downtown
description: It was an exciting weekend in college basketball, with No. 1 Ohio State and No. 2 Pittsburgh barely escaping on the road and No. 3 Duke getting manhandled by St. Johns at Madison Square Garden. But the most astonishing moment came at the end of the game between Manhattan and Marist. Thats right, Manhattan and Marist. The Red Foxes held a 59-57 lead in the final seconds when Manhattans Michael Alvarado got the ball on an inbounds pass with two seconds left, began dribbling up the court and let go of the ball well before the halfcourt line. It banked in off the glass, giving the Jaspers a 60-59 victory and Alvarado a shining moment in January.

title: New York City Ballet
description: Photos of Christopher Wheeldons Polyphonia and For the Love of Duke by Susan Stroman.

title: India Art Summit
description: Eighty-four galleries and 500 artists were represented at this years event in New Delhi.

title: From Sketch to Stage: Milk Train
description: A look at David C. Woolards costume sketches for the revival of The Milk Train Doesnt Stop Here Anymore.

title: Tourists Trapped in Egypt
description: As thousands of foreign tourists and Egyptians try to leave the country, reactions range from nervous to stoic.

title: Bradley Makes a Mark in a Talented Division
description: PONTIAC, Mich.  In a locker room at the Silverdome, the ringside physician Peter Samet asked the battered junior welterweight Devon Alexander a question about the gash above his right eye: Do you want a big scar, a little scar or no scar?

title: A Mistake to Write Off the Weinsteins
description: PARK CITY, Utah

title: Hockey All-Star Game Features Goals Galore
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  Nicklas Lidstrom of the Detroit Red Wings and his opposing captain, Eric Staal of the host Carolina Hurricanes, chose up sides in the first N.H.L. All-Star Game draft, and judging by the final score Sunday, they picked evenly.

title: States Troubles Are Not the Real Risk for Muni Bonds
description: Huge state budget shortfalls make for easy headlines about the $3 trillion municipal bond market. But old woes like abysmal disclosure and more recent wounds like damage to the safety net should worry the sectors tax-wary investors more.

title: Last Fall, Hurling Insults at Cuomo. Now, Backing His Fiscal Plan.
description: Michael R. Caputo has devoted an inordinate amount of time to bashing Andrew M. Cuomo. As the campaign manager last year for Mr. Cuomos Republican rival in the governors race, Carl P. Paladino, Mr. Caputo delighted in coining names like Prince Andrew and comparing Mr. Cuomo to Pinocchio.

title: Who Will Win Super Bowl XLV?
description: Will it be the Packers or the Steelers who add another Super Bowl trophy to their collection? We make the case for both and then let you decide.

title: Columbus Circle Tower Survives Developers Battle
description: The great battle of Columbus Circle ended Friday evening, not with a bang but with the rustle of settlement papers and money being made.

title: Rough Side of Chicago Shakes Race for City Hall
description: CHICAGO  The most memorable scene from this citys mayoral contest would have been inconceivable during Rahm Emanuels chapter at the White House, where the public imagery is painstakingly choreographed: Mr. Emanuel, seated in a windowless basement meeting room, being forced to respond under oath to hours of harsh, personal and sometimes bizarre questions from ordinary Chicagoans, some of whom clearly detested him.

title: Two Out, One In
Had Enough? Just Imagine All-Snow TV
description: What a great winter.

title: An Airport Whose Time May Not Come
description: Stewart International Airport was supposed to be the long-sought fourth major airport to serve the New York metropolitan area. But four years after the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey took control of it, Stewart remains a mystery to most travelers.

title: New York City Investigates Arizona Gun Show
description: PHOENIX  Weeks after a shooting left six dead and 13 injured in Tucson, New York City sent undercover investigators to an Arizona gun show and found instances in which private sellers sold semiautomatic pistols even after buyers said they probably could not pass background checks, city officials said.

title: Merkels Defense of Euro Forged in East Germany
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany seemed to wear Europes debt crisis lightly when she stepped to the podium at the World Economic Forum last week  perhaps because she has already lived through worse.

title: Issues of Race Bubble Up as Republicans Assert New Power in Albany
description: ALBANY  An otherwise routine session last Monday in the New York State Senate erupted into an argument over seating arrangements and office space that hinted at issues of race and gender that are percolating as Republicans assert their authority as the majority party.

title: From Financial Crisis, a Best Seller
description: It lacks the sex and intrigue of the Starr Report and the bone-chilling narrative of the 9/11 Commission Report.

title: Whats at Stake in the N.F.L. Labor Talks
description: The unbridled immoderation of Super Bowl week will provide the N.F.L. one last party to send off a fabulously successful season, full of competitive games and robust television ratings. But then, like a bad hangover after Super Bowl Sunday, aching reality will set in.

title: Sing Along with Tom Terrific
description: Mets fans looking for a reason, any reason, to smile these days might consider this: After a charity affair at a Manhattan restaurant Thursday night, Mets Hall of Famer Tom Seaver, having signed countless autographs during the event, encountered still more autograph-seekers outside as he prepared to head back to his hotel.

title: Keplers Planet Search
description: Launched in 2009, the Kepler telescope has found nine confirmed planets orbiting distant stars, and released a list of more than 300 other possible extrasolar planets. Mission scientists are scheduled to release details of an additional 400 candidate planets later this week.

title: Pepsi Bets on Local Grants, Not the Super Bowl
description: Whats better than reaching more than 100 million viewers during last years Super Bowl? For Pepsi, it could be 6,000 football fans during a high school game on Friday night in central Texas. Or a group of parents who wanted a new playground in their Las Vegas neighborhood.

title: Listening to the Stars
description: The search for distant planets starts with the vibrations of their stars, and in those vibrations lies a kind of music.

title: A New Model for Film Music
description: LOS ANGELES  The Kings Speech collected an impressive 12 Oscar nominations last week. It might have stopped short of a dozen without help from a British entrepreneur who has planted his business at the tricky intersection of film and music.

title: MTV Strives to Keep Up With Young Viewers
description: DECADES ago, there was a television series called Youth Wants to Know. Now, as the TV industry prepares to start its annual advertising sales efforts, everyone, it seems, wants to know youth.

title: Duke Women Take on Role of Unbeaten Underdog
description: DURHAM, N.C.  Four national championship banners hang from the rafters behind the north basket at Cameron Indoor Stadium, a lasting tribute to the success of the Duke mens basketball program and a constant reminder to the womens team of all it has yet to become.

title: Meeting a Doppelganger on Saturday Night Live
description: LOS ANGELES Jesse Eisenberg arrived at the Screen Actors Guild awards Sunday pretty much straight from the afterparty for Saturday Night Live, possibly still buzzing from the adrenaline of hosting the show.

title: Anthony Has Shown He Isnt Afraid to Make a Move
description: Carmelo Anthony wanted to enhance his basketball career nearly a decade ago and ensure his preparedness for a greater national stage. That was not altogether different from his current situation, although there is financial incentive now.

title: In Washington, Revival of the Technology Scene
description: Last year, Sean Glass was ready to return to the United States after living in London to start an online gambling firm that ended up folding. After selling off the companys assets, he wanted to settle in a city with vibrant entrepreneurial and venture capital communities and considered all the usual hubs: Silicon Valley, Boston, New York, Austin, Tex., and Raleigh, N.C. But in July, Mr. Glass, 31, and his wife moved to Washington, D.C.

title: Gazing Afar for Other Earths, and Other Beings
description: MOFFETT FIELD, Calif.  In a building at NASAs Ames Research Center here, computers are sifting and resifting the light from 156,000 stars, seeking to find in the flickering of distant suns the first hints that humanity is not alone in the universe.

title: Protests Old Guard Falls In Behind the Young
description: CAIRO  Last Thursday, a small group of Internet-savvy young political organizers gathered in the Cairo home of an associate of Mohamed ElBaradei, the diplomat and Nobel laureate.

title: Czisnys Return Ends in Skating Title
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  Alissa Czisny, a skater known for both her breathtaking elegance and her painful inconsistency, proved her resiliency Saturday when she won the national title at the United States figure skating championships.

title: At Flickr, Fending Off Rumors and Facebook
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Speculation in technology circles that Yahoo might close or sell Flickr, its photo-sharing service, prompted an emphatic denial this month.

title: Payments by Borders Late Again
description: Borders, the struggling book chain, said on Sunday night that it would delay more payments to its vendors and landlords as it tried to preserve cash and avoid bankruptcy.

title: Nakamura Wins Tata Steel Chess Tournament
For Leno and NBC, Alls Right Again
description: A year after NBC upended its late-night world, order has quietly been restored: Jay Leno is back on The Tonight Show and topping the ratings virtually every week.

title: A Hollywood Cakewalk for Boxings Tough Guys
description: LOS ANGELES Hollywood likes to think of itself as a tough place, but for Micky Ward and Dicky Eklund, the boxing brothers and real-life inspirations for The Fighter, the red carpet at the Screen Actors Guild awards Sunday was a cakewalk. Its a lot calmer here than in the ring, Mr. Eklund said.

title: Glory at the Top Flight for Runners
description: One day a year, a few hundred athletes gather in the foyer of the Empire State Building, shun the elevator and sprint to its 86th-floor observation deck.

title: Myanmar Opens Parliament for First Time Since the 80s
description: BANGKOK  Myanmars ruling generals on Monday convened the first meeting of Parliament in more than two decades, a move they say completes the impoverished countrys transition to a multiparty democracy.

title: Bloomberg Presses Cuomo on Teacher Seniority Rule
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg set up his first major confrontation with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Sunday, publicly demanding that he use his coming state budget to reverse a rule that protects long-serving teachers from layoffs, regardless of merit.

title: For Mets Owners, a Costly Precursor
description: For the owners of the Mets, their involvement with Bernard L. Madoffs giant investment fraud has been embarrassing and costly. They are being sued for hundreds of millions of dollars, and have been accused of having been, at minimum, willfully ignorant of what Madoff was up to.

title: Losses at Afghan Bank Could Be $900 Million
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Fraud and mismanagement at Afghanistans largest bank have resulted in potential losses of as much as $900 million  three times previous estimates  heightening concerns that the bank could collapse and trigger a broad financial panic in Afghanistan, according to American, European and Afghan officials.

title: Political Crisis Starts to Be Felt Economically
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt  An army tank stands guard at the port of Alexandria to make sure no one gets in. The bigger problem is that next to nothing is going out.

title: Date With a Revolution
description: Cairo

title: A Phish Fans Secret Smile
description: CNBC may not have known it, but last week, the financial news network ran one of the greatest Phish shows in recent memory.

title: Converging on Little Egypt, With Anger and Hope
description: They came from every corner of Astoria, Queens: Egyptian taxi drivers, Tunisian shopkeepers and Lebanese doctors, all seeking news and commiseration through the thick and fragrant haze of hookah smoke at the Layali El Helmeya Caf on Steinway Street, otherwise known as Little Egypt.

title: Rich, Poor and a Rift Exposed by Unrest
description: CAIRO  As the government of Egypt shakes from a broad-based uprising, long-simmering resentments have burst into open class warfare.

title: Police Shoot Man in East Harlem
description: An East Harlem man was wounded by the police early Sunday after he opened fire on three sergeants and an officer, the police said.

title: Watson Holds Off Mickelson at Torrey Pines
description: SAN DIEGO  Although he had one PGA Tour victory and a decent showing in the Ryder Cup to his credit before Sunday, long-hitting Bubba Watson had yet to establish himself as a serious candidate for greatness.

title: After Move to Cut Subsidies, Bolivian Ire Chastens Leader
description: EL ALTO, Bolivia  It was the day after Christmas. President Evo Morales was on a trip to Venezuela, Bolivias top ally, so the unenviable task fell to his vice president: announcing an abrupt 73 percent increase in the price of gasoline. The reaction was swift.

title: Define Gender Gap? Look Up Wikipedias Contributor List
description: In 10 short years, Wikipedia has accomplished some remarkable goals. More than 3.5 million articles in English? Done. More than 250 languages? Sure.

title: Teacher, My Dad Lost His Job. Do We Have to Move?
description: WORTHINGTON, Ohio  Diane and Eric Kehler tried not to talk about it in front of the children, but as Jen Hegerty, the guidance counselor at Wilson Hill Elementary School, says, Children have eagle ears.

title: PBS Shows Future in Doubt
description: When the PBS newsmagazine Need to Know started last May it had big shoes to fill, replacing Bill Moyers Journal and Now on PBS. But even as angry e-mails from disappointed viewers have subsided, the producers acknowledge that the show remains a work in progress, and PBS says it has not decided whether to renew it.

title: Protesters Take On Conservative Retreat
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  So much for a quiet little weekend getaway.

title: Lottery Numbers
Reaper Arrives? Grab a Kimono
description: Total fearlessness is not a requirement for embarking on an acting career. But it is definitely a necessity for essaying the role of the dying gorgon Flora Goforth in The Milk Train Doesnt Stop Here Anymore, a curious, rather curdled 1963 play by Tennessee Williams.

title: As the Oil Industry Sees It
description: To the Editor:

title: Dismissal of Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Physicists on Wall Street?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Smoke-Free CUNY
description: To the Editor:

title: Health Care and Morality
description: To the Editor:

title: Within Our Means
description: In the next two months, Gov. Andrew Cuomo and the Legislature will have to make very difficult decisions about how to close a $10 billion budget deficit  which state offices to shutter, which services and aid to cut, which employees to lay off and which taxes to raise. There are no easy fixes left.

title: A Cross of Rubber
description: Last Saturday, reported The Financial Times, some of the worlds most powerful financial executives were going to hold a private meeting with finance ministers in Davos, the site of the World Economic Forum. The principal demand of the executives, the newspaper suggested, would be that governments stop banker-bashing. Apparently bailing bankers out after they precipitated the worst slump since the Great Depression isnt enough  politicians have to stop hurting their feelings, too.

title: Creating a Black Museum
description: To the Editor:

title: The Devil We Know
description: As the world ponders the fate of Egypt after Hosni Mubarak, Americans should ponder this: Its quite possible that if Mubarak had not ruled Egypt as a dictator for the last 30 years, the World Trade Center would still be standing.

title: Is a Bigger House a Better House?
description: To the Editor:

title: More Transactions, on Smaller Orders
description: During the most recent holiday season, consumers who clicked on search ads, like those accompanying Google results, performed 87 percent more transactions with online retailers than they had a year before. But the average online shopping basket was 10 percent smaller, according to Kenshoo, a maker of search-engine marketing software that analyzed three million transactions with its clients, generally large online retailers. In other words, people are spreading their money thinner online.

title: New Electricity Meters Stir Fears
description: INVERNESS PARK, Calif.  Pacific Gas and Electrics campaign to introduce wireless smart meters in Northern California is facing fierce opposition from an eclectic mix of Tea Party conservatives and left-leaning individualists who say the meters threaten their liberties and their health.

title: Cuomo Files Tax-Cap Bill, Surprising Assembly
description: In a surprise move, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has submitted his proposal to limit local property taxes to the State Senate for a vote on Monday, a tactic that seems designed to isolate Democratic lawmakers in the Assembly who have qualms about the measure.

title: Ivanchuk Leads Gibraltar Chess Festival and Korchnoi Is Unbeaten
Sudan Sees Migration of Unrest to Its Streets
description: Security forces beat and arrested student protesters in the Sudanese capital on Sunday as the unrest and antigovernment fervor in Tunisia and Egypt showed their first indication of spreading to the streets of Khartoum, if on a far smaller scale.

title: Mozgov Shows Knicks What a Big Man Can Do
description: The long, frequently frustrating search for a productive, skilled big man led the Knicks to a dozen dead ends before ending, finally, back where it began: in the Russian-speaking quarter of the locker room.

title: For End of the World, a French Peak Holds Allure
description: BUGARACH, France  The rocky mountain of Bugarach, rising just over 4,000 feet in the Corbires Mountains, in one of the poorest and least populated areas of France, has long attracted hikers and nature lovers who like to wander its gentle slopes in search of rare species of orchids.

title: Kings Speech Gets Another Push
description: LOS ANGELES There were no surprises in the movie categories at the Screen Actors Guild awards, which on Sunday night bestowed prizes on all the expected hopefuls: Melissa Leo and Christian Bale as best supporting actors in The Fighter; Natalie Portman as best actress for Black Swan; and Colin Firth as best actor for The Kings Speech. That movie also picked up the groups version of best picture, the best ensemble prize.

title: 12 Years On, Tobacco Suit Due in Court
description: A big tobacco case is set to start on Monday in St. Louis involving dozens of local hospitals, the nations biggest tobacco companies and 12 years worth of filings that fill 43 boxes in the citys towering limestone courthouse.

description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Governments Go Online in Fight Against Terrorism
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  In the Netherlands, the jailhouse recantation of a convicted terrorist renouncing violence has circulated online. Counterterrorism officials say it could make disaffected youth think twice about joining violent extremist ranks.

title: Have You Been Following the News About Egypt?
description: Much has happened in Egypt in the past week. Tens of thousands of protesters called for President Hosni Mubarak to step down, and Mr. Mubarak responded by disbanding his government, while retaining his position. The protests continue. What do you know about Mubaraks regime? How much have you followed this story? What has your reaction been? When and why, in general, do you follow international news? Why should non-Egyptians care what happens in Egypt?

title: Rabid Fans Put Dallas on Itinerary
description: Just moments after the Green Bay Packers beat the Chicago Bears for the N.F.C. championship, Tony Hoes ran for the phone to call Titletown Tickets, a tour operator. After waiting nervously on hold, Hoes plunked down $10,000 for two trip packages to suburban Dallas so he and his wife can see the Packers play in the Super Bowl for the first time in 13 years.

title: Palestinian Adversaries Unite, for Now, on Egypt
description: GAZA The Hamas rulers of Gaza and the rival Palestinian Authority leadership of the West Bank rarely see eye-to-eye on anything. But with mass protests rocking Egypt, across Gazas southern border, the Palestinian adversaries have united in maintaining a cautious silence, hedging their bets given the unpredictability of the outcome and clearly concerned about a possible spread of popular unrest to their areas.

title: Governments Dietary Advice: Eat Less
description: As the nations obesity crisis continues unabated, federal regulators on Monday issued their bluntest nutrition advice to date: drink water instead of sugary drinks like soda, fill your plate with fruits and vegetables and cut down on processed foods filled with sodium, fat or sugar.

title: In the Ruins of Playland, Artifacts of Better Days
description: Nathan Kensinger, photo-chronicler extraordinaire of the citys abandoned spaces, returns this morning with a lavishly illustrated dispatch from the Playland Arcade in Coney Island, which flourished, to varying degrees, from 1935 until 1982. It comes at a moment in Coneys history when several of its more venerable remaining institutions are getting the boot, when, Mr. Kensinger writes, Cha Chas and Rubys have served their last drinks and have, in turn, been served with eviction papers.

title: Go for Broke | Van Cleef & Arpels Cuff Links
description: Downton Abbey, the English high-society drama on PBS, has more than one chap channeling his inner lord of the manor. They would do well to turn to Sandra Cronan. Among the fanciful estate gems at her charming boutique on Albermarle Street, just a stones (or in this case, diamonds) throw from Old Bond Street, is this handsome pair of Van Cleef & Arpels 18-karat yellow gold cuff links with interchangeable bars of tigers eye and lapis lazuli from the 1950s. With big-ticket trinkets like this to tempt the discerning gentleman, no wonder so many lost their estates. About $4,773. At Sandra Cronan, 011-44-207-491-4851.

title: Equality Isnt Always Easy

In a study published in the journal Developmental Psychology, researchers reported that couples who share caregiving are more likely to experience conflict than couples where the wife does more.

title: W.T.O. Is Said to Affirm That Boeing Got Improper Subsidies

title: Ways to Teach About the Unrest in Egypt
description: Egypt, the most populous country in the Arab world, erupted in mass protests in January 2011, as the revolution in Tunisia seemed to inflame decades worth of smoldering grievances against the heavy-handed rule of President Hosni Mubarak. After 18 days of angry protests, Mr. Mubarak resigned and turned over all power to the military on Feb. 11, 2011, ending his 30 years of autocratic rule and bowing to a historic popular uprising that has transformed politics in Egypt and around the Arab world. The announcement, delivered during evening prayers in Cairo, set off a frenzy of celebration, with protesters shouting Egypt is free! The popular protest, peaceful and resilient despite numerous effort by Mr. Mubaraks legendary security apparatus to suppress it, ultimately deposed an ally of the United States who has been instrumental in implementing American policy in the region for decades.Overview from the Times Topics page on Egypt, updated Feb. 11.

title: The Queen Mom Who Almost Wasnt
description: LOS ANGELES The Bagger spent the weekend at various award shows, convening with celebrities and other beautiful people, commiserating about having to be at awards shows. Tough gig, we know. But before we get to the scene on the dance floor with Justin Timberlake and Amanda Seyfried at a Dewars-fueled Screen Actors Guild after-party, let us catch you up on the nontelevised happenings at the Directors Guild awards. The group allows all its best feature film nominees to give a speech before the winner is revealed, which is part of why the event  dinner and the ceremony  was nearly six hours long. (See, it is worth commiserating.) But there were moments of mirth, like Colin Firth and Helena Bonham Carters introduction of Tom Hooper, the director of The Kings Speech (and the evenings ultimate winner). Mr. Firth talked about being nervous performing in front of Mr. Hooper, who kept looking down at his shoes; when he finally looked up, Mr. Firth said he knew hed nailed the part. Ms. Bonham Carter was even more honest.

title: Taliban Gun Lockers: The Rifles of Rural Ghazni Province
description: FORWARD OPERATING BASE ANDAR, Afghanistan  This month Tyler Hicks and I have been working alongside the soldiers of Task Force Iron, an infantry battalion from the 101st Airborne Division that soon will complete a one-year tour in Afghanistan. Were busy editing photographs and wrapping up reporting on some of the operations we observed alongside American soldiers and Afghan police and intelligence officers, and will have at least two stories for the newspaper soon. As we work, we want to pause to share a fresh look at some of the Talibans weapons, based on the battalions recent captures from slain Taliban fighters or caches, as a means to understanding more fully how the Taliban fights.

title: Reputation of a Berry Is Difficult to Confirm
description: For decades cranberry juice has enjoyed a reputation as an effective way to prevent bladder infections. Scientists have doggedly tried to confirm this well-known folk truth with dozens of studies, some in test tubes and some in people.

title: Add Gray Wolf to List of Canines in Africa
description: The Ethiopian highlands are home to two canine species that look deceptively similar, the gray wolf and the golden jackal, according to a new study in the journal PLoS One. Until now, the two midsize animals were thought to be the same species.

title: S.B.A. Settles Discrimination Suit
description: Back in April, The Agenda reported on a lawsuit against the Small Business Administration, brought by a would-be venture capitalist seeking access to government-backed investment funds. The S.B.A. recently reached a settlement  actually, it was in November, but Ive been on paternity leave (twins!)  with Diamond Ventures, an Atlanta-based fund run by C. Earl Peek, an African-American who claimed discrimination after the S.B.A. rejected Diamonds application for a small-business investment company license. But while the settlement is good news for Mr. Peek and his partners, it does not address what Diamond claimed was a far-reaching pattern of bias that affected a whole class of black and other minority investors.

title: The Curious Case of the Unscathed Scooter
description: Updated, 4:33 p.m. | Its the stuff of urban legends: A seemingly serviceable and unsecured motor scooter has been parked for months on Sutton Place South without being driven away, ticketed, towed or, miraculously, stolen.

title: Nick Barnett Unfollows America
description: The first ultra-trivial Super Bowl story to gain sentience, sprout legs and start toppling buildings last week was the drama surrounding the Packers team photo. The story so far: players on injured reserve were scheduled to arrive in Dallas too late to appear in the photo, the shoot was rescheduled, Aaron Rodgers criticized injured teammates who chose to rehabilitate outside of Green Bay, Jermichael Finley and Nick Barnett responded via Twitter, and the silliest controversy ever to swallow the football world whole was spawned.

title: Egypt, Oil and Democracy

title: Found: Footage of the Original Ballets Russes
description: Our knowledge of Diaghilevs Ballets Russes troupe  not the versions after his death in 1929  comes from texts, sketches, photographs and of course dances handed down over the years. But no film of a performance by the original company was thought to exist. Now a curator at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, where an exhibition on the company closed this month, has announced the discovery of less than a minute of performance footage on the Web site of the production house British Path.
